column2: Uncertainty regarding the 12-cents-a-pound loan to cotton growers caused another feverish and irregular market yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended at gains of 1 to 4 points after rushing up nearly a dollar a bale at one time.

This is a supplementary reader, but it is one that may well find a place on the shelves of a public or school library as a book for 10-12-year-olds' individual reading. It contains a large amount of information presented with sympathy and vision.
Three suits to enjoin the government from collecting AAA processing and compensating taxes on cotton and tobacco were dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Murray D. Hulbert.
TOKYO, Aug. 17. -- A navy spokesman today confirmed reports that Japan would not agree to a reduction in the size of warships unless this were accompanied by a reduction in the size of fleets.

A RETROSPECT of the Madrid symphonic season discloses several Spanish novelties of greater or less interest, besides those already noticed in these columns. The capital's oldest ensemble, the Orquesta Sinfonica, still energetically captained by the popular veteran, Enrique F. Arbos, has not lagged in hospitality to native contemporaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Promotions effective Aug. 1 have been granted to 4,355 army officers in approval by the Senate of a list submitted by the President early this week. The promotions are a result of the passage of the Army Promotion Law July 31.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 15. -- Tobacco growers throughout the South Atlantic States who waited for the opening of the South Georgia markets to indicate the price trend of the year, are now convinced that they are to enjoy their second successive profitable season.

WAKE ISLAND, Aug. 17 (By Wireless) -- With the arrival of the Pan American Clipper here this afternoon, 5,200 miles of the "aerial bridge" across the Pacific have been flown, studied and charted. For future engineering filghts, only 3,000 miles remain to be explored.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 17. -- A racing party entitled "Courses de Nuit a Longchamps" was held tonight at the Sands Point Bath Club here. The club was decorated with race course flags and in the Casino a miniature track was laid out, with six racing channels and toy horses.

An insistent demand for stocks easily overcame the natural desire to claim profits on a Summer Saturday, and the average level of prices was pushed to a new high point for the year in the brief trading period yesterday. The rise enabled the market to round out the seventh consecutive week in which the average has closed higher, and at the same time the fifth month of the advance.

Italy has, of course, worked out in advance and to the last detail her program for civilizing the Ethiopians. One of the first steps to be taken as soon as the country has been overrun and pacified will be to make the inhabitants put on shoes.

Supporters of former Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, insurgent candidate to succeed former Park Commissioner John F. Sheehy as Democratic leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District in Manhattan, charged yesterday that the Sheehy nominating petitions included the names of prominent Democrats without their consent or approval.

THERE can be no doubt that the foreign physiologists who are attending the International Congress of Physiology in Leningrad and Moscow will be taken to the Sklifasovsky Institute and various public hospitals, there to behold the work that Soviet physicians and surgeons are doing in collecting and preserving dead men's blood to he used in emergency transfusions.

DETROIT, Aug. 17. -- Output of the automobile industry in the United States and Canada resumed its pace again this week ahead of 1934 levels. Production was 56,386 units, compared with 53,854 in the corresponding week of last year by Cram's Reports, Inc.

THE majestic splendor of the twin cataracts that make Niagara Falls one of the great natural wonders of the world is expected to lure more than 2,500,000 visitors this year. They come from far places. Every State of the Union is represented annually on the hotel registers and guest books of the New York and Ontario reservations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17. -- World activity in chemical science will be reported in more than 300 papers and addresses to be delivered before the ninetieth meeting of the American Chemical Society, which will convene here Monday. About a thousand chemists and industrialists will participate in the sessions, which will continue for five days.

THERE are more books, newspaper and magazine articles, more courses on science for the young than ever. But the schools and universities are not adequately meeting the needs of adult education in science. Neither in Europe or America are the science classes for adults what they once were.

PARIS. THAT fashion is no static art was plainly evident during the past days in Paris. Everything seemed to be moving just a wee bit in one direction or another. Waistlines, sleeves and skirt lengths, all had something to say for themselves.

Recently there has been an interesting and instructive correspondence in THE TIMES columns by Edward J. Carson, Francis M. Field-McNally and Arthur Guiterman, relative to the opportunities for humans to serve as foster parents for orphaned or outcast young birds.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Sensatin, big bay gelding owned by the Rolling Rock Farms of Richard K. Mellon of Ligonia, Pa., this afternoon captured a leg on the Spectator Challenge Cup, one of the important trophies of the eleventh annual horse show of the Riding Club of East Hampton.

ONE of the many foreign airlines to make use of American-built engines is the scenic line from Stockholm to Helsingfors. Many of the patrons of this line are tourists, but there is many a business man as well who finds that he can make the round trip in a day and see his clients at either terminus in the meantime.

ORDINARILY, such is the fate of short story collections, even so fine a book as "Winter Orchard" might slip by in relative obscurity. That it is not likely to do so is thanks largely to the Pulitzer Prize jury, which redeemed itself for previous lapses in taste by awarding the prize this year to Miss Johnson's first novel.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17. -- PWA Project 954 will be Kansas City's trump card in a determined bid for both national political conventions in 1936. It is a $6,500,000 auditorium.

ON BOARD SCHOONER MORRISSEY, in Davis Strait, Aug. 10. -- With beautiful weather, we reached Parker Snow Bay, where we watered the ship beneath the warm rays of the Arctic sun. The little auks from the rookeries filled the air with their music.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- National Guard troops from eight States were converging by train and truck and taxicab on this 100-square-mile encampment tonight as 36,000 soldiers of the First Army were mobilizing near Watertown for the army's greatest peacetime manoeuvres.

ONE of the attractions of the Island of Nantucket, thirty miles out from the coast of Massachusetts, is the sight of the wild deer, which may be glimpsed on any fine evening by persistent motorists and hikers, provided they approach its haunts slowly and quietly after the sun has set and dusk draws on.

C. Frederick Neilson of Shrewsbury, N.J., will make the award of best in show at the sixtieth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be held in Madison Square Garden next Feb. 10, 11 and 12.

GENEVA, Aug. 17. -- Premier Benito Mussolini has sent his first hospital ship to East Africa -- a sinister sign of imminent war. Emperor Haile Selassie has signed the Red Cross convention for the protection of wounded.

A STUDENT prank, which has made a cripple of the man who was the victim of it, is back of all the strange happenings recorded in this new Nero Wolfe story. The victim is Paul Chapin, who has in the meantime become a famous novelist.

The Post-Rogers flight from Alaska to Moscow was to have been the forerunner of extensive surveys of the Bering Sea as a potential air route between Asia and North America, according to a bulletin from the National Geographic Society, issued before the accident.

ARE you prepared to share the honors with your clothes this Autumn? Think it over -- you will be obliged to! There is so much that contributes to smartness in the new clothes that they cannot fail to attract attention to themselves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 14, aggregated $6,612,000,000, or 16 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and slightly above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Throngs of visitors attended today's horse show at the Riding Club of East Hampton. About three hundred Riding Club members, horse show exhibitors and guests lunched at tables under the apple trees at the Riding Club this noon and an equal number dined and danced tonight at the Maidstone Club at the annual horse show dinner.

There is growing conviction among public utility leaders here that no Federal legislation affecting utilities will be passed before Congress is adjourned and they are busy studying the situation with respect to the future.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Commemorating the establishment of this resort as a spa, the annual Old White Week celebration commences today. The climax of the festival is the invitation fancy dress ball to be given in the Cameo Ballroom at the Greenbrier on Friday night, which promises to be one of the most brilliant events ever held here.

WASHINGTON. -- With the passage of Public Law No. 432 the screen has won a permanent place in historical and scientific records. Section 7 of the measure, "An Act to Establish a National Archives of the United States," reads:

IT could be wished that reports on the first twelve-inch gold label Brunswick records to reach us in almost three years might have been as enthusiastic as our delight at seeing the once familiar label in circulation again. May our suspicions that these are in the nature of a trial horse be correct.

Mayor La Guardia has announced the first active step in a serious campaign of noise abatement in New York City with a month of "noiseless nights" beginning Oct. 1. November will be a month of "noiseless days" and thereafter New Yorkers are promised a civic drive on noise for the full twenty-four hours.

EQUIPPED with unbounded sympathy, a scholarly knowledge of Mexican folk ways, and a good friend to tell him many small things about the way life is lived in that country, Hermann B. Deutsch set out to write a novel about the Mexican Revolution.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16. -- Reports indicate an improvement in practically all lines in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. Retail sales are 18 per cent ahead of last year in most cities and rural stores are reporting even better gains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Found guilty on three counts of violating the Grain Futures Act, Thomas M. Howell, Chicago speculator, today was barred from trading on all contract markets in the United States for a period of two years beginning Sept. 15.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The Bar Harbor Club will hold an unusually brilliant scene tomorrow evening as members of the Summer colony gather for the midsummer costume dinner and ball arranged by the club under the direction of a group of young people of the colony.

In a broadcast last week Mr. LAURENCE V. COLEMAN, director of the American Association of Museums, pronounced the perfect hobby to be the collecting of old houses. It is a hobby that requires only modest expenditure (fares and fees), and the collecting by one does not preclude possession by others, even by thousands.

Two men, who, according to the police, attempted to beat their 53-year-old policeman father as a result of a domestic quarrel, learned to their regret early yesterday in Hoboken that the training a patrolman receives on the force stands him in good stead in a rough-and-tumble street fight.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 17 (AP). -- A Tientsin dispatch quoted a Japanese officer as saying tonight that "new demands upon China likely are necessary" as a result of the looting of an express train Thursday, allegedly by "Chinese bandits."

SHOULD President Roosevelt plan to "speak" around the world by radio, or should King George desire to have the sound of his voice relayed throughout his empire, on which the sun never sets, preparation for the vast ethereal web of tentacles spanning the seven seas would first involve consultation with perhaps the most unusual group of radio specialists in the world.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 16. -- Climaxing a dull campaign, Texans will go to the polls Aug. 24 to decide whether they will repeal or retain the present prohibition amendment to the State's Constitution.

With the course for steel production fairly definitely set -- automotive output for the Summer exceeding expectations and new models indicating an increased impetus for that industry in the Autumn, and construction having taken an upward trend -- the financial community now is turning its eye toward the radio industry.

The port of New York is on the defensive on a variety of fronts in an effort to retain its commerce, according to the annual report of the traffic bureau of the Merchants Association, published yesterday. Actions are under way in the courts, before the Interstate Commerce Commision and other bodies, in which traffic moving through the port is at stake.

Within one block of the National Academy of Design, where several of his works have been exhibited in the past, J. J. Muller, recognized as one of the foremost portrait artists in this country, sat in his studio at 144 West 57th Street yesterday, surrounded by his portraits of famous persons and pondering on how he could obtain $200 by Wednesday to save himself and his wife, Rose, from eviction.

Beautification of the right of ways and the station plazas of the railroads, interrupted by the depression, may be resumed before long. Meanwhile the work is being carried on by local communities and by rail employes on their own time. The start of this enterprise was made years ago and in the files of the leading lines are plans calling for large expenditures for landscape gardening when a convenient season arrives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The determination of the government to control open market operations on the Federal Reserve System is emphasized in the unanimous agreement reached by the conferees on the Omnibus Banking Bill, Representative Steagall, chief of the House conferees, said today.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Aug. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- In its first real polo test since arriving in this country to compete in the national open championship, the Hurlingham team from London was defeated today by a combination of similar strength, a 26-goal team, at the Rumson Country Club.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The British policy at the Paris negotiations with the French and Italians is to purchase peace for Ethiopia but not to compel it by threat or even intimation of drastic action against Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy.

GLOUCESTER, Mass. -- As August slides along toward September social activity increases. Not since early July has there been such diversity and quantity of entertainment as awaits North Shore visitors during the coming week -- for the yachtsman, golfer, music lover, tennis enthusiast and theatregoer.

For the most part the series of price advances which have developed on textile and allied lines have been well received by retail buyers. Thus far a minimum of resistance has been given the increases, it was agreed yesterday, owing to the general belief that the advances have been justified by labor or raw material market factors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Retail trade hereabout continues to run ahead of that of last year, while a shortage in August clearance items is forcing an early promotion of all Autumn apparel lines. Various devices are being used, such as small down-payment and hold-delivery offers to break down consumer resistance to purchases of this type in warm weather.

Another step has been taken to coordinate transportation in the United States with the President's signature of the Motor Carrier Act for the regulation of trucks and buses. For the first time since its creation nearly fifty years ago the Interstate Commerce Commission is now vested with broad power to regulate the rates and services of surface carriers outside the railroad field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A bill embodying the views of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and of State Department experts on the powers to be confided to the President to preserve this country's neutrality in the event of a war between foreign powers was introduced in the House today by Chairman S.D. McReynolds.

Boys and girls like history best when it centres around personalities, and to many young readers a historical period becomes vivid and thrilling for the first time when they see it in close relation to the life and deeds of an individual. This volume presents the lives of American women who have played a part in the history of their country.

For more than seven months Signor Mussolini has been talking about war on Ethiopia and pushing military plans for it; yet not once has he explained his real aims. Last Friday Great Britain and France asked what those aims were.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 17 (AP). -- New happiness has come to William Ellery Leonard, 54, poet and professor at the University of Wisconsin, who two months ago was wed to a 27-year-old former pupil.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP). -- J. Lee Barrett, secretary of the Gold Cup Committee, said today he had been notified that Maurice Vasseur of France would challenge next year for the Harmsworth Speed Boat Trophy now held by Gar Wood.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Aug. 17. -- After participating in a quiet family celebration of the twenty-first birthday anniversary of his third son, Franklin Jr., the President left Hyde Park tonight for Washington, where he will take steps to facilitate the early adjournment of Congress.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Dissolution of the Fort bondholders' committee and return of bonds deposited in a receivership reorganization of the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., and affiliated companies were demanded today in a suit filed in Chancery Court by Walter Sperling of Clifton, holder of $2,000 of the bonds.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17. -- The world physiological congress was brought to a formal close today by a plenary session in the Conservatory of Music, in Leningrad, where speeches were delivered by Professor Lapicque of Paris and Professor Ukhtomsky of Leningrad.

Yacht clubs in the vincinity of Port Washington report a far greater increase in their membership rosters than in previous years. At the last meetings of the membership committees of the Manhasset Bay, Port Washington and Knickerbocker clubs several applicants were admitted to membership.

Increased labor costs, higher prices and the possible assumption of workers' contributions to the general fund are some of the developments which industrial management will have to face when the social security measure, which President Roosevelt signed last week, becomes operative, it was pointed out here yesterday by executives.

Staging a comeback unprecedented in the annals of the series, the United States Wightman Cup forces defeated Great Britain for the fifth successive year yesterday in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- The big fashion week, which came to a close with the last of the Winter showings, presented a stylescape replete with contrasts, not to say contradictions. Dashing military or gypsy costumes suggest adventure.

NIGHT falls on Columbus Circle. Street lights twinkle. The incessant rumble of buses and the squeal of street cars on the curves continue unabated. But the area of the Circle to the south of the statue has taken on a new and lively mien.

ROBINSON SMITH and Frederick W. Ayer, a new firm which has been waiting in the wings to take its Broadway bow, will enter this Fall with "Parnell," by Elsie Schauffler. The play is the result of two years' research into the life of the great Irish leader, his stormy fight for Home Rule, his politics association with Gladstone, his personal one with Katherine O'Shea.

MANILA. -- For half a century the Chinese have been the most important retail merchants in the Philippines. They are now rapidly losing that position to the Japanese. The American Trade Commissioner estimates that the latter's shops are doing at least 35 per cent of the retail business of the islands.

HOT weather curbed retail trade in the week and volume here was only even or slightly ahead of a year ago. Reports from other parts of the country told of reduced increases. Gains, which ran as high as 35 per cent, fell to 25 per cent.

Hundreds of American women visiting popular West Indian and South American ports on cruise ships in the last year have accomplished something which dress manufacturers here vainly strove to do for years, namely, created a preference for New York rather than Paris styles among South Americans.

New and more difficult jumps are listed for this year's National Horse Show, which will be held in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 6 to 12. More skill and daring will be required for the obstacles which are comparable to those used in the nightly international military jumping events.

I live in the Peace Party House referred to in THE TIMES of July 28. It was built in 1776 by Colonel James Easton, second in command at the capture of Ticonderoga. Here the patriots and Tories held a three-day peace party in 1783 to celebrate the peace treaty, signed at Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- Considering the high temperature and other uncontrollable conditions, business affairs in this Federal Reserve district are regarded as being in good shape, although an unusual local condition has slightly curtailed retail trade.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- The announcement of the creation of a cultural ghetto for German Jews was made today by Hans Hinckel, the special commissioner for Jewish cultural problems appointed by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister. The Jews appear to have accepted the inevitable rather than to surrender all claims to cultural activity and a new all-inclusive Jewish Cultural Association under the Reich Government's patronage and control has been organized.
TOKYO, -- By railroad building comparable on a small scale to that which opened up the Middle West the Japanese are remaking the map of Manchukuo.
The Ludwig Baumann and Franklin Simon Co. nines triumphed as play in the New York City sandlot championship started at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Speeding up of enforcement of trade-practice rules by the Federal Trade Commission through formation of industry committees and a special department of the commission was suggested here yesterday by Sol A. Herzog, New York attorney, in a letter to Garland S. Ferguson of the commission.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17. -- "Judging by the way they treated me on the long trip across Siberia, in Moscow and in Leningrad," said Professor Walter B. Cannon of Harvard, "the Russians seem to regard scientists as a sort of superman. It is not merely a question of courtesy but of respect and admiration that is perfectly startling to a humble professor."

ALTHOUGH numbered among the younger clergymen of the day. Mr. Van Dusen has already won recognition as an alert and able thinker who faces realities and insists that Christianity must deal with them as they are today and not as they were in some past period.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in Yorkville Court sentenced twenty-one of ninety-seven derelicts to jail yesterday afternoon as the Police Department announced that a total of 582 persons had been arrested since the campaign opened Wednesday night to halt crime in the public parks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- A reaction-dry tendency developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, and liquidation by tired longs appeared in both the corn and the oats pits. Wheat traders had expected sharply higher prices in Liverpool as the result of yesterday's reports of frost in Canada, but they were disappointed at declines of 1/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

SOLDIER KILLED: Leon de Ghilardi, inspector general of the army of Albania (in area a little larger than New Hampshire; in population a little smaller than Los Angeles), was assassinated Thursday in Fieri, Albania. He was a champion of Italo-Albanian friendship and a close associate of his sovereign, King Zog.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The 19-year-old former wife of Clendenin J. Ryan Jr. of New York, whose marriage was annulled, angrily denounced today an American judge's description of the union as "international gold digging."

CHICAGO, -- The Illinois General Assembly, after refusing to give the State a driver's license law, gave it a new traffic code and a legal problem. By an oversight it excluded the courts of justices of the peace and police magistrates from jurisdiction.

ROME, Aug. 17. -- Italy's Ethiopian venture is a perfect example of the ease with which cleverly organized propaganda can create sentiment in favor of war. When early this year the first storm clouds began togather on the horizon, Italian public opinion thought a campaign against Ethiopia would be comparatively easy.

A series of vicious crimes, perpetrated by prowlers in the city's parks, shocked police into galvanic action last week. Flying squadrons swept through parks, waterfronts and squatter settlements, by Friday netting more than 800 arrests in three night-long raids.

THE campaign to silence automobile horns, or at least reduce their blatancy, seems to be getting somewhere. Mayor La Guardia announced last week that he would declare October an educational month of noiseless nights in which the police would admonish motorists blowing their horns unnecessarily between 11 P.M. and 7 A.M.

The disappearance of a little girl calls public attention to a series of atrocities that have been going on for some time in the quiet New England community of Grindle. Animals have been tortured and killed, and there are strange tales abroad concerning them, but this is the first time that a human being has been the victim.

DURING the past few days short-wave reception from Europe has shown a marked improvement in the 49-50-meter or "night" channels. This reminds experienced listeners that daylight hours are becoming more scarce along the North Atlantic pathway of the waves as Fall approaches.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 17. -Sidney Noyes Jr. of Ardsley, former Yale star, who seldom finds time to play tournament golf these days, won the Green Meadow invitation final by beating Tommy Goodwin, Westchester champion, 1 up, at the nineteenth hole today.

Exactly five months have elapsed since the present advance in stock prices began, making the longest period of rising prices since the low point of the bear market was established on July 8, 1932. The upward movement from that date lasted until Sept. 8, 1932; the second bull market covered the period from March 2, 1933, to July 18, 1933.
BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The Eleventh Olympic Games which open here on the first of August, 1936, will be magnificently housed.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17. -- Ted Luther of Youngstown, Ohio, maintained his lead today in the $3,500 open golf tournament by a single stroke over Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Cynara, Disdain and Edwin, trotters owned by William Parkhurst of Maplewood, scored a clean sweep for their owner when they captured all three events in the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today. Each won in three straight heats.

LAKE GEORGE -- C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N.J., and Bolton Landing will defend his title in the fifth annual Sagamore amateur invitation golf tournament, which begins on Thursday and continues through Friday and Saturday on the Sagamore Golf Club course.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The indefatigable 14-year-old Miss Cynthia Clews Wrightson, competing in twelve of nineteen events at the annual Spring Lake horse show today, rode her gray gelding Woodland Storm King to top honors in the ring of the Montclair Riding Club.

Will Rogers, who died in an airplane crash last Thursday, will be remembered for many things, but most of all for his ability to make Americans laugh. His humor, dry, vigorous and essentially American, carried at the same time a homely wisdom.

IN her new novel, Miss Vaughan is not content merely to employ the reliable Cinderella formula; for good measure she throws in unrequited love, Welsh homeliness and London glitter. The result may win a B plus from Hollywood; but it does not rate "passing" from the average reader.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A prediction that Congress will adjourn by next Saturday was made today by Speaker Byrns.

Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, has announced that his staff will issue soon a report giving recognition to the increase in wages paid in the railroad industry since November, 1933. Previously his staff put out a report showing that 150,000 railroad employes received 35 cents an hour or less and that 110,000 worked more than 48 hours a week, during selected payroll periods, in 1933 and 1934.
" How is business?" I asked a business man in Frankfort.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Gold Foam, a 12-to-1 shot which was acquired for $5,000 in a claiming race on the first day of the present meeting, captured the $19,675 Travers Stakes before 25,000 astonished persons today.

FEMININE America is making its mark even in the Wild West. Cowboys and cow talk used to typify the Western cattle-range country, but now soft-voiced college girls explain the developments of the three races -- Indian, Spanish and American -- who have made Southwestern history an exciting story.

MOTOR trucks rumbled across New York's up-State highways yesterday. Some 36,000 steel-helmeted soldiers, with packs, rifles, bayonets and all the stuff of war, were concentrated in a 100-square-mile area at Pine Camp, near Watertown, N.Y., for two weeks of the greatest peace-time army manoeuvres in our history.

Except for continued strength in second-grade railroad liens, bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange was without feature yesterday. The absence of many traders from the financial district was reflected in a sharp falling off in interest in all groups except the rails and a few selected public-utility issues.
AS the eighth in its "Painting of the Week" series, the Boston Museum has selected Van Dyck's portrait of Anna Maria de Schodt, which was placed on view yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- Attaches of the Philadelphia County Commissioners' office are groggy. None of them can recall a time when a greater number of citizens, loaded down with signature-bearing petitions, pounced down upon them than was the case this week, when the time limit was reached for candidates to file their nominating papers for the September primary.

ISTANBUL, Aug. 17. -- While statesmen of most European countries nightly lose sleep counting the dark clouds hovering over the international horizon, leaders of Turkey are among the rare exceptions enjoying a peaceful Summer vacation.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 17. -- The wholesale deportations by the Soviet Government of the Finnish and Estonian-speaking people living in Russian districts adjoining Finland now include the of several parishes, with the result that the churches there are closed, according to an Ingrian refugee who has just escaped into Finland.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- Major General Walther yon Reichenau, who as Chief of the Ministerial Office in the War Ministry is equivalent to a Secretary of State and laison officer between the army and the Reich Government, is to be transferred to active army service Oct. 1, the date set for the calling to the colors of the first class of new conscripts.

A MONG the Fall publications of Houghton Mifflin Company will be a volume entitled "What Is a Book: Thoughts About Writing," edited by Dale Warren. Twenty well-known authors have contributed to this book, each writing a chapter on some particular phase of literary effort.

ONLY a few weeks ago the entire Roman Catholic world celebrated with great solemnity the official canonization of Sir Thomas More, who with his friend Cardinal Fisher was executed by Henry VIII for declining to recognize that pleasing monarch as supreme head of the Catholic Church in England.

Immunizations against diphtheria for the first six months of 1935 were 37 per cent less than for the same period last year, the Health Department pointed out yesterday, urging parents to safeguard their children from the disease, which generally becomes more prevalent with cooler weather.

THE cinema is living with a swagger. Attention suddenly has been directed to the scenery chewing stories of the swashbuckling era and Hollywood is making the most of it. It is the actor's holiday and, when the cycle is over, there will not be a set standing that has not known the crunch of thespian teeth.

GLASGOW, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press). -- The eighty Glasgow Rangers were held to a 2 -- 2 draw by Ayr United in a hard soccer battle 'on-the latter club's grounds today. The match was one of the features in the Scottish football league.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A continuation of the power lobby investigation into the early stages of the 1936 campaign was revealed today as a strong probability.

SHANGHAI, China (AP). -- The spectre of famine -- running-mate of the natural disasters which periodically ravage this harassed country -- now hovers over the teeming plains of the Yangtse Valley, where millions of peasant families have seen their maturing crops wiped out by devastating floods.

When Lord Montague Chanways informs his friend, the Hon. Arthur Stukely Pennington, that he has signed a contract to finance the production of a musical comedy, Pennington foresees trouble. And Pennington is right. There is trouble, and plenty of it.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 17. -- Wiley Post will be buried here when an airplane returns his body from Alaska, while the body of Will Rogers will rest in California.

THE social security program, which has just been embodied in an act of Congress, represents a most significant step in our national development. It is a milestone in our progress toward a better ordered society, providing, as it does, protection against the loss of income due to unemployment, old age, and the death of the breadwinner.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The White Sox and the Philadelphia Athletics divided a double-header before 12,000 fans today.

In contrast with the recent heavy refundings, last week's announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity made the smallest total for a week in several months. The only new calls for August were various bonds and warrants of a half-dozen municipalities in Coolrado. and, excepting the definite call of a large Canadian railroad issue, the redemptions for later months were principally for small issues of industrial and public-utility bonds.

IT seems best to follow Mr. Havighurst's example by at once plunging into his story. No sooner has the S.S. Pamona, with a cargo from Shanghai, docked at Seattle and put the crew ashore than they find they are in for a 20 per cent pay cut and that in consequence the union has called a strike.

WHEN Ella Enslow went from her home in Dawyer, Tenn., to teach in the Shady Cove school she had only two miles to walk or ride; yet, as this simple and touching story shows, she was going into what was for her almost an unknown community.

Although the French liner Normandie holds the record for the fastest crossing of the Atlantic, a trophy designating the Italian liner Rex the record-holder will be presented to her captain and crew at exercises on Tuesday at Genoa. Harold K. Hales of London, donor of the trophy, will make the presentation.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- The advocates of peace and the party of the second part, bent on having its way in Ethiopia whether by force or by diplomacy, are just coming to grips in the tripartite conference which is getting under way here as this is written.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 17. -- Three weeks from now elections will be held to the first Parliament under the new Constitution, but one would hardly know it unless one studied various posters in public places or searched newspapers for little notes on the progress of electoral campaigns.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Local oarsmen had their big day of the year today in the fifty-fifth annual regatta of the New Rochelle Rowing Club, held before a large spectator fleet off Hudson Park. As the feature of the six-event program, the eight-oared crew of the New Rochelle Club turned back the strong Union Boat Club from the Harlem River by two lengths in a half-mile race.

MR. ANDERTON would invoke for the guidance of our discordant time the spirit of Washington, and he devotes this essay-like appeal to the effort of rousing popular attention to certain evils in the life of our republic and of inspiring recognition of the cure for them to be found in Washington's life, character and words.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Steel production continued to expand in the week ended on Aug. 10 at 47 per cent of capacity, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic business situation. Output was up 1 point over a week before.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17. -- Defying threats that he may be manhandled when he makes a speech tomorrow at an Old Settlers picnic at Hopkins, Mo., Judge Merrill E. Otis of the Federal District Court of Western Missouri prepared tonight for his trip to Hopkins, his boyhood home.

OMAHA, Aug. 16. -- While the grain farmer of the Corn Belt is doing battle on one flank with millers and packers over the collection of processing taxes, he is going to have a scrap on the other flank with an ancient antagonist, the cattleman.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 17. -- The great seasonal movement of California's fruit crop began this week.

SURELY Sir Walter Scott would have been pleased with this story of his own boyhood. Just as he dreamed himself back into the past until he recaptured its peculiar flavor, so has Elizabeth Janet Gray delved into the records and re-created not only the atmosphere of late eighteenth-century Scotland but also the spirit of a precocious and extremely lovable boy.

National uncertainties, engendered by the tax program, the revision of the Food and Drug Act, the Walsh bill and other impending legislation have clouded the outlook for advertising for the remainder of the year, with magazines scheduled to be the chief sufferer in loss of revenue, according to comment in advertising circles here yesterday.

MUSIC in London is at a standstill just now and will remain so till the opening of the Promenade concerts at the Queen's Hall on Aug. 10. But at Haslemere, Arnold Dolmetsch and his family have been busy with the eleventh festival of ancient music, which, beginning on July 22, continued till Aug. 3.

ROME, Aug. 17. -- While Italian negotiators were solemnly sitting around a conference table in Paris discussing with delegates of the British and French Governments the best means of avoiding war with Ethiopia, Premier Mussolini was in Southern Italy inspecting divisions of Fascist volunteers about to start for East Africa and promising them sweeping victories over the Ethiopians.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Report has it that the Democratic organization in Illinois is about to turn thumbs down on the renomination of Governor Henry Hornet. It is said that a way may be found which will permit him to retire with dignity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- President Roosevelt today approved grants totaling $15,246,882 for fifty-five local non-Federal public works projects in twenty-seven States, including provision for school, road and water works construction in four counties of New York and New Jersey.

It may be a trifle unfair to take the morbid symptoms displayed by this Congress within the past two months as if they were permanent characteristics. Men who are hot and tired and angry are often subject to nervous instability. They suffer from illusions and frustrations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17. -- California today became the first State to make a direct assault on the constitutionality of Federal laws setting up the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -Slashes in the sugar import allotments for Cuba and the Philippines and similar increases for Hawaii and Puerto Rico were announced today in final adjustments for 1934 and 1935 by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

A FEW years ago, as gardening history goes, the iris was somewhat of a despised "poor relation," usually shunted off into an unkempt corner of the garden. One of the recent striking garden developments has been the manner in which the iris has come to the very forefront of esteem among rich and poor, amateur and professional.
Who are the Ethiopians? Leading ethnologists have presented a clear pedigree and their opinions are backed clearly by scriptural history.

WHAT stroke was it that took Horatius, clad in full armor, to safety across the Tiber? How far did President Adams swim in the two hours he used to spend every day in the Potomac? Would Leander have drowned in the Hellespont had he known the American crawl?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- It became apparent today that Great Britain had not yet issued any formal invitation to a naval conference in October when Wilbur J. Carr, Assistant Secretary of State, made the third consecutive daily announcement that the State Department has not received such an invitation.
CLEVELAND Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Indians won both ends of doubleheader from the Senators today, 8 to 7 and 5 to 0, advancing to within a half game of the fourth-place White Sox.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15. -- Pennsylvania's new equal rights law already is causing anxiety, although it will not go into effect until Sept. 1. If the measure works as its language implies, Negroes would be given equal rights in hotels, places of public accommodation, resort and amusement.

CARLSBAD Caverns National Park, created in 1930, is expected to attract a greater number of motorists to New Mexico this Summer with the recent completion of Walnut Canyon Road, giving access to the park from the main Carlsbad-El Paso highway.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- What Italy wants in Ethiopia has come out here unofficially but indisputably tonight as a result of an utter disagreement between the French and British on the one hand and the Italians on the other regarding occurences at the conference.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Beach Club of Westchester Country Club on Manursing Island here will be the scene on Monday evening of the second of a series of subdebutante dances. Mr. and Mrs. Grover A. Whalen of New York are expected to be the guests of Mrs. William T. Hoops, chairman of the dance committee.

As a result of a ruling by Rufus E. McGahen, Budget Director, seventy-five civil service engineers and architects, all with eight to twenty years' service in the Park Department, have been dropped from the city service, it was learned yesterday.

Incredible as it may appear, the civilized world has adopted no standard of conduct, no law by which it may be governed. The various nations have not agreed upon any code by which they will abide nor upon any authority to which they will submit. Each country is left free to determine for itself the propriety of any action it may take, responsible to no generally recognized jurisdiction.

Many economists seem too prone to regard kilowatt-hour production of electricity as a yardstick of general business recovery. In my opinion, without very intricate analysis, it really is a very unsafe criterion, although unquestionably reflecting the activity of the electric generating industry per se.

Pedro's father was one of the potters whose skill made the Indian village of Tonala famous throughout Mexico for the beauty of its wares. It was an art handed down for generations from father to son, and Pedro himself was already proficient in the craft at an age when American boys are practicing football passes.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 16. -- Building activity in the Fifth Federal Reserve District is virtually double that of a year ago and labor and supply houses are benefiting materially.

TO obtain a landscaping that may be permanently satisfactory, the home owner in most cases must develop his own ideas regarding the planting. Too often this important matter is left to the nurseryman or to the "landscape gardener."

VIRTUALLY every form of organized crime under repeal has been busily exploited by our sensation novelists, but it has remained for the co-authors of this lusty tale to discover what is apparently a fresh phase of depression lawlessnes -- that of the bootlegged oil racket.

MR. GLOVER has lived so much and so zestfully in the ancient world that he makes it wonderfully alive and interesting to the reader. He has been for many years connected with the faculty of Cambridge University as lecturer in classical subjects and he is now its public orator.

Big Bill Lee, knocked about unceremoniously by the Dodgens last Wednesday, made a comeback yesterday at Ebbets Field and Charley Grimm's Cubs took the final of the series, 7 to 1, while a disappointed gathering of fewer than 3,400 fans booed the home team thoroughly.

JUST recently there was a discussion on how far a baseball had been thrown on the fly, and it wound up with G. Herman Ruth betting Col. Henry G. Rice, the Nashville poet, that no one had thrown the horsehide sphere more than 400 feet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- With the strike of the WPA workers a closed chapter, the administration is going ahead with its program of putting 3,500,000 employable men and woman now on direct relief or work relief into the ranks of employes on government-fostered projects.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Experts in the art of defensive play, South Africa's touring cricketers chortled gleefully over the failure of England's strategy in the opening day's play of the fifth and concluding test match between the two counties.

COMING to the other side of another hill, Hashknife Hartley, the roaming cowboy detective, and his faithful follower. Sleepy Stevens, arrive in the Pinnacle neighborhood just in time to undertake the solution of one of the most baffling mysteries the astute Hashknife has yet been called upon to grapple with.

WHEN Charles B. Cochran, the London theatrical producer, concluded arrangements with Vinton Freedley for a production of "Anything Goes!" in the capital of the British Empire it was apparent that something would have to be done in the way of "doctoring" the two "hit" lyrics -- those of "You're the Top!" and "Anything Goes!" -- for the benefit of English audiences.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 13 quotes Representative Rankin of Mississippi as follows:

An autopsy performed yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, revealed a case rare to medical science when a baby boy was found to have lived twenty-seven days with fluid in the cranial cavity instead of a developed brain.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Ethiopians throughout the empire will pray tomorrow for peace. Religious ceremonies and dances, dating back to the time of King David, will be staged before Emperor Haile Selassie and the Empress in St. George Cathedral.

Countering complaints that producers are chiefly responsible for higher prices in a wide range of consumer necessities, producers of tobacco, grocery, meat and textiles cooperated last week in supplying data to show that processing taxes alone are responsible for adding 1 to 12 cents to consumer costs on common staples.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16. -- Labor unrest, with strong possibility of a general tie-up of business in Pacific Coast ports next month, was the most unsettling influence in the week just ended. Waterfront unions are particularly belligerent, having tied up sixteen cargo vessels.

OUTSTANDING among recent events under the auspices of California's Relief Administration was a concert of the SERA Chorus, Giulio Silva director, devoted entirely to "modern American music," though one or two of the composers represented were not of American birth.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Archbishop John Gregory Murray asserted today that birth control organizations were like the Dillinger "mob," as both, he said, were "organized to commit murder."

Weather Bureau officials held little hope last night for early relief from the heat wave after studying the wind directions, barometric readings and other data accumulated during the day. There will be little change in temperature today and the sky is scheduled to remain blue.

Protest against Controller Frank J. Taylor's ruling that a retail sales tax must be paid by firms engaging in the resale of certain chemicals will be made next week, following the issuance of a writ of certiorari to the plaintiffs yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.

PIERRE LAVAL is now heavily engaged in the task assigned to him when he became Premier of France. That task is to straighten out the finances of his country and to bring about a more wholesome economic order. At the same time he is deeply involved in the negotiations over the crisis between Italy and Ethiopia.

THE directly nautical part of Sara Ware Bassett's latest novel is confined to the salty background of a retired sea captain. Her main theme deals with the wealth of romance in the everyday lives of the people in the little Cape Cod town of Belleport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican of Lake City, Mich., prepared for introduction today a bill to reduce the interest on Home Owners Loan Corporation mortgages from 5 to 3 1/2 per cent for the first three years and then 4 per cent annually.

IN both the Soviet and the emigre hemispheres of Russian literature this season's output has been rich. It would be impossible to outline in a brief article all the recent books which are worthy of attention. I will therefore confine myself to those of them which, for this or that reason, appear to me as the most important.

Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to obtain the cooperation of civic and business organizations in the preliminary campaign of education which is to proceed the formal opening of the city's drive against unnecessary noise. This formal drive is scheduled to get under way on Oct. 1 with a month of "noiseless nights."
The market for second-hand newspapers continued brisk in Bryant Park yesterday as the city opened its outdoor library designed to bring literature to park bench-sitters.

Cutting in front of a Third Avenue trolley car beneath the elevated pillars, a speeding five-ton moving van became wedged between the passenger vehicle and a pillar at 1 P.M. yesterday, according to the police. The crash injured twenty-five persons, two seriously.

CENSORSHIP is the chief bane of Hollywood's existence, according to Henry Wilcoxon, the tall, strapping English actor who played Mark Antony in Cecil B. De Mille's "Cleopatra." Mr. Wilcoxon, who is in New York prior to attending the opening of "The Crusades," said that pornography should be banned but that it was silly to carry the insistence on purity to such lengths that the word "liar," for instance, could be allowed only in comedies.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 (AP). -- American track and field athletes made a clean sweep of seven events against Austrian opposition today as Al Moreau of Marksville, La., equaled the listed world's record for the 110-meter high hurdles. Moreau, undefeated in his campaign abroad, was clocked in 14.2 seconds, defeating Leitner by six-tenths of a second.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The trend of American industry is shifting from big cities to their outskirts and from small communities to towns of medium size but rarely to small towns or isolated communities, and then only to escape union control and high wages, according to a survey made by Daniel Creamer for the Population Redistribution Study.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Grand National Treasure Hunt, in which purchasers of amusement park tickets get a chance to compete for prizes in a cartoon-titling contest, is not regarded by the Postoffice Department as a lottery.

The fifty-third annual meeting of the Supreme Council of the Knights of Columbus will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Some 300 delegates and alternates from every State in the Union and Canada, the Philippines, Panama, Cuba, Mexico, Puerto Rico, Newfoundland and Alaska will attend, and thousands of visitors will come here to participate in religious and social activities connected with the convention.

A policy of extended buying, originating in the Middle West, is now spreading rapidly among industrial purchasing agents in other sections of the country, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in its August survey of business conditions.

With government and other insurance in force as a guarantee of the safety of deposits in banks, generally even in excess of the $2,500 postal bank limit, many bankers contend that the desirability and usefulness of the Postal Savings System now are open to serious question.

RESTING in the open spaces of the Samuel Goldwyn Studios is a property known as the railroad train without a country. It moves back and forth over the twin tracks that have been its home for a number of years.
NEWPORT, R.I. -- Following the many dances of last week for young Summer folk here, there will be at least two such parties in the coming week.

NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 17. -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif, won the Newport Casino's nineteenth annual invitation singles tennis tournament today by defeating Frank X. Shields of New York in a five-set struggle before a large gallery.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- The question of what is to be done about the vacancy caused by the death of Charles V. Truax, Representative at Large, is now in the hands of the Ohio Supreme Court.

AT the Art Students League work in various mediums done by students in the Summer classes was placed on view last Tuesday. Also the league is now showing a group of seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth century Japanese prints, together with a few by modern artists.

I have read with a great deal of interest the articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine by Sir Philip Gibbs, "Looking at America," and by James Truslow Adams, "Looking at England." Any thoughtful person cannot but be impressed by the viewpoints of these authors.

Two fine Gobelin tapestries, outstanding among the numerous objects of art with which the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid furnished Ophir Hall, her country residence at Purchase, N.Y., have been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

ONE photoplay like "Alice Adams" (Radio City Music Hall) is worth all the dreary mediocrities of the Summer cinema. An honest, amusing and shyly touching drama of an adolescent girl in a small town, it is both faithful to the spirit of Booth Tarkington's novel and a creative work in its own right.

THE problem presented in "The Well of Loneliness" and "The Children's Hour" is again before us in Gale Wilhelm's brief story of the Lesbian relationship of three young American women. It must be stated at once that this potentially disturbing subject-matter is carefully handled.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Good Hands Cup at the sixth annual Lake Placid Horse Show went to Ingram Sharpe Jr. of Buffalo today. Miss Ann Bernhard of Brant Lake was second and Miss Catherine Searles, Lake Placid, third.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A graphic description of the discovery of the wreck of Wiley Post's plane in Alaska and of how the Eskimos sang a dirge while bearing the bodies to Point Barrow was radioed to the War Department today by Stanley R. Morgan, staff sergeant of the Signal Corps, who first reported the disaster.

In the first year of regulation of the National Securities Exchanges by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the number of issues traded declined and new listings ran behind the levels of pre-depression years, according to an analysis of security listings.

The Cardinals, whom a few hasty folks were inclined to count out a few days ago, still seem to be on their feet, and, what is even more startling, they right now are actually doing the counting themselves.

MOST of the developments in automobile manufacture have emerged after more or less heated controversies. Engineers seem to disagree as much as doctors. Sedan bodies, all-steel bodies, four-wheel brakes and knee action have all passed through the storms of debate.

LAKE PLACID -- Today's water pageant at Schroon Lake, to be marked by some of the fastest speedboat competition on Adirondack lakes this Summer, throws into high gear the merriest week of mid-season in the mountains.

HERE is a companion, and equally admirable, volume to Mr. Horrabin's "Atlas of Current Affairs," with which he recently won much praise. He was, he says, impelled to make this new book because of the realization that grew upon him while working on the former of the necessity of a background of historical knowledge for the right understanding of present-day problems.

WHILE the amateur night in the theatre a half century ago was a Roman holiday for a rowdy audience, radio, in a more benevolent mood, deals more kindly with the novice. So observes William A. Brady, veteran theatrical producer, who says radio has thrown open a gateway to an amateurs' paradise.

INTEREST in the small plane program so actively pushed by Eugene L. Vidal has been heightened by the performance, on the whole very satisfactory, of the Waterman tailless plane, flown by John H. Geisse of the Bureau of Air Commerce from Santa Monica to Washington.

HERE is a first novel that celebrates with realistic details, some humor and considerable vigor the plights of a dozen or more aliens rounded up by the agents of the Department of Labor under the deportation laws. Running through the story, which contains its share of descriptions of rowdy and sadistic behavior, bawdy and grotesque incident and snatches of the language of jail birds and other mugs, is a romantic and idealistic love story.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- With Senate and House conferees still at loggerheads tonight on vital provisions of the administration's tax and liquor control bills, two new problems were added to the legislative controversy which President Roosevelt will be called upon to solve at his conference with Congressional leaders tomorrow night.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Premier Mussolini is paying dearly to send his troops to least Africa, as the latest statistics of the Suez Canal, issued here today, demonstrate. They cover the first six months of this year, and since then the Italian dictator has greatly increased the rhythm of his expeditions, but even these figures show a startling increase in the Italian use of the canal.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Seventy-one pistol teams, most of them composed of policemen, competed in the fourth international police pistol championship match here today on the pistol range of the police of the Township of Teaneck.
VIENNA, Aug. 17. -- Austria's economic position is marked by an increasing general optimism. During the last half year the country has shown incontestable proofs of a steady recovery.

THERE is a tendency among gardeners to assume that Spring and Summer are the growing seasons and that during Autumn there occurs only a sort of mellowing and ripening off of the garden. This assumption, however, is far from correct.

ALONG with the return of tufted red satin and double chairs in horsehair upholstery, as part of the decorative scheme within doors, the fuchsia -- equally redolent of the Victorian era -- is coming back into favor with gardeners for decoration without.

FIFTY-EIGHT play schools and seven day camps are being conducted this summer by the Board of Education in cooperation with the Park Department and relief authorities. About 13,000 children of all ages attend them daily, painting, modeling and "making things."

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 17. -- Through the same murky Arctic skies which lured them to death, the bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post were borne to Fairbanks today in the first phase of the long journey home.

BALTIMORE. ONE hundred years ago, on Aug. 25, great excitement reigned in Baltimore. A momentous event was taking place -- the opening of the railroad between this city and Washington. It was the first railroad to enter the capital and was a part of the Baltimore Ohio system which was inaugurated seven years previously -- July 4, 1828 -- Charles Carroll of Carrollton laying the first stone.

THE Indians of the Labrador peninsula appear to have resisted rather successfully the attempts that have been made over a period of 300 years to civilize and convert them to Christianity. Here is a book that shows the results of an attempt to understand them, and it is quite obvious that Mr. Speck met with greater cooperation than did those who tried to change their religion and mode of living.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Browns opened a six-game series with third-place Boston today by upsetting the Red Sox in both ends of a double-header. Rogers Hornsby's men stretched out a dozen hits to win the opener, 11 to 7, and blanked the visitors, 7 to 0, in the nightcap.

It is matter for congratulation that when the rest of Europe is in a welter of discord the Balkans should be showing an excellent example of peace and amity. For many a decade they have been referred to as "the powder magazine of Europe," always on the point of explosion.

Last week the Massachusetts House of Representatives passed a resolution condemning religious persecution in Germany. Baron KURT VON TIPPELSKIRCH, German Consul General in Boston, was moved to remonstrate against the passage of the resolution and its language.

WOMEN, welcome a complete change of spirit when they leave slapdash Summer clothes and accessories for more formal Fall ensembles. New bags and shoes, now making their appearance in the shops, are quietly elegant, designed to meet that trend toward suaveness which accompanies the first hint of Autumn in the air.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- An afternoon of record shattering, when American speed marks as well as those recognized throughout the world in motor boat racing were lowered, not only established new times for several outboard hydroplane classes but also confirmed the suspicion that the fastest single-engined craft among inboards was Betty V.

CECIL B. MILLE'S "The Crusades," the first road-show photoplay of the new season, will have its world premiere on Wednesday night at the Astor. After that it will be shown twice daily. In its cast are Loretta Young, Henry Wilcoxon, Ian Keith and Katharine De Mille.
PARIS, Aug. 16. -- As time passes and new efforts are made at conciliation of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, the position of France is becoming more difficult.

The views of John Block, president of the Association of Buying Offices, printed in THE TIMES last Sunday, in which he stressed the vital role of group buying in enabling independent retailers to meet chain-store competition are commented upon in a letter addressed to the Business News Editor by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

To the Japanese, assassination is an extreme but accepted form of political protest. The murder last week of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, Director of Military Affairs in the War Office, by Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa, as a protest against efforts to remove the army from the political field is incomprehensible to the average American.

IN the July-August Bulletin, just issued, two of the executives of the Section of Painting and Sculpture, Public Works Branch, Procurement Division, Treasury Department, have contributed pointed and significant comment on mural painting under the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The consideration and signing of bills put through Congress in the end-of-the-session rush of legislation now occupy most of President Roosevelt's time. But very few persons know all that happens to a bill when it goes to the President for signature -- and after he has disposed of it.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 17. -- Bishop Edwin D. Mouzon of the Methodist Episcopal Church South declared here tonight that he was "more hopeful" than he had ever been that the plan for a united Methodist Church of 20,000,000 members in the United States would meet with success.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- The Rev. and Mrs. George Grenville Merrill entertained with a luncheon at Merrilton in honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Wright of Mount Kisco, N.Y.; Samuel Hammill and Miss Lucia Hobson of New York.

IN answer to hundreds of requests "Good-Bye, Mr. Chips," one of the more pleasing and popular of the British dramatic importations, will receive a third hearing in this country when it is broadcast over WEAF'S network at 10 P.M., on Aug. 27.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- Belief was expressed by Richard Walther Darre, Minister of Agriculture, in a book published today that the office of every German marriage clerk should have a superintendent of breeding attached to it.

A NEW parade ground for New York's beach-loving millions is rising along Staten Island's south shore. Borough President Joseph A. Palma, using a silvered pick and shovel, broke ground recently for a $2,000,000 boardwalk. Within a year the structure will be completed and the strange alchemy of human nature will begin transforming the silver into gold for island property owners.

COTTON, says Mr. Garside, who is economist of the New York Cotton Exchange, is of such importance in the United States that it "directly affects a far greater turnover of commercial funds than any other crop." It is of so much more importance than wheat, its nearest competitor in the scale of crop values, that wheat "ordinarily yields less than half as much cash to the growers as cotton does."

CAPE TOWN. -- The recent announcement that the German-African Lines have placed orders for two 16,000-ton ships foreshadows increased competition for the South African Union's passenger and cargo trade. No other trade route in the world is developing to such an extent and the ship-building programs of British and foreign lines for their South African services involve an expenditure of almost $50,000,000.

The volcanic, storm-swept Western Aleutian Islands, far-away possessions which the United States has almost forgotten since they were obtained from Russia in the Alaska purchase of 1867, may figure prominently in our penal and our naval systems if two suggestions made public last week should be put through.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- A total of 476,000 shares of stock was traded on the Chicago Stock Exchange this week, against 377,000 last week and 140,000 in the corresponding week in 1934. This week's volume was the largest since the week ended on Feb. 10, 1934, when 662,000 shares were traded.
MANILA, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The projected treasure hunt of three adventurers ended with their shipwreck in the Northern Philippine Islands, it was disclosed today with their arrival here.

SOMETIMES it is a great mistake to read the publisher's blurb about a new book before reading the book. For, filled with a valiant purpose and a superstitious faith in words, it too frequently happens that he mistakes the book's best significance.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -Eighty-seven yachts sailed in the annual invitation regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club on Moriches Bay today. In addition to the home craft, boats came from both Great South Bay and Shinnecock Bay.

SOMETIMES it is a great mistake to read the publisher's blurb about a new book before reading the book. For, filled with a valiant purpose and a superstitious faith in words, it too frequently happens that he mistakes the book's best significance.
AND what do you do, Charlie Guide?"
Charles K. Ulrich, who was a reporter for The New York Herald in 1912, recalled last night how Will Rogers made his first motion picture during that year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Improved retail trade conditions are largely responsible for a $140,000,000 increase in the amount of money in circulation between Jan. 31 and July 31, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its August bulletin.

Conditions in the world silver market were quiet again yesterday following the excited movements earlier in the week. In London the price rose 1/16d to 29 1/16d an ounce, while in New York the quotation was unchanged at 65 3/8 cents.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Publication today of foreign trade figures for the first seven months of 1935 show a continuance of the discouraging situation with which France has been struggling for the past few years. All figures shown are in millions of francs.
The value off the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Once more the question of the proposed construction of a bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street -- a project over which for some forty years engineers, Federal and city authorities and interested companies have disagreed -- has brought forth sharp debate.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- A throng in which society was unusually well represented, taxed the capacity of the race course this afternoon.

THE past eighteen years in Soviet Russia have seen a conscious attempt to make all cultural manifestations a natural part of the daily existence. The manner in which music has been cultivated and disseminated throughout the land indicates the importance that the government and the party attach to this art.

ITALIAN antique furnishings have a versatility and richness which commend them to the decorator in creating period effects. Few national styles offer so wide a variety of design as they. The great centres -- Florence, Venice, Genoa and Naples -- had each its own technical and cultural characteristics which were reflected in the furnishings which it created.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- Temporarily Puerto Rico is resting from its war on and for Governor Blanton Winship. The calm, however, is not expected to last long. With the precedent of the Virgin Islands compromise whereby opponents of Governor Paul M. Pearson forced his resignation -- without loss of honor -- there are dissatisfied elements here determined to get General Winship out.

E. DONALD STERNER, Highway Commissioner of New Jersey, announced last week that he would approve the appropriation of State funds for work in municipalities provided that 40 per cent of every grant be used to pay for labor.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17. -- News of what was declared to be the first exploration of a mysterious region near the top of the world where some unknown force is said to turn vessels off their courses was received in radio messages today from the Russian exploration ship Sadko.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- For a hog situation like the present one it is necessary to go back as far as the depression of the Eighteen Seventies, the severest that the country had been through up to that time.

Salvatore Benedetto, 24 years old, of 1,615 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, saved a $503 payroll yesterday morning, but his heroism cost him his life. The five men involved in the murder escaped, but one suspect was arrested later.

NO tool-maker is out of work in the Michigan manufacturing area. This is a condition apparent from talks with employment chiefs of automobile factories concerning preparations that are being made for 1936.

Because of the high temperatures which prevailed, the pace of retail trade in the metropolitan area last week was slower than that of previous weeks. Retail executives estimated department store volume ran slightly ahead of or even with the figures for the same week a year ago.

History is repeating itself this year among the country's leading outboard drivers as they load their hydroplanes, their spare motors and other gear on auto trailers week after week and scoot about the waterways entering regattas.

TUOLUMNE COUNTY in California is one of the most famous counties in the United States. Within its boundaries lay a large part, although not the whole, of the Mother Lode, most bountiful of all placer deposits, out of which flowed gold dust and nuggets in an amazing stream, precipitating the great gold rush. Its story has been celebrated in dozens of books.

FIVE months hence the annual round-the-world cruises will be under way. Last week the Cunard White Star Line announced that the Franconia would sail on Jan. 7, the Canadian Pacific announced the departure of the Empress of Britain for Jan. 9 and the Hapag Lloyd substituted the Reliance for her sister ship, the Resolute, and set Jan. 11 as the day to get under way.

While warm weather in certain sections of the country held down retail trade, in most areas early August gains were either maintained or broadened last week. In some instances volume ran 25 per cent ahead of last year.
Such things as sales taxes, the New Deal, the "Huey Long influence" and constitutional amendments will concern some of the country's voters within the next month.

DYNAMITARDS, when indulging in a playful pastime, sometimes conceal their bombs in a bouquet of flowers, whose fragrance anticipates a more explosive sequel. Thus is it that, by polite camouflage, this volume conceals its importance as an injection of the past into the present.

The revenue bill of 1935, if enacted, should permit a new declaration of corporate value but should require no reductions in value for capital stock tax purposes except for capital actually withdrawn, according to a report made yesterday by the committee of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants appointed to study present and pending Federal revenue measures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Rarely has Washington seen such a spectacle of a tired and harassed Congress struggling on toward the earliest possible adjournment as is now on view in the national capital. The things that happen in the final days of any Congressional session cannot be understood unless it it borne in mind that members are physically exhausted, that nerves have been worn to a frazzle and that enthusiasm is at a low ebb.

LONDON, July 29. SOME weeks ago, while discussing in these columns the distinction between the modern, naturalistic style of acting and acting in the "grand" or romantic manner, I spoke of Shelley's tragedy "The Cenci" as a neglected masterpiece and as a supreme opportunity for romantic performance.

Harry Tresnak of the Lenox Hill A.A. captured the metropolitan A.A.U. one mile swimming championship yesterday in the Jerome Cascades pool by defeating the defending titleholder, Ray Ruddy of the New York A.C. by two yards. Tresnak, timed in 23:24.9, won a leg on the James A. Farley Cup.

ATHENS. -- Among the Greek people the division over the proposed restoration of former King George II, son of the wartime sovereign Constantine and head of the House of Glucksburg, cuts across all classes and most professions, takes the older generation back into impassioned defense of the allegiances of its youth and inflames the young with a desire to rid Greece forever of the republican-versus-monarchist feud which has scarred its past twenty years.

An incident illustrating the kindly nature of Will Rogers, how he had helped a young mother overburdened with children and baggage off a Long Island Railroad train after the other passengers had hurried from the car, is described by Frederick W. Lewis of 39-40 Old House Landing Road, Little Neck, Queens.

MONTREAL, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Pete Appleton pitched the Royals to their second straight victory over the Newark Bears today, 4 to 1, and gained his eighteenth triumph of the season. He gave only eight hits, three of which were made by Dick Porter.
Alone the northern coast of Long Island Sound, especially endowed with yachting harbors from City Island to well beyond New Haven, is a uniquely attractive cove between Greenwich and Stamford.

THE announcement that George Balanchine is to be the new ballet master of the Metropolitan Opera comes not altogether as a surprise. It was reported as a possibility in these columns last March, when the American ballet of which Mr. Balanchine is maitre de ballet was concluding its first season at the Adelphi Theatre.

Among the noises which the Mayor's commission might well forbid are the three blasts sounded on a steamer's whistle when she puts out to sea. Not that they shatter the nerves; on the contrary, they are most beguiling. They should be silenced because they breed discontent in the vast majority of the citizens.

The things that happen in the final days of any Congressional session cannot be understood unless it it borne in mind that members are physically exhausted, that nerves have been worn to a frazzle and that enthusiasm is at a low ebb.

SOME weeks ago, while discussing in these columns the distinction between the modern, naturalistic style of acting and acting in the "grand" or romantic manner, I spoke of Shelley's tragedy "The Cenci" as a neglected masterpiece and as a supreme opportunity for romantic performance.

Harry Tresnak of the Lenox Hill A.A. captured the metropolitan A.A.U. one mile swimming championship yesterday in the Jerome Cascades pool by defeating the defending titleholder, Ray Ruddy of the New York A.C. by two yards. Tresnak, timed in 23:24.9, won a leg on the James A. Farley Cup.

An incident illustrating the kindly nature of Will Rogers, how he had helped a young mother overburdened with children and baggage off a Long Island Railroad train after the other passengers had hurried from the car, is described by Frederick W. Lewis of 39-40 Old House Landing Road, Little Neck, Queens.

OCEAN GATE, N.J., Aug. 17. -A fleet of over seventy-five boats competed in the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association weekly races held off the Ocean Gate Yacht Club today. Some of the finest races of the Toms River and Barnegat Bay season resulted, with fair breezes and smooth seas.

Three months ago a group of leaders in New York's industrial, commercial and professional life met at the Waldorf with J.N. Darling, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, to discuss an old, old problem -- what to do about the continued decline of wild life on the North American continent.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP). -Clever hurling by Fred Lucas and Ralph Birkofer gave the Pirates a double victory over the Phillies today.

TOKYO, Aug. 17. -- Japan's mermen -- a great array of distance and breast-stroke swimmers -- seized a commanding lead on the opening evening of the Japanese-American three-day meet, winning three of tonight's four races.

A VERY beautiful book, fit to fascinate any lover of flowers and to delight and inspire any devotee of the art of using them for indoor decoration. Of small quarto format and printed on heavy cream paper, the full-page plates, of which there are eighty or more, have ample space for the presentation of their beauty.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 16. -- Business conditions throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District continue to show improvement, reports to the Reserve Bank here indicate.
