Merchants throughout the area report increasing sales volume, in spite of the seasonal decline, and industrial activity and building operations continue to absorb the unemployed and lighten relief loads.

IN his introduction Sir John Squire, who is one of the editors of the English Heritage Series, in which this is the fifteenth publication, speaks of the book's theme as "one of the most purely national elements in our English heritage." It is a heritage in which our own country shares in a peculiar way.

PLANS for the Third International Congress of Persian Art and Archaeology are now being completed. Sessions will be held in Leningrad and Moscow in September. The organization of the Congress (outside Russia) is in the hands of the International Committee for Persian Art and Archaeology, of which Professor F. Sarre is president, Arthur Upham Pope, secretary, and Professor D. Talbot Rice, treasurer.
PARIS, Aug. 7. -- Deauville is the centre for numerous turfmen and yachtsmen, and the dances at the Deauville Yacht Club, from 5 to 7, are a feature this season.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Henry Spiak, 14-year-old cripple of 9 Mildred Street, Yonkers, was in plaster of paris casts in Yonkers General Hospital today after the first of a series of operations undertaken to enable him to walk. The operation was performed Friday afternoon, surgeons disclosed today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Combining fleetness of foot with a stout heart, Hal Price Headley's Sparta took the measure of a good group of 2-year-olds, including the well-liked White Cockade, when she won the Shawomet Stakes, six-furlong feature for juveniles, with $5,000 added, today.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Joseph D. McGoldrick, former New York City Controller, advocated a pay-as-you-go basis for relief work in a speech here tonight at the fifth annual economic conference for engineers at Stevens Camp. At the afternoon session of the conference, Louis M. Faulkner, Deputy Chamberlain of the City of New York, suggested the use of the taxing power of municipalities as an instrument to compel slum clearance.

WHETHER we call it American English or American speech or the American language (a matter on which writers have long differed and even disputed) does not really matter a great deal, so long as the name carries with it a clear understanding of what it implies.

Among the noises which the Mayor's commission might well forbid are the three blasts sounded on a steamer's whistle when she puts out to sea. Not that they shatter the nerves; on the contrary, they are most beguiling. They should be silenced because they breed discontent in the vast majority of the citizens.

Charges of waste, extravagance and mismanagement were made yesterday against officers of the Madison Square Garden Corporation in a letter sent to stockholders By a committee which is seeking to replace Colonel John R. Kilpatrick, president of the corporation, with Colonel John S. Hammond, now chairman of the board of directors. The annual meeting of the corporation's stockholders will be held on Sept. 24.

FLAT TOP, W. Va., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago editor, told one of America's oldest and largest family reunions today that the socialistic and communistic trends in some parts of Europe were "the antithesis" of what animated America's founders.

TOKYO, Aug. 15. -- Jack Medica of Seattle today bettered the world's 400-meter free style swimming record as he and other American aquatic stars cut down the lead of Japanese opponents in the second program of a three-day international meet.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- The three-power conference on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute collapsed today, destroying the last hope of preventing armed intervention by the Italians in Ethiopia. Discussions will continue through diplomatic channels, but none of the delegations here made any effort to hide that the next date for any new developments will be Sept. 4, when the League of Nations Council will meet.

Legalizing of Sunday theatrical performances was condemned by the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren, associate pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Construction of a northbound ramp to permit traffic from the Thirty-fourth Street district to enter the West Side express highway has been urged upon Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan by the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 19. -- The breakdown in Paris yesterday has left British newspapers appealing for calm judgment while the question is debated as to what should or should not be done at Geneva if what The Times calls the frail hopes of a settlement through diplomatic channels fail.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Catholics of the St. Paul Archdiocese were forbidden today to hold membership or employment in organizations advocating birth control under penalty of excommunication.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18. -- With grain harvesting in full swing throughout the Soviet Union and more than 58 per cent of the plan completed by Aug. 10, the Bolshevist press is predicting a grain crop of 100,000,000 to 110,000,000 tons, 15 to 20 per cent higher than the bumper crop of 1933.

The family of Will Rogers left New York yesterday for Beverly Hills, Calif. In the party were Mrs. Rogers, her three children, Mary, Will Jr. and James; her sister, Miss Theda Blake, and a nephew, James Blake. Mrs. Rogers and her daughter arrived in New York Saturday from Skowhegan, Me., where Miss Rogers had been playing in a Summer theatre.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- Industrial fatalities reported to the workmen's compensation division of the Department of Labor for July totaled 110, according to Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews. This is four less than the number for June and brings the total for seven months to 820 death claims filed.

Alderman Fairchild, in a letter to THE TIMES, takes snap judgment on taxicab rates. He shows a woeful lack of accurate data to guide him. May I call his attention to what THE NEW YORK TIMES said editorially several years ago, in referring to the report of the Taxicab Commission.

This year's blowout of the Maine Three-Quarter Century Club was held last week in Farmington, Franklin County. Franklin County is in the Dirigo Far West, stretching to the Canadian border. Its rivers, the Sandy and the Dead, remind of time and mortality which the lively lads and lassies of the club don't bother their heads about.

Steel operations last week moved up more than 3 points to 51 per cent of capacity, the sixth consecutive weekly advance, according to the magazine Steel. This was the first time since the week of Feb. 16 that operations had crossed the 50 per cent level, the magazine said.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 17. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.7, which compares with 83.1 the week before, 82.9 two weeks before, 82.6 three weeks before and 81.7 four weeks before.

Fortune began to smile yesterday upon J.J. Muller, the portrait artist who had been ordered evicted from his studio at 144 West Fifty-seventh Street if he could not pay $200 arrears in rent by Wednesday. Several persons who read of his predicament offered their help, but the most practical offer came from the most unexpected source.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Private funeral services for Will Rogers will be held at 2 P.M. Thursday at the Wee Kirk o' the Heather in Forest Lawn Memorial Park. Every effort will be made to avoid demonstrations, officials said.
LONDON, Aug. 18. -- Brig. Gen. Sir Alexander Hore-Ruthven, an Englishman, is to succeed Sir Isaac Alfred Isaacs, first native-born Governor General of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Legislators have been furiously active conceiving and presenting bills, and making many of them laws, in the last year, according to the report of the legislative service bureau of the Merchants Association, made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Latest reports on the oats crop indicate serious damage from extremely hot weather in the critical period, with a large percentage of the crop in the best sections severely damaged and of light weight. This has disappointed the trade and caused selling by speculators who had bought futures expecting there would be a large demand, especially from processors, as the crop of 1934 was the lightest and poorest in recent years.

Baron and Baroness George de Latour, Count and Countess G. de Pins, William M. Astor, Baron Jean de Lustrac, Baron Alain de Laters, Count Bonin-Longaree and Mr. and Mrs. Lydig Hoyt are among the prominent persons arriving today from Europe on the French liner Normandie.
The Townsend plan and the share-the-wealth idea were discussed in three sermons here yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Announcement of greater Republican efforts to win the West in 1936 coincided today with word that Senator Borah of Idaho still leads the Lucas poll for the Presidential nomination.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- The advance guard of 600 delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor reached Albany tonight. Members of the executive council met to complete plans for the convention opening Tuesday morning.

World economic barriers and political policies were assailed as antiquated, false and inapplicable by the Rev. John Kent, pastor of Cathcart Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland, in a sermon as guest preacher yesterday morning at Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- A fleet of sixteen Star boats started today in a special regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club and J.B. Moore Jr.'s Lure came home first. Stanley Ogilvey's Jay, sailed by Bill Howe, was in second place, exactly one minute behind the victor.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 28. -- Crowded with 630 tourists on a cruise to Baltic and other Northern European ports, the Cunard White Star liner Laurentic, 18,724 tons, was in a head-on collision in the fog forty miles west of Mersey Bar early today with the Napier Star, 19,000-ton Blue Star liner, en route to Liverpool from Glasgow to complete loading.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Aug. 18. -- Jewish sports enthusiasts will find it impossible to attend the Winter Olympic games to be held here next February.

It is interesting political news that Senator BORAH has indicated readiness to accept the Republican nomination for the Presidency if it is offered to him. Several informal polls taken in various parts of the country have shown that his name is considered with great favor.

Calling attention to some of the recent difficulties over labor wages and payment schedules, Myron L. Matthews, writing in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports, states that no one denies that building trades labor has suffered during the current economic disturbance.

Funeral services for Michael T. McCarron, Tammany leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. at the Church of St. Catherine of Sienna, on East Sixty-ninth Street between First and York Avenues.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Tales of their battle last night and this morning with the tide of Vineyard Sound were told today by the crews in the New York Yacht Club fleet when they came ashore.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Browns scored their third victory in two days over Boston by defeating the Red Sex, 4 to 3, in the nightcap of a doubleheader today after dropping the first game, 5 to 2.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 18. -- George Becker Jr., skipper of the Khaki John, with two straight victories today made a clean sweep of the North Atlantic Coast Snipe Class championship races in Hempstead Harbor this week-end. By scoring three firsts in all, Becker enabled the Sea Cliff Yacht Club to retain the Lake Mohawk Trophy with a total of 4,800 points.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Leo Durocher, dropped by the Yankees and the Reds because he couldn't hit, smashed a home run into the leftfield bleachers with the bases full in the tenth inning of the nightcap today, to give the world champion Cardinals an even break in a double-header with the Braves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- New Deal legislation, effective and proposed, tends to "create machinery susceptible of use by a despotism," the American Liberty League charged today in making public a review of the career of the New Deal in the courts.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals today defeated the Newark Bears twice, 3 to 2 and 4 to 1, to go into a lead of three full games over the Buffalo Bisons in the International League race.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A housewives' "strike" against increased meat prices threatened today to spread from Detroit to Chicago.

War is imminent in Ethiopia not because the peace plans of the last fifteen years have been insincere, but because men lack in their hearts the resources to carry out their good intentions, the Rev. William W. Adams, professor at the Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary in Philadelphia, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street:

The chronicling of new high marks for stock prices has become a bit commonplace now that the share market has just completed five months of the upward trend and the seventh consecutive week wherein the average level has been lifted.

Mrs. Alice Mulligan, a 70-year-old widow living with her daughter, Mrs. Julia O'Brien, at 40 Allen Street, Annadale, S.I., was instantly killed yesterday morning by an automobile owned and driven by Miss Alice W. Cartisser, 26, a nurse at the Richmond Memorial Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- One of those in the White House conference tonight represented the President as favoring House "inheritance taxes to the higher estate levies approved by the Senate in the "Wealth Tax" Bill.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- With three-fifths of the Saratoga meeting history, it seems clearly established that Discovery is best in the handicap division, and Forever Yours the leader among the 2-year-old fillies. But there is nothing much in the 3-year-old division except Omaha and the Juvenile championship is a toss-up with Red Rain apparently best of the many claimants.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Drought was blamed today for the decline and fall of an ancient American nation.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 19. -- Six sailors perished and five others were injured in a bow-to-bow collision of the Cunard White Star liner Laurentic and the Blue Star steamer Napier star in the fog-shrouded Irish Sea today.

WHITE HORSE, Yukon Territory, Aug. 18. -- The 3,600-mile funeral flight with the bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post was resumed today by a fast plane that roared across the wilds of Northwest Canada toward the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- New high levels for prices for hogs and cattle for the season were made here last week. Cattle sold up to $12.50 a hundredweight, an advance of $2 in thirty days, and hogs topped $12.20, 5 cents better than the previous week's top.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- A determination to drive through all of the remaining essential measures on President Roosevelt's reform program, including the controversial Utilities Holding Company Control Bill, and to adjourn Congress by the week-end was reached tonight at a final conference of President Roosevelt and his Congressional leaders.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- The breakdown of the three-power conference here today has left in its wake evidence of a personal misunderstanding between two of the most important statesmen of Europe -- Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Premier Pierre Laval of France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Immediate enactment of a comprehensive neutrality policy for the United States was urged on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today by Senators Bennett C. Clark and Gerald P. Nye, on behalf of the Senate special munitions committee, on the ground that Congress could not, once war has broken out anywhere in the world, declare such a policy without taking sides in the conflict.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18. -- A serious shortage of petroleum and its principal derivative, gasoline, in the United States within the next five to eight years was predicted here today by experts in a report prepared for presentation to the American Chemical Society.

Total traffic in the city for the quarter ended March 31, 1935, on rapid transit lines, street surface railways, Hudson tubes and all bus lines reporting to the Transit Commission amounted to 740,949,000 passengers, according to figures made public by the State board yesterday.

With the response to August promotional sales good, the local wholesale markets continued very active last week. In addition to the orders placed by the large number of visiting buyers, requests for substantial quantities of goods came through the mail.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 18. -- A geologic history of Western New Hampshire during the past 375,000,000 years, as recorded in the bedrock of the Franconia, Littleton and Moosilauke region, is described in the two authoritative brochures the publication of which is announced by Charles F. Bowen, director of the State Planning and Development Commission.

Dissatisfied with the recent functioning of the Police Department and determined to weed out incompetence from its ranks, Commissioner Valentine has secretly instituted one of the most drastic orders in the history of the department, it was learned at police headquarters yesterday.

Harold Guinzburg, president of Viking Press, returns to the United States today aboard the Normandie. Mr. Guinzburg spent a month in London, and during that time read scores of books. Of the lot, he found only one he deemed worth issuing here.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 18. -- Eulace Peacock, Negro flash of Temple University, took four first places and helped win two others today as American athletes finished first in twelve out of sixteen events in competition with French and German track and field stars.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Grain traders the world over are most disturbed at the changed conditions that have come into the grain world within the last year. Those who give the situation much thought express the belief that it is best to forget what has happened in the past and give more attention to the world's crop and the world market as well as to financial conditions.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- The world-wide character of the serious situation that has arisen over Ethiopia was thrown into high relief during today's Anglo-Franco-Italian negotiations when J. Theodore Marriner, counselor of the United States Embassy and Charge d' Affaires in the Ambassador's absence, visited Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, and had a long talk.

A student flier's brother who was riding as his passenger in a rented plane was fatally injured yesterday when the plane plunged into a swamp near 263d Street and Rockaway Boulevard, South Jamaica, Queens, at about 5 P.M., a few moments after a take-off from the Jamaica Sea Airport at Springfield Dock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Discovery of an ancient city-site in North Syria, believed to have been a local capital of considerable importance in the Syrian-Hittite world about the period 1000 B.C. to 500 B.C., was announced today by the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Cubs and the Phillies divided a twin bill today. The Cubs won the first game, 8 to 3, and the Phils took the second, 6 to 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Although declaring that Federal deposit insurance was "not a complete remedy for the ills of the banking system," Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in his first annual report to Congress today, said that there was a marked decline in "doubtful and worthless" securities held by insured banks.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Gaylord Tucker gave a large tea this afternoon at their Summer cottage for Mr. and Mrs. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer of New York. The party followed the third of the large luncheons given by George H. Bull, president of the Racing Association, at the Saratoga Golf Clubhouse.

THE idea of hopeful humans gathering at golf tee for the express purpose of trying to make a hole-in-one is amusing in a sad sort of way. Holes-in-one have been made, of course. And a man going through the proper kind of clay deposit once came up with what is known as the Hope diamond. But nobody, even under the hot sun of South Africa, says "Ho, hum.

YAPHANK, L.I, Aug. 18. -- More than 5,000 representatives and members of the pro-Nazi Friends of New Germany gathered here today for the first of what they hope will be an annual Summer festival. Those present represented local groups of the organization from all sections of the country east of the Alleghany Mountains.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 49 per cent of capacity, representing a rise of 2 points in a week. The rate was the highest since late in March and compared with an average of 46.7 per cent in the first half of the year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a luncheon today at their place on Lake Agawam for Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Harriman, who are visiting Miss Ethel Wickham at Bonnie Bourne. Among their other guests were Miss Wickham, Mr. and Mrs. E. Henry Simmons and Miss Mary Mahony, who is spending the season with her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler, at Leny Cottage.

DETROIT, Aug. 18. -- The elongated Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe tied the Yankees in knots with his pitching today before the season's largest crowd at Navin Field, and, with his bat, hammered them into submission. Thus the tottering McCarthymen skidded eight games back of the Tigers, which practically means hopelessness.

The Citizens Budget Commission issued a statement yesterday criticizing the action of the justices of the Municipal Court in increasing their payrolls in the 1936 budget, and called the increases "unwarranted in view of the fact that the city faces an indicated deficit of $25,000,000 in the budget next year."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- A request that the Cuban Government pay interest on some $40,000,000 of public works bonds now in default was contained in a letter addressed by Senator Nye to Jose Manuel Casanova, president of the Cuban Social Economic Union and head of a good-will delegation visiting the United States.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The final session of Lake Placid's sixth annual horse show this afternoon 'was featured by the attendance of many young people from the camps.

The drawing power of the soloist as a feature of Summer symphony concerts was demonstrated again at the Lewisohn Stadium last night when an audience of 9,000 assembled to hear Harold Bauer perform Beethoven's "Emperor" concerto with the orchestra of Philharmonic- Symphony players under the baton of Alexander Smallens.
The Rev. Dr. Henry H. Tweedy of the Yale Divinity School denounced indifference to crime in a sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-second Street.

A valued correspondent, commenting on a recent editorial in THE TIMES, writes that it was weakened by its reflection of what he calls the "Geneva mind." It would he useless to deny this soft impeachment. But what is the Geneva mind? It is a specific form of the generalized international mind.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- A more confident feeling prevails among leaders in trade, who hitherto have been rather backward in expressing their opinions as to present and future conditions of business and finance. Wholesale and retail trade continues of good volume, with retail sales 10 to 20 per cent above those of a year ago, and wholesale business is up 10 to 15 per cent, although some report gains as large as 35 per cent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Edward V. Hartford, in charge of tickets for the Harvest Ball to be given on Sept. 20 for the benefit of the Rocky Farm Camp for Crippled Children, is creating a contest among the debutantes of the season by offering a prize for the one selling the most tickets for the ball.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Lawrence Marx's Alberta led ten Interclub Class sloops in a special regatta conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club off Larchmont today. Melville O. Griffiths's Kenboy was second, less than a minute behind the winner, with John M. Lovejoy's Wildcat third.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The age-long controversy among scientists and explorers regarding the existence of so called "Gilles-Land" was believed to have been settled today when the Soviet icebreaker Sadko reported to the Administration for the Northern Sea Route at Moscow that thorough search in the vicinity of the supposed terrain had revealed only "pack ice".

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Caissons rumbled across Jefferson County roads and honking lines of New York taxicabs, filled with troops, twisted in and out of heavy traffic as 17,000 National Guardsmen from eight States joined the First Army concentration at Pine Camp today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP). -- For the first time the two competitive States of Florida and California are cooperating in marketing a major farm crop.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Financial circles appeared this week to be considerably more optimistic, the change of mind being favored by the persistent uptrend in Wall Street and the better feeling of business leaders in the United States.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Miss Susan Robertson captured her fourth consecutive national long-distance swimming championship and added the twentieth distance title to the honor roll of the Women's Swimming Association of New York today when she streaked down the State boat channel to win from twenty-six opponents in record time for the course.

The Maine Central Railroad Company has issued details of its plan for exchanging its first and refunding- mortgage bonds due on Dec. 1, 1935, and its 6 per cent collateral-trust bonds due on Jan. 1, 1959, through a group of investment houses headed by the Lee Higginson Corporation.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP). -- New York State's new war on crime will advance on another front next week when police chiefs from the State's cities and villages go to school to learn new tactics in the fight against the criminal.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 18. -- The recent Italian airplane crash meant more to Italy than just the loss of some important men and a three-engined machine, for as a result of it Italy is said to be in a quandary in regard to her military and political plans in Ethiopia.

After twenty-three years with the American and United States Lines, Captain Frederick Fender, assistant marine superintendent of the International Mercantile Marine Company, has decided to retire from all connection with shipping at the end of this month.
It may have been because of a let-up in the recent high temperatures and the depressive humidity in general. Then, again, perhaps it was just the Reds.

ROME, Aug. 18. -- The breakdown of negotiations in Paris has caused neither surprise nor disappointment in Rome because nobody here has ever believed they would end in anything but failure. The most that can be said is that they lasted more briefly than was generally expected since people thought they would continue for about a week.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Ed Dudley, long-hitting Philadelphia professional, won the $3,500 seventy-two-hole golf tournament at the Acacia Country Club today with a score of 285. Dudley, starting the last round four strokes back of the leader, shot the course in 71, two under par, to take first money.

JOHNTSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Ninety-five per cent of the Federal income taxpayers file their returns and make their payments "without a quibble," according to Wright Matthews, assistant to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Indians bounced back from a ten-inning 4-to-2 defeat in the first game of a double-header today and routed the Senators, 13 to 4, in the second encounter, with twenty hits.

The course of prices for cotton futures last week was governed almost entirely by predictions from political quarters concerning the prospects for government loans on this year's crop. The net result was that, after moving over a range of about 80 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week with net advances of 14 to 16 points.

Worship of God through regular attendance at church is one of man's chief duties, the Rev. Frank R. Wilson, rector of St. James Church, Hyde Park, N.Y., of which President Roosevelt is the senior warden, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., Aug. 18. -- Splitting their combination for the first time since arriving in this country, the British Hurlingham polo players assumed the name of Whites in an exhibition match against the Greens and dropped a 9-5 decision before 4,000 spectators at Schley Field today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,283,310,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
A Universal photoplay, "Manhattan Moon," featuring Ricardo Cortez and Dorothy Page, will open at the Globe today.
" Lose a hook and spare a bass" is a new slogan coined by Charles A. French, member of the Pennsylvania Board of Fish Commissioners. It is a thought to which freshwater anglers may well give heed.

Revolutionary elements in the United States are watching "with satisfaction the path we now are treading," Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, warns in a pamphlet to be distributed to members today.

Howard Lindsay and Damon Runyon have at last completed the play on which they were first reported at work long months ago. It has acquired a title, "A Slight Case of Murder," and a playhouse, the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, where it should open next month.

Just what was the object of the Senate Finance Committee's including the British rates in its tabulation of income taxes? Was it to show to the taxpayers in the louver brackets the wonderful fiscal acumen of the administration in saving them from England's exorbitant charges?
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Young Democrats announced today an abrupt departure from tradition for their national convention starting, here Friday.
Tributes to Will Rogers and Wiley Post were paid by the clergy of different denominations here yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- A bold challenge to the extralegal and terroristic National Socialist campaign against Jews, churches, Freemasons and various other alleged enemies of the German State was issued today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, in a speech opening the Eastern Fair in Koenigsberg.

LATTINGTOWN, L. I., Aug. 18. -- The homes of F. Trubee Davison, former Assistant Secretary of War, and Artemus L. Gates, president of the New York Trust Company, were robbed here last night while the two families slept. Jewelry and cash amounting to more than $2,300 were taken from the Davison home. The loss at the Gates home was about $300.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 18. -- Doris Doe, dramatic contralto of the Metropolitan Opera and of the State Opera of Dresden, Germany, sang here today in the White Mountain festival as guest of the Yale Forty Niners at the Chase Barn Theatre. Edwin McArthur accompanied the singer, who gave her recital for the benefit of Morrison Hospital of Whitefield.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The silver tinge on the political horizon, instead of wearing off, has become more prominent in the final phase of this session of Congress.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 67.3 on Aug. 14. This compares with 68.1 a fortnight before, 67.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Net profit of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., for the twenty-eight weeks ended on July 13 was $604, 687 after provision for taxes, depreciation and reserves, according to the financial statement to be given out today. The earnings equal $2.16 a share on the 280,000 shares issued.

Only nine new plays, in addition to a diminishing list of revivals, will be shown on Summer theatre stages this week, marking the beginning of the end of the current season. Only a few more weeks and the barn doors will all be locked. The new plays to be shown are the following, opening performances of which will he given this evening unless noted:

EAST POULTNEY, Vt., Aug. 18. -- With an all-day observance of the Sabbath, at which several hundred persons worshiped as their fore-fathers had done 150 years ago on the same spot, the three-day celebration of the sesquicentennial of Poultney Baptist Church closed today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP). -- A train of eight cars on the Lehigh Valley Railroad carrying more than 300 persons destined for deportation passed through here tonight and will arrive in New York tomorrow about daybreak.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Efforts of the French monetary authorities are being directed toward a reduction in long-term interest rates in the hope not only of lightening the burden of public debt but also of inducing private industry to initiate new works contributing to business recovery.

Dr. Elizabeth D. McDowell, Professor of Speech at Teachers College, Columbia University, in a survey on voice types, just published, asserts that the vocal mechanism of President Roosevelt, the relationship of his mouth, throat and nostrils, is responsible for his "clear, resonant and warm type of voice."

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The great, brown beetle-shaped Betty V, rakish and streamlined with her round, sloping engine hood enclosing a 1,250 cubic inch Packard motor, today finished the accomplishment she started yesterday by winning in three straight heats the national sweepstakes championship, emblematic of American supremacy for motor boats with a single engine.
BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Italo-Ethiopian dispute stirs up several problems that directly concern Europe, observes the Frankfurter Zeitung today.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Frank Sprow, interclub moth class champion, skipper, and Joel Van Sant, both of the Atlantic City Club, tied for honors as the two-day sailing regatta sponsored by the Yacht Club of Stone Harbor and the borough of Stone Harbor closed here today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Three hundred persons were present last night at the Wyantenuck mid-August ball in Great Barrington. The largest of several dinners given before the ball was that of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Blodgett, who had thirty guests at Great Pine farm. They were:

Substantial gains were made by leading commodity futures last week with the exception of rubber, some of the metals and 1936 sugar contracts. The rate of activity was high and bullish sentiment was in evidence. In the cash markets, cotton, lard, raw sugar, coffee, cocoa, printcloths, silk and antimony rose, while tin, rubber, wheat, corn, rye and oats declined.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The minor crisis which suddenly developed in silver at the beginning of the week, bringing its price down 1 1/4d an ounce in three days after more than a month of complete steadiness, appears to be passing. The flurry arose from an unexpected change in the United States Treasury's silver-buying policy in London.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 18. -- A great second-half rally that finally tied the score and then put them out in front in the final period gave the Aurora poloists a victory over Greentree at the Sands Point Club today in another of the open championship test games.

Special patrolmen nd officers wearing uniforms similar to thoseof city policemen without authorization from the Police Department will be required to change by Jan. 1, 1936, into the gray outfits prescribed by the manual of procedure, Commissioner Nalentine ordered yesterday.

The recent letter of Mr. Davidson in THE TIMES prophesying the revival of the Bryan free-silver issue as the main controversy of the next Presidential campaign must have been of decided interest to all who can recall that memorable contest, with its result in the triumphant upholding of the gold standard.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The man in the street in London reads the news about the truculent resistance of Italy to British demands for a peaceful settlement of the trouble in Ethiopia and asks with painful surprise why the traditional Anglo-Italian friendship has disappeared, as if over night.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Silver Dare, owned by Miss Cynthia Myers of Cleveland, took the three-gaited championship sweepstakes at the final session of the sixth annual Lake Placid Horse Show today. Roger Young's Charm of Oakledge gained the reserve ribbon.

In an impressive ceremony, brightened by iridescent gold and silver brocade robes and picturesque icons, Archimandrite Ichernoff Heronim, former head of the Russian Orthodox Mission in Jerusalem, was consecrated Bishop of the Russian Orthodox Diocese of Detroit yesterday morning.

Coney Island, the criterion for beach crowd figures in the metropolitan area and near-by shore points, maintained its reputation by attracting, for the fourth time this year, more than 1,000,000 persons. Although bathers were standing elbow to elbow in the surf, no rescues were reported.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- An unusual degree of activity is being maintained by the stock market, although there are at last signs of holiday influences making themselves felt. In the last day or two industrial securities which had experienced exceptional activity and buoyancy have developed a reactionary tendency owing to profit-taking induced by the substantial appreciation of the last few weeks.

JIGJIGA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18 (Reuters). -- A foretaste of the heart-breaking difficulties an invading Italian army is likely to encounter once it leaves the lowlands of Ethiopia has been given to your correspondent, who has just had the experience, unique for a foreign journalist, of motoring from Diredawa to Jigjiga.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18. -- Notwithstanding the strenuous efforts of State and local police to reduce the alarming number of deaths in automobile accidents in Connecticut, this locality added three more fatalities to the list early today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18. -- "The danger of a new war looms greater and ever more imminent, and preparations for war are now being carried on before the eyes of the whole world," said Premier Vyacheslaff Molotoff last night in a speech to the delegates to the physiological congress.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- The dullness of German business is attributed largely to the uncertainty of the outlook in Ethiopia. It is considered certain that if war is not averted it will assume dimensions large enough to influence international trade materially and in particular to accelerate a world price recovery.

Manifold perplexities confounded children naming the seventeen anonymous animals at the Central Park Zoo yesterday. The contest, which opened Friday, went into its first Sunday under a bright sun that brought eager youngsters from places as far apart as Binghamton, N.Y.; Bergen County, N.J., and the Bronx.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday that special agents had arrested early Saturday a man who, they allege, had attempted to extort $20,000 from Thelma Todd, motion-picture actress, under the threat of death.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 18. -- Trading in cotton here increased last week, mainly because of conflicting advices from Washington concerning the policy of the government on loans to farmers in the current season. In the first half of the week, the impression prevailed that there would be no loans and prices declined more than $2 a bale, helped by favorable advices concerning the progress of the crop.
Other ball clubs may treat them with disdain, but when the Dodgers come in contact with the Pirates that one-time swashbuckling crew is scuttled with neatness and dispatch.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18. -- Before prayers were being offered today in American churches for peace and Ethiopian independence, the Emperor and Empress of Ethiopia, the Duke of Harrar, the Emperor's second son, and Ministers attended a mass in the Cathedral of St. Ghiorghis.

" AL" SMITH already has in hand a number of specimens for his collection of the native fauna of the States in Central Park and Prospect Park. When the plan first came out the question was raised in this column whether many of the States of the Union could qualify as the habitat of a particular animal.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's timely goal in the last thirty seconds on a backhand pass from Bobby Strawbridge broke a 5-all tie and gave the Hurricanes a 6-5 polo triumph over Old Westbury on Bostwick Field today.

The increasing apartment-house-building activity in the Bronx this season has had a stimulating effect upon real-estate conditions throughout the borough and investors and old-time operators are re-entering the market as purchasers of well-located properties.

WARSAW, Aug. 18. -- After their successes of the first two rounds against Czechoslovakia and Argentina in the International Chess Federation tourney, the United States players met with a serious reverse in the third today, when they were pitted against a powerful team presented by Hungary.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- With money abundant here, despite the increased mid-month demand, and banks complaining of a shortage of commercial bills, the flotation of Reich bills is becoming progressively easier. This week witnessed new issues of Reich treasury bonds, and not only the extension of maturity of the Gold Discount Bank promissory notes issued in May, but the sale of a large additional quantity of them.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Sentiment in the corn trade favors buying on all price recessions. Professionals are doing most of the business in futures here, but are timid about buying on sharp advances. Statistically the corn situation is the strongest in recent years, stocks being down to extremely low levels.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- Veiled threats of a juridical investigation into the alleged complicity of former Catholic Centrist leaders in the Rhineland Separatist plots of 1918 and 1919 were made today by Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Nazi Cultural Director, in a speech at a party gathering in Thuringia.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 18. -- The bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post rested in their funeral plane under close guard in a hangar at Sea Island Airport here tonight after a 1,700-mile flight from Fairbanks, Alaska.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 18. -- Several hundred Fairbanks residents were at the field here at 6:05 A.M. to bid silent farewell as the funeral journey of Will Rogers and Wiley Post was resumed.

HOPKINS, Mo., Aug. l8. -- Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis tacitly answered threats of personal violence from farmers infuriated by foreclosure sales in addressing a homecoming gathering in this country town today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Flames visible for four miles destroyed an $8,000 cabin cruiser, forced seven persons to jump overboard and sent one to Atlantic City Hospital, seriously burned from head to foot, late today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Facilitating the dissemination of information about new security issues prior to their effective registration, John J. Burns, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, ruled today that certain private analyses of forthcoming issues might be distributed.

On your financial page today there appears the statement that "the government has been 'making money' in a big way out of its power to issue currency and 'regulate the value thereof'; and in that connection a profit of $3,000,000,000 is mentioned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Restoration to the statute books of two New Deal measures found unconstitutional by the Supreme Court in their original forms neared today as the revised version of the Railroad Retirement Act was passed almost unopposed by the House and Senate, and the latter body gave its approval to a much modified Farm Mortgage Moratorium Law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- The United States Steel Corporation announced today a second appropriation of $20,000,000 to complete the enlargement and modernization of the plants of the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company, their subsidiary, at Gary, Ind.

Colonel John Reed Fitzpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, issued a statement yesterday replying to the committee that is seeking to elect Colonel John S. Hammond, chairman of the board of directors, as head of the corporation. The letter had made charges of extravagance and mismanagement against officers of the corporation.

Additional reorders on furs and to some extent on sports coats were received in the markets here yesterday. Mail orders were substantial, while the arriving buyers continued numerous. Deliveries on dresses are now increasing, although production is still hampered by the scarcity of novelty fabrics for spot delivery.

METUCHEN, N.J., Tuesday, Aug. 20. -- Robert Lees Stevenson 11-year-old boy who has run away from his home in Queens on fifteen occasions, was picked up by Corporal. Austin Kelly of the New Jersey State Police near Woodbridge last night, and was turned over to the police.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Although they were held to five hits and blanked for the first seven innings, the Cubs scored a 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies today to go into a virtual tie for second place with the idle Cardinals. While the teams are tied on games, the Cards are in front on points, the figures being .609 for St. Louis and .602 for Chicago.

With consumer interest in luxury items revived, manufacturers and importers exhibiting goods at the twelfth semi-annual gift show at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday predicted they would set a new record for dollar volume in sales this week.

WARSAW, Aug. 19. -- The fifth round of the international chess tournament was begun tonight, but only one match was completed. Hungary and Sweden, two of the leaders, played a 2 -- 2 tie, while Austria and Argentina scored 1 1/2 points each, with one game adjourned.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- T.O.M. Sopwith has commissioned the firm of Camper Nicholson, builders of the last three challengers for the America's Cup, to construct a new racing yacht for him, it was learned today. Like the others, the boat will be designed by Charles E. Nicholson.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Foreign political news over the week-end had a dulling effect on the stock markets here today and prices generally were lower. British funds and India stocks principally were affected, the latter by reports of a frontier disturbances in the northwest of India, which, following developments in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, caused investors to adopt a cautious policy, and buyng orders were virtually negligible.
The focal point in the foreign exchange market shifted suddenly yesterday from silver to the European gold currencies as "war talk" increased in Europe.

Prices of commodity futures were irregular in yesterday's markets. The volume of trading was slightly higher. A feature was the weakness in silk and cottonseed oil futures. In the cash markets, oats, pork, copper, zinc, tin and wool tops were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, cocoa, lard and rubber were lower.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Will Rogers and Wiley Post came back to Los Angeles tonight at the end of the tragic air journey Rogers had said in his whimsical manner would probably be to "just somewhere."

Two weeks away lies the annual international race of lifeboat crews, a two-mile battle down the Hudson River to the George Washington Bridge. To the winner goes the mythical championship of the commercial ships of the world, a leg on a silver cup and such acclaim as a Labor Day audience may accord.

Emergency police, fire and hospital apparatus sped to 116th Street and the East River shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon following reports that several persons had been buried in the collapse of a building.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Too much publicity on crime and too many sumptuary laws are blamed for the nation's "crime wave" by the National Law and Order Committee of the American Legion.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake approved today a voluntary petition by the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., of Passaic for reorganization of the company under Section 77-b of the Bankruptcy Act and consolidated with it an involuntary petition for reorganization that had been filed in the Federal court in Delaware by holders of $10,000 of bonds.
William Waldorf Astor, son of Lord and Lady Astor and grandson of the first Baron Astor, arrived yesterday from London on the French liner Normandie to spend two weeks in New York.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 19 (AP). -- More than 2,400 delegates from forty-three countries had registered here tonight for the opening of the nineteenth biennial Zionist Congress opening tomorrow evening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- An attempt to establish a new world record for seaplanes over a 1,000-kilometer course with a 1,000-kilogram load is scheduled to begin tomorrow from Hampton Roads, Va., with Brig. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, chief of the General Headquarters Air Force, at the controls.

The results of repeal on the drinking habits of the throngs which flock to Coney Island are analyzed in an article entitled "Liquor at a Family Resort," which appears in the August issue of the "ABC News," official publication of the State Liquor Authority, out yesterday.

Only $900,000,000 of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief fund voted by Congress three months ago is left unallotted; therefore municipalities that fail to submit a full list of PWA projects within the next thirty days will find themselves eliminated from consideration, Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, Assistant Public Works Administrator, announced yesterday when he arrived here after a survey of PWA activities in thirty-six States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- It is at this juncture of a Congressional session that the really effective trades are made, that controversial measures -- repugnant to a majority when standing alone -- go through by small margins.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The proposed work relief "program for youth" was discussed today with State directors of the National Youth Administration at a conference which will continue tomorrow, with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as the principal speaker.

The budget of the Department of Docks will be about $13,000 less for 1936 than it was this year, it was indicated yesterday during a perfunctory hearing held at the Budget Director's office, 253 Broadway.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- The German attitude toward the breakdown of the Paris conference over the Italo-Ethiopian conflict appears to be one of watchful waiting. German thought converges on the eventual repercussions on European politics.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will receive bids today for a new issue of $6,000,000 of one-year notes. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

Passage tomorrow by the Board of Aldermen of the bill to submit Mayor La Guardia's project for a $45,000,000 city power plant to the voters at the November election is almost a certainty, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Wheaton Fregeau of the staff of the Willard Parker Hospital was found dead yesterday in his bathroom shortly after noon in the hospital building. According to the police, he evidently had committed suicide. A bloodstained scissors, a stained razor blade and a used hypodermic needle were found in his bedroom, according to Detective Dominick Pape of the East Twenty-second Street station, and there were wounds on the body.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19. -- The discovery and isolation of a new male sex hormone, much more powerful in its physiological action than the original male hormone isolated four years ago and synthesized last October, was reported here today at the opening general session of the American Chemical Society, in the presence of 1,000 leading chemists from the United States, Canada and abroad.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Fifty-four yearlings, headed by the progency of Bull Dog, imported sire of the stake winners St. Bernard and Coldstream, brought a total of $70,250, an average of $1,301, in the Fasig-Tipton ring tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Lionel Barrymore and Wallace Beery, movie stars, and Mrs. Wallace Beery filed appeals today with the Board of Tax Appeals asking that $11,784 in income tax assessments be set aside.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- A maximum term of forty years and interest rates of between 3 and 5 per cent were prescribed for loans by the Resettlement Administration in an executive order promulgated by President Roosevelt today.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- The State Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York City, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, announced tonight those who passed the examination conducted June 26 and 27 for admission to the bar. Of the 1,417 applicants, 720 were successful.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's twenty-third home run of the season, with a man on base, helped the Athletics today to an 8-to-4 victory over Chicago in the second game of a double-header. The White Sox took the opener, 7 to 2, behind John Whitehead's effective pitching against Bill Dietrich.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19. -- Winning two races and placing third in another, Miss Lorna Whittelsey and her mates from the Indian Harbor Yacht Club held a slim lead today as the series for the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, got under way at the Beach Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- An income-tax controversy involving $886,720, in which the government contends that the Radio Corporation of America underpaid its 1929 income taxes by $199,006, while the corporation insists that it actually paid $687,723 too much, was laid before the United States Board of Tax Appeals today.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 19 (AP). -Flames, rearing through parts of Maine's 15,000,000 acres of sun-baked, tinder dry forest land today, caused Governor Brann to suspend all inland fishing rights, except from boats, and to prohibit smoking or building of fires in the woods.

With local, State, interstate and Federal support, a fresh effort is about to be made to moderate the pollution of near-by waters. New York City's largest immediate contribution toward the attainment of this desirable end is to be the completion, with the aid of Federal funds, of the great sewage disposal plant on Ward's Island, whose role Dr. SOPER described in Sunday's TIMES.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt agrees that woman's place is in the home, but she adds that "if she really cares about her home, that caring will take her far and wide."

SKOWHEGAN, Me., Aug. 19. -- With William A. Brady addressing the audience between the acts and with Sally Rand, Max Gordon, Grace George, Owen Davis and Arthur Byron in the audience, the new John B. Hymer play, "The Little Inn," received its first performance here tonight in a production by the Lakewood Players.

They must have been smiling just at that moment -- Will pushed back deep in his seat, his eyes a-twinkle behind his goggles; Post leaning a bit forward, hands steady on the controls, his lips set in a pleasant curve. Two good friends starting off together again "to see something," as Will said.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Red tape today threatened to tie up about $27,000,000 of highway projects in the State. The delay arose over the inability of State officials to meet certain government specifications. The first award of highway contracts was scheduled for September 4. Another was to have been conducted on September 10.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Dr. Franz Guertner, Reich Minister of Justice, today challenged the world with the most lucid and logical statement of the Nazi idea of justice and the relations of the individual to the State that any official spokesman of the Third Reich has delivered.

Anthony Fokker, airplane designer of Alpine, N.J., who has been touring Europe for the last two months to introduce the Douglass airplane, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie. He said that the Dutch Air Line from Amsterdam to Batavia had tested his airplane and that he had closed an agreement with the Holland Aircraft Company for the manufacture and distribution of Douglass planes in Europe.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Persevering through an obstacle race, J. Seward Johnson and Robert B. Meyer brought the 12-meter sloop Cantitoe here today, winner of a race in which there just about was no second. It was one of the weirdest contests in the annals of New York Yacht Club cruises.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Another draw is in prospect in the fifth and closing cricket test match between England and South Africa, with both teams fighting tooth and nail in a high-scoring game. Surrey's famous home field, The Oval, accommodated a cheering crowd of 25,000 today for the second day of the three-day match.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 19. -Hal Price Headley's Whopper, a sizable son of Pharamond II, came into his own at Narragansett Park today with an easy victory in the Pawtucket Purse, nxile-and-70-yard feature for 3-year-olds.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the city's investigation into organized crime, appointed three more lawyers to his staff yesterday and then left town to devote three days to the uninterrupted study of the transcript of testimony taken before the March grand jury which inspired the present inquiry.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Napoliana, a bay filly by Napolian Direct, won the Illinois Breeders' Futurity 3-year-old pace, opening feature event of the Illinois State Fair Grand Circuit program today.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 19. -- A sixty-foot, brownish-gray reptilian monster, similar in description to the legendary sea serpents, was reported to have been seen by five Wellesley people for the second time late last night in Lake Waban, near Wellesley College, it was stated today.

In his tongue-lashing of the extra-legal Nazi campaign of terror against Jews, churches, Freemasons, and various other "enemies" of the German State, Dr. SCHACHT seems to have had a double purpose. No doubt he is genuinely concerned regarding the repercussions of foreign opinion about recent episodes on German economic life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Big business virtually exhausted the vocabulary of denunciatory adjectives today in condemning the Walsh bill to require NRA standards on government contracts, already approved by the Senate.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 19. -- The problems of a possible kidnapping, the identity of some one whose first name is Lucy and the disappearance of a carrier pigeon -- apparently eaten by a cat -- that carried a faded note telling of the "abduction," faced Orange police tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Bids were invited by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today, returnable at noon Aug 29, on twenty-seven issues of New York City securities ranging from $10,000 to $3,294,000 and aggregating $6,431,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Burial of the bodies of Will Rogers and Wiley Post in Arlington National Cemetery was proposed under a bill by Senator McAdoo passed in the Senate today without debate and sent to the House today. The measure authorizes the Secretary of War to grant permission for the burial if the families desire to take advantage of the offer.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The Axenstein filly Fair Stein, a galloping winner in her previous start here, surprised a good many when she charged through the stretch in game fashion to take the thirty-third running of the Kentucky Claiming Stakes today.

Patented flowers, fruits and other plants have not accumulated very fast since the plant patent law went into effect five years ago, on May 23, 1930, says Science Service. Files of the United States Patent Office allow only 124 plant patents of all kinds contrasted with the thousands of patents on mechanical devices and processes that pour from inventors' brains every year.

Further evidence of an improving demand for real estate in New York was furnished yesterday in a report by the State Mortgage Commission showing that the property supervision department of the commission has negotiations pending or up for court approval for the sale of more than $7,000,000 in metropolitan properties.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- The breakdown of the Paris negotiations has not created so much as a ripple on the surface of the situation in Rome. Everything goes on as it did before the delegates from the three powers met to discuss means to avert war.

On a bid of $800,000 the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as plaintiff, yesterday bought in the sixteen-story apartment house at 423-429 East Eighty-sixth Street, between York and First Avenues. The sale was conducted by Reid Kyle, auctioneers, in an action by the bank against the 425 East Eighty-sixth Street Corporation.

BOSTON, Aug. 19. -- Refusal of Mrs. Gertrude Annas, 35 years old, wife of a clergyman, to bear arms for the United States in the event of war resulted in the denial by the Federal court here today of her application to become a citizen.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- There is good reason to believe that as one result of the breakdown of the three-power negotiations on Ethiopia here the United States will be subjected to one of the most intense campaigns of persuasion that has been experienced across the Atlantic since the days preceding the United States' entrance into the World War.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Attorneys representing the Department of Agriculture and the Grain Futures Administration today filed an answer to Arthur W. Cutten's appeal from an order suspending him from trading on the American futures markets for two years.

VANDALIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Lela Hall of East Lynne, Mo., stepped into a man's game today and stole the show from her masculine opponents for the second straight year as the thirty-sixth Grand American trapshooting program opened.

The casting of "Pride and Prejudice," which is now one of Max Gordon's problems, has almost become a test of professional prowess. Katharine Hepburn was the original choice for the leading role when Arthur Hopkins held the play -- and he held it for her for a year, to no avail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Leaders of the fourteen-week strike at the Camden shipyards of the New York Shipbuilding Company spent today conferring with members of Congress on methods of bringing pressure to bear on the Navy Department to force cancellation of $50,000,000 worth of contracts with the company.

Back in the days of THEODORE ROOSEVELT, when the conservation of national resources was eclipsed in public interest only by trust busting, DAVID T. DAY, of the United States Geological Survey, reported that at the end of 1908 there was in the ground a minimum of eight billion and a maximum of twenty-two billion barrels of oil.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York announced yesterday that under its new 3-cents-a-day plan it was paying the bill of Mrs. Edward F. Hahn of Forest Hills in the Foote Memorial Hospital, Mich., where she was taken for treatment of a broken leg suffered in a motor accident in Jackson yesterday.

The first examination of officers of the Prudence Company, Inc., in the series of hearings authorized under Section 21A of the National Bankruptcy Act, was held yesterday before Adolph C. Kiendl, special referee, in the Federal Court in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Germany's largest exhibition hall, located on the city's exhibition grounds, burned to the ground tonight the result of a short circuit in a booth of the National Radio Show, which was opened by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels on Saturday.

Collection of Young Republicans has been busily pursued for some time. Work of that kind for missionary and exhibition purposes is always going on in theory or fact. Young folks are invited into the tent all the year round. As the "Presidential year" gets closer the Young Democrats appear in gratifying numbers.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- A lie detector, which uses a blood pressure device to gather evidence, "testified" in a compensation case today that the claimant lied. The testimony was admitted as corroborative evidence.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 19. -- Presumably to allocate funds for the purchase of munitions, directors of the Ethiopian National Bank met in special session today under the chairmanship of the Emperor. The bank refused to grant further advances on goods to foreign merchants.

Industrial output last month declined by slightly less than the usual seasonal amount, but recovered a considerable portion of this recession during the first half of August, according to the monthly business survey issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Putting on a burst of speed not equaled this year and seldom witnessed except on the very last day of a session, Congress dashed forward today toward completion of President Roosevelt's reform program, with adjournment by the week-end as a promised reward.

GENEVA, Aug. 19. -- The breakdown of the three-power Paris conference on Ethiopia caused no surprise in League of Nations circles but aroused much conjecture on the immediate future. The breakdown seems both regretted and welcomed.

After a brief address in which he explained to about 500 persons of the neighborhood the advantages of the new project, Mayor La Guardia broke ground yesterday for a series of four buildings which will replace the Park Avenue pushcart market from 111th Street to 115th Street.

DETROIT, Aug. 19. -- George Selkirk was just like his predecessor, Babe Ruth, today at Navin Field in one important essential. He isn't moon-faced and he lacks color, but he was hitting like the forgotten man he succeeded in the Yankee outfield, and his hitting put a temporary halt to the humiliation the McCarthymen have been suffering at the hands of the Tigers.

Defending himself against a compilation of newspaper criticism republished by The Literary Digest on the purchase of common stock of the General Motors Corporation when he was supposedly aware of contemplated increases of dividends, John J. Raskob, a director of the corporation, asserted in a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which he made public yesterday, that he was obligated to buy the stock.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 19. -- War Minister Pera Zhivkovitch had a one-and-one-half-hour audience today with Regent Prince Paul at the castle in Bled. It is reported General Zhivkovitch complained to the Regent about the troubled situation in Yugoslavia, especially in Croatia, where the populace is beginning to disregard police orders.

Tony Norton of the Salem-Crescent A.C. outpointed Vito Tomanelli of the Teasdale A.C. in a 147-pound special bout of the amateur boxing program held by the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island last night. The contest was a return engagement, Tomanelli winning two weeks ago against Norton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Concern to the point of gloom marked today's reaction in administration circles to the collapse of the three-power conversations in Paris aiming at averting war between Italy and Ethiopia. Few officials felt that Premier Benito Mussolini would now be prevented from military operations.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- Mrs. O. Eaton Cromwell gave a beach picnic luncheon at Bailey's Beach today for her house guests, Mrs. Vanderbilt Smith and Mrs. Trimble. Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier, the Misses Gillespie and Miss Eleanor Young were also luncheon hostesses at the beach.

DENVER, Aug. 19 (AP). -- A determined aviator with a fractured leg started on a plane and horseback trip into the roadless, steep upper Laramie Peak country of Wyoming today convinced he will find a smashed plane that carried an Indianapolis business executive, an airport manager and the latter's bride.

It is nothing new. For decades newspaper advertisers have tried to purchase the paper's editorial policies through the advertising department. Yet it brings one up short to find that a supposedly big executive like Howard C. Hopson tried to accomplish this very time-dishonored achievement, as the Senate investigation brought out yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Hal Trosky's home run with the bases loaded in the eighth inning helped the Indians defeat the Senators today, 11 to 5.

Diminutive Tony Nocera of the Rockville Country Club, recent winner of the Long Island caddie title, captured the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual caddie championship tournament yesterday at the Old Belleclaire Golf Club, Bayside.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The originality and versatility of Noel Coward is again demonstrated in the announcement today that he has completed six new plays, varying in length and kind, with which he and Gertrude Lawrence will begin a repertory cycle in Manchester on Oct. 16.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 19. -- John F. Metten, president of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, in a letter to Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, made public today, suggested that a twenty-four-hour ultimatum be given the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America in connection with the local shipyard strike.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19. -- The Midget racing championship of Long Island Sound for the Scoville Cup, won last year by a Stamford boat, Donna R., opened over the Stamford Yacht Club courses today with Pequot and Seawankaka Corinthian taking the lead for the first two races with 11 points each.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP). -- A protest by the Georgia State Revenue Commission against orders issued to New York State police to stop all automobiles displaying Georgia license tags was the subject of a sharp cross-fire of comment between motor vehicle officials of both States today.

The American Locomotive Company reduced its net loss in the first six months of the year, the report for the period, issued yesterday, disclosed. Unfilled orders on July 1 amounted to $3,813,246, against $2,703,374 on Jan. 1 and $7,642,149 on July 1, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Five leaders of the Detroit women who have been on "strike" against high meat prices descended upon the White House and the Department of Agriculture today with demands for lower prices and an immediate investigation of packers' profits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The worst business situation in two decades today confronted Ethiopia as she prepared for possible war with Italy. The Department of Commerce made this statement in a report, which added:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Vice President Garner is expected to head the American delegation that will make a "good-will" visit to Japan en route to ceremonies in Manila in connection with the inauguration in October of the new Commonwealth Government of the Philippines.

FOR the fifth or fifteenth time -- this observer has lost count -- the proposal is to put New York back on the amateur rowing map. The three men in a boat who now think that they have a tail wind and a favoring tide are P.M. Cassidy of the Union Boat Club, H. Newton of the Waverly Boat Club and Max Hirsh of the Nonpareils.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Omnibus Banking Bill, planned by the Administration to centre control over currency and credit in the government, was completed by Congress today when the conference report on the bill was approved in the Senate and House without record votes.
A further indication of a demand for private residences in Manhattan was given in the announcement yesterday of the sale of the four-story American basement dwelling at 123 East Seventy-first Street.

Jean Parker and Eugene Pallette, American stars, and Rene Clair, noted French director, are making their British debut in pictures in the new Alexander Korda production, "The Ghost Goes West." Jean Parker, best remembered for her performance in "Little Women" and "Sequoia," is working outside her native country for the first time.

Barring the presence of Babe Herman, it is quite possible the Giants would have taken the Reds over the hurdles in the second game of the current series at the Polo Grounds yesterday without working up any undue sweat or carrying the thing into an extra session.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19. -- Diplomatic circles here attribute the breakdown of the Chaco peace conference to Paraguay's refusal to entertain Bolivia's aspiration for a port on the upper Paraguay River as a basis for a peace treaty.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Sudden tension developed in British official circles today as a result of the breakdown of the Franco-Italo-British conference on the Ethiopian crisis.

The constitutionality of the Brownell "public enemy" law was upheld by three judges of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday in an opinion affirming the convictions of Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco, who are serving sentences of three months in the workhouse.

The police and the Coast Guard along the south shore of Long Island, assisted by army men, continued yesterday to gather trench mortar fuse heads that have been washed ashore since last Saturday. At the same time they issued warnings to beach frequenters who may have found some of the explosives not to tamper with them.
The unique spectacle of your newspaper sharing publicity and headlines with Washington politicians is both paradoxical and amusing.

While on an inspection tour of the Catskill watershed aqueduct at Gate 1 in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday afternoon, Moe Goldberg, 35 years old, of 33 Norfolk Street, a Works Progress Administration employe of the Department of Water Supply, slipped off a cat-walk and fell into twelve feet of water that flows rapidly through two miles of conduits to the Jerome Park reservoir.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19. -- After a year's interlude, the national doubles tennis championships returned to the historic and beautifully groomed turf of the Longwood Cricket Club today, with the women's doubles annexed as an additional attraction to the men's, veterans', father and son and mixed events.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Aug. 14 shows increases for the week of $206,000,000 in net demand deposits and $138,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and a decrease of $14,000,000 in loans and investments.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 19. -- Attesting her suicide by a note in which she calls "justifiable suicide" the "simplest of human rights," Mrs. Charlotte Perkins Gilman, 75, poet, lecturer and writer, ended her life with chloroform Saturday, but because of her reputed aversion to undertakers, the body lay unreported until noon today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Purchase by the Treasury Department of $33,426,000 worth of government securities during July, almost four times as much as in June, was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Bob McCollum, amateur from South Bay, and Al Brosch, Bethpage Park professional, returned a 64 to capture the one-day amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today on the links of the Seawane Club.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Charges that naval morale was "continuously declining" and that high ranking officers in the fleet and Navy Department have been "notoriously inefficient" were made today by Rear Admiral William S. Sims in The Atlantic Monthly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -Rear Admiral Sims's charge that navy morale was "declining" and high officers have been "notoriously inefficient," today brought this reply from Admiral William H. Standley:

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 19 (AP). -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared today an extra dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock and increased the regular quarterly dividend to 90 cents from the previous rate of 65 cents.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 19 (By Cable). -- The willingness of thousands of proud, savage fighting men to die for their country is Ethiopia's greatest asset in the war that is expected with Italy. Strangely enough, their calm carelessness in the face of death may cost Ethiopia her independence.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- The denunciation yesterday by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, of all those who disturb German economy through extra-legal and terroristic action, frivolous economic dilletantism or sabotage, was interpreted in informed circles today as both a cry of alarm and a demand for a showdown as to who is running the business affairs of the Third Reich.

The cities of the United States in which community chests have been organized and maintained have reason to be especially grateful to Mr. FREDERIC R. KELLOGG, who died on Sunday, for his long and devoted championing of their cause. He was the founder of the Morristown chest, which for years secured the largest per capita contribution in the country, due to his leadership in giving.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- A plan for reorganization of the Bayway Terminal, Inc., of Elizabeth was filed today in Federal court by Samuel Koestler, attorney for the reorganization committee, of which Fred L. Crane is chairman. Mr. Koestler said the plan had the approval of holders of $400,000 of bonds.

Commissioner Valentine declined yesterday to discuss in any detail his drastic edict in which he ordered all commanding officers in the department to prefer charges against men they deemed either physically or mentally unfit for active duty.

J.J. Muller, the portrait artist who was threatened with eviction last Friday if he could not pay the $200 he owed for three and a half months' rent by tomorrow, breathed happily for the first time in many days yesterday when he reported that his rent was paid and that he and his wife were at least temporarily secure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Morgenthau and Wallace and Daniel W. Bell, Acting Budget Director, on the AAA cotton loan policy, and announced plans to address the convention of the Young Democrats in Milwaukee Saturday night, in a radio speech from here.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDS0N, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- A murder mystery played in the atmosphere of a drawing-room comedy, "Murder With Pen and Ink," by Frederick Jackson, opened here tonight with Florence Reed in the leading role. It was the eighth play by Mr. Jackson to be given this Summer at the Beechwood Theatre.

TOKYO, Aug. 19. -- Japan hurled a resounding challenge tonight for the 1936 Olympic Games swimming honors when its powerful team defeated the United States stars, 36 points to 27, as a three-day meet was concluded.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- News in general today was rather favorable to a higher level of wheat prices, and while there was a moderate advance early in sympathy with strength in the wheat market in Liverpool and buying on the Board of Trade here which was attributed to Eastern operators, all upturns here ran into persistent hedging pressure from the Northwest and the close was at net losses of 5/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- During a stormy session in which his belligerent attitude brought a threat of another citation for contempt of the Senate, Howard C.
