Hopson, utilities magnate, told the Senate Lobby Committee today that the Associated Gas and Electric Company had changed its orginal plan of attack on the Wheeler-Rayburn utilities holding company control bill from a campaign of "appeal to reason" to an "appeal to emotions."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Uncle Sam is getting deeper and deeper into the real estate business as an owner of residential property.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- Comments in today's press on the collapse of the three-power conference on Ethiopia indicate that there is no change in the French attitude of impartiality toward the two disputants, Britain and Italy.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- The Boerse was weaker today in reaction to the increasingly unsettled European situation resulting from the Italian action in the Ethiopian dispute. Traders appeared to be more interested in discussing the Koenigsberg speech of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, than in business.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- All favorites advanced to second and third round matches in the opening play of the National Public Park Tennis tournament today.

A movement which was described as mildly corrective took place yesterday in second grade railroad and recently favored public utility bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The price structure of the high grade corporation issues, however, was undisturbed, and several industrial loans in the strictly investment class moved forward to new high levels.

Bertrand Coles Neidecker and his brothers, George W. and Aubrey, who are wanted in France on a complaint charging that they embezzled funds of the Travelers Bank of Paris and Neidecker et Cie., lost yesterday their initial effort to avoid extradition.

Fully 100 stylists and buyers were among the 519 first-class passengers who arrived yesterday from France on the Normandie. It was the general opinion among the fashion experts that the Fall and Winter styles for evening wear for women would take on the effect of Roman and Grecian drapings, or what is called sculptured lines, and that the colors would be rich reds, blues, purples, yellows and greens of the Italian Renaissance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Renewal of the government's cotton loan program on the basis of 10 or 11 cents a pound instead of the 12-cent basis of last year appeared probable tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- A decline of 1 cent in fresh pork loins to 18 to 28 cents a pound wholesale in the local market, reflecting consumers' resistance to high prices, and a sharp break in lard futures were reflected late today in the market here for hogs.

The annual "zero hour" for America's amateur golfers will be reached today when a far-flung army of 903 goes over the top on twenty-six fronts for 176 places for the national championship to be played at Cleveland, Sept. 9-14.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- The utter failure of the attempt by negotiation to prevent Italy from making war on Ethiopia is unreservedly admitted today. There is no hope in further "representations through diplomatic channels," and none are being made.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -Filed by managers for the House in connection with their formal report on the conference with the Senate on the Banking Bill was the following statement:

The security and commodity markets turned reactionary yesterday as Congress began what is expected to be the final week of its present session. The share market suffered its most severe setback since March 5, or shortly before the upward sweep of prices began on March 18.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Guffey-Snyder bill to regulate the bituminous coal industry was passed today by the House in a sectional rather than party division of 194 to 168. The closeness of the result pointed to a likelihood of a stiff fight in the Senate.

A report on the investigation of 505 of the persons arrested last week in the police drive to halt crime in the parks was submitted last night to Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman. The study was made by the Mendicancy Project of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- Premier Benito Mussolini participated this evening in the funeral services here for Luigi Razza, Minister of Public Works, and six others killed within him in an airplane crash near Cairo Aug. 8 while on the way to East Africa.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- The breakdown of the Ethiopian negotiations here caused a slump on the Bourse today, affecting international shares in particular. Suez Canal, which had been firm because of the measures that had been planned in case the Ethiopian struggle was avoided, showed a sharp reaction and fell 260 francs.

Rifle fire cracked to the accompaniment of an occasional clang of a bull's eye in the Radio Museum and Shooting Gallery at 216 West Forty-second Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, at 7:45 o'clock last night, attracting little attention, either from the crowds inside or out.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 19. -- Because of charges that they were of a communistic nature, mural paintings which have hung in the municipal auditorium for two years were removed today by Mayor C.K. Quinn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Over a ten-year period, Howard C. Hopson testified at the Senate lobby inquiry today, he received $654,000 from the Jones Operating and Financial Corporation. The company performed services for public utility operating companies, with about half its business, he said, coming from companies of the associated system.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 19. -- Reports of the breakdown of the Paris conversations reached here this morning, although no official news has yet been received.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Millions of cardboard caps poured out of two roaring machines tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The lever under the price of meats is the old economic statute, the law of supply and demand, representatives of the packers said today.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- According to information that has reached British officials who have been temporarily in Paris for the three-power conference on the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, about 30,000 sick and wounded Italian soldiers have already been transported through the Suez Canal, returning from Italy's African colonies, Eritrea and Italian Somaliland.

New York City is apparently receiving a lesson in politeness and courtesy from the 900 or more Boy Scouts and their leaders from the Pacific Coast States who have descended upon the city in the last few days in lieu of the cancelled National Scout jamboree, which was to have opened in Washington tomorrow, according to the enthusiastic reports that hotel managers and restaurant officials make about them.
SPECULATOR, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The forgotten man of pugilism, Max Baer, has been found again, but you'd scarcely recognize him.

The French liner Normandie docked at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street at 10 A.M. yesterday, two hours ahead of schedule, and caused, considerable congestion and delay in the examination of the baggage of her 1,370 passengers. Ten other liners with 4,800 passengers had all docked in the forenoon, keeping the entire force of Customs Inspectors rushing from pier to pier.
Records continue to fall on Montauk's famous offshore fishing grounds. A week ago the broadbill swordfish held the spotlight. The past week-end belonged to the broadbill's cousin, the marlin.
Records continue to fall on Montauk's famous offshore fishing grounds. A week ago the broadbill swordfish held the spotlight. The past week-end belonged to the broadbill's cousin, the marlin.

NORFOLK, Conn., Aug. 19 (AP). -The presence of a document purporting to be the will of Dr. Michael I. Pupin, scientist and inventor, who died last Spring in New York, presumably intestate, was disclosed today among papers on file in the Norfolk Probate Court.

Luther Rice, 28-year-old burglary suspect, was identified in Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon as a member of Boston's "strip gang," which on May 16 executed four daylight robberies within two hours in the Boston business district.

Two policemen in plainclothes were shot last night at Rockaway and Sutter Avenues, Brooklyn, by one of three Negroes they were about to question last midnight. Both were taken to Beth-El Hospital where their condition was reported as not serious.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- A suit by an estranged wife to collect unpaid alimony, not from her husband but from her husband's parents, was disclosed in Supreme Court here today. The defendants, Henry Willis Smith, 79 years old, New York attorney and former Mayor of Bronxville, and his wife, Catherine, are accused of conspiring with their son to enable him to escape the jurisdiction of the court.

No developments were reported yesterday in the strike of union workers on WPA projects, but a hearing was held before Gerard Reilly, referee appointed by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, on the protest of plasterers' helpers who had quit work on the new Federal Court House Building in Foley Square because of a wage reduction. The hearing was held in the Federal Building at 641 Washington Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- After twenty-nine public hearings at which 110 witnesses testified, a special committee of five trustees of Rutgers University reported today that Lienhard Bergel, instructor in German, had "a feeling of superiority."

The traditional right of a newspaper reporter to refuse to disclose information gathered in the line of duty was recognized yesterday by Judge Charles S. Colden during a trial of four alleged members of the "rifle gang" in Queens County Court.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- "Severity" for prisoners as a Nazi tenet was demanded by Franz Guertner, Minister of Justice, today at the opening of the Penal and Penitentiary Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- President Roosevelt will speak over a nation-wide radio hook-up Saturday evening, addressing from Washington a convention at Milwaukee of the Young Democrats of America, in what is expected to be a fighting political speech replying to recent criticisms of his administration.

A new issue of 40,000 shares of Sonotone Corporation cumulative convertible preferred stock, $1 par value, with common stock option warrants and sinking fund will be offered today by means of a prospectus by Van Alstyne, Noel Co., Inc.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- It was a business-honeymoon trip that took three Indianapolis persons West in the private airplane now reported missing between Helena and Denver.

Nineteen income-tax payers out of twenty take their punishment the way manly little boys do in stories about English public schools. They step up to where the headmaster is waiting with his birch rod, make the necessary set-up in their garments and bend down without a whimper.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- More than 36,000 troops were camped in this 100-square-mile up-State area tonight ready to start tomorrow the series of mimic wars which will "rage" across the sandy loam of Jefferson County for two weeks.
PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 19. -- A 17,767 population loss since 1930 was disclosed today as one result of South Dakota's five-year fight with successive drought and grasshopper plagues.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- A relaxation of the registration requirements for securities issued under reorganizations was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prices of copper in both the domestic and foreign markets advanced sharply yesterday on a heavy volume of business. In the domestic markets sales were made at 8 1/2 cents a pound, a rise of 1/2 cent, while abroad sales were reported at 8 to 8.025 cents.

The American Safety Razor CorporaUon and its subsidiaries report for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $582,866, after depreciation, Federal taxes and.other charges. This is equal to $3.04 a share on 174,800 shares of capital stock, excluding shares held in the treasury.

Irregular price changes occurred yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, ranging over $1 a bale and ending from 3 points higher to 4 poins lower than on Saturday. Waiting for an announcement of producers' loans was an unsettling factor. The market opened with a loss, due to selling from the South, but recovered as pressure lifted.

Military and Renaissance influences were prominent in the Fall and Winter apparel collections which arrived from Paris Monday on the S.S. Normandie. These models will be used for copying purposes in the lines which manufacturers are now preparing. Some will also be used for store display purposes.

The Health Department received yesterday reports of forty-nine new cases of infantile paralysis, the largest total for any day so far this year. Dr. Charles Bolduan, director of public health education, expressed the belief that this marked the peak and that after a short time the number of cases would go down again.
In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Robert R. Reed asks a pertinent question regarding a tax formula and an alternative to the vicious system used today in raising revenue for carrying on government.

HARLAN, Ky., Aug. 20 (AP). -Adjt. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, who led 700 State troops into Harlan County during the August primary controversy, and twenty-five other National Guard and State police officers were indicted here today.

An involved plan whereby a young mother undertook to rob a woman friend of $1,800 in jewelry and other valuables was disclosed yesterday when Mrs. Jeanette Ranola, 27year-old mother of three children, of 2,232 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, was charged with burglary.

Events in Germany are again showing that intolerance and cruelty are self-perpetuating. Indeed, they become more intense as they go on their fated course. The desire to have another class of citizens to beat or terrorize, another set of church organizations to suppress, becomes more violent as the days pass.

Two members of an international expedition to study changes that take place in animals at high altitudes and the adaptability of human beings to varying heights returned yesterday on the Santa Inez. Other members of the party, which represented American and several foreign universities, have already returned.

The complete works of Marjory Fleming, who died before she was 9 years old, yet achieved the distinction of inclusion in the Dictionary of National Biography, are to be published soon by Oxford University Press. Her journals, letters and verses have been transcribed and edited by Frank Sidgwick and the new book is entitled, "The Complete Marjory Fleming."
ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Long Island and Old Westbury, each with a substitute in its open championship line-up, rode through a test game on Schiff Field today, with Westbury scoring, 9 to 6.

Rex Stout, whose mystery novel "The League of Frightened Men" has served as the basis for a United Front of highbrows and mere readers of The Saturday Evening Post, explains himself as follows. Taking a clause from our review as his text -- "the fact that Rex Stout was a legitimate novelist before he took up the trade of mystery monger" -- he writes:

Recent trends in India of importance to American manufacturers are the development of instalment buying and formation of consumer cooperatives, Guy Holman, assistant vice president of the National City Bank of New York, said yesterday in an address at the Export Managers' Club regular luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
VIENNA, Aug. 20. -- It is doubtful whether Austria will participate in the Olympic Games in Berlin in 1936, according to an official statement today.

Christie Bohnsack, program director of the city's broadcasting station, WNYC, and Isaac Brimberg, its radio engineer, were told yesterday afternoon that they had forty-eight hours to submit written explanations why amplifying apparatus was not in readiness Monday morning to carry Mayor La Guardia's words at the breaking of ground for construction of a new city market at Park Avenue and 115th Street.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank was yesterday the highest bidder for six new issues of bonds of the State of Tennessee. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, Sept. 1 and Oct. 1, 1935, and maturing serially from 1937 to 1946, totaled $8,806,000.

New York was one of the first States to make adequate provision for the "emergency" relief of the unemployed. No other State has expended its resources more generously for that purpose. The more liberal its attitude, the more necessary it becomes that those expenditures should be properly checked.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP). -Bulwarking the Tennessee Valley Authority at a point challenged in the Federal courts -- the right to sell surplus power -- Senate and House conferees today reached a complete agreement on the amendments in dispute.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Lieut. Robert Scherer, 25 years old, an army reserve pilot, was killed tonight in a parachute jump from an observation plane in which he was returning to Dexter Airport after taking part in the army war games in this region. George White, mechanic in the plane, made a safe parachute landing.

HAVANA, Aug. 20. -- The Cuban Supreme Court has appointed Special Judge Jesus Rodriguez Aragon to initiate proceedings against former President Gerardo Machado, eighteen members of his various Cabinets and "directors of the Chase National Bank of New York" on charges of alleged fraud presented by Rafael Ramos Bravo, a lawyer, in connection with an $85,000,000 public works bond issue.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20. -- The East showed the straight-shooting West how it's done at the Grand American trapshoot today, taking six of seven championships.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20. -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company today asked the California State Railroad Commission for permission to dissolve nine of its eleven subsidiary corporations, which are incorporated for a total of $225,000,000, according to the petition.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Charged with fraudulent use of the mails in selling about $600,000 in stock of the Polymet Manufacturing Company to 2,500 investors, eleven defendants were indicted by a Federal grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- President Roosevelt opened the Will Cummings Highway on Lookout Mountain, Tenn., today by pressing a telegraph key at precisely 3:30 P.M.E.S.T. This punctuality was made possible only by the quick thinking of E.W. (Doc) Smithers, chief telegrapher at the White House for twoscore years.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Albert Charles Murphy, retired railway supply manufacturer, who left half his residuary estate to Cornell University, showed that the value is $1,991,320 gross and $1,578,596 net. Mr. Murphy left $500,000 in trust to his wife, Mrs. Theresa G. Murphy of Miami Beach, but the appraisal disclosed that the widow elected to take half the estate under the law of Florida, which will affect the Cornell bequest.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- The conciliation commission appointed by the League of Nations to pronounce responsibility for the Ualual and other frontier clashes between the Italians and Ethiopians took second thought today and resumed its sessions here.
BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The Boerse was inactive today. No developments of significance occurred, and traders appeared to be awaiting the results of the recent political events.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Bullish sentiment was much more in evidence today in the wheat market on the Chicago Board of Trade. Lack of hedging pressure and a slackening in the movement of Winter wheat combined with strong cable advices from Liverpool, started buying that carried prices up readily.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20. -- The capture after years of intensive pursuit of vitamin E, most elusive and mysterious of all the vitamins, in highly concentrated crystalline form, was anounced today before a meeting of the American Chemical Society.

A $900,000 program for establishing game-management courses in ten Federal land-grant colleges for the next five years was set in motion yesterday with the announcement of a gift of $150,000 for that purpose from the recently organized American Wildlife Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Congress's rush toward adjournment was suddenly halted today by the Senate's anti-war-profits bloc, who, sounding the alarm of another world war and threatening an interminable filibuster, demanded action on neutrality legislation before the session ends.
LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Smaller powers and France, it was said today, would support the British Government, should it urge Geneva to adopt economic sanctions against Italy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- The unofficial boycott against the high prices for pork products and another sharp break in prices of lard sent the prices of hogs tumbling 25 to 40 cents a hundredweight here today with only fair demand on the decline.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 20. -All the tense excitement which attends a world's championship event held the Narragansett Park racing plant tonight on the eve of the appearance of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery in tomorrow's $25,000 added Narragansett Special.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Nine experts started today in the annual State championship being held under the auspices of the New York State Chess Association. Six of the competitors were from New York City, including Isaac Kashdan of the Manhattan Chess Club, who was unable to accompany the United States team to Poland, and Fred Reinfeld, champion of the Marshall Chess Club.

Several pre-primary political campaigns opened in Hudson County yesterday. The Democrats, headed by Mayor Hague of Jersey City, announced a ticket for the September primaries and Charles H. Stoebling, Registration Commissioner, leading one of the Republican factions of the county, also filed a ticket for State and county offices.

DETROIT, Aug. 20. -- The Yankees got even with Schoolboy Rowe today at Navin Field and squared their crucial four-game series with the Tigers. Sent back at the New Yorkers for his second fling after only a day of rest, the elongated Arkansan fell before a barrage of base hits that gave the McCarthymen enough runs to take the game by a count of 6 to 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- A bitterly fought campaign for the Republican Mayoralty nomination became almost certain today when the final hour for withdrawing nominating petitions found a substantial group of leading candidates still in the field.

Civic leaders in Harlem were appointed yesterday by Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, on the Harlem Housing Committee, which will cooperate with the Authority in connection with the $4,500,000 low-rent project planned for the former Rockefeller property at 151st Street and Macombs Place.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York unanimously condemned yesterday as a "political expedient" the Tax Bill pending before Congress. The organization registered its disapproval at the first extraordinary session called during a Summer recess in twenty-five years.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 20 (AP). -- This blazing hot Red Sea port, the capital of French Somaliland, has suddenly become one of the most important towns in the East. It is the only door land locked Ethiopia has to the sea.

Out of respect to the memory of Will Rogers, the theatres operated by the National Theatres Corporation will darken their screens for two minutes tomorrow afternoon. Other theatre operators have signified their intention of paying a similar tribute.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP). -- Seven men and a woman leaped into fog-shrouded Buzzards Bay today from their sinking yacht, made their way across the rocks to forbidding West Island, and ten hours later were rescued by a Coast Guard boat.

EDWARD SHILLITO, in a recent article on "Unclosed Questions" in The Spectator, discusses the subject to which Mrs. ROOSEVELT has addressed herself -- curiosity. His thesis is that man, "simply because he is man," cannot help asking questions that arise out of experiences which are universal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A surprising show of Senate strength by advocates of the Guffey-Snyder bill to regulate the bituminous coal industry developed today on the first test, a motion by Senator Neely to bring up the measure for consideration, which was carried by a vote of 50 to 21.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Consignments from the Court Manor Stud of Willis Sharpe Kilmer, Regan Farms, Tollie Young and Flying Horse Farm, which totaled fifty-three yearlings, were sold at auction tonight in the Fasig-Tipton paddock.

Keepers at the Central Park Zoo breathed a sigh of relief yesterday noon when the iron gate of one of the bear dens clanged shut with Mishka on the inside. They were relieved first because they had successfully completed a dreaded moving job and second because they were pretty sure that Mishka was now in a cage for keeps.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Yorkshire again widened its margin over Derbyshire, runner-up in the county cricket championship standing, by defeating Middlesex by an innings and 82 runs today, while the Midlanders could obtain only first innings points in a battle with Worcester.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison led an American and British attack today on Germanic and East European collectivist principles in discussing before the International Penal and Penitentiary Congress here the advisability of educating and attempting to reform the criminal. The German delegation warmly supported the report by Judge Nathan Muller of Amsterdam, who asserted that punishment rather than education must be the primary purpose of penal institutions.

Production of pig iron in the United States in the first half of this year amounted to 9,709,899 tons and the output of ferro-alloys was 257,790 tons, a total of 9,967,689 tons, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- With both sides in the Camden shipyard strike still deadlocked, the only hope of ending the dispute which has tied up work on seven naval vessels in the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Company since May 13 appeared tonight to lie in intervention by President Roosevelt.

A "Chinese Fantasy," arranged as the fourth annual benefit for the Suffolk County Cancer Committee, will be held on the evening of Aug. 30 and the afternoon and evening of Aug. 31 on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Wood at Islip, L.I.
SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 20. -- The Olympic retires to the "boneyard" of ships with an enviable list of records.

Plans were filed by the Department of Parks yesterday for a swimming pool and bathhouse in Thomas Jefferson Park, First Avenue and 111th Street, to accommodate 400 bathers. Aymar Embury 2d, the consulting architect, estimated the cost at $436,000.

Providing for the prohibition of the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war to belligerent countries; the prohibition of the transportation of arms, ammunition and implements of war by vessels of the United States for the use of belligerent States; for the registration and licensing of persons engaged in the business of manufacturing, exporting or importing arms, ammunition or implements of war, and restricting travel by American citizens on belligerent ships during war.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Mark Flanagan of Riverhead, former Georgetown golf star, equaled par on the Southampton Golf Club links in a Long Island Golf Association tourney today. He was out in 34 and home in 37.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20 (AP). -The eight seeded stars in the men's division of the national public parks tennis championships advanced today into pairings with eight unseeded survivors and faced a grand scramble for quarter-final berths in matches tomorrow.
The late August demand for apartment quarters in Manhattan and in many suburban districts is resulting in the closing of hundreds of contracts with brokers and owners each day.

MIDWAY ISLANDS, Aug. 20. -Completing the first 1,250-mile hop of its 5,000-mile journey back to California from Wake Island on a trail-blazing mission across the Pacific Ocean to prepare the way for Pan American Airways' service to the Orient, the Pan American Clipper arrived here today at 4 P.M. [Midnight, Daylight Saving Time].

BOWIE, Md., Aug. 20 (AP). -- Five persons, three of them nuns, were killed and twenty were injured as an automobile and a Washington bus carrying more than a score of Negroes to a beach near Annapolis collided on a slippery highway near here today.

For the first half of this year the Richfield Oil Company and wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $794,185 after all charges, including depreciation and depletion. This contrasted with a net loss of $1,427,373, on the same basis, in the corresponding part of 1934.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A week or so ago, after he had added the Tax Bill to his legislative program, thus extending the session of Congress by more than a month, the President told a press conference he thought some new neutrality laws would be useful also if resultant debate would not "unduly prolong the session."

The board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday suspended trading in the September position of the No. 1 sugar contract and ordered contracts in that month liquidate at Monday's closing price, which was 2.58 cents a pound.

In connection with the current anti-noise campaign with the promise of rules being formulated against automobile horn blowing late at night, the question must arise who is to enforce the new regulations?

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20. -Miss Lorna Whittelsey, sailing with her sister Myrtle and Miss Beatrice Kunhardt in the Indian Harbor boat, retained the Syce Cup, won the women's Long Island Sound championship for the sixth time and gained a berth in the women's national championships today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP). -Fresh advocacy of Senator Borah of Idaho for the Republican Presidential nomination was met today by a complete silence on the part of the veteran Senator.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The situation created by the extra-legal National Socialist campaigns against the Jews and other "enemies" of the Third Reich and denounced by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, as a grave disturbance to German business was discussed today at a conference of the competent Ministries, together with a new draft law announced by Dr. Schacht to fix the future legal status of the Jews.

After a five-mile chase by motorcycle police, radio cars and two riot squads, during which he crashed into four automobiles, including a hearse, Pierre DeFontaine, 28 years old, of 309 Eleventh Street, Union City, N.J., was in Hudson County jail in Jersey City last night, sentenced to thirty days. He was captured in front of the jail.

Finding it difficult to determine the purpose of the new law requiring that the designating petitions of candidates for the primaries shall be printed on paper of the color chosen by the Secretary of State, Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer yesterday directed the Board of Elections to accept the petition of Charles A. Loreto, candidate for Municipal Court Justice in the First District of the Bronx in the Democratic primary.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The 250 officers and 4,400 men of the "Fighting First" Division, pride of the Regular Army, rolled out to battle today against an imaginary Red enemy in the greatest American motorized operation since the World War.

Alfred E. Smith denounced Soviet Russia, Germany, Mexico and Socialists and Communists last night in a speech at a "victory dinner" marking the fifty-third annual meeting of the Knights of Columbus at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

HALF a dozen letters demanding that this observer or the American Olympic Committee or President Roosevelt or the nation at large come out firmly and immediately against the participation of the United States in the Olympic Games in Germany next year.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, leading representative of teachers' organizations in the city, is a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Assembly in the Ninth Assembly District, it was disclosed yesterday at the Board of Elections as the time for filing substitutions for primary designees expired.

Fifteen properties in Manhattan and three in the Bronx were put up for bidding at auctioneers' stands yesterday. All the offerings were bought in by the plaintiffs, who acted to protect their liens on the defaulted realty.

Nothing the Dodgers could do yesterday, including some fine hurling by the veteran southpaw, Tom Zachary, was enough to combat the shutout pitching of Big Jim Weaver and Brooklyn dropped the third game of the series to the Pirates, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- For the first time this session and despite a compromise agreement understood to have been reached at the White House Sunday night, administration leaders in Congress conceded today the possibility of adjournment without action on the Utility Holding Company Control Bill to provide for their regulation or ultimate dissolution.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Faint noises, believed to be signals, spurred weary rescue workers early today as they dug to reach twenty-two men trapped underground in the collapse of a partly built subway.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Fifteen youthful South African cricketers tonight celebrated their victory over England in the series of five test matches. Holding the mother country to a draw in the final game concluded at the oval today, the Springboks earned the honor by virtue of winning the second encounter at Lord's early in July -- the only match fought to a decision.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A 50 per cent drop in the government's processing tax collections between June and July resulted from injunctions granted to millers, packers, textile mills, and other processors against the tax, the Bureau of Internal Revenue disclosed today.

The more one follows fishing the more one realizes what an uncertain game it is. Two offshore boats may leave from the same port and cover identical water. One will return with a handsome mess, the other with a cargo of glum and empty-handed anglers.

Most futures were higher yesterday in the commodity futures markets here. Suspension of trading in the old September contracts for sugar and their liquidation at 2.58 cents a pound, Monday's closing price, was overshadowed by the action of the market itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Senator Long in a speech on the floor today criticized the recent presence of Marvin H. Mclntyre, presidential secretary; L. W. Robert Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, and Amon Carter, Texs news-I paper publisher, in the room of iB. B. Robinson, attorney for I-Ioward [ C. I-Iopson, utility executive.

The provision in the pending Revenue Bill of 1935 to "tax in the hands of a corporation any part of the dividends received from other corporations is a radical and revolutionary measure," according to the committee on taxation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 20. -Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, speaking here today, advocated compulsory insurance for all automobiles as the only way to provide protection for the victims of auto accidents and their dependents.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie, thin and careworn, rapidly pressed defensive measures today against a possible Italian invasion.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- At the moment when Franco-American negotiations for a trade treaty are reported to be entering a decisive phase, some importance is attached here to the inauguration today of a new economic committee of four whose purpose is to recommend a complete tariff revision.

S.S. AZAY LE RIDEAU, Aug. 20. -- There is no doubt in the Italian mind that Italy will begin her arduous colonization of the vast and fertile Ethiopian plateau some time in the latter part of September.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Mrs. Joseph F. Stillman gave a farewell dinner, followed by a bridge, tonight at Mayfair cottage, her home in Pond Lane, for Mr. and Mrs. James N. Wallace, who will depart tomorrow after a fortnight's stay at the Irving.

The daily average production of gross crude oil in the United States last week was 2,708,650 barrels, compared with 2,656,850 in the preceding week, an increase of 51,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 18,700 and 14,050 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of California and Texas were the most important changes.
BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Four young men armed with a machine gun robbed the Hotel Ritz-Carlton shop of Hodgson, Kennard Co. of more than $60,000 worth of jewels at 1:45 P.M. today.

If it is MUSSOLINI'S intention to revive the Roman Empire, it is strange that he should begin by attacking a country that was never part of the Roman Empire. The frontier between Ethiopia and Egypt was Rome's furthest south, and the Roman commanders in Egypt were content to stand on the defensive against hostile raids from the Nilotic highlanders.
GLENDO, Wyo., Aug. 20 (AP). -The bodies of three Indianapolis residents, killed in an aerial pleasure tour, were found by searchers late today on a steep slope of towering Laramie Peak.

United States Government bonds broke sharply in late trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Losses were from 1-32 to 15-32 point at the close. Transactions of $6,886,900 in the Federal issues were the heaviest since June 20, when sales amounted to $9,673,400.

Walter W. Head, president of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania from Europe, where he attended the Eighth International Conference of Scout Leaders at Stockholm.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The Browns, cellar-dwelling giant killers of the American League, dropped Boston to fourth place by splitting a double-header with the Red Sox today. Rogers Hornsby's men won their fourth victory of the six-game series, 8 to 5, in the opener, but dropped the nightcap, 7 to 3, as their hurlers wilted before a fourteen-hit attack.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 20. -- After watching a golfer from the Far West play today, many of the Eastern boys are now convinced of the soundness of Horace Greeley's advice.
Call and time money quiet, demand for funds being confined to small lines. Commercial paper fairly active.

The statement of Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, replying to the committee which seeks to elect Colonel John S. Hammond, now chairman of the board of directors, as head of the corporation, was regarded yesterday as indicating that a battle of proxies will be waged before the stockholders' meeting on Sept. 24.

The American Committee on the Ethiopian Crisis, a non-denominational, non-partisan organization to help avert war between Italy and Ethiopia and to guard Ethiopia from foreign aggression, was formed yesterday at a special meeting of the League of Nations Association, 8 West Fortieth Street.

In an effort to obtain a reconsideration by the Equity council of its recent rulings on pay for rehearsals and Sunday shows, and also to supplement a recent appeal for some sort of basic agreement between Equity and the managers, a committee from the League of New York Theatres (the managers' organization) called upon the Equity council at its fortnightly meeting yesterday afternoon.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20. -The foreign threat in the national doubles championship was vested entirely in the racquets of Roderick Menzel of Czechoslovakia and Enrique Maier of Spain at the end of play today at the Longwood Cricket Club as Jacques Brugnon and A. Martin Legeay of France made a dangerous but losing fight against Berkeley Bell and Gregory Mangin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- New York, New Jersey and New England are busily filing applications for new project allotments while winding up the affairs of the first two years' public-works program, Secretary Ickes announced today on the basis of reports submitted by Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, following a three-day survey of the eight Northeastern States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Agreement on a $250,000,000 tax bill which was a complete compromise between the Senate and House drafts but in the main a far cry from what President Roosevelt asked in his June 19 message was announced today by conferees from both chambers, who prepared to submit the result to the two houses tomorrow for final passage.
For the first time since he left this country, James J. Walker addressed Americans last night over a radio hookup from London.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Under the lift of a light southerly breeze, the racing creations of the New York Yacht Club made their last cruise run here today and H.S. Vanderbilt's sloop Prestige again showed her heels to the rest of the fleet.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP). -- Dick Porter pounded the ball in manner reminiscent of his hey-dey with the Baltimore Orioles to lead the Newark Bears to a 5-to-0 vicitory over the Syracuse Chiefs tonight.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Suicide is justifiable in the case of a person suffering from an incurable disease, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, woman leader, declared here today in defense of her friend, Mrs. Charlotte Perkins Gilman. Mrs. Gilman's suicide at the home of her daughter in Pasadena, Calif., became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 19, unless specified:

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Carl K. Withers, Banking Commissioner, announced today the creation of the Division of Conservation of the State Department of Banking and Insurance, to supervise centralized jurisdiction over defunct banks, insurance companies and building and loan associations.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a decreased net operating income for July. Its statement follows:

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 20. -- Covering slightly more than 2,300 miles in exactly nine hours, for an average cruising speed of 252 miles an hour, a big four-motored Boeing bomber which landed at Wright Field, the Army Corps experimental base near here, at 3:45 this afternoon set a new world's record for sustained speed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Two of three favorites were beaten today when the Orange County Fair races were started over the historic Harry Clay track. Bulwark, choice in the 2-year-old event, however, came through to triumph in two straight heats.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The Neddie colt, Good Goods, gave Mrs. Dodge Sloane her first stake victory of the Saratoga season today when he was first in the featured Champlain Handicap. The result was a surprise to many of the form players, but not to observers who had watched his recent races which showed that he was improving steadily.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 20. -- William Sefton of Los Angeles achieved the best pole vault performance ever made outside of the United States when he cleared the bar at 14 feet 3 1/4 inches in an international track and field meet between American athletes and picked European stars today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 20. -Seawanhaka Corinthian's entry, Sunny, with Jimmy Hurd as skipper, today captured the first title race for the Scoville Cup, emblematic of the midget championship of Long Island Sound. The event was sailed over the Stamford Yacht Club course.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Led by Jocko Conlan, who banged seven hits, including two doubles, in eight times at bat, the Chicago White Sox batted their way back into third place today by defeating the Athletics in both ends of a double-header, 13 to 4 and 11 to 4.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20. -- What is claimed to be a world record for long-distance swimming has just been established by the Soviet champion, Nicolai Malin, who covered the 50 kilometers (about 31 1/4 miles) in 17 hours 54 minutes 40 seconds at Sochi on the North Caucasian coast of the Black Sea.

Leon J. Cadore, former star pitcher of the Brooklyn Dodgers, was arrested yesterday in the Securities Bureau of the Attorney General's office, 80 Centre Street, on a charge of grand larceny. He was accused of failure to return four shares of American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock valued at $520 to Miss Louise Curtis, a dietician at Kings County Hospital.

Business leases covering a wide area and involving a variety of trades were reported closed yesterday. A new restaurant in the downtown district is planned following the closing of a long contract for store and basement space in the Cory Building, 183 Varick Street, by the Frontenac Grill, of which Max Friedman is proprietor.

Mike Jacobs, promoter of the forthcoming Max Baer-Joe Louis bout, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday, but did not reveal any plans for the battle. The commission had invited Jacobs to request him to stage the fight in New York.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 20. -- Four members of the crew of the New York fishing boat Juneal, one an East Boston man, were lost and four others were saved when the boat was blown to pieces twenty miles northeast of Nantucket Lightship yesterday morning. A Norwegian freighter, the Belpamela, brought the survivors here today.

While prices on the Cotton Exchange declined $1 a bale at one time yesterday on reports that government loans on cotton might be only 10 or 11 cents a pound instead of last year's authorization of 12 cents, the market steadied when the December sold around 11 cents, recovered much of the loss and ended 6 to 11 points lower than on Monday.

The vast East River Drive improvement came a step nearer realization yesterday when the city took title to three-quarters of a mile of waterfront land between Grand and Fourteenth Streets and immediately laid plans to celebrate the start of work next week on the first link in the boulevard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Swift promotion came to Sergeant Stanley R. Morgan today in recognition of his "initiative, resourcefulness and fine judgment" after the airplane crash that killed Will Rogers and Wiley Post at Point Barrow, Alaska.

DENVER, Aug. 20. -- The constitutional right of the Federal Government to make loans and grants to municipalities and States under the Public Works Administration for the construction of publicly owned power plants was upheld here today by the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.

The erratic course of the share market yesterday appeared to be mainly due to professional operations, which necessarily exaggerated the movements that might be considered more or less normal with a weary Congress seeking to wind up its calendar, a disconcerting turn for the worse in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, and the seasonal flattening out of business activity in many lines.

WAKE ISLAND, Wednesday, Aug. 21. -- Completing a long series of flight tests as final preparations at this base for the opening of the Pan American Airways' service to the Orient in the near future, the trail-blazing Pan American Clipper began its 5,000-mile flight back across the Pacific Ocean to California today at 6:14 A.M. [3:14 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern daylightsaving time].

With an attendance of about 7,500 for the final orchestral program, the Summer season of concerts, opera and ballet at the Lewisohn Stadium was concluded last night, eight weeks from the date of its opening on June 26, as scheduled.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The world Zionist leader, Dr. Nahum Sokolow, with almost the first words of his presidential speech tonight shattered reports that the nineteenth biennial Zionist congress would sidestep the situation of German Jews, out of deference to delegates from the Reich, who were among the representatives from forty-three nations.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange continued dull today, with prices weakening further as a result of scattered selling. British funds, however, firmed in the afternoon, due to Continental buying. Foreign bonds were lower.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to an investor the five-story walk-up apartment house at 1,681, Madison Avenue, near East 111th Street. The flat is on a lot 25 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $11,500. Bachrach Bachrach were the brokers.

The Municipal Art Commission, at a special meeting yesterday in the office of William F. Lamb, architect member, at 11 East Forty-fourth Street, approved the construction of three bridges over the projected East River drive as approaches to the Triborough Bridge.
General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, returned from Washington last night to face the threat of a three-hour stoppage today by white-collar relief workers.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. For the week 948 arrivals were reported, as against 1,109 in the previous week and 1,000 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Immediate and energetic action on all fronts in the work relief program for youth, with resulting benefits in a month as the goal, was urged by President and Mrs. Roosevelt today in "pep talks" to the State directors of the National Youth Administration, who closed a two-day conference preliminary to the inauguration of their State programs.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Joseph N. Weber, president of the American Federation of Musicians and member of the committee of three recently appointed by the executive board of the American Federation of Labor to assist in cleaning up labor racketeering in New York City, was charged with acting oppressively and beyond his constitutional powers, in a suit filed with Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow here today.

Some of us are unfeeling enough to read without sympathy of the sufferings of Congressmen exposed so long to the Gehenna-like atmosphere of Washington. In view of most of the legislation that they have been or will be compelled to pass in order to acquire merit at the White House, the majority of our statesmen haven't been boiled and steamed half as much as they deserve.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- American athletes took first places in seven out of eleven events in competition with Dutch and Belgian track and field stars in Heysel Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Assertions that our silver-purchase policy has hurt Chinese business were contradicted today by James A. Moffett, Federal Housing Administrator, who returned a few days ago from a round-the-world trip which included, at President Roosevelt's request, an investigation into Chinese reaction to the policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The question of our attitude toward joining in economic sanctions against Italy and Ethiopia has not formally arisen in government discussions here, but if as a result of the British Cabinet meeting on Thursday an expression of American views is requested, the matter will be given consideration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The Associated Gas and Electric Company, in which Howard C. Hopson is the dominant figure, claimed losses in its income tax returns for the years 1925 to 1932, inclusive, while reporting to its stockholders profits running in one year as high as $20,000,000.

It took a lot of things, including Mel Ott's twenty-fifth homer of the year, Hank Leiber's eighteenth, four pitchers, among them Carl Hubbell, and a line single by Travis Jackson, before the Giants, again carried into ten innings by the Reds, were able to bring down Chuck Dressen's oddly inspired Cincinnatians at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Dr. S.S. Brukhonenko, Russian scientist, today revived a dog ten minutes after an "incomplete death" in the presence of a group of foreign delegates here for the International Physiological Congress.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Organization of a national third party at a convention early next year, Howard Y. Williams predicted today, will be the forerunner of the election of a third party President in 1940.

Improved sewage control affecting the tidal waters of the metropolitan area must be established to remove an outstanding menace to the health of the communities included in it, according to Charles A. Holmquist, director of the division of sanitation of the New York State Department of Health.

FULDA, Germany, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The future of the Catholic Church in Germany was pondered tonight by the highest prelates of the Reich while Nazi officials kept close tab. A three-day conference, in closed sessions, is considering the "serious situation facing the German church."
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -Better times for the Northwest were seen by trade leaders in a report released today by the Ninth District Federal Reserve Bank.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 20 (AP). -- A curtained transport plane settled to earth before a solemn throng at the municipal airport late today in Wiley Post's last landing.
The hanging of a set of educational murals was begun yesterday morning at Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue.

The Governor's Commission on Unemployment Relief, completing the first comprehensive report by an impartial body on work relief projects in this State, summed up its findings last night as "favorable," although it rated the cost of such projects at 35 per cent greater than it should be under average contract conditions.

ALBANY, Aug. 20. -- Hailed as "the man of the hour" and as a statesman "who has espoused a social justice program unequaled in the history of our nation," Governor Lehman occupied the centre of the stage at the opening session of the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Labor when it met here today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP). -- A third heat was needed today to determine the winner of the Review Futurity for 2-year-old pacers on the second day of Grand Circuit racing at the Illinois State Fair.

WARSAW, Aug. 20. -- Sweden's chess team, by scoring a one-sided victory over the hitherto successful Argentina quartet, retained its hold on first place today in the team tournament of the International Chess Federation at the Army Officers Casino.

A rush of orders in Electric Bond and Share common stock yesterday on the Curb Exchange jammed the books of the five specialists in the issue and caused trading to be halted from 11:42 to 11:47 A.M. In the interval the price was adjusted from 16 to 15 5/8, and in the fifteen minutes following the resumption of dealings 13,600 shares were turned over.

Responsibility for delay in applying for $120,000,000 in Public Works Administration loans to build schools in the city was placed squarely on the Board of Education by Mayor La Guardia in a letter made public yesterday.
The blare of night life on Fourteenth Street came in conflict with the residential quietness of Irving Place in Jefferson Market Court yesterday and quietness won a ruling in its favor.

The Banking Bill as passed by the Senate was an immense improvement over the bill that came from the House. In the measure that has emerged from the conference the Senate -- one might almost say Senator GLASS -- has succeeded in retaining most of the improvements made.

A series of ten travel and adventure films, each accompanied with a lecture or comment by the person involved, will be presented at Carnegie Hall on ten Saturday mornings, beginning Oct. 12. Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will open the series by showing 9,000 feet of film made in the course of his last two years in the Antarctic.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP). -- A military guard of honor, composed of forty army fliers from March Field, will be stationed around the casket of Will Rogers as thousands pay tribute to the actor and writer Thursday morning.

Miss Rose Freistater, the 180-pound school teacher to whom a license was denied on the ground that she was overweight, has put her appeal in the hand of an attorney, it became known yesterday. He is Arthur M. Mabel and he expects to win for his client either on a reconsideration by the board of examiners or on direct appeal to Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education.

ROME, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Italy will attend the meeting of the League of Nations Council Sept. 4 to discuss the Italian-Ethiopian situation, it was said tonight, but it was added in informed circles that this was not to be taken as an indication of any change in Italian policy regarding Ethiopia.

Restoration of salary cuts was asked yesterday by Frederic Kernochan, chief justice of the Court of Special Sessions, for himself and for the fifteen associate justices of that court at a hearing on 1936 estimates before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Home runs by Joe Medwick and Jack Rothrock, each with a man on base, today helped the Cardinals beat the Braves, 6 to 5, despite Wally Berger's twenty-seventh circuit smash of the season.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 20. -- President Jose M. Velasco Ibarra was arrested tonight after part of the garrison at Quito had proclaimed him dictator. He was confined in the barracks of the Imbabura regiment. Congress had announced its intention to force the President to resign.

On motions made by the State Mortgage Commission and by trustees in reorganization proceedings, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday directed the receivers for the Libradar Holding Corporation and Land Estates, Inc., to give an accounting of funds in their possession.

Mayor La Guardia's hope to submit his $45,000,000 city power plant project to the voters at the November election received a severe blow yesterday when, it was learned, Tammany Hall decided to throw its strength against the measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- This comparative statement of internal revenue receipts for July, 1934, and July, 1935, was given out today:

Governor Lehman calls attention to the plight of Jews in Germany in a Jewish New Year's message sent at the request of Benjamin E. Greenspan, president of the Wall Street Synagogue, and made public by the latter yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The cotton situation and the prospective loan rate on the new crop were discussed again today by the President in company wit Treasury and Agriculture Department officials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Alvin Karpis, who is listed as Public Enemy No. 1, has written to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Justice Department's Bureau of Investigation, threatening to kill him.
LONDON, Aug. 20. -- The British Cabinet will hold an emergency session Thursday for consideration of the Ethiopian situation.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

It is evident that Great Britain and France and perhaps other members of the League of Nations are seriously proposing to apply to Italy the economic sanctions authorized by the Covenant in such a case. They wish, however, first to find out what will be the attitude of the United States.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The return of the New York Yacht Club on its annual cruise and the preparations being made for the Astor and Kings Club races and special races for the week-end made the harbor a busy place tonight. There was considerable entertaining on the larger boats of the fleet last night.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Many members of the racing colony will entertain guests at the dinner dance which the Turf Writers Association will give at Riley's, Saratoga Lake, tomorrow night.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 21. -- In an extraordinary confirmation of ratings seeded stars without exception took their places in the quarter-finals of the national public parks tennis championship today.

ROME, Aug. 21. -- Since the breakdown of the three-power negotiations in Paris, Italy has been very quiet. She has continued feverish military preparations but has carefully refrained from making even the slightest move in the international field.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- A platoon of Federal agents rushed to a postal telegraph office here today upon receiving word that a man representing himself as Alvin Karpis, Public Enemy No. 1, had tried to send a telegram to J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington.

WARSAW, Aug. 21. -- Swedish chess players scored again in the international team tournament at the Army Officers Casino today, making a clean sweep on all four boards to defeat Italy by 4 -- 0 in the only match of the seventh round decided in the first session of play.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 21. -- While more than a fourth of the population of this little town was enjoying itself at the farmers' picnic in Belvedere today, four robbers raided the First National Bank and escaped with almost $20,000 in cash.

Federal authorities have allocated about $2,500,000 to the New York Public Library under the WPA program for improvements and repairs to the central building and branches, Harry M. Lydenberg, director of the library, announced yesterday.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Coroner Andrew Calyer said tonight that Mrs. Dorothy Sherwood, the 27-year-old mother who admitted drowning her 2-year-old boy because she was unable to take care of him, had tried in vain to place her baby in a children's home.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Newell P. Sherman, 26, former Scoutmaster and choir singer, was indicted late today for murder of his 23-year-old wife, Alice, by overturning a canoe on Lake Singletary, near Sutton, on the night of July 20.

While Associate Judge John T. Loughran of the Court of Appeals agreed at a hearing yesterday in Kingston, N.Y., to the release of Salvatore Spitale and Salvatore Arcidiaco in $1,000 bail each pending appeal from their conviction under the Brownell "public enemy" law, the Appellate Division of the Court of Special Sessions here affirmed the convictions of five men arrested under the same law in Brooklyn.
SUEZ, Aug. 21 (By Wireless). -- The Suez Canal is alive with increased activity as Italian troop ships pour youth and treasure through this crossroads of the world.

Major Henry H. Curran, vice president of the League for Less Noise, who has been studying noise abatement ideas in foreign cities, is returning today on the Washington of the United States Lines to make his report to Mayor La Guardia.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 21. -- George Scharmer, Assistant Superintendent of Elections in Hudson County, and four other men were locked up in police headquarters here today on charges of conspiracy to perpetrate an election fraud, while the police sought Joshua Ringle, Republican State committeeman from Hudson County and Republican leader of the Seventh Ward in Jersey City, on a warrant charging him with buying false registrations from Scharmer and his accomplices.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 21. -- The Knickerbocker Yacht Club's midget crew sailed victoriously over the Stamford Yacht Club courses today to capture the Scoville Cup, possession of which carries with it the championship among the youthful skippers and sailors of Long Island Sound.

IN Southern Oregon, which is the locale of H.L. Davis's Harper Prize novel, "Honey in the Horn" (Harpers, $2.50), plants and trees and animals and fruits "grew bigger than you expected them to, and some prospered by it, while others destroyed themselves." The same is true With Mr. Davis's raffish and delectable characters.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher who is spoken of as a possible Republican Presidential candidate in 1936, appeared before a gathering of up-State New York Republicans for the first time tonight and declared President Roosevelt's ultimate aim was "substitution of an autocratic government for the type of government the Constitution gave us."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21. -- The memory of Will Rogers will be honored here with three services tomorrow. Private rites for members of the family and intimate friends will be held at 2 P.M. at the Wee Kirk o' the Heather in Glendale. Simultaneously, a sorrowing public will pay its tribute at public services in the Hollywood Bowl, while the humorist's fellow citizens in Beverly Hills will attend rites at the Presbyterian Community Church.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21. -- Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn and Donald Budge and Gene Mako, the two American Davis Cup combinations and top seeded teams here, advanced to the semi-final round of the national doubles tennis championship today at the Longwood Cricket Club.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21. -- The Communist International Congress, which closed last night after a twenty-five day session, has caused varying opinions in foreign circles of Moscow.

Appointment of the Brooklyn Trust Company as trustee for certificate holders of fourteen guaranteed mortgage certificate issues having a total face value of $3,617,000 was announced yesterday. There are about 2,000 holders of the issues, which are being reorganized under the Schackno Act.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Thirty thousand troops slogged for miles across muddy roads today and pushed their way across stubbled fields, tangled forests and green meadows as four National Guard Divisions "fought" in a drenching downpour the greatest mimic battles in American peacetime history.

After four postponements, the intimate revue called "Smile at Me" is scheduled to open tonight at the Fulton Theatre. Jack Osterman, Eddie Lambert, Hal Thompson, Avis Andrews, Dorothy Morrison and Eddie Bruce are its principal performers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Permission to appeal the order of Federal Judge William H. Holly transferring the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation's lease on the Northwestern Elevator in South Chicago to the Cargill Grain Company was granted today to an attorney representing former officials of the Rosenbaum concern by Judge George T. Page of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Bonus marchers from the camp at Kingstree, S.C., one of several camps in which the Federal Government concentrated veterans who descended on Washington with demands for Congressional action, sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES the following "open letter" addressed to Mr. Charles McLean of its Washington staff:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Rexford G. Tugwell disclosed today that he has decided upon a distinct change of policy for new suburban resettlement projects, intended to insure income facilities for residents.
MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 21. -- North America's dwindling part in the world wheat trade, which it formerly dominated, was brought out today in an official report of the Dominion Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21. -- Refinements in technique in the use of lead in the treatment of cancer, which make its use "a more important hope than it has hitherto been thought to be for the control of cancer," were reported here today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. A.E. Osterberg, Dr. J.A. Bargen and Dr. B.T. Horton of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- A somewhat more encouraging report on the possibilities of the settlement of German refugees in Latin America than that of his collaborator, James G. McDonald, League of Nations High Commissioner for German Refugees, prepared by Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, Hispanic scholar of New York, was issued today by Mr. McDonald.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- After complicating difficulties had threatened to break Sunday night's compact, President Roosevelt, Vice President Garner and Charles West, Under-Secretary of the Interior, who is the White House-Capitol "contact man," went into action today to help Congressional leaders push through the legislative program and adjourn the session by Saturday night.

A 62-acre tract at Cape May Point, N.J., has been established as a wild-life sanctuary by the National Association of Audubon Societies; with the support of the New Jersey Audubon Society. The area will be an emergency landing field for weary migrants and an inviolate haven for all forms of wildlife.

A steady increase in the flow of new business coming into the primary cotton goods market encouraged mills and selling agents this week. While the broadening of price advances was an incentive to buying, low stocks in the hands of distributers necessitated most of the orders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Based on suggestions made by the President, a modification of the Pittman neutrality resolution, swiftly passed in the Senate today, was worked out tonight at a White House conference to which Mr. Roosevelt had summoned Secretary Hull, R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, and Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Covering twenty-two and one-half miles over a moderate ground swell, with patches of short seas, H.S. Vanderbilt's sloop Prestige and Rowe B. Metcalf's schooner Sachem today won the historic Astor Cups.
In view of the general election next year an increase of $518,665 was asked yesterday in the budget of the Board of Elections for 1936 at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

The French Hospital, 320 West Thirtieth Street, appealed yesterday to the Public Service Commission for protection against a threatened discontinuance of its emergency "breakdown" electric service by the New York Edison Company. Lucian Jouvaud, president of the institution, notified the commission that the company had served notice that the emergency supply would be turned off unless it signed by Aug. 21 a new contract based on rates recently approved by the commission.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Weight, 139 pounds of it, stopped Discovery before 50,000 persons at Narragansett Park today as A.A. Baroni's Top Row ran the best race of his career to lower the colors of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's famous son of Display.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- A plan under which unemployed men would be trained for industrial employment in plants with training facilities, while carried on WPA rolls at the security wage, has been placed before several of the larger plants in New Jersey by the Works Progress Administration for that State.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Templeton, last year's winner of the national open polo championship, won a convincing victory over the team it defeated in the 1934 final, Aurora, in a test match at the Piping Rock Club today. The final score was 14 to 4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- War talk became more pronounced today in the gossip in the grain trade, and outside interest in the wheat market broadened sharply, with large professional operators active on both sides. Strength in the Northwest and in Liverpool contributed to the increased bullish enthusiasm.

Prices on the commodity futures markets were irregular yesterday with the activity moderate. Following the suspension in trading in the September No. 1 contract on Tuesday, the sugar market was considerably less active and prices were only slightly higher.

Yielding to a threat of parliamentary war, the Senate passed the resolution for neutrality in war. This does nothing to prevent a war, but it did prevent a filibuster. Rather than see their plans for an early adjournment broken up by long debate, Senators wearily adopted the legislation without a roll-call and with only a few minutes of discussion.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 21. -- Emperor Haile Selassie, weeping tears of anguish, warned the world tonight that his imminent struggle with Italy might touch off a conflict that would threaten "the very existence of humanity itself."

Assistants of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of organized crime, made their first move yesterday toward ascertaining what the District Attorney's office has been doing to curb it for the past five years.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21. -- Joe Hiestand, 28-year-old Hillsboro (Ohio) farm boy, won the North American clay-target championship today in one of the most thrill-packed finishes of the Grand American Trapshoot's history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The 1936 navy tactical games, Fleet Problem No. 17, will be held off...

WEINSBERG, Germany, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, America's No. 1 World War draft dodger, today appealed to President Roosevelt "as Commander-in-Chief of the United States Army" to let him come home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Establishment of a special board to survey applications for Federal funds under the work relief program, with a view to making sure that Works Progress Administration funds are not given to communities that have signified intention of seeking Public Works Administration funds on a loan basis, was decided upon today at a meeting of relief heads.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- An amateur-pro team seldom captures a championship two years in succession, but Willie Macfarlane, former national open champion, and Joseph Miller of Oak Ridge accomplished that feat today in retaining their Westchester title.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 21. -- The army today set up as President of the new Provisional Government Antonio Pons, who had resigned as Premier yesterday on learning of the dictatorship plans of Jose M. Velasco Ibarra. Mr. Velasco, President until yesterday, was arrested last night after part of the garrison at Quito had proclaimed him dictator.

A plan of reorganization for Bayway Terminal, Inc., of Elizabeth, N.J., now in receivership, was announced jointly yesterday by two committees representing holders of the company's first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund bonds due on July 1, 1946.

Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, declined to comment yesterday on the expressed views of Mayor La Guardia intimating that the board was responsible for the delay in obtaining PWA funds for new school buildings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Continuation of the processing tax on cotton textile manufactures was recommended today by the Cabinet committee on cotton textiles in a report to the President based on studies covering four months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Six more emergency agencies were put under the Bureau of the Budget today in an executive officer by President Roosevelt, affecting the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation, the two Export-Import Banks of Washington, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Electric Home and Farm Authority.
MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Presenting a slightly rearranged line-up, the Greentree poloists rode over Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes, 15 to 4, on J.H. (Jock) Whitney's estate today.

One of the largest apartment rentals of the Fall season has been closed in 875 Park Avenue, where a specially built duplex suite of seventeen rooms and seven baths has been taken by Mrs. Alfred Hess, sister of Jesse I. Straus, American Ambassador to France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- New Jersey officials of the Works Progress Administration have no authority to propose the use of relief funds to place relief workers in private plants, WPA officials here said tonight.

Opposition to the plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad proposed by O.P. Van Sweringen, president of the Alleghany Corporation, was augmented yesterday when the committee for $40,000,000 of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico first mortgage bonds and $2,354,000 of income bonds announced that it would join the effort to defeat the plan. The $2,354,000 of income bonds will mature on Oct. 1.

A surprisingly large number of people seem to be affected by what may be called the conspiracy complex. Various events, including the great depression, were due to a "conspiracy" of one kind or another. Certain classes of people were seeking to obtain control of the country, or perhaps the business of the country, or perhaps control of the whole world, and in furtherance of their nefarious schemes were and are willing to wreck the country.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The good colt, Crossbow II, by Crusader from Slow and Easy, which races under the silks of Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, proved best in a field of 2-year-olds in the twenty-third running of the Sanford Stakes today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The breeding stock, yearlings and foals of the Elsmeade Farm, owned by Morton L. Schwartz, and a consignment from W.W. Vaughan went under the hammer in the Fasig-Tipton paddock tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The worries of the closing days of the Congressional session did not diminish President Roosevelt's customary exuberance as he held his regular press conference today. He appeared more buoyant than usual.

Motion picture screens throughout the nation will be darkened two minutes at an appropriate time after 2 P.M. today as a last tribute to Will Rogers. Funeral services for the actor, humorist and writer, who died with Wiley Post, the aviator, in an airplane crash in Alaska, will be held in Hollywood at 2 P.M. Pacific Coast standard time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- After a day and a half of rainstorms, postponements and high scores, Chicago today named its district delegation of qualifiers for the national amateur golf championship at Cleveland Sept. 9 to 14.

Jack Doyle, the Irish heavyweight, will make his bid for serious recognition as a contender for the world's championship tonight when he opposes Buddy Baer, Max Baer's 20-year-old brother, in a six-round bout at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

A temporary injunction restraining the officers of the Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders Union from effecting a new constitution which would place control of the union in the hands of a board of eleven men was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron Steuer.

More than 1,000,000 pounds of assorted foodstuffs intended for use in city hospitals and other institutions was rejected as unfit by municipal inspectors in the first six months of this year, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, has lodged an emphatic protest with Chancellor Hitler against the censoring in the German press of the speech Dr. Schacht delivered at Koenigsberg Sunday denouncing disturbances to German business through extralegal activities of National Socialist extremists, according to reports current in political circles today.

Pressure was lifted from the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. All classifications of domestic bonds, including United States Government loans, participated in a broad recovery movement. Italian dollar issues were about the only noteworthy exceptions to the trend and declined 1 to 4 points to new low records.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 21. -- Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge, with her sister, Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds, Mrs. Amy C. Shepherd, Joseph F. Duffy and Miss J. Alice Maxwell were guests at the Mount Washington at a party given in honor of the Princess by Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. McClintic of Pittsburgh. Mr. and Mrs. McClintic started today for Pittsburgh.

Andre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday for Paris on the Normandie of the French Line with Mrs. de Laboulaye. Their names were not printed in the advance list, the diplomat explaining that he had been uncertain whether he could get away from the embassy in time.
