. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, president-elect of the powerful South Manchuria Railway and former Japanese delegate to the League of Nations, told foreign correspondents today that the cardinal points in his policy in Manchukuo were: Firstly, to engage in profitable undertakings only; secondly, to avoid putting further burdens on Japan, and thirdly, to improve the economic condition of Manchurian farmers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Ted Clark, ridden by Jockey Alfred Robertson, galloped to an easy three-length victory in the mile feature at Lincoln Fields today. Cotton Club was second and Onrush third.

Addressing 1,400 Boy Scouts from nine States and three foreign countries on the Mall at Central Park last night, Mayor La Guardia held up the brotherhood of the scout movement as an example to the nations of the world.

Commissioner HARNETT reasserts his belief in compulsory insurance for all automobiles as the only way to provide protection for the victims of highway accidents. Even in this State, whose record is better than that of some of its neighbors, a man, a woman or a child is being killed on the average every three hours, Winter and Summer, night and day.

The submission to the voters at the November election of Mayor La Guardia's city power plant project was assured yesterday when the Board of Aldermen, by a vote of 48 to 1, approved a bill authorizing the referendum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- With a warm expression of desire for continued friendly relations, Dr. Sacke Alfred Sze presented to President Roosevelt today his letters of credence as the first Ambassador of China to the United States. China and the United States decide recently to raise their diplomatic missions from the status of legation to embassy.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Fifty-nine cases of infantile paralysis have been reported to the State Department of Health since July 1. This Summer is slightly above the number for the corresponding period a year ago.

NEW PORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Fox Frissell entertained at a tea in their home, Wildacre, this afternoon in honor of Sir Wilfred Grenfell of Labrador and Lady Grenfell. There were more than 100 present, including members of the Summer colony.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- A final demand for return of $5,153.97, which the present administration of Joliet insists represents overpayment for services rendered in recovering $48,460 of city funds from the closed Joliet National Bank, was sent to President Roosevelt's former New York law firm.

The seven-story apartment building at the northwest corner of 181st Street and Northern Avenue, known as 95 Northern Avenue, was sold by Nehring Brothers for Superintendent of Insurance Louis Pink as liquidator of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A final Senate vote tomorrow on the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill was assured when the chamber put a drastic limit on debate before recessing tonight.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21. -- Encouraged by drought in Argentina, rust in Canada and the United States and the possibility of war in Ethiopia, the new Canadian Wheat Board has reversed the policy, decided on by the government six weeks ago, of throwing Canada's 225,000,000 bushel wheat surplus on the world market at the best price it would bring.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21. -- Greyhound, flashy son of Guy Abbe, today eclipsed his brilliant performance in winning the Hambletonian last week and trotted a mile at the Illinois State Fair in 2 minutes flat, establishing a new world's record for 3-year-old geldings.

The Reds, making their farewell appearance of the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday and still acting stubborn, kept the Giants busy for seven innings looking in vain for a vulnerable spot in their battle front. But in the eighth the Terrymen found it.

Steel stocks dominated the share market yesterday. Heavy buying of these issues transmitted strength to the copper, aviation, chemical and other groups of the war stock list, so-called, and to automotive, farm equipment, and, finally, to virtually the entire market.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A list of eighteen oil royalty offering sheets filed last week was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MAYSVILLE, Okla., Aug. 21. -- Wiley Post's body was brought back to his home town today so that his neighbors might pay their last tribute to the famous flier before the funeral rites tomorrow at Oklahoma City.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday the salaries of principal executives of the May Department Stores Company which were reported in its permanent registration statement with the request that they be held confidential.

Percival S. Howe Jr. has been elected vice president of the Industrial Rayon Corporation in charge of sales. He was for many years vice president of Suncook Mills, Suncook, N.H., and was the first president of the National Rayon Weavers Association

Operations of the American Agricultural Chemical Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30 resulted in a net profit of $1,427,603 after depreciation, depletion, provision for losses on time sales on shipments, reserve for insurance and Federal taxes.

IT appears that Madison Square Garden is still very much in the fight business. There is the scheduled debate for this evening between Jacob Baer Jr., called Buddy, and Jack Doyle from the Emerald Isle, under the Garden auspices in the Long Island Bowl. There is also the brisk battle between Colonel John S. Hammond, chairman of the board of directors, and Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

Casey Stengel's Dodgers continue to astonish the few fans who come out to see them in action at Ebbets Field. Yesterday they completed winning their third straight series when George Earnshaw pitched them to a 5-to-0 shut-out over the Pirates.

State and city authorities moved yesterday to break up a new milk racket which is believed to have been wringing from $600,000 to $1,200,000 a year from the 200 independent wholesale dealers in New York.

Announcement was made yesterday by Nathan M. Ohrbach, president of Ohrbach's Affiliated Stores, Inc., that the 2,000 employes in the Ohrbach stores here and in Newark would continue to operate on a forty-hour week, "despite the deplorable nation-wide tendency among retail firms to go back to the forty-five-hour week."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Only three heats of harness racing, one in each event, were raced at the Orange County Fair today before rain caused a postponement. Volo Arion, the favorite, won the heat finished in the feature event for 3-year-old trotters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2l. -- President Roosevelt made public a report by the Cabinet Committee on Cotton Textiles, discussed cotton loans, discussed railway workers' pensions with labor leaders, held an evening conference on neutrality legislation and broadcast a speech to the Boy Scouts of America.

An emergency gift payment of $13 is to be made to each of the Works Progress Administration workers suffering because of the delay in receipt of their Aug. 15 checks, Administrator Hugh S. Johnson announced yesterday. The total will be $1,209,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Armour Co. has contracted to purchase the properties of Jacob E. Decker Sons, including the meat-packing plant at Mason City, Iowa, and several branch houses, it was announced today by R.H. Cabell, president of Armour Co.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 21. -- I worked with Will Rogers in the last picture he ever made, "Steamboat 'Round the Bend." We finished working in it just about six weeks ago. That's something for me to remember, something to be proud of, until my hour comes.

Under the patronage of an honorary committee headed by Borough President Samuel Levy, final preparations are now being made for the annual Elberon Horse Show to be held on Sept. 1 on the Elberon estate of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil.
INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., Aug. 21. -- Pennsylvania's National Guardsmen of the Twenty-eighth Division began spectacular battle manoeuvres on the huge Indiantown Reservation today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Tests involving the essence of the Guffey-Snyder Coal Control Bill were survived by the measure today as the Senate rejected by 44 to 29 an attempt by Senator Tydings to eliminate the controversial punitive tax on the value of coal at the mine head, and later defeated by 40 to 36 an amendment seeking to reduce the tax from 15 per cent to 5.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- After ten years, Helen Hayes has returned to G.B. Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra." In 1925 she and it opened the Theatre Guild's new playhouse with Lionel Atwill swaggering through a pompous performance of Caesar. If this reviewer's memory is not unchivalrous that production was not one of the gems in the Theatre Guild's diadem.

Distillers, importers and wholesale liquor dealers planned yesterday to ask Edward P. Mulrooney, head of the State Liquor Authority, to protect New York dealers against the dumping of liquor from other States. They complained that State liquor monopolies in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Ohio, and to a lesser degree in other States, were unloading here the whiskies and wines they could not sell at home.
Firms engaged in the manufacture and sale of men's clothing, haberdashery and other apparel lines figured prominently in contracts for the leasing of business quarters yesterday.

In one of the most unexpected upward swings in the history of the industry, steel works operations and scrap prices continue to rise. Ingot output has advanced 1 1/2 points to 50 1/2 per cent of capacity in its seventh consecutive weekly increase, the weekly summary of The Iron Age reports.

In the Tax Bill that has emerged from the conference there is only one major improvement over the bill that was passed by the House. The confiscatory inheritance tax, which was found even on cursory examination to present administrative difficulties so great that neither the House nor the Senate committee could finally be brought to defend it seriously, was thrown out.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Tigers again increased their American League lead to seven games today by defeating the Red Sox, 4 -- 1 and 3 -- 2, in a double-header.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 15 shows the following changes, in paper pesos, from that of July 31:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Phillies and Cubs divided a double-header today, the former winning the first game, 13 to 12, and then losing, 19 to 5.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21. -- The Bolivian Government has informed diplomats at La Paz that it will suspend demobilization if Paraguay does not accept the peace terms proposed by the Bolivian delegation to the Chaco Peace Conference here.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has said that our ways of thinking must be changed, but since most people are too lazy to think, such an amendment and reform can be contemplated without fear. Even if the stream of thought has begun to run uphill, a sense of stability will not be wanting so long as the language of our best thought, which is political, remains standardized and unaltered.

CHATEAUBRIAND said of the Mississippi River -- christened by Father MARQUETTE as the Riviere de la Conception -- that it still "grieves" for the spirit of the French (regrette encore leur genie). And yet it has been unkind to some of the villages and towns of French origin that have built themselves into its banks.

The parking of automobiles in our city streets during the night has become a serious problem which the Police Department must solve. More and more irresponsible owners of cars are leaving them on our public highways overnight instead, of placing them in garages or open-air parking spaces.

Although the cotton trade had expected that a definite announcement on the 1935 producers' loan might be made at the press conference at the White House yesterday, operators were again disappointed and prices on the Cotton Exchange closed at losses of 5 to 7 points.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Aug. 21. -- The chattery rhesus monkey colony at Frank Buck's jungle camp on the Sunrise Highway between here and Amityville gave no warning during the past week that it was aquiver with impending revolution.
My entry this week in the "What's Wrong With the Country Court" is the announcement that a group of Cornell University scientists are tinkering with onions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- President Roosevelt's chief secretary, Louis McHenry Howe, who has been confined by illness to his room in the White House for more than six months, was removed to the Naval Hospital today because of the noise incident to repairs and alterations being made at the Executive Mansion.
DEPOSIT, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Two bandits, aided by a woman, held up the Farmers National Bank today, fired two shots, forced three bank employes into a vault and escaped with about $6,000.

Will Rogers, in a communication addressed to a friend in the other world, once expressed his wonderment at man's fear of death, unless for the reason that "we havent done anything that will live after us." The letter was addressed by the humorist to the late Charles M. Russell, cowboy artist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Cities Service Company of New York, headed by Henry L. Doherty, spent about $200,000 in its campaign to defeat the Wheeler-Rayburn bill, according to disclosures made today before the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee. This was exclusive of any expenses incurred for the same purpose by the 160 subsidiaries of the company.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- In an atmosphere of tension unequaled since the Summer of 1914 the British Cabinet will meet tomorrow morning to decide whether to support sanctions against Italy in the event of aggression against Ethiopia.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 21 (AP). -- David Ben-Gurion, Palestine labor leader, accused the British Government today of having committed "robbery" by artificially cutting the immigration quota of Jews seeking to enter Palestine.

A new issue of $6,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts notes, dated Sept. 3, 1935, and maturing on Aug. 31, 1936, was awarded yesterday at 0.325 per cent to a banking group composed of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, the Chase National Bank, First National Bank of Boston, Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, Merchants National Bank, New England Trust Company and Day Trust.

While Wall Street was not outwardly fearful that American Telephone and Telegraph's directors would alter the dividend rate, there was a noticeable sigh of relief with the announcement that the usual $2.25 quarterly payment had been declared.

Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical managers and president of the Actors Fund of America, will he 84 years old today. At least, 84 is the age which Mr. Frohman says that he will be. The records shows that he was born on Aug. 22, 1850, in Sandusky, Ohio, which would make him 85.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. announced yesterday he had caught a "fixer" in his courts. He proceeded to deal with him with a technique developed to high efficiency in the Seabury investigations. At the same time he declared war on all fixing and extortion in the magistrates' courts and promised vigorous action on all information given by the public.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- After three rounds of the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association in congress at the Hotel Arlington, Norman Lessing of the Bronx and David Polland of Brooklyn are tied for the lead with two victories to their credit and no defeats.

If the pace of a modern army is set by its motorized equipment, then it might be said that military operations have been accelerated a dozenfold since the World War. Up in the Adirondacks the First Division of the regular army made an advance of thirty miles in an hour and a half.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -The Boer se, although inactive, remained firm today. Heavy industrials were quiet and slightly weaker, Hoeseh losing a point. achine issues were firth, Berlin-Karlsruhe gaining 1% points. Chemical shares were mixed and unsteady, I. G. Farben losing point and. Goldschmidt 1. Electrioals were mixed in results, A. E. G. rising IA points.

GLASGOW, Aug. 21. -- Seventy thousand spectators saw Scotland defeat England, 4 -- 2, today in an "all-pay" international soccer match at Hampden Park. The proceeds of the game will he devoted to the King's Jubilee Cancer Fund.

More than fifty employes and officials of Pan American Airways, among them Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, took part in the work of moving the bodies of Wiley Post and Will Rogers from where they crashed at Point Barrow to their homes, it was revealed here yesterday.

Maintaining unbroken the dividend record of $9 a year since 1921, the directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday declared the usual quarterly dividend of $2.25 on the capital stock, payable on Oct. 15 to holders of record on Sept. 16. About $42,000,000 will be distributed to the 675,000 holders of the stock.

SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Two British speed drivers, Sir Malcolm Campbell and Captain George Eyston, sailed in the liner Majestic today bound for the salt flats of Utah, where they will attempt to lower automobile speed records.
Winfield Sheehan, motion-picture producer, and his bride, the operatic prima donna Maria Jeritza, sailed yesterday on their wedding trip to Europe on the French liner-Normandie.

"Annapolis Farewell," a Paramount picture filmed at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, will have its premiere at 8:30 o'clock tonight at the Paramount Theatre. It features Tom Brown, Rosalind Keith, Sir Guy Standing and Richard Cromwell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The administration's last hope for passage in this session of a bill for utility holding company control was staked tonight on the compromise proposal offered at the White House Sunday night which would prohibit control by a holding company, except under certain conditions, of more than one integrated public utility system.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21. -- A large audience filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players, under the direction of Felix Jacoves, gave their fourth and final production for this season, "The Uncertain Lover," a new comedy by Byron Dexter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Stressing the need of cooperation by all citizens to work out national problems, President Roosevelt, in a radio address to Boy Scouts tonight, made this reference to the Constitution:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21. -- Lou Gehrig hit two home runs at Sportsman's Park today, one of which he claimed to be a history-making blow, but only this one brought success to the Yankees as they opened a five-game series with Rogers Hornsby's Browns.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Senators battered three White Sox pitchers for eighteen hits, totaling twenty-five bases, to win the opening game of the series, 15 to 7, today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during July at 73.5 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 74.6 during June this year, and 74.3 during July last year.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- Securities on the London Stock Exchange developed a better tendency today, with conditions more settled, although the business volume remained small owing to the approaching end of the account. The outstanding feature was the fairly sharp rally in gold mine stocks, particularly in South Africans, on the cessation of liquidation at the Cape.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A national committee of lawyers, serving without pay, has been formed by the American Liberty League to study the constitutionality of New Deal legislation and will make its first report early in September.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Protective committees for security holders in the reorganization of the Cuban Cane Sugar Corporation in 1929-30 were headed by bankers whose institutions had large loans outstanding to the company, the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of reorganizations disclosed today.

Following a monthly meeting yesterday, two groups of members of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, numbering about 100 each, toured the Broadway sector routing the pickets of the Allied Motion Picture Operators Union, a rival outfit. Police arrested sixteen.
The New Yol'k Stock Exchange announced yesterday that arrangements had been made for the transfer of a membership at $105,000, a decline of $20,000 from the last previous transaction on Auff. 9.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- George Savino collected only two singles in six trips to the plate, but the first drove in the tying run for the Chiefs in the ninth inning and his second scored Nick Dallessandro with the winning run with two out in the thirteenth to bring Syracuse a 3-to-2 victory over Newark tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A rereading of the Senate debate on the neutrality resolution, and the text of the resolution itself, strengthen the conclusion that this is the most important subject with which this Congress has been asked to deal.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Shut-out pitching by Lloyd Brown gave the Indians a 3-to-0 victory over the Athletics in the second game of their double-header today after the Mackmen had pounded four Cleveland hurlers for thirteen safeties to win, 10 to 5, in the first.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- A defense of the New Deal as marking the beginning of an epoch of social development was made by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, before the convention of the New York State Federation of Labor today.

A long list of foreclosure auctions in Manhattan yesterday was headed by the forced sale of the twenty-six-story apartment hotel at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The building is on a plot 125 by 80 feet. The sale included the abutting property, 92 by 98.9 feet, on Thirty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Continuance of the light demand for fresh pork loins resulted in the outside price being shaded 1 cent a pound by local packers here today, the best quoted at 26 cents, or 4 cents under the top of last Thursday. It was reported that the packers were unable to dispose of even the current small output and had been forced to put the excess in freezers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- An official summary of the report on the cotton textile situation by a special Cabinet committee is contained in the following letter from the committee to President Roosevelt:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- The City Commission authorized Mayor Ellenstein today to apply to the Works Progress Administration for approval of plans to improve and expand the Newark Airport at a total cost of $3,978,411, of which the WPA would pay $3,363,758, and the city $614,653. Employment would be given to about 3,700 men for a year.
Covici, Friede report that July was their best sales month in two years. "Tortilla Flat," by John Steinbeck, is their list leader and Robert Forsythe's "Redder Than the Rose" is second in sales.

It was learned yesterday from an authoritative source that the new American opera for the Metropolitan next season will be the opera "Lucedia," by the American composer, Vittorio Giannini. Vittorio Giannini is the brother of the well known American singer, Dusolina Giannini, a pupil of the late Mme. Sembrich, who has sung much of late years, and with brilliant success, in opera in Europe.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- The secrets of the Catholic confessional were placed in jeopardy in Germany today when a Roman Catholic priest, Father Horoba, was fined 500 marks for "abuse of the confessional chair." The State Attorney at Gleiwitz prosecuted the priest for allegedly attempting to dissuade a woman during a confession from sending her son into the Nazi labor service. She afterward told her husband and he denounced the priest.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- With his mates pounding out nineteen hits. Dizzy Dean today beat the Braves, 13 to 3, to give the Cardinals the series, three games to one, and record his twenty-first triumph of the season.

A warning that "the policy of wasteful expenditure, accompanied by huge, indeed almost unlimited borrowing now being practiced not only in the United States but in other countries as well, must end in either repudiation or inflation" was voiced by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a letter made public last night by Thomas. I. Parkinson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Housing projects and other features of the public works program sponsored by the Federal Government here stimulate the heavy goods industries and the building trades, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in an address to the delegates of the American Society of Sanitary Engineering, in session this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Decrying the "apparent indifference and unconcern" of the Roosevelt administration over the religious difficulties in Mexico, the Supreme Council of the Knights of Columbus voted unanimously yesterday to send the President a letter urging him to withdraw his "opposition" to the Borah resolution, now before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- German citizens read of new attacks on the Jews in the newspapers today. The Stuermer reproduced the school composition of a pupil in the fourth grade who wrote, "The cuckoo is the Jew among birds."

For the nine months ended on July 31 the United States Leather Company reported yesterday a net income of $108,307 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, interest and other charges. This equalled $1.46 a share on 74,105 shares of $100 par, 7 per cent cumulative prior preference stock, excluding shares held in the treasury, on which are unpaid back dividends.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Sagittarius, the heavenly archer, shot a brand-new comet from his bow in the southern sky tonight.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, in a preliminary report for the first six months, reported yesterday a net income of $18,964,318 after all expenses including taxes and reserves, except Federal income taxes. This was equivalent to 75 cents a share on the 6,261,254 common shares outstanding on June 30.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange weakened today as a result of the latest developments in the Italo-Ethiopian situation. Business was restricted as the Cabinet's decision was awaited, although some recovery was noted in the late dealings Further declines in British funds was due more to the absence of buyers than to any selling pressure.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- A Catholic priest observing the prescriptions of his own Bishop in regard to political activities is acting within the law "in the present state of our canonical legislation," Mgr. William F. Murphy of Detroit writes in the September number of The Ecclesiastical Review.
LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 22. -- President James Buchanan's home lies in the shadow of the auctioneer's hammer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The compromise on the "death sentence" in the Utility Holding Company Bill accepted today by the House read as follows:

Dispatches from the meeting of the American Chemical Society in San Francisco yesterday, asserting that improved technique in utilizing lead for the treatment of cancer makes its use "a more important hope than it has hitherto been thought to be," were received "with skepticism and regret" at the Memorial Hospital for life Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, 106th Street and Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Sharp and immediate was the resentment among Southern Senators when the administration announced a government loan of 9 cents a pound on the 1935 cotton crop, plus additional direct grants designed to assure contract signers a total return of 12 cents on cotton produced under Bankhead allotments.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

In 1925 Professor BLAIR BELL of the University of Liverpool, after prolonged researches and clinical studies, reached the conclusion that his lead treatment had definitely "placed the "solution of the cancer problem within "grasp, if indeed it has not already "been accomplished."

ABOUT a week ago President Will Harridge of the American League assessed $100 fines on Managers Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Joe Cronin of the Red Sox for permitting, encouraging or abetting some quaint baseball strategy in the Red Sox park when there was a prospect of rain on the roof.

Engineering construction contracts for the past week totaled $29,438,000, or 15 per cent higher than for the average week thus far this year, but somewhat below the high records of the two preceding weeks, according to figures compiled yesterday by Engineering News-Record.

A schedule calling tentatively for an appropriation of $18,335,667 next year, an increase of $4,396,859 over 1935, was submitted by the Department of Public Welfare at a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- While a squadron of National Guard planes and private aircraft dipped low over Mustin Field at the Philadelphia Navy Yard today, officials of the city, State, army and navy participated in a memorial service for Will Rogers and Wiley Post.

It is an arresting thought that vitamins are not at usually found in chopped straw, in beach sand, in prussic acid and other unpalatable dishes. The scientists go hunting for vitamins in such attractive and familiar jungles as milk, butter, eggs, beef, mutton, oranges, grapefruit, lettuce and olive oil.

CALGARY, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- A Social Credit Government was assured in Alberta tonight as a fifteen-year reign by the United Farmers of the Province came to an end with a complete sweep by their opponents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -Infantile paralysis increased last week in Virginia, Massachusetts, New York, Michigan and Kentucky, in reports compiled today at the Public Health Service. Cases the country over numbered 539.

" Smile at Me," the revue scheduled to open last night at the Fulton, was postponed late yesterday afternoon for the fifth time. According to a representative of the management, the conductor and composer of the show, Jerry Dolan, suffered a nervous collapse at 5:30 P.M., requiring the postponement of the opening until tonight.

CLAREMORE, Okla., Aug. 22. -The airplane crash that killed Will Rogers and Wiley Post was called the saddest news to the United States since the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, in a memorial address today by Representative Josh Lee.

Herbert O. Allen, 47 years old, of 31 East Twelfth Street, chief of the mendicancy squad of the Emergency Relief Bureau at Jefferson Market Court, who was arrested Wednesday on a charge of petty larceny for allegedly accepting money to "fix" a case, denied in the Tombs prison yesterday that he had confessed, according to his attorney.

TOKYO, Aug. 22. -- Japan is willing to participate in the multilateral naval conversations that the British Government proposes to hold in October, provided her fundamental demand for a common upper limit is accepted.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Attorney General Margiotti at Harrisburg today split with Charles F. Kelley, District Attorney, on the grand jury investigation of Philadelphia's magistrates, which started this week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- A death sentence was pronounced tonight over one of the President's "must" bills -- the Federal Alcohol Control plan.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Red Sox upset the league-leading Tigers today to regain third place in the American League with a 10-to-9 victory. The triumph put Boston ahead of the beaten White Sox and Indians, while the Tigers held their seven-game margin over the Yankees.

Two Correction Department physicians, assigned to Correction Hospital, were dismissed from the city service at the order of Mayor La Guardia, it was learned yesterday, for ordering Salvatore Spitale, convicted "public enemy," to the hospital when he had been assigned to pick and shovel work on Harts Island.

Few debates between conferees or arguments on the floors of Congress have excited as much interest as was manifested yesterday by the financial community in the ups and downs of the Utility Holding Company Bill. Professional traders as well as investors brushed aside every other bit of news as attention was centred on the battle raging around the "death sentence" clause and the separate conference reports on the measure.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The sailing of the King's Cup race by the boats of the New York Yacht Club today was a matter of interest to many Summer residents. There were several sailing parties out, the larger of them being aboard the Winchester with General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and aboard the Hi-Esmaro with Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- As the 36,000 troops of the five divisions encamped here prepared tonight for the start tomorrow of a two-day inter-corps "battle," the mystery of the Twenty-seventh Division's failure to hold "Hill 300" in yesterday's divisional manoeuvres was explained.

New York extended a thorough welcome yesterday to 315 French war veterans and their associates who arrived here from Canada on a one-day good-will tour. Included in the division, which is representative of all sections of France, were about 100 members who had been honored for distinguished service during the World War.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Enesco's new opera "Oedipe" will be mounted at the Paris Opera as the most important novelty of the coming season. Considered in advance as one of the finest scores by a modern composer of opera, the work is being prepared with every possible attention.

The Black Diamond Steamship Line and the Compagnie Maritime Belge, operating in the west-bound conference freight pool between New York, Rotterdam, Antwerp and Hamburg, announced yesterday that they would not accept the decision of an arbitrator granting right to the Red Star Line to participate in the pool.
PARIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

DUBLIN, Aug. 22. -- The Irish Flee State is closely following the Italo-Ethiopian crisis, but while a number of Irishmen, including doctors, have volunteered for service with the Ethiopian Army, very few are really anxious to participate in the prospective war.

THE most fascinating book this month has produced is a tome called "Historic Opinions of the United States Supreme Court," selected, with a preface and introductory notes, by Ambrose Doskow (Vanguard Press, $4.50). Pick it up, read Mr. Doskow's prefatory remarks, and then, after a brief dip into the first case, "Madison v. Marbury," skip to the Dred Scott decision.
President Roosevelt affixed his signature to the Social Security Bill with the remark that the bill would provide "at least some measure of protection to 30,000,000 of our citizens."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Battle lines were drawn here today in a dispute raging around a mural depicting war and peace.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Rumors of a possible threat against the position of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, caused prices to fail on the Boerse today. Drops of one to two points occurred in many leading securities. The market became slightly firmer at the close.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Blossoms showered from the sky today on the body of Wiley Post as the tribute of his State was accorded to the fallen airman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Headed by National Chairman Henry P. Fletcher, a group of influential Republican party managers have begun taking steps to assure that the Republican National Convention next year, contrary to recent custom, will be held after the Democrats have written their platform and chosen their candidates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -The bonus-by-inflation issue, which racked the present session of Congress, today was cast squarely before the next session with a vote assured within the first ten days.

The investment demand for stocks reasserted itself yesterday, and as speculative interests appeared less anxious to claim profits, prices worked higher throughout the day with but minor interruptions. News from the Washington political scene during trading hours was so confusing that followers of the market had little success in finding anything on which to base judgment.

Awaiting an announcement regarding a producers' loan, traders on the Cotton Exchange transacted little business yesterday and prices ended at a. loss of 1 to a gain of 3 points. No statement on the loan was made until after the market closed, although early advices had held out the hope that a decision would be announced during the session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Vital reasons why mandatory legislation for the application of neutrality policies should not be voted by Congress but that, instead, permissive authority on such policies should be granted to the President are being advanced by diplomatic groups which have long been studying the question and upon whose advice the administration is said to be largely basing its position.

The pending controversy over the Mayor's favorite project for a $45,000,000 municipal power plant involves three distinct issues: whether such a plant should be erected, whether the question of erecting it should be left to the voters to decide, and whether the local law which has been drafted for submission to a popular referendum meets the requirements of the situation.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will sail tonight for channel ports and Bremen. Her passengers will include Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware, Racquel Torres, motion picture actress; Sir Reginald Clarke, former police commissioner of Calcutta, and the following others:

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22. -- Food and housing cost increases have outrun wage rises in the last year, so that the average American family's actual buying power has declined, though only by a small amount, according to the current Family Buying Power Index just issued by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- With four straight victories to his credit, David Polland of Brooklyn leads in the annual championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association in session at the Hotel Arlington, with Isaac Kashdan, New York internationalist, close behind.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22. -- The Stoyadinovitch Cabinet is faced with a serious crisis. Three Croat Ministers are reported to have handed their resignations to Prince Regent Paul, while Yugoslavia's strong man, War Minister Pera Zhivkovitch, is reported to be ready to join them.

France will be forced off the gold standard in the near future, in the opinion of August Heckscher, banker and philanthropist, who returned from Europe yesterday on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line. Mr. Heckscher said he did not see how any of the gold-bloc nations could stay on gold any longer.

Canada is not confronted with a transfer problem and has experienced no difficulty in providing foreign exchange for external debt service, says the Institute of International Finance in a bulletin given out by its director, John T. Madden.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22. -- History repeated itself today when a band of Tartar Mongol riders from the Central Asian steppes rode triumphantly into Moscow, wearing the national costume with gigantic round hats of rough sheepskin that their ancestors wore in the days of Tamerlane.

The announcement by the AAA last night that a loan of 9 cents a pound would be made on the 1935 cotton crop came as a complete surprise to members of the Cotton Exchange here, despite the corporation's guarantee of 12 cents a pound return to producers.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 22. -Warning was given by the Meteorological Bureau today that a tropical disturbance approaching hurricane force was working slowly northward toward Bermuda.
Luise Rainer, who made her American film debut in "Escapade," will play opposite William Powell in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's forthcoming production, "The Great Ziegfeld."

The expansion of Federal Reserve member-bank reserves through the spending by the Treasury of funds obtained by depositing gold certificates with the Federal Reserve Banks was carried further in the week ended on Wednesday, Federal Reserve statistics published yesterday showed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The roll-call Aug. 1 by which the House refused to instruct its conferees to accept the "death sentence" in the Utility Holding Company Bill and the ballot today in which it ordered acceptance of the Barkley "compromise" show the following vote switches:

Retail credit collections during July gained 1.62 per cent, bringing the average to 46.51, compared with 44.89 for the same month a year ago, according to the twenty-key-store index of the Retail Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. Seventeen of the twenty stores showed increases for the month.
MASSAPEQUA, Aug. 22. -- A revised count, with several districts still to be heard from, indicated tonight that 111 monkeys, fugitives from Frank Buck's zoo near here, were still at large.

Major Henry H. Curran, who got a surprise in London one morning recently when he received a beribboned and sealed appointment from Mayor La Guardia making him the city's noise abatement commissioner, came home yesterday on the United States liner Washington full of designs on the city's myriad noises.

Five Jersey City men arrested for violation of the New Jersey election law in an alleged attempt to pad the registration list in Hudson County were held without bail for action of the Hudson County grand jury when arraigned yesterday in Kearny Police Court before Police Recorder Anthony J. Casale.

The death early Wednesday morning of Miss Lucy Haring, 60-year-old art instructor at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, in her improvised tent on the roof of the People's Tabernacle at 52 East 102d Street, was due to strangulation, Dr. Thomas H. Gonzales, Assistant Medical Examiner, announced yesterday afternoon following an autopsy.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 22. -- Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge entertained at luncheon at the Mount Washington today her nephew, R. Foster Reynolds, and R. Foster Reynolds Jr., who came from their Summer home at Bridgeton, Me.
HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 22. -- Leo Diegel of the Philmont Country Club, Philadelphia, carded a 68, five under par, to assume a two-stroke lead today in the third annual Hershey open golf tournament.

In the "Geography of Strabo," written at the beginning of the Christian era, there is a detailed description of the unsuccessful expedition sent by AUGUSTUS CAESAR into that part of the world to which the ships of MUSSOLINI have been proceeding, as did the biremes and triremes and other vessels under command of AELIUS GALLUS.

Almost unanimous in their opinion that Mayor La Guardia, though the friend of the pushcart peddler, has been "misinformed," speakers last night at a meeting of the Park Avenue Open Air Retail Merchants Association deplored a statement attributed to him Monday that drygoods men must leave the new Harlem closed market.

Continuing his drive to rid the Magistrates' courts of uncivil attendants as well as "chiselers and fixers," Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. announced yesterday afternoon that he had dismissed Jacob Katz, an attendant in Night court.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Defeating Worcestershire today by an innings and 60 runs, Yorkshire today practically won the English County cricket championship. Only the complete collapse of the White Rose County in its three remaining games and the annexing of full points by Derbyshire, its nearest rival, can affect the standing.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 22. -In accounting for the Plymouth purse, at six furlongs for 3-year-olds and up, which featured today's card, J.U. Gratton's Allen Z. scored his first triumph since last May.

Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, N.J, the favorite, advanced to the semifinal round of the girls' Eastern invitation tennis tournament at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, yesterday. She eliminated Miss Virginia Kearns, Staten Island girls' champion, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22. -- State and Federal estate taxes of $913,570 will be assessed against Will Rogers's estate, according to a tentative estimate today by California inheritance tax officials. The figures are computed on the assumption that the Rogers estate would be valued at $5,000,000 on a community property basis.

NEW CASTLE, N.H., Aug. 22. -- A Japanese ball in commemoration of the thirtieth anniversary of the signing of the Russo-Japanese peace treaty was held here tonight. The treaty was signed at the Portsmouth Navy Yard on Sept. 5, 1905, and the envoys of Russia and Japan made their headquarters at the Hotel Wentworth-by-the-Sea, where the anniversary ball was held.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Turning to the field of the "Washington Social Lobby," a Senate investigating committee sought to show today that in the recent campaign against the Wheeler-Rayburn Utility Holding Company Bill Congress members and other persons high in public life, including Marvin H. McIntyre, secretary to the President, and Lawrence W. Robert, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, had been recipients of hospitality from the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Senators buried the White Sox under a barrage of base hits today, making fifteen safeties against Sam Jones and Jack Salveson for a 7-to-4 triumph, their second in a row.

SANTA ROSA, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Amid gunfire and tear gas, 300 self-styled vigilantes tarred and feathered two alleged Communists early today and beat three other men after an all-night hunt for agitators in Sonora County.

VIENNA, Aug. 22. -- Austrian Nazis are strongly backing the Ethiopian horse. There is much talk among Austrian Nazis that the very moment Italy opens hostilities official Germany will reopen its campaign against the Schuschnigg-Starhemberg regime.

The Supreme Council of the Knights of Columbus, governing the order in the United States, terminated its annual convention yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by recommending that every Catholic child be sent to a Catholic school.

Two blind Hoosier boys were led by kindly passersby into police headquarters yesterday morning, the end of their 800-mile hitch-hiking trail from South Bend, Ind., in quest of fame and fortune in minstrelsy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A 4.6 per cent decline in the number of families on relief and a 5.6 decline in relief costs between June and July was reported today by the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Governor Bibb Graves signed the Calhoun bill today granting immunity to newspaper reporters from revealing confidential news sources before grand juries or other investigating bodies and the measure became law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A rise in wholesale commodity prices which placed the average at the highest point since November, 1930, and brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics index to 80.5 for the week ended Aug. 17 as compared with 80.1 the previous week and 76.1 a year ago was reported today by Commissioner Lubin of the bureau.

If X-ray examinations of Max Baer's hands, taken yesterday, reveal that all the bones are sound, the former heavyweight champion of the world will fight Joe Louis in the Yankee Stadium on the night of Sept. 24. Mike Jacobs, who is promoting the bout, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday morning, and asked permission to run the show on the 24th.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22. -- There is a strong probability that a new republic will be formed in South America as a result of the Chaco war. It would be formed of the Bolivian Provinces of Beni and Santa Cruz and probably be called the Republic of Santa Cruz.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP). -- One of the outstanding pitching duels of the season in Cleveland produced a 1-to-0 victory for the Athletics in the third game of their series with the Indians today. Bill Dietrich held the Indians to six hits while Thornton Lee, Cleveland hurler, allowed seven.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Governor Hoffman of New Jersey declared here today that he was not going to be a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- The convention of the New York State Federation of Labor approved at its closing session here today the recommendation of its resolutions committee rejecting a proposal that labor form a party of its own. There were only a few dissenting votes.

MADRID, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Spanish press today published a communique from the Minister of the Interior minimizing the movement of troops to the Mediterranean and deprecating comments of observers that it was a precautionary measure against an Italo-Ethiopian war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A less-than-seasonal decline in June of 0.1 per cent or about 7,000 workers in factory employment and of 1.7 per cent, or about $2,200,000 in factory payrolls as compared with May was reported today by Secretary Perkins.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 22. -- With an accord reached between the White House and Capitol on neutrality legislation, with adoption by the House of a compromise on the Utility Holding Company Bill, and passage by the Senate of the Guffey-Snyder coal stabilization measure, Congress entered the home stretch today with apparent certainty of crossing the finishing line by Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Guffey-Snyder bill to re-establish government control of working conditions, prices and trade practice in the bituminous coal industry was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 45 to 37, but with amendments that will probably necessitate a conference.

On Aug. 16 I went to Forest Hills to see the Wightman Cup matches. With recollections of Wimbledon I arrived at 1:30 P.M. expecting to get a seat, or perhaps standing room, by the skin of my teeth. After paying $2.20 for a ticket, I found myself the sole occupant of the stadium.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 22. -- With Wang Ching-wei resuming, at least for the time being, the concurrent posts of Premier and Foreign Minister, the political leaders who had congregated at Nanking while Mr. Wang's resignation hung fire began to disperse tonight.

News dispatches from Washington, the accuracy of which seems to be beyond question, tell of a Representative in Congress whose father and brothers are being supported by Federal relief agencies. The Representative in question issued a statement in which he attempts to justify himself.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP). -Al Hollingsworth held the Phillies to three hits, two doubles and a triple, today as the Reds pounded out a 9-1 victory in the opening game of the series.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -Signaling the approach of a hot Presidential campaign, Republicans arranged today to give a quick reply to the speech President Roosevelt will deliver Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- President Roosevelt hailed the "stalwart qualities of frontier days" in a talk tonight over the telephone to Sainte Genevieve, Mo., commemorating its bicentennial.

Bank clearings for the first three weeks of August reached the highest figure for that period in any year since 1931. The total for twenty-two leading cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,086,988,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Despite bearish reports regarding the demand for fresh pork and hog products because of high prices, receipts today were 13,000 hogs, as heavy a movement as there has been on a Thursday since February, and with a slow demand from packers prices dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 (AP). --Bands and marching groups in attire characteristic of their States led gay delegations around Milwaukee tonight on the eve of formal opening of the two-day second annual convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America.

Action by the Board of Estimate on the bill authorizing a referendum on Mayor La Guardia's city power plant project was set for Monday yesterday after a conference of members 'of the board in the Mayor's office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Instead of the longed-for 12cent-perpound loan to cotton farmers, the government will grant a 9-cent loan, but Will put into effect a plan to assure "an average return of not less than 12 cents per pound" on the 1935 crop, the Agriculture Department, announced today.

The principle of neutrality in international law does not require a neutral State to abstain from the sale of arms and war supplies to belligerents, as provided in the resolution adopted by the Senate, but could be equally satisfied by selling to both belligerents without favor or discrimination, according to an editorial published yesterday by The New York Law Journal.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- A pair of farm boys were outstanding as 594 of the nation's trapshooting stars warmed up today for tomorrow's feature, the grand American handicap, which will wind up the most sensational week of scoring the annual tournament has ever witnessed.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- The United States Senate's passage of the Neutrality Bill yesterday aroused much interest here, but there is some skepticism. The general impression seems to be that such legislation would not change the existing situation very much, for if American interests became vitally involved, as they did in the World War, it is believed Washington would again abandon neutrality.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Rough seas in this vicinity today played havoc with fishing craft and pleasure boats, giving Coast Guardsmen one of the busiest days of the season and leading to the drowning of two persons and the disappearance of a third.

Battling through eleven innings and a rainstorm that plunged most of the afternoon in darkness and interrupted the encounter at one stage for twenty minutes, the Giants and Cubs showered each other with five home runs as they opened their four-game series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The proposed merger and reorganization of the Fox Film Corporation and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin in Brooklyn. The court denied an application for an injunction to restrain consummation of the plan that Fox Film's stockholders approved by vote on Aug. 15.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Six Alaska fliers shuttled back and forth over the rugged country near the Alaska-Yukon boundary line today in search of an airplane and four persons, missing three days.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The National Socialist party's central publishing house, of which Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler himself is one of the principal partners, displayed its opinion of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's protest against Jew-baiting by sending through Berlin tonight a parade of motor trucks filled with Storm Troopers shouting in unison, "Destruction to the Jews! Germany awake!"

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22. -Black clouds that hung low over Hitchcock Field of the Meadow Brook Club today finally made good their threat and, with a flood of rain, stopped an open championship test match mid-way in the fourth period.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22. -- With an ominous clatter, the Yankee baseball machine cracked up at Sportsman's Park today when it had a chance to pick up ground on the Tigers at the expense of the Browns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A survey of certain industries, principally distributing industries, to obtain data on the effect of the invalidation of codes by the Supreme Court was announced today by the National Industrial Recovery Administration.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Aug. 22. -- With President Roosevelt still strong in the West, representative Republicans, both descendants of the pioneer settlers and youths reared in the automobile period, are gathering here tonight for a two-day regional conference to assess the record of the national administration and to offer a declaration of principles to redeem their own party.
The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents on its stock. This is the first dividend since September, 1933, when 37 1/2 cents was distributed.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 22. -Miss Betty Pietsch gained her second successive one-day tournament victory today when she went around the long Fairfield Country Club course with a gross score of 85. Mrs. Edward P. Stevens and Miss Alice Warner of Greenwich were close to the young Lawrence Farms player, with 86 and 87, respectively.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- One of the large social affairs of the season was the dinner dance tonight by the Turf Writers Association at Riley's Saratoga Lake House. Guests received souvenirs which paid tribute to important racing stable owners.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Touring American track and field athletes won ten of twelve events today in their first meet against picked French athletes. The members of the invading team appeared tired from the strain of their eighth engagement in eighteen days, but they outclassed their rivals in all except the 500 and 1,500 meter runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- President Roosevelt, yielding to tremendous pressure for neutrality legislation at this Congressional session, consented today to a temporary plan whereby arms shipments to all warring nations would be mandatorily barred until Feb. 29, 1936.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- After eighty days of almost unprecedented drought in New England, a torrential downpour swept suddenly across Central New England this evening, resulting in cloudburst conditions. A rainfall of nearly one and a half inches was recorded in Boston, with two inches at Fitchburg.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -President Roosevelt appointed a board to arbitrate the Camden shipbuilding strike, received by "pony express" additions from Western Governors to his stamp collection, consolidated relief activities in the Virgin Islands, and addressed by telephone a meeting of towns people at St. Genevieve, Mo.

United States Government loans were subjected to renewed selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. In the domestic corporation section a spirited upswing in local traction securities carried several bonds in that group to new high marks for the year.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The season's fastest program on a half-mile track was recorded at the Orange County Fair races today. Countess Zabetta, owned by H.M. Clark of Springfield, Mass., annexed the final two heats of the 3-year-old trot with a round in 2:06 3/4, best of the season.

Two hundred and fifteen boys of Italian-American parentage, with their director, the Rev. Joseph M. Congedo, pastor of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 315 East Thirty-third Street, returned yesterday from a four weeks' tour of Italy as members of the second annual Italian Honor Student Movement.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Peter Paul, a gray gelding by Peter Henley, staged a gallant uphill struggle today to win the 2:18 pace, a four-heat race, before 25,000 Illinois State Fair visitors.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- In a statement that apparently disavowed the plan of placing men for training in industrial plants while paying them WPA wages, William H.J. Ely, Works Progress Administrator for New Jersey, declared that job training was possible under the WPA, but that there was "no such project in New Jersey."

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, "discharged" yesterday fifty-nine play school teachers provided for the Board of Education by the Works Progress Administration. He charged that they had abandoned their classes to join in the stoppage demonstration on Wednesday.

Federal Judge Patterson heard argument yesterday on the report of R.P. Stephensen, special master, rejecting the reorganization plan for the McCrory Stores Corporation submitted by a committee of preferred stockholders.

Neil O'Connell, 41 years old, of 594 East 135th Street, the Bronx, one of five men who are alleged to have been operating a milk racket with a yearly "take" of from $600,000 to $1,200,000, surrendered yesterday to Assistant Attorney General Bernard Bienstock in the offices of the Attorney General's Anti-Racket Bureau.

A stockholders' suit to force Howard C. Hopson, vice president and treasurer of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, and John I. Mange, its president, to reimburse the company for more than $1,000,000 allegedly spent for lobbying against the Wheeler-Rayburn Utilities Bill in Washington, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP). -Newark reached two Senator pitchers for thirteen hits and took advantage of five errors to score a 9-2 victory over Albany in the first game of their series tonight. Kempy Wicker, Newark hurler, allowed only five hits.

AUBURN, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP). -Earl (Bud) Kimball boasted in his jail cell here tonight that he had killed twenty-five men, and officers who a short time before had recovered the body of one of his alleged victims said they were planning an extensive investigation.

After having issued $108,000,000 of securities in the last year in its program of refunding its debt at reduced interest rates, the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington registration statements covering two issues totaling $57,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, said tonight that he was "proud" of the record made by Congress and asserted "prosperity" was returning despite criticism of the New Deal.

Filing of petitions for candidates seeking the Democratic and Republican nominations for election to the New Jersey State Legislature this Fall indicated yesterday, as the deadline for petitions expired, how much opposition to Governor Hoffman's State sales tax had grown since the measure was passed by the last Legislature, and showed that the tax would be the chief issue of the primary elections Sept. 17 in many places.

In SAM WARD'S day, and earlier, champagne was the solvent in which irritations were melted. Obstinate opinions were softened, gayety took the place of severity and suspicion. Even international jeolousies were subdued, so that a treaty between Great Britain and the United States could "be floated through on champagne."

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- A spokesman for Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, said today that the case of Dutch Schultz is receiving "careful consideration." A conference of tax officials is to be held in about two weeks to take up the State's plan of action in the alleged tax evasions by Schultz.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The much-discussed emergency meeting of the British Cabinet on the Ethiopian question was held today. The Cabinet sat for five hours, three in the morning and two in the afternoon, with all its twenty-two members present, and its deliberations after mountainous preparation produced a tiny mouse indeed.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- With the exception of one match in mixed doubles and one in the father-and-son event, play in the national doubles tournament was rained out today at the Longwood Cricket Club. As a consequence, the finals scheduled for Saturday will go over until Monday, it was announced by Referee Henry Guild.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York was invited today to address the World Zionist Congress on Jewry's position throughout the world after he had demanded a full discussion of the situation in Germany.

An advance of 0.1 point in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 127.2 on Tuesday reflected moderate gains in the week in the grains and flour, coffee, oranges and lemons, textiles and nonferrous metals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Charles Hayden, senior partner of Hayden, Stone Co., headed a protective committee for second mortgage bond holders in the Eastern Cuban Cane Sugar Corporation, while his partner, Lester Watson of Boston, headed a committee for the first mortgage bond holders, the Securities Exchange Commission's investigation of protective committees and reorganizations brought out today.

The plan conceived by some officials of the New Jersey PWA, who wrote to certain large firms to ask whether they could take on relief workers for "training," while these workers would be kept on the PWA payrolls, was doubtless well-intentioned, but hardly seems well-considered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Despite the protest of leather and cattle interests, bids have been ordered on 187,500 pairs of shoes with composition soles and heels for the Civilian Conservation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -Amid Republican shouts that it was a "Ten Billion Dollar Congress!" the administration's third and last major deficiency bill for this session -- a $92,000,000 measure -today was passed by the House and sent to the Senate.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. F. Taylor Evans, who has arrived at the Irving for a fortnight's stay, gave a reception there today for her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. George Trotter Van Antwerp of Salem, Mass., who are visiting Mrs. Theodore V.A. Trotter and Miss Helen Trotter at Woodhull House, their home in First Neck Lane.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Direct action to end the strike which has paralyzed the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., since May 12, was taken by President Roosevelt today. He issued an executive order establishing a special arbitration board to handle this dispute, involving 4,500 striking workers and $50,000,000 worth of naval construction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 21, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,477,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000, compared with the preceding week, and of $13,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WARSAW, Aug. 22. -- Eight rounds of the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation were completed today in the first session at the Army Officers' Casino, with the exception of one game between Finland and Lithuania.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Top-bracketed winners of today's quarter-final matches in the men's singles division of the national public parks tennis tournament were stretched to the limit to advance to the semi-finals, while the lower bracket pair won easy contests.

The forecast that while President Roosevelt will be re-elected in 1936, the third party movement will grow and will be a vital factor in American politics in the next few years was made yesterday by speakers at a luncheon of the Commonwealth Federation at the Hotel Woodstock, on West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that "less than fifty" of the 14,257 banks composing its membership would have to slash interest rates on "time deposits" under the new banking act.

Apartment deals in the Bronx proved a feature of real estate trading yesterday, properties on Townsend and Leggett Avenues passed to new owners, in one case to operators and in the other to an investor. In Manhattan, a West Side building was purchased by a group which will modernize it, and which plans other purchases for a similar purpose.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Pressed forward by an expression of reluctant approval from President Roosevelt himself, the Barkley "compromise" on the "death sentence" provision of the Utility Holding Company Control Bill was jammed through the House today as many former opponents ran to cover on orders of the Democratic high command and switched positions they had first taken.

The building bureaus in several boroughs were busy yesterday receiving plans for new buildings and alterations of importance. Three large apartment houses were projected, at an aggregate estimated cost of $600,000, and a number of smaller jobs were filed.

A new issue of $4,500,000 of first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds, Series F, due on Sept. 1, 1955, of the Savannah Electric and Power Company, will be offered publicly today by a banking group headed by Stone Webster and Blodgett, Inc., at 100 and accrued interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22. -- Artificial radium, until now a laboratory curiosity, is near the stake of being produced commercially out of common table salt, phosphorus and other cheap and abundant substances for possible use in medicine and other fields of science as a substitute for the extremely costly natural radium.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -With wind-blown burgees and pennants the New York Yacht Club fleet went out today for the King's Cup race, banner event in American yachting. In the trek back from sea H.S. Vanderbilt's sloop Prestige stood out the winner, her tall owner-captain on deck, tired but happy after capturing the King's prize for the fourth time.

All important foreign exchanges declined in terms of the dollar yesterday, the losses in the gold-bloc currencies being particularly marked. French francs dropped 1 3/8 points to 6.62 1/8 cents, guilders 10 points to 67.72 cents, Swiss francs 4 1/2 points to 32.69 cents, Italian lire 3 1/2 points to 8.18 cents, the lowest since July 29, and Belgian belgas 3 points to 16.88 cents, the cheapest since July 23.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Misled and Distract, both bearing the yellow and purple of the Wheatley Stable, finished a neck apart in the Consolation Claiming Stakes, feature today, before a large crowd. William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, and his son, William Woodward Jr., were among those in attendance.
Many vacationists at this time of the year are mystified by the sudden transformation in the appearance of lakes and ponds, whose waters take on a decidedly greenish tinge.
BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- The hit-and-run man has found the sea, the last remaining stronghold of traditional honor.
Prices of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in fairly active trading. In the cash markets, cocoa, lead, cotton and rubber were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, tin and silk were lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- For the eighth time this year a date selected by responsible leaders as certain to mark the adjournment of Congress has vanished into the calendar. The last one was Tuesday, Aug. 20. Previous prophecies began with May 15, and confidently uttering each one was the Speaker, the Senate majority leader or some slightly lesser light.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie, faced with severe difficulty in holding his warriors in check, has threatened with death any Ethiopian who menaces or assaults an Italian, it was learned tonight.
New York turned out in force yesterday at memorial services for Will Rogers and Wiley Post while they were being buried in California and Oklahoma.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Aug. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nichols, who are spending the Summer at Devon, had dinner guests last night at Gurney's Inn, Montauk.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The House today completed legislative action on the joint resolution authorizing New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to establish a tri-State sanitation pact to eliminate pollution of metropolitan waters. The measure was sent to the President for approval.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Reeling off a 67 for a new course record, Bill Goldbeck, 32-year-old professional at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club, Mount Kisco, gained command of the Westchester open golf championship at the half-way post today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22. -- Recovery of gold from solutions where it is present in as small amounts as one part in 4,000,000,000 was reported here today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society by Professor William R. Caldwell of Oregon State College.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $3,032,277 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly report of the bank showed today. In the same time deposits by chartered banks declined $6,728,922.

An Italy whose citizens are 100 per cent behind Mussolini in the present Ethiopian crisis and which has made tremendous industrial strides during the past few years was pictured yesterday by Lawrence Armour, director of Armour Co. and president of the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, in an interview at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

A new issue of $3,250,000 refunding 3 3/4 per cent bonds of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which includes the city of Cleveland, will be awarded to the highest bidder on Sept. 10. The bonds are dated Oct. 1, 1935, and are payable on April 1 and Oct. 1, 1941 to 1950.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade developed a reactionary tendency today as traders suddenly realized that the Jones bill calling for further regulation of commodity exchanges probably would be acted upon by Congress today or tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The companion measure to the revised Railroad Retirement Act, imposing excise and income taxes of 3 1/2 per cent on railroad managements and workers, respectively, for financing the cost of pension annuities, was brought up in the House today under a "gag" procedure and passed in five minutes without a record vote.

A new "share the profits" plan to go into effect shortly, whereby customers and employes of the Hearn Department Store "will be taken into partnership," was announced yesterday by Maurice Levin, president of the store. The plan features the return of 10 per cent of all added business above its sales budget in the form of cash dividends.

The razing of a 150-foot chimney, the last remnant of an abandoned glue factory on the land side of Floyd Bennett Field, will be urged upon the Board of Estimate Monday, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. Removal of the chimney, which must be preceded by the taking of title to the property by the city, will do away with the last physical obstacle in the way of making the city airport an airmail base.

The policy of the government with regard to the projected war on Ethiopia seems to be in danger of confusion. If our attitude toward the belligerents is neutral, it seems inconsistent to deny our citizens the opportunity to carry on such commerce with the belligerents as their necessities in time of war may afford.

ROME, Aug. 2. -- Reports from London of demands for sanctions against Italy caused deep apprehension here, especially because of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's consultations yesterday with leaders of the Opposition and with the dominions' commisioners.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $3,032,277 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly report of the bank showed today. In the same time deposits by chartered banks declined $6,728,922.

An Italy whose citizens are 100 per cent behind Mussolini in the present Ethiopian crisis and which has made tremendous industrial strides during the past few years was pictured yesterday by Lawrence Armour, director of Armour Co. and president of the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, in an interview at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

A new issue of $3,250,000 refunding 3 3/4 per cent bonds of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, which includes the city of Cleveland, will be awarded to the highest bidder on Sept. 10. The bonds are dated Oct. 1, 1935, and are payable on April 1 and Oct. 1, 1941 to 1950.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade developed a reactionary tendency today as traders suddenly realized that the Jones bill calling for further regulation of commodity exchanges probably would be acted upon by Congress today or tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The companion measure to the revised Railroad Retirement Act, imposing excise and income taxes of 3 1/2 per cent on railroad managements and workers, respectively, for financing the cost of pension annuities, was brought up in the House today under a "gag" procedure and passed in five minutes without a record vote.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The defense committee of the British Cabinet ordered the imperial defense machine today to swing into position to maintain the empire's dominance of the Mediterranean, protect its colonies in Africa and keep open its lines of communication.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- An explanation is due to the public when the tameness of the announced decision of the British Cabinet creates an anticlimax to the expected sensation prepared by former Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald's statement that the crisis was the gravest since 1914.

Criticism of the manner in which the State Banking Department has liquidated the Bank of United States was made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Valente when more than 100 depositors of the bank applauded as their spokesman, Samuel Kesselman, voiced his views.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- The strained domestic and international situations, together with the market preparations for a big new Reich loan, caused considerable weakness on the Boerse today. Losses ranged between one to two points, and in some instances more, although a slight recovery marked the closing of the market.

The British polo invasion of Long Island will begin this afternoon with the arrival at Westbury of Captain H.C. Walford, spare of the invading Hurlingham squad. Captain Walford, supported with six ponies, will take part in a special match against Old Westbury at the Meadow Brook Club tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative-at-Large from New York, won her first major legislative victory tonight when the House adopted her resolution for a stay of execution of deportation sentences against deserving aliens pending further Congressional consideration.

In his interview yesterday with The United Press correspondent, MUSSOLINI refused to bow his haughty head or tame his heart of fire. He is resolved to go ahead with his Ethiopian plans, with Geneva, without Geneva, or against Geneva. Still one sees a certain precaution in his latest utterances.

Mrs. Bertrand Coles Neidecker, wife of the banker who is wanted in France on charges growing out of the failure of his ventures there, refused yesterday to tell Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn what had become of $101,914.03 that her husband gave to her.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- The issue over the censoring of the speech that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, delivered in Koenigsberg Sunday, in which he denounced the disturbance of German business by National Socialist extremists, economic dilettantes and saboteurs generally, developed today into a thinly disguised conflict between Dr. Schacht and Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, involving the whole question of freedom of speech in Germany.
