WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Manifest satisfaction with the work of Congress as it neared the close of its session was indicated today by President Roosevelt at his press conference, which consisted, however, of little more than a brief exchange of pleasantries.

HENRY MORTON ROBINSON'S "Science Versus Crime" (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.50) drives home the fact that there is very little future in a criminal career. Persons who have been playing around for years with a plan for a perfect crime -- studying detective stories and gangster movies and chatting about poisons with medical friends -- had better forget all about it.

Last September the Dodgers proved to Bill Terry's satisfaction that they were still in the National League. Yesterday, when the Giant pilot was hoping they would demonstrate the same thing to the Cardinals, Casey Stengel's strange athletes double-crossed him.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Spurred by the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters, Congress forwarded to the White House today a bill for financial protection of survivors of sea tragedies.
LONDON, Aug. 23. -- What was described as an informal meeting of some members of the Cabinet who had remained in London after yesterday's emergency session was held today at 10 Downing Street.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Aug. 23. -- In blunt Western style, Senator Robert D. Carey opened the conference of Young Republicans here today with an attack on President Roosevelt, denouncing him as a dictator who ignored the Constitution. He also warned Postmaster General Farley to abandon the fight to defeat Senator Borah for re-election lest he force the Idaho Senator to become the Republican nominee for President.

The Swedish Augustana Home for the Aged in Brooklyn buzzed with gossip yesterday as the forty inmates whispered the latest news of the romance of Julius Rooth and Mrs. Sophie Nyman that had seeped through the institution despite efforts at censorship.
" Kaiserwalzer," a German photoplay, starring Martha Eggerth, opened at the Seventy-ninth Street Theatre yesterday. "Konjunkturritter," with Weiss Ferdl, is on the same program.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 23. -- The air was filled with fighting planes today as the navy staged its greatest sky and sea parade in behalf of Young America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- "If there was plenty of time I wouldn't ask for such a rule," said Chairman McReynolds of the Committee on Foreign Affairs to the House today in seeking precedence for the "compromise" neutrality resolution. It could fairly be added that, if there were plenty of time, if Congress were not bent upon adjournment, the administration could not possibly agree to such a measure.
May I offer my compliments on your editorial "Neutrality or Sanctions"?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- A fight to force a 12-cent cotton loan broke wide open in the Senate shortly after 8 o'clock tonight, when Senator Byrnes of South Carolina threatened to "talk all night" unless the Senate agree to postpone until tomorrow a vote on the third Deficiency Bill and allow him to offer an amendment which would authorize the Commodity Credit Corporation to continue a flat 12-cent loan on 1935 cotton.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that he had approved "in its general terms" the report of the Hotel and Restaurant Minimum Wage Board recommending minimum wages beginning at 18 cents an hour for women and minors in the industry.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The tide of "war" surged across a ten-mile front here today as 36,000 National Guardsmen and regular army troops "fought" -- a few of them literally -- the greatest peacetime battle in American history.

Times Square's spectroscope this week has shown heavy lines of khaki, red and flesh tint. It is the Boy Scout color scheme. Khaki is the tunic and shorts, red is the neckerchief, and flesh is the faces and knees of thousands of cheerful young lads.

Early adjournment of Congress will complete a continuous session of nearly eight months. The unusual circumstances whereby Congress, despite its previous expectation, was kept at work through a season of extremely trying weather, and the angry feelings aroused by this unlooked-for upsetting of its own original plan, have created an impression that this session has been exceptionally prolonged.

Gilbert and Sullivan would have liked a couple of seats -- if they could have located that many -- on the crowded roof of the Educational Alliance at East Broadway and Jefferson Street yesterday afternoon for the lower East Side's version of their famous opus "The Mikado."

Department of Finance inspectors yesterday rejected 5,180 quarts of milk delivered to Bellevue and Willard Parker Hospitals when they found that the cans containing the milk were rusty in some cases and unsealed in others. The milk came from the Vernondale Farms Dairy Company of 118 Eleventh Avenue, which has a contract to deliver milk to city hospitals for the month of August.

A challenge for an international team race between three American six-meter sloops and three Scandinavian boats, representing Sweden, Norway and Denmark, was received yesterday by Philip J. Roosevelt, secretary of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. The challenge was accepted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Complete accord between Senate and House conferees on a Public Utility Holding Company Bill which he said retained the "death sentence" for all such units more than twice removed from the operating electric concern was announced tonight by Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

Five alleged Communists were arrested last night during a demonstration in the vicinity of Eastern Parkway and Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, where a crowd of about 1,000 had gathered in defiance of orders of the Park Department and the police.

Frederic Francis, an accountant, committed suicide last night by inhaling gas in the kitchen of his apartment in the Southgate Apartments at 400 East Fifty-second Street, in the fashionable Beekman Hill residential district along the East River shore.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- A marked gain in total contributions and a decrease in the communicant membership of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America was reported today by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, stated clerk of the General Assembly.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 23. -- George H. Earle, Governor of Pennsylvania, hailed as the first Young Democrat elected Chief Executive of any State, speaking in the place of President Roosevelt at the Young Democratic convention tonight, called for amendment of the Federal Constitution to meet the needs of the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Responding to a plea from President Roosevelt on the eve of adjournment, Senate and House conferees agreed late tonight on a compromise Liquor Control Bill. The solution was a typical give-and-take measure in which both chambers could claim victories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Wilbur J. Cart, Assistant Secretary of State, by Presidential order today was continued in office for not to exceed five years from Oct. 31, when he would have reached the retirement age.

WARSAW, Aug. 23. -- Only one of the four games between the United States and Yugoslavia was finished and the three others were adjourned today in the tenth round of the international team chess tournament. Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., drew at the third board with Boris Kostisch, erstwhile Serbian champion.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Harland (Hook) Beardslee, defending champion, won the first race of the international star class sailing series today by taking advantage of his knowledge of deceptive tidal conditions.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Newark scored three unearned runs in the ninth inning to break a 5-5 tie and win its second straight International League game from Albany, 8 to 5, tonight.
In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Jay B. Kuhe criticizes Representative Rankin's statement that consumers of electric energy in this country are being overcharged $1,000,000,000 a year.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Brownie Hanover, a 2-year-old colt by Traux, today proved himself a worthy son of the famous trotter, Hanover's Bertha, by conquering five other smart youngsters in the feature event of the Illinois State Fair's closing Grand Circuit program.

As a result of improved passenger traffic the United Air Lines Transport Corporation reported yesterday for the second quarter of this year a profit of $107,326 before Federal taxes, in contrast with a deficit of $426,933 in the preceding quarter.

BOLTON LANDING, Aug. 23. -- Jack Creavy of Albany, State junior golf champion, entered the semi-finals of the fifth Sagamore invitation golf tournament today by handily winning both his first and second round matches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Neutrality legislation mandatorily barring shipments of arms or munitions to any nation at war until Feb. 29 became almost a fact when the Pittman resolution swept through the House without a roll-call today, and the Senate agreed tonight to vote upon the resolution tomorrow before 11 A.M. (Eastern standard time).

Miss Helen Bernhard of the University Heights Tennis Club advanced to the final round in the girls' Eastern invitation grass court tennis tournament at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, yesterday.

General Conditions. Trading in some cuts showed improvement with the advent of cooler weather. Steer hinds and ribs were moving slowly, however, and some offerings were lower. Veal and lamb were little changed, both as to demand and prices. Fresh pork cuts were slightly more active at sharply lower prices. Early trading in kosher meats tndlcated beef and lamb to be slightly stronger and veal mostly unchanged.

The National Labor Relations Act will be the subject of the first report of the newly formed "Lawyers Vigilance Committee" named to scan the legal aspects of New Deal legislation, Raoul E. Desvernine, chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Denying income deductions for bonuses paid, the Internal Revenue Bureau brought claim today against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for income taxes on $5,657,748 paid in bonuses and alleged excessive salaries in 1929 and 1930.

E. Phillips Oppenheim's third book to appear this year will be published by Little, Brown early next month. Its title is "The Battle of Basinghall Street," and it is about a secret war declared against a group of unscrupulous industrialists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Loans and grants totaling $28,022,382 for fifty-six non-Federal projects, among them some in New York and New Jersey, were announced today by the Public Works Administration.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Yorkshire today was declared winner of the English county cricket championship although the season has a couple of weeks to run. Since the competition was inaugurated in 1873 Yorkshire has gained the honor eighteen times.

Two bandits held up a payroll clerk yesterday afternoon in the crowded Lackawanna Railroad Station at Hoboken, N.J., walked their victim through the main waiting room by city and railroad police and detectives and, after tying him in a washroom, escaped with $700.

A ball club imbued with the singular notion that it can beat the Giants even if it never does succeed in winning the National League pennant once more performed its specialty at the Polo Grounds yesterday and again performed it remarkably well.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23. -- Argentina has failed in another attempt to gag the press. She succeeded for several weeks in surrounding the Chaco peace conference with complete secrecy, but South American foreign offices refuse to be bound by the gag that Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister, put on the peace delegations.

Three weeks ago there was a good deal of eyebrow-lifting and "you don't say so"-ing up in Westchester, the bailiwick of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, when word got around that some one had caught lake trout in Rye Lake.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- A Federal investigation of the spread between prices farmers get and those housewives pay hinged tonight on an almost certain Presidential pen stroke.

Bond financing dropped substantially this week, only $16,306,000 in new issues reaching the investment market, the smallest amount since the week ended on May 17, when $10,139,000 was offered. The total compares with $102,884,000 last week and with $16,469,000 in the corresponding period of last year.

Plans for a new hall of biology at the American Museum of Natural History, in which mechanized animals and living organisms will be employed to illustrate the principles of animal life, were revealed last night by Dr. G. Kingsley Noble, curator of the museum's department of experimental biology.

United States Government bonds had yesterday their widest decline of the year on the New York Stock Exchange in the heaviest turnover since June 20. Net losses ranged from 2-32 to 31-32 point. Of the twenty-one issues traded in fifteen declined 1/2 point or more, three broke below par, and two established new low records since their issuance.

The swift progress toward enactment by Congress of the Utility Holding Company Control Bill placed utility leaders here in a state of apprehensive surprise. The development in Washington had been unexpected in the industry, leaders having expressed the conviction last week that Congress would adjourn without further action on the measure.

No news of the theatre yet. Last evening the show business wriggled a little at the Fulton, and half-heartedly committed itself to a revue ineptly entitled "Smile at Me." Edward J. Lambert wrote the sketches and lyrics. Edward J. Lambert and Gerald Dolin wrote the music.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Despite early-morning threats of bad weather, the sun shone today on the largest and most colorful baby parade ever presented here.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- British and American delegates to the eleventh International Penal Congress clashed today with supporters of the German viewpoint with regard to humanization and educational facilities in penal systems.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Club celebrated another year as golf professional in this area by winning the Westchester open championship today for the third time.
John N. Willys, pioneer in automobile manufacturing and former Ambassador to Poland, is in a critical condition at his home, 4,643 Waldo Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, it became known yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23. -- Postmaster General Farley, in an address here today to the California Women's Democratic Study Class, discounted the "dust storms" being raised by foes of the New Deal, advocated wider analysis of the Democratic party's program by women and predicted "another great endorsement" of the Roosevelt administration in 1936.

The rapid installation of air conditioning and refrigerating equipment throughout the country is creating not only "enormous expense" to municipal water works but a hazard to health and life, in the opinion of A.R. McGonegal, chief plumbing inspector of Washington, D.C.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 23 (AP). -- A close vote was predicted by observers tonight as Texans prepared to ballot tomorrow on a proposal to repeal the sixteen-year-old State Prohibition Law. Both wets and drys claimed victory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- No improvement was reported today in the demand for fresh pork. Fresh loins in Eastern markets were said to be 1/2 to 1 cent a pound lower, with shipments from the West going into cold storage. Prices of hogs continued to decline, losing 10 to 35 cents a hundredweight.

The Government's new cotton policy seems to be a half-hearted attempt to extricate itself partially from a serious dilemma. In addition to the plow-up campaign and the acreage restriction which it put into effect in 1933, the Government made loans to the cotton producers at 10 cents a pound on the unsold portion of their crops.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Word was received here today by Mayor Charles Gold that this city's request for a Federal PWA allotment of $1,730,500 for the erection of a new boardwalk and jetty system had been granted by PWA authorities.

What do the County Clerks of the five counties comprising the city do? I have practiced law for over twenty years and I have been unable to learn what services these men perform. I remember once insisting on seeing the County Clerk of New York County to compel a clerk to accept a paper for filing.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- It was officially announced today that Rickard-Walther Darre, Reich Food and Agricultural Minister, had assumed the functions of Price Commissar for products falling under his jurisdiction and had issued orders to prevent any general increases in the prices of food.

The AAA policies of the Roosevelt administration are restoring prosperity to the farmer and thus relieving the national economic emergency, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, asserts in an article in Editor and Publisher, it was announced yesterday.

MATTITUCK, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- For the second time in sixty-eight years the lineal descendants of John Tuthill of Tharston, Norfolk County, England, held a reunion at the Maratooka Clubhouse, on the shore of Peconic Bay, here today to honor his memory. Today's event, which was in commemoration of the 300th anniversary of his birth, was attended by nearly 1,000 of his descendants from more than a dozen States, including California and Michigan.

Republican State Committeeman Joshua H. Ringle of Jersey City was freed yesterday under $1,500 bail after he had been twice fingerprinted and shackled to court officers following his surrender on a charge of conspiracy in a registration fraud plot. He gave himself up at Kearny police headquarters yesterday after police had sought him for two days following a confession by George Scharmer of Jersey City.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., today won the Smithtown Hunt Cup, the trophy event of the first day of the sixth annual North Shore horse show, which opened this afternoon on the grounds of the Old Field Club.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, Aug. 24. -- Driving steadily and surely toward adjournment, now expected today, Congress yesterday sent three more major measures to the White House for Presidential approval, blasted several others from conference and in general showed itself determined and able to fulfill its agreement with Mr. Roosevelt to deliver a completed program before the final hour.

BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 23. -- In a simulation of grim reality, 150,000 Italian fighting men moved into this area tonight to test the Italian military theory of battle by movement as opposed to trench warfare.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 23. -- In what is known as the undertakers' corner of the clubhouse porch there were some trainers sitting and talking and looking out over the track. Tom Healey was wearing a dark suit and a Panama hat. George Odom was wearing a light suit and an air of deep gloom.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Congress sped to the White House today the Frazier-Lemke Three-Year Farm Mortgage Moratorium Bill.

The Securities and Exchange Commission blasted yesterday any hope, entertained by many corporate executives, that confidential reports attached to registration statement would be regarded as such in Washington. In making public lists of salaries of officers and directors of corporations, the commission thus denied the requests of many companies that these data be not given out for publication.

A plan to speed up the rate at which employable persons on home relief are put into jobs under the Works Progress Administration was completed yesterday evening. The program calls for court action against those who decline jobs where the welfare of dependent families is involved.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 23. -- The Senate group that demands that this country abstain from entanglements with any foreign nation will make a drive tomorrow to insure that no Senator visiting foreign countries is empowered to speak for the Senate.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The alarm of the churches over the Ethiopian crisis is reflected in a telegram that the executive committee of the Universal Christian Council has sent to Pope Pius, the League of Nations and the heads of the governments of Britain, France, Italy, Ethiopia and the United States.

FAIRPORT, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, brought his party's "win-the-Assembly" campaign into Monroe County, a key area, with a declaration here tonight that "the decent, thinking people of the State, those with a stake in America, are thoroughly disgusted with Roosevelt promises and political gyrations."

While the prolonged heat wave in many parts of the country interfered with the distribution of early Fall goods during the week, further improvement in the wholesale markets was accompanied by impressive industrial expansion and a stronger flow of cash into the agricultural districts, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A committee of three representatives was appointed yesterday by the Association of Buying Offices to confer with the Coat and Suit Salesmen's Association regarding proposals submitted by the salesmen's group which are aimed at improvements in the salesmen's contacts with buyers at the resident buying offices here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Social Security Board to administer President Roosevelt's program of unemployment insurance and old-age pensions was set up today, with John G. Winant, former Republican Governor of New Hampshire, being chosen by Mr. Roosevelt to serve for six years as chairman.

Unaware that he had suffered a fractured skull in a fall yesterday afternoon from the roof of a four-story building at 539 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, John Cavanaugh, 8 years old, of 537 Bergen Street, insisted that he was not hurt and started to walk to his home.

A historian of modern Greece says that biographical facts are to be had there only so far as the persons themselves are known to their families or neighbors or form part of the history of Greece, there being no "Who's Who" in that little land, so much of whose ancient history is written in the biographies by PLUTARCH.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- Without in any way seeking to minimize the dangers of the situation that has developed over the threat of war between those two League of Nations members, Italy and Ethiopia, French opinion continues to believe as well as hope that finally common sense will prevail.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 23. -- Eighty members of the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, had a clambake party tonight. Among those who entertained guests were Mr. and Mrs. Denison D. Dana of Norfolk, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs. James A. Renwich of Hillsdale, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Except for a routine loan of $93,447,016.23 to the Commodity Credit Corporation for financing the orderly marketing of agricultural commodities and livestock, the principal disbursements of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in July were to banks and trust companies.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- A mild boom in place of the usual Summer slack was reported for Great Britain today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in our foreign markets, which said that business indexes there in July had in many instances reached the levels of 1929, while bank deposits had risen to the highest on record.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The New York State Racing Commission gave out a statement at the race course today which follows in part:

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The tone on the London Stock Exchange was more cheerful today because of the somewhat improved international political situation, although uncertainty regarding the future checked the buying movement. The rally was not maintained, however, prices weakening in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Critics of the New Deal are retarding economic recovery "by subtle indirection, by appealing to irrational prejudices rather than to reason, by quoting slogans while ignoring statistics," Senator Wagner told the Senate today in a prepared speech delivered during a lull in the rush toward adjournment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Discovery will run again tomorrow, according to a decision reached in the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt camp, where it was found that the handicap champion had come back to his Saratoga stable in perfect condition after his defeat Wednesday in the Narragansett Special under 139 pounds.
GENEVA, Aug. 23. -- Information received in high League of Nations quarters of the British Cabinet meeting has made a good impression.

George C. Cutler, who has been a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company since 1930, has resigned from the Guaranty to become president of the Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Baltimore, Md., succeeding Joseph B. Kirby, who died in January.

Between 200 and 300 selected Brooklyn children have been innoculated secretly with the newly-developed anti-poliomyelitis vaccine by the New York City Department of Health in tests to determine the effectiveness of the immunizing agent, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- A complaint charging the Gillette Safety Razor Company with fixing and maintaining prices of safety razors and blades, employing illegal coercive methods to force jobbers and others to observe resale prices, and other violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act was issued today by the commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The hotly disputed Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill finally was voted tonight by an adjournment-minded Congress.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- Sir Percival Phillips in a dispatch from Addis Ababa to The London Daily Telegraph tonight says that the shooting accident in which Baron Philip Muzi Faiconi, Italian Consul at Debra Marcos, was wounded was "unfortunate in more ways than one" for the Italians because they wanted him back at Debra Marcos with the least possible delay.

Flights of oratory by defense lawyers who referred to the Boston Tea Party, the League of Nations, the Italo-Ethiopian situation and world affairs in general marked the first court hearing yesterday on the riot aboard the Hapag-Lloyd liner Bremen a month ago.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol today won her second consecutive women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament when she scored a 91 over the difficult east and centre nines of the Ridgewood Country Club course, where the Ryder Cup competition will be played late next month.

The answer to the burning question in the boxing world, "Are Max Baer's hands in shape?" was officially rendered yesterday. And the response removed the last obstacle to Promoter Mike Jacobs's plans to conduct a fifteen-round battle between the former heavyweight champion of the world and Joe Louis, the Detroit Negro, at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 24.

Sidney Goldwin, 27 years old, a sales manager, of 255 West Ninety-fifth Street, established a record in the annals of Traffic Court yesterday when he pleaded guilty to twenty-four traffic violations and paid a fine of $120.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Defending champions fell by the wayside today in two divisions of the thirteenth annual national municipal parks tennis tourney as finalists were determined in all except the women's doubles.

TOKYO, Aug. 23. -- The expectation that the assassination of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau, by shocking the conscience of the army would cause the army itself to take steps to get soldiers out of politics was confirmed by an agreement reported to have been reached at a meeting of the Supreme Military Council today.

CALGARY, Alta., Aug. 23. -- A benevolent government that promises "credit dividends" of at least $25 a month to all adult citizens of Alberta Province emerged tonight from an avalanche of votes in legislative elections.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23. -- Two teams that may figure in the deliberations of Davis Cup councils gained the semi-final round of the national men's tennis doubles championship today as the last of the foreign pairs was eliminated at the Longwood Cricket Club.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- The State Tax Department has no intention of abandoning its attempt to collect income taxes from Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, said today. Mr. Graves made this statement:

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Phillip Rofer Jr., 3-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Rofer of Frederick Avenue, Babylon, was killed instantly about 4:20 o'clock this afternoon when the car his mother was driving was struck by an eastbound special train at the East Neck Road crossing of the Long Island Railroad in West Babylon.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23. -- Benjamin H. Dwight, chairman of the committee in charge of the East-West tennis matches, announced tonight that in spite of the problems raised by the postponement in the national doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club, the intersectional fixture will start as scheduled tomorrow at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, South Orange, N.J.

The failure of leading steel companies to file prices for the fourth quarter of the year with the American Iron and Steel Institute in the last few days has led the steel trade to believe that the open-price system established by the Steel Code has been discarded definitely.

A broken romance between a young Queens doctor and a nurse to whom he had been engaged for five years, reached a climax last night with the arrest of the doctor on a charge of felonious assault for striking the nurse in an argument in his office last Tuesday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23. -- Four great double - headed Czarist eagles which for more than seventeen years have mounted guard on top of the Kremlin towers over the Soviet Government were ordered removed today.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty in a decision handed down yesterday imposed a surcharge of $168,000 on the Brooklyn Trust Company and Charles H. George, executors of the will of Claude C. Pinney, with interest at 4 per cent from Jan. 19, 1930, for failure to sell Mr. Pinney's New York Stock Exchange membership as of that date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Omnibus Banking Bill, marking a new program of credit control by the government and involving a revision by the Federal Reserve Board, became law today when President Roosevelt signed it in the presence of Congressional leaders and a group representing the Treasury and the Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- An investigation of bank deposits to determine whether wealth concentrates in the hands of rich persons during depressions is being tentatively mapped out by the Federal Reserve Board staff, it was learned today.

Edward J. Atwell, former Sheriff of Richmond County and a member of the Board of Aldermen for three successive terms, was found dead about 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning in a bedroom of his home at 12 Vreeland Place, Port Richmond, S.I. He had been shot through the heart and the police, after a lengthy investigation, listed his death as a suicide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- "Confidential" information filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by eleven corporations was made public today as the commission for the first time forced the release of data which companies wished kept secret.

Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals refused yesterday in Brooklyn to grant a temporary injunction against teamsters' and longshoremen's unions restraining them, pending action by the full court on an application for a permanent injunction, from interfering with or refusing to handle goods hauled in by non-union trucks.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 23. -- Denny Shute, quiet, unassuming professional from the Westward Ho Country Club of Chicago, cracked par for the second consecutive round to take the lead in the Hershey open golf tournament at the half-way mark tonight.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- In a breeze and huge sea roll over which mainsails had to be eased at times on the wind, H.S. Vanderbilt sailed his sloop Prestige home victor today in the first race of the Narragansett Bay Regatta Association counting toward the William H. Vanderbilt Cup.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 23. -- The ammunition factory built some years ago by Emperor Haile Selassie, who was then Ras Tafari, is hurriedly being repaired after having long been in disuse. The greatest secrecy is' being observed and the guards have been ordered to shoot any one trying to enter the compound.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday a refunding plan under which all its outstanding 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds, aggregating $36,383,300, will be redeemed, and a new issue of first-mortgage and first-lien 4 per cent bonds aggregating $25,000,000 will be sold privately to a group of five insurance companies.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Pirates took the first game of the current series with the Braves today by a 7 -- 5 score, collecting fourteen hits off Ben Cantwell and Al Blanche, rookie righthander.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- A lawyer, Joseph Warren Madden of Pittsburgh, was selected today by President Roosevelt as the first chairman of the new National Labor Relations Board. His term will be for five years.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe, driven from the box on Tuesday, came back in rare form today and shut out the Red Sox, 6 to 0. He allowed Boston but four hits, and accounted for half of Detroit's run total by getting a double in the second inning with two men on the bases and smashing a home run in the fifth.

As an outgrowth of disturbances both on and off the field during a series between the Giants and Reds at Cincinnati a month ago, Ford C. Frick, president of the National League, yesterday made known that he has warned all umpires against haranguing or otherwise attempting to control the actions of baseball spectators.

The centenary of the sailing for China of Henrietta Shuck, the first Protestant woman missionary ever sent to the Chinese by any religious organization, will be celebrated at Crozer Baptist Theological Seminary, Chester, Pa., Sept. 22. Mrs. Shuck and her husband were Baptists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade declined early today in sympathy with a sharp break in cotton and lower Liverpool cables, but commission house buying appeared in volume at around 90 cents for December wheat, and heavy operations developed later on the bull side, which the trade attributed to a leading New York operator.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23. -- The Italo-Ethiopian Arbitral Commission, sitting secretly here today, heard three Italian military officers, two of whom were responsible eyewitnesses of the Ualual clash. They were M. Aruizo Rava, then Governor of Italian Somaliland; Captain Roberto Cimmaruta, commanding the Italian troops at Ualual at the time of the incident, and Mr. Porru-Lucci, an aviator who flew over the Ethiopian - British boundary commission's camp just before the incident.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., of New York filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement for a $50,000,000 issue of 3 1/2 per cent fifteen-year debentures.

TOKYO, Aug. 23. -- Japanese authorities, alert for espionage, detained an American freighter tonight and sought two American youths said by the police to have taken photographs of a fortified zone from the ship.

New State and municipal bond issues scheduled for award next week amount to $24,793,064, compared with a revised total of $19,892,258 this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $24,237,905.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 23. -- The North Shore Horse Show, one of the leading social events on the North Shore, opened for a three-day session this afternoon on the Old Field Clubhouse grounds.

Among many memorable remarks made in the closing debate in the House on the Administration Holding Company Bill was the Speaker's appeal to the members not to be swayed by the "unusual powers of logic of the distinguished gentleman from Alabama," Mr. HUDDLESTON, who opposed the "death sentence" to the end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The question of whether the Federal Trade Commission has constitutional power to take under its jurisdiction undue legislative activities in the several States as being a species of unfair competition was argued today before the commission for the first time in its history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- John McDonald, the Tom Mooney witness who repudiated his testimony, today made affidavit in the office of Representative Caroline O'Day of New York that he was "willing and anxious to go back to California and serve time for the wrong I have done Mooney and Billings."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Charging discrimination and favoritism in connection with army motor truck orders, the House Military Committee today attacked Major Gen. Louis H. Bash, army quartermaster general, because of "jokers" in truck specifications.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended a special showing of motion pictures of the Bird Sanctuary of the Southampton Township Wild Fowl Association, which was held tonight in the auditorium of the Southampton Elementary School for the benefit of the sanctuary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- J.D. Ross, advocate of public ownership of utilities and for twenty years superintendent of the largest municipal power development in the country, was appointed a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission today by President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The White Sox, early season surprise of the American League, were tumbled out of the first division for the first time this season when the Senators won their third straight victory here, 4 to 3, in ten innings. The defeat put Chicago in fifth place.

High temperatures again affected retail trade in the metropolitan area this week, and estimates by retail executives put sales volume for the week at close to 5 per cent under the same period a year ago. For the month thus far department store trade was said to be about holding even with or slightly under the 1934 figure.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

BELGRADE, Aug. 23. -- Three members of the Stoyadinovitch Cabinet -- Nikola Preka, Minister of Welfare; Lyudevit Auey, Minister of Justice, and Ignatz Stefanovitch, Minister of Mines and Forestry -- tendered their resignations today.

Two men and a woman, arrested Thursday by police of the safe and loft squad at Delancey and Clinton Streets after an automobile chase across the Williamsburg Bridge, were accused of being an organized shoplifting gang when questioned in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning.

Ability of the share market to withstand disturbing news -- but news not denying the hopeful outlook for industry and trade in general, on which great store has been set -- was demonstrated plainly yesterday when stocks closed irregularly higher with the average reaching a new high mark for the year.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Barnett Janner, a member of the British House of Commons, told the World Zionist Congress today that "Palestine stands as a complete vindication of the Jewish race."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- At the very moment that the Senate lobby committee late today was seeking to show that a "ship lobby" was trying to defeat President Roosevelt's direct subsidy program, partly by means of a joint resolution continuing indefinitely the existing system of ocean mail contracts, the Senate, at the instance of Senator Copeland, rushed through without a record vote the very resolution which, according to Senator Black, the ship companies wanted.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- In the coming Metropolitan Opera season, which promises an unprecedented shake-up in roles, one of the most important changes is to be the assumption by Kirsten Flagstad of the name part of "Norma." The Norwegian soprano, who will sail for New York next month, is working on the role now.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- Four magistrates were indicted on charges of misconduct in office by a grand jury which brought in its first report this afternoon, nine days after it had been instructed by Judge Harry S. McDevitt to investigate all of the city's twenty-eight members of the minor judiciary.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Worried by failing health, Robert V.H. Work, 37, son of Dr. Hubert Work, former Secretary of the Interior, committed suicide today, officers said, by firing a pistol bullet into his head.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23. -- J.B. Royall of Tallahassee, Fla., 51-year-old railway conductor, attended his first grand American trapshoot today, and when the smoke cleared away he had defeated 614 of the nation's best marksmen to annex trapdom's most prized title, the Grand American Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Senate tonight voted to sidetrack for this session the $500,000,000 Flood Control Bill passed yesterday by the House.

Spokesmen for labor organizations having jurisdiction over excavators, pipe fitters, electrical workers, tile workers, carpenters, drill runners, cement masons and metallic lathers protested yesterday against work classifications contained in the proposed contract for construction of the first of six sections of the new Sixth Avenue subway line.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 23. -- Percy M. Pike, retired California business man, won the two races which featured today's all-claiming card at Narragansett Park. His Paradun took the fourth, a six-furlong dash for 3-year-olds, and his Kowtow the fifth, at the same distance. Neither of his horses was favored strongly by the bettors.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Isaac L. Phillips, president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, showed that when he died on Nov. 22, 1923, he had $1,514,164 gross and $1,353,549 net, of which $1,293,267 was in securities. The estate was reduced by debts of $101,990 and other deductions.

An unusually heavy surf, whipped by a strong northeast wind, pounded the south shore of Long Island and the Jersey coast yesterday, making swimming dangerous and holding fishing boats to their moorings. Few men or women ventured far in the water, and when they did they were knocked down by great combers.

A sudden sharp break in prices of sugar futures yesterday featured an otherwise dull market in commodity futures. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats and flour were higher, while coffee (No. 7 Rio), tin, cotton and silk were lower.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Travelers arriving here today from Kenya, Egypt and Sudan said British and other merchants in those districts, who had sold large quantities of foodstuffs, timber, oil, motor trucks and livestock to the Italian Army, would no longer extend credit to Italy.

PLUCKEMIN, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The annual flower show of this community opened today in the local Presbyterian Church chapel. There were several hundred exhibits. The Sweepstakes Cup was won by Mrs. Roy Bleasdale of this town with fourteen points.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Mrs. E.B. Carpenter's Empty Bottle raced to an easy victory over seven other 2-year-olds in the feature event at Lincoln Fields today, scoring by two lengths over the Dixiana Farm's Erin Torch.

MANILA, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate and chief candidate for President of the Commonwealth, said today that the was not in sympathy with the proposal of Pedro Guevara for a United States protectorate after insular independence.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 23. -- While an arbitration board appointed by President Roosevelt made its first moves today in the direction of industrial peace for the Camden shipyard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, conflicting views were expressed here on the President's plan to end the long strike by Tuesday noon.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- Through three hours and over thirteen innings the Yanks battled the Browns today in the quiet of Sportsman's Park before victory finally perched on the banner of the McCarthymen. The score was 6 to 3.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 23. -- Emperor Haile Selassie, who already has decreed death for any Ethiopian who attacks an Italian, took further precautions today to make certain no Ethiopian act or situation would touch off the powder of an African war. And he offered Italy his province of Aussa, hoping its sale might save his empire from war.

Helen Hayes will make her next Broadway appearance as Queen Victoria in Laurence Housman's nine-scene play "Victoria Regina." Once more under the management of Gilbert Miller, Miss Hayes said yesterday that she expected to open here in the play at about Christmastime.

ROME, Aug. 23. -- After the war scare that ran through Italy yesterday, when there was a general impression that serious complications with Great Britain were about to arise, temperatures returned to more normal levels today.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Monkeys, fugitives from the Frank Buck animal "jungle" near here, caused an automobile accident early this morning when a driver crashed into a tree after swerving to avoid thirty-five or more of the animals which had clustered on the highway.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne announced today that the State was investigating charges of "wholesale" deer killing in the Adirondacks involving eighteen men.

Sons of the Orient joined with Western American boys for the enjoyment of hundreds of cosmopolitan New Yorkers yesterday when Japanese and Chinese Boy Scouts, together with a delegation from Utah, were welcomed at City Hall.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Gloria Hanover, owned by Athur Scheurman of Trenton, N. J., and driven by Adam Carr, won the 2:20 pace, fastest event of the closing races at the Orange County Fair today. He led all the way in the first two heats.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard consrauctions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Reflecting the overnight announcement from Washington that only 9 cents a pound would be advanced to farmers on this year's crop, cotton prices dropped abruptly $3 to $4 a bale yesterday before buying from mill interests throughout the world offset part of losses.
Of the week's three major events, two came off per schedule (almost per advance ballyhoo) and only one, sadly, fell among thorns -- which is, at this time of the year, not a bad record at all.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy ruled yesterday that the Millinery Code Authority did not have to refund either back moneys paid in the form of assessments or the purchase price of NRA labels by members of the Code Authority.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The defeat of David Polland of Brooklyn by Isaac Kashdan, youthful New York internationalist, in the sixth round of the annual championship of the New York State Chess Association at the Hotel Arlington today gave Kashdan the lead.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Two formidable combinations collaborated splendidly today to share premier honors in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the first best-ball invitation tournament for the Arthur Man Trophy at the Seawane Club, where sixty-four teams competed.

FIRST ARMY, HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Tanks smashed through barbed wire fences and rumbled at forty miles an hour today across stubbled fields as the Red Second Corps in a furious offensive folded back the Blue enemy's left flank, nearly punched a hole in the centre, and pushed back the First Corps all along a ten-mile front.

VIENNA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Amid the wave of pro-Italian sentiment that has swept the Austrian press considerable attention was attracted today by an article in the semi-official Catholic Reichspost pointing out what it described as the peril to Catholic foreign missions if war began in Ethiopia.

Announcement of the 9-cent cotton loan policy, the third setback to confidence in the cotton textile markets in as many months, stopped merchandise buying abruptly at the close of last week but found mills unwilling to concede that prices will work lower.
EASTON, Pa., Aug. 24. -- Four persons were drowned early today when their automobile plunged through a guard rail on the Lackawanna Trail, four miles south of here, and fell into the Lehigh Canal.

Since 1921 the United Farmers have been in power in Alberta. Last Thursday their party was unexpectedly and woefully beaten in the Provincial elections. The United Farmers were out-bidden. Their Government imported at considerable expense Major DOUGLAS who cures all economic diseases by his social credit pills.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 24 (Reuters). -- The Italo-Ethiopian conflict has attracted special attention here to Britain's position in Egypt and the Sudan. Local leaders are debating Egypt's position in relation to Britain in case of an Anglo-Italian conflict and are studying the possibility of the occupation of the Lake Tsana district in Ethiopia by British troops with or without Egyptian detachments.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 24. -- Morelos Zaragoza, well known writer on economics and finance, applauds President Lazaro Cardenas for his recent statement that Mexico has no intention not to recognize her foreign debt and will renew payments on it when economic conditions permit. Mr. Zaragoza writes:

SOFTLY, in the soft Roman night, the violins sang the loveliest phrases in the adagio movement of the Eroica symphony. It was full moon, and the sound was like the moonlight put to music, the silver voice of the silver light that flooded the vast arches overhead, poured down the deep hollow behind, swept the ancient terraces beyond so that each cypress and stone pine stood listening in a separate radiance.

AS we look over the hundreds of reports, addresses, papers and abstracts which were presented before the American Chemical Society last week we cannot but be struck by the range of the chemist's interests and activities.

DOWN on the Bowery they sang it with delighted swagger; it was sung in seaports from Liverpool to Hongkong, and it is still a familiar childhood echo to adults born 'round the turn of the century. But the rollicking tune has turned out to be prophecy, after all.
Final games in the softball and sandlot baseball tournaments staged by The Daily Mirror during the last three months were played at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Hot weather again affected retail trade in the metropolitan area last week, and sales totals proved disappointing. Department store sales volume, it was estimated, ran close to 5 per cent under the figures for the corresponding week a year ago.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- New England thinks Frank Knox is not -- yet -- a formidable candidate for the Presidency. He is not -- yet -- actually an avowed candidate, but he has not disavowed what others have said in his presence as to his chances in the convention next year.

WITH innumerable Fall shows in the offing, many gardeners are busy these days making advance preparations for their exhibits. Much can be done in a few weeks in the way of getting plants into prime condition, and the experts develop skill in "timing" their blooms for exhibition in such a way that material will be available for the exact dates desired.

BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 24. -- In the darkness of night 150,000 Italian soldiers moved through forest-covered mountains near the Austrian frontier tonight to engage in a gigantic mock battle opening at dawn.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Twenty-two new government works projects in ten counties in New Jersey, it was announced here yesterday, have been authorized by William H.J. Ely, State Works Progress Administrator. The new projects will involve the expenditure of $377,942, of which $296,484 will be provided by Federal funds.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., Aug. 24. (AP). -- Brig. Gen. Frank M. Andrews drove his Martin B-12 bombardment plane this afternoon over the second lap of his 2,000-kilometer flight at an average speed of 165.4 miles an hour, which Colonel Follette Bradley, intelligence officer at Langley Field, said broke three world's records for the 1,000-kilometer course, previously held by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

VOICE FROM ABROAD: The wisecracking voice of James J. Walker, Who left the city and the Mayoralty nearly three years ago, was brought back by radio last week from London. The occasion was a cheer-up broadcast for Thomas Meighan, the movie actor, who is recuperating from an illness at his Long Island home.

GENEVA, Aug. 23. -- There never was a graver moment for the world's peace organization, which includes the League of Nations and the Kellogg-Briand pact, though the danger at its worst is not necessarily fatal. Failure may prove helpful to the idea of the organization of peace by causing it to be reorganized on better lines.

IN all nature there is no purer white than in the petals of the night-blooming cereus. Flowering dogwood, the white, waterlily or the freshly driven snowy may equal but they do not excel it. The flower opens shortly after nightfall and at the first trace of dawn closes forever.

KEUKA, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Loon, piloted by Abram A. Post of the Seneca Yacht Club at Geneva, won the final race of a three-day series and the twelfth district championship of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association on Keuka Lake today, with a total of 32 points.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- Pierre Laval, Premier and Foreign Minister of France, who comes from Auvergne, home of the shrewdest traders in the land, sat in his office at the Quai d'Orsay with the evening paper spread out before him. Evidently he had been reading it, but he was not reading it any longer.

HOLLYWOOD. AMAZING transactions are no novelty in Hollywood, but one has been completed that startled even this town. Samuel Goldwyn has purchased "The Children's Hour" for a reputed $50,000. The play was banned as screen material by the Hays office and its acquisition was sanctioned by that body only with the understanding that its purchase could not be announced, its title not used and its plot discarded.

VIENNA, Aug. 24. -- "Rumors of Otto's return to Austria current in Vienna a few days ago are absolutely untrue, and I could prove they were spread from quarters hostile to legitimists," the monarchist leader, Baron Wisner, told this correspondent today.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Aug. 24. -- A plank for the immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus and another in favor of revision of the monetary system after a world conference, with inclusion of silver in the currency plan of the United States, were rejected by the conference of Young Republicans of eleven Northwestern States at its final session today.

As Congress worked feverishly yesterday to complete its legislative calendar, the security and commodity markets weakened appreciably during the half-day trading period. Stocks opened lower, held lower despite short-lived rallying movements, and closed with losses ranging from small fractions to 2 1/2 points.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- Several small shipments of Costa Rican coffee have been sent to Japan in the hope that a market might be found to offset the unfavorable trade balance resulting from the dumping of Japanese goods here.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Operations in the steel industry soared to 52 1/2 per cent this week, as steadily mounting gains shattered the tradition of a Summer slump.
CALGARY, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The women will do some of the new dealing in Alberta's prospective "$25 a month for everybody" government.

Congressional sanction was given last week to the establishment by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut of an Interstate Sanitation Commission to combat the pollution of the waters of the metropolitan zone. The House of Representatives in Washington concurred on Thursday in a resolution adopted by the Senate; with the President's approval of the measure the States will be in a position to go ahead.

In a recent interview GERTRUDE STEIN refers to EMERSON as one of the passionate writers. Although Miss STEIN'S personal literary style looks like an emotional orgy she has a vigorous critical mind. Her description of EMERSON proves it. Being disciplined and kindly by nature he would have been the last to include himself among the passionate singers, for BYRON and SHELLEY wear that sort of garment more comfortably.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The World Zionist Congress resumed its sessions tonight, after the Sabbath recess, with speakers assailing the Palestine Government's avowed plan to establish a legislative council to rule the Country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- A militant defense of the right to change laws to meet the changing conditions of modern life, interspersed with sharp criticism of "Tories," was delivered by President Roosevelt tonight in a radio speech addressed primarily to the Young Democrats of America, meeting in convention at Milwaukee.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The International Penal and Penitentiary Congress, which has been in session here throughout the week, concluded its deliberations today with a spirited debate over the question of sterilization and emasculation, the introduction of which as preventive-therapeutic and eugenic measures it recommended by a heavy majority of individual votes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 24. -- A notorious golfing character, Mr. H.I. Phillips -- a Connecticut Yankee known on his native Nutmeg fairways as the Wild Man of Woodmont -- was strolling across the clubhouse porch here with a dejected countenance, indicating that he had neglected to bet on the last winner. Suddenly he halted, pushed back his well-worn straw hat and remarked:

Increased activity was shown last week in the calling of bonds for payment before maturity. Following the lull in calls in the preceding week, large refundings in the public utility field raised the volume of retirements considerably. The calls, almost all of which were for future months, included, besides several large blocks of utility bonds, many small amounts of industrial, foreign and municipal issues.

IN "Dance of Fire" Lola Ridge, already the author of several books of verse, comes to a fuller maturity than she has previously shown. Always a thinker, always displaying the keenest interest in humanity, for Miss Ridge poetry and thought are one.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Winning his games in the eighth and ninth rounds and gaining a draw in an adjourned third round game, Isaac Kashdan of the Manhattan and Empire City Chess Clubs of New York today won the State chess championship.

Liberalization of the National Housing Act of 1934 to permit national mortgage associations to issue debentures up to twenty times their capitalization instead of twelve times, as now allowed, is advocated by many in the financial community as a means of further thawing mortgage funds.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Championship honors in three divisions were awarded today in the sixth annual North Shore Horse Show, which will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

Joining in this year's widespread observance of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Johann Sebastian Bach, the Steel Pier Opera Company at Atlantic City will give Bach's "Phoebus and Pan," the composer's only known work which lends itself to operatic performance, in double bill with Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel" this evening on the Steel Pier at Atlantic City.

WHATEVER the Abraham Lincoln who lived and died may have been, he was not the Lincoln we think of by that name. Our Lincoln, however differently we may view him, is a myth. We have created him, and he is a myth in the same way that Odin and King Arthur are.

Veteran shipping men who have seen the speed record for transatlantic crossings change hands five times in the last six years, and who consider the prospect of another change next year if the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary develops her expected speed, remark upon the rapid turnover in championship honors.

Heavy capital expenditures made by industry in recent months are only the start of a wave of "fear" spending based on the certainty of business men that inflation cannot be avoided next year, accountants, industrial engineers and company executives agreed here yesterday.

With gains of 10 to 40 per cent noted this month in furs, better-grade furniture and imported rugs regarded as a harbinger of increased spending, retailers have become more confident of a brisk upswing in luxury and semi-luxury lines during the next four months.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Zombro Hanover, pacing gelding, and Cynara, trotting mare, both from the William A. Parkhurst Stables, turned in the outstanding performances at the regular matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Lotus, sailed by F.P. Schoettle Jr., took the race for the historic Toms River Challenge Cup today off Cedar Creek Point. Lotus scored in the weekly championship regatta as the Toms River Yacht Club played host to the skippers of the larger racing boats of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 24. -- Foreign military advisers who went to the border by air are directing the construction of trenches on the frontiers of Eritrea and Italian Somaliland. This manner of warfare previously was unknown to the fierce Ethiopian warrior, who relied on barricades of loosely piled stones.

When Professor Ben Ingram finds the body of Professor Yerkes and sees that he has been murdered, he immediately recalls having seen four persons leaving the scene of the crime and that three of these persons showed by their manner that they did not wish to be seen.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 24. -- Although Siscoe Gold Mines, Ltd., treated 74,302 tons of ore in the first half of this year, against 59,000 tons in the same period of 1934, the net profit was $503,224, or 10.9 cents a share, against $604,480, or 13.1 cents.

Mrs. A. Barton Hepburn, president of the Panhellenic House Association, will give a luncheon Wednesday at the Beckman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place, for Miss Sylvia Goodman of Wayne University, Detroit, winner of first prize in a country-wide essay contest sponsored by the association during the last six months to further inter-fraternity relationships.
Mussolini's policy in the present crisis is described as "international racketeering" by Allan Nevins in an article on "Italy's Gamble for Ethiopia," in September Current History.
OMAHA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Striking street car workers, still seeking to win their demands after four months of strife, made last-minute plans tonight to take to the picket lines again Monday.

Undismayed by the failure of Congress to act on numerous bills, intended to defeat the administration's reciprocal trade treaty program, protectionist interests last week began a campaign to build up support for their bills by the time Congress convenes Jan. 1.

A NEW discovery has given to artificial respiration, so important a safeguard on beaches the world over and in many industries, a new high level of efficiency and simplicity. Holger Nielsen, a Danish sports inspector, recently made public the details of his method, which competent Danish authorities affirm surpasses the universally known Schaeffer method of respiration.

The weather played quite an important part in retail trade last week, with the advent of a cool spell in Chicago and Atlanta spurring sales, while heat in Boston and this city retarded the movement of goods to consumers. Store showings ranged from a loss of 5 per cent under a year ago here to advances of 10 to 15 per cent in Georgia.

Waldemar Kaempffert's article on frozen monkeys indicates how little is known of the effect of frost on the higher orders of living organisms. Apparently there is an abundance of accurate data available from experiments with germs, but next to nothing with regard to the higher end of the scale.

While fewer buyers arrived in the markets, mail orders increased last week and reorders were more numerous, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Generally speaking, the buying office said, first Fall purchases are complete and a number of the buyers arriving were here for their second purchases.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Driving her own trotting mare, Hollyrood Czarina, 2:09, Mrs. Martin E. Snyder of Plainfield captured the women drivers' race at the Borough Park track today in three heats.

LABELS, unfortunately, have a habit of sticking, and, though he has experimented with other subjects since "Laughing Boy," Mr. La Farge is commonly known as the man who writes about Indians. As a matter of fact there may be some justice in this, for Mr. La Farge is more at home with the Navajos and the Apaches than he is with extra-curricular themes.
The worst enemies of the world and its people are and have been idealists in power.
Emil Polak of 541 East Seventy-second Street made one of his biweekly trips up to Throgs Neck in the Bronx yesterday to work on his subsistence garden.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 23. -- In announcing his candidacy for the Senate next year in opposition to Carter Glass, Randolph Leigh of Fairfax County, director of the international oratorical contest on the Constitution, said this week that "if Roosevelt is to carry Virginia in the general election, Glass must be defeated in the primaries."

VACATION days away from New York offer opportunity to observe how the various acts of the ethereal show are accepted west of the Catskills. Far from the studios, the showmen and the actors surges the real reaction to radio.

ROME, Aug. 22. -- Of all the great powers Italy is the least able to stand the financial strain of war. The heavy expenditure for preparations in East Africa, added to the cost of keeping 1,000,000 men under arms at home, represents a burden that is causing the whole Italian financial structure to creak.
DUBLIN, Aug. 23. -- Industry is booming in Ireland at this season and there is a heavy influx of American and British visitors, many of them wealthy tourists with their own cars.

NEWPORT, R.I -- The naval colony here will vie with the Summer residents this week for the centre of the social stage, and the odds appear to be with the former as far as the larger affairs of the week are concerned.

In the excitement over the Utility Bill, few in Wall Street apparently have noticed that President Roosevelt has selected as Justice Ferdinand Pecora's successor on the Securities and Exchange Commission one of the country's most outspoken advocates of government ownership and operation of utilities.
With a spanking northerly breeze giving every prospect of fast going, twenty-seven yachts started yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Spurred by a resolve to speed this Congress to adjournment, the Senate, at 10 A.M., two hours earlier than the usual meeting time, had plunged into its work.

Balmy days brought success early this week to the outdoor library in Bryant Park where bench-sitters found plenty of time on their hands to sample free literature provided by the city Works Progress Administration.

China will have a strong and modern air force if the national government continues the work along the lines that have been begun, according to Lieut. Col. John Hamilton Jouett, who has just returned to this country after three years' work in establishing the Central Aviation School at Shienchiao.
LAKE PLACID. -- The exit of August from the Adirondack season will this week be featured by numerous interesting sports events, with those scheduled at Saranac Inn commanding special attention.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 24. -- Champion Edelweis du Labory of Salmagundi, a poodle exhibited by Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Griess, was named best in show at the second annual North Shore Kennel Club event at the Myopia Hunt today after a fifteen-minute contest with five other variety group winners.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Because all bids for constructing 120 houses at the $36,000,000 Quoddy power project site were deemed excessive by the Federal Government, army engineers today prepared to build the workers' homes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 24. -- Indicted by the Hennepin County grand jury on a statutory charge involving two girls, Walter W. Liggett, magazine and newspaper writer and now publisher of a weekly paper here, is scheduled to go on trial Sept. 16.

Stimulated by the upturn in prices of securities and volume of trading, the turnover of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange this year already amounts to fifty-three, against sixty-eight for the whole of 1934. Observers predict that if the volume continues to average 1,750,000 shares a day the number of seats sold in 1935 may closely approach the mark of ninety-two made in 1933.

BARCELONA. -- Manuel Azana, who as the Republic's first Prime Minister was responsible for the granting to Catalonia of its autonomy regime which was later to go on the rocks, has given fair warning to the Catalan Esquerra, or Left party, that it must make a clean break from separatism if it is to count on his aid.

Successful functioning of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board during the five weeks of its existence thus far has offered a concrete example of how industry and labor, working together to preserve stability and enforce fair trade standards, can put their house in order, according to Alexander Printz, chairman of the board and head of the Printz-Biederman Company.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Union College closed the first chapter and assured the future of its contribution to the theatre of America when it presented certificates this morning to students of the Mohawk Drama Festival Institute.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1, 1935. THE Soviet composer is a prophet with honor in his own country. It is assumed that his function is to write music, that his works are designed for performance and that certain essentials of life, like food and shelter, are the minimum material return for creative effort.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Celebrating the announcement of Jimmie Dykes's retention as manager for 1936, the White Sox catapulted back into the first division today by a ninth-inning rally that salvaged the final game of the series from the Senators for them, 2 -- 1.
Despite difficulties in handling those already in the fold of the Works Progress Administration, plans have been made to increase greatly the pace of enrolment beginning tomorrow.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The best sailing conditions of the season prevailed on Long Island Sound today and a fleet of sixty-eight yachts, competing in the annual regatta of the New York Athletic Club, welcomed the stiff breeze and rough water.

THERE is much illumination in this book of the situation in India with regard to agricultural conditions, the Indian farmer and the relation of this profoundly difficult problem to the future of the country. It takes on special interest just now because of recent important political developments.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Aug. 24 -- Pending official sanction by the American Power Boat Association, George B. Ward Jr. of Wilmington, Del., today claimed a mark better than the world's record for class C-D inboard boats.

MINICH, Aug. 14 (By Mail). -- The theory that Jews are deliberately fomenting extreme nationalism in Japan in order to imbue the Japanese with the idea of a world mission and then to bolshevize the nation is developed by General Erich von Ludendorff in his fortnightly Am Heiligen Quell Deutsches Kraft (At the Holy Well of German Power).

When, more than a century ago, Thomas Babington Macaulay wrote his essay on Robert Southey it dealt largely with social conditions in England. But a mere change of date and locale gives us the uncanny feeling that Lord Macaulay is actually writing about the United States in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Motorization and mechanization of the army have reached a high stage of development, and the long days of exhausting foot marches seem definitely over, Secretary Dern said today in a radio statement over the Columbia System upon the practical war manoeuvres under way in the New York area by the First Army.

THERE is little probability of new material, or even of a new interpretation, in the life of Mary Stuart. Herr Zweig appears to be substantially in agreement with Marjorie Bowen's "Mary, Queen of Scots," 1933, in finding Mary guilty of complicity in Darnley's murder, and of adultery with Bothwell.

Numerous complaints over the working out of Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act were voiced by credit executives all over the country in replying to a questionnaire sent out by the National Association of Credit Men, an analysis of the survey revealed yesterday.

WHILE there has been no neglect of early English history on the part of scholars, there has been a growing need for a book which would combine and integrate both the established work of the past and the more recent contributions of archaeologists, philologists and other specialists.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 23. -- Farmers of the Northwest are only mildly interested in the latest Frazier-Lemke bill. Designed to relieve the situation by preserving equities for distressed debtors, the measure applies the principles already approved by the United States Supreme Court in the Minnesota mortgage moratorium case.

POLITICAL and economic storms are swirling today about Uncle Sam's overseas dependencies. Once again our scattered territories and insular possessions have engaged the attention of Congress and the nation; the "lovely isles" that Columbus named after St. Ursula and her Eleven Thousand Virgins are in the headlines, and Puerto Rico and the Philippines strain against the bonds that bind them to the Stars and Stripes.

ALREADY one can begin to see signs that "The Postman Always Rings Twice" will have a marked influence upon light fiction. There is sure to be a host of imitators who will find nothing in Cain but the surface attributes of his hardboiled style. And there will be others who, like Helen Adams, will see in Cain's anti-intellectualism a pretext to omit all thinking, even the platitudinous, moralistic thinking of mediocre light fiction.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Aug. 24. -- A crowd of 2,500, the largest gallery to attend a horse show at this resort, witnessed the closing competitions of the Pocono Mountains exhibition today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has filed a "delaying amendment" postponing the effective date of its registration statement for issuance of 100,000 shares of stock, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Cries of "It's a ringer!" filled the air at the finals of the Park Department's interborough city horseshoe -pitching contest held yesterday afternoon at the Heckscher Playground in Central Park. The meet was the culmination of a tournament in which 1,500 contestants participated.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- By an overwhelming vote of 77 to 2 the Senate today completed Congressional action on the neutrality resolution passed in the House yesterday.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The heavy surf that has been pounding the Jersey coast for the last three days caused the death yesterday afternoon of H. Albert Kruegel, 41 years old, of 142 Munn Avenue, Teaneck, N.J. Kruegel, who was swimming in the surf off Ocean Avenue, was caught in an outward racing current and drowned before rescuers could reach him.

THERE is, it seems, a region west of the Mississippi where lingers -- or lingered a long time ito this mechanic era -- an old American custom of fox-huntling, far removed from the chase with horse and hound and horn which is now associated with pink coats both in this country and the shires of England.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- A new plan for Federal control of the alcohol business was dropped on President Roosevelt's desk tonight by Congress.

DENVER, Aug. 24. -- A maniacal fireburg terrorized Denver tonight, after he had kindled three fires in the $6,000,000 City Hall, where he endangered art treasures, and eluded a ring of officers to start a later fire in an office building.

THE works of thirty-one American composers were performed by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor, in the season of concerts on the Mall in Central Park, on the campus at New York University and at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, which ended last Sunday evening.

Sightseeing buses, although out of sight until ready to start, are nonetheless doing a flourishing business since their banishment from Times Square last Spring by the Police Department. A tour of their terminals reveals that patronage is brisk and some of the companies acknowledged it was livelier than before the order was given for the clearance of Times Square and other congested areas.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 24. -- Repeal advocates built up a commanding lead in the latest tabulation tonight of votes in today's special election and considered the sixteen-year-old reign of State-wide dry laws in Texas ended unless a prohibition landslide occurred in some totally unexpected area.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- In cotton-growing sections of the Eighth Federal Reserve District the policy of the administration on cotton prices has had a depressing effect.

LOND0N. NONE but a blind man could miss being aware of the publication of Heinemann's thirty-shilling edition of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom." It is prominently displayed in the windows of every book store, and other methods of publicity have been employed to an unusual degree.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Two tremendous horses, Hal Price Headley's Whopper and George D. Widener's Sation, ran one, two, in the first renewal of the Blackstone Valley Handicap at Narragansett Park today, the Headley colt leading the other home by a length.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The sixth annual Pocono Mountain Horse Show was brought to a close last evening with the annual horse show ball held in the ballroom of the Penn Stroud Hotel here. Efforts are now being made to make the Labor Day week-end a lively one.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- Plans to eliminate ten companies from the corporate structure of the United Gas Improvement in a further effort at simplification are being studied by corporation officials, it was disclosed today.

In the final major A.A.U. swimming meet of the outdoor season, held under the auspices of the Women's Swimming Association at the Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, yesterday, Miss Dorothea Dickinson and Miss Erna Kompa broke two long-established American long-course records.

A record number of boats is expected to assemble at the Knickerbocker Y.C. in Port Washington Aug. 31 for the annual Labor Day rendezvous of the New York Power Squadron, according to an announcement by Thomas S. Deering, chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements.

Each August and September, as the boating season wanes, the engine builders, stock cruiser makers and the naval architects get busy again after their Summer holidays with two aims in view -- to prepare for the National Motor Boat Show in midwinter and to plan and develop, usually in great secrecy, their designs and their production.
