ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- The 1 per cent State sales tax becomes effective in Missouri next Tuesday and the question of how it is to be collected on sales of less than a dollar has been settled, at least temporarily, by the introduction of the homely milk bottle cap as a monetary medium.

PROVING again that Americans are a nomadic people, at least 2,500,000 of them are expected to have trekked through the Mountain and Pacific States before the Summer ends. Although tourist bureaus, railroads, hotel associations and automobile clubs all make varied estimates, there seems little question that 1935 will be a greater touring year than any since 1929.

DESPITE some evidences of recovery more than 11,000,000 Americans are still believed to be out of work. How much will this figure be reduced if and when the full tide of prosperity returns? Will it entirely disappear? If it does not, what provisions shall be made to care for it?

PICARESQUE adventurers began to pioneer in psychology several decades ago, as soon as the spectacular and sometimes fantastic new developments in that science began to attract popular attention. It proved a richly paying field, and they are still working it, although the claims made in psychology's name by its genuine disciples have sobered down a good deal and it has given up its early pirouetting on airy-fairy toes and is plodding along on realistic feet.

BEGIN where Ward McAlllster1 left off," Harry Lehr once said. The ghost of that arbiter elegantiarum might think that was a very good place to leave off for good. Certainly that is the impression a reading of Mrs. Lehr's book gives.

NOT since Mr. De Mille turned his siege guns upon Acre has there been anything like the bombardment being laid down upon the cinema front along Broadway. The hold-over list alone is a matter of wonder, while the new attractions looming upon the horizon indicate that the new screen season is well begun.

A large delegation of members of local numismatic clubs, including those from the New York Coin Club and the Bronx Coin Club, will leave for Pittsburgh today to attend the annual convention of the American Numismatic Association which will begin its business sessions tomorrow.

JUDGING from the fast and high-powered airplanes which have been entered, records are believed to be in the making at the 1935 National Air Races, which will open next Friday at Cleveland, scene of last year's highly successful meeting.
An aroused public has deluged Mayor La Guardia's office staff with suggestions for noise abatement since the Mayor announced his anti-noise campaign early this month, it was revealed yesterday.

LANSING, Mich. -- Michigan's 10,000 prisoners will be charged 70 cents a day in future for rations. Balfe McDonald, wealthy young matricide of Flint, Mich., was used as test prisoner when Auditor General John O'Hara filed a food claim of $464 against the $250,000 estate McDonald inherited from his widowed mother. McDonald is said to be the wealthiest prisoner in Michigan.

THERE is nothing very striking unusual about the psychological situation upon which the story of "The Constant Sex" is based. After all, in the range of human relationships open to the novelist there are no really new and interesting situations.

But surely it is not nearly so futile to hear and heed them now as to listen to the counsels of madness and stupidity that are ringing round the world.

ON July 19 delegates of the American Bar Association paid a call on the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif. The Huntington, always prepared for guests of no matter what profession, tapped the resources of its abundant shelves and staged an unusual exhibition with which to regale the visiting attorneys.
VALETTA, Malta, Aug. 24. -- British plans to throw a tight ring of warships around the Suez Canal, vital question mark in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, were announced officially today.

Aggressive campaigns in this city and in Philadelphia against planned increases in store employe working hours will be waged by the retail unions, it was stated yesterday by R.D. Denise, Eastern representative of the Retail Clerks International Protective Association, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

The Seventy-fourth Congress of the United States convened on Jan. 3, 1935. The next day, before a joint session of Congress -- and crowded galeries -- President Roosevelt appeared in person to report on the state of the Union.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The John Howard Payne exhibit, mounted in connection with the just concluded Mohawk Drama Festival Institute of the Theatre, will be kept intact in the Exhibition Hall of Union College for the benefit of throngs of visitors until this Fall's presentation of the Payne Pageant.

While English manufacturers are superior in evening wear, American producers of daytime and beach wear are "miles ahead" of their British contemporaries, Miss Olive Harbottle, buyer for Fenwick, Ltd., Bond Street branch, London, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- While confronting immense difficulties because of lack of definite data and because of the time element, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration is speeding arrangements to put into operation the Potato Control Act included by Congress in the bill amending the AAA Act sent to President Roosevelt this week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The AAA Amendment Bill, intended both to extend the farm administration's power and bulwark it legally, was written into law today by President Roosevelt.

Declaring that "doubts as to whether or not the severe depression is a thing of the past were rather thoroughly dissolved during the past few months," Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly review of business conditions, yesterday said that indications point to the likelihood of "a splendid Fall upturn" with an increase in the retail-trade field of fully 15 per cent over last year.
It will seem rather strange not to find Miss Virginia Van Wie in the final round of the women's national golf championship at the Interlachen Country Club next Saturday.

Fifteen eager, smiling young representatives of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association sailed yesterday at noon on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic for a four-week tour of England and Ireland.

Yet there are points in connection with the tercentenary tribute to Lope de Vega, currently filling the pages of Theatre Arts (September issue), that bear reference to our more immediate interests.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 (AP). -- With the support of the American delegation, there were indications today that the World Zionist Congress would bring peace next week to Zionist ranks by electing a coalition administration in the World Zionist Executive.

If one prefers a perennial vine to blossom at times in Summer or early Fall when there is not an abundance of flowers in the garden, there are a number to choose from. The sweet-smelling old fashioned Honeysuckle, the graceful Clematis, the rampant Cinnamon Vine, Trumpet Vine and Perennial Pea all offer their services.

A total of 20,000 placements in new Works Progress Administration jobs was set yesterday as the goal for the coming week under the new employment plan for those on home relief which proposes court action against persons who refuse to work.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Four daring women fliers and six men hop for Cleveland tomorrow in a $1,000 air derby sponsored by Ruth Chatterton, flying actress. The flag-off of this race will mark the start of the airplane racing season.

Motor-boat drivers in the 225-cubic-inch class, which probably is growing faster than any other racing division in the United States and Canada, face their busiest series of events of the season over the coming week-end.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's determination to defy the League of Nations, if necessary, is described even by such pro-Italian newspapers as the Journal des Debats as "somewhat dangerous."

TORONTO, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Buffalo West Sides climaxed a day of triumph at the Canadian national exhibition regatta today by taking the senior eight-oared one mile race by four lengths from the Toronto Argonauts. The Hamilton Leanders, Canadian champions, did not race.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Young Democrats of the nation ended their second annual national convention tonight in a burst of cheering for the radio speech addressed to them by President Roosevelt and shouts of confidence for his victory in 1936.

CONNECTICUT has kept its Tercentenary celebration very much in evidence for months. Many exhibitions have been presented, emphasizing now this, again that, aspect of the State's three-century development.

With the New York City Federation of Negro Musicians as hosts, the sixteenth annual convention of the National Association of Negro Musicians will open at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the auditorium of Wadleigh High School Annex, Convent Avenue and West 135th Street.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The New York State Department of Health started something this week when it broadcast through the newspapers an appeal for information regarding what areas in the State are free from hay fever.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Fifteen principal investigations, including in their scope chain stores, lobbying activities of the utility and other industries, air transportation, World War international banking, and the marketing of wool, are authorized to proceed during the Congress recess.

" THESE ELDER REBELS" is a pleasant little story which, rather like a pretty small fish, makes an effort at swallowing too large a bait. When partially hooked, it manages to extricate itself and swim away, gayly flapping its tail at having won freedom.

GERARD HORDYK, the Dutch artist, is having an "Au Revoir" exhibition at Contemporary Arts, where some of his work was seen last June. The present one-man show, which contains for the most part pictures not previously placed on view here, will continue through Aug. 30.

NOT so long ago they were relating how Arthur Kober had outlined a play to Marc Connelly, and how Mr. Connelly, swept by a desire to be a theatrical producer, had given him an advance and told him to go ahead, and how Mr. Kober had gone all the way to Fire Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The most comprehensive guidebook of the New Deal yet attempted will make its appearance within two or three months, to serve as a sort of "Notice to Mariners" for private individuals threading their way through the mazes of the administrative decrees which govern activities of citizens.

WILL ROGERS was the leading citizen of the cinema. Since his tragic death ten days ago millions of words have been written about him. They have embraced his colorful career, his family life, his position as a friend of aviation, his vast gifts and services to charity.

Recovery of trade and rise in stocks, which continued last week, attracted the more attention because they occurred in face of the drastic session-end legislation. Since July, 1932, when the low point in the depression was reached both by business activities and financial markets, the course of recovery has been pursued with the irregularity always present on such occasions.

WHEN Summer session closed at Teachers College last week, hundreds of student teachers from all sections of the country had witnessed the testing of a new theory in education. They had seen demonstrated a low-cost nursery school unit which meets reduced educational budgets without sacrificing essential standards for the needs of young children.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Jack Creavy of Albany, 19-year-old State junior champion, won the fifth Sagamore invitation golf tournament today by trouncing C. Everett Bacon, defending champion, by 5 and 4 in the final.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- N.P. Findley Jr. led the way home in the first division of the SS Class as forty-one yachts took part in the weekly races of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club on Moriches Bay today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 24 -- Democrats in Iowa are busy attempting to minimize the expected political repercussions from the announcement Thursday of a property tax containing the highest millage levy in the State's history.

WOODSTOCK -- The week prior to Labor Day and events of the holiday week-end will complete one of the gayest seasons hero in recent years, despite the damaging July flood. On Saturday the Woodstock Artists Association will open the annual no-jury show at the Art Gallery.

WITH thousands of would-be teachers in a last-minute scramble for Jobs, certain well-paid positions bid fair to remain unfilled for lack of qualified applicants. In various parts of the country schools of the so-called "progressive" type report that they cannot obtain enough teachers of the calibre and education they require.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. (AP). -- The Senate Finance Committee reported favorably today on a resolution by Senator Gore for a study of the entire fiscal system of the United States with a view toward placing it "on a sounder and more scientific basis."

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The stir concerning my visit to Europe has been very surprising because it is based on erroneous information. Any one who draws an analogy between my visit and that of Colonel House [diplomatic adviser to President Wilson] is badly mistaken or simply speaking facetiously.

Europe was filled with alarums last week -- and its fears echoed through a large part of the rest of the world. For the first time it seemed fully to realize the possible consequences of a war between Italy and Ethiopia, and every hour there were new indications of impending struggle.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The comeback of an old-time boat, Alice, sailed by its former skipper, Clinton L. Breckley, featured the fourth annual Ocean City Yacht Club sailing regatta today. Breckley's victory was recorded in the free-for-all engagement, last race of the program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Action on the Utility Holding Company Control Bill, most controversial of the important reform measures given to Congress by President Roosevelt, was completed on Capitol Hill late today and the measure was sent to the White House.

Frisch, Martin, Medwick, Collins Co. maintained their speedy pace in the tense National League pennant chase in Brooklyn yesterday and there was a suspicion abroad that a majority of the 5,000 spectators present were more pleasant about it than otherwise, since the Giants were prevented from gaining on the St. Louis squad.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Whether President Roosevelt's plan to settle the fifteen-week strike at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's plant here is acceptable to both sides in the dispute will not be known before Monday. The company, a spokesman said today, would not announce until that day, or possibly Tuesday morning, whether it would accept or reject the proposal.

TETERBORO, N.J., Aug. 24. -- In order to show that his safety device for airplanes would operate satisfactorily at low altitudes, at which aviation experts have contended that parachutes would be of little use, Harry P. Trusty of Los Angeles sent aloft his specially equipped plane from the airport here this morning and had his pilot drop four dummies from altitudes of 85 to 110 feet. The dummies weighed between 150 and 200 pounds each.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Sweeping Light, 6-year-old, speeded down the stretch today to overtake and beat the renowned Myrtlewood by a neck in the $5,000 added Lincoln Handicap before 18,000 spectators at Lincoln Fields.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Retail trade here took a sharp turn for the better with the arrival of cool weather at the end of the week, but the dollar average with the larger Loop stores remained a little below the level of last year. House furnishings sold ahead of 1934, as did the August sales of fur coats.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Earl Averill's home run with one on base and two out broke a 0-0 tie in the fifteenth inning today to give the Indians a 2-to-0 victory over the Athletics.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 24. -- Political observers, in looking on at the two-day meeting of the Young Democrats, who closed their national convention here today, have gained two distinct impressions of the strength of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the country at large.

HOW to equip children for a profitable use of future leisure is becoming more and more a concern of educators. A comprehensive report on education and leisure has been made available by the New Education Fellowship for the delegates attending its recent regional conference at St. Andrews, Scotland.
BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The Reich Film Chamber urged a ban upon Jewish agents abroad for German films today as new domestic anti-Semitic restrictions made their appearance.

A TWO-MONTH tour of Europe through seventeen countries gave John Royal, vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, a clear picture of international broadcasting and its future prospects. He has returned to Radio City most enthusiastic about the international radio outlook and in the most glowing terms expressed belief that nations will soon be competing with each other for the best talent, no matter the origin or nationality.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- A weary horse strode gamely through the stretch today to win easing up to the shouts of "Discovery in a gallop again." But only an iron constitution and true thoroughbred courage enabled him to score his ninth victory in fifteen starts this season.

That men waiters, suave in manner and proud of their profession, are increasing in numbers has been disclosed apropos of a hearing on the minimum wage for waitresses, held recently before Elmer E. Andrews, New York State Industrial Commissioner.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Fred Perry gave Manuel Alonso a slight sample today of what he has in store for the American stars in the forthcoming national championships as the world's No. 1 amateur tennis player stole the show from the regular competitors in the annual East-West match at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

MANILA. -- Woman suffrage, so joyfully proclaimed for the Philippine Islands two years ago, is being gradually and skillfully shunted out of the political picture. The latest step is the passage of a special election bill under which the officers of the Commonwealth will be chosen in such a way as to disfranchise the women.

The General Motors Corporation, which assisted in the formation of the National Bank of Detroit at the time of the banking crisis in March, 1933, now has a paper profit of more than $13,500,000 on its stock interest in the bank if its holdings are still what they were on Dec. 31, 1934.

A series of dramatic orders, emanating from Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, has kept the Police Department in the headlines in recent months. The challenge of organized crime was met with a reorganized rackets squad, hand picked to cooperate with Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

MISS HAINES is a librarian of long experience who has for almost twenty years been giving courses in library schools in Los Angeles, the University of California and Columbia University, while years of service as managing editor of The Library Journal gave her opportunity to collect large quantities of material which helps to serve as foundation for the advice and counsel offered in this volume.

ALFRED McINTYRE, president of Little, Brown Co., returned recently from England, bringing with him a contract for James Hilton's next three novels. The first of these will probably be published next Summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Suggestion of far-reaching industrial legislation to supplant and re-establish the benefits under the invalidated National Industrial Recovery Act was conveyed in what was expected to be President Roosevelt's parting message to Congress tonight.

THE waning days of August find the salt-water fishing season at its peak around New York. Inshore and offshore waters are swarming with finny varieties, from the lowly croaker to the mettlesome tuna, and countless anglers are reaping the harvest of sport which a bountiful Atlantic yields.

For the first time in more than half a century of tennis in this country the national men's and women's championships will be held in one tournament starting Thursday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

RECENT sales of old masters serve as a reminder that persons who pay (or expect to get) large sums for paintings must have sure means of knowing that the goods involved in the transaction are, in fact, what they purport to be.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- Economics Minister Hjalmar Schacht's broadside against National Socialist extremists, "economic dilettantes" and saboteurs generally has caused the entire world to open its eyes. His breezy frankness scattered for a moment the official propaganda views surrounding this land of make-believe, even though for Germans themselves the nakedness of the Third Reich is hidden by a rigid censorship.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Aug. 25. -- Delay in the adjournment of Congress last night was brought about primarily by a coalition of Southern Senators as a protest against President Roosevelt's plan to reduce from 12 cents to 9 cents a pound the government loan on cotton.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The Old Field Clubhouse grounds, where the annual North Shore horse show was resumed this morning in the second of its three days' session, presented a colorful appearance, with more than 500 persons from New York State, Connecticut and New Jersey present.

IF throwing together most of the accepted ingredients for a mystery story and a romantic novel were all that was required to make a rattling good story, "Gypsy Weather" would be a hummer. It has everything, from circus riders to ancestral ghosts, from a secret staircase to a New York speakeasy.

IN Spain books dealing with the life of Lope de Vega are the most popular with publishers and book buyers now that the third centenary of his death, Aug. 27, is near, New editions and reproductions of his works are to be seen in every bookstore.

Here we have a battle of wits between the District Attorney on one side and, on the other, Peter Clancy, private detective, and Captain Kerrigan of the New York police. Clancy and Kerrigan are old friends and find no difficulty in working in harmony, even though Clancy has no official standing.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Billy Winn of Detroit, driving the distance without a stop, today won the Illinois State Fair 100-mile dirt track automobile race for the second consecutive year. Winn's time was 1:14:39.09 for an average of 80.38 miles an hour.

FROM every section of the traveled world comes word of progress in railway passenger transportation. To meet the demand for speedier and more comfortable travel, a succession of faster trains has appeared, equipped with unusual features designed to make journeying far more pleasant.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Aug. 24. -- Lowell Observatory astronomers have found that the earth is surrounded by a brilliant, colored halo -- that plain Old Mother Earth is about the most gorgeous spectacle in creation, when seen from a distance.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Aug. 24. -- By a slim margin of four points, the Washington Canoe Club, national team title-holder, won the first annual Southern New Jersey canoe racing team championship on Clementon Park Lake today. The District of Columbia paddlers scored 24 points, the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York and the Yonkers Canoe Club of Yonkers, N.Y., tying for second place with 20 each.

EDITH M. STERN has always been especially deft at describing life and manners in New York when the brownstone era was approaching its shabby close. Perhaps the best chapters in the present novel are the earlier ones, in which the mnage of the Fosters is set before the reader.

LIGHTER-THAN-AIR transport, consigned to oblivion by a few admirals, placed on relief, so to speak, by both the Army Air Corps and the Naval Air Service, and of little immediate importance to the traveling public in this country, is very much alive.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Plans are already being made by younger members of the Summer colony as well as by their elders for numerous house parties and a variety of other social activities which will be features of the last two important week-ends of the season.

ROME, Aug. 24. -- The big motor ship Saturnia, formerly the pride of the Italian mercantile marine. left Naples for East Africa at 7 o'clock this evening, bearing 4,500 men of the Francisco Ferruccio Legion of Florence, belonging to the March 23d Division of Black Shirt volunteers.

Because of numerous threats from anti-Nazi elements, the Hotel Astor management has canceled arrangements for the German-American Technologists Association convention, which was to have been held there from Aug. 31 to Sept. 2.

Talks with many hikers on trails in the high northern Adirondack peaks, in the State Forest Preserve, disclosed the extent of the concern felt by those who appreciate the wilderness character of the preserve, guaranteed by Section 7 of Article VII of the State Constitution, over the projects of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

A course in philosophy which seeks to give a student an understanding of his own individual problems and ambitions will be included in the newly developed unified study division of the New York University Washington Square College which opens next month, Dean Milton E. Loomis announced yesterday.

Because of an unusual provision in a bond indenture, the holders of $12,140,000 of 5 1/4 secured serial bonds defauted by the Missouri Pacific Railroad are in a favored position to seize control of 1,600 miles of the company's line, it was disclosed yesterday in Wall Street investment circles.

Without imposing on your space for what may seem a personal matter, I nevertheless wish to correct certain errors of fact your John Martin made Aug. 18 in his Sunday column on the Dance. In recalling a conversation with me before the American ballet was organized, he now regrets I am no longer a director of that organization.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Pirates gave Cy Blanton errorless support today to defeat the Braves, 3 to 2, and Blanton recorded his fifteenth victory of the season.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- A ringer golf tournament, for men and women, will start off on the Homestead course tomorrow and will continue throughout the week. Practically all the golfers in the colony have entered, particularly in anticipation of the Fairacre Challenge Cup Golf Tournament, which gets under way on Saturday.

Twenty years ago, within twenty miles of Boston, a handful of ardent upland gunners developed a shooting game for their own amusement and pastime -- something to keep their gun-barrels warm and their aim "in" during the closed season.

The ideas of Dr. Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht, Herr Hitler's economic "wizard," clashed last week with the activities of Julius Streicher, leading Nazi anti-Semite, and of Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Propaganda Minister. Both sides looked to the Fuehrer for support; but Hitler, on vacation, failed to take a stand.
TOKYO, Aug. 24. -- Two young Americans were cleared by Japanese authorities today of suspicion of espionage.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- One of those threatening terrors of the main that call for thought along with desire broke up the fleet of Class M and twelve-meter sloops expected today for the final races in the series for the William H. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Vincent Astor Cups. With the off-fling of the West Indies hurricane cutting up capers off shore, only four of the eight competitors raced.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 (AP). -- United States Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa predicted tonight that President Roosevelt would be the principal issue of the 1936 Presidential campaign.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Glasgow Rangers went further ahead in the first division of the Scottish Soccer League as a result of games played today. The champions and cupholders had a hard battle at Ibrox Park against Dundee, but finally triumphed, 4 -- 3.

About 2,000 persons took part yesterday at Steeplechase Park, Coney Island, in a revival of the Irish Feis, a festival that flourished in Tara during the reign of King Cormac, two centuries before the arrival of St. Patrick in Ireland.

Puddle Muddle is an imaginary town inhabited by an odd little gnome-like man called Willy Nilly, Rip, his dog; Jelly Bear, Mr. and Mrs. Quacko Duck and others, whose adventures make up the tale. Unfortunately the spontaneity and humor and the absurd logic of true nonsense are lacking, with the result that the story moves along in somewhat heavy-footed fashion.

BOMBAY. -- The Nizam of Hyderabad, often called the richest man in the world and ruler of the biggest native State under the British Crown, is preparing to spend 1,000,000 (about $5,000,000) to celebrate his silver jubilee next October.

MR. DE MILLE has set the new season swinging on its way with his blazing historical carnival at the Astor. Like most De Mille shows, "The Crusades" occasionally causes you to shudder violently and ponder on the mischievousness or bad taste that persuaded the good doctor to plague his pageant with such dreadful stuff as the scene between Richard and Berengaria when the Lion Heart decides that he loves his wife more than the world.

The most considerate and quieting word about the Constitution recently uttered by the President was in his brief address to the Boy Scouts who called upon him in Washington. He truthfully said that the successful working of our Constitution depends upon the "attitude of mind and the degree "of spirit of unselfish cooperation that "has developed in individuals."

AS the motoring season progresses outcries come in from drivers protesting against road troubles which they claim have delayed, annoyed or endangered them, adding to the strain of driving and robbing their outings of much pleasure.

DURHAM, England, Aug. 24 -- Here in the heart of the coal country, a depressed area hardly touched by the general recovery, the unemployed gather in knots on street corners to discuss the startling possibility of Britain's being drawn into war by Italian aggression in Africa.

APPALLED by our current unbelief in God's existence and by the assumption on the part of many earnest people today that what used to be believed about the Deity is no longer true, Father D'Arcy, the author of this essay in apologetics, proposes to set the theistic and Christian ideal in contrast with the atheism and the agnosticism that have taken its place and have found favor in the hearts of many modern men.

LONDON. OXFORD, usually associated with black - gowned students, secluded velvety lawns and vigorous giants wielding oars, is the first town in Great Britain to provide a parking place for bicycles. The new park has accommodations for 150 bicycles, each one resting on a specially shaped steel channel which is raised off the ground.

A study of infant mortality in New York City since 1810, which refutes the popular belief that child deaths have been declining steadily for the last 100 years, was made public yesterday by the Department of Health.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 23. -- Sponsored by Senator Connally and Representative Jones, the export provision included in the AAA amendments sent to the President for signature last week are seen here as the beginning of a permanent solution of the problem confronting the Texas cotton industry.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Professional tennis matches will attract colonists of the North Jersey shore to Asbury Park Saturday night when former players at the annual tournaments of the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club will make their appearance at the Boardwalk Convention Hall as a part of the Colonial Terrace Tennis Club's annual program.

The rejection of more than 1,000, 000 pounds of foodstuffs intended for city institutions in the first six months of this year has focused attention on the big job of providing three meals a day for the inmates of New York's hospitals, prisons, homes and welfare agencies.

Two business agents of the joint council of the Fur Workers Union, an A.F. of L. group with headquarters at 28 West Thirty-first Street, were arrested in Jefferson Market Court yesterday while an associate was getting a preliminary hearing on charges of malicious mischief and assault.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A party of ten fishermen was rescued this morning by the Short Beach Coast Guard and the crew of a near-by fishing craft when their chartered 38-foot fishing cruiser K-11516, owned and piloted by Emil Bachmann of Bellmore, L.I., was swamped by heavy seas. The vessel was attempting to negotiate the passage through Jones Inlet to the ocean.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- A dinner honoring Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins, who on Monday, his seventieth birthday, will have served forty-nine years in public office, was given here tonight by members of the Masonic fraternity.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- Facts and reports combined anew today to demonstrate that in his fight against National Socialist extremists Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, finds himself in a minority in the Hitler government and that various Nazi drives against alleged State enemies will be continued, according to that "law of politics" outlined by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, in a speech yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Aug. 25. -- The first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress, within five minutes of an agreed adjournment at midnight by concurrent resolution, changed its decision in order to permit the cotton and wheat blocs in the Senate to make another effort tomorrow to add 400 millions of dollars to the national budget in guarantees of a twelve-cent cotton and one and one-half cent a pound wheat loan.

THE airplane racing pilots of the country, a daring, restless and impractical group of adventurers, are converging on Cleveland this week. For a few days they are quitting their prosaic jobs as fliers of the air mail, as test pilots for aircraft companies, as instructors in aviation schools or perhaps as clerks in shoe stores or farmers and salesmen, and are moving on to Cleveland's municipal airport, the scene again of the national air races.

NOT weather again took its toll of retail trade in the week, holding down volume in this vicinity to even with, or slightly under, that of a year ago and reducing gains in other centres. Where the temperatures moderated there were gratifying increases, indicating that climatic conditions have recently Been the chief influence upon retail business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- During the consideration in the House and Senate of the Banking Act of 1935 much speculation was rife as to what basic changes might be made in the control and functioning of the Federal Reserve System when the bill ultimately became law.
BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 24. -- At 4 o'clock tomorrow morning extensive Italian Army manoeuvres will begin in this Alpine district. They will last four days.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A gala circus party was held at the Sands Point Bath Club here tonight with several hundred members and their guests in attendance. The entertaining quarters of the club were decorated in circus motif with illuminated balloons, wall posters, gay banners and other paraphernalia of the "big top."

CONTRARY to what would seem to be the prevailing opinion, the Stadium Concerts Committee has pointed that the total attendance for the Summer series of symphony opera and ballet which closed last Wednesday night compares favorably with last Summer's total.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Distinguished leaders of every faith will participate in a religious inspirational service tomorrow afternoon, marking the formal opening of the ninth New York State Fair.

THIS new book by the Coles, equally famous as economists and as writers of detective stories, appears to be the first volume of a crime saga dealing with the adventures of a private detective named Dr. Tancred. Lest this description frighten the prospective reader into letting the book severely alone, it should be stated at once that "Dr. Tancred Begins" stands on its own feet and is complete in itself.

BERLIN. TWO artists, Max Mezger and Hans Ludwig Oeser, have created a beautiful book with the enticing little "Das nieverlorene Paradies," a volume of pictures of plant life in German woods, fields and gardens (Verlag der Gartenschoenheit, Berlin and Berne).

NOBODY will open this book expecting to find a new thing. Irving Bacheller in his seventies is just what he was in his forties when "Eben Holden" and "D'ri and I" gave him his hearing as a celebrant of the common man. The prophet of homespun is always in

HOMELY household furnishings, valued at first for their age and associations, are now discovered to be, not merely "quaint," but, in their own characteristic way, beautiful. To folk art the connoisseur goes for renewed inspiration, finding delight in the details and proportions of carved toy wooden animals and the artistic relationship between the light spindle back of a Windsor chair and its sturdy turned legs.

QUEBEC, Aug. 24. -- An increase in prices for Canadian newsprint in 1936 seems imminent and is responsible for considerable recent activity in newsprint stocks on Canadian markets, according to a financial column in the Quebec L'Evenement.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Labor leaders of New York State today were accused by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, of failure to give the Republican party credit "for its-interest in labor or for its efforts in passing labor bills."

ALTERNATING between his two major interests since retiring from the sea -- belles letters and fiction -- William McFee now offers us in this novel the well-sustained narrative of a captain who lost his command because of one woman and who was enabled to make a successful comeback because of his love for another.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Reds defeated the Phillies in both ends of a twin bill today and crawled up to a virtual tie for sixth place. The scores were 9 to 5 and 13 to 2.

PLENTY of pictures and a fair amount of art may be seen in Brussels during the exposition. The organizers of the Belgian "Century of Progress" have not been filled, as were their predecessors in Chicago, with the fear of having a high-brow show on the fair grounds.

BENUMBED by the loss of Wiley Post, one of the world's great pilots, and of Will Rogers, air transport's No. 1 passenger, who had traveled some 300,000 miles on scheduled airlines without injury, the aviation industry still was able to function with impressive speed and smoothness in the sad mission of flying the bodies of the two victims of their pioneering vacation jaunt to the scene of their funeral rites last week.

DOVER, England, Aug. 24 (AP). -- High wind, rain and a rough sea forced Eva Morrison, 25-year-old Boston hospital librarian, to give up an attempt today to swim the English Channel when she was within four miles of her goal, Cape Gris Nez, France.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2. -- Business for the most part marked time this week on the Pacific Coast. Retail merchandise was moving better at steady levels, with a few grocery items showing improvement over the previous week. Emporium Capwell, a leading department store here, in reporting earnings for the second quarter, confirms the recent belief that mercantile business is on the mend.

This tale of Mr. Penny and his animals should be greeted with jubilation and no doubt it will be, for it is one of the most delightful and entirely convincing bits of nonsense that has appeared in many a day and is a book that adults will find as entertaining as the 6 and 7 year olds to whom they may read it.

Italy, preparing for her offensive against Ethiopia, has been buying far more extensively in the United States than was generally supposed, export executives said here yesterday. A check by one trade group resulted in reports that large quantities of gasoline and oil, steel billets for use in the production of shell cases; copper, iron and steel scrap, cotton, trucks, machine tools and a variety of foodstuffs have been purchased.

Feminine fashion trends for this Winter, including those destined to oblivion as well as those headed for popularity, will come to judgment Sept. 11 in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel before a jury of 1,000 authorities from all corners of the country.

DALLAS, Aug. 23. -- With favorable weather all week in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, rain having fallen over most of the area, the upward swing in business continues. The Summer seasonal slump seems about ended, and reports indicate an early upturn in retail buying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Maine Central Railroad Company today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to "issue, sell and exchange" a total of $25,449,000 bonds in order to carry out a refinancing plan approved by the directors of the road on Aug. 8.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Two sparkling matches that necessitated extra holes today featured the quarter-final round of the first Arthur Man Memorial invitation best-ball golf tournament over the 6,537-yard Seaside links of the Seawane Club.
ROME, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The historical question: "What will Great Britain do?" absorbed Italy today.

CANTON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- War between Italy and Ethiopia would have "inter-color" reactions, according to Dr. Laurens Hickock Seelye, president of St. Lawrence University, who was for thirteen years an instructor at the America University of Beirut, Syria.

Those graying old-time yachtsmen who form the rocking chair fleet on the piazza of most of the clubs on the western waters of the Sound use an outmoded nomenclature all their own. Their memories are vivid of the days of sandbag catboats, for example, and they invariably talk about Cow Bay.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The automobile industry will reach the 3,000,000-unit mark in its 1935 production program within the next six weeks. This is indicated on the basis of output to date, the probable activity of the various plants between now and Oct. 1, and the demand that has kept several plants in production of current models well beyond the date set for switching over to next year's types.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The House tonight passed and sent to the White House a bill to extend until March 31, 1936, the time in which President Roosevelt may cancel existing ocean mail contracts.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 24. -- A musical satire on the New Deal, entitled "Bureau Crazy," will be presented at Walhall, on the estate of Mrs. Valeria Langeloth Bonham, patroness of the Valeria Home at Valhalla, N.Y., on Wednesday evening by the St. Paul's Dramatic Guild.

As an effort to solve the perennial pushcart problem, the new Park Avenue Market for which the Mayor broke ground last week is the most recent and outstanding example. It represents an effort to deal with the small vendor of fruits, vegetables and perishable foods, so that he may be well pleased and so that the public may buy his wares under sanitary conditions.

GREEN BAY, Wis. -- Tank cottage here, a wattle cottage, now said to be the oldest house in the Northwest, was honored at a commemorative ceremony here recently as a tribute to Nels Otto Tank and his wife, Caroline.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Harland (Hook) Beardslee of Newport Harbor won his second straight race of the international star class yacht series today, his expert sailing bringing By-C home in front of the Ace of Port Washington, N.Y., by the slender margin of 51 seconds.

Aubrey C. Neidecker of 829 Park Avenue, brother of Bertrand Coles Neidecker, American head of the closed Travelers Bank of Paris and the brokerage house of Neidecker Cie., New York and Paris, refused to answer questions about the bank's gold transactions yesterday on the ground that it might tend to incriminate him.
After return from a Maine shore holiday, memory's gallery holds these pictures in especially vivid recollection:

THESE two stories tell of child life in Norway a generation ago, with fresh and genuine charm. Little Sidsel, wearing the long skirt that gave her her nickname, first came to the big farm belonging to Kirsty Hoel to bring the yarn that her mother had spun.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Fish, flesh and fowl are sacrificing their skins for the new handbags. Schiaparelli prefers black ostrich feathers to boxcalf and stresses glazed shark for afternoon wear. The smartest types are large, often rectangular.

THE TIMES printed a letter from John Irving Dillon in which he commented on the statement I had made in my letter to you of July 5 that the first theatre to be built in America was erected in Williamsburg, Va., in 1716.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson opened headquarters today for his campaign for the Republican nomination for Mayor, and reports were current that a complete slate would accompany him into the primary.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article dealing with Sir James Barrie's recent entertainment of some seventy children between the ages of 8 and 10. He asked them what types of stories they preferred. It is interesting and rather shocking to note that twenty-six preferred fairy tales, animal stories, sea stories, , while forty-four preferred war stories.

SOME fifty years or more ago there existed in Tucson, Ariz., what Mr. Wellman, the author of this book, refers to as "the Tucson ring of government contractors." These gentlemen eked out a not too modest livelihood by furnishing supplies on Federal contract to the Indians on the reservations, among them the Apaches.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24. (Canadian Press). -- While agreeing that there were common bases for understanding with William Aberhart and his Alberta Social Credit party, H.H. Stevens, Reconstruction party leader, reserved comment today on the reported statement from Calgary by Mr. Aberhart that he would negotiate with Mr. Stevens with a view to joining forces for the Federal campaign.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Cornelia Otis Skinner (Mrs. Alden S. Blodget), will make her annual appearance in East Hampton next Friday evening at the John Drew Memorial Theatre, in her original solo drama "Mansion on the Hudson."

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Roxie Lawson, Detroit rookie, scored a 2-to-0 victory over the Red Sox today in his major league debut as the result of an error by Dahlgren, which provided the break in a pitching duel with the veteran Lefty Grove.

THE calendar indicates that the open season for bagging Summer wearables is nearly closed, but the weather charts prove that the present is an appropriate time for those who wish to replenish their cool wardrobes against the hydrophobic temperatures that seem habitually to mark the dog days.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 24. -- Racing past the faltering leaders as they collapsed down the stretch, Ted Luther, slim Ohioan, and Felix Serafin, husky up-State Pennsylvanian, deadlocked today for top money in the $4,000 Hershey open golf championship.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 24. -- There was a big program of sports and social affairs at the White Mountain resorts today, the gayest Saturday of the season.

WAYLAND, Mass., Aug. 24. -- "Curleyism" and dog racing, approved by the voters last year in a moment of "emotional recklessness," will soon be abolished if the Republican party purges itself of its traitors and "dead wood," declared Robert T. Bushnell, president of the Republican Club of Massachusetts, at the annual outing of the Somerville Republican City Committee at Sandy Burr Country Club here tonight.

LONDON. COLOR films, as exemplified in the Hollywood version of "Becky Sharp" after -- a long way after -- William Makepeace Thackeray, cannot be said to have taken London by storm. In fact, there is no indication that the picture-going public of this little village has welcomed the novelty with anything like the enthusiasm which Gotham, with its corresponding millions, is reported to have displayed.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24. -- Staying within striking distance of the most momentous triumph of their budding partnership, Wilmer Hines of Columbia, S.C., and Henry Culley of Santa Barbara, Calif., had the cup of victory dashed from their lips today in the national tennis doubles championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Evening-up operations for the week-end furnished today a good part of the trade in wheat on the Board of Trade, but news developments generally were in favor of lower prices, making the finish around the bottom at net losses of % to 1 cent a bushel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24. -- Arrangements have been completed by which Pierre Monteux will open the seventeenth season of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra on Nov. 14 in place of Otto Klemperer, who conducts the New York Philharmonic-Symphony during the first half of the season.

ON the last day of the long train trip to Inspiration Valley, an isolated region in the Canadian Rockies, Jack Deering met the Countess Vera Sorenson. That meeting was to prove momentous in its influence on Deering's life. He was a young and successful playwright, coming out to his cousin's ranch for a rest and then for work on a new play.

ONE of the most ambitious and important highway projects in the East is the extension of the Hutchinson River Parkway from its present terminus at the White Plains-Portchester Road (Route 119) to the Connecticut line and the construction from that point of more than thirty miles of the Merritt Parkway across Fairfield County to the New Haven County line at Devon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Joint resolution to deny citizens the right to sue the government for failure to observe the gold clauses in its obligations was adopted By the House today in the compromise form in which it passed the Senate last night, setting Jan. 1, 1936, as the last date on which such a suit could be commenced.

DITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The coming-out ball which Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay C. Hoguet of 59 East Eightieth Street, New York City, are to give at Council Grove, Stockbridge, next Saturday night for their youngest daughter, Miss Anne R. Hoguet, will climax a week of varied activities in the Berkshire Hills.

CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Horses from the Basil Cleland Stables at Bedminster, N.J., and ridden by Basil and Miss Muriel Cleland, took first honors in the first horse show of the Putnam County Driving and Riding Club today, winning five firsts, two seconds, a third and a fourth.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children will be the beneficiary of the Nestledown junior horse show, to be held next Saturday afternoon on the estate of Bernard E. Smith in Bedford Village.

CALGARY, Aug. 24. -- Declaring the integrity of the Province would be maintained, William Aberhart, whose Alberta Social Credit League soared to power in the Provincial election, today said investors in Alberta need have no fear of a Social Credit government.

POINT O' WOODS, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Horace Havemeyer Sr., accompanied by his son, today sailed his International Star Class boat, Vim, from third place to a tie for first with E.V. Ketcham Jr. by winning the final of a series of five elimination races to select a crew to represent the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association in the North Atlantic Star championship to be sailed in Moriches Bay next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- As the first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress drew to its conclusion, after an extraordinary grist of administration laws and a meeting of unusual duration, the reasonable conclusion might have been that the New Deal had been enacted, and the New Dealers were ready for the 1936 campaign of ratification.

MR. BESSIE is the latest writer to undertake the family chronicle. He has dealt with his people during three generations and, like many of his predecessors in the same field, dealt simultaneously with the changing face of American life.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Widespread speculation and concern following reports that the British Mediterranean fleet was to be strengthened with a view to further protection of trade routes to the East in case of war between Italy and Ethiopia brought prompt official denials today both in London and in Malta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Exports, including re-exports, amounted to $173,371,000 in July, compared with $170,184,000 in June and $161,572,000 in July, 1934, the Department of Commerce monthly analysis showed today, a gain of about 2 per cent over June, while imports increased 13 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23. -- At the moment jubilation rather than analysis dominates the reaction of most operators as well as miners of this district to the passage by Congress of the Guffey-Snyder Bituminous Coal Control or "Little NRA" Bill.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The Boerse registered confidence today to provide proper atmosphere for success of the new government loan of 1,000,000,000 marks, but gains and turnover remained small. Most changes were merely fractional. Heavy industrials were friendly, but only among lignites did gains exceed 1 point.

SINCE business linked trade names with radio stars and ethereal shows, Willem van Hoogstraten, director of the Portland Symphony Orchestra, wonders if the microphone does not feed too much dessert and too little bread and meat to the esthetically hungry."

EVERGREENS are particularly adapted for planting around the home because they liven up the whole landscape, especially during the dreary Winter months. They aid considerably in giving a house that cozy, livable appearance that all home owners cherish.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24 (AP). -- William F. Peterson, 52-year-old stock broker under indictment in New York on larceny charges in connection with an alleged $1,000,000 swindle, was arrested here tonight.

Among the passengers on the S.S. Atlantis en route from New York to Bremerhaven is Clarice Claremont, the girl who solved the mystery in "The Murder on Fifth Avenue." That, as we remember it, was a much better story than this one.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The refusal of the Postoffice Department to transfer the air-mail terminus for the New York metropolitan area from Newark Airport to Floyd Bennett Field was announced today, ending the long straggle between Mayor La Guardia and New Jersey officials with complete defeat for the former.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- With close to 500,000 men at their disposal, Federal and State forestry experts are rapidly bringing to a peak the most intensive forest protection campaign ever undertaken in this country. From Maine to California, denim-clad men are at work under the direction of competent foresters and technical experts strengthening the defenses of the forests against destructive fires and combating the attacks of disease and rodents that endanger forest and forage growth.

HERE'S for a hasty jotting down of ideas. Pretty nearly anything goes. Romance is found in Renaissance, comfort in peasant, dash in military and daring in Oriental styles. The main point is to pick the thing that best suits you and your environment.

The report of the American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on July 31 shows a net profit of $506,733 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $2.63 a share on 192,351 no-par shares of capital stock, excluding 754 shares held in the treasury.
NO writer is a fit judge of his own finished work. And conversely, too, it seems as if no writer is qualified to say whether a good movie has, or has not, been made from his book.

LONDON, Aug. 2. THE theatre in London and in the provinces has been surprisingly busy, but has produced, during the last fortnight, little of distinction. Mr. Shaw's "Simpleton," of which the United States had already given us ample warning, has been the leading piece of the Malvern Festival, but I have not seen it.

BEFORE the end of October, the last stretches of gravel on U.S. Highways 31 and 90, east of Mobile, will have been eliminated and this will provide a hard surface traveling all the way from New York and the East to New Orleans and the Mississippi Gulf Coast resorts via Washington, Richmond, Lynchburg, Greensboro, Atlanta, Montgomery and Mobile, it was announced last week by the New Orleans Association of Commerce.

SEVERAL unusual "catches" were made in the world-wide short-wave pool during the past week, when reception varied widely from day to day in regard to clarity and freedom from splashes of Summer static.

ICE cream trickled out on the Washington stage recently. Manufacturers of ice cream and of ice cream freezers were involved, and so was the Federal Trade Commission. There were words about lobbying. All of which means that ice cream has become a child of big business.

LIKE the sea slowly beating down its cliffs, shifting social values cut gradual inroads upon traditional New England. In his first novel Mr. Howe has turned a sympathetic focus upon an adjustment to modernity in a small cove of that coast, a cove where tides beat more gently than along the headland.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Two round-robins, with twenty-four players competing and more than 100 horses on hand, filled the two Phipps fields to capacity today as a number of the open championship players engaged in limbering-up play before tomorrow's test games to be played at the Meadow Brook Club, Bostwick Field and Sands Point.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Chiefs and clan mothers of the Cayuga nation today began negotiations which seek to adjust the differences between the tribe an the United States, which began when the first President was in office.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- Coast shipping interests were much encouraged this week by growing activity in the lumber export and intercoastal trade as evidenced by the taking of several steamers off the disengaged list. Among the vessels placed in commission are the Davenport, Harpoon and Windrush, which had been idle for months because of strike conditions.

NEWPORT, R.I. RHODE ISLAND, for nearly two centuries accustomed to entertaining Summer visitors both from this country and abroad, this season has been playing host to larger throngs than in half a dozen years. Among the pleasure seekers are many strangers, blot also many who come here often -- for the State's resorts are of the type that people become attached to: families return year after year, some of them generation after generation.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Set aside for many years in White Sulphur Springs to honor the achievements and traditions of General Robert E. Lee, the last week in August is again being observed as Lee Festival Week.
GENEVA, Aug. 24. -- The supervisory commission created under the 1931 treaty to limit the manufacture of narcotics to medicinal needs closed its seventh session here today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23. -- The tourist season in Moscow begins about the middle of June and ends the middle of September, reaching its peak in July and August, when one large vessel of the "Northern Lights" or Scandinavian Summer cruises may land several hundred tourists in Leningrad in a single day to visit palaces there.

SLIGHTLY higher prices than those of a year ago are expected for the new Fall radio sets, many of them introducing the all-metal tubes, according to the Standard Statistics Company. As a result, earning prospects of manufacturers are described as "moderately improved."

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23. -- The Chaco Peace Conference has ceased to function without ever having really started on its mission. The American delegate, Hugh Gibson, has returned to his post as Ambassador to Brazil and two Bolivian delegates, Bautista Saavedra and Juan Maria Zalles, have abandoned their delegation and returned to La Paz to lead the political opposition against President Tejada Sorzano.

NORRIS, Tenn., Aug. 24 (AP). -- The one-millionth cubic yard of concrete will be poured into the glistening, white hulk of the Tennessee Valley Authority's $34,000,000 Norris Dam before New Year's Day, bringing the massive storage and power project to completion in slightly more than two years.

Police of the Marine Division were dragging the East River off Corlears Hook yesterday for the body of Lillian Keller, 14 years old, of 610 East Fifth Street, who was believed drowned when a rowboat in which she and four friends were having a moonlight trip was struck by a tug on Friday shortly before midnight.

TOKYO. -- After disturbing Japanese politics for nearly a year the "Minobe affair" was put to rest (as the Cabinet hopes) by a government declaration on the nature of the Japanese Constitution. It was a peculiarly "Japanese" controversy, scarcely appearing rational in Western eyes.
SIMSBURY, Conn., Aug. 24. -- Each believing the other dead, two sisters who had not seen each other for seventy years have been reunited.

ONE does not read the words of the late Count Albert Apponyi of Hungary on the subject of music without a thrill. They constitute the simple and sincere expression of a great man whose career was political, but whose nature drew to a focus many aspects of thought and experience that enrich life.

WARSAW, Aug. 24. -- Taking two more matches, from France by 3 1/2 -- 1/2, and Latvia by 2 1/2-- 1 1/2, the Swedish chess team kept well in advance of all the other nations competing in the international tournament at the Army Officers' Casino, where adjourned games from the ninth and tenth rounds were played in the first session today.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Resolute, which holds the record among transatlantic ships for voyages around the world, was retired from commercial service last week. The sale of the vessel to the Italian Government, which plans to operate her as a troop ship, was announced in Hamburg and the assignment of the Reliance as the line's 1936 world cruise ship to replace the Resolute was announced in New York.

AIRCRAFT -- planes, blimps, autogiros -- are being tried successfully in directing automobile traffic in the vicinity of large cities. Now it looks as if New York will join London, and various communities in New Jersey, in controlling large movements of cars with aerial assistance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Joseph W. Madden, chairman of the new Labor Relations Board, said today that the board probably would be ready to receive complaints and election petitions in about two weeks.

AT Kent, Conn., the Kent Art Association's thirteenth annual exhibition, containing 177 works by living artists together with a group of early American "primitives," will continue through Sept. 1. G. Glenn Newell, Arthur Powell, Robert Nisbet, Harry F. Waltman, William McKillop, A. Sheldon Pennoyer, Ezra Winter, Dines Carlsen and F. Luis Mora are among the exhibiting artists.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 23. -- The attitude of the Corn Belt farmer toward the amended farm bill is mainly one of tentative approval. He is inclined to accept it on faith without knowing a great deal about it, on the assumption that it is meant in the further interest of agriculture and deserves moral support until and unless it proves itself otherwise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- A second attempt to explore the stratosphere will be made by the National Geographic Society and Army Air Corps in October, if weather conditions are favorable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Regulations providing not more than $6 month each to aid needy young people between the ages of 16 and 25 who are unable to attend school because of lack of money for lunches, clothes and carfare, were announced today by the National Youth Administration.

PANAMA, R.P. -- A perennial complaint in Latin America concerns the fact that the people of North America know so little about their neighbors to the south. Newspapers in the United States and their correspondents in Latin America are charged with responsibility for this situation.
BAY SHORE, L.I. Aug. 24. -- Assistant District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry announced today that five men caught in a gambling raid had been dropped from relief rolls.

AFTER a year at the head of Ontario's overwhelmingly Liberal government, Mitchell F. Hepburn, 38-year-old Premier of Canada's most popular Province, remains the most interesting figure on the Canadian political scene.

ARTHUR GUITERMAN writes verse as easily and urbanely as a raconteur makes conversation. Within the memory of man he has turned out prodigious quantities of it. Many of the leading public prints would not dream of going to press without a Guiterman sonnet or quatrain somewhere in the issue.

TETERBORO AIRPORT, N.J., Aug. 24. -- An eighteen-passenger Curtis Condor plane, owned by Colonel Clarence D. Chamberlin, transatlantic flier, was seized through a court order here today to settle a judgment against the aviator for $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- A further increase in steel-mill activity, a new high mark for the season in electric light output, a rise in wholesale prices and a continued advance in stock prices featured business statistics last week, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

WHEN Nature has gone down into the deep valley of the year and snow blots out the enchanting pictures of Summer garden plots, there is still a breath of Spring that even the veriest amateur can create and share with others if he will but get to work now.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Problems of far-reaching importance confront the United States in the threatened war between Italy and Ethiopia. The government is bending every effort to avoid becoming involved in the dispute, and to that end is prepared to apply drastic neutrality measures. At the same time the objectives of the government include feasible contributions to the prevention of war.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP). -- From western skies an airplane landed here today bearing the ashes of Richard Arnett, aviation pilot, and his young bride and Burnside Smith, Indianapolis business executive, who died with the couple when his plane crashed into a rugged Wyoming mountain peak last week.

A long-time plan for the taking over of more than 5,000,000 hilly and unfertile acres of New York land, once settled by hardy pioneers but now considered unfit for farming, is expected to receive new impetus soon with Governor Lehman's appointment of a permanent State Planning Council, as recently authorized by the State Legislature.

The present comparatively slow pace of industrial loans by banks will neither be accelerated nor retarded by the Banking Bill, which was signed by President Roosevelt late last week, according to the opinions of leading bankers here yesterday.

For the time being he serenely pursues his old-fashioned way.

NEWPORT, Aug. 24. -- The White Elephant Ball was given tonight by a committee of the young people of the Summer colony headed by Miss Penelope Winslow. It took place at the Newport Country Club. The ballroom and the large sun room were elaborately decorated with illuminated balloons, flowers and foliage plants.
PARIS, Aug. 14. -- Americans are taking part in the social entertaining that is going forward at most of the principal cure and pleasure resorts in France.

MINDFUL that the ear and a sense of touch at the dial do not always facilitate accurate tuning, designing engineers have equipped many of the new 1935-36 radios with visual tuners so the eye cart aid the ear.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- The peak of the White Mountain season is reached today, with a large number of gay house parties being held throughout the hills. Many distinguished guests have arrived at private homes and at hotels.

Curley of Massachusetts in backing an anti-Nazi resolution adopted by the State House of Representatives after it had drawn the protest of the German Consul General in Boston.

Pressure was lifted yesterday from United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Recoveries of 2-32 to 12-32 point ruled throughout the list on a turnover of $2,208,300, compared with sales of $276,600 the Saturday before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Only a telephone connected President Roosevelt, seated in the calm cool of the White House, with the hurly-burly of Congress tonight.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 24. -- A gift by Williams College of a 1,700-acre estate to the Federal Government for a forestry experimental station has been revealed. The property, given to the college in November, 1933, by Mrs. M. Theresa B. Hopkins of Boston, widow of Colonel Lawrence Hopkins, was known as Buxton Farms. It was valued at $100,000 a few years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Exports of scrap iron and steel from the United States during the first half of the present year topped by a substantial margin exports for any previous six-month period on record. Department of Commerce figures show that foreign purchases for this period totaled 1,154,226 gross tons, valued at $12,502,120, as against 738,848 tons, valued at $7,655,906, for the first six months of 1934.

Curley of Massachusetts in backing an anti-Nazi resolution adopted by the State House of Representatives after it had drawn the protest of the German Consul General in Boston.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24. -- The inner line of the Yankee defense teetered again today at a critical moment, the pitching sagged, and the Yanks lost another ball game to the Browns at Sportsmans Park, a game they could ill afford to drop.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- The foreign exchange market here still is quiet and is characterized mainly by the strength of sterling, which is well above 75 francs to the pound. This firmness in sterling is considered here as being connected with the recovery in the raw-material markets.

With points as distant as Tacoma, Wash., and Galveston, Texas, represented, the sixteenth annual convention of the National Association of Negro Musicians opened with a mass meeting in Wadleigh High School yesterday afternoon. The attendance was estimated at 1,000, with large representation from Indiana, Missouri, Illinois and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Facing the greatest legislative crisis thus far in his administration, President Roosevelt was being looked to tonight for prompt and definite action to prevent a rebellious Congress from scuttling his agricultural program and to end the present session before further damage is threatened to his recovery plans.

Prices of cotton, both spot and future, broke sharply on Friday, following the Government's unexpected announcement of a 9-cent lending rate for this year's crop. The net change in prices on the New York Cotton Exhange in the week was a decline of 75 to 96 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A new record for registration of security issues was set in July, when registration statements covering $530,474,751 in stocks and bonds became effective, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- It still is difficult for observers here to make up their minds whether the improvement now noticeable in business conditions in the United States is because of or in spite of the administration's policy. There is no doubt, it is believed, that politics has interfered with business progress in the United States.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 25 (AP). -John Barleycorn, a furtive fellow in the Lone Star State for the last sixteen years, was returned to citizenship today by a quarter-million Texans.

In connection with the offering to the public next week of $16,900,000 first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1965 of the Philadelphia Suburban Water Company by an underwriting group headed by Hornblower Weeks, arrangements have been made, at the company's request, to afford present holders of called bonds a prior opportunity to exchange their bonds for the new ones.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 25. -- Japanese trade with Peru has continued to develop this year almost as phenomenally as it did in the two preceding years. In the first five months of 1935 Peru's imports from Japan showed an increase of more than 1,000,000 soles over the same period of 1934, the figures being 4,157,702 soles, against 3,154,137.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Fluctuations in prices on grain futures here last week covered a considerable range and closed with net gains on wheat futures of 2 1/4 to 3 cents a bushel. Corn was unchanged to 1/4 cent higher, oats were up 5/8 cent, with rye 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents net higher.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Aug. 25.-The first Sunday horse show to be held on the North Shore, the last day of a three-day event, attracted more than 500 persons today.

Lou Salica, who fought for the United States in the last Olympic Games, will make his bid for the bantamweight championship of the world tonight when he opposes Sixto Escobar, hard-hitting Porto Rican battler, in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at Dyckman Oval.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25. -- The Chaco peace conference has been the scene of American diplomatic failure in the name of idealistic humanitarianism. Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson's project for the liberation of war prisoners has been coldly rejected by Paraguay in the name of international law.

Even the opponents of the President can take little exception to the address which he made Saturday evening to the convention of Young Democrats at Milwaukee. It was couched in generalities, thus provoking no criticism of special policies of his own. It was also nonpartisan in tone, and in excellent taste.

" Broken Headlight" is concerned about minor damages to his automobile, for which he was unable to collect because of the financial irresponsibility of the person causing the damage. He desires to know why collision insurance is not available at rates within the reach of the vast number of owners of low-priced cars.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Experiments with motors of a type that might be used to propel rockets into the stratosphere ended for the day when a motor exploded at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Fragments of hot metal were scattered over a field behind the home of G. Edward Pendray, 491 Westchester Avenue, Crestwood, president of the American Rocket Society.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- In the opinion of many of his colleagues, Senator Tydings of Maryland attained the topmost heights of congressional humor Friday night during his successful filibuster against the Flood Control Bill, which would have authorized an appropriation of $500,000,000 for rivers and harbors improvement, subject to the approval of the army engineers.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 25. -- The Danish Army's biggest seaplane was rushed to Greenland today via the Faroe Islands; Reykjavik, Iceland, and Scoresby Sound to rescue four Danes trapped on the ice off East Greenland in an open motor boat with no provisions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP). -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman heads a long list of high State and service officials who have accepted invitations to attend the annual State convention of the American Legion here from Thursday to Saturday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Seymour Knox's Aurora four turned back the Long Island poloists, led by Johnny Fell, in the weekly high-goal engagement at the Sands Point Club today. The score was 8 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The resignations of Secretary Wallace and Chester C. Davis, AAA administrator, were forecast by friends tonight in the event the cotton and wheat price-pegging amendments to the third Deficiency Appropriation Bill were enacted into law.
WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 25 (AP). -The powerful armies of two imaginary nations sprang at each other at dawn today in one of the greatest war games ever staged.

Edwin Hamlin Carr, retired pastor formerly associated with St. Stephen's Methodist Church, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Metropolitan Methodist Church at Thirteenth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Domestic rates for electricity in the various cities, towns and villages of New York State are the subject of a recent survey by the Federal Power Commission. They show a wide spread between minimum and maximum charges. Thus the Jamestown public plant sells the housewife 25 kilowatts of electric energy for 88 cents, while the Auburn private plant bills her $2.50 for the same amount.

Alternative plans to cut red tape and speed up the rate at which persons on home relief are transferred to jobs of the Works Progress Administration were in readiness yesterday in the event that the one going into effect today proves unsatisfactory.

OCTAVE, Ariz., Aug. 25. -- The up-to-the-minute prospector is letting a washing machine motor "wash" his gold for him.

Four hundred chambers of commerce were invited yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, to cooperate in the movement started by the chamber to coordinate the efforts of citizens throughout the country to solve the fiscal problems facing taxpayers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- For the second day in succession Lawrence Marx's interclub craft Alberta led the fleet today in the special races conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club. Yesterday the Marx boat won her race in the New York Athletic Club regatta.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- It was reported today that clashes between the Catholic Youth and Hitler Youth groups in Catholic sections of Western Germany were mostly the result of attempt by Nazi authorities to force the former into the Hitler Youth ranks.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 25. -Bronzed and active despite his years, August Heckscher, philanthropist and head of the Heckscher Foundation, enjoyed himself as the guest of nearly 600 children today at a birthday party in his honor at the Heckscher Camp, Adams Corners, six miles north of here.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Browns turned back the Senators twice today, 3 to 2 and 7 to 6, before 7,500 fans, taking both games by checking rallies in the late innings.

MILAN, Italy, Aug. 25. -- Touring American athletes finished second to Italian track and field stars in a tri-nation meet on a rain-swept field today. The Italians scored 48 points, the Americans 36 and the French 15.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP). -- The third race of the international Star Class series was won today by the sloop Three Star Too of San Francisco, sailed by Glenn Waterhouse, the 1933 international champion. Waterhouse covered the ten-mile course, windward and leeward, in 2 hours 20 minutes 30 seconds.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, representing rises of 2 points in a week and of 10 points in 5 weeks. The rate is the highest since June, 1934, excepting three or four weeks early this year.

WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 25. -- With Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier and Walter B. Eaton leading the attack, the South Shore poloists routed the Central Park Hunt Club riders, 11 to 5, in the weekly match at Hazard Field today.

When one nation says to another that if it does not do what is demanded a serious consequences" will follow, it is time for the latter to give due heed the warning. This is what the Government of the United States has now said to the Soviet Government in Moscow.

OTTAWA, Aug. 25. -- A delegation composed of J.H. Woods, a Calgary newspaper editor; Professor Montpetit of McGill University, and Miss Frances Kydd of Montreal, will leave Canada this week for Geneva to represent the Dominion at the forthcoming meeting of the League of Nations Assembly.
