SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The race meeting here will begin its final week tomorrow with a fine outlook that the juvenile championship will be clarified by the running of the $25,000 Hopeful Stakes on Saturday, and with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt deluged with offers requesting the appearance of his crack colt Discovery.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- No European country is better versed in the niceties of diplomacy than Great Britain. Quite naturally, therefore, official comment on the neutrality legislation now being adopted by the United States is impossible to obtain.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25. -- One of the strongest notes of protest in post-war diplomatic history was presented to Nikolai Krestinsky, Acting Commissar for Foreign Affairs, by United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt at 4 P.M. today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 25. -The cases of Italy and Ethiopia in connection with the Ualual clash went today to the original four conciliators for judgement. The commission, in a four-hour secret session this morning, finished its examination of witnesses, heard the closing arguments and decided to return to Paris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- From New York City projects totaling $46,508,188 General Hugh S. Johnson, PWA administrator, has been instructed to select those for which a $35,000,000 allotment made today by President Roosevelt will be expended.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP). -The Phillies defeated the Reds in the final game of the series today, 12 to 10. The Phils scored five runs in the first inning on three hits and three Cincinnati errors, but the Reds came back with eight in the second.

" The cotton situation presents one of the most striking illustrations of the unsoundness of the 'economy of scarcity,'" the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in its current issue of the Guaranty Survey. Discussing the country's loss of foreign cotton markets, the bank attributes the recent decline in exports largely to the activities of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Laddie Sanford's Long Island Hurricanes administered an 8-7 setback to the British Hurlingham polo team today in a match which served as preparation for the forthcoming national championship, in which both teams will compete.

The volume of orders coming in to the local wholesale markets was substantial last week, with price advances on a number of apparel and home furnishings lines forcing buyers to expand their budgets. The heat in many sections was responsible for keeping the total of commitments down, however.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- Officers of the British Army transport Neuralia received sudden orders today to take 1,200 troops to Malta next Saturday or earlier to reinforce the garrison there, which is said to be undermanned.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, asserted in a sermon yesterday morning at St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, that it was not fantastic to foresee even in this country a time when, because of persecution, some persons might have to die for their faith.

GENOA, Italy, Aug. 25. -- A towering waterspout swept into the city from the harbor early tonight, killing at least six persons and injuring more than fifty. The spout made its appearance in the midst of an electrical storm. A large section of the waterfront was reduced to tangled wreckage.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Prices of hogs had a sharp setback last week, dropping 10 to 65 cents a hundred-weight, led by butcher hogs exceeding 275 pounds and sows weighing more than 400. Packers paid $12.20 at the opening of the week and $11.55 at the close, a drop of 65 cents. In the previous week $12.20 was the top, with the close at $12.15.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25. -- Headed by Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, five-time winner of the title, the nation's stars are assembled here for the thirty-ninth national women's golf championship, which is to be played at the Interlachen Country Club this week.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, in his Koenigsberg speech emphasized the need to consolidate the Reich's floating debt. This has induced the rumor that a new long-term loan will be announced immediately.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Commerce Department's world economic review of 1934, issued today, summarized conditions in other leading countries as follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the piano recital by Hans Barth, a composer and director of the National School for Musical Culture, which was given this afternoon at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng, in Halsey's Neck Lane for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of Long Island.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The biggest crowd that has ever seen a polo game at Bostwick Field filled both grand stands and stood four deep along the sideboards at the end of the field today as Templeton took a very well played test from Greentree, 11 to 8.

Max Reinhardt, whose film production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" for Warner Brothers will reach New York Oct. 9, will come to America shortly to produce another Shakespeare play for the company, according to Jacob Wilk, manager of the Warner story department, who has just returned from Europe.

To the Young Democrats at Milwaukee Governor EARLE of Pennsylvania brought a message worthy of the proud traditions of his State. Through foreign trade woe and ruin descended upon the United States, even in the days of the Republicans, almost as chary about transacting business with foreigners as the Governor is.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- Recurring rumors that Reichsfuehrer Hitler is suffering from a serious affliction of the throat were definitely dispelled today through an official communique that said the Fuehrer on May 23 had submitted to a minor surgical operation for the removal of a polypus on his right vocal ligaments and that his voice had been restored to its normal strength.

Far gone though the Summer theatre season is, it nevertheless will bring ten new plays to the rustic stages this week -- one more than was scheduled for last week. The plays, opening tonight unless otherwise noted, are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt swung back to the decentralized methods of the Civil Works Administration today in his drive to put punch into the dragging work relief program.

The increasing complexity of government laws and regulations has served materially to increase the problems of business houses and has caused them to appeal in greater numbers to the Merchants Association for assistance, according to the annual report of S.C. Mead, secretary of the organization, made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The radio address delivered tonight by Representative Snell of New York in reply to President Roosevelt's talk to the country last night was as follows:

" The Green Pastures," which Marc Connelly fashioned from Roark Bradford's book, will not go on tour this year. Except for the Summers and minor vacations, it had played since 1930. The movies have bought it, and they want most of the main players for the picture.

Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration, announced yesterday that for the week ended last Saturday eighty applications for mortgage insurance, representing $559,680, were received.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- To make clear why Congress, at five minutes before midnight Saturday, tore up its concurrent adjournment resolution for Aug. 24 and is still on hand this week as a threat to recovery and the reputation of the Democratic party leadership, it is necessary to restate the situation and relist the factors.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Pine Camp, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Serious and startling deficiencies in equipment and in officer and "noncom" personnel, and insufficient training, particularly of National Guard troops, have been revealed in the past week during the manoeuvres here of the First Army.

One of the largest apartment house deals of the present season in the Bronx has just been closed in the purchase of the two six-story multi-family buildings at 2,167 and 2,187 Cruger Avenue, in the easterly section of the borough, by the Exchange Estate, an investing syndicate headed by Isadore B. Geller and Max Rosenfeld.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25. -New national champions in the veterans' and father-and-son tennis doubles were crowned at the Longwood Cricket Club today and play in the mixed event was brought down to the final round.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The conviction in Germany is that British policy alone will determine the decision of the League of Nations with respect to the Italo-Ethiopian dispute. As a result, considerable comment was aroused by the relative firmness of London's last official communique and the sharp anti-Italian interventionist attitude of certain British journals which usually advocate abstention from international entanglements.

Calling Christianity a "mockery in its feebleness," the Rev. Frederick W. Golden-Howes, dean of Christ Cathedral, Salina, Kan., asserted in a sermon yesterday that it might well control the destinies of both nations and peoples. He preached at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, on "The Modern Christ."

Improvement in the method of measuring eye defects of children was reported yesterday by Dr. Edwin Forbes Tait, Professor of Optometry at the Pennsylvania State College of Optometry, at the opening session of the fourteenth annual convention of the American Academy of Optometry at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Aug. 25. -- With more than 3,500 persons present, the first annual picnic of the Kings County and Nassau-Suffolk district councils of the Steuben Society of America was held here this afternoon and evening at the Plattdeutsche Volkfest Park.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Aug. 25. -- Out of the Northwestern conference of Young Republicans, which ended its sessions yesterday, Senator Borah emerged as a favorite candidate for the Republican nomination for President. Senator Robert D. Carey of Wyoming today declared that the sentiment for Mr. Borah had arisen spontaneously and without any stimulation by either the Idaho Senator or his admirers.

There is great danger, if the talk about automobile accidents goes on without active comment from drivers, of the enactment of a lot of laws which will be generally ignored and which will miss the point.

People unable to see the necessity of adaptation and change, even if that means scrapping the rule for the sake of the principle, will not survive the present spiritual, economic and political upheaval, the Rev. Dr. Philip Allen Swartz, secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, warned the congregation at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A 6 per cent increase in industrial production in the first seven months of this year as compared with the same period in 1934 was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in its monthly summary of business conditions.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 25. -- The cotton market here last week was at times rather active and at other rather dull. The dominating factors were the conflicting reports on the policy of the government on loans for the current season. Favorable advices as to the progress of the crop helped at times to give a downward trend to prices, but Senator Bankhead's statement that the 12-cent loans would be continued served to rally values.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Activity in business and manufacturing in this territory improved last week, taken as a whole. Gains were more numerous and larger than they had been recently, although a few lines failed to report material advances. Comparisons with conditions a year ago were favorable for this year, and wholesale distributers of merchandise reported indications of greater activity for the balance of the year.

On San Juan Hill life is gruff and habits are hard. There have been times, indeed, when policemen have patrolled the district in anxious pairs, eyes upturned to rooftops, where "cop killers" have been known to crouch behind chimney-tops and smash bricks down on the heads of the uniformed law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- In a voluminous report analyzing Federal Farm Board losses through Stabilization Corporation purchases of cotton and wheat, through loans to the cooperatives of the country and in other activities, the special Senate agricultural sub-committee, headed by Senator Charles McNary of Oregon, declared that "inexperience, extravagance, avarice and in a few cases dishonesty on the part of officials and employes of some of the cooperatives increased these losses."

HOLMDEL, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Scottish clansmen had their choice today of whether to attend the annual field day of the Caledonian Society of Monmouth County, to which they were all-invited, at the Holmdel sylvan forum of Theron McCampbell, or the first annual foregathering of the State Order of Scottish Clans as guests of Governor Hoffman at Sea Girt.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America voted tonight to call off the fifteen-week strike at the plant of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation under terms of an arbitration plan proposed last week by President Roosevelt.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Six amateur aviators, bound for the national air races at Cleveland, hopped off from the Los Angeles Municipal Airport today for Yuma, Ariz., the first stop on Miss Chatterton's air derby.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles dropped both ends of a double-header to the Newark Bears today, losing the first, 6 to 3, and the nightcap, 10 to 6. A muffed fly by Cazen in the fourth inning of the second game, with three on and two out, resulted in five gift runs for Newark.
ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's first test at the ballot box in 1936 is expected in Georgia.
With the seemingly inevitable at hand, the careening Giants, who for weeks have been flirting with disaster, fought courageously to the last drop at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- The Yankees broke even with the White Sox before a gathering of 40,000 fans at Comiskey Park today, but they lost the services of Earle Combs, perhaps for the season, and struck a new low in their distance from the first-place Tigers.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Scoring four runs in the fifth inning, the Tigers took the first of a six-game series from the Athletics, 6 -- 3, today as Elden Auker registered his thirtenth triumph of the season.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,258,331,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Preceded by an advance detachment of thirty-six men led by Captain Medard N. Suprenant, which moved into Camp Smith yesterday, the main body of the 258th Field Artillery of the Bronx, 650 men, commanded by Colonel Paul Loeser, ar rived here today by train for two weeks of training in small arms.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Developments in the world's wheat situation are more interesting and are attracting greater attention, and operators look forward to more uncertainty in the future than has been in evidence for some time. An unsettled political situation abroad is considered one that might develop seriously within the next few months and in such case many men in the grain trade are more disposed to caution in their operations.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert, who have Milton W. Holden among their guests at Anglesea, were hosts at the principal dinner party here this evening. They had about fifty guests.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 25. -- There is a whitewashed stone in the main driveway of the Saratoga track and on the stone the date "1864" is painted in black letters, indicating the year that racing started at Saratoga Springs. Down town in the little park there is a wide red brick building of three stories and the sign over the front doorway reads "Saratoga Municipal Museum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Improvement in general business conditions in the United States in 1934, marked by the better condition of agriculture and the financial structure, including profits and dividend payments, but offset by the irregular state of industrial improvement, widespread unemployment and "tight" private financing, was reported today in the annual World Economic Review of the Department of Commerce.

Ground will be broken at the foot of Grand Street at noon Wednesday to celebrate the beginning of work on the first link of the proposed East River Drive. Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan announced yesterday a program in which civic organizations and delegations from the Police, Fire, Park and Sanitation Departments will participate.

Movements of prices of commodities were mixed in rather active trading here last week. Sugar advanced it heavy trading in all but the final session, when profit-taking wiped out most of the gains for the week. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats, flour, rubber, raw sugar, pork, copper, lead, zinc, tin, wool tops and hides were higher, while coffee, cocoa, cotton, silk and lard were lower.

For the second time within a year the famous Dean brothers have made baseball history at Ebbets Field. Last September Paul hurled a no-hit classic and Dizzy a three-hit shut-out to win a crucial double-header from the Dodgers and shoot the Cardinals toward a pennant and a world championship.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- The international situation in general is considered delicate and financial circles realize that the position is difficult because France must endeavor to retain Italy's friendship while remaining faithful to League of Nations principles, application of which is being required by Great Britain.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Field Marshall, impressive big bay gelding owned by the Rolling Rock Farms of Richard K. Mellon of Ligonier, Pa., today was awarded the championship rosette in the hunter division, the final event of the sixth annual North Shore Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Old Field Club.

Albert Lowenfels's double-ended ketch Tidal Wave barely got under the wire in time to take top honors in the auxiliary division, while G.I. Steffen's small sloop Spinster won among the sailing division craft as the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight races ended yesterday.

Thirteen Chinese Boy Scouts of a delegation that arrived recently from China to attend the postponed jamboree saw the sights at Coney Island last night and fulfilled symbolically their Scout traditions of prowess on land, on the sea and in the air.

It was reported from Bucharest last week that in a little Rumanian town a thousand people took part in a street battle over the calendar. Several were killed and many injured. It all came about from the parish priest's celebrating the church festivals in accordance with the calendar of JULIUS CAESAR.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 25. -- With the kindly assistance of a bit of geographic scrambling, the West defeated the East in the annual intersectional matches at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today, 5 to 2. A "Westerner" from South Carolina, Wilmer Hines, clinched the engagement early in the afternoon, and the two encounters that followed served as little more than exhibitions.

Anne Lindbergh's "North to the Orient" places first in non-fiction sales on the lists of all the New York stores reporting for this week's best-seller list. This is the first time such unanimity has been noted. Even at the height of its sale "Anthony Adverse" was not listed first by all stores.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 25 (AP). -A vigorous "no" was the cotton trade's response to the proposed twelve-cent cotton loan which tied Congress into a legislative snarl Saturday.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 25. -- With a steady, fresh breeze coming out of the Southwest, fleet of fifty-two yachts competed today in the first invitation sailing regatta on Zach's Bay, under the auspices of the Great South Bay Y.R.A., in conjunction with The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The final week-end dinner dance of the season at the Maidstone Club will take place next Saturday night. The dance will be an immigrant ball. All nations of the world will be represented in the costumes for that evening.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Stalwart Walter Rothenberg of the Winged Foot Golf Club, who distinguished himself on the football field and on the links at Lafayette between 1930 and 1934, today assaulted par with consummate ease, with the result that he and Lester Rice of Lido captured the first Arthur Man memorial best-ball invitation golf tournament at the Seawane Club.
The city administration moved yesterday to get for its welfare cases the Federal assistance promised under the new Social Security Act.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 25. -- Ted Luther of Girard, Ohio, formerly of Corry, Pa., won the Hershey open golf championship today, defeating Felix Serafin of Scranton, Pa., in a second eighteen-hole play-off. Luther carded a 75, two over par, and Serafin 80.

LAMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 25. -Savings of $1,000 left by two boys who were drowned July 10 at Burnt Mills, N.J., have been donated by their parents as a memorial fund for the renovation of Lamington Presbyterian Church, one of the oldest churches in the State.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The World Zionist Congress heard a demand from Kurt Blumenfeld, German delegate, for a world campaign to educate Jewish youth to resist "persecution." Mr. Blumenfeld said that while Nazi attacks on Jews were the most spectacular, there was a systematic persecution in Persia, Iraq and Afghanistan.

Strong northerly winds blowing in here from the Canadian provinces chilled the city and its environs yesterday, bringing temperatures down to within 2 degrees of the record low for the date. At 7:45 A.M. the official thermometers read 57 degrees.

PAPEETE, Tahiti, Aug. 25 (AP). -A dynasty that ruled Eastern Polynesia for about 1,300 years has come to an end in the death here of Tahitoe, the last surviving son of the last reigning King of Raiatea. Tahitoe died here Aug. 9 at the age of 87.

POINTE AUX BARQUES, Mich., Aug. 25 (AP). -- William Lyon Phelps, Professor Emeritus of English Literature at Yale University and defender of the modern novel, had kind words for twenty-nine books of the past year in his annual book lecture here tonight.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 25. -Hundreds of festival visitors this afternoon took advantage of the additional opportunity afforded to hear a concert conducted by Arturo Toscanini when he led the Vienna Philharmonic in the third and last of the special Sunday programs given in the Mozarteum and broadcast to the United States under the auspices of the American Radiator Company.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Manager Traynor's eleventh-inning single with the bases loaded gave the Pirates a 6-5 second-game victory today and enabled them to sweep the four-game series with the Braves. The visitors captured the opener, 9 -- 2, in which Big Jim Weaver held the Tribesmen to six hits. Lucas went the route in the second game.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.6, which compares with 83.7 the week before, 83.1 two weeks before, 82.9 three weeks before and 82.6 four weeks before. The present average is the highest of the year to date and the highest since the week ended July 6, 1930.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- To the average business man it seems unthinkable that Europe should be plunged into a war because of Italy's aggression in Ethiopia, but in this particular dispute there are so many complexities and factors unknown except to the politicians that it is recognized here generally that a dangerous situation exists.

Philip Frank, American violinist who was chosen by the Philadelphia branch of the English Speaking Union to play at the coronation jubilee in London this Summer, is scheduled to give a recital in Salzburg today. He will return to this country late in September.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Precipitated diphtheria toxoid, a new and simplified preparation for the control of diphtheria, is now available for general distribution through district supply stations, the State Department of Health announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The text of the note presented today to Nikolai Krestinsky, Acting Commissar for Foreign Affairs at Moscow, by Ambassador William C. Bullitt, was given out by the State Department, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The State Department, through Ambassador William C. Bullitt at Moscow, lodged with the Soviet Government today a "most emphatic protest" against "flagrant violation of the pledge given by the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics with respect to non-interference in the internal affairs of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- First reactions to the United States note to Soviet Russia from members of Congress who were active in the long dispute that preceded recognition of the Soviet Union were both sharp and favorable.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The Italian Ethiopian crisis has weighed heavily on the financial markets in the past week but, at its close, the feeling of pessimism was lifting.

Eugene F. Moran, chairman of the Port Facilities Committee of the Maritime Association, warned yesterday that the commerce of the port was threatened by proposals to change the harbor lines, vitiating improvements that have been made over a period of years at the expenditure of many millions of dollars.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP). -- A crowd of 28,000 saw the Indians drop a double-header to the Red Sox, 5 to 4 and 8 to 2, today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Declaring he found wide cross-currents running against the "Roosevelt New Deal reform" in the Middle West, Senator Dickinson, Republican of Iowa, returned to the capital today with a prediction that farmers are not going to "junk the Constitution."

Appointment of ninety-one prominent men and women throughout the country to constitute the National Citizens Committee of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, was announced yesterday by Gerard Swope, chairman of the committee, president of the General Electric Company and spokesman for privately supported social work in the United States as represented by the committee.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 25. -Imagine some one combining the doctrines and methods of Aimee Semple McPherson and Dr. F.E. Townsend, and you have William Aberhart, schoolmaster-evangelisteconomist of Calgary, Alberta. You have also the explanation of the notable political uprising in Alberta last Thursday, when Mr. Aberhart's followers swept the Provincial elections to take all but half a dozen of the sixty-three seats in the Legislature.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, the German Finance Minister, opened the Leipzig Fall fair tonight with a speech in which he appealed to the world to accept German goods in order to enable Germany to pay her foreign debts.

ROME, Aug. 24. -- The price of the lira after the government's decree authorizing the abandonment of the statutory gold coverage of 40 per cent remains within limits of oscillations which, although tense, are certainly not alarming, despite the attempts being made by speculators to force the lira lower.

One of the large houses in West End, near Long Branch, N.J., having a frontage of 200 feet on Ocean Avenue facing the ocean has been purchased by E. Ziegler of this city. The property is at 797 Ocean Avenue and was formerly owned by the Policastro family. It contains eighteen rooms and four baths.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 26 (AP). -The Daily Mail published an interview today with Premier Benito Mussolini in Rome in which he was quoted as saying: "It should be realized without the possibility of misunderstanding that whoever applies sanctions against Italy will be met by the armed hostility of our country."

WARSAW, Aug. 25. -- Scoring one-and-a-half points against Denmark in two games finished during today's early session of the international chess tournament, the United States team made an important gain.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 25 (AP). -- A widow of many years, who had dedicated her life to aiding unfortunate children of the Far North, took steps today to adopt her seventh native child.

Joseph Krause, 35 years old, an escaped convict who had been boasting he would not be retaken alive, was arrested yesterday at 11 A.M. on Broadway, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets, and was charged with grand larceny and violation of the Sullivan law.

Taking as his theme the phrase "When God Can Do Nothing," the Rev. Dr. T. Porter Drumm, pastor of the North Reformed Church, Newark, N.J., declared yesterday that God could do little for the world without the cooperation of mankind.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Two White House conversations today failed to pave the way to adjournment of Congress.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- Senator James P. Pope of Idaho, whose actions and assertions on his present visit to London have been subject to an attack in the United States Senate, made a statement today to set at rest "confused reports in my own country concerning my visit and the views I have expressed."

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a letter to H. Eliot Kaplan, counsel to the Competitive Civil Service Association, replying to Mr. Kaplan's recent claim that city employes are paid less than persons holding similar jobs in the State and Federal Governments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- An issue of about $100,000,000 worth of 1 1/2 per cent four-year bonds of the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation, fully guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Treasury, was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

With 175 coaches, newspaper men and specially invited guests in attendance, a week's football school opened in the auditorium of The Herald Tribune yesterday morning. The coaches, mainly those of high and secondary schools, had assembled from widely separated parts of the country to listen to Lou Little, head coach of Columbia, lecture on all aspects of the game.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Texas Legislature will be called into special session soon, probably Sept. 16, to enact laws regulating liquor sales and provide for old-age pensions in conformity with the results of Saturday's constitutional election.

Common salt when bombarded by the nuclei of heavy hydrogen atoms becomes so excited that for fifteen hours it emits rays like those that come from radium. Salt is cheap and radium dear. Who can blame Professor ERNEST O. LAWRENCE for telling the American Chemical Society that "in the opinion of my medical colleagues" the discovery "will ultimately be of greater im"portance to medicine than the discov"ery of natural radioactivity"?

RICHMOND, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Court action to compel the University of Virginia to admit a Richmond Negro girl to the graduate school will be instituted soon under the sponsorship of the Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Dr. J.M. Tinsley, president of the Richmond chapter of the association, indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- With the Senate wheat and cotton amendments to the third Deficiency Appropriation Bill lost in the adjournment of Congress, the administration compromise under which the AAA will increase cotton loans from 9 to 10 cents a pound won the day.

A store and second-floor space on the Fifth Avenue side of the Hotel St. Regis has been leased from the Astor estate by Madame Regina Cattadori for a lace, linen and tapestry shop. In addition to her place at 719 Fifth Avenue Mme. Cattadori operates branch establishments at Palm Beach, Newport, Milan and Venice.

A collective agreement for the settlement of personnel problems has been reached between the Emergency Relief Bureau and its employes, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the bureau, announced yesterday.

An estimate totaling $3,368,222 for 1936, an increase of $153,113 over 1935, was submitted by the Borough President of the Bronx, James J. Lyons, at a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

HARRISON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- John Bilanti's Maltese kitten, called Pinky for no apparent reason, was released this morning after five weeks of imprisonment in a narrow space between Bilanti's three-story frame home at 308 Harrison Avenue and the adjacent building.

Apartment houses and loft buildings were included in foreclosure auction sales held yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx. In the former borough six properties were bid in by the plaintiffs, while in the Bronx two parcels were bid in.
The source of the heavy seas along the Long Island coast during the last few days is no mystery to those acquainted with the sea. The cause was undoubtedly the hurricane off Bermuda.

Of Republican regional revival meetings only the Grass Roots convention can be called a success. There was the flavor of Kansas and the camp-meeting to it. Chatter about candidates was forbidden, at least in public. Later manifestations have been more mechanical.

About a hundred members of the Lawyers Security League, 152 West Forty-second Street, voted last night to send their whole membership to City Hall at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning to demand an audience from Mayor La Guardia so the organization can present a plea for WPA jobs for distressed lawyers not on home relief rolls.

Setting the stage for the opening matches at Forest Hills on Thursday, the draw was made yesterday for the national tennis championships. For the first time in more than a half century they will be conducted as a combined event, with both the men's and women's singles titles at stake.
TORONTO, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- George H. Smith, vice president and general manager of the Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

GENOA, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Squadrons of Fascist militia, carabinieri, firemen and longshoremen worked feverishly today to repair waterfront damage inflicted upon suburban districts yesterday by a sudden storm, marked by a devastating waterspout. Official casualty estimates placed the dead at six, the injured at fifty-three.

The Book-of-the-Month Club selection for October will be "Seven Pillars of Wisdom," by the late T.E. Lawrence, which will be published by Doubleday, Doran on Sept. 27. This book is rolling up huge sales in England.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Texas repeal of prohibition made Oklahoma a dry desert in the Southwest tonight -- surrounded by five wet States and only one dry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Last-minute effort in the Senate in Washington to authorize loans of 90 cents a bushel on wheat, while not regarded by the trade as a serious threat, had sufficient influence at the opening of business today on the Board of Trades, in combination with better than expected Liverpool cables, to advance wheat futures around 1 cent a bushel from Saturday's finish.

Controller Frank J. Taylor introduced at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate his bill to amend the city charter to conform to the Federal Social Security program. The bill, which has the support of Mayor La Guardia, was referred to the Committee on Local Laws.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy refused today to grant the Millville Manufacturing Company an injunction to stop picketing at its cotton mill at Millville, which has been closed by a strike since Aug. 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- A ruling that the city of San Francisco has no authority to sell electric power from the Hetch-Hetchy Dam under the terms of the Raker Act passed in 1913 was passed today by Secretary Ickes.

SKOWHEGAN, Me., Aug. 20. -- Sally Rand tonight conquered an audience that had come out of curiosity to watch the much-publicized dancer in a dramatic role. As Sadie Thompson in "Rain" Miss Rand appeared with the Lakewood players, and her performance gained her many curtain calls at the conclusion of the performance.

A squad of customs agents, making a routine search of the steamship Pipestone County after that vessel had docked last Friday at Hoboken, uncovered more than $134,000 worth of opium and morphine, it was revealed yesterday by H.C. Stuart, Assistant Collector of Port.

The possibility that the government may, under the Silver Purchase Act of 1934, force the price of silver to $1.29 an ounce from its present price of about 66 cents is a threat to the existence of the sterling silver business of the jewelry industry, members of the American Retail Jewelers Association, gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria for their thirtieth annual convention, were told last night by their president, William D. McNeil of New York.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Aug. 26. -- A $3,000 vial of radium, accidentally thrown away, was back at Moe Hospital today after an uncannily precise search by two University of Minnesota scientists who traced it to the stomach of a squealing pig.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Official confirmation was given today to last night's late report that British military establishments at Malta and Aden are to be reinforced by the addition of approximately 1,200 men who will sail on the troopship Neuralia this week.

In a speech in which she attacked Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, and defended the right of women to drink at bars, Miss M. Louise Gross, national chairman of the Women's Moderation Union, advised the Central Council, Restaurant and Liquor Dealers of Greater New York and Vicinity, yesterday to meet soft drink prices and thus increase their business in alcoholic beverages.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 26 (AP). -- A deadlock in the World Zionist Conference was broken tonight when the Orthodox Zionist group (Mizrachi) and the Laborites settled their differences and the general debate was resumed.

While twenty men and women were dining at Brunn's Restaurant at 71-64 Austin Street, Forest Hills, Queens, John D. Carpenter, 33 years old, vice president of the Higbie Management Corporation of 905 Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica, slipped into the men's washroom and killed himself with a pistol.

Women's apparel and accessory manufacturers are showing little concern over the letdown in new business which has developed. Most of them are working on substantial backlogs of orders, on which deliveries are currently being made. The present slowing down is regarded as normal, but it was pointed out that stocks at both retail and wholesale continue of conservative proportions and that the question of prompt deliveries may yet prove vital in reorders next month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Three persons were killed and one injured critically at 5:15 o'clock this morning when the automobile in which they were riding crashed into a telephone pole and a stone wall in Westchester Avenue near the intersection of Purchase Street in Harrison.
NORTHEY ISLAND, Maldon, Essex, England, Aug. 26. -- The results of a war between Italy and Ethiopia, in so far as they affect Great Britain and America, can hardly be in doubt.

To the insistent obbligato of rumors and vague speculations such as generally accompany impending events, Guthrie McClintic has gone about the business of preparing to produce Maxwell Anderson's new play with about as little actual revelation as is manageable in this voluble profession.

The New York Central provided an innovation in the presentation of railroad reports yesterday by issuing its statement for July and the first seven months of the year in a form which showed its operating income both before and after deductions for depreciation and retirement. The statement showed that in the seven-month period the company entered almost $10,000,000 on its books for depreciation and retirements.

Their forces marshaled during the day by a sound truck that patrolled the garment district steadily, more than 2,000 members of the Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union, Local 19,953, A.F. of L., gathered last evening at the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street, and declared a strike, effective this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Star says a statement of George Dimitroff at the recent meeting of the Third International that "the Communist party should support the election of President Roosevelt at the next election because his defeat might enable forces now opposing our forces to give us a body blow" is considered in well-informed quarters as the principal reason for the rebuke sent to the Soviet yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 26. -- The American protest against Communist activity in the United States was not mentioned in the Soviet press today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- A charge that there is under way in this country a campaign by "some persons" against the Soviet Government, was made by Ambassador Alexander A. Troyanovsky today in commenting on the protest yesterday to Russia by the United States against Communist propaganda.

Grace Reid, 10-year-old Negro, a potential stowaway, who spent six and a half hours walking from her Harlem home to the South Street piers in lower Manhattan yesterday, confessed to Patrolman Stephen McCormack who stopped her, that she was on her way to South America.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- A sharp decline in call loans, both in and outside Canada, featured the monthly statement of the chartered banks, issued here today. Current loans in Canada also were down, but current loans outside Canada were only $2,000,000 lower than at the end of last month.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The stock markets here were quiet and uncertain today. The general trend was dull. British funds opened better but eased later on lack of support. German issues were lower, in the foreign market. Home rails were steady but the foreign issues were neglected.

Sir John Foster Fraser, British author, traveler and journalist, arrived yesterday from London with Lady Fraser to spend six weeks in this country writing a series of articles on industrial and economic conditions for a British newspaper syndicate.

GENEVA, Aug. 26. -- Following word of the Senate's confirmation of him as chairman of the Social Security Board, John G. Winant said here today that he had definitely, accepted the post and would sail for the United States in a few days to take up his new duties.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Declaring the recently enacted Potato Control Act an "unconstitutional measure," and stating their intention of openly defying its regulatory provisions, farmers in West Amwell Township, Hunterdon County, have drawn up a resolution protesting against governmental control of potato crops and have adopted a stand for the "preservation of their rights in their own land."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- John B. Kelly, chairman of the Democratic City Committee and the party's leading candidate for Mayor, announced today that if he is elected his firm will not take "a nickel's worth of city construction contracts."

One's first impulse is to say that Congressman SNELL was wrong. He said that this country has prospered for the reason that it is only three generations from shirt-sleeves to shirt-sleeves. Most people remember it as overalls. It is three generations from overalls to overalls.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Esteemed at home and abroad as one of the great teams of the past decade, Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, and John Van Ryn of Philadelphia today carried the objective which they had repeatedly stormed in vain when they were sweeping all before them on the tennis courts of the Old World.

The voters will decide in a referendum at the November election this Fall whether the city, as Mayor La Guardia desires, is to go into direct competition with privately owned utility companies by building a municipal power system.
DENVER, Aug. 26. -- A seventeen-year-old youth was said today by police to have admitted he was the arsonist who set a series of fires which struck terror in the city's business district.

Fearing that acceptance of a share in the $50,000,000 fund set aside by President Roosevelt for the National Youth Administration would open the way for Federal domination of the city school system, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, City Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he would insist on refusal of all such funds unless they were accompanied by a guarantee that local school authorities would have a free hand in their use.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Admiral Cary Grayson's keen St. Germans colt, Bold Venture which has been highly thought of by Trainer Max Hirsch, flashed his best effort since his racing debut when he captured the Cherry Plain Purse today with the Arlington Futurity winner, Grand Slam, driving behind him.

Action of the Senate in demanding a flat 12-cent loan on cotton similar to that of last season, instead of an advance of 9 cents, plus a cash bounty, caused nervous trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Uncertainty over the final decision stimulated short covering which held quotations above Saturday's closing level and left the list with net gains of 3 to 10 points.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 26 (Reuters). -- "For sixteen days I have fasted and prayed fervently for peace for Ethiopia and the world. I should like to appeal to women the world over to join in my prayer."

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The final tune-up for the best of the local junior tennis players before the national junior grass-court championships at Philadelphia next week got under way today as the first two rounds of the girls' invitation tournament were completed at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. John Farr Jr. gave a large reception this afternoon at Gables, her home in Little Plains Road. A feature was a fashion parade, arranged by Mrs. Pleasants Pennington, in which younger members of the Summer colony acted as manikins.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 26. -- Ethiopian natives and Italian authorities alike began evacuation of the capital today amid rapid-fire developments indicative of a general belief that hostilities were almost at hand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt today set up a timetable for the work relief program under which all allotments would be made and all work ready to start by Dec. 15.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 26. -- A violent sixty-mile southwest gale swept over Newfoundland yesterday, leaving a trail of wrecked planes, fishing schooners and boats and unroofed houses. The toll of life is unknown but the crews of at least two fishing vessels were believed to have perished.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. Oliver Gould Jennings opened her home, Belacre, this afternoon for a piano recital by Miksa Merson, Hungarian pianist, whose program consisted of works by Schumann, Chopin and Liszt. There was a large attendance of Summer colonists.

Chick Morlano of South Brooklyn took the decision over Nick Palmer, also of South Brooklyn, in the feature of a program of four- round contests before 2,000 at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, last night. The winner weighed 182 and Palmer 176 pounds.

BERLIN, Aug. 26 (AP). -- An accidental editorial reference in a Westphalian Nazi paper disclosed to foreign correspondents today that Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, had declared at Essen that Germany had a "very great appreciation" of Italy's colonial position.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 26. -- The women golf stars of America went on a scoring spree over the Interlachen Country Club course today and when the qualifying round of the thirty-ninth national championship was finished forty-nine in the field had broken 90.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The United States and Japan are negotiating a "gentleman's agreement" seeking to restrict Japanese cotton textile exports to the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Securities valued at $1,421,826,055 were sold on the country's twenty-one registered Exchanges in July, marking a sharp increase in trading over June, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The Sea Girt Inn, owned by the town and from which it receives a percentage of the receipts, was ordered closed today by H. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, on the ground that indecent performances have been given at the inn.

ONE can take a good deal of pleasure in reading Stefan Zweig's "Mary Queen of Scotland and the Isles" (Viking, $3.50), but for people whose avocation is historical browsing it is not likely to be the dramatic pleasure which Herr Zweig intended. It is, of course, very possible that this companion biography to Zweig's popular "Marie Antoinette" will be read by scores who will take it in the spirit of a romantic novel.
Archbishop Michael J. Curley of Baltimore returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Scythia from his annual visit to his old home in Athlone, Ireland, where his mother died in 1932.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Losses of the Farmers National Grain Corporation for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1935, totaled "a little less than $250,000," according to information made public today for the first time by C.E. Huff, president of the farmers' cooperative.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- It was reported here tonight that in addition to Great Britain, Italy and Latvia had protested informally to Moscow because of Communist activities as revealed at the Comintern Congress.

A funeral service will be held at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow for John North Willys, automobile manufacturer and former Ambassador to Poland, who died at 1 A.M. yesterday at his home, 4,643 Waldo Avenue, Riverdale-on-Hudson, the Bronx. The service will take place at his home.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Despite the rigors of an unusually hot Summer and the rival distractions of the jubilee season, more than twenty London shows have been playing to good, steady business and promise to go right on into the Winter.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 26. -- It was about an hour before the first race and across the clubhouse porch came the elderly but thin, trim and chipper Judge E.C. (Easy) Smith, who has been peering across the line and calling the order of finish at many tracks for many years.

Presiding Justice Lazansky of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn hinted yesterday that contempt of court might have been committed on last Thursday when the merger of the Fox Film Corporation and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., was voted.

In its twenty-sixth-floor suite at 580 Fifth Avenue, where the silence is broken only by the whirr of occasional passing airplanes and a telephone buzzer, the League for Less Noise prepared yesterday to establish a complaint bureau to handle the growing number of requests for aid in abating the city's noises.

Philip Sheehan, 22 years old, the son of Daniel Sheehan, a prison keeper on Welfare Island, and the nephew of Police Lieutenant Cornelius Sheehan of the Marine Division, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein charged with possessing counterfeit $20 notes.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini received his Ministers and Under-Secretaries informally tonight in what was described as a preliminary to an extraordinary Cabinet meeting on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, refused yesterday for a second time to license a Republican charity carnival in a vacant lot on West Twenty-third Street despite assurance by its promoter that it would make plenty of money because if necessary he would hang up a sign reading: "Relief tickets cashed here."

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The Boerse was weak and inactive today. I-Ieavy industrials were inactive with a tendency to weakness. Machines opened firm hut fell at the close, declining to point below Satur-i day's levels. Chemicals weakened, I. G. Farben losing 1 points.

The law committee of the Association of American Railroads is to meet on Sept. 20 to determine what course the railways will pursue as the result of the passage of a new railway pension act. In railroad legal circles it was said yesterday that no decision on any action to be taken had been reached, although an attack on the measure's constitutionality was a possibility.

Thomas Patrick Morris announced yesterday in the offices of his attorney, Bernard H. Sandler, 225 Broadway, that he was planning to ask Surrogate Foley to reopen his claim to the estate of the late John Gottlieb Wendel. Morris served twenty-eight months in the penitentiary after conviction for fraud in his claim that he was a son of Wendel.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has succeeded in getting his scheme for a public electric light plant put to a vote of the people. Members of the Board of Aldermen who come up for re-election this Fall did not dare refuse him. Even opposition members of the Board of Estimate, who suffer from no such immediate political anxieties, felt constrained to "let the people decide" this lively issue.

The prolonged efforts of Congress to put itself -- and the country -- out of misery by adjourning have been greeted with a good deal of cynical laughter. But the whole thing is no laughing matter. There is in it a revelation of the motives and make-up of Congress which should provoke sober thought.

Wall Street was treated again yesterday to more rumors from Washington relating to resignations. Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Secretary of Agriculture Wallace and Chester C. Davis, AAA Administrator, were among those pictured as ready to relinquish their posts.

By a decision of Supreme Court Justice Rosenman yesterday in a suit in behalf of the supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney in his contest with John E. Sheehy for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District, the Board of Elections was directed to permit the Sheehy and Mahoney factions to draw lots to determine which group should lead the ballot in the election for members of the County Committee at the coming primary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Widespread "chiseling" on hours, wages and prices was cited to Congress today in a report by President Roosevelt in a move to bolster his recommendation for legislation next session to retain the "advantages'' of NRA.

CAMDEN, N.J., Tuesday, Aug. 27. -- The directors of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation announced at 2:15 o'clock this morning after an all-night session that they had accepted President Roosevelt's arbitration plan, bringing to and end the fifteen-week strike at the shipyard here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Secretary Morgenthau declared today that he was not disturbed by the recent weakness in the government bond market.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- In naval circles to day War Office orders hastening the departure of 1,200 technical troops to Malta and Aden and dispatching the aircraft carrier Courageous to the Suez Canal were the centre of attention and speculation.

In his presidential address to the British Isles Conference of the New Education Fellowship at St. Andrews, Dr. LINDSAY, Master of Balliol, described two educational experiments. In the Midlands the Worker's Educational Association conducted tutorial classes which were attended by workmen after the day's work was done.
The startling descent of the Giants continues to move in full and alarming flight. In fact, for a time yesterday it was moving so fast the naked eye could scarcely follow it.

Pier practices in the port of New York, particularly the free storage of freight for unlimited periods, are the subject of an inquiry opened yesterday by the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce, on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

NEWPORT, Aug. 26. -- Nearly 100 members of the Naval colony here were present late this afternoon at the home of Commander Hugh Pope Le Clair, U.S.N., of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Le Clair, to witness the marriage of their daughter, Miss Penelope Dear Le Clair, to Ralph Wilson Powers, an attorney of Hyattsville, Md., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Powers, also of Hyattsville.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The mad rush of the St. Louis Cardinals toward the National League pennant hit a snag today when the Phillies won the first of a three-game series by the score of 4 to 3. The world champions retained their half-game advantage, however, as the Giants also lost.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Preparing for the final races tomorrow and Wednesday in the international star boat championships, skippers of the midget fleet spent today tuning up their craft.

ROME, Aug. 26. -- The Italo-Ethiopian situation and European complications arising from it have developed so unexpectedly lately that Italians now look with far more apprehension to the north than they do to the south.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- While the demand for fresh pork was reported today as very slow, and the wholesale price of loins here was 1/2 cent a pound lower, hogs met with a fair demand and closed steady to 15 cents a hundredweight lower, with choice kinds selling readily toward the last.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Athletics and Tigers broke even in a twin bill today, the American League champions taking the first game, 13 to 7, and Philadelphia winning the second, 3 to 2.

Apartment leasing for the Fall season is continuing briskly in Manhattan and in some suburban districts, according to reports received from brokers yesterday. Both small and large suites appear to be in demand, and the activity seems to be divided about equally between the East and West Sides of Manhattan.

The report of the Continental Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30 shows a net profit of $481,978, after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, loss on dimantlement of properties and other charges and after dividend accrued on the preferred stock of its subsidiaries.

Lou Salica reached the top of the bantamweight class last night. The Bath Beach warrior, who started on the fistic trail three years ago as a member of the United States Olympic team, gained recognition as the world's champion in the 118-pound division by defeating the sturdy Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico in a sizzling fifteen-round bout at Dyckman Oval.

Confirmation of Dr. Judah L. Magnes's tender of his resignation as chancellor of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, as reported from Lucerne by the Palcor Agency Sunday shocked leaders in the movement for the development of modern Palestine here yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Enactment of Federal legislation to carry out grudges against certain types of business was charged today by Clarence O. Sherrill of Washington, chairman of the Board of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus and president of the American Retail Federation.

At a recent entertainment in Virginia, a gathering composed of both Republicans and Democrats was discussing the political and economic situation. There was naturally some diversity of views, but there was similarity in the leading characteristic that every member of the group seemed dissatisfied and apprehensive as to the future outlook.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Police here stated tonight that they had taken the automobile in which a Westminster, Md., filling station operator said that he saw a man resembling William Mahan, wanted in connection with the Weyerhauser kidnapping.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Having reached his seventieth year today, Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins took occasion to denounce the religious bigotry and racial hatreds now existing in the world. He deprecated the manifestation of ill will, intolerance and class antagonism in general.

TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- Twenty divisional and garrison commanders, summoned from all parts of the empire, today heard War Minister Senjuro Hayashi tell, in an address, of the measures he has taken to restore discipline. According to trustworthy reports, they assured the Minister of their collaboration.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 26. -- In order to avert Federal control under provisions of the Public Utilities bill which President Roosevelt signed late today, the Hartford Electric Light Company and the Connecticut Power Company have severed their reciprocal interstate power lines.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Mississippi voters will choose a Governor, Lieutenant Governor and other State and local officials in the Democratic run-off primary election tomorrow.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 26. -- Western Long Island Sound, as represented by Jimmy Rousmaniere and his Cold Spring Harbor Club crew, stole the thunder from the Middle West, the south shore of Long Island, New England and New Jersey today as the fifteenth annual Sears Cup series started at the Stamford Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Old Caspar, one of the President's favorite characters in poesy, was unable to tell Little Peterkin many years after Blenheim what good came of the Duke of Marlborough's victory there, and the American public may long remain in similar doubt as to the consequences of the events and compromises of today in the great battle over the cotton loan, upon which the adjournment of Congress has depended.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 26. -- A dinner and dance for the sub-debutante set were given tonight at the Mount Washington Hotel. Mrs. Elizabeth Parcells and W.W. Myers were hosts, assisted by Mrs. Herbert C. Sierck. Among those present were:
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Aug.26 (AP). -- Missourians, their pockets filled with "milk bottle cap" tokens, embark tomorrow upon a relief and pension program unprecedented in the "Show Me" State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Information reached Washington today that some of the larger utilities holding companies may accept the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 -- which President Roosevelt signed today -- without putting the law to a test of constitutionality in the Federal courts.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26. -- A bunch of youngsters, all of them under 17 years of age, showed the cream of the professionals how it's done today as the first three national championships in history were decided by the Skeet Shooters of America.
BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- Germany approves heartily the American protest against interference by the Communist International in American domestic affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Aug. 21, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $90,000,000 in loans and investments, $138,000,000 in net demand deposits and $85,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

What was believed to be the first successful use in this country of "mirror spectacles," which seek to correct certain eye defects by the use of small reflectors attached to the lenses, was described yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Optometry at the Hotel Governor Clinton.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Brazilian Government intends to continue paying as long as possible the services due monthly and fortnightly on all federal, State and municipal debts abroad.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 26. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's proclamation ordering the people to flee to the bushes and meadows if a three-gun air-raid signal is given is now accepted by the natives to mean that war is imminent. There is great jubilation among all who are eager to begin a test of strength with the Italians.

SPRING LAKE, Aug. 26. -- Play in the North Jersey coast bridge pair championships opened tonight at the Monmouth Hotel here with twenty pairs entered in the first of the three nights of play for the Monmouth Trophy.

S. Klein, Union Square merchant, protested to the Bay Ridge Boys Club yesterday that he did not want the funds he was providing to send John T. Kennedy, 10-year-old "Boy Ambassador" 'on a good-will tour to Ireland, to be spent for passage on the Deutschland, scheduled to sail tomorrow.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Farm families from throughout New York State will be in attendance at the State Fair here tomorrow on the occasion of Farm and Home Bureau Day.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in rather active trading. A feature was a sharp advance in coffee in the heaviest trading since Feb. 15. In the cash markets, refined sugar was marked up 20 points, while wheat, corn, oats, flour, lard, tin, silk and rubber were lower.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Dwellings and tenements formed the bulk of real estate sales in New Jersey communities yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Justice of the Peace James J. Westwood of McKees Rocks and Constable Tim Drexler were arrested late tonight in connection with the slaying of the justice's wife, Mrs. Martha Westwood. County Detective Walter Monaghan said both were charged with murder.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Four leaders in the cotton industry here expressed opposition today to the proposed 12-cent-a-pound cotton loan which prevented the adjournment of Congress Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 27. -- The House adjourned sine die at 12:09 this morning. The House clock stood at 11:57, having been turned back.
WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, Bolzano, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini took ranking command today of the 150,000 troops engaged in the vast military manoeuvres near Brenner Pass.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Aug. 26. -- P. Hal Sims, the bridge expert, teamed with George Sullivan, Long Branch professional, today to win the New Jersey P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament with a best-ball score of 66 over the Glen Ridge Country Club course. It was the second time this season that Sims and Sullivan had captured one of these events.

New York's odors, rather than its sights, have most impressed Sylva Goodman, auburn-haired student from Detroit and winner of a national essay contest, on her first visit here. Aromas from pushcarts and from florist shops and the smells of everything from salt water to saloons, or their equivalent, will constitute her most vivid memories as she returns to the campus of Wayne University at the end of the week, she said yesterday.
Floyd Caves Herman, who used to hit home runs in the Flatbush cause, walloped one against the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field to inflict their sixth straight defeat upon the Stengel athletes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Calling Mexican mail order divorces "absolutely null and void" in this nation, the Postoffice Department issued a fraud order today against the Border Law Office at El Paso, Texas.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 27. -- The first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress adjourned sine die shortly after midnight, forced by the rules of the Senate to surrender the Third Deficiency Bill, carrying appropriations for the Social Security program, to the filibustering tactics of Senator Long.

Dancing lessons are coming to be used more and more as a means of acquiring a sense of etiquette, in addition to grace and poise, or just the knack of how to dance, it was revealed yesterday at the opening of the fifty-seventh annual convention of the American Society of Teachers of Dancing at the Hotel Astor.

Luther Rice, 28-year-old ex-convict, who was arrested on Aug. 14 when he tried to redeem a watch pawned after a hold-up on April 24, was identified yesterday in Yorkville court as one of two men who had robbed four employes of a $3,000 payroll at Claremont Inn, Riverside Drive at 124th Street, on Aug. 13.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, automobile racer, is among the passengers who will arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. He is accompanied by Captain G.E.T. Eyston and Flight Lieutenant Staniland. Others aboard include:

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP). -- William Green, presenting an American Federation of Labor charter to the International Automobile Workers Union today, urged the approximately 250 delegates to begin a drive to recruit a quarter-million workers in the traditionally open-shop motor-car industry.

Despite the fact that disappointment was fairly general in the financial community over the failure of Congress to wind up its present session on Saturday, the share market easily overcame a fractionally lower opening yesterday and moved forward steadily to the closing.

Robert Montgomery, who has been on vacation from the Metro studios since June, will leave New York for the Coast tomorrow. His schedule there is uncertain, but his next picture probably will be either "Piccadilly Jim" or "Small Town Girl."
ROME, Aug. 26. -- Informed sources disclosed tonight that the Italian battle fleet was on the point of initiating extensive movements in the Mediterranean.

WARSAW, Aug. 26. -- Dividing the points with Austria in three thirteenth-round games at the Army Officers Casino, the United States gained 1 1/2 points in the international team tournament today. A. Kupchik, A.W. Rake and I.A. Horowitz, Nos. 2, 3 and 4 in the American line-up, all played short games, lasting 14, 17 and 15 moves respectively.

A general stiffening in cotton goods quotations, regardless of how Congress finally disposes of the cotton loan program, appeared likely here yesterday following lengthy conferences between mill executives and their sales representatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The close of the longest session of Congress since 1922, covering 235 days, showed a wide range of important legislation enacted. A summary of the principal measures adopted, their intent and effect, is presented below.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Airport Development, said last night that great dissatisfaction had been voiced at the decision of the Post-office Department to maintain Newark Airport as the Eastern air mail terminal for the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Utilities Bill, providing for the eventual elimination of holding companies except those essential to the operation of single integrated systems, became a law at 3:10 P.M. today when President Roosevelt signed it in the presence of those who led his fight for the bill through Congressional committees and on the floors of the House and Senate.
VIENNA, Aug. 26. -- Another political assassination of an alleged traitor has caused a sensation in the Northern Tyrol frontier zone.
The Down Town Athletic Club, 18 West Street, became yesterday the third establishment to refuse to rent its facilities for the annual convention of the German-American Technologists Association.
Business in money was small, the demand for funds being limited to routine requirements. Quotations remained unchanged for all classifications.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Thirty-six thousand men of the First Army started the last of their series of mimic battles here today, while Secretary of War Darn, high-ranking officers of the American and foreign armies and the Governors of two States watched the tide of "war" surge across the plains and farmlands of Jefferson County.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Charles Chaplin paused today in his studio work to express sorrow over news of the death of Mack Swain. "He was the most amiable and friendly of characters, and I feel real pain at his death," Mr. Chaplin said.
SYRACUSE. Aug. 26. -- Youth made an enviable showing as the Empire State Horse Show, one of the main attractions of the ninety-fifth annual New York State Fair, opened today.

With the belated "discovery" of lake trout in Rye Lake, many of the fresh-water clan in Westchester are scurrying around to tackle stores, picking up copper lines and other gadgets necessary for deep trolling.

Albert Kahn, whose half Brother formerly was associated in business with the brother of a Tammany district leader, was forced to give up his job as a process server on the staff of Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, it became known yesterday, because of his "political connections."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Rental and benefit payments to farmers during the fiscal year ended June 30 totaled $563,438,812, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today. All expenditures of the AAA amounted to $807,686, 134.47, from available funds of $960, 334,220.63, leaving a balance of $152,466,096.16.

A nineteen-word message, carried out of a barren and mountainous region of the Yukon Territory in Northwestern Canada, five days on horseback to Burwash Landing, radioed to Whitehorse and finally telegraphed to the American Geographical Society of New York, brought word yesterday that Walter A. Wood Jr. and three companions had successfully scaled the peak of Mount Steele, one of the highest and most inaccessible mountains in the Northwest.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 26. -- Nazism is constantly gaining ground among the German minority of Rumania, especially among the youth. Governmental measures for dissolving Nazi organizations have been countered by passive resistance and sabotage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- A new obstacle to the construction of the interoceanic canal across the base of Florida to join the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico developed today when the Geological Survey confirmed reports that an old survey in their files found that construction of the canal would have "major effects" on the water supply in Florida.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Stabilization of the country's economic life so the whole United States can be more adequately provided for was urged today by Dr. Carl C. Taylor, national director of the Resettlement Administration, in addressing seventy-five officials representing the eleven States in Region No. 1, attending a two-day conference.

With 4,000 investigators for the Rome Relief Bureau acting as recruiting agents, persons on home relief reported for Federal work projects yesterday at the rate of one a minute in each of the city's forty-six district offices. By the end of the day more than 10,000 home-relief clients had applied for jobs and 5,000 had received assignments.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Germany was presented as an object lesson and a warning, and also defended as a victim of the World War and its bitter aftermath, in the opening discussions today at Williams College of the newly organized Institute of Human Relations.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Swiftly moving police mobile unit squads armed with tear gas and bayonetted guns late today halted the plans of striking Omaha street car company employes to establish a picket line in violation of State laws.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on Sept. 20 for a new issue of $12,096,000 of bonds of the Metropolitan Water District of California. The bonds, which are dated Oct. 1, 1935, and due on Oct. 1, 1950 to 1985, are to be sold in connection with the Colorado River Water Works.

College graduates, who were seeking appointment to teaching posts, informed their examiners that machinations were a form of labor-saving machinery, that fatuous related to corpulency and that manger rhymed with anger, according to the annual report of the Board of Examiners, made public yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. J. Chesney's Cristate scored his second successive victory at Narragansett Park when he raced to a neck triumph over Mrs. H.H. Brown's Happy Helen in the sixth race, mile and a sixteenth event for 3-year-olds, which featured today's card.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP). -- After dropping the second heat to Lawrence Hanover, his only conqueror this season, Greyhound came back to take the third and deciding heat of the $8,070 Championship Stallion Stake, inaugural feature of the five-day Grand Circuit meeting, before 7,500 fans at the New York State Fair today.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The abbot of the cloister of the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer in Bochum and eight other monks appeared today in the Berlin Emergency Court to face another of the long series of exchange law charges brought against Catholic cloisters.

In a letter to Senator HARRISON and Representative DOUGHTON, the President transmits reports gathered by the National Recovery Administration and remarks that "notwithstanding suc"cessful and praiseworthy efforts being "made by many employers to maintain "standards of employment, these in"dicate a tendency toward serious im"pairment of established standards by "a minority."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 26, -- Christian Jensen, who with three companions is trapped in a motor boat in the ice near Cape Berlin, East Greenland, radioed at noon today that their situation was critical and every hour was "precious."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug 26. -- Bob McCollom, 24-year-old son of Sheriff William C. McCollom of Suffolk County and a member of the South Bay Club in Bay Shore, proved the hero today as a record-breaking field of seventy-two teams teed off in an amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Hempstead Club.

Definitely placed under Federal regulation through the signing late yesterday afternoon by President Roosevelt of the Public Utility Act of 1935, officials of public utility companies here and throughout the country settled down for what they expect will be a long and bitter fight in an attempt to prove the law unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Alleged violation by the Soviet Government of its pledges to refrain from Communist propaganda abroad has been the subject of numerous protests from other countries besides the United States. In some cases they have been responsible for open diplomatic ruptures.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP). -- With a "Scotland Yard," patterned after the English system, now in full operation in New York State, Attorney General Bennett today urged the necessity of using another English method of putting the criminal on the spot -- by making him pay for failure to testify.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Nedrow, T.C. Werden's smart 2-year-old, conquered seven other juveniles in the feature event at Lincoln Fields today, beating L.E. Komorous's Higher Cloud by three-quarters of a length after a lively race.
GOLDENBRIDGE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The State police in Brewster were looking today for a thief whose taste runs to seventeenth-century English portraits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Retail food prices advanced slightly during the two weeks ended Aug. 13, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
ALBANY, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman called upon every local law enforcement agency in the State today to act as "shock troops" in his war on crime.

The imminence of war between Italy and Ethiopia as soon as Ethiopia's rainy season ends, as evidenced by Mussolini's "hasty sweat," which "makes the night joint laborer with the day," emphasizes the importance of invoking Article 12 of the League Covenant, which declares:

Business in the garment district was seriously crippled yesterday when 14,000 men and boys answered the strike call of the Ladies' Apparel Shipping Clerks Union and interrupted the movement of merchandise to and from hundreds of manufacturing and distributing establishments.
