A new means for combating cataracts, believed by its originator to be the first successful non-surgical method, was described yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Academy of Optometry at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- An investigation of Senator Long's Louisiana "dictatorship" was reported on Capitol Hill tonight to be a major purpose of an inquiry voted by the Democratic House just before adjournment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Relations between the United States and the Soviet Union were dampened considerably today, in the view of observers here, by the receipt of the note disclaiming all responsibility on the part of the Soviet for actions of the Communist International.

Virtually all classes of fixed-interest bearing securities were under selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation bonds, United States Government obligations and foreign loans all felt the effect of the yielded ground easily against a meager demand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- President Roosevelt personally intervened again today in the muddled situation growing out of the revolt Saturday of Southern Senators against the government's decision to reduce the rate at which it would lend on cotton to farmers cooperating in the Agricultural Adjustment Administration program.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company ended the fiscal year on June 30 with a cumulative deficit of $7,910,154, compared with the cumulative deficit of $13,421,600 on June 30, 1934, according to a report filed yesterday with the Federal Court by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company.

Mayor La Guardia threatened yesterday to go over the heads of Board of Education officials, if they refused to accept a share in the $50,000,000 National Youth Administration fund. The Mayor refused to be disquieted by the fears of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, that NYA funds might open the way to Federal control of the city schools.

Members of the Poultry Shochtim Union, Local 440, whose charter has been revoked by the international organization, met on the lower East Side yesterday, declared their defiance of the edict of dissolution and outlined a court fight which they were confident would give them the right to their livelihood under circumstances in which racketeering played no part.

While failures in the wholesale and manufacturing divisions increased in the week ended Aug. 22, as compared with the previous week, the number of insolvencies declined in the retail group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

SPRING LAKE, Aug. 27. -- Sir Derrick Wernher and Edward M. Goddard, last year's title winners in the North Jersey pair bridge championships, were out of the running when the second night's play in this year's tournament opened here at the Monmouth Hotel tonight.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 27. -- Heavy desertions of Italian Somalis were reported today, but such reports were unconfirmed.

The Glidden Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on July 31 a net profit of $1,813,971 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent cumulative prior preference stock, to $2.26 a share on 650,000 no-par shares of common stock.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27. -- The lowly milk-bottle cap became real money in Missouri today and brought laughter and curses. Some persons "matched" them as they would pennies.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday in Washington that it had failed after exhaustive investigation to find enough evidence against former Mayor James J. Walker to justify criminal prosecution under the income tax laws. He has lived abroad three years.

The group of Standard Oil companies in the third quarter of this year will make cash dividend payments of $17,650,040, which is $932,025 less than the $18,582,065 distributed in the corresponding quarter last year, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- Quotations on the Boerse were weak again today with virtually no exception to the general tendency. Speculation as to the possible weakening of the position of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, and the effect on general European affairs of the plans of Premier Mussolini of Italy still dominate the trading floor.

Thomas E. Dewey, who was appointed a Deputy Assistant District Attorney to prosecute organized crime, took over yesterday the prosecution of five members of the joint council of the Fur Workers Union and in doing so came to grips for the first time with organized labor.

Automobiles, radios and household appliances are the principal competitors of the jewelry trade, it was declared by speakers at the thirtieth annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

However general the feeling of relief may have been in Wall Street yesterday over the adjournment of Congress, it was not manifested in terms of enthusiasm in the share market. On the contrary the market had its widest decline since March 5, or before the long advance started on March 18; leading issues closed weak, at or about the lowest levels of the day, off 1 to 4 points.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The delegates to the World Population Congress were treated at its inaugural session at the University of Berlin today to a dogmatic Nazi address and to a prayer of thanksgiving to Providence for having given Adolf Hitler to Germany.

In a recent newspaper letter about the gift of land for use in connection with small animal experimentation, it was said that people who make gifts of that sort do far more wisely than those who contribute to homes for aged, infirm and stray cats and dogs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has concluded that it has authority through the RFC Mortgage Company to make loans to tax-discount corporations set up under legislation adopted in several of the States and is prepared to do so up to the amount of its funds which are available for such purposes, Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, announced today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Fairbairn of New York gave a dinner tonight at Arrowhead Inn for Mr. and Mrs. E. Terry Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Henry McComb Bangs, Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot and George H. Bull of New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A weary Congress evacuated Washington today, leaving behind it only six major pieces of administration legislation which failed of enactment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Coldstream Stud horses of Elmer Dale Shaffer scored the first Western double of the Spa meeting today when Albania won the curtain raiser and Finance registered a triumph in the Deerhead Purse.
WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, Bolzano, Italy, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini said in a speech to a division of his soldiers today:

Congestion and confusion marked the intake machinery of the Works Progress Administration here yesterday when it proved inadequate to handle the thousands of unemployed who applied for jobs in response to the call of General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator.

Fifty-four new cases of infantile paralysis were reported for Monday in the city, Dr. Charles F. Bolduan, director of Public Health Education, Department of Health, reported yesterday. The total for the year is now 944 cases and forty-two deaths.

The cost of extensive highway and sewer construction and maintenance in Queens was emphasized by officials of that borough at a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen on the 1936 estimate of the Borough President's office.
I was surprised to read in a letter to the editor of the difficulties of an attorney in determining the duties of the county clerks, sheriffs and registers.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 27. -- Honorable retirement at the age of 13 is the prospect for "Lieutenant Bobby," the only dog to hold a bona fide commission in the army of the United States.

Since my initial letter suggesting some form of insurance within their means for small-car owners has evidently brought to the surface a problem which has been disturbing many people, may I say a last word?

LONDON, Aug. 27 (By Wireless). -- Britannia, ruler of one of the greatest empires on earth, is worried. And well she may be, along with all her international neighbors. Never in fifteen years have the dogs of war snapped more voraciously at the jugular vein of the empire, the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A special House investigating committee announced today that it planned to determine whether bondholders were being plundered on municipal, irrigation and reclamation project securities.

The two batting heroes of the major league races, Arky Vaughan, Pirate shortstop, and big Hank Greenberg, first baseman of the Tigers, are headed for honors as the most valuable players of 1935, baseball writers believe.
NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP). -- The By-C won the spectacular fourth race of the international Star Class yachting championship today to hold its slender lead in the series.

If those bucolic purists who have been writing facetious notes to Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey criticizing his milking stance, as set forth in published photographs recently, will bear with the Governor for a moment, all will be explained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a list of twenty-one offering sheets filed with it by various oil interests in the week ended on Aug. 17. It emphasized that the act of filing did not mean that the commission had given its approval or indicate that the commission had passed upon the merits of the issue, or that the material filed was correct.

WARSAW, Aug. 27. -- Poland made a clean sweep of all four boards in its match with Ireland tonight to go into a tie for first place with Sweden in the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation which is in progress at the Army Officers' Casino.

Chase Mellen Jr., Republican County chairman, assailed last night the message to youth broadcast by President Roosevelt on Saturday night as "defeatist doctrine" and "counsel of defeat." Chairman Mellen spoke over WINS under the auspices of the New York Young Republican Club as part of the Republican National Committee's program of replying to the President.

The market yesterday "sold ex-Congress," but instead of advancing on the news of the adjournment, stocks declined rapidly. Various explanations were offered for this development, one being that the market had been overbought too heavily prior to the adjournment to be in a position to advance when Congress ceased its labors.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Preparations were made by the New York Shipbuilding Corporation today to reopen its Camden shipyard on Thursday morning, following the termination of the strike, which started May 13, tying up the construction of seven naval vessels.
The increase in the producers' loan to 10 cents a pound from the 9-cent figure announced last week brought a 13 to 19-point recovery in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Decreasing receipts of hogs, with prospects that arrivals here this month will be the fewest since 1878, brought buyers into the market for supplies today and prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight. Light and underweight hogs, which recently have been leading the decline, showed the most strength.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The last-place Browns extended their victory string to five straight today with a double conquest over the Senators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The problem of government competition with private capital through direct loans to industry was laid directly on the doorstep of Congress today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, in discussing a recent authorization of $3,850,000 to a lumber company in Arkansas for the manufacture of paper.

The rescue of the crew of five men from the sinking auxiliary schooner yacht La Dahama of Philadelphia by the Italian liner Rex was told yesterday in a radio message from Staff Captain Alberto Ottino. The message, received by Aroldo Palanca, general manager of the Italian Lines here at Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, read:

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Prices on the Bourse opened weak today, but the market strengthened somewhat toward the close because of the reported improvement in London. The attendance of brokers on the floor was low, however, and the volume of trading was small.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The new $2,500,000 Randall's Island, N.Y., stadium was selected today as the scene for the final tryouts for places on the 1936 American Olympic track and field squad by the committee in charge of the sport, subject to approval by the general committee.

Five times Sir Malcolm Campbell arrived in the United States firmly convinced that he was going to break the world's speed record. Five times he succeeded. Yesterday the British speed king reached these shores the sixth time, but on this occasion he admitted that his visit is in the nature of an experiment.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27. -- The rumba, tango and foxtrot are insidious enemies of the Bolshevik regime, Komsolskaya Pravda, organ of the Young Communists, contended today in an article calling on young people throughout the Soviet Union to war on this danger.

ATHENS, Aug. 27. -- Soon after having suppressed the Venizelost-Communist movement in Crete, Greece is now faced with another uprising, this time in Royalist Peloponnesus and for entirely economic reasons.

Completely dissatisfied with the result of the Lou Salica-Sixto Escobar bantamweight championship bout at Dyckman Oval last Monday night, which the former won, Lou Brix, manager of the Puerto Rican, arrived at the regular meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday to file formal protest.

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was the smallest for any week since July 3, when 765 arrivals were published. The total was also below the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 27. -Racers sired by Hal Price Headley's Pharamond II took four of the events on today's Narragansett Park card.
HORNELL, N.Y., Aug. 27. -Llewellyn Strobel, 19, planned today to forego all strenuous athletics for the rest of his life to avoid "lightning death" from a small piece of tin lodged in his heart.
Congratulate me! When all the details reach the light the Carnegie Medal may be mine. I am the taxpayer.

The Reynolds Spring Company has declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents, placing the stock on a $1 annual basis. In June, an extra of 10 cents was declared, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 10 cents.

Americans especially interested in Russian trade were concerned yesterday lest Moscow's rejection of the protest of the United States against Comintern propaganda result in a recession in the improved trade that followed American recognition of Russia in 1933 and this year's trade agreement.

With one of the leading mills announcing a blanket 5 per cent price advance, effective at once on all lines of cotton goods, the wholesale market yesterday rallied quickly from the uncertainty with which it was beset by the legislative tangle on the cotton loan.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 27 (AP). -- In a vigorous attack upon Nazi Germany before the World Zionist Congress, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York said tonight that "Germany, which banishes the Jew, must be banished by civilization.''

A few months ago I wrote an editorial for a small Ohio paper on "The Bathtub as the Last Stronghold of American Liberty," as I was then under the erroneous impression that all else had been taxed and processed, or process-taxed, except the water that flows so freely from the tap.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 27 (AP). -- With more than 150,000 votes counted, Hugh White, wealthy lumberman and foe of "Longism," late tonight piled up a steadily increasing lead over Paul Johnson, Hattiesburg attorney, in Mississippi's run-off primary for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

Candidates for teaching positions in the city schools make startling errors in defining and pronouncing familiar words. So it is stated in the annual report of the Board of Examiners. People with college degrees, and not excluding masters of arts and Ph. D.'s, will say that "noisome" means noisy, "littoral" means unpoetic language, and "fatuous" means corpulent.

Prices of commodity futures yesterday were generally lower in normally active trading. In the cash markets, raw sugar sold at 3.50 cents a pound, up 5 points, the highest price in seven years. Flour, cocoa, and cotton also were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, lard, tin and rubber were lower.

After the State Board of Housing had contended yesterday that it had no jurisdiction over the leases in such projects as the Knickerbocker Village development, Supreme Court Justice Roseman reserved decision on an application by the Knickerbocker Village Tenants Association to compel the Housing Board to direct the management of the project to renew leases of fifteen tenants.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27. -With the judges setting a precedent in awarding points and places for a race in which not a boat was able to finish, Skipper John Ware, Eddie Robie and John Willis of Vineyard Haven assumed the lead in the Sears Cup series today.

An edition of twelve copies of a last book by the late T.E. Lawrence is in process of manufacture at Doubleday, Doran's Garden City plant. Two copies will be sent to Washington to establish copyright and the ten others will be offered for sale at $500,000 each.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The American Federation of Labor's new International Automobile Workers Union struck rough going today when a majority of the 276 delegates rejected the Federation's candidate for the presidency of the organization.

PLANDOME, L.I., Aug. 27. -- A round of golf that was within one stroke of par enabled A.W. (Laddie) Biggs, 1934 Long Island amateur champion, to win the Long Island Golf Association one-day tourney at the Plandome Golf Club today.

BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 27 (AP). -On the eve of the important extraordinary Italian Cabinet meeting, rumors were rife in government semi-official circles tonight that as a counter-gesture to Great Britain's sending of her Mediterranean fleet to Suez Canal waters, Premier Benito Mussolini would order the main Italian fleet to the same waters.

For fifty years CHILDE HASSAM was one of the most vigorous of American painters and etchers. His methods, his craftsmanship were ample. His feeling for light and color was subtle and profound. The museums will preserve a reputation which he won long ago, not without struggle and battle.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,688,700 barrels, compared with 2,708,650 the week before, a decrease of 19,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Virtually every producing area showed a slight decrease.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The high privilege and special obligation of the United States to carry on the American tradition of civil and religious freedom in a world increasingly torn by the forces of intolerance, oppression and persecution, was urged tonight by Governor Lehman of New York, in an address before the Institute l rot Human 1Relations at, Williams ICollege.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 17 totaled 311,515,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. The report represented a net decline of 1,878,000 barrels in the week. Current reports for the week indicated a daily average of crude oil production of about 2,770,000 barrels, an increase of 50,000 barrels over the previous week.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 27. -- With the field in the thirty-ninth women's national golf championship now reduced to sixteen players, the geographical distribution of survivors follows: Middle West 6, South 4, Far West 2, East 3 and Canada 1.
Three men were arraigned in magistrates' courts yesterday charged with victimizing women under promise of marriage.
Under cloudy and threatening skies and with a paid attendance of only 1,718, the Dodgers and Reds battled each other to a stand-off at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- An independent Democratic party similar to the Palmer-Buckner party of 1896 is about to be formed, it was authoritatively asserted today by a prominent citizen returning from the California home of William Randolph Hearst.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford halted a crusade by the West Side Association of Commerce to rid the midtown section of peddlers yesterday with some caustic words about selfish business men and self-appointed guardians of the city prestige.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27. -- Soviet Russia today firmly declined to accept the sharp protest of the United States against activities of the Communist International.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- President Roosevelt broke all nomination records during the session of Congress just closed.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 27. -- Reports of the desertion of several thousand Somali troops to the Ethiopian banner reached Addis Ababa today as Emperor Haile Selassie began quietly to pass out reserves of arms to his black warriors.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Assurance that the Federal social security program did not constitute an opening wedge for government control of all forms of insurance was given last night by Louis. H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, speaking over radio station WEVD.

TORQUAY, England, Aug. 27. -Yankee defeated five British Class J yachts in the Torbay Royal Regatta today. In a close finish, with Owner Gerard B. Lambert at the helm, Yankee beat Velsheda, which was second, by 1 minute 45 seconds and Endeavour, which was third, by 2 minutes 55 seconds.

In a letter to holders of defaulted obligations of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation a committee acting on behalf of the bondholders declared yesterday that a unified communication industry was preferable to a reorganization of Postal on terms inimical to stockholders.

Alexander Korda, production head of London Films, who is largely credited, with raising the standard of English sound films to a point rivaling those of Hollywood, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to confer on his new program with United Artists, his American distributers.

The New York Title Insurance Company has formed a subsidiary to be known as Realty Mortgage Servicing Corporation to render a mortgage service business for customers such as institutions, banks and individuals, it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Taking advantage of numerous bases on balls in the first game and hitting in the pinches in the second, the Tigers continued their fast pace in the American League pennant race today as they swept a doubleheader with the Athletics, 6 to 5 and 5 to 0.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- Between 300 and 400 persons attended the tea and reception given by the Art Association this afternoon in honor of the officers and classes of the Naval War College and their families. The guests were greeted by the following:

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically today, and despite a fair upturn at one time, the finish was at the bottom, with net losses 1/2 to 5/8 cent a bushel.

Officials of the city of Buffalo awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,910,000 work relief, water supply and general improvement bonds, dated Sept. 15, 1935, and maturing Sept. 15, 1936 to 1955, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Conditions on the London Stock Exchange were again unchanged today, being very dull under the shadow of the Ethiopian dispute, although some armament shares, including Vickers, came into renewed demand. British funds continued out of favor, going lower in the absence of support.

A decision in the action to stay the merger of the Fox Film Corporation and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., will be made this morning by Presiding Justice Lazansky of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, it was indicated after attorneys on both sides had completed their arguments unexpectedly yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The waning pennant chances of the Yankees suffered another jolt today at Comiskey Park when they split their third double-header with the White Sox before 20,000 fans.
FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The last of a series of the largest peace-time manoeuvres in American army history ended at noon today in a brief but violent thunderstorm.

A trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Company, the Irving Trust Company began suit yesterday in Federal Court to collect $2,019,066 from the government, contending that that sum represented, overpayment of income taxes for the years 1929, 1930 and 1931.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The text of the Soviet reply to the protest of the United States against Communist activity directed against this government follows:
A survey of radio advertising made public yesterday showed that of the 635 advertisers who were using the radio from 1929 to 1933, 448, or 70.6 per cent, had dropped radio advertising in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Works projects totaling $264,254,193, including 234 non-Federal PWA projects to cost $30,121,790, and 170 Works Progress Administration projects sponsored by States and subdivisions throughout the country totaling $151,055,181, were recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments.

ROME, Aug. 27. -- In the present uncertain state of the international situation, great interest attaches to the Cabinet council that Premier Benito Mussolini has convoked for tomorrow afternoon at Bolzano, in the centre of the army manoeuvre zone.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- C.R. Fairey's projected challenge for the America's Cup may be a "Class K" boat having a tonnage of about 107 tons, compared with the larger Class J. boats of 146. It was said today that the famous aircraft builder probably will issue a challenge through the Royal London Yacht Club, of which he was elected commodore a few weeks ago.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Copies of the Aug. 17 issue of the magazine Time appeared on news stands today with one page neatly torn out because of allegedly "offensive and insulting" references to the Duke and Duchess of Kent and other members of the royal family.

Evidence that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is losing no time in making sure that banks know about the provisions of the Banking Act of 1935 as it relates to deposit insurance is seen in the receipt by several banking institutions in this city of a letter explaining the law.
TORONTO, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press). -Gianni Gambi of Italy today won the Canadian national exhibition professional five-mile swim for the world's championship and the first prize of $2,500.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 27. -Two of the Berkshire garden clubs met this afternoon, Mrs. George K. Livermore was hostess at Three Acres for the one in Lenox, and at the tea tables were the Misses M. Symphorosa Bristed and Anna Remsen Alexandre.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Wholesale trade lines in the Seventh Federal Reserve District during July recorded either less-than-seasonal declines or contra-seasonal gains over the preceding month, while department store sales were seasonally below June, the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A 17-hit barrage by the Newark Bears tonight gave them their third straight victory in the current series with Baltimore, 9 to 3. It was the fifth successive loss for the Orioles.

Back-field play was discussed by Lou Little, coach of the Columbia eleven, during the second session of The Herald Tribune's football school yesterday. A group of about 200, composed chiefly of high and secondary school coaches, attended the two-and-a-half-hour lecture in the newspaper's auditorium.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- The fifth arbitrator of the Italo-Ethiopian Commission will be called in tomorrow to assume the heavy responsibility of giving his decision on disputed points of the arbitration of the border clash at Ualual. He will have until the end of the week to declare his verdict, as the commission must conclude its work by Sept. 1, preparatory to the session of the Council of the League of Nations Sept. 4.

With the Mayor's Trophy at stake, the New York City Police and Fire Departments launched the play-off series for the Municipal Baseball League championship yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, and the Firemen carried off the first decision, 7 -- 1.

Helen Vinson, the film actress, reported to Be engaged to marry Fred Perry, English tennis star and world's ranking amateur, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France, after an absence of four months. She made two pictures in England, "Transatlanic Tunnel" and "King of the Damned," and she liked playing in England so well that she will return there in January to co-star with Clive Brook in "The King's Pajamas."

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- From a field of ninety-four players, who turned out for the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association to go around the long and scenic Sleepy Hollow Country Club in intermittent showers of rain today, Mrs. A.U. Rodney emerged the winner with a gross score of 86.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 27, -- Threatening clouds failed to affect the crowds of Hunterdon County residents at the opening of the Flemington Agricultural Fair today. The fair will continue through Labor Day, excluding Sunday. Children of all ages were admitted free.

Before an audience of 800 in the Palace Theatre, Forty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, Louis Borsalino, 31 years old, a member of the vaudeville acrobatic team, "The Four Casting Pearls," missed in a "cast" yesterday and was thrown eighteen feet to the stage.

Bright-colored automobiles were more popular before the depression than they have been since, according to statistics gathered by Howard Ketcham, color engineer, who has made a series of color charts for the permanent collection of the New York Museum of Science and Industry, 220 East Forty-second Street.

Robert V. Santangelo, Assistant District Attorney who has been active in the contest over the Tammany leadership of the eastern part of the First Assembly District, Manhattan, charged last night that a threat to kidnap his niece had been made in an effort to force him out of the campaign.

May I call attention to the recent press dispatch from London in which The Daily Express quotes Dr. E.F. Armstrong, one of Great Britain's leading industrial chemists, as predicting that cotton will be replaced by a fabric made from wood pulp.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 27. -- Derby Dick Thompson, seated on the clubhouse porch, tilted back his chair when Bit of Sorrow was mentioned.

" Page Miss Glory," a film adaptation of last season's Broadway play by Phillip Dunning and Joseph Schrank, will have its New York premiere at 7 o'clock tonight at the Strand Theatre. Featured with Marion Davies in this Cosmopolitan production are Dick Powell, Pat O'Brien, Mary Astor and Frank McHugh.

Court action is in preparation to establish the right of Missouri Pacific Railroad 5 1/4 per cent secured serial bonds to take title to virtually the entire mileage of the company in Texas, Freeman Co. announced yesterday. The firm specializes in equipment trust certificates.

John Wilkinson, the 17-year-old boy who won the Park Department's interborough horseshoe pitching contest last Saturday, beat the old hands again yesterday afternoon by winning the championship of Central Park.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 27. -A complete overhauling of Sweden's defense system is recommended in a report presented to the government today by a commission that has just concluded a five-year inquiry.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Temporary suspension of payments by the Alberta Government on savings certificates until such time as the "new Social Credit government can meet the situation, which involves questions of policy that must be determined by the new Ministry," was announced by Premier Reid today following a long meeting with members of his Cabinet.

A correspondent attempted recently to discredit the letter of a previous writer to THE NEW YORK TIMES who, with a few facts and figures, showed the absurdity of Representative Rankin's statement relative to a one-billion-dollar annual overcharge to American consumers of electric energy.

In the great publishing world manuscripts are being examined on the score of style and originality for possible publication, and Fall lists, already long, are being trimmed and adjusted to make room for newly arrived masterpieces. The humble but ambitious reader may complain that there is too much to read now, and the publishers try to keep their lists, both in books and magazines, within reason by critical selection.

Executives of a score of ship lines operating in the import trade to New York expressed a willingness to enter into an agreement whereby the free storage of freight on piers would be restricted, at the resumption of the Shipping Board pier inquiry yesterday at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

As officials of public utility companies studied yesterday the provisions of the regulatory law signed by President Roosevelt, they reported that many complexities in complying with the act were manifest. While no indication was shown to recede from their decision to test in the courts the constitutionality of the law, many executives set about taking stock of just what it would mean to their capital structures to conform to the new regulations.

Four armed men held up as many employes of a Hoboken (N.J.) pawnshop yesterday afternoon, bound them with picture wire, locked them in a rear room and escaped with money and pawned articles valued at $50,000 to $70,000. Three women and several children in the store at the time were herded into another room while the robbers gathered the loot.

The net loss of the Illinois Central Railroad in July was about $1,000,000, against a loss of $550,000 in July, 1934, according to L.A. Downs, president. He said the company had about $5,000,000 in cash on hand and did not expect to borrow this year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Not only are there definite signs of an upturn for this Fall in manufacturing and retail lines, but now that Congress has adjourned business should go ahead, Jerome D. Barnum, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared here today in an address before a convention of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus.

GENEVA, Aug. 27. -- A comprehensive study of the legal aspect of the question of the League of Nations' closing the Suez Canal to Italy, issued today by the Geneva Research Centre, makes it appear anything but the simple matter that it is often represented as being.

You can't blame Frank for getting sore. If you were 14 years old, and had tugged and wrestled with a big fish for fifteen minutes that seemed like fifteen hours, and your dad was standing by all the time rooting and hollering -- but we're getting ahead of the story.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Westchester County authorities were aroused today when another fatality brought the total deaths in automobile accidents to six since Sunday evening. The latest death occurred at 3:30 A.M. three miles from here, in a crash in which two others were injured seriously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The probability that the security program and other threatened activities of the administration could be carried on despite the wrecking of appropriations for them in the Third Deficiency Bill by the filibuster of Senator Long was expressed today by Congressional leaders after a two-hour conference with President Roosevelt.

Mr. ROOSEVELT said before the adjournment that this session of Congress would be "historic." It is a characterization not far wrong. This Congress will stand out in our political history as having a place of its own. No other Congress in time of peace ever voted such huge appropriations -- something like $10,000,000,000 -- fully twice the amount of the prospective revenue.

SOLON, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A 16-year-old Oklahoma schoolboy and a 52-year-old Massachusetts auto repair shop owner won the smallbore skeet championships of America today in the first national tournament ever staged by followers of that sport.

In the face of sharp attacks against the lira in the foreign exchange market here yesterday, strong support was manifest for the Italian currency. The closing quotation was 8.17 cents, or decline of 3 1/2 points for the day. It was evident to foreign exchange traders that outside influences, probably aided by the Bank of France, were making themselves felt in upholding the lira.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The hurricane that roared across Newfoundland over the week-end swept away forty lives, according to estimates tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Supreme Court tests of the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the Tennessee Valley Authority, two principal pillars of the New Deal, were demanded today in briefs deposited with the court.
T.E. Shapiro Co. have prepared a letter on the General Telephone Corporation.

President DAVIS of Stevens Institute is practicing what he has preached -that one of the chief problems of an educational administrator is the "wise selection of his freshman class." For several years Stevens has maintained a camp, fifty miles from Hoboken, where forty or fifty eager young preparatory schoolboys "study themselves."

So perturbed over the possibility of British entanglement in the imminent Italo-Ethiopian war that he felt that he should not have made the trip, Sir Malcolm Campbell arrived in the United States yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic to try for a new world's automobile speed record.
It is still, technically, the Summer, but Broadway is definitely stirring. And somewhere among the following notes would be the evidence of it:

BARONESS SHIDZUE ISHIMOTO'S "Facing Two Ways: The Story of My Life" (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50) will give the Western reader an odd and wholly startling effect of time telescoped. It is as if some not at all comic Mack Sennett had undertaken the direction of Western history, disguising his real plot with Japanese names, and driving home point after point by foreshortening everything.

SIMLA, India, Aug. 27. -- With the help of airplanes and other implements of modern mechanized warfare, British troops have crushed a rebellion of the Mohmand tribes along the turbulent northwest frontier.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP). -The combination of Ben White, veteran Lexington (Ky.) driver, and a pair of Reynolds horses captured major honors on the Grand Circuit program today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27. -Preparations for the national open polo championship continued today with the arrival on Long Island of the complete invading force from England and with the announcement by the United States Polo Association of the draw and the opening of the public seat sale.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 28. -Automobile financing is not a money-lending business and there is doubt of the constitutionality of legislation attempting to fix company rates and rates for instalment credit, Edward T. Corcoran, New York City attorney, told National Association of Better Business Bureaus today.

Taking of immediate legal steps to restrain the wash goods division of the cotton converting industry from its recently published intention of operating under the f.o.b. cartage terms which were contained in the code for that section of the industry, was announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Charles Robinson, 17 years old, a Western Union messenger, who was looking on, was shot, but not seriously, in an altercation arising from the strike of shipping clerks in the garment district yesterday. The day was marked by many minor clashes between pickets and non-union delivery boys, resulting in thirty-five arrests.

FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Partial failure or inadequacy under field conditions of part of the army's communications system, deficiencies in training and certain mistakes in staff work were some of the criticisms expressed today at a critique of the First Army's field manoeuvres which ended yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28. -- Edward McCullough, local attorney who said he represented Lloyds, London insurance brokers, announced today that he had delivered a check for $2,500,000 to Mrs. Will Rogers, representing a special insurance policy on the life of the comedian.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that world wheat production, excluding Russia and China, probably would reach 3,520,000,000 bushels this year, an increase of about 60,000,000 from last year.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit system, including surface-car lines of the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation and buses of the Brooklyn Bus Corporation, produced a gross income of only $14,999,295 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, compared with $16,768,020 in the previous fiscal year, according to the twelfth annual report, made public yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Ethiopian Minister at Cairo informed Emperor Haile Selassie today that 5,000 Egyptians, Moslems as well as Copts, were ready to form a foreign legion to fight against Italy.

A new issue of $50,000,000 of Pennsylvania Company 4 per cent secured bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1963, is being offered today by Kuhn, Loeb Co. at 100 and accrued interest. The bonds will be a direct obligation of the company and will be secured by the pledge of 375,000 shares of common stock of the Norfolk Western Railway Company, which is priced at $190 a share.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Orioles broke a five-game losing streak today, defeating the Newark Bears, 8 to 5, in the final game of the series here. Harry Gumbert was on the mound for the Flock and registered his twentieth victory.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- At a conference of State administrators, provincial Governors, National Socialist district leaders and price-control officials, called to cope with the rapidly rising cost of living, Richard Walthier Darre, Minister of Agriculture, who recently assumed the functions of price dictator for agrarian products, announced a decree today providing various reductions in food prices, to be enforced by the police.

Plans for new buildings filed yesterday included a set for the erection of a six-story apartment house at West 204th Street and Cooper Street, in Manhattan. Other new structures and alterations were projected in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Selling pressure in the share market was greatly relaxed yesterday after the break in prices on the day before; the demand was not insistent, and the tendency to liquidate was even less so. Except for a flurry of selling in the first hour, when the tape ran 2 to 3 minutes behind in reporting transactions, the market did little more than move aimlessly through the day; the closing was steady.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- Professor Clarence G. Campbell of New York, president of the Eugenics Research Association, appeared today before the World Population Congress here as a champion of Nazi racial principles. He declared that a consanguineous racial group possessed "a high survival value and prospects."

Miss M. Louise Gross said several things worth thinking over in her address, quoted in 'THE TIMES, before the Restaurant and Liquor Dealers of Greater New York. It was a bold thing in America just out of prohibition to recommend the retailing of alcoholic beverages at soda and ice cream prices as a way to wealth.

The night air over Washington Square, Poe Park in the Bronx and McDonald Playground on Staten Island rang last night with close harmony, as a score of male quartets warbled the barber shop ballads of another generation in borough competition for finalist places in the American Ballad Contest for Amateur Barber Shop Quartets of the Park Department.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Discovery of the body of John Hamilton accounted for the last of the Dillinger gang.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 28 (AP). -- A freak gust of wind which caught his plane as he glided to a landing at the Rhode Island State Airport near here this morning took the life of Joshua Crane Jr., 37, widely known New England sportsman and pilot, who had flown more than 3,000 hours and carried upward of 25,000 passengers without mishap.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Benjamin F. Fairless, who was designated today to unify and head the Carnegie and the Illinois Steel companies, is prominent in the steel industry, but at one time was a school teacher. For several years he was a vice president in charge of operations of the Republic Steel Corporation, and he had one of the most important parts in unifying the operations of its far-flung interests.

The Central Foundry Company, which manufactures cast-iron pipes and fittings, employing 1,200 hands in its factories in the South and Middle West, filed a petition yesterday in Federal court for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Deadlocked for the second time, the four members of the Italo-Ethiopian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission called in a fifth arbitrator today to settle their dispute. Nicolas Politis, Greek Minister to France, who has been accepted by both governments as the super-arbitrator, has declared himself ready to accept the role, and tomorrow morning he will sit for the first time with the commission.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article headed "Food Price Inquiry Put Up to Roosevelt. Senate Resolution for Investigation of Spread Between Farmer and Consumer Passes House." The article states that "the resolution orders a Federal Trade Commission inquiry into middlemen's profits.
BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The Boerse today was almost entirely inactive, with evidences of continued weakness. Few declines of more than a half point were registered, however.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 28. -William H. Gallagher's Candimate today regained the form which brought him three straight victories at Suffolk Downs earlier this month when he won the Esek Hopkins Claiming Stakes, a mile and onesixteenth event for 3-year-olds and up at Narragansett Park.
Seven properties in Manhattan were struck down by auctioneers to the plaintiffs in foreclosure sales yesterday. The list included five apartment buildings in Harlem. One scheduled sale was adjourned.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28. -Mrs. Herbert Scott, 40, of North Haven, her 6-month-old daughter, Alice Marie, and son, Walter, 6, were killed here late this evening when they were struck and knocked to the pavement by a hit-and-run motorist on the Boston Post Road.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation reported yesterday, for the year ended on June 29, a net profit of $1,815,266 after all charges and taxes. This was equivalent to $9.91 on each share of common stock outstanding after preferred dividends. It compared with $1,008,834, or $5.69 a common share, in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1934.

The Italian lira rallied further yesterday, but the existence of continued speculative pressure against it was indicated by an increase in the discount on forward contracts in the Italian currency. The quotation for spot lira advanced 2 points to 8.19 cents, while the discount on 90-day futures widened to 70 points, compared with 65 on Tuesday and 55 on Monday.

As diagnostician to a sick industry, Paul T. Cherington, economist, applied the stethoscope of market analysis and announced yesterday to members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association that their business would recover, given proper treatment.

Pressure was lifted from some sections of the bond market, notably United States Government issues, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A, uniform recovery movement was lacking among domestic corporation bonds, however, that group displaying a highly mixed undertone most of the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The navy's commendation for their bravery and efficiency during the loss of the dirigible Macon was conveyed today to three members of its crew by Secretary Swanson. Three others were singled out for special commendation by Vice Admiral Henry V. Butler, commander of aircraft, Battle Force.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 28. -- A first, a fourth and a sixth place today kept the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club representatives from Martha's Vineyard, Mass., on top in their defense of the Sears Cup and the national junior championship.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 28. -- The long quest of Mrs. John D. Crews, the former Maureen Orcutt of New Jersey, for a women's national golf title came to another unsuccessful ending today at the Interlachen Country Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Liquidation of long wheat laid to houses with Eastern connections, some of which were recently aggressive buyers, turned prices downward after a slight showing of strength early today on the Board of Trade and the close was at net losses of 3/4 to 7/8 cent.

SOLON, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The 20-gauge national skeet crown adorned the tousled head of H.B. Joy Jr. of Detroit tonight after he led a field of seventy-five of America's outstanding marksmen with a score of 98 out of 100.

Among the 2,057 passengers arriving today from Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors, and Mrs. Sloan; Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing with Mrs. Lawes, Judge W.H. Rees, chief justice of the Supreme Court of Kentucky, and Mrs. Rees; Dr. Friedrich Fischerauer, Austrian Consul General in New York; Mrs. Chauncey M. Depew and:

Seasonal apartment hunting was featured yesterday by a number of leases in houses in the Yorkville section. Many names were added to the tenant rosters in buildings owned by Vincent Astor along Eighty-second, Eighty-fifth and Eighty-eighth Streets and on East End Avenue.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that 13,000 unemployed men had been put to work on WPA projects in the last three days and that the quota of 20,000 for this week would be filled without difficulty.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Black flags flew at half-staff today on buildings housing the nineteenth World Zionist Congress, a symbol of Jewry's protest against Nazi "persecution" of their race.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Consolidation of resources of six banks in South Dakota to form the largest bank in the State, with deposits of $7,500,000, was announced here today.

Dr. Campbell's attitude toward the National Youth Administration is both unwarranted and unjustified. The NYA was not created to interfere with local jurisdiction over educational policies, but to meet the needs of thousands of inexperienced, untrained, unemployed youths who, without Federal assistance, would not be able to continue their education.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Stopping over at the Oak Ridge Golf Club today on his way to Montreal, where he will play in the Canadian open tomorrow, Joe Turnesa of the Wampanoag Golf Club of West Hartford, Conn., equaled par figures of 70 to take the premier honors in a pro event of the Westchester County Golf Association.

Gounod's "Faust" will be the week-end opera at the Steel Pier in Atlantic City, with performances both Saturday and Sunday evening by the Steel Pier Opera Company. The cast will include Ethel Fox, Orsola Pucciarelli, Beulah McGorvin, Georges Trabert, Harold Kravitt, Edgar Allen and Warren Holland, with Henri Elkan conducting.
ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 28 (By Wireless). -- Arms shipments sufficient to meet the needs of Ethiopia for six months have been arranged with the Japanese.

The application for a temporary stay of the merger of Fox Film Corporation with Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., was denied yesterday by Presiding Justice Lazansky of the Appelate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

When I was a youngster on the lower East Side, I often listened to the Socialists haranguing large crowds on the street corners of that teeming section of our city. They spoke for woman suffrage, popular election of Senators, workmen's compensation, factory inspection and liberal labor laws.

OWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Democratic campaign to retain control of the State Assembly was formally opened today by Speaker Irwin Steingut as he made an attack on the Republican State Chairman, Melvin C. Eaton, and charged that party with fostering a policy of "negation and obstructionism."

Behind Walter Lowe's capable twirling, the Police Department nine blanked the Firemen, 3 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and thereby evened their three-game play-off series for the Mayor's Trophy, emblematic of the Municipal Baseball League championship.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford held three men who are being prosecuted by Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, for the grand jury yesterday on charges of assault, but dismissed complaints against two others who were accused of intimidating witnesses.

WALLKILL, Aug. 28. -- A sort of a county fair is to be given by prisoners in the State Medium Security Prison on Monday for the outside public. It will be a gala Labor Day for the inmates of Wallkill, which has been dubbed the "prison country club."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- President Roosevelt approved today an allotment of $2,031,522 to be used by the Works Progress Administration in New York State. Sponsors of the individual projects will add to this sum $194,483.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 28. -- The Foreign Ministers of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland, who assembled here today to confer on the attitude they would assume at the League of Nations Council meeting Sept. 4 on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis, broadcast appeals for peace tonight, unanimously agreeing that hostilities in East Africa were undesirable.

A new novel by Sinclair Lewis will be published by Doubleday, Doran in mid-October. It is said to be timely in interest. The author locked himself in at his farm in Vermont and worked on the book seven days a week. It will go to press early next week.

A revival in building activities in this country, as marked as that which Great Britain is now enjoying, appears to be developing, Samuel Austin, chairman of the Austin Company, international building firm, said yesterday. Mr. Austin arrived here yesterday from two months' stay abroad.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 28. -Three of the teams entered in the open championship played nine fast periods of polo in a round robin on J.H. Whitney's Greentree field today and produced some of the most interesting competition of the practice sessions which are leading to the open championship.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Wally Berger's twenty-eighth home run of the season gave the lowly Braves a 2-to-1 victory today in the first game of a double-header with the Cubs, but Lon Warneke beat the cellar dwellers, 5 to 2, in the second game.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- Professor Edward Victor Appleton, chairman of the British National Committee for Radio Telegraphy, is reported by The Daily Mail to have discovered in the upper atmosphere a vast layer of intense heat hitherto unknown to science.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- An aggressive campaign is under way by the backers of Colonel Frank Knox, the only avowed candidate for the Republican nomination, to win support of Old Guard leaders and break down the apparent increasing sentiment for Senator Borah.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 28. -- The erratic waters of Jones Inlet became unruly again today at 2 P.M., tossing up a huge wave which capsized the Mermaid, a 24-foot cabin cruiser, sinking the boat and pitching into the water its crew of six men, all of whom were rescued, one in the nick of time.

NOT so many months ago Ellen Glasgow, who was of the first Southern novelists to break away from the old magnolia-blossom tradition, went out of her way to attack the newest school of Southern realists. They were, she implied, mere purveyors of the hectic, literary merchants who were degrading their wares to the level of the Paris postcard.

Mayor La Guardia will insist that the Board of Education accept a share of the $50,000,000 National Youth Administration fund before school officials this afternoon when he confers with Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board, and Henry C. Turner, chairman of its committee on buildings and sites.

Storage conditions on the piers in this port were defended yesterday by spokesmen of two important import trades, testifying at the closing session of the Shipping Board's inquiry at the Maritime Association Building, 80 Broad Street.

Roland Hayes, tenor, and H.T. Burleigh and W.C. Handy, composers, were honored as three outstanding musical artists of the Negro race at a lecture-concert held last night in Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church on 137th Street in connection with the annual convention of the National Association of Negro Musicians in progress here.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The AAA was assailed tonight by two speakers at the annual forum for free discussion of affairs of the nation, the farm dinner of Jerome D. Barnum, Syracuse publisher, which was attended by 250 agricultural, business, political and newspaper leaders.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28. -- About 350 delegates who are in Williamstown for the Institute of Human Relations were guests this afternoon at a garden party and reception given at Buxton Hill by the Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of Eastern Oregon, and Mrs. Paddock.

With the largest American advance sale on record reflecting the rising tide of interest in the sport and leading players from seven nations foregathered to bid for the crowns held by Frederick John Perry of England and Miss Helen Hull Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., the United States Lawn Tennis Association will present today for the first time its national men's and women's championships under one "top" at Forest Hills on Long Island.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's loans of $80,000,000 made several years ago to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, now being liquidated under a receivership, were contrary to the Constitution and laws of the State of Illinois, it was charged yesterday in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- With the backwash of Congress literally flooding the White House offices, President Roosevelt announced today his purpose to work on bills and other official business until past midnight each day of this week, with the goal of departing for Hyde Park on Saturday evening.
Formation of the New York City Pharmaceutical Federal Credit Union, under the supervision of the Farm Credit Administration, was announced yesterday by Joseph J. Hammer, attorney for the new group.

SALZBURG, Aug. 28. -- With performances of "Faust" and "Everyman" concluding next Monday the most successful festival in its history, Salzburg experienced tonight one of the most thrilling events of its extraordinary Summer when the American contralto, Marion Anderson, gave a song recital at the Mozarteum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The conditions imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission upon foreign governments and their subdivisions for the permanent registration of their securities on the Stock Exchanges will be discussed by the commission here tomorrow with Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Frank Altschul, chairman of the Exchange's stock list committee.

In the absence of clarifying statements from Washington regarding various features of the coming loans of 10 cents a pound on cotton, the cotton trade was still endeavoring yesterday to forecast the growers' reactions to the govern menus new policy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- A worthy running mate to The Fighter for the forthcoming Hopeful was uncovered today when a stablemate, Sangreal, ran an impressive race to score by five lengths in the featured Albany Handicap under 120 pounds.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 29. -The Italian Cabinet declaration at Bolzano, which, incidentally, is described in some newspaper headlines here as "Mussolini's conquest declaration," was not received in London until long after last midnight -- too late for general editorial digestion and comment.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Paul Simon, arguing against compulsory insurance liability for automobile accidents, develops a rather dubious chain of reasoning. He is against it because it would give "shyster" lawyers opportunity for fomenting unfounded lawsuits.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Greater fire power and combat effectiveness for the regiment as a tactical unit is expected from a new form of organization announced by the War Department today, made possible by the development of semi-automatic rifles and light machine guns.

Reflecting preparations for her projected campaign in Ethiopia, Italy was shown yesterday by Commerce Department figures to have more than doubled her purchases of scrap iron and steel through the port of New York during July, as compared with June, according to The Associated Press.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 28. -- Today was observed as Stratford Day at the Greenbrier. The program included a morning musicale in the Virginia room by the Greenbrier Chamber Music Society, Lon Chassy conducting; a bridge and tea for the benefit of Stratford Hall, Robert E. Lee's birthplace, and a memorial address on General Lee by Francis Pendleton Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University, given in the Cameo Room tonight.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The league-leading Tigers concluded their longest home stand of the season by shutting out the Athletics, 11 to 0, today behind the four-hit pitching of Roxie Lawson, a rookie right-hander obtained from Toledo a week ago.

"It is no inconsiderable wisdom" said BURKE, if we quote him right, "to know how much evil should be tolerated." For the moment the Democrats in the Senate are heated up to the point of regarding the senior Senator from Louisiana as an unbearable force of unrighteousness.

BOLZANO, Aug. 28. -- Before coming here today, Premier Mussolini addressed his officers, who are supervising vast manoeuvres in this section of Northern Italy, and congratulated them upon the fine showing their troops have made. This demonstrates, he said, that the Italian Army is ready for any eventualities.

After a three-month fight against leukemia, a mysterious blood disease, during which he displayed courage that won the admiration of President Roosevelt and other notables, John Adam Ulrich, 16-yearold Grover Cleveland High School honor student, died Tuesday night in New York Hospital.

All negotiations for the erection of the new $5,500,000 Brooklyn College on the Wood-Harmon site in Flatbush were halted yesterday when notice was received by Controller Frank J. Taylor that the Community Councils of New York had appealed their injunction suit and obtained a stay until Oct. 4.
Judges for the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden were announced yesterday by the National Horse Show Association. The annual exhibition will be held from Nov. 6 to 12.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Lou Gehrig's twenty-seventh home run and two superlative pitching performances by Johnny Allen and Charley (Red) Ruffing at Comiskey Park today gave the Yankees both ends of their fourth straight twin bill with the White Sox.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 28. -- The news from Lucerne that Dr. Judah L. Magnes has resigned the chancellorship of the Hebrew University here is premature. It is no secret he is contemplating such action because of lack of funds required for the maintenance and expansion of the university, especially since this has become an institution to which ousted German Jewish scholars and students now turn.

ROME, Aug. 28. -- The first Cabinet war council dealing with Italy's preparations for conflict with Ethiopia was held at Bolzano this afternoon under the chairmanship of Premier Benito Mussolini, who made a thorough examination of Italy's position with regard not only to Ethiopia but also to the League of Nations and the European powers that have taken an active part in the African issue.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson entertained at a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at The Crossways, her home in Main Street, for Mrs. Henry White of Elm Court, Lenox, Mass., who is spending the late season at the Meadow Club.

Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that he had written to Health Commissioner John L. Rice to ask whether the prevalence of infantile paralysis made it advisable to postpone the opening of the city schools from the scheduled date of Monday, Sept. 9.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Washington and St. Louis broke even today, the Senators snapping the Browns' winning streak of five games to take the first, 10 to 2.

Aside from furs, which have continued to give a notably good account of themselves, active consumer demand for Fall apparel thus far has not expanded much. Sports coats and three-piece suits have stood out in the business which has been done and these items are counted on to do notably well during the coming month.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 28. -- Joining his fiancee, Miss Elizabeth Appenzellar of Rye, and Donald C. Appenzellar at the Mount Washington today, to remain over Labor Day, was E.G. McLaughlin of New York.
The inquiry for money being light in all departments, quotations were carried forward without change.

It is intimated at Washington that the State Department is preparing to answer the Russian reply to its note of protest. That is the natural and almost necessary thing to do. The affair cannot be left hanging in the air by our Government, if it is to consult its own dignity and consistency.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 28. -- The disquieting military outlook in the Baltic region, particularly the insistent rumors of forthcoming elaborate Russian and German naval establishments, is clearly reflected in the Finnish budget bill for 1936 soon to be introduced in Parliament.

Despite the fact that the Post-office Department in Washington announced on Aug. 24 that the Eastern air mail terminal would not be transferred from Newark Airport to Floyd Bennett Field as Mayor La Guardia had urged, the Mayor's Committee on Airport Development, headed by Grover A. Whalen, made public yesterday the selection of a group of its members to press for the designation of the municipal airport as a mail terminal for the Eastern district.
GENOA, Aug. 28. -- Marquis Guglielmo Marconi, distinguished inventor, quietly announced today his intention of joining the colors in Italy's prospective war with Ethiopia.

Reports that the French Government has decided not to go along with Great Britain in adopting "sanctions" against Italy seem to be authentic. It is not that France loves Italy, but that she shrinks from entering upon a course of which she cannot foresee the end.

Passenger traffic increased 5 per cent and freight traffic 4.8 per cent in the first twenty-one days of this month on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, H.S. Palmer, president, said yesterday. He said that a large amount of equipment was being pressed into service in anticipation of a record passenger movement over the Labor Day week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- President Roosevelt took personal charge today of the question of relations with the Soviet Union. He summoned Secretary Hull, Assistant Secretary R. Walton Moore and Robert Kelly, Russian expert of the State Department, to the White House for a formal conference this afternoon, but no announcement was forthcoming at its conclusion.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Indians won their series with the Red Sox, three games out of five, by blanking the visitors, 2 to 0, in the first game of double-header today and then going on to win the second, 3 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The Rocky Mountain West was affected vitally by the filibuster which killed the Third Deficiency Appropriation measure in the closing hours of the Seventy-fourth Congress.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- Although business remained quiet on the London Stock Exchange today a more cheerful feeling prevailed with the belief that after the settlement tomorrow investment buying will be resumed because of the more hopeful view of the Ethiopian situation.

Attorney General Homer S. Cummings sailed yesterday on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines for a vacation in Europe combined with business. While abroad he will study the latest methods in dealing with the crime problem in London, Paris, Brussels and Rome.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Many prominent visitors are arriving here for the final races, with the Hopeful, richest rose of the season, as the feature on Saturday.

The independent debenture holders' committee for fifteen-year 5 1/2 per cent debentures of the McCrory Stores Corporation sent yesterday to holders a letter summarizing the new plan of reorganization filed in the United States District Court here.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Ten persons were known to be dead and nine missing at Kobe today as a typhoon, having swept over Kyushu and Shikoku Islands struck at the industrial heart of the empire. The storm spread over a wide area on the main island from Hiroshimai to Tokyo.

Spokesmen for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company scoffed yesterday at reports that one of their employes had been used as a spy to report on activities of the Transport Workers Union, an organization of subway, bus and street car workers.

Concerning yesterday's war council of the Italian Cabinet, some time must no doubt elapse before we shall know just how much debate preceded the Cabinet's unanimous decision. But it is already safe to say that right from the beginning the utmost harmony and cooperation prevailed among an influential section of the Cabinet.

Wallowing hopelessly in the trough of a high sea, with motors dead, rudder bent and the captain feeling none too well, the Giants were knocked violently off their pennant course for two more points on the compass yesterday as the Pirates scuttled them in both ends of a double-header at the Polo Grounds.

WARSAW, Aug. 28. -- As adjourned games in the fifteenth and sixteenth rounds ended tonight in the international team chess tournament at the Officers' Casino, Poland, Sweden and the United States were bunched practically on even terms.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- A gathering of the American Legion bringing 50,000 visitors here for its annual State convention made Rochester tonight a carnival city. Trappings were everywhere. Curb flags stirred gently. Atop high buildings others whipped out straight.
As a Republican I read with great interest the report in THE TIMES of Senator Carey's recent exposition of the issues of the coming Presidential campaign.

Former Mayor James J. Walker may be expected back in New York in a month or six weeks, close friends asserted yesterday. The Department of Justice announced Tuesday that no income tax prosecution would be attempted against him.

"Top Hat," a Pandro S. Berman production for RKO Radio, directed by Mark Sandrich and with lyrics and music by Irving Berlin, opens at noon today at the Radio City Music Hall. Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers are in featured roles.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- Incomplete returns for yesterday's registration of Philadelphia voters for the Mayoralty primary election of Sept. 17 indicated that on the first of the Fall registration days neither the Republicans nor Democrats had made substantial gains at the expense of the other.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Consideration by the Agriculture Adjustment Administration of plans for plowing under a part of this year's estimated 377,000,000-bushel potato crop was disclosed today in connection with an announcement by the agency that it would begin strict control of the 1936 crop by taxation of excess production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Allotments totaling $20,218,000 for carrying out 613 projects for women in forty-one States were approved today by President Roosevelt. The types of work under the allotments will consist of library work, Braille transcription, art, music, records and clerical work, research and special surveys, emergency homemaking, landscape beautification and community service.

One of the greatest concessions in the history of the defense of the America's Cup by the New York Yacht Club may be made if a challenge is received this Fall for a match next year. It is a proposition that the challenging yacht need not be named until thirty days before the first race.

In announcing sales of three tenement houses in the Yorkville section yesterday Philip Brauneis Jr. of Hardy Brauneis, brokers in the deals, said activity in that area indicated a return to the market of many investors who have not been in the market in some years.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in comparatively active dealing. Sugar futures were lower because of the uncertainty of the ability of refiners to maintain the 20-point advance in wholesale refined prices announced recently.

An agreement in principle has been reached with respect to the handling of the issuance of bonds by the Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts in payment of interest maturing on German dollar bonds from July 1, 1934, to June 30, 1936, it was announced yesterday by Stewart C. Pratt, chairman of the fiscal agents committee for the German dollar bonds outstanding in the United States.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 28. -- The Foreign Ministers of the four Scandinavian countries broadcast simultaneous appeals for peace tonight.

Decision to maintain the present terms of 1-10, net 60, was reached yesterday at a meeting of mill executives and sales agents held under the auspices of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at the Manhattan Club.

Before a group of 230 listeners, including many leading high and prep school coaches and a considerable number of college mentors, Lou Little of Columbia made forward passing the subject of his third discussion at The Herald Tribune's football school at the newspaper's auditorium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The resignation of James A. Moffett as Federal Housing Administrator, effective Sept. 1, was accepted "reluctantly" by President Roosevelt today. The announcement was made at the White House with the release of Mr. Moffett's letter of resignation, dated Aug. 22, and the President's letter of acceptance, dated as of Monday.

Although no definite date has been set, the Board of Estimate was expected yesterday to meet later this week or early next week to act upon the September appropriation for relief. Members of the board already have indicated, although no definite figure has been agreed upon, that relief grants for September and future months will be reduced.

Work on the first section of the $25,000,000 East River Drive, which its supporters hope will be the beginning of "a new birth for the lower East Side," got off to a colorful start yesterday noon when ground was broken at elaborate ceremonies at the foot of Grand Street.

The budget of the Police Department for 1936, totaling $58,030,574 and providing for the restoration of the force to its full quota, was submitted by Commissioner Valentine yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- To J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, John Hamilton was the "most cunning'' crook in the Dillinger gang but also was rated "as we in the bureau rate all gangsters -- to us they're rats."

In the face of a protest from Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, refused yesterday to reconsider his dismissal of relief teachers who left their posts on play school projects to take part in a stoppage demonstration last week.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- Baroness de Villiers Terrage, who is spending her first Summer here with her family, today donated the prizes for a young girls' singles tennis tournament on the courts of the Newport Casino.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Hugh White, wealthy Columbia lumberman, who charged that Senator Long of Louisiana sought to bring about his defeat to extend the Louisiana "dictator's" political influence into Mississippi, had received the Democratic nomination for Governor of Mississippi tonight on the basis of unofficial returns from Tuesday's run-off primary.
Various theories have been advanced by big-game anglers and fishing guides in the effort to explain the numerous catches of marlin in our offshore waters this season.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 28. -The contention that the body of the infant found near the Lindbergh estate in Hopewell, N.J., was not that of Charles E. Lindbergh Jr. will be one of the chief defense points in new legal plans to save the life of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, condemned to die for the kidnapping and slaying of the baby, according to C. Lloyd Fisher, Hauptmann's counsel.

Any one in New York State who does not like his name and wants to change it, can do so without any legal formality whatever, according to an editorial published yesterday by The New York Law Journal. Provided he has no intent of fraud or imposture, he can assume and use any name he pleases.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 28. -Five pairs were closely grouped for leading honors in the North Jersey Coast-bridge pair tournament when the final session of play was resumed here tonight.

Previous city administrations have attended especially to the needs of the West Side of Manhattan. The elevated roadway along the waterfront and the removal of the railroad tracks from grade along "Death Avenue" are the fruit of their labors. It was natural that Mayor LA GUARDIA, with his predominantly social outlook, should turn his eyes to the east, where the great problem of the slums has remained unsolved for so many years.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 28. -- The Governor of Aussa has reported a raid by Issa tribesmen from French Somaliland on his territory for the purpose of stealing cattle. In a skirmish which followed sixty of the raiders were killed. The Ethiopian casualties were not reported.
You publish a letter from Thomas J. Barrett, who seeks an explanation for the President's so-called "must" legislation.

Eleven-year-old Billy Gordon, who did it once before, stole the show last night at a special meeting under the auspices of the Notional Poetry Centre in the horti-cultural hall of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

The Dodgers wound up their home stand against the Western clubs yesterday by defeating the Reds, 4 to 2, to gain an even break in the series and the undistinguished record of winning just half of the twenty-two contests with the hinterland teams.
