Freeman Co. will oppose the treatment proposed by O.P. Van Sweringen for holders of $12,140,000 of 5 1/4 per cent secured serial bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad at hearings on the plan to be held in October under the Bankruptcy Law, Ernest L. Nye, a partner in the firm, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- While little or no improvement was reported in the demand for fresh pork, the light receipts of hogs hero was said to have resulted in packers being able to work off some of the accumulation of pork products which piled up when consumers refused to pay high prices.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 28. -- Pope Pius, in an address yesterday, made a strong appeal against recourse to war as a means of solving the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, the Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, disclosed tonight.

Unless the silver policy of the United States is reversed, it may make China susceptible to an enlargement of Japanese influence within her borders and even make likely an eventual economic consolidation of Asiatic peoples, the New York Trust Company asserts in a discussion of China's economic difficulties in its publication, The Index.

Inclement weather will not be a factor tonight when Jack Doyle, Irish heavyweight, and Buddy Baer clash in their six-round battle at Madison Square Garden. A week ago, when the fight was slated as an outdoor show at the Madison Square Garden Bowl, rain caused a postponement.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 28. -Upon the developments of the New Deal and other "resolute and intelligent readjustments of our constitutional Federal republic to the needs of modern democracy and industrial society" will depend the future course of American history toward a dictatorship of the "right" or the "left," according to Dr. Frank Porter Graham, president of the University of North Carolina.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- Official Russian quarters refrained today from discussion of yesterday's Foreign Office note rejecting the United States protest against Communist International activities.

Bertrand Coles Neidecker, Mrs. Neidecker and his brother, George, were questioned further here yesterday before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, in bankruptcy proceedings instituted Aug. 9 on behalf of creditors of the closed Travelers Bank and its branches maintained by Neidecker et Cie., in Paris, Cannes, London, Amsterdam, Singapore and other cities.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 28. -- Cerise, white diamonds, cerise sleeves, white cap; the racing colors of young Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the 22-year-old owner of Discovery and other thoroughbreds not quite as fast as the king of the handicap division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- A move to pursuade a special House committee to begin an investigation of the Louisiana political situation this Fall was started tonight as opponents of Senator Long expressed gratification over the committee's personnel.
The right of persons charged with contempt of court for violating labor injunctions to demand jury trials was upheld by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn yesterday.

William Randolph Hearst made a formal gesture last night to heal his historic breach with former Governor Alfred E. Smith by suggesting him as a possible leader of an independent group of conservative Democrats to combat the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt in 1936.

Hope that the Utility Holding Company Law will be amended before its provisions for divestment of subsidiaries widely separated geographically become effective on Jan. 1, 1938, was expressed yesterday by J.F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Increased compensation checks will be sent out Sept. 1 by the Veterans' Administration to about 210,000 Spanish-American War veterans and their dependents as the result of Congressional action in restoring these claimants to the benefits they enjoyed previous to the passage of the Economy Act of 1933.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- With the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations, at which the entire Italo-Ethiopian dispute will come up for decision, barely a week off, British subjects in Ethiopia received instructions from consulates today to leave the country within four days.

By fast mail from Hollywood there arrived yesterday on this column's doorstep a bulletin from Eddie Cantor, stating that he has definitely had to call off his plan to appear this Fall in Vinton Freedley's proposed musical show. He was sorry, because he liked the idea.
WARSAW, Aug. 28. -- The Polish Government has not made any protest to Moscow against recent activities of Communists and, as far as is known, has no intention of doing so.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- France's decision to steer a middle course between League of Nations principles and her interest in retaining Italian friendship was confirmed today at a Cabinet meeting, which was presided over by President Albert Lebrun and to which Premier Pierre Laval gave a long explanation of his views and intentions.

Retail shopping space was featured in the listings of commercial rentals yesterday. Several men's and women's clothing shops were among the lessees. A new men's clothing establishment rented the second floor in Loew's State Theatre Building, and a number of other rentals on Broadway were reported. The list follows:

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 28. -- Tentative plans for memorials to Will Rogers, cowboy humorist who was killed in a plane crash with Wiley Post two weeks ago, were discussed here today with citizens of Claremore, home town of the actor.

Although producers of iron and steel have discontinued the practice of filing price schedules with the American Iron and Steel Institute, many individual companies may open their books formally by Sept. 3, Iron Age said yesterday in its weekly summary of conditions in the trade.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- President Roosevelt expressed satisfaction today with the neutrality resolution as a temporary expedient, and set tomorrow for its signing to give it the force of law.

OSWEGO, Ill., Aug. 28.-- Federal agents who found the body of John Hamilton near here today said they identified the body of the Dillinger gang's machine-gunner from the teeth and expressed the opinion that Hamilton was fatally wounded April 23, 1934, in a battle with officers at South St. Paul.

The West Side Association of Commerce, undaunted by the rebuke administered to it by Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Jefferson Market Court Tuesday, voted yesterday to continue its campaign of cooperation with the Police Department to rid the midtown district of peddlers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- About $276,000,000 in additional income taxes was levied by the Treasury Department during the 1934-35 fiscal year as the result of investigations by agents of the income tax unit, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Congressional experts disclosed today that one short paragraph tucked away in the Tax Bill awaiting President Roosevelt's signature holds wide potentialities for the elimination of holding companies.

In line with a broad program for the unification of certain operating subsidiaries, which has been under consideration for more than two years, the United States Steel Corporation will adopt on Oct. 1 a plan of unified operation for its two principal subsidiaries, the Carnegie Steel Company of Pittsburgh and the Illinois Steel Company of Chicago, it was announced yesterday.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company has declared an extra dividend of 87 1/2 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Oct. 1, to stock of record of Sept. 14. In the previous quarter an extra dividend of 37 1/2 cents was paid.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 (AP). -H. Robert Braden, senior warden of Trinity Episcopal Church here, said today the vestry had decided to inquire into alleged "radical" activities of Dr. Lorin Bradford Young of Brooklyn, N.Y., newly named rector of the San Francisco church.

NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Harland Beardslee successfully defended the International Star Class championship in his Sloop By-C today, although finishing sixth in the fleet of sixteen starters. Today's final race of the series was won by the Three Star Too of San Francisco in 2 hours 9 minutes 58 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The temporary scuttling of the social security program until Congress can meet in January, due to the killing of the Third Deficiency Bill by Senator Long's filibuster in the closing hours of Congress, was confirmed today by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Leon Cohen, assistant director of the Trading and Exchange Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has resigned to become treasurer and vice president of the Standard National Corporation, a realty company of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The British Independent Socialist party called upon organized labor today to exert every effort to thwart Mussolini's African program. There was a possibility that labor organizations throughout Europe would act through general strikes and boycotts to combat Italy in the event of war.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, telegraphed a demand to the American Federation of Teachers, meeting here today, that they must purge their ranks of Communists and communism.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 28. -Bally MacShane, 21-year-old hero of many a hard-fought battle over the jumps in this and other countries, today captured the honors in the open jumping event of the first day of the sixteenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair horse show.

Work was seriously curtailed on the Hamilton Fish park project yesterday when many of the 500, men employed there dropped their work in protest against failure of the Works Progress Administration to deliver pay checks due since Aug. 15.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- After more than 170 men and boys, aided by bloodhounds and a scouting airplane, had scoured near-by woods and hills for twenty-four hours, the body of Arthur W. Butler Jr., 20-year-old son of a New York broker, was found at 3 o'clock this afternoon in a wooded section about a mile from his home on Chestnut Ridge Road, Bedford Township.

A new issue of $180,000 refunding school bonds of Highland Park, Mich., School District has been purchased by Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., of Toledo at 100.286 for 2 1/2s. The bonds are dated Sept. 10, 1935, and will be payable on March 15, 1937 to 1943.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The Reich leader of physicians, Gerhard Wagner, has forbidden all German medical men to attend the international medical congress at Montreux, Switzerland, next month. The prohibition results from an article criticizing certain Nazi eugenic and racial ideas which was printed in a magazine published at Basle, Switzerland.

Eight Tuesday evening concerts in Carnegie Hall, with Leopold Stokowski conducting five, will be the Philadelphia Orchestra's contribution to the new season in New York, the eighteenth for this organization as a visitor to Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The league-leading St. Louis Cardinals stormed through to a double victory over the Phillies today before a record week-day throng of 14,000 and increased their lead to 2 1/2 games over the New York Giants, who lost twice to Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- When the Senate convenes in January one of the first moves of the administration leaders will be an attempt to amend the Senate rules to end for all time "one-man" filibusters such as that staged Monday night by Senator Long, who in the closing hours of the session harangued to death the Third Deficiency Bill, carrying funds for the administration of the new Social Security Law and other agencies.

A $100,000 damage suit against Joseph A. Martin, Rockland County political leader, who is chairman of the Suffern Alcoholic Beverage Control Board and superintendent and general manager of the Suffern Stone Company, brought by Mrs. Agnes Cuomo of 129 Orange Avenue, Suffern, wife of Joseph Cuomo, a former employe of the company, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The legality of the $50,000,000 loan made in 1932 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, the old Dawes bank, has been attacked in the Federal court here by a group of stockholders headed by John A. Lynch, it was disclosed today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 29. -- After a strike lasting nearly sixteen weeks, 3,385 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation "clocked in" on time for the resumption of work this morning on seven naval vessels to cost more than $50,000,000.

Members of the syndicate operated in 1929 for the purchase and sale of stock in the Curtiss-Wright Corporation charged in the Supreme Court yesterday that the syndicate managers conducted the transactions in such a way that the managers made large sums and the members lost heavily.

Pending adjustment of their difficulties with the Board of Education, eighty relief teachers who were dismissed because of the stoppage demonstration they staged against working conditions last week, will be placed in other posts under the WPA by General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, it was learned yesterday.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 29 (Reuters). -- French railway officials here are exceedingly concerned for the safety of the Franco-Ethiopian railway in the event that war breaks out between Italy and Ethiopia.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. -- Mrs. Lyttleton Fox gave a large reception this afternoon at the Irving. A feature of the entertainment was a fashion show arranged by Sibour, in which members of the Summer colony acted as manikins. Francis Hartman Markoe designed the setting on a specially constructed platform with a black velvet cyclorama.

Abbott Laboratories has declared an extra dividend of 30 cents and a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents, both payable on Oct. 1 to stock of record of Sept. 18. The same amounts were paid in the preceding quarter.
Four types of electrical waves occurring in the human brain during sleep have been recorded by three scientists at the Loomis Laboratory, Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

" I was extremely interested in Charles A. French's views on cutting the line and releasing small bass deeply hooked," writes Edward Bozorth. "It gives me an excuse to get something off my chest that's been troubling me for some time -- namely, not merely decent treatment of bass and other game fish, but size limits.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 29. -- Queen Astrid's tragic death has plunged the whole Belgian people for the second time within eighteen months into the deepest mourning. There is such grief as has seldom been seen on the faces of the whole people.

The Rev. Dr. John Gass, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Charleston, W. Va., has been elected rector of the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. Dr. Gass has accepted the rectorship and will enter the pulpit here on Nov. 3.

Issuance of a subpoena for certain records of the Guaranty Trust Company relating to the reorganization of the Cuba Cane Sugar Corporation and the Cuban Cane Products Company, Inc., was ordered yesterday by Thomas W. Arnold, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, as the SEC continued here an investigation of the reorganizations begun last week in Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- Aboard the United States destroyer Aylwin, a navy crew sorrowed today over the death of Queen Astrid of the Belgians. They remembered her as a "young and lovely woman who won the hearts of every one of us," when the destroyer visited Belgium last month.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Aug. 29. -- Some of the details of the plans of Endeavour II, the new boat with which T.O.M. Sopwith expects to challenge for the America's Cup, were made known today.

In your editorial on the Russian answer to the American note protesting propaganda you contend that the agreement not to permit the formation or residence of any group with the purpose of furthering social changes in American institutions was binding upon Russia, but "that we have not bound ourselves never to do or permit such things on American soil."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The creation of two independent parties by Democrats opposed to New Deal policies and a combination of Hooverites with certain other Old Guard Republican elements to weaken the popular demand for Senator Borah, now leading Republican possibility, are occupying the attention of political leaders.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- In the event of war between Abyssinia and Italy, neither the United States nor any European State could possibly intervene on the side of Abyssinia. Signor Mussolini knows this. He has a free hand in Abyssinia, and it would be far kinder to the Abyssinians and increase Signor Mussolini's responsibility to public opinion if the fact were at once acknowledged.

Somehow this business of declaring that every new and progressive piece of legislation is unconstitutional immediately after its proposal, and particularly after its passage, is taking on a decidedly farcical air.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- An additional judgeship in the Federal Court for the Eastern District of New York was created today when President Roosevelt signed a bill authorizing him to make the appointment.

Coast Guard cutters searched the waters and airplanes scanned the countryside yesterday for a monoplane flown by Donald K. Phillips, 23 years old, sportsman pilot, who has not been heard from since he took off Wednesday morning from Roosevelt Field for Providence, R.I.

NETCONG, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The trial of Will Searles, farmer, accused of disturbing the peace in peeping at a nudists' camp adjoining his farm and telling the nudists what he thought of them, was adjourned indefinitely today after an uproarious three-hour session in the Borough Hall here.
ROME, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Shocked by the death of Queen Astrid of the Belgians, Italy turned immediately to Il Duce himself to break the tragic news to the Italian royal family.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 29. -- The Aurora polo team, one of the favorites for the national open championship, was forced to rally in the final periods to conquer the Old Westbury riders, 9 to 6, in a test match on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Foreign exchanges were generally weaker in terms of the dollar yesterday. Sterling fell 1/2 cent to $4.97 1/4, the franc was off 3/4 point to 6.61 3/4 cents, the guilder dropped 2 points to 67.80 cents and the Swiss franc declined 4 points to 32.65 cents.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- Within France, and even within her Cabinet, there is evidence of a growing sentiment that finally, if a showdown on the African situation comes at Geneva, France must stand by the League of Nations.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Another attempt at a stratosphere flight will be made from the Black Hills "stratobowl" near Rapid City, S.D., in October, weather permitting, it was announced today.

President Roosevelt has worked out a plan for balancing the Federal budget in 1939 and substituting a $500,000,000 surplus for the present deficit, according to an article by George Creel, appearing in today's issue of Collier's Weekly.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 29. -- New and lower prices for crude oil will be posted by the major marketing companies tomorrow on the heels of price cuts by the Standard Oil Company of California.

NEWARK, Aug. 29. -- The Newark Bears opened their four-game series with Syracuse tonight with a 6-to-0 victory behind the seven-hit pitching of Steve Sundra. It was the right-hander's fourth victory in five starts since joining the Newark club three weeks ago. He fanned eight and walked only one.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Secretary Morgenthau is essaying the role of budget-balancer and is urging upon President Roosevelt a policy of curtailing government expenditures beginning with the fiscal year which starts July 1, 1936, it was learned today.

A judgment for $9,345 was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas Magraw, who was the widow of Edward R. Thomas, in a suit by her former attorney, Charles Rosenbaum, to collect $13,575 for legal services.

LUCERNE, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Saddened by the death of Queen Astrid of the Belgians, delegates to the World Zionist Congress held quiet sectional conferences today, the congress agreeing to hold three sessions daily in an attempt to regain time lost in religious debate.

The Deutsche Bank und Disconto-Gesellschaft of Berlin yesterday issued notice to holders of certificates of participation in its $25,000,000 five-year 6 per cent note due on Sept. 1 next, offering them payment in blocked reichsmark or an extension of the maturity date to Sept. 1, 1938.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29. -- Even though finishing the last race at the end of a tow-line after placing fifth in the morning, the boys from the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club carried off their third successive Sears Cup series and national junior sailing championship today.

The German-American Technologists Association, which was refused accommodations at the New Yorker Hotel, the Hotel Astor and the Down Town Athletic Club, announced yesterday that it would hold its convention tomorrow, Sunday and Monday at Jaeger's Turnhalle, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Gaining admittance through a telephone ruse, two armed men entered the apartment of Miss Janice Dawson, an actress, on the fourth floor of a five-story building at 224 East Forty-ninth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, early last night and robbed Miss Dawson and one of three friends of jewelry valued by them at $4,000.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

To the accompaniment of the slowest trading since mid-July, the share market edged higher yesterday, closing steady with the average gain for leading issues amounting to about 1/2 point. With transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregating but 903,000 shares, the smallest volume for a full trading period since July 16, the market reflected lack of professional interest, inasmuch as many traders have already departed for Labor Day holidays.

The petition designating Charles A. Loretto as Democratic candidate for justice of the First Bronx Municipal Court was rejected by Supreme Court Justice Rosenman yesterday on the ground that it was short 142 valid signatures.

The lack of immediate funds to launch the Social Security Act is not likely to prove a serious obstacle. The necessary appropriations are almost certain to be voted by the next session of Congress in four or five months, and in the interval the work of organization can be got under way.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Bold Lover put on a driving finish to win the $1,500 Autumn opening handicap before a crowd of 10,000 at the Detroit Fair Grounds track today, beating Bamboula by half a length. Miss Monoa closed with a rush to finish a length behind Bamboule.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today allowed an appeal from two orders entered by District Judge William H. Holly in the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation's 77-b reorganization.

Mrs. Dorothy (Sunshine) Browning Hood, adopted daughter of the late Edward West Browning, real estate dealer, is without funds and in debt, according to a petition of her legal guardian and counsel, Daniel A. Shirk. He petitioned Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday to direct the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, executor of the estate, to advance payment of her legacy.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Queen Astrid's death was received here when the pages of newspapers were filled with accounts of heavy casualities in British road accidents which have been responsible for nearly four thousand deaths already this year.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- When Italy throws upon the Council table of the League of Nations next week her elaborately compiled dossier of Ethiopia's sins and shortcomings as an excuse for Premier Benito Mussolini's projected war, the dossier will not be presented before measures have been taken to offset it. In fact, it will come rather as a plea in defense than as a measure of attack.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The cost of hogs to packers increased again today, the smallness of receipts at leading markets more than offsetting the continued slow demand for fresh pork. Despite the unseasonably cool weather, there has been no increase in consumption, according to reports.

John Schroeder, managing director of passenger traffic for the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd combination in the United States, said on his return from Germany yesterday that the recent government order directing decentralization in part of the company's units would not have any effect on the North Atlantic routes.

ATHENS, Aug. 29. -- Italy has begun preparations toward closing the Adriatic in case it should become necessary to control traffic. Confidential telegrams to John Rhallis, the Greek Minister of the Interior, announce that strategic points in Albania along the coast are being armed and fortified by Italians.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Another romance in the British royal family was revealed tonight by the announcement that the Duke of Gloucester, third son of King George and Queen Mary, was engaged to Lady Alice Montagu-Douglas-Scott, fair-haired daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Buccleuch and Queensberry.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, yesterday announced thirty honor scholarship awards for the coming academic year to upper-class students in the Washington Square College. They have a total value of $4,300.

The report of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries, other than the Crown Willamette Paper Company and its subsidiaries, for the three months ended on July 31, shows a net profit of $502,019 after giving effect to all charges for depreciation, depletion, debenture interest and income taxes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- Conflicting influences tended today to restrict speculative interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade. Heavy selling early by a house with Eastern connections was absorbed by professional traders and by brokers here who frequently act for mills, and a rally to above yesterday's finish followed.

The annual Labor Day week-end exodus from the city begins today, and indications yesterday were that the railroads, bus and airlines and steamship companies would be called upon to handle the heaviest holiday traffic in years.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29. -- Resolutions adopted by the recent Communist International Congress, whose activities brought a protest from the United States, instructed "comrades" in all capitalist countries to "bring the working masses closer to a revolutionary assumption of power," publication in the Communist party organ Pravda disclosed today.
Subsidiaries of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday as follows for July and the twelve months:
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The Chicago Bears, champions of the Western division of the National Football League, downed the college All-Star eleven, 5 to 0, on Soldier Field tonight before 85,000 spectators. The last half was played in a torrential downpour of rain.

Max Reinhardt has abandoned his plan of producing "Die Fledermaus" for the Salzburg Music Festival this season and will return to this country early in October, according to a cablegram received yesterday by Warner Brothers from A. Ronald Button, the German producer's attorney.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29. -- Announcement of the death of Queen Astrid was received with horror and dismay in Sweden. The people read special editions of the newspapers, at first in profound silence, most of them unable to believe.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday, although trading activity was limited. Sugar futures receded further on the rescinding of the recent markup of 20 points in the price of refined sugar by several refineries. In the cash market, corn, butter, printcloths, silk and rubber were higher, while wheat, rye, raw sugar, eggs and cotton were lower.

The heaviest rains in Oklahoma in several weeks, fifteen stations reporting one to more than four inches, served to halt deterioration of the planted cotton over a large area and caused a decline of 2 to 15 points in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29. -- The Little Entente conference opened this morning in Bled with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch presiding. The conversations lasted several hours, but no communique was issued.

WARSAW, Aug. 29. -- By finishing their adjourned games from the fifteenth, sixteenth and seventeenth round matches, and drawing all three, members of the United States chess team tonight increased the squad's points to 47 1/2 and held a 1-point lead over Poland and Sweden, which were tied for second with 46 1/2 in the international tourney at the Officers' Casino.

SOLON, Ohio. Aug. 29. -- An Indiana "sure-shot" and a marksman from Massachusetts led the way today as 114 of the nation's outstanding skeet shooters started their three-day race for the all-bore championship.
Buddy Baer, younger brother of the former heavyweight champion of the world, successfully repulsed the foreign threat that was Jack Doyle at Madison Square Garden last night.
Sale will be made on Sept. 16 by the State of Arizona of a new issue of $690,000 tax anticipation notes. Bidders are asked to name the interest rate.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- A surprising three-length victory was scored by Mantagna in the Huron Handicap today, as most players vainly backed Whiskolo from the Milky Way Farm of Mrs. Ethel Mars. Poor judgment by the other riders enabled Jockey Eddie Litzenberger to steal off to such an early lead with Mantagna that there was little contention in the run through the stretch.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- The Boerse was inactive today, although resistant to the recent tendency toward weakness. Few advances of more than a half point were registered, and some securities continued to drop.

Just when the outlook seemed darkest for Bill Terry's floundering Giants those sunshine dispensers from Flatbush, the Dodgers, galloped onto the Polo Grounds field yesterday and chased nearly all the clouds away.
PINE CAMP, Aug. 29. -- By train and truck 17,000 soldiers left the Pine Camp area today as the greatest mobilization of American troops since World War days ended.

Construction by the city of a series of model housing units for the army of city employes, especially those in the low-salaried posts, is being given serious consideration by Mayor La Guardia, it was learned yesterday.

To what extent this country's decreased importation of gold during July ($16,287,000, as against $230,538,000 in June) was connected with our adverse balance of foreign trade may be debatable. The month's $4,327,000 excess of merchandise imports over exports, as reported last week, and its $28,683,000 excess of silver imports, would certainly not of themselves have created foreign credits giving command of foreign gold.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were conducted today in a cheerful atmosphere, although business was restricted by the settlement date. British funds were easier owing to absence of support. Foreign bonds were quiet.

Carlos Hevia, who for a brief time was President of Cuba following the overthrow of the Machado government, was cleared yesterday of all Federal charges brought against him here in 1932, when it was alleged that he had attempted to send a filibustering expedition into the domain of a friendly power.

The statement issued by the Italian Government -- that is, by MUSSOLINI -- is a strange mixture. In parts it maintains the familiar note of defiance and determination. Nothing can swerve Italy from her course. She is prepared, or preparing, for every possibility, even that of a prolonged war. The financial decrees already made public show to what lengths she may be driven to obtain money to pay the costs of a war.

An accounting filed in the Surrogate's Court here yesterday revealed that trusts established in 1899 under the will of Cornelius G. Vanderbilt for the benefit of his children and grandchildren were still worth more than three-quarters of their original principal value.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The league-leading Cardinals lost to the fast-flying Pirates today as Big Jim Weaver turned in one of the finest pitching jobs of his career to down the great Dizzy Dean, 5 to 1.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29. -- Tony Manero of Sedgefield, N.C., Gone Kunes of Norristown, Pa., and Jimmy Hines of Garden City, N.Y., shared the lead after the first eighteen-hole skirmishing in the Canadian open golf championship at the Summerlea Club today.

Thirty Filipino Boy Scouts, touring this country following the cancellation of the National Jamboree on Aug. 8, gave a demonstration of native songs and dances, as well as Scout manoeuvres, yesterday morning on the roof of the Park Avenue Building, occupied as national headquarters by the Boy Scouts of America at 2 Park Avenue.

Russia's sharp rejection of the protest of our State Department emphasizes one of the major weaknesses of the Bullitt document. Our complaint was based solely on the debates in the recent sessions at Moscow of the World Congress of the Communist International.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City dropped $15,000,000 net in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of these institutions, published yesterday. The reduction was due to a fall of $75,000,000 in security loans, non-security loans being, up $7,000,000 and investments up $53,000,000 in the week.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Combining her effective long game with a fine display of short shots, Mrs. Edward Stevens of Greenwich today scored an excellent 83 over the testing links of the Green Meadow Club to win the low gross prize in an eighteen-hole handicap tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, joined the ranks of officers and principal stockholders of corporations who made substantial gifts in July when the inheritance and higher gifts taxes were being urged by President Roosevelt, it was revealed today in reports made public by the SEC.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- If the keepers of Frank Buck's zoo at Massapequa, N.Y., think monkeys on the loose there are a lot of trouble, they have not seen anything yet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Disposition by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $14,489,500 of municipal bonds originally pledged as collateral security for PWA construction loans was announced today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC.

Registering a gain of 25.5 per cent over 1934, bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., totaled $4,555,636,000 against $3,622,921,000 a year ago.
Your paper has again contributed not only to journalism but to the best in diplomacy. Your editorial "Neutrality or Sanctions" proves this conclusively.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- Harry Kritzke, 60-year-old eccentric, had two hobbies. One was his passion for good books and the other was making counterfeit money.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- With more than seventy horses, most of them owned by New Jersey and Pennsylvania exhibitors, in the entry lists, the two-day horse show portion of the annual Flemington Agricultural Fair opened today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The provision in the 1935 Tax Bill, now awaiting the approval of the President, which drops, under certain conditions, capital gain levies in the liquidation of subsidiaries by holding corporations apparently is not clearly understood by many whose properties would be directly or indirectly affected, experts said today.

United States Government bonds rallied sharply in the late trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, after displaying marked irregularity in the morning and early afternoon. Gains ranged from 2-32 to 19-32 point. Sales of Federal issues amounted to $4,611,900, compared with $2,953,900 on Wednesday.

HAVANA, Aug. 29. -- President Carlos Mendieta today refused to discuss any settlement of Cuba's public works bonds now in default with Senators Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota and Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, who are here in representation of American bondholders, on the ground that the present provisional government has no jurisdiction in the matter.

While the Works Progress Administration under General Hugh S. Johnson added another 5,000 unemployed workers to its payrolls yesterday, making a total of 18,000 since Monday, steps were taken by Mayor La Guardia and relief officials to avoid delays in wage payments such as marked the situation in the Department of Parks.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- The World Population Congress meeting here appeared from today's reports to be another example of a staged propaganda assembly, more or less hand-picked by the German committee of the International Union for Scientific Investigation of Population Problems.
Passengers sailing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen include Henry Wilcoxon, film actor; Whitney Straight and his bride, the former Lady Daphne Finch-Hatton, and:

The Department of Commerce yesterday rejected the claim of the Red Star Line to membership in the North Atlantic eastbound freight conference serving the ports of New York, Antwerp and Rotterdam, and ordered the existing conference agreement for those ports canceled.

To have been associated in the production of "Tobacco Road" would give any one a start in the theatre, but Sam H. Grisman is now by way of being a magnate. Preparing to leave today for Chicago, Mr. Grisman paused yesterday to outline a season for himself -- a season that would go somewhat like this:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Seeking to avoid overlapping and duplication of efforts in all the various housing activities of the New Deal program, President Roosevelt directed the establishment today of a clearing house through which the separate housing agencies can keep track of one another's programs.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 29. -- The Long Island team continued its surprising successes against other entrants in the open polo championship today by taking a practice match from the Hurlingham riders of London, 12 to 9, before a large gallery at the Piping Rock Club.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP). -- A world's record for double-gaited stallions was set today by Raider, owned by Michael Schneider of Milwaukee and driven by Harry McKay, as he won the third heat of the 2:20 trot in 2:03 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- A three-month extension until March 31 of the effective date for permanent registration on the stock exchanges of bonds of foreign governments and their political subdivisions was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission after a conference here with Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Frank Altschul, chairman of the Exchange's stock list committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Employes of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its numerous affiliates, recently the subject of investigation by the Senate Lobby Committee, will be privileged to buy $10,000,000 in bonds of the Utilities Employes Securities Company, if a registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission is approved.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29. -- Governmental price-fixing, regulation and control of commodities should end as soon as the emergency has passed, Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared in his address at the New York State Fair this afternon.

" Smiling Henry" Stohl is no longer young and must take care of his money, he said yesterday when he was released from the West Side jail, where he had been sent for twenty-four hours because he could not see why he should pay for lodgings on warm nights.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 29. -- The injury which caused Queen Astrid's death, a fractured skull, was identified with that which killed her father-in-law, King Albert. Doctors who performed a hurried autopsy late today said the forehead wound was in the same position as the one that ended Albert's life in his tragic fall while mountain-climbing in Belgium.

The Citizens Budget Commission and the competitive Civil Service Association have been having a running debate lately over city salaries. A month ago Mr. OSBORN of the CBC gave out a statement complaining that city pay, while scant for some employes, was far in excess of private pay for the majority.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 29. -- Two veterans of many golfing wars and two novices today moved into the semi-final round of the thirty-ninth women's national championship through victories gained in a down-pouring rain on the Interlachen course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 28, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and an increase of $13,000,00 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors, returned yesterday with Mrs. Sloan on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, after a brief vacation in Southern France. Mr. Sloan, whose company recently declared an extra dividend and announced a $50,000,000 expansion program, said that the automobile business in the United States for 1935 would reach about 70 per cent of its previous best year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Recommendations that the ballot and use of public buildings be denied the Communist party, and protests against strike picketing by Legion members in uniform, were laid before the annual convention of the American Legion of New York today at opening business sessions.

To those Wall Street denizens who have traveled the long, hard road from the pre-1929 era, the blossoming of a new railway merger plan at this time recalled wistful memories of a form of corporate endeavor long in hibernation. The enthusiastic buying of "key lines," the secret conferences, and the running out from the latter, which characterized the days when merger ambitions ran high, disappeared with remarkable suddenness under the snuffer of the depression.

" Anna Karenina," co-starring Greta Garbo and Fredric March, will be presented on the Capitol's screen this morning. Based on Count Leo Tolstoy's novel, it was produced by David O. Selznick and directed by Clarence Brown.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith received yesterday without comment the bid of William Randolph Hearst to end their long-standing feud by proposing Mr. Smith as leader of conservative Democrats to oppose President Roosevelt in 1936.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29. -- Evidence of improvement of conditions in the Soviet Union and the consequent diminishing threat of internal remedies and counter-revolution was read here today in a decision by the Soviet authorities to issue new passports for a term of five years, replacing the previous issue, which was for three years.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Cubs gained a game in their drive for the National League pennant today by subduing the cellar-dwelling Braves, 8 to 2, in the final game of their Eastern tour.

History was in the making at Forest Hills yesterday as the elect of seven nations joined in the first combined holding of the men's and women's national tennis championships, but the uniqueness of the occasion failed to disturb the poise of those allotted leading roles.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lehman, brother and sister-in-law of Governor Lehman, occupied the Governor's clubhouse box today for the races. They are stopping at the Gideon Putnam for the balance of the week.

SOME thirty years ago Charles Macomb Flandrau published some travel essays called "Viva Mexico!" They were charming, they were puckish, they were shrewd. And, though they were written about the Mexico of the "Diaz days," they still stand up as THE "must" literature for travelers seeking the flavor of contemporary Mexican days and customs.

For the first time since his appointment as Chief Magistrate, Jacob Gould Schurman visited Night Court last night. He explained that he had come to check on a new system to relieve congestion decided upon two weeks ago at a conference with Police Commissioner Valentine.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 29. -- Belgium, stunned by the sudden and tragic death of her young and gracious Queen, expressed grief tonight in a Cabinet communique, which said:

The dissolution of three member firms and the formation of three new ones, together with changes in seven other partnerships, were announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The firms which are dissolving are Florentino Co., MacQuoid Coady and Price Filston.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- The Nazi censor has suppressed the Papal address on materialism and paganism. Catholic newspapers were allowed to mention the address this morning in connection with Papal references to the Ethiopian conflict, but no reports of the contents of the address appeared.
Lewis E. Lawes, warden of Sing Sing prison, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from his first trip abroad, during which he attended the International Prison Congress in Berlin.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Complete abandonment of "this business of relief" in Alabama and Wyoming after Monday was ordered today by Harry L. Hopkins.
BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- What Dr. Hjalmar Schacht called "disturbances of German business" by National Socialist extremists was painfully revealed by the Leipzig Fall fair, which closed its gates today.

The cheerful bit of news today for Wally Moses, sensational young outfielder of the Athletics whose career was checked by an arm fracture, is that the baseball writers consider him the outstanding major league rookie of 1935.

GLASGOW, Aug. 29. -- Outfitting work on the steamship Queen Mary, which was launched eleven months ago, now is so far advanced that it was announced today she would be towed down the Clyde in the third week of next May.
PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A plan for the reorganization of three bankrupt Western railroads into a system with 15,000 miles of track is to be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by a committee formed to represent preferred stockholders of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Browns opened their final home stand of 1935 by dropping the first of a four-game series to the Tigers today, 13 to 3.

Retail package deliveries improved during the week ended Aug. 24, the increase being 8 per cent as against 6 per cent for the preceding week, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service, covering deliveries made for about 250 stores in the metropolitan and suburban areas.

Rayon and silk fabric production by stock mills during the week of Aug. 24 showed a rise of 4.9 per cent above the previous week and of 42.4 per cent over the corresponding week of 1934, according to figures issued yesterday by the research and planning division of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Keen competition at the Flemington Fair Flower Show resulted in awards to growers in many sections. The show this year was much larger than heretofore and weather conditions resulted in better blooms. The show was held under the direction of Mrs. Frank J. Eppele of Headquarters and Mrs. J. Dothard Dilts of Three Bridges.

The third day of the strike of several thousand shipping clerks, members of the Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union, an A.F. of L. organization, was marked yesterday by a resumption of mass picketing in the garment district. Many clashes and threatened outbreaks of violence kept large details of police busy throughout the day.

Consumption of petroleum products in 1935 will reach a new high record, according The Lamp, official publication of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. It places domestic consumption and export demand for crude oil and its products in the first half of this year at 518,306,000 barrels, a gain of more than 14,000,000 barrels over the same period in 1934.

Astrid, the Swedish Princess, was Queen of the Belgians a little more than eighteen months. From her early childhood she had endeared herself to her own people, and she won the affection of Flemings and Walloons alike when she became Crown Princess of Belgium on Nov. 4, 1926.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Wholesale commodity prices continued their upward trend in the week ending Aug. 24, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1926 average, standing at 80.8 as compared to 80.5 the preceding week and 76.9 the correponding week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- A decision on the next step that the United States Government will take in its dispute with the Soviet Union over alleged interference in the internal affairs of this country, based on the activities of the Third International, was postponed until tomorrow at a conference that terminated late today at the State Department.

United States Senator Huey P. Long issued a statement here yesterday attempting to shift blame for failure to pass the Deficiency Bill in the final stages of the Congress session to President Roosevelt himself.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 29. -- Away out at the far end of the Oklahoma training track here is the Bradley Stable. Green hoops on white; those are the colors that have so often flashed to the front on the turf.

The broad-gauge railroad which extends for 150 miles from Hsinking to Harbin, Manchukuo, will be replaced within three hours tomorrow morning by standard-gauge tracks. The rapid change-over, designed to obviate interruption of rail traffic, will require the concerted efforts of 2,000 men.

A departmental estimate totaling $6,678,146 for 1936, an increase of $258,678 over 1935, was submitted yesterday by the Department of Plant and Structures at a hearing before Rufus E. McGahen, Budget Director.

Since Sept. 7, 1934, time signals broadcast by the Arlington radio station from the Naval Observatory at Washington have been within one one-thousandth of a second accurate, Captain J.N. Hellweg, superintendent of the plant, told members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann announced today that their investigators had found a child on Long Island who "might be the missing Lindbergh baby," but quickly decided against an immediate fingerprint check.

Mayor La Guardia kept Dr. George. J. Ryan, President of the Board of Education, and Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, waiting in a City Hall anteroom for more than an hour yesterday morning, with the result that the school officials finally walked out of City Hall without conferring with the Mayor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- A coroner's jury at Oswego took the word of Federal agents today that a body dug from a hummock near the village was that of John Hamilton, a member of the former Dillinger gang.
Five men who were rescued last Tuesday from the foundering schooner La Dahama of Philadelphia, were landed in New York yesterday by the Italian liner Rex, which made the rescue.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The team of P. Hal Sims and Phillip C. Coffin Jr. won the North Jersey pair bridge championships, which ended at the Monmouth Hotel here early today.

Grace Moore, opera singer and film star, returned on the Italian liner Rex yesterday after a triumphant visit to London, where she sang before the Queen at a command performance at Covent Garden and was acclaimed by the London theatrical world in "La Boheme."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- President Roosevelt, Secretary Hull and other officials sent messages of sympathy to various Belgian personalities as soon as they learned of the death of Queen Astrid. Mr. Roosevelt addressed the following cable to King Leopold III:

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29. -- The will of Isabel Stillman Rockefeller, widow of Percy A. Rockefeller of Greenwich, filed in Probate Court here today, sets up a trust of the residue of the estate to provide for her five children and ten others close of kin.

ROME, Aug. 29. -- It was with real surprise that Italians read today of the unfavorable reception the long and elaborate communique issued at the end of yesterday's Cabinet Council had in at least part of the British press.

The Salvation Army gave lunches yesterday to about 500 skilled mechanics and laborers who had been unpaid by the WPA until yesterday for their work during August in developing playgrounds in Hamilton Fish Park, East Houston and Pitt Streets.

The Police Department baseball team defeated the Fire Department, 6 to 5, yesterday, at the Yankee Stadium for its second straight triumph in the three-game series to win the Municipal Baseball League championship. A crowd of 5,000, with a preponderance of children present, saw the victors gain the trophy presented by Mayor La Guardia after a hard battle.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29. -- The probability of Dr. Judah L. Magnes's resignation as chancellor of the Hebrew University is causing the greatest consternation among friends and well-wishers of the university, Jew and Gentile alike.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, July 31 (By Air Mail). -- An Englishspeaking resident who has watched the Ethiopian situation closely gave this writer today a picture of what may be expected to happen if war comes in East Africa.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 29. -- Queen Astrid of the Belgians was killed almost instantly and King Leopold slightly injured when the motor car he was driving left the road, hit two trees and careened into Lake Lucerne near here this morning.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29. -- With the most powerful and fastest airplanes which have ever been assembled for a single air meet in America, the 1935 National Air Races will open at the Cleveland Airport here tomorrow.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Enlistment of church organizations in a reorganization of the chaplain service in Federal prisons was announced by Attorney General Cummings in an address read for him tonight by Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General, before the Institute of Human Relations at Williams College.

The will of Helen Slade Ogilvie, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, names her daughter, Ida Helen Ogilvie of Bedford Village, N.Y., principal beneficiary and makes provision for charitable and public institutions. St. Lake's Hospital, one of the legatees, eventually will receive the principal of a $50,000 trust fund and the residuary estate.
Except for the taking of a few trades in demand loans and maturity money, there was nothing else of interest in the credit market. Quotations were maintained without change.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The Treasury announced today its inability to float the full $100,000,000 issue of Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation bonds announced on Monday. This unusual occurrence was ascribed by officials to the weak government bond market which has prevailed since Aug. 12.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29. -- An "overwhelming" strike vote by union operating employes of the Wabash Railway Company led today to an order for about 4,500 workers to walk out at 6:30 A.M. Saturday.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 29. -- Several hundred dollars were contributed by Bretton Woods guests to the Mount Washington Hotel employes' emergency sick fund through an exhibition golf match yesterday and the annual masked ball of the employes last evening.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 29 (Reuters). -- Although intense secrecy is being observed by the Ethiopian general staff regarding the strength of its army, it is probable that about 500,000 armed soldiers will be able to oppose the Italians if the latter attack Ethiopia.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Killearn Magician, magnificent bay hackney stallion, owned by the Killearn Farm of Alfred B. Maclay of Millbrook, N.Y., this afternoon was proclaimed the outstanding horse of the sixteenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada decreased $7,004,548 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly report of the bank showed today. At the same time deposits by chartered banks increased $1,091,704.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- President Roosevelt, in a drive to complete his work before a Saturday night departure for Hyde Park and a later journey to the Pacific Coast, today signed several important bills and consulted with heads of various government departments, members of Congress and others.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 29. -- Aging Prince Charles and Princess Ingeborg mournfully chartered an airplane today to fly to Lucerne, Switzerland, to join the grief-stricken husband of their daughter, Queen Astrid of the Belgians.

The first of three American track and field teams returned from its European invasion yesterday when the so-called "Swedish team" arrived in New York on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. The six athletes brought back with them prizes and trophies of all descriptions, but the chief gain from the trip was that of experience.

Italy's urgent need for territorial expansion, together with the "twofaced" policy of the Ethiopian Government, is held by the Italian Historical Society to be chiefly responsible for developments in East Africa.

Signor MARCONI was asked about rumors that he has been experimenting with short-wave devices for paralyzing airplane motors in flight and replied that he had nothing to say. He is not the only man to have his name associated with an anti-airplane death-ray.

Though he has flung away ambition, Mr. HEARST is still inclined, as he was in 1932, to try his hand at Warwicking. From his California hermitage he calls for the revival of the "true Democratic party." Mr. ROOSEVELT has repudiated all the historic Democratic policies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- In a final effort to speed up employment under the works program, Secretary Ickes sent telegrams today to 386 applicants -- States, counties and cities -- notifying them that projects previously approved by the Public Works Administration had been rejected by the WPA, and urging that modified applications be submitted in time to qualify under the Presidential deadline set for Sept. 12.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today rejected the application of Victor Seymour, Nebraska politician, for Executive clemency.

ROME, Saturday, Aug. 31. -- Italian officials heard with astonishment early this morning a report from London that the Emperor of Ethiopia had virtually handed over to an Anglo-American syndicate exclusive rights to the ownership of all oil and minerals in a vast tract of Ethiopian territory adjoining Italian and British possessions to the east of Addis Ababa.

Mayor La Guardia and General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, announced yesterday that they were striving to change to weekly the biweekly paydays that have worked hardship on WPA relief workers.

The Orpheus Male Choir of Cleveland, which arrived in New York by bus on Thursday, will sail this morning on the Ile de France, on their way to Russia. It will give concerts in Leningrad and Moscow next month at the invitation of the U.S.S.R.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30. -- The Buccaneers of Pittsburgh again scuttled the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals today, shooting them full of holes with a fourteen- hit attack to gain their ninth straight victory, 9 to 3.

A letter on this page bewailed American backwardness in the "art" of drinking wine. The writer thinks the reason is our democratic prejudice against a beverage that carries an aristocratic sound, but which is really in South European countries the table drink of the masses.

WARSAW, Aug. 30. -- Forging ahead toward their goal in defense of the Hamilton-Russell Trophy, the four members of the team representing the United States blanked the Rumanian quartet by 4 -- 0 today in the eighteenth round of the international chess tournament at the Army Officers Casino.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- An appeal for a social order in which "there shall be no locked doors between groups" and in which the profit motive will be subordinated to service is made in the annual Labor Day message of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30. -- Francis M. Rickett, a British promoter, told The Associated Press correspondent today that Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, seeking to stop an expected Italian advance into Ethiopia, had deeded more than half his empire to Anglo-American interests for exploitation and development just before last midnight.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

America is going to be virtually devoid of gypsies, at least of the real Spanish gypsies," unless conditions improve here and President Roosevelt lets up on his money control policy. At least that is the opinion of eleven gypsies who sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Scythia to seek better shores.

Charles H. Hyde in a recent issue of THE TIMES took issue with my demonstration of the erroneous statement of Representative Rankin of Mississippi that electric customers of this country are being overcharged more than a billion dollars a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt today signed the Guffey Coal Bill, which in effect establishes a separate NRA for the bituminous coal industry. The ceremony took place in the presence of officials and others primarily concerned with the legislation.

In the too scanty early parade of Republicans mentioned or boomed as candidates for President there is something ghostly, unreal; the irreverent might say comic. What is behind the show? Have its masters, if masters it has, favorites whom they hope to make stars in '36?

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Mayor Doris W. Bradway of Wildwood was acquitted of malfeasance in office by a jury of ten men and two women which returned a verdict at 7:45 o'clock tonight. Her co-defendant, Police Captain Michael Sheehan, was found guilty of the same charge, which was contained in a joint indictment against them.

The "field pulpit" of George Whitefield, noted English evangelist of almost 200 years ago, will be used again for a wayside service Tuesday after the noon worship at John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, known as the "Cradle of American Methodism."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The tender of a loan of $1,000,000 to the Federal Government by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen to finance preliminary work incident to the Railroad Retirement Act was revealed by President Roosevelt today.
New Yorkers who believe that July and August were unusually hot have the statistics of the Weather Bureau to prove it. The mean temperatures of both months were above normal.

An evergreen tree as a memorial to Will Rogers will be planted by the San Francisco Chapter of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, in the George Washington Forest, near the port of Haifa, Palestine, it was announced yesterday at national headquarters, 111 Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Evening-up operations, mainly selling September and buying December and May by scattered longs, while cash interests did the reverse, stood out in the trading in wheat today on the Board of Trade. Outright liquidation in the September and hedging pressure were relatively light.

A loss of 0.9 point carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices down to 126.3 on Tuesday from 127.2 the Tuesday previous. The decline reflected primarily the weakening of livestock and meat prices.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Miss Frances Robbins's big brown gelding Brian Boru, so aptly named after one of Ireland's greatest Kings, became the king of the hunters at the annual Suffolk County Horse Show at the Fair Grounds today.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- The World Population Congress closed today with a dispute in the final business session of the International Union for the Scientific Investigation of Population Problems as to whether the congress had been either international or scientific in the usual sense.
Frederick John Perry of England will start out in defense of his national tennis championship at Forest Hills today as play is resumed following a twenty-four-hour postponement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- While the agitation for third parties among dissatisfied Democrats waxes and wanes as one candidate after another proposed by W.R. Hearst refuses to oppose President Roosevelt, the Republican National Committee is going steadily ahead strengthening its organization over the country.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 30. -- A drizzling rain failed to dampen enthusiasm at the opening of the Chinese fantasy, annual benefit of the Suffolk County Cancer Committee, on the William Wood estate here this evening. More than 1,000 persons were present.

The city of Toledo will meet with cash the $824,200 in bond maturities due on Sept. 1, 1935, it was reported yesterday. Principal payments were halted on Sept. 1, 1932, when refunding bonds were issued.

Re-offering of $50,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, scheduled for Thursday, accounts for the major portion of the total of $57,308,417 of new State and municipal financing reported for sale next week. This compares with this week's revised total of $24,798,064.

There is now under way one bitter conflict in respect to which good citizens need not observe neutrality or even pray for a solution by compromise. This is the race in the National League, where only a few weeks ago the Giants were out in front all by themselves.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- The South Shore poloists advanced into the final round of the Eastern intracircuit polo championship for twelve-goal teams by defeating the Bethpage riders, 8 to 7, in a thrilling overtime match on the J.S. Phipps estate today.

Regardless of the success of the government's plan, the benefits provided in the Federal Social Security Act are not large enough to meet the needs of all classes of society, Theodore M. Riehle, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, declared yesterday.

Thousands of New Yorkers began their annual Labor Day migration to beach resorts and rural retreats early last evening and many more are expected to follow them today. Railroads, air and steamship lines reported exceptionally heavy bookings, and service on all transportation lines was increased to meet the expected requirements.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 30. -- The will of John North Willys, automobile executive who died in Riverdale, N.Y., on Sunday, was filed here today, but a contest of the document appeared likely to prevent probate.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 30. -- Official quarters intimate that Nazi activities in Rumania have reached a point imperatively demanding severe repressive measures. Nazis are overtly forming storm troop groups and march along the streets in their prohibited uniforms with Nazi banners and emblems.
Reductions will be made in the old-age relief funds to be distributed next month by the Department of Public Welfare, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner William Hodson.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30. -- With wind and weather obliging after a day of flat airs and occasional showers, seventeen boats started this evening in the Stamford Yacht Club's annual cruising race to the Vineyard and return.

A proposal for the reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway and its merger with two other bankrupt lines, made public on Thursday, came as news yesterday to the Rock Island's directorate. The proposal, put forward by a committee for Rock Island preferred stockholders, but not with the authority of these stockholders, calls for uniting the company with the St. Louis-San Francisco and the Chicago Eastern Illinois.
Dr. Gregory Schwartzman of Mount Sinai Hospital has developed a treatment by which one type of cancer has shown a favorable reaction in experiments with mice, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Because of the failure of the Newark City Commission to arrange for payment of the assessment against it for relief, payments of rent for relief recipients here have been ordered suspended, the city was advised today in a letter from Chester I. Barnard, chairman of the State Relief Council, to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 30. -- The Midwesterner, who usually mops a perspiring brow all through August, reached for his topcoat today -- and began thinking about coal bills. Unseasonable cold called for more blankets at night and grate fires in the morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The east tower of the famous sky ride of the Century of Progress Exposition crashed to earth this afternoon, bringing to ruin in forty-two seconds what had taken a year or more to build.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Howard A. Swartwood of Endicott, counsel to the Endicott-Johnson Shoe Company, declared at the Industrial Relations Conference here tonight that the Federal and State security laws are "here to stay."

Charges that managers of a syndicate operated in 1929 which dealt in stock of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and affiliated companies conducted affairs in such a manner that those in charge won large sums of money and that the syndicate lost heavily were branded yesterday in the Supreme Court as "cocktail rumors" by Horace G. Hitchcock, counsel for Hayden, Stone Co. and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, two of the managers.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Stepping in on the eve of a planned walkout, the National Mediation Board tonight averted, temporarily at least, a strike of 4,500 trainmen of the Wabash and Ann Arbor Railroads.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Applications by brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission reached a total of 4,801 today. Registration must become effective by Oct. 1 if activities involving interstate commerce are to be continued by the applicants unless a further extension is granted.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Decision of the Treasury officials that they have no case which would stand up in court against ex-Mayor WALKER for income-tax evasions was allowed by general expectation that he would soon come back to New York. The Government is so stern a creditor that he might well shrink from facing it.

WALLACE, N.S., Aug. 30. -- Men of two nations joined at Simon Newcomb's birthplace today in honoring the country school teacher's son who inscribed his name high in astronomy's firmament of fame before his death in 1910.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

BRUSSELS, Aug. 30. -- Mourners from high and low stations, united by common grief for their dead Queen Astrid, filed sadly past a bed covered with white silk today for a final glimpse of her pale, bandaged face. The body of the 29-year-old Queen and mother lay in the black-draped "Thinker's Hall" of the palace.

The resignation of Justice Samuel D. Levy will become effective today after twenty years of service in the Children's Court and the Domestic Relations Court. His resignation, after many insistent demands by Justice Levy, was accepted by Mayor La Guardia, who had reappointed him in September of 1934.

The Rev. William Osborn Baker, formerly pastor of Christ Episcopal Church in New Haven, Conn., has bought from Louis A. Thebaud the residence at 55 Madison Avenue, Morristown, with four acres of land. The house contains fourteen rooms and four baths. Eugene V. Welsh was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The discovery of a vast range of mountains submerged under the cold waters of the Bering Sea was reported today to the Coast Guard by Commander L.V. Kellhorn of the Bering Sea patrol.

Evidence which may lead to the smashing of a large vice ring has been furnished to the authorities by Peggy Brown, convicted of a vice charge, it was disclosed, yesterday by Assistant District Attorney William Goldman of the staff of William C. Dodge.

As Europe plunges deliberately and insanely toward war, it is incredible that the United States should take such a weak and indecisive position with regard to the crisis. The government still believes that we can preserve a position of isolation that experience has shown is not tenable.

Two young ex-convicts were wounded by bullets fired from a passing car at 4 P.M. yesterday as they sat in a small sedan parked in front of a vacant store at 4,036 Third Avenue, a few doors north of East 174th Street, the Bronx. The police believe the shooting was the outgrowth of a gangland quarrel resulting from a $10,000 poolroom holdup two weeks ago.

The Summer season is closing "with some of the most spectacular increases in many years recorded for both the production and distribution of merchandise," and with preparations under way for a wider advance during the Fall, according to the weekly survey issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3O. -- A sharp rise in the death rate for the United States in 1934 was reported by the Bureau of the Census in preliminary figures made public today. These showed there were 1,396,903 deaths in 1934, giving a death rate per 100,000 of estimated population of 1104.9, as compared with 1,342,106 and a death rate of 1067.8 in 1933 and 1,308,529 and a death rate of 1089.3 in 1932.

When JULIUS CAESAR was presenting his agrarian law, the first in his program of laws that came to be known as the Leges Juliae, he laid his proposals before the Senate (having, however, taken as his first step the publication of a daily journal of the days of the Senate, the Acta Diurna.

The substance contained in liver which is responsible for the effectiveness of that food in the treatment of pernicious anemia has been isolated by Dr. H.D. Dakin and Dr. Randolph West, at Presbyterian Hospital, according to an announcement yesterday.

The number of infantile paralysis cases reported to the Health Department yesterday for the preceding twenty-four hours was seventy, the highest for any day so far this year. Officials of the department were not alarmed, however, asserting that the total for the year, 1,133, still was almost 2,000 under the 1931 figure for the same day and that relatively it was insignificant compared to New York's 7,500,000 population.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- With President Roosevelt's signature on the Guffey bill coal men discussed tonight the possibility of a court test.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30. -- The start of the Bendix transcontinental air race brought swift death today to Cecil A. Allen, California flier.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30. -- The clergy of Addis Ababa today appealed to Emperor @Iaile Selassie to cancel a proposed air raid rehe;rsal over the 6apit21. They said many persons Believed actual bombs would be dropped, and there might be attempts to shoot down the planes.
Money market was quiet. Demand for funds was small. Quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY, Bolzano, Italy, Aug. 30. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's realistic war games proved just that today when one soldier was killed and two were wounded during manoeuvres under real artillery fire, with Il Duce and King Victor Emmanuel as spectators.

Captain Thor Eckert, managing director of the Red Star and Arnold Bernstein Steamship Lines, 'announced last night that an application for admission to the Eastbound Transatlantic Freight Conference was being drafted by his lines. He said the decision of Secretary of Commerce Roper, which was announced Thursday, on a complaint of the Red Star Line against the conference's refusal to grant it membership actually was a victory for the Red Star Line.

New York City is a great place to fifty-eight English students who sailed on the Cunard liner Scythia yesterday after spending forty-eight hours wandering along the avenues and byways of the city, but at the same time there is room for improvement.

Richard Bennett, who pretty constantly woos the cinema these later days, will be back on Broadway in a month. The occasion is Maxwell Anderson's play, "The Bridge," to which Mr. Bennett yesterday affixed himself as principal player. The opening date is still unsettled; call it in the meanwhile the week of Sept. 23.

Aromas of Boston's savory baked beans and the appetizing pecan pie of New Orleans will be wafted tantalizingly into the atmosphere of the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries subsequent to its opening at the Hotel Astor on Sept. 30. Announcement of competitions in favorite dishes characterizing different sections of the country was made yesterday by Mrs. Grace Allen Bangs, chairman of the contests committee.

Plans for the first Sunday of the national open polo championship, which falls on Sept. 8 and follows the opening game of Sept. 7, were announced yesterday by the tournament committee of the United States Polo Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Immigration laws of the United States will prevent the mass settlement of refugees in this country, the State Department has informed the Nansen International Office in a communication made public today. The Intergovernmental Advisory Committee had requested that all governments forward information on this subject.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- The Boerse weakened again today after a firm opening. Electrical issues were hit hard, some dropping as much as two points. Heavy industrials were listless and weaker at the close. Potashes were wholly inactive. Machine stocks were quiet, Berlin-Karlsruhe losing 1 1/2 points.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 30. -- About 700 persons attended the sixty-third anniversary invitation Lee Monument ball at the Greenbrier tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Harry L. Hopkins today followed up his order cutting two States off the dole by allotting to thirty-three others just enough to provide direct relief for half of September.

From several directions at once we learn that there is a movement afoot eventually to balance the Federal budget. The story appears that Secretary MORGENTHAU will urge a reduction of Federal expenditures with a view to balancing the budget in some future unnamed year, and on the same day Mr. GEORGE CREEL in Collier's gives us the exact figures with a great air of confidence.
