WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Business conditions continued favorable in Mexico as August wore to a close, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of the foreign field. Although department store sales and retail trade in drugs, hardware and cotton textiles in Mexico City declined slightly under the level of July, consumption of most other staple commodities, as well as the demand for automotive products, held up unusually well.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30. -- "The Little Entente States [Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia] will concentrate all their energy and strength in the service of general peace. They will remain loyal to the League whatever may happen."

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower in quiet trading here yesterday. Raw sugar futures were limited in activity and quotations ended virtually unchanged. In the cash market, corn, eggs and wool tops were higher, while wheat, rye, oats, flour, cotton, silk and rubber were lower.

Now that the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 is law, what will be the next move of the holding companies? Before going into that it might be appropriate to review briefly the reasons for the passing of the act.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30. -- J. Lawrence Pagen of New York, and Blythe Co., New York brokers, were sued for $500,000 damages today on the grounds that they libelously linked Mrs. Charlotte Shelby, mother of Mary Miles Minter, former film actress, with the murder of William Desmond Taylor, motion picture director.

Although there has been an increase in trading in securities, a rise in stock prices and a rapid expansion of the flotation of new securities, there has been no corresponding increase in the demand for credit in the money market here, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York observed in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, published yesterday.

Sinclair Lewis, novelist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, will sail today with Mrs. Lewis on the French liner Ile de France, which departs at 11 A.M. for Plymouth and Havre. Also among the liner's passengers will be forty-one members of the Cleveland (Ohio) Orpheus Male Choir under the leadership of Charles D. Dawe.

A miniature of a model city, made by underprivileged children out of such materials as cardboard boxes, sponges and pieces of string, was the feature display of a demonstration of the Summer projects of the Union Settlement, held yesterday morning in the auditorium of the settlement building at 237 East 104th Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt late this afternoon signed the new tax law, designed to add about $250,000,000 annually to Federal revenue, principally by means of greater imposts on large incomes and estates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Although a Presidential smile today dismissed questions about a balanced budget by 1939, arrangements were made for November conferences to seek a closer balance in 1936.

Albert Nahoum, unemployed father of four children, yesterday lost his suit to compel the city to increase his home relief allowance of approximately $60.50 a month because his hands have become crippled as the result of shoveling snow for the city last Winter.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 30. (AP). -- The bullet-marked bodies of Harry J. Weidner, 53, reputedly wealthy Searsdale (N.Y.) butcher, and Fred Nell, 63, manager of Weidner's apartment building here, were found tonight in the building.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. A.J. Stumpf of the Crestmont Golf Club today scored an 85 to win the women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament over the Green Brook Country Club course. It was the best round of golf Mrs. Stumpf has played in competition this year and was executed in a steady downpour.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP). -- H.C. Rumage's Pharatime, a 4-year-old brown gelding, completely overlooked in the betting, won the Speed Handicap, feature event of today's card at the Michigan State Fair Grounds, by finishing a length in front of Lanier.

Brokers announced another long list of new tenants for apartment houses in the city yesterday. Activity was especially brisk in buildings on the East and West Sides and extended to suburban communities.

Public offerings of new bonds this week amounted to $57,410,000, against $16,306,000 marketed last week and only $600,000 in the corresponding week last year. Three major classifications were represented by issues.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Sales of securities from Canada to the United States in the first half of 1935 amounted to $118,991,511, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today. The total for the first half of 1934 was $103,982,969 and in 1933 it was $91,778,090.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- A rousing call by Governor Lehman for a more adequate national defense as the best guarantee of peace brought a cheering State American Legion convention to its feet here today.

All important foreign exchanges fell yesterday in terms of the dollar, the Belgian currency reaching the cheapest price since its devaluation last March, while the Canadian dollar dropped to the widest discount since April 26.

Bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange quieted down considerably yesterday under pre-holiday influences. The rally in United States Government bonds, which got under way late on Thursday, was checked and that group turned irregularly lower, but a slightly better undertone ruled in the market for domestic corporation issues in dull trading.

Asserting that standards of medical education have dropped in recent years, the American Medical Association in the current issue of its Journal warns that doctors, educators, State Boards of Examiners and public authorities must combat present tendencies lest standards of medical practice be lowered.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Investigation by the Attorney General of 50 per cent cuts in prices of crude oil posted by major oil companies in California was asked in a telegram sent to Washington tonight by the Independent Petroleum Association of California.

WHITE PLANS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Coincident with the announcement today of his resignation as district manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation. Lawrence H. Tasker reported that home loans of a total value of $40,826,261 had been closed in Westchester County since the organization of the work two years ago.

Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. three other former officers and directors of the bankrupt Sonora Products Company are jointly liable to the corporation to the extent of $2,459,562, according to a report filed yesterday in Federal Court by Samuel H. Kaufman, special master.

Madison Avenue is looking up again. There was a time not so long ago when it was in a sorry state, particularly in the congested midtown area. Old-fashioned surface-cars banged around the corner at Forty-second Street and lurched noisily north. Tracks lined with cobblestones interfered with proper surfacing.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Under leaden skies and in a steady, chilling rain the last of the National Guard troops mobilized here left today by train, truck and taxicab, en route to their homes.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Congratulations from all parts of the world poured in today upon the Duke of Gloucester, third son of King George and Queen Mary, and his fiancee, Lady Alice Montagu-Douglas-Scott.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- German Catholicism continues to be the chief target of the nation-wide oratorical barrage against all efforts to remain independent of the totalitarian State. In Baden forty demonstrations were staged simultaneously yesterday against "political Catholicism and Jews."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30. -- Ethiopia's "battle cry of freedom" was sounded by Emperor Haile Selassie in a paper entitled "Light and Peace," issued today. He told how the fathers and grandfathers of the present elder generation died for the freedom of their country and asked parents to give their sons to do the same.
Referring to recent correspondence in THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to automobile insurance, I think the entire principle of this form of insurance is wrong.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Several parties are being arranged by the Summer colony to mark the closing of the racing season here.

Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio impressed 300 men and women charged with various traffic violations in Traffic Court yesterday by reading aloud a pamphlet called "And Sudden Death," by J.C. Furnas, describing the results of automobile accidents with realistic details.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- With seventeen named for the Hopeful Stales, and seven for the Saratoga Cup, the month-long meeting of the Saratoga Association will come to an end tomorrow after one of the most successful sessions in recent years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Thomas J. Hickey, president of the American Association, said today there would be no "little world series" with the International League unless the International agreed to call its play-off winner the league champion.

DUBLIN, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press). -- President Eamon de Valera's forthcoming new Constitution for the Irish Free State will contain a surprise for the other members of the British Commonwealth of Nations, according to well-informed circles here.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia today reached the final round of the women's national golf championship for the eighth time when she defeated Miss Beatrice Barrett, 18-year-old hometown girl, 2 and 1, in the semi-finals at the Interlachen Club.

Charges of inefficiency on the part of regular service to Puerto Rico and of discrimination against the island as a port of call by cruise lines were aired yesterday at a hearing by the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30. -- Gene Kunes, 26-year-old Norristown (Pa.) golfer, used a record-breaking 68 today to take the lead at the halfway mark in the Canadian open golf championship with a thirty-six-hole score of 138.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Saturday, Aug. 31. (AP). -- Four girls, three of them daughters of William G. Wrightson of Orange, N.J., vice president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, and the other a daughter of the manager of the Mount Washington Hotel here, were being sought on Mount Deception early today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 30. -- Revision of the constitution of the National Conference of Jews and Christians emphasizing them spiritual derivation and basis of its inspiration and effort, and its future reliance upon educational methods in its work, was announced at the closing sessions here today of the organization's first Institute of Human Relations.
Fans and other observers may have given up on the Giants, but Colonel Bill Terry emphatically does not concede the pennant to the Cardinals. He only admits that the Red Birds are the team to beat.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 30, -- Many visitors are arriving for the Labor Day holiday. James M. Beck of New York and Washington, with Mrs. Beck, arrived today at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, from Seabright, N.J. Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes will return from their tour of the West on Sept. 10.

"Modern Times," Charles Chaplin's first film in four years, will have its premiere in New York on Oct. 11, according to an announcement yesterday from United Artists. It may serve to reopen the Center Theatre as a cinema.
MANILA, P.I., Aug. 3 (By Mail). -- A new aviation landing field has just been prepared by the United States Army on Batan Island, only about 130 miles from the Japanese island of Formosa.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30. -- The closest finish ever recorded in the Bendix Trophy race brought victory today to Benjamin O. Howard of Chicago in the fifth annual running of the air classic which was the opening feature of the national air races here.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- Week-end and Labor Day entertaining began here tonight. One of the outstanding dinners was that given by Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor at Chetwode. It was their first large party since their arrival a fortnight ago and was principally for members of the debutante set, with Miss Virginia Middleton French, sister of Mrs. Astor, who is being introduced informally this Summer, as one of the guests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30. -- Claudette Colbert, movie actress who tried to remain happily married by living in a separate domicile from that of her actor-husband, Norman Foster, obtained a Mexican divorce from him more than a week ago, it was disclosed today by her business manager, Charles Feldman.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Playing over the well-groomed links of the Ridgewood Country Club, where the international Ryder Cup matches will be held late next month, S. Ashton Clark Jr., 22-year-old member of the home club, today won the first annual thirty-six-hole invitation tournament, which attracted a field of forty-eight.
LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Great Britain's home fleet got ready for Autumn manoeuvres a week ahead of schedule today as the Mediterranean fleet steamed toward the Suez Canal.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Carnegie Steel Company announced today the appointment of James S. McKesson of Cleveland, former vice president and general sales manager of the Corrigan-McKinney Steel Company, as special sales agent to handle exclusively all sales of pig iron.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- The dream of Icarus -- flight by man's own power -- was brought nearer realization yesterday evening and today when at the Frankfurt-am-Main airfield, in the presence of official observers from the German Airsport League, a pilot named Duennbeil made three short but successful flights with a plane driven by a propeller but operated only by his own leg-power, like a bicycle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- An estimate that utility operating companies should spend about $2,000,000,000 in the next year for increased power generating equipment was made today by Basil Manly, acting chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Seasoned international observers tonight saw unquestioned possibilities for future diplomatic tangles in the deeding by Emperor Haile Selassie of half his kingdom to Anglo-American interests for development.
President Roosevelt and General Hugh S. Johnson were bitterly assailed for "starving" WPA relief workers by United States Senator Huey P. Long last night.

Many persons have taken boxes for the benefit polo game to be played tomorrow at the Sands Point (L.I.) Polo Club in aid of the Free Milk Fund for Babies. The contest will be between the Hurlingham team of England and a picked Meadow Brook team of Long Island.

So far as Broadway tradition is concerned, this evening marks the end of Summer. Monday and Labor Day will, proverbially, be the beginning of Fall and a new "season" -- nocturnal as well as theatrical. The Saratoga meeting ends today; Monday night will see the concluding festivities at most of the suburban gay spots.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Ab Jenkins, Utah driver, tonight smashed the world's record of 134.85 miles per hour for twenty-four hours, set recently by John Cobb of London, by racing his powerful automobile through a night and a day at an average speed of 135.47 miles per hour.

Two books by P.G. Wodehouse will be issued by publishers here in September. On Sept. 10 Macmillan will bring out "Enter Psmith," the first of the Wodehouse stories in which Psmith, believed by some to be Mr. Wodehouse's most successful character, appeared.

SOLON, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- L.S. Pratt, 28-year-old Indianapolis sporting goods store employe, had a strong hold on the individual all-bore skeet championship as the nation's leading marksmen ended the second day of their race for that prize today.

The Long Island Railroad Company will file with the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission this morning an application for increases, ranging from 15 to 20 per cent, in its commutation rates.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30. -- Soviet opinion, which has been extremely reserved on the subject of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, finds expression in today's Izvestia in a long article by Karl Radek.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Delegates representing eleven locals of the American Federation of Teachers walked from the floor of the association's convention today.

A resolution urging the construction of a swimming pool on the old reservoir site in Central Park has been presented to Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the secretary of the Board of Estimate by a special committee of the West Side Boys Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday by George P. Hennessy, a member of the committee.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Browns upset the league-leading Tigers today, 8 to 7, stopping a belated drive after staging a late-inning rally of their own.

Dr. Erastus M. Hudson, fingerprint expert who testified in the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., said yesterday that the baby's fingerprints had been preserved from toys and a high chair in the nursery.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 (Reuters). -- Germany next year will have the most powerful and best equipped short-wave broadcasting centre in the world, according to wireless experts here. This is part of her scheme to disseminate German wireless programs throughout the world.

Much has been written on the subject of American music. As a publisher of music I bluntly declare that there is no such thing as American music. By that I mean music typical of a vast nation and its people. The whole world sings, dances, hums and whistles the Tin Pan Alley product, which, upon analysis, proves to be a heterogeneous mixture of Neapolitan airs, English ballads, German folksongs, Hebrew chants,
As one "pale, patient drudge" in the pulp magazine industry, allow me to express appreciation of your editorial in the issue of this date "Fiction by Volume."

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Two conflicting views were presented here today concerning the government's chances of collecting the tax assessment against Al Capone and his old syndicate. Government officials hinted at the chance that large sums had been secreted by the gang leaders and that these could be realized to cover the judgment.

Possibility of an early settlement of the strike of 15,000 men and women called by the Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, received a setback yesterday when the union voided individual settlements negotiated with some 400 employers and continued mass picketing in the garment centre district.

BELGRADE LAKES, Me., Aug. 30 (AP). -- The prediction that President Roosevelt would advocate payment of the soldiers' bonus when Congress reconvened was made today by Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Captain and Mrs. Neville Lawrence of London, who are spending the late season here with Mrs. Lawrence's father and step-mother, Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler, at Leny Cottage, were hosts at a dinner tonight at the clubhouse of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

Despite the stimulating effects of cool weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area was decidedly spotty during the week, reports of retail executives here indicated yesterday. Results ranged from 5 to 6 per cent over the same week a year ago to 1 to 2 per cent under the 1934 figures.
Earnings of two companies in the Electric Bond and Share Company system were reported yesterday as follows:

While trout anglers of New York State visit their favorite streams today to bid farewell to familiar pools and rapids on the closing day of the season, New Jersey fishermen look forward to another month of sport.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- In connection with the Wissahickon Horse Show, to be held on Sept. 12, 13, 14 and 15, there will be a variety of events to start Philadelphia society's Fall season.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, approved yesterday an order directing the distribution of $771,705 to holders of bonds of three issues of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation. The original order was made a week ago yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch of the same court, before whom the corporation is undergoing reorganization under Section 77-b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Heavy lard-type hogs were in good demand here today and prices were 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Other weights were steady to as much as 10 cents lower than yesterday, packing sows showing the most loss.

An intensive search by air and surface craft for trace of Donald K. Phillips, 23 years old, who disappeared mysteriously after leaving Roosevelt Field about 10 A.M. Wednesday, was continued yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug 30. -- The Japanese Government has watched the effect of the American protest to Moscow with pleasurable interest, but avoids giving a hint of its own intentions.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Although a light rain fell the greater part of the day, the skies cleared during the judging of the late classes of the annual Orangeburg fair horse show today and more than 1,000 persons were on hand to see the presentation of the championship rosettes.

The report of the H.F. Wilcox Oil and Gas Company and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on June 30, which was issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $54.794 after taxes, abandonments, interest, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This compares with a net loss of $91,736 in the first six months of last year.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 30. -- A close study of the conditions in which Queen Astrid of the Belgians was killed yesterday points to sheer land almost incredible bad luck -- even worse than the late King Albert's -- combined with faulty road construction as having been responsible for King Leopold's car leaving the road.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The government will attempt to collect about $120,000 in beer taxes from Al Capone, former Chicago underworld king, and fourteen members of the bootleg syndicate which he directed until jailed for income tax evasion in 1933, the Department of Justice announced today.

With the exodus of many from the financial district for the coming holiday, the markets were dull and little changed yesterday. Stock prices fluctuated narrowly in the slowest trading since July 3; transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 830,000 shares.
Real estate interests will bitterly oppose Mayor La Guardia's plan to build model housing developments to be rented on a cost basis to low salaried city employes, spokesmen said yesterday.
LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Driving a borrowed car, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh went visiting among boyhood friends today.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Announcement of new appointments to the faculty of Lawrenceville School was made here today. The school will open its 126th year Sept. 24.

The Very Rev. Joseph A. Murphy, since 1918 a Professor of Philosophy in Fordham University, yesterday took up his duties as the new Provincial of the Maryland-New York province of the Society of Jesus, the headquarters of which are at 501 East Fordham Road, the Bronx. He was appointed in Rome last Wednesday. He succeeds the Very Rev. Edward C. Phillips.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30. -- A visit to the Ethiopian military schools, where officers are being trained under foreign instructors, has given me a glimpse of the preparations Ethiopia is making for the war with Italy that every one here believes is coming.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 30. -- Robert H. Jackson, assistant general counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, told the annual meeting of the International Association of Insurance Counsel tonight that the Treasury Department was making a survey of the administrative features of the income tax and other tax laws as a basis for reforms.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- A pair of striking hunters, exhibited by Captain and Mrs. C.B. Kellogg of Princeton, captured the first two places in the Championship Hunter Stake, one of the feature events today, as the two-day horse show of the annual Flemington Agricultural Fair was brought to a close.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30. -- Delay in settling the Chaco peace is strengthening plans for an early attempt to establish a new republic in Santa Cruz Province of Bolivia, according to a secret separatist junta that has long been working here.

VIENNA, Aug. 30. -- The Reichspost, Austria's leading clerical newspaper, published today a report from its Rome correspondent, whose close relations with the Vatican are well known, dealing with the recent conference of the German Catholic Episcopate at Fulda, regarding which no official communique has been issued.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Ed Lasater, owned by W.N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., and driven by Ben White, won the Syracuse Hotel Consolation Purse, 2-year-old trot, feature of the closing day's Grand Circuit racing program at the New York State Fair today.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held within a range of about 10 points yesterday and ended at a loss of 4 to a gain of 8 points.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- Cooperation between the State Health Department and the Division of Highways in the drive to eliminate ragweed for the benefit of hay fever victims is seen in the statement by Dr. Paul B. Brooks, Acting State Commissioner of Health, that highway officials have ordered careful mowing of shoulders and sides of State roads in the Fulton chain of lakes area to do away with stray ragweed.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 31. -- To the well-mannered and attractive Sealyham terrier, Ch. Rannerdale Sequence of Pinegrade, owned by Frederick C. Brown's Pinegrade Kennels of Bedford Hills, N.Y., went the best in show award at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's first dog exhibition today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The challenge of the Guffey Act's constitutionality was summarized in the bill of complaint filed by James W. Carter here today as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- An allotment of Federal funds totaling $15,000,000 to be used by the Works Progress Administration for carrying out its program in New York City has been approved by president Roosevelt, it was announced today.

A complete ban on the use of automobile horns at night to insure New Yorkers of their sleep is being seriously considered by Mayor La Guardia in connection with the city's anti-noise campaign, it was revealed yesterday.
The chief flaw in the argument of the writer of the letter, "'Ware Idealists," is his limitation of the word "power." He evidently confines it to those having control of governments.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 31. -- More than 1,000 members of society attended the twenty-sixth annual Smithtown Horse Show, held today at Fifty Acre Field, St. James. The show was pronounced to be one of the most successful ever held, both from the standpoint of attendance and the class of entries.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Debutantes continue to be feted. Next Sunday evening a young woman who was introduced at a recent dinner will be the guest of honor at a dinner with music; she is Miss Lebrun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. Lebrun Rhinelander.

WHILE Sam H. Harris is not exactly taking time out to worry about it, there is some question as to what show he will send to the post after "Jubilee!" "First Lady" had seemed the likely choice, but George S. Kaufman, its co-author with Katharine Dayton, is still in Hollywood and will not return until the middle of this month.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Fickle breezes that did strange things over Long Island Sound today turned the sixty-third annual Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club into a drifting match. Only seventy-nine craft out of 111 that started were able to finish the races.

There is just one way to prevent future wars and that is by the use of force to preserve the peace. The history of the world is one of wars, and it is obvious therefore that if we are to discontinue warfare, new methods must be adopted.

AS one of several counter-strategies of the radicals prompted by the ridiculous and often unfounded stigmatizations of their organizers as "foreign agitators" there has developed a definite program among left-wing writers of resurrecting revolutionary episodes in American history, of cherishing the least faint flicker of revolutionary sentiment, and of forging thereof a revolutionary tradition.

HAVING noted during recent years that his fellow-Canadians "were rending their garments with melancholy zeal," Gilbert Jackson sends forth this book, he says, with its one practical suggestion, "that men should rend their hearts instead."

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- Modernization of the British Navy from top to bottom at an immense cost is almost sure to come in the near future because of the revelation that Great Britain is not strong enough at the moment to check Italy single-handed in the Mediterranean.

The amendment to the Railroad Bankruptcy Law signed last week by President Roosevelt was described in Wall Street as a powerful instrument for rehabilitating the investments of insurance companies and savings banks in railroads that have been "frozen" under the terms of the law enacted in 1933.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- The annual navy relief ball, for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society, was held at the Naval Training Station auditorium tonight. The dance was opened by Governor Theodore Francis Green.
NEWARK, Aug. 31. -- Behind the fine twirling of left-handed Ted Kleinhans, the Bears today registered a 7-to-1 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs.

IN the recent army manoeuvres at Pine Camp, New York, motor vehicles are said to have been more extensively used than ever before in military activity. They were used for the transportation of supplies, men, guns and equipment. Trucks, tractors, tanks, armored cars and even taxicabs were called into service.

Liquidation of October contracts against purchases of July by houses handling government business continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Switching operations increased near-month discounts until October sold 20 points or more under May, compared with a recent premium of 30 points, which represented a change in differences of more than a half cent in two weeks. The list receded 9 to 12 points.

Large shipments of gold from Holland, consignments arranged in July when the guilder was under pressure, greatly increased the receipts of the metal here in August over those of the previous month. The month's imports of $38,486,200 compared with $7,322,100 in July and with $44,886,300 in August, 1934, when $13,625,300 also was exported.

It was not long after broadcasting started that the showmen realized their most active season opened with Labor Day and ended with St. Patrick's Day. Tomorrow the curtain rises on what promises to be one of radio's most lively seasons.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver of Westport, Conn., dominated the hunter classes today at the first two sessions of the fifth annual Danbury Fair Horse Show, which opened this morning and will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

LIBERTY CORNERS, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Forty or more representatives of New Jersey glider clubs took part here today in two contests that marked the opening of the annual glider meet of the Associated Gliding Clubs of New Jersey. The two contests were won by a New York glider.

GENEVA, Aug. 31. -- The report that Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy is having a big dossier prepared with a view to asking the League of Nations to expel Ethiopia as unworthy of membership because of her slavery and backwardness is arousing special interest in League circles because of the tributes Mussolini's delegate paid to Ethiopia when she was admitted to the League.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Bounding into the lead in the stretch, Mansco, owned by Thomas C. Worden of Chicago, won the $5,000 added Joilet Juvenile Handicap at Lincoln Fields today. The gelding, coupled with Nedrow, as an entry, defeated Thatagal, the property of Charles T. Fisher of Detroit, by a length and a half, with Rushaway, the entry of J.E. Widener of New York, third.

WALL gardens long have been built to hold terraces and banks, or merely to add an interesting feature to the garden, but the same general list of plants -- alyssums, nepeta, thymus, the commoner dianthus, phlox and campanulas -- continues to be planted.

PARIS. THE average woman, who wants to plan a new Fall and Winter wardrobe that will be novel, chic and practical, may well pause dismayed before the difficulty of choosing among the welter of military, Renaissance, Nineteen Hundred, pre-war, primitive, angelic, medieval, Oriental, Greek, gypsy and many other varieties, including that of the "fringed Nineties," that pervade the new Paris mode.

THE new theatrical season is so near you can almost touch it. In just a few weeks Broadway will grow alive with lights, music, Hamlets, elephants, ticket scalpers, the League of New York Theatres' committees, tap dancers, acrobats, critics and alibis.

LAKE GEORGE. -- Both adults and children will participate in the gymkhana this afternoon at the new horse show ring on the Hotel Sagamore grounds. Fourteen events are on the program, including a horsemanship class for adults over 30 and under 70. There will also be musical chair, greased pole and fancy dress competitions, besides an egg race and a balloon contest.

While it is too early to predict with any degree of accuracy the effect that the new policy of the Federal Government with regard to the production of cotton will have on the export movement of that staple, the belief in some parts of the trade is that it will enable United States cotton growers to recapture some of the foreign business that was lost under previous Federal policies.

A WISE little book is this, and practical in its application of wisdom. Young people who read it even before they begin falling in love will thereby acquire some information about their failings that will be helpful when the experience comes, while those who are in love and are planning marriage would have to search long to find its equal in understanding, wisdom and helpfulness.

BECAUSE of the deliberations of the International Meteorological Conference in session opening this week at Warsaw the practical applications of weather science to human affairs doubtless will be greatly promoted. The machinery of gathering and disseminating weather news probably will function more smoothly.

TORONTO, Aug. 31. -- Glenn Cunningham, great Kansas miler, was beaten in the handicap mile at the Canadian national exhibition track and field meet today, when, starting from scratch, he finished fourth. Joe Mangan, former Cornell star running for the New York A.C., won the event in 4:16:8, with a ten-yard allowance.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the "come as you will" costume dance which was held tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese room of the Meadow Club. The guests, both for dinner and supper, which was served after midnight, were seated at small tables decorated with garden flowers and placed along the walls of the ballroom, leaving an open space for dancing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- More than 500 uniformed policemen, carrying riot sticks, patrolled the neighborhood in the vicinity of Forty-seventh Street and Prairie Avenue on the South Side this afternoon to prevent a parade and demonstration against a Fascist war in Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Labor Day, 1935, heralds the achievement of a new level in the establishment of labor's rights. Unusual legislative gains reward the legislative activity of the American labor movement during the past year. The list of labor laws includes the National Labor Relations Act, the Railway Pension Act, the Guffey Coal Act and the Social Security Act.

THE local lad who went to the big city is home again and all dressed up. He must have made good there, the clothes he's got. That's one way those of the hinterland can always tell whether the prodigal made good. It would be a violation of legend to have it otherwise.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 31. -- An inspiration a St. Paul woman received from a blind piano tuner three years ago today gave promise of enabling the country's 60,000 blind to "see" their way about the cities in which they live.

The Secretary of War has appointed a board of five army officers to make recommendations about the additional air bases called for in the new law. Three of the board are air corps officers and a majority of the five are serving a four-year detail on the general staff. A forward step!

BRIEF as was its existence, the Pony Express comprised one of the most colorful and heroic chapters in the development of the West. It played its part in the nation's history, too, for, as Professor Driggs points out, it was one of the links in the chain of communication which bound the West to the North during the Civil War.

The Works Progress Administration -- launched Aug. 1 as an attempt to solve nationally the local unemployment problems of the country and since then beset by delays -- began to speed up last week. Its first task was to take over work relief from existing local agencies; its second, to create new jobs to substitute for the dole.

EVERY one has recognized a certain type of woman: bony, awkward, dressed in hideous inappropriateness to every occasion, giggling at the wrong time, blushing at the wrong time, so lacking in social charm and graces that one wonders what excuse she has for being.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Germany's "economic dictator," defied Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, again today by reinstating a Reichsbank official who had been sent to a concentration camp.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Exhaustion of the crude-oil supplies of the world, which has been a subject of much discussion since soon after oil was discovered in commercial quantities in the United States, about seventy-five years ago, appears to be at least a century away, from a study of the known and prospective reserves, together with improvements in drilling operations and in locating petroliferous areas.

Tucked away in the piny woods of the Ozarks is the little settlement of Lost Corner, where life goes on with an archaic simplicity unknown to the average American child. Reading of it in Mrs. Simon's story for boys and girls aged 7 to 11, it becomes as appealing as it is novel.
All lines of transportation reported yesterday that holiday travel both outbound and inbound was continuing heavy though the peak of traffic was reached on Friday afternoon and evening.

Those who hold this idea are misled by unconsciously expecting the British to react as if they were Americans by temperament -- that is, excitable, nervous and determined to show that they are a powerful nation.

MEMORIES of the old West will be revived this month in the Pendleton Round-Up, recalling those tense dramas of the dusty plains when cattlemen massed their herds for the long and weary parade to the markets in the early Fall.
Your editorial "August Sport" has inspired the following political reminiscence and comment, particularly with reference to the "quadrennial candidacy" of the distinguished Senator from Idaho.

The Communist International, or Comintern, was founded in March, 1919, with headquarters in Moscow. It is a federation of the Communist parties of the world. Originally it was dedicated to the repudiation of capitalism and bourgeois democracy and to the seizure of power by the world proletariat.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- A new card has been thrown on the table in the diplomatic game that is being played over Ethiopia. The concession by Emperor Haile Selassie of sole rights to oil, minerals and other natural resources of half of his kingdom to an Anglo-American syndicate looked like a trump card for Great Britain when produced, but its value under examination is by no means as certain as it seemed at first glance.

Proposals aimed at more efficient handling of salesmen and broader opportunities for them to contact visiting buyers will be met by the buying offices in a "sympathetic realization of the salesmen's problems," it was stated yesterday by M.B. Read of the William T. Knott Company, chairman of the committee named by the Association of Buying Offices.

Italian Line officials said yesterday that the dispute between the Italian Government and Ethiopia had had little if any effect on passenger figures for ships of the company sailing for Italy. The Rex left yesterday with approximately 500 passengers in all classes, and Aroldo Palanca, director of the company here, said that last year's similar sailing had "only about fifty or sixty more."

GENEVA, Aug. 31. -- What might the League of Nations do to check Italy if the Council at its approaching meeting decides upon that course? What is the League likely to do? In appraising these possibilities and probabilities the first essential seems to be to put these popular questions more correctly -- what might the League members do through the League and what are they likely to do?
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Captain Arnold Miller's recipe for long life is whisky and lion hunting. Mrs. Lucy M. Ulyatt's is work. They ought to know. Both were 101 years old today.

IN this book are collected and reprinted Eugene Wood's stories and sketches of American life in the Eighties and Nineties, which have previously appeared in separate volumes, and, before that, in Ainslee's and McClure's.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- City Treasurer Willb Hadley and City Controller S. Davis Wilson, co-workers for years and now leading rivals for the Republican Mayoralty nomination, gained additional support today as all candidates prepared to jump into an active two-week campaign before the Sept. 17 primaries.

MARY MOORE, who "broke into grand opera on a postage stamp" when she first wrote to the august Metropolitan for an audition, is to sing for the first time in Northern New England this afternoon as guest of the Yale Forty-Niners at the Chase Barn Theatre in the White Mountains.

New Yorkers whose only appreciation of the Old World folk dances has been derived from the news reels will have an opportunity to witness or even participate in the traditional dances tomorrow afternoon at Washington Square, where the American Folk Group will give its first outdoor festival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The closing hours of the first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress added one more to the nearly threescore occasions in the last fifty years when the theoretical majority rule of the United States Senate has been made a mockery by filibusters.

MANlLA. -- Former Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi received a somewhat startling greeting when he arrived on a good-will mission to the Philippine Islands. The eminent Japanese diplomat was accorded the full honors and courtesies due to his rank and distinction, but the newspapers in the Philippines, Filipino and American alike, had no hesitation whatever in expressing a very considerable degree of skepticism concerning official Japanese good-will.

Completely transformed in a period of a few days, the cotton goods market, which was weak and uncertain Monday, closed the week yesterday on the firmest footing which it has enjoyed since early Summer.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- According to present indications, the principles of new laws fixing the status of Jews in Germany will be proclaimed by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler at the National Socialist party convention in Nuremberg starting Sept. 10.

New securities offered publicly here in August made the smallest total in three months, but larger than of a year ago. Bond issues, with few exceptions, were for smaller face amounts, while stock issues marketed came to only a fraction of those in July.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Delegates to the National Convention of Jewish War Veterans tonight unanimously adopted resolutions calling on the Amateur Athletic Union to withdraw certification of American athletes to the 1936 Olympic games in Berlin and asking the American Olympic Committee to withdraw its acceptance of Germany's invitation to the games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Secretary Ickes was at work in his office in the Interior Department tonight when he received the news of his wife's death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31. -- Renewal this week of agreements between Pacific shippers and maritime unions on the basis of awards at the conclusion of the last year's waterfront strike promise at least temporary peace. They followed the formation in all Pacific ports of citizens' groups announcing their intention to take whatever steps might become necessary to prevent a recurrence of a business paralysis inflicting hardship on the public.

Football practice will get under way at four New York colleges this week, when candidates for berths on the Columbia, Fordham, Manhattan and City College elevens report. The fifth major team in the metropolitan district, New York University, will be comparatively late in getting started, since candidates for places on the Violet squad will not appear for their first practice until a week from tomorrow.

Considerably refreshed after their twenty-four-hour respite from competion, the recently harassed Giants swung jauntily back into action at the Polo Grounds yesterday as if such comment as blowing another pennant had never even come to their attention.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 29. -- Political, business and social circles of Louisiana are awaiting with keen interest the investigation of Senator Long's political machine by the House of Representatives' investigating committee.

GENOA. A HUNDRED years ago today Giosue Carducci was born. Two years later Leopardi died, and that great drama of the Italian Risorgimento, which our American Thayer called "the masterpiece of the human spirit," had no other singer.

There has been recently discovered in the overhauling of papers carefully laid away a century ago the original list of subscribers and subscriptions for the erection of the Fredonia Academy in Chautauqua County, New York. This school had a useful educational career before the time of extensive secondary school training now provided throughout the State in the public high schools.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31. -- There is an item in today's Pravda, which surpasses all foreign news in importance, whether it be wars and rumors of wars in the Red Sea and the Mediterranean or protests against the Comintern by foreign governments.

Domestic sales in July of electric refrigerators for household purposes totaled 140,250 units, with a value of $11,020,929, according to reports from fourteen companies, it was announced yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Emphatic opposition to the proposal of the Long Island Railroad was voiced today by James H. Magee, president of the Nassau County Village Officials Association; Robert Kent, Village Clerk of Williston Park, which has over 1,000 commuters, and others in the official life of Nassau County.

Mrs. Anna Wilmarth Thompson Ickes was the daughter of a pioneer family whose home stood on the site of the Congress Hotel in Chicago. Daughter of Henry M. and Mary Jane Hawes Wilmarth, a leading woman philanthropist and active as a clubwoman, she was probably better known in Illinois than her husband up to the time the Roosevelt administration came into being.

ADMITTEDLY we need something modern in ballet form next Winter at the Metropolitan. The ballet as such is not the immediate concern of this writer. But a piece of music which cries out for vivid and imaginative stage spectacle, and which received it recently at Hollywood Bowl, is Ernest Schelling's score, to which are affixed the ironical verses of Alfred Noyes's "The Victory Ball."

If we could take our stand on the moon and equip ourselves with "glasses" that would enable us to see electric radiations to which we are now perhaps mercifully blind we would behold a wondrous earth. It would not only glow with sunlight reflected by the atmosphere but shimmer electrically.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The problem of who is to be president of the World Zionist Organization was dramatically settled here early today when Dr. Chaim Weizmann, noted scientist and internationally famous Zionist leader, announced his readiness to assume the full leadership of the Zionist movement.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The Cardinals retained their one-game lead over the Giants for National League leadership tonight by defeating the Reds, 5 to 2.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Arthur F. Bayliss broke 50 straight to take the high scratch honors in the weekly skeet shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The handicap award went to Robert Morano.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Illinois offered "square" money for its citizens to match with Missouri's "bottle caps" and the tokens of other commonwealths collecting sales taxes.

THESE lines, from Wordsworth's "Prelude," are printed on the title-page of Miss Glasgow's new novel. They sum up, in a very few words, her essential attitude toward life. For although Miss Glasgow may justly be described as an ironist, any one who has read her thoughtfully must see that she wears her irony as a shield.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Business generally continued upward as August drew to a close, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation. The expansion in output apparently has exceeded the usual seasonal increase, following the relatively favorable results of July, when manufacturing production declined less than is usual for the period.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- In spite of the lure of the music festival at Salzburg and the grouse shooting in Scotland, quite a number of Americans are figuring in the diversions of Deauville, where the Grande Semaine began last Sunday and will culminate in the Grand Prix de Deauville next Sunday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 31. -- With the open championships teams waiting for dry fields to renew their test matches for the tourney which opens Saturday, the final of the Wheatley Cups nine-goal tournament was staged today on Whitney Field.

Coca-Cola Company -- Three months ended June 30: Net income after charges and taxes, $4,476,311; compared with $4,308,572 in the second quarter last year. After Class A dividend requirements, net earnings for common stock in second quarter were $3,972,176.

PANAMA, R.P. -- The recent ousting of Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra as President of Ecuador is unusual in Latin-American history for the reason that President Velasco practically overthrew himself. As a potential dictator he proved that he did not realize dictators are made and not born.

JAMES J. WALKER'S imminent return to New York for the purpose of engaging in the general practice of the law cannot be viewed as an isolated phenomenon. If "Jimmy" WALKER is coming back it is one more sign that his country, too, is coming back.

The closing week of August, normally a period indicative of the extent of Summer travel, will this season serve only as a partial trend to the vacation movement, according to the Monthly Survey Forecast on World Travel Tendencies, released by the American Express Company.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The Saratoga Springs Authority, meeting today at the Gideon Putnam, submitted reports to Pierrepont B. Noyes, president, covering the first month of operation of the new Saratoga Spa.

LINA GOLDSCHMIDT, who died last Monday, had been for years a frequent contributor to these columns. In 1933 she and her husband -- the distinguished economist, Professor Alfons Goldschmidt -- were forced to flee from their home in Nazi Germany, and about a year later came to America.

The German-American Technologists Association opened its annual meeting yesterday in Jaeger's New Yorker Turnhalle, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, where it obtained accommodations following cancellations of previous reservations at the New Yorker and the Astor Hotels, and after the Downtown Athletic Club had declined to accept the sessions.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Climaxing a six weeks' controversy between William P. Lynch, director of the Onondaga County Works Progress Administration, and city and county officials, a staff of WPA engineers today settled down to an all-night task of preparing before the deadline of Sept. 1 a list of projects to employ about 10,000 people by Oct. 1 at a Federal cost of about $10,000,000.

A UNIQUE tunnel project has been started through America's backbone, sixteen miles west of Salida, in Colorado. The tunnel, to be seven miles long, will serve to divert water from the west slope of the Rocky Mountains to the eastern side, to drain gold mines and to provide a route for vehicles.

GLASS ON SHAKESPEARE: The nation knows Carter Glass, Virginia's 77-year-old Senator, as an authority on banking. It doesn't know very much about him as a Shakespearean scholar. On Dec. 5, at the College of William and Mary, it will see him in his academic role when he lectures on the Bacon-Shakespeare controversy.

Cool weather stimulated retail trade in the metropolitan area last week, but the gain in sales volume ran under expectations. Results reported by department stores were rather spotty, with some establishments having gains ranging around 5 to 6 per cent over a year ago, while others showed decreases of 1 to 2 per cent under the corresponding period of 1934.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The magnificent string of hunters that Richard K. Mellon sent on from Pittsburgh to the twenty-sixth annual Smithtown horse show completely dominated all the competition over brush and rail today and then, as a crowning touch, captured both the hunter championship and the reserve.
DR. MODESTE ALLOO, former head of the Department of Music of the University of California, will conduct the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra on Central Park Mall next Saturday evening.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Filed with the New Hampshire State Development Commission this week, a joint resolution approving the site of the proposed aerial tramway at Franconia Notch accords powerful support to the expanding State land use program there.
OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Fire Island's latest contest, the kerosene lamp in one corner and the electric bulb in the other, came this afternoon to a definite issue.

A SET of mural paintings for Commonwealth College in Arkansas is being prepared, according to an announcement just received, by Joe Jones, the St. Louis artist, whose one-man show at the A.C.A. Gallery in this city last Spring created much favorable discussion (the show, by the way, returned to the A.C.A. for a Summer "run," and may be visited through this week).

Apparently intended to reassure foreign exporters and at the same time upbraiding the British press for publishing "misleading statements of payments under the clearing arrangement with Italy," the business and financial report of the Association of Italian Corporations declares that "the scrupulous respect of commercial obligations is a fine Italian tradition, and the country is determined at all costs to settle the 'frozen commercial credits' which have been accumulating recently and to prevent their recurrence."

HOLYOKE, Mass., Aug 31. -- William Archambeault, 43, was found dead in his back yard today with a broken back, the victim, police believe, of an unusual automobile accident in which his son unknowingly ran over him.
The letter of Lincoln Kirstein in today's NEW YORK TIMES seems to miss the point of your column of a week ago, a point which is vital to many devoted followers of the ballet:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- It was not mere campaign shadowboxing when Henry Morgenthau Jr., the earnest Secretary of the Treasury, took the fateful step into the ranks of those who seek an early balance for the Federal budget.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The racing season concluded this afternoon with a throng taxing the capacity of the clubhouse.

HAVANA, Aug. 31. -- A demand that the Cuban Government set aside in a trust fund a sufficient amount to pay interest in default and accruing on public works bonds during the current fiscal year has been made on President Carlos Mendieta by a bondholders' committee representing American investors, according to a statement issued here today by that committee.

A TRICK story with no air of double-dealing is a distinct achievement. "Strange Journey" recites the adventures of two Englishwomen whose minds temporarily exchanged bodies. Yet it is told in such a simple, straightforward, disarming manner that it seems an honest case to interest psychic research workers as well as readers ready to be charmed by an unusual tale.
The complete details of the robot heart devised by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, by which organs of humans and animals can be kept alive indefinitely, were given by him for the first time yesterday.

A racket combining usury and intimidation was charged yesterday to Frank Ponzio, 28 years old, of 667 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, following his arrest on charges of extortion and violation of the Sullivan Law.

According to Police Department and other counts, an average of 112,000 motor vehicles cross the East River on Queensboro Bridge every day. This is said to be a larger volume of traffic than is carried by any other bridge in the world.

HOPKINS, Minn., Aug. 31. -- By finishing with two birdies, one of them for a half and the other for the match, Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. of Philadelphia, the former Glenna Collett, today gained the national women's golf championship for the sixth time to set a record that may never be equaled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The text of Secretary Hull's statement on the recent Soviet note replying to our protest of Communist activities in America follows:

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The destructive effect on the British position at Geneva of the news of the Rickett concession in Ethiopia raises the question what financial and political forces are dissimulated behind him. The whole incident is a good illustration of the fact, well known to responsible persons connected with the handling of public opinion, that news need not only be true but also must bear the stamp of probability.

TRENTO, Italy, Aug. 31. -- Premier Benito Mussolini paid a surprise visit today to the town where he was once a newspaper editor and told a cheering populace, "Those who do not know how to grasp the wheel of destiny in historic moments perhaps will never grasp it."
The epidemic of escaped monkeys spread to the lobby of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night and gave two taxi drivers, bellboys and attendants a lively time.

BROADCASTS from OPM, a 15,000-watt transmitter at Leopoldville in Belgium equatorial Africa, found the air of the final days of August ideal for a 6,500 mile jump into the New York area. The signals were strong when intercepted first at 1:15 o'clock one morning on the 10,140-kilocycle channel.
ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- The month of September was proclaimed "highway safety month" by Governor Lehman today.
CROUCHED in the blackness of a hooded cockpit as the ocean-spanning Pan American Clipper swept over the Pacific toward San Francisco Bay this Summer, I had the thrill of a totally "blind" landing.

GERMANY'S economic Commander-in-Chief, Dr. Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht, has startled the world with a strong attack on those National Socialists who are guilty of frivolous economic dilettantism, sabotage, extralegal and terroristic action.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The second annual Nestle-down Horse Show, another of those junior events which are becoming increasingly popular with young horse show followers, was successfully staged in a ring pitched on the estate of Bernard Smith today.

Seven dories manned by tanned lifeguards put out from a pier at New Dorp, S.I., with furious churning of oars at 4:45 P.M. yesterday, and the annual lifeboat race of the United States Volunteer Lifesaving Corps for the championship of Staten Island was on.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 29. -- Two years ago a Negro student, who had graduated at the North Carolina College for Negroes, applied for admission to the pharmacy school of the University of North Carolina.

THE focal point of all the mysterious happenings in this book is the Chamber of Horrors in the Riverpool Waxworks Gallery, presided over by Mrs. Ames and, to a very limited extent, by her slothful husband. As an exhibition, the waxworks is beneath contempt.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- British aircraft factories went on a twenty-four-hour schedule today, while the government was disturbed by dispatches saying Anglo-American interests had obtained a huge concession in Ethiopia.

PRAGUE. -- The fate of refugees from Germany, Austria and Soviet Russia who are living in Czechoslovakia is still in the balance, and in most cases their hopes of rehabilitation are dwindling as time goes on. The various committees are doing their best to alleviate distress but funds have become very low.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Confidence that a majority of American voters will defend the Constitution of the United States against the attacks of its enemies within and without the government was expressed today by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey.

ALEXANDER KORDA, the genial, solidly built Hungarian who pulled the British cinema out of the doldrums with his "Private Life of Henry VIII," arrived in New York last week with an entourage of London Films officials, a mighty thirst for seltzer and several pertinent observations concerning the state of the film industry.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The season at Bar Harbor is ending with a busy two weeks. The presence of H.M.S. York in the harbor was the occasion yesterday of a tea dance tendered by the board of governors of the Bar Harbor Club for Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best and the members of his staff.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 31. -- America's title-holding pair of outboard drivers who led the country in high scoring in 1934 and are again this season thousands of points ahead of the racing pack thrilled a huge throng along New Jersey's inland waterway here today in duels in four classes.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The suddenly inspired Pittsburgh Buccaneers kept up their galloping pace in the National League pennant race today by bowling over the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 0, for their tenth consecutive triumph.

Dr. Alix Churchill, associate secretary general of the International Association for Prevention of Blindness and executive secretary of the International Union Against Tuberculosis, arrived yesterday from Paris on the United States liner President Roosevelt.

A general alarm for a boat described as "a hit-and-run oil tanker" was sent out by the Police Department last night after the craft had collided with a launch in Eastchester Bay, the Bronx. One of three men who had been in the launch was killed by the propeller of the oil craft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- After a final burst of work, including the signing of the last three important measures passed by Congress that remained to be approved, President Roosevelt left Washington tonight for a rest at Hyde Park, N.Y., the site of his mother's home in the Hudson Valley, prior to a trip to the Pacific Coast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The United States cannot and will not oversee business investments of Americans abroad, Secretary Hull indicated today in disclaiming responsibility for the oil lease reported to have been granted by Ethiopia to an American concern.

HOULTON, Me., Aug. 28. -- Aroostook County farmers are facing the prospect of the worst harvest season that they have experienced in many years. Lack of rain, coupled with unusual heat, has turned the Aroostook potato fields, normally green at this time of the year, to brown and black.

THE Harper prize novel for 1935, selected from among eight hundred manuscripts, by Dorothy Canfield, Louis Bromfield and Sinclair Lewis, represents a fun-blooded picture of a relatively untracked part of our historic past, of Oregon during the homesteading period, 1906-08.

WITHIN 100 miles of the city lie two mountain play-grounds which through the years have become favorite objectives for tourists and week-enders from New York and Philadelphia and other Eastern cities. Because the Pocono and the Catskill Mountains are so close they are sometimes taken too much for granted, yet both regions perennially endeavor to offer new attractions or fresh variations of familiar ones.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Swift and emphatic Comment that the American people were determined to steer clear of foreign wars was heard among Senators today as they read of the Ethiopian oil concession involving America and British interests.

WARSAW, Aug. 31. -- Winning a close match from Great Britain by 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 in the nineteenth and final round, the United States team today emerged victorious from the biennial tournament of the International Chess Federation at the Army Officers Casino.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Four young girls, missing in the lofty wilderness of Mount Deception since yesterday afternoon, were found today and returned to their hotel none the worse for their experience.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Aug. 31. -- Under the blistering rays of the tropical sun today more than two-thirds of this island's 10,000 population jostled, both black and white inhabitants, for standing room in the limited roped enclosure in Emancipation Park in the shadow of the old Danish fortress to see Lawrence Cramer inaugurated as the second civilian Governor of the Virgin Islands.

SINCE it was announced that Senatore Guglielmo Marconi is experimenting with a so-called "death" ray to halt airplane and motor cars by ultra-short-wave radio flashes, inquiry among American radio experts reveals an inclination to look upon the idea as fantastic.

BY reviving "Caesar and Cleopatra" at Suffern last week Helen Hayes reminded us that Shaw at his best is no soporific. At his best he is a tingling wit. When the Theatre Guild opened its playhouse in Fifty-second Street a decade ago the learned directors offered Miss Hayes in the part she has just been acting again and Lionel Atwill in the dynamic part of Caesar.

THIS is a story of Harlem's "Little Italy" covering the twenty years centring on the turn of the century. It is a generous-sized, absorbing and colorful novel by an Italian-born American teacher, writer and civic worker.

IN the next few days the Council of the League of Nations will assemble at Geneva for what will probably be the most momentous session it has ever held. For the future of the League is at stake. The League has been successfully defied by Japan in Asia.

MAMMOTH CAVE, Ky., Aug. 31. -- Newly freed from seven tons of boulders by National Park Service employes, Kentucky's "prehistoric miner" continues to hide many of the secrets of his ancient race from modern science.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 31. -- Mrs. Anna Wilmarth Ickes of Winnetka, Ill., wife of Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, was killed this afternoon when an automobile in which she was riding overturned in a ditch beside Route 64 at Velarde, N.M., about forty miles north of Santa Fe.

While a seasonal lull was experienced in some mercantile and industrial lines in various sections of the country during the closing days of August, business in general continued to move at a satisfactory pace, with reports indicating a sharp upturn in trade activity during the period directly ahead.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 29. -- Despite urgings from nearly all of the State's political leaders, including Governor Allred and the former Governors Ferguson, to retain constitutional prohibition, Texas went to the polls last Saturday and amended its basic law to allow the Legislature to regulate the liquor traffic, so long as the open saloon was barred and the right of local option was respected.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lyle Phillips entertained with a supper in the Mount Washington in honor of Rhoulac Anderson and B.D. Potts of Squadron A, New York, who are their guests at the White Mountains polo ranch.

LAC DU FLAMBEAU, Wis. -- When the Moon of the Wild Rice swings over Wisconsin and Minnesota in mid-September, Chippewa Indians will again be busy at one of their first agricultural pursuits; this year with a new major customer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- It is not only the nation which heaves a sigh of satisfaction when Congress packs its bag and goes home. While adjournment does not transform Washington into a deserted city, the departure of the legislators and their thousands of hangers-on permits the nation's capital to return to mental and physical normalcy.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- New England regards the report of the Cabinet quartet on the cotton textile industry as a blow from which the industry may not recover. Nevertheless, the industry will strive to carry on without revision of the hours and wages of the code.

Call and time-loan interest rates in August were unchanged from those of the preceding month, making it the fourth consecutive month in which the same low record quotations prevailed. On the New York Stock Exchange, one-fourth of 1 per cent was charged for call money, against 1 per cent in August, 1934. The rate on the New York Curb Exchange was threequarters of I per cent, compared with 1 1/2 per cent a year ago.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31. -- Gene Kunes, Norristown (Pa.) professional, today won his first big golfing prize, the Canadian open crown.

ROME, Aug. 30. -- Only six months ago the safeguarding of Austrian and Hungarian independence was the focus of all Italian diplomacy, but since then the excitement of the preparations for war in East Africa has so occupied the minds of Italians that they have almost forgotten the existence of the General European problem.

BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- Beating the Braves today was not a difficult assignment for Casey Stengel's Dodgers, but the victory proved costly, for it deprived them of the services of George Earnshaw, probably for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Eastern Maine and the famed California redwood region will have their first national forests as the result of the National Forest Reservation Commission's action in establishing new purchase units in the two great timber-producing sections, Secretary Dern, president of the commission, announced today.

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 29. -- The Ethiopian general staff is making its preparations in the expectation that the first Italian attack will come from the north, with Adowa as the objective -- a direct attack being covered by flank action through the Takkaze Valley and in Northeastern Walkait.

War between Italy and Ethiopia will start "a conflagration" among the white and black races in Africa, in the opinion of Professor Cornelius de Villiers of Stellenbosch University, South Africa, who has arrived here as visiting Carnegie professor at several American universities.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The Intercollegiate Outing Club Association expects a record attendance of about 140 delegates from twenty-five colleges at its annual College Week encampment at Lake Colden, Sept. 7 to 14, Walter E. Williams of Union College, chairman of arrangements, said today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Held in the city jail on orders from New York City police, Herbert J. Teater, 41, today started what his jailors said was his sixteenth foodless day.

Dividends declared in August were larger in the aggregate than in the previous month and in August a year ago. The improvement, however, was not general. Declarations amounted to $258,294,458 for 674 corporations, compared with $172,504,763 for 785 companies in July and with $247,470,283 for 627 in August, 1934.

Two stake events mark the Aqueduct racing program for tomorrow as thoroughbred racing returns to the metropolitan district after the month-long session at Saratoga. In all seven races have been listed on the holiday card, with the main events being the Babylon Handicap for 2-year-olds and the Bay Shore Handicap for the stars of the older division.

Although below the record for a month established in July, the total of bonds called in August for redemption before maturity was the second largest amount for a month since July, 1928, and the largest for an August since this compilation was started in 1927.

PORT-SIDED COW: Farmers know that when you try to milk a cow from the left side, she's likely to kick. So New Jersey dairymen were puzzled to see a picture of their Governor, Harold G. Hoffman, milking from the left, and all calm. The picture was taken on Agricultural Field Day, Aug. 15, on the front lawn of the Governor's Summer place at Sea Girt.

THE United States has gone gypsy for its vacations, and a whole new industry is springing up as a result. The average citizen who once went to some spot in the country or at the seashore for his two-week vacation does this no longer.

Your Tokyo correspondent stated in a recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES that "there are now only 20,000 Japanese living in the Philippines, and the Filipinos are protected against an overwhelming influx by immigration laws." There are no immigration laws that prevent Japanese coming to the Philippines and living there, and there have never been any such laws.

UNDER the above title, Oliver Stewart recently set forth in the London Post what he considered the good and bad features of American, French and English automobiles. He began by quoting L.H. Pomeroy, president of the Institute of Automobile Engineers, as expressing the hope that "English engineers will not be forced into imitation of that massive monument to the family -- the American motor car."

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP). -- After weeks of bitter Republican attack, New York State Democrats plan to swing into their Fall campaign to retain control of the Assembly at a monster rally at Binghamton Sept. 20 and 21, the State committee disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- When Congress convenes in January one of the first moves of the farm bloc in the Senate and the House will be to urge prompt passage of the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Bill, which passed the Senate and went to the House Agriculture Committee, of which Representative Jones of Texas, co-author of the measure, is chairman.

VIENNA, Aug. 30. -- Dr. Eduard Benes, initiator of the Little Entente in 1920, could proudly emphasize a fortnight ago, when the fifteenth anniversary of the existence of this alliance was celebrated in Prague, that it is the only post-war alliance of its kind that has lasted so long.

DURING the coming months New York will listen with keen interest for news filtering out of the Criminal Court Building, where the extraordinary grand jury is to hear witnesses in the racket and vice inquiry.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30. -- A somewhat bewildered and resentful citizenry began to pay a 1 per cent sales tax in Missouri this week with the medium of exchange on sales of less than a dollar being the now famous "milk bottle caps" in denominations of 1 mill and 5 mills.
JUAN LES PINS. -- Incompetent gigolos are causing Riviera night club owners so much worry that a Riviera Gigolo Academy where they will be taught better dancing manners will be started here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- An increase in the number of savings accounts, not including Christmas savings and others of a similar character, of 636,000, or from 25,745,000 to 26,381,000, in the six months from Dec. 31 to June 29 in the 14,173 insured commercial banks was reported today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

ROME, Aug. 31. -- Anti-British sentiment, which had died down a little after Premier Benito Mussolini's declaration at the Cabinet council on Wednesday, flared up again today when Italians read in their newspapers of the vast mineral and oil concession reportedly granted by the Ethiopian Government to the African Development Exploration Corporation.

Cruising folk don't make the same mistake twice on their vacation voyages up and down the Hudson River. It takes only one night at anchor off Newburgh or perhaps Poughkeepsie to teach them the lesson that little comfortable sleep can be expected when the night liners and the freighters of commerce throw great wash and fairly toss them out of their berths.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29. -- The American protest to Moscow against the activities of the Communist International has brought into sharp relief the seventeen-year-old question of the relations of the Soviet Government with the so-called Comintern and world revolution.

FROM time immemorial all political and general discussion has involved the use of certain terms believed to be of central importance -- Liberty, Democracy, Equality, Justice, Religion, Classicism, Inflation, Radicalism. Conservatism, Liberalism, or what not.

IN current efforts that are being made to promote highway safety by reducing motor car accidents, the automobile skid is occupying the attention of scientific minds. A study of skidding has been made by R.A. Moyer, Associate Professor of Highway Engineering at Iowa State College.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- This borough literally turned its back on the Works Progress Administration today by flatly rejecting an offer of $25,000 to construct an athletic field at the local high school. The Mayor and Council decided the same job could be done for $4,500 and voted that the borough would do it without Federal assistance.

A COOPERATIVE college, where faculty and students perform all necessary work from wood-chopping to acting in a Shakespearean play, will open for its third year this Fall. Black Mountain College, near Asheville, N.C., now considers its experimental stage completed.

The Gdynia America liner Pulaski was making her last voyage in the Gdynia-New York service when she arrived here Thursday night. She will be withdrawn from the service to make way for the new Diesel-motored liner Pilsudski, which will sail from Gdynia Sept. 15 on her maiden transatlantic voyage.

DARTMOUTH, England, Aug. 31. -- The American racing yacht Yankee, competing in the last race of the English yachting season under the colors of Gerard B. Lambert of New York and Boston, was badly damaged today when she was dismasted during a heavy squall.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- The report that the Ethiopian Government has granted to an Anglo-American syndicate extensive exploitation rights is the big feature of today's news in Germany. The story is played up under such striking captions as "Blow at Italy" and "Thunderbolt from Addis Ababa."
The first festival in this country of the Society of San Vito, composed of a group of Sicilians to whom San Vito is patron saint, started yesterday and will be continued until tomorrow night.

ENGLAND still is in the midst of its most successful travel season of recent years. The movement that started last Spring, when the silver jubilee exercises were under way, has continued. The American Express Company cable checkings last week showed nearly 26,000 Americans in England, and record crowds were reported at her seaside resorts.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Perfect weather conditions today brought out the largest first-day attendance at the Sturbridge Fair since its inception eighty-one years ago. Large harness fields were sent away with little delay.
FROM John O'Connor, assistant director of the Fine Arts Department at Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, the following communication has just been received:
