DIVORCE and second marriage as experienced by two hypersensitive people is the theme of this rather intense little novel. Ellis was afflicted by "suffering and delicate adjustments to life" and Stephen, though less subtle-minded, was no better off than she.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The right of the Public Works Administration to allocate public funds in loans and grants to municipalities for the erection of electric generating plants and transmission lines over the objection of utility interests will be determined by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia early in the Fall.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in August was the largest in eighteen months, or since February, 1934. On Aug. 12, sales amounted to 2,426,310 shares, the most active full day's operation since July, 1934, and on Saturday, Aug. 10, sales totaled 1,210,770 shares, the largest turnover for a two-hour session since February, 1934.
BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- This was Mayor's Day in Boston. The city was host to four of them, all from New York, and there should have been five. "Stitch" McCarthy was left behind.

THE important exhibition of Chinese art to open in London late in November and continue until the middle of March is slowly taking shape. It is to be held under the joint auspices of the British and Chinese Governments.

CHICAGO. -- The termites have reached Chicago. The big white ants that are not ants have arrived from the South, and their work of devastation has begun. What may be only an advance guard for an innumerable army secretly sapped and undermined a two-story house until strong timbers crumbled and walls cracked.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29. -- Their eyes fixed on the glamorous goal of $200 a month for each person over 60, California's organized Townsend Plan champions have paid little attention to Alberta's election endorsing so-called social credits of a mere $25 a month for each inhabitant of that Canadian Province.

PORTLAND, England, Aug. 31. -- The British battleship Ramillies docked at Portsmouth today with the bodies of three members of the crew of the German freighter Eisenach, who, it was revealed, were killed when their ship was in a collision with the Ramillies in the storm-lashed channel last night.

COLLEGE authorities, realizing that knowledge can best be pursued in surroundings gracious and dignified, are calling on the decorator's art to improve classrooms, living rooms, libraries and fraternity houses. The practiced hand of a decorator is necessary to unify an exterior in Colonial or Old World scholastic style with interiors adapted to the practical uses of today, and to give college rooms the air of quiet beauty which a well-decorated home possesses.

Indictment of four members of an alleged stock swindling ring that was said to have fleeced part-payment investors of $3,000,000 to $5,000,000 was announced yesterday here and in Chicago, where one of the group, Leonard I. Sutterman, was arrested.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. 1%amsay C. I-Ioguet of 59 East Eightieth Street, New York, introduced formally to society tonight their youngest daughter, Miss Anne 1%. HIoguet, at a ball at Council Grove, where her two sisters, Mrs. 9;Vinston H. Hagen and Miss Louise 1%. Hoguet also had their dbut parties.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Chicago had its first glimpse of women on a meat strike today when picketers centred their attentions on food shops and their customers in the 1,200-1,300 block in the Milwaukee Avenue district on the near Northwest side.
BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- The Italo-Ethiopian dispute has given a new fillip to German colonial aspirations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Trading in grains on the Board of Trade today was mainly in evening up for the double holiday, and prices held within relatively narrow limits. Short covering and strength in other markets, however, gave wheat a strong undertone and its finish was 1 to 1 3/8 cents higher, the September-December difference widening fractionally to 2 1/4 cents at the last.

LONDON. IT is not the scenery alone that attracts so many British and foreign visitors every year to Grasmere and Ullswater. The whole district is, in a sense, a literary shrine, as is suggested by the common use of the term "the Lake Poets."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The Immigrant Ball at the Maidstone Club tonight ended its series of Saturday dinner dances for the season. Saturday dances will continue at the Devon Yacht Club. Several hundred colonists and their holiday house guests, in costumes of every country in the world, were present tonight.

The somber hue of the news from Addis Ababa has been relieved. Facing attack by Mussolini seeking to take Ethiopia unto himself, Emperor Haile Selassie has signed a concession turning over to a corporation "backed by the Standard Oil" the rights to seek petroleum and otherwise develop about half of his country -- the half lying next to the present Italian colonies. The deal was engineered by a British promoter, one Francis M. Rickett.

FOR the first fifty or sixty pages this novel sticks so closely to the standard guardian-and-ward plot that each familiar old development comes almost as a surprise. You keep watching, almost breathlessly, for the first branching off from the traditional pattern.

THE several previous Hawaiian romances of Miss Von Tempski, replete though they are with riotous tropical color and first-hand knowledge of the islands, seem pallid affairs beside the more involved and absorbing qualities which she has blended into her

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 31. -- A campaign that has been going on quietly for years has now reached the stage of determined extermination. The campaign is being conducted by the United States Government, in alliance with seventeen States, and the enemy is the common barberry bush, harborer of the dread stem rust of wheat.

Designed specifically to combat racketeering debtors, who in the past have defrauded their creditors of millions of dollars annually through illegal transfers and concealment of assets, a new law will become effective in this State today which will materially change what is known as "supplementary proceedings" following civil judgments.

Because tomorrow is Labor Day the sermons in most of the churches today will deal with unemployment and "The Church and Labor." In Protestant pulpits excerpts will be read from the Labor Day Message of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, issued through its Department of Social Service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Two important cogs in the New Deal machinery will be tested in the Supreme Court during its next term beginning in October. The court has been asked to rule on the constitutionality of the TVA program and the AAA processing tax.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Behind Jack Russell's four-hit pitching, the Senators today won the first of a two-game series with the Red Sox, 3 to 1.

DETROIT, Aug. 29. -- The American Federation of Labor this week in Detroit made its latest attempt to organize the automobile workers of the United States and Canada by the formation, under its auspices and control, of the International Union of United Automobile Workers.

OBSERVATIONS made by technicians of the National Broadcasting Company during the army manoeuvres at Pine Camp revealed an intelligible signal could be delivered through an intricate ultra-short wave relay system despite interference from many of the 268 short-wave transmitters in the battle area.

American manufacturers, engaged in a three-cornered fight with German and Japanese producers for Latin-American markets, are making headway at the expense of competitors in all but a few of the South American countries, surveys made last week by export trade organizations disclosed.

ROME, Aug. 31. -- Italian official circles received tonight with satisfaction, mingled with reserve, a statement by the British Government advising Emperor Haile Selassie to withhold concessions he has granted American and English interests.

Sidney Wood stood at the crossroads of his tennis career yesterday, with 7,000 dismayed spectators looking on in consternation from the Forest Hills stadium as the eclipse of his gifted but errant racquet approached totality for the year.

THE boy who loves to try his hand at woodcarving, the farm woman who experiments with patterns on her hand loom, and even the ordinary city duffer who has only a frustrated urge toward handicraft, all have a new and powerful ally.

A vast new market for the sale of home furnishings and electrical appliances was viewed as officially opened this week with the publication by the Federal Housing Administration of a booklet outlining the types of merchandise which may now be purchased by the public through FHA loans.

A MOVE to "take the talk bars down" for political candidates was introduced in the closing hours of Congress by Representative Byron N. Scott, Democrat of California. He suggested three amendments to the Radio Act which would simplify matters for political candidates, whom he contends are frequently required to pay an advanced rate during campaigns.
To a characteristic group of flannel-clad, pipe-smoking julep-sippers a Virginia professor once suggested that we "study the past in order to make more intelligent observations as to the future."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Another project designed to beautify New York and relieve traffic congestion was begun last Wednesday when Mayor La Guardia broke ground for the first link in the long-discussed East River Drive. When it is finished it will wipe out some of the ugliest spots along the eastern waterfront of Manhattan, provide parks and recreation grounds and add another north and I south highway on which cars can move with reasonable speed.

Bewildered by the scope and number of laws enacted by Congress before it adjourned last week, trade groups and business organizations were still endeavoring yesterday to make a comprehensive digest of new laws and of their probable effects upon business.

Shortly after the body of 4-year-old Elizabeth Vonderhofen of 322 Newman Avenue was found last night in a desolate section of Classon Point, the Bronx, not more than a quarter of a mile from her home, police arrested a 9-year-old boy who they said admitted that he had killed the little girl in a fit of anger.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Aug. 30. -- The AAA wheat program is certain of an encore in Kansas. The prospective big sign-up of Kansas growers on the contracts for the next four years is due largely to the same factors which have attended all efforts of the New Deal to curtail wheat production.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Two horse shows and a flower show are among the season-end diversions of interest to Northern New Jersey shore colonists. The first of the equine events takes place this afternoon on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil at Ocean and Pullman Avenues, Elberon.

SOLON, Ohio, Aug. 31. -- L.S. Pratt, 28, sporting goods store clerk of Indianapolis, today was crowned America's all-bore skeet champion. He won his laurels in the first national tournament ever staged by the skeet fans, breaking 244 of 250 targets to lead a field of 114 by a pair of clays.

It is not exaggerating to say that the people of the habitable earth have been watching with stupefaction the glacier-like drift into another war. They began with incredulity. It did not seem possible that such a conflict should be deliberately planned only twenty years after the war to end war.
Two hundred children brought a bit of rural entertainment to the Bronx yesterday afternoon in a "country fair festival" held on the south lawn of Crotona Park, 171st Street and Franklin Avenue.
TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 31. -- Buffalo Ankerite Gold Mines, Ltd., will soon take over Marbuan Gold Mines, Ltd., it is predicted by Edward G. Kimkel, secretary and managing director of the former company.

LAKE PLACID -- The thirty-third annual Indian Council Fire Ceremony tomorrow night at the Lake Placid Club will be the climax of observances of Labor Day in the Adirondacks and will provide a colorful prelude to the finale of New York's observance of fifty years of State conservation.

DALLAS. -- In an attempt to solve the parking problem on busy downtown streets, Dallas and other Southwestern cities soon may place in operation machines to vend parking space at so many minutes for five cents.

Complete reconditioning of the fifteen public baths in Manhattan is planned by Borough President Samuel Levy as a WPA project. The Federal authorities have made an allocation of $839,550 for this work, which will include repairs and replacements of mechanical and electrical equipment, new tile walls and floors, waterproofing, painting and repairing old walls, and new roofing and skylights.

SHANGHAI. -- Foreign residents here are amazed at the speed with which the Japanese are asserting primacy in China. The complete change in the personnel of the Chinese administration in the North and the elimination of the Kuomintang there, at the virtual bidding of the Japanese Army from Kwantung, have been matched by demonstrations of Japanese dominance in other parts of China.

Removing abandoned street car tracks is a flourishing industry just now -- as was indicated the other day by the announcement that Madison Avenue from Forty-second it Fifty-ninth Street has been made into a smooth and trackless oasis.

The influence of the United States silver policy on the foreign exchange market was brought out last week when a slackening of our Treasury's purchases of silver in London caused a general decline of foreign currencies in terms of the dollar, opening prospects of a renewed influx of gold from Europe.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Autumn season will be officially opened this Tuesday at the Greenbrier with the beginning of the Women's Mason and Dixon Golf championship contest for the President's gold trophy.

It is significant that the Connecticut State Traffic Commission should have issued an appeal to the motoring public last week never to travel at a speed in excess of forty-five miles an hour. It has been the fashion in Connecticut in recent years, as in many other States, to decry speed limits.

ISTANBUL, Aug. 29. -- The turn which the Italo-Ethiopian conflict seems to be taking recalls to the minds of the Turks events of twenty-four years ago, when Italy declared war on Turkey and landed troops in Tripoli. This act of aggression, generally unexpected, had been preceded by a violent anti-Turkish campaign in the Italian press.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 31. -- The swift stroke of Emperor Haile Selassie in turning over approximately half his empire to English and American interests for exploitation was generally regarded today as blocking Italian economic penetration of Ethiopia.

INSTEAD of showing the entire gift of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. this month, as originally planned, the Museum of Modern Art has decided to postpone the exhibition until next January, announcing that "the collection will be amplified before that time by additional paintings given by Mrs. Rockefeller."

ESPIONAGE agents of four nations -- China, Russia, Japan and the United States -- are here conniving against each other for the recovery of a lost, priceless formula which will revolutionize and increase the cruising capacity of warships to a degree that will render the navy of the country possessed of the secret undisputed mistress of the seas.

GENEVA. -- Not over-production of food but under-consumption of it is mankind's real problem, according to a report on "Nutrition and Public Health" by two physicians on the staff of the health organization of the League of Nations, E. Burnet and W.R. Aykroyd.

WITH the turn of the month, even though warm days may still continue, the end of another Summer season is definitely in sight. Jack Frost is on his way from the tundras, and it is but a question of a few weeks at most before his icy breath will blow of nights across the flower borders.

IN the late Eighteen Eighties a poor, unknown young Irish poet living in London dreamed of a drama for Ireland. Ireland was poor, its intellectual energies absorbed in politics. There were no plays that took Irish life seriously, no Irish actors who did more than portray the stage Irishman There never had been an Irish drama, there never would be, was the thought of every one except this young man, whose name was W.B. Yeats.

TWELVE months in the year the potato is the nation's most popular food, ranking high on every family board. But the supply at this season is even greater than the demand. Indeed, the potato has been so abundant this year that Congress recently voted a bill to control our future potato crop.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 31. -- The significance of the Institute of Human Relations, sponsored by the national conference of Jews and Christians, was stressed and its values defined in statements issued here today by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the conference, and by Rabbi Morris Lazaron of Baltimore and the Rev. T. Lawrason Riggs of New Haven, Conn., speaking on behalf of the Jewish and Catholic members of the organization.

Cowl Rider laments that young, children in England are reading war stories and suggests that their minds "are being warped into seeing war from the wrong angle -- the angle of brass buttons and drums." Is it possible that he is concluding too hastily that the effect of such reading must be harmful?

With the strike of 15,000 members of the Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, gaining momentum in the garment district, the police detail there was increased yesterday from 200 to 300 patrolmen and mounted police and the alien and radical squads were assigned to duty under Inspector Michael A. McDermott.

HONOLULU, Aug. 24. -- In preparing our expedition experienced advisers had counseled us against attempting to land on ocean-beaten, tiny Baker Island. They told of smashing surf on treacherous reefs, shark-infested waters. Surf boats from other expeditions, they said, had been upset and smashed, the occupants narrowly averting serious injuries, even possible death.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- While comment is being withheld, the belief in government and diplomatic circles now is said to be that after a period of negotiations which will fully inform foreign interests of the requirements, most of the $4,500,000,000 in bonds of foreign governments and their political subdivisions which are listed on the Stock Exchanges will obtain permanent registration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- The number of shoppers in the large department stores was well ahead of last week, while the cool weather brought a noticeable pick-up in sales of Fall ready-to-wear. The low temperatures, however, brought close-outs of Summer items almost to a standstill, with the result that sales totals were somewhat below those for the final week of August, 1934.

LABOR DAY comes tomorrow, and in another week school children with shining morning faces will be dragging themselves back to work on the three R's. For mothers this means scurrying through shops, looking for clothes for the youngsters. Racks upon racks of attractive garments await them.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The New York State Department of the American Legion bid good-bye to Rochester tonight with unanimous demand for immediate cash payment of the bonus and election of Edward N. Scheiberling of Albany as commander as the high spots of a tumultuous close to its seventeenth annual convention.

IN this most recent book of the long series, a score or more of them, that Dr. Shailer Mathews already has to his credit, he sets forth his conception of what Christianity should be and do in its relations with the world today, his credo of Christian responsibility and practice.

Driving with his Queen through Switzerland in an American sport coupe, with the chauffeur sitting in the rumble seat, young King Leopold III of the Belgians took his eyes off the road for a moment Thursday morning and crashed into a tree. Queen Astrid was instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The neutrality resolution providing for an embargo on shipments of arms to countries at war, and laying down other rules of conduct designed to assure the maintenance of a strictly neutral position by the United States, was signed by President Roosevelt this afternoon.
BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- Two deaths were reported from infantile paralysis tonight and eighteen new eases of the disease were recorded in Eastern Massachusetts during the day.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Ted Macknik, 21-year-old Pennsylvanian, stirred the interest of Detroit mathematicians today with a demonstration of the method by which he contends he is able to trisect an angle, using only a straight edge and a compass.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The search for Donald K. Phillips, missing since he took off from Roosevelt Field for Providence, R.I., Wednesday morning at 10 o'clock, in his own Stinson monoplane, was continued without success today.

HOLLYWOOD producers, who six years ago scorned suggestions from American school teachers, are today definitely catering to school interests and needs. Currently in production or in preparation in Hollywood workshops are no less than sixty-five photoplays, representing an expenditure or investment of approximately $35,000,000, which aim at meeting the standards expressed in rating scales sponsored by teachers.

THE Levant Fair, held annually in September on the shores of the lower Adriatic, is expected this year to turn thousands of merchants and tourists toward Bari, which during the past thirteen years of the Fascist regime has made such progress as to earn the appellation "the Milan of Southern Italy."

THE cinema forecast for the new week is "clear, with little change." It would seem that only two houses are certain of changing their bills; the others, either definitely or fairly so, plan to retain their present tenants for another week or more.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 31. -- Relations between the United States and the Soviet Union will be "seriously impaired" if the Moscow Government continues what this government considers violation of its pledge to prevent efforts from its territory to overthrow the social and political structure of this country, Secretary Hull said in a formal statement issued late today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, started a nation-wide search today for Jack I. Davis, wanted on charges of embezzling $34,500 from the Essex branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, New York.

Lou Little, Columbia's head football coach, brought his series of football talks at The Herald Tribune auditorium to a close yesterday. Discussing various phases of offense and detailing such plays as the off-tackle, the "mousetrap," end runs and the spinner, Little once more emphasized that proper execution meant more than the knowledge of a varied attack.

With many uncertainties removed, particularly the question of the government's new cotton loan policy, and with evidence of returning confidence among buyers, the outlook for the immediate future in the cotton textile industry is distinctly more encouraging, according to Goldthwaite H. Dorr, president of The Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc.

We were interested in your editorial "Calendar Contentions." Though at first blush it appears unthinkable, the recent Rumanian disturbances indicate that people can really get sufficiently excited about the calendar to cause bloodshed.

COOL weather came at a rather inopportune time for retailers in many sections last week, since it checked Summer clearance sales and holiday buying. Recent sharp gains were reduced and in other centres trade ran only even with a year ago. Some pick-up was noted upon new Fall lines, but volume was not done, of course.

WHEN the small garden club, or other local organization, decides to give its first flower show there are many problems facing the inexperienced committee. A survey of the experience of other clubs often saves many serious mistakes.

FIFTEEN THOUSAND pairs of eyes focus upon the champion as he lifts his racquet to serve. The massed spectators about the green arena at the culminating moment of a terrific battle realize that tennis history my be unrolling before them.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 31. -- New Jersey's retail sales tax reaches the two-month mark today, leaving political turmoil in its wake and headed for an unknown destiny at the primaries on Sept. 17, the party conventions and the general election in November, when an entire new Assembly and several State Senators will be elected.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Jimmy Hines, winner in 1933, heads the latest list of entries for the seventh annual Glens Falls open tournament at the Glens Falls Country Club next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Although busier than ever this Summer, Shinnececk Canal, the curious waterway in Southampton which bisects Long Island, will carry, in another season or two, a vastly greater traffic of pleasure and commercial boats as the result of new development plans now nearly completed.

ON October 5 it will be exactly a quarter of a century since the Republic of Portugal was proclaimed and Manoel II was shunted off into semi-oblivion. Therefore this book of travel, although scarcely designed to mark an anniversary, has a certain timeliness in addition to its own intrinsic interest.

FOR people who enjoy well-written stories of English family life, "Enbury Heath" offers entertaining reading. It presents the Gardens of London, a family not cumbrously large, so there's no need for a charted family tree. The point of view is that of the young Gardens, Sophia, 21; Harry, 20, and Francis, 16.

WHAT it takes to be a champion was the topic chosen by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons on a sunny day in Saratoga. The veteran and genial trainer, who carries weight for age, was standing just outside the stall of the Derby winner, Omaha, at the Belair stable and he was still wearing his working clothes. Which is to say that he was wearing his second-best soft hat and was not wearing any tie.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Indications of drastic curtailment in the staff of the National Recovery Administration were seen today in the issuance of an order by the President directing that special efforts be used to find work for persons dropped from the rolls of the NRA.

THE purpose of that part of the program of the National Youth Administration which has to do with aid to students in both high schools and colleges is to provide assistance to those pupils who otherwise find it impossible to continue their courses.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange during the brief pre-holiday period yesterday was exceptionally dull. The turnover was only $3,263,300, reflecting the absence of traders from the financial district for the Labor Day holiday.

UNDER the pale rays of the midnight sun, as Summer draws to an end, several Russian freighters are bucking the ice of the Northeast Passage between Murmansk and Vladivostok. They are the vanguard of the fleet which, in a few years, the Soviet Government hopes will regularly link these widely separated ports each Summer season.

LILY pools and waterlilies growing in them can be kept at the peak of perfection during late Summer and early Fall if the gardener takes a few simple precautions to overcome the troubles which sometimes beset them.

Cool weather stimulated Fall retail trade last week, except in some sections of the South where it has been extremely hot, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Rush deliveries are being requested by store buyers, but the shipping clerks' and truckmen's strikes have delayed ready-to-wear shipments.

DALLAS. -- In a Sharp denunciation of gambling in general and race betting in particular, Governor Allred took the bull by the horns recently by obtaining temporary injunctions restraining the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company and others from disseminating information relative to horse racing in Texas.

THE author of this book was Mrs. Stanford's private secretary for twenty-one years, from the death of her son, Leland, Jr., in the early Spring of 1884 until her own death in the late Winter of 1905 and therefore writes the story of her life from the knowledge born of intimate personal association.

Protesting vigorously against the proposal of the Long Island Railroad to increase all its commutation rates 15 to 20 per cent, effective Oct. 1, public officials and commuters' organizations throughout the territory served by the line prepared yesterday for a bitter fight to block the company's effort to raise fares.

RECENTLY the film critics received from Ernest Pascal, president of the Screen Writers Guild, an earnest petition in which he deplored their tendency to underrate or ignore the work of the screen dramatists. "Why," he inquired, "is screen authorship the only form of creative writing condemned to the general doghouse?

TWO days before the harassed representatives of a befuddled Europe met recently in an unavailing effort to put a brake on him, Benito Mussolini made a pious and peaceful pilgrimage to a primitive old farmhouse in a hill village near his birthplace. He was accompanied by his wife, the unobtrusive Donna Rachele -- Italy's forgotten woman -- and the two sons, Bruno and Vittorio, who as volunteers are joining the flying corps in East Africa.

A great deal of nonsense has been heard in various quarters in the last three days over the fact that the United States Treasury obtained bids for but $85,592,000 of the offering of $100,000,000 of four-year 1 1/2 per cent bonds of the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation.

Home relief investigators were sent out to their clientele at the beginning of last week to recruit 20,000 able-bodied family heads for work on WPA projects. The mobilization was sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and Administrator Johnson, who were dissatisfied with the slow pace at which the Federally financed projects were getting under way.

In The New York University Law Quarterly Review Mr. HUGH FISHER and Mr. MATTHEW MCGUIRE, lawyers in the criminal division of the Department of Justice, discourse learnedly of kidnapping and the statute against it, passed in 1932 and amended in 1934, popularly called the "Lindbergh Law."

ROME, Aug. 31. -- The recall to Italy's colors of another entire military class was announced by Premier Benito Mussolini in a speech delivered today near Trento to 100,000 soldiers massed in a valley after having been reviewed by King Victor Emmanuel at the end of their army manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Almost precisely twenty-four hours after President Roosevelt signed the Guffey bill to create miniature NRA code for the soft coal industry, James Walter Carter, president of the Carter Coal Company, a Washington concern, today began a legal battle to test the constitutionality of the highly controversial law.

ON the morning of Oct. 5, 1930, the British airship R-101 was destroyed at Beauvais. In 1932 Princess Marthe Bibesco published her biographical memoir of Lord Thomson, the British Secretary of State for Air, who perished in the disaster.

The National Constitution Day Committee, with headquarters at 55 Forty-second Street, yesterday announced plans for the observance of Constitution Day, Sept. 17, which will mark the 148th anniversary of its adoption. The chief celebration will be in Faneuil Hall, Boston, with hundreds of other meetings in other sections of the country.

HAVING finished, at least temporarily, his family saga of the Herries clan, Hugh Walpole now renews his interest in the cathedral town of Polchester, the scene of his novels, "The Cathedral," "Harmer John" and "The Old Ladies."

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 31 (AP). -- An X-ray Easter regal lily, a flower made more beautiful by changing its heredity with X-rays, was announced today at the research laboratories of the General Electric Company.
Sinclair Lewis, who has expressed in fiction some pretty definite ideas about his native land, is a shrinking violet on the subject of politics and economics.

THE dahlia grower is being educated by experience, books and shows to demand healthy roots and plants that will flower as their originators predict they will. The reliability of their sponsors and the judgment of experts who have seen them in the field and at exhibitions now largely determine the popularity of new introductions.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- Mainbocher is featuring heavily carved jade or coral clasps in Chinese dragon designs as the sole decorations on many simple black afternoon and dinner gowns. They hold the lightly draped fabric at the neck and waist.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP). -- A dozen Midwestern hog farmers in a suit today attacked the constitutionality of the processing tax, alleging that contrary to its purpose it reduced their income. They asked the Cook County Superior Court to order eight Chicago packing companies to pay them back.

ONE must, he insisted, be above all else spontaneous in one's letter-writing: and proceeded to spin out letters with a freedom and capriciousness it would be hard to match in any other of our prose masters. On principle no doubt he was right, but it is another question whether in performance he was successful.

DERRICK MANN is a famous ski jumper, a "blond viking," employed by the mountain hotel internationally famous for its Winter sports. Gaynor Lord, who manages the tea room, is young, lovely, in love with life, with "the wide emotional range of an actress."

A newer, gayer order of existence will be inaugurated Saturday at the Margaret Louisa branch of the Y.W.C.A., at 20 East Sixteenth Street, as it is reopened for the benefit of girls earning a maximum of $15 weekly. For years the residence had been occupied almost exclusively by a group of older guests.

Sales by manufacturers of articles to be offered as premiums by producers and distributers in various industries will total at least $450,000,000 at wholesale prices during the 1935-36 season, from present indications, according to an estimate made here yesterday by Howard W. Dunk, secretary of the Premium Advertising Association of America Inc.

OTTAWA, Aug. 30. -- William Aberhart, whose Social Credit party swept the Alberta elections of Aug. 22, filling fifty-six out of sixty-three seats in the Legislature, has emerged as the strong man of the Province.

SINCE the coming of the automobile, the ever increasing speed and volume of vehicles have presented to the highway engineer problems of growing complexity. One of these problems is that of measuring the ability of a highway to expedite traffic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- A no-hit, no-run game -- the first in the major leagues since Sept. 21, 1934, and the first in the American circuit in four years -- today admitted 26-year-old Vernon Kennedy of the White Sox to baseball's hall of fame. He blanked the third-place Indians, 5 to 0.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 31. -- The Belgian people, from Dowager Queen Elizabeth to the humblest subject of the Kingdom, continued today to pay a moving tribute to Queen Astrid, whose body lay in state at the Royal Palace.

The polo season will approach its climax this week with the start of the national open championship at the Meadow Brook Club Saturday. In the first match, the Hurlingham team, which came from London for this championship, meets Stephen Sanford's Hurricane team on International Field.

ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Describing the South as the frontier of the nation, Chairman Jud P. Wilhoit of the Georgia Public Service Commission said today the Interstate Commerce Commission would be asked to issue an order "removing the handicap and disadvantage of the high and discriminatory freight rates that at this time are paralyzing this section."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Works Progress Administration announced today rejection by the advisory committee on allotments of fifteen PWA applications totaling $4,478,708 from New Jersey because the cost per man-year was too high. Included in the grant applications were the following:

While heads of oil companies in the Standard Oil group denied they had anything to do with the Rickett concession in Ethiopia, and Wall Street was outspokenly skeptical of the reports, it was learned yesterday that the African Development Exploration Corporation had been incorporated in Delaware on July 11 to exploit the concession.

THE nation's interest has been strongly drawn toward New England since the recent election in Rhode Island. Such questions as these are asked: What is the situation in New England today? How much of her tradition is still potent?

PARIS, Aug. 15, 1935. SERGE LIFAR'S choreographic legend, "Icare," attracted more than routine attention at its recent premiere at the Paris Opera. Henry Malherbe, writing in Le Temps, describes M. Lifar's latest gesture in setting himself up as a champion of "pure dance."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The endorsement of Senator Borah for the nomination for President by the Young Republicans of the Northwest -- and increasing sentiment for him elsewhere -- has brought the Idaho lawmaker to a crossroads in his career.

THE fine old American institution of the shotgun wedding figures very largely in the plot of Octavus Roy Cohen's latest novel-though Mr. Cohen, with that ingenuity for which he is justly noted, has given it a fresh and rather surprising twist.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The long-awaited British challenge for the America's Cup already has been sent to New York by C.R. Fairey, airplane builder and owner of Shamrock V.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The triumvirate of "bone-dry" States has been broken. Since the people of Texas have voted prohibition out of their State Constitution only Kansas and Oklahoma are dry by both Constitution and legislative statute.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Yachting history was made on Barnegat Bay today as twenty-four International Star Class sloops, representing eight Atlantic seaboard fleets, raced in the seventh annual Jersey coast challenge series for the Valspar Trophy.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Adoption of an employe relationship policy governing labor standards, employe collective representation, hours of work, rates of pay, classification and general employment conditions was announced today by the three directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

A COMMITTEE is being formed to award an annual literary prize on behalf of The Limited Editions Club. The prize, a gold medal, is to be awarded to the American author of any book published in the preceding year which is judged by the committee to attain most nearly the stature of a literary classic.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- More than 800,000 spectators watched the opening soccer games in England today. The eighty-eight clubs started the eight months' grind in real football weather. Skies were overcast and grounds rain-soaked.

THE battle over the double bill continues. A matter of some concern to the customers because the quality of films allegedly is involved, producers have publicly revealed their attitude and local theatres are being used as clinical specimens to prove or disprove the theories in question.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP). -- James A. Farley, ending his vacation jaunt to Hawaii, listed two causes for personal rejoicing today before he boarded a train for New York.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31. -- Neutral mediators have decided to drop negotiations on the exchange of Chaco war prisoners in view of their inability to bring the Bolivian and Paraguayan delegations to agreement.

When Mr. Kirstein is content merely to express his opinion there is usually little occasion for excitement. He already achieved considerable note for his opinion some years ago when he opined with characteristic perspicacity and nicety of discrimination that the best dancers in the country were Rosina Galli, Ruth Page, Harriet Hoctor and Tamara Geva.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Roy S. Foyle, piloting his hydroplane Hopatcong Baby at a speed ranging from 38.12 to 46.07 miles an hour, won the Edenburn Memorial Trophy race that featured the Detroit Yacht Club's annual regatta today.
ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Twenty thousand Ethiopian priests notified Emperor Haile Selassie today of their willingness to battle beside regular warriors to resist any invading legions from Italy.
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Aug. 31. -- Governor Lawrence Cramer made history today. He took the oath of office before a native judge. It was the first time such a gesture had been made.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- In one of the most sensational finishes in Saratoga racing history, C.V. Whitney's Red Rain today scraped his way along the fence to win the $44,100 Hopeful Stakes after he had appeared a hopeless last in a field of seventeen.

Starting off with an airplane crash which looks like an accident but isn't, this story rapidly develops into a mystery romance in which two Balkan kingdoms are involved. The scene opens in England with young Peter Osborne peacefully practicing golf shots all by himself.

A STRAIGHT line drawn these days between Waterbury, Conn., and Grafton, Mass., would pass through the beards of twoscore rural gentlemen suffering acutely and volubly from wounded civic pride. To those irate sixty -- the number may have increased to sixty-one since last week's survey -- the name of Clarence Brown is anathema, if not something much less printable.
REDECORATION in a very thorough way has been going forward at the Milch Galleries. All walls have been given a congenial surface of gray, against which the paintings appear to excellent advantage.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Disturbed by the mounting number of accidents caused by motorists stopping suddenly to pick up hitchhikers, Westchester County parkway police today opened a drive to enforce a State statute against roadside solicitation of rides.
STREETS and avenues in Manhattan now under construction, and likely, therefore, to offer impediments to traffic, were reported last week by the Automobile Club of New York as follows:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31. -- With a titan 1935 written in smoke against a lofty blue-gray overcast in the east by Art Davis, Roger Don Rae and Bob Odell, with Old Glory floating down from 2,000 feet at the bursting of an aerial bomb and with "The Star-Spangled Banner" ringing out from the combined brasses of three bands of the Ohio Band Camp, the fifteenth annual National Air Races opened in sunshine here this afternoon.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP). -- State Attorney G.A. Worley tonight said that the death by fire of two of the three daughters of H.G. Denmark, 36, "contains elements that require further explanation."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- All except one of Philadelphia's twenty-eight magistrates must go on trial on charges involving misconduct in office.

With the aid of several of the larger banks of New York City the Works Progress Administration, headed by General Hugh S. Johnson, paid thousands of relief workers yesterday several days in advance of scheduled pay days so that they would not be without funds over the long Labor Day week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The current exchange of indignant notes between this government and the Soviet Union over the former's allegation of interference in its internal affair in violation of the Litvinoff pledge is the latest of a number of disappointments, on both sides, that have resulted since President Roosevelt recognized the Russian Government on Nov. 16, 1933.

LEBANON, Pa., Aug. 31. -- That Old Pennsylvania Dutchman, United States Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana, attended a family reunion today at Long's Grove near here, and made a great hit with all of his kinsmen except "Cousin Cleve," who belongs to the Socialist branch of the family.

Members of the congregation of the First Church of Christ at Arnold Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, Maspeth, Queens, tried hard to build themselves a new place of worship yesterday but had to give up last night with the roof still missing.

STOCKHOLM, N.J., Aug. 31. -- As eager to shun publicity as they were to doff their clothes, about 200 affiliates of the American Gymnosophical Association converged on lonely Rock Ledge Camp, five miles from here, and at 2 o'clock today opened the annual International Nudist Conference.
The Fall handicap list of the Metropolitan Golf Association appears today with 596 additional names and changes of rating.

The survey of streams of the Delaware watershed by scientists of the New York Conservation Department has brought to light a number of unusual specimens of fish life. The stream collections have yielded more than forty specimens, including the more familiar game fish, such as trout and bass, and a number of kinds which anglers rarely catch because of small size, scarcity, or indifference to lures.

From the time when public hearings on the proposed municipal power plant begin, on Sept. 3, until Nov. 5, when the matter will be presented to the voters for a referendum, Mayor La Guardia's pet project promises to be the centre of what might be called an electric storm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- When Majority Leader Robinson suggested to the Senate on Monday evening that if it did not agree to the adjournment resolution sent it by the House the President might be called upon to exercise his constitutional prerogative of adjourning Congress, he touched upon one of the powers of the Chief Executive which never have been exercised in the history of the United States.

WHEN the Pan American Clipper touched her keel to the waters of the Golden Gate, off Alameda, last week, she had completed 22,750 miles of scheduled flying over the Pacific. Guided by the invisible fingers of the radio direction finder, she had laid an intangible but no less real air track two-thirds of the way from California to the Orient.

TOURISTS are stopping at the rate of 400 or 500 a day this Summer to visit the ruins of old Fort Ticonderoga, and the Military Museum established there in a restoration of two of the barrack buildings by Stephen H.P. Pell, whose collections are added to each year.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- With an unusually full program of social activities now under way in this, the last important weekend of the season, there is little indication that Labor Day will mark the end of the Summer's formal entertainments, as in previous seasons.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- Very seldom has any government found itself in such a delicate and complicated diplomatic position as that of France just now on the eve of the Geneva debate on Italian intention toward Ethiopia. For French national interest and national sentiment are torn in three directions.

At Geneva next Wednesday, when the Council of the League of Nations meets to take up the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, the statesmen of Europe will face the most serious crisis which has arisen in international affairs since the World War. To a world that wants peace, Benito Mussolini has made it plain that he intends to make war.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- As the result of the assignment of a CCC camp to Cornell University's new arboretum of 500 acres, work has begun on the project of planting the trees and shrubs in the arboretum, which is eventually to contain all the specimens hardy in the area.

The International Seamen's Union has entered upon a campaign to weed out men holding membership cards who are suspected of being in concert with radical leaders planning a national shipping strike in American ports late this month.

Moscow, Aug. 5, 1935. THE Soviet way of life has raised questions of style for the composers. In their creative work and in their frequent discussions of artistic problems they have attempted to formulate an approach that will fulfill the needs of their society and their time.

In addition to his hopes to complete his schedule of providing municipal yacht basins in each of the five boroughs as part of his vast parkway programs within the next year, Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday announced that he has requested the Federal Government to assist in the establishment of a large yacht basin in the Harlem River, just off the Hudson.

PARMOOR, Henley-on-Thames, Aug. 31. -- When I was at Geneva in 1924 as head of the British delegation, we produced a protocol, a series of amendments to the framework of the League Covenant, whereby all disputes without question are compelled to be submitted either to arbitration, conciliation or to World Court decision.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- In so far as the immediate technical market situation is concerned, Secretary Wallace won a major victory over the Southern Senatorial bloc when he succeeded in fixing the loan on cotton at 10 cents a pound, instead of 12 cents which the Byrns amendment to the Third Deficiency Bill demanded.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 31. -- The country, yacht and beach clubs of Westchester began a round of social events tonight for the week-end and holiday.

IT is worth recording that England now recognizes that its Summers can be, and often are, uncomfortably warm. From this recognition, which seems oddly belated, various notable alterations in social habits have proceeded.
RED LAKE FALLS, Minn., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh landed here late today after a flight from Camp Ripley, near Little Falls, that lasted 3 hours and 25 minutes.

WAYNESBURG, Pa., Aug. 31 (AP). -- A towering granite monument will be dedicated near here Sept. 14 to the war dead of Greene County -- the tribute of a farmer who left his whole $80,000 estate to provide the memorial.

Probably the largest vertical photograph ever made, this picture covers an area of more than 200 square miles. Pictures of the lake have been taken regularly for the United States Government each time the water rose 20 feet since the dam started to fill. The photographs are being used to make an exhaustive silt study in the program of soil erosion control to protect the life of the reservoir.

THE second annual dance festival sponsored by the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College closed in a burst of enthusiasm with two performances by Martha Graham and a group of thirty-six dancers in the State Armory.

THE English Regency -- using that term in a general sense -- when the King in his dressing gown became so mad that he was whimpering when Wellington won the Battle of Waterloo, is a notorious but entertaining period which rounded off the eighteenth century.

MACON, Ga., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Carrying into Federal court his fight on the Roosevelt administration's farm program, Governor Talmadge of Georgia today filed a petition challenging the constitutionality of the Bankhead Cotton Control Act. A hearing was set for Sept. 5 in Columbus.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- Vernon Gomez hurled his 100th major league victory today at Shibe Park as he turned back the Athletics in the first game of a double-header. And, in the nightcap, Walter Brown started his third game of the season, went the route for the first time, and hung up his second conquest.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Many visitors here for the Labor Day holiday will witness the showman's variety jubilee, which opens on Tuesday and continues until Sunday. A comprehensive program has been prepared for every day of the jubilee, designed to provide plenty of entertainment.

WAYNESBURG, Pa., Aug. 31 (AP). -- A towering granite monument will be dedicated near here Sept. 14 to the war dead of Greene County -- the tribute of a farmer who left his whole $80,000 estate to provide the memorial.

Probably the largest vertical photograph ever made, this picture covers an area of more than 200 square miles. Pictures of the lake have been taken regularly for the United States Government each time the water rose 20 feet since the dam started to fill. The photographs are being used to make an exhaustive silt study in the program of soil erosion control to protect the life of the reservoir.

THE second annual dance festival sponsored by the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College closed in a burst of enthusiasm with two performances by Martha Graham and a group of thirty-six dancers in the State Armory.

For more than forty years I have cooperated with various agencies in helping to give the unemployed of this and other cities an opportunity to make use of their enforced leisure in growing potatoes and other vegetables on some of the many vacant pieces of city land.

A newly appointed Police Commissioner of the City of New York is placed in a very difficult position in the second chapter of this story. A woman is murdered in his own apartment in circumstances which make it probable that she has been killed by some one he is bound to protect.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The eighty-second annual Laurel Hill Day will be celebrated on the historic hill at Stockbridge on Friday afternoon. Edwin T. Rice, president of Laurel Hill Society, said to be the oldest village improvement organization in the United States, will preside.
The significance of Labor Day in American life, particularly during the present period of unemployment, was stressed yesterday in Labor Day sermons in many of the city's pulpits.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- In a plane twelve miles out at sea Miss Charlotte Keresztury, 25-year-old telephone operator of 530 Audubon Avenue, New York City, and Leonard Herrmann, 31, of 612 West 144th Street, were married today by a justice of the peace who admitted that he had no right to perform marriages in his own State.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 1. -- After a day and night of calm waters and little breeze, Duncan Sterling Jr. piloted the Class S craft, Felicity, home the victor today in the sixteenth annual Stratford Shoal race conducted by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

Within every person's heart lies implanted a "hidden garden" where lofty ideals and ambitions as well as superfluous ones have taken root, the Rev. Dr. Charles Clifford Peale, minister of the First Methodist Church, Columbus, Ohio, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Economic recovery throughout the world is being retarded by chaotic monetary conditions, the Foreign Policy Association declares in a report issued today. It favors immediate provisional stabilization limited to the dollar, the pound sterling and the franc.

Southern accents, New Englanders looking for Coney Island and hard-working barkers for sightseeing buses cluttered Times Square yesterday as hotels and railroads confirmed the impression that the annual Labor Day exodus from New York had nothing on the influx of out-of-towners.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- A pastoral letter exhorting all Catholics to "stand fast in the faith" -- the outcome of the recent Catholic Bishops' conference at Fulda -- was read today from Catholic pulpits throughout the Third Reich.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt came here today for a long-delayed Summer vacation, but in his baggage was included official business remaining from the recent session of Congress to indicate that he has only changed the scene of his work rather than escaped it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee today lashed out at the administration's patronage policy with an assertion that all persons named to Federal Jobs were "political appointees."

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- The news that American and British oil interests had received a huge concession in Ethiopia received great prominence in the Soviet press today, with headlines such as "Blow to Italian Plans," "Britain Obstructs Italy's Path" and "British Lion Lays Paw on Abyssinia."

A party of English schoolboys spent two days seeing that part of the United States comprised in Manhattan Island. It was an incident in a four weeks' transatlantic cruise from Southampton, which included visits to Quebec and Montreal, and it was typical of recent popular excursions from Europe to which the 59-cent American dollar has largely, contributed.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Father Charles E. Coughlin, speaking at a mass meeting of automobile workers at Belle Isle Park today, proposed the organization of an independent union in the industry with its slogan, "Share the Profits -- Not Share the Wealth."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Paul Derringer pitched the Reds to a 4-to-3 victory over the league-leading Cardinals today, but St. Louis retained its one-game margin over New York as the Giants fell before Philadelphia.

LAURELTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Jewelry and cash with a total value of nearly $1,500 were stolen early this morning from Highlands, the home here of George N. Lindsay, a member of the investment firm of Speyer Co. of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The critical international political situation finds little reflection in foreign exchange markets. Because of the moderate volume to which business has been reduced by the uncertain outlook, it has not been a difficult matter for the various governmental exchange funds to maintain a firm control.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 (AP). -- For the first time since the Treaty of Versailles directed military impotence for the Third Reich, the German Army will hold "real" manoeuvres beginning tomorrow.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The Pendleton Canoe Club of New York made a clean sweep of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association's Labor Day week-end trophy regatta, winning all five races on Lake Sebago today. Three of the victories were individual triumphs for Ernie Riedel, veteran international double-blade champion.

The French liner Normandie will arrive today from Havre and Southampton. Her passenger list includes Edith Mason, American opera singer; Carmel Snow, editor of Harper's Bazaar; Martha Eggerth, Hungarian actress; Mr. and Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, and Mr. and Mrs. Laurence S. Rockefeller.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A twenty-foot remodeled lifeboat will bob away from the levee here tomorrow and head down the Mississippi River on the second leg of a 45,000-mile voyage around the world.
BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- The text of the salient points of the pastoral letter drafted by the Catholic College of Bishops and read today from Catholic pulpits throughout the Reich follows:

An application for public hearings on the Long Island Railroad's recent request for a 15 to 20 per cent rise in commutation rates will be filed with the Transit Commission and Public Service Commission tomorrow by the Association of Long Island Commuters.

Prices of commodity futures moved generally lower here last week. In the sugar market failure met the attempt of refiners to advance the price 20 points. In the cash markets printcloths, silk and hides ended higher, while all grains, cocoa, lard, tin, cotton and rubber were lower for the week.
ZOARVILLE, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Where Spring rains will flood its home sites under thirty-five feet of water within a few years, this Tuscarawas County village held today its farewell homecoming.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- German Catholicism's challenge to National Socialism's authority and philosophy rang out sharp and clear today when a pastoral letter drafted by the College of Bishops in its recent conclave at Fulda was delivered from Catholic pulpits throughout Germany.

Of Broadway's ten practicing legitimate theatres, eight will seek the holiday trade today with special matinees. The two that will not are the Center, which houses "The Great Waltz," and the Adelphi, where the Gilbert and Sullivan players are entering upon their last week.

Until recently holders have not been certain whether the sale or transfer of securities of defunct corporations involved any stamp tax liability. R.M. Smythe, Inc., has received clarifying rulings on the matter from the United States Treasury and the New York State Transfer Tax Bureau.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Laurelton Hall, the home of Louis Comfort Tiffany until his death two years ago, which now houses the art foundation which he established, has been opened to the public, which will be admitted Wednesdays and Saturdays throughout the month, it was announced here today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Delegates to the national convention of Jewish War Veterans of America today adopted a resolution asking that President Roosevelt and Congress "officially condemn the Nazi persecution of Jews in Germany and that the United States sever commercial relations with the Berlin government."

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A three-run attack in the eighth, featured by Al Simmons's single with the bases full, broke a 6-to-6 deadlock and gave the White Sox a 9-to-6 triumph over the Indians before 15,000 today. The victory gave the Sox a sweep of the two-game series.
It was always a pleasure when in Boston in the Eighties to pay a visit to the old court house to have a chat with that delightful person, Mr. Burrage, secretary of the Bostonian Society.

LONGPORT, N.J., Sept. 1. -- In a curious melange of motor boat racing today on the beach thoroughfare of the New Jersey inland waterway, where the frequently turbulent rip tides from the Great Egg Harbor ocean inlet swirled under the bridges and roughened the course, losers sometimes won, winners lost and in one event the biblical prophecy came true, that the first shall be last.

I am glad that my letter concerning county officialdom has created a little interest. It may be of some help in securing the adoption of the amendment to the Constitution of New York State, which is to be voted upon this Fall, permitting the reorganization of county government in New York.

Despite the continuance of cool temperatures at the approach of Labor Day, thousands of men, women and children left the city yesterday for holiday visits. A warm afternoon sun brought a hint of pleasant weather for today, but the Weather Bureau forecast cloudy skies with little change in temperature.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 1. -- at Orchard Lawn, Stockbridge. Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay C. Hoguet entertained one hundred guests at dinner tonight at Council Grove, Stockbridge. Their daughter, Miss Anne R. Hoguet, who made her debut last night, was the guest of honor at a luncheon which Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Kelsey gave today Miss M. Thayer Gibbons and Charles Turner are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Kelsey.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1. -- Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch left Bled today for Paris, accompanied by his Chef de Cabinet Protitch on the invitation of Premier Laval. The visit is in connection with the negotiations of the Little Entente with France and Italy on the possibility of an improvement in Italo-Yugoslav relations and the Danubian pact:

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 1. -- Net profit of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation for the year ended on June 30, after deducting $554,364 for depreciation and depletion, amounted to $1,277,578, compared to a net profit of $492,377 in the previous year, according to the annual report mailed today to approximately 13,000 stockholders.

With a seven race program, featured by two stake events and a hurdle race, the Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will begin today at Aqueduct. The consistent handicap star, Only One owned by Mrs. W. Peering Howe, will try his luck in the Bay Shore Handicap despite top weight of pounds.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,258,277,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WOODBURY, N.J., Sept. 1. -- A few hours after her marriage, Mrs. Helen Mifflin, 17 years old, of 39 Oak Street, Salem, was fatally injured in an automobile accident near here today. Her husband, Donald, 19, a former Salem High School athlete with whom she was starting on a wedding trip to Delaware Water Gap, was unhurt.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- The Yankees ran into a home-run storm at Shibe Park today, but rode out the gale and snatched their fifth straight victory at the expense of the Athletics. The count was 5 to 3.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Price movements of grain futures last week were erratic, with a fair volume of speculative business.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- The Abyssinian controversy continued to dominate business here this week and induced the selling of stocks and bonds on the Boerse, although lira exchange held firmly. The selling on the Boerse, however, was ascribed to uncertainty rather than alarm, as it is believed that Germany hardly could suffer financially from any economic sanctions imposed by the League of Nations and politically it seems destined to gain in any contingency.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Leasing of a second McLean mansion to the New Deal today marked the accession of young John H. (Jock) McLean, 19, to the headship of the family.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP). -- A tropical disturbance believed to have hurricane winds near the centre moved across the Great Bahama Banks westward toward the Florida Straits tonight.

ROME, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A symbol of the determination expressed by Premier Mussolini to recruit his armies to the highest defensive power of the nation, the giant transatlantic liner Conte Biancamano loaded 3,490 troops and officers for East African service today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Ambassador Troyanovsky declined to comment today on Secretary Hull's statement of yesterday that the United States Government is resting on its position in the current propaganda controversy and that the next step is up to the Soviet Government.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- Financial circles have been following attentively the efforts of the French Government toward lowering the cost of living, which already have succeeded partially. Informed observers are convinced, however, that business recovery depends, in the first place, on the restoration of confidence and the return into circulation of hoarded capital estimated at between 30,000,000,000 and 35,000,000,000 francs.

The re-election of President Roosevelt by a large majority was predicted yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, on his return from a six-week vacation which took him to Hawaii and the Pacific Coast.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- Soviet officials were silent today concerning Secretary of State Hull's statement that future friendly relations between the United States and the Soviet Union depended on strict adherence by the Soviet to its non-interference pledge.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Activity in most lines of trade in this district continues at a high level, although in some instances a moderate slackening has been reported. Retailers generally reported last week as good, with every indication of an increase in the volume of distribution.

While yachting enthusiasts found an interesting topic for discussion yesterday in the challenge for the America's Cup made by Charles R. Fairey, English airplane manufacturer, knowledge of which became public on Saturday, there was no formal action on the matter by the New York Yacht Club.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- At the Montauk Island Club many dinners were given this evening by Summer residents of the Hamptons.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Water sports were held this morning at the Seabright Beach Club. The events were under the direction of Edward S.C. Seward. Harry Butler and Harry I. Caesar acted as judges.

Foreign exchanges declined last week. Particular weakness was evident on Saturday when the largest share of the losses on the week were registered. Traders were loath to attribute the reaction to the reported deeding of exploitation rights in Ethiopia to Standard Oil interests as the cause, but it was noticeable that with lower cables from abroad on Saturday morning, coupled with absence of demand on this side, the decline made easy progress.
CROYDON, Pa., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Fritz Gissibl, formerly district leader in the Middle West, was elected national leader of the Friends of New Germany here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The 1935 east-bound transatlantic passenger business has been the largest the American shipping industry has handled since 1929, the United States Shipping Board Bureau announced today.

SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Spanish-American jurors who heard translated testimony returned an inquest verdict tonight describing the fatal injuries of Mrs. Harold L. Ickes, but without fixing responsibility for her puzzling motor car accident.

TOKYO, Sept. 1. -- Risks which for the past three years have made the Soviet-Manchukuoan frontier a danger zone will be brought under control by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's new plan for joint border commissions, if Russia accepts it. After negotiations with the Manchukuoan Government and the Kwantung Army, the Japanese scheme has taken a form which meets the Soviet's objections, according to particulars announced by the Rengo News Agency.

The country faces a critical period because of the rising tendency of employers to cut wages and lengthen hours, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, executive director of the Regional Labor Board, declared yesterday in a Labor Day symposium over Station WEVD.

Labor Day will be observed at all the masses today in St. Patrick's Cathedral, and the last mass, which is at 12:15 P.M., a sermon on "Labor Day" will be delivered, and the national anthem will be sung.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1. -- Harold Neumann of Moline, Ill., won the Louis W. Greve trophy today at the National Air Races, making a clean sweep of the three heats. More than 65,000 were gathered at Cleveland Airport.

Students of devil-lore kept their eyes on Mississippi last week. In the "runoff" Democratic primary HUGH WHITE, a forehanded lumberman, beat PAUL JOHNSON, lawyer and consequently "judge," by some 10,000 votes. The judge sputtered and flamed against "Bilboism," that is, the complex of policies and achievements attributed to the illustrious THEODORE BILBO, eight years Governor and now Senator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- Heavy lard hogs were picked up here readily last week at prices ranging from $11 to $11.75 a hundredweight. The general run of butcher hogs was taken freely. Supplies were materially lighter and prices were governed by the action of the market for cured products.

Speaking from a table above which the German swastika flag and the black, white and red flag of Germany were hung at each side of an American flag, Dr. Gustav A. Mueller, Acting German Consul General at New York, assailed last night the refusal of two hotels and a club to permit the display of the Nazi colors.

Labor Day was born in 1882, when a delegate to a session of the Central Labor Union of New York moved that "a day should be set aside as a "festive day during which a parade "through the streets of the city would "permit a public tribute to American "industry."
MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 1. -- In his speech opening the Mexican Congress today President Lazaro Cardenas proclaimed the government's decision to give women workers equal rights with men in voting.

CALGARY, Alta., Sept. 1. -- When the Aberhart Social Credit Government takes over administration of Alberta Tuesday, its first job will be to raise $10,000,000 or $12,000,000 in the good, old-fashioned way.

MOURMELON, France, Sept. 1 (AP). -- All roads echoed to the roar of nearly 3,000 tanks and armored cars today as concentration of troops was completed for France's Autumn army manoeuvres, its first big test of warfare on wheels.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 1. -- Two residents of Stratford, Harold Bradstreet and Dennis Dennison, went out for a power boat ride in Long Island Sound about 8 A.M. today and between three and four miles off Stratford Light discovered a woman floating on her back.

In Archibald E. Stevenson's letter the ghost of the Lusk committee walks again. The American theory of government, particularly as enunciated in the Bill of Rights, entails the basic concept of progress through free discussion. The Government of the United States cannot express such distrust of its citizens as to bar from them information which bears upon their problems and which they may or may not accept as valid, after due consideration.

BOSTON, Sept. 1. -- As a result of Registrar Frank A. Goodwin's campaign to rid the roads of drivers who have been drinking liquor, 221 licenses and registrations were suspended last week, a record number, Mr. Goodwin reported today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- A movement for a citizen's peace poll throughout New York State similar to the British peace poll of January-June, 1935, in which 40 per cent of the British electorate participated will be started tomorrow at the opening of the Rochester Exposition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Buck Newsom made a single to score Powell with the deciding run today as he won a fourteen-inning pitchers' battle from Lefty Grove and the Red Sox, 2 to 1. It gave the Senators a sweep of the two-game series.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Shucks, sailed by J.H. White of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, today won both races of the seventh annual Jersey coast challenge series for the Valspar Trophy. A fleet of twenty-four International Star Class sloops representing eight Atlantic seaboard fleets sailed.

The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union yesterday came to the assistance of the Ladies' Apparel Shipping Clerks Union in its one-week-old strike by ordering the 1,700 members of the Teamsters Union, Local 102, an affiliate of the international, not to make deliveries to any of the 5,500 plants affected by the strike.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Bitter denunciation of the newly enacted tax program as subversive of American principles was voiced here tonight by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in his annual address at the Parrish Art Musem.

In a hastily convened court in the East Fifty-first Street police station, at noon yesterday, in which Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan presided, Leo Aaronson, 22 years old, an unemployed clerk, of 1,636 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, was held in $15,000 bail as a material witness in the double shooting at 174th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, late Friday afternoon in which one man has died.

HOLMDEL, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Continuing his attack on the New Jersey sales tax, Assemblyman Theron HcCampbell urged today that Governor Harold G. Hoffman be impeached and publicly accused two former legislators of accepting political "bribes" to vote for the tax.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 1. -- An unceasing stream of mourners passed by the bier of Queen Astrid in the Royal Palace again today. From 8 o'clock this morning until midnight, under police direction, groups of about 100 each were permitted to file into the palace every five minutes.

A man who was wanted in Philadelphia for the theft of 600 pieces of jewelry was killed and a detective with the number 13 on his shield was wounded yesterday in a quiet section of Brooklyn. The sounds of the pitched battle in a third-floor apartment at 904 Union Street broke upon the ears of the neighbors who had just returned from church.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Templeton's well-coordinated attack carried the open polo champions to an 18-to-11 victory over the Hurricanes on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today in another one of the test matches for the national title competition, which is to start here on Saturday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- There was much entertaining this afternoon and evening in the Summer colony, chief among the dinner parties being that given by General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at Beaulieu for their week-end guests. They gave a luncheon earlier on their yacht, the Winchester.

Though Secretary HULL'S reply to the brusque note of the Soviet Government contains no grievous words that stir up anger, it does not abate his original severity of tone. It is a cold and passionless recital of the facts. It recalls the specific pledge which the Soviet delegate gave at Washington as a condition of recognition by our Government.

There has been no change in the editorial policy nor is any contemplated in Christianity Today, national periodical of the Fundamentalist group in the Presbyterian Church, says an editorial in the current issue of that publication which appeared yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- The developments of the last twenty-four hours in Ethiopian matters have perceptibly weakened the positions of two of the parties most concerned therein-the governments of Ethiopia and Great Britain.
Thirty-six invited bridge experts will compete on Friday, Saturday and Sunday for the masters' individual championship of the American Bridge League at the Hotel Ambassador.

One has only to read the terms of the grant which an Englishman got for the African Development Company of Delaware from the Emperor of Ethiopia to see what an extraordinary and highly dubious document it is. Take the question of oil alone. The company agrees within one year to start geological explorations and drilling to discover whether there are any oil deposits in the territory mentioned.

LIBERTY CORNER, N.J., Sept. 1. -- More than 10,000 men, women and children witnessed today the second-day events here of the annual glider meet of the Associated Gliding Clubs of New Jersey. Without being aware that it was accidental, they also saw a small glider pulled out of a half spin a few feet from the ground.

The New Dealers, while declaiming against the obsolescence of Adam Smith's economic principles, apparently do not hesitate to adopt those precepts when engaging in the very old business of levying taxes. According to George Creel in Collier's, President Roosevelt intends to levy taxes in proportion to ability to pay and to benefits received.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- Financial circles here have evinced no surprise over the fact that the United States market is marking time after several weeks of almost continuous rise. Although the business situation in the United States has improved in recent months, the Stock Exchange had to a great extent discounted this.

The crews of ten commercial ships, representing seven nations, will compete in the ninth annual international lifeboat race this afternoon over a two-mile course on the Hudson River. Officials of the International Lifeboat Racing Association, which is sponsoring the event, yesterday estimated that if weather conditions were favorable a crowd of 500,000 persons would witness the contest.

FAIRMONT, W.Va., Sept. 1. -- Forty thousand mine workers of West Virginia and Pennsylvania heard John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, Senator Guffey and Senator Neely proclaim in South Side Park today what the speakers said was the dawning of a new era for the coal miners of the nations The Labor Sunday rally was the greatest labor gathering ever held in the northern district of West Virginia.

It is easy to understand the desire of those interested in the welfare of boys living on the upper West Side of Manhattan for a swimming pool on the old reservoir site in Central Park. Swimming is a popular and healthful sport. The more sanitary aquatic facilities that can be supplied to the younger generation of New Yorkers, the better.
