Synchronology is a substitute for the NRA that cannot be declared unconstitutional. It is opposed to government ownership and regimentation. It is a staggered industrial set-up which does not contemplate price-fixing, and will not interfere with the administration's social security legislation.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 1. -- The granting of a concession to the African Development Exploration Corporation by the Ethiopian Government -- officially confirmed here -- has the most far-reaching implications.

" War Memoirs of Robert Lansing," will be published on Sept. 18 by Bobbs-Merrill. Mr. Lansing wrote these memoirs upon his retirement as Secretary of State in 1920. They are said to contain many facts never before made public, and they reflect the personal views and judgments of a man who played a leading part in vital affairs at a crucial time.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Charles B. Stuart's Ariel was first to finish of thirteen Interclub class sloops in the special Sunday regatta conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club off Larchmont today.

Phillip Oehler, 9 years old, the son of a Classon Point boat builder, who admitted slaying Elizabeth Vonderhofen, 4, of 322 Newman Avenue, the Bronx, in a fit of anger Saturday afternoon, will be arraigned tomorrow in the Children's Court, the Bronx.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1. -- Determined, to agree on a new wage scale before the strike deadline, Sept. 16, nine coal operators and nine representatives of the United Mine Workers of America will resume contract negotiations in Washington next Thursday.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 1. -- Emperor Haile Selassie, citing Ethiopia's rights as a sovereign State, told The Associated Press today, "Surely the British Government cannot interfere in a concession granted to the United States."

ELBERON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Before one of the largest gatherings to witness a one-day event in New Jersey for several seasons, the Elberon Horse Show, the first to be held here in seventeen years, was staged on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil today.

Curt Davis, a tall, lean right-hander who seems quite convinced that he can trim the Giants any time he sets a mind to it, stepped out on the mound at the Polo Grounds yesterday and to the complete dissatisfaction of a crowd of 13,000 demonstrated once again that this is no idle notion.

The Christian church today should devote itself exclusively to an aggressive "crusade for Christ" instead of dabbling in politics and in social reforms, the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, said yesterday in his sermon at the St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.

WARSAW, Sept. 1. -- Having disposed of three adjourned games from the eighteenth and nineteenth rounds to complete the schedule of 760 games in the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation, the competitors from twenty nations today attended an informal reception arranged in their honor.

ALPINE, N.J., Sept. 1. -- After Moe Sprinsock, 28 years old, of 1,033 Belmont Avenue, Brooklyn, received a police summons for driving in the wrong direction on 9-W, a one-way State highway, along the Palisades here, at 1 A.M., he fell to his death from a 300-foot precipice near Lookout Point in Palisades Interstate Park.

LONG VALLEY, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Will Searles held a clamless clambake at his farm here today and urged about 900 guests to have a good time heckling the "nuders" on the other side of his barbed-wire fence.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Chicago's midget southpaw, Roy Henshaw, beat the Pirates today for the sixth time this season, 8 to 2, ending the Buccaneers' ten-game winning streak.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver of Westport, Conn., today gained the hunter championship of the fifth annual Danbury Fair Horse Show, this competition being the final event of the two-day exhibition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- How to re-employ the vast army of idle industrial workers in the face of increased replacement of men by machines was called labor's most pressing problem tonight by American Federation of Labor chieftains.

The sale by Valentine Co. of its plant located on the westerly side of Jacobus Avenue, north of the Lincoln Highway, in the Kearny meadows industrial section, to the CO-Operative G.L.F. Holding Company of Ithaca, N.Y., was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey over the week-end.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Two racers owned by Max Hirsch were fatally burned today when fire broke out on board a special train bearing them from Saratoga to New York. Commemoration was burned to death and North Star was so badly burned that he was destroyed.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 1. -- The right of Mexican working women to vote and enjoy other privileges of citizenship was proclaimed officially by President Lazaro Cardenas today in an address opening the annual four months' session of Congress.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Monday, Sept. 2 (Reuters). -- Francis M. Rickett arrived from Addis Ababa early today and in an interview confirmed that he had signed a contract with the ]Emperor of Ethiopia for oil and mineral concessions in the eastern half of Ethiopia.

Edwin Esposito, 25 years old, a collector for the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company, was shot and killed by two robbers at 2 A.M. this morning, just after he had made a collection in the Avenue X station of the Culver line, the first stop north of Coney Island.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Before a crowd of 8,000, the biggest that the Sands Point Club has seen this season, the British Hurlingham polo team came back to victory today over Westbury in another of the open championship test games, the score being 9 to 8.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Four State troopers and an under-sheriff started out to make a routine raid early this morning on the "Farm Rest," a roadhouse near here on the Monticello-Liberty Road. The raid interrupted a holdup in which six bandits were holding up ten men whom they had deprived of their trousers and ended with the killing of one gunman, the capture of four and the escape of one.

Prayers for the late Queen Astrid of Belgium, who was killed Thursday in an automobile accident in Switzerland, were offered yesterday morning by the Rev. Eric G. Ericson at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

I read with interest Archibald E. Stevenson's letter in THE TIMES today on "Our Protest to Russia." He ably points out the difference between what Ambassador Troyanovsky asserts is propaganda in the United States against the Soviet Union, and the actual acts of the Soviet Government itself against the United States.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 1. -- One hundred and sixty Europeans, many of them Italians, evacuated this capital today -- the largest number of white persons to leave in one day during the current Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- The fatal shooting of Fred Tirimacco, a young Philadelphia desperado, in Brooklyn today followed the arrest of Ralph Abbonizio, 22 years old, one of his alleged accomplices, in a South Philadelphia raid at 4:30 A.M.

Park Avenue was the centre of the Fall apartment hunting rush over the week-end. While multi-family buildings on other thoroughfares throughout the city attracted many new tenants, Park Avenue apartment buildings apparently proved most attractive to families seeking large suites.

Little more than a week ago Americans read with a shock of surprise that the followers of an evangelist, one WILLIAM ABERHART, had swept the elections in Alberta on a platform of "Social Credit," and that the new Government promises "credit dividends" of at least $25 a month to all adult citizens of that Canadian Province.

Joseph P. Ryan, head of the International Longshoremen's Association, told The Associated Press last night that "in all probability" a general strike of longshoremen would be called at New Orleans on Tuesday and that, if so, indications were it might spread to "reach proportions of the recent Pacific Coast tie-up."

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- When Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations affairs, arrives in Paris tomorrow to confer with Premier Laval about Ethiopian affairs before proceeding to Geneva, he will find that his already difficult task has been greatly complicated by the oil concessions granted by the Emperor to an Anglo-American consortium.

Price movements in the cotton markets last week were narrower than in recent weeks. At the close on Saturday, prices showed net changes of 12 points decline to 14 points advance on the New York Cotton Exchange.

While trade news is favorable and business men are examining the Fall prospect with unusual interest, there is nothing in the present situation to justify an early boom, and if anything of this kind should occur in stocks, land and the general price level, it would be unfortunate, the magazine Banking, published by the American Bankers Association, says in its current review of business conditions.
Steel operations remained unchanged last week at 52 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel's weekly review.
I am 21 years old and admittedly inexperienced in the ways of the world. However, there is one thing which stands out in my unworldly wise mind with undoubtable clearness.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- British labor's attitude toward the Italo-Ethiopian dispute and this country's policy at Geneva will be determined this week at the sixty-seventh annual Trade Union Congress at Margate. The congress begins tomorrow and will run for a week, overlapping the League Council's consideration of the Ethiopian crisis.

LAURELTON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- A 9-year-old boy, William Behrend of 49 Madison Avenue, Maplewood, was injured seriously here today when the rowboat in which he was fishing was struck by a motor boat in the Metedeconk River. The operator of the boat, after taking the boy ashore and calling medical aid, disappeared before his name could be learned.

BOSTON, Sept. 1. -- Van Lingle Mungo, the Brooklyn mound ace who has been just a deuce in Casey Stengel's deck for nearly two months, came back today to pitch the Flatbush Athletes to an 8-to-4 triumph over the Braves.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Attempting to avoid a large motor boat while taking off in a seaplane near Travers Island in Long Island Sound late this afternoon, an automobile mechanic crashed the plane into a small boat, injuring himself and the 19-year-old occupant of the boat.
BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 1. -- An outdoor vesper service was held at Pecketts Coppermine Camp in the forest at Franconia today and several hundred persons attended.

Last June Dr. ALEXIS CARREL created a mild sensation by announcing his success in keeping organs alive for twenty-odd days in a glass "body" to which blood and "air" were rhythmically pumped by a mechanical circulatory system. The inventor of this pulsing heart and lung was none other than Colonel CHARLES A. LINDBERGH.
Frank Buck will arrive in New York tomorrow from his latest film expedition in the Malay jungles.

Miss Roberta Pennington, whose father, according to friends, was a member of Congress from New Jersey more than seventy years ago, was found dead last night in her apartment where she lived alone at 207 West Eightieth Street. Miss Pennington was more than 80 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 67.9 on Aug. 28. This compares with 67.3 a fortnight before, 68.1 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran gave an old-fashioned house-warming this afternoon at Ranley House, their new home in Halsey Neck Lane. Receiving with Mr. and Mrs. Curran were members of their holiday house party, Mr. and Mrs. Brooke V. Postley and Arthur D. Benson.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 1. -- The inquiring reporter, seeking firsthand knowledge of fishing conditions, must get to the dock about 4 o'clock of an afternoon, when the boats start to return from the offshore waters. Always there is a group of the curious gathered around, debating and speculating.

Five Japanese, including a professor, two employes of the imperial government and two silk merchants, were held for a half-hour by police of Jersey City yesterday for questioning on photographs taken while they were crossing from New York to New Jersey via the Holland Tunnel.
In the name of "most of labor," Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, called yesterday for severance of diplomatic relations with Soviet Russia.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- The report that Germany is seeking a foreign loan with the aim of increasing transfers of debt service is said to be inaccurate. It seems that the report originated in what is considered the undoubted desire of the Ministry of Economics to conciliate United States capital in view of the lapse in October of the commercial treaty.

For general business and financial markets, the week before Labor Day is traditionally lifeless. Last week's inaction on the Stock Exchange was therefore true to form. Following as it did a sustained advance, it would occasion no remark if it were not that the Summer's news developments had been such that a plausible case might have been made out in advance for progressively downward movement.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 31. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.3, which compares with 84.6 the week before, 83.7 two weeks before, 83.1 three weeks before and 82.9 four weeks before.

The Sabbath was a day of toil and trouble for the invested order in the men's national tennis championship at Forest Hills yesterday. But, for all the travail, the status quo remained intact at nightfall save for the exit of Clifford Sutter of Detroit and Martin Legeay of France.

Robert V. Miller, alias Victor (The Count) Lustig, the dignified 45-year-old confidence man whose money-making schemes have kept the police of two continents busy for twenty-seven years, escaped from the Federal Detention Headquarters at 427 West Street shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, noted chemist and Jewish leader, accepted officially today the nomination for the presidency of the world Zionist organization.

PENNINGTON, Gap, Va., Sept. 1 (AP). -- The mysterious stranger who died in a hospital here six weeks ago and was buried after all efforts to identify him failed was officially identified today as Dr. J.F. Lockhart of Clarke Range, Tenn., by his wife and other members of his family.

The forcing of war upon Ethiopia is a "reversion to primitive acts which have no place in a decent, intelligent age, and all who are responsible for it should be held up to the scorn of the world until they repent in sackcloth and ashes," the Rev. Dr. Clifton Macon said yesterday in a sermon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- A stay of twenty-eight months in the death house at Sing Sing prison -- with seven reprieves already granted -- has been established by Anthony Posterino, 43-year-old convicted murderer, it was said here today by prison officials.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The Newark Bears came from behind twice today to take both ends of a double-header from the Syracuse Chiefs and sweep the series from a team that had previously beaten them fifteen times in eighteen starts.

Patrolman William F. Logan, attached to the East 126th Street station, was arrested as a hit and run driver early yesterday morning. He was charged with homicide and leaving the scene of an accident and was suspended from duty.

A brief funeral service for Herman Bernstein, former Minister to Albania, writer, editor and champion of Jewish rights, was held yesterday in the Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West Seventy-ninth Street, near Columbus Avenue.

Dr. A.H. Giannini, chairman of the executive committee of the Bank of America, said when he returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Normandie that the average Englishman bitterly opposed British intervention in the Ethiopian squabble and felt that the League of Nations should be scrapped rather than survive at the expense of world peace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Treasury circulars giving details of the new offerings read as follows:

GENEVA, Sept. 2. -- While the three powers that partitioned Ethiopia by treaty in 1906 prepared for an unscheduled meeting here tomorrow on the eve of the League Council session, observers found increasing support for the belief that the showdown in the Council will be deferred along with the Italian invasion of Ethiopia until early October.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- There was a nose and nose finish today in the twelve-meter class at the Larchmont Yacht Club's 48th Fall regatta.

With the declaration that "heaven is perhaps the only place where an independent, honest official is being appreciated," Magistrate David Hirshfield of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he would retire from the magistrates bench when his term expires on Sept. 23.

PELZER, S.C., Sept. 2. -- A woman was killed and twenty-two persons were wounded here this morning in two brief but terrific bursts of gunfire which resulted when cotton mill workers attempted to return to their tasks in picketed plants of the Pelzer Manufacturing Company.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2. -- Soviet freight car loadings on Aug. 31 reached the record figure of 77,924, which was 11.3 per cent above schedule.

So loaded down with more than 200 assorted trophies, medals and prizes of various descriptions that their baggage had swelled to forty pieces by the time they reached the pier, the members of the second of the American track and field teams to invade Europe this Summer returned to New York on the French liner Normandie yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Ester De Lee, 22, centre of the now famous "Flag Battle of Pompey Hollow," returns to her desk in the one-room rural school there tomorrow with a new battle involving the new trustee yet to be settled by the State Department of Education.

The strike of longshoremen in New Orleans, announcement of which was made by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, on Sunday night, will be called this morning for Sept. 16.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2. -- Cessation of all oil production in three major fields until the recently cut crude oil prices regain higher levels was advocated in a meeting of producers, creditors and workers at Long Beach today. A general mass meeting to take action on the shut-down was called for Wednesday night.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 2. -- Mrs. Skirvin Adams gave a luncheon yesterday in honor of Miss Virginia M. French, one of the season's debutantes. Mrs. Adams, who is chairman of the Merchant Marine Library Association annual book week drive, has appointed a debutante committee to assist her, including the Misses Betty Brooke, Lucy and Elizabeth Saunders, Virginia French, Penelope Winslow, Betty Morris and Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 2. -- Trains carrying 1,500 soldiers will leave Addis Ababa tomorrow under command of Dejesmatch Hapta Michael, veteran of the battle at Adowa in 1895, who will take command at Ualual. Their equipment apparently is not old. Possibly 2,000 other troops will leave on foot.

Manhattan Island, from the Battery to Harlem, was no place yesterday for the native. The greatest Labor Day crowd in thirty years, which had poured in over the weekend from the bogs, the hinterlands and the tall-grass country, had taken the town. There was hardly sidewalk room for home folk.
Edith Mason, lyric soprano, returned yesterday on the Normandie. At the Salzburg Festival she sang Nanette in Verdi's "Falstaff," Arturo Toscanini conducting.

Leo Y. Chertok, who described himself as a representative of American industrial organizations, laid claim last night, according to The Associated Press, to prior concessions for the exploitation of all the oil, gold, silver and mineral deposits "in all of Ethiopia."

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today that labor insists upon adoption of the 30-hour work week. He spoke at a Labor Day celebration here.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Two world records for dirt tracks fell today as Billy Winn of Kansas City finished three seconds ahead of Bill Cummings in the 100-mile national championship auto race at the New York State Fair Grounds.

NEWARK, Sept. 2. -- Cynara, bay mare trotter from the William Parkhurst Stables, driven by Bert Boylan of this city, won the Class A trot, feature event of the holiday matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.
For the first time in several years all three of New York's major league baseball teams joined the other millions of citizens taking a rest on Labor Day.
TOKYO, Sept. 2. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser of the British Treasury, is to arrive here next Friday on his way to China.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 2. (Reuters). -- While Ethiopian circles in touch with Emperor Haile Selassie are exultant over the oil concession reactions in Italy, this move is being watched with the closest attention.

Charging that the members of the Roosevelt administration had flouted their oaths to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution, violated nearly every promise of the 1932 Democratic national platform and departed from every principle and tradition of the Democratic party, Henry Breckinridge declared yesterday that they had forfeited their right to the name of Democrats and suggested "Russocrats" to describe them.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Red Sox and Senators played extra innings today before a crowd of 25,000, the Sox taking the first game, 9 -- 8, in eleven frames, and the Senators the second, 3 to 2, in thirteen.

I read with great interest a letter from Benedict Fitzpatrick. It is a pleasure to find that one of your readers not only feels for wine, as a medium for temperance and health, but also encourages the consumption of domestic wine to encourage a deserving home industry.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 2. -- Five thousand Ethiopian regular troops, accompanied by great quantities of ammunition, set out from Harrar today for a field base.
MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 2. -- "Yes sir, you could have knocked me over with a gaff. This fish ruined my bait and -- "

LITTLE ROCK, ARK., Sept. 2 (AP) -- National Commander Belgrano of the American Legion today outlined the organization's fight for immediate cash payment of adjusted certificates before the Arkansas department convention in spite of a delegate who attempted to prevent delivery of his address.

The Minister of Education in Sweden, in opening a special Summer course for foreigners at the University of Upsala, made his address in Latin. There were thirteen different nationalities represented in the student body, and no doubt the address had to be translated into several other languages before it could be heard of all.

James Stephens, Irish poet and philosopher, arrived yesterday on the Normandie to lecture in Midwestern universities and visit his old friend of old standing, W.T.H. Howe, president of the American Book Company, at the letter's place in Freelands, Ky.

Yesterday was not a good day for tennis and Frederick Perry would rather have sat in his box at Forest Hills, but when he walked off the stadium court late in the afternoon both he and his friends were gratified that he had not put in a strong demurrer against playing in the rain.
The formation of three new member firms of the New York Stock Exchange and several changes in partnerships were announced today.

Peace has been assured until February, and indefinitely thereafter, unless the neutrality resolution is repealed. Nor is that dear soul Will Rogers around, good-naturedly to kid the ears off of a Congress that could be so naive.

The demand for apartments in the city usually experienced early in September is proving especially heavy this year. The current month gives promise of being a busy one for realty brokers and agents of multi-family structures, according to lists of new tenants just given out by renting agents.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- A remarkable and at present inexplicable delay has occurred in the delivery to the Ethiopian Emperor of the British protest against Francis M. Rickett's oil concession and Britain's advice to withhold it. For some reason not altogether clear the protest apparently had not been delivered late tonight.

The statement of the Federal Shipping Board bureau that travel to Europe on American ships, during May, June and July, was the largest since 1929, is one of the straws in the wind indicating financial recovery. It does not prove that the same comparison will hold regarding the season's total tourist movement to Europe, because the greater part of such passenger traffic is conducted on foreign-owned vessels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 2. -- Russian shipments to Italy, with the exception of oil, have increased materially in the past four months. Oil has averaged from 30,000 to 40,000 tons monthly. Coal exports aggregated 29,000 tons in May, 42,000 in June, 56,000 in July and 96,000 in August.

DETROIT, Sept. 2. -- Hotsy Totsy, cigar-shaped craft owned and driven by Vic Kliesrath of South Bend, Ind., speeded away with the laurels in the Detroit Yacht Club Development Trophy race for Gold Cup boats on the Detroit River today. Stepping his craft up to 63.60 miles per hour on the last lap of the final heat, Kliesrath made a sweep of all three heats to triumph easily.

Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment and Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Ned Reigh were the stake winners at Aqueduct yesterday as a capacity crowd of 15,000 welcomed the thoroughbreds back to metropolitan New York after a month at Saratoga. Lowering skies and occasional drizzles of rain affected neither the fast track nor the slow favorites.

Mayor La Guardia will hold a public hearing at 9 A.M. today on the bill, passed by the Municipal Assembly, to submit the question of a $49,500,000 city power plant system to the voters at the November election.

The German-American Technologists Association concluded its three-day convention here yesterday in Jaeger's Turnhalle, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, with the German black-white-and-red and swastika banners hanging alongside the Stars and Stripes.

Those on the lookout for a silver lining to the cloud over the utilities in the shape of the Public Utility Act of 1935 may take comfort from today's announcement by the Federal Power Commission that in "carrying out the "spirit and evident intention of Title "II of that act" it intends to "seek the "fullest cooperation from the State "utility commissions."

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 2 (AP). -- A stiff fight over election of the executive authority for the World Zionist Organization delayed the World Zionist Congress today, causing abandonment of the forenoon session. Delegates to the congress debated unofficially the merits of an executive committee on which all parties would be represented, and one composed of a group of "strong men."

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Francis J. Gorman, vice president of the United Textile Workers of America, in an address today called on organized labor in the South, particularly textile workers, to stage next year a one-day strike and enforce Labor Day.

Two Tammany leaders, John C. Sheehy of the Fifteenth Assembly District and Marshall Ingrain of the Seventh, both of whom are facing opposition for re-election, announced yesterday the appointment of campaign committees. Mr. Sheehy is opposed by former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney and Mr. Ingrain by Edward G. Hagan.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The stock markets here remained quiet and dull today as they are likely to continue until the result of the Geneva discussions is known, although prices were fairly well held up with an absence of selling pressure.

ROME, Sept. 2. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's grant of half of Ethiopia to Francis M. Rickett as an oil and mineral concession is asserted here to be null and void on the ground that the same concession, or a part of it, had previously been granted to an Italian subject.
The traditionally heavy Labor Day automobile traffic along main arteries in the metropolitan area took its annual toll yesterday in death and scores of injuries.

Forty-two new members of the teaching staff of New York University have been appointed for the 1935-36 academic year beginning this month, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday. The list of appointments follows:

Under a project designed to help them make themselves partly self-supporting, persons on relief in this State have planted 80,000 subsistence gardens with a total crop estimated in value at $2,500,000, C.C. Carpenter, director of the division of rural activities for the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, announced yesterday.

An independent bondholders' protective committee for Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad securities, composed of James D. Colyer, Louis I. Kane and Henry Schienk, and for which Weiss, Pels Grant are counsel, has petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to make an exhaustive inquiry into the reorganization plan of the St. Paul which has been presented to the commission.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The Hitler regime can boast that the population of 148 more or less feudal estates that had been turned into peasant colonies by the State has nearly doubled. Figures just released by the Reich Statistical Bureau show the 148 estates, owned chiefly by Prussian Junkers, had 12,181 inhabitants before being taken over by the State.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The German press today contained no direct reference to the pastoral letter from the Catholic College of Bishops read from Catholic pulpits throughout Germany yesterday. It is highly improbable Catholic newspapers will venture to discuss it, let alone reproduce striking portions of the letter, which sharply criticized Nazi principles and practices.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 2. -- The fury of a tropical storm beat across the Florida Keys tonight, and as it whirled northwestward the entire southern tip of the peninsula was warned of possible hurricane winds on both coasts.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- An even 100 yachts raced in seven classes today in the closing championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association. The international star class concluded its series for the Bamberger Trophy as Jay, sailed by Stanley Ogilvy of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, placed second to win this award in addition to the Valspar Trophy.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 2. -- An appeal to Prague police last week by a German emigre, Gerhard Berthold, and his wife for protection against alleged murderers said to be pursuing them led to the arrest of the couple and two accomplices today as German secret police agents.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Secretary Ickes, his shoulders bowed in grief, arrived in Chicago today to await the body of his wife, Mrs. Anna Wilmarth Ickes.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Prospects favor increased wheat exports from Canada, says the September letter of the Royal Bank of Canada.
FULTON, Mo., Sept. 2. -- The coils of a permanent wave machine and the cream-covered fingers of a beauty parlor operator are helping cure mental cases among women in Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in announcing that a "stop" order had been issued suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed on May 27 by the National Educators Mutual Association, Inc., of Nashville, made public today an opinion bitterly critical of the promoters.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 2. -- The largest throng visiting the White Mountains since 1929 assembled here to take part in the Labor Day activities at the various resorts. The entertainment program included baseball games, golf matches and social events.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2. -- A capacity crowd of 75,000 at the National Air Races saw Harold Neumann, who already had won the Greve trophy at this meet, double in brass to take the closing-day feature, aviation's land plane classic, the Thompson trophy, carrying $6,750 first money out of a total prize money of $15,000.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., Sept. 2. -- The annual Labor Day luncheon today at the Lenox Club was attended by more than 200 members and their friends. Mrs. Edwards Spencer entertained thirty, Miss Louise Edey twenty-two and Mrs. Henry Livingston Lee eleven.

A sharp rise in gross operating revenues for the twelve months ended on July 31 is reported by Electric Power and Light Corporation, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share System, and subsidiares. Higher operating expenses and taxes, however, substantially reduced the net income. Net equity in income of subsidiaries for the three months ended on July 31 shows a loss of $486,450.

The Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union plans to enter the second week of its strike in 5,500 establishments in the garment district today with a mass picketing demonstration in which 5,000 strikers, their wives and children are scheduled to participate, Philip Gosseen, manager of the union, announced last night.

To the month of September, which only today may be said to be getting seriously on the job, since the first two days were a Sunday and a holiday, this friendly caution may be extended by way of greeting: Be yourself.

THE rain was falling patter-patter on the Polo Grounds. Colonel Bill Terry was seated at his desk in the clubhouse. Travis Jackson and Gus Mancuso occupied chairs pulled up close to the manager's desk. They were in conference. After about ten minutes, Travis and Gus moved off and there was a chance to catch Memphis Bill alone and heckle him on baseball affairs.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Indians divided a double-header with the Browns today, dropping the first, 4 to 1, when Mel Harder lapsed momentarily in the third inning, and winning the second, 7 to 2, behind Paul Andrews, who scored his eleventh victory against five defeats.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 2. -- All theatres in Englewood were ordered closed today and an indefinite ban was placed on public meetings when two children here were found to be suffering from infantile paralysis. A third child is suspected of having the disease and is being held in an isolation hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Declaring that now was the time to instill new loyalties, new hopes and new faith in young Americans, Mrs. William A. Becker, president general, today announced a nationwide "youth program" for the Daughters of the American Revolution.

By a strange paradox known only to the show business, the skies frowned yesterday afternoon on other forms of entertainment, but smiled on the theatres of Times Square. The theatres smiled back. Eight of Broadway's ten legitimate playhouses offered holiday matinees, and almost without exception they sold out.

The dignity of labor should be maintained, unfair demands of employers and employes ended, and the right to private property upheld, the Rev. Thomas J. Higgins said in a sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. He spoke at a special Labor Day Mass at 12:15 P.M.

Secret Service agents, local police and the authorities of neighboring cities cooperated yesterday in the search for the errant Robert V. Miller, alias Victor (The Count) Lustig, whose unlooked-for departure from the Federal Detention Headquarters at 427 West Street via a rope of bed sheets early Sunday afternoon balked the government's plan to bring him to trial this morning for possession of counterfeit money.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2. -- Russian officials showed no disposition today to deprive Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the last word in the incident that arose out of Communist International activities.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Probability of a steadily increasing overseas demand for Canadian newsprint is suggested in the September letter of the Royal Bank of Canada.

Miss Dorothy Proesch, director of the Braille Theatre Guild of Evanston, Ill., the only organization of its kind, returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday after an extensive tour of Europe to seek new dramatic material for presentation by her sightless actors.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Young King Leopold paid scant heed to his own injuries and refused to rest today, staying instead close to the body of his Queen, Astrid, to watch the slowly moving lines of mourners come to pay their last respects.

With a fifty-year history of 135 printings behind it, "Ramona," by Helen Hunt Jackson, is about to appear for the first time in a low-priced reprint edition. Grosset Dunlap will bring it out on Sept. 7 in a first edition of 50,000 copies. Three film versions of this book have been made and a fourth is being talked about.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 2. -- Closely guarded by Department of Justice agents, William Weaver, under indictment in the $200,000 Edward G. Bremer kidnapping, and Myrtle Eaton, wanted in the same case, were brought to St. Paul late this afternoon.

LIBERTY CORNERS, N.J., Sept. 2. -- More than 2,500 spectators attended the last events of the three-day tournament of the Associated Gliding Clubs of New Jersey on the Schley Estate here today. It was the second annual meeting of the association.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Hollyrood Czarina, trotting mare owned by Mrs. Martin E. Snyder of Plainfield and driven by Johnny Manziano, turned in an impressive performance in winning the Class B trot or pace in straight heats on the light-harness racing card at Trough Park today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2. -- After devoting more than sixty hours to slatting about in light airs, punctuated by periods of fair breezes and hours of flat calms, S.A. Gilpin's small jib-headed yawl, Delight, from Branford, Conn., today carried off the Vineyard Trophy, chief prize in the Stamford Yacht Club's annual race to Vineyard Sound lightship and back.

AVON, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Mavis, a half-bred yearling by Star of Gold-Clodagh, she by Adams Express, today was awarded the rosette as the champion of champions among the title winners in the first day of the annual Autumn show of the Genesee Valley Breeders Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Kansas City, with its air-cooled auditorium seating 20,000 persons, which will be completed by the end of the year, will be the chief bidder for the Republican National Convention next year, according to word coming today from City Manager McElroy.

Working on descriptions given by the ticket agent of the Avenue X elevated station of the B.M.T. Culver line in Brooklyn, the police are searching for the two youths who shot and killed Edwin Esposito, 27 years old, a collector for the company, at 2 A.M. yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- An invader from Panama, Golden Rock II, came like a shot through the stretch today to win by a length and a half in the $5,000 added Marquette Handicap, closing feature of Lincoln Fields' twenty-five-day meeting, and pay the golden odds of 36 to 1.

Dr. F.G. Hall and Dr. W.H. Forbes of Harvard University will arrive today on the Grace liner Santa Rita from South America, where they were members of the International High Altitude Expedition in the Chilean Andes. Others on the Santa Rita include:

The selection of William C. Hecht Jr., Republican leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, South, as manager of the campaign to re-elect Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, was announced yesterday.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, Sept. 2. -- A deliberate attempt of Arthur Greiser, President of the Senate, and other National Socialist members of the Danzig Government to snub the League of Nations commissioner for the Free City, Sean Lester, at a reception given by the latter for the officers of the visiting German cruiser Admiral Scheer was reported today by the press, obviously acting on official inspiration to emphasize the attempt.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 2. -- A Brooklyn high school student who escaped arrest once today because he "looked so young and innocent" was held here tonight for Federal authorities on a charge of possessing counterfeit money.

The RKO theatres in New York and other key cities have contracted to show the entire output of Warner Brothers pictures this year, according to a joint announcement yesterday by the two corporations. Last season, Warner films were divided evenly between the RKO and the Loew circuit.

The banking situation is not without its favorable aspects despite the plethora of funds in the banks for which little use can be found and with prospects that these conditions will be intensified rather than ameliorated for some time to come, according to the September issue of Banking, published by the American Bankers Association.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP). -- David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, declared today in a Labor Day address that "labor has a stake -- a big stake -- in the success of the TVA project."

James N. MacLean, general chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, announced yesterday that to date the local committee has been instrumental in having about $4,500,000 in delinquent taxes and water bills paid to the city by obtaining for home owners loans from the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 2. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell -- his bronzed features flecked with salt crystals and smiling happily -- clambered out of his giant Bluebird today after a trial run on the salt beds of Utah and announced he would attempt early tomorrow to better the world's land-speed record of 276.816 miles an hour he already holds.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2. -- There was a round of entertainment throughout the day for holiday guests at various estates.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 2. -- A cold, mean half a gale roared in from the northeast today to spread dangerous waves and whitecaps over the course, but the conditions held no terrors for a 16-year-old Hill School boy, John H. Thacher.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The ranks of farmers who hold quasi-official positions in the enforcement of the AAA's major crop-adjustment programs have reached a total of 111,500.

PELZER, S.C., Sept. 2. -- Representative H.C. Godfrey of Spartanburg blamed the mill management for the rioting here today. As president of the South Carolina Federation of Textile Workers, he issued a statement, saying:
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Eltinge F. Warner gave a large reception and tea today at their Dune Estate. Their guests included:
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- Rallying in the last two miles, Pat Dengis, Baltimore aircraft mechanic, won the Valley Forge to Philadelphia marathon tonight.

Mr. FARLEY has returned to us from the islands of the sea with his broad Pacific warming smile. What lover of his kind has not followed him affectionately in his travels? We have seen him crowned with flowers almost as bright as his predictions. We have watched him as he illuminated with his joyous presence the dread and somber mouth of Maui.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Our Count made a brilliant finish in the $3,000 Governor's Handicap today to set a new Detroit track record for a mile and a sixteenth and defeat Arson by half a length before a crowd of 22,000.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- As the critical hour approached for the League of Nations Council to take up the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, Great Britain's crack Mediterranean fleet steamed today into strategic positions around the entrance to the Suez Canal.
I read the letter from Genevieve W. Mason in which she speaks of relieving the bewilderment and need of animals that have fallen on hard times.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2. -- The Russian ice-breaker Sadko reported by...

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- Sterling and dollars were exceptionally strong today on the Paris Exchange market with the pound being quoted at 75.20 and the dollar at 15.16. Dutch florins and Swiss francs also advanced to 10.25 and 4.93, respectively. Italian lire weakened to 1.2390.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The Westchester Playhouse opened the last week of its sixth season tonight with Gilbert and Sullivan's "Patience," the first musical presentation ever undertaken here by Richard Skinner and Day Turtle, managers of the local Summer theatre.

A slight advance for last week in the average retail cost of most meats, poultry, seafood and vegetables was reported yesterday by the Consumer's Food Guide of the City Department of Public Markets. Only fruits showed a decline.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Industrial Commissioner Andrews of New York State told a State Fair audience today that "at no time in the history of industry have employer and employe realized their dependence upon each other as they do now."

Through the principal streets of New York's Little Italy, down Elizabeth, up Mulberry and back and forth through the intersecting streets, a devout procession of many thousands followed the effigy of the boy Saint Vito last night, ending a three-day celebration held here for the first time in honor of the patron of the town of Ciminna, Sicily.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- The thirteenth annual Up-Country Hunter and Pony Show, scheduled for Sept. 18, will be held as usual at Hawthorne Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Sharp at Berwyn. The show is unique in the resolution of its original members, that no cup should ever be awarded.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Fifty labor leaders of Philadelphia and Camden paid tribute to the late Peter I. McGuire, the "Father of Labor Day," at his grave in Arlington Cemetery here today.

The Buick Motor Car Company, a division of the General Motors Corporation, has provided more than 10,000 men with steady jobs this year, at wage rates that were the highest in the company's history, it was announced yesterday by Harlow H. Curtice, president land general manager.

MARGATE, England, Sept 2. -- The British trade unions opened their sixty-seventh annual congress at Margate today and found themselves in a quandary between their hatred of war and their hatred of fascism, which they fear that war alone can exterminate.

With fewer buyers in the wholesale markets here last week the garment industry experienced a slight seasonal lull in activity, although a fair volume of orders were received through the mail for Fall merchandise. The dress division was the most active section of the market, with immediate deliveries of popular-priced lines being called for by retailers.

Many have been called, but some are still forgotten. Among those who have not shared in the New Deal are the small up-State farmers who produce milk for cash and endeavor to raise everything else they need. State and Federal bulletineers have discovered, quite impersonally, that they are farming sub-marginal land, and advise them to move away.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Security and Exchange Commission announced today receipt from ten companies of registration statements representing proposed security issues valued at $13,373,250. The statements, whose publication does not imply approval by the SEC, are listed as follows:

Appealing to the Jews of America to renew their efforts to obtain large sums for the aid of German Jews and those of other lands, Felix M. Warburg, national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that $1,500,000 had been raised in this year's campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of the Joint Distribution Committee and the American Palestine Campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- An increase of 12,057 in employes in the executive branch of the government during July brought the total to 729,769, the Civil Service Commission reported today. The payroll for the month was $111,110,248, against $109,295,704 in June.
The homeward rush of Labor Day excursionists and Summer vacationists was in full swing last night and it is expected to continue through this morning.

SANTA FE, N.M. Sept. 2 (AP). -- Physicians reported tonight that "immediate danger" had passed in the condition of Mrs. Genevieve Forbes Herrick and Ibrahim Seyfullah, survivors of the automobile crash in which Mrs. Harold L. Ickes was killed Saturday night.

PORTLAND,.Me., Sept. 2 (AP). -The Brown Company, $74,000,000 paper manufacturing concern, announced in a statement to bondholders today it was unable to meet the interest due on its bonds and would file a petition for reorganization under the new National Bankruptcy Act.

A warning to seamen that groups with Communist leaders were attempting to obtain control of Atlantic Coast maritime unions was issued yesterday in a statement signed by the agents of four branches of the International Seamen's Union. The union is an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Secretary of State Hull moved today to spike fears in the Mid-West that Canadian wheat would be "dumped" in this country.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2. -- With 31,000 fans cheering them on, the Cardinals opened their long stand at Sportsman's Park by winning a double-header from the Pirates today, 4 to 3 and 4 to 1. They had to play sixteen exciting innings over 3 hours 29 minutes to capture the first game.

At Hyde Park the President is to spend three weeks ostensibly for a rest. But there is no doubt that many official reports will be delivered at his Summer residence, that he will hold important conferences there, that he may have to decide grave issues of foreign policy which may arise.

An issue of $6,431,000 City of New York 4 per cent serial bonds, due on July 1, 1936-63, will Be offered today by a group composed of the Chase National Bank, Chemical Bank and Trust Company and R.W. Pressprich Co., priced to yield 1 to 3.90 per cent, accrued interest to be added.

Cardinal Hayes, named by Pope Pius as his personal representative to the seventh Eucharistic Congress to be held in Cleveland, Sept. 23-26, will make the pilgrimage in a special train. With him will be a personal escort of 100 priests and fifty lay delegates, men and women, from archdiocesan organizations.

The letter of Marguerite Benson to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published Aug. 21, in which the executive director of the American Birth Control League says that "the Archbishop's statement that birth control is 'killing an unborn child,' is absurd since birth control is the prevention of conception," may now be answered.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Three persons were killed late last night in the fiery crash of a Western Air Express plane a few minutes after it took off in a fog from Union Air Terminal at Burbank on its way to Saugus to pick up passengers for Salt Lake City.

MIAMI, Fla., Tuesday, Sept. 3. -- Aground on a hurricane-lashed reef, the steamship Dixie rested in a perilous position early today off the Florida Keys as her 260 passengers and crew of 140 anxiously awaited rescue by Coast Guard vessels speeding to their aid.

Health Department officials will confer this morning on the question whether the current spread of infantile paralysis in the city is serious enough to justify keeping the schools closed beyond next Monday, the scheduled opening date.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- The list of laws passed by the recent session of Congress and approved by President Roosevelt was completed today when he signed an act permitting the Menominee Indians, in Wisconsin, to sue the government in the Court of Claims in an effort to recover lands and obtain compensation for timber that has been cut.

MANHASET, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Greentree, with Thomas Hitchcock Jr. playing polo that often equaled his best during his days as the ten-goal leader of the game in this country, moved definitely into the position of dark horse for the coming national open championship by defeating Aurora, second highest rated team of the entries, in a test match today.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- Following steadily and without alteration the line of policy laid down ten days ago by the British Cabinet in regard to the Italo-Ethiopian differences, Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, stopped in Paris today on his way to Geneva to explain to Premier Pierre Laval that the Rickett oil concession in Ethiopia will not make the slightest difference in the British Government's attitude.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Naval officials disclosed plans today for a radical shift in air policy designed to increase efficiency in that fighting arm.

NEW ORLEANS, Tuesday, Sept. 3. -- Officers of the Morgan Line, owner of the liner Dixie, which went aground on a Florida reef shortly before midnight last night with 400 aboard, released the following passenger list early today:

Vaudeville, already almost extinct in New York, moved one step nearer its grave yesterday with the announcement that four of the five Loew's theatres in Greater New York still showing vaudeville would abandon their variety bills within the next few weeks.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 2. -- Section 7a of the National Industrial Recovery Act, despite an inadequacy which he attributed largely to the absence of proper labor representation in code making and enforcement, was of great benefit to the organized labor movement, Frank Morrison, secretary of the American Federation of Labor, declared in a Labor Day address here today.

The budgetary requests for 1936 of 100 city departments to date total $24,226,980 more than the 1935 budgetary appropriations for those departments, the Citizens Budget Commission disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- An audience watching the premiere performance of Lenore Ulric's new play, "Portuguese Gal," at the Broad Street Theatre here tonight saw Frank Allworth of Bayside, L.I., playing the part of a tipsy policeman, drop realistically to the stage midway in the second act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Declaring that with the States now rests the responsibility of enacting legislation which will result in maximum benefits to workmen in unemployment insurance, Secretary Perkins in a Labor Day radio address tonight pointed to the State of New York law as illustrating the salient factors desired.

Robert C. Nelson, paroled Sing Sing convict, is under arrest, Department of Justice agents revealed yesterday, for the robbery last January of jewels valued at $185,000 from Mrs. Margaret Hawksworth Bell at Coral Gables, Miami, Fla.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Funeral arrangements for Charles Dickinson, who died today in New York, were delayed pending the arrival in New York of his sister, Dr. Frances Dickinson, from Orange City, Fla. The body probably will be returned to Chicago for burial, according to Boyd Dickinson of Geneva, a nephew and president of Albert Dickinson Company, wholesale seed concern.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, Edward K. Curtis took the position that between absolute neutrality and intervention in the Ethiopian crisis the latter would be "the wiser, sounder and even the less dangerous" policy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox said in a statement is sued today "higher living costs" and "higher taxes" would aid a Republican victory in 1936 because they were "uniformly fatal for the party which has to defend them."

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Cubs and Reds divided their double-header today, Chicago taking the opener, 3 to 1, but losing the second game, 4 to 2, as a ninth inning rally fell short with the tying run on base.

American crews scored a complete victory yesterday afternoon in the annual international lifeboat race on the Hudson River. Led by the crew from the tanker W.C. Teagle of the Standard Shipping Company fleet, the three American entries finished in one-two-three order, while crews of five rival foreign ships were strung out behind them at the end of the two-mile grind from Spuyten Duyvil to George Washington Bridge.

The production of cotton in Southern Brazil, which threatens harm to the main export industry of the Southern United States, presents another case of underestimation on the part of the American business men. The reports by Colonel James E. Edmonds in The Saturday Evening Post are excellent lessons to those experts whose vision does not extend much beyond the limits of Main Street.

STOCKHOLM, N.J., Sept. 2. -- About 200 delegates to the International Nudist Conference at Rock Ledge Camp near here held their closing session and election of officers today fully dressed and under cover. Rain and chill winds forced a temporary abandonment of principles, it was explained.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The openly critical pastoral letter from Catholic Bishops, read Sunday in all churches of the faith throughout the Third Reich, failed to cause even a ripple today in Nazi government circles. One of the Ministers closest to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler said privately the government considers the Nazi regime stands so solidly now that nothing can shake it.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Tigers took two games from the White Sox today to increase their American League lead over the idle Yankees to nine games.

Outwitted by the card players he and three companions had marked for a robbery, George Gerolimatos, 19 years old, of 521 East Fourteenth Street, was taken to the prison ward at Believue Hospital last night suffering from injuries inflicted by the intended victims.

Although it began to rain only a few minutes later, several hundred children managed to get in considerable intensive recreation yesterday morning after a new playground had been opened with ceremonies at 173d Street and Fulton Avenue, the Bronx.

The Hal Roach studios, closed for more than a month, will be reopened on Monday, reports a bulletin from the local headquarters of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. On Mr. Roach's schedule are a screen version of the operetta "The Bohemian Girl," Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy's next feature-length picture; an as yet untitled story which will star Thelma Todd and Patsy Kelly and a two-reel comedy with Charley Chase.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Tests as to changes in State constitutions will be had in the primaries in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New Mexico on Sept. 17. In Pennsylvania the changes suggested by Governor Earle, the first Democratic Governor in more than forty years, are along the lines of the revision urged by some New Dealers in the Federal Constitution.

Robert V. Miller, alias Victor (The Count) Lustig, who escaped Sunday afternoon from the Federal Detention Headquarters at 427 West Street, was still at large when the government's case against him for possession of $51,000 in counterfeit money was called before Judge T. Blake Kennedy of Wyoming in Federal court yesterday morning.

The special grand jury that was convened at the order of Governor Lehman to investigate organized crime in Manhattan is to meet today in the County Court House for the first time since the meeting at which it was organized more than a month ago.

It being a bit too early in the season to practice handling a wet football, Fordham's gridiron forces were driven indoors for their initial workout of the year yesterday. But Coach Sleepy Jim Crowley did not find this experience as bad as expected, because by the end of the afternoon he had his squad of thirty-five running through signals with proper deftness and assurance.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- More cheerfulness marked the trading today on the London Stock Exchange as political fears lessened, although business remained quiet. British funds opened lower, but recovered later as fresh support developed after a slackening of Continental selling.

Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin reserved decision yesterday on an application by members of the Marine Firemen, Oilers and Water Tenders Union of the Atlantic and Gulf to restrain its officers from putting a new constitution into effect.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- In the face of heavy pressure from the State Department, the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, definitely revealed today as owner through a subsidiary of the vast oil concession in Ethiopia, decided to cancel the lease and will so advise Emperor Haile Selassie's government.

Rumors of the retirement of veteran police officers circulated through police headquarters late last night when a teletype order went out from headquarters commanding thirty-one men, all-between 60 and 65 years of age and ranging in rank from inspector to sergeant, to report at the chief surgeon's office at l0 o'clock this morning.

The frame pulpit from which George Whitefield, English evangelist of the eighteenth century, is said to have addressed 10,000,000 persons in Great Britain and America, was used again yesterday afternoon, for the first time in 165 years, it is believed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Two subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric System have filed with the Federal Power Commission the first application under provisions of the new Federal Power Act, which constitutes Title II of the so-called "Holding Company Law" approved by the President on Aug. 26.

Harry Fishbein of 60 Second Avenue testified before Supreme Court Justice McGeehan yesterday that his was the illegible signature on the petition filed in behalf of Dr. Solomon Goldenkranz, whose leadership of the Eighth Assembly District is being contested by Charles A. Schneider.

The Friends of the New Germany concluded their third national convention last night at the Yorkville Casino by installing officers who declared they were done with compromise as a means of enlisting other German organizations in support of Nazi principles.

MIAMI, Sept. 3. -- Leaving more than 100 reported dead in its path through the Florida Keys, a tropical hurricane swept northwestward along the west coast tonight and lashed at the resort city of St. Petersburg and at Tampa, centre of the State's cigar industry.

An underwriting group headed by Hornblower Weeks will offer today to the public the unexchanged portion, about 43 per cent, of a new issue of $16,900,000 first mortgage 4 per cent bonds of the Philadelphia Suburban Water Company, due in 1965.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- Prices of hogs advanced here today, cold weather, small receipts and firmness in fresh pork combining to lift the market 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, light light-weight hogs and pigs leading. Fresh pork was quoted as somewhat higher in Eastern markets but there was no change here, the best selling at 25 cents a pound wholesale, or 5 cents less than about three weeks ago.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Ody H. Lamborn, president of Lamborn Co., Inc., to its board of directors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- Speculative interest in the grain markets was small today and while wheat advanced early in sympathy with strong cable messages from Liverpool and reports of continued drought in Argentina, the buying was not aggressive.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The scheduled two days of match play for members of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Association at the Winged Foot Golf Club turned into a round of straight medal play today, as the drizzle and generally inclement conditions made a morning and afternoon session inadvisable.

"The time to get good news is when it's raining," said JAMES STEPHENS in one of his writings -- in "The Demigods," was it not? And it should be raining whenever he enters our harbor, as it was on Monday. He is as welcome as a migrant from another planet or another plane of existence, so like one of the creatures of his imagination is he.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 3. -- After drifting in a disabled speedboat since late Labor Day afternoon without food or dry clothing, Walter Buschman of 15 Court Place, Flushing, and Clem J. Seusing of 46-71 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, were picked up by men of the Coast Guard station here at noon today.

The Dixie was built at a cost of $2,400,000 by the Kearny (N.J.) Shipbuilding Company, and was designed by A.S. Hobble, superintending engineer of the Southern Pacific Steamship Lines. She sailed on her maiden voyage to New Orleans Jan. 28, 1928, under the command of Captain Charles P. Maxson.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 3. -- William Winter, British chess champion, tonight scored a brilliant victory in the first round of the international chess masters' tournament, in progress at the Klub Szachowy. Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland also triumphed in his initial test.

Chairman Milo R. Maltbie announced yesterday the suspension by the Public Service Commission, for the statutory period of 120 days, of the increased commutation rates filed with it by the Long Island Railroad. The railroad sought an increase of 15 to 20 per cent, effective Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that only about $25,000 had been recovered from stockholders under double liability assessments in the RFC's efforts to collect upon the $90,000,000 loan which was made to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, the old Dawes bank, in June, 1932.

Two leading banks here, the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Bankers Trust Company, yesterday announced reductions of one-third on their dividend rates. In each case the reduction was the first change in the dividend of the bank since July 1, 1929.
BERLIN, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Despite a steady rain that drenched the players, twenty-two teams started in the amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Roslyn Harbor Golf Club today.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The parable of a house that must be repaired and modernized from time to time but which remains unchanged, except that it is a better and safer place in which to live, was recited by President Roosevelt tonight as he stood in a misting rain and talked to about a hundred of his Hyde Park neighbors.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, took steps yesterday to obtain the aid of the New York Representatives in Congress, in the fight to elect a Republican Assembly, by writing Bertrand H. Snell, minority leader of the House, asking the help of the Congressional delegation.

Announcement of details of the refunding operation involving the Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s by the Treasury Department and, in addition, $500,000,000 new financing, held the centre of interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- Neither Italy nor Ethiopia is to blame for the armed clash that occurred at Ualual last Dec. 5, according to the verdict rendered unanimously today by the five members of the arbitration and conciliation commission that was appointed early in June to settle the dispute.

A policy racket among West Side taxicab drivers was revealed yesterday morning following the killing of Aloysius Basini, 34 years old, of 51 West Fiftieth Street. A deposed policy collector and former garage concessionaire was accused of the slaying, and another man was held as a material witness.

TRENTON, Sept. 3. -- The borough of Hohokus, of which State Finance Commissioner Lang is Mayor, has a net debt of 8.67 per cent of its assessed valuation. The bond act passed by the Legislature this year makes the legal maximum 7 per cent.

Equipped with sun glasses for disguise and an arsenal that included a sub-machine gun, three robbers cowed two dozen persons in the Trade Bank of New York branch at 108 Avenue-B yesterday afternoon and escaped with between $7,000 and $8,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Aug. 28, issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows a decrease for the week of $81,000,000 in loans on securities and increases of $9,000,000 in other loans, $38,000,000 in investments and $49,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
The city's schools will open on schedule Monday, health officials decided yesterday after a survey had shown a substantial decline during the week-end in new infantile paralysis cases.

PELZER, S.C., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Civil authorities today pressed investigation of the sanguinary Labor Day dawn rioting at the Pelzer cotton mills here while two companies of National Guard preserved order in the strike area.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 3. -- George H. Moses, former United States Senator from New Hampshire, and Mrs. Moses, who are guests of Colonel and Mrs. William A. Barron at the Crawford House, Crawford Notch, were honor guests at a dinner at the Mount Washington given tonight by Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3. -- Like Britain, Italy and Latvia, Japan protested orally against Comitern propaganda activities through her Ambassador to Nikolai Krestinsky, Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, instead of by the note method adopted by the United States.

The financial community yesterday received the Treasury Department's announcement of the exchange offers for the called Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s quietly. Both the 1 1/2 per cent three and one-half year notes and the 2 3/4 per cent ten to twelve year bonds, it was believed, would fit into the government bond market satisfactorily although it was apparent that many anticipated a somewhat more attractive rate on the long-term maturities.

Captain Einer William Sundstrom, master of the Dixie, is a veteran of sail and steam. In his thirty-four years at sea -- thirty-one of them with the Morgan line -- he has survived numerous storms and accidents, but despite several narrow escapes, he has always clung to the belief of the old-line sailorman that a captain should go down with his ship.

RENO, Nov., Sept. 3. -- A divorce was granted hero today to Mrs. Marion T. Gibson from Langhorne Gibson of New York City. They were married on Sept. 16, 1922 and have two children. Agreement was made for the custody of the children. Mrs. Gibson charged cruelty.

Attempts at the world record for the mile in an automobile have been made in many sections of the globe. Previous to Sir Malcom Campbell's record run on the Utah salt flats the hard, white sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., had been the mecca of the world's leading drivers.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 3. -- Without fanfare and without orations, the first contingent of what appears to be a large troop movement entrained here early this morning.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3. -- A group of Berkshire women, who are "Friends of the Moment" are sponsoring a fashion show at Curtis Hotel, Lenox, on Thursday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock for the benefit of the blind. The manikins will include the Misses Aileen Kelly, Nora Bullitt, Priscilla Herron, Mary Channing, Anne Treadway, Susan M. and Margaret L. Kelsey, Barbara Longcope, and Hope and Beatrice S. Procter.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- A sensational change is about to take place in the diplomatic setting of the Ethiopian crisis. The bombshell of the revelation of Francis W. Rickett's dealings with Emperor Haile Selassie has produced an effect deeper than could be imagined if only official statements were taken into account.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- For the first time in the history of the Long Island Golf Association's father and son championship, a team won the title for the second time today when Harold M. Butler of the Hempstead Golf Club and his son, Edward R., led home a field of twenty-one teams in the twelfth annual fixture at the Rockville Country Club.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Theodore F. Talmage, son of Mrs. John Frelinghuysen Talmage of Tollemanche House, Ocean Avenue, East Hampton, was the winner of the three principal trophies for this year's Star Class yacht races at the Devon Yacht Club.

Eleven-year-old Murray Weiner of 1,834 Madison Avenue and his brother, Arthur, 7, stole out of their Harlem home early yesterday morning with $1.50 taken from their penny bank and a small handbag containing clothes. Late last night they still were missing.

TYLER HILL, Pa., Sept. 3. -- Fortified by fifteen veterans and some promising sophomores, City College's twenty-seven football candidates arrived at the Wayne Country Club today to begin a two-week practice period for their second season under the tutelage of Benny Friedman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Government expenditures during the first two months of the fiscal year 1935-36 broke all peace-time records, Treasury Department reports indicated today.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- The Sixth Army Corps manoeuvres continued today with a repetition of yesterday's display of tanks and motorized sections. They were again accompanied by radio publicity covering every aspect of the war game played by the traditional red and blue armies.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3. -- A group of explorers on the icebreaker Sadke reported tonight that they had landed on the newly discovered island in the polar regions, had planted a red banner and had claimed the land in the name of the Soviet Union.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 3 (AP). -The heavy condition of the track at the State fair grounds limited today's program of Grand Circuit racing to three events. The featured Horseman Futurity trot in which Greyhound, Hambletonian stake winner, will race, was postponed until tomorrow.

Receipts of the Argentine treasury in August increased to 92,700,000 pesos ($30,000,000 at official exchange rates) from 69,700,000 pesos ($23,000,000) in August, 1934, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. Credit operations increased less than 1,000,000 pesos.
Sir Malcolm Campbell yesterday became the first man to travel at a speed exceeding 300 miles per hour on land.

Your editorial about pulp magazines headed "Fiction by Volume," in THE TIMES, was so typical of the attitude of the partially informed and the misinformed that I cannot resist the temptation to answer it. As publisher of approximately ten Western, Detective, Flying, Spy, Mystery magazines, I am particularly amused by your characterization of this publishing world as "little known and officially unrecognized."

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3. (Reuters). -- Entirely dependent upon artificial irrigation, Egypt and Sudan naturally regard the proper protection of the upper basin of the Blue Nine as a vital factor in her existence. The British Government has always been mindful of these interests.

Last week was one of the most favorable so far this year in New York City from the standpoint of vital statistics, according to the weekly report of Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Department of Health. The birth rate was 13.3 compared to 13 for the same week last year and 12.8 for the week ending Aug. 24.
Recruiting of additional employes for WPA projects was resumed yesterday, with another 5,000 unemployed added to the work-relief rolls.

Use of advertising space by Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores increased 4.03 per cent last month, according to figures issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. A total of 1,998,975 lines was used in August, as against 1,921,530 lines in the same month a year ago.
Charles Solomon, Socialist leader and 1934 Gubernatorial candidate, said last night that Socialists would support the power plant referendum to be submitted to the voters this Fall.

EDMONTON, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press). -- It was the end of a long political trail today for William Aberhart and the opening of a new one when he was sworn in as Premier of Alberta and the leader of the first Social Credit government in the world.

One fears that international oil makes international reasoning slippery. On the point of law and American practice, Secretary HULL was asked yesterday if this Government would do anything to protect Americans in their contract rights to develop the oil resources of Ethiopia.

Democracy is safe as long as America preserves its right to the freedom of religious worship. Governor Lehman told more than 5,000 delegates to a nation-wide Negro Baptist convention last night at a pre-convention meeting in the New York Coliseum, 177th Street and the Boston Post Road, the Bronx.

Helen Hayes, actress, and her husband, Charles McArthur, producer, will sail today on the French liner Normandie with their daughter, Mary. Edgar Selwyn, producer; Fredric March, film actor, and Mrs. March; Douglas Montgomery, actor, and Erick Locke, assistant to Ernst Lubitsch, producer, are others of the stage and film world among the Normandie's passengers.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- Growing protests from German mothers against the "motherhood courses" now given to their daughters in schools and camps find renewed expression in a letter written by one despairing mother, who calls herself one of the first adherents of the Third Reich, to a periodical called The German Woman Fighter.
At tonight's concert of the Bronx Symphony Orchestra in Prospect Park, Boris Besrodny, cellist, will appear as soloist, playing Bruch's "Kol Nidre." George Allen Foster will conduct.

ROME, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Secretary of State Hull's announcement of a Standard-Vacuum Oil Company decision to withdraw from its Ethiopian concession caused great surprise tonight as it had not been understood definitely in official circles that American interests were involved.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Sept. 3. -- At a largely attended campaign meeting here tonight Liberal Leader Mackenzie King predicted that Prime Minister R.B. Bennett would declare this week for the formation of a national government. In the broadcast which Mr. Bennett will deliver on Friday, said the Opposition leader, he will declare that Canada needs a national government and that he is prepared to form one.
LONDON, Sept. 3. -- Dr. Azat Wargmeh Martin, Ethiopian ]inisl ter in London, was. the guest or

The Dixie, an oil-burning, single-screw liner, built in 1927 by the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydocks Company at Kearny, N.J., had passed around the southern tip of Florida when she stranded on one of the numerous reefs and shoals that make the Florida Straits one of the most dangerous shipping lanes in the world.

Columbia has invited a squad of forty-one football candidates to report at Baker Field on Friday to complete physical examinations and other pre-season formalities before practice starts next Monday, it was m announced yesterday by Manager William Sitterley.

Refunding of the last of the Government's war bonds, marking retirement of the wartime obligations and their completed conversion (in so far as they had not been redeemed in cash, before or at maturity) into bonds with a distinctly lower rate of interest, is a striking event in fiscal history.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Sept. 3. -- The definite abolition of the democratic and parliamentary system in Estonia, which was announced by Propaganda Minister Oidermaa before an audience of 10,000 signifies the present dictatorial regime considers firmly established the new rule of the country and has resolved gradually to introduce corporative representation as foreshadowed for several months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- How the distress calls from the liner Dixie reached radio operators up and down the coast is pictured in a summary of the work of the naval radio stations in connection with the wreck. The summary as given out today by the Navy Department is as follows:

MIAMI, Sept. 3. -- Homer De Loach, bakery route manager, returned here tonight from the storm-whipped key area and told of destruction in Veterans' Camp No. 1, as viewed from across raging Snake Creek.
