BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Suits for the recovery of $600,000 were brought today in various Superior Courts of Massachusetts against the Chase Securities Corporation on the behalf of eight closed banks, State Bank Commissioner Henry H. Pierce announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The President has approved an allotment of $5,000,000 to the Army Corps of Engineers for preliminary construction work on the controversial sea-level canal across Florida. The canal will extend by way of the St. John's River from its mouth to Palatka, then by way of the Oklawaha and Withlacoochee Rivers to the Gulf of Mexico. The Gulf terminal will be near Port Inglis.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Forty-two strong, Manhattan's varsity football squad reported to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan at La Salle Military Academy today and engaged in the initial workout of a two-week session of pre-season training here.

Mrs. Martha Nicholson Doubleday Hoyt, widow of Richard Farnsworth Hoyt, banker and sportsman and one-time partner in the firm of Hayden, Stone Co., filed a right of election in Surrogate's Court yesterday in the estate of her husband.

Leo Y. Chertok, a New York representative of several American manufacturing concerns in Russia, said yesterday that he was undecided just what he would do with the option on a fifty-year gold, platinum and oil concession in Ethiopia, which would be used as a security for a loan of not less than $1,000,000 to that country.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning signed the bill which will submit to a referendum this November the question of whether or not the city should build a $49,500,000 municipal power plant to compete directly with existing privately owned public utilities.

Louis A. Stone, like so many others who advocate the consolidation of the five counties within New York City, has been deceived by the entirely incorrect claim of supposed economy. Theoretically, it seems absurd to have "five sheriffs, five county clerks, five registers and five district attorneys in one city."
GENEVA, Sept. 3 (AP). --Senator James P. Pope of Idaho predicted today the foreign policy of the United States would be affected by the present meeting of the League of Nations Council.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- Although the remainder of the National League schedule, as it stands, would not permit the Giants and Phillies to arrange another date for their double-header which was rained out both Labor Day and today, Manager Bill Terry tonight was still hopeful of playing those two games in the event they are needed to help decide the pennant.

For the first six months of the year the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,123,544 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after six months' regular dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, to 96 cents a share on 700,000 shares of no par common stock.

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- The unanimous decision that the conciliation commission reached on the Ualual clash gave both Italy and Ethiopia a clean bill of health, awarded no damages and decided that neither nation was responsible for subsequent developments growing out of the incident.

Characterizing Mayor La Guardia as "New York's Republican No. 1," George Brokaw Compton predicted last night that the Mayor would he renominated on the Republican ticket in 1937 and would be re-elected.

Nine railroads in receivership, or one-third of the number listed on the New York Stock Exchange, failed to signify before Monday, the deadline set by the Exchange, whether they intended to seek permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 3. -- The sixth robbery this Summer of homes of the wealthy in Nassau County on the North Shore of Long Island was disclosed here today by the police. No arrests have been made.
Beneficial rains over the holidays in much of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas lowered prices slightly on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with losses of 2 to 8 points.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- Cheering, singing and waving their caps in the air, 1,000 troops of the Royal Artillery, the Signal Corps and the Engineers sailed for Malta today aboard the army transport Neuralia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The announcement by Secretary of State Cordell Hull that the Ethiopian oil lease would be canceled, read by him at an extraordinary press conference late today, follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Federal Government moved today to stamp out abuses connected with the marketing of live poultry in the New York metropolitan area left uncontrolled by the Supreme Court's invalidation of NRA codes in the Schechter case and which it believes have multiplied since that time.

Price advances on a number of hosiery and cotton piece goods lines were announced by important mills yesterday and brightened the outlook for these industries for the remainder of the year. The hosiery increases were put through to compensate for sharply higher silk quotations, while the cotton goods mills, in the face of lower levels for lint, marked up prices in an effort to put the industry closer to profitable operations.

A man identified by papers in his room, and by the story of a woman who aided him in his last moments, as Ernest Henkel, former director of personnel at the Metropolitan Opera House, died last night at the Hartford House, 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, a shelter maintained by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration for unemployed and transients.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Three scientists of the University of Rochester today began construction of a magnetic accelerator, or cyclotron, for making "artificial radium" and smashing atoms.

T.O.M. Sopwith, whose bid for the America's Cup last year with his Endeavour resulted in a wind-up of the match in unpleasantries, is out of the picture as far as seeking the prize in the immediate future is concerned. This comes about by the challenge of the Royal London Yacht Club on behalf of Charles R. Fairey.

Albert B. Hawkins, 47 years old, a certified public accountant with offices at 111 John Street, was found dead of a bullet wound at 11:30 A.M. yesterday in the bathroom of a six-room apartment in which he lived with his wife and three children at 175 Riverside Drive.

Declaring consumer cooperative purchasing in England is stronger today than ever before, Charles G. Tomlinson, advertising director of the Cooperative Wholesale Society, Manchester, said yesterday in an interview that the movement, because of its "influence in creating individual and community solidarity saved England from a serious catastrophe and social upheaval during the depression years."

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 3. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, British land speed ace, twice thundered over a measured mile to an official world's record of more than 300 miles per hour in his sixton Bluebird on the salt flats of Utah today, an official corrective announcement disclosed tonight.

The biggest tennis show ever assembled under one "top" in this country yesterday ran afoul of bad weather for the third time in less than a week's run and the distracted officials fear lest postponements exceed the record set tn the women's tournament of 1933.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press). -- A general advance in prices was registered today at the opening of the Canadian Fur Auction Sales Company, Ltd., attended by buyers from the United States, Europe and many parts of Canada.

Bertrand Coles Neidecker was questioned further here yesterday in a Federal bankruptcy inquiry into the affairs of Neidecker Co. and the Travelers Bank which he operated in Paris, London, Brussels, Amsterdam and elsewhere in Europe, and which closed while he was on the way here from Paris last July.

This evening will distinguish itself by playing host to an opening, "Moon Over Mulberry Street," which should arrive at the Lyceum Theatre at 8:40 or thereabout. It is the work of Nicholas Cosentino, and has to do with an East Side boy and a Park Avenue girl.

In spite of the insistence of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia that he had given a concession to Standard Oil interests to develop the eastern half of his country, officials of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Corporation have steadfastly denied Since last Friday that they were interested in, or had any knowledge of the deal.

A trifle late for the Labor Day week-end, because their barge did not arrive until early yesterday morning, three sightseeing calves made a hasty tour of the midtown area at 6 A.M., causing considerable damage to the seat of a policeman's trousers in Times Square and the total loss of a $30 plate-glass window near Grand Central before they were finally returned to keep their rendezvous with the slaughter-house butchers.

KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP). -'(By Telephone to Havana and Cable to. New York) -- This city es.caped the main force of the storm which swept across the Florida Keys from 10 P. M. Monday until daylight today, causing some property damage here, but no loss of life and no injuries.

MIAMI, Sept. 3. -- A hole in her hull amidships and taking water slowly, the Morgan liner Dixie, with 351 persons aboard, was still stranded late tonight on the coral out-cropping of a Florida key sixty miles south of Miami, on which she ran in the hurricane last night.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,665,100 barrels, compared with 2,688,700 in the previous week, a decline of 23,600, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 23,300 and 10,400 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of Oklahoma and California were the important changes.
BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- Statistics just issued for July for 500 cities and resorts show Germany's tourist trade has increased this Summer about 25 per cent over last year.

The High Cloud gelding Highomar, which formerly carried the J.H. Louchheim colors, and is now racing for Steve Kerrigan, was a decisive winne of the feature at Aqueduct yesterday as a rain-swept crowd of regulars watched the races.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 3. -- Estimated of the 1936 budget just presented to Congress show revenues calculated at 136,000,000 soles which, with a surplus of 2,500,000 soles from 1934, brings the total to 138,500,000, against which disbursements are balanced.
BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- "At Home Abroad," the first new revue of the season, opened this evening at the Shubert Theatre. A capacity audience was present.

The chronicle of worldly failure and dire hardship written in the career of WILLIAM WATSON, the English poet, was apparently not brought to a close by his death last month. His widow is now seeking employment in domestic service.

AVON, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Competitions for brood mares and foals marked the closing sessions of the annual Autumn Horse Show of the Genesee Valley Breeders Association, which was concluded today with championship awards in the two divisions.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- Nine-year-old John Martin, son of the Ethiopian Minister to London, stood on a table tonight at a meeting of the Nile Society, pleaded for Ethiopia's cause and cried in a boyish treble, "Give us guns and we'll fight!"
Squads of detectives moved swiftly through the rainy gloom of the streets of Manhattan last night in the fifth police round-up this year and the second in less than a month.

Methods for overcoming the staccato of the pneumatic riveter's hammer, one of the major disturbances encountered by New Yorkers whenever a large new building is erected, will be studied by the Real Estate Board of New York as a part of its contribution to the anti-noise campaign.

Foreign exchanges cheapened further yesterday in terms of the dollar, the French franc dropping to 6.59 1/2 cents, the lowest price since June 15 and within 1/4 point of the figure at which gold can be shipped here from Paris. The Belgian belga fell to 16.80 cents, a new bottom mark since the devaluation of that currency last March and 4 points under the theoretical gold-import point.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Treasury has floated in a single day a $500,000,000 issue of 1 1/2 per cent three and one-half year notes, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 3. -- I am happy I am the first man to drive a land vehicle over 300 miles an hour, and am happy, naturally, that I had a blown tire at a speed of more than 250 miles an hour, and lived to tell the story.

Except for moderate activity in the commercial paper market, there was little else of interest in the money market. Stock Exchange call loans and maturity money were in light demand at prevailing quotations.

In submitting a budget which was nearly $3,000,000 less than anticipated expenditures in 1936, the difference to be made up out of relief funds, Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday that the city should begin to assume the entire responsibility for the upkeep of its park system.

Eight religious and charitable institutions receive bequests totaling more than $100,000 in the will of Michel C. Bouvier, senior holder of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. The will disposes of bequests totaling more than $1,500,000.
MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 3. -- "What are the odds against an angler catching a broadbill swordfish on rod and reel?"

GENEVA, Wednesday, Sept. 4. -- The news that George S. Walden and H. Dundas, respectively chairman of the board and vice president of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, had informed the State Department in Washington that their corporation owned the concession granted to the African Exploration and Development Company in Ethiopia, came as a shock to Geneva, where, despite all assertions to the contrary, it was believed that British money was involved.
Deaths in the heavy traffic of the holiday week-end exceeded 300 in the nation, an Associated Press compilation disclosed last night.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3. -- This resort is making extensive preparations for the appearance of civic and political leaders before the Democratic National Committee in Washington in January to present the city's bid for the Democratic national convention next year.
Nine travel-stained boys, pupils of the Horace Mann School, and their tour director, John Dallavo, returned to New York City yesterday after a 13,000-mile automobile tour of the United States.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The nineteenth world Zionist Congress ended early today after the election of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, veteran leader of the movement, as president of the world Zionist organization. Only six votes were cast against Dr. Weizmann. Former President Nahum Sokoloff was unanimously named honorary president.

AMARILLO, Texas, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Gray-haired "rebels" of the South shook their heads in a none-too-sure air today in discussing a proposed joint meeting with their old "Yankee" foes -- the Grand Army of the Republic.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 3. -- For the second time within eighteen months the Belgian people were united today in deep mourning at a funeral of one of their royal house. Every social, every political and every religious difference was wiped away.
Your editorial "What Next for Utilities?" is written in a spirit of forbearance of which I am incapable.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- Storm Troopers who packed the Sport-Palast, where Julius Streicher recently sounded his anti-Semitic war cry, received orders from their commanders tonight to go out among the masses as "the prophets of Adolf Hitler" and prepare the nation for the coming racial laws, which "shall free the German people from the Jews."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Nose-heaviness and the possibility that ice had developed in the carburetor of their plane were assigned officially today as the reasons for the fatal crash that took Will Rogers and Wiley Post to their deaths on Aug. 16 in a shallow lagoon near Point Barrow, Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today amendments to its rules covering the use of Form 10 by corporations and Form 11 by unincorporated issuers for the registration of securities on Stock Exchanges, chiefly to adjust them to steps taken to provide other forms for certain classes of issues.

Four boats and their skippers and crews, composing the Bermudian team which will face a Long Island Sound Interclub Class quartet in an international team match beginning Sunday, arrived yesterday aboard the Furness Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda.

Resolutions authorizing two bond issues of $3,870,000 and $1,200,000, completing the program of refinancing the floating debt of Jersey City, were adopted yesterday on first reading by the City Commission. The $3,870,000 issue will be one of general refunding bonds.

Alex L. Hillman, president of Godwin and Arcadia House, firms which for several years have published light novels for circulating libraries, and Sam L. Curl, sales manager for these two companies, announce the formation of a new publishing company to be known as Hillman-Curl, Inc.

Richard H. Brown, former $100,000 a year president of the Manhattan Electrical Supply Company, who had been convicted and sentenced to five years in prison on mail fraud charges and also fined $18,000, was found dead by his wife yesterday morning in his apartment at 7 East Eighty-fifth Street.

In an effort to bring about a settlement of the strike of 12,000 shipping clerks, push boys and allied employes in the garment district, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, with a membership of more than 100,000 in this city, intervened in the situation yesterday.

Now that the cole slaw question has been threshed out, leaving us a more enlightened and grateful people, will somebody please open a spinach versus Swiss chard controversy and thereby contribute to the happiness of the children of the nation?

A.M. Andrews, former chairman of the board of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, has sent a letter to the company's stockholders asking for proxies to be voted in opposition to the present management at the annual meeting of the company on next Wednesday.

A sharp break in crude rubber futures and spot prices and unusual strength in wool top futures yesterday featured an otherwise dull trading session in the commodity markets here. In the cash markets all of the grains, mess pork, tin, silk, rubber and sugar were lower, with wool tops and coffee higher.

The first of the monthly index numbers, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows decline in the wholesale commodity price index during August of three-eighths of 1 per cent, and is 3 3/8 per cent below the average of March 1. Compared with Sept. 1, 1934, it shows an advance of slightly less than 1 per cent.

With the armies of Europe and Asia bidding against American rug producers in all world carpet wool markets, the rug industry in this country is faced with the necessity of advancing prices in the coming few months if it hopes to fill the domestic demand for floor coverings, M. Karagheusian, president of A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., rug manufacturers and importers, said here yesterday.

TORONTO, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Harold Wilson of Ingersoll, Ont., at the wheel of his Miss Canada IV, tonight defeated eleven of the continent's fastest midget speed boats on choppy Lake Ontario to win the first heat of the world championship race for 225 cubic inch hydroplanes.

A great deal is being written about cotton lately, and part of it is true. But the propaganda for a lower price is almost as fierce as is the farmer's demand to be protected, and many false arguments are used to attempt to instill the fear that the South is losing its age-old monopoly on the world's market.

GEORGE KITCHIN'S horrifying autobiographical narrative, "Prisoner of the Ogpu" (Longmans, Green, $3), is addressed to tender consciences everywhere. Unfortunately, people who still possess tender consciences are in one devil of a fix, and the chances are that Mr. Kitchin will only add to their general state of paralysis in the face of the facts of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The estimated net proceeds of security issues, exclusive of those for reorganizations, filed under the Securities Act of 1933, with the Securities and Exchange Commission from Jan. 1 to July 31 was $994,000,000, of which $768,500,000 was to be used for refunding and $225,500,000 for other purposes, figures compiled by the commission show.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 3. -The start of the third race at Narragansett Park today was delayed twenty-two minutes, first by the discovery that Admiral Cary T. Grayson's Onward, original choice of the bettors, had received a badly twisted knee in a warmup run just before being saddled.

Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor overcame their reluctance about appropriating city funds for the purchase of school sites yesterday and opened the way for launching within sixty days the largest school-construction enterprise here since the depression began.
The Board of Estimate voted $3,150,000 yesterday as the city's share of an $11,059,000 relief appropriation for September. The balance of the cost will be borne by the State and Federal governments.

TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Sporadic rioting between workmen of city and county political factions left four men wounded and dozens with bruised heads as citizens nominated a Mayor and Election Board members today.

Resumption of trading in the security and commodity markets yesterday after the holiday found traders in a cautious mood; steady to firm openings of prices gave way to irregularity, and the closings were lower. The share market was steady at the last at lower levels, the setbacks ranging from small fractions to 1 7/8 points; trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 904,000 shares, compared with 830,000 on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Senate munitions investigators asked the Justice and State Departments today to help find Anthony Fokker, world-famed airplane designer.

Three Boy Scouts, who faced the perils of African jungles without a shiver seven years ago, were reduced to red-faced embarrassment yesterday when they had to don short khaki pants and pose for newspaper photographers.

A prize cake created by Theodosia Hession, 14-year-old Girl Scout, of 377 East Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was formally added yesterday to the menu of all Schrafft's Restaurants in New York. The first slice of the cake, a devil's food, was cut by Theodosia at 11:30 A.M. in the Schrafft's restaurant at 220 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Robert C. Nelson of 2,531 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, known to the police as Chicago Bob, was examined for several hours yesterday by J. Howard Cater, Assistant United States Attorney, in connection with the return of the $185,000 in jewels stolen from Mrs. Margaret Hawksworth Bell at Coral Gables in Miami.

Dr. Paul Reese, 64 years old, a dentist, and his wife, Catherine, 54, were found dead at 1:45 P.M. yesterday on the floor in the kitchen of their home at 879 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn. The police said they had committed suicide and ascribed the act to financial difficulties.

The Dixie may be the first commercial ship to be affected by the new maritime liability law which was sponsored in the recent session of Congress by Representative William I. Sirovich of New York and signed last Tuesday by President Roosevelt.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- A cheerful report on the condition of the country was given to President Roosevelt today by Postmaster General Farley in their first visit since Mr. Farley, who is also chairman of the Democratic National Committee, began more than six weeks ago a tour of the United States that ended with a cruise to Hawaii.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Sep Palin drove his undefeated 3-year-old trotter Greyhound to his eighth straight victory of the season today. A twenty-four-hour rain had slowed the State Fair Ground track a trifle.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4. -- Henceforth there will be no discrimination in the Soviet public schools against children of former aristocrats, officers, business men, Kulaks and the like. A decree published today over the signature of Joseph Stalin, General Secretary of the Communist party; and Vyacheslaff Molotoff, President of the Council of Commissars, expressly forbids inquiry into a pupil's antecedents beyond his age and name and the name and address of his parents.

When American book collectors discuss the illustrators of books they almost invariably include comment on the work of T.M. Cleland, although previous to this month Mr. Cleland never had illustrated a book completely. He made all the illustrations, however, for the two-volume edition of "Tristram Shandy," which the Limited Editions Club is issuing to its members this month, designed the entire edition, and made the special marbled paper for the binding with his own hands.
The special grand jury investigating organized crime returned its first indictment yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Prices of leading bank stocks fell heavily yesterday morning in the over-the-counter market following the announcement on Tuesday of reductions in the dividends of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Bankers Trust. Company.

MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 4. -- A subpoena requiring his appearance before the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry was served this evening on Anthony Fokker, airplane designer and manufacturer, at the Montauk Yacht Club here.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 4 (AP). -- A college went on the auction block here today. A professional auctioneer knocked down the movable property of Cotner College as trustees sought to meet pressing obligations which caused the institution to close two years ago.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (AP). -- A group of Russian explorers climbed upon, flew over and photographed today the Arctic island that they reported discovering yesterday. They radioed back to civilization that they found it covered with snow and ice, with thousand-foot elevations, fresh water springs and animal life.

NEWPORT, R.L. Sept. 4. -- A decidedly different scheme of decoration, all in indirect lighting effects, is being planned for the harvest ball to be given on Sept. 20 at Newport Beach for the benefit of the Rocky Farm Camp for Crippled Children.
MYAMY, Sept. 4. -- Flying down the Florida East Coast Keys below Miami in a chartered Pan-American plane I witnessed today three major disasters in one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Allocations from PWA and Work Relief funds totaling $2,055,618 for forty-six non-Federal construction projects in twenty-two States were approved today by President Roosevelt. The grants represent 45 per cent of the estimated costs.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Secretary of State Hull's action in persuading the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company to surrender its Ethiopian concession has aroused more gratitude on the part of the British Government toward Washington than has been felt in a long time.

KATTIWICZ, Poland, Sept. 4. -- Married to his father's divorced wife and stepfather of his father's son, Count Bolko Hochberg, son of Upper Silesia's wealthiest man, Prince Hans-Henri von Pless, tried to obtain alimony through the courts today from the Prince on behalf of the former Princess.

The driving rain added to rather than detracted from the excitement at Aqueduct yesterday as the races were run to the accompaniment of a spill, disqualification and a suspension. Jockey Eddie Arcaro also scored the first triple of the meeting.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Sept. 4 (AP). -- The elements whipped Ohio streams into another frenzy of destruction today, adding thousands of dollars damage to the millions in losses caused by last month's disastrous floods.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Governor Lehman declared tonight that the Democratic administration of State affairs had "made good on promises."

A contest over the will of John N. Willys, automobile manufacturer, was foreseen yesterday when his widow, Mrs. Florence E. Willys of 4,643 Waldo Avenue, the Bronx; Arthur W. Pickett of 2 Park Lane, Mount Vernon, and Marion Paul Gooding of 25 Central Park West, executors under the will, applied to Surrogate James A. Foley to be appointed temporary administrators of the estate in this State.
MIAMI, Sept. 4. -- The horror visited on the Florida keys by the hurricane was made vivid in stories told today by survivors who were brought here.

ABOARD S.S. ATENAS (of the Dixie Rescue Fleet), Sept. 4 (AP). -- Passengers taken aboard the S.S. Atenas from the stranded Morgan liner Dixie said tonight that at no time was there any sign of panic among them during the time since Monday night that they had worn life preservers awaiting rescue.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Percy Pike's Little Nymph, the lightweight of the field, raced to a four-length victory over Hal Price Headley's Tinkling Brook in the Beavertail Claiming Stakes, at six furlongs for 2-year-olds, today at Narragansett Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Silver purchased by the Treasury Department since the adoption of the new silver policy now exceeds 500,000,000 ounces, official reports disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Daily average crude petroleum runs to stills in July were slightly higher than in June, according to a report prepared by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior, for Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator.

Mayor LA GUARDIA'S term is not half over, yet the prophets of renomination are already chanting from the tripod. This prematurity of compliment is hallowed by old custom. It expresses nothing but the good-will or hope of the seer, unless there breathes through it a longing for the next vacancy in some fat office.

The strike of shipping clerks, push boys and allied employes in the garment district, which began last week, threatened yesterday to develop to proportions that may involve more than 100,000 garment workers of all classifications acting in sympathy with the strikers.
The prospects of a renewed influx of gold to the United Sates were widened yesterday as foreign currencies continued to cheapen in terms of the dollar.

PINE BROOK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- A four-hour hunt in the rain by a posse of twenty armed farmers for a pack of fifteen wild dogs that have been killing barnyard stock and game in this community for months was fruitless today. The hunt will be resumed tomorrow.

Four tiny toads that look like "an ornament for a signet ring" were placed on display yesterday in the reptile house of the Bronx Zoo. They are the first shown among. more than a dozen new South American arrivals representing "the Birds of Paradise of the reptile world," according to Raymond Ditmars, curator of reptiles.

Charges of discrimination by foreign flag lines operating between the West Indies, the United Kingdom and Europe were made by the American Caribbean Line, an American flag operator, at a hearing yesterday before A.L. Lansdale, Shipping Board examiner, at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- Approximately $400,000,000 was spent in New England by about 4,000,000 Summer visitors, an increase of between 20 and 25 per cent over the tourist trade of last year. About $500,000,000 was spent by tourists in the all-time high-year of 1929.

After four hours marked by listless trading, the share market came to life yesterday in the final hour of business and advanced briskly to close generally higher on the day. Of total dealings on the Stock Exchange of approximately 1,000,000 shares, nearly 50 per cent was done in the last hour.
The line-up at police headquarters stretched out for two hours yesterday as 144 of the 289 prisoners arrested in Tuesday night's round-up were paraded across the gymnasium platform.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 4. -- Senator Huey P. Long's legal fees as representative of State boards under dictatorial laws he enacted at special sessions of the Legislature during the Winter months are believed now to nave netted him in the neighborhood of 100,000.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Work at Consumers Research, Inc., came practically to a standstill here today when forty-one employes of the concern, men and women, went on strike. Fifteen non-union members joined with the strikers and four other employes were persuaded by pickets, who sat in automobiles during the rain, to stay away from the plant, a two-story building of brick and stone situated in the outskirts of Washington.

Earnings of the Eastern railroads held up best in the first seven months of this year, according to a report based on returns by 145 Class I railroads issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. Lines in this region showed a decrease of 4.6 per cent in net operating income, while the Southern and Western companies reported declines of 21.4 and 41.7 per cent, respectively, compared with a year earlier.

Once again rain intervened at Forest Hills yesterday to send the few hundred indefatigables in the stadium scurrying for cover and set back the final matches of the combined national tennis championships until Monday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday the cancellation of the liquor license of the Crystal Club, Inc., 450 East Fifty-second Street. The announcement said that the club, which was opened last Spring in the basement of an apartment on the East River opposite River House had "ceased to be conducted as a bona fide club."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 4. -- The "G Man" of psychology, the English scientist, Professor C. Spearman of the University of London, tonight told the American Psychological Association about "new tests of ability."

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge is back with Miss Gertrude Watson at Onota Farm, Pittsfield, from Greensboro, Vt. Miss Watson had a dinner party in her honor tonight. Among other guests were Mrs. Dexter P. Rumsey of Buffalo, Mr. and Mrs. Willem Willeke, Miss Kathleen Parlow and Ulysses Buhler.

The United States liner Manhattan, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has among her passengers Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth and her daughter Paulina, who have been in Europe attending the wedding of Mrs. Longworth's nephew, Count Rene de Chambrun, to Miss Jose Laval, daughter of the Premier of France.

Samuel Goldwyn's first production for the new season, "The Dark Angel," starring Fredric March, Merle Oberon and Herbert Marshall, will have its premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Rivoli. Adapted from the Guy Bolton play by Lillian Hellman, author of "The Children's Hour," and Mordaunt Shairp, author of "The Green Bay Tree," the film was directed by Sidney Franklin.

Behind the astounding record of 301.1292 miles an hour made over a measured mile by Sir MALCOLM CAMPBELL lie a long experience in driving racing cars, superb courage and skill and twelve years of determination and scientific study. No mere accident is his performance.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway is expected to ask the Federal court in Chicago for permission to delay, at least until Feb. 28, the filing of a plan of reorganization for the company as a result of action taken at a meeting of the directors here yesterday.

Asserting that the oil concession granted to his company by Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia "had come to us in the normal routine of our business," George S. Walden, chairman of the Standard Vacuum Oil Company, yesterday said that the officials of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., "were not advised until after the press dispatches from abroad were published that the concession had been obtained."

Loans on securities to member firms increased $3,106,720 in August, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The total at the end of the month was $772,031,468, compared with $768,934,748 at the close of July.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The Catholic question became vital again today after a pause broken by last Sunday's pastoral letter -- which exhorted Catholics to "stand in the faith" -- with a police order in Hamburg forbidding the wearing of uniforms by Catholic Youth groups.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- A hearing on the proceedings in bankruptcy leading to the reorganization of the McLellan Stores Company will be held on Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its study of protective groups and reorganizations on which it will report to Congress in January.
When moderate covering developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, prices improved readily 7 to 16 points, as trade demand for several days had exceeded the quantity of hedges coming on the market.

A vagrant who had been panhandling along rainy First Avenue collapsed from malnutrition shortly after 8 o'clock last night on Forty-ninth Street opposite the lower end of the fashionable Beekman Place area.

HARLAN, Ky., Sept. 4 (AP). -- The death he had predicted, assassination in the midst of Kentucky political fury, struck down Elmon C. Middleton, Harlan County Attorney, today in a dynamite blast as he started his automobile.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today continued to reflect the disposition to mark time pending the news from Geneva. Business remained quiet generally, although some good features developed.

Three young men were arrested on disorderly conduct charges yesterday morning during a demonstration by the American League Against War and Fascism to protest Italy's war preparations against Ethiopia in front of the Italian Consulate at 134 East Seventieth Street, near Lexington Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Mayor George T. Jones of Joliet announced today that a check for $5,153.97 was received by him today from the New York law firm of O'Connor Farber, thus ending the controversy between the city and the lawyers, who formerly were partners of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- An air of relief prevailed at the State Department today over the satisfactory solution of the troublesome Ethiopian oil concession, which Secretary Hull announced last night. Officials felt that the voluntary renunciation of the concession by the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, owner of the African Exploration and Development Corporation, to which Emperor Haile Selassie granted exploitation rights to half of his kingdom, was the best possible outcome for an embarrassing situation.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Sixty students from Bellmawr were excluded from their classes at Haddon Heights High School today because of the failure of the Bellmawr Board of Education to pay $5,572 tuitibn fees owed to the Haddon Heights School Board for last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The Treasury's new $500,000,000 issue of 1 1/2 per cent 3 1/2 year notes which was sold yesterday was oversubscribed about two and a half times, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher here yesterday, with sugar futures making impressive gains. In the cash markets all of the grains, cotton and rubber were higher, while tin and silk lost ground.

ALBANY, Sept. 4. -- Lester W. Herzog, State Works Progress Administrator, is in Washington tonight preparing to submit to Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Administrator, a Statewide PWA program calling for $352,715,555 for fifty-one projects.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission is a tiny body, as Government agencies go in these days. Its budget request for next year -- $380,000 -- is only a midget among the great bats that are roosting in Budget Director MCGAHEN'S anteroom. Yet there is no more important function in all the City Government than that which this board is discharging under the Fusion administration.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Continued cool weather and reports that the movement of fresh pork into consumer channels was the best in several weeks caused an advance of 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight in the prices of hogs here today. The top of $12.10 showed a gain of 20 cents and came within 10 cents of the high level established about three weeks ago.

The joint legislative committee to investigate mortgage bondholders', stockholders' and creditors' committees announced after an executive meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore that its investigation also would include trust companies holding defaulted mortgages for trust accounts, investment and brokerage houses trading in mortgage issues, and the mortgage companies.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Litigation growing out of the preparations made to move the New York Stock Exchange to Newark in September, 1933, was ended today with a compromise settlement between the city of Newark and Herbert J. Hannoch, receiver for the City Center Corporation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- A marked revival in the demand for flour, in both the Northwest and the Southwest, and strength in foreign markets carried wheat prices sharply higher today. No material pressure developed on the Board of Trade from hedgers and the finish there was around the top, with net gains of 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel for futures.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Rain reduced the number of players today in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's medal play tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club for the second day and sent scores soaring even above the mark they reached yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Tension was heightened today by a report that Italy had set Sept. 25 for the launching of an attack against the outcome.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4. -- I was assigned to cover the evacuation of the veterans' work camps on the Florida Keys. With a joy soon turned to sorrow, I boarded the special train at Homestead, seventy miles from the camps.

Robert C. Nelson, a paroled convict," who is known as Chicago Bob and the "walking pawnshop," admitted yesterday that he had played an "innocent" part in the recovery of $185,000 worth of jewelry stolen last January from Mrs. Margaret Hawkesworth Bell in Miami, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- President Roosevelt's action in bringing administrative expenditures of twenty emergency agencies under the supervision of the Budget Bureau was taken over the protests of chiefs of many of these agencies, it was learned tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The ballroom "wall flower," that sad-faced soul who has no one to dance with, got a chance today -- a three-person dance.

Thirty-fourth Street's Manhattan Opera House will probably rejoin the legitimate theatre colony this season. Under a lease now ready to be signed, Max Reinhardt's production of "The Road of Promise" is expected to open there on Dec. 20.
AMARILLO, Texas, Sept. 4. -- Dixie's Stars and Bars will fly again at Gettysburg if North and South meet for friendship's sake in 1938 where they fought in '63.

One of four gunmen who obtained $1,700 by holding up seven employes of the Park Laundry at 522 East Eightieth Street was captured yesterday morning after a chase up First Avenue that ended with the crash of their car and the firing of one shot as they fled.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4. -- The John Jacob Astors and three guests narrowly escaped injury today when two boiler tubes blew out on their yacht while they were cruising in Narragansett Bay.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The Boerse continued to fall today after showing signs of slight strength at the opening. Heavy industrial shares were mixed in trend, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/2 point. Potash issues again were inactive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- All government agencies which might be able to assist in the emergency presented by the Florida storms were held in readiness for action today.

A twelve-day engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning on Oct. 9 will inaugurate the third American season of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo. The program will include seventeen productions. After the New York engagement, the company will leave on a six-months' tour of the United States, Canada and Cuba.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4. -- A report that refinancing to clarify and strengthen the position of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company by eliminating its bank loans was discussed today in New York by officials of the company and representatives of Hayden, Stone Co. was confirmed here tonight by E.B. Greene, president of the iron company.

Real estate trading covered a wide area in Manhattan yesterday when sales and leases of properties from the downtown insurance district to Washington Heights were reported. In this borough deals met the demand for both business and residential improvements.

The American Water Works and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on July 31, subject to audit, a net income of $2,801,778 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion and preferred dividends of subsidiary companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The suicide of George C. Hanson, United States Consul General at Saloniki, was announced today by the State Department. Mr. Hanson shot himself Monday on board the steamship President Polk while traveling to this country for medical treatment for a nervous collapse he had suffered recently. He was in the care of the ship's doctor. The President Polk is due to reach New York Monday.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 4. -- Prolonged matches marked the second round tonight of the international masters' tournament in progress at the Klub Szachowy. Three of the five games were adjourned and two were drawn. William Winter of London, British champion, was the first to finish with Kolski, one of Poland's five representatives.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 4. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, the only man ever to travel on land at the rate of five miles a minute, expressed the hope today that his tests would result in the construction of safer motor cars.

The report of the Gold Dust Corporation and subsidiary companies for the year ended on June 30 shows a consolidated net profit of $2,097,477 after providing for Federal and Canadian taxes, depreciation and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock outstanding, to 97 cents a share on the voting trust certificates for common stock in the hands of the public on June 30.

About 130,000 workers, or little more than 50 per cent of the total to receive employment in this city under the Federal work relief program, are now employed on WPA jobs, it was revealed yesterday at the office of General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York.

ROME, Sept. 4. -- The Italian position at Geneva has been weakened in the last twenty-four hours by two unexpected developments. The first was the verdict of the arbitration commission on the Ualual incident clearing both sides, which was far from coming up to Italian expectations.

Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina, who demonstrated in 1932 that a man did not have to be a prohibitionist to hold elective office in the South, passed through New York yesterday on the second leg of a 9,000-mile tour of the United States during which his automobile trailer will be his hotel.

By an Executive order issued yesterday the President brought the last of the great spending agencies under the control of the Bureau of the Budget. This is the culmination of a movement for administrative reform which has been going on for some weeks. It came to be seen that these independent organizations set up for special purposes were getting out of control.
All auxiliary transport equipment of Pan American Airways was assembled at the Miami base yesterday on orders from J.T. Trippe, president of the system.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Donning the gloves for the first time since he knocked out King Levinsky in Chicago last month, Joe Louis buckled down to serious training today in preparation for his battle with Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 24.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Continued violation by trunk line railroads serving New York Harbor of Interstate Commerce Commissions directions against the storage of freight at non-compensatory rates was charged in briefs filed with the commission today by the Boston Port Authority and the Warehousemen's Protective Committee.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Augie Galan, outfielder, hammered out two more home runs, one with the bases full, to support Larry French's steady pitching today, and the Cubs downed the Phillies, 8 to 2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4. -- The Bureau of Appointments of Yale University announced today the award of thirty-one restricted scholarships, totaling $13,057, to students from Connecticut high schools who expect to enter Yale this Fall.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 4 (By Cable). -- Heavy rains continue to fall over the Ethiopian plateau. Their effect upon the terrain surrounding Addis Ababa became quite apparent to this correspondent in a twenty-mile journey through the morass on mule-back.

MIAMI, Sept. 4. -- Inquiries today brought various explanations of the lateness of the special train sent from here Monday in an effort to evacuate veterans and others on the keys before the hurricane arrived. The train had taken aboard not more than ten of the hundreds who awaited it when it was wrecked.

It seems unbelievable that the appalling fatalities of automobile traffic cannot be halted. The announcement in THE TIMES of Aug. 27 revealing the casualties during July is horrifying. There is a way to stop this tragedy, but the means would reduce the number of owners and drivers of automobiles probably 20 per cent or more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The hulk of controversial legislation was acted upon in the last session of Congress, and the coming session preceding the national conventions will be devoted to the supply bills and minor legislation. This is the belief of Speaker Byrns, who left today for his home in Nashville, where he will rest until he joins the Congressional party going to the Philippines on Oct. 15.

Bill Baxter is indignant. The affable secretary of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, whose devotion to the truth is not diminished by his loyalty to the Jersey fishing grounds, feels that an impression has gone forth that the offshore fishing season is over, and takes his pen in hand to deny the base canard.

THE racing secretary and handicapper for steeplechase events in these parts is -- and has been for some years -- Frank J. Bryan, who is a tall, spare, elderly gentleman with a short white mustache, big spectacles and a kindly disposition. He dotes on talking about jumpers of any kind, the brush-hurdlers of the steeplechase events on the big tracks and the post-and-rail jumpers of the hunt meetings.

MIAMI, Sept. 4. -- Some of the victims of the hurricane which swept the Florida Keys told vivid stories of terror as houses were swept away in swirling waters that accompanied winds of 80 to more than 100 miles an hour.

Helen Hayes, stage and film actress, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie with her daughter, Mary MacArthur, but her husband, Charles MacArthur, who had booked to sail with them for a round-trip on the Normandie, canceled his reservation at the last hour.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 4. -- The Egyptian Cabinet has approved the Egypto-Sudanese agreement regarding the distribution of Lake Tana waters. Much speculation has been caused here regarding the next step. Some believe Britain will induce Emperor Haile Selassie to sign an agreement with Egypt for the construction of a dam.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The National Association of Letter Carriers adopted a resolution today favoring legislation to establish a court of appeals which would sit in final judgment on postal employes facing charges involving possible dismissal.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe stayed yesterday any further examination of Bertrand Colas Neidecker, which has been proceeding during the last three weeks before Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn at 280 Broadway, under Section 21a of the Bankruptcy Act.

One of the most unusual controversies in Wall Street's history will come up for settlement in the tribunal of the American Arbitration Association today when arbitrators will consider the claims of thirty-two firms party to "when-issued" trading in Alleghany Corporation $2.50 prior preferred stock.

GENEVA, Sept. 4. -- In a new and better atmosphere, cleared of suspicion by Secretary of State Hull's firm action on the Standard-Vacuum oil concession, the Council of the League of Nations began this evening its discussion of the Italo-Ethiopian problem.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Henry Levine of the Inwood Golf Club today captured the medal in the fourteenth annual junior championship of the Long Island Golf Association over the rain-soaked links of the Rockville Country Club with a card of 81.

It is not a new dictum that the health of the people is the highest law, but it is more and more invoked as science makes its advances, especially in the prevention of disease. That the educational authorities awaited the advice of the health authorities before fixing the date of opening the schools in this city is but another indication of the priority of health in public concern.

Three impatient thieves, with a foresighted demand for fur garments, were sought by the police in New York and Connecticut last night after they had escaped with a mink wrap valued at $1,500 from the show window of Russeks Fifth | Avenue, Inc.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4 (AP). -- The yacht Byronic brought fifty-two injured to hospitals here from the hurricane-stricken Florida keys.

The United States Government was urged to use its influence to prevent war and "help save Ethiopia'' yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. L.K. Williams of Chicago, addressing more than 2,000 Negro Baptists at the opening session of the fifty-sixth annual National Negro Baptist Convention in the Bronx Coliseum.

World peace depends on redistribution of colonial possessions to meet the needs of Italy, and of Germany and Japan as well, Colonel Edward M. House, former close adviser of Woodrow Wilson, declares in an article in the current issue of Liberty.

JMMY COLLINS was one of the many skillful air pilots in the United States who found money to be a necessity and jobs scarce. To support a wife and two children he made a living by testing Navy ships. For $1,500 he would put a new ship through all the motions, looping, snap-rolling, slow-rolling, spinning, flying upside down, and doing true Immelmann turns.
Numerous leases in the midtown area by manufacturing firms were reported yesterday.

New cases of infantile paralysis reported yesterday to the Health Department totaled sixty-three. This was an increase over the average of the preceding four days, the total for which was 147, but officials pointed out that the daily figures were apt to fluctuate considerably without affecting the general downward trend which they believe has set in.

Frank J. Taylor, Controller, announced that arrangements were completed yesterday for the sale of $10,000,000 New York City revenue bills, carrying a 2 1/2 per cent. interest rate, to J.P. Morgan Co., who acted as agent for the group of city banks under the agreement with the city.

When we say that the Federal budget is unbalanced, we mean that governmental spending exceeds the revenues which the government has the courage to collect by taxation. The reigning Democrats shrink from extracting from the nation the huge sums the administration is disbursing, and they thereby display political sagacity.

TORONTO, Sept. 4 (AP). -- After trailing in second place for four and one-half miles Miss Charlotte Acres of Vancouver forged to the front with the finish line in sight tonight to win the Canadian National Exhibition's five-mile swim for women.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The rapid negotiations that led to the cancellation by American Petroleum interests of the concession obtained from Ethiopia last week were hailed by President Roosevelt today as proof of the end of "dollar diplomacy."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Reports that the section near Snake Creek on Upper Matecumbe Key was "strewn with bodies of men, women and children" reached the Coast Guard station here this afternoon by radio from the Miami air station.
More rain for today was predicted by the Weather Bureau last night, with probably cooler weather.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Clean Government Republicans are pledged to repeal of the State sales tax at the next session of the Legislature, the Rev. Lester H. Clee, leader of the faction, announced in opening the campaign of the group at its new headquarters, Broad Street and Raymond Boulevard, here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Present indications are that a modernized Copyright Law will be enacted in the next session of Congress. Those advocating revision of the 1909 Copyright Act advanced toward their goal in the session just ended when the Senate passed a bill which met with the approval of most authors and book publishers.

Provision in the city's budget for thousands of new books to replace worn volumes in the city's public libraries was requested yesterday at a hearing on the 1936 estimates before Budget Director McGahen. The total added amount asked for books was $657,400.

MIAMI, Sept. 4. -- Scenes of horror and desolation greeted the eyes of rescue workers tonight as they penetrated the storm-battered Florida keys to count the dead, estimated unofficially at upward of 200, while the hurricane apparently was blowing itself out in South Georgia.

Activity in the apparel and accessory markets increased here yesterday, but the general volume continued somewhat below expectations for this period. The explanation in wholesale circles was that many retailers are still waiting for consumer action on early Fall merchandise before placing substantial reorders.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Paul E. Hood of Miami, who went to the Snake Creek section last night on a rescue mission, described a weird scene today.

I note in THE TIMES a statement by Dorothy Proesch of the Braille Theatre Guild to the effect that this organization is the only one interested in dramatics for the blind. It is unfortunate that such a statement should gain currency in New York, where for many years a number of organizations interested in the blind have had groups of blind players, some of whom have given performances on Broadway.
The demand for funds in the day loan and maturity money market was small. Quotations were carried forward without change. Commercial paper was moderately active, but the discounts continued steady.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- On the ground that the emergency peak had passed, President Roosevelt signed an Executive order today placing the administration expenses of the last seven recovery agencies under the Director of the Budget as of Oct. 15. The President later explained that economy was one of the ojects sought.

Among his proudest possessions Babe Ruth today cherishes a lifetime pass for all National League baseball games, the gift of the circuit, forwarded to the Babe by President Ford C. Frick. The number of the pass is 500. In acknowledging receipt of the pass, Ruth declared it a "touch of sentiment and appreciation that will never be forgotten."
Friends and relatives of New York passengers aboard the stranded liner Dixie besieged the Morgan Line offices here all day yesterday.

Louis Francis Budenz's letter in your issue of Sept. 2 very correctly states that "the American theory of government, particularly as enunciated in the Bill of Rights, entails the basic concept of progress through free discussion."

American crews took first and second place in the annual lifeboat race on the Hudson, and it is pleasant to note that the roster of the winning boat reads so much like a big American football team. The nine men, including the coxswain, were JULIUS PALU, AKSEL SELVIK, ORIN JEWETT, CLYDE TAYLOR, A. LARSON, HERMAN KASTBERG, JOHN P. HUNEKE, HAWKINS FUDSKI and WILLIAM F. STEVENS.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4. -- Admiral Isamu Takeshita, Japan's official messenger of world good-will, in which capacity he and a party of four will tour the United States to eliminate "all misunderstanding between the two nations," arrived today on the Tatsuta Maru.

A new crisis in the dissension-torn Teachers Union here was reached with the announcement yesterday that its entire list of officers would resign in protest against left-wing activity in the union's ranks.

The arbitration that will be opened today to settle the controversy in respect to certain dealings in preferred stock of the Alleghany Corporation, when issued, serves to show how readily Wall Street adapted itself to the changes caused by the depression.
GENEVA, Sept. 4. -- The text of important parts of the Italian memorandum against Ethiopia, placed before the Council of the League of Nations today, follows:

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4. -- Nearly forty-eight hours after being trapped on the treacherous rocks of French Reef, sixty miles south of here, during a hurricane, passengers of the Morgan liner Dixie were en route once more for New York, this time aboard Coast Guard boats sent to their rescue.
Directors of the American Agricultural Chemical Company of Delaware declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share, compared with 50 cents quarterly paid previously.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept.-4. I-Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Duryea, who were athe Hedges during July, have returned for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. 01n'ey B. Malts at their Lee' Avenue residence.

CINCINNATI. Sept. 4. -- The Giants, launching their grand offensive in the West today, thundered over a measured distance at considerably less speed than 300 miles an hour. In fact, for a time they threatened not to get started at all, as Colonel Bill Terry and Sir Carl Hubbell experienced considerable difficulty coaxing even a few clicks out of the motor.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Favorites marched ahead today in the first round of the women's Mason and Dixon golf tourney, undismayed by a steady downpour of rain.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Splashing through a kick-back of the Caribbean blow, six crews of sailors started the women's national championship today off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Through driving rain two of them came through two races tied on points.

Following the example of the Public Service Commission, the Transit Commission moved yesterday toward a 120-day suspension of the schedule of increased commutation rates recently filed by the Long Island Railroad. The company's application was referred to George H. Stover, counsel for the commission, who will prepare a suspension order for formal adoption.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Twenty-two offering sheets of various oil interests in connection with the proposed sale of securities were filed last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The act of filing, the commission said, did not give its approval to any security, or indicate that the commission had passed upon the merits of the issue, or that the material filed is correct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- A union of business and farming interests in the South and West in an organized drive against high tariff rates on things the farmers buy was foreseen today by Secretary Wallace in the event the AAA processing taxes are terminated by the Supreme Court and no suitable substitute is found to replace them.

If the incipient season turns up nothing inferior to "Moon Over Mulberry Street" we may thank the gods for being kind. Nicholas Cosentino's simple idyll of the Italian quarter, which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, believes in human warmth, good cheer and democracy.

Business failures in the retail and wholesale groups showed increases in the week ended Aug. 29 as compared with the previous week, while in the manufacturing division there was a slight decline in the number of insolvencies, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A telegram commending his stand in opposing the recent Anglo-American Ethiopian oil concession was dispatched to Secretary of State Hull last night by the American Committee on the Ethiopian Crisis, a non-partisan, non-sectarian committee of educators, clergymen and others formed to aid Ethiopia to preserve her sovereignty.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4. -- The Argentine Supreme Court has ruled that holders of defaulted provincial bonds must sue United States bankers for redress rather than the province which issued the bonds and then defaulted.

East Side tenancies led in the apartment rentals reported yesterday. Max Schling, florist, leased six rooms in 130 East Seventy-fifth Street from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company through the William B. May Company. Carmen Barnes, novelist, rented in 30 Beekman Place from Bing Bing.

Probably, as THE TIMES has indicated editorially, the utility holding company executives have ground for their apprehensions as to the effect of the recently enacted Federal Public Utility Law. But is not their situation similar to that which confronted the executives of the Stock Exchanges and their members a little more than a year ago when the Securities and Exchange Act was passed by Congress?

NORWICH, England, Sept. 4. -- Scientists were told tonight by Professor William Whitehead Watts in his presidential address opening the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, that the tidal pull of the sun and moon might be one of the mysterious forces that help to cause the building of mountains and the formation of land masses on the surface of the earth.

The wife from whom Howard W. Reed, 58 years old, a cashier, decided to go far away two years ago when he was alleged to have stolen about $5,700 from the New York Hospital, where he was employed, surrendered him in District Attorney Dodge's office yesterday.

Five hundred children from the gas house district in the West Sixties will be the guests of Uncle Robert, radio entertainer, at his seventy-first birthday party Saturday at 3 P.M. in Riverside Park between Seventy-third and Seventy- fifth Streets.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Old Jess Haines failed today in his eleventh bid for his 200th major league victory but his world champion Cardinal teammates rallied behind a relief hurler to pound out a 6-to-3 triumph over the Braves.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4. -- Besieged for two days and two nights by a mad Atlantic storm in the Morgan liner Dixie, 164 passengers and members of the ship's crew were saved tonight from rocky French reef by gallant men of a rescue fleet.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 4 (Reuters). -- The Ethiopian Government tonight adopted the attitude that the oil concession would not be canceled after all.
TOKYO, Sept. 4. -- Both the army and the government hope General Senjuro Hayashi's resignation as War Minister will close the most disturbed chapter of modern Japan's domestic history.

Demand for pictures of Sir Malcolm Campbell's race against time in his Bluebird in Utah on Tuesday resulted in a new photoradio transmission record, the Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday. In one operation, radio flashed a picture through from San Francisco to London, while at the same time New York radio men intercepted and made copies of the picture.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Charges made on Tuesday by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, that two law firms here had virtually engaged in double dealings with the RFC in its liability suits against stockholders of the former Central Republic and Trust Company, were denied emphatically today by the concerns.

Sculptured models in bronze and copper of the two Ohrbach stores in Union Square and in Newark, as well as of the original store that marked Nathan M. Ohrbach's first venture into retail merchandising, were presented last night to the merchant at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria.

The new Banking Act, in spite of the multiplicity of its provisions, in its final form made little progress toward curing what many authorities consider the greatest weakness in our banking system -- its dual control either by national or by any one of forty-eight different State laws.

All too frequently the people are prone to elect Senators, Representatives and other officials, upon the solemn promise of candidates that they will, if elected, vote for (a) reduction in government expenditures; (b) less government in business; (c) maintenance of a sound currency; (d) less nepotism; (e) maintenance of constitutional principles; (f) a balanced budget; (g) taxes necessary to cover all government expenditures,

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Kept under restraint throughout most of the mile and seventy yards of the featured fifth race today at Narragansett Park, the Liberty Lane Stable's Stickhandle won by a head from Jess Spencer's Chatuga.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- A bill amending the Grazing Act, which governs administration of the 165,000,000 acres of public domain, was vetoed by President Roosevelt today because of provisions which Secretary Ickes reported would nullify the original act, result in capture of most of the public domain by the States and make the carrying out of conservation plans impossible.

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD RELIEF TUG CARRABASSET, Sept. 5 (via Tropical Radio). -- The S.S. Dixie captain described today a night of horror at sea when his hurricane-buffeted ship pounded on the rocks of French Reef as he feared for the safety of 231 passengers and 122 in the crew.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5. -- Spattering rain, low visibility, the time-worn excuse in naval battle array, and about all the nastiness nature could muster were no deterrents today to the sailors after the women's national championship.

Transatlantic steamship companies, which a few months ago ceased to hold social affairs on board ships in port, as a result of protests by hotel men, are faced with the curtailment of another time-honored feature of ocean travel -- the bon voyage drink indulged in by passenger and visitor at sailing time.

Annually increasing savings to the city as a result of the revision of utility contracts were stressed by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, at a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen on 1936 estimates of the department.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The Carlyon Arms, famous old hostelry at 42 South Broadway here, which perhaps more than any other building is symbolic of the historic White Plains which gave way to modernity, was started on its way to oblivion today when its furnishings were sold at public auction.

Bonds of domestic corporations, led by local traction securities, moved forward aggressively yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The upswing in the traction issues, while strictly an independent group movement, came at a time when the market for railroad liens and many selected public-utility bonds turned strong.

MIAMI, Sept. 5. -- The casualty list from the tropical hurricane in the Florida keys was placed tonight at 256 dead and 252 injured in an "official count" by the Red Cross as a controversy developed over failure before the storm to evacuate the hundreds of World War veterans, among whom were most of the victims.

The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., not including subsidiaries or undistributed applicable income, reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a net income of $9,809,775 before interest and other deductions, but after expenses and taxes.

The city council of Los Angeles has approved a resolution to invite tenders on $3,000,000 of water bonds, to be awarded on Sept. 17. Bidders are to name an interest rate not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds are part of the $38,000,000 voted in 1930 for the city water system, of which $29,600,000 has been sold.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation to be at the highest point of the year to date.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, announced tonight that Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, one-time New York beer baron, had been served with a new tax assessment notice, demanding payment of more than $70,000 for alleged non-payment of State income tax for the years 1929 and 1930.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Declaring that the government already is "well within President Roosevelt's budget" for the 1935-36 fiscal year, Secretary Morgenthau today predicted further reductions in Federal administrative costs as a result of the Budget Bureau's new control over emergency agencies.

Brock Pemberton, producer, and Zona Gale, author, the team which won the Pulitzer Prize for 1921 with "Miss Lulu Bett," have joined theatrical forces again. Miss Gale is dramatizing a story of her own entitled "Afraid to Marry," of which the last instalment recently appeared in a national magazine. She will arrive shortly from Portage, Wis., with the first draft of the play.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The first appearance of English capital in the American motion-picture industry came today when the board of directors of United Artists Corporation announced that Alexander Korda, London producer and director, had been made a member of the board.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $887,646,105 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Sept. 1 was $30.44, compared with $29.76 at the beginning of August.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Young Terry Moore equaled a modern major league batting record today as the world champion Cardinals defeated the Braves, 15 to 3, to retain top standing in the National League.

NORWICH, England, Sept. 5. -- Professor Frank Debenham, director of the School for Polar Research, Cambridge University, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science in an address today that "air power" from Antarctic blizzards might provide a new source of electrical energy for future generations.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- One of the East's major golf tourneys, the Glens Falls open, will get under way for the seventh time tomorrow with 140 leading professionals and amateurs among the competitors.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The Boerse became somewhat firmer today after a mixed opening. Issues of heavy industrials were very quiet but friendly. Potash shares were quiet, Aschesleben gaining 3/4 point. Machine stocks remained weak with Berlin-Karlsruhe declining 3/8 point.

Mental ability is largely conditioned by the G element. So a British scientist has just told the American Psychological Association meeting in Ann Arbor. It is, therefore, a distinct disappointment to find on closer scrutiny that mental G is not a vitamin, like so many other capital letters of the alphabet now being studied by science.

BELGRADE, Sept. 5. -- The popularity of little King Peter, whose forlorn situation as nominal ruler since the murder of his father, King Alexander, has made a great appeal to all classes of Yugoslavs, is being made very evident in connection with his twelfth birthday tomorrow.

The steep rise in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System was checked in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly statistics of the system, published yesterday. These showed that excess reserves had fallen from the high record of $2,780,000,000 reached last week to $2,670,000,000.

Another effort to settle the strike of shipping clerks in the garment district, accompanied by sympathetic walkouts by thousands of other workers, was launched last night by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Her experiences aboard the liner Dixie while the seas pounded it on French Reef were related over the telephone from Miami today by Miss Marie H. Shields, 25 years old, who with her 12-year-old sister, Eleanor, found the adventure a great lark.

Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association in North Atlantic ports from Portland, Me., to Norfolk, Va., will meet in New York from Sept. 16-18 to draft demands for a new wage and working contract to replace that which has been in effect during the past year and is due to expire Sept. 30.
Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson decided yesterday that injunction suits brought by eight corporations to restrain the Federal Government from collecting processing taxes had been improperly filed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Government pressure to force New York State to provide more money for work relief projects is understood to have been asked of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, by Lester Herzog, State Works Progress Administrator, in a conference today.

Mrs. George Bethune Adams, who at the age of 87 still is active as the director of Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, was called out of bed early yesterday to quiet an angry stray dog which had resisted three policemen and frightened all the others at the East Fifty-first Street police station.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher frequently mentioned as a Republican Presidential candidate, declared today for "some form of export bounty" for the farmers. He made his statement in an exchange of telegrams with former Governor Clyde M. Reed of Kansas.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5. -- The Roosevelt administration's "tax-the-rich" program is simply a campaign to "smash" Henry Ford, the Ford dealers and service managers from twenty-nine States east of the Mississippi were told at their meeting in the Traymore Hotel here today by W.J. Cameron of Dearborn, Mich., personal representative of the automobile manufacturer and frequently his spokesman.

Negotiations for the city's acquisition of the rapid transit properties of the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway, for inclusion in a general unification plan, appeared yesterday to be reaching a climax, with an early settlement in prospect.

Leslie Weldon and Curt H. Reisinger gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis to celebrate the birthday of Mrs. Weldon. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Ford, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Metzleur, Mr. and Mrs. Halsey Brewster, the Misses Edmee Reisinger, Eleanor Metzleur and Alma Otto; Franklin Metzleur and Einar Christensen.

Increased concern regarding women's apparel deliveries was shown yesterday by local and out-of-town retailers as potential spread of the packing and shipping clerks' strike threatened to embrace workers throughout the dress and coat industries.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 5. -- A sturdy sophomore from Notre Dame, two prep school lads and a high school student advanced to the semi-final round of the fourteenth annual junior championship of the Long Island Golf Association today over the rain-swept links at the Rockville Country Club.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the year to date crossed the 200,000,000-share mark yesterday; this time a year ago the total had reached 256,000,000 shares. With yesterday's turnover of 1,891,000 shares, the aggregate for 1935 was brought to 200,999,000.

Mayor La Guardia aligned himself yesterday with the group of city officials opposing the Long Island Railroad's proposal to increase its commutation rates 15 to 20 per cent.
