He instructed Corporation Counsel Paul Windels to see that the city voiced its opposition to the new rate schedules when they come up for concurrent public hearings before the Transit Commission and the Public Service Commission.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- The Newport Garden Association held its September meeting this afternoon with Mrs. Edward V. Hartford at her home, Seaverge. Mrs. William B. Bristow, the president, presided and presented as the guest speaker Leonard Barron of New York, president of the American Rose Society.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Fire discovered about 3 o'clock this morning almost destroyed the Shelter Rock Country Club on time I.U. Willets Road in the Searingtown Colony. Five employes sleeping in the clubhouse narrowly escaped with their lives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Railroad Credit Corporation and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad have agreed to seek cancellation of a court order which permitted the road to execute a new note to the corporation for $1,685,000, payable on May 27, 1937, which was to provide for a note which matured on May 28.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., is charged with forty-five separate violations of Federal rules and regulations concerning the keeping of flight records by the Communications Commission on Radio Broadcasting in a report on aspects of the crash of the plane Sky Chief that killed Senator Bronson Cutting and four others at Atlanta, Mo.

Mayor La Guardia last night told 5,000 Negro men and women, gathered at the fifty-sixth annual national Negro Baptist convention at the Bronx Coliseum, that there would be no discrimination in this city against Negroes as long as he was Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A controversy raged today about the failure to evacuate veterans before the hurricane struck the Florida Keys Monday, Charles C. Clark, acting chief of the Weather Bureau, said the warning issued Saturday, Sunday and Monday all showed the trend of the storm.

Next Sunday a referendum is to be held in Switzerland on the "total revision" of the Swiss Constitution. This is in conformity with the provision of the Constitution that a referendum on any subject or on the whole Constitution itself must be held if it is demanded by 50,000 Swiss voters.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 5. -- This was an easy day for Manhattan's varsity football candidates. Head Coach Chick Meehan limited the single session on the drill field of La Salle Military Academy to ninety minutes of running and conditioning exercises designed to work out the stiffness caused by the first scrimmage yesterday.

Indications of a revival of book purchasing for replacement by libraries and institutions have been found by Dodd, Mead. These publishers say that during the past week they have placed orders for printing and binding 160 titles of "stock" books, the great bulk being books which have been on their list ten years or more.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 5. -- Emperor Haile Selassie issued new decrees today to restrain oral and published attacks upon Premier Mussolini and Italy. The Emperor ordered Kidane Mariam Takle, who is editor of the Amharic language publication, Voice of Ethiopia, arrested for using violent language against Italy.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Recent boxing drills have indicated that Max Baer plans an offensive in the early rounds to dispel any thoughts Joe Louis may entertain of scoring a quick knockout in their bout Sept. 24 at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Acting as a mediator between the Senate Munitions Committee and the British and French Governments, the State Department has taken custody of a truck load of J.P. Morgan Co. records.

The following table shows expected revenues which will accrue to the city in 1936 fro sources other than the tax levy on real estate and the city's general fund. These moneys go to various city departments and boards in conformity with special statutory requirements:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The articles that cannot be exported to belligerents in case war breaks out anywhere in the world, under the terms of the mandatory neutrality resolution passed by Congress in its closing days, are now the subject of intensive study by the State Department, Secretary Hull indicated today.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Preparations for the convening of the World Jewish Congress, the first in modern history, will be completed by next Spring, it was decided at a meeting here today of Jewish leaders representing twenty countries on the committee of Jewish delegations, the international Jewish representative body founded at the Versailles peace conference to protect Jewish minority rights, according to the Palcor Agency.
While infantile paralysis appeared to be on the wane here yesterday, authorities in New Jersey were doubling their efforts to prevent a spread of the disease in that State.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Final rehearsals are being held for the first Guild Hall amateur night to be given in the John Drew Memorial Theatre on Saturday for the benefit of Guild Hall. Drama, comedy, songs, a pony ballet, tap dancing and sleight-of-hand are some of the acts to be given by amateurs of both the Summer colony and the permanent village.

Warners announced yesterday plans to produce "Life of Beethoven," a film biography of the celebrated composer. Erich Wolfgang Korngold, Viennese composer, will arrange the Beethoven compositions for a symphony orchestra of 125 pieces, and William Dieterle, who assisted Max Reinhardt in producing "A Midsummer Night's Dream," will be the director. No-casting selections have been made.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- To the growing list of concessions to Ethiopian riches that Emperor Haile Selassie has been reported to have granted, another must be added, according to today's Paris Soir. It is an apparently legitimate and still enforceable contract signed by Haile Selassie, then regent, with two French brothers named Bayart on May 6, 1919.
An arrangement, described as "entirely satisfactory," was made yesterday for the distribution "by the schools" of funds of the National Youth Administration for needy high school students.

With prices of commodity futures generally steady to lower yesterday, wool top futures provided the outstanding feature with an advance to new high levels for the year. In the cash markets, cotton and rubber were lower, while all the grains, dairy products, lard, tin, silks and hides were higher.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5. -- Preparations to float the Morgan liner Dixie, driven aground on French Reef sixty miles south of Miami by a hurricane Monday night, began today following transfer of all passengers to other ships.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has requested through the Park Department a PWA grant of $277,935 for necessary renovations in the oldest section of the museum building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- With his goal still to place the 3,500,000 unemployed at work before Nov. 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today announced that 873,563 jobs have been provided by the administration's work relief program.

Five hundred persons, representing the United States Army and Navy, the foreign consulates in New York and the Belgian colony here, attended yesterday morning a memorial service for Astrid, Queen of the Belgians. The service, a solemn high mass of requiem, was at St. Albert's Belgian Catholic Church, 433 West Forty-seventh Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- D.W. Tomlinson, assistant to the president of Transcontinental and Western Air; Harlan Hull, chief pilot, and Howard Morgan, a radio engineer, landed the record-holding Douglas DC-1 at Newark Airport at 5:11 daylight-saving time this afternoon after a non-stop high-altitude flight from Kansas City in 5 hours 4 minutes.

ROME, Sept. 5. -- Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations, in his speech at Geneva yesterday is held to have put so clearly the whole Italian case that no additional explanation from Rome is necessary.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Outside speculative interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade increased today, and despite considerable profit-taking at 92 cents a bushel and over for the December, the undertone was much stronger than of late, and the finish was at net gains of 1 to 11/4 cents.

Forty-four of the forty-five RKO theatres in Greater New York will become double-feature houses tomorrow. The lone exception in the metropolitan circuit will be the Palace, Broadway vaudeville stronghold, which will continue to show only one feature picture at a time.

Sportsmen's organizations in all parts of New York State have received 4,500 of the 7,600 quail which are to be distributed this year from the Conservation Department's quail farm at Middle Island, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Aug. 24 amounted to 310,131,000 barrels, a decline of 1,148,000 from the previous week, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Sept. 5. -- Almost seventeen years have "rolled by" since the end of the World War, but the men of the American Legion still shoulder great responsibilities and "your service to the nation is needed now," President Roosevelt, in a letter to Robert L. Insko, commander of the Virginia Legion, told "my next-door neighbor," the American Legion, Department of Virginia," in a communication read to the convention today.

Straggling stag lines formed along Forty-second Street west of Broadway last night and stared at the posters in front of dark and empty burlesque theatres. Nobody was there to explain that New York was experiencing its first burlesque strike.

The share market gave an impressive demonstration of strength from the outset yesterday, resuming the advance started late on the day before under the leadership of the automotive, steel and farm-equipment issues; to these active groups were added electrical equipment and finally the transit stocks.

Samuel Laufbahn, in his letter to THE TIMES, hits the nail on the head when he advocates a system of taxation to be levied on the current, demonstrated, national wealth, or, as he puts it, "total national income," rather than upon estimated value and alleged individual income.

The quality of the tournament committee's patience was strained to the breaking point at Forest Hills yesterday as rain fell for the fifth day in the space of a week to wash out another program of play in the national tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -Chairman Fletcher of the national committee today summoned members of the Republican executive committee to meet in Washington Sept. 25 to get ready for the 1936 Presidential campaign.

ATHENS, Sept. 5. -- The suicide of George C. Hanson, United States Consul General at Saloniki, who shot himself aboard the liner President Polk en route to New York, shocked the American colony and officials here when they learned of it this morning.

Retail package deliveries in metropolitan and suburban areas declined slightly for the week ended Aug. 31, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. An increase of 7 per cent over a year ago was reported, against a gain of 8 per cent in the preceding week.

Eight men were charged with bookmaking and one with disorderly conduct after a raid yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock by seventeen plainclothes men and detectives on two large rooms on the fourth floor of the Brooklyn Elks Club, 150 South Oxford Street, near Atlantic Avenue.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Kept indoors since Tuesday by the unfavorable weather, Fordham's football players finally managed to go through their paces out-of-doors when they engaged in a two-hours session on Fordham Field yesterday afternoon.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 5. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes of Washington returned today for a week's sojourn at the Mount Washington, where they spent six weeks of the early season. Since then they have toured the Great Lakes, Yellowstone and Glacier Parks and the Canadian Rockies.

Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League and former chairman of the National Democratic Committee, returned from Europe yesterday with Mrs. Shouse, on the United States liner Manhattan.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Fearful that a woman railroad passenger stricken with smallpox may have spread the disease to others in New York State, the State Health Department late today addressed an urgent appeal to all persons who traveled on the same train with her to be vaccinated immediately.

Among the nostrums currently brewed, one of the most pernicious would attempt to limit taxation to some "experimentally sound portion" of the national income. As expounded by Samuel Laufbahn in THE TIMES, "it should long ago have been the task of students of finance to establish the proportion of taxes to the entire national income, beyond which the economic machinery cannot normally produce.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of the birth of the late Jane Addams will be observed today by a meeting in the plaza at City Hall at noon and another in the afternoon at the home of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg in White Plains.

Continuing cloudy and wet weather for the fourth day brought the appearance of a rainy season to the city yesterday and rounded out two weeks of below-normal temperatures. More rain is expected today, with little change in temperature.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- An immediate and thorough investigation of the causes for the extraordinary loss of life in veterans' camps in Florida as a result of the hurricane was ordered by President Roosevelt today.

Operations of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a net profit of $2,577,550 after depreciation. Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to 51 cents a share on 5,000,000 no par shares of capital stock.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5. -- It was all Greek to the Giants today and this, at least, should soften the news that Colonel Bill Terry's grand offensive through the West crashed into an early fall as the Reds bagged the second game of their series here, 4 to 1.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP). --The Red Sox could not score enough runs to win for Lefty Grove today but they could and did for Wes Ferrell and as a result split a doubleheader with the Indians. Cleveland won the opener, 8 to 1, while the Red Sox and Ferrell took the afterpiece, 6 to 1.

It is pleasant to think of Mr. ROOSEVELT, who has done so much for and spent so much on the agricultural vote, as himself the farmer, happiest on his own acres and in his modest cot. Farmers from other parts of the country come to see him and talk about crop prospects and prices and the latest thing in silos.
The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, will bring among her passengers:

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 5. -- On a course so water-logged that mashies were used instead of putters and cups had to be bailed out before balls could splash into them, the first mother-and-son tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was held in the rain at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

Approximately one-sixth of the 240,000 persons on home relief, or about 40,000, are unemployable because of physical deficiencies, it was indicated yesterday in a report submitted to General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for this city.
LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, who arrived in London from Aix-les-Bains this afternoon, exclaimed the first thing when he reached 10 Downing Street:

Sir Thomas Beecham, British conductor, has been engaged for three weeks of guest appearances with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. He will direct the orchestra from Jan. 2 to 19 in a total of eleven concerts.

Controller Taylor's estimate of $96,750,000 in general fund revenues for the city in 1936 is itemized in the following table. To the $96,750,000 total estimated, the Controller explained, is to be added a surplus from the current year of from $4,000,000 to $4,500,000, a factor which will bring the general fund total to approximately $101,000,000.

Presiding Justice Martin of the Appellate Division, at a hearing of appeals in primary election cases, assailed yesterday the "waste of money" and delay involved in technical objections to designating petitions and the "farcical" nature of some provisions of the law.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A divorce suit charge that Jayne Manners, actress, asserted she "knew plenty" about the unsolved disappearance of Justice Joseph Force Crater of New York was made today by her husband, Maurice L. Kusell, and promptly denied by the New York show girl.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 5. -- The Ethiopian Government instructed its delegates at Geneva today to make neither concessions nor compromises, but to stand firm by their instructions. It is understood here a certain amount of discretion was given to the delegates, but on the question of the protection of sovereign rights of Ethiopia no latitude was allowed.

Following is an incomplete list of new WPA projects announced yesterday at the office of General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, together with the sums allocated to each and the average number of persons to be employed per day on each project:
PARIS, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

When the oil concession by Ethiopia was canceled, the country was informed that "dollar diplomacy" was forever at an end in the United States. That phrase was once applied to certain practices and activities by our Government which were open to abuse. It is well if we are permanently rid of them.

New York City's budget for 1936, now in the course of preparation, must not exceed $539,695,777, the sum total of revenue the city can expect to collect during the coming year, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.

OTTAWA, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Prime Minister Richard B. Bennett sent a formal warning to the Japanese Government today that unless the 50 per cent surtax imposed against principal Canadian imports was removed the 1913 trade agreement between the two governments would be terminated.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5. -- Casey Stengel made four defensive substitutions in the eighth inning today, which he entered with a 4-1 lead, including a pair of pitchers, but all his strategy was nullified by Bud Hafey's big bat.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Minor league baseball, from the double A International League and American Association down to the smallest of the Class D circuits, has boomed out of the red ink and into the black this year for the first time since the depression set in.

Two special trains arranged by H.H. Gray, general Eastern passenger agent of the Morgan Line, left Miami last night bearing the passengers from the grounded Dixie to New York. Although the time of arrival was indefinite, the trains were expected at the Pennsylvania Station at an early hour tomorrow morning, a half-hour apart.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 5. -- The women's Mason and Dixon golf tourney swung through the second and third rounds today with only one upset, the defeat of Mrs. Jack Hoblitzell of Parkersburg, West Virginia women's champion.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 5. -- If this city cannot make up its mind by Sept. 12 to agree on hayling a postoffice Built on the site i which the government purchased here more than two years ago, the $85,000 Federal Building appropriation will be withdrawn.

The action of the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, in filing a petition in bankruptcy proved to be the crux of arguments presented before the tribunal of the American Arbitration Association yesterday by counsel for Wall Street firms which are engaged in a controversy over the validity of dealings in the corporation's $2.50 prior preferred stock on a when-issued basis.

A "war" against sin throughout the world has been declared by General Evangeline Booth of the Salvation Army, with headquarters in London. General Booth was for more than twenty-five years commander of the Salvation Army in the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Operators on the London Stock Exchange opened quietly today, but turned firmer later, as the international situation appeared to have a more hopeful outlook. The rumor that the United States intended further devaluation of the dollar in the near future accelerated the upward movement, resumed recently, in South African gold mine shares.

Summoned into the spotlight for inspection by members of the press and of the staff, Fall fashions made their bow last night at the Bergdorf-Goodman store in the first comprehensive preview of designs by both French and American couturiers.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- During the opening of the second phase of the French Army manoeuvres in the vicinity of Rheims today, two bombing planes flying toward the scene of operations collided in mid-air and crashed to the ground, killing all ten of their occupants.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The writer is now able to reveal that confidential conversations with Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy quite outside the events in the League of Nations are actively proceeding. As long as the channel of communications is other than Geneva, Il Duce exhibits an eminently reasonable attitude.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 5. -- Dr. S. Tartakower, who played first board for Poland, runner-up to the United States at Warsaw, assumed the lead tonight in the international chess tournament in progress at the Klub Szachowy when he defeated Kolski of this city in a Queen's gambit declined lasting forty-four moves. Dr. Tartakower complicated the position to such an extent that Kolski overstepped the time limit.

Powerful finishes by Jockeys Sammy Renick and Den Meade had much to do with the results in the main races at Aqueduct yesterday. The former was up on Little Miracle, winner of the feature, while Meade captured the race next in importance with Bird Flower.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 5. (Reuters). -- Munitions are being secretly moved by night from arsenals near Addis Ababa to various points westward as a precaution against raids over this capital, one of the highest officers in the Ethiopian Army revealed today in an exclusive interview with this correspondent.

Holcombe Ward, chairman of the United States Davis Cup Committee, yesterday advised Frank Parker, young No. 4 American ranking tennis player, to continue his studies. Parker, who is not yet 20, announced on Wednesday that he intended to quit prep school and devote all his time to developing his tennis game.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Six yachts seeking three berths on the American team of six-meter sloops which will answer a Scandinavian challenge started competition today in the elimination series conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, and one of them, Herman Whiton's Cherokee, remained unbeaten in three races.
Business in the credit market continued along small lines, with quotations unchanged for all classifications.
Directors of the Acme Steel Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 121/2 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. Similar payments were made on July 1.

The retirement from J.P. Morgan Co. of a group of partners and staff members, headed by Harold Stanley, William Ewing and Henry Sturgis Morgan, to form an investment banking firm to be known as Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., was announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5. -- In a series of rescues packed with gallantry and maritime efficiency, all of the 231 passengers and most of the crew of the grounded and shattered Morgan liner Dixie were safely ashore tonight after three harrowing days in hurricane-lashed waters off the Florida keys.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff, received today an oak cluster for his Distinguished Service Medal, won during the World War, from Secretary Dern in recognition of his services during more than four years at the head of the army's general staff.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Blue Eagle died an official death today when the National Recoved Administration issued an administrative order canceling all Blue Eagle reproduction authorizations and declaring further reproductions of the insignia to be contrary to the policies of the NRA.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 5. -- The "lie detector" detects "painful complexes" rather than lies, members of the American Psychological Association were told today at their convention here. How the device works was explained by Dr. Verne W. Lyon of Chicago, who reported on 100 cases where the detector was used on juvenile criminal suspects.

Members of the Nut Club have a four-foot alligator chained to the bar in their meeting place at 2,650 Bergen Road, Jersey City, and are wondering what to do with it. The reptile, which is four feet long and unfriendly, arrived in a crate Wednesday night from Thomas Smythe, 23 years old, a member of the club, who is now in a CCC camp at Tiajuana Creek in the Florida Everglades.

Supreme Court Justice, Frankenthaler paved the way yesterday for a speedy reorganization of the $10,000,000 issue of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company known as series Q, when he signed an order directing the certificate holders to vote by Sept. 30 on the manner in which they want the new trustees to be chosen.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Frank Demaree's single with the bases loaded and one out in the eleventh inning gave the Cubs a 3-to-2 victory over the Phillies today.

Declaring that the electric properties controlled by the American Water Works and Electric Company constitute an "integrated public utility system," as defined under the Public Utility Act of 1935 and that as such they "should not be subject to dissolution under its terms," H. Hobart Porter, president, said yesterday in a letter to stockholders that continued ownership of the water works and other non-electric properties "should be permitted" by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 4, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $8,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

A committee for Iowa Central Railway first mortgage 5 per cent bonds headed by George E. Roosevelt of Roosevelt Son, announced yesterday that, at least for the present, it would not register its certificates of deposit permanently with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5. (AP). -The fastest time of the meeting and an almost blanket finish marked Grand Circuit racing at the State Fair Ground today.

Storm clouds are gathering, as well they might, over the potato-control provisions in the new AAA Amendment Act, which became law on Aug. 24. Though the potato provisions fill some thirty pages in the original text of the act, they received only an hour's debate in the House and less than that in the Senate.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP). -- George L. Fuller, 17, of Augusta, Ga., won the Group A match of the Junior Rifle Corps shoot today. It was one of the preliminaries to the national rifle matches which open Sept. 7.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5. -- Gold production in Russia is increasing by leaps and bounds, especially from placer workings in Siberia and Central Asia, where there are now upward of 100,000 men employed on the basis of a "grub stake" plus a percentage of the gold, with free housing and clothing.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The German Foreign Office issued a semi-official declaration today that if Ethiopia were expelled from the League of Nations Lithuania must also be expelled and argued that, on the basis of yesterday's debate in Geneva, Lithuania should be expelled anyway.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5. -- The Soviet ice-breaker Sadko reported today it would explore a region surrounding the newly discovered Arctic island in an effort to substantiate a theory the island is part of a land screen protecting the European continent from polar ice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Wholesale commodity prices declined slightly during the week ended Aug. 31, the composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics standing at 80.5, as compared with 80.8 the preceding week and 77.5 the same week a year ago. The index is based on the 1926 averages.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP). -- Secretary Morgenthau today praised the rescue work of the Coast Guard following Monday's tropical storm.

GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- Italy withdrew from the League of Nations Council table this evening during a renewed hearing on her dispute with Ethiopia. She demanded suspension of the Council on the ground that Ethiopia's representative in his speech had insulted Italy.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Steaming homeward through an early morn ing mist off the coast of Portugal today, the Cunard-White Star cruise liner Doric of 16,484 tons was ripped open to the waterline on the starboard side by a collision with the French steamer Formigny, of 2,166 tons.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 5. -- The Trades Union Congress adopted almost unanimously today a resolution declaring its faith in the collective peace system operating through the League of Nations and supporting its general council's statement of policy on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute.

Joe Bolognia could not pass up the chance yesterday to play the role of hard-boiled movie-type gunman before a real motion-picture camera and sound-recording apparatus in the office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan in Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 5. -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania received today forty-one tenders from thirty-three bidders for its $50,000,000 issue of tax anticipation notes, but the State Board, headed by Governor George H. Earle, accepted only seventeen bids, totaling $10,635,000.
When will lawmakers learn that a law, however commendable its objective, is indefensible if it be impractical to enforce? Our city's traffic rules are a conspicuously current example.

MIAMI, Sept. 5. -- Investigation into the Florida Keys hurricane deaths is expected to centre on delay in arrangements for a relief train which was sent to evacuate the veterans, but was trapped and wrecked by the storm before it could take them aboard.

HARLAN, Ky., Sept. 5 (AP). -- The dynamite-bomb assassination of Elmon Middleton, County Attorney, was blamed by four Harlan County officials tonight on reprisals for his crusade against slot machine operations in this mountain community.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The laboratory of Consumers Research, Inc., at Bowerstown, near here, where seventy employees went on strike yesterday for recognition of their union and the reinstatement of their leaders discharged for organizing the union, remained closed today.

CAPE MAY, Sept. 5. -- A resolution condemning organizations in the United States "owing allegiance to other nations" and opposing efforts to introduce communism or fascism in America was adopted tonight by delegates to the seventeenth annual convention of the New Jersey department of the American Legion, which opened here today.

RAIN again. No baseball. No tennis. There is that matter of getting a football schedule laid out. Might as well get at that now. Saturday, Oct. 12, will be the first choice. The world's series will cut off the view of the football games on Oct. 5. Where is that shiny new Football Guide edited by W.R. Okeson and pasted together by the esteemed John T. Doyle? Ah, here it is. Have at it!

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- With the filing by the Detroit Edison Company of an application for an issue of $49,000,000 of 4 per cent bonds to be used for refunding purposes, the aggregate of filings of all kinds of securities, including reorganizations and certificates of deposit, since Jan. 1 reached an aggregate of $1,918,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is studying rules and regulations for the control of activities in the over-the-counter markets and making a check through regional offices of statements by brokers and dealers seeking registration.

The rush for apartments for Fall occupancy was maintained Lhroughout the city yesterday. All along the East and West Sides of Manh attan, brokers and renting agents were especially busy signing up new tenants. Some apartments were rented furnished. Several apartments were taken in buildings in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Russian purchases of American un-manufactured cotton worth $3,559,469 and of heavy machinery valued at $1,156,632 carried July exports to that country from the United States to more than double the value of those of the preceding month and quadrupled those of the corresponding month last year, according to figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday in twenty-two principal cities in the United States showed an increase of 21.2 per cent over the corresponding week last year. The total for the five business days, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $4,261,026,000, against $3,515,887,000 a year ago.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Mrs. J. Hartley Mellick Jr., the former Caroline Prentice Hoagland, and Miss Virginia Uppercu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Inglis Uppercu of Rumson, were sponsors of a dinner and fashion show tonight at Vivian Johnson's here for the benefit of the Monmouth Memorial Hospital of Long Branch.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The National Coal Association decided formally tonight to cooperate with the government in the administration of the Guffey Coal Stabilization Act.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- George Getz, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, announced today that the committee would not engage in any extended drive for party funds this year but would rely on contributions from State organizations and small, voluntary contributions to carry on committee activities until December.

This week's heavy rainfall has caused the postponement of the start of the national open polo championship from tomorrow until Sunday and brought about a slight re-arrangement of the original schedule. Announcement of the changes was made last night at the Racquet and Tennis Club following a meeting there of the tournament committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The tragedy in the Florida Key's, where hundreds of veterans lost their lives in the Florida hurricane, was not traceable to negligence in his organization, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, asserted today.

Differences between months, which have been shifting rapidly on the Cotton Exchange in the last two weeks, moved further in the direction of carrying charges yesterday and October contracts ended with a loss of 4 points, while the July closed unchanged on the day. Other months receded 4 points each.

TORONTO, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Harold Wilson of Ingersoll tonight won his second successive heat in the ten-mile championship race for 225-cubic-inch motor boats on the Canadian national exhibition course on Lake Ontario.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HARLAN, Ky., Sept. 6. -- Tenseness seems to brood over Harlan tonight at word that Adjt. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt is leading 700 State troops here to guard against violence and fraud at tomorrow's run-off Democratic primary. This election centres in the battle for the Governorship nomination between A. H. Chandler and Thomas S. Rhea, one of the most bitter in Kentucky history.

Columbia called its football candidates yesterday and forty-one reported to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field. Throughout the day a staff of assistants measured the men for uniforms and Dr. Louis M. Rousselot, assistant team physician, passed on the candidates as to their physical fitness.

" I forget who it was," writes SOMERSET MAUGHAM, "that recommended "men for their souls' good to do each "day two things they disliked: it was "a wise man, and it is a precept that "I have followed scrupulously; for "every day I have got up and I have "gone to bed."
May I add a brief tribute to a worthy New Yorker whose untimely death occurred a few days ago?

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 6 (Reuters). -- At a luncheon given today in honor of the good-will mission from Japan headed by Katsuji Debuchi the guests were bluntly told that expansion of their country toward Australia was not wanted. Sir Frank Clarke, president of the Victoria Legislative Council, was one of the hosts who indulged in this frankness.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, is going to Geneva Sunday to proclaim the attitude of Britain not only on the Ethiopian crisis but also on the problem of collective security in Europe.

Steel ingot production not only scored a gain last month of more than 110 per cent over August, 1934, and of 24 per cent over July, 1935, but the total for the month was the largest for any month this year, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The General Electric Company, a leader in the electrical equipment manufacturing field, announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend rate on its common stock from 15 to 20 cents a share. The dividend will be payable on Oct. 25 to holders of record Sept. 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The fact that deposits of the McLellan Stores Company were seized by creditor banks in January, 1933, was "immediately responsible" for the filing by the company of a voluntary petition in bankruptcy, William W. McLellan, former president of the chain-store organization, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today at a hearing dealing with the bankruptcy.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 6. -- Hokuao dominated the running of the featured fifth race today at Narragansett Park, a mile and one-sixteenth for 4-year-olds and up. The 6-year-old roan from the stable of J.L. Roberts led from flag fall to finish to score by two lengths.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Lehigh Power Securities Corporation, reports for the twelve months ended on July 31, 1935, gross operating revenues of $34,429,109, an increase of 2 per cent over the total of $33,800,573 for the same period in 1934.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Miss Betty Jane Ferguson of Huntington, L.I., this afternoon Won the first leg on the Twilight Hour Challenge Trophy, one of the important events of the first day of the fourth annual Middletown-Goshen horse show, which opened on Historic trotting track this morning and will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 6. -- Dr. Ernest H. Gruening, Director of the Division of Territories and Island Possessions of the United States Department of the Interior, was blocked today from naming Chancellor Carlos Chardon of the University of Puerto Rico as head of the Federally financed $40,000,000 Puerto Rican reconstruction undertaking.

An armed gang of four held up employes and a customer of the St. Albans branch of the Bank of the Manhattan Company in Queens at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, escaping with $6,500 just before policemen, summoned by a girl clerk hiding in a telephone booth inside the bank, arrived.

OTTAWA, Sept. 6. -- "We will not be embroiled in any foreign quarrel where the rights of Canadians are not involved," declared Prime Minister R.B. Bennett in a radio broadcast here today. Mr. Bennett's speech, the first of a series of four, did not contain that appeal for a National government which his Liberal rival, Mackenzie King, predicted in St. John last Tuesday.

WITH the rain pouring down outside, there was mention around a table at the Yale Club yesterday noon that maybe the outdoor program around here could be resumed if they let the ball players and tennis players romp around under umbrellas.

A comprehensive "check sheet," listing the surveys necessary by industrial companies before launching new consumer products, was released yesterday by the marketing and research division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.

The Health Department announced yesterday the first drop this Summer in the weekly total of infantile paralysis cases. For the week ending yesterday morning at 9 A.M. 281 were reported, compared with 361 in the preceding week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6. -- Continuing what might be called their drive for seventh place, the Dodgers assimilated one of their most decisive defeats of the year today when they went down before Cy Blanton and the Pirates, 13 to 0.

OYSTER BAY, L.I, Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Ballantine, who are at Council Rock, their country home overlooking Oyster Bay, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Helen Ballantine.

New York City faces serious overcrowding in its junior and senior high schools this year, members of the Board of Education said yesterday. The schools, which open Monday, were already badly crowded at the close of the last school year. An increase of between 10,000 and 12,000 pupils in the secondary schools has been met with only one new high school building -- the Samuel Gompers High School at Wales and Tinton Avenues, the Bronx.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Cardinals rallied in late innings behind Dizzy Dean's effective relief hurling today and took their third consecutive victory from the Braves, 6 to 4.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- The Boerse was firm today, although not very active. Some advances of 2 points were registered, nevertheless. Among the heavy industrials, the rise was led by Vereinigtestahl's gain of 1/2 point. Chemicals were firm, I.G. Farben rising 3/4 point.

Another edition of 10,000 copies of Willa Cather's new novel, "Lucy Gayheart," has been sent to press by Knopf, bringing the total number of copies printed to 63,000. Random House reports that Gale Wilhelm's "We Too Are Drifting," has been selling at the rate of one edition a week.

With an unusual exhibition of 300 dahlia blooms representing fifty-three varieties, Mrs. William R. Simonds of Southampton, L.I. won first prize of $20 in the most important class of the First Annual Dahlia Show, which opened yesterday afternoon in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Heavy ocean swells washed the stranded steamer Dixie higher aground on French Reef, sixty miles south of Miami, as Morgan Line officials today expressed hope of refloating the ship.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Cecil Hursey, a 20-year-old Savannah grocery clerk, pedalled to victory in the fifty-mile bicycle race today, taking 7 points for his performance and winning the 1935 national amateur bicycle championship.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The race for the lead in the first round of the Glens Falls open golf tourney resulted in a quadruple tie today.

Louis D. Lighton has joined Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a producer, and as his first assignment will make a film based on Hudyard Kipling's "Captains Courageous," in which Freddie Bartholomew, the boy actor, will be starred.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Cardinal Prince, star pacer owned by E.J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., and driven by the veteran Sep Palin, suffered his first defeat of the year as the Grand Circuit meeting closed today.

It has been rumored that the Administration may take the large sum of money appropriated for building a fine embassy in Moscow and use it to build in some other foreign capital where they don't write curt notes to Mr. HULL.

With the cancellation of another day of play in the national tennis championship at Forest Hills yesterday, the committee in charge at least could enjoy the dubious satisfaction of having equaled a record.

In the old days the city fathers figured out expenditures first and revenues afterward. That made their task very simple and agreeable; so long as the constitutional limit was respected they did not have to sit up nights worrying about where the money was coming from.

For a number of years the Long Island Chamber of Commerce has been conducting a campaign for the improvement of Jones Inlet. If there ever had been any doubts as to the vital necessity of deepening, stabilizing and controlling this much-traveled waterway, through which thousands of fishermen pass each year, they certainly were dispelled by the recent series of mishaps to fishing craft.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, said yesterday that the selling of liquor in port on steamships which did not hold a State liquor license was a clear violation of the law, but that any action against the steamship companies was up to the police authorities.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia will arrive today from Naples, Genoa and other Mediterranean ports. Among her passengers is James Gerard, former United States Ambassador to Germany; Iglesias Ambrosio, Spanish Ambassador to Mexico; Max Steuer, New York lawyer, with Mrs. Steuer.

NEWARK, Sept. 6. -- The Newark Bears gained a half game on their fourth-place rivals, the Baltimore Orioles, tonight when they divided a double-header with Albany while the Birds were losing to Syracuse.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Jayne Manners, film actress and former New York show girl, reiterated today to a District Attorney's investigator her previous assertion that she knew nothing about the strange disappearance of Supreme Court Justice Joseph F. Crater in New York five years ago.

By a 3-to-1 vote, the Appellate Division overruled yesterday the objections of insurgents and handed down a decision which gives first place on the ballot in the Sept. 17 primaries to the regular Democratic candidates for county committee-men in fifteen of the twenty-three Assembly districts in Manhattan, The court reversed Supreme Court Justice Rosenman.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6. -- King Peter's twelfth birthday celebration began in his absence this morning with the firing of 101 guns. By 6. A.M, all roads leading to the; great Banjica military parade ground were crowded with persons on their way to see the birthday parade.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

It is the last half of September that will find Broadway hitting something like an old-time stride. The boys really will be jockeying around then for opening dates. They already are jockeying around, in fact, and some of the dates listed below certainly will have changed when the time comes.

President Roosevelt and the New Deal were praised last night at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the National Negro Baptist Convention at the Bronx Coliseum. Dr. William E.B. Dubois, Professor of Sociology at Atlanta University, told the 3,000 men and women at the meeting that under the New Deal Negro labor was receiving its due share of recognition.

ROME, Sept. 6. -- The firm attitude assumed by the Italian delegation at Geneva yesterday, especially its refusal to have any contacts with Ethiopian representatives, is heartily approved by the Italian press. The speech of Professor Gaston Jeze, Ethiopia's French spokesman, is especially resented, although the press carefully refrained from printing an adequate account of it.

Dr. Heber Harper of Teachers College, Columbia University, who was the American adviser at the Anglo-American Institute of Moscow University, which closed in July after several hundred English-speaking students had arrived in the country for study, said on his return yesterday that he did not think anti-Soviet propaganda had caused the cancellation.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- In trying to escape from a police officer who was taking him to headquarters after his arrest for allegedly stealing 60 cents from a gum-vending machine, Michael Januzzi, 18 years old, of 112 North Sixth Avenue, was shot and is in a critical condition tonight at Mount Vernon Hospital.

Somewhere between PWA and WPA, between Federal, city and borough initiative, between local pride and the desire to have somebody else pay for local improvements, Queens Boulevard has got lost. It stretches out toward Jamaica, beckoning the home-coming Long Island motorist.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The texts of President Roosevelt's reply, under date of Sept. 2, 1935, to a letter from Roy W. Howard, as well as Mr. Howard's letter, under date of Aug. 26, follow:

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray. printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Inclement weather checked the expansion of initial Fall retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week. The results reported by department store executives were decidedly spotty. Some stores were said to have shown increases over last year of 2 to 3 per cent, but average sales for the week were estimated as being close to 5 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago.

Brevity, the Joseph E. Widener colt which many thought was bumped out of his winning chance in the Hopeful, will have an opportunity to vindicate himself this afternoon at Aqueduct in what looms as one of the most interesting runnings of the Junior Champion Stakes.

VIENNA, Sept. 6. -- Still another Austrian concentration camp has been created by the Heimwehr Governor of Upper Austria, Count Revertera. He has instituted a camp in which beggars will be confined and forced to labor.

New State and municipal bond financing scheduled for next week amounts to $13,920,441, against this week's revised total of $62,208,419, most of which was $50,000,000 Commonwealth of Pennsylvania tax-anticipation notes. The weekly average for the year to date now is $25,307,923.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 6. -- The board of trustees of Lehigh University today elected Clement Clarence Williams, dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Iowa, as president of Lehigh to succeed Dr. Charles Russ Richards, recently resigned.

The devastating Florida hurricane, although considerably moderated, stopped off long enough on its way north in the direction of Maine to cause an unestimated amount of damage and privation along the south coast of New Jersey, according to reports yesterday.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 6. -- The unemployment problem is worse than ever before, despite improving business, Hugh S. Johnson asserted tonight in calling for a fundamental interpretation of the Constitution to restore the NRA.

President ROOSEVELT'S letter to Mr. ROY HOWARD brings to mind another letter written by another President. In Civil War times ABRAHAM LINCOLN wrote a letter in defense of his Administration, with a renewal of his resolve to save the Union at all hazards, together with an argument that the war to save it was not a "failure," as some Northern newspapers were complaining.

A syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $3,500,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts Metropolitan water bonds maturing on July 1, 1936, to 1965. The price paid for the bonds was 101.04 for 2 1/2s.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Late batting rallies today brought the Browns a pair of victories over Washington, 11 to 8 and 2 to 1.

TORONTO, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Harold Wilson of Ingersoll, Ont., drove his Little Miss Canada IV to the world championship for 225 cubic inch hydroplanes over the Lake Ontario water course tonight.

Those who criticized the treatment of the borders of the wide walk along Fifth Avenue and Central Park must now be disposed to praise the Commissioner of Parks for sticking to his plans. In the interstices of stone a kind of grass has made the most of its opportunity, and has furnished what appears to be a stretch of greensward.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Max Baer's boxing drill today, his twelfth of the grind for his meeting with Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium Sept. 24, showed him in punching form that, it was agreed by observers, was the most impressive he has displayed in camp.

With the news of the day distinctly favoring the side of the advance, the share market responded briskly yesterday, leading issues closing 1 to 4 points higher on the day in the heaviest trading since Aug. 13. The rise enabled the market to better the high mark set on Nov. 9, 1931, against which all recent comparisons have been made; the market level is now the best since September, 1931.

Continued pressure against the fdreign exchanges yesterday carried the franc down to 6.59 cents, the lowest price since June 12, sent the pound sterling to $4.93A, the cheapest price since June 21, and the 'Swiss franc to 32.50_ cents, the lowest figure since June 1.
New bonds totaling $30,799 000 were offered publicly in this market this Week, compared with $57,410,000 last week and with $31,628,000 in the week a year ago.

Commodity futures prices were mixed yesterday in reasonably active trading. December sugar continued strong, adding 8 points to its gain of 13 points in the two preceding days. In the cash markets, cotton, wool tops, oats, flour, corn and lard were higher, while rye, rubber, silk and tin were lower.

A declaration of war on the swastika and the Friends of the New Germany in this country was made public yesterday by the Friends of Democracy, an organization addressing itself likewise to Americans of German origin.

David Burnstine, the highest ranking contract bridge master on the lists of the American Bridge League and one of the fourteen "first masters" listed by the United States Bridge Association, led a field of thirty-six invited experts last night at the close of the second of five sessions of play at the Hotel Ambassador to determine the 1935 masters' individual championship.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association signaled the start of its thirty-sixth Academy of Music season today.

Hurricanes, floods and heavy rain storms retarded consumer buying in various sections of the country this week, while wholesale markets turned quieter, in spite of substantial reorders, as retailers awaited further evidence of the strength of buying power, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- In celebration of the birth seventy-five years ago of the late Jane Addams, founder of the organization, the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom met this afternoon at the home of Felix M. Warburg, banker. More than 200 guests listened to talks by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, Miss Pearl S. Buck, Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Miss Katherine Devereux Blake, who presided, and Dr. Alice Hamilton of Harvard University.

Increased sales in August over the same month last year were reported by nine chain-store and mail-order companies which to date have made public their figures. Of these, only two showed a decrease for the eight months' volume, both of which were losses of 1.2 per cent below the same period in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected soon to extend the date by which brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market must obtain registration if they are to continue any activities which involve interstate commerce.

With four addresses scheduled and one or two more tentatively arranged, Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange, faces a busy Autumn. On next Wednesday he will speak to the twentieth annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association in Atlantic City on the public relations of the Exchange.

A suit to compel John T. Madden, dean of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University and president of the Alexander Hamilton Institute, to join with other stockholders of the institute in voting to oust the present management at a meeting of the stockholders in Jersey City on Sept. 20 was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- A veritable potpourri of Congressional bills fell before Presidential vetoes today as Mr. Roosevelt plodded through his task of clearing away the backwash of Congress.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 6. -- After trailing by three holes at the twelfth tee, Charles Metzger Jr. of the home club rallied today to beat Jack Gerlin of the Old Country Club, 1 up, in the final of the fourteenth annual junior championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Rockville Country Club.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 6. -- Charles A. Waters, State Treasurer, sold today $7,420,000 of the $50,000,000 tax-anticipation notes that were offered at par and 1 1/2 per cent interest. When the bids were opened yesterday it was decided to sell notes only to bidders whose bids were on that basis and $10,635,000 of notes was disposed of.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Miss Hester Lansing Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lansing Parmelee Reed, made her debut tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at Windy Hill, their Summer home in this colony. The party was similar to those given for her sisters, Miss Julia Reed, last season, and the former Miss Ruth Reed, now Mrs. Samuel Hazard Gillespie Jr., during a previous Autumn.

In an opinion that attacked the Nazi Government of Germany Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky yesterday dismissed five of the six men held on charges of unlawful assembly in the riot during which the swastika flag on the bow of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen was torn down on July 26.

A small, twenty-eight foot whale-boat with seven or more Sea Scouts aboard has been missing since Wednesday and last night was believed wrecked or stranded somewhere along the Hudson River between Kingston, N.Y., and New York City.

Among the big moments of Broadway in the early Fall there was, naturally, last night's opening of the "Folie Parisienne" at the French Casino. Last Winter Mr. Carroll's former playhouse played host to the "Folies Bergere Revue,'' and Times Square and adjacent sectors knew pretty much what to expect.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6. -- Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff's appeal for peace before the League of Nations Council yesterday and an editorial in Izvestia commenting on it make it clear that the Soviet Union has the friendliest relations with Italy, but will support the League covenant against Italy if necessary.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- After getting a terrific dusting from wind, sea and rain this morning and proving practically nothing, the six-meter yachts competing in the elimination series being conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club came back for more in the afternoon, sailed two races and had their number reduced by two.

The public utility holding companies of the nation, as an industry, are determined to test the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935, reports to the contrary notwithstanding. A preliminary statement, outlining the course of action, together with the reaction of the industry as a whole to the new regulatory law, will be made public in the latter part of next week.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Olney B. Mairs will give a buffet supper for forty persons tomorrow evening before the "amateur night" at the John Drew Memorial Theatre. A final rehearsal was held this afternoon for the pony ballet in the "amateur night" in which twelve young girls of Southampton and East Hampton have been trained by John Larenegan of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey and of the Edison Electric Institute, filed today with the Federal Power Commission the first application for permission to be an officer or director of more than one utility power company.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Speeding homeward on a special train, 213 passengers and 69 of the crew from the steamship Dixie bought newspapers at every stop to read again and again the accounts of their ordeal and rescue after nearly seventy-two hours at the mercy of the hurricane.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Essex defeated Kent by 137 runs in the closing match of the English County cricket season today. The result leaves the standing of the leading clubs unchanged, Yorkshire having clinched the championship two weeks ago.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Roger Hughes, 15, of Youngstown, Ohio, making a 368 out of a possible 400, won the individual championship match today in the national competition of the junior rifle corps' small-arms firing school. The National Rifle Association rifle and pistol matches will open tomorrow.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, accused President Roosevelt today of attempting to "uproot" the foundation of the United States and substitute "the colored putty of his weird policies for the hard rock foundation that is the Constitution."
Three robbers seized a brief ease containing $12,000 worth of jewels from a salesman on Forsyth Street at 12:15 P.M. yesterday and escaped in an automobile.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Eighteen veterans and nineteen newcomers are striving for places on the New York Giants football team, which is holding its pre-season practice at the Blue Hill Country Club. Coach Steve Owen had his squad out for its second scrimmage of the week this afternoon after a lengthy blackboard drill in the morning.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 6. -- W. Winter, British champion, moved into first place in the international chess masters' tournament at the Klub Szachowy, the fourth round of which was contested tonight. He defeated Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland in a hard-fought queen's pawn opening, lasting sixty moves. Dr. Tartakower, who suffered his first defeat, dropped into second place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Class railroads of the United States not only failed by $55,165,546 to earn their fixed charges in the first half of 1935, but, after allowing for additional contingent charges, sustained a net income deficit of $62,025,201, according to figures made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Paul Meyer, acting chief inspector of the Hospital Department, was removed from office yesterday by Hospital Commissioner S.S. Gold-water after having been found guilty at a departmental trial of three charges of official misconduct.

The president and three other officials of a Brooklyn painters' union, now on strike, were booked soon before midnight at the Bergen Street station, Brooklyn, on a charge of extorting $300 from Louis Rogoff, a boss painter, of 785 East Second Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Augie Galan, who tripled in the eighth inning to tie the score, hit a home run in the tenth today and for the second day in succession the Cubs took an overtime 3-to-2 decision from the Phillies.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Exactly 117 business men, thirty-three women and eleven musicians, according to tonight's count, are ready to do their part for Montclair's "old red barn." The business men will paint, the women will supply food and the musicians will play to protect the half-century-old Erie Railroad station at Walnut Street from becoming a curiosity.
We were all kicking about the hot Summer. Why, New York City and its suburbs were about the swellest Summer resort for all residents and those who chose to visit us.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- The Cologne radio station continued to broadcast today the thunder of cannon and the rattle of machine guns as the Sixth Army Corps manoeuvres were resumed. Chancellor Adolf Hitler arrived on the scene of the German manoeuvres at Lunaberg at about the time President Albert Lebrun arrived for the French manoeuvres at Champagne.

Harry A. Gordon, referee, filed a report in the Kings County Supreme Court yesterday holding that 410 purchasers of real estate mortgage bonds from S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of New York, now in receivership, had been defrauded by false representations of salesmen.

Protestant Episcopal institutions inherit the bulk of the estate of the Rev. Dr. Olin Scott Roche, rector emeritus of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in West Twentieth Street, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate. The value of the estate was not disclosed as the petition for probate has not been filed.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 6. -- Three former amateur golf champions practicing for the national amateur tourney at The Country Club today tallied their scores and found them high in the seventies.

Relief teachers who were dismissed for participation in a WPA stoppage on Aug. 21, although being denied assignments to educational projects now, will receive individual consideration as to their eligibility for appointments in the future, the Board of Superintendents decided yesterday.

Declaring that a borough commissioner of parks had no authority to give a lease on park property for a definite time, Justice Albert Cohn in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday ordered the Morris Yacht Club to vacate the quarters it had occupied for forty years in Pelham Bay Park, in compliance with an order issued by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

TRENTON, Sept. 6. -- State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin disclosed today that receipts from the 2 per cent retail sales tax for July, the first month of collection of the new levy for emergency relief, amounted to $1,872,675.

A mass resignation of members of the Teachers Union because of left wing activity in the ranks of the organization is expected to follow the resignation of the union's officers at an executive board meeting in about ten days, Dr. Henry R. Linville, president of the union, said yesterday.

The new securities corporation of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., which is being organized by a group of partners in J.P. Morgan Co., will be completely separated from the latter firm, it was shown in the certificate of incorporation which was, filed yesterday in Albany.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt today appointed Stewart McDonald of St. Louis as Federal Housing Administrator to succeed James A. Moffett.

Although sales of October contracts by houses doing government business were estimated at 25,000 bales or more again yesterday, differences on the Cotton Exchange narrowed instead of widened and October closed 8 points higher than on Thursday, compared with a gain of only 4 points on the July.

The domination of the male and the inferiority of women may be "mere fictional invention," but the idea is so firmly rooted that nothing can shake it, according to Dr. Alfred Adler, noted Viennese psychologist, who arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for his fourth season as lecturer at Long Island Hospital Medical School.

Efforts to mediate the strike of shipping clerks in the women's garment industry were postponed yesterday afternoon until Monday morning, it was announced by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Women all over the world Began yesterday on the seventy-fifth anniversary of the birth of the late Jane Addams a campaign to obtain fifty million signatures to a "Peoples' Mandate to Governments" to end war.

GENEVA, Sept. 6. -- Anxious to give the impression of business as usual and to soften the effects of Italy's refusal to engage in discussion with Ethiopia across its table, the Council of the League of Nations turned today to routine League affairs.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Psychology holds neglected keys which would help solve present unrest, Dr. Albert T. Poffenberger of Columbia University, president of the American Psychology Association, said tonight in the annual presidential address to the associations convention.
The fifth annual hunts meeting under the auspices of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association will be staged this afternoon over the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Rye, N.Y.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Representative Snell, Republican leader of the House, commenting on President Roosevelt's letter to Roy W. Howard, said today that "if it hadn't been for the New Deal, recovery would now be much further advanced."

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Packers are lees aggressive in buying hogs than they were and are waiting to learn the effect of the recent advance in the price of fresh pork on the consuming public. As a result of the slower demand prices at the yards dropped today 10 to 30 cents a hundredweight, packing sows losing most.

Business leaders generally and others yesterday welcomed President Roosevelt's announcement that his basic program of reform and recovery legislation had reached "substantial completion" and that business would now have a "breathing spell." Many said that the effect would be beneficial.

TORONTO, Sept. 6. -- Because the plaintiff failed to comply with an order directing him to put up $1,000 additional security for costs, Fred H. Barlow, K.C., Master in Chambers at Osgoode Hall, today dismissed with costs the action brought by James A. Noell, real estate agent of Los Angeles, against the Toronto General Trusts Corporation, the National Trust Company and George Roy Sproat, executors of the estate of Charles Vance Millar.

In a setting of real pine trees and amid the chirping of crickets, city and State officials opened yesterday afternoon a picturesque exhibition designed to inform the nation's millions that New York State has everything that can contribute to the happiness of the traveler and recreation seeker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt's statement in his correspondence with Roy W. Howard that his basic program "has now reached substantial completion" and that the "breathing spell" for business to go forward without further disruptive legislatin is here, not only inspired confidence among many business men but was approved by members of his party in Congress.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6 -- Three separate investigations began today to determine whether war veterans who died in the tropical hurricane which swept the Florida Keys could have been saved.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- A long-awaited announcement of the "substantial completion" of the experimental phases of the administration program as it affects business was made today by President Roosevelt.

ATHENS, Sept. 6. -- Identifications given to buildings excavated in the Athenian Agora by American archaeologists under the leadership of Professor T. Leslie Shear of Princeton University, are disputed by Professor Wilhelm Doerpfeld, dean of German archaeologists, who is known for his explorations on the site of ancient Troy, in the Ionian Islands and in the area adjacent to that excavated by the Americans.

President Roosevelt is being criticized for his contemplated speaking tour. It is argued that he should not stay away from Washington in these crucial times, when he should be near his soundest advisers in the capital.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6. -- The cry "in the name of humanity, cannot Italy be stopped," was made here today at the sixty-first annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union in the opening address by the president, Mrs. Ida B. Wise Smith of Evanston, Ill.

Falling on a background of favorable news from the business and financial worlds, President Roosevelt's letter to Roy W. Howard, promising a "breathing spell" from legislative reforms, caused a sharp rise in stocks and corporation bonds yesterday.

The Rev. Thomas A. Daly, for thirty-six years a priest of the Paulist Community and who has conducted preaching missions in every part of the United States, will today take over his duties as newly appointed pastor of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, the "mother parish" of the community.

Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of fine arts, Carnegie Institute, announced last evening the names of the six artists, three Europeans and three Americans, who will comprise the jury of award for the 1935 Carnegie international exhibition of paintings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade early today as a result of buying induced by strength in Winnipeg, by reports that announcement would be made tonight by the Canadian Wheat Board as to the minimum price to be paid to producers and by persistent purchases of futures here, which were regarded as removing hedges against further liberal sales of flour.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6. -- First round pairings for the national amateur golf championship, starting Monday at The Country Club, were announced tonight. The first match is scheduled for 8 A.M., and there will be five-minute intervals between the contests.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 6. -- When the wind struck Matecumbe Keys Monday night the Russell family, prosperous pioneer residents of the keys, numbered seventy-nine persons. Today only eleven are alive.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 6. -- President Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano appointed a new Cabinet tonight as follows:
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6. -- Sorely beset as they are, the Giants were faced with still another misfortune today when even the magic spell which Harold Schumacher has held over the Reds these past few years threatened to desert them in their greatest hour of need.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.1 point to 12.6.2 on Tuesday from 126.3 on the preceding Tuesday. The index of food products prices declined as a result of lower pork and sugar figures. Beef prices, however, advanced.

Holders of Bush Terminal first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on April 1, 1952, have been notified by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, successor trustee, that the instalments of interest which matured on the bonds on April 1 and Oct. 1, 1933 and 1934, and April 1, 1935, well be paid tomorrow and after at the office of the bank.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Governor George H. Earle demanded tonight the withdrawal of the United States team from the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games.
Both sides of the burlesque strike still were deadlocked yesterday as the Burlesque Artists Association doled out about $2,500 to chorus girls and other performers pending settlement of their fight.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 6. -- Owen Johnson, the novelist, for the twelfth successive year won the most important prize today at the annual Stockbridge Grange Fair in Town Hall with his display of farm and garden products. He had 130 entries, representing the largest display ever grown on his estate, Ingleside.

One of the most stubborn myths of the depression era has been the belief that a depreciated currency is a great stimulus to exports. By lowering the value of a currency in terms of other currencies the prices of exported goods are made cheaper, while those of imported products become correspondingly dearer.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in August aggregated $24,266,464,474, a decline of 7.3 per cent from the turnover in July, but a gain of 21.8 per cent over August of last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- An official estimate of 300 dead among the World War veterans in the hurricane which swept the Florida Keys was submitted to the Federal Emergency Relief Administration by its representative in Florida.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (AP). -- An earnest appeal to Catholic priests to "stop, look and listen" before acting or speaking, as they are being watched for material to be used against the church, was issued today by the German Catholic episcopacy.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Officials of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company awarded today a contract for $9,000,000 in equipment trust certificates to the First Boston Corporation, highest bidder.

Mayor La Guardia disapproved yesterday of forty-four of forty-six proposed "white-collar" engineering projects ranging all the way from a survey of radio interference to a survey of tent caterpillar eradication and suggested that the funds appropriated for those projects should be transferred to "worthwhile white-collar projects."

Abe Feldman, East Side contender for the world's light-heavyweight crown, halted Mickey McAvoy of Ridgewood in fifty-one seconds of the third session of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Luna Park indoor arena last night. Part of the proceeds of the show will go to the John Sherman Association of Brooklyn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 6. -- Miss Frances McElwain, skipper, and her crew, consisting of Miss Frances J. Williams and Miss Katherine Johnson, today won the women's national sailing championship for the Cohasset Yacht Club, member of the South Shore Women's Yacht Race Association of Massachusetts.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 6. -- A new appeal to the League of Nations to seek a settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute at its present session is contained in a communique that Emperor Haile Selassie issued today dealing with the conciliation commission's finding.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association sought a conference yesterday with American steamship owners with a view to drafting an agreement on salaries and working conditions for radio operators on merchant ships.

Continued rain through Thursday night and yesterday morning ended all hope of starting the national open polo championship at Meadow Brook tomorrow. Early yesterday the tournament committee put the opening game of the tournament off until Tuesday, when Hurlingham and the Hurricanes will play their twice-postponed match on International Field, starting at 4:30 o'clock.
One further word about those lowly pulp magazines; a point or two not coveted by your recent editorial and which Pulp Publisher A.A. Wynn failed to mention in his letter of defense.

NORWICH, England, Sept. 6. -- A new triumph of laboratory science comparable in some respects to the production of heavy hydrogen was announced today to the British Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Gustav Hertz, physicist at the Siemens engineering works in Berlin.

NEWFPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- Despite, disagreeable weather today there was considerable entertaining both in the afternoon and evening. Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. entertained at a dinner at Terra Mare; Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick were hosts at Ocean View; Colonel and Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin entertained at Auton House; Miss Virginia French gave a luncheon at the Muenchinger King and Mrs. Marion Eppley had luncheon guests at Beacon Rock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Widespread dullness was noted by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly report on the business situation in several South American countries, though there were some highlights to relieve the gloom.

A frog, Prohibiton by name; age, two and one-half days; size, three-eighths of an inch; weight, unknown, battled briskly yesterday for a dry cause, but, like its namesake, the Eighteenth Amendment, went down to defeat.

The use of half-cent and mill coins to permit payment of the correct sales tax would be a nuisance on both sides of the counter. And quite unnecessary since it would be so easy to make the payment equitable by following the standard rule of rounding out to the nearest cent.
