HARRINGTON, Del., Sept. 6 (AP). -- A Pennsylvania Railroad freight train piled up today at a culvert which flood waters had washed out, killing Robert H. Lane, the fireman, and Charles Williamson the head brakeman, both of Wilmington.
TORONTO, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals clinched the International League pennant tonight by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, in a mound battle between Ray Fritz and Whitey Hitcher.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that dealings would be suspended within ten days in the securities of six companies because of their failure to comply with permanent registration requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
During the past few months several acquaintances, disgusted at the insincerity of professional politicians, have voiced the intention of refraining in future from voting.

Acting Mayor Deutsch said yesterday that the 1936 budget could be balanced by reducing the $20,000,000 reserve included under the bankers' agreement; by instituting a flat 4 per cent cut on each department's non-salary expenses and by other economies which he would present to the Board of Estimate.

ROME, Sept. 6. -- There can be no doubt concerning the motives that prompted Premier Benito Mussolini to hold general army manoeuvres on a hitherto unprecedented scale just a week before the League of Nations Council meeting that was called upon to examine the possibility of applying sanctions on the eve of an outbreak of war in East Africa.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 7. -- A measuring rod by which one may learn whether one is at heart a radical or a conservative, Red or reactionary, was described to the American Psychological Association here today by Theodore F. Lentz of Washington University, St. Louis.

SAVAGE'S life is one of the extraordinary stories of literary history, the life of a sponger, spendthrift, egotist, libertine, blackmailer, next door to a murderer, and (infinitely worse) possibly a pander to one of the lowest brothels in town; yet he made and kept his mark in the world.

SHORT CREEK, Ariz., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Blinking lights in a region where a colony of men are reported to have several wives each caused authorities today to suspect a "conspiracy against justice" by a group called "the last of the old Mormons."

THE great majority of American children now attend full-time schools until they reach the age of 16 years. Moreover, every careful student of current trends toward smaller families, child-labor legislation and changing economic conditions is convinced that within a very few years more than 90 per cent of all young persons will be require, by law or necessity to remain in full-time school attendance until after they are 18.

Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, founder and president of the Carroll Club, opened the sixteenth season of that organization last week, on her return from France and Italy, with the appointment of a new program director -- Miss Anne Daly. For twelve years Miss Daly has directed the health program of Mount St. Vincent College at Mount St. Vincent-on-the-Hudson, and for the last four Summers has been associated with the Carroll Club's camp at Pawling, N.Y.

MINEOLA, Sept. 7. -- An order signed this morning in Patchogue, L.I., by Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman, and filed in the County Clerk's office here today, grants an interlocutory decree of divorce to Marjorie Post Hutton, daughter of the founder of General Foods, Inc., from Edward F. Hutton, chairman of the board of directors of that company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The date by which registrations of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter markets must become effective has been postponed until Jan. 1, a delay of three months, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 (AP). -- German Army officers expressed satisfaction with and foreign military observers voiced admiration tonight of Germany's large-scale manoeuvres involving an estimated 200,000 soldiers in ten corps areas.

BERLIN. -- Almost unique among the nations of Europe -- after sixteen years of post-war indigence -- Germany is paying her way. She is paying more easily than wealthy Britain or thrifty Finland. She has cash inexhaustible for "work-creation," for soldiers, for barracks, for ministerial buildings and pompous railway stations, for concentration camps for street parades, for villas of Nazi magnates and sometimes of Nazi underlings.

THE greatest Summer travel record since 1929 has been achieved during 1935. In the last few months more than 50,000,000 Americans -- 30 per cent more than last year -- temporarily broke the bonds of job and home to find rest, recreation or the thrill of discovery in vacation spots throughout the world.

WHILE both major and minor novelists of Russia have been made available for English and American readers, a pall of mystery hangs over even the major Russian poets as far as the Anglo-Saxon reader is concerned.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 7. -- Winning his fifth-round game with A. Frydman of Poland tonight, after scoring in his adjourned game with V. Mikenas of Lithuania from the second round, Dr. S. Tartakower, captain of Poland's international team at Warsaw, regained first place in the master's tournament at Klub Szachowy.

The French, who are great ones for solidifying bits of wisdom in maxims, have a saying Qui veut noyer son chien l'accuse de la rage. He who wishes to drown his dog accuses him of being mad. The proverb was flung at Italy by the Ethiopians last week at a meeting of the League of Nations Council.

VIENNA, Sept. 7. -- More than half the Austrian trade deficit this year will be covered by revenues from tourist traffic, it was revealed today. The revenue from tourist trade, is expected to total $40,000,000. The number of foreign visitors increased from 45 to 50 per cent and in some parts of the country by more than 140 per cent.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Competition of millers for undamaged wheat has raised the cash premium to the highest figure attained in years at this season, market authorities said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Acting under instructions from the German Government, Ambassador Luther called on Secretary Hull today to lodge a formal, although oral, protest against the action of Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in freeing five men arrested in the riot aboard the Bremen on July 26.

AT one time or another almost every one has been stopped suddenly by the appearance in the street of some bonneted and befeathered and spinsterish figure with velvet choker and high-buttoned shoes and a general fantastic but intriguing air of a different period and setting.

PELZER, S.C., Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Pelzer union of the United Textile Workers of America today ratified an agreement between the shop committee of the union and the management of the Pelzer Manufacturing Company to end an eight-week strike.

TWO books by Alexandra David-Neel lie before me: "Arjopa," telling of this explorer's pilgrimage to the sacred city of Lhasa, and "Meister und Schueler," where she endeavors to give us a birdseye view of the Tibetan religion.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 7. -- Charged with murdering her 9-year-old stepdaughter Marilyn, Mrs. Ada Schueler, 25-year-old wife of Oscar J. Schueler, vice president of Schueler Brothers, Inc., manufacturers of soft drinks, is held tonight without bail pending arraignment before the grand jury for Fairfield County.

Winthrop Parkhurst quotes at length from Macaulay's essay on Southey's "Colloquies" to bear out his thesis that any governmental interference in the economic life of a nation -- we take it Mr. Parkhurst has in mind the United States of the present day -- is to be discouraged.

Even though, technically, two weeks of Summer weather remain on the calendar, restless stirrings among the memberships of the leading organizations of women throughout the country presage impending activity in their ranks. Plans already made or in formation indicate that this Fall will be notable for several significant movements in the development of the major groups, and for the energy and spirit with which clubwomen launch their programs for the coming year.
BUFFALO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Art Chester of Chicago and Roger Don Rae of Lemont, Ill., cornered all of the honors today in the opening of the third annual Buffalo air races, before 7,000 spectators.

GENEVA, Sept. 7. -- What is now being decided here in the Council of the League of Nations is really whether sovereign States are capable of uniting in common action to prevent war. This is still an open question after fifteen years of effort for peace.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- If Joe Louis doesn't succeed in stopping Max Baer in the first round or two, there is a possibility that the former heavyweight champion's stiff right hand counters will reward him with just such a victory as the Brown Bomber hopes to score.

The stories in this volume, which are taken from the book of Genesis, were adapted from the Yiddish and translated into German and are now put for the first time within the reach of English-speaking children. The author has kept the flavor of the Old Testament; his retellings have the vigor of folk literature and are pleasantly lacking in the sentimentality which so often disfigures rewritten versions of the Bible for young people.

PURCHASE, N.Y. Sept. 7. -- More than 700 persons attended the Harvest Festival held here tonight in a large tent erected at Ophir Farm, the Whitelaw Reid estate, to aid the Summer play schools of the Child Study Association. Many of the guests arrived in rough-riding costumes and others came in jeans and overalls.

A fierce competitive battle between recalcitrant jute mills in Calcutta and those holding to a production agreement looms after Feb. 1, when the current pact expires, if the former producers do not return to a shorter work week, it was predicted here yesterday in the local burlap market. Approximately fourteen of the smaller mills have adopted a fifty to sixty hour week, whereas the remaining fifty-five are continuing on a forty-hour basis.

If the price of scrap steel continues to rise from its present level, the independent steel producers, who have been relatively heavier consumers of scrap than the larger units, will lose part of the advantage that they have held for several years over the huge integrated steel companies, according to steel executives.

PIRAEUS, Greece, Sept. 7. -- While officially condemning Italy's Ethiopian campaign as an imperialist attempt to subdue a free people, the Soviet Union is furthering the Fascist aims and profiting from them by exporting supplies to the Italian camps in Africa.

DEREK BENTLEY, after months of idleness and dissipation in Macassar, his allowance cut off due to the death of his father, jumped at the chance of even a second mate's berth on the Chinese tramp Tsien Fu, but had he known of the skullduggery afoot and the dangers into which he was to run, it is doubtful if he would ever have boarded her, despite his enforced inactivity and depleted funds.

The problem of setting up a city budget for 1936 within the $539,695,777 limit set by Controller Frank J. Taylor was complicated further yesterday with the submission of additional departmental requests for $105,172,048 to Budget Director Rufus E. McGahan.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were principally for future months, rather than for September. Calls for this month were few and, except for one block of foreign bonds, were all for municipal loans. The month's total of prepayments is now $350,304,000, compared with $233,146,000 in August and $156,124,000 in September, 1934, at corresponding dates.

TO make life easier for the child at odds with his environment has been the aim of a study carried on during the past year under the auspices of the Jewish Board of Guardians. While the venture into a field which continues to puzzle psychologists is still in the experimental stage, it already promises to throw new light on the general problem of the non-social child.

Today will mark the reopening of numerous churches which have been closed for all or part of the Summer, the return of many of the pastors from their annual vacations and in some of the edifices the resumption of Sunday evening worship.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 6. -- The Corn Belt farmer has been notified to make up his mind within the next few weeks whether he wants another corn-hog control program or not. Since that notification is coupled with the subtle warning that uncontrolled production might result in a return to the prices of 1932-34 and since there is a strong feeling that the AAA is sincerely watchful of the farmers' interest, an affirmative vote is anticipated.

With only one new building to relieve congestion the city's public school system will be in full swing again tomorrow morning when 1,200,000 children and 36,000 teachers return to their class rooms for the Fall term.

THROUGH Z: On Thursday the French Academy completed the dictionary of words in good usage which it started forty-nine years and ten months ago. The last word was zygomatique; that which is zygomatique has to do with the cheekbone. Webster's Dictionary has half a page after zygomatic (the English version), culminating in the impressive zyzzogeton, a genus of South American leaf hopper.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7. -- Miss Ethelyn McKinney will give a tea dance and garden party at her home, Insfree, on Sept. 14 to introduce her niece, Miss Jean McKinney, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Glen Ford McKinney. After being graduated from the Edgewood School, Miss McKinney spent some time abroad.

HONOLULU, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The luckless schooner Seth Parker, once proud broadcast ship that became a fish carrier with the Hawaiian Tuna Packers, labored through mid-Pacific waters today depending on a worn out set of pumps to keep her afloat after she had sprung a leak, while a Coast Guard patrol boat raced to her aid.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7. -- Forty years ago a small group of well-to-do men met at the Newport Golf Club and played the first national amateur golf championship. There were thirty-two, most of them from the East, and Charles B. Macdonald became the first champion when he defeated C.E. Sands, 12 and 11.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- A list of the fourth class of candidates for naval flight training was made public today by the Navy Department.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Numerous telegrams and letters testifying to a favorable reaction to President Roosevelt's announcement yesterday that his recovery program had reached the point where business could have a "breathing spell" arrived at Hyde Park House today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Rutgers University will open its 169th year on Monday, Sept. 16, when a freshman class, limited to 400 students, will report for the annual orientation period designated as Freshman Week. The first term will be formally started Sept. 20, with the convocation of faculty and students in the gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Industrial activity in the last week of August was somewhat curtailed by holiday influences, but for the entire month the weekly index showed a greater-than-seasonal gain over July, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey.

Through a door bearing the legend "This Building Closed" walked yesterday a steady stream of young women seeking registration as members in the new cooperative residence plan of the Margaret Louisa Y.W.C.A., 29 East Sixteenth Street, just off Union Square.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals swept their four-game series with Boston by drubbing the last-place Braves by 8 to 5 today for their sixth consecutive triumph.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7. -- About 500 of the young married couples, debutantes, subdebutantes and their escorts attended the third Summer dance at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. Dancing took place on the outdoor platform.

The striking shipping clerks' union plans a demonstration of some 4,000 pickets in the garment district tomorrow morning if the seven employers' associations fail to reach an agreement at the postponed conference with union leaders, it was announced yesterday by Philip Gosseen, manager of the Ladies Apparel Shipping Clerks Union.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6. -- In this land of paradoxes there is nothing more paradoxical than the Soviet attitude toward the United States which varies along the whole scale from admiration and warmth to coldness and ill-will. I say "toward the United States" advisedly, because for Americans as individuals there is nothing but friendly feeling.

ONE of the most powerful and ceremonial posts in the British Parliament, that of Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Commons, has just been relinquished by an admiral (retired) and taken over by a brigadier general. The admiral is Sir Colin Keppel, who has been "policeman" of the Commons for more than twenty years; his successor is Brig. Gen. C.A. Howard.
WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 7. -- A mass meeting of striking employes of Consumers Research, Inc., was held here tonight, at which strikers and their sympathizers spoke.

PARIS. THE statue silhouette looms all-important in the Paris Winter evening mode. Leading couturiers have taken to studying sculpture and seem to be preoccupied with anatomy. They seek to reveal and accentuate the natural proportions of the feminine figure rather than shroud them with masses of material.

September's shorter days are going to keep the week-ending yacht skippers nearer home. Because twilight comes too early for many to make the run to Lloyd Harbor or Northport they will examine their Chart 223 again and wonder why all Summer they've been passing up Hempstead.

Three of David Frome's books about Mr. Pinkerton and his friend Inspector Bull of Scotland Yard are here included in one volume. The stories included are "The Hammersmith Murders," "Two Against Scotland Yard" and "The Man From Scotland Yard."

THERE is a Rembrandt exhibition at Amsterdam this Summer and it is something of a national event. No visitor to Holland (or The Netherlands, as the country now prefers to be called) is allowed to forget it for a moment.

LAKELAND, Fla., Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt's allocation on Tuesday of $5,000,000 to begin work on a $146,000,000 cross-State ship canal for Florida means that a goal set up years ago is in sight, and places in tangible form a project certain to have far-reaching significance, directly involving the commerce of perhaps a score of States.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The amateur night given as Guild Hall benefit this evening the John Drew Memorial Theatre proved so popular that it was decided to repeat the performance next Saturday evening. Both members of East Hampton's Summer colony and permanent residents were represented on the program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- With the Democratic party threatened with two possible split-offs in the 1936 Presidential election -- one led by Senator Long and the other by conservatives claiming to be Jeffersonians or defenders of the Constitution with its States' rights provisions -- the effectiveness of third parties in American political annals is being studied.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The "old red barn" -- Montclair's shabby railroad station at Walnut Street -- became the centre today of what may be a battle of wits and paint brushes between the Erie Railroad and local business men, housewives and musicians.

Six new world's records in outboard racing, made during recent regattas, were adopted and approved officially last week after investigation and action by the joint racing commission of the National Outboard Association and the American Power Boat Association.

Mrs. Harry Whitney, chairman of the executive committee of the New York City League of Women Voters, will preside tomorrow morning at the first meeting of the year at headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street. Nearly a hundred members are expected to attend and to participate in the formation of plans for the Autumn pre-election work.

One of two women arraigned yesterday afternoon in Yorkville Court on a disorderly conduct charge for having caused a disturbance in the offices of the Italian Consulate, which they entered by a ruse, was held by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke in $100 bail for further hearing.

WHEN 1,000 boys and girls who have just moved into Hillside Homes, the Works Progress Administration's large municipal housing project at Boston Road and Eastchester Avenue, enroll tomorrow in the Anne Hutchinson School, Public School 78, which is just across the street from their homes, they will find a unique reception awaiting them.

Aroused by the proposal of shipping interests to increase inter-coastal freight rates on various food and grocery products, wholesale distributers and manufacturers will meet here on Thursday to organize an industry-wide movement to strongly protest to the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce against approval of the new schedules.

Developments in Mexico that led to the recognition of women as "citizens" entitled to take an active part in the political affairs of their nation were sketched here yesterday by Mrs. Margarita Robles de Mendoza, founder of the Union of American Women and Mexico's leading feminist.

The Little Old Woman Who Used Her Head made red flannel coats to keep her geese warm so that she could pluck their feathers out for a featherbed; she saved her corn by catching the rats and keeping them as pets; when her geese were cold in the barn she moved their roost into the house and then, annoyed by their squawking, she put her bed in the barn.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- Two men and a boy died successively today from black damp gas in an unfinished forty-seven-foot well in the little Grasshopper community northeast of Chattanooga.

Vigorously pursuing the advance begun late on Thursday, the share market closed strong yesterday in the heaviest trading for a half-day session since Feb. 10, 1934. Transactions on the Stock Exchange reached 1,289,000 shares, with the tape frequently falling a minute or two behind in reporting sales; the record for a Saturday, established on May 3, 1930, is 4,867,000 shares.

WITH a three-day program at Lake Placid beginning on Thursday, New York brings to a close the golden jubilee celebration of her forest preserves. MILLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Youthful equestrians of Dutchess County had their innings today at the third annual Millbrook junior show, held at Killearn Farm, the estate of Alfred B. Maclay. Fifteen events were held, none of the competitors being more than 16 years of age. It was the parents who looked on with interest as the winners were selected.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Two Far Western A.A.U. swimming records fell today before the onslaught of an array of leading candidates for the United States 1936 Olympic team.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Paquin is launching buckskin panel skirts and jackets, inspired by the costumes of American Indians. The leather is fringed, embroidered and perforated. These skirts are made to buckle on over the divided skirts or knickers of tweed hunting or other active sports suits.

The assembly, which will draw attendance of women from different parts of the country, is sponsored by The New York Herald Tribune.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Mussolini Cup for the best foreign film exhibited at the third biennial motion-picture exhibit was awarded to the American film "Anna Karenina" (Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer), starring Greta Garbo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The Federal Government has resumed control over social phases of the liquor traffic. Regulations are being drafted to put into effect the Federal Alcohol Administration Act signed by the President on Aug. 28 -- the same regulations, practically, which had been in effect under the NRA codes scrapped as a result of the Supreme Court's Schecter decision.

All units in the financial world will be represented by speakers at the twentieth annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association to be held in the Ambassador Hotel, Atlantic City, from tomorrow until Wednesday. DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Ted Clark, C.N. Mooney's chestnut horse, raced to an easy victory in the $3,000 Wyandotte Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, beating Our Count by two lengths. Easy Sailing was third, two lengths back of the place horse.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7. -- Henrietta Leaver, 19-year-old high school graduate of McKeesport, Pa., who came to Atlantic City as "Miss Pittsburgh" to compete in the Showmen's Jubilee, this year's name for the annual beauty contest, was selected by nine judges tonight for the title of "Miss America."

Pouch, president of the Concrete Steel Company and chairman of the industrial advisory committee on loans in this district, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Chicago's celebration of Constitution Day Sept. 17 will be held in the private stadium where Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert C. Hoover were nominated for the Presidency in 1932, while $5,000,000 worth of public amphitheatre will lie empty on the lake shore.

POUNDRIDGE, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP). -- George Bailey, 12, the object of a search by police of two States since Thursday evening was back home and happy tonight. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vernon F. Bailey, said they were "too thankful to think of punishing" the boy, who was picked up this afternoon in New Canaan, Conn., by Sergeant I. Jagoda of the State police at Brewster, N.Y.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Bonds purporting to be payable in gold, even though they contain the "hedging clause" sanctioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission, cannot be qualified for sale in Illinois, Attorney General Otto Kerner held today.

THE old shortage of school buildings and equipment still confronts the city's educational system as the new school term opens tomorrow, but in other respects the coming year promises to be one of notable progress.

David Burnstine, New York contract bridge expert held a substantial lead over a field of thirty-five other master bridge players as the masters' individual championship of the American Bridge League ended its fourth session last night at the Hotel Ambassador.

ALL but one of the midtown cinema houses expect to retain their present programs during the new week. The lone starter on this week's film schedule is Paramount's "The Big Broadcast of 1936," which will settle down -- on Friday morning -- at the Paramount.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Proposals for reorganization of the McLellan Stores Company after it had filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy in January, 1933, and the attitude of the various banking interests toward the propositions made were reviewed today at a hearing by the Protective Committee Study of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6. -- While refusing to predict the outcome of the bituminous mine wage contract conference that has been resumed in Washington for the fifth time, preceding and following the ending of NRA, authorities on the industry here feel practically certain that a peaceful settlement will be reached.

The city's burlesque houses will resume business today at the old stand -- if not quite at the old wage scale. Late last evening, after three days of bickering and conferences, the industry's first labor strike ended on a note of arbitration. Once again Forty-second Street is prepared to become the midway of Manhattan, and burlesque artists can dance again.

INTIMATIONS that we would see larger transport planes on the airways of the United States in the next year -- especially large sleeper planes -- have proved well founded. American Airlines has ordered a fleet of the new Douglas enlarged model and expects delivery of them in February.

IN well-managed gardens roses give their second bloom -- often finer in quality, if not so abundant as the Summer show -- through September and well into October, sometimes even into November. Rose specialists find that it pays well to continue spraying and feeding throughout this month.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 7. -- The Louisiana Legislature assembled tonight in the seventh special session in thirteen months and immediately received thirty-one bills bearing the approval of Senator Long.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Close to 1,000 spectators, including Promoter Mike Jacobs, State Athletic Commissioner D. Walker Wear and 200 delegates to the annual National Colored Baptists convention, now in progress in New York, were present today when Joe Louis donned the gloves for the second time since he started training for his Sept. 24 match with Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium.

IF her book is a true index, Miss Dennis, on her extensive excursions through her native province, saw very little and heard a great deal. At any rate, it is mostly what she heard that she shares with the reader

Although spotty trade conditions prevailed in some sections of the country last week, due principally to adverse weather conditions, business in general continued to show progress, with retail merchants extremely optimistic over the outlook for the Fall selling season.

SINCE most of the bright Paris designers are turning back the pages of history books for fashion inspiration, domestic jewelers can but fall in line. A good thing it is, too, for the current version of the quaint and lovely settings of fin-de-siecle jewels and of the precious stones whence come Renaissance colors afford glamorous accents for one's first dressy Fall outfit.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 7. -- Declaring he feels that an impartial hearing cannot be obtained in Hennepin County, Walter W. Liggett, editor of the Mid-West American of Minneapolis, today petitioned for a change of venue in his trial on sex charges.

ONE hesitates to call this novel great -- for greatness is a quality not wisely to be attributed to anything hot off the press -- but it is certainly better than good. Naomi Royde-Smith has written several previous novels which have been uniformly smooth and competent and not very much more.

Every year between August and November three or four West Indian hurricanes may be expected to come up from tropical waters and strike the mainland between Texas and Florida. Once a season, on the average, the full force of the wind chances to hit a point where there are men to kill and buildings to wreck; that happened last week in the Florida Keys.

OF all the arts, the motion picture was vested by Lenin with the gravest responsibility. "For us," said he, "it is the cinema that is the most important." The laconic declaration was made when talking pictures were yet potential. Stalin has watched with approval the growth of that most important of arts.

WHEN the time for planting shrubs comes round in Autumn the gardener who wishes to improve his landscaping will have vividly in mind the dullness of the shrub borders during the Summer weeks just passed.

In his usual garrulous and roundabout fashion Mr. Keeler tells a story in which there is a super-abundance of mystery and excitement, but no murder. The main theme of the story is an elaborate insurance fraud to be carried out with the aid of the skull mentioned in the title.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 6. -- Idaho has been stirred by the announcement that the New Deal will concentrate in the Northwest next year on an attempt to elect a Democrat to the United States Senate in place of William E. Borah, who will seek his sixth consecutive term should he not be nominated by his own party for the Presidency.

THE ART OF HOME LANDSCAPE" is one of a number of books being published nowadays which bring the subject of landscape design to the attention of the average individual. These works are filling a very real need and by the time they have been thoroughly digested there is reason to hope that the landscaping horrors of suburbia will be minimized.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- There has scarcely been any moment in the history of the past fifteen years when the French doctrine of collective security in Europe has seemed further from realization than just now.

GENEVA, Sept. 7. -- The Italian and Ethiopian Governments have been asked to do nothing to hinder or compromise the peace efforts of the League of Nations Council's committee of five while that committee has the Italo-Ethiopian dispute under consideration.
The American Legion auxiliary of Oceanside will meet tomorrow evening in the clubhouse on Long Beach Road to elect officers for the coming year.

Unless the city begins to increase its park appropriations in the near future, many parks, parkways and playgrounds will have to be closed and fenced off from public usage when relief funds are no longer available, according to Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

James W. Gerard, former United States Ambassador to Germany, said on his return from a visit to Europe yesterday that Americans spend far too much of their money abroad. He advocated a tax or a similar curb on extravagance abroad.

Captain E. Hengstenberg, the newest addition to the Hapag Lloyd Line's North Atlantic staff, arrived Monday in command of the liner Berlin. His new post was made possible by the sale of his former command, the Sierra Cordoba, by the Hapag Lloyd Line to the Italian Government for service as a troop ship or as replacement for a commercial ship assigned to troop service.

Kitchin, whose death in London at the beginning of last July may well have been induced by his privations and sufferings, spent four years, 1928-1932, in Russian prisons and in various penal camps in Arctic Russia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Representative Amlie, Progressive, of Wisconsin, chairman of the American Commonwealth Political Federation, said today that President Roosevelt's signal of a "breathing spell" for business meant "the end of New Deal liberalism."

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 5. -- The prediction of The Winchester Star, owned by Senator Harry F. Byrd, that President Roosevelt will receive the backing of the Virginia delegation at the Democratic National Convention next year, and the accompanying statement that Mr. Byrd's name will not be presented to the State Democratic convention in 1936 for any national office, are political developments of major significance in this State.

LONDON, Aug. 15. THE Autumn exodus is rumored and is about to begin. New contracts are everywhere being made. Soon the actors and actresses who made them will be gone -- some to Hollywood, some to British film studios, some to the New York stage.

Manhattan has been stirred by a raid on its sidewalk canopies. Hotels, restaurants and night clubs especially are marked for discipline and warned that these protections will be carted away if they are put out in dry weather.

An amicable arrangement of the disposition of the oil produced by the Standard Oil Company of California from its concession on the Island of Bahrein in the Persian Gulf has just been made in London, it was reported yesterday in the trade here.
BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Indians smothered a ninth-inning rally by the Red Sox with a triple play today in the first game of a doubleheader, both games of which they won, 5 to 3 and 5 to 4.

Foreign exchanges continued weak yesterday, but closed irregular. Sterling was down 1/2 cent to $4.93, a loss of 3 1/4 cents in the week, while the franc again dipped to 6.59 cents, but closed at 6.59 1/4 cents, unchanged on the day, but down 1 1/4 points on the week.

ARMAMENT is the order of the day and war games the order of the hour. Recently there have been taking place on the Continent military manoeuvres involving the greatest display of armed might since 1918. It is in Europe that armaments are most conspicuous, where potential enemies are huddled close together and where a power of the first rank, hitherto restricted, has quickly equipped itself with the newest and most destructive weapons.

THE GOLD CHASE" starts out very promisingly for the kind of tale it is intended to be. Louis Aulone, an engaging old fellow and something of a gay dog, discovers a map which cryptically points the way to a treasure concealed somewhere in the Florida country by De Soto on his great wilderness march.

When General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, announced on Thursday that one-sixth of the 240,000 home relief workers were too ill for work, he was laboring under a misapprehension, it was learned yesterday from members of his staff.

The 22-foot Danish naval sloop Ingolf entered the harbor of New York yesterday and exchanged a twenty-one-gun salute with Fort Jay on Governors Island as she passed through the harbor, carrying the Danish naval flag here for the first time in nearly fifty years.

THIS latest novel by Warwick Deeping comes as something of a surprise -- and rather a pleasant one. Both its manner and the pattern of its plot differ substantially from anything contained in his recent work. It would be too much to say that Mr. Deeping has abandoned his didacticism entirely.

In this story Mr. Oppenheim takes a vacation from international intrigue in a Monte Carlo setting and devotes himself to describing a big business battle in London. The battlefield is Basinghall Street, where the offices of Woolito, Limited, are situated.

A contingent of forty-seven New York University athletes, Head Coach Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens and trainers and managers will leave the city today for the pre-season football training camp at Lake Sebago, near Sloatsburg, N.Y.

The nation, by Presidential pronouncement, has its "breathing spell," and the stock market is pounding ahead at breath-taking speed. Gains in stock prices for the week just completed were the greatest of any week since that ended on June 15 and brought the price level back to that of September, 1931.

MANILA, Aug. 5. -- Floods in the Philippines, which the cables have reported as the most widespread and destructive in a quarter of a century, have been a result of an abnormal juxtaposition of the unusual weather factors which effect the islands.
THIS little story has no connection with Francis Thompson's "Hound of Heaven." Sarah Addington, who is a "fanatic" about animals, has written a purely canine fantsy of a heaven for dogs.

OTTAWA, Sept. 6. -- Prime Minister R.B. Bennett's broadcast speech this week -- the first of a series of four which he will deliver in ten days -- did not contain an appeal for national government for Canada. It thus failed to justify the prophecy made by his chief opponent, the Liberal leader, Mackenzie King, in a platform speech in St. John on Tuesday during a tour of the Maritime Provinces.

Something more than the persons rescued from the wave-pounded liner Dixie came yesterday morning into the concourse of the Pennsylvania Station. It was something more pulse-driving than data on the number of hours suffered in darkness or the wrecking of antennae in the merciless gale or the height of the waves that last Monday teamed with the hurricane in a futile attempt to pitch vessel and lives into the sea.

BARCELONA. -- The Atarazanas, a ship-building plant which was turning out some of the finest craft of its day when Columbus set sail toward the still unknown America, is being demolished to make room for a continuously expanding and improving modern city.

ON the little island of Monhegan, twenty miles off the coast of Maine, artists, we learn, have been industriously at work this year. Etchings of Monhegan subjects by Frederick Dorr Steele; water-colors and etchings by Sears Gallagher; prints by Warren P. Lombard -- these, along with other material, have been exhibited there.

AMERICAN humor has come in for broad examination since the passing of Will Rogers, latest of the line of funny men of major rank to win the applause and the affection of the nation. Philosophers attempt anew dissect and analyze this phenomenon of our soil and to observe wherein it differs from kindred growths elsewhere in the world.

GENEVA, Sept. 7. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Russion Foreign Commissar, successfully proposed to the League of Nations Council today that it instruct the League's economic committee to study two questions of commercial policy with a view to making conventions on them.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Myrtlewood retained her honors as the fleetest sprinter in the Milwest at the Hawthorne track today.

During August the sooty atmospheric pollution in the air over New York City averaged 1.32 ton a cubic mile, an increase of .01 of a ton over the July average, it was said yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist at the Federal Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.

CANTON. -- Canton's "independent government" is indicating by the huge increase in military expenditures a determination to forge ahead with plans long outlined for the development and expansion of Kwangtung's naval, land and air forces.
What will the hotels of America do to meet the increasing competition from tourist cabins and camps?

THE time has arrived to go back and do justice to the single disks, which one is so apt to overlook with album sets being released so regularly. Perhaps it is only because these latter have been so uniformly good of late that the loose records of the last few months seem on the whole to be less interesting than usual.

A rifleman who displayed disregard of where his bullets struck was being sought yesterday by police of the East 104th Street police station. Three persons were struck by bullets, presumably from a .22 calibre rifle, and a number of windows were broken in the block between 102d and 103d Streets in Lexington Avenue.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- The New German Army, which threw off the shackles of Versailles shortly after Adolf Hitler came to power and thereby revolutionized the political constellation of Europe, permitted the world to take its first peek at its prowess in action and at the achievements of more than two years of German rearmament when during the last week it held its first large manoeuvres since the World War.

The increase in the birth rate recorded in 1934 may be attributable to increased dependency on relief, it is pointed out in the Statistical Bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for August, 1935, which was placed in circulation yesterday.

The Yellow Taxi Corporation of New York, which ceased operation of taxicabs and started liquidation several months ago, filed yesterday a voluntary petition in bankruptcy in Federal court. The petition, a legal formality in final liquidation, listed liabilities at $1,059,768 and assets at $3,447.

The sun shone over Forest Hills and a great crowd of 10,000 spectators turned out in the stadium yesterday for the long-deferred resumption of play in the national tennis championships, but there was no sunshine in the heart of Roderick Menzel of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- A call for bids on thirty-five municipal security issues amounting to $4,116,000, all of them bought from the Public Works Administration, was issued today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Securities of thirty-two municipalities in fifteen States, including four New York communities, are in the list. Bids are to be opened immediately after noon Sept. 19 at the offices of the RFC here.

The Bergen County Federation of Garden Clubs opened the fourteenth annual flower show yesterday at the Hackensack Woman's Club house. The show, which will be continued today, had eighty-three classes of exhibits, including the conservation, special club and club displays.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Increased attendance figures and other signs of a new buoyancy sent the Middle Western farmer home today from his prime annual holiday -- the State Fair -- with reasons for prolonging the glow of his week's vacation from the fields and the flocks.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Hamilton of New York entertained a party tonight at the Mount Washington, where guests included Mr. and Mrs. Leo Ehrhart, Mr. and Mrs. Myron L. Keith, Mr. and Mrs. G.E. Keith, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sanderson, Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds and Mrs. G.M. Bowers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- A university professor of geography and his wife who have spent nearly half the last thirteen years in or traveling to and from "out of the way" places took off by plane today for a six-month jaunt into the interior of South America and said it was a "commonplace" trip "in the interests of science."

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Miss Connie E. Johnston of Bryn Mawr, Pa., today added the title in the hunter division to the numerous other awards her hunter string had captured at the final session of the fourth annual Middletown-Goshen horse show. She carried off the championship with her gray gelding, Nacoma.

The city's noise abatement campaign will be officially opened tomorrow afternoon when representatives of more than a hundred business and civic groups will assemble at City Hall to discuss ways and means of combating the noise nuisance in New York.

VIENNA, Sept. 7. -- The constituent congress of the new Zionist Organization opened tonight with 350 delegates from forty-three countries, representing 750,000 Jews in all parts of the world, who are following the leadership of Vladimir Jabotinsky, the revisionist leader.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The Sands Point Bath Club celebrated the close of its formal season of entertaining tonight with a final dinner dance entitled "Bal au Revoir a l'Ete." Many dinner and supper parties filled the club to capacity.

IT was quite appropriate that the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts should play a prominent role in the celebration of Connecticut's Tercentenary. The Yale gallery is closely related, through John Trumbull, to the early artistic achievements of our American painters; and in presenting a series of exhibitions vitally reflecting phases of the State's cultural development, it has performed a real service.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 7. -- With competitors firing until darkness obscured the targets, the National Rifle and Pistol Association matches opened on the ranges of the Ohio National Guard today. Army statisticians were swamped by scores and it was announced that winners in the individual pistol and Camp Perry instructors matches probably would not be determined until tomorrow morning.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Newark virtually clinched fourth place and a position in the International League play-offs tonight by taking both ends of a doubleheader from Albany. The scores were 10 to 0 and 4 to 3. Willard Hershberger's single with the bases loaded and two out in the last inning decided the nightcap.

Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Ned Reigh, a 5-to-1 shot, survived a bitter stretch duel before 15,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday and won the Junior Champion Stakes by half a length in a manner to stamp him as a colt worthy of recognition in the top flight.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 7. -- More than 500 attending the second annual convention of the New England Young Republicans here heard several speakers at a dinner tonight. Among these was Representative Risk of Rhode Island, recently victorious in an election battle with a New Deal candidate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Senators held to sixth place today by defeating the Browns 7 -- 4, and were tied at 4 -- all when the second contest of a double bill was called in the tenth inning on account of darkness.

Last night in Atlantic City they placed the crown oh the fair brow of Miss America, 1935. Her name will be most likely in the news sections of today's paper, but comes too late for this column. One cannot even speak with confidence about the coronation robes.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Magistrate Vincent J. Girard was arrested tonight and police slated him on charges of "drunk, disorderly and resisting arrest."

DETROIT, Sept. 7. -- If America decentralizes, becomes a land with homes, farms and factories spread more or less evenly over the countryside, as many economic students believe it should, future historians may credit Henry Ford with having pioneered the movement.

Greenfield, candidate for the leadership, and his supporters in the Young Men's Tammany Club from describing their candidates as "regular Democratic candidates" in the coming primary fight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- The world's wheat markets were swept higher today by the announcement that Canada would pay farmers a minimum price of 87 1/3 cents a bushel for No. 1 Northern wheat, basis in store at Fort William, and that all restrictions on future trading would be removed in that market on Monday except a 3-cent limit on daily fluctuations.

The unexpected announcement last week of reduction of dividends by two leading banks here and the fall in bank stock prices which ensued were a sharp reminder to Wall Street that the banking business faces a period of dwindling earnings at a time when operating costs, for numerous of reasons, appear likely to rise, rather than decline.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, assailed today the labor record of Irwin Steingut, Democratic Speaker of the Assembly.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt told a Young Republican rally here tonight that the nation's heritage has been squandered by "opportunist politicians and crack-pot professors."

Like the opera and the movies, the circus and the theatre, radio has featured players and now builds the productions around them.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, said tonight he hoped that Governor Lehman would accept renomination.

Twenty-five hundred Communists, massed at the north end of Union Square to mark International Youth Day, chorused a demand yesterday for a united front of workers against Fascism and "its twin brother," war. They urged similar unity to protect Soviet Russia and the "interests of the working class."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- A coalition ticket to oppose President Roosevelt in 1936 will be discussed informally by the executive committee of the Republican National Committee when it meets here late this month. The most prominent names so far advanced are those of Henry Ford for President and Lewis W. Douglas, former Budget Director, for Vice President.

NEW YORK'S "market city" in the Bronx has become a thriving city in fact. This project, long known as "Hylan's folly," has won a place as one of the three biggest distributors among the fifty-five metropolitan centres for provisions.

MILLERS FALLS, Mass., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Three boys not yet in their teens were dead today, victims of shifting sand of a sandbank.

IT is becoming more and more generally recognized that the elimination of the accident repeater would do much to reduce the number of street and highway casualties. The accident repeater is a driver who, through willful recklessness or some faulty driving habit, becomes involved in two or more accidents in a relatively short period of time.

Details of the program for the celebration of Constitution Day under the auspices of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, were made public yesterday. Dates of the observance are Sept. 16 and 17.

The southern hurricane reached into the Atlantic Ocean on Friday and tossed the Italian liner Conte di Savoia around for several hours, according to passengers and officers who told of the experience when the liner docked yesterday. Captain Antonio Lena, master of the vessel, said that "everything suddenly went boom."

How best to build a freight-car tunnel under the upper New York Bay to connect Brooklyn and Jersey City will be considered at a public hearing called for Sept. 10 by the New York Port Authority, under whose auspices this important work is projected.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Despondent following a nervous breakdown, Richard Wallace Schabacker, 36, financial editor of Forbes Magazine and an authority on stock market trends, mortally wounded himself today by firing a bullet from a .22-calibre rifle into his right temple.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 7. -- Mrs. Elizabeth S. Willis today obtained a divorce from Walter I. Willis of New York City on the grounds of cruelty. The suit was not contested.

ALTOONA, Pa., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Lou Meyer of Huntington Park, Calif., setting an average speed of 86 1/2 miles an hour, roared to victory today in a 100-mile automobile race over the Altoona-Tyrone Speedway -- last dirt track championship race of the season.

A REFORMATORY for 5,300 bandits has been established in China under the approval of General Chiang Kai-shek, who believes that these criminals can be turned into useful citizens. The philosopher's stone for accomplishing this is compounded of education, disciplinary training and attention to "spiritual" needs.

Constructive operations continued to dominate bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange through the two-hour session yesterday. Almost all classes of domestic corporation issues extended their gains with many forcing their way into new high ground on fairly active trading. Total transactions amounted to $6,621,400 as compared with $3,262,300 on last Saturday.

OKLAHOMA'S gift to dramaturgy, Lynn Riggs, is coming back. Mr. Riggs has crossed a State line or two, has written a play about New Mexico entitled "Russet Mantle," and Jerome Mayer and Murray Jay Queen are the owners of it.

ESCANABA, Mich., Sept. 6. -- The week-end visit of United States Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg and Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, at the Summer home of George F. Getz, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, near Holland, has aroused speculation as to what roles these two prominently mentioned Presidential possibilities will assume in the forthcoming political campaign.

EDMONTON, Alberta. -- The movement to institute a remedy for the present unhappy and unsatisfactory conditions within the Province of Alberta reached its momentum on Aug. 22, when a social credit government was elected with a sweeping majority of fifty-six out of sixty-three members of the Legislature.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved yesterday within a 10-point range, and ended at losses of 5 to 8 points.

WHICH years of a person's life are likely to be the most creative? According to a new psychological investigation reported last week by Dr. Harvey C. Lehman of Ohio University the odds seem to be on the early thirties, at least for scientists and writers.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 7. -- A strong plea for peace and for the fulfillment in peace of all aspirations of the Italian people was made by Pope Pius this morning following a papal mass in the basilica of St. Paul's Outside the Walls.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Mississippi River Motor Ships Syndicate today asked the PWA for a loan of $3,979,100 to construct six steel-hulled river boats "to open up a new era of excursion and tourist travel on inland waterways."

WITH Frederick Stock entering his thirty-first year as its conductor, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will begin its forty-fifth season in Orchestra Hall, Chicago, on Thursday afternoon, Oct. 17, repeating the same program on the afternoon of Friday, Oct. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- With twenty-seven of Philadelphia's twenty-eight magistrates under indictment for misconduct in office, the grand jury investigation of the magisterial system moved into a new phase this week. On instruction from President Judge Harry S. McDevitt of Common Pleas No. 1 the jurors, who launched the investigation in August, were held intact as a special grand jury to continue their work.

For the six months ended on July 31, the City Stores Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $270,552 after depreciation, reserve for contingencies, minority interest, Federal taxes and other charges. In the corresponding six months of last year the net loss was $608,058.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Czech-Polish jealousy simmered today as troops stood guard against a fresh outbreak across the border from the Polish city of Cieszyn [Teschen]. The troops were necessary after Polish Nationalists, who form a majority of the population in some districts, drove through a number of communities on a mission of wreckage.

Mayor La Guardia's disapproval on Friday of forty-four out of forty-six proposed "white-collar" projects ranging from surveys of the traffic shift to buses and tent caterpillar eradication was denounced yesterday by Willis R. Morgan, president of the City Projects Council, an organization of "white-collar" WPA workers.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7. -- General business conditions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District have maintained a satisfactory level. Credit is expanding slowly and banks report less than the usual demand from flour mills and grain elevators. Some reduction is noted in unemployment, seasonal in character.

THE Fall season in the cinema has made a brave beginning. The incomparable Garbo continues to be the world's foremost screen actress in "Anna Karenina" (Capitol), in which the Hollywood dramatists regard Tolstoy's great work with respectful intelligence.

CORNWALL, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Another impressive triumph was recorded by that successful Scottish terrier campaigner, Ch. Flornell Soundman, owned by the Braw Bricht Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Voorhees of Jericho, L.I., to climax the Storm King Kennel Club's eleventh annual exhibition today at the Kenridge Farm race track.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- New England is divided over the potato policy of the administration. Even the Senators from Maine, both Republicans, split over it. The Democratic Senator from New Hampshire favored it, the Republican Senator opposed it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Augie Galan's hitting, plus Bill Lee's six-hit pitching, gave the contending Cubs a 4-to-0 victory over Philadelphia today, and with it a clean sweep of the four-game series.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The fifth annual race meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association attracted a large throng of socially prominent persons to the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here. The eighth annual Connecticut Cup race was the feature event this afternoon.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Sept. 7. -- Three large hydrogenation plants for the production of synthetic gasoline are expected to be in operation in the Ruhr during the second half of 1936, according to today's reports from Essen. All will work with coal, but will use different processes, because experiments have not yet proved the advantage of any one process.

MIGUEL ANTONIO OTERO has a clear title to write of the frontier, for he grew up with it. His three hundred pages are full to overflowing of its glamorous, heady, outrageous doings, but he can say of them, all these things I saw and part of them was.

A long list of highway accidents here and abroad has impressed the country with the shocking toll of life taken by the automobile. Despite increasing efforts at prevention, there are nearly 100 deaths every day on the highways of the United States alone.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Up-bay skippers, flying the colors of the Mantoloking Yacht Club, invaded Tuckerton Bay today and won the coveted Barclay Trophy in the eighth annual race for that cup. The contest featured the Little Egg Harbor Yacht Club regatta marking the close of the sailing season for the New Jersey coast.
The Yankees came out of the storm cellars yesterday after five days of captivity and split a doubleheader with the White Sox before a crowd of 22,000 at the Stadium.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. IT may or may not be an encouraging portent on the theatrical horizon that Boston is starting its regular season this Autumn a fortnight earlier than last year. Two musical shows are already in town.

The names of twenty Republican Assembly district leaders pledged to the re-election of Chase Mellen, Jr., as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee were made public yesteday by William C. Hecht Jr., Mr. Mellen's campaign manager.

A plot to steal a magnificent rope of pearls belonging to the Rajah of Chitipur fails for several reasons, one of which is indicated in the title of this novel. The subordinate figures in the plot refuse to permit themselves to be moved about like pawns by the master mind.

Zonta International swings into its new season under the leadership of Miss Dora Zeun of Rochester, who was elected president at the national convention at Riverside, Calif., in July. Action taken at the convention has spurred work on two important projects of the organization.

THESE eleven tales are concerned mostly with Iowan villagers and farmers in the little river town of Ontarns. Simple, almost anecdotal in character, they have a homely folk quality which distinguishes them from most regional fiction.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Up with the leaders all the way and then suddenly out ahead in a quick change of position two jumps from the end, Ward A. Wickwire's aged bay gelding Lucier was the surprise winner today of the Connecticut Cup, the three-mile feature of the fifth annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association.

Mail orders received from retailers following the Labor Day holiday were the largest so far this season, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Inclement weather in many sections of the country caused a tapering off of this demand toward the end of the week.

THE Great Waltz" closes at the Center Theatre Saturday evening and opens on Thursday, Oct. 3, at the Boston Opera House. That transition, ordinarily a matter of baggage hauls, bill posting and date juggling, is an event of peculiar importance in the case of Max Gordon's Viennese divertissement which has occupied the stage of the Radio City playhouse since time immemorial -- that is to say, Sept. 22, 1934.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7. -- The Dodgers' speedy drive toward sixth place lost none of its momentum today, but Pilot Casey Stengel's temper was gone when he entrained for Cincinnati tonight after his team dropped the third straight game to the Pirates, 5 to 4.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Mickey Cochrane's Tigers beat the Athletics in both ends of a double-header today, winning the first game, 9 to 7, and then rubbing it in with a 15-to-1 conquest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Unlike the tornado of the temperate zone, which comes suddenly down from the clouds, travels at express-train speed for a few minutes or a few hours over the land while whirling on its axis at many times that speed, and then vanishes, the tropical hurricanes -- such as that which took heavy toll in Florida last week -- is a long-lived and deliberate affair.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5. -- Missouri's Old-Age Pension Law technically went into effect on Aug. 27, but the date on which those eligible for the bounty will receive their first funds has not yet been set.

THE value of a picnic as an antidote for official cares is recognized by President Roosevelt, who recently took a group of aides and secretaries on one of these impromptu jaunts to Sugarloaf Mountain in Maryland. Picnics are a form of diversion in which rich and poor may share alike and have been indulged in, though not always under the same name, for many centuries. They are still popular.

HE will be 75 next Friday. Once he was a king in France with 2,000,000 American soldiers for his subjects; he had a larger business organization than any corporation and was spending more public funds than Ickes and Hopkins together.
EUROPE'S two outstanding radio exhibitions were recently held simultaneously in London and Berlin. Two hops in an airliner made an easy journey between the shows separated by 600 miles.
MIAMI, Sept. 7. -- Cremation of the hurricane dead on the Florida Keys was begun today to offset the danger of pestilence.

How much it costs to run a car is always a matter of interest to the motorist. In the article that follows a driver of long experience explains his system of accounting and sets down the record for five years.

More than 35 per cent of the student body of the evening division of the New York University College of Engineering made the 1934-1935 honor roll of that institution, it was announced yesterday by Professor William R. Bryans, assistant dean and chairman of the scholarship committee of the college.

DEL RIO, Texas. -- Consideration of regulatory measures on liquor control will harass members of the Forty-fourth Legislature when it meets in special session on Sept. 16. They must find a remedy for a situation that has grown steadily worse through years of procrastination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- President Roosevelt today placed $27,315,217 at the disposal of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, for one of the most extensive programs for subsidizing literature and the arts in the history of governments.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Midwestern League for Economic Equality announced today it would go to bat next month for the AAA in its court battle to retain the processing tax.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 6. -- At the League sessions in Geneva, Scandinavia, with its population of 12,000,000, stands solidly behind the demand that the present crisis be solved by applying the fundamental principles on which the League is based.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 7. -- On Oct. 30, 1936, some Toronto mother may inherit half a million dollars under the terms of a will made June 7, 1921, by Charles Vance Millar, rich Toronto lawyer, promoter, mining operator, turfman and jokester, who died Oct. 30, 1926.

HERBS OF THE EARTH" is written by a man whose heart and soul, nourished by sun, rain and soil, open like blossoms in his own garden. His beautiful prose unconsciously approaches poetry and one finds one's self reading its cadences as though it were free verse.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Little Jackie Grub, who can rattle off more words and sentences than a youngster three times his age, said "Holy smokes!" and set about showing Dr. Bring Bryngelson how a left-handed, 20-month-old boy speaks the English language with the 1,100 words he knows.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Any consideration of this country's foreign policy at this critical juncture of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute must inevitably recall our procedure in the events leading up to the establishment of Manchukuo by the Japanese.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- The vigorous denunciation of the National Socialist Government of Germany by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in a verdict in which he acquitted the rioters who tore the swastika from the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen on July 26, precipitated today a violent storm of protest in the German press as well as in semi-official pronouncements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Republican women will start their 1936 campaign activities on Constitution Day.

SOMETHING less than a year ago Stephen Payne published his first Western thriller, "Lawless Range," which, while one of the wildest and most hectic tales in the year's crop from that field, gave promise of better things. That promise is measurably fulfilled in this his second Western.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage gave a supper dance tonight at Rynwood, their country home in the Cedar Swamp Road colony here, to introduce to society their youngest daughter, Miss Magdelaine Richmond Salvage.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice, chairman of the city's committee, has arranged the program for entertaining Vice Admiral Mathew Best, R.N., and the officers of his flagship, H.M.S. York, during the stay of the ship in Newport from Sept. 13 to 19.

Some years ago Professor S.S. VISHER of Indiana University classified tropical cyclones into "hurricanes," "gales," and "lows." By a hurricane he meant, as meteorologists always do, a rotary storm attended by a wind of at least seventy-five miles an hour. An average of three such violent cyclones sweep the tropical North Atlantic between June and November every year.
On Nov. 5 New York City residents will vote on the question of collectively going into the electric power business. Last week Mayor La Guardia signed a bill calling for the referendum.

THE New Masses prize contest for a novel with a proletarian theme, conducted jointly by The New Masses and the John Day Company, has been won by Clara Weatherwax of Oakland, Calif., with a novel entitled "Marching, Marching!" It will be published by the John Day Company early in November.

SIXTY miles almost due west of Key West, and forming the tip of the Florida Reef, lie the Dry Tortugas. On the centre island of this little group of seven keys stand the weathered battlements of America's largest masonry fortification -- Fort Jefferson.

A NETWORK of ten government broadcasting stations, possibly later to be augmented by two powerful short-wave transmitters for international relay work, is included in an enlarged program of radio development for Spain, ac cording to a report from Madrid, Legislation authorizing the network provides for gradual elimination of existing stations as their concessions expire and as new transmitters are ready to take their place on the air.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Monday morning a few minutes before 11 o'clock a tired man will walk out of the closely guarded doors of a Department of Agriculture office bearing in his hands sheets of paper with mimeographed figures which would mean the fortune of any one who could see them ahead of the rest of the world.

REPORTING in the Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, three electrical engineers, S.K. Wolf, D. Stanley and W.J. Sette, present findings to show that the voice of Lauritz Melchior, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, approaches the ideal as that ideal is determined by electrical laboratory tests.

SHANGHAI, China (AP). -- The millions of dollars bequeathed to the missionary movement in China by the late Ella Wendel, eccentric New York woman, are speeding the day when foreign missionaries will no longer be needed in China.

DUBLIN. -- As part of its plan to make the Free State economically self-sufficient, Eamon de Valera's government is now setting out to establish an Irish merchant marine. Under present conditions more than 90 per cent of the shipping to and from Free State ports is carried in British ships.

SALZBURG, Austria. -- It is difficult to give a clear account of a country as complicated as Central Europe. Neverthless, after spending several weeks there and after talking with tourists and people from neighboring States who come for the baths, and conversing in their several dialects with the peasants of the Tyrol and Carinthia, three ideas stand out fairly distinctly.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The first and major phase of the French Army manoeuvres ended today with a victory for the Southern attacking army against the Northern enemy entrenched along the Aisne River. All week mock fighting went on with the latest mechanized units of the French Army.

SILVERSPURS was a bad hombre. He was sleek, smooth, suave, fairly well featured, big, heavy and vain as a peacock. He kept his silver spurs brightly burnished. While he balked at no crime in the whole category, he'd rather shoot a man in the back than stand up to a fair fight.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Dispatches from Geneva affirm and deny that Premier Benito Mussolini has given assurance that Italy will not make war in Africa as long as the League of Nations committee of five has the Italo-Ethiopian dispute under consideration.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- New York dispatches relating to the release of five men arrested in the Bremen riot superseded other news in afternoon newspapers, but Magistrate Brodsky's remarks in giving his decision were not published.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Peter Daylight, bay gelding, owned and driven by John Patten of Roselle, won the Class A trot, feature race of the Weequahic Park matinee, sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey, today.
A comprehensive educational program of free lectures for the coming season has been arranged by the Metropolitan Museum of Art for all who wish to take advantage of them.

BEARING the title, List of Books on Music, a valuable booklet of fifty-seven pages has been issued by the National Association of Schools of Music. Together with the name of the publisher, date of issue and the price of the volume or set of volumes, the booklet lists in alphabetical order more than a thousand works, including biographies, lexicons, essays, treaties on technical guides, collections of letters, school man-...

Europe is keeping pace with the United States in the march toward recovery. At the recent Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce at Paris, a cross-section of world business opinion revealed a more promising outlook than at any period during the last five years.

BARCELONA. -- Word has been received in Barcelona by Education, S.A., a realty holding company, that the Patronato, which has been examining protests against the seizure by the State of supposed Jesuit properties in 1932 and 1933, has voted for the return to their owners of such properties as exist in this region.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The racing season of the Yacht Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club came to an end with the sailing of the Commodore's Cup events on Moriches Bay today. The final regatta of the Summer brought 45 yachts to the starting line.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7. -- One of the most striking and most consistent phases of Soviet foreign policy has been the establishment of friendship and cooperation with Iran [Persia] and Turkey. The Soviet Union has often been accused of carrying on the expansionist policy of Czarism under a different form and flag, but its relations with Iran and Turkey are a complete denial of such a charge.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 7 (Reuters). -- The Italian Government today communicated to Belaten Gheta Herouy, Ethiopian Foreign Minister, its decision to withdraw four consulates from Ethiopia, Count Luigi Vinci Gigliucci, Italian Minister, notifying the local government.

ROME, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The authoritative Giornale d'Italia said tonight groups of armed Senussites (a North African Moslem sect) were concentrating on the border of Libya, an Italian possession, with "mysterious support."

DEFINITE progress is reported by Claude J. Holding, president of the New York State Automobile Association, in the organization's drive for lower license fees. During the Summer, Mr. Holding says, various members of the Legislature and prospective candidates have announced their intention of supporting the proposal.

Inclement weather checked the expansion of initial Fall trade in the metropolitan area last week. Department store results were reported as notably spotty during most of the week, although several stores were credited with sales increases ranging from 2 to 3 per cent over a year ago.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Aquila, owned by T.R. Baxter of the Raritan Yacht Club of this city and skippered by John Novaky, won the opening test in the three-race series today and took the lead in the first annual national championship of the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Another voyage on the Houston, one of the Navy's fast cruisers, is in store for President Roosevelt if he chooses to return by the water route after his visit to the San Diego Exposition.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The British naval strength in the Mediterranean as represented by the fleet that is just beginning its second cruise out of Malta this Summer consists of four battleships, eight cruisers, three flotillas of destroyers and submarines, one aircraft carrier and various supplementary service units.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Sept. 7. -- Charles Nicholson started work yesterday on the design of Endeavour II, which T.O.M. Sopwith is building as a challenger for the America's Cup in 1937.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Miss Afton Ramsey, 23, a stenographer, plunged to her death from the seventeenth floor of a Loop office building this morning. A coroner's jury returned a verdict of "suicide while in a despondent frame of mind over a love affair."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7. -- Unable to stand the pressure any longer, what with the Cardinals squeezing them from the top and the Cubs from below, the Giants were unceremoniously jostled out of second place today in the National League pennant race and quietly dropped into the third slot as they blew the final game of their series with the Reds, 4 to 2.

THE talk was of decency in the theatre. It was prompted chiefly by a discussion of "Tobacco Road." Some of the folks who had been offended by the degradation of Erskine Caldwell's characters complained that the play served no good purpose.

In its effort to banish war, the League of Nations, now concerned with the Ethiopian question, has been fighting a long and difficult battle. Sometimes it had marked success in settling international disputes; again, it could make little headway.

When President Roosevelt signed the Rivers and Harbors Bill recently he took another long step toward utilizing the nation's power resources and adding to Federal control over running water. The dredging of rivers and harbors is an old story -- not always, in the past, an edifying one.

WASHINGTON -- In reviewing the health conditions of the nation's relief population, Administrator Harry L. Hopkins gives much of the credit for present high health standards to the home economists on the staffs of State, county and local relief administrations.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg's neo-pagan Germanic movement, which has often challenged "political Catholicism," itself came under fire today for trying to organize young people's groups.

Work will be started within the next ten days on a two-anti-a-half-mile boardwalk on the south shore of Staten Island, George W. Allison, Commissioner of Public Works of Richmond Borough, announced yesterday. The project is one of the major items on the Works Progress Administration schedule in the city.

ON closing day at Saratoga the steeplechase was won by the Greentree Jungle King, F. Williams up. A little fellow, as steeplechase riders go, is Jockey F. Williams -- small and trim, lean and hard. He doesn't show his age but he must be "rising fifty." He was going over the jumps on horseback in 1908. He was just about the best steeplechase rider in this country a quarter of a century ago.

THE depression is on the way out. Millions of Americans are still on relief. There are idle factories with broken windows even in fairly bustling communities. There are half-empty office buildings, ornate quarters of defunct banks for rent, swanky-looking country clubs with signs on the highway to the effect that the public is welcome on paying the greens fee.

ON a frontier strikingly different from the one that moved steadily westward as the nation grew, an experiment unique in American history is now under way. This experiment involves the colonists of Matanuska Valley in Alaska.

The worried-looking person on the Jacket of this book is probably Inspector Hannasyde of Scotland Yard. He has good reason to be worried, for he has on his hands the most exasperating group of murder suspects that can well be imagined.

SOME of the small ferns native to the Eastern part of the United States are excellent subjects for rock gardens. They are choice enough to be used in association with the most cherished alpines, and diminutive enough to be in scale in small rock gardens.

Two noteworthy events in last week's financial markets were the oversubscription by 150 per cent of a 3 1/2-year Government loan, offered at par with the very low interest rate of 1 1/2 per cent, and reduction of dividends by two important New York banks.
