Both incidents arose directly from a striking phenomenon of the period -- this year's unprecedentedly low rates for money.

Complaints that the Export-Import Bank of Washington, Federal agency created to assist in building up foreign trade, has given only a fraction of the help expected were made here yesterday as a movement to demand more concrete results from the institution gained headway among exporters.

A MAN who, being a physician, takes the scientific viewpoint, here endeavors to show that between science and religion are harmony and cooperation, and not antagonism. Dr. Harman is an English physician of high standing, a specialist in ophthalmology, and evidently also a man of wide culture, accustomed to think deeply into life's problems and to question with independent thought solutions that seem to him superficial.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The present issue before the world, we free churchmen feel, is not a local one affecting the fortunes of two nations. It is a universal question upon the settlement of which depend the happiness and welfare of living and unborn.

Whether the American oil concession in Ethiopia was to be explained as merely part of a struggle for oil which has been going on with increased pressure since the war, or whether it was partly brought about by astute advisers of the Ethiopian Emperor as a last desperate stratagem to check Italian invasion, this recent incident has served again to centre attention on the battle for "liquid gold" and the men who engineer its diplomacy.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 7 (AP). -- C.H. Garrett, Dallas inventor, gave a private demonstration today of a recently patented contrivance which he said substituted water for gasoline as fuel for internal combustion engines.
Encouraging news on the waterfowl situation comes from the United States Bureau of Biological Survey.

At 5:30 yesterday morning a tug towing six barges down the Hudson River dropped a whaleboat near 133d Street and six Sea Scouts rowed ashore. The youths hove to beside the Sea Scout base ship Minas Princess to find that they had been "lost" and that their safe arrival occasioned a vast amount of relief.

NORFOLK, Conn., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Probate Judge J. Sedgwick Tracy reserved decision today at the conclusion of a hearing on the validity of a will executed twenty years ago by the late Professor Michael Pupin of Columbia University.

Assemblyman Samuel Pesin of Jersey City took issue yesterday with the action of a committee of trustees of Rutgers University, who cleared Dr. Frederich J. Hauptmann, head of the German department of the New Jersey College for Women at New Brunswick, of charges that he had used his position to disseminate Nazi propaganda.

ALTHOUGH Congressmen reserve their most sentimental superlatives for eulogies of the places and people whence they sprang to near-fame, they should not be taken too seriously. Many members actually dread the return home which adjournment of Congress imposes upon them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Fresh rumors of stabilization negotiations were stirred up, and promptly denied, when it was disclosed today that two high Treasury officials are planning European tours.

In a court room jammed with cripples, Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning quietly and expeditiously disposed of cases against seventeen crippled defendants charged with creating a disturbance in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau offices, 902 Broadway.

The Cunard White Star liner Majestic is due in port Tuesday on the first leg of her two-hundredth round trip in the transatlantic trade. She has traveled about 1,250,000 miles in her fourteen years of service and was the largest commercial ship afloat until the new French liner Normandie entered the service this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Repeal of the Prohibition Act has been increasing membership in the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and in the fund for carrying on the organization's work, according to speakers at the sixty-first annual convention, here today.

NO ordinary, run-of-the-mill book about India is this, but a mosaic of memories of a very busy, useful and happy life spent there by a member of the British Medical Service who, by virtue of his work, saw a great deal of both native and English life from the inside.

The housewife who bends over a fruit stall and picks brightly colored oranges in preference to the paler type is wasting her time, for the color of the fruit has no bearing on the nutritive content, reports a bulletin from the Department of Agriculture.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7. -- In a wind chase around Long Island Sound today Horace Havemeyer's 12-meter sloop Mouette scored a victory of 1 minute and 16 seconds over W.J. Strawbridge's Mitena. Cantitoe, in the hands of J. Seward Johnson, was third, and Van S. Merle-Smith's Seven Seas fourth.

The need for thorough and comprehensive studies of both marketing and production problems by companies in launching new consumer products, in order to prevent financial losses and to assure success of the new items, was stressed by O.C. Holleran of the marketing and research division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce in a "check sheet" on the subject released yesterday.
BRASS EAGLES is the name of "New York's Biggest Store," the most efficient and most scientific distributing organization in the world, the final word in modern American merchandising.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Painters, sculptors and residents of the Berkshire hills gathered at the Berkshire Playhouse this afternoon for the varnishing day tea and reception which marked the opening of the annual Stockbridge exhibition.

DO you collect postage stamps? If so, you have probably heard of the Mauritius two-penny "postoffice," the thirteen-cent Hawaiian missionary, thenine-kreutzer Baden, 1861, with the color error, and the British Guiana one-cent, 1856.

Since the Chicago sportsman, Thomas M. Howell, landed the world's record tuna with rod and line off Liverpool, N.S., last Summer, a number of United States sportsmen have been trying their hand at this thrilling sport in these waters, according to the Fish and Game Department of the Canadian National Railways.

Former Prime Minister Alexander Papanastasiou of Greece, known as "the Father of Greek Democracy" because of his part in the founding of the Republic of Greece, in an interview here yesterday at the Hotel St. Moritz asked the support of the 600,000 Greek-Americans in developing national unity in Greece to rid that country of its present political unrest.

FIFTEEN American singers have been added to the Salmaggi Opera Company for its performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. These are Blanche Dewalt, Eleanor Little, Pina Sarro, Merya Grayson, Viena Mayblon, Eva May Krom, Vita Bufalo, Mary Makanova and Elizabeth White, sopranos; Regina Bellini, Frances Gaile and Costanza Mankel, contraltos; Henry Johnson, Albert W. Beewalte and Robert J. Elinor, tenors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Roosevelt-Howard secret correspondence, released at Hyde Park on Friday to a not-too-astonished world, was obviously no spontaneous matter.

PANAMA. -- The public debt of Nicaragua, slightly more than $8,000,000, averages less than $11 per capita, and interest and part of the amortization were paid promptly last year, according to the report of Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, American Collector General of Customs, to President Juan B. Sacasa and the Secretary of Finance.

IN the public life of Britain, as doubtless in that of the United States, there is a small but noisy section of people who have been justly described as "bloodthirsty pacifists." On the one hand, they fight tooth and nail against adequate defensive armaments; on the other, they are constantly meddling in the affairs of foreign nations and demanding "sanctions," which is a euphemism for war, against any country of whose actions they disapprove.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 7. -- With classes for jumpers featuring the session, competition in the two-day Long Branch horse show started today. The event, staged in a ring pitched on the grounds of the Auguste N. Montulet Riding School, is being held for the benefit of the Long Branch Elks' Crippled Kiddies Fund.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 7. -- A challenge to Federal interference in the affairs of Louisiana, now under complete control of Senator Huey P. Long, whose domination is probably to be investigated by a Congressional committee, was offered at a special session of the Legislature convened tonight at 10 o'clock, midnight New York time.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Maintaining a sub-par pace that gave him a 69 yesterday, Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., former Westchester caddie, obtained an undisputed lead in the Glens Falls open golf tourney today with a thirty-six-hole score of 139.

ROME, Sept. 7 (AP). -- A government spokesman tonight said that the Italian Minister at Addis Ababa, acting on his own initiative, had withdrawn Italian consular employes in Ethiopia to Addis Ababa. He did this, it was explained, on his own initiative and not under orders of the Foreign Office.

The three airmen who robbed the Cathedral of Pamplona, Spain, the other morning and then flew away over the Pyrenees have not only on their track Scotland Yard, which was first communicated with because the Madrid police supposed that the bandits were Englishmen, but the police of eleven nations besides, according to information gathered by The News-Chronicle of London.

THE combination of the old and the modern in Russia lends a spice to the communities of that changing land. Russia realizes that it has many features that are valuable for their very age. The result is a program of modernization in industry and in social planning paralleled by an attempt to preserve that which is old and distinctive.

State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday the appointment of four committees to study and map a program for the Interstate Industrial Compacts Commission of New York State, of which he is chairman.

THE Max Baer-Joe Louis heavyweight bout scheduled for Sept. 24 at the Yankee Stadium will be described direct from the ringside over the combined WEAF-WJZ networks. The gong will open the fight and the broadcast at 10 P.M. It is expected that Graham McNamee and Ford Bond will describe the blows and sidelights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Charles E. Stuart, vice president of the Export-Import Bank, said today that loans completed to date amounted to $8,795,280.21, of which $7,000,000 represents the Cuban silver guarantee. Commitments approved by the bank and awaiting acceptance by the applicants aggregate $32,013,327 and projects now under consideration by the bank amount to $23,074,270.

NO MORE DIET: Helen Hayes, in private life Mrs. Charles MacArthur, set her course last week for London and fifty pounds (avoirdupois, not sterling). She sailed from New York to confer with Laurence Housman, in whose play, "Victoria Regina," she will appear on Broadway in December.

DEL RIO, Texas. -- Whether the Texas Rangers under the new coordinated State police system of Texas will mark the decline of the famous organization or the opening of a new chapter of outstanding service is a question that Texans throughout the State are wondering.

JOHN EGLINTON'E name and work have long been known to those who follow with any closeness the course of Anglo-Irish literature. His portrait hangs in that most entertaining of all Dublin galleries, "Hail and Farewell," and he is also in "Ulysses," the other great point of reference for Anglo-Irish letters.

Blaming the "kick-back" system, under which wholesale liquor salesmen allegedly split commissions with retailers in order to get orders, for a large part of the current price-cutting in liquor retailing, members of the Wholesale Wine and Spirits Merchants Association have joined with the Society of Spirit Salesmen in a joint effort to end the practice.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- Two Californians, Miss Jacque Virgil of Beverly Hills and Miss Patricia Henry of Los Angeles, were among the first to reach the quarter-final round in the girls' national tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

HERE is a saga of Irish boyhood made up of ten corking adventures, in most of which the Bold Blades of Donegal reenact, among the mountains and valleys inland from Inver Bay, all the bloodthirsty encounters between Irish and English that have most appealed to them in ballad or history.

HARLAN, Ky., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Harlan citizens voted under National Guard guns for the third time in two years today as Kentuckians registered their verdict between two Democratic factions in the State-wide run-off primary, nominating candidates for Governor and other offices.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- All-time records in Philadelphia were believed to be broken tonight as the polls closed on registration of voters for the municipal election. Today was the last of the three Fall registration days.

WINCHESTER, Va., Sept. 7 (AP). -- While terming President Roosevelt's announcement of a "breathing spell" "both timely and gratifying," Senator Byrd declared today that "the next logical step is to make a drastic reduction in governmental spending in recognition of improved business conditions."

HARLAN, Ky., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Harlan citizens voted under National Guard guns for the third time in two years today as Kentuckians registered their verdict between two Democratic factions in the State-wide run-off primary, nominating candidates for Governor and other offices.

THIS novel, Briffault's first, has been awaited as an important event. Its publication proves it to be one. It comes as close as any writer using the English language has come toward depicting and interpreting, on a really large scale, the society of pre-war Europe. Here is Proust's world spread over an entire continent; here is the stuff of innumerable Edwardian memoirs given a sturdier form and a more imaginative expression.

RAIN and storms in many sections of the country held down retail trade volume during the week, which would have been affected anyway by the holiday. Some districts that had been reporting the sharpest gains found business moving only about even with last year. School wear was described as the most active department.

THERE are few poets whose death would have any considerable "news value" nowadays, but the passing of Sir William Watson was placarded by our evening papers as the most notable event of the day. The Times thinks this highly significant, since it had become the fashion to regard him as a Victorian out of touch with modern life and thought.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- John Cunniff and Frank Giessen of the Branch Brook Park public golf course, medalists and defending champions, moved through two rounds in the third annual New Jersey best-ball championship at the Hackensack Golf Club today to enter the semi-finals.

THE hitch-hiker is out of luck. Once the picturesque knight-errant of the highways, he is today considered at best a nuisance, at worst a dangerous racketeer. With a mounting record of robberies, assaults and even murders traced to harmless-looking thumb-wavers along the road, police and lawmakers in many States have declared war on the free rider.
RETHEL, France, Sept. 7 (AP). -- France's modernized army on wheels was found swift and strong but costly today by Col. Jean Fabry, Minister of War, in manoeuvres over old battlefields.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- For a belated vacation, President Roosevelt has come back to a Hudson River estate with a sprawling house, shaded by century-old trees, that is home to four generations of the Roosevelt family. Here he finds the rest he cannot find elsewhere.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Percy Hubbard, Fairbanks flier, whose plane crashed Tuesday 100 miles up the Chena River as he was searching for his missing partner, Arthur Hines, was found today by a rescue party.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 7. -- Paul Shield's six-meter yacht Challenge was chosen today to defend the Seawankaha Cup against Crown Prince Olaf's Norna of Norway, and also joined two others on the team which will face a Scandinavian trio for a special trophy.

In his recent letter "Political Observer" seems to be disturbed by the possibility that Senator Borah may be the next Republican nominee for the Presidency. Apparently the gentleman from Idaho is objectionable on a number of grounds, not least of which is his undeviating dry record.

EXCEPT on rainy days, children forget their toys at this time of year and find their amusement out of doors -- in playgrounds, at swimming pools, on beaches and in parks. With Christmas nearly four months away and not a flake of snow in sight, it is hard for junior to remember that he must be a good boy now if he wishes to be visited by Santa Claus later.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Joseph Hankins of Empire, Ala., won the Crowell Trophy rifle match with a perfect score of 50, it was announced today at the headquarters of the national rifle matches.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 8. -- "The concession was signed, sealed and delivered, and I shall have five years as the period within which I am obliged to begin operations," said Francis W. Rickett late this afternoon when he landed at Suez from the steamship Porthos.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- Conjectures that the position of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, in the present Nazi government has been shaken are declared in informed circles to be baseless. It is admitted, however, that he is still more unpopular among Nazi extremists since his speech at Koenigsberg condemning anti-Jewish disorders and his later speech at the opening of the new Reich Chamber of Economy.
GREEN VILLAGE, N.J., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Time in the last year has stood still for Chief Officer William F. Warms, his wife and their child.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrives today with 1,950 passengers from Bremen and Channel ports. Among them are Junius S. Morgan and S. Parker Gilbert, bankers; Cyrus H. McCormick of Chicago, and Mrs. McCormick; Jan Kiepura, Polish tenor; Mrs. James Donahue and her son J. Woolworth Donahue, and Raymond Loewy, industrial engineer.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- If war breaks out at the end of this month, Italy will strike her first blow at Adowa, hoping to avenge on the spot by a resounding triumph the great disaster of 1896. It is believed armored cars and tanks will play an important part in the offensive.

IN "Freedom of the Press" (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.75) George Seldes has done for the newspaper business what James Rorty's "Our Master's Voice" did for advertising: he has assembled numerous instances of bad judgment, human frailty and outright corruption and has returned a blanket indictment. Just how far the indictment is relevant cannot be determined, however, for Mr. Seldes's philosophy is not clear.

Francesca Braggiotti, wife of John Lodge, who surrendered his legal practice here for a successful career on the American and French screen, will leave for Italy tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia, where she will study Italian folk lore and dances with the intent of composing a modern Italian folk ballet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- In the most optimistic statement on the recovery movement it has yet made, the American Federation of Labor today said that business was showing greater vitality than in any upswing since 1933 and that "the last four months of 1935 may well bring the highest level of industrial operations and earnings for any similar period since 1930."

More than 4,500 musicians have been aided during the last four years by the Musicians Emergency Fund, according to a statement issued yesterday by the board of directors, of which Walter Damrosch is chairman.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas entertained a large number of their friends at a luncheon at the Clambake Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Consumers of electric current saved in the year ended on June 30 more than $47,000,000, and if savings subsequent to that date are included, they approximate $60,000,000, according to an electric rate survey made by the Federal Power Commission.

OVER the links of the Country Club of Cleveland there will now start another attempt of the United States Golf Association to discover whether golf is an ancient and honorable game or just good clean fun for the kiddies.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 8 (AP). -- A stormy but futile attempt to pass a resolution favoring immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus stirred the closing session today of the second New England Conference of Young Republicans. The organization opposed the processing tax and voted not to commit itself to a Presidential candidate.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Catholic church favors union of the State and the people, but under God's leadership, Bishop Konrad Preysing said today, referring to the German church controversy in a pastoral letter read in all churches of the Berlin Diocese.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- Carl Hubbell was the man of the hour for the Giants today. In fact, he was their man for one hour and fifty-one minutes as he spun a six-hit performance to pitch the Terrymen to victory over the Pirates in the opening clash of their four-game series here.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 9. -- Partisan differences within the groups composing the national Cabinet compelled Premier Keisuke Okada today to take charge of the Communications Ministry temporarily.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 8. -- A "blind" giant transport plane completed a sightless flight from Newark to Municipal Airport here today in what D.W. (Tommy) Tomlinson, who piloted the ship strictly by radio beam and calculation, said was the longest such trip ever made by a commercial aircraft.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Fred Jacoby Jr., veteran driver of North Bergen, N.J., who recently won the New Jersey State championships in Classes A, B, C and F, today demonstrated that he will be the outstanding contender in the Eastern championships late in the month at Philadelphia.

The Hayden Planetarium at Central Park West and Eighty-first Street will be opened to the public at 10 o'clock Thursday morning, Oct. 3, it was announced yesterday by F. Trubee Davison, president of the Planetarium Authority and of the American Museum of Natural History, of which it forms a part.
The sale of a factory in Newark and the foreclosure of a theatre in North Bergen featured New Jersey realty trading over the week-end.

HEWLETT, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Martin Rudich, 22 years old, son of Magistrate Mark Rudich of Brooklyn, was arraigned this morning before Justice of the Peace George Johnson in the Bellmore court on a charge of driving while intoxicated. He was paroled in the custody of his mother, Mrs. Rae Rudich, who is Democratic co-leader of the Sixth Assembly District, Brooklyn, for a further hearing Sept. 18.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean and five other members of the league-leading Cardinals' hurling corps pitched two four-hit games today, but the Phillies got the "breaks" to take the nightcap, 4 to 2, after being blanked, 11 to 0, in the opener.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- More than 1,000 persons, including survivors and relatives of victims, attended memorial services for the Morro Castle dead here today.

Magistrate BRODSKY was probably the most surprised man in this city at his own sudden leap into international fame or opprobrium. He may have done his duty in the case of the men charged with rioting on the German steamer Bremen when she was in this port.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Consumers' Division of the NRA has started an attack on consumer problems under authority of an order by the President, for the purpose of maintaining and bettering the American standard of living.
Admiral SIMS, long the stormy petrel of the naval service, in the September Atlantic criticizes the navy's system of promotion. He writes:

John R. Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, has sent a letter to stockholders asking their support in a proxy fight against John S. Hammond, chairman, for control of the annual meeting on Sept. 24. Mr. Kilpatrick, in his letter, says only two of the present directors of the corporation have aligned themselves with Mr. Hammond's committee.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Kentucky waited amid a political hush today to learn the outcome of one of the State's bitterest factional battles in many years, 'which closed with the Democratic State-wide run-off primary Saturday. A Governor and other officers were nominated.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Greentree, with Thomas Hitchcock Jr. playing as well as he has all Summer, found stern resistance before defeating reorganized Westbury at the Sands Point Club today in a polo match hastily arranged when it was decided that the field, a very quick drying one, would permit practice for the open championship.

While business volume was small in the cotton markets last week, prices held within a narrow range. Active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated only 16 to 24 points. Net changes for the week ranged from an advance of 5 points to a decline of 1 point.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The statement of the Bank of France dated Aug. 30 shows a normal month-end expansion in discounts and bank notes in circulation. An increase of 133,000,000 francs in the gold reserve caused no surprise, for in the last week of August the firmness of sterling against the franc became attenuated and the market held without the necessity for the British Equalization Fund to intervene.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6. -- Trading in the cotton market here was rather sluggish last week although there were occasional spurts of activity. Price fluctuations were frequent but comparatively narrow and were influenced mainly by transferring from October to the later months and the various private crop estimates which appeared in the week.
ROME, Sept. 8 (AP). -- For the second time within a month, it was announced officially today, the rediscount rate of the Bank of Italy has been increased.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's crowded agenda compelled him to dispose of a diplomatic ceremony today which under normal conditions is reserved for any ordinary weekday, and as a result pedestrians along the Wilhelmstrasse were treated to an unusual Sunday spectacle this noon.

ROME, Sept. 8. -- Premier Benito Mussolini proclaimed today in two brief speeches that the Italian people "want peace provided it is ac companied by justice," and on the other hand, "we shall march straight on."

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- History turned back its pages almost 200 years today for a glimpse of rugged pioneer America and the burial of the skeletons of four Massachusetts volunteers who lost their lives in the famous battle of Bloody Morning Scout on Sept. 8, 1755.

The promotion of 56 members of the New York University faculty for the university's one hundred and fourth academic year, which will begin this month, was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 8. -- With their usual inconsistency the Dodgers climaxed a three-game losing streak to the Pirates by taking two decisions from the Reds today and tightening their hold on fifth place.
SPRINGFIELD, Col., Sept. 8 (AP). -- A mother and her four children huddled in a cave throughout last night to escape a storm which blew their farm home away and drenched this dust bowl area.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- With the filing in Washington of a formal protest by the Reich through Dr. Hans Luther, the German Ambassador, the indignation in the press over Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky's indictment of the National Socialist Germany cooled down even if its sting continued to irritate and the incident was made the occasion for anti-Semitic exploitation by the more extreme Nazi newspapers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Losing a double-header to the Browns and running their losing streak to eleven straight, the Athletics fell into the American League cellar today while the victorious Browns took possession of seventh place.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Sept. 8. -- While six striking employes were picketing the residence of F.J. Schlink, author and technical director of Consumers Research, Inc., near here, early this afternoon, A. Robert Rogers, one of the pickets, was knocked down by an automobile.

Huey Pierce Long has many friends and many enemies, a statement that could well be made about any man who has delved as deeply into the political world as he. But in the case of Senator Long his enemies have received more publicity than his friends.

What the Christian world needs today is the passing of the old law that might makes right, the Rev. Dr. Paul T. Shultz declared in his opening sermon at the First Moravian Church, Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street, where services were resumed yesterday morning following the Summer recess.
Fred Perry of Great Britain found himself in the tightest spot he has known in the entire season of championship play yesterday with 13,000 spectators making a bedlam of the Forest Hills Stadium.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 9. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's counselors urged him today to maintain an iron front in the face of new peace schemes emanating from Geneva, which they feared might endanger Ethiopia's independence.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- While the Abyssinian dispute continued to be the centre of public interest, its depressing influence on business slackened and after midweek the Boerse suddenly became active and strong.
Generous applause sounded in the city's burlesque theatres yesterday as the chorus girls, having bested the producers in a three-day strike, went back to work.

Foreign exchanges were under pressure last week, an aftermath of the tense political situation growing out of the Italian-Ethiopian affair. Invariable lower cables from abroad, before our opening here, gave a hint of the unsettlement there and was followed here by local operators. The trading pace was not fast, business on the whole being light and the demand at a low ebb.

Factors making for strength in the steel markets continue to dominate, as the steel industry enters a period which is expected to develop somewhat more than the normal Fall pick-up, according to the magazine Steel's weekly review.

No new candidates come to Broadway tonight, but a couple of old friends are dropping in to renew acquaintanceship. At the Belasco there will be for three weeks or more the Group Theatre's double bill of Odets plays, "Awake and Sing!" and "Waiting for Lefty." To the Longacre comes "Kind Lady," starring Grace George. The cast of each play remains as it was.

Memorial services for the victims of the Morro Castle disaster, in which 124 persons lost their lives, were held yesterday afternoon by the Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association at Public School 59, 228 East Fifty-seventh Street. Seventy-five members of the association, survivors and relatives of victims of the tragedy, attended.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 8. -- A group of 150 members of the Profile Club, an organization of men interested in insurance, and their wives are passing the week end at the Maplewood Club, where a dinner, golf and tennis events and bridge for the women were enjoyed today.

Falling leaves, a touch of brown in the foliage and coolish evenings are not the only portents of Autumn. Signs that gunning days lie just ahead also are provided by the influx of mail from the boys who operate shooting preserves in adjacent areas.

In an address to Italian veterans yesterday, MUSSOLINI declared that he wanted peace, but that it must be "peace with justice." That was almost an exact repetition of the language of the Pope a day or two earlier. His Holiness, however, went further than the Duce, by asserting that he had special information which led him to believe that there would he an adjustment of the controversy between Italy and Ethiopia without war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Republican National Committee declared today that the business, financial and industrial interests of this country do not want "merely a breathing spell" from President Roosevelt's regime -- "they want a complete rest cure."

So far the business recovery of the last few months has had very little effect on railroad earnings. In the first six months of this year the Class I railroads suffered a net loss of $62,000,000, as compared with a net loss of $23,000,000 in the same period last year.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8. -- The classical Chinese drama, "Lady Precious Stream," which was translated by Dr. S.I. Hsiung and has been running 300 nights in the Little Theatre in London, will open in New York early in November, it was announced here today by Morris Gest, who has obtained the American rights.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- The Bank of France will come to the rescue of the wine market just as a month ago it aided wheat, Pierre Cathala, Minister of Agriculture, announced today in an address at Ambert. The bank will advance money through the Credit Agricole Fund to farmers desiring to hold back their wine but needing ready cash to do so.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8. -- Slightly more than 200 of the nation's leading linksmen were bivouacked here tonight awaiting the call to arms tomorrow when the firing starts in the thirty-ninth national amateur championship.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The tendency of the stock market here has remained a set affair this week, dealings being slightly more active and not only for speculative account. Heavy buying was noted for investment. The stock and money markets, therefore, disclose a trend by hoarded capital to seek reinvestment.

The Governors Island poloists rode into the semi-final round of the Second Corps Area's ninth annual fifteen-goal invitation tournament by subduing the New York Athletic Club at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday. The officers gave away one goal by handicap, but gained the decision at 8 -- 6.
Your charming, hay-scented editorial, "September Pastoral," revives other bucolic memories.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- A chaotic situation exists in the world's wheat markets. There are many conditions that have never existed heretofore, but there were indications at the close of last week that there is likely to be a speedy readjustment in supplies, demand and price movements.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Red Sox moved from fifth to fourth place in the American League race today, changing places with the White Sox, whom they defeated, 6 to 2 and 5 to 2, in a double-header attended by 23,000.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 8. -- A monster demonstration was held this morning in the form of a parade through the principal streets of La Paz in protest against Paraguay's refusal to proceed immediately with the repatriation of prisoners. Similar demonstrations were held in all other Bolivian cities.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a list of what it characterized as "itemized recommendations" for reductions totaling $13,638,490 in city appropriations to keep the city budget for 1936 within the $539,000,000 limit set last week by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The greater ease which was noticed in August in the money market here became accentuated after the month-end expansion, call money falling from 2 3/4 to 2 5/8 per cent. The outside discount rate, however, remains between 2 3/4 and 3 per cent.

A verbal picture of frightened women braced against sliding furniture and wearing awkward lifebelts, but constantly dabbing powder on their noses and touching up their lips, was presented yesterday morning at the Pennsylvania Station by Sol J. Lupoff, who recounted his impressions of the steamship Dixie's near-disaster on a hurricane-swept reef off Southern Florida.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 8. -- Negligence played no part in the failure to evacuate the 684 World War veterans from camps in the Florida Keys before 282 were killed and 106 were injured in the hurricane last week, Aubrey Williams, representing Harry L. Hopkins, and Colonel George E. Ijams, representing General Frank T. Hines, reported tonight to President Roosevelt.
Developments were late in arriving yesterday at the Stadium, but, in the end, the Yankees took a double-header from Steve O'Neill's Cleveland Indians before an approving crowd of 30,000.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 8. -- The fifty-five-foot yacht "Marmari," owned by R. McCullough of New Rochelle, N.Y., burned and sank after a series of explosions on board on Long Island Sound tonight five miles off Sherwood Island, Westport.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8. -- Before the shooting at the Capitol tonight Senator Long's batch of special session bills, including three aimed at drastic curtailment of New Deal activities in Louisiana, were ready to be advanced to third reading in the House for final passage tomorrow. They were sent through the House Ways and Means Committee at a session this morning which lasted only an hour.
LONDON, Sept. 7. -- So far as the conflict between Italy and Ethiopia is concerned, there seems, in the City's judgment, to be only slender hopes that this will be avoided.

MOUNT STERLING, Ill., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Frank Orr's $40,000 private potlatch was the brightest event of his eighty-third birthday anniversary today as he received the felicitations of the forty nieces and nephews or their heirs, to each of whom he gave a $1,000 check.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Raynor, who have had the Stephen Kelsey place on Lee Avenue this season, entertained at a buffet supper and dance there last night for eighty guests.

In letters to THE TIMES under captions of "Our Indecisive Position" and "Peace Until February," each writer has ably described and deplored our unwillingness to contribute by protest our moral influence in an effort to check a world conflagration.

Prices moved generally higher last week in the commodity futures markets here, with interest centred in wool tops. In the cash markets all commodities moved higher except pork, tin, silk, rubber and hides.

GENEVA, Sept. 8. -- The economic depression, the refugee problem and the status of women promise to dominate the meeting of the sixteenth Assembly of the League of Nations, which opens tomorrow, as long as the Italian threat to Ethiopia, Britain and the covenant remains confined to the Council.

Colonel Henry Breckinridge, former Assistant Secretary of War, declared yesterday that "monetary witch doctors of Washington" had created a "silver racket" that permitted speculators to reap a harvest and drained China of its silver money.

Christ's conception of truth and justice has had a marked effect on the governmental principles of this country since its foundation, the Rev. John Marshall Chew of Newburgh, N.Y., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Nemesis caught up with Matthew Lynch, alias Chewie, a well-built six-footer who could not keep out of trouble, some time Saturday night. His bullet-pierced body was found at 11 o'clock yesterday morning twenty feet from the west rim of Winchester Boulevard, between Grand Central Parkway and Nassau Boulevard, Douglaston, Queens.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8. -- United States Senator Huey P. Long was shot through the stomach and gravely wounded tonight as he walked from the chamber of the Louisiana House of Representatives, where he had been directing the passage of bills aimed to strengthen his grip upon the politics of the State and to fight the New Deal and Roosevelt policies.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Developments at Geneva in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute continue to weigh heavily on the markets here and it is almost certain that they will blow hot or cold as events there pursue their tortuous course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Department of Commerce estimates that the American fleet of wind ships which still is trying to compete with the steam engine in ocean trade, has dwindled to around a dozen vessels.

Tammany, out of power in New York City for two years and with little patronage from the Democratic State and national administrations, is having an unprecedented number of district leadership fights in anticipation of a victory in the municipal election of 1937.

It has usually been a familiar experience for trade activities and financial markets to hesitate for a few weeks after Labor Day, awaiting some distant sign of Autumn tendencies. As a matter of record, every year since 1928 has witnessed in September decreasing trade and falling markets.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- A good volume of business with irregular and higher range of prices was handled in all grain futures here last week. Closing prices were around the best levels of the week with a more cheerful feeling among holders. Changing of trades from near to distant months furnished a large part of the business.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- A closer study of the town-government problem with a view to eliminating both politics and the multiple overlapping agencies of municipal and county organizations was urged by President Roosevelt tonight in an impromptu talk to a large group of his neighbors.

The Christian ideal for marriage and the home was discussed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Robbins W. Barstow, president of the Hartford Seminary Foundation, Hartford, Conn., at the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 181st Street.

The screams of two children attracted the attention of Patrolman Daniel Collins last night about 6 o'clock as he was walking along Pier 10 at the foot of Old Slip. Running to the end of the pier, he found the children leaning over the dock shouting hysterically to an object splashing around in the waters of the East River below.

The Philadelphia Company and subsidiaries, not including the Beaver Valley Traction Company, which is in receivership, and its subsidiary, have reported for the year ended on July 31 gross operating revenues of $46,878,880, compared with $46,893,596 in the preceding year.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 8. -- A member of the National Assembly, Victor Florencia Goytia, is holding at bay at his residence policemen who have an order for his arrest in connection with the recent theft of machine guns and other arms and of ammunition from the United States Army at Corozal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Collection of $3,299,435,572 in Federal internal revenue taxes in the 1934-35 fiscal year, the heaviest tax collections in fourteen years, were reported officially today by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

During the past month of lively political discussion most of the Republican talk relating to 1936 has been on candidacies rather than on national needs and party essentials. And in all the discussion no one has been named who offers any promise of leadership fitted to prevailing political conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today that lumber shipments during the week ended Aug. 31 made another advance to the highest reported point of the year with the exception of two weeks in April.
ALMA, Col., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Fire which trapped them in a mountainside bunkhouse as they slept killed six gold miners early today. Twelve others broke through a small window and escaped.

POMPTON, LAKES, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Joe Louis, whose punches are compared to dynamite, failed to put any one of his four sparring partners on the floor in his workout today, his hardest since he set up headquarters here in preparation for his 15-round bout with Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 24.
Tiny motor boats churned bubbly wakes in the conservatory lake in Central Park yesterday at the annual regatta of the New York Society of Model Engineers.

Although supporters of Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, expressed confidence yesterday in his re-election, the group of leaders opposed to him predicted that Mr. Mellen would be defeated when the new county committee meets for organization ten days after the primary election on Sept. 17.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- A speech by Hartford MacNider, former United States Minister to Canada, scheduled for delivery tonight at a Republican rally here, was delivered by radio, the rally being postponed because of rain.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8. -- Edward Laurence Doheny, who wrested one of the world's largest fortunes from the oil fields of California and Mexico, died at 8 o'clock tonight at his home here. He was 79 years old.

James McDade, Millrose A.A. star, captured the metropolitan A.A.U. 20,000-meter championship run, which was held under the auspices of the Hudson Democratic Club in Manhattan yesterday. The victor finished strongly, about 100 yards ahead of John Thompson of the Tappen Post of the American Legion.

A reception for former Prime Minister Alexander Papanastasiou of Greece by 6,000 Greek-American republican sympathizers at Mecca Temple yesterday afternoon was interrupted for five minutes while a police detail forcibly ejected A.A. Athenson, Greek-American royalist leader, his wife and their 8-year-old daughter for starting a monarchist demonstration.

What the world needs most is more of the spirit of Mary, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at high mass yesterday morning. He exhorted the congregation to pray to "the all-powerful Mother of God" for the improvement of world conditions and the preservation of Christian civilization.

Newsreels showing Joseph Bolognia confessing to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn that he killed Edwin Esposito, B.M.T. collector, during a hold-up will go on exhibition for two days, starting tomorrow night, at the Embassy Newsreel Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Senator Long had a passion for being guarded. In New Orleans and other parts of Louisiana he was always accompanied by his private bodyguards and at times by squads of militia. In Washington he was without military protection but his bodyguard was with him always except when the Senator was on the floor of the Senate. Whether or not Mr. Long carried a gun himself is doubtful.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The facility with which the huge amount of United States war bonds was converted has impressed French financiers greatly, especially as in the same period the Federal Treasury has not ceased borrowing to cover its budget deficit.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- George Lansbury, head of the British Labor party, said tonight that he was seriously considering resigning his leadership because of the conflict between his own unalterable pacifism and the new tendency among some of his party followers to favor force if necessary to prevent Italy's waging war on Ethiopia.

Russia has developed into one of the most profitable markets, while Denmark has ceased, at least temporarily, to provide any field for United States goods, according to Robert C. Lee, vice president of the American Scantic Line. Mr. Lee returned last week from a two-month trip to Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Estonia, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Germany and Belgium.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 8. -- Sixteen new gold mining properties graduated from the ranks of prospects in the last year to swell Ontario's gold production. This, with increased operations of established companies, accounted for a rise of $143,169 in the recovery of gold in the six months ended on June 30, compared with the first half of 1934.
Contracts for the sale of properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were announced over the week-end.

The Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, stated clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, pleaded for a rallying of the resources of the church to combat the evils of present-day world conditions in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
STALINO, Ukraine, U.S.S.R., Sept. 8. -- A runaway airship, boarded in midair by its captain, was brought safely back to port today after a six-hour struggle against the elements.

GENEVA, Sept. 8. -- In the lull that has fallen upon the Italo-Ethiopian negotiations here it is possible to take account of the progress that has been made so far. It is impossible to escape the conviction that this progress has been more apparent than real.

ROME, Sept. 8. -- A word of peace passed the lips of Premier Benito Mussolini for the first time in months this morning when, in speaking to the international conclave of war veterans that was addressed by Pope Pius yesterday, he said that "Italy loves peace."

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Prices of livestock, particularly hogs, fluctuated so fast here last week that it was difficult for traders to keep track of them. Hogs advanced $2 a 100 pounds in the week, reaching $12.45, or, including the processing tax, $14.45.

Three men were shot and one of them killed just before 3 A.M. today when two gunmen drove their automobile alongside a taxicab at Northern Boulevard and Thirty-first Street, Long Island City, and opened fire without warning.
Anthony Cugino, Philadelphia desperado, sought for many months in connection with eight murders, committed suicide shortly before midnight last night in his cell at police headquarters.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8. -- The second Congregational minister to give up his pastorate in the past few months, the Rev. Lyman H. Merrill tendered his resignation from the pulpit, at morning service today, as pastor of the historic Stanwich Congregational Church.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 8. -- Statistics denoting a preference of American transatlantic travelers for American ships are seen by Galliard Ravenel, shipping executive, as a challenge to the shipping industry and the government to join hands in building a greater merchant marine.

ALBANY, Sept. 7. -- Governor Lehman announced today that the public conference called by him to discuss "Crime, the Criminal and Society'' will open on the evening of Sept. 30, probably in the Senate chamber, and will run through Oct. 1, 2 and 3.

Funeral services for Robert E. Simon, prominent real estate operator, who died Saturday at his home, 404 Riverside Drive, will be held at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning in Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street. As chairman of the building committee of Town Hall, Mr. Simon was largely responsible for the erection of the present home of the organization.

Change is an integral part of the universe, not only in material and organic things, but also in the spiritual and intellectual world, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland declared yesterday in his sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, East Sixteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square.

" The value of an ordered life is wholly lost the moment it usurps a place of primary importance," the Rev. George A. Trowbridge, the rector, said yesterday morning in his sermon at All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.
My associates and I have been much interested in Francis Brown's thoughtful article "An Inquiry Into the New England Mind."

The American Youth Congress, which claims 853 affiliated organizations with 1,350,000 members, attacked President Roosevelt's National Youth Administration yesterday and charged that it was insincere in its program for youth welfare.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- The brilliant young actor-manager, John Gielgud, who is now scoring in the title role of "Noah," soon will produce "Romeo and Juliet," with Laurence Olivier and himself alternating in the parts of Romeo and Mercutio, with Peggy Ashcroft as Juliet and Edith Evans as the Nurse. (Miss Evans acted the Nurse for several weeks last season in New York in the Katharine Cornell version.)

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Black Eagle, agile black gelding belonging to Mrs. Adam Gimbel, and Vanity Box, striking chestnut mare owned by Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farms, scored in the two championship sweepstake events which marked the closing session of the two-day Long Branch Horse Show today.

A conference to bring about a settlement of the strike of garment shipping clerks will be held at 4 P.M. today at the Hotel New Yorker. Representatives of eight employer associations and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union will take part.

Montclair, N.J., is the site of what some will call a mistaken public works project. More than one hundred citizens of that well-known community have banded themselves together to put a new coat of paint on the Erie Railroad station and otherwise freshen up what they describe as the "old red barn."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Champion Southball Moonstone of Halcyon, greyhound owned by the Halcyon kennels of Edward T. Clark of Goshen, today won the handsome piece of plate offered by John H. Morrison for best in show at the exhibition of the Middletown Kennel Club.

Magistrate David Hirshfield of Brooklyn, who announced last week that he would retire when his term expires on Sept. 23, made public yesterday a letter he had sent to Mayor La Guardia expressing his continued friendship for the Mayor in spite of rumors that the Mayor had decided not to reappoint him.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Dividing a double-header with Albany on the final day of the regular season Newark captured fourth place in the International League and qualified for the Governors' Cup playoffs, which start Tuesday.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Six Canadian airplanes carrying eighteen persons arrived here today on a Montreal-Roosevelt Field goodwill flight, returning the courtesy of the flight made to Canada in July by several American planes piloted by Long Island sportsmen and aviators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- After having been slowed down moderately for a few days by the observance of Labor Day, business in this territory regained almost all the losses in the latter part of last week and made a better showing in the closing days.

Activity in the wholesale markets here last week was featured by a heavy volume of mail orders in all departments, but the shipping clerks' and truckmen's strike seriously retarded deliveries in the ready-to-wear division. With the new lines more complete, apparel buyers are expected to arrive in the market in large numbers this week.

PINEBROOK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Eager to see Monmouth County's notorious wild dogs before the local vigilantes train shotguns on the animals on Sept. 21, scores of urban visitors jolted down the dirt road from Red Bank today and conducted intrepid search parties.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Three American boats, a British ship, twenty men and a cargo valued at $200,000 -- one of the largest captures since prohibition was repealed -- were seized by Cape May Coast Guards shortly before last midnight ten miles southeast of Atlantic City.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 7. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.5, which compares with 84.3 the week before, 84.6. two weeks before, 83.7 three weeks before and 83.1 four weeks before.

MOSCOW Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Soviet icebreaker Sadko announced by radio today it had discovered three new islands in the unexplored Arctic zone between Franz Josef Land and Northern Land, formerly Nicholas II Land.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 8 (By cable). -- In the face of new efforts of the League of Nations to avert Italo-Ethiopian hostilities, significance was seen here in the preparations made by Swedish instructors at the Ethiopian artillery school, thirty miles from Addis Ababa, to send their wives and children out of the country.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- The Rev. Henry Purcell Veazie has resigned as rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church here to accept a call to the pastorate of St. Francis's Episcopal Church in San Francisco, one of the best known of the communion in that city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- By this time next year the government plans to have a card index completed which will show, with a flip of the wrist, the exact age of every man, woman and child listed in the 1900 census.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- The Interclub sloops of Long Island Sound and the One-design boats of Bermuda began their international match series today under the auspices of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- Stock corporations formed in the State in August numbered 1,413, as against 1,450 for the same period of last year, it was reported today by the corporation bureau of the Secretary of State's office. This brings the total number of new concerns, formed to date this year up to 12,690.

The world is on the verge of another great war because of human faithlessness, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said in a peace message made public here yesterday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 48 per cent of capacity, against 50 per cent in the preceding week and 51 per cent in the week before that, which was the highest week of the year excepting the four weeks through Feb. 16.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Royal Reveler, big chestnut gelding of the Tanrackin Stables, retained the Wyoming Challenge Plate today in the feature event of the sixth annual Tanrackin horse show held on the Gustavus T. Kirby estate.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 8. -- There can be no permanent recovery in industrial aid economic conditions in this country without the three fundamentals of a balanced budget, a sound currency and economy in government, Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, told the opening session of the twenty-second annual national business conference at Babson Park here today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Had those responsible in industry and government accepted the philosophy of trade unions and reduced the work week to take care of mechanized production there would have been less suffering in the world. Charles P. Howard, general president of the International Typographical Union, told the annual convention gathered here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, seeded first, reached the quarter-final round of the eighteenth annual girls' national tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today. She beat Miss Jean Harshaw of Philadelphia, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

Oswald Jacoby, a member of the Four Aces contract bridge team, which has dominated the field of bridge competition for two years, won the masters' individual championship of the American Bridge League yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Ambassador.

Because they were "not adequately protected by enforcement of existing laws," thirty persons have lost their lives in tenement fires in New York City this year, seventeen welfare and housing organizations point out in a petition they have just presented to Mayor LaGuardia asking for a public hearing on the 1936 budget of the Tenement House Department and urging the employment of 390 additional tenement inspectors.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Forty-five-year-old Willie Macfarlane of Tuckahoe, N.Y., proved again that he is still a great tournament golfer by capturing the Glens Falls open with a record-breaking score of 274 today.

WARSAW, Sept. 8. -- Prime Minister Walery Slawek had some 180 Deputies returned to office today in the new Sejm of 208 members. The remaining members of the new Parliament include some Ukrainian Jews and a few Radical peasants, who will not oppose the regime which excluded all political parties from the electoral contests.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, seeded first, reached the quarter-final round of the eighteenth annual girls' national tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today. She beat Miss Jean Harshaw of Philadelphia, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

Oswald Jacoby, a member of the Four Aces contract bridge team, which has dominated the field of bridge competition for two years, won the masters' individual championship of the American Bridge League yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Ambassador.

Because they were "not adequately protected by enforcement of existing laws," thirty persons have lost their lives in tenement fires in New York City this year, seventeen welfare and housing organizations point out in a petition they have just presented to Mayor LaGuardia asking for a public hearing on the 1936 budget of the Tenement House Department and urging the employment of 390 additional tenement inspectors.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Forty-five-year-old Willie Macfarlane of Tuckahoe, N.Y., proved again that he is still a great tournament golfer by capturing the Glens Falls open with a record-breaking score of 274 today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The 36,000 volumes of legal reports and treatises presented to the Supreme Court by Senator Peter G. Gerry of Rhode Island have taken their places on the shelves of the new marble Supreme Court Building.

WARSAW, Sept. 8. -- Prime Minister Walery Slawek had some 180 Deputies returned to office today in the new Sejm of 208 members. The remaining members of the new Parliament include some Ukrainian Jews and a few Radical peasants, who will not oppose the regime which excluded all political parties from the electoral contests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The State Department today made public an exchange of letters in regard to possible reciprocal trade agreements between Canada and the United States. The letters are two in number, one to Secretary of State Hull from W.D. Herridge, Canadian Minister to the United States, and the other Mr. Hull's answer.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,227,209,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 8. Munition makers and affiliated interests were held responsible for periodic war scares, usually timed to occur just before consideration of the appropriation bills by Congress, by Senator Gerald P. Nye, Republican, of North Dakota, in a speech here tonight before the national convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 8. -- The 1935 professional football season opened here today with the champion New York Giants defeating the Passaic Reds, 33 to 0, in an exhibition game before 8,000 at the School Stadium.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Twenty-five persons escaped injury today when a Chicago-to-Newark airplane of the American Airlines ground-looped before 3,500 persons attending a program of air races and the Buffalo-Boston plane of the same line was forced to turn back as a motor went dead over Batavia, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Roxie Lawson, rookie Detroit pitcher, who had won his two previous starts by shut-outs, forced across the winning run with a pass in the ninth inning today to give the Senators a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers.

ATHENS, Sept. 8. -- Royalist military leaders and politicians, said to include General Repas and General Rosspopoulous, head of the federal constabulary, circulated rumors of a revolutionary coup during the past week-end to frighten Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris into deciding on his return from his vacation in Germany tomorrow, on restoration of the monarchy.
Apartment rentals announced over the week-end showed continuing gains in the leasing field. As for the last several weeks, the demand for rooms covered a wide area.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Richmond today watched the James River gradually subside from a flood crest of 25.5 feet, passed last night at midnight, while maintaining precautions against danger to waterfront property.

The contest for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District between John E. Sheehy, the incumbent, and former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney has reached the afternoon tea and reception stage, it became known yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8. -- The Netherlands Minister at Washington, Jonkheer van Haersma de Witt, is the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes A.L. Van Den Bosch at their South Street Summer home, Pittsfield, and was entertained with a dinner in his honor tonight.

William H. Egan celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday as station master of the Pennsylvania Railroad terminal. During his service at the station Mr. Egan greeted the various Presidents and countless notables.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The steadiness of sterling in the face of a disturbing international political situation is a tribute to the prestige which the British Exchange Fund has acquired in its management of that currency. At the same time, sterling is displaying a decided undercurrent of weakness

Despite repeated assurances by Health Department officials that the trend of infantile paralysis eases here is proceeding steadily downward, thousands of mothers will keep their children home when schools open this morning.

A model of the ancient temple of Queen Hat-shepsut, representing ten years of excavation and research by the Egyptian expedition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and nearly a year's work by architectural draftsmen and modelers, has just been placed on exhibition at the museum to show the pubic just what a great Egyptian temple of about 1480 B.C. looked like.
Sleepy Jim Crowley, gifted with the powers of persuasion, is attempting to convince twenty-one sophomore giants that they form the finest football material in the world.

GENEVA, Sept. 9. -- The sixteenth League of Nations Assembly opened this morning ruled by forces that would keep the Italian challenge to Ethiopia, Great Britain and the League out of it as much as possible.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- George Lansbury, who may resign the leadership of the Labor party because many of his associates would resort to war if necessary to check Italy, declared his views tonight at a political meeting in Dumfries.

Now that the AAA has the cotton bolls all counted, has established pig allotments and spud control, another problem looms upon the governmental horizon. Essentially a farm problem, it nevertheless has its effect upon the nerves of that forgotten man, the urban voter and taxpayer.

Abhorrence of the attempt to assassinate Senator LONG is felt by every right-minded American. The crime was, fortunately, committed not by a political enemy of the Senator, but by a man who had been nursing a personal and private grievance -- until his mind was possibly thrown out of balance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Filing of fourteen additional registration statements for a total of $31,809,949 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The list follows:

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Harry McKay, 55 years old, of 75 Madison Street, Hempstead, a familiar figure here for the last several years as a purchaser of old gold, died of heart failure at 1 o'clock this afternoon at the wheel of his automobile as he was driving along Glen Cove Avenue through the most crowded part of this city.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 9 (By Wireless). -- Oil cast back upon Ethiopia (by a canceled concession), far from having a calming influence, may kindle a fire in native quarters that will imperil the lives of all foreigners in Addis Ababa.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses charged yesterday that the Works Progress Administration had been sending him "Bowery bums" for his relief projects. He declared that he could not and would not use "bums" for his park work and announced his intention of "sending them back within twenty-four hours."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Republican National Committee had a surplus of $24,986.64, according to its report filed with the clerk of the House today for the period from June 1 to Aug. 31. The receipts amounted to $70,820.36, which included contributions and a loan of $3,500.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 9. -- H.J. Bordwell, general manager of the Erie Railroad Company, in a letter to Mayor Oscar L. Carlson today practically ended the expected battle over the painting of the "Old Red Barn," better known as the Walnut Street Station, by assuring Montclair's town officials that the depot is on the railroad's painting program for the present season and will be done within a few weeks.

The share market continued higher yesterday but the boisterous enthusiasm witnessed at the close of last week was lacking. The trade news of the day was encouraging, but the rapid rise in stock prices since late Wednesday afternoon invited profit-taking which operated to hold the advancing tendencies in check.

An increase of 50 per cent in bookings since this time last season was reported yesterday by NBC Artists Service Bureau, of which George Engles is managing director. An improvement of 130 per cent in the last two seasons over the year 1932-33, the worst during the depression, has also been recorded.

In a letter to THE TIMES from James Balsam he proposes to station observers at some vantage point where the time it takes to break down the patience of pedestrians, thereby causing them to risk their necks dashing acrosss streets, might be estimated. The duration of the traffic signal would then be set according to the breaking-point of the average pedestrian's patience.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9. -- The text of the prayer offered tonight in the Louisiana Senate for Huey Long follows:

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 9. -- With the exception of three adjourned games, seven rounds in the international chess masters tournament at the Klub Szachowy had been completed tonight. Dr. S. Tartakower, foremost Polish representative, took first place, one point ahead of William Winter, the British champion.

Trading interest in the listed bond market was switched to United States Government bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The enthusiasm which carried second-grade domestic corporation issues sharply higher last week subsided considerably, and that list turned dull, with price movements restricted to comparatively narrow limits.

Jacob J. Rosenblum, Assistant United States Attorney, who played a prominent part in the investigation of the income tax case of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, spent yesterday afternoon conferring with Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Sept. 4, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $81,000,000 in total loans and investments and decreases of $116,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $31,000,000 in net demand deposits and $7,000,000 in time deposits.

The club room on the twelfth floor of the Times Annex looked like the agricultural hall of a State fair yesterday with a striking display of flowers and vegetables exhibited by twenty-five employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES and their families in the first annual Times flower show.
Business in money in the new week ran to the same small lines at unvarying quotations for all grades as has been witnessed for some time now. Routine requirements made up the day's trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The government moved rapidly today to clear the decks for the expenditure of $5,000,000,000 of State and Federal funds for work relief, at the rate of $420,000,000 monthly, as PWA announced the closing of its books on new applications four days before the deadline set by President Roosevelt for that act.

Public education may be said to have been the passion of ROBERT E. SIMON. In his devotion to this cause he made an avocation his vocation. No private citizen could have given himself more unreservedly -- more unselfishly, more intelligently than did he in behalf of the teachers and children in the public schools and especially in bringing the school and the home, the teachers and the parents into more helpful relationship.

Highly indignant at the "flagrant neglect" which permitted Anthony Cugino, Philadelphia criminal wanted for eleven murders, to commit suicide in his cell at police headquarters just before midnight Sunday, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that "somebody is likely to lose his job over this."

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A party of Soviet Arctic explorers, after landing from the icebreaker Sadko, claimed three small islands discovered near Northern Land in the name of the Soviet Union today. Professor George Ushakoff, leader of the expedition, flew over the islands later and fixed their positions for map markings.

A brilliant 68 on his own ball by Walter Scheiber enabled the Hillcrest Golf Club professional and his amateur partner, Lee W. Faber of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, to capture premier honors in the Long Island Golf Association's amateur-pro best-ball tournament at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York:

Former Prime Minister Alexander Papanastasiou of Greece was the guest of honor at a farewell dinner last night held at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, under the auspices of the Hellenic Society of Columbia University. About 100 persons were present.

Twenty-eight dashing knights of the gas-house district, from 10 to 14 years old, engaged in a jousting tourney yesterday afternoon, fighting not for the hand of a fair maiden but for one of the Gramercy Boys Club's green sweat shirts instead. In place of horses, they used barrels.

Thunder echoed over the Bronx yesterday as glowering skies cast gloom dyer the Yankee Stadium. However, the detonating reports came not from an atmospheric disturbance but from Yankee bats as the McCarthymen hammered two hurlers for ten solid smashes and chalked up their third straight over Steve O'Neill's Indians.

Governor CURLEY of Massachusetts may not be close to the business and bosom of Mr. FARLEY at present, but as an exponent of the faith that is in, and frequently comes out of, that association of personalities and three-gentlemen-at-once, JAMES of New York is even exceeded by JAMES of Boston.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- The stock markets here were quiet but cheerful today, with somewhat better feeling on the latest Ethiopian news. British funds were steady and firmer in the afternoon. Brazilian issues were higher in the foreign market.

Advances in sugar and wool top futures continued to feature the trading in commodity markets here yesterday. Although most markets were dull a steady undertone was in evidence. In the cash markets, cotton, rubber and silk were higher while the grains and tin declined.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, announced yesterday that what is expected to be the most intensive campaign ever waged by a party in this State in an "off" year would be started soon after the primary election in an attempt to recapture the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A cotton crop this year of 11,489,000 bales was forecast today by the government crop reporting board on the basis of Sept. 1 conditions at 64.5 per cent of normal. The estimate was 309,000 bales, under the official forecast on Aug. 1 and still further below the 12,200,000 bale crop indicated by the average of private estimates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Miss Marion McDougall of Portland, Ore., winner of the women's Western golf title a year ago, toured the soggy Northmoor Country Club course in 38, 43 -- 81 today to take the lead in the seventh annual women's seventy-two-hole Western Derby.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Father Coughlin, Detroit priest and close friend of Senator Long, wired Mrs. Long today:

LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Miss Mary McKee, elderly tourist from New York, who had been the object of an intensive search following her disappearance last Thursday near Victoria Falls, Rhodesia, Africa, was found dead today by a native, according to an Exchange Telegraph dispatch.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Continued improvement in important business and industrial lines in the Summer months or the maintenance of gains already made, contrary to seasonal trends, was reported by the Department of Commerce to day in its monthly survey of current business.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- An apparent shift in the trend of Japan's foreign trade toward easing the penetration of world markets has gained notice in official Washington.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses took a group of engineers, city officials, civic leaders and newspaper men yesterday on a tour of inspection of the three major non-relief projects under his direction -- the West Side Highway extension through Riverside Park, the Henry Hudson Parkway and the Triborough Bridge.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Buying of wheat futures in North American markets today lacked the snap that characterized the trading on Saturday, and while Winnipeg forged ahead early to a new high level for the season, an easier undertone developed as the result of free hedging sales and the Canadian market closed 3/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel lower than on Saturday, with May leading.

Rain once more caused a revision of the plans of polo officials to start their national championship today. A very heavy downpour early last night, added to the soaking of the past week, brought the postponement of the opening game which was to have been played today between Hurlingham of England and the Hurricanes and set it over until Thursday.

A group of twelve college youths who passed the Summer crossing the Atlantic and touring European waters in an 85-foot schooner, the Wanderbird, returned yesterday on the liner Kungsholm with glowing reports of their season as "real honest-to-goodness sailormen."
BATON ROUGE, La., Tuesday, Sept. 10. -- The political implications apparent in Senator Long's death formed a subject of widespread discussion early today.

Our administration officials and their economic advisers have seemingly become possessed of a phobia as to the efficacy of crop control, as exemplified by the recent potato-control legislation, for the economic rehabilitation of our nation. In all fairness, this policy indicates an understanding of the factor that is mainly responsible for business stagnation, namely, the surplus of goods and commodities.

Expected for several days, the movement of gold from Paris to the United States started yesterday. The first actual shipments, totaling $3,358,000, reported at the Federal Reserve Bank include $1,658,000 which will arrive here on next Monday on the Bremen and $1,700,000 coming on the Ile de France, due on the following Wednesday.

A strong possibility that the city will have to resort to another payless furlough for municipal employes in its effort to find a road out of its budgetary problems for 1936 was indicated yesterday by Leo J. McDermott, Assistant Budget Director, at a hearing on the Board of Higher Education estimate for next year.

When the Soviet Government sells wheat, coal and oil to Italy for use in Ethiopia it might come under the head of ruble diplomacy. In any event, it makes a rather pretty contrast when capitalist America makes its citizens cancel an Ethiopian oil concession in the interest of world peace while the Soviet Government helps to provision an imperialist nation preparing to make war upon a colonial people.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The resort to violence was denounced as un-American by President Roosevelt today in a statement expressing deep regret over the attack last night on Senator Long.
