With higher leather levels bringing predictions of advances in retail shoe prices within two months, the semi-annual style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association and the official opening of Spring leathers by the Tanners Council of America got under way yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to an atendance of some 1,200 merchants, manufacturers, designers and tanners.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9. -- Several of this season's debutantes will assist in the collection of books for the American Merchant Marine Library Association, which formally opened a week's drive today at City Hall when Mayor Henry S. Wheeler presented the first book to Mrs. Skirvin Adams, chairman of the committee which is conducting the drive.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The annual fair for the benefit of Ascension Farm School at South Lee is to be held in the Stockbridge Town Hall on Saturday. Mrs. Ira M. Dixson is general chairman and John H.C. Church treasurer.

Haphazard and unscientific, the present Federal tax machine is nevertheless an effective engine. Washington dispatches yesterday pointed out that it produced $3,299,000,000 in internal revenue in 1934-35 -- the largest amount received by the Government in fourteen years.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Chick Meehan has spent one full year regretting the optimistic outlook he assumed before the start of the 1934 season. He does not want to make that mistake again. But behind a guise of deep pessimism the dynamic little Manhattan College coach is trying to hide the hope that this time he will be able to give the Jaspers a real football team.

Looking benevolently but firmly at our Republican friends, we are tempted to wonder if at this early stage of the game, before it is begun, in fact, they are not about as hard up for principles as for candidates. Doubtless both these necessaries will be evolved in time by trial and error and judicious preliminary selection and rejection.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The construction of the light cruiser on which bids were rejected today will fill the total tonnage allowed the United States in this category under the London naval treaty.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The name of Edward J. Reilly of Brooklyn, chief defense counsel in the Hauptmann trial, will not appear on the ballot for the Democratic nomination for County Judge in Kings County.

Japan is not seeking "to increase the burden of armament" in her denunciation of the 5-5-3 naval ratio, Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador at Washington, declares in an exposition of "Japan's Policies and Purposes," to be published in book form in a few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Overcoming an early Washington lead, the Tigers held to their 8 1/2 game lead over the Yankees today by rallying in the late innings to defeat the Senators, 5 to 4, in a game that was halted after seven innings on account of rain and darkness.

About three weeks ago death claimed Professor Frederick Dielman, who headed the Department of Art at the College of the City of New York for years. When I sat under him from the Fall of 1910 to June, 1911, the course was prescribed for all seniors. It was fortunate that this included science students, as well as those in the art courses.

Adoption of a processing tax clause to be included in all sales contracts by the underwear industry was announced here yesterday by Roy Cheney, managing director of the Underwear Institute, Inc. At the same time Mr. Cheney, discussing the results of a two-day meeting of his executive committee in Atlantic City last week, said that the voluntary code for the industry was progressing and might be adopted by a majority of mills by November.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- Corporal Raymond D. Chaney of the United States Marines, Quantico, led 1,170 rivals for first honors in the Navy Trophy event at the national rifle and pistol matches today.

The need of drastic changes in game conservation methods, if the country's valuable game bird resources are to be maintained, is indicated in a study of State laws of the present as compared with those of twenty-five years ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- Censorious press comment fanned today the popular indignation arising in the Third Reich against the action of Magistrate Brodsky of New York in freeing five persons arrested in the riot aboard the German liner Bremen.

New York's noise abatement campaign got under way at City Hall yesterday with a general agreement among speakers at the first conference that unnecessary noise could be largely eliminated if the populace remembered its good manners. cal foes called up to express regret over the attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- An investigation of the attempted assassination of Senator Long, and the men responsible for it, was proposed today by Representative Clare G. Fenerty of Pennsylvania, a member of the special committee appointed recently by Congress to inquire into the political activities of the Louisiana Senator.

A plan of reorganization for the Davison Chemical Company was filed yesterday in the United States District Court for the district of Maryland under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act, it was announced here. It is being sponsored by the reorganization committee, headed by E.J. Quintal.
MOSCOW, Sept. 9. -- The outright ownership of land "forever" has been the dream of Russian peasants for centuries. It is now being realized under the Soviet.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The Boerse was weak and closed inactive today. Heavy industrials fell slightly, chemicals were soft, I.G. Farben lost 1 point, electricals were inactive, shipping shares fell, Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd lost 1/4 point.

Neisner Brothers, Inc., operator of a chain of stores and its wholly owned subsidiary, Neisner Brothers Realty, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $185,587 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- A study of the entire question of marriage and divorce, with special reference to the position the Lutheran church must take toward the matter of remarrying divorced individuals, will be made during the convention of the Eastern district of the American Lutheran Church, which opened this afternoon with the Rev. W.E. Schuette of Sewickley, Pa., president of the Eastern Conference, presiding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Passing the $10,000,000,000 mark for the first time since its establishment in February, 1932, loan authorizations by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on Aug. 31 totaled $10,080,523,441, of which $5,622,153,904 was in advances to other than Federal agencies or for relief, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, announced today.
Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, Columbia University, will return from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. Others due on this liner include:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9. -- The Giants' activities in the West came to a complete standstill today when a drizzling rain washed out the second game of their series with the Pirates and sent it over into a double-header for tomorrow.

VIENNA, Sept. 9. -- Reports of the warm reception accorded to the new Italian Ambassador to Germany by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler tonight appeared in the evening's Austrian newspapers very inconspicuously, but nevertheless attracted considerable attention.

One subsidiary of the Associated Gas system charged another subsidiary more than $85,000 for fill for a gas plant site, when the fill actually was supplied free of charge by the State of New York, according to testimony given at a hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- New York University's football squad of forty-three candidates opened its training camp at Lake Sebago today with two brisk sessions under the direction of Head Coach Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens and his staff.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- Factory employment increased 1.9 per cent in the State from the middle of July to the middle of August and payrolls advanced 4.4 per cent during that period, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today.

With trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday approximating 2,000,000 shares, the record of daily business reaching this total, or above, now stands at nine for the year. Last year at this time thirty-two such days had been recorded, twenty-eight of which occurred in January and February, while there were two each in May and July.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Caught in a northwest squall late this afternoon before they could finish the second of two international races off the American Yacht Club, the teams of Sound Interclub and Bermuda One-Design skippers were hard put to carry on.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Although Canada's gold production in the first half of this year was above the total in the first half of 1934, this country has dropped to fourth place among the gold producers of the world, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A decision to lay the dock labor dispute at New Orleans before the National Labor Relations Board as soon as possible was reached at a conference today between William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Joseph P. Ryan, head of the International Longshoremen's Association.

The Federal Power Commission handed an unsolicited testimonial to the electric light and power industry yesterday in the shape of an announcement that savings to electric customers during the year ended on June 30, 1935, amounted to nearly $50,000,000. They were the result of rate reductions by a large number of private and public plants averaging 3.5 per cent.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Max Baer had a fairly active training session today. The former heavyweight champion labored in the morning at roadwork and wood-chopping and in the afternoon viewed slow-motion pictures of the Joe Louis and Primo Carnera fight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Reports of a better demand in the East for fresh meats influenced the markets here today. There was a pronounced scarcity of light hogs and pigs and prices soared 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight with Eastern and local interests competing for the scant supply.

GENEVA, Sept. 9. -- Behind Italy's demands for more colonial rights there lurked in the minds of many at the opening of the League Assembly today the spectre that soon Germany -- deprived of all colonies -- would proclaim her needs for territory outside Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Two Easterners, a Midwest star and one Californian today reached the semi-final round in the girls' national tennis championship tournament on the grass courts of the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Scoring a 78 over the East Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today, Joseph F.M. Gagliardi, a member of the home club, captured the John D. Anderson Memorial Medal in the qualifying round of the twenty-third annual title tournament of the New York Athletic Club.

While traffic on the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad is running below last year's levels now, indications are for a better turn, S.T. Bledsoe, president, said yesterday. Reduced movement of grains and livestock account for the present situation, he said.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- More than 300 advertising representatives of banks from all parts of the country gathered at a convention of the Financial Advertisers Association here today with the most confident attitude toward business recovery and new opportunities for the development of banking that has had public expression since 1929.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 9. -- The chimes of ancient Nuremberg will ring in the sixth national conclave of the National Socialist German Labor party at sunset tomorrow, and as their tolling ceases Reichfuehrer Adolf Hitler and his executive staff will receive the city's official welcome at the Town Hall.
May I record for the future historian of the manners and daily life of our times what happens to a man who writes a letter which is printed in THE TIMES?

Should the rest of the States follow Nebraska's example and adopt unicameral Legislatures? Professor WILLIAM B. MUNRO discusses this question in The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science. Many reputable political scientists believe that they should.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 9. -- President Lazaro Cardenas opened the Seventh American Scientific Congress in the Palace of Fine Arts today, accompanied by the Acting Minister of Foreign Affairs, Jose Angel Ceniceros; other Cabinet Ministers and diplomats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- About $480,000,000 of the called Fourth Liberty Loan bonds, of which $1,250,000,000 are outstanding, was refunded in the first week of the conversion operation, Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Lieut. Gov. A.B. (Happy) Chandler, militant foe of the State sales-tax law, rolled up a majority of 20,523 over Thomas S. Rhea for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination tonight on returns from 3,063 of the State's 4,219 precincts.

Great Britain's chief hope in the women's national tennis championship passed from the Forest Hills scene yesterday and the most-talked-of American Davis Cup prospect was being swept toward his exit in the men's singles when rain intervened to earn him a reprieve and trap several thousand of the remaining onlookers in the stadium.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- Premier Pierre Laval took a train for Geneva tonight to rejoin the critical discussions on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute. He hopes to have a conversation with Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, tomorrow morning.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Numerous questions of jurisdiction as between Federal and State relief authorities were discussed by President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman today while the latter was luncheon guest at Hyde Park a House.

A syndicate composed of the Chase National Bank, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, the Harris Trust and Savings Bank and others will offer today a new issue of State of Tennessee 3.90 per cent highway refunding bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1955, and/or 1958, at prices to yield 3.35 per cent.

Mr. LANSBURY, the leader of the Labor party in the House of Commons, recently called upon religious leaders everywhere to make their voices heard against war. What he had in mind, of course, was the threatened war in Africa, with the possibility of its spread to Europe.

Montgomery Ward Co. announced yesterday that sales for August were the largest for that month since 1929, and showed a gain of 20.8 per cent over August, 1934. The total volume for the month was $22,848,599, compared with $18,914,957 in August, last year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9. -- Manager Frank Frisch went hitless today on his thirty-seventh birthday as his Cardinals went down to an untimely 4 to 3 defeat before Philadelphia.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Miss Rosalind A. Everdell, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Everdell, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at their home in the Shelter Rock colony of this village.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Evidence produced today at the hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the bankruptcy proceedings of the McLellan Stores Company showed that the United Stores Corporation, in obtaining a controlling interest, had purchased up to Nov. 22, 1934, 227,800 shares of the store company's common stock at an average price of $8.58, an aggregate of $1,954,524.

In their first quarterly meeting of the new season 451 members of the Actors Equity Association yesterday afternoon prepared to face the issue of a proposed new basic agreement between Equity and Broadway's producers and theatrical managers. The meeting was held at the Astor Hotel.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9. -- In a subdued session, the House of Representatives today pushed through passage a new batch of bills which were sponsored by Senator Long and aimed at the Federal administration.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9. -- The dramatic story of the attempt to assassinate Senator Huey P. Long in the $5,000,000 State House and the killing of his assailant, Dr. Carl A. Weiss, was related today by eye-witnesses at a coroner's inquest.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Denison Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Moore Jr., Mrs. Oliver M. Wallop and Mrs. John W. Cross Jr. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. Somers Smyth of Brookline, Mass., for her daughter, Miss Noel Smyth, who returned on the Conte di Savoia and has joined her mother at the St. Regis.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Newark's relief situation was complicated further today when Reginald Parnell, City Director of Revenue and Finance, returned to his office after a vacation in Nova Scotia and announced he would not issue the $510,803 in emergency bonds voted last Wednesday by the other four members of the City Commission, without a court test of the legality of the issue.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Representative William I. Sirovich of New York said today that President Roosevelt has approved a suggestion that he add to his Cabinet a secretary charged with the task of stimulating American interest and participation in the arts and sciences.

Three consecutive favorites scored at Aqueduct yesterday to mark the first time form has been so consistent since the thoroughbreds returned from Saratoga. Significant, Star Shadow and Esposa were the respective winners of the third, fourth and fifth races.

Prospective jobs for approximately 80,000 relief workers were wiped out yesterday by Washington's rejection of a number of PWA projects in New York State for which applications totaling $70,000,000 had been made, it was estimated last night by Arthur S. Tuttle, Acting State Director of the Federal Public Works Administration.

An improvement in world trade, as reflected by greater tonnages moving through the port of London, was reported yesterday by A.E. Wildey of the Port of London Authority. Mr. Wildey arrived from Toronto, where he attended the Canadian National Exposition, and will sail tonight for London.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Eltinge F. Warner was hostess this afternoon to seventy-five members of the Ladies Village Improvement Society at its annual meeting. Mrs. John Adams Mayer and Mrs. William Taylor presided at the tea tables.

Directors of Abraham Straus declared yesterday an extra dividend of 15 cents a share and the regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Sept. 30 to holders of record of Sept. 21.

WARSAW, Sept. 9. -- Of the newly elected Deputies to the Sejm, 190 out of 205 belong to the government bloc. By-elections will be held in three constituencies where candidates did not attain the necessary 10,000 votes.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. H. Landon Holt, wife of an executive of the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn, N.Y., miraculously escaped death this afternoon when she fell 150 feet from a cliff overlooking an abandoned quarry facing Mount Pleasant Avenue into a shallow pool of rain water.

Total assets of the Phoenix Securities Corporation increased from $5,839,017 on Feb. 28 to $7,643,060 on June 30, according to the statement submitted by the company to the New York Curb Exchange in connection with the listing of 8,595 additional shares of its $3 convertible preferred stock, Series A.

With a better-balanced and more formidable string of mounts than they had last year, members of the Chilean Army jumping team arrived here yesterday aboard the Chile-North American liner Antofagasta. They are to begin preparations for their participation in the nightly international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show, which is to be held in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 6-12.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Replying to the criticisms leveled by Republicans against President Roosevelt's promise of a "breathing spell" for business in New Deal legislation, Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee in a statement today asked critics what Roosevelt policies they would repeal in event of Republican success in 1936.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The formation of a New Jersey Labor party seemed probable as the State Federation of Labor opened its fifty-seventh annual convention here today.
Having recently celebrated my thirtieth wedding anniversary, I offer a few suggestions on how to stay married to one man or one woman.

Columbia had its football forces, numbering forty candidates, engage in their first practice sessions of the campaign yesterday at Baker Field. Coach Lou Little and his large staff of assistants instructed the Lions at morning and afternoon drills, totaling five hours in all, and at the end of the day it was a tired but enthusiastic squad that jogged to the showers.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- By banner headlines and large-type newspaper placards, England learned today of the attempted assassination of Senator Long.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Running their current winning streak to six straight games, the Cubs moved to within a game of the league-leading Cardinals today when they downed the Braves twice, 5 to 1 and 2 to 1, while the world champions were dropping a decision to the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Another long step in the administration's program to build to full London treaty strength was taken today, when the Navy Department authorized construction of twenty-three fighting ships, including an aircraft carrier and a 10,000-ton cruiser.

An all-American final in the women's national tennis singles was attained yesterday when Miss Helen Jacobs eliminated Mrs. Phyllis Mudford King of England and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan rose to her greatest heights to beat Miss Kay Stammers of England in one of the most exciting and brilliant matches ever played in the Forest Hills Stadium.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 9. -- There was a period today when a King could do no wrong.
Bernard F. Weadock, vice president and managing director of the Edison Electric Institute, issued yesterday the following statement:

CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Eugene Foley of Livingston received the sweepstake prize for winning the greatest number of ribbons at the community flower show held today at the Caldwell Women's Club. Second and third prizes went respectively to Mrs. Edgar Newell of West Caldwell and Mrs. William Rae of Caldwell.

About 48,000 workers, most of them unskilled laborers, have been added to WPA payrolls since Aug. 1, General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for this city, announced yesterday. Of this number 39,000 were placed in the last fortnight.

Mail reorders received here yesterday on school and college wear, sports coats and accessories were again heavy, despite the retarding effect of inclement weather last week. Pressure for quick deliveries of dresses on order continued strong.

Another effort made yesterday at a conference in the Hotel New Yorker to settle the strike of shipping clerks and push boys in the garment district failed to get results as 100,000 dressmakers were preparing for what the Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union characterized as "a dress rehearsal for a general strike."

Summer ended unofficially but with crushing finality yesterday for most of the city's 1,170,000 school children as they trooped back to elementary, junior and senior high schools in the five boroughs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The breakdown of prohibition was attributed today to an inheritance of the dislike for authority under which this country obtained its independence by Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean of the Drew University Theological Seminary at Madison, N.J.

NORWICH, England, Sept. 9. -- Cosmic rays shooting to the earth from limitless space may be partly responsible for microscopic mutations of genes and chromosomes within living cells and so may be one of the forces causing growth and evolution.

Federal receipts from liquor taxes were greater in the fiscal year 1934-1935 than in any pre-prohibition years except 1918 and 1919, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The tax rates in 1918 and 1919 were exceptionally high.

GENEVA, Sept. 9. -- Hope that out of the new conciliation committee of five powers established by the League of Nations Council last Friday there may come some solution of the Italo-Ethiopian problem received a decided setback this evening.

MONTREAL, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press). -- The annual convention of the International Typographical Union was asked today to declare itself as favoring the Townsend plan of national revolving pensions, calling for the payment of $200 a month to those over 60.

Mayor La Guardia pressed his campaign for a municipal "career service" on a new front yesterday when he suggested that the appointment of Supreme Court justices be taken "out of partisan politics" under a system which would permit their designation by bar associations from the ranks of the lower judiciary.

Federal receipts from liquor taxes were greater in the fiscal year 1934-1935 than in any pre-prohibition years except 1918 and 1919, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The tax rates in 1918 and 1919 were exceptionally high.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9. -- A graphic description of an airplane stratosphere flight by Victor Nikolaivich Evseyef, who reached a record height for the Soviet Union of 12,010 meters [about 39,403 feet], was printed today in the army newspaper Red Star.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9 (AP). -- A bereaved mother, Mrs. C.A. Weiss Sr., "thanked God" today that Senator Huey P. Long is still alive.

The A.S.P.C.A. has asked the Park Department to join it in a wild animal expedition, it became known yesterday. Details of the safari, which will be made in the initial stage by automobile, then by boat and finally on foot, are to be arranged at a conference today.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed paying agent for the following issues: $960,000 of Ketchikan, Alaska, 5 1/2 per cent public improvement bonds dated March 1, 1935; $225,000 of Union Free School District 7, Corinth, N.Y., 3.60 per cent school bonds dated March 1, 1935; $200,000 of Central School District 1, Schroon Lake, N.Y., 4 per cent school building bonds dated Sept. 1, 1934.
BATON ROUGE, La., Tuesday, Sept. 10. -- United States Senator Huey P. Long died at 4:10 o'clock this morning (6:10 A.M., New York Time).
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The cigar industry petitioned the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today to eliminate the processing tax on cigar leaf tobacco.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 9. -- Plans for establishment of a loan council to effect, after the recent British pattern, a voluntary reduction of the interest rate on Canadian Federal railway, provincial and municipal debt were announced by Prime Minister Bennett in a radio broadcast tonight.
Sales of automobiles by the General Motors Corporation last month were the largest for any August since 1929, it was announced yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Competing in a field of sixteen teams, Mrs. Robert C. Lake of Plandome and Mrs. G.M. Gordon of the home club gained the qualifying medal as play in the annual two-ball championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association opened today.
ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The Court of Appeals today unanimously upheld the constitutionality of this year's legislative act which created the Mortgage Commission.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- A knowledge of the elements of design is essential to those who would arrange flowers artistically, John Taylor Arms, president of the Society of American Etchers, told about 200 garden enthusiasts who braved the rain tonight to attend the first of a series of suburban meetings held by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with local garden clubs.

The reunion in Fifty-second Street grew more tender yesterday when Alfred Lunt suddenly popped up as an addition to the Board of Managers of the Theatre Guild. He is rehearsing "The Taming of the Shrew," which the Guild and John C. Wilson will present this Fall, and his relationship with the organization has been a long one, dating back to 1924 and "The Guardsman."

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, denied on his return from Europe yesterday that he had any knowledge of the Ethiopian oil and mineral concession to the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, which astounded the world on its announcement a week ago and threatened to disrupt international efforts to arbitrate the African dispute.

Hasty steps toward reorganization of the American Federation of Teachers are being taken by representatives of both its right and left wing factions. By this, they hope to keep the question of revoking the organization's charter and chartering a new national teachers' union in its place from being raised at the American Federation of Labor convention in Atlantic City next month, according to dispatches from Washington last night.

DETROIT, Sept. 9. -- At a signal from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, workmen this afternoon demolished the first house in the city's $6,600,000 slum-clearance project. She motored here at 2 o'clock and left for Hyde Park late this afternoon.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 9. -- Although the general impression is that the Ethiopian concession has been dropped as a result of the withdrawal of the Standard-Vaccum Oil Company at the request of Secretary of State Cordell Hull, the British promoter, Francis W. Rickett, seems to entertain a different view.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Competing in a field of sixteen teams, Mrs. Robert C. Lake of Plandome and Mrs. G.M. Gordon of the home club gained the qualifying medal as play in the annual two-ball championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association opened today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 9. -- Although the general impression is that the Ethiopian concession has been dropped as a result of the withdrawal of the Standard-Vaccum Oil Company at the request of Secretary of State Cordell Hull, the British promoter, Francis W. Rickett, seems to entertain a different view.
The annual Citizens Union appraisal of the work of the New York County and Bronx Assemblymen revealed yesterday a lack of harshness toward the Tammany members of the lower house.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10 (AP). -Lieut. Gov. A. B. Chandler rode to victory tonight in his race for the Democratic nomination as Governor of Kentucky on a crest of votes apparently swelled by his denunciation of "dictatorship," "bayonet rule" and the State's 3 per cent sales tax.

The unexpected reduction in Monday's official estimate of the cotton crop created sufficient trade buying yesterday to steady prices on the Cotton Exchange and show net gains of 9 to 14 points at the close.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Suggested revisions of the Federal Reserve Board's regulations in order to carry out the new provisions in the Banking Act of 1935 have been drafted by the board and are being circulated among the twelve Reserve Banks for criticism, it was learned today.

Fist fights, disorders and minor acts of violence again marked the strike of shipping clerks in the garment district yesterday as police strove to maintain order and protect non-striking errand boys and push boys from being molested. Fifteen arrests were made in the day.
" The Goose and the Gander," featuring Kay Francis and George Brent, opens tonight at the Strand.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -- A pair of newcomers to the girls' national tennis championships, Miss Elena Ciccone of Newton, Mass., and Miss Patricia Henry of Los Angeles, today gained the title round at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The American Rolling Mill Company ordered the resumption of dividend payments on its common stock yesterday, with the declaration of 30 cents a share, payable on Oct. 15 to stock of record Oct. 1. The dividend will be the first paid by the company since Jan. 15, 1931, when 50 cents a share was distributed on the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- A comprehensive plan for ending the twelve-year receivership of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad through its dismemberment and joint purchase with a $7,200,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the newly organized Associated Railways Company and eight Western trunk lines participating in the deal.

The Treasury reported yesterday a slight increase of money in circulation during August. This is a normal trend. The amount of currency in circulation is usually at a low level in midsummer; an increase ordinarily begins in August, and expansion continues irregularly throughout the Autumn and early Winter, reaching a peak shortly before the holidays, when money is withdrawn from the banks for Christmas shopping.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Regular and independent political organizations in Westchester County were in confusion today as a result of the ruling of the Court of Appeals that primary petitions were void if not made out pursuant to the requirements of the recently amended election law.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 10. -- "Japan will not tolerate the establishment of a Communist government in any portion of China or in any other part of Eastern Asia, but will act independently to destroy such a regime," declared Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Military Attache of the Japanese Embassy at Peiping in an interview here that was characterized by amazing frankness, revealing the Japanese policy toward China with unprecedented clarity.

Sailors Snug Harbor, haven for retired seafarers on Staten Island, had a new picture yesterday. Some thirty Gloucester fishermen, now among the aging sea dogs rounding out their years at the harbor, had a section of their home port framed and hung on the wall of the main hall near the library.

The United States liner Manhattan will sail today for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg. Among the pasengers are Herman Oliphant, general counsel of the United States Treasury; Commander B. W. Thompson; Professor Edwin F. Wilsey, head of the physics department of Robert College, Istanbul, and E. M. Loew, president of Loew Theatres.

A census recently completed by the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission discloses some interesting figures on the food value of fish and game taken by tho licensed anglers of the State. Thc survey covered the season of 1938.

Having come from among them, knowing their minds, needs, wants and prejudices, the secret of Huey Pierce Long's sway over the State of Louisiana was always to be found in the people who inhabited the villages on the edges of the swamps and bayous and the back country of his State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Dropping seven birdies, Miss Patty Berg, 17year-old Minneapolis golfer, today established a course record of 40, 37 -- 77, two under par, to take a five-shot lead at the half-way mark of the women's Western seventytwo-hole tournament.

WOODMERE, L.I., Sept. 10. -Playing over her home course, Mrs. Edward Oppenheimer today captured low gross honors in a oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with a score of 86 at the Woodmere Club.

The keel of the 10,000-ton cruiser Honolulu, which will cost $16,000,000 to complete, was laid yesterday at the navy yard in Brooklyn. The vessel will be a sister ship of the Brooklyn, the keel of which was laid last March.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- A slightly bearish construction was placed today by the trade on the government's estimate of the Spring wheat crop at 163,000,000 bushels, or 8,000,000 above the average of recent private returns. The figures on corn, showing 2,184,000,000 bushels, were regarded as bullish though, being 70,000,000 under the estimates here.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 10. -- The international conference of the Association for the Emigration of Jewish Youth to Palestine opened at the Amstel Hotel tonight under the chairmanship of Professor Ornstein of the University of Utrecht, chairman of the Netherlands committee, in the presence of delegates from the United States, Bulgaria, Britain, Finland, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Yugoslavia, the Scandinavian countries, Switzerland, Hungary, Palestine and South Africa.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 10.--TheNew York League for Animals willbe materially benefited as the result of the bridge party given byMiss Rosa Anna Grosvenor at herhome, Wyndham, this afternoon.This is an annual benefit entertainment given by Miss Grosvenor forthe League, of which she is anofficer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- International relationships have never been at such a low ebb as at present, Secretary Hull told a delegation of European students at the State Department today. The students represented the Confederation Internationale des Etudiants, and came principally from Great Britain, France and Belgium.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 10. -The powerful "dictatorship" created by Huey Long was inherited tonight by his trusted lieutenant. Governor O. K. Allen, but the Governor's ability to conduct it was in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Further details of the conflict of interests in connection with the bankruptcy proceedings of the McLellan Stores Company in 1933 and 1934 were developed today at the final session of the hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

While everybody is waiting for work relief jobs Mayor La Guardia has just rejected forty-four of forty-six proposed white-collar projects, and he was fully justified in doing so. What a dearth of creative imagination they revealed! Surveys, and surveys of surveys; that is all they could think of.
The Board of Elections appealed yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine for the assignment of sufficient police to the polls on primary day, next Tuesday, to insure an honest and orderly election.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -I happened to be one of the witnesses to the tragedy of our age, being one of the physicians to care for Senator Long.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 10. -- The New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, defeated the Orange Tornadoes, 21 to 0, in an exhibition game at the Knights of Columbus Stadium tonight before a crowd of 12,000.

JASPER, Alta., Sept. 10 (Canadian Press). -- A hazardous trip over mountain trails by saddle and pack horse from the isolated headwaters of Colonel Creek ended here when Mrs. P. A. Curtis, wife of Captain Curtis, New York publisher, reached Jasper Hospital.

The Indians yesterday made their fourth attempt to beat the Yankees on their visit to the Stadium and sought to solve the pitching of young Vito Tamulis. But they finished the afternoon as far from their objectives as the Yankees now seem to be from the American League pennant.

All the factors of organized bedlam associated with important theatrical first nights pervaded the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel until the wee sma' hours this morning. Rehearsal was in progress for an "edited" style review that will, it is predicted, make market history in this country, and a feverish energy characterized the preliminaries, under the auspices of the Fashion Group of New York.

It is just like the Republican National Committee. A surplus of $25,000 is announced, but instead of attributing it to the general economic revival brought about by President ROOSEVELT, the Republicans turn around and say that Mr. ROOSEVELT ought to take an example from them and start in to balance his own budget.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10. -- The New Jersey Federation of Labor, in convention here today, went on record in favor of repeal of the State sales tax and voted the sending of telegrams from each of the 720 State affiliated unions to President Roosevelt urging the promotion of slum clearance and Federal housing projects in New Jersey.

A check for $250,000 was handed over to the Boy Scouts of America yesterday afternoon by the Indemnity Insurance Company of North America. It represents the chief part of the money which the insurance company is obliged to pay because the Scout National Jamboree, which was to have been held last month in Washington, had to be canceled owing to the prevalence of infantile paralysis.

HAVANA, Sept. 10. -- Antonio Hernandez, son of the late famous revolutionist, Colonel Blas Hernandez, was brought to Havana this morning gravely wounded as the result of a political shooting affray yesterday in a cafe at Moron, Camaguey Province.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Field, Glore Co. will offer today the new issue of $24,000,000 Republic Steel Corporation 4 1/2 per cent general mortgage convertible bonds, Series A, due Sept. 1, 1950. The bonds will be priced at par and accrued interest.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Mrs. H. H. Pike and Miss Anne Weeks of the Rockaway Hunt Club won the only close match at the North Hempstead Country Club today in the first round of match play in the annual women's Long Island two-ball golf championship.
ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin was quoted by The Albany Evening News today as saying that Senator Long's death was "the most regrettable thing in modern history."

NORWICH, England, Sept. 10. -The terrific stellar explosion that revealed a nova or "new" star in the constellation Hercules last Winter was declared today to have been perhaps the most important from the scientific standpoint of any of these mighty convulsions studied in modern times.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 10. -- Several colonists from neighboring resorts drove today to the Mount Washington to entertain at tea. Among them were Mrs. Albert W. Porter of the Sugar Hill colony, whose guests included Mrs. S. D. Barkalow and Miss Carolyn Barkalow of Denver and Washington, and Miss Mary Wheeler and Mrs. Thomas C. Brown, also of Washington.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- A twentyfoot putt at the home green that went down for a birdie 3 gave Christopher W. Deibel of Youngstown, Ohio, a decided edge in the initial eighteen-hole round of the United State seniors' golf championship at Apawamis today.
BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- The Boerse was very quiet today, showing weakness at the opening and resistance toward the end of the session.
BERLIN, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Sept. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

" A Slight Case of Murder," which deals none too seriously with gangsters, four murders, Saratoga racing, the liquor business and the like, will open this evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Damon Runyon, specialist of the blue plates, and Howard Lindsay are the authors, and the latter is director and producer.

The spurt in shipments of foreign gold to the United States, predicted in financial circles on Monday, failed yesterday to live up to expectations, although it was reported at the Federal Reserve Bank that $12,750,000 in gold from all sources was in sight.

A slight increase in cases of diphtheria for the second successive week was reported yesterday in the Health Department's weekly statistical analysis. There were nineteen cases compared with fourteen the previous week and six the week before that.
On the first leg of her twohundredth Atlantic voyage the Cunard White Star liner Majestic, which docked here yesterday, brought a strange assortment of good and bad luck to some of the passengers.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 10. -Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain, and Secretary Roper came to Hyde Park House this evening to spend the night as guests of the President in his vacation retreat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Flags on the Capitol and Senate and House Office Buildings fluttered this morning to the top of their poles and then were lowered to half staff as a sign of mourning for Senator Long.

Five hundred members of the Association of Long Island Commuters met last night at Jamaica High School, 168th Street and Gothic Drive, and vigorously protested the fare increases applied for by the Long Island Railroad.

A final split in the Teachers Union appeared inevitable yesterday as Dr. Henry R. Linville, president of the organization, barred any possibility of compromise with left-wing factions on the ground that "the basis for confidence has been completely destroyed."

TRENTON, Sept. 10. -- State Auditor Walter R. Draby reported today that eighty-three subdivisions of government in New Jersey were in default on bonds and had scrip outstanding on June 30. Total scrip authorized was placed at $22,985,949, and of that amount $4,621,122 was unredeemed.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP). -The Browns made a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Athletics by winning the final contest today, 8 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The death of Senator Long was almost the only topic of conversation and comment in political Washington today, as the few members of Congress still in Washington joined in expressions of regret at the assassination.

The city has been seeking unsuccessfully to obtain a reduction in rent paid by its Finance Department for property owned and occupied by an organization headed by Mrs. William Church Osborn, wife of the chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, it was asserted yesterday at a hearing before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that he had arranged with J. P. Morgan Co., agents for the city's bankers, to borrow $20,000,000 tomorrow, in accordance with the procedure laid down in the bankers' agreement. The loan, which will bear an interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent and which will be payable on or before Dec. 31, will be used to meet city payrolls and for the purchase of supplies and materials.

DEMAREST, N.J., Sept. 10. -Fifty-four flower growers in the northern part of Bergen County participated in the annual flower show held here today at the Demarest Garden Club. Mrs. George Morton was chairman of the show committee, Raymond Stone and Mrs. A. F. Brundage of Montvale were the judges.

A shooting gallery to make the guards more proficient in the use of firearms is only one of the many improvements at the Metropolitan Museum of Art begun within the last two months with WPA funds, it was disclosed yesterday by Harry Cassell, superintendent of the WPA museum project, in a report to General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City.
The Municipal Art Commission gave preliminary approval yesterday of a model of the memorial to Father Francis P. Duffy which it is proposed to erect in Times Square.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Less than 37 per cent of the nation's currency is in circulation. The remaining 63 per cent is held in the vaults of the government as reserves, according to the Treasury Department's official circulation statement for August, issued today.
Huey Long was a political genius, and an evil genius, in our opinion. We have to discuss him in his political aspect; and in his political aspect we can find nothing good to say of him.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -Mrs. Charles C. Griswold entertained today at Hillhome, Stockbridge, for twenty-four members of the Ulster County Garden Club, New York, of which Mrs. Hermon A. Kelley is the president. The group visited her Prospect Hill garden.

Some teams start football training with punting and passing drills. Some even scrimmage. But this year Brooklyn College had a form of preliminary exercise that is its exclusive routine. It consisted of cutting down weeds on the practice field with scythes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -There was one Senator, and perhaps one alone, whose voice would still Huey P. Long, and that was Senator Borah of Idaho.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10.--John J.Ghingher, State Bank Commissioner, was elected today president ofthe National Central Bank here,established in 1868. He will succeedWilliam E. Katenkamp, vho becomes chairman of the board.Mr. Ghingher will resign as BankCommissioner, a post he has heldsince February, 1933. Previously hehad been vice president of the Baltimore Trust Company.

Contracts for commercial space in the midtown district of Manhattan, and particularly in the West Side garment centre, provided a feature of the business leases reported yesterday. In several cases the buildings were reported as fully occupied.
GENEVA, Sept. 10. -- Efforts of a subcommittee of the Council of the League of Nations to keep Italy and Ethiopia at peace apparently had run into a stone wall tonight.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 10. -- The presentation of a faithful reproduction of a historic imperial ceremonial sword of the first German Empire by the city of Nuremberg to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler today marked the opening of the National Socialist party's "congress of freedom."

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -As word flashed across the nation of the death of Senator Huey P. Long, who succumbed to an assassin's bullet just before dawn today, the forces which will decide the destiny of the political empire he founded in Louisiana began to shape their strategy for the political fight to come.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 10. -- Drawing his game in the eighth and semi-final round of the international chess tourney at the Klub Szachowy tonight, Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland continued to hold the lead by a narrow margin. He opposed K. Opocensky of Czechoslovakia in a queen's pawn opening and repetition brought about the draw in fifty-five moves.
GENEVA, Sept. 10. -- The Secretary General of the League of Nations gave out late this afternoon the following communication received from Ethiopia's delegate, Tecle Hawariate:

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 10. -- Ready now to fight Max Baer in the Yankee Stadium, though the engagement doesn't take place until Sept. 24, Joe Louis, Detroit's Negro sensation, has just about given up fight preparations for the more pressing duty of rooting home Mickey Cochrane's Detroit Tigers.

TORONTO, Sept. 10. -- Clouds of calcium and other gases were shot out from Nova Herculis, the new star that appeared last December, at speeds up to 700 miler per second, Dr. Dean B. McLaughlin of the University of Michigan observatory reported today at the opening session of the American Astronomical Society.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- An Autumn flower show was held today by the White Plains Garden Club and the garden section of the Contemporary Club of this city in the auditorium of the Contemporary Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The long-submerged struggle between Secretary Ickes and Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, regarding the type of projects to be dominant in the vast workrelief program just getting under way flared into the open today and will be carried to President Roosevelt at Hyde Park tomorrow for a final showdown.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Young Teddy Talmadge of the Peconic-Gardiner's Bays fleet gave his rivals a stern view of some good sailing today as the eleventh annual Atlantic Coast championship series of the International Star Class got under way.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -- The deathbed of Huey Long brought together for the first time in years the four Long brothers, who at times differed bitterly over politics and personal affairs.
Mayor La Guardia made public a list yesterday showing sixty-five projects to be financed by the Federal Government at a total estimated cost of $117,241,674.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -Governor Oscar K. Allen said today: "We are going to follow the principles of Huey P. Long."

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Although "for political reasons" no attempt was made to relay for British listeners a message of peace by Empress Menen of Ethiopia to the women of the world tonight, some radio experts had no hesitation in saying that the broadcast was deliberately jammed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP). With Joe Cascarella scoring a close mound decision over Steve Sundra, Syracuse today defeated Newark, 3 to 2, in the opening game of the International League play-off series involving the second and fourth place teams.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Names of eighty members of the National Will Rogers Memorial Commission were announced today by Governor E. W. Marland. Acceptances have not been received from all persons on the list and there will be some additions, the Governor said.

In one of the fastest performances seen here in years, the John P. Grier filly Marching Home, which races for Mrs. William Ziegler Jr., was timed at 1:17 4-5 for six and one-half furlongs yesterday to demonstrate once more that the Aqueduct racing strip is faster after a rain than after the sun has dried it out.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -Lieutenants in the Long political organization are trying to settle upon one man to direct the affairs of one of the best operating machines ever known in this country.

Following irregularity in the early trading, the share market firmed up yesterday on the news of a fairly long list of favorable dividend declarations to close steady and generally higher. The motor, steel, electrical and farm-equipment issues were the centre of attention.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10. -Sixteen coal companies operating in Harlan County condemned the Guffey Soft Coal Act as the vehicle of five different kinds of unconstitutionality in a suit for injunction against its enforcement they filed in Federal court here late today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -Buck Newsom had control as well as speed today and shut out the Tigers as Washington whipped the American League leaders, 6 to 0. Able to solve Newsom for only six hits, Detroit saw a full game drop from its advantage over the secondplace Yankees.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Cubs continued to get good pitching today and breezed through to a 4to-0 victory over Boston as Charley Root pitched a six-hit shutout. It was Chicago's seventh straight triumph and its eighteenth in twentyone games with the Braves this season.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Autumn flowers and arrangements were featured at the flower show of the Valley Garden Club today at the American Legion Building here. Mrs. Robert E. Rew was chairman of the show committee and Mrs. Harold Thorn, of the exhibit committee.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- The liner Olympic, which made her last Atlantic crossing in April, has been purchased from the CunardWhite Star Line for breaking up by Sir John Jarvis, wealthy publisher who has been interesting himself in finding work for the town of Jarrow, one of the derelict spots of Tyneside.
Apartment house, dwelling and theatre deals were included in the Manhattan trading reported yesterday.

A strike of radio operators on American merchant ships operating from the Port of New York has been called for tomorrow by the New York marine division of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, it was announced last night.
A slight increase in the cost of living for wage earners from July to August was reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- In Britain where, as The Daily Mail says, political assassination is regarded with particular loathing, the manner of Senator Huey P. Long's death aroused general sympathy. To The Financial News it appeared that his pose as a roistering, uneducated "gang politician" was nothing more than a deliberate veil shielding a brilliant organizer, a first-rate lawyer and an unrivaled public speaker.

The legend, which happens to be a true one, is that the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences had its origin in a wheelbarrow. Somewhat more than a hundred years ago a young man, AUGUSTUS GRAHAM, whose name is remembered in one of its foundations, took a wheelbarrow to collect books in order to start an educational project for those beyond school age.

AUSABLE FORKS, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Whatever may be said de mortuis, the administration politicians cannot but feel that the removal of Huey Long from the 1936 Presidential equation eliminates one of those hazards in the path of a candidate over which many a sure man has stumbled on his way to office.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 10. -- Italian officials expressed astonishment today at the decision of Emperor Haile Selassie not to permit Italy to send troops to Addis Ababa as a special legation guard. The Emperor gave no reasons for his decision.
Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Norman Thomas and General Hugh Johnson were among those here yesterday who expressed regret at the death of Senator Huey P. Long.

The first tangible results of the city's anti-noise drive developed yesterday when Magistrate Farrell convicted twelve men who were charged with using loud and boisterous language in a dice game at 4 o'clock in the morning.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York voted yesterday to apply to the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce for suspension of the proposed new freight rates which the intercoastal ship lines have published, effective Oct. 3, and for investigation of their reasonableness.

Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic yesterday after her annual Summer visit to England and France. She added to her itinerary this Summer by going to Scotland, but confined herself to watching others shoot the coveted Scotch bird.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman asked Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief Magistrate of the New York City magistrate's courts, today for a report on statements made by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in discharging five men arrested in connection with a demonstration aboard the German steamship Bremen on July 26.

State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews yesterday reported an increase of $106,110 over July in the cost of building plans submitted during August to the State Department of Labor. One hundred and eleven plans were submitted, nine less than during the previous month, but totaling in cost $898,520 as against $792,410 for July.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10. -Three of the national polo championship contenders rode through an easy round-robin on Mitchel Field today though the turf was heavy, resulting in one fall, in which James P. Mills, Aurora's No. 2, narrowly escaped injury.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 10. -Senator Long left behind him a satirical book, soon to be published, which contains not only his plans and aspirations, but gives an imaginary history of his first year as "President."

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, honorary night superintendent of the Central Park Zoo, who has been scouring the country for new additions for his yawning cages, will soon have two unusual charges to look after.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10. -- Watson Clark annexed his twelfth triumph of the year today as the Dodgers made it three straight over the Reds in a contest again marred by Cincinnati errors. Three misplays by Kiki Cuyler, Ival Goodman and Lew Riggs led to three unearned runs in the eighth, to give Brooklyn the decision by 4 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Repeal of Senator Long's "dictatorship" laws by the Louisiana Legislature was urged today by James M. Thomson, publisher of The New Orleans Item and Morning Tribune.

The granite-like defense that sheathed the lightning of Ellsworth Vines's attacking strokes two years ago at Forest Hills brought about the downfall there yesterday of the player who bas been heralded as the successor to the former champion's mantle.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- A sense of security prevails in banking circles the like of which has not been felt for several years, Rudolph S. Hecht, president of the American Bankers Association told 2,000 business men here today at the twenty-second annual national business conference.

The first prosecution to arise from the racket investigation of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, was brought to a swift close yesterday morning before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, when Dominick Tossone, 19 years old, pleaded guilty to a charge of attempted extortion.
Eleven properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday, as follows:

Arthur S. Tuttle, acting State director of the Public Works Administration, declared yesterday that most if not all of the 106 work relief projects, totaling $70,000,000, which have been rejected by the Public Works Administration in Washington will be redrafted and resubmitted for action by the Federal authorities.

Walter Kappe, editor of the organ of the Friends of New Germany, and regarded as their spokesman in this country, declared last night that his organization had embarked on a policy of establishing the "complete principles of National Socialism" in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- A combined wheat crop of 594,615,000 bushels, the smallest with a single exception for any season since 1904, was forecast today by the government crop reporting board.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Criminal charges of conspiracy to evade income taxes against eight former executives of the Universal Aviation Corporation and the Aviation Corporation, which controls it, were dismissed today by Federal Judge Charles B. Davis, who approved a settlement.

The sound of riveting machines floating in through Times Square windows may be heard with mixed emotions. As a sign that somebody is building up again, instead of tearing down, it is welcome enough. The suspiration of the buses on Madison Avenue at night, while subtly disquieting, is a vast improvement on the clangor of the street cars which they displaced.

Green eyeshading and mascara, with perhaps a sprinkle of gold or silver "star dust" on the shading, will be a feature of women's facial "make-up" this Fall and Winter, on the theory that "glamorous evenings need glamorous women," and because the outstanding Italian influence in styles demands "elegance and fantasy."
When Harold Buttenheim states that "ability to pay and benefits received are sound bases for taxation" he is asserting that a black and a roan are horses of the same color.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, chief of the Army Air Corps, will retire after thirty-six years of service at the end of this year, the War Department announced today. His intention to retire some time this year was made public by General Foulois some time ago.

Including the expense of removing the abandoned surface car tracks, the Works Progress Administration is repaving sections of Madison Avenue at less than half the original estimated cost and at a little more than half the contract price.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Thirtysix offering sheets by oil interests were received last week, the SEC announced today. The filing did not give to a security the commission's approval or indicate that the commission had passed on the issue's merits or decide that the material filed was correct.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press). -- A resolution calling for the boycott of German goods and declaring opposition to the participation of United States athletes in the Olympic Games at Berlin next year was unanimously adopted here today by the convention of the International Typographical Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10. -- Robert V. Fleming, first vice president of the American Bankers Association, appealed today to members of the Financial Advertisers Association, in convention here, to "make it possible for the government to get out of business."

Prices on the commodity futures markets were mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Most staples fluctuated within a narrow range. In the cash markets all the grains, rubber and cotton were higher, while lard and tin sold off.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- British public opinion evidently is hardening itself in advance to the inevitability of war in Africa regardless of what Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, may say tomorrow or what anybody else can do at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- James A. Farley will resign as Postmaster General at the time of the meeting of the Democratic National Committee to be held here about Jan. 8. He will be succeeded by Frank C. Walker of New York, director of the National Emergency Council and head of the Division of Applications and Information of the Work Relief Program, who has consented to serve as Postmaster General until after the 1936 Presidential election.

Local traction bonds were bid up briskly in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Interest in other domestic corporation bonds lagged, with prices fluctuating within comparatively narrow limits. Renewed pressure against Italian dollar loans was a feature in the market for foreign issues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The removal of Senator Long, the administration's most implacable foe, by an assassin's bullet, ends, in the opinion of observant politicians, the threat of an ultra-radical independent Democratic party next year.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- A ball club whose gyrations have been extremely difficult for the eye to follow catapulted itself right back into the National League pennant race today as Colonel Bill Terry's Giants wrenched both ends of a double-header from the Pirates while a crowd of 8,000 implored the Corsairs to produce a different result.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -Frank B. Frishmuth, 86 years old, a retired tobacco manufacturer, plunged to his death from his room on the fifteenth floor of the Hahnemann Hospital today.

Of HUEY LONG personally it is no longer necessary to speak except with charity. His motives, his character, have passed beyond human judgment. People will long talk of his picturesque career and extraordinary individual qualities. He carried daring to the point of audacity.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 10. -- The Ethiopian Government has refused the request of Count Luigi VinciGigliucci, the Italian Minister, to bring 200 Italian troops and six machine guns to guard his legation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 10. -Taking two more of their international races against the Bermuda One-Design team, the Long Island Sound Interclub crews led tonight in the series, three contests to two. They competed off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

Frank Kelly, "the original Shipwreck Kelly," who has roosted for more than 17,500 hours on various poles, ascended one atop a building at a busy intersection on University Avenue, the Bronx, on Monday and yesterday a policeman sent him a summons on a rope.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10. -- There was only one really momentous match in all the sixty-four that were played on the Country Club of Cleveland course in today's second round of the national amateur golf championship.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 10. -- Alleged confessions by Alberto Antonio de Sedas, Panaman drug store clerk, and Homero Ayala, former chief of police of Panama, R.P., resulted in the discovery last night of the machine guns and part of the other arms stolen from the United States army ordinance depot at Corozal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Prince Pest made it three victories in a row when the 7-year-old son of Prince of Umbria Bother scored in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature event at Hawthorne today, scoring by a head over Mrs. W. T. Westrope's Vanita.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Titus Jr. gave a dinner last night at their home, 120 East Seventy-fifth Street, for John B. Dunbar of Chicago. The other guests were: Mr. and Mrs. Marshall W. Pask, Mr. and Mrs. Junius Powell, Mrs. E. Schrieber Carter, Miss Mary Kempner, R. Gould Morehead and Edward H. Jewett Jr.
BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- The Friends of the New Germany have sent from their recent meeting at New York to the headquarters of the Association of Germans Abroad the following cablegram:

Brig. Gen. William E. Horton, U.S.A. (retired), was taken yesterday afternoon to the Post Hospital, Governors Island, in an army ambulance from Somerville, N.J., near where he had become suddenly ill the day before.

With Alfred E. Smith among the judges, Park Commissioner Moses as master of ceremonies and Mayor La Guardia as favored listener, the Bay City Four, a barber shop quartet from Brooklyn, warbled their way to the first prize in the finals of the American Ballad Contest for amateur barber shop quartets on the Mall in Central Park last night.
Does it, as Cyril Brown believes, matter so much whether or not we vote? The wrong men get in anyway. At least, we think them wrong as long as they are in office. Only dead men get monuments.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday for the second quarter of this year estimated net earnings of $796,000 after expenses, estimated Federal income taxes, interest on new debentures of the company which bear interest from Jan. 1 in accordance with the plan of reorganization, reserve for losses of Paramount Broadway Corporation and companies which are inactive or the future status of which is uncertain.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- Yesterday's brisk recovery in prices on the Bourse was not maintained today. So little business was done that quotations sagged in all departments. French banks and industrial shares, which were buoyant yesterday, fell off in a weak manner.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Sept. 10 -The Rev. Carl McIntire, pastor of the Collingswood Presbyterian Church, Collingswood, N.J., was ordered suspended today from the church and the ministry because of "violation of his ordination vows."

Heavily laden with trophies, souvenirs and pleasant memories of a two months' competitive tour which carried them through Finland, Norway, Sweden and Poland, the last of the three American track and field teams which campaigned in Europe this Summer arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Majestic.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10. -Through careful direction of children's leisure-time activities and stimulation of early desires for certain types of refreshments the National Women's Christian Temperance Union hopes to fight crime and juvenile delinquency and curb liquor tendencies in the future.

If past expressions are to be considered, the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad's bondholders will show no enthusiasm for the plan filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission for dividing the property among major Northwestern lines.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday sought the views of civic and transportation interests of the port district on its proposal to build a railroad freight tunnel below the upper bay, linking Greenville, N.J., and Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.
The Great Northern Railway's management is considering plans for meeting the maturity next July 1 of $105,859,000 of general mortgage 7 per cent bonds. An announcement is expected later in the month.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10. -- Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan approved today a fee of $85,000 to Charles Edison as executor of the estate of his father, Thomas A. Edison, the inventor, and a counsel fee of $30,000 to McCarter English, counsel to the executors.

The forward impulse which has prevailed ever since July, in general business as on financial markets, and which has been accelerated (so far at least as the stock market is concerned) since the President's promise to "give industry a breathing spell," calls for some examination of the question how far we have yet got back toward normal.

Presiding Justice Martin of the Appellate Division, at a hearing of appeals in election cases, declared that some provisions of the Election Law were "farcical." It has been my privilege to appear as attorney for one of the insurgent democratic candidates for high office in Brooklyn, and I have had occasion to come in contact with the workings of that law.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10. -Oscar Kelly Allen, 53-year-old Governor of Louisiana, who now becomes titular successor to Huey P. Long as head of the political machine the Senator built, has often claimed to he the man who made Huey Long a success.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Competition in the Scott Trophy rifle match today resulted in nine men tying for first place with perfect scores of 50. The next seventeen tied with 49 points each. The contest was one of the events of the national rifle matches in progress here.

A new peak in the present buying season was reached during the week ended yesterday when the number of buyers registered in the market was the highest since the week of Jan. 9, when 1,257 arrivals were listed. For the week 1,240 buyers were reported as against 402 in the preceding week and 789 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- Jewish children are to be isolated in separate Jewish public schools after Easter of next year, Bernhard Rust, Reich Minister for Culture, decreed today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 10. -Leading all the way through the five and a half furlongs of the feature race today at Narragansett Park, T. F. Swords's 2-year-old gelding Richstrike won by three lengths from Mrs. W. H. Cane's Armful over a heavy but drying track.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- The demand for fresh pork has slowed down as the result of the recent advance in prices, but this failed today to affect the market for hogs. Prices here were generally strong to 15 cents a hundredweight higher, with some sows regarded as 25 cents higher.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 10. -About 300 of the sub-debutante daughters of members of the Nassau Country Club, their guests and young men who are to return to school and college this month attended the last of the junior supper dances tonight at the club.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared last night that the solution for the nation's problems of unemployment and depression rested upon a powerful and militant labor movement able to increase mass purchasing power through collective bargaining.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Lord Beaverbrook's newspaper, The Evening Standard, said today that there was "regret" for the Huey Long assassination but not much "sympathy" for Long himself.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- A threerun rally in the eighth inning, after Joe Bowman had held them to one hit and one run, gave the Cardinals a 4-to-2 triumph today over Philadelphia. The victory, coming after two straight defeats at the hands of the Phils, enabled the Red Birds to maintain their one-game National League lead over the second-place Cubs.

The Associated Gas and Electric system, through F. S. Burroughs, vice president, issued yesterday an explanation of the revelation made by the Public Service Commission that one Associated subsidiary had charged another subsidiary $85,000 for fill for a gas plant site, when the fill actually had been supplied free of charge by the State.

The first of the political teas that seem destined to play an important part in the contest between former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney and John E. Sheehy for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District was held yesterday.

The present business upswing, the first due to "inherent economic strength" and not "government spending or currency action" is the healthiest the country has enjoyed so far, M. A. Mittelman, president of the National Shoe Retailers Association, told 1,500 merchants, manufacturers and designers at the concluding session of the group's spring style conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,660,200 barrels, compared with 2,665,100 in the preceding week, a decline of 4,900, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 22,150 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and a gain of 17,800 barrels in California were the principal changes.

A group of twenty-two persons, representing the stage, screen and writing fields, have accepted appointment to the advisory board of the New Film Alliance, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Merritt Crawford, its president.

ATHENS, Sept. 10. -- Former King George's restoration was nearer today than it had been at any time since he left Greece eleven years ago when Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris, under the unremitting threats of his royalist military leaders, led by War Minister George Kondylis, declared himself in favor of a "republic with a king."

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that no one should worry over the possibility of new payless furloughs for city employes at this stage of the fixing of the budget. The Mayor spoke after President Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, had said flatly that he would not vote for another furlough.

Copyright, 1935, by the New York Times Company and NANA, Inc. Bryan Grant eliminated the 1935 tennis sensation, Donald Budge, yesterday by taking the fourth set in their postponed match with as cleverly conceived a mixture of attack and defense as has been seen at Forest Hills in several seasons.

The long-smoldering feud between General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for this city, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses, under whose jurisdiction many thousands of unemployed are at work or assigned to WPA projects, flared up yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10. -- Weather clear, track heavy. They had a fine bright Autumn day for the second round of the amateur golf championship over The Country Club course here today. There was a light breeze, scattered white clouds and a high blue sky overhead, but underfoot the fairway was still soft from the recent rain. Getting around the course was a carrying job all the way.

Members of the New York County Republican organization opposed to the re-election of Chase Mellen Jr. as county chairman pointed yesterday to the fact that seven out of the twenty Assembly district leaders who were announced last Saturday as having signed pledges to support Mr. Mellen failed to attend a conference Monday afternoon called by William C. Hecht, Mr. Mellen's campaign manager.

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., acting yesterday as the result of persistent reports that the city and Interborough security holders had reached a definite agreement on transit unification, charged that a stock-rigging movement was in progress.

ATHENS, Sept. 11. -- Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris refused the demand of royalists today that Parliament should invite former King George to return as a private person before the plebiscite on monarchial restoration. Both the Premier and War Minister George Kondylis said the plebiscite would be held without the ex-King being present.

The cosmetics industry was urged to defend itself against "unwarranted attacks" upon its products and against unfair legislation at Washington by speakers at yesterday's sessions of the Perfume and Cosmetic Buyers Conference and Exhibition being held at the Hotel Commodore.

A final step toward constructing the city's largest high school, the Franklin K. Lane, at Jamaica Avenue and Dexter Court, Brooklyn, was taken last night when the Board of Education approved plans for its construction at a cost of $2,160,000. The building will cost $3,500,000 to complete.
In your editorial on potato control you state: "This year's potato crop is estimated at 377,000,000 bushels, which, while high, is far from record-breaking."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11. -- Amid attractive floral decorations of garden flowers, in which purple, pink and white predominated, Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander gave a luncheon at the Muenchinger-King today for a group of her Summer colony friends. Mrs. Rhinelander is being rejoined by her daughter, Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander, later in the week. Miss Rhinelander is at present visiting friends on Long Island.
