LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- For the next fortnight the New York University football squad will be deep in the woods at its camp here, but once Coach Mal Stevens gets his young stalwarts out of the woods he has every expectation that they will stay out of them for the rest of the season.
The final round of the men's national tennis championship will be a bitter battle between Sidney Wood and Wilmer Allison, and I expect to see Wood come home the victor in a very close match.
Verree Teasdale and Allen Jenkins will have roles in Warner Brothers' forthcoming screen version of "The Petrified Forest," in which Leslie Howard will star, with Bette Davis as his leading lady.
Money market was stationary so far as business and rate variations were concerned. Demand was light and quotations unchanged for all grades.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- Although at Nuremberg today Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler himself proclaimed the primacy of National Socialist politics over business, and Nazi publications like the Black Corps of the Storm Troops are openly blocking the contrary speech at Koenigsberg by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the Economics Minister, the business part of this politics continues to cause concern for the men charged with financing it.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 11 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Dr. Judah L. Magnes was elected president of the Hebrew University in Palestine, it was officially announced here today, following a meeting of the university's board of governors.

Persons who have visited the Hayden Planetarium in Chicago and the many who will soon have the privilege of seeing the Hayden Planetarium in New York will be interested to know that Cicero, in his "Republic," refers to an astronomical sphere, constructed by the famed Archimedes and taken by Marcellus from the conquered Syracusans, which showed the motions of the sun, moon and "those five stars which are called wandering and irregular."

Closing strongly to vindicate the faith of those who consider him the outstanding 3-year-old jumper, Driver yesterday captured the Harbor Hill Steeplechase at Aqueduct by four lengths. His stablemate, Prattler, landed second. Both carried the familiar green silks of Thomas Hitchcock.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- With the deadline for the filing of applications for Public Works Administration allotments set for tomorrow, applications on file today totaled 10,699.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- President Roosevelt, in his "psuedo role of dictator," forced unconstitutional legislation through Congress in order to make revision of the Constitution an issue in 1936 if the Supreme Court upsets his basic reforms by declaring the AAA and other acts unconstitutional, Representative Snell of New York said today in a review of the Congressional session just passed, printed in the final issue of the Congressional Record.

The New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the first listing of a "beer stock" since the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, when it admitted 390,412 shares of no-par capital stock of the Pfeiffer Brewing Company of Detroit. The stock heretofore has been traded on the Detroit Stock Exchange.

In an effort to facilitate the filing of claims by thousands of owners of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler signed an order yesterday directing Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, to show cause on Tuesday why a blanket proof of claim should not be filed for each list of certificates other than an individual claim for each investor.

A supreme court of fashion handed down its verdicts on the Winter mode at the Hotel Astor last night, through the medium of members of the Fashion Group of New York. Its ultimatum for elegance, for color and for verve gratified 1,500 interested observers gathered from many areas, whose report on the promenade will exert influence on the women's apparel market as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Argentina is the only foreign government which has instructed its diplomatic representatives here to arrange for permanent registration of its bonds with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned today. Other embassies and legations have received no instructions from their governments on the SEC's requirement that foreign issues be registered, and some of the diplomatic officers were not aware that registration is required.

Movements of prices for futures in the commodity markets were mixed yesterday, and the day was marked by the suspension of floor trading in the December and January No. 1 sugar futures contracts. In the cash markets wheat, coffee and tin were higher, while corn, rye, oats and rubber declined.

The French lined Lafayette, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, has among her passengers a group of thirty-seven exchange students who will attend schools here under international educational exchanges.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Domestic wheat markets made a poor response today to sharply higher cables from Liverpool, independent strength in Winnipeg, continued drought in Argentina and the strained political situation in Europe.

The feud between General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses over problems affecting the employment of thousands of jobless workers on park projects assumed acute form yesterday when Mr. Moses informed General Johnson that unless certain conditions were complied with he would begin next week wholesale dismissal of the men.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. ll. -- Charles S. Hosford Jr. of Pittsburgh was recommended to President Roosevelt today as a member of the Federal Coal Commission by Senator Guffey, author of the act setting up a "little NRA" for the bituminous coal industry.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 11. -- A plot to overthrow the government of President Harmodio Arias of Panama was involved in the theft of arms from the United States Army at Corozal, according to army authorities. Former Chief of Police Homero Ayala engineered the plan, according to the testimony of Edward Paine, former United States soldier, in the Magistrate's Court of Balboa at the arraignment of Ayala today.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 11. -- With eight rounds completed, the ninth and final round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Klub Szachowy has been scheduled tomorrow. Only three of the ten competitors are left with any chance to win the first and second prizes, which rest among Dr. S. Tartakower and S. Kolski of Poland and Reuben Fine, United States.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 11 -- Adolf Hitler abandoned politics and military strategy to lecture his disciples at the Nazi party convention tonight on the subject of art -- especially his pet hobby, architecture.

The Bronx was the centre of active real estate trading yesterday. Most of the deals were for apartment houses. Contracts on a Jerome Avenue plot and a one-family dwelling in East 182d Street marked the first change of ownership of the properties in more than thirty years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges tossed away a tight game with a wild throw in the twelfth inning today to give the Senators a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers.

As the time approaches when the issue of $19,172,000 of bonds of Consumers Power Company, now on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission, will become effective, it is indicated that this financing will be the first to be undertaken by the recently organized Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

The Universal Carloading and Distributing Company, with offices in many of the principal cities, has completed the opening of a new station in the Bronx, at Westchester and Brook Avenues, it was announced yesterday by F.N. Melius, president.

What complicates the problem of taxation is that we are confronted with certain inherent contradictory factors which cannot well be reconciled. We would like to broaden the base of the tax system so as to make every one tax-conscious, but it is axiomatic that, on the tax-gatherer's side, the tax which yields best is the one passed along in such a way that the persons who pay do not realize they are being taxed.
Ten properties in Manhattan were bought in at auction sales resulting from foreclosure proceedings yesterday. Most of the improvements consisted of apartment buildings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace said today that the Farm Administration had asked the Budget Bureau for $2,000,000 to carry out the potato control program until Congress appropriates funds.

Trading in local traction securities again provided the high light in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. After reaching new high levels in early trading, the tractions broke sharply following a statement by City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. that the securities already were selling at prices higher than any even considered for them in unification proceedings.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Paul Dean, shaky in his preceding start against Boston, pitched masterfully today against the Phillies and the world champion Cardinals maintained their National League leadership, winning, 10 to 2.
VATICAN CITY, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Bishop Hayes of Helena, Mont., today was named rector of the North American College in Rome.

Controller Frank J. Taylor will open bids at 2 P.M. today for a new issue of $6,000,000 New York City special corporate stock notes, dated Sept. 18, 1935, and maturing on March 18, 1936. The banking groups that have been invited to submit tenders for the notes have been requested also to specify the rate of interest.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The sum of $352,000,000 has been requested for New York State projects by the Works Progress Administration, Lester W. Herzog of Albany, administrator of the PWA for the State, told the 750 members of the Regional Library Conference here today.

Speakers of three faiths called for an American boycott of the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday in honor of George Lathan, prominent British Laborite and chairman of the British section of the World Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi Council.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11. -- A volley of two dozen pistol shots reverberated through the St. Louis City Hall and across an adjacent plaza this afternoon, leaving two politicians and two policemen wounded, in the first violent outbreak of a long-smoldering political feud here.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 11. -- A letter written by George C. Hanson, former United States Consul General at Moscow, who committed suicide Sept. 2 on the liner President Polk on his way home from Greece, was made public today in a copyrighted article in The Bridgeport Times-Star.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The Ridgefield Park Garden Club today announced the winners in its eleventh annual flower show, which took place at Roosevelt School Saturday and Sunday. Presentation of awards was made this evening at a brief ceremony in the Municipal Building by George W. Morss, president of the club.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- The Wimbledon Cup match of the National Rifle Association tournament was captured today by Ben C. Comfort of St. Louis, who had a perfect score of 100. Fourteen of his twenty shots hit the exact centre of the bullseye.

Foreseeing an increase in aviation in the next few years that will make additional airports necessary in New York, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that the city was seeking another airport site in the Bronx.
The sun that refused to shine for the Yankees most of last week shone too brightly yesterday and cost them their farewell clash of the season with the Indians before 5,000 at the Stadium.

A $25,000 damage suit was filed in Supreme Court yesterday against the American Committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, 17 Battery Place, by the Hammond Research Corporation on the ground that the committee made a negligent report on the seaworthiness of a wooden schooner purchased by the research company, headed by John Hays Hammond Jr., which caused the plaintiff the damage sued for.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Following is the text of the broadcast that Empress Menen of Ethiopia made at Addis Ababa last night but that was not heard distinctly because of radio interference, intentional, according to some experts. It was cabled to London by the Reuters Agency.

IN "Literature and Society" (Lothrop, Lee Shepard, $3) Albert Guerard offers us what he considers the perfect social recipe for the concoction of good literature. It is: train a writer in a period of ferment and revolt, let him live on into a period of tightening authority, but make sure the authority is too thick-witted to detect heresy or insult if it is at all subtle.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Mixing nineteen hits with Boston's fielding lapses, the Cubs sped to a 15-to-3 victory over the Braves today and kept pace a game behind the league leading Cardinals.

The share market assumed a more confident tone during most of yesterday's session in the heaviest trading since July 26, 1934; profit-taking, particularly toward the closing, was taken care of without much difficulty and final prices were irregularly higher.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Harold Halsted of Moriches Bay, the defending champion, took the honors today in the second race of the Atlantic Coast championship series for international star class yachts, but Eddie Ketcham of the Great South Bay fleet put his ancient craft Draco into first place in the point standing.

Riverside Church will eventually receive a bequest of $100,000 if it sets up a reading room as a memorial to Joseph L. Porter of 31 East Seventy-ninth Street, husband of Carita H. Porter, who died on July 18. The bequest was listed in her will, which was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11. -- Premier Aberhart of Alberta, who was elected to office on the Social Credit party ticket, today obtained a loan of $2,500,000 from the Dominion Government, with the approval of Prime Minister Bennett.

BATON ROUGE, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The last Huey Long special session of the Louisiana Legislature ended today with the lawmakers obeying the wishes of their dead master and enacting his final decrees into law.
BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- The Boerse opened unsteady today, but became firmer toward the closing of the session.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11. -- Speakers at the annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union deviated today from the usual attack on liquor to make a bitter critical survey of radio broadcasting program and the newspapers.

John Zarcone, 12 years old, put on a show yesterday afternoon in the garage at the rear of his home at 130-20 Fifty-eighth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, for a juvenile audience that could not distinguish between make-believe and reality.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The Democratic National Committee is still deeply in debt. Its unpaid bills on Aug. 31 amounted to $417,868.18 for obligations incurred in the 1928 and 1932 campaigns. Despite earlier official assertions that the deficit had reached a vanishing point, the report filed today with the clerk of the House showed that the debt in the last six months had been reduced by only about $85,000.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division signed an order yesterday creating four additional Special Terms of the Supreme Court to hear the mass of pre-primary disputes involving nominations by both Democratic and Republican parties in the majority of the twenty-three Assembly districts of New York City.

The Republican party of New York County seems to be undergoing disintegration under the present leadership. Thousands of its members are leaving because of antagonism and inability of the leadership to unite the party. Ever since the new leadership there have been attempts to displace district leaders and to discriminate against party workers for the purpose of concentration of power, which, in effect, would eliminate representative party organization.

A great champion lost his purple cloak of invincibility yesterday in the most staggering reversal witnessed at Forest Hills since William Tilden was toppled from his throne by Henri Cochet in 1926, and another champion, Miss Helen Jacobs, set a new record in American women's tennis.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11. -- For a district that was not supposed to have any exceptionally outstanding golfers the East has managed to do itself proud thus far in the thirty-ninth national amateur championship.

Fourteen players reached the round of sixteen in the ninth national professional singles tennis championship which started yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Among those who advanced were Karel Kozeluh, George M. Lott Jr., Lester R. Stoefen, Alfred H. Chapin Jr., Frank T. Hunter and Herman Peterson, all of whom are seeded.
While the East Side led in volume of apartment rentals reported yesterday, numerous tenancies in the suburbs also were listed:

HYDE PARK, Sept. 11. -- President Roosevelt entertained at luncheon yesterday Father Charles E. Coughlin, who has used his radio forum to make some of the strongest attacks on the administration program.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced last night that it had abandoned any hope of averting a strike of its members on American merchant ships operating to and from the port of New York and that action would be taken today at 10 A.M. on nineteen vessels.

What will chiefly arrest attention in the Government's monthly report on the grain crops is the plain intimation that, despite the estimated increase of nearly 20 per cent over 1934 in this year's wheat yield, the harvest will still be insufficient to provide for home requirements.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the seven months ended on July 31 amounted to $2,248,954 after taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. This equaled $2.15 a share on 1,045,279 shares of $100 par capital stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11. -- Wall Sreet is a natural target for all the "prejudices and antagonisms" which the resident of Main Street holds against banks, big business and even against New York City itself, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared here today at a meeting of the Financial Advertisers Association.

The problem of casting "Pride and Prejudice," which has been harrying Max Gordon since he acquired the play, now is reported solved. Adrianne Allen and Helen Chandler will have the two leading feminine roles, they say, with Colin Keith-Johnston, H. Reeves-Smith, Jessie Busley, Lucile Watson and Percy Waram in other roles.

A clear intimation that the resigning officers of the Teachers Union would ask the American Federation of Labor to intervene in the faction-tangled affairs of the American Federation of Teachers was contained in a statement mailed yesterday to all members of the Teachers Union by the seven officers.

Joe Vollmer, junior halfback, figured prominently in Columbia's football workouts yesterday at Baker Field. The Lions drilled more than five hours during the morning and afternoon, and toward the end of the latter session Coach Lou Little sent his first team into light contact work with the reserves.
LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange dropped today as a result of the Geneva deadlock, even yesterday's rise in Wall Street failing to help the international list.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 11. -- All the $50,000,000 of State tax-anticipation notes, except about $4,000,000, has been sold, Charles A. Waters, State Treasurer, said today. The State Treasury disposed of $38,000,000 and there are options on $8,000,000.

Sportsmen's organizations of Connecticut that conducted a winning campaign last Winter for legislation to give the fish and game officials discretionary power to fix seasons and adjust bag limits now are to enjoy the first benefits under the new dispensation.

Placement of 81,606 persons in the State in jobs in the first six months of 1935 was reported yesterday to Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews by William H. Lange, director of both the New York State Employment Service and the State branch of the National Re-employment Service.

RYE, N,Y., Sept. 11. -- Christopher W. Deibel of Youngstown, Ohio, obtained a firmer grip on the United States senior golf crown today as the first section of 300 competitors for the historic cup completed their rounds at the Apawamis Club.

Dr. WILLIAM MILLER, in his authoritative history of Greece, looking into the future from the year 1928 (four years after the change from a monarchy to a republic), wisely said of Greece, without expressing a predilection for either the monarchical or republican form of government, that given peace her progress is certain.

GENEVA, Sept. 11. -- The session of the League of Nations Assembly, devoted almost wholly to the burning question of Ethiopia and the League's attitude toward the threatened Italian aggression, was notable today for the clear and diplomatically precise declaration by Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, of Great Britain's attitude.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Scoring 21 1/4 to 15 points in the sixth race of their international match, the Bermuda sailors today evened the series with Long Island Sound interclub class skippers at three contests each. A seventh race tomorrow will decide the issue.

Herman Handler, 40 years old, a bookmaker who lived at the Hotel Belvedere in West Forty-eighth Street, near Ninth Avenue, was found shot dead at 7 o'clock yesterday morning in his roadster in front of 108-14 Thirty-seventh Road, Corona, Queens.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 11. -- Ethiopian forces that have been holding advance positions on the Eritrean frontier withdrew eighteen miles today to avoid any border incidents with Italian troops reported nearing the same area.

In explanation of the recent declaration by General Motors Corporation of an extra dividend of 50 cents a share, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, stated yesterday in distributing the dividends to shareholders that payments were determined solely by earnings and the future needs of the business.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 11. -- While the League of Nations Council sits uneasily in the judgment on their case, the Italian people maintain an almost fatalistic calm. On the eve of a war, as everybody here believes, the imminent war-makers seem perturbed less than the would-be peace-makers.

A quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the $3 convertible preferred stock of the General Telephone Corporation was announced yesterday by the directors. The dividend is the first since completion of the reorganization by which General Telephone was formed to acquire the assets of the Associated Telephone Utilities Company.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- A single stroke held Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old freckle-faced Minneapolis girl, in the lead of the women's Western Derby seventy-two-hole medal play golf tournament today.

The frost and storms of more than a century had dimmed the inscription on the tomb of Alexander Hamilton, and visitors to Trinity Churchyard often passed the stone without recognition. For several days stonecutters and masons have been busy at the tomb, and yesterday the task of recutting the letters and cleaning the face of the stone was completed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The will of Mrs. Anna Wilmarth Ickes, leaving practically all of her estate to her husband, Secretary of the Interior Ickes, was filed for probate here today. It was estimated by Frederick Z. Marx, the lawyer who filed the will, that the estate, consisting principally of real estate, is valued under present conditions at $500,000.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11. -- Colonel Bill Terry, never remiss in revealing that he possesses at all times the courage of his convictions, once more laid Roy Parmelee on the line today in the hope that Big Tarzan would come through and help the Giants in the present desperate drive to recoup their lost fortunes.

Caught napping by an eleventh-hour announcement from Washington that the army's two sixteen-inch coast defense guns at Fort Tilden, Rockaway Point, Queens, would be fired this afternoon at 2 o'clock, civic leaders of Neponsit, Belle Harbor and Rockaway Park hastily organized a protest last night with Representative William F. Brunner of Rockaway Park as their spokesman.
TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 11. -- The "dark" nebulae are not really dark, but seem to shine by reflected starlight.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it would receive bids for the construction of the first section of the Sixth Avenue subway, between Fortieth and Forty-seventh Streets, on Oct. 4 at 11:30 A.M., at its offices at 250 Hudson Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11. -- Soviet opinion on the Italo-Abyssinian dispute has hardened perceptibly in the past ten days and the tone of the press, if not actually changed, has undoubtedly undergone a certain modification.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11. -- One-sided matches marked today's play in the annual women's Long Island two-ball golf championship at the North Hempstead Country Club as four teams entered the semi-final round.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Stormy Weather, Philip Le Boutillier's Bermuda-rigged yawl, which captured the transatlantic race last June from Newport to Bergen, Norway, and then went on to win the famous Fastnet Cup race in England last month, anchored-off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, her home port, this morning after a successful return trip.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 11. -- Emperor Haile Selassie held a long meeting with his Ministers and foreign advisers this afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11. -- By avoiding too many damaging errors and knocking Uncle Tom Zachery out as early as the fourth inning, the Reds today salvaged the final game of their series with the Dodgers, 7 to 4, giving Paul Derringer his eighteenth triumph and gaining an even break on the season's play between the two clubs.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 11. -- Thousands of his fellow citizens paid their last respects today to Senator Huey Pierce Long, whose body lay in state in Memorial Hall of the towering Capitol which is to be his tombstone.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11. -- A fleet of sixty-seven craft competed today in the opening races of the third annual Fall series of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. The races started and finished in the harbor, but only the larger craft went out on Long Island Sound to Execution Light before beating back to the finish line.

Although active trade and foreign buying yesterday lifted prices on the Cotton Exchange to the best figures of the week, an increase in hedging operations in the last hour wiped out the improvement and left quotations a point higher to a point lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The United States is likely to import some 25,000,000 bushels of wheat from Canada in the coming year unless millers, bakers and ultimately the housewives are willing to use the low-grade wheat productive of a low grade of bread, Secretary Wallace said today.

Undoubtedly it was with a great sigh of sincere relief that every inhabitant of our city looked over the newspaper this morning to learn that Mayor La Guardia had definitely expressed himself against unnecessary noises and inaugurated a noise abatement campaign.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 11. -- The Bolivian Government has signed a contract with the Hochschild Company for the construction at Titicaca Lake, 12,500 feet above the sea level, one of the biggest hydroelectric plants in Latin America. It will be able to supply electricity for all the needs not only of Bolivia but of neighboring countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Receipt of a registration statement for a $20,000,000 issue of 4 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The statement had been filed Sept. 5 at the SEC's San Francisco office.

The constitutionality of the deposit insurance feature of the National Banking Act of 1935 was challenged in a suit filed in Federal court yesterday, which asked that the Manufacturers Trust Company be enjoined from paying assessments that will be due the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Conversion of called Fourth Liberty Loan bonds into new 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes of March, 1939, will cease with the close of business on Saturday, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. The Treasury, however, will continue to refund the called Liberty bonds into new 2 3/4 per cent Treasury bonds of 1945-47 "until further notice," according to the Secretary's announcement.

PRAGUE, Sept. 11. -- Minister of War Josef Machnik in statements to various newspapers has charged that German-speaking citizens of Czechoslovakia showed hostility toward Czechoslovak troops engaged in their recent manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - (AP). --Conflict between New York State regulations and Federal law tonight brought the possibility that about $50,000,000 in postal savings deposits in New York banks may be turned back to the Treasury.

Steel ingot production moved up this week 2 points to 52 1/2 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since the middle of February, according to the summary of Iron Age, issued yesterday. The magazine said the automobile industry had been responsible for a little of this gain, but that larger releases from it were expected in two or three weeks.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- In a telegram to Governor Hoffman, made public here today, G.E. Wilson, secretary of the Retail Merchants Association of New Jersey, declared that a survey by the association showed that the sales tax had caused a 9 per cent decline in business in Northern New Jersey in August and had driven business out of the State.
GENEVA, Sept. 11. -- The text of the address of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, before the Assembly of the League of Nations follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The East-West marriage of the foster son of the President of China and a former dime-store clerk may end in a divorce court, Forrest F. Smith, an attorney, said tonight.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that he had obtained funds for the construction of the proposed $1,000,000 stadium on Randall's Island despite the refusal of Public Works Administrator Harold L. Ickes to permit the use of Triborough Bridge funds for the project.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Ernest V. Chamberlin, a retired newspaper editor and correspondent, was killed late last night by a hit-and-run driver in Grahamsville, where he had lived for the last nine years.

New welfare legislation aimed at reorganization of relief agencies to provide better care for dependents was introduced in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor, former Welfare Commissioner under Mayor Walker.

Mrs. Charles Stollberg gave a dinner last night at the Biltmore to celebrate the seventy-fifth birthday of her husband. The other guests were Mr. and. Mrs. Forrest Figsby, Mr. and Mrs. Kent Corson, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Fenton L. Gilbert, Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Blank, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Frey, Mr. and Mrs. Sam Small, Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Zane and Kenneth Adams.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
The strike of shipping clerks in the garment industry ended yesterday when the strikers accepted an employers' proposal for a forty-four-hour week and $15 a week minimum wage.
Gross revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in the first week of September ran about at the same levels as last year, according to Howard S. Palmer, president.

ROME, Sept. 11. -- What hopes Italy ever had -- and they never were very great -- that it would be possible to devise some formula at Geneva for legalizing her war with Ethiopia were destroyed today by the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, before the Assembly of the League of Nations.

When Elizabeth Hartog sold to Dora Fuchs the houses at 711-13 E. llth St. for a consideration shown as $21,500. Mrs. Fuchs gave a purchase money mortgage to Louis N. Hartog for $16,500, payable ten years hence at 6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today that the nation's farmers will have a cash income of $6,700,000,000 in 1935 -- the largest in five years.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Syracuse made it two straight over Newark in their International League play-off series today by defeating the Bears, 6 to 3, behind the six-hit flinging of Hy Vandenberg. Johnny Kroner's home run with the bases full in the seventh inning broke a 2-all tie and gave the Chiefs victory.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The mounting cost of Britain's defense measures in the Mediterranean was discussed at a two-hour meeting at 10 Downing Street today between Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and the heads of the defense departments.

Postmaster General FARLEY must have a malicious pleasure in disappointing those punctilious Progressives in Congress whose nerves he has abraded. His professional zeal has not always been discriminating in their eyes. He has seemed to them no better than one of the wicked of the days before civil service reform.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 11. -- Foes of the National Socialist State and such optimists as may have read into recent non-party pronouncements forebodings of a reversal from Nazi extremism were bluffly notified today by Adolf Hitler that the mandate of his party superseded the authority of the State and its bureaucracy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Three New York State corporations, the Elmira Light, Heat and Power, the Empire Gas and Electric and the New York Central Electric Companies, have applied to the Federal Power Commission for authority to sell their franchises and all properties to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, which joins in each application.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 11. -- The President will find that his tremendous relief and other projects will make as many enemies for him as they do friends, Roger W. Babson said during a question period at the annual National Business Conference at Babson Park here today.

In response to rumors published in the Chilean press that the Chilean Government was threatening to take over the properties of the Compania Chilena de Electricidad of Santiago, a subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company, C.E. Calder, president of the latter company, said yesterday that he hoped the matter would be settled amicably.

With the franc marking somewhat of a precedent here by closing at 6.59 1/4 cents, or just above the gold-shipping point for the sixth consecutive day, further engagements of the metal for shipment to the United States were reported yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank.

Consider that the season has almost opened. Although "A Slight Case of Murder," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street last evening, is only part of a play, it has the professional touch in its liveliest moments, and it is reassuring to know that the professionals are still interested in the theatre.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The veteran Sam Jones, backed by the lusty hitting of his mates, pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 10-to-2 victory over the Red Sox today in the last of the 1935 games between the clubs. Zeke Bonura hit his twentieth homer of the season off Dusty Rhodes in the fourth inning.

Mrs. Florence B. Hill, 50 years old, reputed possessor of a fortune of $1,000,000 and daughter of the late George M. Hill, Chicago publisher, committed suicide early yesterday, the police said, by leaping from her ninth-floor apartment at 1,212 Fifth Avenue, near 102d Street, into a rear court yard.
Postponed three times by rain and wet fields, what promises to be the most interesting national open polo championship in modern years will start today on two fields.

New York City serial bonds and corporate stock notes issued since Nov. 1, 1933, were protected against gold-clause suits yesterday, when the Sinking Fund Commission adopted a resolution to pay these securities in legal currency rather than in gold.
A clubhouse, several business buildings and flats and various dwellings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Hector Bywater, naval authority, in an article in The Daily Telegraph today asserts that Great Britain's next navy estimates are expected to provide the largest program of shipbuilding introduced since the World War. Priority, he says, will be given to cruisers and destroyers and an increase in personnel of at least 5,000 is forecast on excellent authority.

Twenty-nine students entering Columbia College have received scholarships valued at more than $44,000, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank H. Bowles, acting director of admissions of the university. Pulitzer free scholarships for the most promising graduates of public high schools in New York City went to ten young men and nineteen others received special honor scholarships from schools in eleven States.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 11. -- Rumania's National Peasant party leaders rallied their followers today for an advance on the capital in a drive to remove Mrs. Magda Lupescu, friend of King Carol, as a power behind the throne. Some of the more optimistic leaders predicted that 200,000 persons would join in the "farmers' march on the capital" some time next month.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept 11. -- They are all Yankee traders up here in the Jersey lake and hills district, and it's astonishing how well goods and services can be exchanged with the use of little or no money.

Business leasing reported yesterday centred in the midtown area. Stern Brothers Co., a sixty-seven-year-old firm of diamond importers and cutters, leased in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, to which the company will move after twelve years in 2 West Forty-sixth Street. A. Sheldon Jaffe was the broker.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Hector Bywater, naval authority, in an article in The Daily Telegraph today asserts that Great Britain's next navy estimates are expected to provide the largest program of shipbuilding introduced since the World War. Priority, he says, will be given to cruisers and destroyers and an increase in personnel of at least 5,000 is forecast on excellent authority.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Consumer resistance to high prices for fresh pork caused packers to act today with extreme caution on the buying side of hogs. While prices were steady to 10 cents a hundred-weight higher early, the upturn was quickly lost and some sales of heavy butchers late in the day were said to have shown as much as 25 cents decline.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Leaders of America's machine tool trade, regarded as an accurate forecaster of general business, estimated today that the 1935 volume of this industry will approximate $150,000,000, about $20,000,000 more than in 1929, the biggest previous year in its history.

The efforts of Secretary Hull to establish reciprocal trade relations with foreign countries are not progressing as fast as they ought to. A few treaties have been executed, but not enough to appreciably increase our trade.

Every so often the Port Authority goes through the form of considering the construction of the freight tunnel under the Upper Bay, from Greenville to Bay Ridge, which is a part of the "Comprehensive Plan" for the unification of port facilities to the ultimate effectuation of which it is dedicated.

Dr. Charles Norris, Chief Medical Examiner of the city for eighteen years, whose investigation of the sensational murder cases of New York had made him widely known as an expert on medical jurisprudence, died last night at his home, 344 West Seventy-second Street.

TRENTON, Sept. 11. -- Of the 263 candidates running for the primary nomination both on the Democratic and Republican Assembly tickets 178 have pledged themselves to repeal of the State sales tax and for economy in State government, the State Sales Tax Repeal Association said today.

The department of education of the American Museum of Natural History, which began in 1904 to educate the school children of the city in the mysteries of the natural sciences, will conduct this school year its annual educational program to reach virtually every one of the 1,000,000 school children of the city, it was announced yesterday.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, as selling agents, alone are offering today, by means of a prospectus, a new issue of $50,000,000 of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, at par and interest. The debentures are dated Oct. 15, 1935, and will mature on Oct. 15, 1950.

Excellent early retail activity has developed in millinery, and current reorders are adding materially to the backlog of business upon which manufacturers are working. Retailers here reported yesterday that the better-grade hats are selling well in upstairs departments, with the result that the average sale in this department is showing a substantial gain.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- President Roosevelt moved tonight toward swift completion of the $4,000,000,000 work relief program as he began a series of conferences at Hyde Park House. At the same time, he was expected to make every effort to eliminate a condition which, despite official denials, obviously has brought Secretary Ickes, the Public Works Administrator, and Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, to the point of open conflict.

The split dividing the moderate German elements controlling the United German Societies of New York from the renewed all-Hitler evangelism of the Friends of the New Germany reached a stage marked yesterday by the resignation of C.K. Froehlich as president of the United German Societies, on the request of the Hapag-Lloyd Line, of which he is passenger traffic agent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Securities and Exchange Commission have not yet been able to agree on publication of the salaries paid the company's officers or on the form of presentation of other financial data, it was disclosed today.

An amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange, which will become effective within the next fortnight if approved by the membership, substantially liberalizes the policy in respect to allowing non-members to trade on the floor of the Exchange.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11. -- There is a growing impression in diplomatic circles that the terms of peace between Bolivia and Paraguay will be arranged soon between Generals Enrique Penaranda del Castillo and Jose Felix Estigarribia and will be then forced upon their respective governments under threats of military revolts if they are not accepted.

For the first half of this year the Colonial Beacon Oil Company, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reported yesterday a net loss of $2,105,980 after taxes, interest, depreciation, amortization and minority interest. For the first six months of last year the company showed a net loss of $1,047,578 after similar deductions.

Fashion is by no means indifferent to serious world problems. Green mascara will be the popular eye-shading for women this Winter, "with perhaps a sprinkle of gold or silver star-dust." When a green-eyed monster besets a lady the thing is called jealousy.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- While a phonograph played melodies of the past to the accompaniment of the sizzling of "hot-dogs" cooking over live coals, the President and Mrs. Roosevelt today held their annual picnic for members of the White House party who accompany them from Washington on their visits to Hyde Park.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Published reports that Postmaster General Farley planned to resign his office in January and devote all of his time to his other duties as chairman of the Democratic National Committee resulted this morning in a long-distance telephone call by Mr. Farley to White House headquarters.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11. -- There is a growing impression in diplomatic circles that the terms of peace between Bolivia and Paraguay will be arranged soon between Generals Enrique Penaranda del Castillo and Jose Felix Estigarribia and will be then forced upon their respective governments under threats of military revolts if they are not accepted.

For the first half of this year the Colonial Beacon Oil Company, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reported yesterday a net loss of $2,105,980 after taxes, interest, depreciation, amortization and minority interest. For the first six months of last year the company showed a net loss of $1,047,578 after similar deductions.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Joe Louis lost his temper with a couple of sparring partners today. As a result, all the warmth and sleepy good humor of the day departed from him and for his help. Instantly there were two hits, two runs and two errors on the part of the sparring mates.

Reporting a need for new apparatus, additional inspectors, radio equipment and hose, John J. McElligott, Fire Commissioner, submitted a departmental estimate for 1936 totaling $22,361,895, an increase of $51,389, at a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

A sound truck plastered thickly with candidates' portraiture rumbled up to the corner of Jefferson and Madison Streets last night, manoeuvred into position against the low curb and jolted to a stop, ready to be the stage from which henchmen of David A. Mahoney were to make their final pleas to his district for his re-election as its leader.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 12. -- The Hitler government today summoned the National Socialist Reichstag for an extraordinary session here next Sunday evening for the purpose of "receiving a declaration by the government."
President Roosevelt's application of the term "un-American" to the shooting of Huey Long may be broadened somewhat.

After successfully evading police traps for five months, Nunzio Salvatore, 21 years old, a butcher's helper, of 2,318 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, was arrested at noon yesterday when he violated a minor traffic ordinance.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Three more battalions of infantry, comprising about 1,800 of the best seasoned troops in the British Army, will be sent without delay to the troubled Mediterranean, the War Office quietly announced today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 12. -- Close followers of Senator Huey P. Long have been threatened with death, it was learned today, if they attempt to perpetuate the political machine he created or punish those suspected of having had a hand in his murder.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 12. -Showing to excellent advantage, Marmoset, graceful chestnut mare belonging to Miss Ann Colgate of New Vernon, captured the John Prentice Schley Challenge Cup event, a feature of the opening session of the three-day Far Hills horse show today.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Reports were current in Paris today that, in the event of non-settlement of the ItaloEthiopian quarrel and of an invasion of Ethiopian soil by Italian troops, the following procedure will be adopted.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12. -- Little or big, they all look alike to William Lawson Little Jr., the California Siege Gun who now dominates the golf world just as Bobby Jones did before he retired in 1930 with no more territory left to conquer.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 12. -Marty Madden's consistent gelding, Chancery, won the featured Barrington Purse, a mile test for 3year-olds, today in close to record time at Narragansett Park. Carrying 115 pounds, the heaviest burden he has borne all year, Chancery ran the mile in 1:37 4-5, only four-fifths of the track record, to score by two and a half lengths over Percy Pike's Time Flight.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 12. -- Emperor Haile Selassie received news of Great Britain's firm stand at Geneva today as "a wonderful New Year's present."

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan took issue yesterday with an assertion by Walter P. Warrendorff, Manhattan borough engineer for the Works Progress Administration, that the relief agency is repaving Madison Avenue at about one-half the private contract cost.

The proposed sale of 60,000 shares, constituting half the capital stock of the Ohio Match Company, for $2,800,000 to John G. Daniel was approved yesterday at a meeting of the creditors of the bankrupt Kreuger Toll Company, the holding company of the late Ivar Kreuger's worldwide enterprises.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The Reichsbank offers dollar interest rates of 4 per cent to American holders of 5 1/2 per cent Young loan bonds and of 5 per cent to American holders of 7 per cent Dawes loan bonds in an announcement tonight. The offer applies only to interest coupons due respectively on the coming Oct. 15 and Dec. 1.

In an effort to solve the problem of keeping Central Park an oasis of lawns and shrubbery without curtailing the recreation of small children, the Park Department will begin the construction today of nineteen playgrounds around the outer rim of the park.

JULE BROUSSEAU'S first novel is called "A Preface to Maturity" (Crowell, $2.50). The theme, however, has no insidious connection with the way the book is written, for Miss Brousseau has a style that never draws one's attention away from the subject, either by awkwardness or by verbal pyrotechnics indulged for their own sake.
Two North Bergen industrial parcels were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- Postmaster General James A. Farley predicted today a larger gathering at the Binghamton convention Sept. 21 than attended the Elmira convention of 1933, when more than 8,000 were present. The conclave will open the Democratic State campaign.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 12. -- Dr. Savielly Tartakower of Poland won the chess tournament which ended at the Klub Szachowy tonight by drawing his game with Reuben Fine of New York in the ninth and final round. The Franco-Polish expert finished with a total score of 6 1/2 -2 1/2, comprising five victories, three draws and one loss.

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- European developments, as far as Geneva is concerned, await what Premier Pierre Laval will say in the League of Nations Assembly tomorrow when he makes known the attitude of France toward the stand taken by Great Britain in Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's speech.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 12. -Six men started repainting the Walnut Street station of the Erie Railroad here, otherwise known as the "old red barn," this morning, thus ending an incipient movement by residents of the vicinity to renovate the "eye-sore" at their own expense and by their own labor.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Pirates began experimenting for a possible 1936 line-up today and defeated the Phillies, 11 to 0, behind the neat pitching of Big Jim Weaver.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 12 (AP). -- The effects of the social security program will determine savings banking of the future, Carl M. Spencer, president of the Savings Bank Association of Massachusetts, said today at the annual meeting of 1,000 members of that organization.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12. -Sixty-four candidates for the Yale football team presented themselves at the university athletic office today for physical examinations. The work will continue until Saturday afternoon, when the squad will depart by bus for the training camp at Gales Ferry, where the men will be quartered for nine days.

The "Bronx leadership," which is seeking control of Tammany Hall at the risk of losing the Mayoralty election again, is responsible for the primary contests in Manhattan, State Senator Abraham Kaplan, former president of the Civil Service Commission, charged in a statement last night.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Sept., 12. -- By way of proving that yesterday's victory was no accident, Harold Halsted in Chuckle II repeated it today, at the same time taking a good step forward toward the successful defense of his Star class Atlantic Coast championship.

Edward C. Wayburn, well known as Ned Wayburn, teacher of many stage dancing stars, and his wife, Marguerite K. Wayburn, both of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, filed petitions in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court. Mr. Wayburn gave his liabilities as $567,579 and Mrs. Wayburn hers as $378,538.
Four armed thugs held up the fur store of Max Alfus, Inc., at 2,189 Broadway, near Seventy-seventh Street, at 9:20 A.M. yesterday and fled with furs valued at $1,500. The merchandise was insured.

Charging that the proposed increase in intercoastal shipping rates will add approximately $1,000,000 annually to the costs of chain stores and wholesalers of food products, representatives of large distributing organizations along the Atlantic Seaboard, at a meeting here yesterday, took action to file a vigorous protest with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

Eugene O'Neill's next play cycle for the Theatre Guild will comprise seven items, and for a complete swing around that cycle four years (sic) will be required. The first will arrive next season. Thereafter, beginning in 1937-38, two plays will be offered in each season until it is all over in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Forms and regulations for the registration or exemption of public utility holding companies will be made public soon, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in its first public statement under the Wheeler-Rayburn Utility Law.

There is much dust and heat and hullaballoo in some of the Assembly districts about the district leadership and the chairmanship of the New York County Republican Committee. Fights for Democratic district leadership might be thought to indicate a natural and healthy condition of the party.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, who holds the world's record for automobile speeding, declared here yesterday that fast driving had no place on regular highways and that road safety was a public responsibility.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -Mr. and Mrs. Willem Willeke gave a reception and musicale at Mountain House, Pittsfield, this afternoon in honor of Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge. She was at the piano in the Schumann piano quintet with the South Mountain String Quartet, of which she is the founder.

As Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday was about to set a date for the trial of Joseph Pepe, 45 years old, an ex-convict, on a compulsory prostitution indictment, Pepe pleaded guilty to a lesser offense, comprising a misdemeanor, for accepting money from an immoral source.

It is astonishing to find so much undue sentimentality expressed and manifested about the death of Senator Huey Long. Naturally, no one wants a man in high office assassinated any more. than one wants a man less prominently and less obnoxiously in the limelight murdered or a child kidnapped.

The coroner's inquest was a subject of derision as long ago as in SHAKESPEARE'S day. In this country it has been an object of criticism for more than seventy years. When LEONARD WALLSTEIN was Commissioner of Accounts under Mayor MITCHEL he reported, after investigation, that the elective coroner in this city represented a "combination of power, obscurity and irresponsibility" which resulted in gross inefficiency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -Earl Whitehill, veteran Washington southpaw, turned in his best pitching performance of the year today as he held the Indians to three hits and the Senators won, 3 to 0. It was Whitehill's fourteenth victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP). -Breaking their losing streak after dropping thirteen games in succession, the Athletics swept both ends of today's double-header with the White Sox. They won the first game, 11 to 2, and the second 4 to 3 after Chicago had tied the score with a two-run attack in the ninth.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 12. -The word "war" echoes in one's ears wherever one turns these days throughout Egypt.

To insure high standards in municipally built structures, a panel of outstanding architects has been appointed at the request of Mayor La Guardia to cooperate with the Municipal Civil Service Commission in preparing a list of architects particularly fitted to handle special works projects for the city, according to an announcement yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Members of the Financial Advertising Association who have been attending a three-day convention here relaxed in a concluding "session" of golf today before returning to their homes in all parts of the country with new messages of hope and confidence for the future of banking.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 12 (AP). -Seventeen Deputies of the minority bloc of the Mexican Chamber were ordered removed from their seats tonight as a result of last night's gunplay on the floor of the Chamber in which two Deputies were killed and two wounded.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- Sale of $30,000,000 of emergency unemployment relief bonds will be conducted by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, at his office here at 1 P.M. on Sept. 24. The bonds are the last of $130,000,000 authorized during the depression, some of which have already matured.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- For the fifteenth time since the inauguration of the series the senior golfers of the United States defeated the Canadian veterans in the annual match for the Duke of Devonshire Trophy by 30 to 2 at the Apawamis links today.

Lou Little, a natural pessimist to whom even the rosiest outlook would appear as a melancholy purple, has real reason to view with alarm this year. Graduation riddled his Columbia football squad and left him with the herculean task of building all over again.

Forty-seven persons, including nine women, were arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of disorderly conduct for blocking the sidewalk while staging a protest demonstration and parade in front of the offices of The Daily Mirror, 235 East Forty-fifth Street.

An investigation was begun yesterday by the business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange into charges of stock-rigging in prices of Interborough Rapid Transit Company securities made by City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.

Bonds of virtually all classifications were subjected to selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Several groups were conspicuously heavy, including the local tractions and Canadian National Railway issues, which tended to depress, to some extent, prices in other groups.

ROME, Sept. 12. -- All Italy is waiting with curiosity and anxiety the speech Premier Pierre Laval of France is expected to deliver tomorrow at Geneva. It is expected to show whether Great Britain's threat to withdraw into a state of splendid isolation if the League of Nations covenant is not applied has had the effect of swinging Mr. Laval into line with British politics or whether he will continue to champion the Italian cause.

Leaving City Hall about 5 o'clock last evening, Mayor La Guardia said that he had received no word during the day on the Hyde Park conference between President Roosevelt, WPA Administrator Harry Hopkins and PWA Administrator Harold Ickes and other works program officials.

Directors of the Tide Water Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common capital stock. The preferred stock was retired on Aug. 15. On June 29 the company paid 30 cents a common share and on March 30 it paid 35 cents, a total of $1.15 so far this year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Frolic, the Atlantic class craft of Margy and young Bob Bavier, today scored her second victory in two days in the third annual Fall series of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- "Mutilation" of work sheets of the New York Power and Light Company, after the sheets had received only a preliminary examination by accountants for the Mack legislative committee, was described at a public hearing of the committee held in the Capitol today.

During the fiscal year 1935-36 the Federal Government will spend about $400,000,000 directly on road construction and improvement, Thomas H. MacDonald chief of the United States Bureau of Public Roads, declared yesterday in addressing members of the Asphalt Institute in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- Miss Jean Heyward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shubrick Heyward of Wilmington, was introduced by her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. L. du Pont of Montchanin, Del., at a dance which they gave at the Vicmead Hunt Club tonight.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The Yankees' pennant hopes have been fading slowly for the past month, but yesterday at the Stadium when they tangled with the league-leading Tigers in the first struggle of a five-game series they took a very definite turn toward disappearing completely, all because the McCarthymen couldn't stand prosperity.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area increased 8 per cent during the week ended Sept. 7, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. In the preceding week the increase in deliveries, made for about 250 stores, was 7 per cent.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 12. -- After witnessing a pageant of 56,000 labor service men the Nazi party convention met again tonight to listen to speeches by leaders of the movement. Visitors were treated to a torchlight parade by 10,000 political organizers in honor of Adolf Hitler in Zeppelin Meadow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- In a brilliant stretch drive, Miss Marian Miley of Lexington, Ky., conquered Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star, for first place in the women's Western golf derby today by a three shots.

Evelyn Hoey came into prominence along Broadway in 1929 when she sang some of Cole Porter's songs in "Fifty Million Frenchmen." Before that she had been in touring companies and in a night club in Paris, and afterward she took part in other revues.

To validate a proposed bond issue of $45,000,000, the B.F. Goodrich Company filed suit yesterday in the Supreme Court here against a group of stockholders for a judgment that at meetings of stockholders of the company in July, a proposal to mortgage the company's franchises and property for $45,000,000 as security for a bond issue was approved by 75 per cent of the preferred stockholders and a similar proportion of the common stockholders.

The threat of Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney, to testify in General Sessions yesterday in rebuttal of a defense witness, caused Aaron J. Moore, 49 years old, to plead guilty to criminally receiving $4,500 in loot from an apartment burglary last June 9.
PARIS, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Fall apartment hunting rush continued over a wide area yesterday. Renting agents announced that they had signed up tenants for rooms in practically every residential section of the city. The demand was especially heavy on the East and West Sides, with the former leading in rentals of large suites.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- After two hours and thirty minutes of deliberation, a jury of eleven men and one woman tonight acquitted Magistrate Jacob Dogole on two charges of misconduct in office. The verdict was received by Judge Robert L. Lamberton, who had presided over the three day trial.

The report of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company for the year ended on June 30 shows that while net sales of $28,986,092 were the largest for any twelve months in the company's eighty-three years of existence, operation resulted in a net loss of $438,063.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Charging J. P. Morgan Co. with negligence and misrepresentation, William T. Snow of Brookline today filed suit in the Federal court seeking to recover $500,000 for alleged violation of a banking contract.

Quotations for call and timemoney were unchanged, but therewas evidence that a hardening inthese quotations might be expectedfrom the fact that some lendershave withdrawn offerings of termfunds at the one-quarter of 1 percent figure. Business was small inboth sections, however.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Dollar volume of department store sales increased in August, but the gain was smaller than is normal for the season, causing a slight recession in the Federal Reserve System's adjusted index, the Board of Governors announced today.

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower here yesterday in rather active trading. Coffee, rubber and cottonseed oil futures were under heavy pressure. In the cash markets rye, oats, cocoa and tin were higher, while wheat, corn, lard, cotton and rubber were lower.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Unloosing an attack that drove Ray Benge away in the second inning and continuing on Van Mungo with even greater violence, the Cubs today crushed the Dodgers beneath a 13to-3 score and extended their winning streak to nine straight.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The German Embassy has been informally notified that Germany will not enjoy generalization of tariff concessions made in the course of reciprocal trade negotiations completed or under way with other countries, it was learned today.
" The Big Broadcast of 1936," with Bing Crosby, Mary Boland, Charles Ruggles and an aggregation of wellknown radio entertainers, begins an engagement this morning at the Paramount.
Osbert Sitwell recently advertised in London newspapers that he would read no more manuscripts by aspiring writers unless the manuscripts were accompanied by a fee of $5 a page.

With one exception, the quarterfinal bracket of the ninth national professional tennis singles championship was filled yesterday on the courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Each of the seven players to advance, headed by William T. Tilden, is seeded.

HARRISON, N.Y., Friday, Sept. 13. -- Helen Vinson, motion picture actress, was married at the Town Hall here just before last midnight to Fred Perry, English tennis star. The couple motored here from New York, accompanied by four friends, and asked at the police station how they could be married.

Two witnesses from Atlanta, Ga., in the trial of Samuel L. Gaines, William L. Jarvis and fourteen others on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy, testified yesterday before a Federal judge and a jury that in the Fall of 1933 they had traded in stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation for Mr. Gaines with $45,000 provided by him.

A patrolman was injured by a flying rock and ten pickets were arrested at about 8:30 o'clock last night as the aftermath of a dispute between members of the Cafeteria Workers Union, Local 110, and Patrolman Robert Troy of the West Forty-seventh Street station outside Bickford's at 225 West Fortysecond Street.

German capitalists "with many millions to invest" were reported yesterday to be negotiating for a site for a large brewery in New York, but the names of the sponsors of the project and the details of their plan remained a mystery while real estate men sought in vain to get in touch with them.

Five months ago the United States Government clearly foreshadowed the action it is now about to take with respect to American trade with Germany. At that time Secretary HULL pointed out that we were negotiating reciprocal trade agreements with various nations, and that these agreements had resulted and would continue to result in a lowering of american tariffs on certain imports from countries entering into such pacts with us.
Wilmer Allison of Texas became amateur tennis champion of the United States by beating Sidney B. Wood Jr. with ease in the final round of the national singles at Forest Hills.

In a survey of the legislative and financial aspects of insured mortgages prepared by Theodore R. Goldsmith of Charles E. Quincey Co., it is contended that insured mortgages, as created by the Federal Housing Administration, soon may prove to be one of the more important types of investments for institutions and should be profitable to banks on account of both liquidity and the relatively high return which they provide.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -The amounts meat prices have increased in the last two years were tabulated today by the Labor Department. Since August, 1933, the following average increases were reported:

Sir SAMUEL HOARE'S address to the Council of the League at Geneva is said to be the frankest and boldest ever made by a British Minister at such a world conference. He certainly spoke as one having authority. It is not his personal view that he expounded, but the deliberate policy of the British Government.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 12. -Long Island Sound's interclub sloops today won their international match with the Bermuda one-design boats. The local craft took the seventh and final race off the Larchmont Yacht Club, 19 points to 17 1/4. They thus broke the series' tie of six all in the racing between the fleets.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Aurora came through its initial match in the national open polo championship tournament with a well-earned 11-to-9 triumph over the hard-riding and ever-pressing Westbury quartet on Bostwick Field today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The "rackets" operating within the New York City poultry industry are costing poultry shippers and producers more than $1,000,000 a year, W. Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures for New York City, testified today in a Department of Agriculture hearing on a proposal to designate the metropolitan area of New York as territory subject to the licensing provisions of the amended Packers and Stockyards Act of 1935.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12. -- Grief-stricken by the news of his daughter's death, Henry J. Hoey, a dress manufacturer, said today that Henry H. Rogers 3d, on whose estate near Philadelphia, Evelyn Hoey, 24-year-old show girl, was found shot to death, was "very jealous."
Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d was cut off with a $500,000 trust fund under the will of his father, Colonel Henry H. Rogers 2d, who died on July 25 of this year.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- The merger of Dana College and the University of Newark into a single university this Fall is virtually assured, it was announced after the meetings of the boards of trustees of the two institutions today.

Shipwreck Kelly has perched on a lot of flagpoles in the last fourteen years, but it was not until yesterday that any one succeeded in getting him down against his wishes. It happened in the Bronx, a place whose flagpoles he now intends to shun forever.

The Long Island Lighting Company was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission to issue $5,992,300 of first refunding mortgage gold bonds, Series C, 4 per cent, under an existing mortgage. The bonds, to be dated June 1, 1935, and to mature in 1960, will be sold at not less than par and accrued interest.

A confidential preliminary report prepared by a subcommittee of the newly formed Lawyers Vigilance Committee, formed to investigate the legal aspects of the New Deal legislation, holds that certain phases of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act are unconstitutional.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 12. -- The Grand Army of the Republic indorsed today the proposal for a joint reunion at Gettysburg in 1938 between the "Blue and the Gray."

SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 12. -Howard Hughes, wealthy oil man and film producer, was credited with an unofficial world's speed record for land planes of 352 miles per hour today after he made four attempts to establish a new mark over a special course at the Irvine ranch, near here.

The United Light and Power Company and subsidiary companies issued yesterday a consolidated statement for the twelve months ended on July 31 showing a net income of $818,885 after taxes, depreciation, interest, amortization, preferred dividends of subsidiary companies, and minority interests.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 12. -After three cases of infantile paralysis had been reported here, Dr. Elias Freidus, city health officer and school physician, ordered today that no children under the age of 12 be permitted to attend school in Long Beach until further notice.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Packers, especially the smaller houses, have curtailed their buying of hogs in view of the pronounced consumer resistance to paying high prices for fresh pork. For this reason prices of hogs dropped 10 to 35 cents a hundred weight here today with heavy weight butcher hogs showing the sharpest losses at the last.

The rise in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System was resumed in the week ended on Wednesday, following a decline the week before. The rise in the week just completed amounted to $150,000,000, bringing the total to a new high record at $2,820,000,000.

ATHENS, Greece, Sept. 12. -After refusing to negotiate with the royalist Cabinet in arranging a plebiscite, George Papandriu, leader of the Republican party, and other Venizelist leaders requested President Zaimis today to resign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Predicting that government financing would offer no problems for the next few weeks, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that he and Mrs. Morgenthau will sail from New York Saturday on the Conte Grande for a month's vacation in Portugal and Spain.

Between forty and fifty American operas have been submitted to the management of the Metropolitan Opera Association for possible production in the new season, Edward Johnson, general manager of the organization, said yesterday on his return from a brief holiday in Canada.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12. -- Fears arose today for the safety of seventy-eight persons, including many leading Russian scientists, aboard the Soviet ice-breaker Sadko, which is being pounded by a terrific Arctic storm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The National Lumber Manufacturers Association, in an analysis issued today, estimates that the lumber shipments for 1935 will be 16,415,000,000 feet, while production will be 15,436,000,000, on the basis of reports and estimates of regional associations.

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- Tecle Hawariate, the Ethiopian delegate, sent to the Council of the League of Nations tonight a copy of a letter to Baron Pompeo Aloisi, the Italian delegate, that he had received from a Belgian photographer protesting against Italy's use of one of his photographs in the album of alleged Ethiopian atrocities that it recently filed with the League and charging that the interpretation placed on the photograph was "completely inaccurate."

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $712,953 during the week ended yesterday, the weekly report of the bank showed today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $8,638,395.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- A joint subcommittee of Appalachian soft-coal producers and United Mine Workers of America gave up its attempt today to draft a new wage and hour agreement to succeed the contract expiring Sunday midnight.

VIENNA, Sept. 12. -- Official Austria's hostile attitude toward the British policy at Geneva and the subservience of the well controlled Vienna press to Italian propaganda was particularly emphasized today in a sharply worded article in the Clerical Weltblatt, which openly proclaims its article to be inspired.

Dr. Van Noyes Verplanck of 34-17 Eighty-fourth Street, Queens, an assistant physician at Bellevue Hospital, was pronounced a suicide by poisoning after an autopsy yesterday by Dr. Milton Helpern, Assistant Medical Examiner. Dr. Verplanck was 44 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- A goal from the mallet of Stephen (Laddie) Sanford early in the final period enabled the Hurricanes to down Hurlingham by 9 to 8 today at International Field and ride into the semi-finals of the national open polo championship.

After almost a decade of endeavor at home and abroad, Wilmer L. Allison Jr. of Austin, Texas, was rewarded with his first major national singles crown yesterday, to go down in the records as the oldest player to win the tennis championship of this country for the first time.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- Joseph C. Grew, United States Ambassador to Japan, who is visiting Captain Isaac C. Johnson, U.S.N., inspector of ordnance in charge of the Naval Torpedo Station, and Mrs. Johnson, was guest of honor at a luncheon for forty persons at the Clambake Club today.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated narrowly yesterday and ended with losses of 6 to 7 points.

An appropriation of $29,089,788 was requested yesterday by the Sanitation Department to keep the city clean in 1936. The departmental estimate submitted to Budget Director McGahen showed an increase of $806,299 over 1935.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, told Italy in an address broadcast from Geneva tonight that he was just as anxious as anyone else in Europe to find a settlement in Africa that would do "justice to Ethiopia's national rights and Italy's claims for expansion."

Distance as the crow flies is not the true distance between two points for the purpose of serving a subpoena in a Federal supplementary proceedings. Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson in voiding yesterday a subpoena served on William Fox, motion picture producer, at Atlantic City in a $300,000 judgment suit, ruled that the distance must be the shortest way by ordinary means of travel, and not by airplane.

Francis T. Ward of Clark, Dodge Co. was nominated yesterday for chairman of the New York Group of the Investment Bankers Association of America, the nominating committee announced. William J. Minsch of Minsch, Monell Co. was named for vice chairman, and Hearn W. Streat of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation for secretary and treasurer.

Miss Laura Ingalls set a new transcontinental record for women pilots yesterday when she flew from Los Angeles to New York non-stop in 13 hours 34 minutes. The flier, who has made repeated attempts at the record only to be forced down on the way, came through this time at an average speed of close to 200 miles an hour.

The upward movement in bank clearings is continuing, but at a slower rate. The total for the twentytwo leading cities in the United States, for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $4,686,763,000, compared with $4,367,125,000 a year ago, an increase of 7.3 per cent.

The officers of the Teachers Union were still determined yesterday to present their resignations today at a special meeting of the union's executive board, despite pleas by minority groups in the organization that they retain their offices.
There can be no justification or excuse for murder; and the murder of Senator Long cannot properly be referred to by any citizen otherwise than with regret and abhorrence.

After one of the longest and most bitter stretch duels of the meeting. William Woodward's Valse won the featured Kathleen Purse at Aqueduct yesterday by the narrow margin of a nose, with Maxine F. second. The two were heavily supported in a field of five and dominated the running throughout the six furlongs.

When Chairman FARm' vas recentlyat Hyde Park and was, as usual, carryLug every State in the Union in advance of next year, a reporter with aninquisitive mind asked him if hethought there would be any difficultyin raising a campaign fund for 1936.
