Hemade light of the matter, replying thatit would be easy to get all the moneyneeded.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The Boerse was inactive today, interest being limited to specialties. Heavy industrials were quiet. Potash shares were passive and those of machine companies were mixed. Metalgesellschaft gained 1 1/3 points. Chemical issues were weak and quiet, with I. G. Farben losing 1/2 point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Increasing enthusiasm among European bankers, economists and government officials for currency stabilization, on a provisional basis at first, was reported today by Charles E. Stuart, vice president of the Export-Import Bank, following a tour of European countries to study credit conditions.

The will of William Charles Gotshall, engineer and archaeologist, filed for probate yesterday, bequeaths six-tenths of his residuary estate to four educational institutions. A bequest of $25,000 is made to the Explorers Club and his collection of paintings and works of art are left to the State of New York for hanging in the Educational Building at Albany, and his books to the State Library, together with $35,000 for the maintenance of the collections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, an increase of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $11,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

At Forest Hills it has been one day of excitement and pride after another, and in the climax it is hard to see how the American cup of rejoicing could have been more completely filled. It is gratifying to have the national championship come back to America.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were dull today, with prices unsettled pending developments in the international situation.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper, under the sponsorship of Crosby Gaige, made their first joint appearance this evening at the Plymouth Theatre in "Othello," before an audience that found the enervating weather no hindrance to their enjoyment.

That General PERSHING reaches today the age of 75 in good health and full physical and mental vigor is a fit occasion for felicitating him. In the years since the war he has apparently taken to himself the saying that "In "peace there's nothing so becomes a "man as modest stillness and humility."

Headed by Governor Lehman-and scores of high-ranking military and naval officers, more than 600 persons attended a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton last night to Brig. Gen. John J. Byrne, commanding the New York National Guard Coast Artillery Brigade, who retires today after almost forty-six years of service.

A banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank and including Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., Salomon Bros. Hutzler and R. W. Pressprich Co. yesterday won the award of a new issue of $6,000,000 of New York City special corporate stock notes on a bid of a premium of $319 for a 1.15 per cent interest rate.

Mrs. Cecelia Jacobs, 48 years old, was home again yesterday with a tale of having been kidnapped by two men who wanted to keep her out of the campaign of her son, Elias H. Jacobs, who is running for renomination as Alderman from the Twenty-third District as a Democrat.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 12. -Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d, 31 years old, son of the late Colonel H. H. Rogers, New York City financier, was in Chester County Jail here tonight while authorities tried to determine definitely whether Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy star, who was a guest in his country home in Lyndel, killed herself last night or was murdered.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- It is with the greatest circumspection and caution that the Bourse is following the course of events in Geneva. Yesterday it reacted favorably to the speech of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, while today it is waiting to hear what Premier Laval of France will say tomorrow.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 12. -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement reminding Italy and Ethiopia of their obligations under the KelloggBriand pact:

With renewed weakness in all gold-bloc currencies in the foreign exchange market here yesterday, additional engagements of gold were reported at the Federal Reserve Bank. They amounted to $8,100,000, the largest being reported from France where $4,950,000 was bought in Paris.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 (AP). -- A threat of military rule by Governor Floyd Olson brought quick closing today of the Flour City Ornamental Iron Works, focal point of last night's strike rioting in which two persons were killed and thirty others injured, three perhaps fatally.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of vice and rackets, yesterday announced the appointment of Jacob J. Rosenblum, former Assistant United States Attorney, who participated in the prosecution of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, to his staff.

General JOHNSON has done the sensible thing in meeting Commissioner MOSES' demands for more foremen to direct work relief enterprises in the parks. These were all planned and approved in advance, on a basis of so much material, such-and-such equipment, so many men and so many foremen and supervisors.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association yesterday effected a strike of radio operators on eleven American flag ships leaving the port of New York but failed to prevent the sailing of a single ship. While pickets marched in the streets adjoining the piers, the ships affected by the union's decision pulled away for their destinations with substitute operators in their radio rooms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Wholesale commodity prices declined onetenth of 1 per cent last week, thus continuing the downward movement that began in the last week in August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The decrease placed the general index at 80.4 per cent of the 1926 average, which was 3.3 per cent above a year ago.

A severe setback, which threatens the defeat of David S. Rendt, Chairman of the Richmond County Democratic Committee, was received yesterday by the Rendt organization in three adverse pre-primary decisions in the Supreme Court.

The public utility industry of the country, determined to prevent an "attempt to advance a theory of state socialism * * * inimical to the rights of the American people," mapped preliminary plans yesterday for a legal test of the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

The Rev. John J. Casey, private secretary to Cardinal Hayes for the last three years, has been honored by Pope Plus XI with the rank of private chamberlain, carrying the title of the Very Rev. Monsignor. His new rank makes Mgr. Casey an honorary member of the papal household, entitling him to certain privileges when visiting the Vatican.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- A hearing on the pending readjustment of the indebtedness of the city of Coral Gables, Fla., will be held next Monday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Italy and Ethiopa were reminded in positive terms of their obligation under the Pact of Paris (the KelloggBriand pact) to settle their differences by peaceful means in a formal statement issued late today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 12. -The body of Senator Huey P. Long was returned today to the Louisiana soil from which he sprang to challenge existing economic and political systems. Untold thousands from this and neighboring States saw him laid to rest at funeral services which were a unique and fitting tribute.

Apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx passed to new control in transactions announced yesterday. Brokers also reported leases of dwellings in Manhattan. The Central Savings Bank sold to Jacob Goldner the six-story apartment house at 255-57 West Twentysecond Street on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet.

HAMBURG, Sept. 12. -- William Gill, an American seaman and a member of the crew of the liner George Washington, is under arrest here and will probably be tried on the charge of having defamed Reichsfaehrer Adolf Hitler.

Control of the $3,000,000,000 Van Sweringen railroad empire, which came into the hands of Wall Street bankers through a $48,000,000 loan default on May 1, will be sold Sept. 30 at public auction, J. P. Morgan Co. announced yesterday.
A flurry of excitement was created in fishing circles along the Jersey coast a few days ago by the reported catch of a barracuda with rod and reel.

Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine devoted more than an hour yesterday morning to a lecture to the commanding officers of the uniformed and detective forces. About fifty officers, from deputy chief inspectors in charge of boroughs down to deputy inspectors and acting captains in charge of a division of detectives, gathered in conference and listened to both instruction and admonition covering a wide range of subjects.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 12. -- The speech made by Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, before the League of Nations Assembly yesterday has made the most profound impression in Addis Ababa.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 12. -Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne appealed for closer cooperation between lovers of wild life and forestry experts in his address tonight before the dinner of the American Forestry Association, held at the Olympic Arena, in conjunction with the State's threeday celebration of fifty years of conservation.
MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 12. -- The University of Mexico was occupied yesterday by twenty-five students of radical tendencies, accompanied by more than 100 workmen of communistic affiliations.

General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator here, is determined, he said yesterday, to permit no disagreements among officials to interfere with the task of putting unemployed men to work. Accordingly he has agreed to meet the demand of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, to supply 678 foremen for the 25,000 additional men sent by the WPA into the parks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Probability that the government would spend $500,000,000 annually for several years on its public works program was seen here today by officials as a result of President Roosevelt's statement at Hyde Park that, even if industrial production were resumed tomorrow at the 1929 rate, industrial efficiency has increased to a point where only 80 per cent of the 1929 man-power would be employed.

Mrs. Henry J. Hoey collapsed at her home, 349 East Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday morning upon learning that her daughter had died at the Pennsylvania farm of H. H. Rogers 3d, and refused to believe that she had committed suicide.

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- The time has come to utilize the Briand-Kellogg pact to prevent aggressive warfare, Senator James P. Pope of Idaho told the press here today. He expressed himself as favoring having this done by a conference of the treaty's signatories to outlaw aggression and believed such a conference would probably have to be initiated by "the founders of the pact," which would give a prominent role to the United States.

TORONTO, Sept. 12. -- The nebula in the constellation of Lyra, which looks like a luminous smoke ring when seen through a telescope, is really about twice as large as astronomers have previously thought, according to Dr. John C. Duncan of the Whitin Observatory of Wellesley College.

John A. Leach, a third deputy police commissioner, presiding yesterday at police headquarters at the trial of a patrolman charged with assault, told another policeman testifying for the defense that he could not understand why he was not facing charges.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12. -- A galloping gallery came through the woods from the fourth green and clustered around the fifth tee high on a hillside. Only Lawson Little draws galleries of that size these days. An array of marshals, flourishing long bamboo poles, cleared the way for the players.

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- The League of Nations issued yesterday its fourth annual World Economic Survey, expressing in it more hope for recovery than at any time since the depression began and also the belief that "the key to the situation probably lies in the United States."

Roy Paulding, former assistant municipal court clerk, was arrested last night on a charge of grand larceny and taken to the Tombs. Paulding, who lives at 21 Manhattan Avenue, resigned from his court job more than two years ago. His arrest at this time came about through Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard's inquiry into conditions in the city's municipal courts, the arresting officers declared.

The highest point since June, 1930, for The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was reached on Tuesday, when the index advanced to 127.9 from 126.1 (revised) the Tuesday previous and 120.7 a year ago.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, Republican, of the Twentieth Congressional District here, threatened last night to initiate a Congressional inquiry into the railroad reorganization activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, particularly with regard to Van Sweringen roads.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Knight B. Owen, 41, socially prominent member of Martha's Vineyard's once wealthiest family, was shot and killed late this afternoon as he sat at the wheel of his automobile at a garden party near Lake Tashmo.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12. -- The Soviet Government has mastered the Arctic Ocean this year. Ten days ago two ordinary freight ships reached Kamchatka from Murmansk and yesterday two other vessels, the Anadyr and the Stalingrad, arrived at Murmansk from Vladivostok ten days ahead of scheduled time.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 12 (AP). -- George Scott of Absecon, N.J., won the Winchester Trophy match in the National Rifle Association tournament today by outranking two competitors who had the same score of 197 out of a possible 200.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Sir James Jeans announced today that the universe is at least 100 and possibly 1,000 times as old as some astronomers have believed it to be.

To over-the-counter dealers the most interesting case now before the Securities and Exchange Commission, aside from their own regulation, is that of the Maryland Casualty Company, which has asked the commission to have its stock stricken from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12. -- At a late hour this afternoon Colonel Bill Terry mopped his brow on the west bank of the Mississippi and may well have composed the following cryptic message to his home office in New York:

The Union League Club, at its September meeting last night in its rooms at Thirty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, adopted a resolution proposed by the club's public affairs committee calling for the election of a Republican Assembly in the forthcoming election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Federal Government today asked the Supreme Court to overrule a decision by the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit which held that the Public Works Administration cannot condemn land for housing and slum clearance projects.

Poison fumes from his lamps and engines, together with a mechanical breakdown in his radio transmitter, nearly brought death to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd during the seven months he spent alone in his "advance base" in the Antarctic, according to final sections of his diary, published for the first time today in the current issue of The American Magazine.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 12. -Differences over the manner of conducting the work relief program among President Roosevelt's chief lieutenants were settled in an atmosphere of complete harmony late tonight after a series of intermittent conferences at Hyde Park House which occupied more than twelve hours.

The main office of the Western Union at 60 Hudson Street, where almost instantaneous communication with any part of the globe is a daily routine, acted as host yesterday to an agent of communication common in the days of Napoleon, but almost non-existent today.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 13. -- Rumors here that the government is on the point of issuing orders for general mobilization were officially denied today, but last night's State Council at the palace, at which no definite decisions were taken, probably discussed measures for such mobilization in certain events.

New life insurance produced in August was 7. Oper cent less than in August last year. In the first eight months of this year the cumulative total was 3.2 per cent greater than in the corresponding period of 1934, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported to the Department of Commerce.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol led a field of seventy-eight players in a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Arcola Country Club today. She returned an 87, one stroke better than her club-mate, Miss Gall Wild.

Lawrence N. Martin, referee in an accounting by the Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee of a $675,000 bond issue sold by S.W. Straus Sons on the Cambridge Court, an apartment house at 3,640 Bowne Street, Flushing, filed his report in the Supreme Court yesterday, finding that a dividend of 4 per cent can be paid to the owners of $675,000 of outstanding bonds.

After some eleven weeks in which no gold had been drawn from Paris to New York, shipments have begun again; in the present week $20,500,000 has been taken. During the two months of immunity from American withdrawals, gold reserves of the Bank of France had risen about $87,000,000, but they are approximately $650,000,000 under this date last year, chiefly because of $350,000,000 bank gold given up for American during the intervening twelvemonth.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Standing in the shadow of cloud-capped Whiteface Mountain this afternoon Governor Lehman dedicated a bronze tablet mounted on a boulder of Adirondack granite to commemorate fifty years of conservation in this State.

Testimony indicating that Philip H. Philbin Jr. was able to corner 49,000 shares of Atlas Tack Corporation stock in 1933, when the stock rose from $6 to more than $30, with the aid of $600,000 advanced by William L. Jarvis and Samuel L. Gaines of Boston, was given yesterday at the trial of Jarvis and Gaines and fourteen others on mail fraud charges in Federal Court.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The First National Bank plans to place its stock on a $4 annual dividend basis and retire $10,000,000 of the $25,000,000 in preferred stock owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, about Jan. 1, 1936, it was reported from authoritative sources today.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 13. -- W.F. Riedell, governor of the Manhattan Revolver and Pistol Club of New York, equaled an American record and broke a world mark in the National Rifle Association matches today.
In a desperate effort to halt the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday, Marse Joe McCarthy threw Lefty Vernon Gomez at Mickey Cochrane's crew in a pitching test against the gigantic Schoolboy Rowe.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ADDIS ABABA, Aug. 15 (By Air Mail). -- Hapte Mikael, a grand old Dedjasmatch of Ethiopia, is now somewhere in the Province of Ogaden, near the border of Italian Somaliland. With him are 20,000 of his fighting men -- the "doomed battalion," they call them because they will be the first to face Italian fire if war comes.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13. -- Walter Emery drove first from the tee today. The field in the national amateur golf championship over the links of The Country Club here had been thoroughly drawn and quartered in the six rounds of eighteen-hole firing. Walter was the leader of the surviving quartet at dawn. He was also the youngest of the survivors.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- Francis William Rickett, British financier, landed from Rotterdam at Croydon Airdrome this evening full of determination to stick to the Ethiopian oil concession "lock, stock and barrel." The concession, he declared, "is mine entirely" and will not be sold to Italy.

Contests in two Assembly districts, one Democratic and one Republican, were emphasized yesterday by the Citizens Union in making public its recommendations on candidates for Assembly and Aldermanic nominations in Manhattan and the Bronx at the primary election next Tuesday.

The semi-final round of the ninth annual national professional tennis singles championship was filled with the four top-seeded players yesterday, William T. Tilden 2d, Karel Kozeluh, George M. Lott Jr. and Lester R. Stoefen scoring on the courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

The American rights to the biography of Arnold Bennett by his wife, Dorothy Cheston Bennett -- which attracted attention in England late last season ---- have been bought by Claude Kendall and Willoughby Sharp and will be published by them on Nov. 22.

More than 2,300,000 "Consumers' Protection Labels" have been sold since July 15, when they were first placed in circulation, it was announced yesterday by Alexander Printz, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board at a meeting here of the executive committee of the New York regional area.

Individual loans and separate insurance policies in the financing of automobile purchases were advocated yesterday by Joseph A. Reid of the New York Underwriters Insurance Company at the closing business session of the annual meeting of the New Jersey Association of Underwriters held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Red Sox reached a quintet of St. Louis moundsmen for twenty-five hits to' day, but were forced to divide a double-header when the Browns staged a four-run drive in the eighth inning of the second game.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13. -- With all due respect to Walter Emery, who is admittedly a very fine golfer, the general opinion around The Country Club of Cleveland tonight was that W. Lawson Little Jr. of Stanford University will have no trouble succeeding himself as national amateur champion some time tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Steady increases in Federal liquor-tax revenues indicate that "bootlegging is definitely on the way out," Arthur J. Mellott, organizer of the Treasury's liquor tax enforcement division, said today in his final report to Secretary Morgenthau.

An uptown move by an old textile firm was reported in the business leases listed by brokers yesterday. The A. Steinman Company, Inc., for thirty years at 114 Bleecker Street, has leased the store and second floor, about 30,000 square feet, in 343-61 Fourth Avenue.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
"The Great Waltz" takes its leave of the Center Theatre tonight, finally and officially, with an estimated $42,000 gross for the week and one all-time record for Broadway's legitimate houses.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 13. -- A new unofficial speed for land planes of nearly 353 miles an hour on one flight was set today by Howard Hughes, oil man and movie producer, in a series of six flights over a closed course near this place. Official timers said that a world aviation record probably will be formally allowed.

Aside from the pronounced strength in the metal shares, the main body of stocks moved irregularly yesterday. The closing was steady, with industrial issues averaging slightly higher and the railway group a little lower on the day. The trading volume showed further contraction, dealings on the Stock Exchange amounting to 1,731,000 shares, against 1,880,000 the day before.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The Geneva speech of Premier Pierre Laval of France was received with varying degrees of enthusiasm, misgiving and actual doubt here tonight, but all sources agreed that there was no sign as yet that the East African war clouds would be dispelled.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Series champions in eleven classes were decided today in the concluding races of the third annual Fall regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. A fleet of sixty-six craft took part in the events, which were contested over calm waters in a light southeast wind.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Charles H. and Daniel G. Tenney Jr., sons of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Tenney of this community and New York, were hosts tonight at a dinner dance at Penllyn, their country home, as a farewell to the debutante and younger married set of the North Shore colonies before they return to Yale University, where they are both students in the Law School.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- With the arrival of the H.M.S. York this morning, entertaining began in honor of Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best, Lady Best and Miss Best and will continue during the next six days.

GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- The voice of France, which with that of Great Britain is crucial in this matter of the Italian threat to peace, was heard today in the League of Nations Assembly, and it was one with the British voice.

Stimulated by favorable weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area went ahead notably during the week. A number of stores here showed increases in excess of 12 per cent over a year ago, with the average for New York and Brooklyn stores estimated as showing a 10 per cent rise over 1934.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Works Progress Administration, finally selected by President Roosevelt to carry out the major part of the vast work-relief program, plunged today into preparations for spending additional funds on light construction projects and providing jobs for 3,500,000 persons by Nov. 1.

Liberalization of the rules of the Stock Exchange regarding the appointment of alternates to conduct the floor business of governors who are devoting their time to affairs of the Exchange may result, it is said, in the admission of new partners to certain firms.

The Fall series of film presentations by the Cinema League of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue, will start tomorrow night with "Chapayev," a Russian production.

The Steel Navigator of the Isthmian Line entered the harbor yesterday after a forty-day trip from Singapore with Frank Buck's cargo of wild animals, birds and reptiles. As the ship eased into its pier at St. George, S.I., the din of a floating menagerie could be heard for several blocks.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Emily McClurg won the sweepstakes prize for the highest number of points today at the flower show of the Stewart Manor Garden Club in the Stewart Manor Country Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade today, following a minor recession early, in sympathy with somewhat easier cables from Liverpool and on selling by several houses with Eastern connections. Aggressive buying developed, however, toward the last from houses that had been leading sellers of late, and an oversold pit condition was disclosed.

Mayor La Guardia indicated last night that $52,000,000 city projects involved in the current dispute between WPA Administrator Harry Hopkins and PWA Administrator Harold Ickes would, not be abandoned regardless of how the controversy ended.

WOODBURY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Miss Sarita Blagden, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Blagden of Willogate, Huntington, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance given in her honor by her cousins, Mr. and Mrs. Linzee Blagden, at their home here.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13. -- The greatest interest has been aroused here over what is believed to be a change in the British attitude regarding collective security.

The opera company headed by Alfredo Salmaggi will open a season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight with "Carmen." The cast will be headed by Bruna Castagna, Rosa di Giulio, Sydney Rayner, Angelo Pilotto and Nino Ruisi, Alberto Baccolini conducting.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Charles F. Chapman won the sweepstakes prize this afternoon in the annual dahlia show of the garden department of the Plandome Woman's Club, which was held in the club rooms of the village hall. The show was small because of the recent rainy weather that spoiled many of the dahlias that were being grown for it.
PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Premier Pierre Laval undoubtedly has achieved a triumph among Frenchmen of all parties by his speech today at Geneva.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Representatives of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce termed "ridiculous" today the contention of the Albany Port Authority Commission that railroads serving the port of Albany should be required to absorb wharfage charges instead of the steamship lines, as at the port of New York.
BERLIN, Sept. 13. -- The Boerse was inactive and weaker today. Heavy industrials were stagnant.

VIENNA, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Winfield R. Sheehan, American motion picture executive and new husband of Maria Jeritza, former Metropolitan Opera singer, was made an honorary citizen of Unterach, Austria, today to the accompaniment of angry protests from a section of the nation's press.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- While Britain and France were taking a common stand against Italy at Geneva, the British, French and Italian Governments quietly delivered a joint warning to Lithuania yesterday to respect her undertakings under the Memel statute of 1924.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- The State Superintendent of Banks, George W. Egbert, has taken over the Empire Credit Union, 625 Madison Avenue, New York City, to conserve its assets, the Banking Department announced today. The amount due creditors and shareholders on Dec. 31 last was $1,813.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- Coming back strongly to overcome the opposition's 7-point advantage, the Pittsburgh Pirates conquered the Philadelphia Eagles, 17 to 7, tonight before 20,000 fans in Temple Stadium in the opener of the National Football League's fourteenth season.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 13. -Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of the Orchard Hill Kennels of Lock Haven, Pa., today dominated the annual specialty event of the Pekingese Sleeve Dog Association of America, which was held on the lawns of Catawba Farm.

Is Oxford going to the demnition bowwows again? For such is the normal destination of colleges. Mr. ALAN CAMPBELL JOHNSON has a piece in The Spectator about the social behavior of undergraduates, male and female. There are five of the former to one of the latter.
GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- The text of the address of Premier Pierre Laval of France to the League of Nations Assembly today follows:

Does it help the cause of greater safety on the roads to be told that home is a greater hazard than the deadly automobile? In fact, the State Safety Conference at Trenton was told that home is the most dangerous place on earth.
Plans for the erection of several new dwellings were announced yesterday in connection with sales of building sites in the Riverdale and Spuyten Duyvil sections of the West Bronx.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The task of carrying about 2,400,000 unemployed persons through the coming Winter was given today to the Works Progress Administration by President Roosevelt after he learned that the heavy construction program of the Public Works Administration could not get into full swing before late in the Spring of 1936.

Students of Times Square economics have observed that Broadway, during the last week or two, has resembled the West in the mining days. Every one just seems to have more money. The theatres are getting some of it, the movies a part and the night clubs the remainder.

WENONAH, N.J., Sept. 13. -- The Wenonah Military Academy, which for thirty-one years has instructed some of America's foremost athletes, was closed today. Major C. Meade Lorrence, superintendent, said the action was taken because of poor enrolment.

The American Merchant liner American Merchant sailed last night for Plymouth and London four hours late as the result of a sudden strike of its engine-room and deck staffs and its three radio operators.

The Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park was gay last night with boating parties at the Venetian water carnival staged by the Department of Parks. More than 200 rowboats plied the still water, reflecting the lights of many vari-colored lanterns, while a crowd estimated at more than 15,000 viewed the carnival from the shore.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Although his fight with Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium a week from Tuesday is still eleven days away, Joe Louis is in such fine condition that he could step into the ring at once for what he considers the most important battle of his short but spectacular career.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday and trading was moderately active. Crude rubber futures continued under rather heavy pressure and coffee prices were lower. In the cash markets all the grains, cocoa, tin, silk and wool tops were higher, while lard, cotton and rubber were lower.

TOKYO, Sept. 13. -- Efforts of correspondents to draw out Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, on the Ethiopian question proved again today that Japan's attitude is that of a spectator watching a fight from a high window.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP). -- Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State in Woodrow Wilson's postwar Cabinet, today called upon the members of the New York Press Association to "defend the Constitution."

A sandwich man wearing a light worsted suit, gray felt hat and steel-rimmed glasses walked solemnly through Times Square yesterday morning bringing to Broadway a message from a father and mother who for a year have searched the nation in vain for their 17-year-old daughter.

Dr. William I. Sirovich, chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Patents, said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would be the first corporation to be examined in the committee's investigation of the effect on public welfare of patent pooling, cross-licensing or patent manipulation.
On top of the reported capture of a barracuda in New Jersey waters, mentioned in this colmn yesterday, comes new information regarding the presence of strange visitors from tropical seas.
It seems that a certain odium attaches to any legislation that has to do with silver. The Silver Purchase Act of 1934 is no exception.

The long-threatened split in the teachers' union, the result of warfare between left-wing groups and the old leadership, became a reality yesterday when the officers and two-thirds of the executive committee resigned in a body from their official positions and from membership in the union.

ROME, Sept. 13. -- Italy announced tonight she would go straight ahead with her plans in East Africa, and at the same time a semi-official newspaper said the country would take "answering measures" to Great Britain's concentration of a fleet in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A reciprocal trade agreement, based on most-favored-nation treatment, was signed today by the United States and Colombia, Secretary of State Hull and Miguel Lopez Pumarejo, Colombian Minister, announced. The agreement, to be effective, must be approved by the Colombian Congress, ratified by the President of Colombia and approved and proclaimed by President Roosevelt.
Frederick J. Perry, England's great tennis player, will be unable to play for eight weeks, an X-ray diagnosis by Dr Louis Sachs of 470 Park Avenue disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- The Syracuse Chiefs scored their third straight triumph over the Newark Bears before 10,000 imploring home rooters tonight to gain a commanding lead in the International League play-off. They need only one more game to gain the right to a place in the finals.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13. -- With full military pomp of the early days of American history, 1,200 members of the Centennial Legion, representing National Guard and veteran organizations of the thirteen original States, including the Old Guard of New York and the Seventh New York Regiment, converged here today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13. -- Because of changed conditions, the Hartford-Connecticut Trust Company, one of the largest State-chartered banks in New England, has withdrawn from membership in the permanent Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and at least two other banks in this area plan action on the advisability of affiliating with the FDIC.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Director for New York City, gave personal notice to President Roosevelt today that he planned to quit his position between Oct. 1 and Oct. 15.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Larry French, who started the current winning streak of the Cubs by turning back the Phils nine days ago, kept it going today when he pitched the Bruins to their tenth straight triumph, 4 -- 1, with the Dodgers and their hurling ace, George Earnshaw, as his victims.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 13. -- A highly interesting program of classes for hunters featured the second day's session of the annual three-day Far Hills horse show at the fair grounds today, excellent work by the majority of the timber toppers resulting in keen competition.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13. -- Flinging caution and science to the four winds, the Giants tore into the Cardinals today as though seventy-seven odd demons were clawing at their heels, tossed Sportsman's Park into a turmoil of excitement and flattened the Cardinals, 13 to 10, in ten innings of the weirdest sort of baseball seen in many a year.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Rookie Walter Hilcher, recalled from Toronto, defeated the veteran Ed Brandt of the Braves in a pitching duel today to give the Reds a 1-to-0 victory.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Royal K. Fuller, 59 years old, former newspaper correspondent and Commissioner of Canals and Waterways, was found dead in his office here late today with a bullet wound in his right temple.

A complete audit of the lower courts of the city to take in every court but the Supreme Court, has been undertaken by the Department of Investigation and Accounts, Commissioner Paul Blanshard announced yesterday. It will be aimed especially at ferreting out the shortcomings of "political loafers," he explained.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The market for hogs was unsettled today. Butcher hogs weighing over 275 pounds were as much as 25 cents a hundredweight lower, with 250 pounds and lighter offerings as much as 10 cents higher, compared with Thursday's low level.

TORONTO, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press). -- The economic theories of Father Coughlin may be moulded into the machinery of government with which Premier William Aberhart of Alberta expects to distribute $25 a month to every adult in his province, where 731,600 persons reside.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 13. -- Convinced from all available evidence that Miss Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy actress, killed herself Wednesday night at lonely Indian Run Farm, the country estate of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d in Lyndell, Chester County authorities released Mr. Rogers from jail today.
Members of the Authors League of America received yesterday a letter from the organization announcing its preparations to help needy authors and dramatists obtain government relief.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Regulations governing the dealing in securities on a when-and-if issued basis and the solicitation of proxies are being put in final form by the Securities and Exchange Commission in clearing the decks of some of the remaining rules governing Stock Exchange activities before the full burden of carrying out the provisions of the holding company section of the Public Utility Act of 1935 is faced.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Two first-class sailing jobs were turned in today as Horace Havemeyer Jr.'s Vim won the fourth race in the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship series and Harold Halsted's Chuckle II increased his lead in the standing with a fourth place in the face of adversity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- An American "Youth Program" is to be formulated, the foundation of the first inclusive study of the conditions vitally affecting the lives and development of the nation's boys and girls ever undertaken in this country.
PARIS, Sept. 13. -- On his seventy-fifth birthday General John J. Pershing received today a bust of himself by George Conlon, American sculptor.

George Hiram Mann, attorney with offices at 79 Wall Street, is looking for some good "lost cause" or at least a cause with something less than an even chance. Mr. Mann; a self-styled Tory now in his sixty-third year, has won a battle he has been waging for more than a quarter of a century.

Dropping further, the Dutch guilder in the foreign exchange market yesterday reached its lowest price since July 27, when the monetary crisis of the midsummer was at its height. Coincident with the decline in the guilder increased engagements of gold from Amsterdam to the United States were reported.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Superb hurling by Curt Davis, who did not permit an enemy batsman to reach first until two were out in the fifth, enabled the Phillies to defeat the Pirates, 5 to 1, today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Gratification was evident at the State Department today over the favorable world reaction to Secretary Hull's reminder of yesterday that Italy and Ethiopia are bound by the Pact of Paris to settle their differences by peaceful means.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said here tonight that he could not "afford to stay in Washington indefinitely," but he declined to say whether he would resign within six months.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 13. -- Police used a dozen tear-gas bombs today to disperse 600 persons, mainly unemployed, who gathered at City Hall to demand increased relief and to protest police action at the Flour City Ornamental Iron Works Wednesday night, when two men were killed and more than thirty wounded.

TYLER HILL, Pa., Sept. 13. -- The City College football squad is in the State of Pennsylvania and Coach Benny Friedman is in a state of expectancy. High up in the Pocono Mountains at the Wayne Country Club the Beavers are industriously training for the forthcoming football season with line prospects excellent and backfield outlook uncertain to an extreme.

Skilled union laborers on strike in protest over low WPA wage scales staged a turbulent demonstration in front of the Astor housing project, Avenue A and Third Street, at noon yesterday. At one point in the demonstration a volley of stones was hurled across the street at the project, and a few minutes later the strikers surged across the street shouting to the 300 non-union men on the job to join their ranks.

If the Van Sweringen brothers of Cleveland carry out their announced intention to bid for control of their $3,000,000,000 railroad empire when it is put on the auction block by J.P. Morgan Co. on Sept. 30, they must take this action through agents and not in their own name, it was disclosed yesterday by some of their business associates.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The speech of Pierre Laval, Premier of France, at Geneva today had a cheering effect on British Government securities on the London Stock Exchange. Industrials, too, recovered quickly from the depression of the last few days, although dealers reported only a slight increase in business.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Interstate Compact Commission of six oil-producing States was an organized body today, ready to function for three desired results: Conservation of natural resources, prevention of waste and prevention of price-fixing within the oil industry.

ELLIS PARKER is County Detective of Burlington County, N.J., a county that is mainly agricultural, only 23,000 of the 93,000 population living in towns. The people are not wealthy; the average expenditure per capita is about $290 a year. Yet Mr. Parker is no cloth-hat. Many are ready to agree that he is the best detective in America, if not in the world.

The Department of Health reported yesterday thirty-two new cases of infantile paralysis for the preceding twenty-four hours, bringing the total for the week ended yesterday at 9 A.M. to 238. Officials said that this showed a "gratifying continuation" of the decline in weekly totals which began the week ended Sept. 6.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Athletics, scoring eight runs in the first inning when Babe Phelps issued six bases on balls, took their third straight from the White Sox today, 19 to 7.

One of the largest recent realty transactions in the West Hudson section of Hudson County was recorded yesterday in purchase of the former Clark Thread Company plant at East Newark by the East Newark Realty Corporation of 605 Broad Street, Newark.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Although he had already left for Ohio, Christopher W. Deibel of Youngstown officially was the United States senior golfing champion today. None of the 120 competitors in the second half of the field that concluded the 36 holes of play at the Apawamis Club links this afternoon was able to come within ten strokes of the 153 total which Deibel posted hero yesterday.

PANAMA, Sept. 13. -- Government officials said tonight it would require more than eight hours for men on horseback to reach the scene of the crash of the commercial plane in which passengers and the pilot lost their lives today.

The moonshiner antedated the Eighteenth Amendment and has survived repeal. Yesterday the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department reported that in the course of the last fiscal year it seized and destroyed 16,988 illegal stills. This figure compares not unfavorably with those reported during the heyday of national prohibition, when a new industry, fabulous for its quick profits, developed overnight.

The general expansion of trade movements this week attained proportions that exceeded estimates for initial Fall progress, retail distribution showing the most generous consumer response to new merchandise offerings in five years, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP).-- Battering a pair of Cleveland pitchers for thirteen hits, the Senators scored their fourth successive victory today by defeating the Indians, 5 to 3.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13. -- One of the participants in the parley which the late Senator Long told his colleagues in the Senate was called to arrange for his assassination revealed today that its sponsors were four members of the House of Representatives friendly to the New Deal and hostile to the Louisiana dictator.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 13. -- Adolf Hitler called his Reichstag into an unexpected session here Sunday to proclaim the Nazi swastika banner as Germany's only national flag and to pronounce it the "flag of freedom," members of the Reichsfuehrer's personal entourage said tonight.

The Singing Society of the Austrians, Inc., denied yesterday that permission for a meeting in the society's Hall of the Austrians, 245 East Eighty-second Street, had been refused because of threats of loss of patronage made by Nazi leaders.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- Scathing comments on the decision of Magistrate Louis Brodsky of New York in the case of the Bremen rioters are published today in the current issue of The Economist, which in the last two years has been bitterly hostile to the Hitler regime.

A revival of activity in the municipal bond market is indicated for next week when new State and municipal financing scheduled will amount to $45,781,200. This includes $4,116,000 bonds to be sold by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on Thursday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. W. Ellison won the sweepstakes prize in the cultural class and Mrs. Beatrice Sanborn was the winner of the sweepstakes prize for artistic arrangement at the flower show of the Pleasantville Garden Club held today in the Episcopal parish house here.

The army's two sixteen-inch guns at Fort Tilden, Rockaway Point, Queens, silent since the Fall of 1924, were fired yesterday afternoon with surprising results, as far as residents of adjacent residential communities were concerned.

To blase New Yorkers Friday the 13th apparently does not mean as much as it used to. Business went on as usual, couples were married as usual and on Madison Avenue passers-by even accepted an invitation to step under a ladder -- although a few made certain reservations.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Robert C. Lake and Mrs. Gerald M. Gordon today gained the Long Island women's two-ball championship on the North Hempstead Country Club course, but only after conquering tenacious opposition from Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel and Mrs. George E. Hackney, who carried the match to an extra hole.

ROME, Sept. 13. -- If a high explosive bomb had gone off among the Italians crowded in hundreds around news stands this afternoon to read Premier Pierre Laval's speech at Geneva they could not have been more thunderstruck. At the very worst, they expected the French Premier would maintain his attitude of benevolent neutrality toward them where a problem of action was concerned.

School officials, submitting a budget of $141,574,071 for next year, $87,092,677 of which would be furnished by the city and the remainder by the State, were told yesterday by Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen that while he was in sympathy with the system's requirements, the problem was to provide for all departments within budgetary limitations.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Many ribbons were awarded at the annual Fall show for dahlias and gladioli now being held at the gymnasium of Rutgers University here.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 13. -- Organization of an official international meteorological office -- a world weather bureau -- to coordinate the meteorological services of various countries with a view of improving and prolonging the range of weather forecasts was one of the main topics of discussion of the international conference of the directors of meteorological services of more than thirty countries, held in Warsaw this week.

Renewed selling pressure against United States Government issues marked bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. In the heaviest trading since Aug. 23, when sales amounted to $9,139,300, the Federal loans absorbed more than half of the day's turnover, sales reaching $8,195,900, against $4,006,200 on Thursday.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 13. -- Twice hailed today as the "grandest man in Virginia public life," Senator Carter Glass tonight told about 1,500 young Democrats of the State in annual convention and guests from six other States that when they entered public life they should "present honest convictions and let the people reject or accept them."

Ethiopia still hopes for a peaceful solution of her difficulties with Italy, Emperor Haile Selassie reiterated yesterday in a radio talk rebroadcast to American listeners by the National Broadcasting Company.

Alderman Elias H. Jacobs of the Twenty-third Assembly District, Manhattan, obtained yesterday from Magistrate McKiniry in Washington Heights Court a summons returnable Sept. 16 charging criminal libel to Assemblyman Alexander H. Falk, his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Alderman.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan ruled yesterday that neither side in the battle for the Tammany leadership in the Fifteenth Assembly District could claim to be the "regular" Democratic body of the district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Appointment of General Hugh S. Johnson to head the new Bituminous Coal Commission was urged tonight by a producers' committee, claiming to represent more than half the industry.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP). -- A mild mannered 53-year-old recluse admitted tonight, State Police Sergeant Joseph Fratus said, that he killed Knight P. Owen in the third slaying on this island of Marthas Vineyard in 176 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Reappearance of the "auction system" in government financing operations is probable because of the Treasury's tentative aims for handling the public debt, it was indicated today.

BERLIN, Sept. 13. -- The promise of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, to pay interest on the Dawes and Young bonds held by Americans in dollars, even if at reduced interest rates, was characterized in official quarters today as a "friendly gesture," which immediately produced rumors that Germany would begin new trade negotiations with the United States.

Your editorial regarding the "unforeseen'' effects of currency depreciation on foreign trade is interesting in the traditional lack of understanding it displays of the true economic significance of this form of monetary action.

GENEVA, Sept. 13. -- The League of Nations Council committee on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis is considering whether a one-time League project for aiding the Negro republic of Liberia is applicable to Ethiopia.

Out on Long Island Sound, off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club off Oyster Bay, another attempt will be started this afternoon to capture the Seawanhaka Cup, second in importance of all yachting trophies to the America's Cup, and most elusive instead of stationary.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Greentree rode into the semi-final round of the national open polo championship today by galloping away from Long Island to win the last of the first-round matches by 15 to 9. Greentree now meets Templeton when the defending champions swing into action Sunday in the second semi-final. Aurora and the Hurricanes will play tomorrow in the first semi-final at 4 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Inquiries being made of various Stock Exchange firms in New York by agents of the Securities and Exchange Commission have to do with the commission's study of the advisability of the segregation of brokers and dealers, the commission said today in a formal statement.

HARRAR, Ethiopia, Sept. 13 (By Cable). -- Wehieb Pasha, Turkish hero of the Dardanelles during the World War and now chief of staff of the Ethiopian Army on the southern front, is confident that Ethiopia can repel any invading Italian force in his sector.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Eighty flower growers of Hillsdale and neighboring communities participated in the sixth annual flower show opened here today by the Sun Dial Garden Club of Hillsdale. About 300 exhibits were shown.

The construction of play areas on the rim of Central Park having been begun, the discussion of their desirability is academic. But the argument in their favor offered by Mr. MOSES after the fact is perhaps more persuasive than it would have been before the fact. It is that the only other possible solutions are either to keep children out of the park entirely or else to cease trying to maintain its appearance.

The cold breezes which sweep across Washington Square Park signal the termination of Summer and soon Patsy Grazzianni will be forced to place his hot-dog cafeteria in storage. The Winter will also conclude the business operations of Patsy's compatriot. Ercole Panessa, the bootblack, who has enjoyed a most profitable season.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13. -- Repeal of decrees which Senator Huey P. Long was driving through his Louisiana Legislature when he was assassinated became tonight an objective of the late Senator's foes, already out to seek defeat of his stricken organization at the polls, as Long's men held out an olive branch to Washington.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Governor Lehman today proclaimed Sept. 17 as Constitution Day and asked schools, churches, patriotic and fraternal organizations and the people generally to observe it for the "purpose of better understanding of our fundamental law and its history as the source of our collective freedom and happiness."

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, will sail today on the Italian liner Conte Grande for a month's vacation in Spain and Portugal. He will be accompanied by his wife. The Conte Grande will also have among her passengers Bernardino Molinal, symphony conductor, with his wife; Mrs. Edith Gould of New York, and the following, who will board either in New York or at Boston when the ship calls there tomorrow:

Public offerings of new bonds this week amounted to $119,293,000, compared with $30,799,000 last week and with $4,725,000 in the corresponding week of last year. The financing was the heaviest since the $234,148,000 in the week ended on July 19.

More than 100 foreign exchange students representing colleges and universities of Europe and South America attended the opening session of a three-day conference of the Institute of International Education at a dinner and meeting last night at the Riverdale Country Club, Riverdale-on-Hudson.

The North American Administrative Committee of the World's Sunday School Association will hold its semi-annual meeting Thursday, beginning at 10 A.M., in the Hotel Astor. A report on his recent mission to China for the organization will be given by the Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle, Dean of Yale Divinity School, who is chairman of the World Council of the association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The new Social Security Board called upon the thirty-five States with old age pension laws today to file their administrative plans for approval if they expect Federal aid.

Fluctuations were limited and trading was unusually light on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, quotations ending 1 point lower. What was said to be the first time on record, each active trading position recorded the same loss from the previous closing quotations for that delivery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Rust damage to the wheat crop has been unsettling to trade in Canada, according to the weekly survey of foreign business conditions issued today by the Department of Commerce on the basis of reports received from its representatives abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- Lewis Carlisle, who several years ago while a prep school boy at Hun began an outboard racing career that brought him to the top of American amateurs in 1932 as the country's high point scorer, made a sensational comeback into national prominence today to win two of the four titles for Eastern championships.

The New York Stock Exchange seat of the late Arthur J. Low is being leased at a monthly rate of $277.76, it was revealed yesterday by the filing of a petition in Surrogates' Court by the widow of the former member. This, according to all available records, is the first renting of a seat on the big board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- President Roosevelt has approved further allotments totaling $4,016,145 for WPA projects in New York State, the Division of Applications and Information announced today. The projects approved are in sixteen counties. Those in six counties close to New York City are as follows:

HYDE PARK, Sept. 13. -- President Roosevelt left at 11 o'clock (Eastern daylight time) tonight for a twenty-four-hour trip to the Adirondacks, where he planned to dedicate officially tomorrow the White Face Mountain Highway, a project originated while he was Governor.

King Saxon, sprint champion of the season, will make a return to competition this afternoon in the mile and a sixteenth of the Aqueduct Handicap, the $7,000 test which will feature the closing day of the Queens County Jockey Club's meeting.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 13. -- For the second straight day Mrs. William du Pont's Quarryman, from the Foxcatcher Farms, Delaware, captured one of the feature events in the Wissahickon horse show today.

CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. C.W. Giltzo of Roseland won the greatest number of important awards at the first annual community flower show sponsored by the Roseland Women's Club today at the Presbyterian Church there.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Despite two claims for foul against the Brookmeade Stable's Good Goods, the horse won the second running of the Rochambeau Handicap, a mile and three-sixteenths for 3-year-olds and up, today before 45,000 fans.

TWO openings will occupy the London mind this week, says the cable, and they are: "Nina," Hubert Griffith's adaptation of Bruno Frank, which is due at the Criterion on Tuesday, and "Please, Teacher," a musical show with Bobby Howes, which should arrive Thursday at the Hippodrome.

THROUGH extensive research of dusty records two centuries old or more, the exact colors used on the walls of rooms in Colonial days have been discovered. Detailed descriptions and formulas for mixing pigments have been brought to light and old rooms have yielded evidence of their original hues after later coats of paint have been laboriously scraped away.

TRENTON, Sept. 14. -- Brunswick Pike from Trenton to Elizabeth may be changed from a four-lane highway on three sections of concrete to a thoroughfare with two full-width lanes for traffic in each direction separated by a grass-covered centre.

ALTHOUGH bulbous irises have long been known and grown, it is only in recent years that the general gardening public has begun to appreciate these exquisite flowers. They have been called "orchids of the garden" and they do in reality rival the orchid in form and color.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13. -- While Europe's attention is distracted by the war clouds darkening over Africa, the Japanese methodically continue their plans for "extension of influence" over China. The Russians are watching them impassively but with the keenest vigilance.

IF a cultural education is defined broadly as one which leads to a sympathetic understanding and appreciation of life rather than narrowly in terms of a traditional curriculum, it is easy to show that a sound training in science and engineering may have as great cultural value as a course in the so-called liberal arts.

BEELIN. IT is no easy task to do justice to Paul Gurk, novelist and Kleist Prize winner, within the limits of a short article. His works, written in a highly personal style, are rich with ideas, profound wisdom and subtle observation.

QUEBEC. -- For the second time in ten years a Governor General of Canada will disembark at Quebec and be sworn into office here. On Oct. 10 John Buchan (Lord Tweedsmuir) arrives on the Empress of Britain for a five-year occupancy of Rideau Hall and the Quebec Citadel, as King's representative in the Dominion.

LONDON. -- For many years it has been the custom for the British to consider the naval problem in European waters as falling under two principal divisions: the North Sea and the Mediterranean. Recent events indicate that this separation cannot be maintained much longer.

A freer spending attitude on the part of consumers is expected to facilitate acceptance of slowly rising retail prices, according to retail executives here. Marking the first advance in sixteen months, retail price levels moved higher in August and the belief was expressed that a small but steady upward movement is now beginning that may carry into next year.

Father Knickerbocker donned his frills and furbelows yesterday mornning, mobilized his maximum fanfare -- the Police, Sanitation and Fire Department bands -- and delivered a blaring welcome to a delegation of fifty Chicago officials and citizens.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The Boars were eliminated from the International League play-offs tonight for the third straight year when they lost their fourth consecutive game to Syracuse, 5 -- 2.

BARRING a last minute change in plans, four celluloid ambassadors of goodwill from the Gold Coast will settle down this week at first-run houses along the local cinema sector. The four new pictures will take places beside four others which have been held over for the week.

Six Columbia assistant football coaches turned actors for a few hours yesterday as they trod the boards of a stage at the Hotel McAlpin. The occasion was the annual rules interpretation meeting of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association, with the audience consisting of some 300 coaches, officials and graduate managers.

NO less than twenty-six-bills affecting communications and radio in one way or another were introduced in the first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress. Those enacted into law were few and far between. The rest automatically go over to the second session of the same Congress, scheduled to begin Jan. 3, 1936.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Radical changes in Chicago's high school courses to provide "education for the crowd," the pupils who are not headed for college, are contemplated by William J. Bogan, Superintendent of Schools. It is his view that for more than 80 per cent of the pupils the courses are now cluttered with non-essentials which waste their time, largely because of the traditional view of the high school as a preparatory school for college.

CAIRO. -- The threat to the independence of some 10,000,000 Ethiopians has caused 300,000,000 Moslems, especially the 40,000,000 inhabiting the Near and Middle East -- Egypt, Palestine, Syria, Transjordan, Iraq, Iran, Arabia -- to rise in protest.

A NEW type of flower show, beginning to assume important proportions, is that in which the exhibitors are employes of a business organization, managing and staging their own show, usually in the building in which they work.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A new Washington season record for successive victories -- five straight - was hung up by the Senators today as they defeated the Indians, 5 to 1.

MITCHELL, S.D. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration, now the object of heavy attack in the courts, has behind it, in the role of defenders, a trained and organized "army" of nearly a quarter of a million farmers in 4,500 counties of the nation's farming area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The trend of industrial activity in the United States this month continues relatively favorable, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey. Production statistics were featured by a sharp rise in steel ingot production this week, following the recession over the holiday period.
Johnny Broaca came up with his best pitching performance of the season at the Stadium yesterday to save the Yankees from a double rout at the hands of the Tigers.

Geneva dispatches on the Italo-Ethiopia dispute have mentioned the possibility of applying League sanctions. In popular English "sanction" is used in the sense of approval, giving countenace to or rendering valid by assent. Quite contrary is the meaning of the word in League documents, where French usage has been followed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- The most unusual primary campaign this city has ever seen will be climaxed in Tuesday's election when party nominees will be chosen for scores of city offices, headed by that of Mayor.

THIS long novel is concerned with the fortunes of three brothers brought up on a farm. Their father, Francis Odell, had come to the old Indian Territory as a pioneer in the Eighteen Seventies and married a woman with Indian blood in her veins.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The strange case of a patient whose stomach turns over and then rights itself several times within a few weeks faced physicians here today at City Hospital.
The New School for Social Research will open its Fall term on Sept. 30 when, for the first time since its founding in 1919, it will offer more than 100 courses for adults.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The Constitutional Government Club, with headquarters here, will open a national membership drive Tuesday. This action was decided upon at a meeting of the executive committee of the new women's organization, held at the home of the founder-chairman, Mrs. Thomas Jardine of Alston Court, this borough.

MANY are the books that have been carefully prepared and sent forth for the purpose of grooming into efficiency and success persons who want to be impressive and popular public speakers. But, notwithstanding their number and variety, here is one that really tackles the subject in a different spirit and by different methods.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 14. -- After a layoff of two days. Joe Louis resumed training today for his bout with Max Baer. The Detroit fighter went through seven rounds of boxing against four sparring mates. He worked easily, holding back his hardest punches.

GENEVA, Sept. 14. -- The League of Nations' procedure toward bringing the Italo-Ethiopian issues to a showdown was moderately speeded today in the gloom following Premier Benito Mussolini's rebuff to the peacemakers.

The ratification of acts performed in behalf of a principal is a measure not infrequently employed for the purpose of acknowledging responsibility for, or for the legalizing of, an agent's past acts. Ratification has many uses.

IN spite of the criticism that they might encourage petty and vindictive spying, citizen motor patrol systems have been established in several widely separated parts of the United States. Ventures of this character, to be sure, are both limited and tentative.

THE chiefs of Scotland Yard are sorely worried by a series of mystifying apparently related crimes, murders, robberies and latterly kidnappings, which rumor and hazy clues aver to be the work of a homicidal Negro at large in London.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The modern spa here, created in accordance with plans originated in 1929 by a group led by President Roosevelt, then Governor of the State, was viewed by him for the first time today in a hurried visit.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Tiny Tim, sturdy nine-year-old bay gelding belonging to H. Rivington Pyne of Far Hills and shown by Miss Emily Stevens, was named grand champion hunter as the annual three-day Far Hills Horse Show came to a close today.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Several thousand Lehigh Valley residents gathered at the Allen-town-Bethlehem Airport here today to participate in the beginning of air mail service for Allentown and Bethlehem.

SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY will conduct the opening concert of a festival in Stockholm on Wednesday, after having led the Stadtorchester in a Sibelius Festival at Helsingfors. His Stockholm program, as announced, will include P.E. Bach's concerto for strings, Sibelius's symphony No. 7 and Tchaikovsky's symphony No. 5. Dr. and Mrs. Koussevitzky plan to sail on the Gripsholm from Gothenburg on the following day for New York.

THIS slender volume will be of very considerable value for the libraries, faculties and students of schools of journalism, for it treats its theme on a wide barns and develops it with careful attention to detail. Apparently a thesis presented as a candidate for the Ph.D. degree, it has been prepared with the comprehensive and conscientious research, the scholarly methods and the persistence in following every lead of possible material demanded for such work.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- If Casey Stengel's anger can inspire a ball club it looks bad for the champion Cardinals. For after the clawing Cubs had finished with the Dodgers today, Stengel was in a blazing rage that boded ill for Frisch's men in the coming series.

The amount of rolling stock in service on the Class I railroads continued to decline in 1934, according to a report by the Association of American Railroads. Only the number of electric and motor locomotives showed an increase.

Privately financed building construction is contributing heavily to the upturn in the heavy industries, according to an analysis of steel production for the first half of this year, issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

IN a few more weeks Fifty-second Street will again be Catfish Row, the home of magnificent heroes and villains. Presently Porgy will shuffle into its dreary court and will meet Crown and Serena, Sporting Life, Robbins and Crown's Bess.

Italian troops are massed in Eritrea threatening the town of Adowa lying a few miles to the south in Ethiopia. The town has a deep national significance for the Italians. The name appears again and again in the speeches of the Duce; troops starting for the "front" chalk "Adowa" on the railway cars.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Twenty-four faculty changes were announced today by Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, on the eve of the opening of the college for its 140th year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- With Joseph Warren Madden as its chairman, the new National Labor Relations Board, set up during the past session of Congress, is ready to begin its duties.

The grip which American raw cotton exporters had on world markets and which has been slipping steadily for two years was abruptly strengthened last week when Liverpool cotton buyers turned to American suppliers for cotton which Brazil is unable to deliver.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13. -- The assassination of Senator Huey Pierce Long has thrown Louisiana politics into frightful confusion. For a State which has had its political thinking done for it by one man for seven years the prospect of a return to self-government is staggering.

WESTPORT, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- President Roosevelt experienced the sensation of having a tire on his car go fiat today for the first time in all the thousands of miles he has motored since he became President.

John Barrymore, 53-year-old star of stage and screen, and Miss Elaine Barrie, his 19-year-old protegee, of 280 Riverside Drive, have quarreled and have reached a parting of the ways, it was revealed yesterday.

People who are out shopping for empires may be glad to know that there is a fine railroad empire to be picked up cheap. It is the Van Sweringen railroad dominion which Messrs. J.P. Morgan Co. will offer for sale at public auction on the last day of this month.

HOLLYWOOD. AS Summer nears its close, studio press departments are bristling with adjectives and stupendous announcements. Out of the welter of gargantuan plans, a number of succinct items were plucked. P.J. Wolfson sold "The Indestructible Mrs. Talbot" to Paramount for $15,000, a figure which included the complete shooting script.

Featured by four stake events of increased value, the Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will get under way at the Jamaica course tomorrow afternoon, with excellent prospects that it will be one of the best sessions in the recent history of the organization.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Sunderland and Manchester City advanced to a tie with Huddersfield Town for the leadership of the English Football League today. While Huddersfield was held to a 1-1 draw by Derby County, Sunderland gained a fine 2-0 victory at Stoke, and Manchester City, at home, overcame Birmingham, 3 -- 1.

I am one of seven million New Yorkers and I think we are the most patient people in the world. We put up with the passer-by who solemnly refers to "little old New York" as Gotham. We forgive the gentle raillery of O. Henry when he talks of our town as Baghdad-on-the-Subway, for he was one of us, and more than that he was O. Henry.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, leading the city's fight against organized crime, has begun to call upon the special racket grand jury for action. Henceforth the public's interest in the war against racketeers, up to now concentrated on the workings of the investigating staff built up by Mr. Dewey, will be broadened to include the secret sessions of the grand jurymen in the county court house.

WITH the Presidential election hardly more than a year away, the Republican party may now boast that is beginning to be convalescent; that it is, in fact, in the best condition it has known since November, 1930, if that is anything to boast of.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Outwardly, at least, Illinois politics presents the picture of harmony on the Republican side and germinating factional unrest on the Democratic.

Market conditions, with legal considerations, have acted to popularize thirty-year bonds to an unusual extent in new financing this year, investment bankers said yesterday. This condition has been most pronounced in the financing by public utility companies.

ALICE was sitting in her office, quietly painting her finger-nails, when there came an imperative knock on the door. From long experience she knew it must be one of the Mad Hatters and, from its peculiar resonance, she suspected it was the Mad Hatter from United Artists.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Driving Tony Freitas from the box in the sixth inning with a barrage of seven hits, four for extra bases, the Braves snapped their 14-game losing streak today and won from the Reds 6 to 4.

TO Darwin man, zoologically dignified as homo sapiens, is the descendant of an Old World anthropoid ape. Anthropologists, embryologists, and comparative anatomists still accept that view. But in what part of the Old World did man do his descending from the ape?

ARTLESS, crude and melodramatic, this book contributes an insignificant mite to literature dealing with the race problem. Stephen Durant, a brilliant lawyer of Santa Marta, Calif., discovers on the eve of his marriage that he has a heritage of Negro blood.

DESPITE its rather inept title, this is the best novel that Edison Marshall has produced in several years. He is clever, ingenious, versatile, prolific. Having ranged in earlier tales from Alaska to Antarctica, he sets the opening scene for this one in Manila. But it soon shifts to Hanoi, Southwestern China, and, eventually, the "kingdom" of Yunnan.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- In the wake of the galloping gallery that watched the lean Walter Emery start the final golf festivities by tossing a couple of birdies in the teeth of the stout Lawson Little, there was a chance to stand under the shade of a spreading elm and take a backward look over the torn turf of The Country Club here. There were some stirring episodes this week.

The staff of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration was decreased 26 per cent from July 1 to Sept. 1. according to Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman. The number of employes has been reduced from 922 as of July 1 to 681 as of Sept. 1.

THE geyser frolic of Yellowstone National Park has undergone odd changes in the last few years, according to ranger naturalists, although Old Faithful continues its punctual, hourly performance. Whatever the reason -- perhaps a deficiency of moisture is responsible -- the park, which boasts 100 geysers, has been writing a new saga in geyser activity.

Automobiles will be coursing soon through the section of the Park Avenue tunnel between Thirty-third and Forty-first Streets, recently abandoned by street car traffic. Under the direction of Samuel Levy, President of the Borough of Manhattan, and through the aid of the WPA, this new artery of traffic has been stripped of its rails, reduced to gentler grades and is being smoothly surfaced.

Mrs. William A. Becker of Summit, N.J., president general of the D.A.R., leaves tomorrow for her visits to State conferences. On Tuesday she will be at the Chicago Woman's Club for a meeting of the regents of the fourth division of Illinois and on Saturday will attend the State meeting for Utah at Salt Lake City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- While protests are arising to a crescendo against the Irish potato-control plan enacted by Congress shortly before adjournment, a strong supporting element began to make itself heard this week above the clamorous opposition.

A forthcoming entertainment that has aroused the interest and cooperation of many in society is the annual dinner dance under the auspices of the social service and hygiene committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, which will be held on Oct. 2 at the St. Regis to open the new King Cole Room of the hotel.
