THE task of scanning the entire United States from the air, to make certain that charts for airmen correspond with what the airman actually will see when he flies over the territory represented, has been completed, Eugene L. Vidal, Director of Air Commerce, announced last week.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Westchester politicians over this week-end are making hurried preparations for the most confused primary election in the county's history.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14. -- Battling heroically and at times with an effort born of despair, the Giants, who appeared to have catapulted themselves clear out of the National League pennant race a few days ago, shot right back into the thick of the fighting today as for the second successive afternoon they brought down the Cardinals in a titanic extra inning struggle.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A last-inning three-run rally gave Philadelphia a 7-to-5 victory over the Pirates today.
Alert to the approach of election day, the New York City League of Women Voters is already operating on projects in furtherance of the organization's nonpartisan objectives.

Higher prices will be the chief problem when most merchandise lines for Spring are opened by manufacturers in the next few months, according to opinions expressed here yesterday. Lines in which the price question will be uppermost include men's clothing, shoes, percales, hosiery and several others.

War clouds lowering over Europe lend sharp emphasis to a summary of four years of effort for peace on the part of women's organizations in many countries presented by Miss Mary A. Dingman of Geneva to the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War. Miss Dingman is chairman of the disarmament committee of Women's International Organizations and is conferring here with member groups pledged to promote peace.

Miss Helen Stephens, the 17-year-old farm girl from Fulton, Mo., who has emerged at the front in women's track meets since last March, utilized the speed in her long legs to run easily away with the 100 and 200 meter sprint titles in the national outdoor track and field meet at Ohio Field yesterday.

SHANGHAI. -- The greater part of China's rapidly growing air force is hereafter to be centred in Western Szechuen Province, probably at Chengtu, the capital. Nanchang, the present great air base, will soon occupy a secondary position.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Sept. 14. -- In a grove of live oaks bearded with Spanish moss, the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith appeared today before 10,000 followers of the late Senator Huey P. Long as his anointed apostle to sound a battle cry for a national campaign for the redistribution of the country's wealth.

FEATURED in the September issue of The London Studio is a well-illustrated article on "The Art of Rumania" by Georges Oprescu, who notes that "the characteristics which govern contemporary Rumanian art began to make themselves felt strongly about the year 1900.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Mrs. Robert Bacon gave a supper dance tonight at Old Acres, her country home on the Jericho Turnpike, to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Hope Bacon, daughter of Mrs. Paul E. Gardner and the late Elliott Cowdin Bacon.
TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 14. -- Toronto's ten-year motherhood marathon has little more than a year to run.

Skilled union workers who went on strike and demonstrated on Friday in protest against the WPA wages paid to workers on the Astor housing project at Avenue A and Third Street announced yesterday that they would push their fight relentlessly.

In connection with the observance of Constitution Day on Tuesday, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition original manuscripts, newspapers, pamphlets, broadsides and pictures dealing with the deliberations of the Federal convention, which was held in Philadelphia in 1787 to frame a new Constitution for the country.

That retail buying from dry goods jobbers has reached the best level in many months was indicated here last week when the wholesalers sent orders into the local market for fairly substantial quantities of Fall goods.

BY rights, there should be troops of Horse Guard parading these early Fall afternoons in West Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets. Helmeted and cuirassed Life Guardsmen should be wheeling four abreast in front of the Music Box and Imperial Theatre and a high-busbied band should be squared off about the entrance to Shubert Alley, making the ambient air tremble with the music of "God Save the King!"

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14. -- Senator Theodore G. Bilbo referred today to the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, organizer of Long "Share-Our-Wealth" societies, as a "damnable self-made liar." He denied charges made by the Rev. Mr. Smith in a radio address last night.

Like Desmond G. Jobity, I, too, have noticed the tremendous decrease in attendance at the Stadium concerts. However, I attribute this decrease not to the lack of interest in music on the part of the audience but rather to the other nightly music events being offered in the city parks and elsewhere.

LONDON, Aug. 29. DURING the last ten years the influence of the American upon the English theatre has steadily increased. To what extent that influence has been mutual it is impossible for an Englishman to say.

CROONING GOVERNOR: In addition to horses, whisky, blue grass, colonels and beautiful women, Kentucky occasionally produces a good political fight. By virtue of the latest one, Albert Benjamin (Happy) Chandler, scornfully dubbed a crooner by his opponents, is the Democratic party's candidate for Governor.

Excellent business in most departments was reported last week by retailers as favorable weather conditions stimulated consumer buying, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Sportswear sales went ahead considerably, with knitted apparel, coats and suits highlighted.
PHILADELPIA, Sept. 14. -- Alfred A. Biddle, broker, was seriously injured today while horseback riding on his l00-acre estate at Newtown Square.

Football stands now on the edge of a new season and, like most of the ones which have gone before, it is described as having bigger and better prospects than ever before. There is more reason for this, though, than in any recent season, for this year the college teams will start their play without the bother of rule changes of any sort.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14. -- Even the locker-room bench seemed to groan under "pressure" as golf's colossus, William Lawson Little Jr., sat down heavily on it after defeating Walter Emery and winning his fourth straight amateur championship today.

As Tuesday will mark the 148th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution, and as this will be widely observed under the auspices of the National Constitution Day Committee, clergymen will today preach patriotic sermons. Many will include prayers for a peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian situation.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Ted Lyons and John Whitehead won a pair of pitching duels for the White Sex today, Lyons turning in a 4-to-2 triumph over the Athletics in the opener and his team-mate emerging victorious, 2 to 1, in the ten-inning nightcap.

THE status of the dollar in the past year has brought about an important movement of passenger traffic from Europe to the United States. Tourists with two weeks or more of free time have come here on specially arranged trips, viewed the tall buildings and busy streets and, in some instances, traveled some miles inland.

Ringleader of a gang of Anglo-American crooks -- but one of whom knows their chief's identity -- for a year past Mr. Dell had prospered enormously from the blackmail and abduction rackets managed with such ingenuity as to render his prey powerless to openly prosecute him or resist his unrelenting extortions.

Walter R. Sharp, Professor of Government at the University of Wisconsin, who returned Friday from a study of conditions in Europe, characterized the Italo-Ethiopian dispute as only one of the dangerous problems confronting Europe, in a speech to the foreign affairs committee of the New York Young Republican Club at a luncheon meeting yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- In a bleak, wintry setting that made blankets and overcoats welcome among the 6,000 who sat in the big stands at International Field, Aurora fought its way through to the final round of the national open polo championship today in the most exciting game the tournament has produced so far, defeating the Hurricanes, 11 to 10.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- Entertaining in honor of Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best, R.N.; Lady Best, Miss Best and the officers of H.M.S. York, which is in port for six days, continued today.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Outwardly everything is calm in France just now. Throughout the holiday season there has been a truce to political agitation, except for sharp outbursts at Brest and Toulon at the beginning of August. But already, with the ending of Summer, there are signs and portents that very soon the struggle between the various political camps will be in full swing.

Where did New York State, more than sixty years ago, get its first crude notions of that conservation policy which has since become one of the brightest jewels in its crown? Possibly from Wyoming. On March 1, 1872, President GRANT signed the act of Congress establishing the Yellowstone National Park.

As one who for twenty-five years considered a subscription to symphony concerts a necessity and attended the best in opera, concerts and theatres for over forty years, may I add a constructive thought to Mr. Jobity's challenge to the public of New York City?

THE English have never been strong on diet, at least not in recent generations. The poor have lived largely on tea and potatoes and bread, the more fortunate on meat and potatoes with an occasional unappetizing and weedy-looking bit of "greens" thrown in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Works Progress Administration has just launched a program in the fields of the arts that has a twofold objective. First, and most important, it will provide useful work at their usual occupations for the thousands of writers, artists, musicians and actors throughout the country who have been forced to accept public relief and whose creative gifts have suffered from unemployment.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 13. -- The amazing victory of the 37-year-old Lieutenant Governor of Kentucky, Albert B. (Happy) Chandler, over the power and patronage of the administration of Governor Ruby Laffoon in his race for the Democratic nomination for Governor, has impressed Kentucky as has no other development of politics since the days of the martyred Governor William J. Goebel.

MILITARY captives, indentured servants, a hospital matron, a Jesuit priest, travelers upon various missions, were the writers of the diaries and letters which this book brings forth into the light of day and modern print so long after they were written.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Miss Dorothy Schmitt, 25-year-old daughter of Jacob Schmitt, retired New York builder, was believed drowned last night in Long Island Sound near here when she was lost overboard from the thirty-foot cabin cruiser, Darius, owned by Russell Robinson, New York razor manufacturer.

IN "Fig Tree John" Edwin Corle has combined the usual functions of the novelist with some which seem to belong to the amateur of ethnology. He has made a very thoughtful and dexterous ef fort to get inside a mind as different from his own, as different from that of any white man of the present century, as night from day.
HOLLYWOOD. THE ghost of Will Shakespeare approached the guard at the door to sound stage number 8.

ELIZABETH, H.J., Sept. 14. -- PWA officials will reconsider the $5,300,000 grade-crossing elimination project in this city, which is slated for rejection because of the magnitude of the work and the length of time required for its completion, Mayor Joseph A. Brophy announced this week upon his return from a conference in Washington.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- Senator David I. Walsh in an address at the launching of two new destroyers at the Charlestown Navy Yard today warned that the United States did not intend to become involved in the Ethiopian crisis in behalf of American citizens, "corporate or otherwise."
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 14. -- The massing of 10,000,000 Fascists to sound the war cry from every piazza in Italy is not just one more melodrama.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Lafayette College will open its 10th year Thursday, when the freshman class will report for the annual freshman orientation program, which begins on Sept. 19 and continues until Sept. 23.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 14. -- Postage Due, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's entry, sent Maryland's major Fall racing season off to a hair-raising start today by driving down the homestretch to come up from third and win the $10,000 Added Eastern Shore Handicap by half a length.

IN connection with Senate Resolution 146 to investigate the airplane crash of May 6 in which Senator Bronson Cutting was killed with other passengers, Senator Royal S. Copeland, chairman of the committee subsequently appointed, has sent out a letter to members of aviation industry seeking. suggestions for making air transport still safer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during August was reported today by the Census Bureau at 408,410 bales of lint and 57,866 bales of linters, compared with 391,771 and 62,137 during the previous month and 421,451 and 61,808 during August last year.

LAFCADIO HEARN once said that every time he heard of a new book, he read two old ones. That many people agree with this Peter Beilenson must believe, because he has busied himself in making our old friends available in fine new feathers. Consumed at an early age with a great ardor for real printing, he launched, on hope and a hand-press, an infant venture which he christened the Peter Pauper Press of New Rochelle.

Representative Charles D. Millard and Frank A. Vanderlip will be among the speakers on Wednesday at a meeting at Carrollcliff, home of Mrs. Howard Carroll at Tarrytown, under auspices of the Women's National Republican Club.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 13. -- Complicated by crude oil price cuts in California, the danger of overproduction in the Louisiana half of the new Rodessa Field on the Texas-Louisiana line, and disclosures of alleged graft and inefficiency in the administration of Texas Oil Control Laws, "hot oil" has been lately growing steadily hotter here.

George Hiram Mann, attorney, of 79 Wall Street, who has just won his twenty-five-year fight for back pay for navy yard workers, passed yesterday at his home, 11 Middagh Street, Brooklyn, laying plans for his next campaign.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Princess Tsahai, youngest daughter of Haile Selassie, who traces her ancestry back to the Queen of Sheba, broke with the tradition of the imperial house today when, with her father's consent, she became a voluntary worker for the First Field Ambulance unit of his army.

GRADING of the surface and construction of bridges on the Laurelton Parkway, between Cross Island Boulevard and Sunrise Highway, is now being pushed, according to the Long Island State Park Commission. At the intersection of the parkway and the Sunrise road a traffic circle and junction span will be built.

The fourth annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America will be held tomorrow and Tuesday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. A special invitation has been extended to controllers, other company officers, public accountants, engineers and others interested in the programs to attend the sessions.

THIS is a delightful book about a fascinating personality. Sir Charles Stanford came in the later years of the Victorian period. His works, together with those of Sir Hubert Parry ad Sir Alexander Mackenzie, were the things that chiefly roused England and English music from the dreary lethargy that had so long hung like a pall and made it worth more serious consideration than it had been given for many generations.

TWO hundred years ago the patron saint of Paris, fairest of cities, turned her face graciously to the west, and gave her name, and perhaps something of her spirit, to a tiny, crude village far across the sea and half way across another continent, a speck of civilization set down in the midst of endless miles in which white faces were unknown.

Six thousand feet above the sea, on the left bank of the River Hassam, stands Adowa, a city old to war. There, as in all Ethiopia, men carried roses in their hands last week to welcome the New Year -- the year 1652 by Ethiopian reckoning. Our Sept. 12 was their Tut 1, New Year's Day, and, as always, they feasted and sang.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Ins., will hold its first meeting uor the Fall and Winter season at the Hotel Astor this morning with the president, Clara I. Austin of East Orange, presiding. The proceedings will mark the twenty-second anniversary of the formation of the organization and a program for the most active season in its history will be arranged, including a membership drive.

LONDON. -- Events in Ethiopia have brought to light another chapter in the many-chaptered history of that famous old coin, the Maria Theresa dollar. This handsome Austrian relic has not been legal tender in Austria since 1854, but the Vienna mint has continued to manufacture it to order for use in a few African and Arabian countries which have not until lately had currencies of their own.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Doremus will give a dinner at their home on Wednesday to introduce their debutante daughter, Miss Clarissa Doremus. The guests will later attend the debut supper dance of Miss Jane Rovensky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Rovensky, at the Greenwich Country Club.

The President of the United States pinch-hit as a statistical expert Friday; he drew a graph. It was a rough job, hastily sketched on the back of a manila envelope, but it made clear the question he was seeking to explain to newspaper reporters at Hyde Park who were curious about the solution he had hit upon for the latest problem in work relief.

RAYMOND HOLDEN, finding life chaotic and perplexing, has undertaken to imitate faithfully its pattern, or the lack of it, in "Chance Has a Whip." Whether he likes to or not, the reviewer must face the question whether such a method is justifiable.

THIS little book indicates that when Jimmy Collins crashed to earth, on a day last March, from a height of 10,000 feet his plane carried with it to destruction not only a test pilot of superdaring and skill but a man with the heart of a poet and the gift of words.

W.C.T. U DRINKS: The Woman's Christian Temperance Union held its sixty-first annual convention at Atlantic City last week and made plans to keep the younger generation out of the re-legalized saloons. It was proposed to inculcate a taste for non-alcoholic beverages, with fruit ingredients and inviting names.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 14. -- With the arrival of 2,400 students here on Thursday, Dartmouth College will officially open its academic year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Hamlin Garland reached his seventy-fifth birthday today, enthusiastic over his latest book which will describe his "forty-five years of psychic research.'

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 14. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr., Lakewood's most prominent resident, is nearing the end of his Summer visit here, but as yet no preparations are being made for his departure to his Winter home at Ormond Beach, Fla.

THAT type of horror story which centres about an abnormal personality is ably related by Richard Curle in his new novel, "Who Goes Home?" Choosing for his setting a charming old English country house of an especially quiet and restful kind, not in the least gloomy, and selecting his characters mostly from pleasant, everyday people, he has, nevertheless, managed to produce an atmosphere of brooding mystery and terror.

Jerome Goldman, 6 years old, of 1,367 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, "the boy in the iron lung" at Bellevue Hospital, was taken out of His artificial respirator for twenty-two minutes yesterday morning, the longest period he has been out in the two weeks he has been confined in the apparatus after suffering an attack of infantile paralysis on Aug. 25.

The Treasury closed its books yesterday on the offer to exchange new 1 1/2 per cent notes for the Fourth Liberty Loan bonds called for redemption on Oct. 15. It will, however, continue until further notice to accept subscriptions for the 2 3/4 per cent bonds of 1945-47 which it offered as an alternative.

After several postponements, six men who had been arrested after the rioting at the sailing of the Bremen on July 26 were brought before Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky on Sept. 6. Magistrate Brodsky dismissed five of them and held the sixth, who was alleged to have struck a detective with metal knuckles, for the grand jury.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- A new undergraduate department for training of young men and women for politics and public life will be established at Temple University when it reopens Sept. 25.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 14. -- President Roosevelt "is not far removed from the mental processes of the late Huey Long," Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, asserted this afternoon in an address at an outing of the Republican Committee of Schenectady County at Endries's Grove, near here.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP). -- In his first appearance on a tennis court since he won the national title, Wilmer Allison went down to defeat today in an exhibition mixed doubles match at the Pacific Southwest tournament.

I read with interest Winthrop Parkhurst's defense of economic liberalism. Then I had the pleasure of reading S.Z. Starr's reply, in which he holds laissezfaire responsible for "children of 4 and 5 working infamously long hours for wages which were even then infamously low; women, whose wages did not equal the cost of feeding a mule, doing the work of mules in coal mines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The Bureau of the Budget has begun a review of the salaries paid to about 70,000 employes in New Deal emergency agencies in an effort to cut the government's administrative expenses.

United States Government bonds drifted lower on a fair turnover in the two-hour trading period yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading interest lagged among the domestic corporation bonds, however, and with the exception of only a few individual issues, prices fluctuated within a narrow price range.

DUBLIN, Sept. 13. -- While the legislators are enjoying a vacation until October and President Eamon de Valera of the Free State Executive Council is engrossed with international affairs in Geneva, Irish municipal administrators are busy discussing their problems in a conference at Limerick during this week.

THE product here labeled "Made in America" is our old friend, the self-made business man who, alien born, rises from poverty to millions. A rapidly diminishing commodity on today's market, he was manufactured in the era of expansion after the Civil War with what now seeems breath-taking ease.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 14. -- With a parade of 150 army tanks through the streets of Nuremberg today as a prelude and an even mightier display of military power scheduled as the grand finale for Monday, the National Socialist Reichstag has assembled for a momentous session here tomorrow to implement the decisions reached at the Nazi party congress that has been meeting here since Tuesday.

IF you were asked to point out two names in this business that probably would never be up in lights together on a Broadway theatre, they might easily be Erwin Piscator, some time director of the radical German stage, and Times Square's own Lee Shubert.

John F. O'Brien of South Orange, chairman of the taxation committee of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, calls attention to the probability of higher real estate taxes if the recent statement is true, he says, that 75 per cent of the candidates for the coming year's Legislature in New Jersey, have pledged their willingness to repeal the State sales tax.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 14. -- At the annual meeting held here today of the Netherlands Society for a Managed Currency, Holland's leading protagonists of devaluation of the guilder stated the reasons why the Netherlands' gold-standard policy was detrimental to the country's interests and why the government should at last follow the example of so many European countries and the United States.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Commander James E. Van Zandt of the Veterans of Foreign Wars charged here tonight that scores of veterans who lost their lives in the hurricane on the Florida Keys on Labor Day had been sent to the key camps from Washington to forestall another bonus demonstration.
The clank of ash and garbage cans, as emptied by Sanitation Department employes, is to be muffled, Mayor La Guardia ruled yesterday, thus assuring New Yorkers a few more hours of uninterrupted sleep.

NANUET, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Horticulturists from all parts of Rockland County and Northern New Jersey attended the opening of the annual show of the Sun Dial Garden Club of Nanuet today at the Nanuet fire hall. With more than seventy classes to be judged at the two-day session the show is one of the largest Fall exhibits ever held in this section.

A discussion on war tactics disorganized a youthful hunt for mud hens in the New Jersey meadows yesterday and sent a 14-year-- old Negro boy seriously wounded to Christ Hospital, Jersey City. He was the victim of a bullet fired by a white companion.

With little in the news of the day which might exert an influence, marketwise, stock prices fluctuated within narrow confines during the two-hour trading period yesterday and closed steady at slightly lower levels. Trading of 632,000 shares on the Stock Exchange was less than half of the volume of the Saturday before when the market was responsive to President Roosevelt's reassurance of a "breathing spell" for business.

THIS is a plain tale of plain people, written in the spirit of understanding, integrity and balance. It is a story of American coal mining which shows a fresh naturalistic approach toward those American workers who, following their Old World traditions, transplanted themselves to the New World to carry on from where they had left off.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Mrs. Arthur White won the greatest number of first prizes at the sixth annual flower show of the Chappaqua Garden Club here this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Henry L. Van Praag, president of the club.

PICTORIAL statistics -- a modern device for showing quantitative facts in pictures -- came into the news the other day when Mayor La Guardia disapproved a proposed WPA study of their educational advantages. Possibly he thought such a study superfluous, since for the past ten months WPA workers on another project in this city have been detailed to produce charts of such statistics for educational and government agencies.

Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, sailed yesterday on the Lafayette to preside at the meeting of the board of directors of the federation in Brussels, Sept. 23 to 26. She was accompanied by Miss Helen Havener, publicity chairman.

Two men were burned to death and five others, three of them firemen, were injured yesterday in a spectacular fire that destroyed a two-story corrugated metal building of the Knickerbocker Ice Company occupying the block on Dumont Avenue between Union and Powell Streets in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

KING GEORGE, Queen Mary and the King's father, Edward VII, have never been commemorated in London street names. But now the London County Council is considering a proposal to rename Upper Berkeley Street and Upper George Street, both in the Mayfair district, as Queen Mary Street and George V Street, and this almost certainly will be done.

The twenty-fifth year of Columbia University Extension will begin on Sept. 26 with an increased enrolment and an enlarged program of studies, it was announced yesterday by James C. Egbert, director of university extension. It will have a faculty of more than 400.

Miss Helene Mullins, novelist and poet, was run down by an automobile and critically injured early yesterday at Seventy-second Street and Columbus Avenue. She was reported to be in "the same condi tion" last night at the Roosevelt Hospital.

IN view of what seems to be an increasing interest in the masters of Spanish art and especially in Goya, a number of whose paintings are to be in the approaching Spanish exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, there is plausible excuse for writing a trifle more about Goya.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- After more than 100 taxpayers at a public meeting here had approved a municipal expenditure of $20,000 for improvement of Flint Park, the Village Board set Sept. 30 as the date for a community-wide referendum on the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- It was a startled capital that heard of the death of Senator Huey Pierce Long, appalled by the manner of his going. But with contemplation grew the realization that with the Dictator of Louisiana passed the threat of an effective ultra-radical independent movement to prevent the reelection of President Roosevelt.

Patriotic organizations of veterans' groups, schools, business men and others will join on Tuesday in marking Constitution Day with a more elaborate observance than in previous years. The date is the 148th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution by the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, 1787.

REVIEWING a first novel makes one feel like a visitor being shown an infant. There is still a lingering consciousness of the sincerity and pain which went into the process of giving it life. Does the infant or novel differ from millions of others, and what are its distinguishing features?

FOR the third time since its "seizure of power," the National Socialist regime last week assembled its hosts at Nuremberg for a "Reich Party Day." This was not a congress or convention, because these terms imply debate; and there was no debate because that would have been contrary to the "principle of leader-ship" on which the Third Reich is founded.
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brokaw, who crossed a few days ago, are staying a short time at the Majestic before going on to London.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14. -- Fairly satisfactory conditions prevail in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Retail sales have declined slightly, but not in a marked degree, being estimated at about 16 per cent ahead of last year, with excellent prospects for a heavy turnover this Fall.

The possibility that the Republicans will be strongest in the urban States in next year's Presidential elections and the Democrats strongest in the rural States has been suggested by the recent Rhode Island election and by subsequent Republican tactics.

THE charming story of a shy little 17-year-old's first romance, during the blissful two weeks of her Spring vacation, is the slim but sufficient basis for Lida Larrimore's new novel. The plot is a little dusty but, as Miss Larrimore tells it, seems refreshing, spontaneous, appealing.

LAST week saw the end of the most profitable season of active service the Air Corps Reserves of the Second Corps Area have had in many years. When it was about to start a month ago, however, it appeared to those most concerned to be on the verge of complete failure.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14. -- Another maritime strike appears to have been averted, at least temporarily, by agreement on both sides this week that existing contracts shall remain in force until Sept. 30 while a negotiating committee attempts to achieve by collective bargaining a basis for new compacts.
Mrs. John Campbell of Eighth Street, Hoboken, will be installed as president of the Hoboken Democratic Ladies Official Club at a meeting Tuesday evening in 309 Washington Street, Hoboken.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society's Sunday afternoon concerts for the 1935-36 season will be broadcast by WABC and affiliated stations. Tentatively, the first broadcast is scheduled for Oct. 13, from 3 to 5 o'clock, Otto Klemperer conducting.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Stewart Bowers, 19-year-old Gettysburg College sophomore, pitched the Red Sex to a 5-to-2 victory over the Browns today. He gave eight passes and allowed eight hits but was effective with men on base.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Fifteen per cent of American motorists, a scientific investigation has shown, arc not safe drivers because they cannot see well enough.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Possibility that a cat may be the carrier of germs which have caused death and serious illness to the children of two families in one house was under investigation today by city health officials.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 18. -- Arizona is making its last desperate fight for what it considers its rights in Colorado River water after completion of Boulder and Parker Dams. Instead of fighting on the defensive, Arizona is taking the offensive.
Bitter contests, of Which there are an unusually large number for an "off" year politically, will mark Tuesday's primary election in New York City.
RADIO retailers in New York report an appreciable increase in business, and quite generally agree "we are off to a good start."

George J. Abrams, chief investigator of the Honest Ballot Association, directed attention yesterday to the charges of fraud and intimidation made by rival candidates for Tammany leaderships and asked why there had been no prosecutions.

Comparatively few contests will mark the primary election on Tuesday up-State, and these are of local interest. There are contests for Democratic nominations for the Assembly in five counties -- Erie, Oneida, Onondaga, Orange and Westchester.
LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Three Cabinet Ministers speaking in different parts of the country tonight emphasized the unity of the British Government and people in support of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Delay until next June in work on the Merritt Highway and similar Connecticut works projects was indicated today as a result of the revamped program ordered by President Roosevelt.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

THE cinema is on a spree. Box office reports from all over the land have sent this giddy industry careering. There are forty-two pictures being prepared for the cameras, in process of being shot, or already being shown in the theatres, which were budgeted at more than $750,000.

We have had an ever-increasing prevalence of infantile paralysis or epidemic poliomyelitis during the 1935 Summer, so that in the Eastern States the cases reported have been far in excess of the normal number. According to the United States Public Health Service, there have been reported for the first thirty-five weeks of 1935 5,417 cases within the registration area.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 14. -- The merger of the Premier mines of the Premier Gold Mining Company, Ltd., and the properties of British Columbia Silver Mines, Ltd., and the Sebakwe Cold Mining Company, Ltd., will be completed by the end of this month, H.A. Guess, president of Premier, reported this week. The mines are in the Salmon River district of British Columbia.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The Boerse achieved virtually the year's record for inactivity today. Some considerable losses were suffered, however, due to the almost total absence of buyers. Heavy industrials were stagnant. Machines dropped suddenly and Schubert Salzer lost 3 points. Electricals weakened. Shipping shares weakened slightly, Hamburg-American losing 1/8 point.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- Fred Jacoby Jr., the North Bergen, N.J., scenic artist, solo, although national high point outboard champion for 1934 and again in the lead this year by more than 3,000 tallies, had never been able to clinch an Eastern title, corrected this deficiency in a big, emphatic way this cold, damp afternoon on the Schuylkill course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- A contract for building a new transatlantic liner with the latest safety devices must be made by the United1 States Lines before Dec. 16, Secretary Roper ruled today.

Police magistrate jurisdiction has been much discussed in the last few days in view of the remarks of Magistrate Brodsky regarding defendants accused of causing a riot on board the German steamship Bremen. In holding one defendant for trial and discharging the others he used language which caused the German Ambassador to protest to the Secretary of State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- E.D. Shaffer's St. Bernard returned to form today to capture the $5,000 added Hawthorne Handicap. Top Dog was second, with Spanish Babe third. The son of Bulldog ran the mile and an eighth in 1:50 3-5.

ROME, Sept. 14. -- Italy has replied to the proceedings of the past few days at Geneva with a declaration that destroys the last slender chances of a peaceful solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy. Italy rejects in advance any compromise proposal that may be suggested.

A SECOND instalment of its American exhibition opened Tuesday at the Valentine Gallery, containing work by the same group of artists participating through the Summer: Eilshemius, John Kane, Joseph Stella, Raphael Soyer, Milton Avery, Leon Hartl, Charles G. Shaw and John Koch.

TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 14 (AP). -- The Tucson Daily Citizen said in a copyrighted story today that it was informed by a source it considered reliable that a nation-wide revolt was scheduled to start in Mexico Tuesday morning.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Norna IV., the six-meter yacht of Crown Prince Olaf of Norway, today won the first race in her challenge match for the Seawanhaka Cup. In a seesaw contest with Paul V. Shields's craft Challenge, the defender of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Norna IV, of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club, triumphed by 45 seconds over 12 miles of windward and leeward sailing.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12. -- To be a Canadian voter these latter days is to be a happy man. There has been no general election in Canada for more than five years, which is slightly more than the limit contemplated by the fathers of Canadian confederation.

The fantastic absurdities of murder fiction extend themselves unreservedly in this tale of Chinese Tong men on the lethal rampage in Hempstead, L.I. -- other localities too -- and the murderous havoc they wreak ere wiped out by the combined valor of private sleuth Masters, his own trusty aides, and the dauntless police.

TORONTO, Sept. 14. -- Reduction of the Canadian prices of farm machinery, tractors and cheap automobiles to the level prevailing in the United States was promised the Canadian farmer by Prime Minister Bennett in a broadcast here tonight. Prices of such machinery were factors in the farmers' costs of production, he said, and they must be level with those "in the country from which we normally import -- the United States."

The leaders association of the Central Nassau Girl Scout committee has announced the first get-together meeting of the Fall will be held at the Girl Scout camp at Grey Beach, L.I., next Saturday and Sunday. After this session the meetings are to be held on the third Wednesday of each month.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Showing aggressively and with true terrier spirit, champion Flornell Soundman today was awarded the highest honors of the fifteenth annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Kennel Club.

GDYNIA, Poland, Sept. 14. -- "The liner Pilsudski is a symbol of Poland's might and the proudest monument for Poland's greatest son," Bishop Okoniewski of Pomorze said this morning when he blessed the flag which was hoisted on the first transatlantic liner built for Poland and bearing the name of Poland's great soldier and statesman.

MUNSING, Mich. -- With the coming of the Fall rainy season Michigan and Wisconsin are proceeding with vast tree-planting projects. In Hiawatha National Forest in Michigan the United States Forestry Service will direct the placing of 4,874 jack pine seedlings and 1,027,000 Norway pine seedlings, the total forming one of the largest single planting programs ever undertaken.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, 71, drove his 26-year-old bride to "Bealls Pleasure" in Maryland today in his own small coupe, for a wedding like those in Washington's time.

New York University starts its 104th year tomorrow when the vanguard of approximately 30,000 students assemble for opening lectures in the professional schools, or enroll in other of the university's fourteen schools, colleges and divisions.

QUIETLY a graphic change has come about in the accessory world. Gloves, bags, shoes and stockings have simultaneously burst into color this Fall; there are wines, greens, rusts, in addition to the usual browns and black.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Two of the outstanding horses in Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's stables, the 9-year-old chestnut geldings His Elegance and Trolly, were designated as the champion and reserve hunters respectively in the twenty-second annual Greenwich Horse Show, held at the John Sterling estate today under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds and the Greenwich Riding Association.

Announcing that thenceforth he would have nothing more to do with pro bono publico, General Hugh S. Johnson obtained an agreement with President Roosevelt on Friday by which he will leave the job of Works Progress Administrator for New York City by Oct. 15.

As brisk a convocation of Republican women as the country has had in many months will be held tomorrow and Tuesday at the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West Fifty-first Street. Political as well as patriotic significance attaches to the assembly in observance of Constitution Day, its importance being emphasized by the number and official character of the visitors from other cities scheduled to attend.

THERE'S a broken heart for every light on Broadway" is apparently still a good theme song. Donald Henderson Clarke works it very hard in his new novel, adapting it to a group of Socialists and radicals, young and idealistic in the days before the war.

UNLESS subscribers to Bibliographical Notes and Queries are of methodical habits, or unless they equip themselves with some sort of binder for back numbers, they are going to lose track of the interesting discussions which enliven its pages.

Stanley Osserman, counsel for the Andrews-Dodge proxy committee of stockholders of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, made public last night a letter addressed to the New York Stock Exchange calling for an investigation of the manner in which member firms have executed proxies to be voted at the company's annual meeting.

The discovery of new islands in the Arctic Sea between Franz Josef Land (Nansen Land) and North Land (formerly Nicholas II Land) is the result of the intensive Soviet efforts to learn more of the ocean currents and possible land barriers in this region as an aid to their development of the Northern Sea Route.

THIS is a companion book to "All's Fair," published a year ago, which dealt with the secret activities of the British War Office system of espionage, as directed from Holland, in the great conflict of 1914-1918.

RECOVERING from its setback last month, retail trade last week jumped ahead to levels that prevailed in July over most of the country. Stores in this locality showed gains of 12 per cent or more in some instances, while the average increase was put at 10 per cent.

The playgrounds baseball championship of the city was decided yesterday morning on the North Meadow of Central Park, with the team of Lyons Square Playground, Bryant and Whitlock Avenues, the Bronx, victorious, 2 to 0, over Brooklyn-Cooper Square Playground nine.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The appointment of the American composer, Roger Sessions, to the faculty of New Jersey College for Women was announced today by Dean Margaret T. Corwin, who also announced the appointment of eleven additional new faculty members. Mr. Sessions will serve as lecturer in music.

Led by a substantial increase in consumer demand for all lines of Fall merchandise, particularly wearing apparel, business in general moved forward at an accelerated pace in almost all Federal Reserve Districts last week, giving further evidence of one of the most satisfactory months for trade operations since last Spring.

NOW the 1935 vintage of jams and jellies for Fall and Winter lines fruit store shelves and kitchen window sills. On the market this year are wine jellies, tinctured with muscatel, claret, sherry or port. There are exotically flavored fruit preserves to dress up the hot meat dish that is returning now to every menu.

WARSAW, Sept 14. -- The Polish Republic has a new Parliament and the government of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's successors has an overwhelming majority in the Sejm, yet the Opposition, which boycotted last Sunday's election and has not a single Deputy, insists the regime suffered a crushing defeat.

THE radio industry will exhibit a complete new line of receiving sets in a setting of industrial and household appliances at the National Radio and Electrical Exposition opening on Wednesday at the Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Sept. 15. -- Appalachian soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers agreed just after midnight to extend their present wage and hour contract until next Sunday midnight, thus averting a threatened strike in nearly every soft coal field in the country.

Led by Don and Ray Ruddy, the New York Athletic Club's water polo team, national outdoor and indoor titleholder for the past two years, defeated the Bedford Y.M. C.A. sextet, 24 to 10, in a semifinal game of the national A.A.U. soft-ball championship at the Jerome Cascades Pool last night.

ABOUT half a million young men and women will enter the 1,500 colleges, universities, normal schools and junior colleges of the nation within a few days. The freshmen will begin their studies with high hopes. If past experience is a criterion, we may expect one-third of them to drop out during the coming year. Another third will disappear from the campuses before graduation.

Five thousand members of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies participated in a mass demonstration yesterday in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau's offices at 902 Broadway in protest against a threatened reduction in the administrative staff because of the transfer of clients to Works Progress Administration projects.

More than a score of motor cruisers, the largest fleet in several years, will enter the Colonial Y.C.'s annual race on the Hudson today for the Jules Heilner Bear Mountain Trophy. This fixture is the second of New York's two annual tests for power yachts, the first having been the N.Y.A.C. race to Block Island in July.

The New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, will begin its thirty-fifth season tomorrow, when members and new students will register in one or more of the forty-two courses available in commercial, trust, investment, savings and international banking and related subjects.

In the Contemporary Review for September is printed the address which Sir HERBERT SAMUEL made at the opening of this year's Liberal Summer School. It was, naturally, devoted in the main to the political situation in Great Britain, but its opening paragraphs were of a different and broader import.

Although scale-buying orders for trade account caused resistance yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, an increase in hedging pressure brought a slow decline, which carried the October into new low territory for the week and left the list 10 to 12 points down.

What the United States does not consider military secrets was illustrated a few days since with the release of five Japanese tourists arrested by police in New Jersey when seen making photographs in the Holland Tunnel. They were released promptly on their explanation they were there making records of a recreational tour.

John H. Baker, executive director of the National Association of Audubon Societies, takes issue with the More Game Birds Foundation on the question of the effect of restrictive legislation on the supply of wild life.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney of Upperville, Va., captured the Rose Tree Challenge Cup, feature competition of the Wissahickon Horse Show, today before the largest crowd of the week. The threat of rain failed to keep down the attendance.

The largest increases in employment have been most consistent in industries that have advanced furthest along the lines of mechanization and have become organized on a mass-production basis, Herman H. Lind, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, said yesterday.

In the Virginia Quarterly Review Mr. CLAUDIUS MURCHISON, formerly of the University of North Carolina, asserts that the fundamental tenets of ADAM SMITH'S economic doctrine are unalterably true. In a world full of "controlled" and "national" economy, price-fixing, restriction of the free flow of goods, bristling restriction and retaliation, this adherence to the "classical" theory is refreshing and wholesome.

Despite the increase in the domestic output of crude oil in the first six months of this year, the total was under the demand by 126,000 barrels daily, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist. The deficiency, besides additions of 21,000 barrels daily to stocks, were made in that period by imports, which averaged 147,000 barrels daily, he adds.

MILLAN, Aug. 20, 1935. OFFICIAL details are published concerning the new statutes which Propaganda Minister Ciano's recently created Theatrical Inspectorate is now applying in all Italian State Subsidized opera houses -- namely, La Scala, the Royal Opera, the Vittorio Emanuele of Florence, the Carlo Felice of Genoa, the San Carlo of Naples and the Teatro Massimo of Palermo.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The belief that the Italo-Ethiopian conflict will now be confined to Africa and will not involve Europe was expressed by Joseph Paul-Bonconr, France's permanent delegate to the League of Nations, on his arrival here from Geneva this morning.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14. -- The hole-by-hole description of the final match today between W. Lawson Little Jr. and Walter Emery for the national amateur golf championship follows:

Dr. Walton H. Hamilton's statement concerning the forthcoming activities of the Consumers' Division of the NRA will bring very little encouragement to the average consumer. Dr. Hamilton informs us that more and yet more studies will be made of the various problems afflicting the consumer.

JUNGLE GOLD tells of the Gargantuan doings of one those rugged extraverts and supermen whom most of us outwardly condemn, but secretly Admire with not a little touch of envy. For Stephen Pentecost was pre-eminently an uninhibited man of action.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 14 (AP). -- One of the greatest mountain-making periods in the earth's history, the growth of the Rockies, perhaps still going on, was described to the seventh American Scientific Congress today by Dr. Wallace W. Atwood, geologist and president of Clark University.

KITCHENER, Ont., Sept. 14 (AP). -- A new treatment for tuberculosis, involving the use of a raw extract of spleen, is described in the September issue of The American Review of Tuberculosis as the discovery of Dr. George F Watson, a Kitchener physician.

William T. Tilden 2d and Karel Kozeluh, seeded-first and second, respectively, entered the final bracket of the ninth annual national professional tennis singles championship before a fair-sized gallery at the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday.

An increasing breakdown of code standards throughout the country since the invalidation of the National Industrial Recovery Act was reported by members of the executive council of the United Textile Workers of America as they closed a three-day session yesterday at their national headquarters at the Bible House, Eighth Street and Third Avenue.

LONDON. -- Europe is having a run of youth in high political office. Dr. Schuschnigg, Austrian Chancellor, is 38 years old. Dr. van Zeeland, Belgian Prime Minister, and Dr. Salazar, Prime Minister of Portugal, are both 42, while Hitler of Germany is only 46, and General Goemboes of Hungary is not far behind him.

BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- A naval reserve aviator and his mechanic were being sought tonight by State Troopers and civilians after what appeared to be a forced landing followed by an ex plosion had been reported from the vicinity of Mount Beacon.

IN a series of experiments in the North Atlantic the Western Union cable ship Lord Kelvin has demonstrated the practicability of a new "submarine plow" which will lay telegraph cables beneath instead of upon the ocean bed. In the last decade, owing to the larger trawlers employed in deep-sea fishing, the damage done to cables by these ships has cost the telegraph companies an average of $500,000 a year.

PAHIS. THE LOST PATROL," which began the Summer at the Edouard VII and promises to carry through the dog days without any difficulty, has developed a demand for he-men and heroism in the French cinema. The French like the picture -- not only critics but audiences, just as they enthusiastically admired "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer,"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Secretary of State Hull today expressed regret to the German Government because Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky of New York indulged in expressions "offensive to another government with which we have official relations" when he discharged five out of six prisoners charged with participation in the riot aboard the Bremen on July 26.

Twelve years ago the puny National Socialist party held its first congress at Nuremberg, then a strong centre of radical socialism and communism. Last week the mighty National Socialist party held its sixth congress in Nuremberg, now one of the strongest centres of Nazism in the Reich.

The abundance of life on an Indiana farm seventy-five years ago is seen through the eyes of the small daughter of a large family of Quakers. Lowry was just turning 7, so the story is concerned with those details which are of particular interest to boys and girls from 8 to 10.

IN his vigorously and constructively thought book, "Experiencing Pictures," published three years ago, Ralph M. Pearson, director of The Design Workshop, observed: "We want our principles mixed with fresher fare. At the cost of considerable pain we have got back again some of the spirit of childhood and, after mature reflection, frankly we are not ashamed."

Arthur R. Robinson, former United States Senator from Indiana, who was a bitter opponent of United States recognition of Russia, returned on the liner Europa last week after a visit to Russia that convinced him that he had been correct in his stand.

The banks of the nation account for "considerably more of the mortgages and modernization loans that the Federal Housing Administration is insuring than all other classes of institutions combined," says Robert V. Fleming, first vice president of the American Bankers Association and president of the Riggs National Bank, Washington, in a letter sent to all members of the association.
Reading the "Reminiscences of a Very Old Man" (John Sartain, 1808-97), I came across the following part of a description of old London in his youth:

A further decline in the number of new cases of infantile paralysis was reported yesterday by the Health Department. The total for the twenty-four hours ending at 10 A.M. was twenty-nine compared with thirty-two for the preceding day and thirty-three for the previous Saturday.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The annual horse show of the Lawrence Farms Hunt Club will be held in the outdoor ring of the clubhouse here tomorrow. The proceeds will go toward the District Nursing Association of Mount Kisco and vicinity.

ROME, Sept. 13. -- The Italo-Ethiopian controversy has brought about many situations that would have been incredible six months ago and one of the most surprising is the state of tension between Italy and Britain, which is so acute that the possibility of war is being openly discussed.

While two ships were delayed in sailing yesterday by the strike of radio operators, the American Radio Telegraphists Association announced it had signed an agreement with the Grace Line, releasing all its ships from the effects of the strike.

OCEAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 14. -- A warning to all parents to keep children indoors after dark in this part of New Jersey has been given here by Police Chief Frank W. Eisele as the outcome of recent attacks by a pack of wild dogs.

THE proposed motor-road tunnel under Mont Blanc opens to travelers the exciting prospect of a new short cut between France and Italy via Geneva. The home of the League is today one of the outstanding tourist centres on the Continent, yet all the existing tunnels which provide short cuts through the Western Alps have left it far to one side.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of August: Total imports, 59,140,000; exports of British products, 34,880,000; re-exports, 4,180,000; total exports, 39,060,000; excess of imports, 20,080,000.

LONDON. ALLAN N. MONKHOUSE has many claims to be heard on literary matters. When he received, in 1929, the honorary D. Litt. of Manchester University, Professor Samuel Alexander presented him as one who had demonstrated how empty might be the antithesis commonly drawn between journalism and literature.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Smooth-swinging Joseph Gagliardi, a member of the home club, today captured the twenty-third annual championship golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club by defeating Dr. Thomas J. Conte, 2 up, in an exciting 18-hole final over the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club.

F. William Zelcer, Mayor La Guardia's dollar-a-year aviation commissioner, resigned his post yesterday. He explained in a formal letter that his business affairs had suffered through his devoting a year and a half to the city's interests, and that he must attend to them.

PANAMA, R.P. -- Trouble brewing for some time between El Salvador and Guatemala threatened an open rupture recently, when a clash is said to have occurred on the location of the new boundary between Salvadorean National Guardsmen and Guatemalan soldiers.

MADISON, N.J., Sept. 14. -- The sixty-ninth year of Drew University will begin when Dr. George W. Briggs, Professor of the History of Religions and lecturer in science, will deliver the matriculation address on "Religions and the Christian Aim" at the Seminary Chapel in the afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Representatives of the thirteen original States, here for the celebration of the 121st anniversary of "The Star-Spangled Banner," heard appeals today for perpetuation of the Constitution and for preservation of peace through adequate national defense.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- There was a noticeable lack today of the aggressive buying that marked the session late yesterday in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade, and some local longs went out of their holdings to even up for the weekend, resulting in a somewhat lower range of prices.

Favored by fine weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area last week made the best showing since the spurt noted in July. Many stores had increases ranging up to 12 per cent or more over last year, with the average of department store increases put at about 10 per cent.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 14. -- Complaints continue to be heard from many parts of this republic about the dearth of small change and also the poor quality of the 50-centavo notes issued a few months ago because of the sudden rise in the price of silver and consequent speculation and hoarding.

MOTOR tourists of America are more and more going over the country towing their cabins behind them, just as is Senator Reynolds of North Carolina, now traversing many States in his "land yacht." This craft, in which he visited New York City a week ago, is a roomy passenger-car pleasure trailer, one of numerous types now seen on the main traveled ways.

WHEN the hurricane warnings go up at Puerto Rico and along the coasts of Florida and the Gulf at this season of the year, ship masters and men ashore prepare for trouble. There are always hurricanes coming out of the Caribbean in the early Fall.

Research needs and activities in the field of distribution, the part the retailer plays in recovery and the rise in consumer cooperative buying will be among the major subjects to be discussed at the seventh Boston Conference on Distribution to be held on Sept. 23 and 24, according to the detailed program issued yesterday.

The urgent need by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and its affiliated agencies for an additional $2,500,000 for relief funds this Fall is discussed in an article, "There's Been No Let-Up," published in the September number, just issued, of its organ, "Federation Illustrated."

DESERTING the somber hues and strong passions of his impressive "Ravens' Brood," Mr. E.F. Benson has reverted to his lighter and more popular vein. "The Worshipful Lucia" is an amusing satirical study, not merely of life in a small English town but of certain foibles of human nature in general.

Long Island yachtsmen will fight a bulletless war on Sept. 29. Battle flags will fly. There will be hubbub and great excitement. A martial air will pervade the normally peaceful purlieus of Freeport, Baldwin, Woodmere, Rockville Centre and the rest of pacific Nassau County.

Adequate advertising of new security issues is one of the most troublesome problems that the Securities and Exchange Commission has had to face, according to John J. Burns, the commission's chief counsel. Efforts of the SEC to simplify publicity requirements, however, "have been hampered and to some extent completely frustrated by the fears of issuing corporations and underwriting houses," he told the Financial Advertisers Association in Atlantic City last week.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 14. -- Thomas W. Slick, Federal judge, today denied the suit of two of the largest soap manufacturers in the country and declared the product of Lever Brothers of Hammond, Ind., did not infringe on the patents of the plaintiffs. The Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company and the Procter Gamble Company had charged that the manufacturer of "Rinso" was an infringement on precess patents.

Confused by the threats in connection with government investigations and also by the various proposals in Washington to tighten official control of the nation's food industries, representatives of all branches of the grocery and allied lines throughout the country will meet here this week to formulate a definite plan of action to meet these moves.

A team of Brooklyn boys defeated a team of Manhattan boys yesterday afternoon in the baseball game which wound up the series of tournaments of street games held during the Summer under the sponsorship of the Community Councils of the City of New York, aided by the recreation department of the Works Progress Administration.

GENEVA, Sept. 14. -- The Ethiopian delegation to the League of Nations in making a 6,000-word "preliminary reply" today to the Italian memorandum on the Italo- Ethiopian dispute calls it "an accusation without precedent in international relations."

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- The Young Republican movement in New England is off to a good start. The lively meeting at Portsmouth last week-end was marked by plenty of enthusiasm, a reasonable amount of bickering, and discreet but probably wise action.

ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- In the four weeks' period ending Aug. 31, 1,077 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive were either revoked or suspended, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles announced today. Of the total number 401 will require proof of financial responsibility before applications for new licenses will be considered.

Efforts of trade association executives to arouse industry to prepare for a projected revival of the National Industrial Recovery Act at the next session of Congress have to date proved practically fruitless, with business men either unconcerned over the possibility or confident that a new law cannot pass, opinions expressed here yesterday indicated.

SUNDAY has somehow ceased, fairly suddenly, to be the day it used to be. One of the oldest of human institutions and one of the slowest to yield to change. Sunday has edged astonishingly far to the left in a single generation, as if making up for lost time.

THE successful rock gardener must first and foremost be a good propagator of those dwarf plants which find particular favor in his eyes. Many of the finest rock plants are comparatively short-lived, or are fickle under cultivation, and therefore it is desirable to have always at hand a stock of young plants to replace those which may succumb to the heat and humidity of our Summers or to the conditions in our hard Winters.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Brimful with confidence and determined to register the first "foreign victory" of the international series, ten British professional golfers started for the United States today to meet an American team in the fifth of the Ryder Cup series at Ridgewood N.J., Sept. 28-29.

THERE is a shortage of first rank musicians in the Soviet Union. Those who preside over the country's musical organizations admit the existence of the problem, despite the fact that the development of talent is stimulated on all sides.
VALETTA, Malta, Sept. 14. -- A sweeping censorship of the press was imposed by a government decree today. Two other ordinances also reflected the tension between Great Britain and Italy.
LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The existence of Italian designs on Egypt is held in influential quarters here to have been proved by today's defiant Cabinet pronouncement from Rome.

SOME books enrich the writer and nobody else. It is the reader of this book who will be rewarded. He will be introduced to a man who made history. Also, he will be tempted to ask himself whether such history is worth the making.

Dr. Henry R. Linville, who resigned as president of the Teachers Union along with other officers at a special meeting Friday, declared yesterday that conciliatory overtures by minority groups had been in reality "demands" which would have led to continuance of factional strife in the union.

DID America do as much for Lafayette as Lafayette did for America? It is a question well worth consideration, thinks Mr. Gottschalk, whose long, scholarly and judicial examination into his life before he embarked upon the venturesome enterprise of aiding the embattled Colonists has convinced him that America had upon Lafayette a very great and very beneficial influence.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Representative Charles F. Risk of Rhode Island, Republican, charged today that the Federal administration "is attempting to punish Rhode Island voters for having the temerity to vote for a Republican candidate for Congress."
CLEMENTON. N.J., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Three New Yorkers and a Texan reached the semi-finals of the George A. Crump Memorial Cup golf tournament over the difficult Pine Valley Country Club course today.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- A five-day freshman week program opened at Elmira College yesterday with a chapel address by the new president of the college, Dr. William S. A. Pott.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 14. -- President Lazaro Cardenas informed Rector Fernando Ocaranza today that the National University must be reorganized, "leaving its autonomy and legitimate functions, but not as a sovereign entity authorized to interpret the laws of the State, much less to oppose the laws' spirit."

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 14. -- Dr. Elizabeth G. Kimball of Benzonia, Mich., has been named adviser to a special group of fourteen freshmen who will enter Mount Holyoke College this week as members of a new two-unit study plan. An old New England homestead, Sycamore has been set aside for Dr. Kimball and the students, who come from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Kentucky, Ohio, Michigan and Illinois.

SANTA CLAUS, Ind., Sept. 14 (AP). -- A shrine to Santa Claus is being built at this Southern Indiana hamlet, bearing his name. Workmen moved about the task of landscaping the thirty-two-acre site today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Varuna, H.R. Robertson's sloop, defeated Spartan and Katharine today in the race for larger craft in the annual Fall regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. A fleet of fifty-nine boats competed over rough waters under cloudy skies.

WHITEFACE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The doctrine of "It can he done," a slogan of President Wilson's from which the administration has drawn inspiration for changes in methods of government, was broadcast from a mountain top today as President Roosevelt dedicated the Whiteface Mountain Highway, a memorial for New York State's soldiers who died in the World War.

It is strange how the New Dealers, composed of professors and members of the intelligentsia, disregard the opinions of philosophers of the past. Europeans were rather late in recognizing that America had produced one philosopher in the person of Ralph Waldo Emerson.

Take tornadoes. Nothing can more quickly shuck off the inherent trashiness of the modern frame of mind than to find yourself tossing about in one, somewhere between the Florida Coast and the Bahama Islands.

The Governor's Proclamation of "Constitution Day" urges its observance for the purpose of obtaining a better understanding of our fundamental law and its history "as the source "of our collective freedom and happi"ness," but a collective freedom that has in its guarantees individual liberties.

Mrs. James Russell Parsons, former vice chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, came out yesterday against the re-election of Chase Mellen Jr. as county chairman. In a letter to Morton Baum, leader of the Ninth Assembly District and a former supporter of Mr. Mellen, Mrs. Parsons, who was elected vice chairman two years ago at the same time that Mr. Mellen was elected chairman, characterized Mr. Mellen as conspicuously unfit for the chairmanship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Government records reveal that 55 cents of every dollar spent by city consumers for ten basic foods in August was distributed among processors transportation agencies, wholesalers, retailers and other food handlers.

THE University of Michigan's $5,000,000 windfall last week will enable it to offer exceptionally attractive opportunities in graduate work. The grant, made by the Horace H. Rackham and Mary A. Rackham Fund of Detroit, includes $1,000,000 for a new building and equipment and $4,000,000 for permanent endowment.

For many years the Soviet has been trying to solve a waif and stray problem presented by thousands of homeless urchins who wander in city and village streets, living by their wits and committing crimes that range from petty theft to murder.
ELKINS, W. Va., Sept. 14 (AP). -- The first frost bearded the high country today, warning the hill folk that the time was near to make the traditional obeisance to their elected Queen of Autumn.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Resignation of Dr. George Burgess Magrath, nationally known pathologist and medical examiner for the northern Suffolk County district for twenty-eight years, was announced tonight by Governor Curley.

The Summer play schools and day camps of the works project committee of the Board of Education will bring before the public tomorrow many potential designers of stage sets, actors, mural painters, modelers, engineers and other craftsmen among the 12,805 pupils who were enrolled.

ST. THOMAS, V.I. -- With the inauguration of Lawrence W. Cramer to succeed Paul M. Pearson as Governor temporary calm has come to the Virgin Islands, which for many months were torn by the bitter controversy over the Pearson administration.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The "biological regeneration" of the German people continues to engage National Socialist race experts to a degree that definitely threatens to make it a national fetish, and the slogan "Race, blood and soil" more recently is being reiterated with a vehemence born of Teutonic thoroughness in all things, whether they concern the soul, the body or the mind.

MRS. OVERBECK is the wife of a mining geologist and with him she has roamed the far corners of the earth, in jungles and deserts and on mountain tops, and in this book she tells about life in a mining camp up in the tops of the Andes, whither he was called "to run down a bit of tin in Bolivia."

BOMBAY. IF complete aeronautical education had been available in India, it would have been unnecessary for dozens of Indian students to proceed to England or America to obtain instruction in the higher arts of the profession, according to Captain A.T. Eden, principal of the proposed Aeronautical Training Centre to be opened in Delhi early next month.

" WE in America must rebuild our democratic system of managing ourselves. We operate a complicated social and economic machine. If we do not devise a method for controlling it wisely and surely the machine will run away with us.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14. -- All hail the king of the golf world:

As a result of the newsreel in which he told how he and five companions had killed Edwin Esposito, a B.M.T. collector, on Sept. 2, Salvatore (Duke) Scata, 18 years old, of 198 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, has been identified as being guilty of a murder in Philadelphia, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County announced yesterday.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The United States small-bore rifle team, firing in the R.W.S. Challenge Trophy match today, amassed 3,951 points out of a possible 4,000. This was only 20 points lower than the record for this match, made by the United States team in 1934.

To mark the spot where the late Wiley Post started and landed on his record-breaking solo flight around the world in seven days, a bronze plaque was unveiled yesterday afternoon at Floyd Bennett Field. The memorial was embedded in a nine-foot star of concrete, which had been set in the surface of the field between the apron and the east-west runway down which Post had charged the Winnie Mae to start his epochal flight.

There was once a great landowner whose vast properties were surrounded by many smaller ones. And a withering drought came upon the land. Crops were ruined, cattle perished of thirst and desolation was everywhere.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Eames MacVeagh, 60 years old, member of a prominent Chicago family, must pay $2,500 to Miss Louise Hagen, 47 years old, an artist, of Woodstock, N.Y. This ruling was made this afternoon by Municipal Judge Joseph H. McGarry in the suit brought by Miss Hagen to enforce a contract under which she alleged that Mr. MacVeagh had promised to pay her $250 a month for life.

THE author of this slender volume modestly disclaims any right to be called, in the technical sense, either a scientist, philosopher or a metaphysician. He calls himself, so far as actual knowledge is concerned, "a true agnostic," because he is ready to admit that "he knows nothing."

THIS first novel by a 22-year-old English woman is essentially an attempt -- and an unusually successful one -- to render articulate the dumb longings and inchoate meanderings of thought that attend ordinary adolescence.

Initiation last week of new gold movements to the United States from France and Holland in response to the continued weaknesses in the franc and the guilder, in terms of the dollar, has resulted in total gold engagements in Paris for our account of $20,553,000 and in Amsterdam in the amount of $13,230,000.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 14. -- Development of the new Rodessa oil field, uncovered a few weeks ago in Northwestern Louisiana, is already causing complications involving the production proration order of the Railroad Commission of Texas.

Outlines for the coming season's program in the National Council of Jewish Women emphasizes the "defense of liberal principles," Mrs. Marion M. Miller, executive director, said yesterday. A study of the repercussions of the Hitler regime in Germany and of the imperialistic attitude of Italy will be prominent, she stated, in the work of the council throughout the country.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Because Shanghai's foreign police raided a Japanese home here yesterday when looking for a suspect in a kidnapping, members of the local Japanese colony demanded today "vigorous action" against the Municipal Council and the governors of the International Settlement.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 14. -- The consistent gelding Luckite carried the colors of J.W.Y. Martin to a hard-earned victory in the two-and-a-half mile Piping Rock Cup race which featured the Fall meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association over the Rockaway Hunting Club course today.
SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Max Baer is a changed man.

The bitterness of some of the district leadership fights has moved Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to make special preparations for guarding the polls against violence at the primary election Tuesday. Both Democratic and Republican parties are involved in factional disputes, and in consequence extra details of uniformed men and detectives have been assigned.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13. WE can boast a theatrical season at the moment, what with a real show downtown and a real show in Hollywood. The downtown entry opened Monday night at the Belasco when Ina Claire began a fortnight's engagement in her last season's vehicle, "Ode to Liberty."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Officials scanning the latest reports of the prison population of the country predicted today that convicts in Federal penitentiaries would reach another new high this Fall.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14. -- Unusual interest is attached to this year's Autumn manoeuvres of the Red Army which began Thursday on a wide front west of Kiev and will continue four days.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 14 (AP). -- The Nebraska Methodist Church Conference today ousted the Rev. W.L. Hadsell of Lincoln by an overwhelming vote. The action was taken in executive session because of the refusal of Mr. Hadsell to make a final payment of $9 of his allotted assessment into the conference fund for aged ministers, their widows and children.
ROME, Ga., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Guns blazed in a pitched battle between pickets and a group of workers at the Rome Stove and Range Company today, one worker being fatally shot and three others wounded.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Return of warm weather had a deterrent effect on retail buying in the larger de partment stores this week, although volume as a whole measured up well with a year ago. One organization, which held a special sale and employed extensive newspaper space, drew 300,000 persons and was forced to carry over the sale to a second day.

SHANGHAI. -- With Japanese and Chinese cotton textile industries beckoning for raw material, China is making a stupendous effort to improve and enlarge her cotton production. It is hoped that with Japanese encouragement and assistance, especially in the northern provinces, China will be able to develop the cultivation of cotton to such an extent that Far Eastern cotton textile industries will be independent of foreign raw material.
