A piece of cargo that arrived two months ago at the Chelsea pier has refused to leave, and the pier staff has virtually abandoned hope of getting rid of it. The cargo in question is a small monkey that arrived from India July 10 in the American Pioneer liner City of Dalhart, escaped upon arrival and has since been footloose along the piers in the Chelsea district.

FOR the first time in more than two decades the peace of Europe lately has been closely linked with a threatened conflict in Africa Newspaper readers the world over have become suddenly aware of strangely named places near the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean where a large European army, equipped with the newest instruments of scientific devastation, has been concentrated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- There has been in recent months much speculation on the effect of the depression on health. Certain dramatic statements have been made indicating a severe breakdown, but on the whole the assumption has prevailed that the declining general death rate of the past few years has meant a state of physical well-being among our people.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14, -- Six persons were killed this afternoon when their automobile was struck by a Reading train at an unguarded crossing at Churchville, Bucks County. The wreckage was dragged fifty feet along the tracks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Widespread repercussions based on fears that thousands of local public works projects might be scrapped today enveloped President Roosevelt's revision of the $4,880,000,000 work relief program.

The luck of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, which has been the talk of the turf all season, was good enough yesterday to survive a bad start, a disqualification and a nose finish to give him his twenty-ninth stake victory of the season.

All communicants of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York are called on by Cardinal Hayes to receive Holy Communion on Sunday, Sept. 22, as an intention for the seventh National Eucharistic Congress to be held in Cleveland, Sept. 23-26, to which the Cardinal is the Papal legate. Cardinal Hayes will leave Sunday evening, Sept. 22, on a special train for Cleveland.

As a result of the tracing of twenty-four recent cases of typhoid fever to clams in the Canarsie area of Brooklyn, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, said yesterday that about 100 "beach combers" would be put to work removing the hard and soft shell clams from the sands there.

ALMOST all medicines are poisons. The difference between the lethal action of a potent drug and its curative action is the quantity of the substance administered. For this reason the science of posology (the study of the doses of drugs) has assumed vast importance in the practice of medicine.

The 1935-1936 year book for the Garden City Woman's Club, one of the largest of the women's clubs in Nassau County, numbering 325 members, and a member of both the State and Long Island Federations of Women's Clubs, is now in the mails. It lists the new executive board and the new standing committees for the season's activities, as well as the program.

ATHENS, Sept. 12. -- Only former King George's attitude to a restoration by force as undesirable and a popular referendum as necessary now holds suspended the deathblow to the Greek Republic and the creation of a constitutional monarchy.
McCLURE, Pa., Sept. 14 (AP). -- In a direct attack Colonel Theodore Roosevelt today labeled President Roosevelt a "faithless" public officer.

PARIS. SEVERAL interesting and really new outlines have been revealed by the Paris Winter fashion openings. Some of these will be immediately adopted, while others are worth watching because they forecast the future, though they will probably make very little impression on the mode as a whole before next Spring.

There was a melancholy air over 422 East Third Street yesterday where, in the second-floor flat, Mrs. Sophie Dorsey, 24-year-old mother of four children, had been served with an eviction notice for nonpayment of rent. Her mother, Mrs. Elizabeth Geary, janitress of the building, and a few neighbors had dropped in to express differing viewpoints on the tactics to be used in meeting it.

HAVANA. -- Cuba will soon have an army of women in uniform, an unprecedented step on this island, where women have won but never yet exercised the right to vote, if plans of the military authorities now organizing the Women's Military Reserve are carried to completion.

TO arouse the interest of ardent Wordsworthians it is only necessary to say that in this volume, to be followed by two more, Ernest de Selincourt has most ably brought together, after long and careful garnering, the extant letters of William and Dorothy Wordsworth, addressed to a wide circle of correspondents, and, during periods of separation to each other.

THERE is not much room for argument in discussing the pestilential spread of the double-feature program, lately climaxed and solidified when the great Loew and R-K-O theatre chains formally adopted the practice.

Net profit of the Timken Detroit Axle Company and subsidiaries for the first half of this year amounted to $397,425 after Federal taxes, depreciation and other charges. This is equivalent after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock to 31 cents a share on 980,000 shares of $10 par common stock.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Harold Halsted of Moriches Bay turned in his most convincing triumph today to carry off the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship for the second year in a row.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- Quaint vehicles, silhouetted in black against white walls, hunting scenes with the dash of pink coats, white barriers and the sorrel of mounted horses, formed a background tonight for the Wissahickon Hunt Ball at which nearly 1,000 guests danced in the Wissahickon Farms Clubhouse at Whitemarsh.

ROOSEVELT FEILD, L.I., Sept. 14. -- With all dials of the conventional navigating instruments hidden from the pilot and sealed by a representative of the National Aeronautical Association, a Lockheed Vega monoplane flown by Ray Brown and belonging to the General Tire and Rubber Company, left Roosevelt Field this morning for Albany.

THE International Exhibition of Persian Art at the Hermitage Museum, if not quite equal in magnificence and intensity to the London Exhibition of Persian Art in 1931, far surpasses it in comprehensiveness and also in historical importance.

MANUEL GALVEZ has played the role of a sensitive barometer of tribulations, social injustices and the brutality of men against each other since he first set himself the task of revealing the weaknesses of the educational system in Argentina, when he had barely reached the age of 27.

The record of the divorce of Jack Dempsey and Estelle Taylor In Reno in 1931 was produced in the Federal court yesterday at the trial of James C. McKay and William J. Graham of Reno, Nev., on charges of use of the mails to defraud in connection with alleged operations of an international swin dle ring. The trial is before Judge Robert J. McMillan of Texas and a jury.

THIS book should have a warm welcome at the hands of all those who are "fed up" with vanity and ignorance masquerading as scientific omniscience on the subject of race, with prejudice concealing itself behind pretense of scientific knowledge, with all the sinister hodge-podge of assertion, prophecy, pseudo-science, sentiment, theories spun out of ignorant assumptions that for many a year have been proclaimed to a too docile public as simon-pure scientific conclusions on racial qualities.

THE Czech musical public is mourning the loss of Otakar Ostrcil, who died last month in Prague, where he was for fifteen years chief conductor of the Czech National Theatre. Mr. Ostrcil was also a composer of note. He was 57.

NOW that business has been promised a breathing spell the prospects for musical entertainment are considerably brighter. From the business point of view these carousals are the riskiest ventures our theatre merchants take.

NEARLY a century and a half ago Pierre Samuel du Pont de Nemours, member of a solid French Huguenot family that had risen to distinction in the final days of the old monarchy, toyed with the idea of taking up land in Kentucky and establishing an estate -- almost a State -- which he would call Pontiana.

A HUNDRED years ago tomorrow Charles Darwin first landed from the warship Beagle on Chatham Islands in the Galapagos Archipelago, which lies some 500-odd miles west of America under the Equator. "By far the most important event in my life," he wrote in his pocketbook, the one which "has determined my whole career."

Two men went into the Essex House, apartment hotel at 160 Central Park South, shortly after noon yesterday, ascended nineteen floors in an elevator and entered the apartment of Miss June Knight, stage and screen actress. They bound and gagged Miss Knight and her maid and walked out with about $4,950 in jewels and $50 cash.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 14. -- Anybody who wants a title can buy one now in the "Nobility of the United States" if he has the money -- S200,000 to $1,000,000, depending on the rank he picks.

MR. MYERS'S early novels "The Orissers" and "The Clio" have been praised by a few, but now he is about to be read by a large and appreciative audience. There can be no doubt that once the charming introduction has been begun with little Prince Jail on the palace balcony watching the drama of the snake in the gutter, the reader will continue with increasing enjoyment and respect.

DALLAS, Sept. 14. -- With favorable weather prevailing throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, retail trade continues good all over the territory. Dry goods and clothing merchants report sales approximately 15 per cent above those for the corresponding period last year.

THE principal causes of the lamentable decrease of the valuable forms of American wild life from a state of almost incredible abundance are two: (1) Too much shooting and trapping by a constantly increasing number of sportsmen and (2) the accompanying destruction of wild life habitats by agriculture, drainage, deforestation and pollution.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13. -- Penniless Americans of the old stock, driven from Oklahoma, Arkansas, Texas and other States by the depression and the drought, have been pouring into California for eighteen months past in broken-down flivvers, and are today providing the tens of thousands of fruit and vegetable pickers required to harvest the State's crops.

DETROIT, Sept. 13. -- In Detroit, where every one regards Henry Ford as a neighbor, the news that he has been suggested as the Republican Presidential nominee in 1936 by a group of University of Pennsylvania professors caused little comment.
Russell Kent is in error when he says that the Presidential power to adjourn Congress was contained in the Pinckney plan.

FAR more than Katharine Brush and her imitators, Fannie Ferber Fox is wholly a woman's writer. These slick, perceptive short stories, whose locale is mostly Chicago or small Middle Western towns, are devoted to the pettier aspects of feminine character and to the kind of observation which a woman best appreciates.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- Schiaparelli has a striking novelty in afternoon handbags; this new model is constructed like eighteenth century saddlebags; the supple section, which in its prototype was slung over the horse's back, is draped over the wrist.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- A plan for reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad Company under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Law without need for raising new capital was submitted today to Federal Judge John P. Barnes in the United States District Court here. Consummation of the plan would require the use of $82,000 of the estimated $850,000 cash in the treasury on Jan. 1, 1936.
The Insurance Advertising Conference will begin its annual three-day conference tomorrow morning at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y. The executive committee will meet this evening.

IN an article printed on this page last Sunday, a motorist who preferred to identify himself publicly by his initials, S.P.M., reported that, after keeping records for five years, he had found that the direct cost of operating an automobile averaged about 2 1/2 cents a mile and that, with depreciation included, but not license fees, insurance and garaging, the cost per mile was in the neighborhood of 3 1/2 cents.

ALTHOUGH the catalogues of the various colleges list their respective curricula with confusing exactitude, no space therein is ever given to that part of undergraduate life which probably ranks as high in importance in the mind of the average new student as anything else -- the proper wardrobe for him to select.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 14. -- The beginning of an ambitious political adventure the ultimate aim of which is the overthrow of French rule An Syria and the fusion of Palestine and Syria under some Arab Prince has come to light this week through a series of incidents in which the intelligence service of Syria took no small part.

UNDERTAKEN as emergency measures, the adult education programs are evolving as a permanent phase of the American educational system. Reports from nearly every State of the Union indicate that adults are taking an increasing interest in community life and are returning to the schools in unprecedented numbers.

The committee on stock list of the York Stock Exchange called yesterday on the fiscal agents of foreign governments and their political subdivisions to expedite the permanent registration of foreign bonds before March 31, 1936, the deadline fixed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The cosmogonists have been in distress ever since they discovered that the universe is expanding like a soap bubble blown up by Sir JAMES JEANS'S mathematical god. It must have begun expanding about 10,000 million years ago, according to the most popular estimate. But the stars are far older.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- More than 100 British warships -- about the third biggest navy afloat if compared with the entire fleet strength of the United States and Japan -- were believed by diplomats to be concentrated tonight in the Mediterranean. Their officers awaited developments in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

Sports editors and fight experts from Boston to California, eyewitnesses to the greatest accomplishments of both warriors, pick Joe Louis by a ratio of almost two to one to knock out Max Baer in the Yankee Stadium a week from Tuesday night.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- More than 100 British warships -- about the third biggest navy afloat if compared with the entire fleet strength of the United States and Japan -- were believed by diplomats to be concentrated tonight in the Mediterranean. Their officers awaited developments in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

Sports editors and fight experts from Boston to California, eyewitnesses to the greatest accomplishments of both warriors, pick Joe Louis by a ratio of almost two to one to knock out Max Baer in the Yankee Stadium a week from Tuesday night.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Except for a contest in Haverstraw Township on naming Republican committeemen, Rockland County is free of contests in the primary election set for next Tuesday. For the first time in years the Democratic party is holding over all committeemen in the county.

Far from enjoying a "breathing spell," business is just beginning to feel the effects of the legislation passed by Congress during its recent session, according to Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation.

SEPTEMBER'S air is a tonic for short waves. No better proof lurks in the air than the signals of ZHI, Singapore, which flashed across 12,400 miles to register in New York. It was detected on the 6,010 kilocycle channel one morning at 5:30 o'clock.

Stuffed baby alligators, Dresden china shepherdesses, wigs, false mustaches, whistles, socks, bridal veils, the complete works of Shakespeare and similar items were disposed of last Tuesday at the auction sale held in the lobby of the main New York Postoffice.

This folk tale relates four episodes in the youth of Yen-Foh, the quick-witted youth who, according to tradition, grew up to be a sage of old China. Even as a boy he knew how to think his way out of predicaments and he was equally helpful when his friends were in trouble.

I have read with interest, as I do all his writings, R.L. Duffus's recent review of "The Magnate," Hermann Hagedorn's lively volume on my friend, the late William Boyce Thompson. Mr. Duffus has, however, seemed to gain from this volume certain impressions that are quite contrary to the observations and convictions of Mr. Thompson's own friends.

Stuffed baby alligators, Dresden china shepherdesses, wigs, false mustaches, whistles, socks, bridal veils, the complete works of Shakespeare and similar items were disposed of last Tuesday at the auction sale held in the lobby of the main New York Postoffice.

This folk tale relates four episodes in the youth of Yen-Foh, the quick-witted youth who, according to tradition, grew up to be a sage of old China. Even as a boy he knew how to think his way out of predicaments and he was equally helpful when his friends were in trouble.

I have read with interest, as I do all his writings, R.L. Duffus's recent review of "The Magnate," Hermann Hagedorn's lively volume on my friend, the late William Boyce Thompson. Mr. Duffus has, however, seemed to gain from this volume certain impressions that are quite contrary to the observations and convictions of Mr. Thompson's own friends.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Despite her need of raw materials and semi-manufactured goods for war purposes, Italy is buying less and less in the British market, it is revealed by Board of Trade figures for .August, published tonight.

ATHENS, Sept. 14. -- Former King George, through a monarchist intermediary, declined today to cooperate with Royalist leaders in their proposed restoration by a vote of Parliament, whose members are all Royalists. The former King emphasized once again that only a national referendum that showed the support of the whole people would satisfy him.

A minor historical fact of some present interest, which has been very rarely recorded, is that in the only war this country ever waged in Africa the United States Navy had Italy as an ally. When at Tripoli in 1804 the American fleet under Commodore Preble attacked the pirate stronghold, it was helped by six small gunboats and two bomb ketches manned by Italian crews under command of American officers.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, arrived from Geneva last night to find himself the hero of peace societies, churchmen and all the Liberals and Socialists who have been finding fault with the government for its foreign policy in the past four years or more.
PANAMA, R.P., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Searchers completed a fifteen-hour jungle trek late today to report the discovery of a wrecked commercial plane with all eight occupants dead.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and last distributions ordered by directors:

BELIEVE it or doubt it, there are some amazing things to be learned from the Yogi of India. We have Mr. Paul Brunton's word for it, backed up by the testimony of Sir Francis Younghusband, who writes a foreword to this record of a search for the secret of India's spirituality.

Japan's most important consideration today is the preservation of peace, according to an article by Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, appearing in the current issue of the magazine Asia. The article, dealing principally with Japanese-American trade relations, is entitled "What Japan Wants."

EXCEPT when presented as a ballet, to which it was adapted and from which our favorite passage was excluded, Rimsky-Korsakoff's Op. 35, otherwise the symphonic suite "Scheherazade," seldom does more than merely irritate us.

A plea for the extension of the "breathing spell" for business to the cigar-manufacturing industry by eliminating the AAA processing tax on cigar-leaf tobaccos was made in a letter to President Roosevelt, sent by Howard S. Cullman of Cullman Brothers, Inc., 161 Front Street, tobacco dealers. The letter was made public yesterday.

SOME cleverer critic may some day devise a fitting name for that genre in current literature which is a combination of history and fiction, or of biography and fiction. The time-honored terms of historical novel and biographical novel do not apply here, since such works are obviously history or biography with a dash of fiction.

In reply to Mr. Gladwell's reply to my letter of the week previous in which I mentioned the possible unpleasant effects brought upon children's minds through reading glorified war stories, I wish to clear from Mr. Gladwell's mind a slight misapprehension.

RESCUE of the sunrise margin of Manhattan Island from the blight which fell upon it when the lustily growing city swarmed northward after 1830 and buried its rustic landscape under bricks and mortar -- this is one of the purposes of the new East River Drive, ground for the first section of which was ceremonially broken by Mayor La Guardia a few days ago.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 14. -- A new German religion, with God manifesting Himself in an invincible German nation and with Adolf Hitler its modern prophet, appeared in the making tonight if Nazi party convention events and utterances could be taken as indications.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A feeling that, barring accidents, the Federal Government is out of the woods on its financing problems has begun to pervade the Treasury Department. Mid-September probably will be looked back upon as the beginning of a comparative respite after two and a half strenuous years in which the government had to refund about $14,473,000,000 of maturing obligations and borrow $9,509,000,000 of additional cash.

Striking radio operators of the American Radio Telegraphists Association continued yesterday to picket steamship lines that have not signed wage and working condition agreements, and last night held a large outdoor meeting in Front Street between the Whitehall and Atlantic Avenue ferry houses.

World industrial production continued to advance during July, improvement being general in practically all sections except South and Central America, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board. World prices of international staples, as reflected by a composite index, remained unchanged.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 15. -- With the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, using the slain Senator's "martyrdom" for leverage, seeking to succeed Huey P. Long at the head of a national movement for redistribution of wealth, enemies of the Long machine, aiming to offset the Long influences in every field possible, moved today to create a rival martyr.

Warning against the creation of new industrial and residential slums with the resumption of building construction here, the City Club of New York yesterday urged sweeping changes in the present zoning regulation which would drastically reduce "the excessive building heights and density of population now permitted within the city."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15. -- In the presence of a record crowd of 43,000 roaring St. Louisians, baseball's celebrated "Gas House Gang" ran out of gas today as an inspired Giant team hammered its way to its third straight victory over the Cardinals by a score of 7 to 3.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky, whose criticism from the bench of the swastika emblem brought a formal expression of regret from Secretary Hull, found a defender yesterday in the ranks of his colleagues. Magistrate Nathan D. Perlman told the second annual conference of the Association of Hungarian Jews of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania that he saw "no reason for Judge Brodsky to apologize for what he said."

The Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, dean of Canterbury Cathedral and one of England's, outstanding liberal churchmen, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic to lend his dynamic personality to the advancement of the social credit idea in Canada.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 52 per cent of capacity, 1 point above the previous high rate in this movement, in the week ended on Aug. 24. Meanwhile a slight decrease had occurred because of the holiday.

The first major move toward putting into practice the program of individualized instruction projected for the city school system by Dr. Harold G, Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, will be taken today with the distribution to teachers and principals of a selected list of 174 books on progressive teaching methods.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- German comment on trade development in the United States on the whole is favorable, since it is believed here that the collapse of the NRA system of codes will foster recovery through private initiative. Apart from the upward movement of the stock market, the steadiness of which impresses observers here, the principal stress is laid on the revival of the capital market.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Prices of hogs moved erratically here last week, advancing to $12.25 a hundredweight on Wednesday, a jump of 15 cents, as the top, while $12 was the best price at the close of the week. The range the previous week was $11.90 to $12.20 and the close was at the lowest figure, $11.90.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, eldest son of the late President Roosevelt and former Governor General of the Philippines, will join the publishing house of Doubleday, Doran Co. of Garden City, it was announced this afternoon by Nelson Doubleday at Woodside, the Roosevelt Summer home in the Cove Neck section.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- After losing the first three games of' the series with Washington, the Indians came back today to down the Senators in both ends of a double-header, 16 to 4 and 6 to 3.

Weakness in the Holland guilder stood out as the most important price change of the week's trading in the foreign currencies. It touched a low of 67.32 cents on Friday, lowest since July 27. There was a collateral break in the futures market, 90-day forwards selling at a discount of 320 points.

In a brief filed with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and made public here yesterday, the cigar manufacturing industry maintained that the processing tax on cigar leaf tobacco should be abandoned because the price of the leaf is now touching parity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A sharp attack on the government's attempt through the AAA to regulate production was made today by the American Liberty League, which stated that even Soviet Russia had not devised a more complete system of control than that embodied in the so-called potato act.

A painting by Charles R. Knight depicting the astronomical mythology of the Blackfeet Indians will face the main entrance to the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, it was said there yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Eighteen letter men from last year's team were among the sixty-five candidates for the 1935 Princeton football team who reported to Coach Fritz Crisler at the Osborne Field House today preparatory to the opening of Fall practice tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Bainbridge Colby, leader of a movement for a Jeffersonian revival of Democracy, has recalled his acceptance to address the American Legion Convention in St. Louis. He did so after some Legion leaders had indicated that his presence at the convention might stir up partisan political feeling.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Jock Whitney's Greentree riders galloped into the final of the national open polo championship on International Field today with a stunning upset of the favored Templeton team, last year's champions and the strongest sort of favorite to repeat this year.

If Mr. STALIN were looking about for proof that Moscow is not interfering in our domestic affairs he might call Secretary HULL'S attention to the smash-up of the local Teachers Union. The recent Comintern Congress at Moscow proclaimed the new policy of a common front between Communists on the one hand and all labor, democratic and liberal elements on the other hand.

Setting the pace throughout, a Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club quartet composed of William and Robert Allen and Merrill and Jack Fink downed the Fort Jay four, 12 -- 3, as the preliminary round of the ninth annual Second Corps Area fifteen-goal invitation polo tournament ended yesterday at Governors Island. A crowd of 1,500 looked on.

Members to serve on the National Women's Committee of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, selected because of "acknowledged leadership in civic and welfare service over a period of years," were announced here yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as chairman of the women's committee, after a conference with Gerard Swope, chairman of the mobilization in its third year.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15. -- At the grand ball of Baltimore's historic Fifth Maryland Regiment here last night, some inconsiderate person had the audacity to steal the saber worn by Brig. Gen. John Philip Hill, under appointment from Governor Harry W. Nice. The general is adjutant general of the Maryland National Guard.

Park and recreation facilities throughout the State have been developed and improved more comprehensively since 1931 than in previous boom years as a result of the work relief program set up to help the unemployed, a report of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration declared yesterday.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15. -- The unveiling today of the monument to the Rev. Franjo Bulic, Croat archaeologist, who until his death two years ago had worked on excavation of the Roman city of Salona, near Spalato, was turned into a demonstration of reawakened Croatian nationalism.

Karin Hardt plays the leading part in "Acht Maedchen im Boot," the current offering at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre. This is the German original of Paramount's production of "Eight Girls in a Boat," which was shown to New York audiences in January, 1934.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- The Most Reverend William Temple, Archbishop of York, and Professor Corrado Gini, Italian statistician, are among the eighteen scholars from American and European universities who are to be visiting members of the Harvard faculty this year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Roaring along under full steam and with the encouragement of 30,000 howling North Side fans, the superheated Cubs today flattened the Dodgers, 6 -- 3, to sweep the series, extend their winning streak to an even dozen contests and increase their hold on first place to two games over the Cardinals.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Theodore Kowaleski, a 33-year-old member of the local police force who completed a four-year high school course last June while working nights on his regular police beat, will enter Wesleyan University next Thursday to begin a pre-medical course preparatory to entering Tufts Medical School.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Entertaining for Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best and Lady Best and the other officers from H.M.S. York continued today.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Easier conditions noticed in the money market here last week became more marked this week. Interest on call money fell from 2 5/8 to 1 3/4 per cent. Loans against defense bonds fell from 3-3 1/8 to 211-16-2 3/4 per cent.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 15. -- National Socialist Germany definitely flung down the gauntlet before the feet of Western liberal opinion tonight when the Reichstag, assembled for a special session here in connection with the "Party Day of Freedom," decreed a series of laws that put Jews beyond the legal and social pale of the German nation, and in token of this act proclaimed the swastika banner to be the sole flag of the German Reich.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- National aspects are involved in Pennsylvania's primary election next Tuesday.

About 134,900 free rides, or 67,450 round trips, between city parks and the congested tenement districts of Manhattan and the Bronx were provided for children of the poor by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in July and August.

The sharp upswing in retail buying recently in various sections of the country was reflected in all branches of the wholesale market here last week. With consumer response to the new Fall merchandise offerings heavier than anticipated, buyers arrived in the market in large numbers to cover their immediate needs and to place advance orders as prices strengthened.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The depression in the financial markets caused by international politics showed signs of lifting this weekend. Applauded although it was, the firm adherence of the British Government to the covenant of the League of Nations, as expressed at Geneva, clarified the position only as it concerned Great Britain.
A furnished apartment consistingI of fifteen rooms and six baths in 1,060 Fifth Avenue was leased by L. Elliman Co. to Theo-I Douglas dore W. Case of Auburn, N. Y. Other new rentals follow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Charged with combining to control retail meat prices from 1927 to 1933, ten major packing companies will be called upon to answer tomorrow to Secretary Wallace.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig criticized the newspapers of the United States for news distortion and assailed the American motion-picture industry for retarding world understanding, in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

Commodity futures generally were higher last week, although movements were mostly erratic. Coffee futures, after a sharp advance in the first part of the week, turned reactionary but closed at a net gain for the week. In the cash markets wheat, oats, coffee, mess pork, tin, silk and wool tops were higher, while corn, rye, flour, lard, cotton and rubber were lower.

Open-air folk dancing was given in Washington Square yesterday afternoon by members of the American Folk Group of the Folk Festival Council of New York in peasant and rustic costumes. About 2,000 persons, shepherded by employes of the Park Department and special police squads, looked on while the dancers dipped and whirled.

When Sir MALCOLM CAMPBELL warns against the dangers of speeding, that's news. Having himself traveled jauntily at the rate of 301 miles an hour, he is entitled to an opinion on the subject. It is that fast driving has no place on regular highways. His own country has recently established speed limits of 30 miles an hour in built-up areas.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,227,188,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The imminence of war between Italy and Ethiopia, with Europe perhaps involved, prompted more than one member of the clergy to warn their congregations yesterday that they must choose between peace and war.

Ingot production virtually equaled the high record of 54 1/2 per cent for this year to date, established in the first half of February, when it rose 2 points to 54 per cent of capacity last week, according to the magazine Steel. The publication also says that prices in general have been maintained for the fourth quarter without formal announcement.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A series of upsets marked opening matches of the men's singles in the Pacific Southwest tennis championships today.

To Harlem falls the dubious distinction of having the most densely populated block in the city. The area, containing 3,871 tenement residents, is bounded by 142d and 143d Streets and Lenox and Seventh Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- As an indication that few of the large State banks, not members of the Federal Reserve System, will withdraw from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, that organization announced today that the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, with resources of $476,000,000, and the Franklin Savings Bank, with resources of $97,000,000, both of New York City, had announced their intention of retaining their membership in the FDIC.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 15. -- Francis Grubb, county detective, who drew dark inferences yesterday from the fact that the only fingerprints on the revolver that killed Miss Evelyn Hoey last Wednesday night at the Summer home of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d, were her own, has reverted to his original theory on the case.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The American Federation of Utility Investors has voted to expand its program to include the championing of the interests of investors in all recognized industries. It henceforth will be known as the American Federation of Investors.

ROME, Sept. 14. -- The recent action in raising the discount rate of the Bank of Italy to 5 per cent forms a part of the measures that all governments regularly take in case of war. It is noteworthy, however, that government securities here have not suffered the slump that was expected as a consequence.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 15. -- Adolf Hitler's Reichstag, stung by the strictures of a New York magistrate against the Nazi emblem, tonight pronounced the swastika to be the Reich's sole flag, hurled defiance to Jews throughout the world and limited German citizenship to members of the Germanic race.

An estimate that more than $258,000,000 annually is saved for the taxpayers of the nation in the cost of elementary and high school education by Catholic schools and teachers was made yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Michael A. Reilly, pastor of St. Barnabas Church, Woodlawn, the Bronx.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 15. -- In the best workout he has had since he opened his camp, and before a crowd of 4,500 which set a new record for attendance, Joe Louis went through seven sizzling rounds of boxing today in preparation for his fight with Max Beer a week from Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP). -- First Baseman Gus Suhr equaled the National League record for consecutive games today as Pittsburgh beat Philadelphia, 5 to 3, in the final appearance of the Phils at Forbes Field.
MANILA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A salvo of predictions that Manuel Quezon would be elected first President of the Philippine Commonwealth next Tuesday marked the campaign rallies here tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The Military Order of the World War, commissioned officers who served during the conflict and those who rose to that rank before the formal declaration of peace in 1921, opened its fifteenth annual convention here today.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES account of the luncheon at the Hotel Astor in honor of George Lathan it is said:

John S. Schubert, 28 years old, of 64-32 Palmetto Street, Ridgewood, Queens, was killed at 6:30 A.M. yesterday on Metropolitan Avenue, Maspeth, near Fifty-sixth Street, when an automobile he had tried to stop after it had struck another man pinned him against a pole at the curb.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Sewell L. Avery, president of Montgomery Ward Co., urged stockholders today in a letter accompanying the semi-annual report to use their votes in an effort to end "burdensome and inequitable taxes."

The sudden intrusion of business into art delayed the operatic death of Aida for nearly half an h0ur last night at a performance by Alfredo Salmaggi's Chicago Opera Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Egbert Moxham's sloop Jester defeated nine Interclub rivals today in a special regatta conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.
Johnny Murphy, to the delight of 20,000 fans at the Stadium yester-I day, sent the league-leading TigersI away with a defeat on their last visit of the American League season here.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- By dint of late rallies, the Athletics broke even with the White Sox today. They won the second game in ten innings, 7 to 5, after losing the first, 8 to 2.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 15. -- Before the golf clan scattered from The Country Club there were gatherings on the terrace and in the grill, where the youngsters and veterans swapped tales of the links.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Reds made it four out of five in the season's final series with the Braves, winning both ends of a double-header today, 1 to 0 and 7 to 6, before 13,000 fans.

A snoring man, seeking surcease from the city's mad whirl on a bench in the Fourteenth Street West Side subway station, was the bait between 3 and 6 o'clock yesterday morning for a police trap that collected seven subway pickpockets.

On the eve of tomorrow's primary election, David B. Costuma, Commissioner of Elections and leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, declared yesterday against the re-election of Chase Mellen Jr. as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

Tammany, which has district leadership contests in sixteen of the twenty-three Assembly districts in Manhattan, was preparing yesterday for a series of warmly contested battles in the primary election tomorrow. In each of these districts the contestants plan closing meetings tonight and the clubhouses yesterday were filled with workers getting last-hour instructions.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hayden Channing entertained tonight at dinner at The Ledge, Lenox. The guests were Mrs. Channing's mother, Mrs. J. Frederick Schenck; Mrs. Ross Winans Whistler, Miss Kate Cary, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, Mr. and Mrs. George Higginson, Harris Fahnestock, Giraud Foster and George L. Kingsland.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Dr. Robert Hockman of Wheaton, Ill., will leave this capital in a few days with the first foreign medical unit for the northern military front.

Steps toward international stabilization of currency as essential to world recovery are urged by Sir Arthur Salter, English financial expert, writing in the October issue of Foreign Affairs. Because there are important reasons against permanent stabilization at this time, Sir Arthur suggests what he thinks would be an acceptable system midway between the present instability and complete and rigid stabilization.

"This church has always been favored, by the grace of God, with able and consecrated pastors," the Rev. Dr. Arthur Brunn of Brooklyn, president of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synodical Conference, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, West Forty-sixth Street, just west of Eighth Avenue.

'Tis a beautiful afternoon as I sit on a bench in Union Square. The Communists are raving about their fantastic theory. The leaves on the trees are yet green, Irish rose trees are still blooming and the grass is greener than it was this time last year. The drought then affected all the land.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- No observer returning to London after a period spent amid verbal technicalities and diplomatic fencing at Geneva could fail to be impressed by an increasing tenseness in public sentiment created by developments in the Ethiopian quarrel.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Confronted by a formidable field, Tupelo, sprightly chestnut gelding from Mrs. Julius Bliss's string of capable jumpers, gave an excellent performance to capture the hunter championship sweepstakes, a feature of the fifth annual Lawrence Farms Hunt Club horse show today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A steady increase in residential building in thirty-seven States east of the Mississsippi was hailed today by Colonel F. Charles Starr of the Chicago Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, who remarked that as usual after depressions returning prosperity was well under way before the fact was generally realized.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 68.4 on Sept. 11. This compares with 67.9 a fortnight before, 67.3 a month before, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The first meeting of the Fall and Winter season of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., was held yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor, Mrs. Clara I. Austin of East Orange, N.J., the president, presiding. It was the twenty-second anniversary of the society.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Private conversations between Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, and Pierre Laval, French Premier, when both were at Geneva last week were of historical importance, the writer is able to reveal.

The horoscope of HAMLIN GARLAND could not have been confidently cast, since the exact date of his birth is not certainly known. "Who's Who" gives it as Sept. 16, but he himself insists that it was the 14th. Either way, no horoscope cast seventy-five years ago could have foretold such a career as his has been.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The return of the Bank of France this week made a good impression in financial circles. Not only did note circulation and sight liabilities show a heavy decrease after the month-end expansion, but the gold reserve, which already had risen more than 130,000,000 francs last week, rose another 315,000,000, thereby causing the gold-cover ratio to rise from 74.68 to 75.37 per cent.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- New champions in both the men's and women's divisions were crowned today in the Metropolitan Archery Association title tournament. The competition brought out one of the largest fields in several seasons.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 15. -- Every possible preparation is being made to protect the vital artery of the British Empire -- the Suez Canal. The British Admiralty and Royal Air Force are rushing warships and planes to Egypt.

Plans for a business building to replace two dwellings in the midtown area were announced over the week-end in connection with the sale of 626 and 628 Lexington Avenue, near the corner of Fifty-third Street. The houses were sold by Annie E. Horn, executrix of the Horn estate, to the Throndock Realty Corporation, which will raze the residences and erect a two-story structure immediately.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 15. -- Two thousand shrieking Ethiopians clamored before the Imperial Palace today, begging Emperor Haile Selassie for arms and shouting: "We want war!"

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A prospective demand for a Congressional investigation of the heavy loss of life among veterans in the recent Florida hurricane, and the ever-present bonus issue were paramount questions before delegates arriving tonight for the annual convention of Veterans of Foreign Wars.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- For the first time since the Italian Government began its preparations for war against Ethiopia, French opinion as reflected by the press became conscious today that there was real danger of a war of much greater magnitude than Premier Mussolini has proposed and that in one way or another France must become involved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A warning against pressure by political and group interests to bring about artificially higher price levels which might eventually react adversely to producers themselves was voiced today in a report by the Brookings Institution on the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's results in control of the dairying and livestock industries.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The normal responsibilities of the Presidency were displaced in Mr. Roosevelt's routine day by the duties of his position as a leader in the religious life of this small community where he has been for several years senior warden of St. James Episcopal Church.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals, newly crowned International League champions, advanced another step toward the play-off finals today by defeating Buffalo, 3 to 0, to take the lead in their preliminary series.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- More than 15,000 persons visited Camp Smith today when Governor Herbert H. Lehman reviewed the 369th Infantry of Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Hundreds of Negro women in New York City will obtain emergency employment under the Works Progress Administration, which will place them as housekeepers and practical nurses in the homes of families on the relief rolls in Staten Island and the Borough of Queens, where either one or both parents of the household are afflicted with illness or other disability.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A million-dollar issue of "peace bonds," described as an "investment in peace" and offered to the American people by the National Council for Prevention of War, with thirty-one affiliated organizations, will go on sale tomorrow.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP). -- State Tax Commissioner Mark Graves today criticized the "carping and fault-finding attitude toward the Roosevelt administration by Republican party chiefs who," he said, "are forced to admit that in the State and nation we are definitely recovering from the depression."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15. -- Paraguay has ordered mobilization of five classes of reserves. Diplomatic circles are admittedly perturbed because this action appears to be a violation of the peace protocol of June 12 which terminated the Chaco war.

Today is the last day for payment of the city sales tax for the third period, Controller Frank J. Taylor reminded business men yesterday. He recalled that the date for payment for the third period was advanced to yesterday by a recently enacted local law, but because yesterday was Sunday, he will accept returns postmarked as late as midnight tonight without any penalty.

The Navy Department is preparing to develop the Naval Reserve by the training and drilling of a limited number of officers of merchant ships at sea and at designated shore stations. Sufficient funds will be sought from Congress next year to put the plan into effect.

When voters from New Jersey go to the polls tomorrow to nominate candidates for election to the State Legislature in November they will pass upon the tax policies of Governor Harold G. Hoffman, who was elected to office in a brilliant Republican victory last year.

The appointment of a committee to direct the effort to have the 1937 American Legion convention held here was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. Frank L. Polk was named general chairman of the committee and Robert E. Condon was appointed executive chairman.

A world-wide revival among Christians of the ancient practice of "tithing," the payment to God and the church of one-tenth of a person's net income, was urged by the Rev. Oscar Lowry, Chicago evangelist, in a sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15. -- The Red Army revealed yesterday a new method of warfare in the shape of a mass parachute attack from the "Blue" planes upon the rear of the defending "Red" forces in the Ukrainian manoeuvres near Kiev.

The British dinghy sailors who will oppose the Long Island Sound Frostbite skippers in the first series of international races here later in the month arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic. They brought with them the craft with which they will seek the honors.

DETROIT. Sept. 15. -- Major Alexander P. De Seversky of Farmingdale, L.I., bettered the world speed record for amphibian planes by thirty-nine miles an hour at the Wayne County Airport today when he drove his 710-horsepower craft 230.03 miles an hour over a three-kilometer course.

Temper and worry are "the two greatest causes of human misery," Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at high mass yesterday morning when he directed the congregation to "cultivate the habit of gratitude" and to beg God for "a cheerful heart, an even temper and a gentle mind."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The Public Health Service painted mosquitoes in its search for a way to prevent airplanes from bringing the disease-bearing pests into this country.

In your editorial on railroads I notice the statement: "It is in the heavy industries that the greater part of our unemployment exists, and a large section of these industries is closely dependent on railroad prosperity."

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Major crimes as a whole decreased 7 per cent during the first half of 1935, Department of Correction statistics revealed today. The figures were made public in a semi-annual report by Frank A. Leonard, department statistician, to Dr. Walter N. Thayer, Commissioner of Correction.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 15 (AP). -- European and United States balloonists started today the twenty-third James Gordon Bennett international balloon race. The great bags drifted east by northeast toward the Baltic States and Russia before a wind estimated at 45 miles an hour.

Artificial production of the newly isolated male hormone testosterone in unlimited quantities has been accomplished by its chemical synthesis in the laboratory of Dr. L. Ruzicka at Zurich, Switzerland, it was reported here yesterday in a cable to the American Chemical Society.

EMPORIA, Kan., Sept. 15 (AP). -- William Allen White, editor and author, said last night that Kansas has "an open mind" toward all potential Republican Presidential candidates, despite an incipient boom for Governor Landon.

Clifford Ray Parliman, former aviator and well-known real estate operator, was arrested at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in a bungalow at Woodland Beach, S.I., by a postoffice inspector and two detectives on charges growing out of a land-development project in which investors were alleged to have lost $500,000.

Contracts for construction of a southerly link of the West Side Express Highway, extending from Canal Street to Rector Street, would be ready for advertising in sixty days, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan announced yesterday.

The Queens Midtown Tunnel Authority has applied to the PWA for a loan and grant totaling $58,365,000, to be used in constructing a vehicular tunnel under the East River, between Manhattan and Queens, it announced yesterday. A loan of $43,224,000 has been requested, while $15,141,000 has been asked as a grant.

GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- Ten days of speeches and manoeuvres here and in Rome have brought the League of Nations closer to sanctions than ever in its short history, but it is still far from applying even the milder ones.

According to the official statement of the Italian Government on Saturday, the Italo-Ethiopian controversy "admits of no compromise." This amounts to a rejection in advance, without knowing what it may be, of the proposal on which the committee of the League of Nations has been working.

In response to your editorial "Happiness" may I call your attention to the Mark Twain Lectureship for the Advancement of Humor, which is now being offered to the universities? This is in view of the fact that it might serve as an approach to your "Chair of Happiness."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The American love for comfort and luxury received a large share of the credit today as Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, Cleveland economist, commented on the 1935 improvement in business conditions.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP). -- With victories assured in two events, the United States small-bore rifle marksmen looked for a three-way victory tonight in international events. In the Dewar international test, the United States team scored 7,936 today to top England, its nearest competitor, with 7,918.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley told reporters this afternoon he had "no doubt that Mr. Roosevelt and the administration will help those who have been friendly to him in Louisiana."

The Virginia Electric and Power Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Sept. 27, 1935, for the primary purpose of considering the authorization and creation of a new mortgage on the property and to authorize the issuance of bonds, the aggregate amount not exceeding $40,000,000, under the new mortgage.

Within sight of his five children, Detective Daniel Sullivan, 40 years old, a police hero, shot and killed his 38-year-old wife in a quarrel at their home at 537 Senator Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. One of the children, Evelyn, 12, was seriously wounded when she stepped into the line of fire to aid her fleeing mother.

Since cotton prices broke approximately 1 cent a pound about three weeks ago, they have fluctuated narrowly around the 10 1/2-cent level. Last week prices for futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a range of 27 to 30 points, and closed the week with net changes ranging from a decline of 4 points to an advance of 2 points.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Financial circles here feel that the conciliatory efforts of Premier Laval in Geneva came up against the intransigence of the Italian Government, and that the possibility of arriving at a pacific solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy is now more doubtful.

Clergymen of different denominations in this city appraised the life of the late Senator Huey Long in their sermons yesterday, some giving credit for what he had accomplished, but all deploring the ruthless methods by which he achieved his ends.

Big Bill Tilden blasted a service ace down the centre line to defeat Karel Kozeluh in their final-round match for the national professional tennis singles title on the courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush yesterday. This master stroke climaxed a great rally which earned the veteran a five-set triumph over the Czechoslovak star.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports with 2,055 passengers, a record number for any ship this year. Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Willis H. Booth, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Co.; Lauritz Melchior, tenor at the Metropolitan, and Dr. Peter W. Dykema of Teachers College, Columbia University, are among the prominent passengers.
The first frost of the season for the metropolitan area was predicted last night by the United States Weather Bureau.

President ROOSEVELT could not have found a more appropriate platform from which to announce to the nation his program of continued conservation. The scene was as impressive as that which TYNDALL described in his rhapsody on the Alps: hundreds of peaks and myriad lakes and streams joining in the celebration of man's achievement.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Sept. 15 (AP). -- This historic naval town and its late Summer holiday throngs evinced no excitement today over the possibility that an international crisis might call Great Britain's fleet into action.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Addressing 300 county and municipal officials and party workers who met in support of the candidacy of State Senator Frank Durand of Monmouth County, Governor Harold G. Hoffman tonight declared that the adoption of a "pay-as-you-go" policy represented the only course that would solve the financial ills of both New Jersey and the nation.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- Difficult and dangerous as the European situation now is, it is not inducing investors here to part with their securities. Quite a number are being attracted to the United States market because of its greatly improved prospects and of its remoteness from Europe.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15. -- The official Soviet press today called Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Nuremberg assembly a "gigantic mobilization test" in preparation for a war against Soviet Russia. The newspaper Pravda called it "a hysterical anti-Soviet meeting."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Champion Milson O'Boy, Irish setter, owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York City and handled in the ring by Harry Hartnett, today once more reached the pinnacle of canine fame when he won best in show at the annual exhibition of the Westchester Kennel Club.

A plea for the dedication of America to the protection and defense of the Constitution as "the greatest charter of liberty" in "these days when the foundations of liberty seem crumbling and uncertain" was voiced last night by Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State in the Wilson Administration, in a radio address over a coast-to-coast network.
Under caption "Senator and President" the writer of a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES alleges and deplores the editorial support given by your paper to Franklin D. Roosevelt and his policies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The 50,000 Democrats of the South enrolled by the Southern Committee to Uphold the Constitution, headed by John H. Kirby of Houston, will unite with any party that promises to carry out "American" doctrines in 1936, if the Democratic party nominates President Roosevelt, Mr. Kirby declared today.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 15. -- The text of the address of Reichsfuekrer Hitler to the Reichstag today follows:
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Led by Dusty Cooke, the Red Sox overcame a five-run, first-inning splurge by St. Louis to beat the Browns, 9 to 5, today and help Lefty Grove record his eighteenth victory.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 15. -- Two thousand Negardis, or traveling Ethiopian merchants, many of whom are Moslems and most of whom operate from Addis Ababa, assembled in St. Giorghis Square this morning with rifles and cartridge belts.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 15. -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, Spanish aviator, on his way to visit his sweetheart here, landed this afternoon at San Marcos, in the State of Guerrero, on the South Pacific Coast near the Port of Acapulco, after having got 125 miles off his course from Vera Cruz to this city.

The nation is being educated in the belief that Federal relief will always be available for those who do not want to work too hard. Uncle Sam keeps a free lunch counter in Washington, and millions are always available for loans. Losing money means nothing to the government, where millions have been lost in cornering wheat, cotton,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- A system of three-man regional agencies in twenty-one cities to handle labor complaints under the Wagner Act was announced today by the new National Labor Relations Board.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a report in which it contended the city could save $5,000,000 a year on the wages it pays to city laborers and mechanics by reducing their pay to a level 25 per cent higher than that generally prevailing in private employment.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 15. -- The New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, scored their third victory of the season today, defeating the Danbury Trojans, 32 to 0, before 7,500 spectators, the largest crowd that ever witnessed a gridiron game here.
WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. William du Pont's Quarryman was named champion hunter today at the Wissahickon Horse Show and Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Bon Diable was placed in reserve.

Divers disgruntled Republicans keep grumbling at the Republican National Committee. They complain that it is inefficient, behind the times, unequal to its responsibilities and opportunities. They err grievously. A Washington correspondent of our neighbor The Herald Tribune shows that "the leaders" of that committee are deep-revolving thinkers, gifted with acute foresight and the creative imagination as necessary to high politics as to high poetry.

Connecticut's sea-going legislator, State Senator Daniel F.B. Hickey of Stamford, came down from Long Island Sound to the Hudson yesterday. He took the foul and fair currents as he found them, calculated the tides with uncanny accuracy and, in a 70-mile race upstream and down, performed the utterly unheard-of feat of finishing with an error of only six seconds to win the Bear Mountain cruiser race.

Necessarily the Government is guessing when it estimates that American farmers will have a cash income of $6,700,000,000 in 1935. But the guessing is done by a competent agency, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, and the method used in arriving at this figure is that traditionally employed in earlier calculations of this kind.

PESHAWAR, India, Sept. 15. -- Thirty thousand British Indian troops from Peshawar, Nowshera, Jhelum and Rawal Pindi have concentrated along Gandab Road as a preliminary to advancing across Nahakki Pass and entering the Mohmand territory of Kamali, into which British Indian soldiers never before have entered.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Sixty persons were injured today when a 25-yard stand holding more than 400 collapsed at Max Baer's training camp, while the former heavyweight champion was working out with one of his sparring partners.

American sportsmen who may be planning early hunting trips to New Brunswick will have an opportunity to vary their activity with a bit of salmon fishing, for on several streams the angling dates dovetail conveniently with those of the gunning season.

Production and billings declined in the silk and rayon woven goods industry in the week ended Sept. 7, according to a report issued yesterday by The National Federation of Textiles, Inc. The combined totals for all classes of mills showed a drop in production of 11 per cent and a decline in unfilled orders at mills of 0.3 per cent.

If the business situation were free from doubts and misgivings instilled by the long succession of experiments at Washington, it would hardly be doubted that an Autumn season which has begun as this one has would end with genuinely vigorous recovery.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Socialist leaders today redoubled their efforts to arouse their followers against the danger of an "imperialist war."

Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue, writes in the first issue of The Hospital News Service, issued tomorrow, that New York's 3-cents-a-day plan for hospital care is now the largest community-wide, non-profit hospital service in the country.

Interest in bond redemptions was centred more last week in proposed retirements than in actual calls made, which, as in the previous week, remained small. Bonds called for payment before maturity were chiefly for later months, only some small lots of State and municipal issues being added for September.

Samuel B. Finkel of Boston has been appointed director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, president of the organization, at its headquarters, 71 West Forty-seventh Street. Mr. Finkel succeeds Herbert Askwith, who resigned to devote himself to other interests.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Theoretically, the United States has been at war since October, 1934, when the armed forces of two "European powers" invaded the Atlantic coastal area.

Despite top weight of 124 pounds, Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment looms as the choice in the Wantagh Handicap, main event on the opening card of the Jamaica Fall meeting today. The session will run for two weeks, followed by those at Belmont Park and Empire City.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The Ethiopian crisis fell into the background in the last week, being replaced as the centre of interest by the Nazi government's demonstration in Nuremberg and by the convocation of the Reichstag last Sunday.

An immediate "woman-to-woman" campaign to inform the American people how their liberties are being curtailed by the Roosevelt administration was advocated last night by Mrs. Henry S. Caraway, president of the Women's National Republican Club, speaking at a dinner of the Republican Educational League at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The bodies of Lieutenant Lincoln C. Denton and his mechanic, Clinton Hart, Naval Reserve fliers from Floyd Bennett Field, were found this morning amid the wreckage of their plane near the top of a rugged ridge southeast of here known as Ram's Head Mountain.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The typical family on relief in New Jersey is native white, has two children under 16 years old and the father is an unskilled workman who was regularly employed before the depression but for the last two or three years has not been able to obtain regular employment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- For the sixth time this year negotiations were started afresh today to obtain a new wage and hour agreement for the vast Appalachian soft coal fields.

The New York Athletic Club's water-polo sextet retained its national A.A.U. outdoor soft-ball championship by routing the Central Queens Y.M.C.A. team, 24-9, at the Jerome Cascades Pool yesterday. The Winged Foot squad has captured national honors, both indoors and outdoors, for the past two years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Increased activity in botl wholesale and retail trade, with sales 10 to 25 per cent larger than a year ago and up to 30 to 50 per cent in a few special lines, was the feature of general business in this territory last week. Retail trade was especially active, with attractive offerings of sea sonal lines. Mail-order houses reported a record business, offering special attractions in men's and women's clothing.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 16. -- The causes and details of the accident in which forty-one officers and men of two of Japan's modern warships were injured during target practice Saturday morning are undisclosed. An expert commission under Vice Admiral Gen Matsushita has been formed to investigate the accident, especially to determine whether it was due to technical defects.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.1, which compares with 84.5 the week before, 84.3 two weeks before, 84.6 three weeks before and 83.7 four weeks before.
The adequacy of the Constitution was discussed yesterday afternoon over station WOR by Laurens M. Hamilton, up-State Assemblyman, and Charles Solomon, State leader of the Socialist party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A census of business which is expected to make available data of importance to governmental bodies and private interests in the program of recovery and expansion and another census to prepare an alphabetical index of all individuals covered by the census of 1900, necessary for the operation of the Social Security Act, will begin tomorrow, Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce announced today.

With two Yale 150-pounders and one from Princeton in the boat, the New Rochelle Rowing Club swept to victory in the junior quadruple shell competition that was one of the features of the annual metropolitan championship regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Harlem River yesterday.
READING, Pa., Sept. 15. -- The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League defeated the Reading Keystones, 7 to 0, today before 3,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- New demands for a slash in next year's Federal spending came today from two members of Congress who help figure out taxes to pay the bills.

The real estate interests of the city took a position yesterday squarely behind Mayor La Guardia in his efforts to reduce the noise of New York, but in offering suggestions for the abolition of noise they also presented a criticism of the Mayor's approach to the problem.

JACKSON, Mich., Sept. 15. -- John Denton of this city said tonight that his brother, Lieutenant Lincoln C. Denton, had sent a telegram to their sister, Mrs. Georgiana Hotchkiss of Liberty, N.Y., that...

Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder in Jersey City yesterday issued an order restraining the American Hide and Leather Company, a $10,000,000 concern incorporated in New Jersey, from acting on a plan to reorganize its financial structure at the annual meeting of the stockholders tomorrow in Jersey City.

Music in Germany is no longer a medium of artistic expression but definitely a means of propaganda, in the opinion of Dr. Peter W. Dykema, Professor of Musical Education at Teachers College. Columbia University, who returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday after a tour of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- In a statement defending the processing tax, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration insisted today that the tax was a "factor of small importance in the sharp discounts in the price of Spring wheat." It declared that the increased price which farmers were receiving for "wheat of light weight" resulted chiefly from heat and dust damage.

If future Aidas are to continue to grace the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the guidance of Alfredo Salmaggi, the Grand Opera Artists Association must agree to class opera outside the realm of "manual work, like barbers," the impresario announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The suggestion cabled to Secretary of State Hull from Geneva by Senator Pope of Idaho for the United States to convene a world conference of the governments that signed the Briand-Kellogg peace pact to consider the obligations under that instrument in the light of the Ethiopian crisis was pronounced fantastic today by Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

Increases amounting to a total of $127,975 in the budgets for New York City's five Surrogates' Courts were asked for 1936 at a hearing yesterday before Rufus E. McGahen, Budget Director. In presenting estimated requirements, the representative of each court urged restoration of the pay cuts, especially in the lower brackets.

LOS ANGELES, Sept 16. -- Will Rogers's will, bequeathing all of his property to his wife, was admitted to probate in Superior Court here today. No official estimate yet is made of the value of his estate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Five companies have agreed in stipulations, the Federal Trade Commission announced today, to cease trade practices alleged to have been in violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16. -- The first attack upon the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was made in Federal District Court here today in a petition filed by F. Donald Fenhagen and J.B. Whiteworth, trustees for the American States Public Service Company controlling water and power companies in Illinois, Idaho, Michigan, California, Oregon, Montana and Indiana.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board must pay into the Federal Treasury $600,000 to $1,000,000 in floor taxes and license fees on its liquor business, under a decision handed down here today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

As he rose from a chair to greet two acquaintances in a Bowery restaurant yesterday morning, Nicolo Grupposo, a small-time gangster with a police record dating back to 1920, met the same fate that befell Dion O'Bannion, Chicago's North Side beer baron, when O'Bannion shook hands with one of three "friends" who called at his florist's shop in November, 1924.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A question of fact as to the extent of congestion of the paupers' burial ground adjoining the churchyard of historic St. Paul's Church, East Chester, should be determined by an investigation, Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich suggested this afternoon in reserving decision on a motion by the church to enjoin the city of Mount Vernon from further burials in the potter's field.

Governor LEHMAN in his "Constitution Day" proclamation asked for "the fullest display of the American flag." Twenty-one years ago FRANKLIN K. LANE, native of Prince Edward Island and a naturalized citizen of the United States who became Secretary of the Interior, read to the employes of the department a message on the "Makers of the Flag" which should be repeated wherever the flag is displayed and especially in the schools.

In calling for an "immediate and drastic revision" of the zoning ordinance the City Club comes to the support of a reform long overdue. New York was a pioneer in this field. Its original zoning ordinance, adopted in 1916, set an example for the rest of the country.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -Direction of the Federal Alcohol Administration, division of the Treasury Department newly created to supervise manufacture and sale of alcoholic beverages and of other commercial products containing alcohol, was placed today in the hands of Franklin Chase Hoyt, retired jurist who served with distinction in Hew York's courts for twenty-five years.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Sammy Byrd broke up a battle of Rookie pitchers today, his eleventh-inning single giving the Reds a 3-to-2 decision over the Phillies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- War talk became today a major influence in the wheat market on the Board of Trade and there was little opposition to an advance late in the session, the close being at the top with net gains of 1 3/8 to 2 /14 cents a bushel, the May leading.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Harvard's varsity football squad, 122 members strong, ushered in its 1935 season today under the guidance of its new head coach, Dick Harlow, formerly mentor at Western Maryland. With a twelve-man coaching staff, the only Harvard-bred member of which was Johnny Dean, halfback and 1933 captain, the Crimson forces drove through two long sessions.

The Children's Medical Division of Bellevue Hospital will ultimately receive nearly all the estate of Mrs. Anna Phipps Tinker, who died June 30, 1934, the appraisal showed yesterday. Mrs. Tinker left $257,943 gross and $243,740 net, of which $254,196 was in securities.
Winds of gale-like intensity and terrific tidal currents that coincide with the full-moon period proved anything but a happy combination for many deep-sea anglers over the week-end.

Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey, in Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on an application of Henry J. Glynn for an order directing the Chase National Bank to turn over to the Sheriff of New York County about $600,000 of stock owned by the United Steel Works Corporation and its affiliate, the Gelsenkuerchen Mining Corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Preparations for Westchester's most hectic primary in many years were being concluded tonight as party organizations instructed their members how to properly write in the names of designated candidates. The largest write-in vote in the county's history is expected.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- No race could be sailed today in the Seawanhaka Cup match between the Crown Prince of Norway's challenger, Norna IV, and the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club defender, Paul Shields's Challenge. There was no wind on Long Island Sound.

President Roosevelt is not interested in recovery or reform but solely in re-election, John D. Hamilton, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, asserted last night at the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

A verdict for more than $3,000,000 against the Aluminum Company of America in a suit brought by the Baush Machine Tool Company of Springfield, Mass., alleging monopolistic trade practices, was set aside yesterday by the United States Circuit Court and a retrial ordered.
ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- Alfred H. Schoellkopf will resign as chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration on or about Oct. 15, Governor Lehman announced tonight.

ATHENS, Sept. 16. -- The Italian destroyer Montarari, accompanied by two submarine chasers, arrived today off the Island of Seriphos after leaving Laurion at midnight. The vessels are still without authority to remain in Greek waters, although it was the fifth day of their stay without communication with shore.

Net profit of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and subsidiaries in the first six months of this year amounted to $3,418,097 after depreciation, Federal taxes, minority interest and other charges, but before depletion. The profit is equivalent to 32 cents a share on 10,769,379 shares of no-par capital stock.
