WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- With the approval of President Roosevelt, a new five-year program for the care and education of young people was begun today at the opening session here of the newly created Youth Commission, sponsored by the American Council on Education and financed by a grant of $800,000 from the General Education Board, a Rockefeller foundation.

Vance McCaulley, 28 years old, son of the late Mrs. Francis Dunlevy McCaulley of Denver, Col., was found dead with a bullet wound in his head, in his apartment at 444 East Fifty-seventh Street, in the Sutton Place neighborhood, yesterday soon after 1 P.M. The police listed his death as a suicide.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A total of $759,000,000 of called Fourth 4 1/4 Liberty Loan bonds, of which there was $1,250,000,000 outstanding, has been refunded during the first two weeks of the Treasury's conversion operation, Acting Secretary Coolidge announced today.

The plan of the Works Progress Administration to obtain employment for Negro women as "housekeepers and practical nurses" in the homes of families on the relief rolls in the borough of Queens, in cases where either one or both parents of the household are afflicted with illness or other disability, was criticized yesterday by Dr. Morris Bender, president of the Queens County Medical Society.

Testimony to prove that Bertrand Coles Neidecker, head of the closed Travelers Bank of Paris, is under the jurisdiction of the Federal court here for purposes of bankruptcy proceedings was offered yesterday afternoon at a hearing before Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn at 280 Broadway.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16. -- Before a ladies' day crowd of nearly 14,000, Paul Dean today defeated Van Lingle Mungo in a hurling duel and the Cardinals took the opening game of their series with the Dodgers, 1 to 0, to keep pace with the Cubs and gain a full game on the Giants.

In an effort to check the flight of gold from Holland and protect the guilder, the Bank of the Netherlands yesterday raised its discount rate from 5 per cent to 6 per cent. The move was fairly effective, for the guilder registered a net gain of 6 points from its closing price on Saturday.
MONTREAL, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Montreal advanced to the final round of the International League play-offs today by taking the deciding game of its series with Buffalo, 8 to 0, before 7,000 fans.

Leaders and workers of rival Democratic and Republican factions ended a hectic campaign with meetings throughout the city last night as the public authorities took unusual precautions against disorder or irregularities at the polls at the primary election today. The polling places will open at 3 P.M. and close at 10 P.M., one hour later than formerly.

Mayor La Guardia and a group of city officials paused for a rapturous view of their city from the roof of a high building yesterday while waiting for a delegation of visitors from Chicago who had been delayed while seeing the city from the bottom up.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, left Washington tonight to discuss the work-relief program with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park tomorrow for the second time within a week.

Favorable over-Sunday weather brought a slight increase in hedging pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices lost 3 to 8 points, closing at the bottom. Owing to scale price fixing orders in substantial volume, the October contract fluctuated over a range of 4 points and resistance developed as the near month approached 10 1/4 cents a pound.

GENOA, Italy, Sept. 16. -- Italians believe in the existence of a secret war chest, which will be used in the campaign against Ethiopia or in any other contingencies. How it was accumulated nobody has specified, but stories circulate everywhere of buried treasure Premier Benito Mussolini can draw on when all known resources fail.

Representatives of the radio operators who are on strike for a new working contract with several of the American flag lines serving the port of New York conferred yesterday with officials of four lines on terms of settlement, while strikers picketed piers in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16. -- The past month has witnessed an extraordinary phenomenon in the Donetz coal field, whereby the output of one miner with an automatic hammer has been pushed up from the "normal" average of five tons in a six-hour shift to the fantastic figure of 310 tons.

Marking the final step in the refunding program of the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., offering will be made today of $30,000,000 first and refunding mortgage bonds, series of 4s due in 1960, and $27,500,000 of serial 2 1/2, 3 1/2 and 3 3/4 per cent debentures by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- With receipts of hogs the second smallest on record for any Monday, packers were unable to shave their cutting-out loss on the dressed product, which is now estimated at $1.75 to $2.75 on every hog killed. Warm weather and a slow demand for fresh meat also was without effect and prices advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with some under-weights selling at advances of 25 to 50 cents.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 16. -- A coroner's jury, consisting of six West Chester men, was chosen today to conduct the inquest into the death of Evelyn Hoey, New York showgirl, who was found shot to death last Wednesday night in the country home of Henry H. Rogers 3d.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Italian interests have acquired from British owners sufficient shares in Mosul Oil Fields, Ltd., and the British Oil Development Company to control both the companies which hold a concession of about 45,000 square miles from the Iraq Government.

GALES FERRY, Conn., Sept. 16. -- A squad of fifty-nine Yale candidates assembled today on the gridiron constructed under the supervision of Major Frank Wandle, trainer, for the morning and afternoon sessions that inaugurated football practice.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 16. -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, young Spanish aviator, who accepted the challenge to fly all the way from Spain here to visit his sweetheart, finally ended this morning a flight lasting four months. His 7,000-mile air journey from Santander, Spain, was accomplished in the face of a series of misfortunes that would have discouraged a much older pilot.

George Hiram Mann, still chuckling over the recent victory in his twenty-five-year fight for back pay for navy yard workers, received an unexpected visitor yesterday in the person of an old client who he thought was dead. In fact, Mr. Mann was fairly certain until yesterday that none of the original claimants was alive.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- Tightening carefully its pressure on Premier Mussolini, the British delegation to the League of Nations made it officially known to the press tonight that it had been engaged in explanatory talks with the French and other delegations regarding economic sanctions in the event Italy resorts to war.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Supreme Court Justice W.F. Bleakley of Yonkers directed the Westchester County election commissioners today to restore to the Republican primary ballots for use in the Ninth Ward of Yonkers tomorrow the names of three candidates who were on the ballot heretofore, but were ruled off by the commissioners last Friday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- Mrs. Kauffman, wife of Commander James L. Kauffman, executive officer of the naval training station, gave a farewell tea today at the station for Mrs. Jonathan E. Harlow of Boston, who had been the guest of Commander and Mrs. Kauffman for a month.

Speaking in behalf of the cotton dress industry, the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers sent a letter to the Works Progress Administration in Washington yesterday objecting to the WPA sewing project designed to produce 18,000,000 cotton dresses for distribution to unemployed and needy persons.

If there existed a lingering hope that the Yankees had a chance for the American League pennant, it disappeared yesterday when the McCarthymen opened their final series of the year against the Browns at the Stadium.

Noel C. Scaffa, private detective specializing in the recovery of stolen jewels for insurance companies, was sentenced to six months in prison by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks yesterday. Scaffa was convicted July 26 of perjury committed before a grand jury investigating the theft and recovery of $185,000 worth of jewelry stolen last January from Mrs. Margaret Hawkesworth Bell, former New York dancer, in Miami.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 16 (AP). -- The National Boxing Association's estimate of the quality of heavyweight fighters was recorded tonight in a listing of only six top men with association rankings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Evidence purporting to show that twelve large meat-packing concerns had entered into a price-fixing combination in violation of the Packers and Stockyards Act was introduced at a hearing today before Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

Munford Baker, 43-year-old securities expert and son of the late Elizabeth Gowdy Baker, a widely known artist, was killed yesterday morning when he fell or jumped from a kitchen window in the rear of his sixth-floor apartment at 137-139 West Twelfth Street.

MENTOR, Ohio, Sept. 16. -- Declaring that this country "faces a constitutional crisis," Fred G. Clark, national commander of the Crusaders, in a radio broadcast tonight, described the precautions which the framers of the Constitution took to preserve States' rights and freedom for all classes of society.

Spurred by an injunction from Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Sr., widow of the President, to defend the Constitution as the mainstay of "the liberty that we stand in terror of losing," Republican women from twenty States rallied here yesterday in opposition to the policies of the present Roosevelt administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Manifestly in happy mood, Secretary Hull announced today that 280 Foreign Service workers had been promoted and forty young men taken into the Foreign Service. The promotions were the first among officers above Grade V rank since July 1, 1931.
MINISINK HILLS, Pa., Sept. 16. -- Forty-six University of Pennsylvania varsity football candidates were sent through a strenuous opening-day double drill in Camp Wyomissing today.

PORTLAND, England, Sept. 16. -- A bare skeleton of Great Britain's mighty Home Fleet rode at anchor in Portland Harbor tonight on the eve of the whole fleet's scheduled departure for Autumn manoeuvres in the North Sea.

Wide variations in the reading ability of the city's school children, with 51 per cent deficient on the basis of a nation-wide norm and 14 per cent retarded by two years or more, were indicated yesterday by the results of a standard reading test among 21,738 pupils in 250 classes of 6B grade.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Seven New Jersey pros qualified for the national P.G.A. championship at Oklahoma City by leading a small field home in a thirty-six-hole qualifying test today at the Essex County Country Club.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The New Deal non-partisan majority of the Camden City Commission, in a surprise move today, essayed a wholesale replacement of Republican incumbents in high municipal offices.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 16. -- Simplification of the pension system was urged today at the opening session of the United Spanish War Veterans convention.

A special assignment of tenement house inspectors to prohibit the assembling of people on the roofs of apartment houses adjoining the Yankee Stadium on the night of the Beer-Louis fight was announced yesterday by First Deputy Commissioner Harry M. Prince.

The French liner Ile de France, arriving late today from Havre and Southampton, has among her passengers Dr. Alexis Carrel, noted research scientist; Walter E. Edge, former United States Ambassador to France; Wallace Beery, screen actor; Mrs. George H. Earle, wife of the Governor of Pennsylvania; Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York, Dr. William Allen Neilson, president of Smith College. Others one the list are:

One of the objects of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of the files of brokers' advices to customers seemed to be to ascertain if the brokers had not strongly "tipped" issues with which they might have been loaded. If this were true, it would be a forceful argument for complete segregation of the functions of dealers and brokers, a matter on which the SEC must report to Congress on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- On the diplomatic front in London there was no relaxing of the tension today. Within two or three days the British Government will tell the French that it stands by every word of Sir Samuel Hoare's speech to the League of Nations Assembly last week.
Money market continued quiet. Business was small and quotations were unchanged for all classifications.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Two important developments in the speeding up of American railroad passenger service were disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Sam Jones, veteran White Sox right-hander, limited the Senators to four hits today as Chicago battered a pair of Washington pitchers for a 9-to-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- How the Coral Gables Corporation, whose officers were also the heads of the municipal government of the once widely heralded "Florida paradise," realized fabulous profits on the transfer of various property and facilities to the organized citizenry of the development was unfolded today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Sept. 11, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $61,000,000 in loans and investments, $192,000,000 in net demand deposits, and $150,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

HITLER was, according to advance predictions, to blow a trumpet in his speech at Nuremberg. It turned out to be very like a penny whistle. He scarcely touched upon any of the great issues which are agitating public opinion in Europe. Particularly in the question of peace or war which is filling men's minds, he appeared like a man unable to make a choice.

A 20 per cent increase in receipts on the third instalment of the Federal income tax, payment of which was due yesterday, was reported last night by Almon G. Rasquin, collector for the first internal revenue district with headquarters in Brooklyn.
The temperature dropped yesterday to 49.6 degrees at 7:45 A.M., establishing a record for the date. The previous record for Sept. 16 was in 1923, when the temperature dropped to 51.1 degrees.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Senate Munitions Committee is inquiring into how much it would cost the government to own and operate plants to build ships, airplanes and other weapons of warfare.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Cleveland took the series opener from the Athletics today, 8 to 5, before a crowd of less than 500, the season's low.

Dr. CHARLES NORRIS, as Chief Medical Examiner of the city, owed his skill to something more than his fine personal equipment. As the medical officer called upon in deaths of violence with suspicion of foul play, he had a much wider experience than falls to any similar public official in any foreign metropolis.

The Fifty-eighth Street Theatre, nee the Golden, gets an opening tonight, when Nora Lawlor's play, "Few Are Chosen," arrives there. An ambitious lady, Miss Lawlor is also the producer, and in the cast are Ara Gerald, Alma Kruger, Mary Hone, Norma Downey and others.

The Supreme Court of the District of Columbia heard yesterday the first argument in a controversy which may well rank in importance with the Schechter case in the history of the New Deal. The question at issue was the constitutionality of one of the measures enacted at the last session -- the Guffey act, establishing a "little NRA" for the soft coal industry.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- The use of "public hysteria" as an aid in the fight against disease after the July floods in the southern section of the State was described today by the State Department of Health.

An application to examine United States Senator Royal S. Copeland before trial in a suit against him and nine other officers of the defunct Knickerbocker Discount Corporation, of which he was president, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

MANILA, P.I., Tuesday, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Braving rain in many parts of the archipelago, Filipinos began casting ballots today for the first President of the new Commonwealth Government, a Vice President and members of the National Assembly.

ROME, Sept. 16. -- A warning to France that if she casts aside Italy's friendship now over the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, she may never again regain it was delivered today by the authoritative newspaper La Stampa of Turin.
Horatio S. Abbott, one of Coney Island's real natives, viewed in retrospect yesterday the old days of the island as he prepared to leave it after seventy-six years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The Roosevelt administration appears to be fully awake to the necessity for an adequate defensive force for our country, according to Lieut. Col. George Ijams of Baltimore, commander-in-chief of the Military Order of the World War.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Fluton, owned by the Foxcatcher Farms and ridden by Maurice Peters, carried 103 pounds to an easy victory in the John Boles Trophy race at six furlongs for 2-year-olds today. The victor paid $13.40 for $2 straight.
Harry Leon Wilson's "His Majesty Bunker Bean," which was made twice as a silent film, will be brought to the screen this season by RKO Radio, with John Arledge in the leading role.

Thirty-one successive victories in championship match play is enough to show in itself that WILLIAM LAWSON LITTLE Jr. is a great golfer. But there is additional evidence LITTLE was battling not only against human opponents but against par, and his record of playing the Cleveland course in nineteen strokes under par reveals the kind of golf those opponents were up against.

The United States liner Washington reported last night via Mackay Radio that she had intercepted a distress message from the British freighter Mary Kingsley that most of her crew had been injured and that she was shipping water in mountainous seas off the coast of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Linking a plea for the integrity of the Constitution with an attack upon the New Deal, Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, in a radio address tonight, said that this league was founded a year ago because of "insidious and persistent and alarming efforts to undermine the Constitution."
MONTREAL, Sept. 16. -- The Canadiens, the Flying Frenchmen of the National Hockey League, passed into the hands of Ernest Savard, baseball magnate, today.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Reginald Parnell, Director of Revenue and Finance, was ordered by the State Supreme Court today to issue the $510,803 in emergency bonds to meet the city contribution toward relief in 1935, assessed by the State Relief Council.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- The Boerse opened the week with further losses and continued inactivity. Heavy industrials fell and Hoesch, Glockner and Schuckert lost 1 point each. Machines dropped, Berlin Karlsruhe and Orenstein and Koppel losing 1/2 point each.

PARIS, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy warned the world again tonight, the newspaper Matin reported in a published statement by Il Duce from its Rome correspondent, that sanctions against Italy by the League of Nations meant war "and the danger of recasting the map of Europe."

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's secret police struck today at one of the largest and most important Catholic organizations in Germany by suppressing, in the intensely Catholic district of Muenster, Westphalia, the Catholic Labor Union, or "working men's club."

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Conceding that "it is entirely possible that it may be repealed," Governor Hoffman reiterated today in a preprimary election statement that he still believes the sales tax is sound and necessary and that he will fight for it "to the last." This was interpreted by political observers to mean that he will veto a repealer if passed by the 1936 Legislature.

The overture to Verdi's "Nabucodonosor," an early and infrequently heard opera of the Italian master, will be performed tomorrow evening by the Municipal Chamber Symphony under the direction of Jacques L. Gottlieb at the Educational Alliance at a free WPA concert.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Pirates turned back the Braves, 5 to 3, today. Spectacular relief pitching by Rookie Mace Broom featured.
UNTERACH, Austria, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Maria Jeritza, piqued because some Austrians do not like her second marriage, refused today to sing for the home folk.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Playing with Rocky Rich of Elmsford, Joe Gagliardi, who won the New York A.C. championship for the third straight year on Saturday, led a field of thirty-three teams in the Westchester pro-amateur golf tournament at Winged Foot today.

With more than 200,000 Democrats expected to participate in the primaries in Kings County today, rival Democratic groups closed one of the county's bitterest primary campaigns last night with predictions of victory, but it appeared that the regular organization, headed by Frank V. Kelly, had the edge.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 16. -- Sergeant Claude N. Harris, of Lancaster, Calif., a member of the United States Marine Corps, received the title of America's champion rifle shot today, after he topped 1,661 competitors in the national individual rifle match.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 16. -- Emperor Haile Selassie received the British Minister, Sir Sidney Barton, this afternoon and afterward called his advisers to the palace.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16. -- A passenger and freight-carrying "parachute kite," which Soviet aviation authorities said they believed would be able to ascend into the stratosphere, had its first successful trial today, lifting four tons of cargo.

Benjamin F. Fairless will be president of a new company, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, which will unify the operations of the Carnegie Steel Company of Pittsburgh and the Illinois Steel Company of Chicago, largest subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Declaring that the sales tax was the issue in tomorrow's primary elections in New Jersey, the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, predicted tonight that the candidates of the Clean Government Republicans of Essex County, whose ticket he heads, would win the party nominations tomorrow.
William H. Clark is with Reynolds Co. as general manager of their bond and institutional departments. Harold H. Cook is manager of the corporate bond department.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Much embarrassment is being caused to the French Government by reports published in various countries regarding the policy France will pursue if and when hostilities break out between Italy and Ethiopia and a decision must be taken regarding Italy's position by the Council of the League of Nations.
Shortly after the Armistice in 1919, an ardent movement started in the United States denouncing war and calling for the use of moral forces in diplomacy to settle disputes among nations.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The favorite prevailed in the featured Wantagh Handicap as Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment led from start to finish at the opening of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Jamaica before 8,000 yesterday. Strongly backed in a field of five, the daughter of High Time and Nobility was driving at the end of the six furlongs under the handling of Don Meade.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday the appointment of a three-man committee of administration to further the liberalized educational program of the university's School of Architecture.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The assistance of advertisers in eliminating unfair competition in the insurance business and in informing legislators regarding the problems of insurance was asked tonight by Howard P. Dunham, vice president of the American Surety Company of New York and former Insurance Commissioner of Connecticut.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Stocks generally were dull here today on increasing evidence that war between Italy and Ethiopia is inevitable. At the same time, the market is not enthusiastic over the possibility of economic sanctions against Italy, which, it is felt, might check Great Britain's trade recovery.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in a slightly more active market. The strength in raw silk futures was a feature of the trading. At one time silk was 6 cents a pound higher. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, lard, tin, copper, silk and rubber were higher, while flour, raw sugar and butter were lower.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- Official sanction of the Department of Justice is awaited by Daniel F. O'Connell and Edward J. O'Connell, Albany County Democratic leaders, before $15,000 in rewards is set aside to be paid for information leading to the capture of three fugitives indicted for the $40,000 kidnapping of their nephew, John J. O'Connell Jr., here in July, 1933.

Mrs. Preston Davie, vice president of the National Republican Builders, visited a captains' meeting in the Fifth Assembly District last evening to support the present co-leader, Mrs. Anna B. McCann, and to speak against the re-election of Chase Mellen Jr. as New York County chairman.

The plan of reorganization for the Butterick Company, publishers of magazines and patterns, as amended in hearings before him, was approved by Peter B. Olney Jr., special master, in a report filed yesterday with Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Representative Bertrand H. Snell, House minority leader, is again on the warpath against those who are "attacking" the Constitution. The alleged "attack" seems to consist of expressed, inferred or suspected intent to amend. One wonders whether actual amendments might constitute murder or treason.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- The British continued today to place their naval defenses in readiness for any emergency.

The crews of three Hapag-Lloyd liners, all under the North German Lloyd flag, will change national flags officially this morning in accordance with instructions received from Germany following the decree that makes the swastika the national emblem.

Referring to Mrs. Anna Blomberg's letter on "How to Stay Married" may I say that her suggestions are excellent as far as they go, but they do not go deep enough. To be sure, she can hardly know the crux of the matter after a mere thirty years' experience.

The Empire State, training ship of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, returned yesterday to its base in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, following a three and one-half month cruise to European ports. It was the fifth annual Summer cruise of the Empire State and covered 10,178 miles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Acting on instructions from President Roosevelt, the Treasury Department informed its customs agents today that beginning Oct. 15 they will no longer extend to imports from Germany the tariff reductions granted to other countries through generalization of reciprocal trade agreements.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The board of strategy that bandles the ring fortunes of Joe Louis went into a huddle today and put the Detroit Bomber through a secret workout intended to correct some minor faults before he meets Max Baer in their scheduled fifteen-round fight at the Yankee Stadium next Tuesday night.

The labor standards established under the NRA are gradually being broken down and the workers must unite to obtain legislation assuring them the forty-hour week, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, chairman of the Regional Labor Board and vice president of the Consumers League of New York, said last night.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The first balloon was down today in the twenty-third James Gordon Bennett Cup international balloon race. It was the German bag, Deutschland, which landed near Riga, Latvia, about 600 kilometers [372.6 miles] from Warsaw, at 1:55 P.M. [8:55 A.M., New York time.]

KATSA, Northwest India, Sept. 16. -- In preparation for an advance over the Nahakki Pass against the hostile tribes in Mohmand territory, Brig. Gen. J.C.E. Auchinlock, commanding the British Indian punitive expedition, visited his front line today to examine the situation.

Candidates for line positions had their busiest day of the season yesterday at Baker Field as Columbia started its second week of football practice. After a three-hour drill in fundamentals during the morning the Lions had a two-hour scrimmage in the afternoon and practically every lineman on the squad had an opportunity to display his ability.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., Sept. 16. -- T. Suffern Tailer of Piping Rock and Charles Lacey, pro from the Lakeville Club, combined today to shoot a 67 and win the amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Golf Association held over the windswept No. 4 course of the Salisbury Country Club.

The increasing tension of the European war situation found reflection yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange, with all groups moving lower in the second slowest trading session of the month. Uncertainty surrounding the financing plans of the United States Treasury also continued to exert an unsettling effect upon government issues.

What is described as "a new kind of biography" has been evolved to tell for the first time the life story of John Reed. It is entitled "One of Us: The Story of John Reed," and consists of dramatic lithographs by Lynd Ward and a narrative by Granville Hicks.

The new investment house of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., organized to engage in the underwriting business formerly handled by J.P. Morgan Co., formally opened its doors for business on the nineteenth floor of 2 Wall Street yesterday morning.

Five men were drowned and five others were rescued early yesterday after a 25-foot workboat over-turned suddenly in the choppy waters of the outer harbor while unloading supplies from the lighthouse tender Tulip to the Romer Shoals Lighthouse Station.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 (AP). -- By unanimous vote of more than thirty-five representatives of member clubs, the South Atlantic Association of the Amateur Athletic Union tonight instructed its National A.A.U. convention delegates to vote against participation of a United States team in the Olympic Games next Summer at Berlin.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 16. -- The fight that is being waged by insurance companies to prevent Federal and State taxation of life insurance proceeds was outlined here today by C. Vivian Anderson, recent president of the National Association of Life Underwriters.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Homer S. Cummings, United States Attorney General, who arrived in Paris today, was mistaken for an ordinary American tourist by a minor French customs official and for a while Franco-American relations underwent a slight strain.

Precious stones and burglars' implements scattered on the floor of the Bowery Diamond Exchange at 87 Bowery revealed at a glance yesterday the frustration, apparently by fright, of a well planned robbery while the burglars were within striking distance of almost $1,000,000 in jewelry and gold.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Bounding fearlessly from one crucial series to another, the Giants plunged headlong into a great baseball turmoil today, but, due to a somewhat faulty take-off, they missed their objective and wound up all sprawled out.

Share prices were mildly reactionary yesterday as profit-taking appeared in moderate volume. There were not, however, indications of any important liquidation. The stock market's closing was steady, with the trading volume on the Stock Exchange of 1,490,000 shares the smallest for a full day since Sept. 4.

Mayor La Guardia announced last night that he would go to Hyde Park this morning, with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Administrator, to confer with President Roosevelt on the work relief situation in New York City.

After some months of earnest study and consultation with a number of people who operate all types of motor vehicles. I have come to the conclusion that brakes, steering apparatus and other mechanical devices have been so perfected that, if the motorist were given a fair chance to see the road, he could operate his car as safely and flexibly as he walks.
TORONTO, Tuesday, Sept. 17. -Len Koenecke, outfielder for the Brooklyn Dodgers, was killed in mid-air over Long Branch race track early today after a fight with the two-man crew of an airplane.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Golden Gate station of the Coast Guard on San Francisco Bay reports everything which happens on one of the printed forms it uses to record the salvage of an ocean liner. So when a runaway horse came within its ken, the result startling.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company issued yesterday a final report for 1934 which showed drastic revisions from a preliminary report published on July 23 and the dropping of Howard C. Hopson from its list of officers. The earlier report was made public when agents for Congressional committees of investigation were seeking in vain for Mr. Hopson, who was designated as the "master mind" of the system.

DE QUEEN, Ark., Sept. 16. -- The "shadow of Huey Long will be back in Arkansas at the next election," the assassinated Senator's brother, Dr. George S. Long of Tulsa, told 3,000 Sevier County Share-the-Wealth Club members and others here today.
HARRAR, Ethiopia, Sept. 16 (By Cable). -- After seventy years the little Moslem town of Jijiga, near Harrar, has again witnessed a Turkish general riding toward an enemy.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Hal Price Headley's 2-year-old bay colt Hollyrood came home in front today in the Maplewood, six-furlong event for juveniles, as Rockingham Park opened its twelve-day meeting.

There are not enough cases in the magistrates' courts to continue the emergency relief mendicancy bureau there for the rehabilitation of vagrants, Chief City Magistrate Schurman announced yesterday, and eventually the bureau would be moved to the Emergency Relief Bureau at 59 Leonard Street.

Two plans are reported near completion at Geneva. One is the conciliation offer, strongly urged by France, which Italy is expected to reject. In that case the alternative plan calls for an economic boycott of Italy should she begin an unprovoked war. This would be to apply the sanctions prescribed by the Covenant of the League.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- The directors of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston at a special meeting today recommended that the stockholders authorize an issue of new stock to retire $16,000,000 of short-term debt now outstanding. The stockholders will attend a special session on Oct. 7 to consider the recommendation and, if their vote is favorable, they will fix the amount of the stock issue and the price at which it will be offered.

OTTAWA, Sept. 16. -- An all-time record in the number of Dominion election candidates was set up today, four weeks before the election on Oct. 14, when the list of aspirants to the 245 seats in the House of Commons stood at 645, one more than the 1921 peak.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A respite from the regular boxing grind was enjoyed by Max Baer today. Instead of coming into town to perform against his assortment of sparring partners, the ex-heavyweight champion of the world remained in his retreat, deep in the woods, and freely aired his views on his forthcoming fight with Joe Louis.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Tigers increased their lead over the Yankees in the American League pennant chase today, beating the Red Sox, 5 to 3, while the Browns were defeating the McCarthymen.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The futility of disarmament efforts in the present state of European conditions was conceded today by Norman H. Davis, chief delegate of the United States to the Geneva and London conferences, after a tea-time conversation with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park House.

TOKYO, Sept. 16. -- Preliminary inquiry into the "prayer meeting plot" of July, 1933, has resulted in the committal for trial by the Supreme Court of fifty-four persons on the charge of rebellion, and by the Tokyo District Court of five persons on the lesser charge of attempting murder.

The Territory of Hawaii announced yesterday through its treasurer, W.C. McGonagle, a new issue of $1,750,000 of public improvement bonds for award on Sept. 23. This sale follows by a few weeks the marketing of a refunding issue in the amount of $4,430,000.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 16. -- A roving monkey and the problem of overcoming its attraction to specially cooked fried chicken and hard-boiled Grade A eggs prepared by the chefs of exclusive Llewellyn Park, faced an unhappy 16-year-old boy here tonight.

The future of the Academy of Music on Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, virtually was assured yesterday when Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the corporation, announced that capital stockholders and second mortgage bondholders had been asked to surrender their claims.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The government won the first round today in the battle for a constitutional test of the Guffey Coal Law.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, repudiated yesterday a nomination for member of the Democratic County Committee of the Tenth Assembly District made by the Democratic association of that district, which is supporting Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post for leader.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The government won the first round today in the battle for a constitutional test of the Guffey Coal Law.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Mrs. Aubrey T. Barnes entertained the Great Barrington Garden Club at Graystones, North Egremont, for the annual meeting today and the Rev. D.R. Edward Russell Bourne of New York was elected president to succeed Mrs. George O. Forbes.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, repudiated yesterday a nomination for member of the Democratic County Committee of the Tenth Assembly District made by the Democratic association of that district, which is supporting Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post for leader.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- On the eve of the Army-Navy game at Philadelphia last year Fritz Crisler sat with two New York football writers in the taproom of the Penn A.C. ruminating on what Yale's eleven iron men had done to his "unbeatable" team.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 16. -- Charges that leaders of the Roosevelt wing of the Democratic party in Louisiana conspired in the assassination of Senator Huey P. Long were reiterated today at the inquest into the killing of the assassin.

The Consolidated Gas System is seriously considering filing an injunction suit within the next few days against Mayor La Guardia's proposed municipal power plant, it became known last night. The suit, if filed, probably would be in the form of an order restraining the holding of the referendum on the power plant project at the November election.

ROME, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Benito Mussolini answered Great Britain's concentration of fighting ships in the Mediterranean tonight with a sudden order dividing Italy's armed naval force into Adriatic and Mediterranean fleets.

Theodore Martin Riehle, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, said yesterday that reference to the amount of life insurance in force in the United States, $98,000,000,000, and the large number of policyholders, 63,000,000, led many persons to wonder whether the saturation point of life insurance sales would not be reached soon.

Cool weather has stimulated so much early consumer purchasing of Fail needs that current retail trade is estimated to be running about two weeks ahead of last year at this time, according to merchants who were in the markets here yesterday.

Back from a tour of housing projects in Europe, Nathan Straus yesterday was full of praise for government low-Cost housing and park construction abroad. Mr. Straus, who was designated by Mayor La Guardia to report upon municipal housing in European cities which he visited in the Summer, said he would have a formal report of his survey ready for the Mayor within two weeks.

H.C. Davidsen, an official of the German Foreign Office, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. For thirteen years, until 1907, he was Professor of German at Cornell University. He said he had many friends there and that he would visit them for several weeks.

His campaign for the election of the Tammany leader of the Fifteenth or "silk stocking" Assembly district between former Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy, present leader, and former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney reached a hectic end last night with meetings at the Sheehy clubhouse at 1,019 Madison Avenue and the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club, 21 East Seventy-sixth Street.
A tall, slim man slipped into the office of Nicholas Arcerri, assistant cashier of Newborg Co., brokers, of 60 Broadway at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning.
MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Juan Ignacio Pombo was welcomed to Mexico City today by his sweetheart and 5,000 cheering Mexicans who had awaited him since last May.

Throughout the city today, the American flag will be displayed conspicuously to mark the 148th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution, while in many quarters there will be patriotic exercises and a general rededication of service to the Constitution and its ideals.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16. -- Lasting peace was the mutual wish expressed today at the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States by the American veterans and representatives of the Dai Nippon Zaigo-Gunjin-Kai, the veterans' association of Japan.

Good citizens, if a little surprised, should be pleased by the ampler preparations than usual made by the Police Commissioner and the Attorney General for today's battle at the primaries. This army of policemen, this fat division of sworn assistants, these reserves in waiting, these radio patrolmen remind us not of the disorder to be apprehended but of the disappearance of "apathy" in a gratifying number of Assembly districts.

Izzy Jannazzo, East Side welterweight, held Harry Dublinsky, Chicago contender, to a draw in the feature ten-round bout which ushered in the indoor boxing season at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Dr. Elizabeth C. Adams, a Bellevue Hospital interne, testified as a State witness yesterday in General Sessions at the felonious assault trial of Daniel Elwood, 46 years old, an automobile mechanic, for fracturing the skull of her ambulance driver, James Mullins, in April, 1933.

Accused of having destroyed property in the home of Archbishop Athenagoras, head of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, Pano Stamos, 37 years old, formerly rector of St. George's Greek Orthodox Church in Philadelphia, was held in $100 bail yesterday in Long Island City magistrate's court.

Yesterday's fine, crisp weather proved too great an attraction for 2-year-old David Greene, who walked nonchalantly from his home at 501 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly after noon, despite the fact that he lacked both a shoe and a stocking on one foot.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16. -- The four-day manoeuvres of the Red army near Kiev ended yesterday with a major engagement between the Blue assailants and the Red defense. The struggle began with a heavy attack of the Blues upon the right of the Reds, who were protected by a river.

Supporters of Chase Mellen Jr., candidate for re-election as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, struck back yesterday at David B. Costuma, leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District and Commissioner of Elections, who announced his desertion of Mr. Mellen on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Assertions that the Roosevelt administration is planning to establish an absolute autocracy at Washington through revision of the Constitution were voiced tonight by Frank O. Lowden, Republican, former Governor of Illinois, and Joseph B. Ely, Democrat, former Governor of Massachusetts.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 16. -- Dr. and Mrs. Stewart Lee Jeffrey entertained with a tea today at the Mount Washington Hotel for Baron and Baroness von Hagendorp of Miami Beach, Fla., who have a cottage at Pecketts, Sugar Hill, for Autumn.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- The Reichstag's formal designation of the swastika banner as the flag of Germany puts the seal on totalitarianism and the country will henceforth march under the crooked cross. Its adoption, Chancellor Adolf Hitler told the all-Nazi Reichstag, sitting in extraordinary session yesterday, represents liquidation of a debt of gratitude to the Nazi movement.

The political history of Louisiana for the last seventy years has demonstrated beyond question that a commonwealth can be democratic in form of government and nevertheless become a corrupt despotism in the control of selfish demagogues.

The constitutionality of the Public Utility Act should be settled as soon as possible, according to Robert E. Healy, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is responsible for enforcement of the act.
" Special Agent," a Warner Brothers-Cosmopolitan production, with Bette Davis and George Brent, opens this morning at the Strand.

Mr. and Mrs. John B. Aspegren gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Molly Trowbridge Townsend and John Curtis Gibbons, whose marriage will take place Saturday in Christ Church, Greenwich, Conn. The other guests, who also will be members of the bridal party, were:

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Mrs. William H. Dieffenbach won the honors at the Fall show of the Nyack Garden Club held today in the American Legion Building here. She won three firsts in the dahlia classes and tied for first in the miscellaneous class.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Estimating that a surplus of from 20,000,000 to 30,000,000 bushels of non-milling wheat exists in the Pacific Northwest, the Farmers National Grain Corporation recommended today that the AAA. export this grain to foreign markets under the amended AAA Law.

The Brooklyn Democratic organization headed by Frank V. Kelly was riding early this morning to an overwhelming victory in the party primaries as the returns trickled in from all parts of Kings County.

Apartment leasing, both in the city and suburbs, continued in volume yesterday. As an indication of activity, it was reported that leases have been signed for more than 1,100 of the 1,416 apartments in the five buildings of the Hillside Homes development at Boston Post Road and East Chester Avenue, the Bronx.

Yesterday's statement at Geneva by the Italian delegation puts a slightly better face on the question uppermost there. It was explained that when the official communique of the Italian Government last Saturday declared positively that Italy would accept "no compromise," the intention was not to exclude the possibility of negotiations.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 17. -- A crowd of more than 20,000 persons, 6,000 of them school children, applauded wildly today as Herbert Hoover, in a Constitution Day speech at the San Diego Exposition, voiced a sharp attack on dictatorial governments and assailed the Roosevelt administration.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 17. -- For the first time in history a Bolivian airplane landed in Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, today. The neutral Chaco Military Commission, invited by President Eusebio Ayala to make the visit, left the Bolivian headquarters in the Chaco this morning for Asuncion in a trimotored Bolivian commercial plane.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17. -- Dr. Thomas S. Baker, ill for more than a year, retired today as president of Carnegie Institute of Technology.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17. -- News of Len Koenecke's tragic death struck the Brooklyn baseball club with numbing force early today and sent the players on the field against the Cardinals in a depressed mood that no ordinary ill fortune of baseball could have brought about.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 (AP). -- War veterans swung today from consideration of world peace proposals to a more personal matter, the soldiers' bonus. They heard Representative Patman of Texas assure them that the adjusted service certificates would be paid soon after Congress convenes in January.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17. -- Tuckahoe, historic estate on the James River near Richmond, where Thomas Jefferson spent his boyhood, was sold today for $75,000 to the Rev. and Mrs. N. Addison Baker of this city by its owners, John G. Coolidge, Harold J. Coolidge and Roger Coolidge of Boston.

Ralph Beaver Strassburger, a former Naval Academy football star, now a well-known capitalist and horseman, was accused in the Supreme Court yesterday of transferring property estimated at $1,000,000 to his wife, Mrs. May Bourne Strassburger, daughter of the late Commodore Frederic G. Bourne, to escape payment of judgments for $130,139 obtained abroad by brokerage firms, and now held by Howard J. Delaney.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Republican leader J. Russel Sprague chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Nassau County, was more strongly entrenched tonight than ever as Republican leader. Almost complete returns indicated that his adherents had won about 80 per cent of all election districts.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, who has won more games than any other pitcher in the American League, hurled his twenty-fourth victory of the season today, and, by his 5-4 triumph, brought the Red Sox up on even terms with the Tigers for the series, each holding one victory.

TOKYO, Sept. 17. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Treasury, leaves for China tomorrow without having obtained Japanese cooperation in the British plan for financial assistance to stabilize the Chinese currency.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Syracuse, conqueror of the circuit champion twelve times in twenty-two games during the regular season, again turned back the Royals in the opening game of the final round of the International League play-offs tonight, coming from behind to take a 7-to-6 decision.

A partial victory for the labor unions in their fight for the prevailing wage rate on WPA jobs appeared probable yesterday as a result of recent negotiations in Washington, it was disclosed yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator in this city.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17. -- Political rivals for control of the State ruled for seven years by Senator Long met here today to plan their coming struggle for power.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Already challenged by holders of 40 per cent of its general mortgage bonds, outstanding in the amount of $31,000,000, the management's plan for reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway encountered new opposition today when counsel for the RFC told the Interstate Commerce Commission that it contained provisions which that agency could not accept in principle.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- George H. Houston, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, asserted today that the corporation faced bankruptcy unless a proposed plan for reorganization of its capital structure, now before the Federal District Court, was approved by creditors and the court.

The Federal housing program "is on the brink of being a total failure," Langdon Post, Chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, said last night at a mass meeting called by the National Public Housing Conference at the Henry Street Settlement Building, 99 Park Avenue.

Advance buying, executed in copper last week on rumors of impending price advances, swung into broader channels in industry yesterday as purchasing executives began covering requirements to the end of the year on tin, lead, zinc, coal, lumber, iron and a variety of other commodities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- While he held to his intention not to split Harvard's football squad into varsity and junior varsity squads, Coach Dick Harlow today began selection of a nucleus for this year's first ream.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Miss Eleanor Woodward, a small, slender airline stewardess, told today of a battle with Len Koenecke on Monday while flying at nearly 10,000 feet between Chicago and Detroit.

In her dispatch to THE TIMES yesterday from Genoa Mrs. MCCORMICK reported a widely shared belief among the Italian people "in the existence of "a secret war chest, which will be used "in the campaign against Ethiopia or "in any other contingencies." How this was accumulated, or where it is kept, no one specifies; "but stories "circulate everywhere of buried treas-"ure Premier MUSSOLINI can draw on "when all known resources fail."

David A. Brown, philanthropist and one of the most widely known representatives of international Jewish welfare causes, addressed a meeting given in his honor by the directors and officers of the American Ort Society, at the Advertising Club last night, as the formal opening of the Ort's campaign to raise $500,000 for its refugee work abroad.

In honor of her non-stop flight across the continent in 13 hours 34 minutes, to set a new record for women fliers, Miss Laura Ingalls was the guest at luncheon yesterday of the Advertising Club of New York at its clubhouse, Park Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

A sharp break in prices of United; States Government securities tended yesterday to cause a general weakening in the entire list on the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Four Federal issues made low records, while five fell below par.
BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- The Boerse was inactive today, although the trading failed to develop further losses.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 17 (AP). -- A. Rossaco's Dowdy Dell, a recent long-priced winner at Saratoga Springs, came home first today in the Long Meadows Purse, feature event for 3-year-olds.

Half a dozen witnesses appeared yesterday before the extraordinary, grand jury investigating vice and racketeering in New York County, which remained in session for thirty minutes beyond the usual two hours in order to hear them. The names of the witnesses and the nature of their testimony were withheld by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor.

LONDON. Sept. 17. -- Eileen Bennett Whittingstall, who, as Miss Eileen Bennett, was acclaimed the most beautiful of Great Britain's tennis stars, is being sued for divorce by Edmund Owen Fearnley Whittingstall, an artist.

A recent editorial expressed some doubts as to whether dollar depreciation has acted as a stimulus to our export trade. A comparison was made between the percentage of increase in our exports in 1934 under a program of currency depreciation, and the percentage of increase in certain foreign countries which retained their parity in gold prices.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses at last got General Johnson where he wanted him yesterday -- out on an inspection of some of the WPA park projects over which they have been quarreling. The tour was a peaceful one, however, with the two officials addressing each other almost affectionately as "Bob" and "Hugh."

Governor Harold G. Hoffman, who carried the Republican party to a surprise victory when he was elected to office a year ago, suffered a severe defeat at Republican hands in the State's primary elections yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange after early weakness made a quick recovery this afternoon as a result of what appeared to be more reassuring news from Geneva.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 17. -- Emperor Haile Selassie declared today that under no circumstances would he accept a tripartite protectorate, should the League of Nations recommend it.

Three Tammany Assembly district leaders, Alderman David A. Mahoney of the First District, Dr. Solomon Goldenkranz of the Eighth District and former Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy, went down to defeat in the primary election in New York City yesterday.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- After announcing that the New York University football squad had been invited to scrimmage against West Point on Saturday, Coach Mal Stevens sent the Violet varsity candidates through two spirited sessions today.
Apartment buildings on corner plots in the Bronx figured in several of the real estate deals reported yesterday. Sale were reported for properties on Sedgwick, University and St. Lawrence Avenues.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 17. -- A general condemnation of all Communist and Socialist "theorism," severance of relations with Soviet Russia and a universal service law for mobilization in time of war was voted here today at the fifteenth annual convention of the Military Order of the World War.

WARSAW, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Five of the thirteen balloons, including the American, that started from here Sunday in the twenty-seventh James Gordon Bennett international race were reported down today, but the Polish bag Kosciuszko appeared headed for a record.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 17. -- At a private farewell reception to important Nazi leaders after the conclusion of the party congress yesterday, Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler repeated the previous categorical order to stop all "individual action" against Jews, meaning that anti-Jewish riots and maltreatment must cease.

GALES FERRY, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Ducky Pond, Yale's head coach, ordered the first dummy scrimmage of the season today in which a tentatively picked eleven took part. Pond said tonight that actual scrimmaging would be held in both morning and afternoon sessions.

A few days before last Christmas the president of the Edison Electric Institute journeyed to Washington to make a personal plea to President ROOSEVELT to have the Administration join in a friendly suit to determine the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority and its program.

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,749,850 barrels, compared with 2,660,200 in the previous week, a gain of 89,650, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 43,800 barrels in Oklahoma, 23,400 in California and 18,600 in Kansas were the principal changes.

The National Electrical and Radio Exposition opens at 11 o'clock this morning in the Grand Central Palace. More than sixty manufacturers of electrical appliances for home and industrial use will join with radio manufacturers in exhibiting their latest apparatus.

A verdict of guilty of third-degree assault was returned by a General Sessions jury yesterday against Daniel Elwood, 46 years old, of 329 East Twenty-fifth Street, an automobile mechanic, for fracturing the skull of a Bellevue Hospital ambulance driver in Elwood's home with a blow in the face.

GHALANAI, Northwest Frontier Province, India, Sept. 17. -- The Third Infantry Brigade of British Indian troops under Lieut. Col. Bennett today carried out a reconnoissance along the Toratigga Valley in the direction of Khapak Pass.

From several directions has come criticism of the AAA program. The Brookings Institution has just reported on the results of the Government control in the dairying and livestock industries, and the cigar-manufacturing industry has filed a brief asking that the processing tax on cigar leaf tobacco be abandoned.
Prices of commodity futures were uneven yesterday in the trading here. In the cash markets, all of the grains, cocoa, lard, zinc, cotton, silk and rubber moved up and eggs and tin were lower.

Directors of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of $8.75 a share on the 7 per cent cumulative prior lien stock for the period from May 1, 1929, to July 31, 1930. The arrears on Aug. 18 were $43.75 a share.

Soaring wheat prices claimed first attention in the markets yesterday. In Chicago, May wheat sold above $1 a bushel for the first time this season, with futures in Minneapolis up the 5-cent limit permitted in a single day. The share market moved irregularly higher in diminished trading, with the "munitions" stocks showing marked strength.

The football forces of Columbia and Manhattan engaged in a two-hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field and the Jasper squad outplayed the Lions. It was the final heavy workout for the Green eleven before it meets Niagara University at Ebbets Field on Saturday in its opening game of the year.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Phillies took two games from the Reds today by one-run margins.

Little, Brown are hastening the publication of "Measuring Ethiopia -- and Flight into Arabia," by Carleton S. Coon. This is an account of an anthropological expedition into Ethiopia which has its adventurous aspects. The book was originally scheduled to appear in the Spring, but now publication has been set for Oct. 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- A suggestion that a group of bankers was "playing God" in their efforts to assist the credit of the city of Coral Gables in 1930 was made today by Thurman W. Arnold, Securities and Exchange Commission examiner.

The annual statement of the New York Cotton Exchange, showing the movement into sight, supply, forwarding to mills and exports of American cotton for last season and the preceding two years was released yesterday.
WASHIIGTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Income tax collections above the estimates and exceeding last year's figures were reported by the Treasury today as it counted results from another quarterly instalment.
A plea of guilty to defrauding a man under pretext of having him appointed to a city job was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Louis Mendell, 51 years old, of 3,396 Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn.

For the new issue of $5,900,000 city of Denver, Col., bonds up for award yesterday, a syndicate composed of the Bankers Trust Company, Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Edward B. Smith Co. and the First Boston Corporation and associates, was the successful bidder.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- Export and import statistics for the first eight months of this year, which were issued today, demonstrate that in foreign trade, as in other branches of France's economic structure, no improvement has yet set in.
The sleight-of-hand boys in the booking offices are still at work. Thus:

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 17. -- In one of the bitterest primary contests in the history of the Republican party of this city the organization forces scored today a decisive victory, winning in all but two places on the City Committee.

Primary Day went by yesterday with comparative quiet at polling places all over the city, including even the most embattled areas, as an army of close to 10,000 policemen on foot and in radio cars, supplemented by 2,500 workers from the Attorney General's office, kept watch.

PANAMA, R.P., Sept. 17. -- Captain Homero Ayala, former Chief of Police of Panama, who is now held in $10,000 bail by the Canal Zone police in connection with a theft of arms from the United State Army post at Corozal, has petitioned Foreign Minister J.D. Arosemena for his return to Panama.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Assured of an all-university contest for Mayor in the coming elections, members of the faculty and graduates of Princeton University manifested their interest in active politics by flocking to the polls in the primaries here today.

NUREMBERG, Sept. 17. -- The National Socialist "party day of freedom" was over today, and every train, truck, automobile and road going from this city was jammed with the brown battalions that for a week here staged an orgy of enthusiasm and that are now taking the spirit and lessons of this congress back to their homes in every part of the country, as well as to many places abroad.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- A demonstration of fire-walking as practiced by natives at religious ceremonies in India and elsewhere was given privately before a party of scientists and doctors at Carshalton, Surrey, today without any one being able to offer any explanation of how the feat was performed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Using three teams on the offensive against a scrub eleven, Coach Fritz Crisler sent his Princeton football squad through a three-hour stationary scrimmage on University Field today to bring to a close the second day of Fall practice.

The fact that Rogers Hornsby signed a new contract yesterday to manage the Browns didn't mean a thing to the Yankees when the teams clashed at the Stadium. The McCarthymen went quietly but determinedly about the task of defeating the clan from St. Louis, 4 to 3.

Internes in the service of the Department of Hospitals will receive a monthly salary of $15 if requests submitted to Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, are granted.

Dr. Alexis Carrel, noted research scientist of the Rockefeller Institute and collaborator with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in several recent experiments, broke a reserve of many years yesterday on his return from Europe on the French liner Ile de France by discussing at length his ideas on what science could do to solve the problems of man.

The State Mortgage Commission announced yesterday that it had obtained from Supreme Court Justice Philip A. Brennan in Brooklyn an interlocutory order directing the treasurer of the school board of Hempstead, L.I., to show cause why payment in full and with 6 per cent interest on tax liens should not be accepted.

A strike of 12,000 members of the Underwear Workers Union, Local 62, affiliated with the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, was approved yesterday at a membership meeting in the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, after union leaders had reported a deadlock in negotiations with their employers.

GENEVA, Sept. 17. -- The committee of five of the League of Nations Council after having worked all day announced officially tonight that "a further meeting will be held tomorrow morning to bring suggestions suitable for forming a basis for negotiation into final shape."

The first New York victory for Mrs. John D. Hertz since that in the Saratoga Cup was scored yesterday in the first division of the Parkside Handicap at Jamaica when Wayne Wright lanced Watch Him between the other contenders in the last sixteenth and won going away in a tight finish.

GENEVA, Sept. 17. -- Dr. L. Ruzicka, who returned to Zurich yesterday from the United States very pleased with its interest in his work in artificially producing the male hormone, was back in his laboratory today continuing his work. Interviewed there by telephone from Geneva, he said in fact that only now could the real work begin.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Bob Sweeny, former Oxford golf star, who is here on a visit from England, toured the Brookville Country Club links today in 71 strokes for the best gross score in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament.

It seems quite obvious that wars are fed by the trade surpluses on the world market. Between 1914 and 1930 it is estimated that our trade surplus, that is, the amount of our goods which we sent out in excess of the goods which we received in return, was in the neighborhood of $27,000,000,000.

Representatives of a score of technical groups, construction and fire-protection associations met yesterday in the Engineers Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, to map out a program designed to bring about coordination of conflicting building codes in various parts of the country.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- The Cairo correspondent of The Times of London cables his paper tonight that for a month Egypt has been the object of vigorous Italian propaganda which, apart from representing the Italian case in the Ethiopian dispute in favorable colors, appears to aim at aggravating the differences between Great Britain and Egypt and stirring up trouble for Britain.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. The total was also less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 933, as against 1,240 for the previous week and 1,040 in the same period last year.

Two detectives of the main office squad at police headquarters arrested Gustave Freeman, a Frenchman, shortly after he stepped down the gangway of the French liner Ile de France at 5:30 o'clock last night.
In a thin early morning haze over the inner harbor, the Grace liner Santa Barbara and the Ambrose Lightship were in collision off the Quarantine dock on Staten Island yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 17. -- While informed sources emphasized the unfriendly nature of British "precautions" in the Mediterranean area, it was learned that Premier Benito Mussolini had ordered restored to service two of Italy's war vessels, lying inactive in docks at Taranto.

Ceremonies held yesterday morning aboard the three Hapag-Lloyd liners berthed here marked the official triumph of the swastika banner of Chancellor Hitler over the black, white and red standard of an older Germany.

Midtown business rentals reported yesterday included a lease by the National Grain Yeast Corporation, James Roosevelt, president, in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street. The company, established in 1926, has its plant in Belleville, N.J. Henry I. Chanin of Chanin Management, Inc., also reported that Oldetyme Distillers, Inc., which concern occupies part of the forty-third floor in the Chanin Building, is moving to the entire forty-fifth floor.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The Consolidated Gas system began two lawsuits yesterday in a move to prevent the referendum on a municipal power plant from being held at the November election.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 17. -- A speech from the throne with which Queen Wilhelmina today opened a session of the States General was pessimistic and made an unfavorable impression in financial circles here. On the other hand, there were no further gold withdrawals today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17. -- After dropping the first game of a doubleheader to Paul Dean and the Cardinals, 4 -- 2, the Dodgers today crept in under cover of darkness to capture the seven-inning nightcap, 8 to 7.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 18. -- London newspapers agree that the report of the League of Nations committee of five will be unacceptable to Italy. Following are statements by correspondents appearing in the newspapers:

General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, was burned in effigy yesterday after the effigy, a six-foot doll with head of cabbage and scarlet fireman's hat, had been carried before relief workers engaged in the construction of recreation buildings at Crotona Park, Fulton Avenue and 172d Street, the Bronx.

REGINA, Sask., Sept. 17. -- In a vigorous opening speech here in a Western election campaign which his opponents had freely predicted would prove a humiliation for him, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett threatened drastic measures against the interests which have been fighting his efforts to nationalize Canada's grain trade,
ROME, Sept. 17. -- The attention of Italians is being attracted more and more by the warlike preparations Great Britain is making in the Mediterranean.

In your editorial "How Far Has Recovery Gone?" you devote your entire attention to the record of machines and securities and disregard our human problem. Yet it is necessary to remind our prophets in and out of politics that only the solution of our human problem will determine whether and how far we are on the road of real recovery.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Dollar wheat returned today to the blackboard on the Board of Trade after an absence of nearly six months as the result of broad and general buying based on sensational reports of crop deterioration in Argentina. Both the December and the May deliveries here sold at new high marks for the season, while all futures in Winnipeg and leading foreign markets were in new ground, with Buenos Aires in the lead.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 17. -- Following is the text of former President Herbert Hoover's Constitution Day speech here today:
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Indians registered a 5-to-3 victory over the Athletics today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- Reflecting chiefly increased operations in iron, steel, textiles and clothing, gains of 2 per cent in employment and 11 per cent in payrolls in Pennsylvania factories were recorded in mid-August compared with told-July, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.

After the price of copper had been advanced to 9 cents a pound on Monday, domestic buying of that metal quieted yesterday at its new price level. However, there was a good demand for the metal abroad and prices advanced 2 1/2 points to the equivalent of 8.60 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Calumet Calculation, sterling pacer owned and driven by Harry Whitney, won the classified pace at the Fair Grounds today in four fast blanket finishes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Although the United States is not likely to be involved in a foreign war, maintenance of world peace is the immediate responsibility of all nations, United States Senator Marvel M. Logan of Kentucky declared here tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 17. -- The opening today of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup polo tournament brought with it the end of British hopes for this season, for the Hurlingham team of London succumbed to Long Island, 16 to 10, on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

MANILA, Wednesday, Sept. 18. -- An overwhelming victory appeared assured for Manuel Quezon in the election of the first President of the new Philippines Commonwealth as returns came in from yesterday's polling.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Sept. 18. -- Defeat for Governor Earle's plan to rewrite and "modernize" Pennsylvania's sixty-one-year-old Constitution to help bring the Commonwealth into line with the Roosevelt New Deal social security program appeared probable early today.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 17. -- Speaking as a member of President Roosevelt's official family, Secretary Roper tonight projected for possible decision by the nation the issue of a constitutional amendment permitting "bold, direct action'' in times of "acute national distress."
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Most of the British Isles and Northern France were slowly recovering tonight from the effects of the fiercest storm they had experienced in years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Unless the Yankees work a baseball miracle, the world series will open in Detroit on Wednesday, Oct. 2. This was decided today at a meeting of representatives of five clubs still having a mathematical chance of victory in the two major leagues, with Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, acting as chairman.

Major Gen. T.Q. Ashburn, president of the government-owned Inland Waterways Corporation, attacked yesterday the policies of the American railways toward government regulation as "selfish." He addressed about 350 representatives of railroads, water lines and shippers at a luncheon meeting of the Traffic Club of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Gambling among inmates of the Bronx County jail annex, at 161st Street and Third Avenue was reported to the State Commission of Correction today by John L. Schoenfeld, who as inspector urged installation of the "charge-slip" system, as recommended after a previous inspection.

New York City last week had the lowest infant death rate for any week in its history, the Department of Health reported yesterday. There were sixty-three infant deaths, a rate of 32.5 per 1,000 births.

Mention of the Constitution of the United States makes one think that perhaps this column has been unfair to SINCLAIR LEWIS. He was recently assailed here on the grouted of a statement issued by his publishers to the effect that Mr. Lewis had to lock himself up in his Vermont farm to write his latest book.

As far as could be learned at the Stock Exchange yesterday, the proposed extension of members' telephone quotation service to the bond section is no nearer realization than it was three or four months ago when Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, mentioned the project at one of his first press conferences.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 17. -- For three college generations the ancient Japanese gong that is heard on the banks of the Severn only when Navy beats Army remained as mute at Autumn time as the harp that hung on Tara's walls.

Although many are called to labor in the vineyard of the Lord, "Few Are Chosen" to remain, and Nora Lawlor has written a simple chronicle play on that reverent theme which was acted lovingly at the Fifty-eighth Street Theatre last evening.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 17. -- Reports from the Black Sea port of Constanta indicated today that British ships in Rumanian and Bulgarian harbors on the Black Sea had received orders immediately to proceed to Gibraltar. Excepted from this order, it is said, are only those ships that are taking cargoes of mineral oil, which can wait until they take aboard their cargoes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. (AP). -- AAA officials said today that no notice would be taken at this time of individuals who had announced that they would not abide by the Potato Control Law. They said the law would affect only potatoes grown after Dec. 1, 1935.

With the demand for tickets for the fight between Joe Louis and Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium next Tuesday night so great that it has almost swamped his organization, Mike Jacobs, promoter for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, felt assured yesterday, and with no little satisfaction, that the gross receipts would reach $1,000,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Charlie Grimm's amazing Cubs, whose winning streak has brought the Wrigley entry from practically nowhere to a point where it needs only to thunder down the homestretch to bag the National League pennant, seemed to bear a charmed life today.

Among the addresses heard yesterday urging a continuance of the Constitution in its present form and the rejection of proposed amendments for "liberalizing" the basic law of the country were those in Faneuil Hall, Boston, and in the Chicago Stadium.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Christopher Artele, 20 years old, of 21 Harrison Avenue, Garfield, N.J., was sentenced today to serve seven to ten years in the State penitentiary in connection with the hold-up last July of five golfers, one of whom was shot, on the Ridgewood golf links.
No change was apparent in any section of the money market, the demand for funds being light and quotations unchanged for all classes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Warm weather and a slow demand for fresh meat was largely responsible for a drop of 15 to 25 cents a hundred weight in the prices of hogs here today, with some sales of weights under 180 pounds showing losses of 35 to 50 cents.

Influenced by a sharp advance in wheat, fears concerning the pacific outcome of events in Europe and disappointingly small hedging pressure, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned upward abruptly yesterday. After gaining about a quarter cent a pound at one time and reacting slightly toward the close, the list ended 15 to 21 pouts higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Rumors that Joseph P. Kennedy would resign from the chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission were revived here today as he prepared to sail for Europe next week.
