The Center Theatre, which closed last week after "The Great Waltz" had ended its forty-four weeks' run, will be reopened as a motion picture house early next month, it was announced yesterday. The exact date of the opening and the name of its first film presentation have not been decided upon.

Local issues dominated the primary election in areas outside New York City yesterday and with the smoke of battle cleared State chieftains of both parties planned an intensive election campaign for control of the Assembly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today took under advisement a request by attorneys for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway asking an extension of six months, to Feb. 27, 1936, in which to file a reorganization plan under Section 77 of the amended Bankruptcy Law.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Manager Jimmie Dykes's double in the fourteenth inning scored the deciding run today as Chicago defeated Washington, 3 -- 1.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Sylvan M. Barnet, member of the brokerage firm of Barnet, Fuerst Co., who committed suicide Jan. 10, 1933, by jumping from a window of his apartment at 911 Park Avenue, shows that he left $856,850 gross and $784,597 net.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 17. -Judge John P. Nields, in the United States District Court, today approved a modified reorganization plan of the Celotex Company, providing for $500,000 in new working capital obtained by Bror Dahlberg, president, from Wallace Grove of New York.

VIENNA, Sept. 17. -- Austrian police today confiscated an issue of the Prague Press which reprinted a story published in London that Franz von Papen, German Minister to Austria, is extremely active in trying to unseat the Austrian Government. Government circles vigorously denied the story.

A bitter attack on New Deal legislation was launched yesterday by Clinton L. Bardo, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, at a luncheon meeting of the New York Trade Association Executive at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Back to work went Max Baer today after his short vacation. The ex-champion held a serious sparring session which, if it did not show him to be much of a boxer, demonstrated that he is as strong as steel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The filing of eight additional registration statements under the Securities Act for a total of $15,499,575 all representing new issues was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It seems a pity that Patsy Grazzianni and Ercole Panessa, compatible partners, find themselves halted in their business venture for the lack of a reliable hamburger recipe; especially, since they have gathered sufficient data to insure a prosperous Winter, when, according to Abraham Cohen's letter, they may bank on their following indulging in the luxury of hot-dogs, hamburger and shoe shines.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP). -- Caprain Richard Sundstrom said today that he hopes to have the Morgan liner Dixie, grounded by the Labor Day hurricane, afloat again in less than a week.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Westchester voters settled many local and county contests today by writing in nominations which caused extensive confusion and spoiling of ballots.

The Banking Act of 1935 fails of its purpose to give the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve an effective control of the national credit, according to an analysis by J.H. Riddle, economist of the Bankers Trust Company.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best, commander-in-chief of the American and West Indies Squadron of the British Navy, and Lady Best were hosts aboard H.M.S. York here tonight. After they had given a dinner on the flagship they joined with the ship's officers in giving a dance.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 17. -- The government is firmly convinced that, when the proposals of the Geneva five-power committee are made known,. the interests of Ethiopia will demand that she await a decision by Italy before stating her own decision.

It was not so long ago that New York sportsmen eager to experience the sensation of hooking a giant fish looked only to distant waters -- Catalina, New Zealand, Tahiti -- where pioneers in big-game angling, led by Zane Grey, had blazed the trail to new fields of romance and adventure.
BERLIN, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 14 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

GENEVA, Sept. 17. -- France, speaking in the second committee of the League of Nations Assembly through Georges Bonnet, Minister of Commerce, and really addressing London and Washington, made a bid today for stabilization of currencies.
A dozen properties, including four in Manhattan and eight in the Bronx, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:
DES MOINES, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Polk County Grand Jury brought to seven today the number of Democratic State officials indicted since Jan. 1.

The busiest area in the city in the daytime, judged by the number of workers, is that bounded by Fifth and Eighth Avenue, Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets, according to a map made public yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning and the New York City Housing Authority.

A reproduction of the little shop on Canal Street in which Aaron Arnold in 1827 began a modest mercantile establishment which has grown into the modern Arnold Constable Co. store at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, will be open to the public for a month beginning today.

A new assistant concertmaster and a new solo viola player will be among the changes in personnel presented when the New York Philharmonic-Symphony opens its ninety-fourth season in Carnegie Hall on the evening of Thursday, Oct. 3, under the baton of Otto Kiemperer.

While most foreign currencies continued weak, the guilder rallied strongly here yesterday as a result of the declaration of Queen Wilhelmina, in opening Parliament, that devaluation could not be considered a means of benefiting the Netherlands.

The Associated Cigar Manufacturers and Leaf Tobacco Dealers, which has filed a brief with the AAA asking for the abandonment of the processing tax, does not believe that this will cause an immediate fall in prices, Samuel Blumberg, the organization's counsel, explained yesterday.
Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax, the main source of revenue for its pay-as-you-spend relief policy, have amounted to $27,033,282 so far, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 17.-- Unemployment relief problems were considered again by President Roosevelt today in a conference that in its general conclusions indicated still further delay and possible complications in the full carrying out of the contemplated work-relief program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- An indication that President Roosevelt is prepared to take a greater part in the actual direction of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program than heretofore was given by Secretary Ickes at his press conference today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 17. -- The Richmond Valley Garden Club is to hold its annual meeting tomorrow at the Berkshire Garden Centre in Stockbridge and tea later will be served at the home of Mrs. Henry W. Dwight.

The first public offering of insured mortgages of the Federal Housing Administration will be made here today in the amount of $1,250,000. The mortgages are priced to yield from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. They are on properties in eight States.

Demands for wage increases, reduction of hours and improvement of working conditions in hotels in this city will be presented to the Hotel Association next week, it was announced yesterday by a committee acting for twenty-seven unions in the hotel and restaurant field affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax, the main source of revenue for its pay-as-you-spend relief policy, have amounted to $27,033,282 so far, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 17.-- Unemployment relief problems were considered again by President Roosevelt today in a conference that in its general conclusions indicated still further delay and possible complications in the full carrying out of the contemplated work-relief program.

Speakers stressed the economic and religious hardships experienced by minorities in Germany at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Astor in honor of Nathan Straus, who arrived here several days ago after a tour of England, France and Switzerland.
BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Major interest in today's primary elections in Suffolk County centred in Republican committee contests in forty-one election districts.
For four and a half hours in Yorkville Court yesterday, Magistrate August Dreyer heard one witness testify in the case of two women accused of spattering ink on an Italian vice consul on Sept. 7.

Men and women in native costumes from all parts of the world moved past a background of massed flags in City Hall Plaza yesterday in a pageant symbolizing the nationalities absorbed in the American population since the adoption of the Constitution 148 years ago.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Miss Cherry Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guthrie Shaw of Three Gardens here, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance at the Apawamis Club.

In the first six months of this year net income of 158 companies in the iron and steel industry aggregated $30,923,927 after all charges, or 22 per cent more than the $25,305,232 reported in the corresponding period of last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

From echoing oratory, interspersed with much humor and some tears, the Women's National Republican Club swung last night to a historic tableau as the closing feature of its two-day observance of Constitution Day. Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, as head of the National Republican Club, presided at the final session in the clubhouse at 3 West Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The government will not oppose a Supreme Court review of a suit testing the validity of the Tennessee Valley Authority's power policy, and the way is thus cleared for a hearing at the court term which opens Oct. 7.

The concern which maturity is taking for youth makes some reparation to the oncoming generation for the unhappy state in which they find the earth. The States in our Republic have been from their Colonial days mindful and increasingly mindful of their obligation to youth, just as a matter of preparing them for literate citizenship.

There are laws to forbid the use of the American flag for advertising purposes or for purely partisan displays. The Constitution is not similarly protected. Some of the speeches and statements made on Constitution Day were over the limits of good taste, certainly, and were so extreme and shrill in tone as to stir the suspicion that selfish and party ends were more their object than the preservation of the Bill of Rights.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Sandwiched between relief conferences today, political conversations were held by the President, the first consisting of a talk on State affairs which brought Robert H. Jackson and Vincent Dailey, former counsel for the Internal Revenue Bureau and both of them State political leaders, and the second an evening talk with Postmaster General Farley and Charles Michaelson, publicity director for the Democratic National Committee, who came here as overnight guests.

SAN FRANCISCO, Spt. 17 (AP). -- Weeping from excitement, Tom Mooney lost a preliminary round today in another of the long legal battles for freedom waged by the man accused of a Preparedness Day parade bombing here in 1916 which killed ten persons.

TORONTO, Sept. 17. -- With the pilot and his companion under arrest on a charge of manslaughter, provincial authorities started a thorough investigation today of the battle in a careening airplane high over this city in the early hours this morning in which Leonard Koenecke, outfielder for the Brooklyn baseball club of the National League, was killed when he attempted to take control of the plane in his own hands.
S. Sloan Colt, president of the New York State Bankers Association, announced yesterday the appointment of a committee on nominations for directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- A sudden attempt to end a double-edged boycott resulting from Nazi anti-Jewish measures was made tonight by the National Socialists' organization for trade and industry.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 (AP). -- A five-run lead set up in the first inning enabled the Pirates to gain a 6-to-4 victory over the Braves today.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- From the Mediterranean and from the windswept waters around Great Britain there came further signs today that this nation is placing her fighting machine in readiness for any trouble that may come from the present crisis between Ethiopia and Italy.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The public must be made to realize that insurance means security, and that schemes to "put corporations on the spot, soak the thrifty and bedevil business generally" menace their insurance savings, Allen B. Sikes, eastern manager of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Westchester Country Club here today.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 17. -- Walter O'Hara, owner of the Narrangansett track, came to Rockingham Park today to win a race with his 4-year-old bay gelding New Deal.

While failures in the retail and wholesale divisions declined during the week ended Sept. 12, as compared with the five business days in the previous week, there was a light increase in manufacturing lines, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradtreet, Inc.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Governor Lehman asserted today that the election of a Democratic State Assembly next November is "particularly important to those who wish to see enlightened and humane government continue."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- In one of the sharpest Republican primaries held here in recent years, former Mayor James D. Tweed today defeated James G. Graham, former secretary to the late Governor Benjamin B. O'Dell, for the nomination for Mayor by 105 votes.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Some surprise has been caused in London by statements emanating from Rome to the effect that an invitation addressed early this year to the British Government by the Italian Government through its Ambassador, Dino Grandi, to discuss their reciprocal interests in Ethiopia has met with dilatory and evasive procedure.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Borough President Levy of Manhattan disclosed yesterday that he anticipated a taxpayer's suit designed to halt the conversion into a vehicular tunnel of the trolley car tunnel under Park Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Forty-second Street.

Auctioneers offered six properties in Manhattan and thirteen in the Bronx at foreclosure sales yesterday. The improvements consisted chiefly of dwellings and multifamily buildings. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs in the actions.

GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- Following is a summary of the plan drafted by the committee of five of the League of Nations Council for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy. The proposal, which fills seven double-spaced typewritten pages, is for the most part a skeleton outline. The quoted passages given here are unofficial translations by the Geneva correspondent.

A sweeping victory for opponents of the New Jersey sales tax, and a corresponding defeat for Governor Harold G. Hoffman, Republican, who backed the measure as a means of providing cash revenue for unemployment relief, became evident when a complete check was made last night following the State's primary election Tuesday.

The Regional Labor Board under Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, executive director, which has been quiescent during the interval between liquidation of the NRA and establishment of the new National Labor Relations Board under the Wagner Labor Disputes Act, resumed operation yesterday.

Democratic committeemen of Richmond County will meet at Stapleton within the next two weeks to elect William T. Fetherston county leader to succeed David S. Rendt, leader for ten years. Mr. Fetherston's election was assured in the primary Tuesday in which he nominated his entire slate of candidates and won 680 of the 710 county committeemen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Applications of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets with the Securities and Exchange Commission totaled 4,884 through Sept. 16, it was announced today. Additional requests are coming in and it is expected that the total will exceed 5,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The designation of Marriner S. Eccles of Utah, banker and industrialist, to be chairman of the reorganized Federal Reserve Board confirmed a widely held belief in New Deal financial circles that he was the appointee apparent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 -- Thomas J. Mooney, fighting once again for freedom and vindication, came to court in San Francisco today with photographs taken during the Preparedness Parade of 1916 in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Opposition of the bondholders protective group to the management's plan of reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway was broadened today into a frontal attack by institutional investors upon the perpetuation, through reorganizations, of minority control of large railroad systems as hearings on the plan continued before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The story of a referendum held in December, 1926, to authorize the sale of $4,500,000 of bonds of the city of Coral Gables and of various activities in connection with the marketing of the issue were unfolded today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a continuance of its inquiry into the promotion of the project in the days of the Florida land boom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- President Roosevelt proclaimed today the week beginning Oct. 6 as Fire-Prevention Week and urged officials and civic leaders in every State to "encourage the study of ways and means" to eliminate fire hazards.

The Communist party, short of sounding the first call, will make every effort to form a serious Farmer-Labor party powerful enough to cause a shift in present political alignments before the 1936 Presidential election.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- President Roosevelt announced tonight that he would nominate Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, to be chairman of the reorganized board, to be known as the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, when the new Banking Act becomes effective on Feb. 1, 1936.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18, -- Miss Rosa Christoph, 25-year-old maid at the home in Montclair of the late Edwin M. Rine, retired vice president and general manager of the Lackawanna Railroad, was named the beneficiary in a $100,000 trust fund in the will of Mr. Rine, filed here today.
BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- One workman was killed and about a dozen others were injured, some perhaps fatally, as the 80-year-old Hollis Theatre collapsed today while wreckers were demolishing it.

The Yankees weren't equal to the task of an appropriate farewell to the Browns at the Stadium yesterday. As a consequence, they had to be content with an even break in a twin bill that attracted about 5,000 fans and a split of the four-game series with Rogers Hornsby's clan.

The cornerstone for the city's new sewage disposal plant at Avenue Z and Knapp Street, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, the first to be put in operation, was placed yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia in the presence of city, State and borough officials and borough civic leaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Prices of hogs continued to decline today, dropping 10 to 35 cents a hundredweight and showed a loss of 35 to 60 cents from the high point of last week. The demand was not aggressive. Continued warm weather has decreased the demand for meats and consumers show little indication of relenting in their refusal to buy because of relatively high prices.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- On this clear and balmy afternoon, with a crowd of 33,000 rending the air with a mighty paean, Chicago's astounding baseball machine gained its greatest momentum and trampled the luckless Giants underfoot to annex its fifteenth straight victory.

ROME, Sept. 18. -- A medical miracle is happening in Italy's East African colonies of Eritrea and Somaliland as Premier Mussolini prepares for the totalitarian solution of the controversy with Ethiopia.

BUFFALO, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, told members of the Erie and Niagara County Bankers Association here tonight that "most of your troubles are past" and suggested that the first thing to do was to go "in search of good loans."

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Kate, owned by the Howe stable and ridden by R. Merritt, took the Holly Beach, fifth and feature event of today's program. The race was for distance performers over the mile and 70-yard route. Her time was 1:43 4-5.

Federal attorneys, defending compensation taxes levied under the AAA, received a setback in the United States Customs Court yesterday when Judge David H. Kincheloe ruled against their plea that a suit attacking the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act be dismissed on the ground that the action was not within the jurisdiction of the Customs Court.

Manifestations of strength, some short-lived, featured many groups of stocks yesterday as the market endeavored to shake off the lethargy that has persisted for about a week. The "war" news, domestic politics and the hopeful midweek reviews of trade were among the leading topics of the day, with some angles thereof inducing new buying.

Jim Downey, John Zuck, Pat Byrne and Co-captain Red Welch will be Manhattan's starting backfield for the opening game with Niagara University at Ebbets Field on Saturday. This quartet, a predominantly veteran combination which averages about 170 pounds, was named yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan at the conclusion of a two-hour drill at Innisfail Park.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Cy Blanton scored his eighteenth victory today, aided by Rookie Outfielder Bud Hafey's seventh-inning double, as Pittsburgh beat the Braves for the third straight time, 5 to2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The possibility that a voluntary program with benefit payments may replace the tax control plan for potatoes developed today as the Farm Administration called a hearing of potato growers in Washington for Oct. 3.

The United States liner Washington, which will dock either late tonight or tomorrow morning with 959 passengers from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has on board Rear Admiral James C. Pryor, U.S.N., retired, who attended the International Congress of Military Medicine and Pharmacy at Brussels; Anne Bullitt, daughter of the American Ambassador to Russia; Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, and:
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were again in a state of suspense today pending further developments in the Ethiopian dispute, with business much restricted.
Autumn months are to the surf caster what the mayfly hatch in the Spring is to the trouter.

Exports of scrap iron and steel from this country to Japan and Italy in the last thirty months have been nearly twice as large as in the entire eight preceding years, it was shown yesterday by figures compiled by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A new enrolment program, aimed at enlisting more than 100,000 youths in the Civilian Conservation Corps and broadening the rules under which members are accepted, will be started Oct. 1.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, who yesterday pitched his twenty-fourth victory of the season, filled the hero's role again today. Pinch-hitting for Oscar Melillo with the bases filled in the ninth, he drove in the run that gave the Red Sox a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Streaking through sunlight over black, jumping water, Crown Prince Olaf's Norwegian yacht Norna IV today won her second race in a row in the Seawanhaka Cup series. She defeated Paul Shields's Challenge, the defender, by 8 seconds over a twelve-mile triangular course.

Officials of utility holding companies have received unofficial word from Washington that several leaders in the industry are soon to be invited to the capital for a conference with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- A recapitulation of primary returns showed today that there were few upsets in the ranks of Westchester party committees.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18. -- Mrs. Emerson Root Newell of Round Hill and Texas gave a tea dance at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, this afternoon to present to society her cousin, Miss Mary Goldthwaite, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Campbell Goldthwaite of Montgomery, Ala. About 400 guests attended.

The work of preserving the facade of St. Patrick's Cathedral was begun yesterday forenoon. Taking part in the ceremonies were former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector, and other clergy of the archdiocese.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18. -- A new South American frontier incident has arisen, this time between Argentina and Bolivia. It is charged that Bolivia is occupying 2,700 square miles of Argentine territory in Jujuy Province. The Senate has agreed to hold a secret session tomorrow to consider the question.

ROME, Sept. 18. -- A government spokesman said tonight the report of the Geneva committee of five on the Italo-Ethiopian situation would be referred to the Cabinet for consideration, but that Italy did not regard it as a basis for discussion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- President Roosevelt is expected to recommend to the next Congress a six-point forest conservation program.

The breakdown of the sound apparatus on the film projection machine at the R.K.O. Orpheum Theatre at Fulton Street and Ashland Place, Brooklyn, provoked a vocal demonstration of disapproval that so frightened the management that a riot call was sent to Brooklyn Police Headquarters early last night.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- After an encouraging opening the Bourse dropped suddenly today into an extremely pessimistic mood as a result of reports that the Italian Government would reject the recommendations of the League of Nations committee for settlement of the Ethiopian dispute.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini, giving his first impressions of newspaper versions of the League of Nations peace plan, was reported today by G. Ward Price, Rome representative of The Daily Mail, to have remarked it looked as if the committee of five thought he was "a collector of deserts."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 18. -- A message received today from Tecle Hawariate, Ethiopian delegate at Geneva, informed the government that the report of the League Committee of Five was favorable to Ethiopia. The report itself reached the palace at 6:30 P.M. [12 noon yesterday in New York] and is now being deciphered.

Just what sort of campaign for silence has been instigated by our city government? Are the specialists in noise abatement so occupied measuring decibels emitted by street cars that they are unaware of what has been assaulting the ears of Yorkville residents lately? I refer to the ear-splitting street rallies which Tammany Hall has been sponsoring for one John E. Sheehy.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Pinero, bay colt by Guy Day-Pongee Silk, owned by Thomas Havens and driven by Harry Whitney, easily won the 2-year-old trot at the Fair Grounds today. Pinero scored in two straight heats, Indiana Belle taking second money, while Harris Moon placed third.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The Syracuse Chiefs made it two straight over Montreal's Royals today in their play-off series for the Governors Cup by hammering out seven runs in the eighth for a 10- to-5 victory.
Mayor La Guardia had a few comments to make yesterday on Tuesday's primary election.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler signed yesterday an order permitting Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to liquidate the Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of America. This is the sixteenth title and mortgage guaranty company to be put into liquidation.

Joseph Dunninger, chairman of the investigating committee of the Universal Council for Psychic Research, who has exposed many alleged miracles, turned last night to an analysis of the fire-walking of Kuda Bux, young Indian, whose exploit puzzled scientists in Carshalton, England, Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- President Roosevelt instructed the Treasury Department today to extend until Jan. 1 generalization of reciprocal tariff concessions to Canada, France, the Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. Under his original instructions, these privileges would have been withdrawn from those countries on Oct. 1.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Many of the 300 or more spectators at Max Baer's training workout today were treated to a sight rarely in evidence before. They saw the big, amiable ex-heavyweight Champion of the world get mad.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher in the trading here yesterday. A greatly improved tone was apparent in the sugar market. In the cash markets corn, cotton, silk and rubber were higher, while wheat, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, lard, tin and wool tops declined.

James C. Sheridan, chairman of the Democratic Executive Committee of Queens and deposed county leader, yesterday tentatively extended the olive branch to the triumvirate leadership -- Peter J. McGarry, Edward W. Cox and John C. Donovan -- of the county organization in asking for a united party to support his ticket which defeated the organization designees for nine of the seventeen nominations in the primaries Tuesday.

With the retirement to private life of its president, Dr. THOMAS S. BAKER, the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh loses the services of an educator of large views and rare constructive ability. Before he assumed the duties which he now lays down after thirteen years the Institute was recognized as a good technical school which met the more practical, vocational needs of the Pittsburgh coal and iron district.

Carrying on his campaign to drive racketeers out of the live poultry industry in this city, Market Commissioner William F. Morgan Jr. called upon the American Federation of Labor yesterday to join the fight to expel racketeers from local unions engaged in the industry.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 18. -- By scoring four birdies for the round, Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today won the low gross award of the Long Island Women's Golf Association one-day tournament, with a total of 42, 42 -- 84, two over women's par for the Lakeville Golf and Country Club course.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18. -- H. M.S. York, with Vice Admiral Sir Matthew Best, commander-in-chief of the British, American and West Indies squadron, will conclude its week's stay here tomorrow morning, when the cruiser will leave for Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Officials of the Veterans Administration calculated today that the government is spending about $760,000,000 this year on war veterans and their dependents.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- German children will in future receive one-sixth less schooling than in the past. Every child, under a decree issued today by Bernhard Rust, Nazi Minister of Education, must devote one day a week to Hitler Youth activity or the study of National Socialism.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Colonel Lloyd Collis, consulting engineer, said yesterday that only as a last resort would he bring a taxpayer's suit to halt the conversion of the street car tunnel on Park Avenue below Forty-second Street into a vehicular tunnel.

Mayor La Guardia is forcing the issue on a municipal power plant as part of a broad political program which he hopes, through alliance with President Roosevelt, may lead him eventually into the White House, Newbold Morris, Republican Alderman from the Fifteenth district, said yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday his plans for widening the usefulness of the chief medical examiner's office to science and organized medicine.

Ninety-five exhibitions of new equipment in radio, lighting, air conditioning and home electrical appliances were opened to the public yesterday at the 1935 National Electrical and Radio Exposition in the Grand Central Palace.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The owners of several big Jewish stores in Berlin were informed today by the National Socialist Shop Union heads within their stores that capital subscriptions were being raised among their employes to purchase their businesses.

MYRON BRINIG has the gift of seeing his fictional characters through a slightly sentimental haze that makes them more endearing than ordinary mortals. He can even make cantankerousness a virtue. But, like Robert Nathan and Barry Benefield, he can always stop just short of going "ham," and he has a saving sense of irony to serve as lemon juice in his generally sweet concoctions.
BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The Boerse was quiet and prices were slightly weaker today.

Voluntary compliance by a substantial majority of the woolen mills of the country with their former NRA code practices, which have been continued by rules of business procedure, was reported here yesterday by Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, in making public the results of a questionnaire.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18. -- The United States Steel Corporation will spend $140,000,000 for changes in plants and betterments soon, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board, announced today to 300 of the city's business and financial leaders gathered in the William Penn Hotel to hear from the heads of the $2,500,000 corporation their plans for the future.

GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- The League of Nations committee of five announced this afternoon it had "adopted the text of suggestions capable of serving as a basis for negotiations" in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, and Salvador de Madariaga, the chairman, submitted this text to Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy and Tecle Hawariate of Ethiopia this evening.

An inventory of the health of public school children since the opening of the Fall term will he presented by teachers on School Health Day, Sept. 26, marking a change in procedure from the practice of setting aside one day for testing pupils for physical defects, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Cities and States face a new and perplexing problem this week as the Federal Government starts to "liquidate" its transient relief program.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Electing John J. Ahern of St. Paul president, the National Boxing Association put off today until its 1936 convention at Houston, Texas, definite action on a proposal for a "czar" to rule over boxing.
An increase in West Side activity was apparent in the apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

An increase of 0.11 per cent was shown in retail credit collections during August, according to the index of twenty "key" local stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The average for the month was 39.28, against 39.17 last year, the increase being the twenty-seventh for the last twenty-eight months.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18. -- Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation, today called upon business men to get into politics in order to safeguard the principles of government which had made possible the epochal economic progress of the United States.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The thirteenth annual meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference closed in the Westchester Country Club here today in an optimistic mood regarding the future of insurance and insurance advertising.

Constructive forces assumed the dominant position yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The market turned about completely from the tendencies prevailing earlier in the week, and under the leadership of United States Government bonds showed a strong undertone most of the day.

GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- The League of Nations handed tonight to Italy and Ethiopia its plan to keep them from war -- a plan the Italian delegation had already called "absolutely inacceptable as a basis for negotiation."

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- It was officially announced today that Berthold Jakob-Salomon, German Jewish emigre journalist who was kidnapped from Swiss territory last March by Nazi agents with the connivance of German Government officials, had been returned to Switzerland yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- Pennsylvania voters have refused to heed the pleas of their Democratic Governor, George H. Earle, to rewrite the Commonwealth's 61-year-old Constitution, described by the Governor as "a relic of horse-and-buggy days."

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Eight more of Britain's fleetest destroyers hastened down the Mediterranean from Gibraltar tonight. Reports also came from Gibraltar that the 33,500-ton battleship Nelson, carrying Admiral Sir Roger Backhouse, commander of the home fleet, was expected there shortly.

Mayor La Guardia continued yesterday to assail the action of the Consolidated Gas Company in seeking to have the courts prevent a referendum on the construction of a municipal "yardstick" power plant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Potential losses of $27,437,593 by only four Eastern railroads as a result of maximum passenger fares proposed by one of the commission's examiners were cited today in a joint reply made to the Interstate Commerce Commission by all Eastern roads except the Baltimore Ohio.
WARSAW, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Two of the thirteen balloons in the twenty-seventh Gordon Bennett International Cup race -- the German and Netherland entries -- remained unaccounted for today.

J.A. Riley Co., textiles, has leased the sixth floor, about 9,000 square feet, in 260-66 Fourth Avenue, southwest corner of Twenty-first Street. The firm has been in Leonard Street for a long period. William H. Whiting Co. and M.M. Shulman arranged the rental.

Misinterpretation of signals was held responsible yesterday for the crash early Tuesday morning of the Grace liner Santa Barbara and the Ambrose Channel Lightship off the Staten Island quarantine station. A hearing on the crash was held before Captain George Fried, chief of the Steamboat Inspection Service here, and Captain Karl C. Nielson and James Smith, local inspectors.
TOKYO, Sept. 18. -- The activities of Daba Birrou, Ethiopian representative who has just reached Japan, are arousing extensive curiosity among the diplomatic corps.

TORONTO, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Ontario authorities, apparently satisfied that they have all the information they need to proceed with an inquest into the strange death in the skies of Leonard Koenecke, baseball player, decided to hold it tomorrow night as originally scheduled.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton scored a double victory in the hunter division during the first session of the thirty-third annual Mineola Horse Show, which opened today on the Fair Grounds and will continue through tomorrow afternoon.
Norman C. Norman, famous for his challenges of the NRA, the RFC and the government suspension of gold payments, set his lance yesterday in behalf of the humble potato.

TORONTO, Sept. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Announcement was made here tonight that under an agreement effective on Sept. 12 all policies of the Capital Life Assurance Company of Ottawa have been reinsured by the Confederation Life Association of Toronto.
The concentration of the British and Italian fleets in the Mediterranean area focuses world attention upon the relative naval strength of these two powers.
Will Rogers's posthumous photoplay, "Steamboat Round the Bend," featuring Anne Shirley and Irvin S. Cobb, will be presented today at the Radio City Music Hall.
A ferry crossing of the North River during the quarter-hour before 7 P.M. on Sept. 10 was an experience to be remembered for beauty and splendor by all who shared it.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18. -- A lead of 3 to 1 going into the last half of the sixth inning wasn't enough for the ancient arm of Tom Zachary today. The Cards knocked him out in the seventh and romped away with the game, 6 -- 3, thus holding their second-place position, two and one-half games behind those extraordinary Cubs.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association decided on a new policy in staging their 1935 championship and, consequently, the tourney was inaugurated today at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club with match play the order of the day.

The "greatest experiment in public taste the motion-picture industry ever conducted was announced yesterday to the board of directors of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America by Will H. Hays, the organization's president. He spoke at a quarterly meeting at 28 West Forty-fourth Street after his return from Hollywood where he studied production plans and amplified the work of the production code administration.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18. -- Political opponents of Senator Long's dictatorship made it clear today that they were counting on the national administration to fight their campaign for them in the Federal courts.

This will be a big night for Broadway -- literally Broadway, for a change. For at 8:30, "At Home Abroad," which they describe as a "musical holiday" by Howard Dietz and Arthur Schwartz, will open at the Winter Garden. After billing and all else have been arranged there emerge the following stars for the proceeding: Beatrice Lillie Ethel Waters, Herb Williams and Eleanor Powell.

Up and down two trenches twelve feet long filled with glowing charcoal of a temperature of 800 degrees a young Hindu walked barefooted day before yesterday in England and left the attendant scientists mystified.

In the arrest of Gustave Freeman, 32-year-old Frenchman, charged with bringing 120,000 allegedly counterfeit French lottery tickets into the country, Federal authorities believed yesterday that they had thwarted a plan to sell the tickets here at a profit to the French promoters of nearly 1,900 per cent.

Pointing out that the chief concern of exporters and importers today is the freeing of international trade from obstacles which continue to retard the economic movement of goods and services, James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council, yesterday sent out formal call for the organization's annual convention in Houston, Texas, Nov. 18, 19 and 20.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has obtained an injunction against H.P. Wickham of Minneapolis, doing business as the Minneapolis Stock Traders Service and the Grain Marketing Service, officials of the SEC here were informed today.
Under the largest volume of business in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1.50 a bale at one time yesterday and closed with net gains of 18 to 24 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- General Douglas MacArthur, retiring chief of the general staff of the army, will supervise the organization of the national defense forces of the new Commonwealth Government of the Philippine Islands, the War Department announced today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Templeton, after the hardest sort of a struggle on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, came through to the semi-final round of the Monty Waterbury Cup tournament, most important handicap event of polo, by the margin of a single goal.

The recent statement of ex-Senator Arthur R. Robinson in THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning the "terrible conditions" which exist in the Soviet Union is of particular interest to me, as I have just returned from a Summer spent in Russia observing general conditions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The Senators evened their series with the White Sox today by taking both ends of a double-header, 5 -- 4 and 3 -- 1.

Although production of steel ingots has been reduced one-half point to 52 per cent of capacity this week, the downward shift apparently has little significance beyond reflecting the sensitiveness of rolling schedules to the flow of orders, The Iron Age says in its weekly summary.

Extension of the city's three-point emergency relief tax program for another year after its expiration date of June 30, 1936, will be made necessary by mounting relief demands, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at City Hall.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 18. -- James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, watched Joe Louis go through seven rounds of boxing today in preparation for his fight with Max Baer Tuesday night, and though he previously picked Baer to win, he said he may still change his mind and favor the Detroit Bomber.

The city's tentative "understanding" with the B.M.T. for purchase of that company's rapid transit interests at a net price of $185,000,000 may be imperiled unless Mayor La Guardia's negotiators are able to reach a similar agreement with the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway interests within the next few weeks, it was indicated yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP). -- A ninth-inning rally game the Reds three runs and a 6-to-5 victory over the Phils today.

ALGECIRAS, Spain, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The powerful citadel of Gibraltar, across the bay, recaptured its World War appearance today with British airplanes roaring overhead and cruisers carrying out defensive manoeuvres.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 18. -- Price reductions ranging from $40 to $385 on Buick 1936 models were revealed today by President H.H. Curtice of the Buick Motor Company before nearly 100 newspaper men from throughout the United States, here for a preview of the complete line which Mr. Curtice said would be announced formally to the public Sept. 28.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty signed an order yesterday allowing Dorothy Browning Hood of Dunn, N.C., to draw $10,000 from the estate of her father, the late Edward W. Browning, wealthy real estate dealer, and to receive $800 a month for her maintenance pending settlement of the estate.
All departments of the money market were quiet in tone and steady in quotation. Business was light all around.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18. -- A memorial monument to Johns Hopkins, whose $7,000,000 gift made possible the establishment of the university and hospital which bear his name, was dedicated today in the presence of hundreds of citizens besides professors and students of the university, and physicians and department heads from the hospital and medical school.
PARIS, Sept. 18. -- Surprise and some consternation are being expressed in Paris at the action of the British Government in dispatching to the Mediterranean so large and powerful a fleet.
Bob Quinn, general manager of the Dodgers, declared yesterday he was totally in the dark on reports that he would be offered the presidency of the Boston Nationals, according to The Associated Press.

The Federal jury in the second trial of James C. McKay and William J. Graham, Reno (Nev.) promoters charged with mail fraud in the operation of a confidence ring, was locked up at 11 o'clock last night in the McAlpin Hotel after a twelve-hour deadlock.

ROME, Sept. 18. -- A Cabinet council was held this morning under the chairmanship of Premier Benito Mussolini, but it disappointed all Italians because it did not concern itself at all with the general European situation or the Anglo-Italian situation in particular, which is now monopolizing interest here, but limited itself to approving a number of financial measures to raise the money necessary for waging war in East Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The Indians made a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Athletics by taking both ends of today's double-header. The Redskins won the first game, 10 -- 5, and the second, 10 -- 0.

GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- While the broad lines of the so-called international mandate over Ethiopia were being secretly rounded out today, a standing committee of the Assembly was discussing the League of Nations administration of existing mandates.

Stricter enforcement of the State Liquor Authority's label regulations to assure a "square deal" to consumers was announced yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the Authority, in an article in the September issue of The ABC News, publication of the board.

NAHAKKI, Northwest Frontier Province, India, Sept. 18. -- The British Indian punitive force operating under Brig. Gen. J.C.E. Auchinlock, attained its objective early this morning when the troops began to filter through Nahakki Pass into the plains of Kamalai.

Sammy Renick, winning rider in the Aqueduct Handicap last Saturday, scored a triple yesterday at Jamaica when he was astride Below Zero in the featured Belgrade Claiming Stakes after bringing Aileen C. home first in an earlier race, and Chatterfol in the nightcap.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The 15-inch guns of the battle cruiser Hood, the largest and mightiest warship in the world, tonight are guarding the Strait of Gibraltar, the western gateway to the Mediterranean, through which all Italy's foodstuffs and other raw materials coming from the open Atlantic must pass.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Discussing definitely for the first time his trip to the West Coast, scheduled to begin next week, President Roosevelt made known today that he planned only two formal speeches, one at Boulder Dam and the other at San Diego.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18. -- Dr. R.H. McKee, Professor of Chemical Engineering at Columbia University, reports that hybrid breeding methods are being used to produce a fast-growing quality of tree which will be of immense value in reforestation and in providing for pulp and paper.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- With the conclusion of the Nuremberg party conclave the governmental ministries in Berlin are resuming their functions. The Foreign Office, which was virtually depopulated last week, again presented a normal appearance today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Pacific Lighting Corporation of San Francisco has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of $10,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1945.

Under the present set-up of the Government's work-relief program, the personal approval of the President must be given to every project before it is undertaken. In theory, he is required to exercise the wisdom of Solomon in deciding a myriad of such questions -- to cite a few recent examples -- as the following:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Rising war clouds abroad have not yet affected the present or prospective assignments of American naval ships nor any changes in fleet orders under consideration, Secretary of the Navy Swanson said today.
Small housing parcels continued to furnish the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The National Conference for Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., is planning to introduce in the Legislatures of the forty-eight States this Winter legislation which will make it possible to conduct lotteries under supervision for the benefit of hospitals and other institutions.

The primary election on Tuesday settled a number of factional fights within Tammany Hall, left an equal number of perennial battles unsettled, and apparently will have no immediate effect on the policies of the Hall or the stability of the Dooling leadership, it was indicated yesterday.

Through spokesmen who would not permit their names to be used, the construction unions that have been demanding the prevailing rate of wages on WPA jobs let it be known yesterday that they would not be satisfied with the compromise plan disclosed by General Hugh S. Johnson, local Works Progress Administrator, as being considered in Washington.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP). -- A new approach to the motion picture "problem" on the part of the 23,000 local units of the National Congress of Parent-Teachers Associations was indicated today by a change of leadership in its committee relating to the industry.

NEWARK, N.J., Thursday, Sept. 19. -- A family quarrel which started last night in an apartment in the Clinton Hill section of Newark ended early this morning in the death of four men, one of whom, the police believe, killed the three others and then, after telephoning Newark police headquarters, shot himself through the heart with a twelve-gauge buckshot pump gun.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., Sept. 18. -- More than 600 persons, including almost every prominent Republican living in Nassau County, attended a dinner here tonight to open a drive for funds to finance the Republican 1936 campaign in this country.

Because of a lack of equipment and clothing the city's prisons are "run like poorhouses" and the wearing apparel of the inmates is like that one would expect to find in "a little Idaho jail," Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, declared yesterday.

Realty trading in the city yesterday was featured by deals for flats in Yorkville. Several rentals of private homes also were reported. In Brooklyn there was a good demand for dwellings and tenements.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Virtually unanimous approval of the revived plan for a 40-foot Delaware River channel from Philadelphia to the sea was voiced today by business and shipping interests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- New York City's request for approval of a plan to establish and operate a foreign trade zone at Stapleton, Staten Island, will be considered at public hearings today by the Foreign Trade Zone Board to begin Oct. 12.

That 39.2 per cent of the residential areas of the city is occupied by single-family residences is shown in a survey recently made by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning with the cooperation of the New York City Housing Authority.
After fifteen years of unjust attack from hesitant and parochial minds, the League of Nations stands forth today as the noblest secular institution in the history of mankind.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 18. -- The 1936 budget, sent to Parliament today, shows total expenditures of about 711,000,000 guilders, leaving a deficit of almost 109,000,000 guilders. Through a reduction in taxes on wine, liquors and beer the deficit will be increased by 10,000,000 guilders more, making the total 119,000,000, which the government intends to eliminate by further economies and a few new taxes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 18. -- There was a decided increase in consumption of both fuel and lubricating oils in the last year and the greatest demand in history for premium products, J.E. Moorhead of Oil City, Pa., executive secretary of the Pennsylvania Grade Crude Oil Association, said today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18. -- The leaders of both major parties, John S. Thorp, Democrat, and J. Russell Sprague, Republican, were more strongly entrenched today than ever in their posts as a result of yesterday's primaries. Committeemen favorable to the two leaders won easily.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A vigorous attack on New Deal policies was made tonight by James A. Emery, chief counsel of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a letter to members of the association in which he warned that industry must be prepared to meet further government control, "perhaps more extreme than any yet suggested."

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 18. -- Sation, George D. Widener's 5-year-old chestnut gelding, emphasized his position as the outstanding sprinter at Rockingham Park today, when he won the Pierce Speed Handicap from ten fast competitors. On the sleek back of Sation were loaded 136 pounds, a burden which would have overwhelmed a lesser horse.

DUBLIN, Sept. 18. -- John Thomas Kennedy, 10-year-old good-will ambassador from the Boys Club of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, N.Y., to the boys of Ireland, arrived here today from Kilmalloch to pay his respects to Lord Mayor Alfred Byrne.

It is a good thing that we should begin to think about taxation. In the coming years the matter will more and more engross the minds of people as taxation itself will become more vital in their everyday lives.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Lord Ponsonby has resigned the leadership of the Labor party in the House of Lords and Sir Stafford Cripps has resigned from the party executive because of differences of opinion with the party on foreign policy and the party's decision to support League sanctions to enforce peace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A report of the National Lawyers' Committee, holding the National Labor Relations Act unconstitutional and "a complete departure from our constitutional and traditional theories of government," was issued today by the American Liberty League.

Pennsylvania's Constitution goes back to 1874. Doubtless there is in it ancient matter, unsuited to these times. Piecemeal revision by amendment is too leisurely for the reformers. Lest the people be tired, amendments may not be offered to them more than once in five years.

Few upsets were revealed yesterday with the final tabulation of the results in the primary election contests up-State for the Democratic and Republican nominations for the Assembly. Local issues predominated in the campaign.

Frank V. Kelly, returning from a luncheon with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park, expressed confidence last night that the insurgent Democratic candidates who were defeated by the Brooklyn Democratic organization at the primaries would return to the regular party fold to make certain an impressive victory on election day.

The union inland freight terminal operated by the Port of New York Authority handled about 30,000,000 pounds of freight last month, the largest business since its opening as a public facility, in October, 1932, it was announced yesterday. This represents a gain of 1,100,000 pounds, or 9 per cent, in railroad freight over the corresponding month a year ago, and 17 per cent over August, 1933.

The draw was announced yesterday for the final polo tournaments of the season on Long Island, the two Autumn Plates events. Play in the twelve-goal tournament will get under way today at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., at 5:30 P.M., when a Great Island-Ox Ridge team will meet J.H. (Ben) Phipps's Nuts in a first-round match.

CLIFTON SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP). -- On the heels of the primary election, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, delivered a new attack tonight against the Democratic State and national administrations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Investigations of income taxes by Internal Revenue agents during the fiscal year 1935, which ended June 30, resulted in recommendations of assessments aggregating $276,008,250.07 in addition to taxes reported voluntarily by individuals and corporations, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Liberal profit-taking in wheat developed today on the Board of Trade as a result of reactionary tendencies in Liverpool and Buenos Aires, but an excellent class of buying marked the recission. Brokers who frequently represent mills took about 1,500,000 bushels of futures and support came also from mills in Minneapolis.

In general, Tuesday's primaries in this city scored in both parties victories for the regular organization. That is what an organization is for, to get out the vote in support of its leaders. For a primary election the polling was unusually heavy. But that only meant more and harder work for the district captains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A Supreme Court review of a decision of the Court of Claims awarding the Ford Motor Company $2,115,313 in interest on an overpayment of income tax for 1919 was asked today by the government.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18. -- A special investigation by regular army officers of Civilian Conservation Corps camps to learn whether reports of Communist activities were true and a Congressional inquiry into alleged subversive movements in the United States were recommended today by the Military Order of the World War.

With a view to simplifying the activities of its field organization, a new plan, which will eliminate division offices in New York, Chicago and San Francisco, is being put into effect, it was announced yesterday by Austin S. Igleheart, president of General Foods Sales Co., Inc.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18. -- Soviet industrial production for the final quarter of this year will not be far short of the total annual production in 1928, when the first Five-Year Plan was started.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The United States Marine Corps rifle team of ten men won the national rifle team match today with a total score of 2,816 out of a possible 3,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, has detailed his plans for presenting an extensive group of new works, many by American composers, during the coming season, which will open on Oct. 4.

It is highly desirable that the Constitution of the United States should be better understood and that there should be careful conformity to its requirements. It is to be hoped that Governor Lehman's proclamation of Sept. 13 may tend to the attainment of these objects.

Evidence that some of the enormous hoard of privately owned gold in the vaults of London banks is beginning to move out of that refuge in fear of the rising threat of war was provided yesterday by an announcement in banking circles that $8,200,000 in gold had been engaged in England for shipment here.

Kenneth F. Simpson, leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, was selected yesterday, at a caucus of the forces opposed to Chase Mellen Jr., as their candidate to succeed Mr. Mellen as Republican County Chairman.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- Following Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's intervention through his last Reichstag speech in the election campaign now under way in Memel Territory, which was detached from Germany by the Treaty of Versailles, four other German Cabinet Ministers have issued statements in a special Memel number published by the Prussian Gazette of Koenigsberg.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $196,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday. The rise resulted chiefly from a gain of $178,000,000 in the banks' holdings of direct obligations of the United States, reflecting subscriptions to the recent offering of 11/2 per cent notes.

The end of the protracted war between three rival unions of moving picture operators here and unionization of the city's 600 film theatres appeared in sight yesterday when it was learned that negotiations for a merger of the three organizations and establishment of a uniform wage scale were approaching successful conclusion.

The accidental discovery of the remains of a giant mastodon that thundered over the plains of the Middle West during some remote period between 50,000 and 100,000 years ago was reported yesterday by Dr. Walter Granger, curator of fossil mammals of the American Museum of Natural History.

Eversley Childs has resigned as chairman of the board of directors of the Bon Ami Company and has been elected president. H.D. Crippen resigned as president and general manager because of ill health. Alvah E. Davison has been made vice president and general manager.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars in annual convention today adopted a resolution demanding a Congressional investigation to fix the blame for the "appalling loss of lives" of World War veterans in the hurricane which swept the lower Florida keys Sept. 2 and 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Recovering from the minor recession of the two preceding weeks, wholesale commodity prices last week rose 0.4 point, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
The Calumet Club Building at 12 West Fifty-sixth Street is to be sold at foreclosure by Joseph P. Day on Oct. 3, in an action brought by the Chase National Bank, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Admiralty continued today its censorship of all news of naval movements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- An order authorizing State Works Progress Administrators to reduce at their discretion the hours of labor on work relief projects below the maximum of forty hours a week established by President Roosevelt was signed today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

NAPLES, Sept. 19. -- The Neapolitan population is drawing the happiest omens for the success of the Italian campaign in East Africa and for a solution of the international difficulties in which Italy now finds herself from the speed and completeness with which the traditional miracles of St. Januarius occurred today in the Cathedral of Naples and in the sanctuary of Pozzuoll.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 19. -- At a meeting of outstanding Netherland concerns in the field of ready-made clothes and kindred articles here today it was unanimously decided to declare a complete boycott of German goods because of the violently anti-Semitic attitude of the Nazis as expressed by the anti-Jewish decree promulgated last Sunday.

Radio and electrical appliance representatives at the exposition in Grand Central Palace said yesterday the display was a success from every angle. Larger crowds were in evidence than on Wednesday, the opening day, when 6,000 paid admissions were counted.

Gustav A. Lange, veteran skipper who was in command of the Ambrose Channel Lightship when it was in collision Tuesday with the Grace liner Santa Barbara, testifield at the Federal hearing yesterday that he had deliberately swung his little craft to hit the Santa Barbara head on to save his vessel from being cut in two.

Frequent reference to the British "Peace Ballot" has been made in the dispatches concerning the Italo-Ethiopian controversy. But it may be doubted if the matter is well understood in this country. It was known that some 11,000,000 voters had taken par in the ballot, or about one-half of the number in a British general election.

Coach Chick Meehan yesterday named Manhattan's starting line for the opening game with Niagara at Ebbets Field tomorrow, thus completing the selection of the Jasper first eleven. Four veterans were included in the 190-pound forward wall, which was picked at the conclusion of a brisk ninety-minute drill at Innisfail Park .

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $12,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Three "R's" -- Roosevelt, Russell and Rivers -- were seen tonight by political observers here as a possible obstacle to the political ambitions of Governor Eugene Talmadge, critic of the New Deal.

A revision of the Code of Criminal Procedure whereby persons accused of crime would be encouraged to talk more freely at their preliminary examination was recommended in a report of the Commission on the Administration of Justice, made public yesterday by State Senator John L. Buckley, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Striking a vital blow at the management's plan for reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, V.V. Boatner, director of regional coordinating committees, today told the Interstate Commerce Commission that the "friendly interest" of the Chesapeake Ohio in the smaller carrier would neither help nor hinder its progress toward recovery.

The National Collegiate A.A. committee on swimming records has approved a long series of intercollegiate and interscholastic standards, most of them established this year, it was disclosed yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman, who also called attention to changes in the classification of marks.
Sales of various housing properties on the upper West Side featured the real estate market in Manhattan yesterday. Brokers also reported several leasehold deals.

With the day approaching when the United States Supreme Court will make known its decision on the constitutionality of the AAA, brokers are wondering how the stock market and the commodity markets will act if the court scraps this measure as definitely as it outlawed the NRA.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP). -- James Seligman, an attorney, announced tonight that he had taken action to bring libel suits, involving $2,000,000, against Mrs. Victoria Lincoln Lowe, author of "February Hill"; R.H. Macy Co. of New York, Farrar Rinehart of New York, publishers of the book; J.J. Little Ives Company of New York, the printers, and The New York Daily Mirror, which ran the book in serial form.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Leaders of the Glass Container Association of America laid plans here today for a stiff defense against the competition of the tin can as a beer container.
DES MOINES, Sept. 19 (AP). -- A resolution demanding that the AAA program "be immediately halted and Secretary Wallace returned to private life" was voted today by the Iowa Farmers Union.

Events in the sugar market yesterday, including a rise in the price of refined sugar and a report that Cuba would forbid further shipments until next year, overshadowed interest in the trading in futures on the commodity markets. All the grains, cocoa and rubber were higher in the cash market, with lead, silk, wheat and flour setting new highs for the year.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Roy Johnson and Babe Dahlgren featured a late batting attack today to decide a pitching duel between Lefty Grove and Al Crowder, and give the Red Sox a 4-to-1 triumph over the league-leading Tigers.

Nearly thirty-five hours after receiving the charge of Federal Judge Robert J. McMillan, the jury in the second trial of James C. McKay and William J. Graham, Reno (Nev.) gambling and night club promoters charged with mail fraud in the operation of a confidence ring, was still deadlocked last night. At 9:30 P.M. the jurors were taken to the Hotel McAlpin and locked up for the night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Secretary Roper depicted business conditions with a glowing, bright-tipped brush tonight and said no other conclusion was possible than that improvement had resulted directly from New Deal efforts.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A calculating burglar, working with fiction-like exactness, emptied the bedroom safe of Mrs. George Breen of $25,000 worth of jewelry, the Harrison police disclosed today. Her husband, a New York broker, is president of the Westchester Country Club.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The Boerse was weak throughout today's trading. Heavy industrial shares registered considerable losses, Rhinestahl declining 2 points, Vereinigtestahl 1 and Mannesmann 1. Potash issues showed resistance at the opening, but softened toward the close.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Efforts to solidify the local ranks of the Republican party, split into factions during the primary campaign, began today under the leadership of Controller Wilson, the Republican Mayoralty nominee, and Edwin R. Cox, chairman of the city committee.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 19. -- With the two divisions just dispatched from Italy to Libya the Italians now have an army of more than 100,000 men and a well-equipped air force in that colony, mostly concentrated close to the Egyptian border. The British are making extensive preparations in response. Without a sign of excitement they are going on here in great haste.
Money market remained dull. Barring routine demands little else in the way of new money was done. Quotations were unchanged.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 19. -- The report of the committee of five of the League of Nations Council has not yet been considered by the State Council here, and any statements that the Ethiopian Government will approve the proposed settlement of the dispute with Italy are, therefore, premature.
Secret Service men of the Treasury Department announced yesterday a capture that was regarded as their greatest exploit since the smashing of the $1,000,000 counterfeiting conspiracy of 1898.

TOKYO, Sept. 19. -- All copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 4, 6 and 11, dealing with a Cartoon of the Emperor in the magazine Vanity Fair, against which Japan protested, are now at the Home Office undergoing examination. Postal officials today said it was unlikely that they would ever be delivered.

The share market received its most important setback yesterday since Aug. 27, many leading issues losing 1 to 4 points, a few even more to as much as 6 1/2 points. Professional followers of the markets are finding it increasingly difficult to comprehend the troubled European situation, and the natural disposition to go slowly in making new commitments in stocks and to realize on speculative holdings was emphasized yesterday.

Six firemen and a woman tenant were injured and about fifty persons were driven down fire escapes and ladders to the street when flames swept a five-story tenement building at 25 Leroy Street, at Seventh Avenue, at 3 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Additional gifts bringing the total to around $40,000,000 since President Roosevelt advocated an inheritance tax and higher gift taxes were shown in supplemental reports of stock transactions and holdings for July by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that it had signed agreements with the New England and American Hampton Roads steamship companies whereby wage scales and recognition of the association as the spokesmen for the radio operators were granted.
An interesting experiment in the raising of cottontail rabbits was begun last Fall by Raymond J. Kenney, director of the Massachusetts Board of Fisheries and Game.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

OCALA, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP). -- A thundering blast, touched off by President Roosevelt, tore out the first hole in the route of the Gulf-Atlantic Ship Canal today, while Senator Fletcher predicted ultimate completion of the greatest waterway undertaken by the United States since the Panama Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Secretary Ickes attacked as "gross impertinence and flagrant impropriety" today the action of the National Lawyers Committee of the American Liberty League in declaring the National Labor Relations Act unconstitutional yesterday.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Paul King gave a large supper dance at their home here tonight to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Sybil Lewis King. Dancing was continuous throughout the evening under a bright-colored marquee that had been set up on the lawn for the occasion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Lack of pressure of cash wheat on the world's markets and further war talk caused general buying of futures and the cash article today on the Board of Trade and abroad, which sent prices to new high levels.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Mrs. Elizabeth W. Smith, Wynnefield resident, and her divorced husband, Major Aaron E. Carpenter, caused the arrest last night of a man charged with trying to extort money from Mrs. Smith under the guise of "publicity" regarding the marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence R. Carpenter, to Reginald Hugh Murray of New York and Palm Beach, which is to take place Oct. 15.

ROME, Sept. 19. -- No Italian has ever made a secret of his complete lack of confidence in the ability of the League of Nations to devise a peaceful solution of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, but if there was a last shred of hope of averting war in East Africa it seems to have been destroyed by the proposals drawn up by the committee of five.

Mrs. Indiana Mountain Saint Clermont may never sail the sea, spaceless and illimitable like the plains where her forefathers once freely roamed, but if she does not it will not be because she gave up easily.
Small housing and industrial properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 19. -- All but hopeless that Premier Benito Mussolini would even deign to discuss the suggested Ethiopian peace plan of the committee of five of the League of Nations Council, the British delegation tonight began to talk openly of what to do in the event of rejection.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- News was received in London tonight that the Italian Government, through Fulvio Suvich, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, had communicated to Count Charles de Chambrun, the French Ambassador in Rome, an offer to withdraw troops concentrated on the Libyan frontier of Egypt and to recall cruising submarines from the line of communication in the Mediterranean.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Reds clung to fifth place in the National League today as Paul Derringer won his twentieth victory, turning back the Phillies, 6 to 1.

The Park Department issued an appeal to the public yesterday to refrain from fishing for ducks in the Central Park lakes. That the appeal was not just an idle gesture was disclosed by Dr. Harry Nimphius, park veterinarian.

Provision for more than 100 clerks as well as new stenographers and technical employes was sought yesterday by Russell Forbes, Commissioner of the Department of Purchase, in his 1936 budget, to replace relief workers and to effect a reorganization of his department.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The Wheeler-Rayburn public utility legislation, carrying its drastic "death clause" for holding companies, appeared today as an added factor which may upset the present slow-moving plans for reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP). -- All games of the 1935 world series again will be broadcast by radio under the sponsorship of the Ford Motor Company, Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- A stronger undertone developed in the market for hogs today, due more to lack of selling pressure than any improvement in the general demand. Some sales of lard-type hogs were regarded as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, a better call being experienced owing to the upturn in lard futures. The top price was unchanged at $11.80, while the average was 5 cents higher at $10.85.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A concise picture of the State's financial position was given today by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, in a circular sent to prospective investors in the $30,000,000 issue of emergency unemployment relief bonds to be sold on Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19. -- Henry Pylkowski, better known as Babe Risko, of Syracuse, who fifteen months ago was fighting four-round opening bouts in his home town, tonight won the middleweight championship of the world.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 19. -- Miss Molly Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Cummings, was introduced in society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at their home in Round Hill.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Consternation and despair among the incredulous people of Szechwan Province followed today upon Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's withdrawal of the province's bank notes at a 20 per cent discount.
