SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Montreal halted the Chiefs' dash through the International League playoffs by gaining a 5 to 2 triumph over Syracuse before 9,000 fans today.

Options on stock of the Madison Square Garden Corporation to Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, its president, and on shares of the National Cash Register Company to Colonel Edward A. Deeds, chairman of the board, were disclosed yesterday in the monthly reports of reacquired stock released by the New York Stock Exchange.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 19.--The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, self-constituted heir apparent to Senator Long's following among converts to his scheme for redistributing the country's wealth, attempted today to assure himself of an important place in the councils of the political machine which made his mentor the dictator of Louisiana.

Mr. and Mrs. Carleton H. Palmer gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Their guest were Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Larsen, Mr. and Mrs. William D. Whitney, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bromley, Mr. and Mrs. Eustace Seligman, Dr. and Mrs. John Anderson, Mrs. Allerton Cushman, Chester U. Palmer and William E. Harkness.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Aurora, marking time until the final of the national championship against Greentree on Saturday afternoon, rode through seven shortened periods of a polo game on Mitchel Field today against the British Hurlingham team.

Assemblyman Michael J. Gillen of Brooklyn, author of the bill to substitute illuminated box-like signs for automobile license plates which was passed by the last Legislature but vetoed by Governor Lehman, was no protection for two employes of the sign manufacturer last night when Mounted Patrolman Edward Dillon of Troop B stopped them as traffic law violators.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Two fellows of the Louis entourage were trying trick shots at pocket billiards and Shufflin' Joe was lounging back in an easy chair, watching and listening. He was wearing a plaid bathrobe. No work today. Just taking things quietly.

Adding many new names to apartment-building rosters throughout the city, brokers and renting agents yesterday found an especially brisk demand for suites in buildings on Park Avenue. The renting there involved large flats, the tenants including names well known in the theatrical profession.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The discovery of important works of art during the 1934-35 excavations on the site of ancient Corinth, in Greece, were announced here today by Professor Richard Stillwell who recently returned to resume his duties at Princeton University after four years of work in Greece.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19. -- Testifying in his fight for freedom today, Thomas J. Mooney told A.E. Shaw, Supreme Court referee, that he never participated, in the dynamiting of anything nor had he taken part in any acts of terrorism. At the same time he admitted pride in his efforts to organize workers in a street-car strike before the 1916 Preparedness Day bombing.

The pamphlet report of the United-Carr Fastener Corporation and subsidiaries for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income, including $11,734 profit on debentures retired, of $309,445, after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, minority interest and other charges, including $11,734 profit on debentures retired.

Matchmaker Tom McArdle of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday announced the complete preliminary program for the Joe Louis-Max Baer fifteen-round fight Tuesday night at the Yankee Stadium. The supporting card includes seven bouts, two of six rounds each and five of four rounds each.

On a bid of $600,000, the three five-story buildings at 681-87 Madison Avenue and the four-story building at 30 East Sixty-second Street, forming an "L" around the southeast corner, were taken over by the United States Trust Company in a foreclosure action yesterday against the estate of Bradish Johnson. There was due on the property the sum of $837,333. Robert Fishel was the broker.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19. -- A tribute to the American business man's increasing and sincere self-government, paid by George McCorkle, an officer of the Federal Trade Commission, marked the thirty-third annual convention of the National Petroleum Association in the Hotel Traymore here today. Mr. McCorkle has been with the Trade Commission since it was organized on March 16, 1915, and he directs its trade practice conference division.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Treasury asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to assess William Fox of movie fame $3,566,585 in income taxes on money received during 1929 and 1930.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Them activities and expenditures of the bondholders protective committee of the city of Coral Gables were developed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission at a continuation of its inquiry into the troubled affairs of that real estate promotion.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Long Island retained possession of the Myra D. Paterson Trophy at the Plainfield Country Club today, scoring 18 1/2 points to 16 1/2 for New Jersey and 10 for Westchester. Thus the Long Island women's golf team holds possession of the Spring and Fall triangular match titles.

Reflecting a heavy transfer of funds from the banks to the Treasury due to income-tax payments and cash subscriptions to the recent Treasury offering of 11/2 per cent notes, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $260,000,000 to $2,560,000,000 on Wednesday, compared with the high record of $2,820,000,000 a week before, it was disclosed in the weekly report of the Reserve System, published yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Danseuse, 8-year-old thoroughbred chestnut mare, today was awarded the hunter championship of the thirty-third annual Mineola horse show. The star of the stable of Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d, East Hampton, L.I., was ridden in all her events by Miss Polly Potter of Westbury.

Irvin S. Cobb, the humorist, who is appearing with Will Rogers in "Steamboat Round the Bend" at the Radio City Music Hall, has signed a long-term contract with Twentieth Century-Fox. His next assignment will be the featured role in a film provisionally titled "Everybody's Old Man."

Who would have said a good many things only a little while ago? Only a year ago who would have said that in a threatened Mediterranean conflict Italy's antagonist would be Great Britain and not France or Greece or Turkey?

More than 97 per cent of the cotton-textile industry, measured by active spindles, is operating on former basic code wage and maximum hour schedules, according to a report submitted yesterday to the executive committee and the board of directors of the Cotton-Textile Institute by its president, Goldthwaite H. Dorr.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Gene Mako, American Davis Cup hopeful, eliminated the No. 1 player of France, Christian Boussus, in the third round of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships today, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2. The defeat was the third suffered by the foreign contingent in men's singles.

Special agents of the United States Senate committee investigating alleged lobbying activities on the part of the public utility companies during Congressional consideration of the Public Utilities Act have moved into the main offices of many of the companies with headquarters in New York City, a survey of the various corporations revealed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Charles Russell Geary, 42-year-old handyman of Tobyhanna, Pa., shot his brother and two uncles to death in their home early today because of dissatisfaction with the disposal of the estate of his aunt, police declared after completing their investigation of the deaths of four men found at 938 South Twentieth Street.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Continued uncertainty over the international outlook caused a further restriction of business today on the London Stock Exchange, although prices were fairly steady.

GENEVA, Sept. 19. -- After long debate the League of Nations Assembly's first committee unanimously adopted today a resolution in which, without committing itself to the Montevideo convention's principle of equal nationality rights for women, the committee "draws the attention of members of the League to the fact that the Montevideo convention is open to adherence by all States."

TOKYO, Sept. 19. -- About 2,000 members of the Black Dragon Society, the Patriotic Students Federation and kindred organizations welcomed Daba Birrou, described in the press as president of the Ethiopian Military Academy, at the Tokyo station today.

The United States was urged yesterday to withdraw from the Olympic Games next year in a protest against Nazi policies. Mrs. Sonja Branting, arbiter in Domestic Relations at Stockholm and a delegate to the recent penal Congress at Berlin, said that such a gesture would help to discredit Hitler with his own people.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Austin B. Ryan, 45 years old, fire chief of this village, who disappeared from his home at 114 Leverich Street here last Friday and for whom warrants on charges of forgery and larceny were issued today, surrendered tonight to the police at Merrick, L.I.

Emergency crews worked all day yesterday to restore normal water, gas and telephone service to the downtown Brooklyn region adjoining Smith and Schermerhorn Streets, where a twenty-inch water main had burst about 5 A.M., flooding streets, sidewalks and near-by buildings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept, 19. -- Seth M. Milliken of the Apawamis Club today set the pace with a 79 in the opening half of the first championship of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP). -- William J. Kelley, a guest at the farm home of Henry H. Rogers Jr., the night Evelyn Hoey, New York show girl, was found shot to death, testified at an inquest tonight that he and Mr. Rogers heard one shot from her room.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- After five years in the doldrums, the real estate market in nearly all parts of the State has turned definitely upward, according to leaders arriving for the opening sessions of the thirty-first annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

A suit for $630 was brought yesterday in Municipal Court, Part II, against the City of New York by a Harlem liquor dealer for alleged loss of property during the Harlem riot last March. It was regarded as a test case on which the decision of many similar suits, involving possibly a total of $1,000,000, may rest.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The plight of the Jews in Germany was brought before the League of Nations by the Committee of Jewish Delegations today in an appeal that "the conscience of mankind will not tolerate that Jews should be degraded in this century as pariahs."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

ISLINGTON, Ont., Friday, Sept. 20 (AP). -- A coroner's jury early today returned a verdict of "self-defense" in the killing of Leonard Koenecke, Brooklyn baseball player, in an airplane early Tuesday during a struggle with William Joseph Mulqueeney, pilot, and Irwin Davis, parachute jumper.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Two Westchester golfers and one from far-off California found New Jersey conditions to their liking today, and carried off the scoring honors in the annual Arcola Country Club invitation tourney, one of the most popular events of the entire golf year.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Running away from Crown Prince Olaf's Norwegian yacht Norna IV, Paul Shields's Challenge, misnamed defender, today won the third race for the Seawanhaka Cup. The American boat defeated the Norwegian 40 seconds after leading all the way over a windward and leeward course of twelve miles.

The power of the Federal courts to declare unconstitutional a Congressional statute is the American classic of political theory. During our national history many attacks have been made upon this doctrine. But the rule has been steadfast and when passions are quiet little is heard against it.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Paul Runyan, National Professional Golfers' Association champion and Westchester open titleholder, made his first appearance today in the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship.

With seven games left to play, the Cubs can clinch the National League pennant by winning five of the contests. The Cubs have two games to play with the Pirates and five with the Cardinals. With five Cub victories, the Cards could not win more than seven more games, and in this case the final standing would be:

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Calumet Denver, the chestnut colt of Henry Fettle, Brightwaters, N.Y., won the 2:18 trot today at the Mineola Fair Grounds, leading his field by a half length and five lengths, respectively, in the first and third heats.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Changes in the set-up of the United States Steel Corporation were explained today by its executives at a luncheon attended by about 200 leaders in Chicago business and industrial life.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Big battleships in the Mediterranean will be more of a liability than an asset, in the opinion of Dr. Oscar Parkes, who for the past seventeen years has been editor of "Jane's Fighting Ships," authoritative British yearbook on the world's navies.

A survey made by the American Iron and Steel Institute shows that of 470,464 stockholders who own most of the steel industry of this country, 64 per cent owns less than twenty shares each and almost 88 per cent owns less than 100 shares each.

MINISINK HILLS, Pa., Sept. 19. -- Harvey Harman and Fritz Crisler are a pair of as even dispositioned and likable young coaches as will be found in the ranks of the fraternity, but each of them is causing the other no end of worry and loss of sleep -- and rightly so.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler rejected yesterday a plan proposed by the State Mortgage Commission for the reorganization of the $24,000,000 issue of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, and known as Series C-2.

Under the influence of a fresh European war scare bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday turned weak. Selling was not in particularly heavy volume, but profit-taking, in some instances, and a general disposition to liquidate, as in the case of Italian issues and selected domestic corporation bonds, were the directing forces and resulted in lower prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Officials of leading public utility companies have been invited by the Securities and Exchange Commission to meet with it here early next week to discuss the application forms for registration and the rules and regulations which must be prepared, especially those dealing with conditions under which exemption may be claimed by a holding company and any subsidiary from the application of the Holding Company Act.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19. -- Calling on Dizzy Dean to keep his team in the pennant race, Manager Frankie Frisch saw his faith justified today when his ace hurler held the sixth-place Dodgers to six hits, while the Cardinals gathered thirteen off Ray Benge and young Tom Baker to win easily, 9 to 1.

William Mulcahy's appreciative letter thanking you for the verse you print daily on the editorial page, reminds me of how remiss I have been in not writing you in like vein. I am perhaps deeper in your debt than he is. Nearly ten years ago you printed some delightful verses entitled "The Sea-Look," over the signature of Kadra Maysi.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 (AP). -- A miner who was sent to prison for killing a man but who escaped, married, turned preacher and used the nation for his pulpit, was paroled today by Governor Guy B. Park.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Eight miles off the Michigan coast, the Lighthouse Service has stationed a ship without a crew to perform all the functions of warning mariners of nearby danger.
New York will have two rival celebrations of German Day on Oct. 6, in honor of the first German settlers in America.

The strains of the Negro spiritual, "Give Me the Old Time Religion," resounded in Pennsylvania Avenue court in Brooklyn yesterday during the hearing of eight Negroes charged with disorderly conduct. The spiritual was sung with fervor after a half-hearted beginning, at the request of Magistrate Malbin, and resulted in a dismissal of the charges against the defendants.

The threat of war involving Italy, Ethiopia and Great Britain has resulted in increased rates for marine insurance on freight moving to the potential war zone, and ship lines are scurrying to protect their interests. Rates have been increased many times and in the last few days have reached new highs, according to shipping men and insurance brokers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The resignation of Cyrus H. McCormick as chairman of the board of directors of the International Harvester Company was announced today after a meeting of the board. He is succeeded in the office by his brother, Harold F. McCormick.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 19. -- New hope for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian problem was felt in government circles here today as news was received of the British naval movements and of possible Italian receptiveness to the report of the committee of five at Geneva.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 19. -- Coal companies today won, by legal strategy, the right to a constitutional test of the Guffey Coal Act in Federal court here Sept. 27, their counsel precluding the objection of "prematureness" which enabled the government to avert such a test in another case in Washington Monday.

The United States will continue to work for the preservation of peace "in every practical way," Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared last night in a statement broadcast over a Columbia Broadcasting System network in connection with the inaugural program of "To Arms for Peace," arranged by World Peaceways and a commercial sponsor.

WARSAW, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The thirteen entries in the Gordon Bennett international balloon race, which were cut loose here Sunday, were all reported safely aground today, with the Polish bag Polonia apparently the winner after landing 1,054 miles away, in Stalingrad Province, U.S.S.R., near the Caspian Sea.
The editorial "Realistic Housing" was most timely and will, I hope, stimulate further discussion.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ROME, Sept. 19. -- An editorial in the authoritative Giornale d'Italia tonight said that Great Britain had made the peace proposal of the five-power committee unacceptable in order to force Italy to reject it and have recourse to war

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Cooking and beating are the secret of making literally a hundred grades and characters of paper from the pulp of a single tree, delegates declared here today at the Fall meeting of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- Not even the once impregnable Carl Hubbell could stem the mad dash of the Cubs today as Charlie Grimm's inspired band of Chicagoans smashed their way to a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Giants by winning the final engagement, 6 to 1.
Rust, the game filly which makes up the entire stable of Louis Strube, who also trains the daughter of Spanish Prince II, scored what was in many ways her most important victory yesterday at Jamaica.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP). -- A thrilling double play started by Outfielder Woody Jensen that cut off the tying run was the final scene Pittsburgh fans had of their 1935 team at home as the Pirates beat Boston, 7 to 6, today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- In a move directed at simplification of its structures, the Monongahela West Penn Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the American Water Works and Electric Company, has called a special meeting for Oct. 11 at which time details of merging certain West Virginia properties will be voted on by the stockholders.

It is obvious that both Mr. Tappan and Mr. Lazarus have forgotten the past. In their desire to save the building industry they attempt to give us, in lieu of craftsmen, high school boys and pineapple cutters for the erecting of "simple structural steel skeletons." Who is to cover these skeletons and with what?

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The steady movement of British warships toward the Mediterranean and Red Seas continued today, with 350,000 tons of warcraft already on station from Gibraltar to Aden ready for any challenge from Italy.

General Hugh S. Johnson, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday the first step in his program of reviewing the entire WPA set-up in this city with a view to economy, efficiency and utility of projects.

Business leasing activity centred in the midtown area yesterday. The Full Moon Products Corporation, Mrs. Pauline Rubin, president, rented a store in 57 West Forty-fifth Street as the first of a proposed chain to sell imported general merchandise. The Rusenberg-Murray Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Carrying documents sharply critical of some New Deal actions and enactments, the directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will begin tomorrow their first session since Congress adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Treasury will start advertising its "baby bonds" next week in magazines. On Tuesday the first paid notice will appear in a national weekly magazine, to be followed by paid copy in five other weekly periodicals.

As was abundantly forecast, the New Jersey primaries resulted in a defeat of Governor HOFFMAN on the question of the State sales tax. Enough members of the Assembly in the next Legislature were nominated to make sure repeal of the sales tax in 1936, provided the Senate, which is now reported doubtful, is also opposed to it.

MOUNT KISCO, Sept. 19. -- The only player to break 100 in a field of thirty-seven starters, Mrs. Ruth R. Young today won the low gross award of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Lawrence Farms Country Club. Though the rest of the course was heavy, the greens were hard and fast. Mrs. Young's winning score was 46, 51 -- 97.

Jacksonville, Fla. The city of Jacksonville, Fla., will enter the investment market on Dec. 1 with a new issue of $700,000 refunding bonds. They will be dated Dec. 15, 1935, and mature in 1952 and 1956. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Upward of 15,000 Lemocrats were mobilized tonight for a two-day rally here to map the fight for continued control of the Assembly.

A six-story apartment house to be built at 245-47 Seaman Avenue will cost $90,000, according to plans filed yesterday by George G. Miller, architect, for the Evelyn Building Corporation of 321 Edgecombe Avenue. The site is 50 by 84 feet.

Heavy internal revenue tax payments swelled bank clearings last week to the largest aggregate recorded since mid-July. The total for twenty-two principal cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,846,314,000.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday was the successful bidder for a new issue if $3,000,000 public building and improvement bonds, and $967,000 refunding bonds, of the city of St. Louis, Mo. The price paid for the bonds was 100.319 for $3,000,000 as 3 1/4s and $967,000 as 3s.

The triumvirate leadership of the Queens Democratic organization remained silent yesterday on whether or not they would back the Sheridan nominees for county offices to be filled in the November elections. Sheriff Peter J. McGarry, Edward W. Cox and John C. Donovan conferred with supporters on the executive committee Wednesday night but took no action and no endorsements were made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Bids for thirty municipal bond issues taken over from the Public Works Administration were received today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, when the securities were offered at public sale.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 19. -- The board of visitors of the University of Virginia directed the graduate dean of the university today to "refuse respectfully" the application for entrance into the School of Romance Languages recently made by Alice C. Jackson, daughter of a Negro druggist.

A temporary injunction was granted yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox to restrain Mrs. Sybil K. Neidecker from spending or secreting $121,914 traced to her possession here, pending a determination whether or not this amount belongs to the depositors of the closed Travelers Bank operated by Neidecker Co. in Paris and elsewhere abroad.

Declaring that electric rates in this city were entirely too high, former State Senator Nathan Straus offered his services yesterday to Mayor La Guardia in support of the city power referendum at the Nov. 5 election.
The following is the text of the order signed yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA administrator, permitting State Directors of the WPA to reduce working hours below the present forty-hour minimum:

Trading in frozen eggs was begun on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday morning with activity centred in February futures, which ranged in price from 19 1/2 to 19 3/4 cents a pound, with sales of three contracts. Prices held firm during the day, with considerable interest displayed by wire houses representing out-of-town traders.

Miss Irma Duncan, adopted daughter of the famous dancer, the late Isadora Duncan, was married to Sherman Skinner Rogers of this city yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in his judicial chambers.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Byron Nelson's attempt to add the New Jersey P.G.A. championship to his State open title was blocked by Maurrie O'Connor of Branch Brook at the Baltusrol Golf Club today and the youthful Ridgewood professional is scheduled to face O'Connor in an eighteen-hole playoff tomorrow.

HARRAR, Ethiopia, Sept. 19 (By Wireless). -- Slipping out quietly, as though motoring for pleasure, Italian Consul Giardini and his three aides have left Harrar for Jibuti, French Somaliland -- the most ominous sign this provincial capital has known since the first menace of war.

Again from the White Mountains, in whose direction we have become accustomed to look for wise and courageous counsel at the beginning and end of the college year, as if we were all his students, come the words of President HOPKINS of Dartmouth. He gives them the title "fragments of truth."

The body of Katherine Poillon, a gray-haired woman of 62, lay last night in William F. Lynaugh's funeral establishment at 1,093 St. Nicholas Avenue. She died late Tuesday night in a hall bedroom in a tenement at 550 West 168th Street, west of Amsterdam Avenue.

The San Carlo Opera Company left yesterday for Montreal where it will begin a coast-to-coast tour tonight with a performance of "Samson et Dalila," Cyrena Van Gordon and Aroldo Lindi will head the cast in the opening presentation and Carlo Peroni will conduct.

Trading continued active on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, with prices moving into new high ground before an increase in hedging pressure, combined with less aggressive outside buying, started a setback which left the list a point higher to 3 points lower than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Government statisticians said today that America's long idle carpenters, bricklayers and other skilled workers were beginning to find jobs in the construction of private homes.

There is not the remotest likelihood that the Socialists will cooperate with the Communists to form a farmer-labor party in 1936, according to a statement issued yesterday by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for Governor in 1934.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- German schools must bid farewell to their worldwide reputation for thoroughness, school teachers in Berlin admitted today in commenting upon the decree issued by Bernhard Rust, the Minister of Education, yesterday reducing by one-sixth the amount of time German pupils devote to their studies.
Ultra-violet air, completely free from contaminating bacteria, is described in the current issue of Science, official publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Borough President Ingersoll of Brooklyn announced yesterday that more than 1,000 prominent men and women in the borough had received invitations to serve on a citizens' committee to finance the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The committee will seek to increase the membership of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, thus enabling the institute to take the title to the academy building on Lafayette Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- In a broad program for stimulating private building and employment, the Treasury Department sponsored today the formation among representatives of the durable goods industries of a housing display council which will attempt to give a "powerful stimulus to housing construction and modernization."

Roderick Stephens Jr., skipper, and his crew of four who sailed the Bermuda-rigged yawl Stormy Weather to triumph in the transatlantic race from Newport to Bergen, Norway, last June were honored last night at a dinner given by Philip Le Boutillier, owner of the craft, at the Princeton Club.
A small recession took place in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices during the week, the index declining to 127.8 on Tuesday, from 128.0 (revised) a week before.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 19 (Canadian Press). -- A slight increase in note circulation and increases in the reserve held in sterling funds and in United States funds were shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, compared with the previous week.
PARIS, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

This evening belongs to that returning truant-producer, Jed Harris. "Life's Too Short," by John Whedon and Arthur Caplan, is the play. The Broadhurst is the theatre -- and, if there is anything in omens, Mr. Harris once had a play called "Broadway" at that house.

I write to protest against the proposed monument to Father Francis Duffy which the Municipal Art Commission has approved. It seems to me entirely appropriate that the City of New York should pay public tribute to Father Duffy, but the form of the proposed monument will be a deep offense to thousands of citizens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- A 34 per cent increase in third-quarter income tax collections was indicated today by Treasury Department reports. Collections in the first seventeen days of September amounted to $148,503,213 this year, as compared with $110,798,296 a year ago.

Individualism and States' rights versus socialism and government domination of American economic life with all its social implications will from now on be the dominant political issue in this country, according to David Lawrence, whose book, "Stumbling Into Socialism," is published by the D. Appleton Century Company today.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 19. -President Roosevelt devoted his principal interest today to international affairs as he continued the series of conversations that have been his principal occupation during the eighteen days spent at Hyde Park House.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Max Baer received the official medical going-over today and was pronounced in perfect shape. The California heavyweight, whose fifteen-round fight with Joe Louis is only five days distant, was examined by Dr. William Walker of the New York State Athletic Commission, and the report was all that Baer could hope for.

The Teachers Union Auxiliary, a citizens' group of 500 members, organized in 1922, has dropped its affiliation with the union because of the factional strife in that organization which led to the resignation of its officers last week.

In and about Boston, colleges are thick. There the proprieties and niceties of speech have long been cultivated. A cold east wind of scorn bites the offender against the amenities. So we outlanders have believed. What is our astonishment and pain when the worthy Democratic Mayor of Boston, Mr. MANSFIELD, talks of the worthy Democratic Governor of Massachusetts, Mr. CURLEY, much in the manner of CICERO against VERRES.

Robert Briffault's "Europa" went into its fifth large printing on Wednesday, Scribners say, adding that Mr. Briffault's first book, "Psyche's Lamp," written while he was in the trenches during the World War, sold exactly six copies.

It is time to renew those old articles of faith in the theatre. Several nabobs of the stage, including Beatrice Lillie, have assembled the first accomplished revue of the season, "At Home Abroad," which was put on at the Winter Garden last evening.

WARSAW, Sept. 19. -- Almost on the eve of sending his reply to the League of Nations Ethiopian proposals, Premier Benito Mussolini made a diplomatic attempt today to win Poland over to Italy's side and away from the united front of nations opposing Italy at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The first active step to guard against possible American embroilment in a war was taken today when Secretary of State Hull called a meeting for next Tuesday of the National Munitions Control Board, set up under the new Neutrality Act.

Timothy J. Creeden -- Sergeant Creeden of the Second New York, later changed to Eighty-second New York Volunteers -- will be ninety-six years old tomorrow. The day will be spent much like other days, like yesterday and today save for a family birthday dinner in his home at 357 West Eighty-fourth Street.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 19. -- The biggest strike in the history of the city of Vera Cruz, involving more than 6,000 men, became effective this afternoon, leaving the republic's most important port without railway, light, power, street car and shipping facilities.

ONE by one all our novelists are turning to the theme of industrial and social conflicts. Yesterday it was Myron Brinig, today it is A.J. Cronin, whose "The Stars Look Down" will be reviewed in these columns tomorrow. At last fiction is catching up with the front-page news, or rather the events of six years have, by normal processes of saturation, at length filled the well-springs of the creative imagination to overflowing.

Third Deputy Police Commissioner John Anderson Leach, who has served under eight commissioners since his appointment Jan. 23, 1918, will retire early in November, it was announced at Police Headquarters yesterday. Mr. Leach will be 70 years old on Nov. 10.

LONDON Sept. 19. -- The Royal Marines, who have been doing guard duty at the royal palaces, today exercised the privilege, held for two centuries but never used, of marching through the City of London "with colors flying, drums beating, and bayonets fixed."

A rate war among freight lines operating between the United States and South Africa which has brought rates on general cargo down from $20 to $4 a ton in the last three months, caused the Robin Line yesterday to ask the Shipping Board to investigate the situation.

HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP). -- A heavy guard was thrown around the campus of Mount Holyoke College tonight as State troopers and local officers pressed their search for John Bey, desperate Connecticut fugitive.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 19. -- A storm in a teacup over a cable dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES has been raging in the Budapest press since Tuesday.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 19. -- The United States since the World War has been "afraid to grow up," President Hopkins of Dartmouth declared today in his annual convocation address opening the college year. Pointing to the promise held by the nation two decades ago, Dartmouth's head asserted:

Five Manhattan properties and three in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The largest parcel was a fifteen-story apartment house in West End Avenue. The results were as follows:

GENEVA, Saturday, Sept. 21. -- A British spokesman said early today that not one British warship would be withdrawn from the Mediterranean until the Italo-Ethiopian dispute "is on its way toward a settlement."

It has been judicially determined in Illinois that any man who could make money in Wall Street these last five years must be of sound mind. An inmate of the State Hospital for the Insane, committed there at the instance of his own-father a few months ago, petitioned the courts for release.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Central Maine Power Company of Augusta has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for not exceeding $29,500,000 refunding-mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/4 per cent, dated Oct. 1, 1935, and due on Oct. 1, 1960, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had amended the rule for form E-1, which is generally used under the Securities Act of 1933 for the registration of securities sold in the course of reorganizations, so as to clarify and modify some of its provisions.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The new order of Mr. HOPKINS, WPA administrator, is in effect a complete capitulation to the demand of union leaders that "prevailing" wages be paid on all Government work-relief projects. It does not raise the monthly amounts to be paid to any one individual.

With only a few dissenting votes, the members of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday adopted four amendments to the by-laws of the Exchange. The three first amendments, concerning delivery dates, the sale of cotton "on call," and conversion contracts, will be in effect on all contracts maturing in August, 1936, and thereafter.

New Yorkers are showing considerable interest in the exhibit of the reproduction of the pioneer shop on Canal Street in which Aaron Arnold launched the mercantile enterprise which has grown into the modern Arnold Constable Co. department store at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, it was reported yesterday.

William Krebs, 43 years old, employed as a porter at $20 a week in the Bell Building, 320 Fifth Avenue, received a certified check for $20,000 last night following announcement earlier in the day that he was winner of the first prize in the Grand National Treasure Hunt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20. -- Thomas J. Mooney's renewed try for freedom through State courts was threatened today when Warren K. Billings, convicted with him for the 1916 Preparedness Day parade bombing, said from his cell in Folsom penitentiary that he might refuse a deposition upon which Mooney counts heavily.

Prices of practically all commodity futures were higher in the trading here yesterday. Sugar futures continued to advance. In the cash markets, rye, lard and rubber were higher, while wheat, corn, oats, tin, cotton and silk declined.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Three men today robbed Jack Hoffman, New York diamond salesman, and his assistant of jewels valued at $15,000 and escaped through the Loop. Hoffman had just left his apartment in the Congress Hotel to call on customers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20. -- Before many thousands of persons including 20,000 visitors. Governor Flores da Cunha opened today the Porto Alegre Exposition in commemoration of the centenary of the Rio Grande do Sul secession war. President Getulio Vargas, Finance Minister Arthur do Souza Costa and members of the foreign diplomatic corps were among those present at the opening ceremonies in the Southern Brazilian city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Federal Housing Administration has applications on hand to insure mortgages on $365,500,000 worth of low-cost housing throughout the country, and sixty-six private projects, to cost $175,000,000, probably will be undertaken with the government insuring the necessary mortgages.
The American Tankers Corporation, Marshall B. Hall, president of 21 West Street, has leased new executive quarters in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. The lessee operates five ships.

Major Patrick J. Walsh has been renominated for president of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, according to the list of candidates announced yesterday by Secretary-Treasurer Charles A. Elbert. Virtually the entire slate of officers has been renominated.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Brunn, president of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States, will speak and take part in the sessions of the annual New York Pastoral Conference of the district beginning Monday at 2 P.M. and continuing until Thursday afternoon in St. Luke's Lutheran Church, Forty - sixth Street, just west of Eighth Avenue.

The total attendance at the radio-electrical show in Grand Central Palace so far has exceeded by more than 50 per cent that of last year at the same time, it was announced yesterday by the managers of the 1935 national exposition. Exhibitors expressed their appreciation for the response by the public and dealers.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Carl Dill drove J.W. Coughlin's Iosola's McElwyn, bay gelding by Mr. McElwyn, to his second victory of the week at the Mineola Fair today, beating a strong field in the handicap trot.

A conference has been held in Budapest during the last few days to consider a transcontinental route extending from London to Istanbul. It is to be called "European Highway No. 1," or its equivalent in the languages of the lands through which it is to pass -- and does in some of its stretches already pass.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Sharply attacking many phases of the New Deal, General Hugh S. Johnson revealed plans today for taking the stump as a friendly but vigorous critic of the administration.

Firing will be light on the football front today as the gridiron sport moves into a new season. It will be another fortnight before the great autumnal hysteria reaches its usual peak, but more than two-score games are on the schedule for the day to give the more rabid fans a slight taste of what is to come.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- While the capital speculated as to his successor, Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an interview today predicted that new capital issues would soon appear in large volume to spur on recovery.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The battle for the eighth annual New Jersey P.G.A. championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club became a marathon today, with Byron Nelson of Ridgewood and Maurrie O'Connor of Branch Brook still tied for the crown after ninety holes of play.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Johnny Deering, Joe Roberts's slim apprentice jockey, took personal charge of the proceedings at Rockingham Park today when he piloted Stainforth to victory in the Cheshire Purse in a field of eight.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Jail is no place for the habitual drunkard, Judge Jacob Gitelman of Rochester's City Court told the conference of the New York State Association of Magistrates here today.

Francis Minot was elected chairman of the board yesterday at a directors' meeting of John G. Hall Co. Andrew B. Sides, formerly a vice president of the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., was elected executive vice president and Linzee Hooper, vice president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Augusto Rosso, the Italian Ambassador, discussed the Ethiopian situation with Under-Secretary of State William Phillips today, but the purport of the conversation was not disclosed. It was the Ambassador's first visit to the State Department since July 10, when Secretary Hull summoned him to impart this country's hope for a peaceful settlement of the dispute, then becoming acute.

Mr. FRANK KENT has a piece in The American Mercury called "America is Conservative." He sets off no firecrackers and Blazes with no serried columns. The subject is commonplace. It is unnecessary to decorate it. He uses the old arguments. He points at the multitudes of holders of life insurance policies, savings bank depositors, home owners.

The acquisition of about 500 new subscribers as a result of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's subscription campaign during the past Summer was made known at a meeting of the committees which have been engaged in the drive, held yesterday at Steinway Hall.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Of the score or more of fighters, managers, trainers and newspaper observers who for the first time saw Max Baer go through his regular training workout today only James J. Braddock went on record as favoring Baer to defeat Joe Louis when they clash at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.

Housing properties again proved attractive to buyers and leasing tenants in the city yesterday. While activity failed to maintain the pace of the past few days, it showed a continuing demand for flats in Yorkville.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Fears of war in the Mediterranean shook the financial markets in London today, pushed British Government issues to their lowest levels of the year and caused heavy selling of sterling in the leading financial centres of the world.

An offering of $30,000,000 of relief bonds by New York State, scheduled for Tuesday, is included in the $39,992,490 financing listed for next week by thirty-nine States and municipalities. This compared with a revised total for this week of $47,747,502.

Field agents of the National Association of Audubon Societies have observed migrating birds in astonishing numbers during the past few weeks at the Witmer Stone Wildlife Sanctuary near Cape May Point, N.J.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 20. -- A field of fifty-four teams started today in the Nassau Country Club's best-ball invitation golf tournament, with Richard M. Potter of the home club and Max B. Kaesche of Ridgewood, N.J., winning the qualifying medal with a par-equaling round of 35, 35 -- 70.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- A flurry of minor injuries struck the Princeton football camp today as Coach Fritz Crisler drove his husky squad through a long double workout on University Field. Three Tiger players reported to the team physician at the end of practice with injuries that will keep them out for periods varying from two days to a week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Simon Wexler, member of the Chicago Board of Trade, was charged today by Secretary Wallace with violation of the Grain Futures Act and was cited to appear before a referee to show cause why he should not be barred from the fifteen Exchanges in the country dealing in grain futures.

The frequently rumored resignation of Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission finally materialized yesterday. Brokers expressed regret at his retirement but said that men of his executive ability could not be expected to sacrifice their personal affairs in the public's welfare for an indefinite period.

ROME, Sept. 20. -- A decree, signed by King Victor Emmanuel and issued in the Official Gazette, set up a commission of the nation's highest commanding officers for "revision of the agreements which have disciplined the conduct of war among belligerents and neutrals."

The Long Island Railroad filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday a substitute schedule of higher commutation fares, to take the place of the schedules filed last month when it applied for the rate increases. The new schedules contain the same fare rises as those already filed, but extend until Jan. 27, 1936, the present rate for twelve-trip weekly commutation tickets.

With a Presidential contest not far off, the abandon with which political partisans are beginning to swing their verbal shillalahs may be largely overlooked as a healthy symptom of a democracy. But have not the attacks upon Franklin D. Roosevelt transcended the limits of fairness, logic and good taste?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- A crisis in the bituminous coal wage negotiations was precipitated tonight by the failure of subcommittees of operators and miners to reach an agreement after five days of conferences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Exports of the United States, including re-exports, amounted to $172,204,000 in August, compared with $173,371,000 in July and $171,984,000 in August, 1934, according to the monthly analysis issued today by the Department of Commerce.

Polo's most important event of the 1935 season, the meeting between Greentree and Aurora, will be staged today on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club to decide the year's national open championship. The starting time of the match has been set for 3:30 P.M. and officials in charge have emphasized that the game will be played unless weather conditions make it absolutely impossible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, announced today that a "gentleman's agreement" limiting Japanese textile exports to the Philippine Islands has virtually been reached between his government and the State Department.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Edgar S. Bowling, 60 years old, of the Scarsdale Golf Club, today won the first championship of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association with a score of 160 in a field of ninety-two contestants.

New bond financing in this market this week totaled $74,623,000, compared with $119,293,000 last week and only $1,565.000 in the corresponding week a year ago. Only two major classifications were represented, and only one new group was added -- Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

Nervous trading characterized the share market throughout the day yesterday as the troubled European situation claimed first attention; reports bearing on the state of trade and industry received comparatively scant attention, even the daily discussion in trading circles of the New Deal being relegated to the background.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Thompson of Round Hill, this place, entertained nearly 1,000 guests at the Greenwich Country Club at a tea dance today to introduce their daughter, Miss Jean Thompson.

RYE, N.Y., Saturday, Sept. 21. -- A woman ticket seller was found guilty by a white jury here shortly before 1 o'clock this morning of discriminating against Negroes last Summer while selling tickets at Playland Park, Westchester County operated amusement centre, here.

For the most part, retail trade in the metropolitan area maintained a fast pace during the week, although slightly warmer weather was less of a stimulating factor than in the previous week. All of the department stores were credited with increases, with the average gain for the week placed at around 10 to 12 per cent over a year ago.

SAYLORBURG, Pa., Sept. 20. -- Herbert McCracken is winding up one of the longest coaching regimes of the East at Lafayette this year as he enters upon the twelfth and last season of his football stewardship.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Wilmer Allison, national champion, and Frank Shields, No. 3 in the United States rating, moved into the semi-finals of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

A course embracing the artistic, social and educational aspects of the motion picture will be opened next week under the joint auspices of the New York University School of Education and the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday by Frederic M. Thrasher, Associate Professor of Education.

Unemployment being a lean subject, John Whedon and Arthur Caplan have treated it to a skinny play, "Life's Too Short," which was put on by Jed Harris at the Broadhurst last evening. Or perhaps unemployment is not the basic theme.

The postponement of the Boston opening of "Jubilee!" from Thursday until this evening also has set back the Broadway premiere, scheduled for Oct. 5 at the imperial. The show now is expected here the week of Oct. 14.

The resignation, announced by the President yesterday, of Chairman JOSEPH P. KENNEDY of the Securities and Exchange Commission will be widely regretted. Since he assumed the post, something more than a year ago, public confidence in the commission's intelligent administration of an admittedly complicated law has been steadily growing.

A city-wide program of free indoor concerts with symphonic programs in every borough will be inaugurated on Oct. 2 under the auspices of the New York Concert Unit of the United States Works Progress Administration, according to an announcement made yesterday by George Crandall, manager of the concert unit.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Another step in its "new era" policy, directed toward getting a larger share of the automotive industry's business, was announced tonight by the United States Steel Corporation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Receipts of hogs today of only 3,000 head set a new all-time low record for a Friday, and of the arrivals 1,300 went direct to packers, leaving only a handful for sale in the open market. In view of the reduced supplies packers found it inadvisable to open their killing floors, with the result the demand for hogs dragged.

Next Christmas, her thirty-first birthday, will be one of the most significant days in the life of Mrs. Hannah Gruber Medoff, who operates a shoe store at 1,585 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn. She planned a home on Park Avenue yesterday as she discussed the $150,000 legacy she will receive that day from the estate of a physician who was charmed by her childhood smiles at the Chrystie Street Settlement.

The mailing of advertisements of erotic books to a minister and to religious institutions brought two book publishers to grief in Federal court yesterday. A strong desire on the part of Postmaster General James A. Farley to close the mails to obscene advertisements of such books was said to have started postal inspectors into action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Plans for strengthening the banking system by arranging mergers of weak banks with stronger institutions and by the absorption of slow assets in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are being considered, it was learned today.

Apartment renting continued at a brisk pace yesterday. Among the lessees was Miss Adele Poston, who took a suite of sixteen rooms and six baths in 544 East Eighty-sixth Street through Douglas Gibbons Co.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Driving Flint Rhem from the box in the first inning, the Montreal Rovals defeated Syracuse, 8 to 1, today, drawing up on even terms with the Chiefs in their International League play-off final series. Each team has now won two games.

The crack juveniles, The Fighter and Postage Due, will clash this afternoon in the Remsen Handicap, and the weight-carrying sprinter, Sation, will be further tested under 133 pounds in the Interborough Handicap, the two events being the features of a seven-race program at Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the Coral Gables promotion was concluded today with a review of events which ended in the failure of plans for the refunding of the bond issues, many of which had been defaulted.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- The State Department of Labor, in its monthly review of industrial accidents, pointed to a decrease in vehicle accidents as a "hopeful sign that the effort being made to reduce motor-vehicle accidents may at least be taking effect in industry."

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 20. -- Governor Oscar K. Allen, temporary custodian of the late Senator Long's political dictatorship in Louisiana, struggled yesterday with the hardest problem he has faced since his old friend was slain.
LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Nervousness over the foreign political situation caused weakness today on the London Stock Exchange.

A Manhattan football team, regarded in pre-season estimates as the strongest of four Jasper elevens coached by Chick Meehan, will launch its campaign at Ebbets Field this afternoon, facing Niagara University, an opening foe of no mean calibre.

At the joint dinner dance, Miss Noble wore a gown with a bodice of silver and white sequins with full white net skirt, and a corsage of white orchids. Miss Carrott's gown was of ahes of roses of the Grecian type, with scarf and gold belt. Her corsage was of gardenias.

Dr. Charles Norris, chief medical examiner of New York City for eighteen years, who died on Sept. 11, set up a trust fund of $250,000 for the benefit of his widow, Eugenie Norris of 344 West Seventy-second Street, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20. -- An unusually large list of Yale athletes won honors in general scholarship averages last year, according to the list announced today. Leaders in other extra-curricular activities displayed versatility by ranking high in the scholarship activities.

Reorganization of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, on the basis of a $1,500,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for working capital and the payment of $33,000,000 indebtedness with new stock, was proposed in a plan submitted here yesterday to Federal Judge John Knight.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- The docking of H.M.S. York at the North Wharves of Philadelphia tomorrow will launch a week of entertaining in this city.

Mayor La Guardia headed a group of city officials who welcomed Captain Eddie Rickenbacker at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn yesterday when he landed in a new ten-passenger plane he had flown from Columbus, Ohio.

A feverish advance in foreign markets yesterday carried prices on the New York Cotton Exchange to the best figures of the week, with July contracts changing hands at 11 cents a pound. As on the two preceding days, when the December delivery rose to around 10 3/4 cents, the market ran into enough hedges to cause reactions.
ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The possibility of an all-Winged Foot the annual Arcola Country Club golf tournament developed today when Tommy Goodwin and Arthur Lynch won their first two matches.

To help its patrons in solving perplexing problems which affect their happiness, Hearn Department Stores, Inc., Fourteenth Street and Fifth Avenue, will start an unusual experiment beginning Monday. A new service, to be known as the Bureau of Human Relations, will be offered patrons of the store.

A plan whereby patients in the low-income group would be treated by private physicians for $1 and $2 fees, under study by the Medical Society of the County of New York since last Spring, will be abandoned because a majority of the members of the society has failed to support it, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Leo Y. Chertok, the New York broker who claims to have an oil and mineral concession from the Ethiopian Government, had a two-hour conference with Dr. Martin, the Ethiopian Minister to London, today and afterward announced that the question of a loan and the concession had been settled "to the satisfaction of both parties."

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Lions, playing behind the same powerful forward wall that stamped them as an outstanding defensive team last season, had no trouble routing the Philadelphia Eagles, 35 -- 0, tonight in Detroit's National Football League opener.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 20. -- A country newspaper woman who defied a farmers' mob and printed their names and her own account of their resistance to Federal officers testified for the government today in its prosecution of fourteen men accused of contempt of court in halting a farm foreclosure sale at Plattsburg Aug. 15.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The ever-widening influence of governmental agencies on the realty market occupied the attention here today of the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20. -- A plan of reorganization for the Davison Chemical Company and two of its subsidiaries, the Davison Realty Company and the Eastern Cotton Oil Company, has been filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Mickey Walker of Rumson, N.J., former world's welterweight and middleweight champion, made another successful step in his comeback by outpointing Charley Weise, Ridgewood, in the main six-round bout last night at the Luna Park Indoor Arena, Coney Island.
PARIS, Sept. 20. -- Some recovery took place on the Bourse today at the end of a week of steady depreciation in almost all departments.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 20. -- Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d frankly related to a coroner's jury here tonight that he had quarreled with Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy actress, in an upstairs bedroom at his Summer estate near Lyndell, shortly before she was found shot to death on the night of Sept. 11.

A greater amount of advance buying to insure timely deliveries to the stores was agreed upon as essential under present market conditions by the general merchandise managers group of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, 1,440 Broadway, who have just completed a two-day meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Seasonal slackness in business was experienced in the United Kingdom during August, according to the weekly survey of foreign business conditions issued by the Commerce Department today on the basis of reports from its commercial attaches abroad.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The peace of the Pompton Lakes area was slightly disturbed today. Joe Louis laughed out loud. It wasn't the hearty roar of the hilarious Baer. It was something between a chuckle and a cackle. It was a shining new bicycle that caused it.

Faced with a growing movement to oust him as Republican County Chairman, Chase Mellen Jr. gathered his own leaders around him yesterday and urged them to stand steadfast in the conviction that the backers of Kenneth F. Simpson did not have enough votes in the county committee to win a victory.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20. -- Duquesne University defeated Illinois Wesleyan, 20 to 6, at Forbes Field tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, has promised to see that the hours of labor for skilled workers on WPA projects throughout the country are reduced sufficiently to make hourly wage scales equivalent to present union scales, according to union officials with whom Mr. Hopkins has conferred.

A 600-pound male brown bear that arrived at the Central Park Zoo Thursday ran amuck yesterday afternoon and, before a crowd of more than 100 horrified onlookers, chewed and clawed a small cub to death and mangled another so badly that it had to be shot.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The tenor of reports reaching London tonight from Geneva, Rome and Paris is all to the effect that tomorrow, when the Italian Cabinet meets, Premier Benito Mussolini must make the most fateful decision of his career.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney issued a statement yesterday asserting that the forces supporting him for the Democratic leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District had won a clear-cut victory, despite opposing claims by backers of John E. Sheehy, his rival.

A noted scientist is quoted in THE TIMES of Sept. 18 as saying: "There is no escaping the fact that man is definitely not created equal, as democracy, invented in the eighteenth century when there was no science to confute it, would have us believe. This fact cannot be suppressed, and it is very sad."

NEW BRUINSWICK, Sept. 20. -- The entire student body of 1,200 and the faculty of Rutgers University attended the convocation here today which opened formally the 170th academic year of the university.

Wage contracts were signed yesterday by the Oriole and Yankee steamship lines with the American Radio Telegraphists Association granting increased pay to radio operators of the lines and recognizing the association as spokesmen for their men, it was announced.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 20. -- The National Bituminous Coal Commission, which will administer the Guffey Coal Act, setting up a "Little NRA" for that industry, and the Bituminous Coal Labor Board, which will handle labor problems arising under this system, were named by President Roosevelt today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- In obvious preparation for a major offensive of organized business against the New Deal, the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today submitted a referendum to the 1,500 member organizations, representing some 750,000 individual business men, asking their opinion on the trend of legislation since President Roosevelt took office.
The money market was colorless. Demand for funds was light and quotations unchanged for all classifications.
Claire Courteol Deane's interesting contribution, "Trade Surpluses and War," mentions two or three erroneous assumptions regarding foreign trade and its relation to military conflict.

The threat of European conflict rattled financial markets severely yesterday. On selling emanating largely from abroad the stock market suffered the worst setback since July 26, 1934, prices of bonds, including United States Government issues, dropped sharply, and grain, cotton and other commodities were unsettled.

TORONTO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Manslaughter charges against two Detroit fliers in the case of Len Koenecke, big league baseball player, who was beaten to death in a dramatic fight in an airplane high above the city, were dismissed today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Challenge, the Seawanhaka Cup defender sailed by Corny Shields, today took the fourth race in the match with Crown Prince Olaf's Norwegian six-meter yacht Norm IV and thus evened the series between them. The deciding contes will be held tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20. -- Reports that President Roosevelt had definitely abandoned his plan to appear before the seventeenth annual convention of the American Legion, which officially opens here Monday morning, cast a depressing spirit over the first arrivals today. There were hopes, however, that Mr. Roosevelt would find himself able to leave Washington in time to reach St. Louis on his Western trip before adjournment Thursday.

Bonds of all classifications suffered yesterday the broadest decline of the month on the New York Stock Exchange. War became the paramount topic of discussion in financial circles and was the principal motivating force in the dealings on the security markets. Transactions amounted to $16,036,900, compared with $10,488,900 on Thursday.

Unable to agree on a verdict nearly fifty-two hours after receiving the case, the jury in the second trial of James C. McKay and William J. Graham, Reno, Nev., gambling house proprietors charged with mall fraud, was discharged yesterday afternoon by Federal Judge Robert J. McMillan.
POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Joe Louis will stage his final training camp boxing session tomorrow and practically bring to an end his preparations for Tuesday night's fight with Max Baer.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Anxiety over the Anglo-Italian conflict and the liquidation in preparation for meeting subscriptions of the first public loan of the Nazi regime produced another heavy drop in prices on the Boerse today, to which the cancellation of war-risk clauses by German insurance companies added impetus.

The editorial "Overdoing It" was timely and unanswerable. It also was a call to sober thinking on the part of some of our leading citizens. The time, indeed, has come for an exposition of the fact that "just now, in the preliminary heat of the coming Presidential campaign, it seems to be the intention of certain politicians to take over for their own party alone the defense of the Constitution."

Retail sales activity gained greater momentum last week, with a wider variety of merchandise included in the demand, which leaned strongly toward quality goods, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. While the upswing was slower in those districts where the weather turned warmer, the agency states that the gain for the country ranged from 10 to 22 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

GENEVA, Sept. 20. -- There was an increasing belief here today that Premier Bonito Mussolini would not flatly reject the peace suggestions of the League of Nations but would give an evasive answer capable of keeping the negotiations open and preventing the League Council from proceeding under Article XV of the covenant until he is ready to invade Ethiopia or to accept some compromise.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Praising the mutual and cooperatice principle as the "cornerstone of American business," State Controller Morris S. Tremaine tonight addressed the Federation of New York State Cooperative Agents at a dinner meeting.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- Premier Pierre Laval returned to Paris from Geneva this evening to attend the Cabinet meeting tomorrow at Rambouillet, called to approve the budget plans of Finance Minister Marcel Regnier. According to Mr. Regnier's statements the budget for 1936 will mark a great decrease in expenditures and will balance at about 40,000,000,000 francs.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 20. -- The Nebraska Supreme Court sent this State's relief and old-age pension program to the scrap heap of unconstitutional legislation today.

ROME, Sept. 20. -- The possibility of war with Great Britain continues to hang like a heavy pall over Italy. Rightly or wrongly, the Italian people are convinced that for some inscrutable reason of her own that they cannot understand Britain is ready to precipitate a European war if that is the only means of keeping Italy out of Ethiopia. This prospect naturally fills them with grave anxiety.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20. -- The American Petroleum Association, representing producers and refiners mostly of the Appalachian field, reserved decision here today on the proposed voluntary code of fair marketing practice for the industry.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

American Fruit Growers, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $331,241 after taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. In the preceding year the company showed a net loss of $169,601.
A jury of six men in Municipal Court yesterday awarded $450 to William Feinstein, Harlem liquor dealer, for stock he said had been destroyed in his store during the Harlem riot of March 19.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

HILLSBORO, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP). -- At least five persons were killed and seven injured in the collision of a Chicago Eastern Illinois passenger train and a motor car near here late today. Fourteen race horses were killed or injured so badly they were destroyed.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Patsy Tiso of the Copake Country Club, Craryville, N.Y., today won the assignment of attempting to stop Paul Runyan in the Metropolitan P.G.A. title tournament.

TORONTO, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Bondholders of the Great Lakes Paper Company adjourned today for two weeks after hearing details of four bids submitted for the assets of the company. None of the offers proposed any payment of cash, but only different arrangements of new bond and stock issues, with various guarantees as to tonnage.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 20. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and national chairman, tonight expressed complete willingness to meet the Republican challenge to make the New Deal the issue in the campaign for the election of an Assembly this Fall.

The improvement in business activity in recent months continued during August and the first half of September, with both production and trade showing gains, according to the monthly report yesterday of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Max Baer has many more supporters than Joe Louis among those who are making wagers on their fifteen-round bout scheduled for Tuesday night at the Yankee Stadium, but Louis still rules a 1-to-2 favorite, according to Jack Doyle, Broadway commissioner.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Little King Ananda of Siam scorned glittering gold and silver gifts for ordinary toys on his tenth birthday today. Behind the guarded doors of his villa he played with his brother and sister after receiving formal congratulations from his 11,000,000 subjects, brought by a delegation of nine Siamese diplomats.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 20. --The resignation of Joseph P. Kennedy as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, submitted two weeks ago, was accepted by President Roosevelt today. Mr. Kennedy will relinquish his post on Monday and sail for Europe with his family on the following day.

The Equity Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of 5,999,844 shares of United Founders Corporation common stock in exchange for securities of some subsidiaries of United Founders and of one other corporation. United Founders stockholders will meet in Baltimore on Oct. 10 to vote on the transaction.

Appropriations requested in the 1936 budget total $582,155,677, or $42,459,900 more than the $539,695,777 limit set by Controller Frank J. Taylor, according to figures made public yesterday at the final hearing on departmental estimates before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

There are a number of openings in the night club-hotel regions during the current week, every one from Forty-second Street to the Park being engaged in boasting "society orchestras" and debutantes, sophistication and general smartness.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -Brig. Gen. William Wallace Atterbury, retired president of the Pennsylvania Railroad and one of the outstanding leaders of American rail transportation, died unexpectedly at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon at the Bryn Mawr Hospital.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- The Public Works Department today forwarded for approval of PWA Administrators a $13,000,000 grade-crossing elimination program, encompassing ninety projects, thirty of them in New York City at an estimated cost of $5,500,000.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Belle Grier, 4-year-old daughter of John P. Grier, carrying the colors of O. Blank, won the featured fourth race today in an easy fashion.

The Equity Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of 5,999,844 shares of United Founders Corporation common stock in exchange for securities of some subsidiaries of United Founders and of one other corporation. United Founders stockholders will meet in Baltimore on Oct. 10 to vote on the transaction.

Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy yesterday directed Robert Tyler, the Dapper Don Collins of many combats with the law, to answer Monday before the grand jury a long series of questions that he had refused to meet on the ground that his constitutional rights would be impaired. He had been cited for contempt.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Frank Ritchie, a national secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association and investigator for the American Christian committee on the non-Jewish refugee problem in Germany, reported today that the number of Christians "who suffer persecution on account of their Jewish descent is double that of the persecuted Jews."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The management's plan for reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway hurdled the first obstacle in the way of final approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission today when Dr. Oliver E. Sweet of the Commission's Bureau of Finance overruled a motion of the bondholders' group that the plan be dismissed as "prima facie impracticable."

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 20 (Canadian Press). -- League of Nations sanctions against Italy were called for in a resolution adopted today by the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada to halt Premier Mussolini's proposed invasion of Ethiopia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Heavy profit-taking in leading wheat markets developed today, the selling being somewhat too much for the buying despite a continuation of war talk and of the drought in Argentina. Liverpool and Winnipeg opened at new high levels for the season with the dollar-a-bushel quotation posted in both markets.

The prospect of working eighty hours a month, instead of the present 120, for $93.50 on WPA jobs was coolly regarded by leaders of skilled labor in the American Federation of Labor unions yesterday. After several meetings, however, spokesmen decided to defer all official statements until General Hugh S. Johnson, WPA Administrator, returned from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The Navy Department announced today that it had sent four expert radio operators to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to set up an emergency system of communication for the State Department.

Mr. and Mrs. Hunt Tilford Wagstaff gave a supper party last night at the Central Park Casino for Mrs. Wagstaff's sister, Miss Sally Comly. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. William R. K. Taylor Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Clive Spencer Huffman Jr., Miss Anne Halle, Alfred Wagstaff 3d, William T. Adee and Arturo Ramos.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The list of eleven executives of public utilities who have been invited to meet here on Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to discuss preliminary registration forms and regulations dealing with conditions of exemption from the provision of the Holding Company Act was made public today by the SEC, along with a letter sent to the executive concerning the subjects to be taken up.

More than 500 members of the freshman class of Columbia College gathered on the Morningside Heights campus yesterday to participate in events of the traditional freshman week which precede the official opening of the university's 182d academic year next Wednesday.

A motion to vacate the warrant for the arrest of former President Gerardo Machado, whose extradition is sought by the Cuban Government, was denied yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter. The warrant is based on a charge of murder and embezzlement of government funds.

The International Seamen's Association obtained yesterday from Federal Judge Grover M. Moskowitz in Brooklyn a writ ordering the master of the British freighter City of Evansville to appear in court Monday to show cause why the members of his crew have been unable to obtain shore leave while the ship is in port.

Supreme Court Justice Carew, who heard the suit by Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt for the custody of her daughter, Gloria, filed a memorandum yesterday explaining that he made George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist, who are the guardians of the child's $3,800,000 estate, parties to the case so he could deprive the mother of her income if she took Gloria out of this country.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area for the twelve shopping days ended Sept. 16 showed a rise of 10.3 per cent, over the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Italian liner Rex, arriving today from Mediterranean ports with 1,757 passengers, will bring Katherine Cornell, actress; Mgr. Diego Venini and Mgr. Carlo Grano, delegates of the Pope to the Eucharistic Congress in Cleveland; Jules Brulatour and his wife, the former Hope Hampton; Primo Carnera, Italian boxer, and W.H. White, general manager of Thomas Cook Son. Others on the list are:
