BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- The League for Germanism Abroad, an association for propaganda among German-born citizens in other nations, has issued an appeal to all citizens of the Reich to furnish it with addresses of emigrants of their acquaintance who have become citizens of other States.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Big Dave Smukler started in where he left off last year by leading Temple University to a 51-0 victory over St. Joseph's College at the Owls' stadium tonight before a crowd of 23,000 persons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- If the high-flying Cubs, riding along on an amazing sixteen-game winning streak, get in the approaching world series, they will be a different looking club from the one which lost four in succession to the Yankees in 1932, according to Manager Charlie Grimm.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 20. -- While the attention of America and Europe is focused on the Italo-Ethiopian dispute and its probable European repercussions, China watches with apprehension, believing she will have to face unaided what is considered a certainty, that if hostilities begin in Africa, Japan will consider the situation a recurrence of the great opportunity afforded during the World War to exercise a free hand in the Far East.

Definite steps to organize a food and grocery conference committee along national lines were taken yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker of representatives of manufacturing, wholesale and retail organizations in the industry. The principal aim of the group will be to establish principles of fair trade practices in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Francis J. Gorman, vice president of the United Textile Workers, today criticized the fifty-eight lawyers who rendered an opinion several days ago through the American Liberty League on the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20. -- More paper is being used each year in the United States and more Southern pine and imported pulps are being used in its production, according to reports to the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry.

After Quitting His Job. Nick, known for twoscore years as the official bootblack of the government Barge Office at South Ferry and along the Battery seawall, died of diabetes Thursday afternoon at the home of his sister, Mrs. Anthony Lorenzo, 1,884 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn.

For the better part of two years the great unsolved problem of recovery from the depression has been posed by the durable goods industries -- that is, by industries manufacturing such products as steel, iron, lumber, building materials and machine tools. In the other great group of American industries -- consumers' goods industries -- an early revival of activity began in 1933 and very large gains have subsequently been made.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- If the high-flying Cubs, riding along on an amazing sixteen-game winning streak, get in the approaching world series, they will be a different looking club from the one which lost four in succession to the Yankees in 1932, according to Manager Charlie Grimm.

ALTHOUGH most of the Yiddish producers complained that their ledgers were stained with the tears of red ink last season, they are now behaving as if a look around the corner showed prosperity. For when the new season begins on Sept. 28 there will be no less than twelve companies in this city -- six operating in Manhattan, four in Brooklyn and two in the Bronx.

FORD DOES NOT CHOOSE: Henry Ford, who has been repeatedly boomed for President, and has repeatedly voiced his distinterest in politics, took occasion again last week to deny any interest in Ford-for-President talk. At the same time he said he thought business was on its way up, and "I do not believe the political campaign of next year will have any appreciable effect on business, one way or the other."

Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, Australian flier, sailed on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic yesterday for what he hoped would be his last long flight. His plane, Lady Southern Cross, in which he flew here from California, was shipped by freight to London, and from there he hopes to "hang up" one more record before ending his adventurous career in the air and turn to the administrative side of flying.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- More than 300 members of the Association of Blauvelt Descendants held their annual meeting today at the historic Dutch Reformed Church here. There was no such dissension at the meeting today as marked the affair last year when a family named Blauvelt of reputed pirate fame was barred from the association.

THE two artists whose work is on exhibition at the Ferargil Gallery, preparatory to its tour through the country, stopping for exhibition at leading museums, are, I am told, 100 per cent American. I am trying to make up my mind what that means.

THE Fall season is yielding its annual crop of country fairs, where hogs, "hot dogs" and horticulture, for a day or a week, compete for the attention of millions throughout the land. In State capitals, county seats and thousands of smaller communities the fair has just been held or is about to open -- as inevitable a part of the American Autumn scene as verdure turning brown or gold.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 20. -- The Share Our Wealth Society, boasting some 9,000,000 members who have paid no dues, was peculiarly Huey Long's. He brought it into being, fostered its growth by use of his Senatorial frank and supported it on enforced contributions from State officeholders who owed their jobs to him.

Mail orders again were heavy last week and a substantial number of buyers were in the markets here, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Women's apparel, school wear, boys' furnishings, holiday items and home furnishings were actively sought by buyers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Phillies and Braves divided a double-header today. The locals captured the first game, 6-0, as Curt Davis held the visitors to six hits to gain his sixteenth triumph of the year. Boston took the nightcap, 4 -- 0, when Betts allowed only three hits.

ELGAR'S native city, Worcester, played host to the Three Choirs Festival this year and made it evident in many ways that the memory of her famous son is held in honor. On the opening day a stained-glass window reproducing scenes from "The Dream of Gerontius" was unveiled in the cathedral by the Lord Lieutenant of the county, the ceremony being followed by an exceptionally thoughtful performance of "The Dream."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Midnight Sunday is the deadline for one of the longest collective bargaining negotiations in American trade-union history. On Feb. 18, more than seven months ago, representatives of the United Mine Workers met with a committee of bituminous coal operators to discuss the terms of a new contract to take the place of the one due to expire on March 31.

BAMBODE, Western Ethiopia, via Khartum, Sept. 21. -- On the Ethiopian hills and mountains big drums are now rumbling calling all the tribes and races to arms. This is the method Emperor Haile Selassie uses in giving orders and seeking information from the interior.

While hundreds of persons passed the busy intersection of Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, robbers yesterday morning bound the proprietor, porter and a customer in the D. Gumbinger jewelry store, 52 East Forty-sixth Street, snatched a handful of diamond rings and escaped.

Mrs. Robert Lyman Grant will launch the season's program for the Montclair Women's Club at a board meeting at the Montclair Golf Club tomorrow afternoon. At 1 o'clock Mrs. Grant will be hostess at a luncheon there for the board members.

THERE appear to be few fields human endeavor in which more confusion arises than flying and its accidents. The Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, through Howard Mingos, editor of The Aircraft Yearbook, last week sent a long letter of protest to The New Yorker on this very subject.

TOKYO, Sept. 21. -- An analysis of the advantages Japan may expect to reap if Italy and Ethiopia go to war appeals in today's Nichi Nichi, which shows that in every field except wheat and chemicals Japan would gain.

Members of thirteen nearby garden clubs will be guests of the Junior League North Mianus Garden Club in Greenwich. Conn., at a floral exhibit and lecture in the North Mianus Recreation Centre on Thursday evening.

A widespread movement among cotton dealers, mills, exporters, converters and garment manufacturers to bring into actual operation the government tolerance plan on exports will be inaugurated at a dinner meeting on Oct. 2 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, when representatives from a half-dozen associations and others in the industry map out a program, it was learned here yesterday.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 21. -- Charles E. Wetzel, advertising manager of the United Gas Improvement Company, was found dead early this morning on a bank of the Little Lehigh River in a suburb. He had been beaten about the head and the upper part of his body, which was partly submerged in the river.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP). -- In the most sensational match of the Pacific Southwest championships, Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, national doubles titleholders, advanced to the final today with a 6 -- 4, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4 triumph over Christian Boussus and Jacques Brugnon of France.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Pennsylvanians must seek other methods of achieving the "more abundant life" than through rewriting their Constitution, at least this year.
OV the "Othello" which will begin the Merivale-Coopsr season here next Friday night, Edwin F. Melvin recently wrote as follOWS in The Boston Transcript:

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Several social and sports events have been planned for the Autumn [at the Milbrook Country Club, ineluding a mixed foursome and clambake for tomorrow. An lnterclub golf match, with Hubbard Heights members of Stamford, Conn., has tbeen arranged for Sept. 29, with a buffet supper.

THE big news for this early Fall morning must read like a digest of the shipping page. For actors are converging on this port, and authors and their agents, all defying quota laws, customs inspections and the local drama critics. J.B. Priestley, who was encountered at least once by the ship news boys, is in charge; the whole movement is his party.

The start of construction near Greenville, Miss., on Tuesday of that State's first "cotton road" is expected to be witnessed by Federal officials and a score or more members of Congress, the Cotton-Textile Institute announced yesterday. In addition, several Governors, highway commissioners, engineers, Mayors and county road officials of half a dozen near-by States are expected to attend.

Formation of a committee to represent minority stockholders in the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railway holding structure, was announced yesterday by Daniel W. Blumenthal of Maurice B. and Daniel W. Blumenthal.

THE Encyclopaedia Britannica Company, 3,301 Arthington Street, Chicago, Ill., has in preparation a book called "The March of Man," to be published in the near future. It is described as a chronological record of all events from prehistoric times until the latter part of 1935.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 21. -- Northeastern University's eleven scored once in each period to defeat the American International College of Springfield, 26 to 0, today at Huntington Field. It was the opening of the third football season for the winners and the second for the losers.

Nine graduates of the city's high schools have received scholarships in the Cooper Union Institute of Technology, valued at $1,200 each, it was announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the union's board of trustees.

FOR its eighteenth season in its home city, beginning on Oct. 10, the Cleveland Orchestra, conducted by Dr. Artur Rodzinski, will present eighteen symphony programs on Thursday evenings and Saturday afternoons and undertake the production of four operas, to be given on Thursday and Saturday evenings.

READERS whose memory goes back thirty years will recall the sensation produced in the literary world by "The Scarlet Pimpernel" when it first appeared, in 1905. At a recent luncheon Baroness Orczy, the author of this "best seller," gave some interesting particulars of its history.

The Binghamton convention of the Democratic Union and allied groups was called "an orgy of idle words" by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, in a statement telephoned yesterday from his home at Norwich, N.Y., to Republican headquarters in this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21. -Mayor Ellenstein announced today he had received word from Washington of the approval of a $3,400,000 grant by the Works Progress Administration for expansion and improvement of Newark Airport. The Mayor ordered his engineering staff to rush detailed plans for the project.

Seven maps which indicate the population of New York City works and lives -- what the conditions of crowding are in each block in the city -- have just been prepared as a basis for future changes to provide for the welfare and comfort of the city's seven millions.

TWO English childhoods, one in the Eighties, the other in the second decade of the present century, are described here, and reflect within their small compass fifty years of change in the larger world outside. In writing, nine years ago, for private circulation among friends, a memoir of the tragically brief life of her daughter, Lady Acland was impelled to set down her memoirs of her own childhood.

AS each new Stuart Chase book drops on the conveyor belt, one views it with the same mixed feelings as one would a beautiful new streamlined car, with glistening gadgets, but with a motor that knocks and pounds and finally stalls.

POLICE departments of today are becoming more and more motorized. Reports from various parts of the country show a definite trend toward buying armored cars, which are used not only for criminal pursuit but for safety education.

The address of the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare, to the League Assembly expressed the sincere desire on the part of the British Government for a new order in international relationships -- international concert of effort for peace and advance.

Children between the ages of 5 and 9 like their mothers better than their fathers, according to Dr. Margaret Simpson, Research Assistant at Teachers College, Columbia University. The results of her survey were announced yesterday in The Teachers College News, official publication of the college.

THIS gentle, kindly, hopeful little book indicates how essentially ennobling and refining in their effect upon human character gentle, humane and loving ideals and beliefs can be when they are consistently held and lived by year after year.

SUMMONED to Washington from the United States Embassy staff in Moscow, Remington Post is assigned to the hazardous task of running to earth and foiling a gigantic Communist conspiracy to overthrow the governments of Latin America and transform their countries into a new world Union of Soviet Republics.

ON the theory that the greatest gulf to be bridged in the transition from prep school to college is social rather than academic, Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn has inaugurated special courses to prepare students for college life as well ms college study.

EL PASO, Texas. -- Those hard old gods who decreed that much of the Western United States should be desert are not vacating their commands without a struggle, despite the modern engineering skill that builds dams to make gardens of the arid plains, according to reports from the irrigation project under the Coolidge Dam in Arizona.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- Hands will be warm this Winter regardless of hearts. Paquin's flower muffs for evening are already important for theatre and night-club wear. Feather muffs matching feather toques are the style highlights of the Autumn racing season.

LONDON. -- The Italian Government's indictment of Ethiopia as an unworthy member of the League of Nations invites contrast with the attitude they took when the Ethiopian request for admission to the League was discussed at Geneva in 1923.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has high hopes of setting out this week on a vacation trip that will take him first to the West Coast and then fishing in Pacific waters. Between three and four weeks have been allotted tentatively to this holiday. If time and circumstances permit, he will board a Navy ship at San Diego and cruise leisurely in the direction of Cocos Island.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Maurrie O'Connor, professional of the Branch Brook public links, today became the eighth New Jersey Professional Golfers Association champion, beating Byron Nelson of the Ridgewood Country Club in the second eighteen-hole play-off at the Baltusrol Golf Club today with a 71 to Nelson's 73.

FEW people question the decisive advantages any modern civilized nation enjoys in war with backward countries, even when the latter are, like Ethiopia, peopled by intelligent natives who are born warriors and enjoy strong natural positions.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 21. -- With a putter as hot as a poker just pulled out of the glowing embers. Ernest Pieper, tall, shuffling Californian, made short work of Foy W. Porter, his opponent in the final round of the annual Arcola invitation golf tournament today.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 18, 1935. RESEARCHES made for material to amplify the biography being prepared in England of Frederick Delius, famous English composer, who died in France last June, have revealed an obscure period of his life which was spent here teaching piano, violin and theory at the old Roanoke Female College.

RAILROADS keep speeding up schedules to hold their customers against the encroachments of air and bus lines. Drastic time-cuts on important routes throughout the country have consistently featured railroad news during the last year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP). -- A big fourth inning featured by Hal King's homer with two on base gave the Montreal Royals a 6-to-4 victory over Syracuse before 8,000 fans in the final game of the year here today. The triumph gave Montreal a 3-to-2 edge in the International League's final series for the Governor's Cup.

ROME, Sept. 20. -- The arrival in the Mediterranean of powerful units of the British home fleet has caused Italians to look with much anxiety on the possibility that Britain is preparing to take active steps to prevent them from carrying out their plans in East Africa.

THIS book came into being -- as every book should, although not every one attains its birthright -- out of ardent interest in and wide and intimate knowledge of its theme. Mrs. Hall, who is responsible for the main part of the work, has been all her life interested in patchwork quilts and their patterns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- With President Roosevelt fully informed today of the stalemate in the bituminous coal wage negotiations and with the camps of miners and operators completely isolated from each other awaiting tomorrow's momentous meeting between operators and miners, the prospect of a nation-wide soft coal strike at midnight tomorrow increased measurably.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- Until the Reich Government makes known the manner in which the anti-Jewish laws enacted at Nuremberg are to receive practical application the effect of those decrees can only be conjectured. As proclaimed at the National Socialist party's "Congress of Freedom" last Sunday they constitute only a framework for definitive legislation, but that framework is of sufficient elasticity to encompass complete realization of the National Socialist anti-Semitic policy.

BEFORE the actual opening of the new season, which takes place tomorrow with the appearance of Carlos de Vega and Sarita at the Town Hall, there is still time for one or two travel notes from American dancers who are in other quarters of the globe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Faced with the necessity of providing jobs at the rate of 50,000 daily if the work-relief program is to reach its scheduled peak by Nov. 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, laid down four fundamental policies today, by which WPA State administrators must carry out the task and later operate the program.

HESKETH PEARSON'S account, in Harper's, of GILBERT and SULLIVAN'S joint work in composing text and music of those comic operas which still, after fifty or sixty years, hold a foremost place on the contemporary stage, adds little to what was already known regarding the constantly strained relations of the two collaborators.

Official opening of the Autumn program in the various branches of the Young Women's Christian Association will take place this week. More than 1,500 young men and women will attend the gala at the central branch, 610 Lexington Avenue, on Saturday evening, it is anticipated, and visit the demonstration classes in tap and social dancing, cookery, gymnastics, swimming, music and bridge, closing with a style show and a dance.

CAROLINE DORMON has the good fortune to be an artist as well as a tireless student of nature. "Wild Flowers of Louisiana" is an adequate field book for the nature lover, but it is much more than this, for it contains twenty-four beautiful color plates of the author's flower studies and numerous interesting line drawings.

Whenever there is speculation as to a clash between Great Britain and Italy in the Mediterranean, the question at once arises: What will be the role of aircraft, and how effective will they be on the sea? In case of such a war the old controversy as to whether aircraft can sink or disable battleships would probably be settled at the start.

ALTHOUGH many new varieties of pickle come to market in September, the housewife turns to what she calls the pickles and relishes of the "good old days." And at this season she makes them herself. Baskets of green tomatoes and inch-long cucumbers are bought at the greengrocer's stall, for the housewife makes her piccalilli in quantity.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 21. -- The international situation has had the effect almost of a panic on business circles in Egypt, particularly on the local stock market. Following several days of weak markets, quotations in the last two days fell comparatively heavily.

Germany, not Italy, offers the real threat of general war in Europe, declares Frank H. Simonds in an article entitled "The Drift to War" in the October issue of Current History. "The Ethiopian crisis has been, in a sense, a side issue," Mr. Simonds explains.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Calumet Evelyn, flashing black mare owned by the McConville Brothers of Ogdensburg, N.Y., in winning every heat of the Almahurst free-for-all pace at today's opening of the last Grand Circuit meeting of the season, twice lowered the former world record for 4-year-old pacers and raced the fastest three heats ever paced by horse of any age.

EVERY year the little island of Malta in the Mediterranean is visited by multitudes of sightseers. Today that island is a scene of more feverish activities. Nothing may come of it, but the most famous of Britain's naval stations is preparing to stand a siege.

THE time of the falling of leaves approaches. Already the raucous Autumn notes of the jays presage the flashing of blue wings through the crimsoning foliage of sumac and gum trees. In the garden the dahlias are at the height of their glory, yellow and bronze and gold in the sun's slant rays -- a final burst of color before Jack Frost cloaks them in drooping mourning.

Seldom can the world have been in such a condition of puzzled uncertainty as today. Everywhere we see individuals and rulers in doubt what to think, what to say, what to do. They feel themselves in the presence of a crisis which, if not surmounted, threatens to bring countless evils in its train.

The architecture committee of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, which now constitutes the museum's department of architecture, has announced a series of exhibitions for the coming season.

While women and children sipped sodas at the counter, Leonard Josephie, head of the insurance brokerage concern of Josephie Son, 116 John Street, shot and killed his partner, Abraham Ross, in the drug store they jointly operated in the George Washington Hotel, Lex ington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Hopeful cheers by President Roosevelt failed today to save the White House baseball team, dubbed by him the "Tigers," from defeat in the third annual game with the "Saints and Sinners," organized by Lowell Thomas, author and radio commentator.

A case recently tried before Justice Lester Lazarus in the Municipal Court brought out some facts which stress very strongly, declares Samuel R. Schneider of the New York bar, the necessity for receivers, before entering upon their duties, to know definitely what are their legal rights and obligations.

With manufacturing operations, wholesale distribution and retail trade showing improvement in the last thirty days, a general improvement in industrial turnover seems assured for the Fall months, according to the September report of the National Association of Purchasing Agents' business survey committee.

In the September Atlantic, LEWIS W. DOUGLAS, former Director of the Bureau of the Budget, argued that as unemployment is centred chiefly in the capital-goods industries, any substantial increase in employment in those industries depends, not upon consumer spending, but upon the extent to which additional savings are invested.

There is little modernity in the eighth outdoor art exhibition and sale which opened yesterday in Washington Square and which will go on until Sept. 29. Of the more than 400 artists exhibiting, Alice Mason, 83 Horatio Street, is the only one showing abstractions.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Hal Trosky, Indians' first baseman, drove his twenty-fourth, home run of the season today in leading an eleven-hit batting attack that defeated the White Sox, 7 to 3.

The entire contents of this meritorious anthology had prior publication in Tower Mystery Magazine, edited by Mr. Horner, who has selected the stories for their present form and prefaced them with an able critical essay on crime fiction.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney were hosts here tonight at a supper dance at their country home in honor of the polo players who have been competing in a series of international matches at the Meadow Brook Club.

THE garden visitor who sees at this season of the year some particularly brilliant bit of orange-red color in the flower border and goes to investigate what it is is more than likely to discover a group of Gaillardias.

CHANGE has come over the country weekly newspaper as change has come over the country itself. Only in most backward counties may be found the old weekly, the four-page flea-bitten sheet, loudly political, whose editor is also postmaster.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The advisability of naming a coalition Presidential ticket next year and adopting a conservative platform with emphasis on social legislation will be a question for informal discussion by the executive committee of the Republican National Committee at a meeting here Wednesday.

THIS year No. 10 Downing Street -- home of British Prime Ministers -- completes two centuries of public service, for it was on Sept. 22, 1735, that Sir Robert Walpole took up his residence there. Since that day history has been unfolded in this brickfaced house, devoid of ornament to the point of ugliness and bounded by dingy railings.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21. -- The neutral military mission in the Chaco has demobilized 93,000 men of the Bolivian and Paraguayan armies since July 10, according to its report to the Chaco peace conference. The report says Bolivia has demobilized 49,490 and Paraguay 43,500.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Thoroughly fit, and confident of victory, Joe Louis ended target practice on his crew of sparring mates today and brought to a close his long training grind in preparation for his fight with Max Baer.
SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Max Baer wound up heavy training, today for his fight with Joe Louis, and will take things easy until ring-time Tuesday night.

THE tide is coming back! The ebbing faith in the peace movement is on the turn. The signals which fly from the League of Nations are enheartening to every thoughtful man or woman, even if the storm which is impending should break upon the hills of Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The only American war vessel in Mediterranean waters has been recalled to the United States, the Navy Department announced today. The destroyer Dale is at Livorno, Italy, but has been ordered to report at Washington in time for the celebration of Navy Day on Oct. 28.

GEORGE COLBY was a rich man's son and proud of it. He was good at games and sports, but his snobbishness kept him outside the life of the school and left him on the last day of the term friendless, though still convinced that his money could be used to bring him everything he might desire.

The absence in this restrained, thoughtful novel of customary mystery ructions, of baffling crimes, super-malefactors and indomitable sleuths, may retard the book's appeal to that reading public partial to these sensational features.

I have been an attentive reader of letters to the editor. I encountered recently, for the first time, a correspondent -- Herbert C. Pell -- who perceives a difference between capitalism and business. In his indictment of business practices Mr. Pell declares:

The Atlas Corporation is acquiring at par for investment a $630,000 refunding bond issue of the Mueller Brass Company and is also acquiring options to purchase 54,200 shares of its common stock, according to a statement filed by Mueller Brass with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON. H.G. WELLS has discovered a new role for himself -- showman. He is collaborating in a series of film dramas of which he, the man behind the scenes, is the star. His forthcoming picture, "Things to Come," depicts the course of events in the next fifty years or so.

The commodity futures markets were generally higher in the short session yesterday, although trading activity was limited. In the cash market corn and oats were higher, while wheat, rye, lard, tin, cotton and rubber were lower.

OF course, if you have never gone to the movies, you probably never have heard of Frances Marion. But if you have, even though it has only been once or twice, you must have noticed her name on the screen credits. She is probably Hollywood's most prolific screen writer.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Jockey George Woolf turned in a brilliant riding performance at Rockingham Park today to capture the $5,000 added Bennington Handicap on Mrs. C. Crane's Ladfield.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 21. -- Continuing his long string of triumphs, Paul Runyan proved today that he can be champion of his district as well as National Professional Golfers Association titleholder by winning the Metropolitan P. G. A. crown at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club.

LONDON. WHATEVER has happened to his fame in the United States, Scotland at any rate has not forgotten Andrew Carnegie. He was born at Dunfermline, across the Forth Bridge from Edinburgh, on Nov. 25, 1835, and the four Carnegie Trusts which he has left at Dunfermline are planning to do ample justice to his approaching centenary.

THE first of the 1934 Rhineland wine will go under the hammer in October at the city of Trier, in Germany. Of the wine industry of the Rhine district Trier is a renowned centre, long associated with the growing of grapes and the manufacture of the section's most important product.

After allotting allowances up to 250 yards to approximately twenty rivals, Joe McCluskey of the New York A.C., former national steeplechase champion, stepped two miles in 9:18.6 yesterday to furnish one of the features of the New York A.C.'s 135th track and field games at Travers Island.
AMONG Dr. Johnson's less intimate acquaintances was the humble man who had tried to become a philosopher but found that "cheerfulness was always breaking in."

MADRID, Aug. 29. INTEREST in the tercentenary celebrations in honor of Lope de Vega has been limited for practical purposes to the somewhat daring experiments of that youthful playwright and poet, Federico Garcia Lorca, who has boldly stepped in not only to "adapt" the works of Spain's great dramatic author, but to introduce song and dance where they did not exist.

CROCUS blooms in the Autumn may be obtained from Fall Crocus species planted in August or September. They usually bloom within four weeks. The flowers are similar to those of the Spring-flowering Dutch Crocus and add a delicate bit of color to the vivid Fall garden.

GARDENERS are becoming convinced that Autumn is the best season for rearranging the garden. At this time most plants are growing less actively than in the Spring, and so one does not have to work against the onrush of growth that makes Spring replanting so hurried.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 19. -- When President Roosevelt goes to Georgia for his Thanksgiving vacation at Warm Springs, he may find himself beset by Southern Democratic leaders with protests against the proposed abolition of the century-old two-thirds rule at the party's national convention next year.

Completing the production of the largest pack of vegetables in the history of the canning industry in this country, producers face the ensuing selling season with the assurance of a stable market, with current demand good and future commitments the heaviest in years.

Delegates from six States will arrive in Providence, R.I., tomorrow for the twenty-sixth New England Conference of the General Federation of Women's Clubs opening Tuesday. Governor Theodore Francis Green of the host State will address the assembly on Tuesday night and Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson, national president of the federation, will come from Washington to participate in the sessions at the Providence-Biltmore Hotel.

JOHN JAMES AUDUBON was a naturalist and painter. Donald Culross Peattie is a naturalist and writer. Since he is therefore a painter in words he feels "uniquely bound" to the great pioneer in American ornithology and he offers his "Singing in the Wilderness" as "a salute" in praise of a national hero.

The markets were unruffled by the news yesterday that Italy had rejected the peace plan of the League of Nations. Stocks fluctuated narrowly throughout the two-hour trading period and closed steady, a shade higher, on the average.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- The Boerse was stronger today, recovering some of this week's losses. The buoyant reaction was in response to reports that Italy and Great Britain may be able to reach a basis of agreement and that war is not imminent in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Income tax collections for the first twenty days of September were $226,352,401, an increase of 41 per cent over the $160,359,334 collected in the same period last year, the Treasury announced today.

While leaders of white-collar workers sharply attacked Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, yesterday on the ground that he was seeking to convert Works Progress Administration workers on security wages into Public Works Administration jobs at the lower wage scale of the WPA, leaders of the skilled workers' unions awaited a conference with General Hugh S. Johnson, WPA administrator.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 19. -- Although the light tobacco growers of North Carolina are greatly agitated over the fact that prices on the middle belt markets are averaging around 18 cents, as compared with more than 27 cents a year ago, AAA officials say they see no cause for alarm.

ROME, Sept. 21. -- Italy's rejection of the Geneva peace plan, a government spokesman said tonight, "left the door open" for further discussion of the Italo-Ethiopian question and created a definite note of optimism that differences with Great Britain may be straightened out.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Contracts for parkway construction projects prepared by the State Department of Public Works and approved by the Long Island State Park Commission will be let the first two weeks in October. There will be seven contracts, the cost of which total more than $2,000,000.

THE accent isn't always on youth! Certainly not when it comes to the debutante's mother. After all, she is the axis around which that gay young thing's orbit swings. She too is a glamorous person. While daughter flits merrily from party to party, mother has her own social functions to fulfill.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Plans of the State of Alabama for an early retrial of nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case were announced today by Lieut. Gov. Thomas E. Knight Jr., who has been retained as special prosecutor.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced here yesterday that seventy-five radio operators had gone on strike on Great Lakes freighters, adding their weight to the association's demand for recognition, higher wages and better working conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19. -- Herbert Hoover's speech at San Diego last Tuesday, in which he warned of dictatorship, and a forthcoming speech at Oakland on Oct. 5 are serving to remind California that he is still very much in the 1936 Republican picture.
The fully amortized, insured mortgage gives the borrower a greater measure of safety by eliminating the renewal difficulty, points out Stewart McDonald, Assistant Federal Housing Administrator.
PIERRE, S.D., Sept. 20. -- Petitions demanding a special session of the South Dakota Legislature to raise the tax on gasoline from 4 to 5 cents have failed to budge Governor Tom Berry.

Bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange during the two-hour session yesterday was considerably quieter than operations of the previous day although prices continued to seek moderately lower levels. Pressure was lifted from some sections, notably the railroad issues in the domestic group, and the Italian obligations in the foreign list.

The Mohmands are a Pathan tribe holding about 1,200 square miles of land above Peshawar in the Northwest Frontier Province of India. Their territory is hilly, arid and barren. Poverty and an inherent pugnacity have made them consistent foragers into the southern plains.

GARDENERS have taken to planting roses in the Fall. It is a common-sense thing to do. Yet a few years ago the setting out of a rose plant at any time other than in the early Spring, just as it was beginning to push into growth, was looked upon as very questionable practice.
There will be a nation-wide broadcast over the WEAF and WJZ networks of the Max Baer-Joe Louis fight Tuesday night.

In "Everyday Children," Hildegard Woodward, who has illustrated many children's books and whose drawings for "America Travels," by Alice Dalgliesh, were particularly noteworthy, has written the story as well as made the pictures.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 21. -- McClelland Barclay gave an informal exhibition of twelve marine paintings done on the coast of Maine this Summer in his beach studio this afternoon, afterward entertaining at tea. He also invited his guests for tomorrow afternoon.

TO any one who has read the author's previous books, "Ex-Mistress," "Night Nurse," and "Promiscuous" -- or even only their titles -- "Public Sweetheart No. 1" will seem a typical Dora Macy novel. It tells the story of Violet Chester -- dancer, actress and screen star -- who was loved by literally hundreds of men, but who was true in her heart to one love in spite of her five marriages.

With the majority of local stores having given their assurance that they will require that all coats and suits bought by them will bear the "Consumer's Protection Label," the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board is extending its efforts in that connection to retailers in other cities, it was announced yesterday by Alexander Printz of the Printz-Biederman Company, chairman of the board.

The threat of war abroad and crop shortage reports have sent the price of wheat to new high levels, stimulated the grain markets of the world and brought to the fore the question whether the price of American bread will be advanced.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- In recent proposals of the Illinois WPA, of which Robert J. Dunham is Federal director. Methodist laymen of the Middle West foresee possible revival of the old issue of separation of church and State.

Recent clashes between Park Commissioner Moses and General Johnson, chief of the WPA in New York City, have directed attention to the unprecedented program, primed by Federal work-relief money, for the expansion of the city's park and recreational facilities.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Reds delivered a smashing blow to the Cardinals' pennant hopes today, defeating the world champions, 9 to 7, as the Cubs continued their long winning streak. The Reds seem destined to take over the role of last year's Dodgers, who blasted the Giants out of a title after being easy prey all season.

In a setting of old-time fistic splendor. Max Baer, former heavyweight champion of the world, and Joe Louis, sensational young Detroit heavyweight, are scheduled to box Tuesday night for the distinction of being recognized as foremost challenger for the world's heavyweight title, now held by James J. Braddock.

THE theatre season is here again, and Times Square once more feels the autumnal madness. All Summer it rested in woodland groves, in colonies, on beaches adjacent to the Little Theatres-by-the-sea. But now it is back in town.
Mayor La Guardia left the massive Bronx Supreme Court Building at 161st Street and the Grand Concourse at noon yesterday bound for an inspection of a series of possible airport sites.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21. -- Two factions of Senator Huey P. Long's machine got together tonight to make common cause against the enemy, a ticket backed by President Roosevelt's administration and headed by Representative Cleveland Dear.

Two indications of trends of transatlantic travel were shown by announcements made yesterday by ship lines. The announcements were that the liners American Importer and American Farmer would dock tomorrow with 114 and so passengers, respectively, and that the Hapag Lloyd liner Albert Ballin would carry a delegation of men interested in the spirituous liquors industry when she sails for New York from Hamburg on Oct. 3.

DALLAS, Texas. -- Unless all signs fail, Senator Morris Sheppard, veteran of the struggle for national prohibition and senior Texas Senator, is to have his hands full if he should decide to seek re-election next year.

THREE new films, two from the Hollywood workshops and one an importation from France, are scheduled to be presented during the new week. First comes the foreign visitor, "Maria Chapdelaine," which will have its American premiere on Tuesday at the Cinema de Paris, formerly the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

ADDIS ABABA. -- I arrived in Jijiga (from Harar) in a military lorry, accompanied by Balambaras Ali Nur, an Ethiopian Moslem, who is commander of the British Somaliland frontier and game warden of the Ogaden. Our escort consisted of five of his soldiers in peaked cotton caps and thorn-proof gaiters.

Uncertainty as to the future prevails among the public utility companies of the country, a survey of the larger corporations reveals. Since they were harassed by the Senate committee's investigation of alleged lobbying practices during Congressional consideration of the new regulatory law, the companies have had little success in trying to determine their status individually under the Public Utility Act.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 21. -- Plans have been announced for the winding up of Northern Aerial Minerals Exploration, Ltd., the company that J.E. Hammell formed in 1928 to "crack open" the sub-Arctic regions of Northern Central Canada.

BY association when one hears the words "buffalo" and "elk" one thinks of Western plains and mountains, for few of us realize that both these animals were once to be found in the regions bordering the Atlantic Ocean.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The Council of Ministers approved this morning the budgetary project for 1936, which not only balances completely on paper but reduces expenditures 20 per cent compared with 1935. By this budget the Laval government pledges continuance of its deflationary program to restore French finances to soundness after years of chaotic extravagance.

RECENT Congressional action has authorized an appropriation of $100,000 for a commemorative park area at Appomattox Court House, Va., providing complete restoration of the Civil War picture as presented there by Generals Lee and Grant.

AMERICANS who want to hear broadcasts from China must get up early or stay up late. The waves of ZBW, Hongkong, flash across this part of the world in the "dead of the night." Recently, at 4:15 A.M., in New York, an announcer on the 8,750-kilocycle channel disclosed that ZBW was relaying a program from Daventry, England, but he did not say whether the broadcast was a direct relay or from a recording.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 21 (Reuters). -- Although Ethiopia had feared the rejection of the peace proposals of the League of Nations, the rapidity of the Italian Cabinet's decision caused astonishment and anger when the news was flashed here today.

In announcing plans for the consolidation of several of its operating subsidiaries, the United States Steel Corporation gave impetus last week to the movement for simplification of corporate structures that was begun more than a year ago, according to industrial leaders in Wall Street.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 21. -- Working steadily through a field of eleven, Good Gamble, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 3-year-old chestnut filly, won the $10,000 added Potomac Handicap today in a rousing stretch battle.

THE radio designer's dream to put foreign stations at the fingertips of Americans who manipulate the precision dials of modern all-wave radios comes true at the National Electrical and Radio Exposition now being held at the Grand Central Palace.

As is usually the case on Saturday at this season of the year, hedging operations occurred in volume on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices eased and ended with losses of 6 to 11 points on the day. Nevertheless, the broadening tendency of the market again was in evidence, with trade buying orders on slight recessions and apparently increasing at each point decline.

MOST delphinium growers prefer to do their planting in the Fall rather than in the Spring. There are sound arguments for this preference and they apply both to seed planting and to transplanting established plants, either home grown or from the nursery.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Impartial enforcement of the State Milk Control Law was demanded by the Mutual Dairy Cooperatives, Inc., in a resolution adopted after an eight-hour session here today.

THE great group of readers who chortle with delight at the mere mention of P.G. Wodehouse will agree with the publishers that a Wodehouse book needs no blurb. They refer you simply to the hilarious experiments in hog-calling, beginning on page 67, in which Lord Emsworth valiantly tries to learn the magic call to lure his pining prize pig, the Empress of Blandings, back to the delights of her trough.

In the eyes of at least one comparative newcomer to the field, the dignity and prestige of the traditional Broadway "name," with its elaborate build-up, have been smashed irrevocably. The havoc has been wrought by the exigencies of a season of "past successes and tryouts" which it was my privilege to direct under the banner of a well-known producer, to whom I shall refer arbitrarily as "Martin."

THE GIRLS GREW OLDER: A flapper is a young duck, not yet able to fly. About 1889 the word came to be used to indicate a young woman no better than she should be; within two decades that harsh definition was toned down and the term meant a young woman who enjoyed breaking an occasional convention.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 21. -Best of more than 800 dogs benched today at the seventh annual exhibition of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club was the striking white poodle Champion Edelweis Du Labory of Salmagundi, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Griess of Hamilton, Mass., and handled in the ring by Percy Roberts of Noroton Heights, Conn.

Protestants, Catholics and Jews will collectively and separately observe today as a special Sunday for "reconstruction" at the beginning of the new church year. Interest of leaders of all three faiths centre in the meeting to be held under the auspices of the "Religion and Welfare Recovery Committee" this afternoon, to be addressed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Mayor La Guardia.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- When at Geneva Tuesday the French Minister of Commerce, Georges Bonnet, invited the governments and peoples who are members of the League of Nations to take concerted action to assure better commercial exchange by stabilizing their currencies at fixed parities, he spoke on behalf of all parties and all interests in France.

Mgr. Diego Venini, private chamberlain to Pope Plus XI, and Mgr. Carlo Grano, papal master of ceremonies, both of whom reside in the Vatican, arrived here yesterday morning on the Italian liner Rex. They were sent by the Pontiff to be a part of the personal suite he nominated to accompany Cardinal Hayes to the seventh National Eucharistic Congress in Cleveland, Ohio.

A celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of Gimbels department store in this city and the ninety-third anniversary of the Gimbel organization in the nation will begin Thursday. It will be marked by a Silver Jubilee sale.

PARIS. MANY of the smartest women in Paris are busy at the moment preparing for the hunting season. Some are bound for Hungary to chase wild boar. Others are headed for the Highlands and bird shooting.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- For the first time in its history, the open cup, symbolic of the polo championship of the United States, will rest on the mantel of Greentree. Jock Whitney's long chase after this trophy ended today with a victory for his team over Aurora, 7 to 6, in the final match of the tournament.

DETROIT, Sept. 21. -- The Tigers, behind brilliant pitching by two of their four mound aces, mathematically clinched a second consecutive American League pennant today by sweeping a double-header with the Browns, 6 -- 2 and 2 -- 0.

The first Philippine Presidential election, by clearing the air somewhat of partisanship and propaganda, has made it easier to look beyond the romance of future independence to analyze more clearly, its problems and dangers.

THE realm of pugilism is all stirred up. The reason: Shufflin Joe Louis vs. Max Adelbert Baer. The date: Tuesday evening. The place: Yankee Stadium, New York City. The prize a cash settlement based on the gate receipts and the winner to get a match with James J. Braddock for the heavyweight championship of the world.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Max B. Kaesche and Richard M. Potter, medalists in the Nassau C. C. invitation best-ball tournament yesterday, continued shooting sub-par golf through two rounds of match play today to lead the first flight into the semi-finals.

Haunters of college libraries may have run across copies of DISRAELI'S novels on whose blank pages were penciled "keys" of the supposed originals of the characters. Such little studies in conjecture and resemblance are pleasant enough to the curious with time on their hands.

Advocating the adoption of a model gasoline tax law by every State, the second annual report of the American Petroleum Industries Committee was issued yesterday. It cited thirteen methods of preventing gasoline tax evasion. A three-day meeting of the committee for the northeastern district adjourned yesterday.

Immediate improvement in American facilities for doing business with China will be urged in the official report to be published early next month by the American economic mission which toured the Far East last Spring, under the auspices of the National Foreign Trade Council and other trade groups.

THE new novel by Nelia Gardner White is more than an entertaining story. It is a vigorous study of the conflict in a sensitive woman's character. In "The Fields of Gomorrah" Mrs. White tells the story of John McKinstry, a devout and fearless young Methodist minister, and of his wife, Lucy.

DUBLIN, Sept. 10. THE Abbey Theatre Directorate has made its peace with Sean O'Casey, but the aftermath has been to plunge the theatre and its directors in a welter of public controversy and condemnation for the past three weeks. The outcry began soon after the unfavorable criticisms of "The Silver Tassie" appeared in the Dublin newspapers.

Twenty-five members of the Police Department will have the option of resigning on pension or accepting forced retirement before Jan. 1, 1936, as a result of the medical examinations of members between the ages of 60 and 65 years, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.

A debutante committee has just been appointed by Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt to assist with plans for the dinner dance of the social service and hygiene committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, which will formally open the new King Cole Room of the St. Regis on Oct. 2.

Mrs. Ethel Mars's The Fighter and George D. Widener's Sation, each a heavily backed favorite, were the respective winners at Jamaica yesterday of the Remsen and Interborough Handicaps, twin features which attracted a capacity crowd of 15,000.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21. -- Busby Berkeley, film dance director, must face two counts of second degree murder in connection with the three-car collision which cost the lives of two women last Sept. 8, the Los Angeles Municipal Court ordered yesterday after a preliminary hearing.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21. -- The Soviet sub-stratosphere balloon of 2,200 cubic meters, piloted by B. Romanoff and A. Badykin, is said to have broker the world long-distance record in a 1,328-mile flight from Moscow to the Kara Kum Desert, east of the Caspian Sea. The balloon was in the air fifty-six hours.

THERE is going to be a ninth inning finish to the pennant race in the National League according to all signs and portents. On one field, too. Last year it was different. It was something like those chess tournaments played by cable. The Giants, losing in the East, didn't know the worst until they received word that the Cardinals were winning in the West.

Canine aristocracy as well as just plain "mutts" reigned supreme on the Hotel Biltmore roof yesterday, where nearly 100 children viewed a dog circus conducted by Captain Ernest Engerer. The celebration marked the opening of dog-checking kennels, maintained on the roof, which offer checking privileges to members of the Dog Owners Guild of America and to hotel guests.

THE elegance which many decorators now impart to period rooms is often enhanced by an antique crystal chandelier. Candelabra and prism-ornamented wall lights of Colonial and Early Republic days contribute also to the restoration of old-time charm.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Unemployment relief costs in the next few years may yet be met by the State of New Jersey without a sales tax. That the tax, which has been producing the necessary funds since July 1, will be repealed, or at least modified, and other methods of financing relief tried, seems evident in the light of results in the State's primaries Tuesday.

TODAY gardeners go in for color, but in great-grandmother's day fragrance was considered quite as desirable. Fragrance is as much to be worked for in the garden, however, as formal effects or color, for it has a subtle charm. A tiny home-made arbor, round which the scent of wild grapes breathe in the twilight, still surely stirs the heart.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 21. -- The stadium dedicating jinx, hot weather and, most of all, a superior University of Virginia football team took the edge off William and Mary's opening football flame today as the teams battled to a scoreless tie.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Democrats of New York State, by a platform resolution adopted today at a joint convention of the union of Democratic clubs, the Democratic Lawyers' group and the Democratic Veterans' League, called for the election of a Democratic Assembly this year on State issues.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 21 (AP). -- The fourth annual newspaper prestige week, endorsed by Governor Earle, opened in Pennsylvania today with the aim of educating the public in newspaper service and functions.

An ever-increasing momentum in the headquarters of the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries heralds the approach of the opening date of its second annual consumer convention. Three hundred and thirty-five social service groups are dispensing tickets for the event -- a benefit for them -- which will occupy exhibition and program space at the Astor Hotel from Sept. 30 to Oct. 5.

THE subject of this play is the will of the peoples of the world to peace. Its hero is not John Gordon, President of the United States, nor Koye, popular leader of the Japanese masses, but the common men and women whose hidden desires they express and whose latent energies they release.

THE fourth volume of the American edition of "Men of Good Will" contains the seventh and eighth Books, "The Lonely" and "Provincial Interlude." For the moment the beam of the great searchlight which M. Romains has been playing upon the city of Paris in the ten years before the war has become intense and pointed, rather than sweeping.

THOUGH he seems to be a new entrant in the mystery field, Mr, Margashack evinces in this able and refreshing detective story the fertile, inventive facility of a long experienced hand. His crime problem is posed in the murder of Diana, a once famous London actress, still persisting in her career, though her popularity has declined with the coming of middle age.

FOLLOWING a series of delays, Harold Lloyd's "The Milky Way" neared completion at Paramount with the Dionne quintuplets looming as a possible addition to the cast. This is the first film made by Mr. Lloyd under other than his own banner in some years and it is being regarded by both the star and the studio as one of the major comedy accomplishments of the season.

PRAGUE, Sept. 21. -- An appeal to the court to increase his sentence on the ground of its undue leniency was entered yesterday by a workman named Schroder, who was sentenced Thursday to one month's imprisonment for violently assaulting his jailer.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21. -- Interest in this year's Carnegie International Exhibition of Modern Painting, which will open here on Oct. 17 and continue through Dec. 8, is enhanced by the plan of the Carnegie Institute to celebrate during the show the centenary of the birth of Andrew Carnegie, founder of the International, donor of the building in which it will be held, and provider of the funds for the annual exhibition.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21. -- The Italian liner Augustus has been instructed by the Italian Government to carry to Italy all available volunteers in Brazil, believed to be 1,000, who are sailing Oct. 5. It was reported yesterday that Italy would not call all such volunteers just yet, but this was reversed today when word was passed that all volunteers must embark immediately.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 21. Formal opening exercises were held today in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel to mark the beginning of the eighteenth academic year of New Jersey College for Women. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, was the speaker.

Although unseasonably warm weather retarded retail purchases of Fall merchandise in some sections of the country last week, reports from all of the Federal Reserve districts indicated a further improvement in business conditions in general.

Freesia bulbs can be forced into flower indoors, but are not hardy for outdoor planting in this locality. Although there is no trick to growing them, complaints are often heard of their failure to blossom.

THE report of the Massachusetts Highway Accident Survey, just published, throws new light on various phases of the great national problem of highway safety. This searching scientific study of the factors leading to highway accidents was made throughout the Commonwealth of Massachusetts as projects of the CWA and TERA under the direction of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

An unusual silver medal issued in 1792 during the administration of President George Washington for presentation to Indian chiefs sold for $410 yesterday at the conclusion of the coin sale conducted by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

WHILE Director Eugene Vidal is devoting much time and energy to his efforts to stimulate American aviation manufacturers' interest in both cheaper and safer airplanes, individuals abroad are actually doing something about it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Industrial activity in the first half of this month was maintained at the rate which prevailed in August, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

Striking swiftly and surely with the puissance of a veteran combination, Jasper sophomores sent the Manhattan football team off awinging yesterday by turning back Niagara, 25 to 6, for the most impressive debut in the history of the Green.

LONDON, Aug. 29. IVOR NOVELLO has had produced at the Haymarket a new piece, called "Full House," which describes how a fluttering widow (Lilian Braithwaite) turned her house into a gambling club and, more in folly than knavishness, got into trouble.

IN fiction, as in life, the younger generation never seem to be quite the men their fathers were. The old glamour with which Percival Christopher Wren surrounded his heroes of the French Foreign Legion -- and particularly that family of adventurous brothers, of whom Beau Geste was the first-born and most shiningly adventurous -- has begun to wear a little thin and threadbare.

CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 20. -- To travel through Manitoba and Saskatchewan to Calgary and to talk freely with politicians and electors en route is to arrive at two conclusions about that recent and unprecedented phenomenon of Canadian politics, the Aberhart social credit scheme.
VALETTA, Malta, Sept. 21. -- Italy's rejection of Geneva's peace proposals was received today with apprehension as to what it may signify for this island outpost of the British Empire.

The new Polish liner Pilsudski is scheduled to arrive at Quarantine Tuesday at 3 P.M. and dock at Sixth Street, Hoboken, about 5 P.M. it was announced yesterday. The Pilsudski is the new flagship of the Gdynia America Line, and is making her maiden voyage from the port of Gdynia.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The Most Rev. Mgr. Francis Xavier Ford, Vicar Apostolic of Kaying, China, was consecrated a Bishop here this morning at the Maryknoll Seminary of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

AUSTIN, Minn., Sept. 21 (AP). -- George A. Hormel, head of the local packing concern bearing his name, expressed amusement today at the report that $500,000 in securities had been stolen from his Bel Air (Calif.) residence, saying he doubted that more than "a small amount of valuable paper" had been taken Tuesday night.

Two performances of "Faust" on Oct. 5 and 8 will inaugurate the Westchester Little Opera Company's new season at the County Centre, White Plains, given in cooperation with the Westchester County Recreation Commission. Subsequent operas, as announced, will include "Carmen," "Traviata," "The Barber of Seville," "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," all in English.

A joy-riding party in a ten-year-old open roadster ended suddenly early yesterday with the deaths of two men and injuries to three other persons in a crash on the Miller Elevated Highway at Twenty-third Street. Not only had the occupants roamed the West Side for new bars to visit, the police said, but they continued their drinking in the automobile as it careened on its erratic course.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were all for later months. Municipal calls predominated, but numerous small lots of foreign bonds and four large domestic issues also were announced for payment. The total of $350,611,000 for September, unchanged from the previous week, compared with $236,143,000 in August, and with $156,735,000 in September, 1934.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 21 (AP). -- After setting the pace for three rounds, Sam Snead, youthful Hot Springs professional, weakened in the final round today, and the veteran Bill Burke of Cleveland slipped ahead to win the $2,500 Cascades open golf championship with 291.

Full steam ahead for four days would bring British warships from a base on the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean to Aden and the crucial Italo-Ethiopian zone in East Africa. To reach the same destination from Malta in the Mediterranean would require a day or two longer, and in addition, both at Malta and en route, the fleet would be exposed to hostile attacks.
FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 21. -- Luckite, owned by J.W.Y. Martin of Baltimore, won the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase today before a crowd of 15,000. Rain fell during most of the event.

Mrs. Harriman N. Simmons, chairman of the Woman's Educational Committee for Social Service in Elizabeth, N.J., has been invited to represent the Elizabeth organization at a conference which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the National Women's Committee of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, has announced for tomorrow and Tuesday in Washington, D.C. Mrs. Roosevelt's committee of sixty-seven women will be responsible for guiding a nation-wide interpretive campaign for welfare work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- If war breaks out between Italy and Ethiopia, or between any other powers, President Roosevelt will have to declare an embargo on shipment to them from this country of "arms, ammunition or implements of war." He is compelled to do so under the terms of the Neutrality Act Congress passed just before it adjourned.

The flight of capital from Europe to the United States continued in full swing yesterday when $21,854,000 more gold was engaged abroad for shipment here. Of this amount $9,539,000 was taken in Great Britain, where gold has begun to flow out of the private hoards held in London banks for the account of wealthy individuals and institutions both here and in Europe.

One of the most important things for our society today is to make a home which is attractive to go to rather than to leave. Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, told the delegates at a recent meeting of the Purdue Research Foundation homes conference.

As compared with other States, the methods of taxation heretofore employed by the State of New York have been generally regarded as most scientific. The net taxable income under the general income tax laws of this State has been, and still is, calculated upon a more rational basis than that under the income tax laws of the Federal Government.

LONDON is pretty much like New York: it, too, will have a busy week. Come tomorrow, the big event is the opening of Old Vic's season with Ellis Robert's new metrical verse version of "Peer Gynt," with William Devlin in the title role, Vivienne Bennett as a Solveig and Florence Kahn -- Mrs. Max Beerbohm -- as Ase.

No longer interested whether either party is still considered in the league, or out of it, the Giants and Dodgers cuffed each other around for close on to five hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday, while a crowd of 14,000 doubtless marveled how so much energy could be expended with so little to be gained.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19. -- A white-hot Mayoralty campaign, the elimination election for which is ten days away, revolves about Cleveland's growing reputation for labor disturbances and will furnish a laboratory for those who believe the national labor picture is changing.

In observance of the seventeenth anniversary of its founding, the Civic League of New Rochelle will present a program on Wednesday afternoon at Salem Baptist Church. Miss Anne Schulman, president, will officiate and introduce the speaker, Mrs. William Dick Sporborg of Port Chester, who will talk on "Crime Prevention."

MOSCOW, Sept. 21. -- The most important result of the icebreaker Sadko's expedition was the establishment today that Atlantic waters are the dominating factor in Arctic ice movements -- a finding that was necessary to the inauguration of regular freight and passenger traffic through the Northeast Passage according to Professor George Ushakoff, leader of the expedition.

A trunk packed with spurious French National Lottery tickets was confiscated when the steamer Ile de France docked here last week. United States Treasury agents declared that their action saved would-be ticket buyers $100,000.

THE question is the meaning of the phrase "teaching or advocating communism." "The term 'communism' is used loosely to cover all forms and theories of social ownership of wealth, but has a more specific current meaning to denote the type of revolutionary socialism first expounded in the Communist manifesto of Marx and Engels of 1847, and today held by the various Communist parties that exist in most countries and are united in the Communist International."

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Liberal profit-taking lowered prices again today in the world's leading wheat markets. The dollar quotation was eliminated from the blackboards on the Board of Trade here and wheat closed 3/4 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel down on the day, the latter on the May.

AMONG events planned by the League of Composers for its thirteenth season is the New York premiere of a musical dramatic work, as yet unannounced, to be given in the Spring of 1936 in conjunction with the Cleveland Orchestra, with which the league co-operated last February for the New York premiere of Shostakovich's opera, "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk."

The letter of Mrs. Anna Blomberg on how to stay married has not touched the problem from the vast domain of sociological history. The fact stands out that happy marriages plus female rule never troop in harmony.

The crisis which now confronts the world had its origin in one of those frontier incidents which are frequent in the less developed regions of Asia as well as Africa. On Dec. 5, 1934, there was a fight at Ualual, on the border between Ethiopia and Italian Somaliland, between Italian troops occupying that place and the Ethiopian escort of an Anglo-Ethiopian boundary commission.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20. -- The encounter at Geneva, between Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, and Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, throws sudden and rather unexpected light on Soviet-Polish relations. That is to say, Colonel Beck's speech revealed to the world divergences between the two countries that had been known to insiders and occasionally hinted at in newspapers but not overtly expressed.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21. -- Argentina's wheat acreage is 25 per cent below that sown last year, according to the Ministry of Agriculture's first estimate, while the flaxseed acreage is 24 1/2 per cent less. The report says that in many sections of the northern part of the cereal belt the wheat sowings are 40 per cent under those of 1934.

SAN FRANOISOO, Sept. 21 (AP). -- New complications loomed in Tom Mooney's habeas corpus bid for freedom tonight as court action to halt his hearing was threatened and another potential witness in his behalf appeared.

Kenneth F. Simpson, who was selected on Thursday as the candidate of the anti-Mellen Republicans for the Republican County Chairmanship, announced yesterday his willingness to be a candidate and to serve if elected.

TOO much, perhaps, has been said by awed visitors of an excessive speed and flurry prevalent in the keeps sacred to the fabrication of film drama. The latest to deplore it was Boris Shumiatsky, the doyen of the Soviet movie impresarios.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 19. -- In spite of the assertion by Dr. George S. Long before 3,000 share-the-wealthers in Western Arkansas last week that the shadow of his brother, the late Huey P. Long, "will be back in Arkansas in the next election," friends of Senator Joseph T. Robinson are tremendously relieved because of the tragic turn of events in Louisiana.

FAR more accurate as a picture of real life than many a more ambitious novel, Margery Sharp's unassuming, quietly told story has maturity and a good deal of humor. It relates the history of a woman, Caroline Smith, who wasn't in the least re markable, who never did anything extraordinary; who, as she herself reflected at the last, "had never even been to Switzerland."

The explorations and observations of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition during fourteen months in the earth's coldest latitudes will be described by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd at Carnegie Hall Oct. 12. It will be his first New York appearance since his return from the Antarctic four months ago.

INJECT prolan, a sex hormone, into newborn female rats and they are able to become mothers in two days. But what of the young that these infants bring into the world? Dr. F. Wolff of Hanover, Germany, finds that they are defective.

The European "war" news came pretty close to dominating the security and commodity markets last week; stocks and bonds were lower on the week, and commodities generally were higher. Foreign selling came into the share market, but hardly in sufficient volume to cause, in itself, the setback given to stock prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The country-wide struggle with unemployment will reach a new pitch of activity on Nov. 1, when, if the President's program is carried out, 90 per cent of the 3,500,000 employables on the nation's relief rolls will be at work on various public projects.

Oscar was a white turkey who became the pet and mascot of the poultry store. He was stolen, escaped from the thief, met with surprising adventures, just missed being a Thanksgiving dinner and finally found safety in the zoo.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Performing in a splendid manner throughout the day, Kildare, capable 9-yeal-old grey gelding entered by Captain and Mrs. C.B. Kellogg of Princeton, was the outstanding entry among the hunters and open-jumpers as the New Brunswick Horse Show was successfully staged today.

There ought to be a law compelling Cecil B. de Mille, the cinema director, to restrict his actvities to fields other than history. "The Crusades," his latest picture, is an insult to the intelligence of the public.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- A new campaign for realty tax relief was begun by the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at the closing business session of the thirty-first annual convention here today.

GENEVA, Sept. 21. -- The League of Nations Assembly's first committee adopted yesterday a resolution requesting the Council to put the protocol of the revised statutes of the World Court into effect Feb. 1, 1936. It made this conditional upon the final instruments of ratification being deposited in sufficient time and also upon the absence of objections to this procedure by States that have not ratified in the meantime.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 21. -- The Cabinet and, later, the Executive Council met all day today to study the report of the Committee of Five of the League of Nations, just received from Geneva, and started to draft Ethiopia's reply detailing her view on the seven points presented.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Declaring that Germany presents "an example of a ruthless government, bloated with temporal power," the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Church urged today that the United States take no part in the 1936 Olympics in that country.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Walter Gordon Merritt, general counsel to the Anthracite Institute, declared at a meeting of coal merchants today that the institute was preparing to take "very drastic action" to stop Pennsylvania coal bootlegging.

PARIS, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Court of Appeals took less than five minutes today to reject the plea of three Croats charged with complicity in the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia that they were the victims of discrimination.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- Taking Fordham Johnny Murphy off the relief roll, Manager Joe McCarthy was gratified by seeing the young man hold the Red Sox to one earned run, while the Yankees backed his good work with a 5-2 victory before 7,500 spectators at Fenway Park today.

TRENTON, Sept. 21. -- The Supreme Court overruled today the action of Camden voters in ratifying a proposal for the construction of a municipally owned electric light and power plant. The court held the petition on which the referendum was ordered did not contain the signatures of the required number of qualified voters.

JERUSALEM. FREQUENTLY called the world's most famous international city, Jerusalem is constantly adding to the diverse attractions which it offers. Recently the Municipal Council, taking advantage of the increased revenue, launched upon a five-year beautification program that aims to add sanitation and physical comfort to the sentimental and religious values of the Holy City.

Both the social and the serious phases of the work of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, will be outlined for the coming season this week. The first Fall meeting of the executive committee, it was announced yesterday, will be held on Wednesday, with Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, newly elected president, wielding the gavel.

Two boys were killed and the mother of one of them seriously burned shortly after last midnight when a fire swept through the attic of a two-story stucco dwelling at 99-06 158th Avenue, Howard Beach, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -Full rights of citizenship were restored today to Charles Allen Ward, former convict who now controls a $1,000,000 corporation in St. Paul. His rise from convict to capitalis in ten years attracted attention again as the Department of Justice announced President Roosevelt's action, which took place Wednesday.
The 182d academic year of Columbia University will begin on Wednesday with ceremonies at Morningside Heights and at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre.

Gains in retail trade thus far this year have been accompanied by use of a greater variety of promotional plans to stimulate business than at any time since 1929, a survey here during the week disclosed. Practically all of the plans, which range from "share the profit" projects to innovations in charge account and instalment sales, were reported yesterday as functioning successfully.
