WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Faultless jumping by the aged black gelding Round Up enabled the West Point team to triumph in the $500 jumper championship stake which featured the sixth annual horse show of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club today.

WITH the opening of its 189th year on Tuesday Princeton University will take long strides in liberalizing its courses of study. The changes will include the "No-Course Plan" for advanced seniors; relaxing of freshmen requirements; new courses in religion and architecture, and -- parodoxically enough, in view of the religious courses -- the abolition of compulsory chapel for juniors and seniors.

The sale of $30,000,000 of New York State emergency unemployment relief bonds on Tuesday is awaited with somewhat more than the usual amount of interest in municipal bond circles because of the unsettled conditions that have prevailed recently in the market for tax-exempt securities.

An injunction against Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post was sought yesterday in the Supreme Court in behalf of the Association of Knickerbocker Democrats, an independent political group, whose members say that Mr. Post has misrepresented the principles of that organization.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Following is the platform adopted for the State Democratic campaign at the joint State convention of the Union of Democratic Clubs here today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- An office of arms and munitions control has been established in the State Department, it was announced today, to carry out the registration of manufacturers and the issuance of export and import licenses under the direction of the Munitions Control Board, which will meet for the first time Tuesday.
UPON the blue waters of the Mediterranean, from whose shores European civilization has spread over the world, have lately fallen the shadows of a new empire and a new instrument of warfare.

WHILE warm weather cut into retail sales somewhat last week, reports from most centres continued to be quite cheerful. The stores here found their increases reduced a little, but they were averaging about 10 to 12 per cent ahead of a year ago. Apparel lines were most active, particularly in the sports wear divisions. Accessories were not in such brisk demand.

BOMBAY. -- People in India have shown deep and spontaneous sympathy for Ethiopia as Mussolini has prepared to attack. Meetings have been held all over the country protesting against Italy's aggressive attitude; resolutions passed have been cabled to Emperor Haile Selassie.

AN 18-year-old girl, wreathed in an aura of beauty and doom, is the romantic heroine of "Frost at Morning." She comes upon the scene as an unwanted but chivalrously welcome guest in a serenely lovely old English country place.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 21. -- A fleet of fifty-one craft competed today in the sixtieth annual regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, held under excellent conditions off Execution Light. A steady southwester gave the skippers plenty of sail work.

HIS excellent novels of the Montana mining country -- "Singerman," "Wide Open Town," "This Man Is My Brother" -- proved that Mr. Brinig was a writer of achievement and greater promise among our younger realistic novelists.

GENESEO, N.Y., Sept. 21. -Six hundred persons were guests today of Representative and Mrs. James W. Wadsworth in observing the one hundredth anniversary of Hertford House at a "centennial party" that opened this afternoon and will continue tomorrow.

RADIO'S symphonic season will get into full swing within the next few weeks. Members of the Detroit Symphony, with Victor Kolar conducting, and introducing a noted soloist on each program, will open Sept. 29 from 9 to 10 P.M. over WABC's network, under the sponsorship of a motor-car manufacturer.

ATHENS, Sept. 21. -- Communists leading the anti-restoration movement among industrial workers and peasants, particularly in revolt-torn Macedonia, are encountering severe governmental repression in their strategy of cooperation with the old-line Venizelist parties.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 21. -- P. M.C., undefeated since the Army game of 1933, ran into a powerful Villanova eleven today and was routed, 41 -- 0, in the Main Line Stadium.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- For ten thrill-packed minutes the Cubs' sensational winning streak hung by a thread today, but the pride of the Ozarks, Lonnie Warneke, came to the rescue to weave it into the seventeenth straight victory by stopping the Pirates and giving the men of Grimm a 4-to-3 conquest.

To a crescendo of machine-gun fire, thudding hoofs, droning airplane motors and martial music, the annual benefit program for the Army Relief Society was held yesterday afternoon at Governors Island before more than 1,500 persons, including many prominent in civic, social and military circles.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The quick thinking of Henry Hull, star of "Tobacco Road," prevented a near riot at today's matinee performance in the Selwyn Theatre.

The tenth anniversary of the junior membership of the New Rochelle Woman's Club will be celebrated on Tuesday with a candlelight supper and bridge at the clubhouse. Mrs. Richard R. Young, chairman, will preside at a meeting preceding the entertainment. Miss Virginia Eldredge and Miss Jean Daniels will be co-hostesses.

MATERIAL selected by the American Artists Group, Inc., for its national traveling exhibition of etchings, lithographs and woodcuts by thirty-eight native print makers has been assembled and was shown last Monday and Tuesday at Weyhe's.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Germany bluntly warned the world tonight that she "cannot be held responsible for the acts of East Prussians" if the guaranteeing powers do not assure a free and fair Landtag election in Memel Sept. 29.

Turned out of school by the teacher, Mary's little lamb tried to find some one who was happier and more cheerful in demeanor than his solemn father, mother, uncles and aunts. However, the hounds, who had the saddest faces in the whole world, the grave oxen plowing the field, the frog who sadly said "Gl-u-mp" as he dove into the water, were all equally depressing.

GENEVA, Sept. 21. -- The Italian Cabinet's communique today was at first almost universally taken here as a flat refusal of the peace suggestions of the League of Nations committee of five on the Ethiopian crisis, causing, in the words of a member of the British delegation, "acute disappointment."

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- Few boom towns in the West can surpass the record of Eastport, Me., the most down-eastern of all the towns of the United States, and only a few months ago definitely down and out. Passamaquoddy is doing for Eastport what the mines did for the bonanza towns of Nevada.

ROME, Sept. 21. -- The Italian Government today replied "no" to the proposals elaborated by the League of Nations Committee of Five at Geneva for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy. But it is a rejection that is neither very emphatic nor absolutely categorical.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The New York University football squad closed its camp at Lake Sebago and came over for an informal scrimmage with Army today. The two teams clashed from 3:15 until 5:30, working on a schedule of playing ten minutes and resting for two, during which time the coaches, Gar Davidson and Mal Stevens, went on the field to correct errors.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- Following a rather slow August, department store sales in the First Federal Reserve District, so far in September, have been distinctly satisfactory. Practically all merchants report a turnover this month 5 to 10 per cent above the same month a year ago. Sentiment in retail circles is decidedly optimistic.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The American Ballet, of which Edward M.M. Warburg is director, will be presented Saturday evening at the County Centre here for the benefit of the Rick Hill Camp fund of the Westchester County Girl Scouts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Senators defeated the Athletics, 5 to 4, in the second game of a double-header today after dropping the first, 4 to 1.

Increases over a year ago were again general in retail trade in the metropolitan area last week, although the rise in temperature checked buying slightly on some days. Estimates indicate that the average gain in department store sales for the period was about 10 to 12 per cent over a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. ALFRED LUNT and Lynn Fontanne have been devoting themselves assiduously since last Monday evening to making life a pleasanter thing by placing themselves and the Theatre Guild's version of Shakespeare's "The Taming of the Shrew" at our complete disposal at the Chestnut Street Opera House.

Frank M. Folsom, general merchandise manager of Montgomery Ward Co. declared yesterday the mail order company was following a normal buying policy on merchandise and that, while there is every indication that business will be good during the Fall and Winter season, "it would be a mistake to operate on any wild buying basis."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21. -- While supporters of the eleven candidates for national commander of the American Legion were staging a bitter contest, members of the organization poured into this city today for the annual convention.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- Although Rome's refusal to accept the Geneva suggestions for settlement of the Ethiopian dispute is not considered final in Paris, no one here seeks to deny that the situation is becoming increasingly dangerous. MRS. COLBY is particularly remembered for two brilliant novels of manners, "Green Forest" and "Black Stream." In them she dealt primarily with the frailties and falseness in the upper social stratum of American life. In "Black Stream" she directed wit and satire against the emptiness of New York society and revealed a gift for separating the pseudo-aristocrat from the real.

SALES and deliveries of cars continued at a high point last week. . . . New passenger cars sold in metropolitan New York during the first eight months of this year totaled 91,692, a 20 per cent gain over the corresponding period of last year, and less than 3,000 below the figure for the entire year 1934, it is reported by Sherlock Arnold, Inc.

Up from the city's park, playground and "sandlot" baseball fields, two undefeated teams in the Yankee Sandlot Baseball League, conducted annually by the Childrens' Aid Society, rose to the eminence of a major league baseball diamond yesterday when the Cubs of the James Centre captured the championship pennant by defeating the Indians of the Schermerhorn Playground at the Yankee Stadium.

Two taxpayers, a person and a corporation, both affiliated with the Consolidated Gas system, brought lawsuits against the City of New York last week to prevent the scheduled referendum, in the November election, on a municipal power plant to compete with Consolidated.

Miss Jessie W. Winksworth of Camden will be inducted into office as president of the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women at a meeting of the executive board on Saturday at the Berkley-Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park.

MANY amateur gardeners do not feel the urge to plant until Spring comes along. She went to the home of her daughter, Mrs. Antoinette Russell, the wife of Dr. John Russell.

Murray Polonsky, 26 years old, a paroled convict, attempted to take a uniformed policeman for a "ride" yesterday in a stolen automobile, the police said, but the plan did not work. Instead Polonsky will be arraigned tomorrow for violation of the Sullivan Law and grand larceny.

A 28-year-old lieutenant of the air corps reserve, the first transatlantic flier to get away successfully this year, was winging over the Atlantic toward Kaunas, Lithuania, last night. The flier, Felix Waitkus. had taken off as the sun rose at Floyd Bennett Field at 6:45 o'clock yesterday morning for the Lithuanian city, 4,486 miles away.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Competing before 30,000 spectators, Floyd Davis of Stanwood, Iowa, driving a Gerber Special, won the thirty-lap metropolitan auto race title at the Mineola Fair today. He defeated such stars as Chet Gardner, Southern ace, and Billy Winn, former Eastern champion.

Forty-five hundred volunteer workers, headed by business and professional leaders, will take part in the Fall campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, it was announced yesterday by Waldemar Kops, chairman of the Business Men's Council, the federation's fund-raising unit.

Bennett has been preparing the Canadian electorate for a disappointment, or at least long deferment of their hopes for the conclusion of a reciprocity arrangement with the United States.

THE enlarged program of the Department of Fine Arts of the Graduate School of New York University for 1935-36, as outlined by Professor Walter W.S. Cook, chairman of the department, emphasizes anew the striking developments in this field of education within the past generation.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19. -- Farmers of the Corn Belt, pleased with the progress of agricultural recovery, note with increasing interest and satisfaction the disposition of Republican leaders to tread lightly on the toes of AAA, and to acknowledge the justice of some form of price protection for farm products.

THIS year marks the centenary of the discovery that Mount Mitchell in North Carolina is the highest peak east of the Mississippi River, and a large number of tourists have visited the mountain and the picturesque surrounding country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Rural Electrification Administration today named the Niagara Hudson group of power companies in New York State as one of those undertaking programs to supply electricity to rural homes not now served.

EXHIBITIONS in the local galleries are still not very numerous, although, with a sort of animatedly gentle insistence, such as have put in an appearance serve to remind us that before long another season will be in full swing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- In furtherance of their plan to oppose New Deal policies, directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States decided at their final meeting today to submit to the business world a revised plan for equitable taxation.

Why do people persist in recommending public spending as a means of promoting the national welfare? They have never observed a successful demonstration of its efficacy. On the contrary, there has been sufficient evidence that wherever tried it has failed.
CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- An effect of soaring meat prices that make life difficult in certain Southern homes is the high cost of fat-back.

FALL sowing is nature's pattern, but it took the rock-garden to show gardeners the full advantages of Autumn-sown seeds, not only of alpine plants but also for many of the border perennials. Fall sowing first came into vogue because numerous true high alpines refused to germinate at all without a long dormant period while they lay buried beneath Winter snows.

THE poetic, wistful and mystical side of the Irish character is strongly emphasized in these five love stories; the same characters appear in each tale, which fact is no doubt the reason why the publishers have chosen to describe the book as a novel.

ANEW type of college, intended, to produce the "well-adjusted artist" is being started this Fall by Temple University in Philadelphia. With specialized training in sculpture and painting, it will combine a thorough academic education.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21. -- A new method, which for the first time will enable colors to be accurately measured, matched and duplicated, was described here today at the Fall meeting of the Technical Association of the pulp and paper industry.

THIS novel is in typical Temple Bailey vein. It is fragrant with sentimental romance, verging on the poetic. But for plot it has more than the usual quota of complications. And there is a touch of tragedy to point up the happiness of three pairs of lovers who are finally matched up.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP). -- A universal transfer system, Chicago's nearest approach to its long held dream of unified local transportation, went into effect at midnight tonight.

THE American Methodist Church celebrated at the beginning of this year the hundred and fiftieth anniversary of its establishment and therefore this account of its birth and of the men who prepared the way for it and brought it into being comes at a fitting moment.

EVER since Plato posed the problem of the poet's place and art in society by excluding the artist, as a divine but anti-social madman, from his ideal republic, philosophers and estheticians have sought, with endless permutations of the same thesis and with varying degrees of success, a definitive answer to the baffling question of what constitutes art and beauty.

A casual visitor to Rome who might assume that there the enemy land of Halle Selassie would be mentioned in hushed tones of hate is surprised to find that, conversely, a wealth of pictorial admiration is being lavished on the Ethiopians and their homes.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- New Orleans eliminated Memphis from the Southern Association playoffs today by downing the Chicks, 7 to 5, for their third straight victory.

RIO DE JANEIRO. AIRMAIL planes recently were ordered to go off their regular routes in order to fly over the fabulous and only partly explored jungles of Matte Grosso in hopes that thirteen missing Brazilian geologists would be sighted.

MANILA, Sunday, Sept. 22 (AP). -Leaders of General Emilio Aguinaldo's National Socialist party, which was defeated in last Tuesday's election, announced today they had cabled to President Roosevelt a protest against the conduct of the balloting.

IT was not so long ago that, while styles in clothes came and went with the seasons, styles in shoes remained pretty much the same, year in and year out. That order has changed. During the last twelve months more spectacular fashions have developed in shoes than perhaps the entire preceding decade saw.

OF the more than 3,000,000 miles of roads in the United States, only 150 miles represent toll highways, according to a survey by Earnest B. Bearnarth, travel director of the Automobile Club of New York. Toll roads in New York and fees charged are listed as follows:

Incensed at rumors that a special committee sent here from Washington to check on work at the Appraiser's Stores, where foreign merchandise is examined, has recommended a reduction in the force of packers and openers, importers late last week began to bombard the Treasury Department with demands that personnel in certain departments at both the Appraiser's Stores building and the Custom House be increased.

"Notwithstanding some improvement this Summer, the duck crisis is still serious and the duck hunters of the continent, as well as others concerned in the protection of the native waterfowl fauna of the continent from depletion, or worse, have anxious years ahead."

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Sept. 21. -- Dr. Boyd Edwards, headmaster of the Mercersburg Academy, has announced the completed roster of the academy senate. The council, which is the student governing body, is composed of ten students, either appointed or elected, and five faculty members.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- The Capone gang is back in the gambling racket in Cook County. Until a few nights ago Ralph Capone, brother of Al, was running the old "ship" headquarters in Cicero, where Al used to be undisputed chief of the pirates, for capacity crowds of eager and fatuous players, while a little further down the street John Capone, better known as "Bottles," was working behind the betting counter in the Hi-Ho Club.

IN this new tale of early ranching days in Colorado Peter Field narrates certain further exciting exploits of Pat Stevens, One-Eyed Ezra and Sharp-Shooter Sam, that trio of thoroughbred oldtimers who used outlaw methods (the only ones they knew) to enforce the law, whom he introduced to Western fans in his first novel, "Outlaws Three," published two years ago.

LOOKING toward 1938, both Detroit and Cleveland have been centres of automotive interest. In the Detroit area, previews of new Dodge and Buick lines of cars were given before dealer assemblies. With the assembly lines of ten factories closed for change-over, the previews are to continue preparatory to the opening of the automobile show in New York on Nov. 2.

That was truly a piece of news of world-wide interest that THE TIMES brought to us from Moscow, that, through the prolonged efforts of Mrs. Litvinoff, wife of the Soviet Foreign Commissar, basic English is to be henceforth taught not only to officers and men of the army but also ultimately in the schools.

ASOLO, Aug. 25, 1935. A STAGING of exceptional interest is Gabriele d'Annunzio's play "La Citta Morta" (The Dead City), now being given, with so-called incidental music by Gian Francesco Malipiero, at the castle of Caterina Cornaro, in Asolo, in memory of Eleonora Duse, who is buried here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The opening of the public schools brought a good increase in retail business, although by comparison with 1934 the average for the large Loop department stores was somewhat lower where no special sales events were featured.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Taking her third straight race, the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's Challenge today kept the Seawanhaka Cup, blue ribbon prize of small yacht racing, at home for at least another year.

A SERIES of five one-man concerts devoted to American composers will be presented at the New School for Social Research on alternate Friday evenings, beginning Oct. 4. The composers represented will be Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Walter Piston, Roger Sessions and Virgil Thomson.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 21. -- Expressing its opinion that the University of Wisconsin was an "ultra liberal institution in which communistic teachings were encouraged and where avowed Communists were welcome," and directing criticism at its administrative officers, a Wisconsin Senate committee reported today on its investigation of radical activities at the State institution.

Fred Jacoby Jr., the Jersey commuter who has been running away from his field of competitors all season, widened the gap of his lead over Joel Thorne of New Rochelle during the past week, according to the tabulations of George W. Sutton Jr., president and statistician of the American Power Boat Association.
The largest freshman class in recent years will be welcomed at New York University tomorrow when 5,000 freshmen meet administrative officers and faculty members in the annual orientation program.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT is clearing up his desk in preparation for another swing across the country. The third Summer of his term ran a long course before affairs of state permitted him to consider a long journey, but the press of official business did not damp his enthusiasm for travel.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The season's training here at Camp Smith under the direction of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, will end tomorrow with the departure of the 369th Infantry of Harlem, commanded by Colonel John G. Grimley.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Thirteen farmers who led a mob which blocked a Federal farm foreclosure sale at Plattsburg Aug. 15 were sentenced today to from one day to three years' imprisonment.

BALLINROBE, County Mayo, Irish Free State, Sept. 22. -- Felix Waitkus, 28-year-old American, who set out yesterday morning on a projected non-stop flight from New York to Kaunas, Lithuania, crashed as he made a forced landing in a field near here at 10 A.M. today [6 A.M., New York time].

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The White Sox came back strong behind Monte Stratton's steady pitching today to stop the Indians' eight-game winning streak with a 9-to-2 victory after dropping the first game of a double-header, 6 to 3.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- A free shot from the 60-yard mark by Eric Tyrrell-Martin brought victory to the Hurlingham polo team today at Bostwick Field in the British four's farewell appearance in this country. They defeated Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes, 8 to 7, in an exciting match before 3,000 persons.

VIENNA, Sept. 22. -- The usual foreigner's picture of this capital as a city of song and laughter -- often disturbed by events of recent years -- would receive another rude shock if the foreigner could read the orders for an air "attack" on Vienna, scheduled for Tuesday.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 22. -- Eastern outboard racing drivers dominated competition in the second day of the national championship regatta on Lake Sequoyah today, winning four of the five titles decided as the sport's major attraction was brought to a close.

The increasing tendency on the part of major film-producing companies to draw on the old classics and other established literary works as possible screen material has resulted in the formation of the Committee for the Advancement of the Screen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Tom Mooney's attorneys, defeated on every legal motion they have made thus far in his habeas corpus fight for vindication, planned today for one more technical attempt to Broaden the scope of the case.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 23. -- After almost continuous session from 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning until 3:30 this morning, operators and miners in the Appalachian wage conference announced that they had been unable to reach an agreement and the strike of more than 400,000 bituminous coat miners became effective.

President Roosevelt has taken a personal interest in seeing that the crew of the Morgan liner Dixie, grounded on a Florida reef in the recent hurricane, will not be thrown into the ranks of the unemployed because the ship is out of commission.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Top score in the six-meter yacht team race between the Scandinavian countries and the United States was taken in the initial contest today by the American boats, 11 1/4 points to 10. The Seawanhaka Corinthian sailors of this country finished in first, fourth and fifth places. The Scandinavians came in second, third and sixth.

The site selected for the proposed world's fair, planned for opening on April 30, 1939, is a tract of 1,003 acres, running some two miles in length and about a third that distance in its greatest width.

Sales and leases of tenement houses and dwellings in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn featured realty transactions announced over the week-end. Many of the properties were bought for investment. In the first sale of the parcel in half a century, the five-story building containing fifteen apartments at 328 West Twenty-sixth Street was purchased for investment by the Circle Estates, Charles A. Diamond president, from a client of Louis I. Schrag.

Democratic hope of retaining control of the State Assembly has been greatly increased by reports received by Postmaster General James A. Farley, State and national chairman, at the convention of the Union of Democratic Clubs and other party groups at Binghamton, on Saturday, it was learned yesterday following Mr. Farley's return to this city.

In trading the most active since last Spring, prices of cotton futures here last week broke out of the rut in which they had kept for three weeks and advanced to the highest levels reached since the readjustment to the new government loan. Part of the advance was lost subsequently, but active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week at net gains of 15 to 21 points.

A plan for reorganizing the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Company, which includes among its creditors the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was announced yesterday by a committee which was appointed some time ago by a group of the larger creditors.
Charles B. Howe, administrator of the WPA adult education project under the Board of Education, announced yesterday a two weeks' extension of registration for all courses under the project.
A man was killed and five other persons were injured in a collision between two automobiles at 193d Street and Central Avenue, St. Albans, Queens, early yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22. -- The Council of People's Commissars of the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic, the largest unit in the Soviet Union, announced today new laws that abolish the "postcard divorce" system and strike at the roots of many complaints about Soviet divorce procedure.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP). -- State police tonight were investigating the death of M. Earl Davidson, 28, member of a prominent Glens Falls family, who was found shot dead along a highway today. He had been missing since Friday night when he left his home ostensibly to mail a letter at the postoffice.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The result of yesterday's meeting of the Council of French Ministers is considered inconclusive in London, which desires more precise indications that Premier Pierre Laval will stand by the promise given Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare of cooperation in giving practical effect to any Geneva decision to protect Ethiopia against aggression.

Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced yesterday that a total of $6,848,005 has been released to home-relief families in the last twenty months through the activities of the bureau's Insurance department.

George Williams, 32-year-old Negro of 2,150 Seventh Avenue, a Harlem street singer and guitar strummer, crooned his way to freedom in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday. Magistrate Frank Oliver, who had just returned from a tour of Southern Italy, expressed appreciation of Williams's playing and singing of "The Isle of Capri" and then dismissed a disorderly conduct charge against the prisoner.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Governor Hoffman moved here late tonight to remove the sales tax issue from the coming State elections in November by a proposal he is understood to have made to prominent Republican leaders at a conference at the Little White House for a moratorium on the tax until Jan. 31 of next year, at which time the new Legislature will convene.

There still exists a class of women, not yet quite extinct, who live on the returns from railroad bonds and first mortgages. In many instances their fathers were merchants or professional men, who gave these women, when children, every intellectual advantage that was deemed necessary in the Nineties or before.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- St. Thomas's Episcopalian parish here celebrated yesterday the centennial of its organization as an ecclesiastical corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- In generally strong commodity markets here which are being stimulated by the threat of war, wheat occupies the leading position. This week the price rose from 6s 1d a hundred-weight to 6s 7 1/2 d. Last July the year's low mark of 4s 6d was touched, the price having receded steadily to that level from the high mark in 1934, which was 6s 4 3/4 d on Aug. 7.

The body of Wing Lock Wei, 43 years old, international tennis player who several times headed China's Davis Cup teams, former Shanghai banker and son of the late Sir Bosham Wei, Chinese Ambassador to the Court of St. James, was recovered from the Hudson River off Gansevoort Street yesterday morning.

The week opens with the uncertainties in Europe piled higher than ever and the tension even sharper. That the relations between Great Britain and Italy are severely strained yesterday's statement by the British Government sufficiently indicates, as does the exchange of official views between the British Ambassador in Rome and the Italian Foreign Minister.

LINCOLN, Mass., Sept. 22. -- This town seems on the verge of losing a million-dollar bequest because the Selectmen cannot figure out how to pay $100 a year rent for a safe deposit box for Julian De Cordova, art collector. Mr. De Cordova has a will in the deposit box which is reputed to contain the bequest,

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Prices of hogs last week were highest at the opening and almost lowest at the close. The range on the best light hogs was $11.80 to $12.15 a hundredweight. The average price of all hogs for the week was $10.95, compared with $11.05 the previous week and $6.85 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- An address by President Roosevelt will open the sessions of the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs Conference, meeting here tomorrow for a two-day session to outline plans to raise private charity funds for the Winter.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22. -- The gathering of war clouds in Europe was the main influence in the cotton market here last week. Trading was more active than it had been and prices tended upward. Conditions were accentuated by the sharp upturn in wheat and generally higher outside markets.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22. -- The New York Giants made a good start in defense of their National Football League championship today, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates by 42 to 7 Before 24,000 spectators, the largest crowd that ever witnessed a pro game in this city.

Dr. Hugo Leichtentritt, German critic and musicologist, arrived on the Statendam yesterday, to conduct a course in music research at the New York University Graduate School, beginning on Oct. 5. The course will consist of lectures and a seminar discussion similar to courses in French and German universities.

Last week's financial markets were alternately dominated, on the one hand by the steadily brightening business picture in America; on the other, by apprehensions over the deadlock between Italy and the League. On Wednesday, the stock market went to the highest of the year, reaching an "average" not touched since Sept. 12, 1931; on Friday, it had lost most of this month's previous considerable advance.

A world's fair for New York in 1939 stirs the imagination. Who would have thought of such a venture three or four years ago, when business and trade were prostrate and the future appeared uncertain? The "Century of Progress" was launched in a sea of doubt -- everywhere except in Chicago.

New York's world fair of 1939 will mark the anniversary of one of the great historical events of this city and the nation. In 1939, it wills be exactly 150 years since that epoch-making day on which George Washington, at the age of 57, his health impaired by more than forty years of ceaseless toil, submitted to the wishes of his countrymen and was inaugurated as the first President of the United States.

The new investment banking company of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., organized recently by a group of former partners in J.P. Morgan Co., will make Its debut today in the bond market with an offering of $19,172,000 of first-lien and unifying mortgage bonds of the Consumers Power Company, carrying 3 1/2 per cent interest, due in 1965, and priced at 99 and accrued interest.

A section of curved plate glass nearly three feet square was scheduled to arrive by air express at Newark Airport early this morning in a rush shipment to replace a section of glass that was cracked as it was being installed in the window of a Fifth Avenue jeweler.

Benjamin A. Levett, chairman of the committee on customs service and administration of the Merchants Association of New York, announced yesterday that he would go to Washington this week to seek an early decision from the Treasury Department on the request for a hearing on suggested changes in the customs redelivery bonds.

The first of what have become known as world's fairs, or expositions, as contrasted with the ordinary local fairs which have existed from time immemorial, took place in London with the opening of the Crystal Palace Exhibition in 1851. Its cost was $1,600,000, its receipts $2,500,000.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- The Moss Hart-Cole Porter musical show, "Jubilee," which opened last night at the Shubert Theatre to the acclaim of an overflowing audience, was termed by first-nighters big, beautiful, amusing, spectacular and for the most part in admirable taste.

With registration already in progress in some instances, the ten Community Music Schools affiliated with the settlement houses of the city will re-open within the next three weeks. Instruction in voice, piano, violin, 'cello and other instruments will be given, as will theory, harmony, composition, and, in special courses, music appreciation, rhythmic dancing, orchestration, dramatics, diction, harpsichord, theremin, chamber, opera and theatre music.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Braves established a modern National League record for losses in a single season when they bowed to the Phillies in both games of a double-header today, 7 to 5 and 4 to 3.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Donald Budge eliminated Francis X. Shields from the Pacific Southwest tennis championships today in the semi-final round, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

A New Deal in government and economics may he necessary, but it can accomplish little good if it is operated by narrow-minded, selfish men and women, the Rev. Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of Drew University, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 22. -- A thousand persons assembled on the campus of Crozer Theological Seminary here today, the 100th anniversary of the sailing of Mrs. Henrietta Hall Shuck as the first American woman missionary to China, were told by speakers that the results of Mrs. Shuck's work were still felt among the Chinese.

Bertrand Russell's description of the end of the world reads like a Christmas card compared with the Bible's pictures of war, rumors of war, and chaos, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The appointing board of the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Church announced today eighty-six changes of pastorates in the four districts of the church in New Jersey. The announcement was made at the close of the annual conference here. The body also disclosed that next year the conference would be held at Ocean City, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, 1 point under the rate in the preceding week and 3 points above the rate in the week before that. The fluctuation is ascribed to some orders being held over from the week containing the Labor Day holiday, which was not an official steel-mill holiday, but was observed this year by some of the mills.

ROME, Sept. 22. -- The communique issued after yesterday's Cabinet council represents a distinct and undeniable retreat from the position that Premier Mussolini had obstinately maintained previously, but it is a retreat and not a rout.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, announced today that the establishment of Red Cross first-aid stations on highways in a campaign to reduce deaths from motor vehicles was rapidly progressing.

IF your powers of generalization about China have been limited to a paraphrase of Noel Coward's incontestable statement, "Oh, yes, China; very large, China," Lin Yutang's "My Country and My People" (John Day, Reynal Hitchcock, $3) is a clean breeze to blow away your vagueness. It comes with the inevitable (but excellent) introduction by Pearl Buck, and it makes the Chinese out to be the moist charming and civilized people imaginable.

MONROE, La., Sept. 22. -- More than 10,000 disciples of the Share-Our-Wealth cult founded by Huey P. Long gathered under a broiling sun here today to cheer speakers who accused the Roosevelt administration of encouraging Senator Long's assassins and to swear with upraised hands that they would avenge his death.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- A year's resettlement program, costing from $220,000,000 to $225,000,000, was reported today to have been charted definitely by Rexford G. Tugwell.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Latham Reed of Southampton, L.I., are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas at Brick House, and this evening Mr. and Mrs. Thomas entertained in honor of their guests at the Clambake Club. At the same time Mrs. Thomas's son, Townsend Sackett, was entertaining at Brick House in commemoration of his birthday anniversary.
On Constitution Day you well asked: "In what circumstances does Congress possess or lack power to impose an excise as a means of achieving a social purpose?

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Seventeen general officers, the largest assembly of army chieftains in the history of the Pacific Northwest, were here today directing a big war game involving driving an enemy invader out of the Puget Sound region.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York will hold its annual convention on next Thursday and Friday in the Hotel Statler, Buffalo. About 500 savings bankers, from all parts of the State, are expected to participate in the convention, which will have for its theme "The Ideal Savings Bank."

Reflecting the steady rise in retail sales volume throughout the country, reorders were heavy in the wholesale markets here last week, with many merchants specifying immediate deliveries, particularly in the dress division. Interest increased in dinner and evening wear, and there was an active demand for "bar" dresses featured in many of the new collections for the Fall and Winter formal season.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- For the first time since his return from a German prison to France, Berthold Jakob-Salomon today gave an account of his treatment there. He had been ordered by his doctor not to receive visitors and to take a complete rest because he is extremely weak and very nervous.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- Germany's interest in the drift of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute is giving way to concern over the outcome of next Sunday's elections in the Memel district, and while an impressive reaffirmation of loyalty to the German Fatherland is confidently expected, the German press is anything but convinced that Lithuania intends to grant Germans living there a free and honest election.

Morris Emert, 45-year-old proprietor of a picture-frame store at 1,787 Madison Avenue, between ll7th and ll8th Streets, was shot and killed in a scuffle with two Negro hold-up men soon after 3 P.M. yesterday. Two Negroes were arrested after the shooting and charged with homicide.

Early morning developments at the Polo Grounds yesterday indicated that the throaty salesmanship and expert snaring of nickels land dimes by the white-coated Harry M. Stevens, Inc., hot dog vendors during the Giant-Dodger double-header Saturday, had gone pretty much for naught.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22. -- President Roosevelt has definitely decided that he will not attend the seventeenth annual convention of the American Legion, which opens here tomorrow for a four-day session, it was "semi-officially" reported to Commander Belgrano and other Legion officials shortly after the arrival of Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Higher prices were recorded by virtually all grains here and in all leading world markets last week, with the finish well toward the highest level of the season and a more bullish feeling than for a year or more. In fact, the surroundings in the grain trade were most unusual and it is said no similar situation has been experienced.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Miss Sarah Lippincott O'Neill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.P. O'Neill, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea which her parents gave at Temair, their home in Rydal.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- If, as is suggested here, Premier Mussolini's slightly qualified "no" to the suggestion of the League Committee of Five regarding settlement of the Ethiopian dispute was made not only to gain time but also sympathy there seems some chance of his succeeding in France.

IT isn't the fault of Madcap Max if every one doesn't know all about the Big Bad Baer. It probably is his regret that he doesn't live in a glass house wired for sound so that he could be seen and heard at all hours. But Shufflin' Joe Louis is different. The somber slugger from Detroit is a strangely silent figure in the rowdy realm of pugilism.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 22. -- East is East and West is West, but where Notre Dame football is concerned there is no distinction between the twain.
Reviewing the 1935 trout season in New York, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne is of the belief that the fishing, based on reports from game protectors, was better than for several years.

Governors Island carried off the Second Corps Area polo championship for the third straight year yesterday by subduing the Monmouth County Country Club in the final of the ninth annual tournament at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22. -- The Soviet press carries a report from Khabarovsk, Siberia, today that Japanese-Manchurian authorities plan to send at the end of this month a flotilla of Sungari River naval vessels into waters of the Soviet Union near Khabarovsk and through the Kazakevich Canal.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The war scare has caused money-market supplies to diminish and rates are tending to harden. The outside discount rate this week was 3 per cent against 2 3/4 per cent. Call money oscillates between 1 3/4 and 2 per cent.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- Their cast depleted by a rush-order ERA performance of "Macbeth" in Saugus, members of the New Theatre Players of Boston last night asked New York to send by automobile and airplane substitutes in the cast for presentation of "Stevedore," a Negro waterfront strike play, in the Repertory Theatre.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Ten strong, the members of the British Ryder Cup team reached here shortly before noon today to prepare for the fifth in the series of professional international golf matches at the Ridgewood Country Club Saturday and Sunday.

On July 14, 1853, the first World's Fair in the United States was opened in Crystal Palace in New York. The Crystal Palace was the wonder of its day. It stood on what is now Bryant Park and was constructed entirely of iron and glass, containing nearly 40,000 square feet of glass and 1,250 tons of iron.

ROME, Sept. 22. -- Since yesterday subtle changes have been perceptible in the atmosphere here. Pervading the Sunday crowds in the streets was a vague feeling that the Cabinet's reply to the report of the League committee of five reopened by a crack the door to compromise which had been slammed shut last week.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The weakness in the pound sterling and in the European gold-bloc currencies in terms of the United States dollar is becoming a subject of considerable comment here, especially as it is leading to a further large movement of gold from Europe to the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- The final act of the greatest home town baseball show since 1916 was a masterpiece today as the Cubs blanked the Pirates, 2 to 0, to run their spectacular winning streak to eighteen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- In a review of the Banking Act of 1935, issued today, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System emphasized the concentration of responsibility for the national credit policy in a single statutory body, of which the board has a majority of the members, as one of the major accomplishments of the law as finally passed by Congress after long deliberation and controversy.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Going best in show on two successive days apparently is becoming a habit with the immaculately groomed blue-white poodle Ch. Edelweis Du Labory of Salmagundi, for today that well-known entry of Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Griess of Hamilton, Mass., topped some 600 rivals in the fourth annual Camden County Kennel Club show after having taken the premier laurels among more than 800 dogs at Far Hills yesterday.

At the entrance of the Democratic and the Republican tent the head barker stands, loudly praising the attractions of his own show and jeering at those under the other canvas. With a sobriety of statement and soundness of opinion quite unprofessional, Mr. FARLEY says that an Assembly campaign should be fought on State issues.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 22. -- The controversy in Congress over the Skoda arms contracts continues, and former War Minister Marco Auli, who returned here after starting for Panama, may speak in his own defense in the Senate tomorrow.

One thing which greatly puzzles the visitor from Mars is that in the last week of daylight-saving time the labor leaders are dissatisfied with an eighty-hour working month. To be sure, a twenty-hour working week is emergency, but the Martian tourist has not failed to note that people are speaking of a normal thirty-hour week.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 21. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.2, which compares with 85.1 the week before, 84.5 two weeks before, 84.3 three weeks before and 84.6 four weeks before.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- An extraordinary demonstration of baseball's lure to Hub fans was given today. Forming the largest crowd in American League history here, 47,627 persons filled every inch of seating and standing room. Possibly 5,000 stood or sat on the field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- A constitutional test of the New Deal's farm program became the first objective of government lawyers mapping strategy for Winter Supreme Court tilts.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- Thousands of members of the Croix de Feu organization took part today in surprise rallies near Paris, while other rallies were held in a dozen widely separated parts of France and in the colonies. The purpose of the meetings was to demonstrate on a national scale the organizing ability, fidelity to orders and strength of the Nationalist organization.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,277,034,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- After a dull opening with moderate declines, the week's stock market here suddenly became active, with steady selling throughout the entire list, lignites excepted. Substantial reactions occurred among the leaders, nor did minor stocks escape the liquidation.

As a pleasant prelude to the Yiddish theatre season, which begins at the end of the week, a revue was presented Saturday night and last night at the Civic Repertory Theatre by the Zulaches Troupe. Under the management of the actors Judah Bleich, Zvi Scooler and Wolf Barzel, a company of much the same personnel has been producing such shows at irregular intervals for several years.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- A double victory over the Reds, 14 to 4 and 3 to 1, today stimulated the Cardinals in their desperate fight to win the National League pennant.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 22. -- In the hasty departure separately by plane tomorrow of Reconstruction Director Ernest Gruening and Relief Administrator James Bourne, who plan to seek aid from President Roosevelt, Puerto Ricans see a counterpart of the controversy between Secretary of the Interior Ickes and Relief Administrator Harry L. Hopkins.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- The financial markets, in the last few days, have been reflecting a feeling of despair that a peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute can be achieved. Coming at the end of a long period of suspense, the markets have reached a pitch of sensitiveness to international political developments from which they were relatively immune in the early days of the crisis.

At great expense Mr. Golden has seized the privilege of playing a legitimate drama on Sunday. Perhaps that will turn out to be the most distinctive thing about "A Touch of Brimstone." which opened at the Golden Theatre last evening. It is a venomous character study of a venomous New York theatre producer, written by Leonora Kaghan and Anita Philips and played in an incongruous key of comedy by Roland Young.

"War scare" selling which entered the securities markets last week was not apparent in the commodity futures markets here. Prices, in fact, firmed toward the close of the week in direct contrast to the stock markets. In the cash markets, all the grains and cocoa, lard, copper, lead, zinc, cotton, silk and rubber moved up, while coffee, raw sugar, tin and wool tops declined.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 22. -- After an uphill fight in the semi- final round, in which they defeated Max Kaesche and Richard Potter, the medalists, Mark Flanagan of Riverhead and J. Ebb Weir today won the Nassau Country Clubs invitation best-ball tournament, conquering Kenneth H. Sheldon of the home club and Charles F. Shelden of Siwanoy, 2 and 1.

Continuing their assault on meet records, women athletes of the Metropolitan Association A.A.U. sent three standards into the discard, established one and equaled another as the two-day senior outdoor track and field championship meet was concluded yesterday at McCarren Park, Brooklyn.

Visitors to the outdoor art show in Greenwich Village yesterday were manifold and varied. Six of them were collegians suggesting the rah-rah era which many educators believe has passed. They came to heckle and lasted just long enough to be threatened with arrest.

Congratulations on your editorial on baby bonds, in which you suggest that the government show in its advertising the total revenues anticipated in 1935-36, together with the total expenditures. Other questions that investors would also be interested in having answered are:

ATHENS, Sept. 22. -- The National Defense Council passed defense measures today in connection with the threatened Mediterranean conflict. The text of the measures, however, was not divulged. The press has been forbidden to publish details regarding troop movements.

World powers are on the point of permitting materialism to trick them into another gigantic, war, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, begging Catholics everywhere to "attend in spirit" the national Eucharistic Congress, which opens today in Cleveland, and "pray to the Prince of Peace to extend His spirit over the world and avert the catastrophe which seems to be threatening."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Kenboy, Interclub Class yacht owned by M.O. Griffiths, today defeated a strong fleet in a special regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

A regular round-the-world air service within the next four years was predicted yesterday by Albert Plesman, managing director of the Royal Dutch Air Lines, who arrived on the Holland-America liner Statendam with a group of aides and assistants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A plan to transform the regular army within five years into a model fighting force for speed and efficiency and comparable striking power is outlined by General Douglas MacArthur, retiring chief of staff, in his farewell report made public today.

The recent controversy between organized labor and WPA officials over "prevailing" wages has prompted the Dow Service to make a survey of building trades wages in twenty-one construction centres outside this city. The study was made to learn what justification there is, if any, to support recent suggestions for an adjusted wage scale on new building jobs here.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Although Joe Louis had definitely ended training and was not to do any more boxing, a crowd of 2,300 gathered at his camp today to get a final look at the Detroit boy before he faces Max Baer in the Yankee Stadium Tuesday night.

Sir THUE SALTER'S discussion, in the current Foreign Affairs, regarding the practical possibilities of international stabilization of the currencies, is perhaps the first concrete suggestion of the way in which the thing would have to be done. He cites, apparently with approval, the unanimous judgment of the preparatory committee report to the World Economic Conference in 1933, to the effect that world-wide re-establishment of a fixed gold standard would require the following conditions precedent:
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Wallace Beery will be starred by Twentieth Century-Fox in a film version of "A Message to Garcia." The film, which is to be directed by John Ford, also will serve to introduce Simone Simon, French screen star, who recently was signed by the company.

War clouds hang in the sky because the nations "have never thought themselves through" without recourse to battle, the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.
Manager Bill Terry, for all his years still one of the top-ranking first basemen and hitters in the major leagues, will wind up his career this week as a regular player for the Giants.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 23 (Reuters). -- Passengers on the liner Homeric, which called here today bound for Southampton after a cruise of the Mediterranean, observed the warlike change that has taken place here in the last ten days.

Comparing the dangers of man's journey through life to the hazards of a seaman's voyage, the Rev. Dr. Percy B. Wightman, in a sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, declared that God, love, sacrifice and hope are the "four anchors which hold men steady and make for a glorious and victorious life."

The neutrality legislation "rushed through" Congress at the close of the last session is not an effective safeguard against keeping the United States out of another war, it is said in a summary of anti-war proposals, "War Tomorrow: Will We Keep Out?" published today by the Foreign Policy Association.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Gains in all lines of business which started recently made further headway last week in this district. The main feature in the improvement was in staple goods distributers coming in- the market for fresh supplies to meet increased consumer demand.

The first Sunday night opening of a play in New York took place last night at the Golden Theatre, 238 West Forty-fifth Street, with the presentation by John Golden of "A Touch of Brimstone," his first play of the new season.

Foreign exchanges were under pressure last week with the imminence of open hostilities between Italy and Ethiopia. The Holland guilder was the only exception to the downward trend, and this bill was apparently benefited by the firm position of Queen Wilhelmina against devaluation, or dropping from the gold standard by Holland.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 22. -- A plaque in recognition of his "furtherance of inter-religious amity" was presented to Governor Harold G. Hoffman at the Little White House this afternoon on behalf of editors of American-Jewish publications from coast to coast.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 22. -- Everett Andrews Colson, Maine Yankee, who may be described as "a power behind the throne" in Ethiopia, carried on today at Emperor Haile Selassie's side despite doctors' orders to seek a lower altitude.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 22. -- Senator William E. Borah, minority member of the Foreign Relations Committee, discussing constitutional government in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System, declared that there would be little possibility of war in Europe today if constitutional government prevailed throughout its countries.

This being the time of season when the Dodgers think only in terms of next year, it proved a comparatively simple task for the Giants to grab the series final yesterday at the Polo Grounds, 5 to 2. It was the Flatbush brigade's farewell appearance on the Harlem.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 22. - The Federal Government should pay the cost for the proposed improvement of Barnegat Inlet, which is part of the national project for a canal extending from Montreal to Norfolk, Va., it was declared here today by Archibald N. Jordan, originator of the plan.
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The British Foreign Office issued the following important communication this evening:

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The communicants of the Central Methodist Church here had a strange reception this morning as they marched up to the building to attend the 11 o'clock service. Walking slowly up and down in front of the church were eight pickets, three women and five small children, all carrying large canvas and paper signs.

SPECULATOR, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Max Beer put the training gloves away today after two rounds of boxing with Abe Feldman. The former champion of the world will have nothing on his hands until Tuesday night, when he enters the ring against Joe Louis.

The city still has a borrowing capacity of $329,500,000 within the debt limit set by the State Constitution, Controller. Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. His statement supplemented the data in a pamphlet in which the city debt was analyzed by First Deputy Controller Duncan MacInnes.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis entertained at dinner tonight at Oronoque, Stockbridge. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed, Mr. and Mrs. R. Jay Flick and Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The American League champion Tigers got only three hits off Earl Caldwell, late of San Antonio, Texas, today, and the Browns won a brilliant pitchers' battle, 1 to 0.

Formation of the Transportation Association of America to help "a balanced system of transport" in this country has been announced by Donald D. Conn of Chicago, executive vice president. The association will hold its first board meeting in the Union League Club, Chicago, on Wednesday.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 (AP). -- City ordinance "U-I" was not intended to keep 10-year-old business women from conducting a dog washing business, City Manager McElroy today assured the young sponsors of "the exclusive beauty parlor for dogs."

At this time, when so much interest is centred about the Constitution and various writers are deploring the ignorance of the American citizen concerning this document, it seems appropriate to call attention to a statute passed in Georgia in 1923. This law represented in the acts and resolutions of the General Assembly at page 130. provides:
Several dwellings in Queens were sold in deals announced over the week-end.

Republican organization meetings in the various Assembly districts in New York County tonight are expected to provide, in some districts, a "count of noses" on the candidacies of Kenneth F. Simpson and Chase Mellen Jr. for election as Republican county chairman at the general meeting on Wednesday night.

Wrestling will return to Madison Square Garden tonight when Jack Curley inaugurates a new season with the presentation of Danno O'Mahoney, newly crowned world's champion, in the defense of his title. The Irishman will clash with Jim Browning, former titleholder, in the feature finish match.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The speech made last week in Geneva by the French and British delegates had made a good impression in Paris financial circles, but the intransigent attitude recently adopted by Italy toward Great Britain has changed the atmosphere here,

LAMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- In the first competition in the breed ever held outside of Germany, Amsel v. Holzgarten, owned and handled by George McKay Schieffelin of Gladstone, N.J., was the winner of the initial field trial meeting of the Dachshund Club of America, concluded here today.

A banking group headed by Yarnell Co. will offer to the public today a new issue of $2,000,000 Delaware River Joint Commission Philadelphia-Camden Bridge 4 1/4 per cent bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1933, and maturing in varying amounts from 1938 to 1973.

Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, chairman of the Judicial Council of the State of New York, made public yesterday a letter he had sent to the presidents of the eighty-three bar associations in the State, setting forth a proposal to clear up congested court calendars through the use of the full force of the judiciary.
An important series of letters written from the Mediterranean area by the British naval hero, Lord Nelson, has come to this country from Italy, it was announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22. -Argentina experienced last week its first real business boom in several years. The peso increased its exchange value in comparison with all other currencies, including those of the gold-bloc countries. Meat and grain prices soared and quotations on all investment paper strengthened under heavy pressure of surplus funds seeking profitable outlets.

A sea-going monkey, who for the last two days has been the object of a frantic chase up and down a large part of the Jersey City waterfront, continued to elude his pursuers, a squad of railroad detectives, throughout yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes, the legate or the personal representative of Pope Pius XI at the seventh National Eucharistic Congress to be held in Cleveland today, tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday, left here last night for that city with an escort of 250 priests and members of the laity who are delegates from archdiocesan organizations.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Lined up in battalion formation, the 369th Infantry of Harlem, Negro, commanded by Colonel John G. Grimley, with the band playing, lowered the flag and formally closed the season here at Camp Smith this morning.

A first folio of Shakespeare, remarkable as the first copy of the famous 1623 printing to be brought to the United States, has been acquired by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, the rare book collector, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- George F. Getz has been a boxing fan for many years and became an actual supporter of the prize ring when he assisted in the promotion of the second Dempsey-Tunney championship fight in Chicago. That fight was promoted by the late Tex Rickard, but the Illinois boxing laws prohibited a person not a resident of the State from engaging in the management of a championship battle, hence Mr. Getz's connection.

We consider your editorial entitled "Realistic Housing" an excellent presentation of the difficulties inherent in low-cost housing. It should serve to bring home to the many theoretical housing enthusiasts the difficulties involved.
TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Rev. Cyril F. Stevens, rector of St. Mary's Catholic Church, has taken over the management of the Ticonderoga National Bank.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Templeton, with a great show of power in the opening periods, moved into the final round of the Monty Waterbury Cup tournament, last of the important polo events of the season, on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- To crystallize "the nation-wide sentiment calling for some tangible expression of the regard in which Will Rogers was held by people in all walks of life," a commission, headed by Vice President Garner, was announced today to arrange memorials to the screen comedian.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Aiming to make Wednesday's Republican meeting here the most important deliberation of party chieftains in years, Chairman Fletcher of the national committee has drafted agenda to cover campaign action for 1936 on many fronts.

As Max Baer and Joe Louis completed training for their fifteen-round bout tomorrow night in the Yankee Stadium, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday directed his attention to the herculean task of converting the home of Colonel Jacob Ruppert's baseball club into a boxing arena.

Interfaith cooperation for economic recovery and spiritual reform was advocated by leaders of the nation, State and city and by Catholic, Jewish and Protestant spokesmen at a meeting yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, under the auspices of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

The greatest world's fair in history, commemorating the 150th anniversary of the full establishment of the United States Government with the inauguration in this city of George Washington as first President, will be held in 1939 and 1940 on a tract exceeding 1,000 acres and reaching from Flushing Bay to Kew Gardens, Queens, according to 9 program outlined yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Representative Chester C. Bolton of Ohio, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee and a member of the House Appropriations Committee, produced figures today to show that a total of $30,720,000,000 had been appropriated by Congress and made available for expenditures by the Roosevelt Administration.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22. -- The first great joint meeting of the electric and motor bus transit industries will open here tomorrow with six simultaneous conventions.

Freight moving between the Atlantic seaboard ports and New Orleans will be tied up by union longshoremen unless the demands of the International Longshoremen's Association for a new wage contract in New Orleans is granted, according to officials of the union.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- A test mobilization disturbed by a clash with Communists today massed thousands of Croix de Feu Nationalists in forests and fields throughout France under the command of Colonel Francois de la Rocque, the man who would be dictator.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 22. -- The State Council decided this afternoon to accept the report of the League of Nations Committee of Five in principle, but sent a radio request to Geneva for the full text before giving final approval.

Doubtless the State Department is watching closely the drift of affairs in Africa and Europe, but its concern on this score is not responsible for the fact that the new National Munitions Control Board has been summoned to meet for the first time in Washington tomorrow.

GENEVA, Sept. 22. -- The main points made by Premier Mussolini in finding the peace suggestions of the committee of five of the League of Nations Council inadequate are, according to good sources, the following:

This year will be the best for the motor car industry since 1929, Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday in announcing completion of plans for the annual show.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- The lowest death rate for July in the history of New York State was recorded this year when the percentage of mortalities dropped to 9.6 per 1,000 of population, the Department of Health revealed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Treasury has completed, for the time being, its movement of silver dollars from the cramped quarters of the Philadelphia Mint to its spacious new depository here.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association, which has supported a strike of radio operators on American merchant ships during the last ten days, protested last night to President Roosevelt against the use of allegedly inefficient operators assigned to replace the strikers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Following is the text of the informal remarks of President Roosevelt before the annual meeting for the Mobilization of Human Needs:

Three undersized Negro schoolboys, meek in spite of their careers as small-time thugs, shuffled in turn to the microphone on the platform at the line-up in police headquarters yesterday and admitted having taken part in a half dozen hold-ups in which two men were killed.

Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy yesterday directed Charles Baron, vice president of the Garment Centre Trucking Association, to make full and truthful answers to questions put to him by Jacob Grumet, Assistant United States Attorney.

DETROIT, Sept. 23. -- The Detroit Civic Opera Society, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and the Arts of Musical Russia, a New York organization, have joined in a plan that its sponsors hope will lead to the establishment of national opera in the United States, it was disclosed today by Thaddeus Wronski, artistic and executive director of the new music unit.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23. -- Massed throngs made up of 100,000 spectators lined the streets at reverent attention this morning as Patrick Cardinal Hayes, the first American prelate so named for such an occasion, arrived here to act as the personal representative of Pope Pius XI at the seventh National Eucharistic Congress, opening tomorrow morning.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 23. -- Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons told the Federal Parliament today that Australia stood solidly behind the British Government in the effort to uphold the League of Nations covenant in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

A government investigator, who was disgruntled because he had just lost his $4,600-a-year job with the Securities and Exchange Commission through inefficiency, turned traitor to his cause and offered to sell out to J. Edward Jones, whose oil royalty activities were under investigation, Charles T. Murphy, Assistant United States Attorney, charged yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 23. -- More than 2,000 new automobiles with an aggregate value exceeding $2,500,000 will leave the Packard plant here tomorrow afternoon in what is said to be the largest driveaway that has ever started in Detroit. The drivers will be distributers and dealers from every State in the Union and every Province of Canada who have assembled here in the largest convention the Packard Company has ever held.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration's cash register today rang up an additional $800,000,000 intended to stimulate its dragging campaign to transfer 3,500,000 individuals from the dole to jobs by Nov. 1.

Buyers seeking fill-in merchandise in apparel and accessory lines were active in the wholesale market yesterday. Aided by cool weather, stores did a heavy volume of business over the week-end. Resident offices here said yesterday was one of the busiest of the Fall season and predicted that the week would set an early Fall record If weather conditions continue favorable.

The 15,000-ton motor ship Pilsudski, the first commercial vessel built for the Polish merchant marine since Poland won her independence, is scheduled to arrive at Quarantine at noon today on her maiden transatlantic crossing. The arrival and a reception of officials greeting the vessel will hold her down the bay until 3 P.M., when she will start for her pier at Sixth Street, Hoboken.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of Gimbel Brothers in New York City was celebrated yesterday at a luncheon in the store tea room given by Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt, who returned today from their wedding trip to Bermuda, were guests of honor tonight at a dinner dance given by Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Mr. Vanderbilt's mother, at Cedar Knoll, her country place in this colony.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Despite the deflation of NRA which followed the Supreme Court's decision in the Schechter case, that agency, as "skeletonized" by Congress, was carrying 2,760 employes on its payroll as of Sept. 7, at a total outlay of more than $7,000,000 a year.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Hope that a peaceful settlement is yet obtainable of the Italo-Ethiopian difference or at least that a wider conflict will be avoided dominated the Bourse this morning and caused a welcome recovery after last week's slump. There also was satisfaction with the account of the budget position given on Saturday by Finance Minister Regnier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Charles D. Hilles of New York is attempting to marshal the Republican forces of the East and New England for uninstructed or favorite-son delegates to the next national convention so that the Old Guard leaders may hold the balance of power in the nomination of the Presidential candidate.

Recent argument between Democrats and Republicans about the Constitution has been mostly shadow-boxing. Republicans assume that the Administration intends to try and have the Constitution amended so that the Federal Government can do about everything it pleases.

Mayor La Guardia urged 1,000 members of the National Poultry, Butter and Egg Association at the opening of their annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to cooperate with the city in its efforts to curb the traffic problem resulting from the trucking of food land produce through the city streets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Indirectly eyeing an arming Europe, the National Munitions Control Board will set out tomorrow to formulate rules for the government's first attempt to supervise the war implement industry. At the call of Secretary Hull the board's statutory members -- the Secretaries of the Treasury, War, Navy and Commerce -- will organize tomorrow to:
BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Some eight of the leading pastors of North Germany met here tonight as delegates to the third synod of the Opposition Protestant Church and the Prussian Confessional Church.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- Great Britain, after six days' meditation, gave today in the League Assembly's second committee a non-committal reply to the plea for stabilization which France made there Tuesday. Then Georges Bonnet, Minister of Commerce, had offered to reduce quotas in return for Britain's stabilization of the pound.

The flight of capital from Europe slackened perceptibly yesterday. Foreign exchanges were generally stronger, the franc in particular advancing to a price which makes gold shipments to this country from Paris no longer profitable. The guilder, on the other hand, fell back below its gold import price once more.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Mrs. Ada Alden, 79 years old, whose writings won her the national poetry prize three years ago, came down to breakfast this morning wearing socks -- her usual Summer hose -- and seemed to have forgotten that yesterday she almost drowned in Long Island Sound.
ROME, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Italy calmly made preparations tonight to evacuate port cities in case of necessity and watched 200,000 newly mobilized soldiers report for duty.

Net profit of the Hercules Motors Corporation for the quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $149,871 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. The profit is equivalent to 48 cents a share on 310,100 no-par shares of capital stock. This compares with a net profit of $95,644 or 30 cents a share in the preceding quarter, and $73,663 or 24 cents a share in the second quarter of 1934.

Demonstrating, perhaps for the benefit of the youth of the land, that perseverance in the end must triumph, the Braves, making their last appearance of the year at the Polo Grounds yesterday, finally succeeded in winning a game from the Giants on the Harlem.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The filing of fifteen additional registration statements under the Securities Act, totaling $10,987,560, of which $9,317,800 represents new issues, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Prices of hogs advanced sharply today as the result of limited offerings. The receipts of 9,000 head were only 700 above the all-time low for a Monday and it took only a fair demand to lift the general market 15 to 30 cents a hundredweight, while underweights were 35 to 50 cents higher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The obligation of industry above all other elements of the community to support social welfare services which have been made increasingly necessary "as industrial life creates new problems of community living" was emphasized today by President Roosevelt in an address opening the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs.
