WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Repayments totaling $21,392,639 by banks and trust companies to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during August, compared with new loan disbursements of $9,727, 894 to such institutions in the same month, were shown by the agency today in its monthly report to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- With the largest bituminous coal strike in the nation's history in effect, miners and operators of the Appalachian area spent four hours today in conference hoping that their deadlock might be broken, but adjourned this evening without having made much progress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Sept. 18, issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $372,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations, $32,000,000 in other investments, $111,000,000 in net demand deposits (including government deposits) and $22,000,000 in time deposits, and a decrease of $216,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.
Walking in Pearl Street ordinarily has been neither a lucrative nor an eventful mode of exercise for Albert Correri, 22-year-old deliveryman for the Old Colony Coffee House, 190 Pearl Street.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Without any design to poach on the paradoxical Mr. Chesterton's preserves, it may be said that fundamentally the situation in the Army football camp is sound, but in the fundamentals the squad has fallen considerably short of satisfying the coaches.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- Completion of the banking reform and social insurance portions of the New Deal program has "now paved the way for pro-profit recovery" and the country is entering upon the third phase, which will feature "profit security," Major L.L.B. Angas, author of "The Coming American Boom," declared today at the luncheon session opening the seventh Boston conference on distribution.

Kenneth F. Simpson, who will oppose Chase Mellen Jr. tomorrow night for the chairmanship of the Republican county committee, last night was unanimously re-elected leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, his home district.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The Boerse was mixed today, becoming steady on a relatively firm basis toward the closing. Slight losses predominated. Heavy industrials closed with slight gains and Mannesmann rose 1 1/4 points. Machines opened weak but regained their losses, except for Berlin Karlsruhe, which lost 1/4 point, and Orenstein and Koppel, off 1/2.

ROME, Sept. 23. -- The improvement in the international situation that began immediately after the Italian Cabinet Council last Saturday has been gaining ever since. The wave of optimism that is sweeping over Italy is not the result of any single observable fact, but rather of an indefinable feeling that the general atmosphere has lost a great part of its tenseness.
Scholarships have been awarded by Columbia University alumni clubs in ten States to students entering Columbia College this Fall, it was announced yesterday.

The mystery surrounding the death of Wing Lock Wei, international tennis player and member of a prominent Chinese family, was not dispelled yesterday by an autopsy that showed he had died of asphyxiation due to submersion.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The Nazi party's Economic Information Agency, representing official or semi official opinion of party leaders, appeared today with a plan for, liquidating Jewish businesses in Germany.

Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter granted yesterday an application to restrain the international officers of the organization from revoking the charter of Local 440 of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butchers Union of North America and from granting a charter to a new local.

Hyacinthe Ringrose asks why it is that America cannot consider joining the League of Nations. An answer can be given in two words: ignorance, pride, It is, I believe, a regrettable fact that the average American who talks of Washington and Jefferson and the "Farewell Address" is unacquainted with his subject.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The wheat market developed an easier undertone today and prices on the Board of Trade were at their lowest point. Quotations were about 2 cents a bushel below Saturday's final on selling induced by weakness in cables and at Minneapolis, pressure on May from commission houses and the failure of new buying to develop despite the more warlike news from Europe.

Colonel John S. Hammond, chairman of the board of directors of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, withdrew yesterday the Supreme Court action by which he sought to control the voting, at today's scheduled meeting of the stockholders of the corporation, of 40,000 shares of stock held by the Atlas Corporation and other investment companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- James M. Landis, one of the group of men who wrote the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, was elected chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today, with the approval of President Roosevelt, after his selection had been strongly advocated by Joseph P. Kennedy, the retiring chairman.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Professor Mabel Newcomer of the Economics Department at Vassar College greeted the freshman class today with a warning to go slowly and observe for a time before jumping to conclusions.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Sept. 23 (AP). -- A mythical army of a half million men waited tonight for dawn's zero hour, when they will be called upon to repel a "foreign invader" of the Pacific Northwest, the sector deemed by military leaders as the logical danger point of such an attack.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- The Pittsburgh Pirates were buccaneers in more than name only today, forcing the Cardinals to walk the plank to the tune of 12 to 0 and leaving the 1934 world champions with little more than hope that they can pass the league-leading Cubs and win another pennant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Eight hours of continuous conferences on widely diverse topics marked the first day for President Roosevelt, following his return to Washington this morning from his visit to Hyde Park.

. . "Maria Chapdelaine," French film version of Louis Hemon's novel, featuring Madeleine Renaud and Jean Gabin, will have its American premiere today at the Cinema de Paris, formerly the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

Two former Governors -- Alfred E. Smith, Democrat, and Charles S. Whitman, Republican -- joined yesterday in urging public non-partisan support for the candidacy of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora for election to the Supreme Court.

Store leasing provided a feature of real estate activity in the metropolitan district yesterday and offered evidence of continued growth in retail trade in many lines. Several mid-Manhattan shops drew new tenants.

IF it doesn't rain, Max Baer and Joe Louis will come stepping through the ropes tonight in the Yankee Stadium. Madcap Max, ex-champion of the world, the hot-and-cold hitter. Shufflin' Joe, the stealthy stalker with a two-hand attack and a one-track mind. The hilarious Harlequin of Hollywood against the somber slugger from Detroit. Light laughter against dark lightning.
MECCA, Arabia, Sept. 23. -- The famous Hedjaz Railway, which Colonel T.E. Lawrence and his Arabs wrecked in the World War, is to be rebuilt with British and French help.

No one will be surprised to hear that the peace play by John Haynes Holmes and Reginald Lawrence is not a suave and silken theatre bauble. "If This Be Treason," which the Theatre Guild put on at the Music Box last evening, feels a little uncomfortable in the playhouse where slickness makes a better showing than thought.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The League of Nations revealed today that Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State of the United States, had resigned his seat in the Permanent Court of International Justice, the World Court. A letter to the president of the court, dated Sept. 9, reads:

James Fitton, who was employed until last month as an appraiser for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment charging that he solicited and accepted bribes from applicants for loans.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- Desertton means six months' wait for a di- vorce under the new Soviet law, it was revealed today in an article in the newspaper Trud, explain- in.g yesterday's decree on divorce reforms. Registration of the di- vorce will be made either in the presence of both parties or an of- ficlal confirmation that both par- ties are aware of the forthcoming decree.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Romuald Kraus, a young sculptor of 605 Beach Terrace, the Bronx, who has been on the relief rolls within the last year, won the Treasury's competition for a figure of justice to be placed in the new Newark post-office and court house.

It is in response to a nation-wide sentiment that a national commission has been established to devise ways of perpetuating the memory of Mr. ROGERS. Headed by Vice President GARNER, who will have the aid of many prominent men as advisers and members of committees, the commission will seek to raise a general fund.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The official text of the League of Nations Committee of five plan for an Italo-Ethiopian settlement [an extensive summary appeared in a Geneva dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES last Thursday] follows:

ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- Governor Lehman's conference on "crime, the criminal and society," which will open here Monday night, will be attended by some 500 delegates, he said tonight in announcing the program. The speakers include:

Immediate and widespread approval greeted yesterday's announcement of plans to hold here in 1939 and 1940 the greatest world's fair in history. The event will commemorate the establishment of the United States Government and the inauguration of George Washington as President in 1789.

Nearly a decade has elapsed since any sports event has created a situation such as that which faced New York hotel managers yesterday. With fight fans pouring in, the great majority of the hostelries in the midtown section reported capacity houses.

Patrolman Daniel Guiney, 32 years old, of the Bergen Street station, who was appointed to the department two months ago by Commissioner Valentine, was arrested on a charge of felonious asault and suspended from duty early yesterday after, it is alleged, he fired several shots into the air in front of 761 Bergen Street, Brooklyn.
Industrial and farm estate deals featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

SPAVINAW, Okla., Sept. 23. -- Six world's outboard speed records fell by the wayside today as star pilots from all parts of the United States competed in amateur and professional division time trials over a measured mile course on Lake Spavinaw.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The Old Vic season opened tonight with the first performance of Ellis Roberts's new version of Ibsen's "Peer Gynt." The title role was brilliantly portrayed by William Devlin, who is in his early twenties. Mr. Devlin surprised London last year as the youngest King Lear in history, and recently scored deputizing John Gielgud in "Noah," when the latter was ill.

Dark-eyed Senorita Maria Elena Rivero may not marry the cavalier Juan Ignacio Pombo after all -- and that is going to be a terrific shock to the millions all over the world who have been following Senor Pombo's epic efforts for the last five months to reach his charming friend in a frequently interrupted flight from Spain to Mexico.

A few months ago ALDOUS HUXLEY, usually regarded as extremely tough-minded and cynical, announced that he was convinced not only of the authenticity of telepathy, but that the testimony in regard to "fire-walking" forced him to believe that "certain "people are able by some unexplained "mental process to immunize their "bodies against the effects of intense "heat."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Sept. 16 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 2,318,395 running bales, including 14,711 round bales, counted as half bales, and 580 bales of American-Egyptian.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- A plan to establish uniform regulation of the milk industry, especially with regard to interstate movement of milk, was whipped into shape here today by members of the Governors' Emergency Milk Committee of four of the seven States to be affected.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, assistant to General Hugh S. Johnson, local Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that she would relinquish her post on Oct. 6. She will retain her position as regional NRA director.

Formulation of a plan for a suggested union of all the branches of the Lutheran Church in America was authorized yesterday at the Ministers' Conference of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States at the annual meeting at St. Luke's Church, Forty-sixth Street west of Eighth Avenue.
Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan announced yesterday that 2,500 WPA men would be put to work on numerous street paving jobs in Manhattan to be done jointly by WPA forces and the city.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Syracuse Chiefs won the International League play-off series and the Governor's Cup by defeating the pennant-winning Montreal Royals, 2 to 1, today in the seventh and final game.

The dance season was officially opened last night, at least a month earlier than usual, with a recital of Spanish dances by Carlos de Vega and Sarita at the Town Hall. The performance, which will be repeated tonight, was by way of inaugurating the celebration of Lope de Vega's tercentenary, and several of the dances by Sarita gave him a nod in passing.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, declared yesterday that Democratic predictions of the election of a Democratic Assembly, following the convention at Binghamton, represented another chapter in the "New Deal bedtime stories."

James R. Ullman is a brave man. On an evening when the attention might naturally wander to the Yankee Stadium, he is simply opening a new show -- "Blind Alley," by James Warwick, an Australian now resident in Hollywood. It is a psychological study of a gunman and a doctor, a melodrama that has been called, in the past, both "Smoke Screen" and "Crack-Up."
Commenting yesterday on the election of James M. Landis to the chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said:

Premium merchandise will be used this year to supplement promotional efforts in wholesale and retail selling to an extent never before equaled in the industry's history, Howard W. Dunk, secretary of the Premium Advertising Association of America, sponsors of the Atlantic Coast Premium Buyers Exposition, which opened at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, said last night.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Dr. Neil McLeod, 35 years old, an instructor in the pathology department of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, was killed instantly today when the car in which he was a passenger overturned on the Lakewood-Lakehurst Highway.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- As the legal, social and economic "liquidation" of the Jewish problem in Germany begins to approach completion the National Socialist party is also beginning to devote itself with renewed energy to that side of the racial issue concerned with the creation of an international race-conscious German "community of blood."

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Robert Tyre Jones Jr. of Atlanta, whose grand slam of golf honors was climaxed by his partial retirement from competition, today visited the Ridgewood Country Club, scene of the Ryder Cup matches this week-end.

More than a year after the merger was originally proposed, stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation yesterday approved the acquisition of the assets of the Corrigan, McKinney Steel Company, and control of the Truscon Steel Company. They met in the company's offices in Jersey City.

Inbound traffic on early morning trains from Chicago yesterday was the heaviest in six months, the New York Central Railroad reported. More than 1,400 passengers arrived on six morning trains, the Twentieth Century and three other trains arriving in two sections each and the Commodore Vanderbilt in three sections.

The demand for choice seats for tonight's fight at the Yankee Stadium was so great early last night that speculators were asking $250 for a pair of ringside seats. Other prices ranged from $27.50 up to $80 for single seats.

Mayor La Guardia swore in yesterday Magistrate Lawrence B. Dunham as a justice of the Court of Domestic Relations and former State Senator Alvah W. Burlingame and Peter A. Abeles as city magistrates. The ceremony was held at City Hall.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- Evidences of the existence of populous settlements with highly developed ancient culture on the barren frozen tundra of Yamal Peninsula, beyond the Arctic Circle, have been uncovered by an expedition of Soviet archaeologists working for the Institute of Anthropology and Ethnography of the U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- A list of what shall be considered "munitions and implements of war" under the Neutrality Act was completed today by the new State Department Arms and Munitions Control Office and will be submitted to the National Munitions Board at its first meeting tomorrow.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Nassau College-Hofstra Memorial, the first advanced co-educational institution on Long Island beyond the boundaries of New York City, opened for work today. Dean Arthur D. Whitman welcomed 150 students to the spotless building and landscaped grounds, given to New York University by the late William S. Hofstra as a college for the people of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Joseph F. Shadgen, engineer, who drew up the preliminary plans to hold the 1939 World's Fair in New York, said yesterday at his home in Jackson Heights that after he had completely thought out his ideas their magnitude made him hesitate to tell any one about them.

Wide differences of opinion exist, based on the continuing Federal budget deficit and the piling up of excess reserves in the nation's banks, concerning the possibility and nearness of "inflation." Such a well-known international authority on money as Professor KEMMERER of Princeton, for example, has predicted that the cost of living may rise 116 per cent.

MADISON, N.J., Tuesday, Sept. 24. -- A black panther, reported loose somewhere on the five-mile stretch between here and Livingston, N.J., was engaging the attention early this morning of most of the police of five near-by towns.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- The Dodgers hung on to sixth place by dividing a double-header with the Phillies today in the close of the local National League season. The Phillies took the opener in ten innings, 4 -- 3, but dropped the nightcap, 8 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Total conversions at the end of the third week of the refunding of $1,250,000, 000 of called Fourth Liberty Loan bonds amounted to $796,000,000, T. Jefferson Coolidge, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced today, with the admission that refunding of the securities "is dragging."

West Side activity made up a large part of the apartment rental turnover reported yesterday. Numerous leases were arranged in the Greenwich Village section. The upper West Side also was strongly represented.

Sammy Renick, leading rider of the meeting, was the deciding factor yesterday at Jamaica in a driving finish in which his mount, Good Goods, nosed out the Espino filly Esposa, which races for the Middleburg Stable. Only three ran, but there has not been a closer finish than this one in which the outsider prevailed, sustaining the turf maxim: "Play the outsider in a three-horse field."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23. -- In an atmosphere of patriotic fervor the annual convention of the American Legion opened here this morning with 12,000 delegates and visitors unashamedly shedding tears as Mme. Schumann-Heink, introduced as the "beloved American mother," sang the national anthem and followed it with "There Is No Death."

The list of passengers arriving today on the French liner Normandie from Havre and Southampton includes Gerard B. Lambert, sportsman, who has been racing his yacht Yankee in England; Mr. and Mrs. John Mortimer Schiff Jr. of New York, Pierre Cartier, international jeweler; George Blumenthal, chairman of the executive committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; George Washington Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company.

Daniel Frohman, dean of the New York theatre, recalled yesterday an incident in the life of De Wolf Hopper in which the noted comedian forgot his lines while playing an important role under the Frohman management in 1884.

Eric Seelig, former light-heavyweight champion of Germany, made his American debut last night at St. Nicholas Palace by knocking out Al Rossi of New Haven before 4,000. Seelig won with a straight right to the jaw after 55 seconds in the eighth round of the scheduled ten-round bout.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Robert V. Miller, who escaped from the Federal house of detention in New York by sliding down a rope of bed sheets, has been charged with the first violation of a new law making it a Federal offense to escape from Federal custody.

Stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Corrigan, McKinney Steel Company yesterday approved, after a long series of adjournments, the plan of consolidation that was first proposed in July, 1934. For more than six months, they were denied the fruits of this union by a Federal suit which sought to block the transaction on the ground that it violated the anti-trust laws.

For the last two weeks a series of thefts have been committed in the justices' chambers of the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building. Although the detectives at Butler Street station have been investigating, they were disinclined last night to give out any details.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The long training grind over, Joe Louis went into seclusion today. A guard posted at the roped-off gateway to the cottage where he has lived for more than three weeks barred visitors and no one but members of the household was permitted to see him.

Thirty-five thousand needy students in high schools and colleges throughout the State will receive $400,000 this month from the National Youth Administration, according to an announcement last night by Fairfield Osborn Jr., State NYA director. Fifty-five per cent of the students are in the city.

SUSANVILLE, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Thomas A. Tully, 24 years old, heeding the advice of his father, Jim Tully, writer, pleaded guilty to an attack charge today and was sentenced to one to fifty years in prison.

Max Baer arrived in New York last night, primed to the peak for his fifteen-round battle with Joe Louis. The former heavyweight champion of the world left his training camp at Speculator, N.Y., shortly after noon and motored to Schenectady, where he boarded the train that carried him here.

Contrasting with the nervousness and fairly heavy turnover which characterized the bond market during the latter part of last week, trading on the New York Stock Exchange virtually came to a standstill at intervals yesterday. The volume was the smallest since June 3, as sales amounted to $7,176,400, as compared with $16,036,000 on last Friday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 23. -- In a northwest breeze that spread out as if it were shaken by a huge, revolving fan, the Scandinavian trio of six-meter yachts defeated the United States team today in the second of five races. The Scandinavians scored 11 points to 10 1/4 for the Americans.

A course in appreciation of music will be presented at the Town Hall on fifteen Sunday afternoons at 5:30 o'clock, beginning Oct. 20, under the auspices of the International Music Guild. Leonard Liebling will be the commentator and among the guest artists will be Florence Easton, Benno Rabinof, Louise Bernhardt, Mario Cozzi, Muriel Kerr, Emanuel Feuermann, Hortense Monath, Grisha Goluboff, Klara Kwartin, Ray Lev, the Stradivarius Quartet, Nancy Wilson and Genia Luboschutz.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Rosalind, owned by Gibson White, 21-year-old Lexington youth, clinched her claim to the title of best 2-year-old trotter today when she won the $5,000 Kentucky futurity in two straight heats. The time, 2:03, in the second heat was the fastest of the year for Juveniles.
To what extent may nations profit by conventions which limit national sovereignty?

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 23. -- Wiser counsels within and without Emperor Haile Selassie's immediate entourage have finally convinced conservatives of the folly of immediate mobilization, but plans for mobilization are ready and now it is possible to give accurate figures on the armed men Ethiopia could command if war began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The Yankees, settled firmly in second place with no possibility of moving either up or down, continued playing out their string by beating the Senators, 5 -- 1, today without extending themselves greatly.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- "Koanga," an early opera by the late Frederick Delius, had its first performance in this country at Covent Garden tonight, opening the new Autumn season of English and Italian operas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Cash income from the sale of farm products in August this year was estimated today by the Agriculture Department at $549,000,000, compared with $451,000,000 in July this year and $536,000,000 in August, 1934.

A new book club has been formed by Sheed Ward, Catholic book publishers. It is to be called the Sheed Ward Book Society. Members will pay a subscription fee and will receive ten books each year. The new biography by Alfred Noyes, "Voltaire," will be one of the first books distributed.

The share market appeared not to be unduly perturbed yesterday over the lack of progress reported in Geneva in the Italo-Ethiopian controversy. That is not to say that foreign selling of American stocks was not present to some degree, but such liquidation as did come from this quarter was absorbed readily as a little more attention was paid to trade reports.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, made public yesterday a report received from Charles J. Mylod, special deputy in charge of rehabilitation of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, in which the recommendation was made that the company be reorganized.

The ski team that will represent the United States at the Fourth Olympic Winter Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, next year, was announced yesterday by Leib Deyo, chairman of the Olympic ski committee. A squad of fifteen skiers was named to make the trip.

Trends were mixed yesterday in trading in futures in the commodity markets here. Sugar again pushed into new high ground. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats and silk were higher and corn, flour, cocoa and tin lower.

President ROOSEVELT expressed yesterday his appreciation of the heroic work -- "and I use that word 'heroic' deliberately" -- done in recent years by the private welfare agencies of the nation. The occasion was the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs, inaugurating local campaigns for funds in all parts of the country.
Harold S. Frankenheimer has joined Dunne Co.

ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh studied in secrecy today the strange apparatus and steel tower assembled by Dr. R.H. Goddard for piercing the mysteries of the stratosphere with rockets.

Thomas M. Farley, Tammany leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District, who was removed as Sheriff by Governor Roosevelt on testimony developed in the Seabury investigation, left an estate of $109,448 gross and $84,136 net, it was disclosed yesterday in an accounting filed in the Surrogate's Court. Mr. Farley died April 3, 1934.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Timothy Dwight College, the ninth undergraduate college at Yale, which has been under construction a year, was opened today as the university's academic year officially commenced.
The following statements regarding tonight's fight were made by the principals and their managers yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Pointing with pride to their eighteen-game winning streak, the pennant-seeking Cubs view with grim determination their five-game series against the Cardinals starting in St. Louis Wednesday. Although the Cubs are on top in the National League, they have defeated the world champions in only five of seventeen games.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Leadership of the New Jersey Republican organization was completely disorganized tonight as the party prepared to hold its annual convention here tomorrow. At a stormy, all-night meeting in the Summer home of Governor Hoffman at Sea Girt, it was learned, leaders pledged to repeal of the sales tax broke with the Governor on his plan for a sales-tax moratorium.

Faced with a shortage of competent relief teachers, school officials have been conferring with representatives of the Works Progress Administration on the possibility of relaxing relief requirements to permit the employment on school WPA projects of persons on the regular eligible lists for teaching appointments, even though they do not qualify under the "pauper" rule, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The Dayton Power and Light Company, Dayton, Ohio, has filed an application under the Securities Act of 1933 for the registration of an issue of $20,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds due on Oct. 1, 1960, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

John J'. Atwell, identified with realty in the metropolitan district for many years, has formed a realty firm to be known as John J. Atwell, Inc., with offices in 152 W. 43d St., to specialize in Long Island properties.

Paul H. Davis Co. and Francis Bro. Co., the latter of St. Louis, will offer today 50,000 shares of Economical-Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc., no-par common stock at $16.50 a share. The drug store company, a Michigan corporation, has seventy-five stores in Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania, of which sixty-two are in Detroit.

The strain and testing at Geneva will doubtless continue for some days. It is a case for individual nations represented there -- for Italy, above all, but also for France and Great Britain -- to show the world of what stuff they are made. But the supreme trial is that of the League of Nations itself.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 23 -- Passenger transportation has been sharing in the business revival, the American Transit Association was told today in the Hotel Ambassador here at the opening of its fifty-fourth annual convention. Solemn warning was given, however, that within the next few years 75 per cent of the transit industry's rolling stock will be obsolete unless the industry invests "at least $470,000,000" in replacing out-moded equipment.

"Business in Government," reviewed in THE TIMES by John Chamberlain, will remind many readers of Stuart Chase's prophecy published in 1931 as a John Day pamphlet under the title "Out of Depression and After."

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 23 (AP). -- A man believed by police to be James A. MacIlvaine, 45, a second vice president of the Chase National Bank, New York, plunged to his death tonight from his room on the tenth floor of the Lamar Hotel here. Hundreds of theatregoers saw the tragedy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The national administration was warned today that destruction of the existing economic order lurks in governmental policies of industrial regulation. Speaking before the convention of the American Mining Congress, Colonel Willard T. Chevalier, vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, termed such policies "not the proper responsibilities of a government."

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The stock markets here were more cheerful today after last week's sharp setback. Fresh buying brought a quick recovery, particularly in British funds, although later they lost some of the early gains.
GENEVA, Sept 23. -- The text of the Ethiopian reply to the League of Nations on the proposed solution of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute follows:

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 23. -- Strange marine conditions which several months ago killed millions of fish in the Gulf of Mexico along the northern end of Padre Island recurred the past three days off the coast here. Today the shore for at least fifty miles is lined with tons of dead fish.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Two hairpins, a lipstick and an empty wallet gave the State police two lines of investigation tonight as they sought a motive for the mysterious slaying of M. Earl Davidson, 28, member of a prominent Glens Falls family, whose bullet-pierced body was found yesterday on the Glens Falls-Luzerne highway.

A large-scale replacement of waitresses by waiters, with the possibility of using hotel waiters to make up rooms as stewards do on ocean liners, was predicted last night by Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, in a speech at the monthly dinner of the society at Massoletti's Tower Restaurant, 70 Pine Street.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 23. -- After an inauspicious start that cost them two strokes on the first two holes, Ferd Catropa, professional at the Cedar Point Golf Club, and Pete Vairo rallied to score a sparkling 64 and win the amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Southern Parkway Country Club today.

Controller Morris S. Tremaine will open bids at 1 P.M. today in his office at Albany for a new issue of $30,000,000 New York State emergency unemployment relief bonds. The bonds are dated Sept. 25, 1935, and mature in equal annual installments over the next ten years.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
One of the largest bus terminals in Manhattan will go up shortly on leased land fronting on West Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, it was learned yesterday.

A sharp rise in real estate activity on Long Island, and an increased demand particularly for business properties in Queens, will result from the announcement of plans for the world's fair there in 1939, according to real estate men who have followed the development of the Island for many years.

The contest for the chairmanship of the New York County Republican Committee between Chase Mellen Jr., the incumbent, and Kenneth F. Simpson, reached a new height of bitterness last night through a series of clashes of the rival factions at Assembly district organization meetings at which district leaders were elected.

ON BOARD THE MOTOR SHIP PILSUDSKI AT SEA, Sept. 23. -- Tomorrow morning, several hours ahead of scheduled time, the Pilsudski will arrive in New York. Most of the tourist-class passengers are eagerly looking forward to seeing the "wonder country," the United States.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews led a field of 114 players in the qualifying round of the women's New Jersey State championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club today, shooting a pair of 41s for an 82 and a three-stroke lead over Miss Charlotte Glutting, the defending champion.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The full British Cabinet will consider the Italo-Ethiopian crisis tomorrow for the first time since the emergency meeting a month ago, when the Ministers hurried back from their vacation haunts to discuss Italy's rejection of the Paris proposals.
The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission yesterday issued a summary of its activities in conservation and propagation for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1934, and ending June 30, 1935.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Turnesa brothers, Mike and William, of Fairview teamed up to win the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur one-day tourney over the links of the Whippoorwill Golf Club today. The pair scored a 66, five under par for the course, which was in particularly good shape.

Following a setback of more than $1 a bale in the closing days of last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed from 1 point lower to 4 points higher than on Saturday under a reduced volume of business. Uncertainty over the outcome of efforts to avert hostilities in Africa and unusually light ginning in the last period influenced the trade.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- A shift in the diplomatic position of Italy late today confused the Ethiopian situation in the League of Nations after there had been a demonstration that the League was taking a firm position.

TOKYO, Sept. 23. -- Surrounded by even more than the customary secrecy, the Japanese naval manoeuvres will enter their culminating phase tomorrow, when about 180 warships, organized in three fleets, engage in mimic war in the waters near Japan's northeastern home coasts.

Koenigism, no matter how it may be disguised, must not be permitted to regain control of the Republican party in New York County, Chase Mellen Jr. declared last night at the organization meeting of the County Committee of the Fourteenth Assembly District at the Ivy Republican Club, 1,300 First Avenue.

Tonight in the ring at the Yankee Stadium Max Baer, former world's heavyweight champion, and Joe Louis, sensational young Detroit Negro heavyweight, will meet in a scheduled 15-round bout that is expected to attract a crowd of 95,000 and gate receipts of close to $1,200,000.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 23. -- Backers of the State administration's Huey P. Long -- Share-Our-Wealth ticket, from Governor Oscar K. Allen down, tried every means at their disposal today to heal the breach between the organization and Lieutenant Governor James A. Noe, who insists that he will run for Governor on an independent ticket.

The extraordinary grand jury investigating racketeering has been hearing testimony from certain New York restaurant owners, it was learned yesterday, who have been paying close to $2,000,000 a year in tribute for the last few years to a group organized as a "restaurant owners' association."

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Special high school curricula for the "headworker" and the "handworker" to prevent continuance of secondary education in "bewilderment" was advocated tonight by Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, Union College president.

ROME, Sept. 23. -- Premier Mussolini and Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador, talked for almost an hour tonight, and informed Italian and British observers were quick to suggest the possibility of direct negotiations between the two nations to settle the Ethiopian problem, at least in so far as it affects Europe.

The stature and voice of De Wolf Hopper were the stuff of tragedy, those who marveled at him were prone to point out down the years, which treated him with such strange gentleness. He stood 6 feet 2, a great, sometimes even gaunt man, with a thunderous voice that might set the back-drop shivering, to say nothing of the audience.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- A decrease in the value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles in August compared with July was reported today by the Department of Commerce. The index, which makes allowance for the number of days as well as for usual seasonal movements, dropped to 71.0 in August, on the basis of the 1929-31 average, from 81.0 in July and 78.5 in June.
The Department of Parks dedicated five playgrounds in various parts of the city yesterday afternoon.

Autumn arrived officially last night, a day later than usual. The sun reached the autumnal equinox, when it shines directly on the earth's Equator and day and night are of equal length the world over, at exactly 7:39 o'clock, daylight time.

By tomorrow morning we should have another good index to economic recovery. It is the size of the Baer-Louis gate at the Yankee Stadium. The automobile industry is set for the best year since 1929. The boxing industry must go back two years earlier for its peak.

An estate of $11,826,779 gross and $9,471,763 net was left by Herbert N. Straus, vice president of R.H. Macy Co. and president of L. Bamberger Co. in Newark, when he died, on April 6, 1933, it was disclosed by the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Five persons who had pleaded guilty or had been convicted on arson charges and who later were used as witnesses for the State to break up a ring which had caused many incendiary fires in Brooklyn were sentenced to long terms in prison yesterday by Judge Franklin Taylor in the Kings County Court.

"SO you are writing hop the book fom Odder Kober, vot dot dope calls it 'Gewittersturm Over Bronx'? And it's not so long ago I can see him now alraddy yet plehing in stritt. Alvays writing tings on sidewalk, writing tings on side buildings, writing tings on beck fences. Dot's vot I told my hosband, some day dot schlemiel grow op, he'll be a writeh.

Allan Hutchins, 32 years old, son of Patrolman Sidney Hutchins, shot and killed himself with his father's service revolver yesterday in the apartment they occupied at 660 Madison Street, Brooklyn. Dr. Gluck of Bushwick Hospital said Hutchins was killed instantly.
The new week in money started without any change in the character of the market. The demand for funds was light and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

Danno O'Mahoney tried some new tactics last night and successfully defended his title as world's heavyweight wrestling champion against Jim Browning, former titleholder at Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 7,000.

The action of the stock market during the last three trading sessions has indicated to some observers that the war scare is rapidly subsiding in Wall Street. Market letters distributed by brokers yesterday showed that the financial community was taking the European sword-rattling much more calmly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Declaring that the oceans that many Americans regard as protecting barriers from foreign enemies would not serve as such for five minutes after war involving us really started, Mrs. Roosevelt called upon the women of the nation today to "begin thinking about war" and how to substitute for it some more practical way of settling international difficulties.

If there is any one more deadly than a gangster, it is a professor of psychology, according to "Blind Alley," which was acted at the Booth last evening. It is shutters for any gangster who comes under a psychologist's thumb. Hal Wilson and his mob decide to hide away in Dr. Shelby's home for a day while they are passing through.
Bernard M. Baruch declared on his return from Europe yesterday that the impasse between Italy and Ethiopia was a test of "whether the world is on the level" in its outcries against war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- President Roosevelt held the first Cabinet meeting in almost a month today, as well as the last that will be held for another month, and continued a series of conferences begun yesterday in an effort to clear his desk of work by Thursday evening, when he expects to begin a journey to the West.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Frank E. Gannett announced today the formation of a foundation to distribute after his death at least 75 per cent of the chain's net income for "public charitable, educational and general philanthropic purposes."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Wealthy residents of the exclusive Summer colony on the North Shore of Long Island, frightened by the successes of a "phantom" burglar, have armed themselves and their employes, it was disclosed here today.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 24. -- A coroner's jury of six West Chester men reported tonight after five hours of deliberation that Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy actress, "came to her death at Indian Run Farm, near Downingtown, by the hands of a person or persons unknown to this jury."

Fall sales volume is running well ahead of last year and the store management expects the business from October to Christmas to be the best since 1930, Neil Petree, president of James McCreery Co., told 1,200 employes yesterday morning, at a rally celebrating the organization's ninety-eighth birthday and the completion of a four-month modernization program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Gertrude Chase Kreischer, in which she states that "even if motor trucks and buses do pay to the last farthing, they are a nuisance and a danger," indicates honest wrath inspired by the periodical essays on the menace of highway transportation sent to stockholders and bondholders by the railroads.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept, 24. -- President Neilson, at the first chapel exercises which officially began the academic year at Smith College this morning, announced the award of important scholarships as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Thirty-four State banks having deposits of $207,168,000 have withdrawn from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation because of the new permanent insurance law, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the FDIC, announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- An unknown and unpublished account of the Arab revolt, written by the late Colonel T.E. Lawrence, has just been acquired through a member of the United States delegation to the Paris peace conference by Gabriel Wells, New York bookseller.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "obvious" conclusion that the way to take the greatest number of men off the relief rolls, in expending $4,000,000,000, is to use them on works of little or no permanent value, because such works require less expenditure for material and tools than those of permanent capital value, has again been aired by the argument between Messrs.

Gross earnings of the Commonwealth and Southern and Southern Corporation and operating units in the year ended Aug. 31 amounted to $118,178,615, compared with $113,566,452 in the previous twelve months. After deducting operating expenses, taxes, interest and other fixed charges and providing for retirement reserves or depreciation, the balance was $8,222,412, equivalent to $5.48 a share on the outstanding preferred stock, $6 series, against $8,252,495, or $5.50 a share.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24. -- Wild Bill Hallahan gave only three hits as the Cardinals defeated Pittsburgh, 11 to 2, today to give warning to the league-leading Cubs that the 1934 world champions are not yet out of the National League title chase.

International Printing Ink. The International Printing Ink Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly of 35 cents dividend on common, placing the stock on a $1.40 annual basis, against $1 previously. The regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 on the preferred also was declared.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A good deal of wonder seems to have been excited by the performance of a young British Indian who walked barefoot and uninjured over a pathway of incandescent charcoal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Mayor La Guardia discussed today with General Hugh S. Johnson, President Roosevelt and Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, the matter of selecting a successor to General Johnson as New York City WPA director.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 24 (AP). -- The LaSalle Stable's Lawrence Hanover won the forty-third renewal of the $14,000 Kentucky trotting futurity today in sensational style, the time for his two heats being the fastest of the year, averaging 2:01. Second was Miss Kate B., owned by W. N. Reynolds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The United States laid claim to another world airplane record today after an altitude flight by Benjamin King, engineer and sportsman-pilot.

JUDIQUE, N.S., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Seven half-dead seamen were washed ashore near here today with the news that five of their companions on the Halifax motor vessel Hurry On had died in a storm which had forced them to abandon their little ship twelve hours earlier.

ROME, Sept. 24. -- Premier Mussolini's report to his Cabinet today on "the possibilities of development of the Italo-Ethiopian situation on the basis of some articles of the League Covenant" was followed tonight by a press campaign against Ethiopia's continuance in the League of Nations.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The contours of Germany's new defense forces were revealed in dim outline today when it was announced that technical preparations for mustering the first draft of conscripts under the new universal service law had been completed.

The Pilsudski also brought over four stowaways who made their appearance after the vessel had left Copenhagen. They were put to work. According to the captain they denied that they were intentional stowaways, explaining that they had become so excited at the departure of the new ship that they forgot to leave.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Dr. C.G. Abbott, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, hailed today the success of Dr. Robert H. Goddard's rocket flight tests at Roswell, N.M., as a significant advance for many fields of science.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The propriety of the New Jersey Chancery Court using its jurisdiction to rule on an application for the appointment of a custodial receiver for British Type Investors, Inc., was questioned here today by Merritt Lane, attorney for the corporation, in a hearing before Alfred A. Stein, vice chancellor.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24. -- Hailed as "the foremost Catholic layman of the United States," Alfred E. Smith of New York stirred an audience of 43,000 to wild enthusiasm tonight at the general assembly of the seventh national Eucharistic Congress by a bitter denunciation of communism as the antithesis of "communionism."
Max Baer was beaten by a great fighter. There are no alibis, and Max wouldn't want to make one.
The new season's first full week has brought the theatre to such a pass that tonight it has to double up the openings. They are, to get down to the matter without delay:

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner today on the Board of Trade, an early dip being followed by an advance of around a cent a bushel from yesterday's finish. Commission house selling developed on the upturn and the close was unchanged to 1/4 cent lower on the day, the latter on the May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Delegates to the 1935 Mobilization for Human Needs adjourned this afternoon to begin in their respective communities the organization of the campaign for funds with which to carry on social welfare agencies from which Federal Government aid must soon be withdrawn.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- Eighty leading Protestant pastors and laymen meeting here as delegates of the Third Synod of the Prussian Confessional Church were informed curtly today by Dr. Stahn, government commissar, at the opening of the meeting that it was regarded with disfavor by the government.

The conflict between Colonel John S. Hammond, chairman of the board of directors, and Colonel John R. Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, was thoroughly aired yesterday at the annual meeting of the corporation's stockholders, held in the Garden.

The shipment of European gold to this country since the beginning of September has reached such proportions as to call for comment. This is more particularly so because of the common ascription of the movement to fear of war entertained by European markets. Such apprehension may conceivably have been a contributory cause, but it certainly was not the primary influence in the transfer of $164,000,000 gold in barely three weeks.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- The report adopted today by the committee of five left it to the Council of the League of Nations to decide definitely whether Premier Mussolini had or had not officially answered its suggestions for a peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute.

ATHENS, Sept. 24. -- The Greek public is increasingly apprehensive over the question of Adriatic, Ionian and Aegean sea power, complicated by severe criticisms by Italian Senators and the press in Italy upon the coming visit to Greek waters of the mighty British Mediterranean fleet.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Fully three weeks ahead of their schedule, the great gray battleships of Britain's Mediterranean fleet are moving steadily nearer to the shores of Italy on their so-called Autumn cruise.

Arriving yesterday afternoon at the head of a good-will delegation of five Japanese war veterans, Admiral Isamu Takeshita, retired, declared an important common objective of his country and ours was to stop the spread of communism. He expressed satisfaction over the friendly relations between the two nations.

The easing of tension over the Italo-Ethiopian situation found reflection yesterday in the diminishing flight of capital from European monetary centres as well as in the quotations for currencies on the foreign exchange market here. The guilder, the only weak spot in the list, moved nervously but with outside support and closed the day at 67.58 cents, its final quotation on Monday.
Plans for expanding the work of the Neurological Institute of New York to make it a leader" in its field were announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick Tilney, its medical director.

Steamship lines operating from Atlantic coast ports in the deepwater trades rejected yesterday the demands of the International Longshoremen's Association for a new wage contract which would include increases of five and fifteen cents, respectively, for a forty-four-hour week and overtime.

A small army of policemen, 1,500 strong, was assigned by Commissioner Valentine to direct the crowds outside the Yankee Stadium last night. The rush of spectators making their way to the various entrances was greatest between 8 and 8:30 o'clock, but at all times it was a most orderly, jovial gathering. Every one appeared to be in good humor.

Stolen anthracite coal with an estimated value of $20,000,000 annually is flooding Eastern coal markets, undermining the price of legitimate offerings and jeopardizing the jobs and investments of thousands, according to speakers at a luncheon here yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 24. -- Unless the resolutions committee of the Republican State Convention writes into the tentative platform for the coming legislative campaign a plank declaring for repeal of the sales tax, which was sponsored by the party's own Governor, the fight will be carried to the floor when the convention reassembles next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Donald R. Richberg, in his first comment on public issues since retiring as chairman of the National Recovery Board, conceded today that the abandonment of NRA had not brought the dire results he predicted.

It is not that the American woman loves Paris modes less but that she loves American fashions more that is responsible for the trend toward native styles here, Herbert L. Redman declared last night in discussing the attitude of the woman consumer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Three opinions expressed today in Federal Court here unsettled the reorganization proceedings of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railway Company before Judge James H. Wilkerson.

George Vanderbilt, who became 21 years of age on Monday, at the same time became entitled to one-fourth of the principal of his share in the estate of his father, the late Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, it was said yesterday by associates.

The defense at the trial of William H. Rabell, former investigator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, accused of having solicited and accepted a bribe from J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, attempted yesterday to show that Jones had told Rabell last June that "he had the goods on" John J. Burns, general counsel for the commission, and Joseph P. Kennedy, until last week its chairman.

The Municipal Art Committee will present 110 programs of drama, opera, symphony concerts, ballet, films and lectures in fifteen of the city's high school auditoriums, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman of the committee.

Joe Louis tried to catch a nap before the fight last night. Next to throwing punches, sleeping is the best thing that the Brown Bomber does. A green curtain, strung across the Bomber's dressing room, separated him from the preliminary boxers, but handlers and hangers-on could not restrain their curiosity.
It took the Giants a long time getting around to beating Curt Davis, tall righthander of the Phillies, but they finally made it yesterday in their closing day of the season at the Polo Grounds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- An afternoon of endeavor to start the new college year with a canary as a mascot ended for The Yale Daily News today with the disappearance of the bird in the direction of Cambridge and a report, vouched for tonight at the News office, that three members of the Harvard Crimson had been seen speeding northward with an unidentified bird in the rumble seat.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market. based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares a follows. Quotations are in cents;

KAUNAS, Lithuania, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Lithuania, in a semi-official reply to recent charges in Germany of unfairness in the Memel election next Sunday, declared today that Berlin reports that 11,000 electors had been deprived of the right to vote were entirely false.

ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 24. -- After a day's study of the rocket experiments of Professor R.H. Goddard, Clark University physicist, by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Harry F. Guggenheim, it was announced here tonight that funds would be provided by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation for continuation of the work.

Samuel Pomeranz, 45 years old, who described himself as a realty broker, surrendered in the District Attorney's office yesterday on an indictment charging he defrauded a woman of $450 under the pretense that he would obtain a $5,000 loan for her from the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Eleven men, true blue as the color of their jerseys, worked as near a miracle as the gridiron has witnessed in years in Palmer Stadium last November.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- The full British Cabinet met today for the first time since the emergency meeting of last month and again its deliberations concerned almost solely the situation created by Italy in European affairs. All the Ministers were present except Anthony Eden, secretary for League of Nations affairs, who could not leave Geneva.

The Rev. Dr. William Koepchen, known as "The Protestant Bishop of Times Square," was re-elected yesterday afternoon for the thirtieth year as president of the New York Pastoral Conference of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio, and other States.

Activities directly connected with preparation of the Flushing meadows as a world's fair site got under way yesterday when Park Commissioner Robert Moses detailed a staff of surveyors to make a complete study of the 1,003-acre tract between Flushing Bay and Kew Gardens, Queens.

Only eleven deaths from automobile accidents were reported in the city last week, the lowest total for thirty-one weeks. Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday. Of the deaths five were in Queens and three each in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 24. -- If the government of Premier Hendryk Colijn has its way, The Netherlands will refrain from monetary experiment and adhere to the gold standard. This policy again was expressed by the Premier today in an address, his first since the recent political crisis, delivered before the lower house of the States General.

In sympathy with strength in markets and the expectation that few notices would be circulated this morning, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday and closed unchanged to 8 points higher than on Monday.

Five hundred Persian lamb skins were carried away at 6 o'clock last night by five hold-up men from the fur loft of Abraham Greenberg on the fifth floor of 226 West Twenty-ninth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. No money was taken from the five men working in the loft.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- A showdown between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the public utilities industry on the latter's intention either to cooperate in the working out of the Holding Company Control Law or to hold back pending final adjudication of its basic validity is expected at tomorrow's conference of SEC members with representatives of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Secretary of Labor Perkins reported today that in August factory employment rose by 2.8 per cent and payrolls by 6.7 per cent. Of ninety industries surveyed, sixty-eight showed increases in the number of workers and seventy-two in payroll gains.

TRENTON, Sept. 24. -- Blasting any hope Governor Hoffman might have had that the minority party in the Legislature might again come to his aid and make possible adoption of his proposed sales tax moratorium, the Democratic State Convention made public today a tentative platform declaring for immediate repeal of the levy.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 24. -- To show his firm attachment to civilized principles, Emperor Haile Selassie opened today a new model prison near Akaki, three miles from Addis Ababa. The occasion was attended with some ceremony and foreign journalists and members of the diplomatic corps were invited.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 24. -- Talking down hostile audiences in Victoria and Vancouver which tried to deny him a hearing, Premier Bennett ended today the first half of a Western tour which appears to have improved the electoral chances of his government.

Arguing yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Dore in the suits to prevent the scheduled referendum on a municipal power plant, former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, on behalf of the plaintiffs, declared that the city's plan for underwriting the project was a "fantastic scheme" for a project that may or may not be successful.

VIENNA, Sept. 24. -- Three populous suburbs of Vienna today were turned into technical "cities of dead" during a practice air attack. The mock attack was carried out with such realism that hundreds of person suffered from tear gas, two soldiers were badly wounded by explosions and three members of the Heimwehr in a military motor car were seriously injured in a collision.

It was with a bit of regret that the Dodgers said good-bye to the Braves yesterday. The time had come for parting after the teams had met in a double-header at Ebbets Field, with the local club taking both contests, 5 -- 3 and 6 -- 5, the latter in eleven innings.
Max Baer had a weight advantage of 11 1/4 pounds in his bout with Joe Louis last night, the ex-champion scaling 210 1/2 and the Detroit Negro 199 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The largest single week's business done by financial institutions throughout the country in modernization and repair notes insured and in home mortgages selected for appraisal, was recorded last week, the Federal Housing Administration announced today.

The success of policewomen as members of the pickpocket squad at police headquarters appeared assured yesterday with the arrest of a man described by the police as a convicted shoplifter by two women who were assigned to duty with the squad on Sept. 11.

KANSAS, CITY. Mo., Sept. 24. -- Any political group seeking to win the votes next year of the Middle Western farmer from President Roosevelt must be able to offer as much in Federal subsidies as the present administration, or a workable substitute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Twenty-five offering sheets of various oil interests were received in the week ended on Sept. 21, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The SEC stated that in no case did the act of filing with the commission give any security its approval or indicate that the commission had passed on the merits of the issue or that the material filed was correct.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,744,500 barrels, compared with 2,749,850 in the preceding week, an increase of 24,650, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 161,500 barrels more than the calculations of 2,613,000 barrels a day by the Department of Interior for September.

Another sign of recovery is the publishers' Fall announcements, which promise the richest season in several years. The truth of this judgment cannot be statistically corroborated and must remain in the realm of opinion. Yet it is an opinion that would probably be shared by most professional reviewers and discriminating readers.

Net income of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company for the eight months ended on Aug. 31 is estimated at $4,173,521 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the income is equivalent to $5.82 a share on 528,765 $50 par shares of common stock.

An important portrait by the Venetian artist Titian has been bought by John Bass of New York, president of the Fajardo Sugar Company of Puerto Rico, from the Vienna offices of the E. A. Silberman Galleries of New York and Vienna.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Nocturnal excursions of a woman storekeeper here today resulted in the round-up of a burglary gang which has been operating for mouths in Fairfield and Westchester Counties.

A sharp advance in crude rubber futures and a setback in sugar quotations, the first in five days, featured trading in the commodity markets here yesterday. The cash markets were strong, no losses being recorded.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- The decision on whether Italy has definitely rejected the peace plan of the committee of five of the League of Nations Council, thereby ending conciliation in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, was delayed today until Thursday and left for the Council to face then.

The largest crowd that ever witnessed a sporting event in New York turned out at the Yankee Stadium last night to see Joe Louis, the sensational Detroit Negro, trade punches with Max Baer, former world's heavyweight champion.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The Boerse was slightly weaker and relatively inactive today. The unfavorable turn of the Italian negotiations before the League of Nations meeting in C-eneva, combined with continued reports of profit-taking and the effect of varfou government measures to depress the market, favored the general atmosphere of resigned pessimism.

Joe Louis entered the ring last night a married man, and his radiant bride, who until ten minutes before Joe left the apartment house at 381 Edgecombe Avenue for the Yankee Stadium was simply Miss Marva Trotter, 19-year-old Chicago secretary, sat in a ringside seat and urged her man on to do his best.
Harlem went on an unrestrained rampage of general din and impromptu parades last night in celebration of the victory of Joe Louis over Max Boer, while more than 500 policemen looked on.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24. -- Miss Julia A. Berwind entertained friends with a farewell party at Bailey's Beach today. Miss Berwind and her brother, Edward J. Berwind, will close the Elms tomorrow morning and will depart for New York for the Winter.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann, exhibiting flowers and vegetables grown at Sunken Orchard her country home on Sandy Hill Road here, won first honors today in the first day's judging at the twenty- fourth annual Fall flower show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society.

The future of The Churchman, Protestant Episcopal publication, the existence of which had been threatened by a libel verdict against it, was regarded as assured yesterday because of united efforts by Protestant, Catholic and Jewish sources to guarantee payment of the $10,200 verdict, should this be necessary after an appeal is decided.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The opening exercises of the 189th academic year of Princeton University were held here today in the university chapel. Upper classmen, 640 freshmen and more than 1,000 guests were present.

Michael Corso, 26 years old, known to the police as "Mike the Killer," who had been questioned twice in the past five years in connection with murders, was arrested yesterday afternoon after he had wounded a detective chasing him as he fled from a hold-up in which he and three companions had obtained $2,800.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- In an effort to straighten out the income tax tangles left by the financial collapse of the late Ivar Kreuger, Swedish match leader, Robert H. Jackson, general counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, and eight revenue agents will sail from New York for Europe tomorrow, the Treasury announced today.
Ray Benson of New Haven, back from a week's fishing trip to the Fish River chain of lakes in northern Maine, relates an incident that is reminiscent of pioneer days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Joe McCarthy deserted the Yankees to attend the fight in New York, but had he remained here he would have seen nothing to bring any creases to the managerial brow. Under the direction of Art Fletcher today the team collected sixteen hits, to gain an easy 14-6 victory over the Senators.

Despite the fact that he had beaten Max Baer and become the logical challenger for the heavyweight title, there was no great jubilation in Joe Louis's dressing room as he returned from his victory. He was as calm as when he went into the ring, but was perspiring and sank into a chair.

Sixty-four players qualified in three districts yesterday for play in the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual handicap tournament. The eligible golfers will compete for the title in match play at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., Oct. 2-4.
HELSINGFORS, Sept. 24. -- Paavo Nurmi has run his last race. The Flying Finn, the greatest runner the world has ever known, has decided to hang up his shoes after his long and brilliant career.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 24. -- Congress was virtually placed under arrest today as the government began a battle to force passage of a bill postponing the national elections.

A pronouncement by a French court was introduced in evidence here yesterday before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, to support an application for bankruptcy adjudication in the United States against Neidecker Cie and the Travelers Bank of Paris and elsewhere abroad.

Albert Correri, 22-year-old deliveryman for a financial district cafeteria, who found and restored $150,000 in negotiable government bonds dropped by a messenger on the sidewalk near his place of employment on Monday, got a new job yesterday with C.F. Childs Co., at 1 Wall Street, owners of the recovered securities.

PARIS, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Premier Pierre Laval today decided to abandon as hopeless his long efforts to mediate the Italo-Ethiopian quarrel, and to concentrate on the strong stand taken by Britain, officials said.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 24 (AP). --Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York criticized Federal crop control tonight as "a senseless violation of the law of supply and demand" and termed supporters of the New Deal "reactionaries to an extraordinary degree."

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- Faced with the impossibility of making a living in Germany and threatened by further plans for the liquidation of Jewish business in the country, several thousand Jews have now presented to the Reich Ministry of the Interior through their central committee a project for wholesale Jewish migration to Ecuador.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Francis Lane, Harvard's outstanding halfback of the 1933 season, did not remain long on Dick Harlow's reserve squad, the reported yesterday and started with the scrubs, but today was sent to pilot the third team.

Share prices made further modest recoveries yesterday to the accompaniment of slow trading. The intricacies of European politics are little understood here -- possibly not much more so in financial centres abroad -- but inasmuch as no "overt act' has yet been committed, each day that the controversy is prolonged tends to relax the tension in the markets.

When a truck from Central Park Zoo reached Pier 7, at the foot of Rector Street, yesterday, to pick up six 100-pound Galapagos turtles and a giant condor, a great problem that had disturbed Lee Trenholm temporarily was solved.

On the occasion of its tenth anniversary the editors of the Viking Press have drawn up a ten-year best-seller list. The concern's ten leaders, each of which has sold more than 100,000 copies, are as follows: "Power," "Ask Me Another," "Rasputin, the Holy Devil,"

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. George Rudnick, an eight-handicap player from Salisbury, today won the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by returning a gross score of 85 over the Westchester Country Club course. In second position, and the only other player to break 90, was Mrs. A.U. Rodney, Quaker Ridge star, who carded an 88.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Indians blasted out fifteen hits, including three home runs, today defeating the Tigers, American League champions, 14 to 7.

A quick-thinking patrolman averted an accident yesterday at the risk of his life by driving a truck containing 1,500 gallons of gasoline through heavy smoke and out of range of a fire along the open south curb of Twenty-eighth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, where repaving work was in progress.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 24. -- After having been closed for fifteen days under control of the Leftist bloc of students, the National University of Mexico will open its doors tomorrow under the direction of Luis Chico Goerne, a lawyer, who was unanimously appointed as director today.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Essex County Republicans of the Clean Government League tonight won a two-year battle here, electing W. Stanley Naughright of East Orange, former majority leader of the Assembly, as chairman of the county committee and taking complete control of the Republican organization. Jesse R. Salmon, veteran leader of the county party, was badly defeated.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- After a two-hour drifting match, a southwest breeze sprang up this evening and, with a few minutes to spare within the time limit, the third race in the international 6-meter match between the trio of Scandinavian nations and this country was finished.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 24 (AP). -- With Howard and New Deal finishing first and third, respectively, the silks of Walter O'Hara's Araho Stable dominated the running of the one and one-sixteenth miles of the Philadelphia Road Handicap at Havre de Grace today.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on Oct. 4 for a new issue of $6,000,000 of Commonwealth of Massachusetts public works bonds, maturing serially from Sept. 15, 1936 to 1940, inclusive. Bidders are requested to name the rate of interest.
New York again was host yesterday to throngs of visitors, here from many States to attend the big fight.

A European war is inconceivable, in the opinion of Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and co-author of the Kellogg-Briand pact, whose resignation as a judge of the World Court was announced Monday.

The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was slightly above the total for the preceding week and substantially over the figures for the corresponding week last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Chase Mellen Jr., candidate for re-election as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee issued last night a challenge to Kenneth F. Simpson, his opponent, to run against him for temporary chairman of the committee at its organization meeting at Mecca Temple tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24. -- St. Louis quit business today to crowd twenty-deep along a three-mile route and witness the annual parade of the American Legion, which for more than nine hours wound its way past a reviewing stand where Commander Frank N. Belgrano Jr. and other notables saluted and applauded.

The passenger list of the United States liner Washington, sailing today for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg, includes thirty American and Canadian Rhodes scholars of 1935, going to Oxford for two years of study.
The Boston Maine Railroad reported yesterday a profit and loss surplus of $6,473,755 on June 30, against $6,233,679 a year previously. Total assets were $291,604,297, against $289,881,098.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Walter Duranty's report of Russian economic progress would be even more vivid if translated into human values.

Breaks in water mains are a frequent item in the day's news. A rather serious one occurred in the Borough Hall district in Brooklyn last week. Water works engineers say it was caused by the unequal settlement of soil resulting from subway excavation work near by.

J.B. Priestley, the British novelist and playwright, said yesterday that his visit in the Far West last year had been so enjoyable that he was going to bring his family over to live there through the Fall and Winter. He arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania to attend to the opening of his play, "Eden End," next month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Assertions that political conditions favored the election of a Republican President next year were made here today by former Senator Lawrence C. Phipps, national committeeman from Colorado, and Earl S. Kinsley of Vermont, who arrived for the meeting tomorrow of the executive committee of the Republican National Committee.

SCENE: One office, two men, three tickets for the big fight. The two men were waiting for Olin Dutra, the heavyweight golfer, to arrive by plane and head toward the Yankee Stadium with them. Hence the third precious pasteboard. While waiting for Dutra, the conversation went as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Sept. 21 THE TIMES printed a letter, "On Being 'Created Equal,' " by Cornelia J.S. Denslow. Lovers of libertv are grateful to Mrs. Denslow for treating a solemn subject in such a clever and effective fashion.

More than 7,500 State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System have participated in the plan for Federal deposit insurance which was launched in 1934. The new Banking Act recently passed by Congress gave them the privilege of withdrawing from this plan merely by filing notice of their intention to do so, at any time within thirty days after the passage of the act. The deadline for such action was reached last Saturday.

Columbia and Manhattan engaged in a two-hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field, and while the Jaspers bad a slight advantage on the offense the Lions brought cheer to their supporters by their improvement over last week's session.

An exhibit of fluorescent minerals that attempts to give a bee's eye view of the world of color will be placed on view in the astronomical hall of the American Museum of Natural History within a few days, probably on Friday, it was announced yesterday.
The first of a series of WPA frescoes for the new model prison, the House of Detention for Women, at Sixth and Greenwich Avenues, is nearing completion under the brush of Miss Lucienne Bloch.

ROME, Sept. 24. -- The Italian Cabinet met again for almost four hours this morning, and the rather obscure communique issued afterward has given rise to a virtual maelstrom of speculation and conflicting interpretation.

The riding of Sammy Renick again featured the racing at Jamaica yesterday as he hung up his second triple within a week by booting home Highomar, Red Jug and My Kentucky, further to confirm his place as leading jockey of the meeting.
