UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Present and past champions of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association entered the second round of the State championship tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club today, together with the other two seeded contestants.

A Banking group headed by the National City Bank was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $30,000,000 of New York State emergency unemployment relief bonds with a tender of 100.5699 for 21/4s, or an interest cost basis to the State of 2.146 per cent.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- With Irving Burns hitting a two-run homer in each game, the Browns defeated the White Sox in both ends of a double-header today, 3 to 0 and 6 to 3.

The work of providing playgrounds in Greater New York goes on apace under the Fusion Administration. Mayor LA GUARDIA officially opened five new ones on Monday. These are but part of the intelligent and comprehensive program planned to give breathing spaces and recreation, free from the dangers of play in the streets, to a continually growing number of city children.

LA TUQUE, Que., Sept. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Dr. James (Bud) Stillman, New York surgeon, pleaded guilty before Magistrate L.X. Lacoursiere today to a technical charge of theft and malicious destruction of property. He was fined $10 and costs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Despite light receipts of hogs here today prices dropped sharply, with the general market off 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight and underweights as much as 40 cents lower. Packing sows and heavy butcher hogs were quoted as steady to 10 cents lower, the continued firmness in lard being a factor in the latter kinds.

Joe Louis, the sensational Detroit Negro heavyweight, hammered his way into a match for the world's heavyweight championship last night at the Yankee Stadium when he knocked out Max Baer, the Californian who formerly held the title, in the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round bout that brought back to boxing a gate close to the million-dollar mark.

The La Guardia administration's campaign for a favorable vote on the municipal power plant referendum in November was formally opened yesterday at a luncheon of the Consumers Public Power Plant Committee at the Caruso Restaurant, 130 West Forty-second Street.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- The British and French delegations in the economic committee of the League of Nations Assembly recommended today that all governments follow the policy of combining the freeing of trade with the stabilizing of money that Secretary of State Cordell Hull gave the world in the recent United States treaty with Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Retail food prices advanced seven-tenths of 1 per cent in the two weeks ended on Sept. 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The increase was due to higher prices for eighteen of the forty-eight foods included in the report affecting five of the eight commodity groups.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Roscoe Pound submitted his resignation today as dean of the Harvard Law School. The resignation is to become effective a year hence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 24. -- A series of speakers at the fifty-fourth annual American Transit Association convention here declared today that the trolley car does not meet the public demand. To go on with such equipment was extremely short-sighted police for an industry with $4,000,000,000 capital investment, they said.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Newell P. Sherman, 26-year-old choir leader and Scoutmaster on trial here for his life on a charge that he murdered his wife, Alice, swore today he had never confessed the crime.

Joe Louis, the sensational Detroit Negro heavyweight, hammered his way into a match for the world's heavyweight championship last night at the Yankee Stadium when he knocked out Max Baer, the Californian who formerly held the title, in the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round bout that brought back to boxing a gate close to the million-dollar mark.

The La Guardia administration's campaign for a favorable vote on the municipal power plant referendum in November was formally opened yesterday at a luncheon of the Consumers Public Power Plant Committee at the Caruso Restaurant, 130 West Forty-second Street.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- The British and French delegations in the economic committee of the League of Nations Assembly recommended today that all governments follow the policy of combining the freeing of trade with the stabilizing of money that Secretary of State Cordell Hull gave the world in the recent United States treaty with Belgium.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24. -- The text of Cardinal Hayes's address opening the Eucharistic Congress was as follows:
ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 24. -- Harry F. Guggenheim announced today that the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation would continue support for the rocket exper-

A World War soldier of the Sixteenth Infantry, First Division, United States Army, will receive the Distinguished Service Cross today at Governors Island. At the same time an Army Air Corps enlisted man will receive the Soldier's Medal for peacetime bravery.
For half an hour yesterday at the weighing of Max Beer and Joe Louis the bout hung in the balance because of an argument over the make of gloves the fighters would wear in the ring.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The grand jury that has been investigating the conduct of Westchester mortgage companies since last Winter this afternoon voted "no bill" in the cases of the Westchester Title and Trust Company and the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company, both of this city.

Members of the National Poultry, Butter and Egg Association mobilized at the closing sessions of their thirtieth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to fight extra trucking charges imposed by union drivers here on butter and eggs brought by overland trucks to the downtown market district.

Final adjustment of the wage controversy between the Federal Government and the trade unions as affecting skilled labor on WPA jobs appeared near last night with an announcement in behalf of organized labor in this city calling off the two-months' old strike on WPA projects.

When ordinary Democrats fight they are excused because it is their nature to. When members of a party long famous for its moral earnestness and devotion to high-sky ideals shake their fists and howl at one another, what is the pained observer to make of it? Two years ago Mr. CHASE MELLEN Jr. was made chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

The attendance at the Joe Louis-Max Baer fight at the Yankee Stadium last night was the third largest in the history of boxing, being exceeded only by the gatherings at the two Jack Dempsey-Gene Tunney bouts. Last night's contest drew 95,000, the paid attendance of 84,831 being swelled by more than 10,000 complimentary admissions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The rollicking Cub pennant parade, which hasn't missed a step since its surprise formation Sept. 4, tonight headed for Sportsman's Park in St, Louis, the dugout of the incredible and unbelieving Deans.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Aurora, runner-up to Greentree in the national open championship, was eliminated from the Monty Waterbury Cup polo tournament today in a well played match on Cochran Field at Meadow Brook, losing to Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes, 13 to 10.

Pugilism has been notable for the number of young men it finds in obscurity and lifts to eminence. But the pages of boxing history hold no parallel to the meteoric rise to fame and fortune of Joseph Louis Barrow the Detroit Bomber.
LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were more active and made a further recovery today.

Business failures declined in the three major trade groups, including the retail division, during the week ended Sept. 19, as compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Lillian Hellman, the playwright, will talk at 6 o'clock tonight on "The Difference Between Writing a Screen and a Stage Play" at the first of a series of weekly lectures on screen writing being offered by the Division of General Education of New York University.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24. -- Friends of Senator Huey P. Long revealed here today that he died without disclosing whether he had made any provision for his family beyond the life insurance policies he carried.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24. -- An enrolment of 7,440 students in Harvard University was announced when registration closed tonight. This is an increase of 139 over last year's total of 7,301. Late registrations this week are expected to swell the current total even further.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Possible settlement of the bituminous coal strike of more than 400,000 miners within another twenty-four hours of negotiation unless unforeseen contingencies arise was indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull conferred today on the forthcoming steps to be taken for the registration of all makers of munitions, under Section 2 of the Neutrality Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Enthusiastic reports of better business were brought to Washington today by the Federal Advisory Council, while Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, simultaneously told of a pick-up in employment and payrolls.

On the ground that the American Tobacco Company and its advertising Agency, Lord Thomas, Inc., appropriated a suggestion for a $3,000,000 advertising campaign for cigarettes without compensation, a suit was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against them for $300,000 and an injunction restraining the use of any ideas submitted by the plaintiff, the Griswold Company, an advertising agency.

The 16,000-ton motor ship Pilsudski, first transatlantic liner to be built by Poland since she regained her independence and symbol of the emergence of Poland as a maritime nation, reached Quarantine on her maiden voyage from Gdynia at 9:41 o'clock yesterday morning.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Rhode Island clergymen received today from President Roosevelt copies of a letter asking them to write him "about conditions in your community."

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Business executives at the final session today of the Boston Conference on Retail Distribution were warned by Melvin T. Copeland. Professor of Marketing at the Harvard Business School, that unless the administration cuts expenditures and curbs dangerous credit expansion, the "stage is set for a price rise surpassing that of the war years," which will culminate in a "disastrous wild boom."

A recent picture of an Ethiopian war dance does not seem at first glance to be altogether a service to HAILE SELASSIE'S people. If the dark-skinned warriors look very formidable, they also look pretty wild, and that is right up MUSSOLINI'S street.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, told the public service group of the Eucharistic Congress today that "a Catholic cannot hold himself forth as a good citizen unless he is a good Catholic" and "receives the sacraments frequently."

Backed by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Edsel B. Ford, an educational campaign against excessive drinking will be conducted by the recently organized Council for Moderation Inc., it was announced yesterday by Everett Colby, president of the group.
" Give me a cigarette, somebody. And hey, Red! Run out and get me a bottle of beer, will you?"

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. (AP). -- Warren K. Billings and Thomas J. Mooney, convicted 1916 Preparedness Day parade bombers who had not seen each other for nineteen years, met dramatically today at the Hall of Justice, scene of Mooney's habeas corpus hearing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- By compelling those who solicit voting proxies to make known in detail the exact interests for which the control is being sought and the purpose to which it is to be put, the Securities and Exchange Commission in rules issued today endeavored to erect a further safeguard about the interests of investors.

The Fall campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to raise funds for the completion of its 1935 budget of $4,350,000 will be headed by Lawrence Marx, it was announced yesterday by Felix M. Warburg, chairman of the board of trustees.

Columbia spent its entire practice session of three hours yesterday at Baker Field in bolstering its running attack. Although the Lions displayed considerable improvement, defensively, in the Manhattan scrimmage on Tuesday, Coach Lou Little was far from satisfied with the offensive blocking, and yesterday's drill was designed to improve the interference.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Dr. Katherine Blunt, president of Connecticut College, has been served with papers summoning her to appear before Judge Simpson in the Superior Court Friday to show cause why she should not be restrained from prohibiting students of the college from patronizing the College Inn in Mohegan Avenue.

Senator Borah, archpriest of the Constitution, in his recent radio talks mixes his love of that document with foreign affairs and shakes up a concoction to cure wars. The Senator believes that constitutional government taken three times daily will not only cure dictators, but will keep away wars.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- President Cutten, speaking today at the annual convocation of Colgate University, told students and faculty that unless our present civilization substitutes higher controls for the natural checks that have been removed it will commit suicide.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- President Roosevelt made public today the letter of resignation of Joseph H. Choate Jr. as director of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, under date of Aug. 15, and his own letter of acceptance, dated Sept. 23. Mr. Choate's letter follows:

The United Licensed Officers Association announced yesterday that it had started negotiations with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce to obtain a new working contact for officers employed on the government-owned merchant fleet, which is operated under contract by private companies.

About 7,000 persons attended a meeting held last night in Madison Square Garden to protest against any invasion of Ethiopia. After listening to speakers denounce imperialism, both as a general method of extending national territory and as exemplified in Italy's threatened invasion of Ethiopia, the meeting voted to send a cablegram to the League of Nations.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25. -- The government's bill postponing the national elections was passed by the Chamber of Deputies early this morning, but an effort to railroad it through the Senate failed because three Socialist Deputies broke the quorum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The conclusion that no amount of redistribution of existing wealth can bring substantial economic progress, but that this must come through an effective distribution of a greatly enlarged productive output, was announced by the Brookings Institution today as having been reached after a three-year study of ways to economic progress.

To hear Senator Borah deploring the evil effects of partisanship, especially in relation to our foreign policy, is enough to make the angels weep. If, as the Senator asserts, the high hopes that were entertained after the great war of an effective organization of the world for peace were wrecked, whose fault was it?
The Ryder Cup teams of Great Britain and the United States were honored last night at a dinner and dance given by the Professional Golfers Association at the Hotel Biltmore. More than 400 attended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Federal Trade Commission refused today to produce at public hearings its own evidence of alleged unfair competition in legislative activities by the International Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers and six of the country's largest milk distributing companies.

With the completion of legal and financial details, the merger of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Corrigan, McKinney Steel Company, in accordance with the plan approved by stockholders of both companies on Monday, became effective yesterday, it was announced by T.M. Girdler, chairman and president of Republic Steel.

BELLMORE, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Martin Rudich, 22-year-old son of Magistrate and Mrs. Mark Rudich of 637 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, was found guilty by a petty jury of six men before Justice of the Peace George Johnson here this evening of driving while intoxicated.

With advices reaching the trade here that the Autumn cocoon crop is 10 to 15 per cent under the short crop of a year ago, raw silk rose yesterday to $1.97 for the September position on the exchange and to $2 to $2.02 1/2 for crack double extras in the open market, the highest levels since 1933.

Charges of "frauds and irregularities" in the primary campaign in the Fifteenth Assembly District, in which, on the face of the returns, Jeremiah T. Mahoney defeated John E. Sheehy for the Tammany leadership, were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday on behalf of the Sheehy faction.
A diverse reaction to the President's request for their advice in the handling of the nation's social and economic program was revealed in the comments of clergymen yesterday in numerous cities.

Faced with the possibility that the October city budget may not provide for the continuance in jobs of the entire present personnel of the Home Relief Bureau, 5,000 members of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies voted last night at St. Nicholas Palace, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, to empower its executive board to call a stoppage "whenever it deems it necessary."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- President Roosevelt proclaimed today a list of arms, ammunition and implements of war, the makers, exporters or importers of which must register under Section 2 of the Neutrality Act with the Secretary of State before Nov. 29. After that date, all exports and imports of these articles may be made only on license issued by the Secretary.

A plan for the temporary deferment of the payment of interest on the Warren Brothers Company's 5 1/2 per cent gold notes and 6 per cent debentures has been approved by the directors and is being distributed to all bondholders. The coupons affected are those due on Sept. 1, 1935, and March 1 and Sept. 1, 1936.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Sept. 25. -- Ethiopia sits behind its serried escarpments to the west and guards the precious waterholes in the south, while trusting nothing white -- neither man nor nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Completion of the work of allocating or earmarking all of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief fund before his departure for the West tomorrow night was promised today by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Before embarking on a round of conferences which included twoscore callers, President Roosevelt tasted an anticipatory thrill as he made preparations for his fishing excursion into tropical waters to begin in about ten days.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP). -- The story of a choir singer's infatuation for a girl he could not marry was read to a jury today at Newell P. Sherman's trial for the murder of his wife.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether a municipality making a profit from operation of its own electric light plant may apply the earnings to tax reductions or general funds.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP). -- By trotting a mile in two minutes flat against time today at the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders Association track Calumet Evelyn became the world's fastest double-gaited harness horse of any age or sex.

After having written in verse of heroes of history, Maxwell Anderson has gone one step further. In "Winterset," which was beautifully played at the Martin Beck last evening, he has written a verse tragedy of tatterdemalions along the East River waterfront. To report it with any sort of respectable decision a reviewer needs more time than there will be before the next edition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- President Roosevelt gave at a press conference today the first definite indication that he may not press for legislation to revive the powers of the government over business embodied in the old National Recovery Administration.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Old Westbury rode into the semifinal round of the sixteen-goal Autumn plates polo tournament with a thrilling 9-to-8 triumph over the Squirrels on Belmont Field of the Meadow Brook Club today. Hubert Phipps scored the winning goal forty seconds after the overtime period got under way.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Myrtlewood, 3-year-old filly from Kentucky, is the sprinting champion of the Western turf.

In an atmosphere of international friendship and good-will, the official greetings of New York State and New York City were extended last night to the Polish delegation which arrived on Tuesday on the new 16,000-ton liner Pilsudski of the Gdynia-America Line.
BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The Reich Government confessed defeat and offered control of the Protestant church today to opposition Protestant leaders and Confessional synods.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and including the First Boston Corporation; Kidder, Peabody Co.; Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; R.W. Pressprich Co., and the Northern Trust Company of Illinois, was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $7,000,000 of City of Boston tax-anticipation notes.

Goldman, Sachs Co. yesterday won the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of city of Rochester, N.Y., public welfare bonds, at a price of 100.13 for l 3/4s. The bonds are dated Oct. 1, 1935, and mature serially from Oct. 1, 1936 to 1940.
On Sept. 9 an editorial appeared in THE TIMES headed "The Railroad Problem," the last paragraph of which read as follows:

ADDIS ABACA, Ethiopia, Sept. 25. -- Mobilization has been ordered in frontier provinces, but no move has thus far been made in central Ethiopia. Emperor Haile Selassie's order is a compromise between the diplomatic viewpoint of his foreign advisers and the traditional attitude of his more warlike elder councilors.

To be able to present stronger arguments to the Securities and Exchange Commission against segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers, the New York Stock Exchange has sent to London Dean K. Worcester, executive vice president, and Robert L. Stott, a member of the board of governors, to study the broker-"jobber" system employed by the London Stock Exchange.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- President Angell at the annual freshman class rally tonight said he was delighted to say that Yale University is finally to house practically all the members of the class in college dormitories for the first time in many years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Victor F. Ridder, New York publisher, has been appointed Works Progress Administrator for New York City, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, announced today.

I LIVE IN VIRGINIA," Julian Meade calls his book (Longmans, Green, $2.50). This means a garden of phlox and zinnias; it means an arbor where the scuppernongs are ripening. It means Nancy Astor's homecoming. It means that elegant Richmond gentleman whose eyes tell nothing, Mr. Branch Cabell, ne James Branch Cabell. It means Mr. Jefferson's university at Charlottesville.

Midas, an extremely shaggy English sheepdog wearing kilts, lumbered off with the first prize yesterday afternoon at a Dogs of All Nations parade staged in the Park Lane Hotel garden by the Puppy Club.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 25. -- All able-bodied warriors of Ethiopia's northern provinces advanced today toward the Eritrean front. They began reforming and expanding the military units that had been disbanded last Spring at the beginning of the rainy season, which is now ending.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Street railway and bus spokesmen declared today in speeches at the closing session of the convention of the American Transit Association in the Hotel Ambassador that the interests of the public and the transit companies are the same.

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The Boerse opened weaker today, but showed some resistance toward the closing of the session. Activity was limited. The firmness at the end was attributed by official commentators of financial sheets to the industrial activity.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Under a ruling made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, any "foreign public corporation or other autonomous entity, in the nature of a political subdivision, except a State, province, county or municipality or similar body politic," may, at its option, use either Form 18 or Form 21 for the permanent registration of bonds on the stock Exchanges.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Running races were introduced in place of harness events today at the Interstate Fair track. Each race was worth $200, with the prize money split four ways.

ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 25 (AP). --Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh completed today three days of intense study of plans for a rocket intended to shoot at 700 miles an hour into the stratosphere, possibly to a height of 150 miles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- A charge that he had been approached with a proposal to "frame" Tom Mooney was made by Israel Weinberg, one of the original defendants in the 1916 Preparedness Day bombing case, at Mooney's habeas corpus hearing today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 25. -- A split developed today in the ranks of the politicians bent on ousting the followers of Senator Huey P. Long from office. The Long machine is already divided by the rival candidacies of Judge Richard Leche and Lieut. Gov. James A. Noe.

Reorganization of the firm headed by the late Michel C. Bouvier, dean at the time of his death last July of members of the New York Stock Exchange, was announced yesterday by the Exchange. M.C. Bouvier Co. will be succeeded next Monday by Bouvier, Bishop Co., whose partners will be John V. Bouvier 3d, John G. Bishop, Henry C. Scott and John Vernou Bouvier Jr.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 25. -- A grand jury investigation of the fatal shooting of Evelyn Hoey in the Summer home of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d near Lyndell, on Sept. 11, will not be called this week, if at all, William E. Parke, District Attorney of Chester County, said late today.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Joe Louis earned the largest purse of his short professional career on Tuesday night. The Detroit Bomber now has fought twenty-five times since he left the amateur ring and is yet to be defeated. He has scored twenty-one knockouts and gained four decisions.

Police Commissioner Valentine celebrated his first anniversary as commissioner yesterday. Except for the more than 150 telegrams from well-wishers which arrived at his office at police headquarters, the commissioner insisted on foregoing any "fuss or notice" of the occasion.

Net profit of the Consolidated Laundries Corporation for the third quarter of the company's fiscal year amounted to $42,104 after providing for all charges, including depreciation, interest and taxes. After allowances for cumulative preferred stock dividend requirements for the quarter, the profit was equivalent to 8 cents a share on 400,000 shares of common stock.

PRAGUE, Sept. 25. -- J. Butler Wright, the United States Minister, yesterday presented to President Thomas G. Masaryk of Czechoslovakia the medal of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation in accordance with a resolution it adopted last May.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The Philadelphia Society for the Preservation of Landmarks, of which Miss Frances A. Wister is president, will have an exhibition to be known as "Needlework of Yesterday and Today" in the John Wanamaker Art Galleries during the week beginning Oct. 28.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Ferrell brothers performed in brilliant fashion today when the Red Sox completed their home schedule with a 7-2 victory that swept the final series with the Athletics.

Many of the best players of the metropolitan district competed in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Queens Valley Country Club in Forest Hills yesterday. Mrs. Robert Lake of Plandome reported a gross score of 82 to win the award.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd received last night the bronze plaque of the Columbia Broadcasting System for the outstanding contribution to radio in 1934. The presentation was made in the CBS studios, 485 Madison Avenue, during a broadcast of the first radio reunion of members of the second Byrd expedition.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City announced yesterday he had been informed that the Works Progress Administration had approved the city's application for an $800,000 grant to build a municipal sports stadium.

Numerous dinners were given last night at the Plaza in conjunction with the opening of the Persian Room for the season. With Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hartford were Mr. and Mrs. Edward S.J. McVickar, Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Chrysler, Mr. and Mrs. Waddell Catchings, Miss Louise McKelvy, Douglas Thomson and Frank G. McKelvy.

With fewer than 2,000 bales of cotton certificated here and only about 6,000 bales at the seven other markets, there were no deliveries yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. The other delivery points are Galveston, Houston, New Orleans, Mobile, Savannah, Charleston and Norfolk.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Enjoying a two-stroke margin over the field of 121 competitors, Mrs. J.J. Lawlor of the Gedney Farm Golf Club, captured low gross honors in the third annual women's invitation tourney at the Green Meadow Country Club today.

TRENTON, Sept. 25. -- The resolutions committee of the Republican State Convention approved here today a tentative platform containing a plank leaving the question of repeal of the sales tax to the next Legislature, which convenes Jan. 2, "whose representatives will have been elected on this issue," and recommending no action be taken before that.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- A registration statement for the issuance of $55,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1950, was filed by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933.

Kenneth F. Simpson, candidate of the forces opposed to Chase Mellen Jr. was elected at 2:25 o'clock this morning chairman of the Republican County Committee, succeeding Mr. Mellen, who was a candidate for re-election.
B,leat trade conditions and wholesale prices in .New York.
When Joe Louis knocked out Max Baer Tuesday night in the Yankee Stadium, the Negro youth who two years ago was a $5-a-day laborer, again made a boxing match a million-dollar spectacle.

Metamorphosed into a wire-haired Ethiopian-Zulu, stripped to the waist and armed only with a spear and a shield, Jack Dempsey fought a losing battle yesterday against wild, humorous elements as he was made a member of the Circus Saints and Sinners at the Hotel Gotham.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 25. --Hundreds attended the New England conference of State Federations of Women's Clubs today to welcome Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson of Tulsa, Okla., new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, who is on her first visit to New England.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Early-season sensations of the American League, the White Sox today were definitely buried in the second division.

In many respects yesterday's stock market followed the pattern of the days immediately preceding, trading continued at slightly more than 1,000,000 shares on the Stock Exchange and prices fluctuated within narrow ranges to close a little higher on the average.

Hyman I. Fischbach, attorney for J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties whose activities are being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, testified yesterday in Federal Court as a government witness at the trial of William H. Rabell, former investigator for the commission, accused of having solicited a bribe from Jones.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25. -- On the very summit of Mount St. James there came within the ken of this intrepid mountain climber today a picture such as rarely falls upon the sight in the course of a season's peregrinations around the college football circuit.
The vote in the Mellen-Simpson fight for chairman of the Republican County Committee follows:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The United States, represented by skippers Frank Campbell and Clair Farrand, got off to a flying start today the international sailing dinghy series with Great Britain began off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Unless liquor dealers clean house and place their business on a "clean, decent and respected" basis new and strict government regulatory measures may be adopted, representatives of the city, State and Federal Governments last night warned a meeting of leading liquor distributers at the Astor.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 25. -- George Wells of the Hopewell Valley Country Club, a new member in the New Jersey State Seniors' Golf Association, added a second round 82 to his Tuesday's score of 78 to take a six-stroke lead in the fourteenth annual championship of that group at the Essex Fells Country Club today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- The Gas House Gang of St. Louis was gassed today. Withering fumes from the unerring smokeball of Lon Warneke, and one terrific explosion off the bat of 19-year-old Phil Cavarretta left the world champion Cardinals all but lifeless today as the rampaging Cubs blanked them, 1 to 0, for their nineteenth straight victory, a brilliant conquest that put them within only one more triumph of the National League pennant.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond devoted two hours today to various types of contact work. First, skeleton scrimmaging, using only the backs and ends, was tried. Later the varsity rehearsed the simple formations which the regulars are perfecting, and finally a lively supervised scrimmage tested the new attack and the line-up which was named today.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Struggling through the home stretch, Donald Christmas's Accolade captured the $2,500 White River Handicap at Rockingham Park today after the most furious battle of the Fall meeting.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, a symphony in brown, was arrested at the Packer House here late this afternoon and tonight was put under $10,000 bond by Acting Recorder Harry S. Medinets for hearing tomorrow afternoon as a fugitive from justice.

Plans for acquisition and dissolution of the Moto Meter Gauge and Equipment Corporation were disclosed yesterday by the Electric Auto-Lite Company in a listing statement filed with the New York Stock Exchange. The Exchange also announced that it had admitted to listing the securities of four other corporations.

OYSTER BAY. L.I., Sept. 25. -- Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann won the Sweepstakes Prize, a silver plate, this afternoon in the final judging of entries in the twenty-fourth annual flower and vegetable show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society which closed tonight in the auditorium of St. Dominic's School.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Deeply perturbed by mounting anti-Olympic agitation in the United States, Dr. Theodore Lewald, 70-year-old president of the German Olympic Association, decided today to make a spectacular appeal to the American people to support the games.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 25. -- The Ethiopian Government has just rescinded the permission granted to the Red Cross unit commanded by Dr. Robert William Hockman of the American Presbyterian Hospital to travel southward to the Ogaden front, on the ground that missionary activity among the troops is unacceptable.

A four and a half-hour conference of committees representing ship-owners operating in the deep-sea trades and the International Longshoremen's Association ended last night in concessions by both sides on a new wage and working contract.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25. -- Taking no chances on overworking his football squad, Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard today kept his two ranking elevens out of scrimmage, but varied the routine by putting the "A" and "B" varsities through fast dummy work against the recently organized scrubs instead of at the machines.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 25. -- American proposals for a Southern Pacific air service with Auckland, New Zealand, as the terminus is understood to be the subject of discussions between the New Zealand and British Governments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Industrial production gained during August by about the usual seasonal amount due to increased steel production, compensating for declines in automobile output and relatively stable conditions in other industries, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today in its monthly business summary.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- The assertion that an "irresponsible, spending government at Washington" is driving the country toward destruction of its currency, widespread suffering, "crucifixion" of the "middle class," dictatorship and some form of fascist or collectivist State was made by Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, before the American Mining Congress today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Dissatisfied with the team's execution of fundamentals, Coach Fritz Crisler drove his Princeton football squad through a long blocking and tackling session on University Field today. The players showed much improvement over their work in Saturday's practice game.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., are expected to underwrite an offering of securities issued as part of the refunding of a $105,859,000 general mortgage 7 per cent bond maturity next July 1 of the Great Northern Railway. Plans under discussion call for the issuance of bonds bearing 4 1/4 per cent interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The intention of the public utilities industry to fight the Public Utility Act to the last legal ditch was impressed upon members of the Securities and Exchange Commission today in a two-hour conference, during which representatives of the industry pledged their cooperation "for our own good" in 'the working out of the administrative policies set forth by the act."

Steel operations have been reduced from 52 to 51 1/2 per cent of capacity as a result of the automobile industry's delay in getting into production of models of its cars for 1936, according to Iron Age's weekly summary of the steel market, issued yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Thursday, Sept. 26. -- A flowing river of 200,000 devout men and women poured into the great bowl of the Municipal Stadium early this morning to give the most striking testimony yet of the religious fervor kindled by the seventh National Eucharistic Congress now in session here.
The money market showed no change, either in business or rate structure. The turnover was small and quotations unchanged for all grades.

Dr. GOLDWATER asks that the city budget be stretched to include an allowance of $15 a month for internes in city hospitals. Hitherto they have received only their board and lodging. Accustomed to regard their hospital work as a vital part of their training, they have had to meet incidental expenses out of their own pockets.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, speaking at the opening exercises of the university's 182d academic year yesterday, attacked certain trends in modern education, declaring that many social Ills and individual shortcomings could be traced to the deficiencies of modern schooling.

With the probability increasing that war rumors will have less effect on the stock market as the days pass, brokers are wondering what new influences will arise to determine the course of prices. Pessimistic speculators in Wall Street appear to be abandoning the bearish arguments that were used as an excuse for lower prices last week.

With the support of Mr. ROCKEFELLER and Mr. EDSEL FORD, the recently organized Council for Moderation is to undertake an educational campaign to promote the temperate use of liquor. There is no intention of resorting to legislative action or of participating in a controversy over the merits of repeal.

Perhaps the man's robust faith in human nature was cracking under the prolonged strain of the Ethiopian crisis. At any rate, he turned to the man in the next seat and smiled cynically and said how wonderful it would be if we could discover a moral equivalent for heavyweight prizefights.

GENEVA, Sept. 25. -- The League of Nations Council, now composed of Foreign Ministers, might be composed of Ministers of Finance and Commerce when important financial or economic questions are up for discussion, Georges Bonnet, French Minister of Commerce, suggested in the Assembly's second committee today.

Static offering, by means of a sanctus, will be made today by a banking syndicate headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., of a new issue of $49,000,000 of Detroit Edison Company general and refunding 4 per cent bonds that will mature on Oct. 1, 1965. The bonds are priced at 103 1/2.

His thumb! Think of that! Early in the afternoon Madcap Max dashed out of the boxing commission office shouting "The fight's off!" Why? Because the Louis handlers at first refused permission to let the Harlequin of Hollywood use a pair of gloves made specially to protect his thumb.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Shelving temporarily the dispute concerning the nine cents a ton demanded by the United Mine Workers of America for piece workers, the subcommittee of four representing miners and operators in the Appalachian area, turned their attention today to problems affecting the various districts.

Mr. and Mrs. Cedric Major of Washington gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Ryan, Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Ettinger, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy C. Mooney, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Saunders, Mr. and Mrs. William Reynolds, Mr. and Mrs. C. William Coughlin, Mrs. A. Harding Paul, Miss Betty Vosburgh, Miss Eleanor Gallagher, Albert Paul and C.B. Allen.

What changes are needed in New York State's fish and game laws? That will be the central theme of discussion at the first Autumn meeting of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association at the court house in White Plains next Tuesday evening.

The American Ice Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50t cents on the preferred stock. Previously quarterly dividends of $1.50 were paid from Jan. 24, 1920. In 1918 and 1919 an extra dividend of $1 was distributed, so that the company has been paying the annual rate of $6 since 1918.

Renewed weakness overtook the foreign exchanges yesterday, indicating a continued flight of funds here from abroad, but the day's engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were smaller. A total of $15,948,000 of gold was reported as taken abroad for import to this country, but of this amount $10,689,000 from France had been engaged last week, although not previously reported.

The seasonal apartment rental rush was reflected again yesterday in long lists of new tenants compiled by brokers. The East Side, particularly in midtown, led in volume for the day. Various duplex apartments were taken, several of them being in cooperative houses.
Bosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, will begin at sundown tomorrow. In the Hebrew calendar the new year will be 5696.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 25. -- Serving notice that the nation's great industries, recovering through their own efforts and the irresistible force of economic law, will not tolerate future governmental interference, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, assailed "panaceas" and "quack ideas" in an address here today.
B.E. Snyder of the R.B. Davis Company, Hoboken, has been named treasurer of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., to succeed H.D. Crippen, who resigned because of ill health.

Until Governor LEHMAN called attention to it the other day, most citizens of New York State were probably unaware that they will be called upon in November to approve a constitutional amendment providing for the reorganization of county government. The first part of the amendment relates to up-State counties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25. -- George T. Richards, 72 years old, civil engineer and retired former president of Drake Stratton Company, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia railroad contractors, died here today at his Summer home, 5,505 Ventnor Avenue.

ROME, Sept. 25. -- It is considered almost certain that the grand mobilization of all the forces of the Fascist regime -- which was announced just a fortnight ago when Premier Mussolini wad still riding on his high horse and defying the League of Nations and the world to do their worst -- will be held tomorrow.

The premiere showing of the motion picture of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which has been produced by Warner Brothers, has been taken over for the night of Oct. 9 at the Hollywood Theatre to raise funds for carrying on the educational work of the English-Speaking Union of the United States.

Constructive operations continued to dominate the trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover was $9,733,700, compared with $8,886,900 on Tuesday. The improvement in sentiment was reflected in rising tendencies over a broad list of bonds in most classifications.

MADRID, Sept. 25. -- After Spain had been without a Ministry for six days a new Cabinet was formed tonight, another Centre-Right Wing coalition just as representative of the Cortes majority as was the preceding government.
BRYN MAWR, Sept. 25. -- Ideal weather greeted a record opening-day crowd as the thirty-ninth annual Bryn Mawr horse show got under way today.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 25. -- The annual exhibition of Lenox handiwork was opened today in Sedgwick Halt under the auspices of the Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president and Miss Edith O. Fitch librarian.

Expediting its new construction program, the Board of Education, at a meeting yesterday, approved plans for four new school buildings, providing seats for 8,250 children and costing nearly $2,500,000.

In advance of the meeting of the Republican Executive Committee in Washington, its purposes and functions were kindly explained to a not too interested public. These Republican leaders are not going to put forward a candidate for next year. They are not even to draft policies or write a party platform for the National Convention.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- War talk apparently has lost much of its influence in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, but prices fluctuated erratically today. The September, after breaking early, rallied sharply on scattered buying, to close 1 3/8 cents a bushel higher than yesterday, while the December was up 1/4 cent.

Concern over the future of Christianity because of the "inconsistency" of the attitude of the "Church of Rome" in regard to the impending conflict between Ethiopia and Italy was expressed yesterday at the final session of the Long Island Conference of the United Lutheran Synod here.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- When actual developments are lacking in so vital an issue as the present Italian threat to Ethiopia the rumor monger gets his chance. He was extremely busy today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- A complaint was issued by the Federal Trade Commission today against Gus Martel of 198 Broadway, New York, charging unfair competition in the sale of a correspondence course in muscle development and physical culture.

A new prize competition of $1,000, with additional royalty, for the best mystery-detective novel by an American or Canadian author, is announced by Dodd, Mead, publishers of the Red Badge detective story list. Manuscripts must be submitted before June 15, 1936.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Hitherto the policy of British empire governments has been to reserve empire air mails for empire airlines. This policy is to be applied in the extension of the Australian route to New Zealand in 1937. It will probably apply to Canada when the Atlantic air service is instituted and it is possible the British Empire may join Australia and New Zealand with Canada by air service.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- The League of Nations received this afternoon a cablegram from Emperor Halle Selassie of Ethiopia, its second direct message from him, asking the Council, which meets tomorrow, to take precautions against the use by Italy of frontier incidents as a pretext for aggression.

Now that Constitution Day has come and gone and we have at least partly recovered from the blasts of our Republican friends about what dire things would befall us if the Constitution is not considered a fixed and inflexible instrument, it may be well to investigate further into this subject which they seem determined to use as an issue in the coming Presidential campaign.

ROME, Sept. 25. -- Improved relations between Great Britain and Italy resulted tonight in cancellation of the sailing from Naples tomorrow of 10,000 soldiers for Libya. Because of the decline in tension between the two governments, it was explained, the reinforcements in Libya, which borders upon Egypt, are not necessary.
Although the letter of Mrs. Gertrude Chase Kreischer regarding railroads vs. buses is very appealing, it presents only one side of the picture.

History repeated itself yesterday at Ebbets Field. A year ago, when the Giants were in the thick of the pennant race, the Dodgers ruined their chances in the final two games. The stakes were a bit different yesterday as the teams met for the last time this year, but that didn't mean a thing to the Stengelmen, who beat their interborough rivals in both ends of a double-header, 10 -- 4 and 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- President Roosevelt today was awaiting responses to a large number of letters which he mailed privately to clergymen throughout the country asking for personal reports on their observations of conditions. The sending of these letters became known late yesterday when some of them were delivered to addresses.

KAMLOOPS, B.C., Sept. 25. -- Prime Minister Bennett made a statement at a meeting here last night to contradict an impression produced by previous speeches that the Canadian Government had lost all hope of a trade agreement with the United States before the next Presidential election.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

Manufacturers figured largely in the business leases reported yesterday. Among the retail renters was the Liggett Drug Company, Inc., which took a store fronting sixty-three feet in Lexington Avenue at the southeast corner of Seventy-ninth Street.

The Japanese delegation of five war veterans headed by Admiral Isamu Takeshita, retired, on a good-will tour of the United States spent its second day in New York yesterday touring Brooklyn as guests of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of New York.

Announcement of the results of the balloting by stockholders of the Madison Square Garden Corporation was postponed again yesterday because the validity of proxies voted at the annual meeting the day before was challenged.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- A flood of resolutions, aimed chiefly at communism and including one demanding withdrawal of recognition of Soviet Russia, was adopted by the convention of the American Legion here today. The resolution on Russian recognition asserted that the Soviet Government had not ceased "its sponsorship of subversive activities" in this country.

Dominic Tossone, 319 East 112th Street, the 19-year-old youth who was the first to be indicted by the special grand jury investigating rackets under Thomas E. Dewey, the special prosecutor, received yesterday an indeterminate sentence in Elmira reformatory from Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

The heroism of a World War veteran who charged the Germans although wounded and of a soldier who saved a boy from drowning was recognized yesterday morning at Governors Island by the United States Army with full military honors.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Mrs. Anna Kerston, a widow, refused tonight to allow her daughter, Margaret, 15 years old, to be taken to a hospital for an emergency operation for a ruptured appendix, and locked the doors of her bungalow at 291 Alpine Street, on the outskirts of this city, against policemen and physicians who tried to persuade her the girl's life was seriously threatened.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Treasury took a new lease on life tonight because Miss Mary M. O'Reilly's service had been extended by Presidential order beyond the retirement age.

The Flushing River, running through the tract selected for the projected New York World's Fair of 1939-40, will be made navigable for boats with draft up to 18 feet for a considerable distance into the fair grounds, according to Park Department plans for development of the tract, it was learned yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Indians won the final game of their season series with the Tigers today, 3 to 2, collecting ten hits.

In 1910 a Nebraska lawyer of 40 who had given up the practice of law because he wanted to investigate and ponder deeply its history and philosophy, took a professorship at the Harvard Law School bearing the name of one of its famous teachers, JOSEPH STORY.

A total of 1,738,586 persons heard 662 free concerts by the nineteen instrumental ensembles of the WPA Concert Unit between June 1 and Sept. 15, according to an announcement of attendance figures by George Crandall, manager of the concert unit.

Acting Mayor Bernard S. Deutsch assailed the Consolidated Gas Company system yesterday for its contemplated program of Sunday radio broadcasts to create "good-will" among consumers. If the company's plan was to get the voters in a mood to reject the proposed referendum on the issue of a municipal "yardstick" power plant, he declared, it was doomed to failure.

Gerard B. Lambert, owner of the racing yacht Yankee, and the first skipper to take a large single-sticker to British waters in more than two decades, was back at his desk at 250 Park Avenue yesterday "trying to recover from the marvelous reception" accorded him abroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement and proclamation establishing of categories of arms, ammunition and implements of war follows:
The New Dealers are up in arms again. This time because a group of lawyers dared to announce that, in their opinion, the National Labor Relations Act is unconstitutional.

A recovery in sugar futures from their setback of Tuesday was a feature of the trading on the commodity markets here yesterday. In the cash markets wheat, corn and silk advanced, and rye, lard, rubber and wool tops were lower.

A bid of $3,046,999 was made yesterday by the Bowery Savings Bank for the fifteen-story Hotel Montclair at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The bank bought in the property as plaintiff in a foreclosure action against the Lampton Holding Corporation and others.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 26. -- Every available London fireman with all the latest fire-fighting appliances failed last night and early today to end a fire that, starting in the afternoon with a wisp of smoke from an upper window, in ten hours destroyed the new seven-story warehouse of the Colonial Wharves, Ltd., containing 400 tons of crude rubber and vast stores of tea.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The freight-car requirements of motorcar factories in this area in the next three months will be two and a half times greater than in the corresponding period of 1934, K.A. Moore of the Automobile Manufacturers Association predicted today.

Adrian H. Muller Sons sold yesterday at auction at 18 Vesey Street 74,500 shares of common stock of the De Witt Clinton Company, Inc., to John E. Connelly of 149th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, for $53,000. The De Witt Clinton Company controls the De Witt Clinton Hotel in Albany.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Carl R. Griffin, vice president and cashier of the Passaic National Bank, was elected president of the Passaic County Bankers Association at the annual dinner meeting tonight at the Montclair Golf Club. He succeeds Evard E. Puryear, president of the Paterson National Bank, who was toastmaster at the dinner.

The shortest-priced favorite to lose since the Fall season began on the metropolitan tracks went to defeat at Jamaica yesterday when the E.R. Bradley entry of Bien Joli and Banister finished two, three behind Wha Hae after being backed to 9 to 20.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 25. -- Bridge was blamed tonight for the defeat of Oklahoma women in their fight for the right to hold major State offices.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews and Miss Charlotte Glutting, who have divided equally six of the twelve championships held by the Women's New Jersey State Golf Association, entered the semifinals of the thirteenth annual tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

A steady stream of apparel and accessory orders has reached the wholesale markets here this week as continued favorable weather stimulated Fall retail trade in many sections. Buying interest in sports coats has been notable, reflecting the record business being done by many retailers in this merchandise.

Bruce Gimbel, 23-year-old son of Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., will enter the store's service today, carrying on the tradition established ninety-three years ago when his great-grandfather, Adam Gimbel, opened a frontier trading post at Vincennes, Ind.

An emergency call was broadcast through Station WNYC at 8 o'clock Tuesday night for a volunteer to give a pint of blood. It was needed to save the life of a woman dying at Beth David Hospital after giving birth to a child. She was a charity patient. The call was urgent. No one answered.

The spending spirit of flush times was abroad at the Yankee Stadium -- heartening in some respects to the watchers for recovery -- and the city's various communities shared largely in the distribution of the large sums spent by those who attended the Louis-Boer fight.

The Center Theatre, sister house of the Radio City Music Hall, will be reopened as a cinema next Wednesday at 8:45 P.M., with "Here's to Romance," a Jesse Lasky production for Twentieth Century-Fox. The film will star Nino Martini, Metropolitan Opera tenor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- Miss Alice Mann Huber, 19-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson C. Huber of Wynnewood, was injured fatally, and her escort, Robert Morris, 23, of this city, was hurt seriously in a collision early today between a taxicab and the car in which they were riding.
PARIS, Sept. 25. -- The feeling of optimism and buoyancy continued on the Bourse today. Prices were well maintained in all departments in a fair amount of business.

With forty-five new students entering, the General Episcopal Theological Seminary in Ninth Avenue, near Twentieth Street, reopened yesterday for its 118th year. Thirty of the new men are in the junior class, while the fifteen others are transfer or graduate students.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 25. -- In corrugated seagoing to her liking. Crown Prince Olaf's Norwegian six-meter yacht Norna IV romped into first place today in the fourth race of the team match between Scandinavian and American boats.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during August, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 26. -- British shipping companies operating between the United States and Far Eastern ports are expected to join today in deciding to avoid the Red Sea and the Suez Canal and add about 2,000 miles to their journey by traveling around the Cape of Good Hope.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Federal Judges Oliver B. Dickinson of Philadelphia and John P. Nields of Wilmington today dismissed the bill of complaint filed by the principal railroads of the East against an Interstate Commerce Commission order fixing maximum rates on china clay, or kaolin, shipped from southern points to New England.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, Sept. 25. -- Sunday's elections in the Memel district, where the National Socialist urge for expansion into the Baltic region meets the bulwark of Lithuania's urge for survival, will he carried through according to the letter and spirit of the Memel autonomy statute, guaranteed by Great Britain, France and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Former President Hoover's friends definitely informed members of the Republican executive committee of the national committee today that he was not a candidate for the nomination for President next year. His sole interest in the party, as its titular leader, they declared, was to see the nomination of a standard bearer uncompromisingly opposed to New Deal policies and the adoption of an "anti-Socialistic platform."
Most of yesterday's buying and selling of real estate in the city was done by operators. The activity showed a demand for apartment houses over a wide area.

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- Five phases of the crime problem will be dealt with by judicial, social welfare, scientific and police authorities in the conference to fight crime which Governor Lehman will open here on Monday night. The Governor declared today that no vital part of the problem will be left untouched by speakers at the general sessions or participants in the round-table discussions.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 25. -- Testimony that thirty-five enlisted men from Fort Clayton had been treated for insanity between Dec. 11, 1934, and July 14, 1955, was admitted in the Federal District Court here today at the opening of the trial of Nelson Rounsevell, publisher of the Panama American, on charges of criminal libel.

TIENTSIN, China, Thursday, Sept. 26. -- "A new political set-up, politically as well as economically independent of Nanking, is necessary in North China," declared Major Gen. Hayao Tada, new commandant of the Japanese garrison in Tientsin, in an interview today with twenty Japanese correspondents.

What Philo Higley and Philip Dunning have accomplished in "Remember the Day," which opened at the National last evening, is more notable than what they have not accomplished. They have not arrived at any resolute conclusion; that is a pity, for it robs the play of significance and dismisses you from the theatre in a languid frame of mind.

The presence of the Polish motorship in our harbor -- a wandering bit of Poland attached for the moment to our shores -- gives us special occasion to recall gratefully the supreme gift of Poland to this planet -- the Copernican system. The name "America" was first put on the printed page in an introduction to the Cosmography of PTOLEMY printed in 1507 in St. Die in the French Vosges.

Nearly 1,000 vaudeville actors, managers, booking agents and friends of the theatre enthusiastically endorsed last night a resolution of the American Federation of Actors to request a conference with President Roosevelt to lay before him a plan to restore vaudeville to the theatre.

Following is the text of the report submitted to General Hugh S. Johnson by a committee headed by Colonel William J. Wilgus, appointed by the administrator to survey the WPA problem here and make recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission amended its rules today to provide that any issuer may incorporate, by reference in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933, any exhibits previously or concurrently filed with the commission as a part of another registration statement under that act, or as a part of any application for registration filed under the Securities Act of 1934.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 26. -- Abolition of the rationing system throughout the Soviet Union and a widespread decrease in bread and other food prices were decreed tonight by the Kremlin, the order to become effective Oct. 1.

Although General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, was not ready yesterday to make known his decision on the wages of skilled labor on WPA projects in this city, it was revealed that the trade unions in the construction field had won a substantial victory on the issue.

By an odd coincidence I was lunching in the Colonial Grill Room of the Thaddeus Stevens Hotel in Lancaster. Pa., when my eye fell on Mrs. Gertrude Chase Kreischer's letter in THE TIMES. It describes the sad estate of certain nice old ladies whose inherited railroad securities are not all they used to be.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa, from Bremen and Channel ports, will bring 1,832 passengers in today. They include Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, with Mrs. Welles; Mrs. Vincent Astor, Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York, and Victor F. Ridder, secretary of the Staats-Herold Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The smallest world wheat crop in thirteen years was forecast today by the Bureau of Agriculture Economics, which placed it at 330,000,000 bushels less than the short crop of 1934.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Acting Secretary Coondge announced today that the Treasury this week will borrow $100,000,000 on short-term bills, $50,000,000 in excess of refinancing needs.

The question of the safe limit of our public indebtedness has, so far, been answered in meaningless generalities by both politicians and financial writers. For obvious reasons we distrust the New Dealers' claim that the limit is far away, and we cannot believe in Republican warnings that the limit is close at hand.

The president of Colgate University is worried. "Nothing could threaten the race," he tells us, "as seriously as "social legislation. It is begging the "unfit to be more unfit and inviting "the fit to join the ranks of the unfit." The sins of the philanthropists are equaled only by those of the doctors, who have "done everything they could to keep the unfit" and to curb "nature's natural checks."

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The Boerse was firm today. Heavy industrial shares went higher, Gloeckner gaining 2 points. Potash issues were friendly. Machine stocks showed gains, Berlin-Karlsruhe improving 3/4 point. Electrical shares made notable upturns, Schuckert rising 2 3/4 points and Siemens 2.

The year 5695 in the ancient Hebrew calendar will end today at night-fall and the year 5696 will begin. The Jewish New Year will be observed by orthodox, conservative and reform congregations the world over.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 26. -- It is now clear that the arms embargo has been definitely broken and the Ethiopian Government expects a shipment of arms from Belgium any day.

TRENTON, Sept. 26. -- State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin's new system of distributing gross receipts taxes on gas and electric property among the municipalities on the basis of "plant capacity" rather than local assessments was declared illegal by the Supreme Court today.

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark, will return today for a visit to her home. She will arrive on the steamer Scanmall, which docks in Jersey City, accompanied by her daughter, Miss Helen R. Owen, and Miss Margaret Brenner, a friend.

The latest announcement from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer regarding its forthcoming production of "The Great Ziegfeld" is that Ann Pennington will appear as Ann Pennington. Another recent addition to the cast is Reginald Owen, who will impersonate the late impresario's manager.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 26. -- Miney Myerson, George W. Ogle's 5-year-old bay gelding, outfooted Happy Knot and a half a dozen others today to win the Portland claiming purse by a neck at Rockingham Park.

ALBANY, Sept. 26. -- The constitutionality of Section 114 of the Public Service Law was attacked in the Appellate Division, Third Department, today by the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company in a fight in an order of the Public Service Commission which required the Bronx company to reduce its schedules by 20 per cent and directed the Yonkers concern to reduce electric rates 6 per cent.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, says Joe Louis can be beaten.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday, but hedging pressure in the last hour closed quotations at losses of 3 to 5 points.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 27. -- Great Britain is sending a note to Washington during the coming week-end giving notice that Britain must regain her liberty to make considerable naval increases, according to The Daily Express. The newspaper observes that this is tantamount to denunciation of the Washington and London naval treaties.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 26. -- Ethiopia gave France permission today to send 180 French white troops into this country to guard the railroad from Addis Ababa to Jibuti, French Somaliland, Ethiopia's only rail outlet to the sea.

The business conduct committee of the Stock Exchange has not completed its inquiry into the recent rise and fall of the traction stocks, Charles R. Gay, president, said yesterday. There was no certainty, he added, when the investigation would end, nor was it certain whether its results would be made public or simply referred, if necessary, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A proposal for the construction of a permanent, municipally owned convention hall to be ready for use coincidentally with the opening of the projected New York World's Fair of 1939-40 was made yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York in announcing support and approval of the exposition project.

Wholesale and chain-store sales rose in August over the level of a year ago, but retail department store sales declined slightly, according to the monthly report on trade in this district published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The Prussian Confessional Synod today flatly refused the Hitler government's offer to capitulate and replace Dr. Ludwig Mueller, the Nazi Reichsbishop, with a directorate made up of opposition Protestant pastors.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were fairly firm in undertone in quiet trading today. British funds improved, receiving investment support. Foreign bonds were quiet. Home rail shares drooped, lacking support. International issues were dull.

Cardinal Hayes, with his personal suite and his escort of almost 250 lay representatives of archdiocesan organizations, is due to arrive in Hoboken at about 10 A.M. today, returning from the Cleveland Eucharistic Congress, to which he was the Legate of Pope Plus XI.
GIBRALTAR, Sept. 26. -- Despite alarming reports in the Spanish press of the danger of a gas attack against the famous Rock of Gibraltar, people here remain calm and go about business as usual.

Colonel George B. McClellan, former Mayor of New York, returned from Europe yesterday and vigorously defended Premier Mussolini's intended invasion of Ethiopia. He held that neither the United States nor Great Britain was in a position to criticize the Italian dictator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 25, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,477,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $13,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

One of the immediate lessons of the new ship Pilsudski is that it was built in an Italian shipyard, along with a sister ship that will soon be coming along. This brings up the question why the Italians, who are turning out such fine ships for themselves and for other countries, cannot stay at home and go on building ships for the world at large instead of traipsing off on dubious imperial adventures in Ethiopia.

At the head of this season's Shakespearean parade come Gladys Cooper and Philip Merivale, opening tonight at the Barrymore in "Othello," the first of their two-play repertory for Crosby Gaige. (The other is "Macbeth," which will be along on Oct. 7.) Kenneth MacKenna and Alexandra Carlisle are featured in the supporting cast, and Henry Herbert has directed, with settings by P. Dodd Ackerman.

Prices of commodity futures were generally steady here yesterday. Only cottonseed oil and cocoa lost ground. All grains except rye, tin, wool tops and rubber advanced in the cash markets while lard and cotton were lower.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Big Hank Greenberg, who studiously scans the batting and fielding averages of every club in the major leagues when he's not out at first base for Detroit, believes the Tigers have the best club in baseball -- the Chicago Cubs not excepted.

Lawson Purdy's timely protest against the growing disbelief in equality of rights for all mankind suggests the query: Is not the dispute over governmental interference with individual rights and liberties largely a matter of terminology?

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Corn was the speculative leader today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade as the result of an official forecast for heavy to killing frosts tonight over Iowa, Nebraska, the Dakotas, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Northern Michigan, while both Missouri and Kansas may have light to heavy frost.

Francis T. Ward of Clark Dodge Co. yesterday was elected chairman of the New York Group, Investment Bankers Association of America, at the annual meeting and luncheon of the organization at the Bankers Club. William J. Minsch of Minsch, Monell Co. was elected vice chairman and Hearn W. Streat of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation was elected secretary and treasurer.

In large packing cases, roofed over with heavy-gauge wire mesh, Mike and Melissa, two young bears from the Canadian Northwest, arrived at the Pennsylvania Station yesterday morning, travel-stained and touchy. They are gifts from Jasper National Park to the new Prospect Park Zoo, in Brooklyn, and were sent here by courtesy of Canadian National Railways and the Railway Express Agency.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The Whites defeated the Blacks, 9 -- 6, in a practice game staged at the conclusion of Princeton's football practice today. The Black team lined up with the first-string back field of Ken Sandbach, Gary LeVan, Homer Spofford and Captain Constable.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- The question of how long Premier Benito Mussolini, as a result of today's League of Nation's Council action, can be prevented from starting war without incurring League sanctions was a favorite topic of discussion tonight. Opinions differed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26. -- In a turbulent session, during which Representative Patman of Texas, author of the $2,400,000,000 "printing-press" Bonus Bill, was booed, the convention of the American Legion today again went on record for immediate payment of the bonus.

Two City College students, Meyer Rangell, vice president of the student council, and Meyer Schwartz, suspended at the close of last term for creating a disorder at the annual R.O.T.C. exercises in Lewisohn Stadium on May 29, were reinstated and placed on indefinite probation yesterday by the faculty-student discipline committee.

After declining for eight months, the outstanding volume of bankers' acceptances rose $916,665 in August to $321,807,411 on Aug. 31, according to the monthly survey report of the American Acceptance Council, issued yesterday. This total was $198,195,307 under the amount of acceptances outstanding at the end of August, 1934.

HERE, at last, is a trade edition of T.E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" (Doubleday, Doran, $5). It is, so we are assured, complete, unabridged, definitive. There should be no more reason for mystification. Yet the mystification about Lawrence remains; more than an Arab burnous hides this man from mortal eyes. After reading "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" one still asks "Why?"

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Taffy Volo, owned by R.J. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C. won the forty-sixth renewal of the Transylvania in the Grand Circuit meeting today after one of the hardest battles the event has seen in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Treasury announced today that it will redeem $8,424,000,000 of its outstanding gold clause bonds and notes at par and accrued interest at any time up to Jan. 1, thus opening a way for retirement of the last Federal securities carrying the gold payment promise.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26. -- Beseeching God for peace for the entire world, Pope Pius XI brought to a triumphant close the greatest convocation of American Catholics in recent years by broadcasting, his paternal apostolic benediction to the final ceremony of the seventh National Eucharistic Congress here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- A threat of Senate summons for any utility or other company refusing to give full information to the Senate Lobby Committee was expressed by Chairman Black today as new questionnaires were dispatched in a final effort to obtain voluntarily the data that are desired.

John N. Turner, former navy diver who has plunged many times for the Police Department, explored the muddy depths of Newtown Creek in Brooklyn for three hours yesterday in a futile search for two bags of jewels valued at about $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- A 36 per cent increase in the dollar volume of trading on all registered security exchanges during August over the total of the preceding month was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who was picked up in Perth Amboy yesterday as a fugitive from justice, was outmanoeuvred by the Federal authorities here today and instead of gaining his freedom on low bail was a prisoner tonight in Hudson County Jail in Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Charles G. Dawes, banker and economist, presented tonight a business man's "unexpected discovery" of a method of determining when a depression would end and he reiterated his widely published contention that the United States is on the road to recovery.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- While Captain Walter Hagen was giving his Ryder Cup players a double practice round over the Ridgewood Country Club course today, the British invaders enjoyed a day of comparative rest although the international matches are only two days away.
QUEBEC, Sept. 26. -- A severe attack of grip which settled in the bronchial tubes tonight held Harry K. Thaw in a Quebec hospital bed and halted his return to the United States. He is 66 years old.

VICTOR RIDDER, publisher of the Staats-Zeitung, is an excellent choice for successor to General JOHNSON as Works Progress Administrator of New York City. As president of the State Board of Social Welfare and a member of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, he is intimately familiar with the whole relief problem.

MEMEL, Sept. 26. -- The Lithuanian Government has taken extraordinary military and police precautions to make sure that the election of the Memel Diet, due Sunday, is carried through in peace and quiet and without any forceful intervention from across the German border.
