LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The official British reaction to today's proceedings of the League of Nations is that the Council is acting more quickly than was expected. The comment does not extend the comparison to the Council's unanimity and firmness, but that may safely be implied.

Large apartments in buildings on the East Side were taken yesterday in a continuance of the Fall renting rush. The demand for rooms was about equally divided between the East Side and the West Side. It extended, however, to other sections of the city and out into the suburbs.

The quiet advance in bond prices that characterized the market from the beginning of the week was checked yesterday and mild reactionary movements spread throughout the principal domestic groups, while foreign issues turned irregular to slightly easier.

Accompanied by her 15-year-old daughter, Elsa, and with thirty cold-storage ptarmigans to pass through the customs, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, Kirsten Flagstad, arrived from her native Norway yesterday on the Stavangerfjord.

The Port of New York Authority filed a brief yesterday with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce supporting the principle of port equalization as expressed in the new frieght tariffs of the intercoastal ship lines, which are scheduled to become effective next Thursday.

Loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $30,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday. Security loans were down $7,000,000, non-security loans up $31,000,000 and investments up $6,000,000.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 27. -- London's "unquenchable fire," steadily eating into a range of seven-story rubber and spirit warehouses on the Wapping Street waterfront, was still unbeaten at midnight after defying for thirty-two hours every fire float and engine that could bring a jet of water to bear on it.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 26. -- Keen competition marked the second day of the Bryn Mawr horse show today.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- Texts of the statements made before the League of Nations Council in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute today by Anthony Eden, British Minister for League Affairs, and by Premier Pierre Laval of France are as follows:

Retail trade throughout the country is approaching normal and faces the best Fall and Christmas holiday period in five years, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., said yesterday in an interview here. Sales volume during the last quarter of the year should top the 1934 figures by 15 per cent or more, he declared.

The followers of Henry George gathered yesterday in their tenth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker, made plans for spreading the tenets of the economist-philosopher, which, they believe, will solve the economic ills of the nation, and received reports of progress already made.
It took the Yankees a long time to get there, but they finally achieved their longest winning streak of the year as they turned back the Senators, 4 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Illinois Bell Telephone Company of Chicago in a statement filed today asked registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of $45,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, series B, due on Oct. 1, 1970.

COLT'S NECK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- A man said by the police to have been William A. Brady Jr., 35 years old, the New York theatrical producer and son of William A. Brady Sr., the producer, was burned to death this afternoon in a fire near here that destroyed the one-story bungalow of a friend, Miss Elise Chisholm.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company, a $700,000,000 organization, whose directing head, Howard C. Hopson, waged a bitter fight against the Utility Holding Company Bill during the last session of Congress, will be the subject here of a Federal grand jury inquiry.
PARIS, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Newspaper criticism of the Treasury's advertising campaign for its "baby bonds" shows a lack of knowledge of the securities, Acting Secretary T.J. Coolidge remarked today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26. -- The United States Government, through the medium of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be represented at the hearing tomorrow before Judge Coleman in the United States District Court here on the petition of trustees of the American States Public Service Company, it was learned today.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 26. -- George Wells of the Hopewell Valley Golf Club, playing in his first tournament as a member of the New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association, won the fourteenth annual championship of that group today with a thirty-six-hole total of 160.
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Lord Tweedsmuir, the new Governor General of Canada, said today that a fourth British empire was in the making. He told the Royal Empire Society at a farewell luncheon:

Admiral Isamu Takeshita, Lieut. Gen. H. Ninomiya and the three other representatives of the Japanese Ex-Servicemen's Association who are visiting New York on a good-will tour, were luncheon guests of the directors of the Japan Society yesterday at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Warren K. Billings charged today that he and Tom Mooney, sentenced to life terms for the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing in 1916, were "framed" by a private detective.

Plans for putting into practical use the recently developed means of sending facsimile weather charts and newspapers from shore to ships have been completed and machinery will be installed on four passenger liners within the next thirty days.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Frank J. Holleran, consistent Greenwich player who yesterday was runner-up in the third annual Green Meadow invitation tournament with a round of 86, today scored an 87 to take low-gross honors in the Women's Westchester Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition at Wykagyl.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26. -- Bad management, insufficient capital and excessive interest payments were branded as the three causes of savings banks' difficulties by Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, in his keynote address today at the opening session of the association's fortieth annual convention.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The Yale varsity worked on perfecting its precision and timing today, especially in passing, and spent half an hour practicing on kick-off. A practice game on Saturday is indicated as the only contact football of the week.

J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, who is attempting to restrain the Securities Exchange Commission from interfering with his activities, testified yesterday as a government witness at the trial in Federal Court of William H. Rabell a former commission investigator, who is accused of having solicited a bribe from him last June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Roosevelt tonight set in motion machinery for a new recovery drive which he hopes will rally labor, management and the public to the final victory over the depression.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Margaret Kerston, 15 years old, was operated on successfully at Perth Amboy General Hospital today for a ruptured appendix after her mother, who had hysterically refused medical aid for her daughter all night, finally was persuaded by a parish priest, physicians, the police chief, a social worker and neighbors that the girl would die unless surgical attention were obtained promptly.

The son of a famous producer and a favorite American star. William A. Brady Jr. was born to the theatre. From his birth in New York City in 1900, he was trained in the exacting Broadway school until, in his early twenties, he was not only theatre wise but ranked among the most brilliant of the younger producers.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Germany has given official written assurances that she will conform to the Olympic statutes against discrimination against race, color or creed during next year's Olympic Games. As further proof of this intention she has invited two Jewish women to become members of the German Olympic team.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- Statements made before the Council of the League of Nations today in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute by Henriques Ruiz Guinazu of Argentina, president of the Council, and Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, are as follows:

The volume of bank settlements continues heavy, the increase being well distributed throughout the country. Total clearings of the twenty-two principal cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,040,128,000, against $4,193,245,000 a year ago.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 26. -- The text of the radio address by Pope Pius to the Eucharistic Congress at Cleveland today was as follows:

Farrar Rinehart say that Frederick Wight's long novel, "South," is gaining its best press notices outside of New York City. The Chicago reviews are excellent, the publishers say, as are most of the Southern criticisms.

Plans for the annual period of registration of voters, which will begin Oct. 8, are being completed by the Board of Elections, it was announced yesterday. It is expected that about 1,600,000 voters will register, as against 1,977,000 last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- A jury in Westchester County Court, after five hours' deliberation tonight, found Peter Mohlsick and Howard Eichler, Peekskill youths, guilty of murder in the first degree. They were sentenced by County Judge Gerald Nolan to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison the week of Nov. 3.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge, who has been called the "fairy godmother of chamber music," was the guest of honor at a dinner given by 141 of her Berkshire friends at the Pittsfield Country Club tonight. Edwin T. Rice of New York and Stockbridge briefly expressed appreciation of Mrs. Coolidge's interest in the promotion of music in Berkshire County.

WESTPORT, Conn., Friday, Sept. 27. -- A fast east-bound freight train rammed the rear of a work train on the bridge over the Saugatuck River near here at 1:25 o'clock this morning, the wreckage bursting into flames and blocking all four tracks on the main line of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Returning to City Hall today, after a three-day absence, Mayor La Guardia will find the 1936 budget one of the chief problems awaiting him. The Mayor was in Washington for a talk with President Roosevelt Tuesday, and on the following day he went to St. Louis for the American Legion convention.

Offers from syndicates in Detroit and Chicago for a match featuring Joe Louis have been received, Mike Jacobs, promoter of the Twentieth Century S.C., revealed yesterday. These offers would match the Brown Bomber with James J. Braddock, Max Schmeling or any other suitable opponent.

Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., reported yesterday for the four months ended on Aug. 31 a net profit of $25,719 after depreciation, interest and Federal taxes. The earnings are equivalent to 89 cents a share on 28,780 no-par shares of $5 cumulative prior A stock, which will be outstanding after the exchange of 259 shares of old preferred stock not yet presented for exchange.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Princeton sport teams will meet fifty-four opponents this Fall, according to the complete program announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. Competition in the intercollegiate cross-country championships also is listed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26. -- This is the year of the new deal in football at Harvard, the stronghold of conservatism and tradition, and searching inquiry about the premises flails to reveal the faintest bit of dissatisfaction with the way the experiment is working out.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 26. -- A jury that debated for nearly four hours tonight returned a verdict of "no cause for action" in a suit brought in the Federal court here by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia against Ocean City, N.J.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26. -- Meeting under the slogan "Unite the young generation of toilers of the entire world around the banner of the Communist International," several hundred delegates, including Gil Green, secretary of the American Young Communist League, gathered last night at the opening session of the sixth World Congress of International Youth in Moscow's House of Trade Unions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Following are the Treasury gold clause securities outstanding and covered by the redemption offer made today:

Still in the throes of indecision, the share market fluctuated narrowly yesterday in continued slow trading; the closing was irregular, and by a close count prices could be shown to have declined slightly, with more than 25 per cent of the issues that were active holding unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Substantial reductions in processing tax rates on most types of tobacco for the marketing year, 1935-36 are provided in new regulations issued today by Secretary Wallace with the approval of President Roosevelt.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on an application by Franklin P. Ferguson on behalf of Adolf Gobel, Inc., for permission to sell its wholly owned subsidiary, Jacob Decker Son, of Mason City, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Roosevelt took into his own hands today the troublesome problem created by prison-made goods in competition with private industry, setting up an agency for the purpose of eventually reorganizing the entire system of prison industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is giving the Federal Communications Commission only perfunctory cooperation in its $750,000 investigation of the system which Congress ordered last March, Commissioner Paul Walker charged today.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26. -- The Argentine aviator, Francisco Aroza, flew head down for four hours and thirty minutes this morning, beating the world record of Milo Burcham, an American, by twenty-four minutes and thirty-eight seconds. Burcham will remain the recognized recordholder, however, because Aroza's flight was not controlled by the International Aeronautic Federation.
Your issue of Monday, Sept. 9, contained an editorial entitled "Realistic Housing."

The symphony orchestra of the American Ballet will present a group of new American compositions during the tour of the organization this Fall. The works to be performed will be chosen through a nation-wide competition to be conducted by the management of the ballet, it was announced yesterday by Alexander Merovitch, president of Musical Art Management and manager of the American Ballet.

Heavy imports of gold and disbursements by the Treasury lifted the reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System $100,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly report of the system, published yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Miss Patricia Cramer, discharged employe of Local 1733, Federation of Dyers, Printers, Finishers and Bleachers of America, continued picketing the union's office today with the assistance of two other girls.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Gold Foam, winner of the Travers Stakes for E.J. Benjamin's Starmount Stable of New Orleans, but a disappointment in the Potomac Handicap, carried his speed for a mile and seventy yards today to defeat three other high-class 3-year-olds in the Roseland Purse at Havre de Grace.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 26. -- Even in circles close to the government the news given out today that Premier Julius Goemboes was leaving for Germany for an indefinite stay -- to extend at least over the week-end -- in order to visit General Hermann Goering, Air Minister, and meet Chancellor Hitler came as a bombshell.
Columbia had its second scrimmage of the week yesterday at Baker Field, a two-hour drill with the City College squad. On Tuesday the Lions engaged Manhattan.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 26. -- For the third successive year Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of White Beeches and Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring are in the final for the women's New Jersey golf championship.

Mid Victorian, making her first start since the sport at Saratoga, raced gamely and well in the featured Inwood purse at Jamaica yesterday to survive a nose finish which had the form players hanging on the ropes until the judges posted the number of the favorite.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Continued small receipts of hogs here, today's arrivals of 5,500 head establishing a new all-time record low for a Thursday, and only 3,000 head expected tomorrow, failed to check the downward trend in the price of hogs.

The WPA program of unemployment relief, on which the Federal Government is spending $5,000,000 a week, is the "most expensive kind of relief that could be devised," "extravagant," "wasteful" and "inefficient," General Hugh S. Johnson, works progress administrator, declared yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the Advertising Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- On the eve of his departure for the West, President Roosevelt approved today the allotment and expenditure of $321,588,412 of Federal funds for work relief. Of this total, $21,256,375 is for WPA projects in nineteen States, $200,139,037 for the PWA construction program and $100,193,000 for the government housing program.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Sept. 21 showed an increase of 20 per cent, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figures declined somewhat from the increase reported for the previous week, when the deliveries, made for 250 stores in the metropolitan and suburban areas, rose 26 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- An aggressive campaign to gather the youth of the country into the Republican fold, with the argument that eventually they would have to pay for "the wasteful extravagance of the New Deal administration," was decided upon at the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee yesterday, it was announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- With one of the scheduled races postponed by agreement among the four skippers, the United States dinghy sailing team increased its lead today over Great Britain in the series being conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club in the North American Dinghy Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- As the first foreign government to comply with the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Act governing the listing of securities, Argentina presented today to the SEC an application for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $241,500,000 of its bonds already outstanding.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. The American Ballet, the successful domestic dance group engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Association after its introductory appearance in New York last season, will give its Westchester premiere performance on Saturday night at the County Centre.

For the past week there has been a steady gain in the volume of fish taken by patrons of open and charter boats at Montauk, according to officials of the fishing information bureau of the Long Island Railroad. They report the peak was reached last Sunday, with an average catch of fifty sea bass, porgies and blackfish.

Dahlia blooms from the Eastern seaboard, produced under ideal weather conditions for this type of Autumn flower, favorably withstood comparison with Western varieties sent by airplane for display yesterday at the opening of the annual show of the American Dahlia Society in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The show will close this evening.

Despite a tendency of live stock and meat prices to weaken, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced to 128.4 on Tuesday from 127.9 (revised) the Tuesday previous and is now the highest since June 10, 1930.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- The League of Nations Council reluctantly, but not irresolutely, started to cross the Rubicon today. Before a crowded, silent hall it unanimously agreed in Italy's absence to these proposals of its President:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Tribunal raced to victory in the mile and a quarter event for 3-year-olds and up, feature of the closing program of running races at the Trenton Fair half-mile track today. With McCarthy up, the bay gelding ran the distance in 2:17 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Postoffice Department announced today an air-mail agreement with Pan-American Airways, Inc., and Pan-American-Grace Airways, Inc., which "will result in an annual saving to the government of approximately $1,000,000 as compared with the mail pay to these companies on July 11, 1934," or about 15 per cent.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 26. -- Emperor Haile Selassie is counting heavily on the American people's moral if not official support of sanctions against Italy, he told this correspondent. He expressed doubt whether the United States would be able to remain neutral in the event of a European conflict.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Roosevelt has given assurances to organized government workers that jobs in the various New Deal agencies will be placed under civil service as soon as the Civil Service Commission can bring up its register to meet the requirements.

NEWBURGH, Sept. 26. -- Defeat of the county home rule amendment at the November election would be an admission that "our democratic form of government is crumbling and that our people are growing entirely subservient to selfish local dictatorships," Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, said today in a speech before the Orange County League of Women Voters at Cornwall.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- Negotiations were advanced today between Russia and Rumania for a pact of mutual assistance along the lines of the agreements the Soviet Union has formed with France and Czechoslovakia. Dr. Nicolas Titulescu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, will go to Moscow soon to sign it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- President Roosevelt turned a cold shoulder to the radical wing of the Congressional "silver bloc" today with unmistakable evidence of his purpose not to disturb the present silver purchase policy of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Following are the details of allotments made today in New York State under the programs of the Works Progress Administration, the Public Works Administration and the Government Housing Board:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- A "striking improvement in real estate and home financing conditions" was reported today by John H. Fahey, Chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, after a nation-wide survey. He said the corporation's foreclosure proceedings, which now number 1,614, may reach 5,000 in the next year, but this would represent a small percentage of the loans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The joint conference of miners and operators presenting the Appalachian area late tonight ratified the terms for a settlement of the strike of 400,000 bituminous mine workers as drafted by subcommittees.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26. -- Rainfall, as steady as the march of the carefree Chicago Cubs, washed out Charlie Grimm's plans to clinch the National League pennant today and gave the four-down-and-four-to-go St. Louis Cardinals a merciful rest for a final double-header rally tomorrow.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26. -- The North Mianus Garden Club, a project of the Greenwich Branch of the New York Junior League, held its first flower show tonight in the Recreation Centre, North Mianus. About a hundred persons were present.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada showed an increase of $11,283,341 in the week ended on Sept. 25, according to the weekly statement issued today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $2,870,515.

Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, announced yesterday in behalf of Cardinal Hayes the transfer of many priests in Manhattan, the Bronx, Richmond and the rural section of the Archdiocese to different parishes.

J.P. Morgan Co., representing the committee of banks, has been notified by Controller Frank J. Taylor that this city will issue on Monday $20,000,000 of revenue bills, against which are pledged the second half of the taxes for 1935. The bills, 2 1/2 per cents, are to be redeemed on or before Dec. 31 next.

The amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange empowering the committee on admissions to allot floor alternates to governors of the Exchange engaged on official business was carried only by the narrowest of margins, the Exchange disclosed yesterday.

No matter how it is told, a story of inhuman treachery is horrifying and calls for merciless revenge. That is the sort of story disclosed in "Paths of Glory," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. Humphrey Cobb first told it in the novel that bears the same title.

ALEXANDRIA, Sept. 26. -- The Public Security Department of the Egyptian Government is secretly engaged in working out detailed plans for the organization of public security throughout the country and anticipating all possible eventualities.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

With two teams ready for action on a shock troop basis, Manhattan's football squad will make its second start of the season tonight at Ebbets Field against a formidable St. Bonaventure eleven. The game, it has been announced by Brother Anselm, director of athletics, will be played even if it rains, starting at 8:30 o'clock.
A chronology of the President's comments on NRA since the Supreme Court decision of last May shows an unmistakable trend:

Metropolitan Realty Holdings, Inc., Isidore Wolff, president, through a subsidiary, the Dorsey Realty Syndicate, Inc., leased for a long term a plot fronting 135 feet on Journal Square, adjoining Loew's Theatre, Jersey City. A three-story building with eight or ten stores, in addition to showrooms and offices above, will be erected on the site.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Scandinavia, with its trio of Norwegian, Swedish and Danish 6-meter yachts, today captured the international match against boats from this country. The final score was Scandinavia, 54 1/2 points; United States, 50 3/4.

Kenneth F. Simpson, newly elected Republican County Chairman, took over the party reins yesterday, and found himself confronted with the difficult task of restoring harmony to an organization shot through and through with bitterness and personal grudges.

Details of salaries of executives, the names of important stockholders and the amounts paid in brokerage and other fees by fifteen general-management investment trusts listed on the New York Stock Exchange are contained in registration statements which the trusts have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The ship lines operating from Atlantic coast ports in the deep-sea trades accepted yesterday the recommendations of a committee that the terms of a settlement with the International Longshoremen's Association be accepted and a new wage contract signed for the coming year.

Public operation of electric plants may result in substantial profits and yet fail to bring to consumers the rate reductions to which they are entitled, according to testimony heard yesterday by the joint legislative committee investigating public utilities throughout the State.
WILDER, Idaho, Sept. 26 (AP). -- To Senator William E. Borah the League of Nations has become only "a screen for the hypocrites who are trying to divide the territory of Europe."

For an organization that has many times been pronounced "dead," the League of Nations is showing itself very much alive. Its action yesterday is the boldest and most significant ever taken by it. By a unanimous vote of the Council -- Italy, of course, not voting -- it was decided, with great solemnity, to proceed in the future under Article XV of the Covenant.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

FLOURISHING a fresh cigar, Herr Joe Jacobs says that his Larruping Landsmann, Herr Max Schmeling, is just yearning for a chance to get in the ring with Shufflin' Joe Louis. Rather odd, at that. A few months ago Herr Schmeling turned up his Teutonic nose at the chance.

The franc fell yesterday to approximately its gold-import point, and continued weakness in the foreign exchange market registered the persistence of the capital flight from Europe to this country. The franc lost 1/2 point, carrying it to 6.59 cents.
ROME, Sept. 26. -- The decisions reached at Geneva today were received with mixed feelings in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Wholesale commodity prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent last week, reaching a new high for the year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Victory in this year's Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup polo tournament, most important of the handicap events of the year, lies between Templeton and Greentree.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- John B. Kelly, Democratic nominee for Mayor, won the support today of a second unsuccessful candidate for the Republican Mayoralty nomination.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Eyes of political leaders turned westward tonight, along the trail of President Roosevelt in his trip across the continent.

Every person who won or lost a wager on the Louis-Baer prizefight last Tuesday night became a criminal and is technically subject to prosecution, according to an editorial appearing in today's issue of The New York Law Journal. The editorial, entitled "Pugilism 'Knocks Out' the Law," calls attention to outmoded statutes, both State and Federal, and urges that such laws, counter to public sentiment, be repealed.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Screams that shattered the quiet on Lake Singletary on the night when, according to the Commonwealth, Newell P. Sherman, scoutmaster, drowned his wife, were described today at his trial for murder.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was featured by transactions in which the purchasers of houses announced plans for modernizing the properties.

Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock and called for redemption on Dec. 1, at 101 and accrued interest, the company's entire funded debt approximating $20,000,000 of debentures which mature on June 1, 1939.

Many explanations are put forward for the deposition of Mr. CHASE MELLEN Jr. from Mr. KOENIG'S ancient throne and the accession of Mr. KENNETH SIMPSON to that siege perilous. Mr. MELLEN is said to have acquired demerit by his encouragement, finally withdrawn, of another sovereign out of business, former Chairman MACY.

At least seventy-nine fresh vegetable dinners were served last night to needy families living near Seward Park, because yesterday afternoon was harvest time for the children in the Farming Clubs of the Educational Alliance, with headquarters opposite the park at Jefferson Street and East Broadway.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26. -- The State of Maryland today won priority in claims against two Maryland public utility corporations which are in process of reorganization under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Following is the text of the questionnaire sent to utility companies by the Senate Special Committee investigating lobbying activities:

CATSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Alfred E. Volckmann, 20-year-old butcher boy charged with the "thrill slaying" of a minister's daughter, pleaded not guilty to a murder indictment today and paled as court room spectators hissed.

Following is the new wage scale for skilled and intermediate employes on WPA projects announced yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator. The wages to be paid will be for sixty hours of work.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP). -- An alleged confession by 19-year-old Leroy Drake, a frail, junior college student, led police today to the bodies of his uncle and aunt in a motor car at the bottom of the harbor, thirty-five feet below the surface.

Eight Manhattan properties, including a twelve-story apartment house on a Riverside Drive corner, were bought in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday. In addition to the flat, the other improvements consisted of a dwelling, various tenements and a vacant parcel on West Street.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Public Service Commission disapproved today inter-company loans among the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the People's Natural Gas Company and the Columbia Natural Gas Company and ordered the money repaid.

The business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange has completed the investigation of trading in local traction issues requested by Adolf A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, without discovering any infractions of the regulations of the Exchange or the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was reported in Wall Street yesterday.

Your editorial "A Time of Hesitation" must give pause to every one who reads it, and in these days of turmoil and distress it inevitably raises the question how much of this turmoil is due to the general breaches of faith that have become almost fashionable, so that confidence no longer exists.

After a triumphant visit here on her maiden voyage the Gdynia-America liner Pilsudski will depart tonight for Poland. Her list includes Adam Koc, Vice Minister of the Treasury; Sea Bishop Stanislaw Okoniewski; General Gustav Orlicz-Dreszec, president of the Overseas and Colonial League, and Stefan Lenartowicz, Director of Council of Poles Living Abroad.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The Marshall Field Co. merchandise express returns from its fourth and final 1935 tour early Sunday morning, with over 60,000 individual merchandise orders, valued at $1,500,000, to its credit since first leaving Chicago early in June.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Grover A. Whalen Jr., the 14-year-old son of New York City's former Police Commissioner, was to have gone back to school this morning. Instead, he casually wandered off into the woods near his father's residence here, and for a frantic few hours several hundred persons, including local police and State troopers, searched for him.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Jubilant Charley Grimm, pilot of the new champion Cubs, slapped his happy players on the back and showered them with excited congratulations today after they had won the pennant, then ordered Pitchers Bill Lee, Charlie Root, Lonnie Warneke and Catcher Gabby Hartnett back to Chicago to rest for the world series with the Tigers.

Business conditions in the trading areas surrounding seven principal Eastern cities are between 10 and 15 per cent better than a year ago, with the outlook for the next few months one of constant improvement, according to opinions expressed by credit men yesterday meeting at the National Association of Credit Men.

" Red Salute," Reliance's first production for the new season to be released by United Artists, goes on exhibition this morning at the Rivoli. Also on the new bill is the second film edition of Major Bowes's "Amateur Theatre of the Air."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Efforts of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to remove the New York Central Railroad from the "embarrassing position" of having $69,000,000 of bank loans outstanding on a "demand" basis while, at the same time, advancing the status of its loans to the road will be renewed on Monday, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, made known today.

POTOSI, Mo., Sept. 27. -- Richard Freeze, 23-year-old Joliet, Ill., gas station attendant, was in jail here today, twice wounded by town vigilantes who frustrated his attempt to hold up the Bank of Irontown after the cashier had surreptitiously set off an alarm.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Stephen A. Wilson calls attention to a law passed in the State of Georgia in 1923 requiring the teaching of the Constitution of the United States in all schools and colleges sustained or supported by public funds, and suggests that it would be well for some of the other States to enact similar legislation.

The trading in commodity futures here yesterday was quiet, the only activity appearing in sugar, where the spot price was at a new high level. In the cash markets all commodities were lower except wheat and tin.
The entrance of our government into the housing field seems to be following the traditional incompetency, inefficiency and wastefulness characteristic of many other forms of governmental enterprise.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company was placed under Federal court juristion today pending reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

Application will be made to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by Frederick V. Goess, receiver for the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, for a loan sufficient to pay a dividend of 10 per cent to depositors of the bank.

GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- The United States can cooperate under the Neutrality Act actively or passively in five out of six possible non-military sanctions in the event of the League of Nations applying them to Italy, the Geneva Research Centre; an American organization, declared today in a report on "American neutrality and collective security."

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 27 (AP). -- New Haven Railroad officials directed their attention tonight to clearing away a mass of battered cars and twisted steel on the Westport drawbridge, the result of a crash between two freight trains in which an engineer was killed and three members of the crews injured.

Of $580,000,000 authorized to stimulate credit in industry, only about $155,000,000 has been lent by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Federal Reserve banks one year after the authorization, according to a survey by the Associated Business Papers, Inc., and the National Conference of Business Paper Editors.

Three sections of Queens Boulevard, the main traffic artery through Queens, which have annoyed motorists for several years will be repaved next month as a Works Progress Administration project to cost $1,500,000, it was announced yesterday by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens.

KENOSHA, Wis., Sept. 27. -Marked similarity between the letter sent this week by President Roosevelt to clergymen and the one sent by Governor La Follette of Wisconsin to clergymen in this State on March 5 was noted here today as a result of a comparison brought about by a Kenosha minister.

A crowd of 18,000 watched the Manhattan College eleven play some wide-awake football last night under the floodlights at Ebbets Field in conquering a stubborn St. Bonaventure College team, 32 to 13. It was the Jaspers' second straight victory.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27. -- Confident that the bonus question would be finally settled early in the January session of Congress, nearly a quarter-million World War veterans who attended the seventeenth annual convention of the American Legion were on the way home today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Commissions paid for the buying and selling of securities are not ordinary business expenditures and cannot be handed as such on income tax returns filed by brokers, dealers or the public, the Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today.
A silencing program in the early morning milk delivery will be started by the Borden's Farm Products Company on Monday, Harry A. Cronk, president of the concern said yesterday.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 27. -County authorities were convinced today of the identification of William A. Brady Jr., 35-year-old New York theatrical producer, who died yesterday in a bungalow fire. His father, the producer, came here today and arranged for the funeral.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Miss Cynthia Clews Wrightson, accomplished young equestrienne of Orange and a veteran exhibitor in the show ring, experienced a great deal of success today with her graceful 7-year-old chestnut mare, Lady Mary, as competition in the tenth annual two-day Montclair Horse Show started.

After filling of a quantity of December buying limits at 10.55 cents a pound on Thursday, hedging operations supplied sufficient contracts to fill an accumulation of orders at 10.50 cents yesterday, so that prices on the Cotton Exchange moved off to a loss of 4 to 6 points.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The pace of business continued to slacken today on the London Stock Exchange. British Government securities declined fractionally and industrials were generally easier. Exceptions to the ruling weakness were brewery building and nickel shares.

TOKYO, Sept. 27. -- Japanese warships today circled the area in the northwest Pacific where fifty-two officers and men were swept from the decks of sister ships when a typhoon pounded the fleet during its war manoeuvres, but scant hope was held for the bodies' recovery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Industry and trade in France continued at a low level in August with no evidence of greater freedom in making purchases, according to the Commerce Department today in its weekly review of foreign business conditions, based on reports from its commercial attaches abroad.
The labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in August, issued this week, compares with preceding months and years, with the three-year average of 1923-25 taken as 100, as follows:

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 27. -- The Demara, or parade day of the feast of Maskal, the traditional festival marking the end of the rainy season, began in Addis Ababa today on the fourth successive day of almost unbroken dryness. The wind, settling into the north, at last found its true quarter this morning when the earliest swallows, presages of the dry season, arrived.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Cassius M. McDonald, who for years has maintained a fine residence in one of Detroit's fashionable suburbs, sat in a jail cell here tonight on a charge that he arranged for disposal of $72,000 of the $200,000 ransom money paid to the kidnappers of Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL EN ROUTE TO CALIFORNIA, Sept. 27. -- A pledge to maintain the proportionate naval strength of the United States in relation to world armaments, by treaty if possible but under all circumstances, was given by President Roosevelt today.

An international program was staged by the delegates to the tenth annual Henry George Congress at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. Speeches were made by delegates from Denmark and England, and greetings were received from many foreign countries, including one from Viscount Philip Snowden, former Chancellor of the Exchequer of Great Britain.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The Prussian Confessional Synod today adopted resolutions condemning both the principles of State supremacy in the Protestant Church and government's recent decrees calculated to establish it. The same synod yesterday rejected the government's offer to replace Dr. Ludwig Mueller, Nazi Reich Bishop, with an officially appointed directorate made up of some of the synod's own leaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The finance committee of the Cook County Board has begun consideration of new plans for refunding the county's $42,000,000 of bonded debt. The committee received four plans, one of which was presented by Clayton F. Smith, president of the County Board.

Outside of the masters, submasters, tutors and ushers in the innumerable alphabetical compartments of the Federal Government, is there a busier knot of simpler minds than those of the executive committee of the National Republican Committee? Both political parties are always trying to pull into their tents the youth of our land.

After telling Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday that the 1936 budget would conform with the $539,695,777 limit set by Mr. Taylor, Mayor La Guardia went into deep seclusion with the task of cutting $42,459,900 from the departmental estimates for next year.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 27. -The frenzied political manoeuvring which followed the assassination of Senator Long has served to obscure an investigation which is being conducted into his murder, but a high authority of the State administration said today that every effort is being made to prove that he was killed by plotters who used Dr. Carl A. Weiss Jr. as a tool.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27. -- Social insurance never can be a substitute for individual initiative and saving, Dr. Harold Stonier, educational director of the American Bankers Association, asserted here today at the closing session of the fortieth annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

By winning the first game of their double-header with the Cardinals in St. Louis yesterday, 6 to 2, the Chicago Cubs clinched the National League pennant. They also won the second game from the dethroned world champions, 5 to 3, and thereby extended their amazing winning streak to twenty-one consecutive victories.

A concert will be given Monday evening at the Riverside Baptist Church under the auspices of the newly organized Music Committee of the Youth's Division of the Greater New York Federation of Churches. Announced to appear are Frances Barnett, soprano; Edward Karnikian, bass-baritone; Broadus Staley, pianist, and a string trio consisting of Eugenia Limberg, Betty Barbour and Virginia Duffey.

Thirteen new cases of infantile paralysis were reported to the Health Department during the last twenty-four hours, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Four were in Manhattan, four in Brooklyn, two in the Bronx and three in Queens.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Department store sales in the Seventh Federal Reserve District in August rose more than seasonally over July, retail shoe trade gained sharply, and furniture, house furnishings and chain-store sales recorded normal improvement, the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Forty issues of municipal and similar securities aggregating $6,002,500 and including one of $2,756,000 of bonds of Newark, N.J., were offered today for sale by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- A strong trend toward granting Ethiopia's request that impartial observers be sent to her frontiers to guard against incidents developed today in the first meeting of the League of Nations Council sitting as a committee of the whole minus Italy and Ethiopia.
Residential properties in three boroughs were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Counsel seeking the release of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer received a double setback today when Federal Judge William Clark not only overruled their motions to reduce Schultz's bail from $75,000 to $25,000 but refused as well to allow the $60,000 in property bail offered by bondsmen as an instalment for Schultz's release.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Temple University, twice behind during a thrilling football game, battled its way to the front against Centre College tonight, beating the Kentuckians, 25 to 13, before a crowd of 15,000 at the Owls' stadium.

During the Roosevelt Administration there have been few additions to the forces composing the permanent establishment of the Federal Government, largely under civil service. But the various "emergency" agencies have sprouted like mushrooms, offering an enormous feast to the spoilsmen.

H. Spencer Auguste gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Henry C. Dickens of London, grandson of the late Charles Dickens, and his daughter, Miss Monica Dickens, the author. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. White 3d of Philadelphia and Mrs. L. Clark Winter.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27. -- The first test of the constitutionality of the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utility Holding Companies Act, which was enacted slightly more than a month ago, got under way in the last hours today of a seven-hour hearing before Judge William C. Coleman of Federal District Court.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday the suspension until Nov. 28 of the new rates of the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system for auxiliary and breakdown service. At the same time it extended until Jan. 1, 1936, the effective date of the schedules on conjunctional billing.

MEMEL, Sept. 27. -- It became certain today that the election to the Memel Diet Sunday would take place under the eyes of diplomatic representatives of Britain, France and Italy, the three European guarantors of the Memel autonomy convention, and under the scrutiny of more than a score of press representatives from all parts of the world.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 27. -- Miss Sylva Annenberg of Lakeville today teamed with Donald O'Brien of Fox Hills and led home a field of eighty-eight teams in the annual invitation two-ball golf tournament of the Piping Rock Club with a 74.

Auctioneers handled a large volume of foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Thirteen properties in the former borough and four in the latter were put up for bidding, all being struck down to the plaintiffs who instituted the court actions.

For the first time since March 17, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, will preach tomorrow. He has entirely recovered his health. Hereafter he will preach, administer his church and lecture at Union Theological Seminary.
In THE TIMES of Sept. 19, under the caption "Our Position in the World," Hyacinthe Ringrose ably discussed our "innocuous desuetude" in constructive efforts to maintain world peace.

Dapper Don Collins, known to the police as the Beau Brummell of confidence men, stood in Federal court yesterday morning collarless and unkempt, having passed the night in the Federal House of Detention.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 27. -- The fourth annual Autumn Horse Show of the Byram River Beagle Club will be held at the show ring of the club on Riversville Road, Greenwich, tomorrow, starting at 9:30 A.M.

BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- The Giants and the Braves split their doubleheader today, the Braves taking the first game by 6 to 4, and losing the second, 8 to 5. The Giants were helpless against Frankhouse for seven innings in the curtain-raiser, but made a threat in the eighth.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27. (AP). -- Republicans of the Eighth Judicial District today nominated Justice Harley N. Crosby of Falconer and William J. Hickey and Frank A. James, both of Buffalo, as candidates for Supreme Court Justices.
BERLIN, Sept 27. -- The Boerse was inactive and mixed, with a considerable tendency toward weakness. Losses of 1/4 to 1/2 point were common after a firm opening.

The foreign exchanges continued under pressure yesterday and the flow of gold from Europe increased. New engagements of gold for shipment here amounted to $11,800,000, of which $8,100,000 was taken in France, $3,000,000 in Holland and $700,000 in India.

Now is the time for those religious leaders of New York City who have imagination to begin making plans for showing the far-reaching influences of religion upon civilization at the coming New York World's Fair in a manner that will equal the greatness of the opportunity.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 27. -On a table outside the Ridgewood Country Club, guarded by a stalwart New Jersey policeman, reposes a small golden goblet known as the Ryder Cup.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- From official quarters, both British and American, there came emphatic denials today of last night's report that Great Britain was about to send a note to the United States invoking the "escalator clause" of the London Treaty and announcing her intention to expand her navy.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 27. -- With eight deputy sheriffs swearing that their fusillade was entirely in self-defense, and with as many eye-witnesses insisting the contrary, the fatal shooting yesterday of Mrs. Sophie Crempa approached today the status of a cause celebre.

The nomination of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora by the Republican First Judicial District convention Thursday night was attacked yesterday by former Assistant District Attorney Alexander Rorke as "the completion of the first stage of a political agreement" far worse than "judiciary deals of the past."

The night clubs, the supper clubs, hotels, restaurants, dance parlors and all the rest next week will reach the proper pitch of enthusiasm for the Fall. A score or more are removing Summer's webbing from the doors or are changing their bills in honor of the new season.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday remained in the doldrums of the day previous as prices fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits. Few movements worthy of mention developed, with the market generally reflecting a lack of interest.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 27. -- A year ago Earl Blaik arrived on the Dartmouth campus from West Point to be welcomed by an enthusiastic undergraduate body as the man who would bring about the long-awaited renaissance in the Green's football fortunes.

GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- Representatives of Britain, France and Italy said today that those powers had presented identical notes to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler asking the German Government for assurance of its contribution to tranquility in Memel Territory.

Doubleday, Doran reports that its first edition of 25,000 copies of T.E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" was exhausted before the date of publication. A second edition of 10,000 copies has been ordered.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 27. --Mrs. Florence B. Ilch's champion collie Lucason of Ashtead o'Bellhaven, which for the last three years has been judged the best collie exhibited at Madison Square Garden, New York, performed the greatest feat of his seven-year career today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27. -- Hang up the warning signs in the Detroit jungleland. The rampaging Cubs are on their way with leveled sights that seem as if they can't miss.

While higher temperatures in many parts of the country slackened the rate of merchandise movements to some extent this week, the general progressive trend was not altered to any substantial degree, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

About 2,000,000 Jews in the New York area gathered in their synagogues and temples at sundown last night to usher in the year 5696 of the Jewish calendar with age-old prayers and ancient ceremonials, marking the beginning of a ten-day period of spiritual stock-taking which closes on Oct. 7 with Yom Kippur, twenty-four-hour period of fasting and prayer.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- Three of the four guarantors of the Memel autonomy -- Britain, France and Italy -today gave fresh assurances to the German Foreign Office of their determination to vouchsafe the German voters in Memel Territory a free and unobstructed election on Sunday.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, the mother of the President, who recently celebrated her eighty-first birthday, came here from Hyde Park yesterday to present prizes to children at the annual harvest day festival at the children's gardens. The gardens, located on land provided by the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, Sixty-fourth to Sixty-seventh Street at York Avenue, are maintained by the New York Plant and Flower Guild, of which Mrs. Roosevelt is president.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP). -- No sooner had the news flashed through Chicago that the Cubs had clinched the championship today than a wild scramble to get world series tickets started.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Small receipts of hogs, with only 1,600 head offered for sale here today after deducting the 1,400 head direct to packers from the total of 3,000 posted for the day, was without effect in halting the downward trend in the market.

Control of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company and the adjoining Virginia Public Service Company by the Associated Gas and Electric System through acquisition from the Chase National Bank of their entire outstanding common and capital stocks was announced last night by Associated Gas.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27. -- In a luncheon party for Great Barrington horse show judges at the Berkshire Inn today were J. Macy Willets, Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Partridge, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Chase and Miss Clara van Lennep, chairman and secretary of the horse show committee.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 27. -- A swift advance of seventy-two yards on ten plays as the second half opened gave Bucknell a victory, 7 to 0, over Pennsylvania Military College tonight before a crowd of 4,000 at the Bisons' opening football game.
The contest for control of the Madison Square Garden management was won late yesterday afternoon by Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Garden Corporation.

Philip Merivale and his colleagues have taken Shakespeare at his word in the revival of "Othello," which was put on at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. Under Henry Herbert's informed direction they have told the familiar story of jealousy and murder, and, for the most part, they have told it honestly.

The French pioneer priest, Father ALLOUEZ, in the midst of his reports of baptisms and masses tells of nuggets and rocks containing valuable metals which he found in the course of his missionary journey in the seventeenth century among the Indians out on the shores of Lake Superior.

Following custom, Yiddish theatres throughout the country officially open their season today, the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah. In New York eleven companies will offer their first productions, four being on Second Avenue, Manhattan.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 27. -- A resolution condemning compulsory automobile insurance as increasing accidents was adopted by the National Association of Insurance Agents at the final session of its annual convention here today.

East Side rentals accounted for a large percentage of the apartment activity reported yesterday. Among the lessees was John Charles Thomas, singer, who took a penthouse apartment in the Hotel Berkshire, 21 East Fifty-second Street, through Albert M. Greenfield Co.

By bringing their sensational pennant bid to a successful conclusion yesterday Charlie Grimm's Cubs gave Chicago its fourteenth National League championship, a record which surpasses that of any other city in either of the two major leagues.

The French Government has notified holders of its twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent bonds, payable on April 1, 1937, that the Oct. 1, 1935, coupons, payable at J.P. Morgan Co., are also payable at Caisse Centrale du Tresor Publique in Paris at the rate of 25.5171122 francs to the dollar.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Nine men, one of them a Federal agent, and officers of a trucking company stood indicted tonight on charges of conspiracy to divert 100,000 gallons of alcohol and defraud the government of $500,000 taxes in one of the largest plots of its kind since repeal of prohibition.

With an array of sophomore talent which augurs well for the future, the Fordham football team will open another chapter in its gridiron history today. The Maroon eleven will take the field against Franklin and Marshall College at the Polo Grounds, starting at 2:30 P.M.

Large crowds cheered the passing Presidential train in Ohio yesterday, and will undoubtedly continue to do so as Mr. ROOSEVELT journeys across the country. Popular demonstrations will mark his entire route. He deserves such a reception, and will naturally be pleased by it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Several thousand local unions of the United Mine Workers of America in twenty-eight States were notified today to direct their members to return to the coal pits on Tuesday, the date designed by miners and operators for ending the strike of bituminous miners which began last Monday.
Depression and circumstance have made a barber of Samuel Moscovitz, but he does not mind. His tonsorial undertaking has elevated him to a prominent position among the inhabitants of his neighborhood.

The big parade is under way. Football steps off in full stride today as the heavy artillery swings into line with the light skirmishers who started the campaign a week ago. Except for a few stragglers awaiting another Saturday, the Autumnal rush may be considered on.

Supporters of Charles J. Conklin, candidate for Tammany leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, appealed yesterday to John T. Dooling, chairman of the Tammany law committee, to investigate the alleged election of Herbert L. Bruce, a Negro, as the district leader on Thursday night, with a view to contesting Mr. Bruce's right to sit as a member of the Tammany executive committee.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- A prison sentence of nine months on a check charge was given today to Lord Edward Montagu, who recently wanted to join the French Foreign Legion and once was held as a material witness in a California murder mystery.

Registration statements filed with the SEC by twenty-two investment trusts whose shares are traded in on the New York Curb Exchange show that compensation paid to individuals or organizations for executive management ranged from nominal amounts to $277,870 a year.

Lower rates, more intensive consumption and an increase of 50 per cent in the mileage of rural lines are required to enable this State to carry out a proper program of rural electrification, according to testimony given yesterday by Morris L. Cooke, head of the Federal Rural Electrification Administration, before the joint legislative committee investigating public utilities.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 27. -Ernest S. Van Hise, Welfare Commissioner of Suffolk County, was injured fatally here this afternoon when the automobile he was driving was in collision with a truck at Park Avenue and Greenlawn Road.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation has declared a dividend of $1 on the Series A and B $6 preferred stock, payable Nov. 1 to stock of record Oct. 14. On Sept. and June 1 of this year dividends of 75 cents were paid on these stocks.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 27. -- Nelson Rounsevell took the stand in his own defense today in the criminal libel suit brought by Major Gen. Harold B. Fiske, after which the defense rested. District Attorney James J. McGuigan did not cross-examine the publisher of The Panama American.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- A message of gratification over its endorsement of more liberal international trade policies, which he called "dramatic and encouraging," was sent by Secretary of State Hull to the Economic Committee of the Assembly of the League of Nations.

Retail trade maintained an active pace during the week, despite the Indian Summer weather which prevailed. Purchasing of Fall apparel and accessories was less brisk than in the preceding week, but interest in many types of home furnishings was marked.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 27. -Even though the British did their best sailing today, the United States team clinched the international dinghy series, carried off the North American Dinghy Association Gold Cup and took first place in three races held off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting today became the first player to win the women's New Jersey State golf championship four times, accomplishing that feat as she successfully defended her title against Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews, a three-time holder of the crown, with a 4-and-2 victory at the Upper Montclair Country Club.
The formation of four new firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and the dissolution of another were announced yesterday by the Exchange.

In assembling for its quarterly conference the Advisory Council of the Federal Reserve Board, consisting of twelve experienced bankers elected by the twelve Reserve Banks to represent them, brought to Washington what is described as "the most hopeful sum"mary of conditions since the depres"sion began."

HESKETH PEARSON'S new biography, "Gilbert and Sullivan" (Harper, $3), is written according to a neatly simple recipe. This is the recipe: take the hearts of existing memoirs and biographies, broil them over a quick fire of psychoanalysis, season heavily with anecdote, and serve in a cheery manner.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 27. -- "Conditions in the money market" which prevent refunding of $24,640,000 of gold note issues on next Tuesday are blamed by the Standard Gas and Electric Company for a petition which it filed today in the United States District Court here for reorganization under Section 77B of the National Bankruptcy Act.

A comparatively dull period for new State and municipal financing is indicated for next week, when $12,320,651 is scheduled for sale. This compares with a revised total of $41,922,490 for this week. The weekly average for new offerings by States and municipalities for the year to date stands at $26,171,171.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Henry Ford is reported to see advantages in dashboard telephones from which busy executives could talk to their offices while traveling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -Three key NRA officials were disclosed to have resigned today on the heels of the appointment of Major George L. Berry to an apparently dominant position in the old Blue Eagle organization.

Cardinal Hayes arrived yesterday from Cleveland, Ohio, where he was the personal representative of Pope Pius XI at the seventh National Eucharistic Congress. With him on the trip east was Alfred E. Smith. On the same train were 250 pilgrims from the Archdiocese of New York.
Numbers and not letters will be used to designate ringside seats at all major outdoor fights here, Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, declared yesterday.

Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, declared yesterday that he would consider it unfortunate if the new 4 per cent tax to be imposed on unincorporated businesses should be construed to include the operations of syndicates, joint ventures and certain types of pools.

WPA workers on projects of the Board of Education now number 9,000 men, 7,000 of whom have been assigned since Aug. 1, it was learned yesterday when announcement was made from Washington that $3,003,120 had been allotted for the repair of 769 school buildings.

Under the rules promulgated this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission for solicitation of proxies, corporations are required to file with stock exchanges as well as with the commission copies of the proxy form and the explanatory matter now required to accompany it.

" Dear Mr. President," the comedy by Doty Hobart, will not have its scheduled premiere tonight at the Mansfield, Irving H. Cooper, its producer, yesterday withdrew the show for rewriting and general repairs. Members of the cast were paid two weeks' salaries at the Equity office and the scenery was carted away from the theatre.

The New York Central Railroad and the Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday an arrangement for coordinated omnibus and train service in the railway's territory. The railway is to acquire an interest in the Eastern Greyhound Lines, a Greyhound Corporation subsidiary, which will be renamed the Central Greyhound Lines.

European varieties of dahlias shared honors and interest with giant native blooms at the closing sessions yesterday of the annual dahlia and Fall flower show of the American Dahlia Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The exhibition, which opened Thursday, closed last night after breaking all previous records for attendance.

Spencer Trask Co. capture the Hayden Trophy yesterday in the thirteenth annual golf tournament for that prize at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L.I. The winning score was 316. This was the third victory for Spencer Trask Co. and gives them permanent possession of the present Hayden Trophy.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- More Nazi than the Nazis, the American League of Friends of the New Germany is putting pressure on the German League for Germanism Abroad to try to force it to propagandize in the United States for the adoption of Nazi dogmas by all German-Americans.

New bonds for $134,233,000 were offered publicly this week in the most active period since the week ended on July 19, when $234,148,000 in new issues went on the market. This week's financing compares with $74,623,000 last week, and with only $6,270,000 in the corresponding period of last year.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Newell P. Sherman flatly denied late today that he had drowned his wife, Alice, because of his love for another woman.

A field of eight, headed by C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp's King Saxon, has been named for the Continental Handicap, closing-day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's meeting at Jamaica today. Whether or not the son of Saxon can carry his speed and top weight of 126 pounds for the mile and a sixteenth is what the test is expected to prove.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- New Jersey will receive $18,008,875 of Federal funds for forty-five projects to cost $20,623,633, as its share of the final $200,139,037 PWA fund, it was disclosed today with the publication of a complete list of New Jersey projects approved by President Roosevelt.

There are 8,639 WPA jobs in seventy-one classifications "going begging" here because of the inability of the Emergency Relief Bureau to supply workers listed as qualified, General Hugh S. Johnson, retiring Administrator, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Strong cable messages from Liverpool and aggressive buying by houses with Eastern connections lifted wheat prices 1 1/2 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel today in the early trading on the Board of Trade. The September sold at $1 for the first time since Sept. 19, and the distant futures were only 1/8 cent under that figure.

A field of eight, headed by C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp's King Saxon, has been named for the Continental Handicap, closing-day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's meeting at Jamaica today. Whether or not the son of Saxon can carry his speed and top weight of 126 pounds for the mile and a sixteenth is what the test is expected to prove.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- New Jersey will receive $18,008,875 of Federal funds for forty-five projects to cost $20,623,633, as its share of the final $200,139,037 PWA fund, it was disclosed today with the publication of a complete list of New Jersey projects approved by President Roosevelt.

There are 8,639 WPA jobs in seventy-one classifications "going begging" here because of the inability of the Emergency Relief Bureau to supply workers listed as qualified, General Hugh S. Johnson, retiring Administrator, said yesterday.

The memorandum of understanding which contemplates the city's purchase of the rapid-transit properties of the B.M.T. at a net price of 185,000,000 will continue in force for sixty days beyond Oct. 1, the original expiration date, City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. announced yesterday.

One of the great events of amateur steeplechasing, the Meadow Brook Cup, will have its thirty-seventh running over the course in Morgan Meadow, Old Westbury, today. Started in 1883, the Meadow Brook has grown until it is now one of the most coveted amateur racing trophies, and its records are studded with the names of great horses and the best amateur riders.

City College's second football season under the guidance of Benny Friedman, former Michigan all-American quarterback, will get under way at Lewisohn Stadium tonight when the Beavers oppose Brooklyn College in the opening contest of a seven-game schedule. The kick-off is set for 8:30 P.M.
The city of Minneapolis, Minn., will enter the investment market on Oct. 24 with a new issue of $760,000 of bonds. The bonds will mature in one to twenty years.

" I have read with extreme interest your article of Sept. 18 regarding fishing for giant tuna near Ambrose Light," writes Alexander Lyle of Long Beach, L.I. "There must be many who would like to take a shot at this kind of fishing if they only knew the details of how to go about it.

ROME, Sept. 27. -- The Cabinet will meet again tomorrow morning to consider the Italo-Ethiopian situation and its European reactions. But things have been moving so slowly since the last meeting on Tuesday that it is not expected the Cabinet will have any very important decisions to announce.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- An increase of almost 100 per cent in the number of airplane passengers using Newark Airport the first six months of this year over a similar period in 1934 was announced here today by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein. He reported that from January to June this year, 92,361 passengers used the port.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- More than 350,000 farm families are already being aided financially to get a new start in life, and 75,000 more will be helped shortly with the $262,000,000 definitely allotted to Rexford G. Tugwell's Resettlement Administration by President Roosevelt just before he left the capital yesterday.

AMHERST vs. COLBY -- Wait a minute. This is just signal drill. A trifle of touch tackling. Coming in from the fight camps and the baseball diamonds and the golf links the football guesses can't be expected to be in midseason form. Possibly that's all for the better. Sight unseen, one trustful vote for Amherst.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Jack Orr, owned by Gibson White, 21-year-old Lexington youth, won the inaugural Geers Stake for 2-year-old pacers at the Grand Circuit meet today. The winner was driven by Thomas Berry.

The share market yesterday was largely a repetition or the indecisive markets of earlier in the week; trading continued slow, although slightly more active than on the day before; prices fluctuated within narrow limits; reports of improving domestic trade generally offset the nervousness over the foreign situation; large holders of stocks -- institutions and individuals -- preferred to stay on the sidelines as professional interest in the market, although hesitant, inclined toward bearishness.
Mayor La Guardia received Mayor Stefan Starzynski of Warsaw and his party at City Hall yesterday and discussed problems of municipal government with them through an interpreter.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO CALIFORNIA, Sept. 27. -- President Roosevelt's plans to solidify the Democratic party ranks on his trip met with a rebuff in one phase today when Governor Ruby Laffoon and Thomas S. Rhea, leaders of the Kentucky Democratic faction defeated in the recent primary election, declined an invitation to board his train.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Resources of institutions of the building and loan type which have applied through the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation for insurance for each of their investors against loss up to $5,000, passed the $900,000,000 mark last week, the insurance corporation announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- With the League Council proceeding to deal with Italy under Article XV. comprising the report and recommendations which will probably be accepted by all but Italy, her war on Ethiopia immediately it starts will come automatically under Article XVI, which implies sanctions.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries, excluding the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement a net income of $2,128,581 in the first six months of the year, equal to 33 cents a share on its no par capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The United States is still waiting for advice from the British Government as to the advisability of holding a world naval conference this year, as provided in the London treaty, Secretary of State Hull indicated today.

It is of considerable importance in Ethiopia that it takes perhaps a month after the rains stop for the ground to dry out, but that it takes only a few days after the rains begin for the ground to get pretty wet. In other words, from the point of view of military operations, the wet season is longer than the dry season.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27. -Governor Ruby Laffoon and Thomas S. Rhea, leaders of the defeated faction in Kentucky's bitter Democratic primary fight, offered explanations today of why they refused to confer with President Roosevelt on his special train as it skirted the northern boundary line of the State.

HAVANA, Sept. 27. -- Hurricane winds were rising in Camaguey Province late tonight, and the vortex was calculated to follow a course slightly west of Santa Cruz del Sur in that province. It was expected by the weather observatories to sweep thence northeasterly across the east central portion of the island, thus following about the same path as the destructive hurricane of 1932.

The free port plan which is being worked out by the Federal Government, based on the Celler Bill, passed by Congress in 1933, envisions four of this type of ports, it was learned yesterday. Two would be located on the Atlantic Seaboard, one on the Gulf and one on the Pacific.

Various economists commented yesterday on the opinion expressed on Thursday in Chicago by Charles G. Dawes, banker and former Vice President of the United States, that business indices apparently heralded the final year of recovery from depression.

" If the allegations made before me are true, this matter should be brought to the attention of the Bar Association, if not of the District Attorney," Supreme Court Justice Dore said from the bench yesterday after hearing allegations against Frank Hendrick, an attorney of 120 Broadway.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Sept. 27. -- Mrs. Effie S. Buxton, 69 years old, mother of Dr. Kenneth S. Buxton, head of the Department of Chemistry at Washington College here, was beaten to death with a hatchet today in the Buxton apartment in a residential district.

A police detail was kept busy from noon until 6 P.M. yesterday as crowds collected intermittently before the Hotel Governor Clinton, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-first Street, to watch pickets who marched in front of the building carrying placards reading "We Protest the Presence of Nazis in This Hotel."

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark, the only American woman envoy, returned from Scandanavia yesterday on the American Scantic liner Scanmail for a two months' leave of absence. Accompanied by her daughter, Miss Helen Rudd Owen, and Miss Owen's school friend, Miss Peggy Brenner, Mrs. Owen landed at Exchange Place, Jersey City.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27. -- Kansas State, Big Six Conference champion last year, downed Duquesne, 12 to 0, in a bitterly fought football game at Forbes Field tonight before 8,000 spectators.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith asserted his prerogatives as Honorary Night Superintendent of the Central Park Zoo once more last night, this time to preside over a not-so-solemn meeting at which were named forty-six animals in the Central Park and Prospect Park Zoos.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 28. -- Exports and imports in the month of June showed a slight decline, compared with the same month of 1934, but Peru's foreign trade in the first six months of this year showed an increase.
