WHILE flying in his command plane, Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Hawaiian department, was presented recently with an unusual review by the pilots of the Eighteenth Composite Wing high over famed Waikiki Beach.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 28. -The best of more than 500 dogs judged today at the annual show of the Englewood Kennel Club was the famous Irish setter Champion Milson O'Boy, owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York and handled by Harry Hartnett of Harrison, N.Y.
ROME, Sept. 28. -- If one considers the present conflict merely as an Italian enterprise in Ethiopia at which Great Britain has grown suddenly alarmed, one cannot conceive its exact importance.

THIRTY readers a day in 1925; thirty an hour in 1935. Ten thousand volumes in 1925; 45,000 in 1935. Figures like these from the Henry M. Seymour Library of Knox College, Galesburg, Ill., are significant, not only as a record of achievement of one department of one college but as an indication of a trend in the development of college libraries throughout the country.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 28. --"Count" Victor Lustig was arrested here today by Department of Justice and Secret Service agents who have been on his trail since Sept. 1, when he escaped from the Federal House of Detention in New York, where he had been held since May as the leader of a gang of counterfeiters.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 (AP). -The remaining members of the once powerful regular political machine of New Orleans, which was shattered by Senator Long, signed up today to support the ticket put out by the Long and Governor O.K. Allen forces in the Jan. 21 primary.

Eleven youths and seven girls were arrested on charges of unlawful assembly last evening when the police broke up a picket line of thirty students and unemployed persons protesting against "Red Salute," a motion picture with a military theme, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli Theatre, Broadway at Forty-ninth Street.

OBSERVANCE of a Religious Education Week begins today throughout the United States, and especially in the larger cities. The conferences are inter-denominational and, in Greater New York, they are arranged at various centres in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island by the Federation of Churches.

On Tuesday Paul Schaefer will complete fifty years of service as deputy sexton of St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity Parish, at Broadway and Vesey Street. Although 75 years old, he is still very active, and is energetic enough to rise every day at 5 A.M., to open the historic old church at 7 o'clock.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 28 (AP). -- National Guardsmen advanced tonight on what Governor Laffoon calls Harlan County's "reign of terror" over roads made familiar to them by two other marches this year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Evening-up operations furnished a good part of the trade in wheat today on the Board of Trade. Prices held within narrow limits, but there was a lack of aggressive support, and the finish was 1/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel net lower, short covering toward the last causing a reaction from the inside level.

PANAMA, R.P. -- A wave of proposals in constitutional reform has moved from Guatemala south to Ecuador within the last few months. In Guatemala it resulted in the so-called election for another seven-year term of General Jorge Ubico.

NOW is the time to plant peonies. The peony does not enjoy being lifted and moved about at any time; still less does it like having its roots divided. But these things must happen if peonies are to grow where none grew before, and the season in which least harm ensues to the plant is the early Autumn when the roots are nearly dormant.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 28. -- Good Goods, the Brookmeade Stable's brown 4-year-old colt, staged a brilliant drive in the last quarter today to win the $10,000 added Havre De Grace Handicap by a nose.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- Easily the feature of the New England business situation has been the development of a boom in wool and in woolen and worsted textiles. Summer Street during the last week or two has been strongly reminiscent of conditions which prevailed during the World War.

Vans rumbled through the streets of Manhattan late last night, thousands of families labored hurriedly to pack their household goods and other thousands went from one apartment house to another in a last-minute search for new quarters as New York prepared for the final rush of the traditional Oct. 1 moving day.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The German Government decreed today complete supremacy of the State over the Protestant Church by empowering Hanns Kerrl, Minister of Church Affairs, to make church laws and appoint church officials.

THE ranks of the older generation of American booksellers were further reduced this month by the death of two of its members, Charles Sessler and Merle Johnson. Mr. Sessler devoted the last fifty of his four-score years to the active development of his business, which grew into one of the largest and most famous in the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Illinois has its own "pyramids" which, while they do not reveal the wealth of buried cities such as found in the Near East excavations, still show with scientific accuracy the cultural evolution of the prehistoric people who dwelt in these valleys long ago.

NEW tourist lanes have been opened to Panama, approaching it from both the east and west. Tours of three weeks' duration have been in effect on both Grace and Panama Pacific ships for several months, and last week the two lines announced a joint service from New York.

New York's lack of flowers saddened Stefan Starzynski, the Mayor of Warsaw, Poland, on his final sight-seeing tour of the city yesterday. He and Mme. Pauline Starzynska arrived on the new Polish liner Pilsudski last Tuesday and sailed for home on her at 1 o'clock this morning.

Maskal, the Feast of the Cross, which is supposed to mark the end of the season's rains, was celebrated in Addis Ababa last Friday in a torrent of rain. Warriors in bedraggled lion skins were forced to cut short their customary and ceremonial bragging; processions of richly robed and thoroughly soaked priests broke ranks and sped to shelter.
FREMONT, Neb., Sept. 28. -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows:

Several clergymen will today discuss in their sermons the letter of President Roosevelt to ministers, priests and rabbis of the country last week asking them for advice as to how to solve some of his governmental problems. Many pastors will return to their pulpits today from their Summer vacation.

Thousands of persons in New York City do not know where to turn for help when in distress, it has been disclosed by a survey made by the Welfare Council of New York City, which made public the results.

Thousands of needy college and high school students in the city and State are looking forward to the receipt within the next two weeks of the first checks from the National Youth Administration which will assure the continuance of their education.

Off to a 7-to-0 lead in the first three minutes, City College kept clean its football record for the Brooklyn College series by registering a 20-to-6 victory at Lewisohn Stadium last night for the fourth Beaver success in as many gridiron meetings with the Kingsmen.

Trading in stocks was no better than routine during the short trading period yesterday. The volume or business on the Stock Exchange, 519,000 shares, was the smallest total for a day this month; the same was true of the listed bond market, in which transactions amounted to but $3,638,900.

Frank B. Kellogg's resignation as a judge in the World Court (Permanent Court of International Justice) brings into action the complicated mechanism for nominating and electing his successor. Candidates are put up by the national groups in the old Court of Arbitration, which still carries on in quarters across the hall from those of the Court of International Justice, created by Article XIV of the covenant of the League of Nations.

YOU would scarcely recognize the Brooklyn Museum, with its lifted face. Formerly the facade was wont to wear a kind of forlorn and vacant expression, due to the great unused flight of steps; steps that couldn't, as a matter of fact, be used because they had of late become unsound.

The ceiling of numerous small lots of municipal bonds for payment in October and several large amounts of industrial and public utility liens for payment in November and December was announced last week. This month's total of bonds called for redemption before maturity was unchanged from the previous week at $350,611,000, compared with $236,143,000 the preceding month and $158,235,000 in September, 1934, for corresponding weeks.

Five leading hotel men in statements yesterday approved the proposal of the Merchants Association that the city build in Manhattan a great convention hall in conjunction with the 1939-40 world's fair. The association has urged upon Mayor La Guardia the need for a permanent municipal hall of that sort.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- In striking contrast with early pictures of Il Duce cheering his African troops, The Daily Telegraph published today a dispatch from a correspondent who asserts that transports are returning from the Red Sea loaded with men too broken by the heat of Eritrea even to raise a hand in salute to those outward bound and that they arrive in silence.

Flags generally are heraldic records of historic circumstances. Germany finally has felt impelled to decree that the swastika blazoned on the native colors of black, white and red shall be both the German commercial and national emblem. It is left with the Fuehrer Chancellor to designate the forms of the war and administrative flags.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 28. -- The advancement of science has literal significance for faculty and students of chemistry, physics and psychology at Wellesley College who moved this week into their quarters in the new Hall of Science on Norumbega Hill.

While Geneva struggles with the Ethiopian crisis a serious problem has developed nearer the centre of European events. Today the population of the autonomous territory of Memel, which was part of Germany until the end of the World War and is now under Lithuanian rule, will go to the polls to elect a Diet.

OCTOBER'S approach gives the cue for new headline acts to stalk upon the ethereal stage. This afternoon at 2 o'clock, the WJZ curtain rises on an hour matinee to be broadcast weekly with diversity as the keynote.

Passengers on a crowded Long Island Railroad train who left New York at 1:39 A.M. yesterday in the hope that they were on the way to Long Beach and intermediate stations experienced a shock of surprise when they found themselves gliding smoothly along on the way to Flushing, a route leading in an entirely different direction.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Testimony in the weeklong trial of Newell Paige Sherman, scoutmaster and choir-singer, on charges that he drowned his wife, ended today after the defendant had admitted improper relations with another girl for whose love the State charged he committed murder.

General Hugh S. Johnson, who Federalized work relief here and expanded it 75 per cent since Aug. 1, will be superseded as WPA administrator by Victor F. Ridder on or about Oct. 15. General Johnson, admittedly tired of work "pro bono publico," is resigning voluntarily.

CONRAD AIKEN will probably be neglected for the present. It is true that his first novel, "Blue Voyage," met with a certain popularity by accident of its theme; but although his short stories and his second novel, "Great Circle," were far finer, the public and most of the critics have become increasingly apathetic.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 28. -Colgate's Red Raiders opened their 1935 football campaign this afternoon by defeating Niagara University, 30 to 0, before 3,00 spectators at Whitnall Field.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Miss Mary Frothingham Clay was introduced to society today at a tea given by her mother, Mrs. Henry A. Berwind Jr., and Mr. Berwind at their home in Chestnut Hill.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27. -Kentucky's reborn $100,000,000 distilling industry is threatened with destruction as the result of an active campaign by the drys to defeat repeal of the State's constitutional prohibition amendment. Those in the liquor business who have awakened to the situation are in a blue funk.

THOMAS CARLYLE in "Sartor Resartus," it will be recalled, asked a couple of questions. The first was: "To the eye of vulgar Logic, what is man?" The answer was: "An omnivorous Biped that wears Breeches."

In the Fall issue of the Catholic Book Survey, just published by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, are listed 112 approved books. The committee, which is headed by the Right Rev. Michael J. Lavelle, says that, "though the Summer season is the slack period in the publishing business, it is gratifying to find that so many books of worthwhile character have been issued."
When Ray heard we were going up to Kensico Reservoir the other day, he said: "Why waste your time? There's no news there, and the fishing is punk."

In line with the recent trend to provide a large variety of extracurricular activities for students of Hunter College, elaborate programs of events have been arranged by the clubs and societies of the college for the current semester. These will supplement class work and enable students to relax in congenial environment. Besides the weekly meetings with faculty and extra-college speakers, twenty-five of the thirty-five clubs have planned special affairs for the term.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- In circles close to the Emperor general mobilization is believed to be imminent.

The annual dinner dance of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will be held on Wednesday formally to open the new King Cole Room of the St. Regis. The entertainment, which will benefit the work of the Hygiene and Social Service Committee of the association, has been in preparation for several weeks and has received an encouraging response.

PARIS. ONE of the most amusing things about modern fashions is the nonchalance with which Paris couturiers treat materials. The traditional "wool for morning, silk for afternoon, brocade for evening" technic has passed right out of the style picture.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 28. -The United States and British dinghy teams ended their international series today off the Larchmont Yacht Club with the American sailors more firmly entrenched in first place than ever.

ATHENS, Sept. 28. -- An official dispatch from the Greek island of Samos reports four Italian seaplanes were observed several times last week coming from the Dodecanese Islands and flying over the fortified Turkish shore line at a great height. Military manoeuvres are taking place on the Turkish coast.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Being Premier in France is never an easy nor a comfortable job. Since this third republic was founded, in 1871, there have been ninety-nine Ministries with ninety-nine Premiers, and during the three and a half years of the present legislature there have been no fewer than ten, including the present Cabinet, presided over by Pierre Laval.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., of New York City, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 an application for the registration of $5,500,000 of fifteen-year 4 per cent sinking fund bonds due on Nov. 1, 1950, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

RECEPTION of European short waves has been exceptionally poor for the past week, and the reason, according to engineers who study reception on the international channels, is the reversal in polarity of the sun-spot magnetism that occurs once every twenty-three years.

Amid stormy scenes and unusual bitterness the Republicans of New York ousted Chase Mellen Jr. as county chairman last week and cleared the decks for the 1936 Presidential engagement by electing Kenneth F. Simpson in his place.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP). -In a veto message which contained a hint that a special session of the Legislature may be called, Governor Philip La Follette today disapproved the so-called excess-profits tax on incomes, which was designed to raise $2,000,000 for the biennium for high school aids.

TOKYO, Sept. 28. -- Japan's economic policy in relation to China was discussed for ninety minutes today by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota and Finance Minister Korekiyo Takahashi. It is authoritatively learned the conversation was to expose the existing situation, with an outline of Mr. Hirota's plans for concrete economic collaboration.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Sept. 28. -- Mrs. Thelma Buxton, whom police say killed her mother-in-law, Mrs. Effie S. Buxton, 69 years old, with a hatchet yesterday, will be examined by alienists tomorrow under a compromise agreement reached by her lawyer and the State's Attorney.

In lonely Roswell, N.M., Dr. GODDARD pursues his experiments with rocket motors. The more serious rocketeers, of whom he is the most important, the most resourceful and the most experienced, at first scarcely dared to breathe a word of the possibility of navigating interstellar space with mechanism not dependent on the oxygen of the atmosphere.

WHEN young Jim Vestal, Texan by birth, wanderer by choice, rode over into Arizona to take a look at the Verde cattle country the sheep-men had already begun to come in with flocks that were ruining the lower reaches for cattle grazing.
LONDON, Sept. 28. -- Two points in the Italian official communique summarizing the decisions of today's Cabinet meeting in Rome on the Ethiopian crisis interest British leaders.

LOUISIANA State University, which the late Senator Huey P. Long called "my university," has opened for the 1935-36 academic year with an enrolment of nearly 6,000 -- triple the attendance of 1928 when Mr. Long became Governor of the State.

Four spoiled city children discover an astonishing world of delights on a farm in the Tennessee foothills in this second book by the author of "Those Plummer Children." Used to a luxurious home and expensive pleasures, they regarded with acute distaste the prospect of farm-life with an unknown aunt when their father died and their home had to be sold.
MONTE CARLO. -- Attendance at the roulette tables in the Casino has now dwindled to the point where the law of averages has ceased to work, and the house is losing money heavily.

EDMONTON. -- Alberta, one of the youngest Canadian provinces, which has gained sudden notoriety through electing the first Social Credits Government in the world, has always been a pioneer in progressive legislation.

This story grew from the author's reminiscences of her own childhood and there is an artless simplicity about it which faithfully conveys the flavor of an earlier day. The three Warrens, Rosie, Violet and Ralph, lived in the rectory of an old Southern town just before the turn of the century.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Forty-two members of the senior class at Princeton University will study under the "no-course" plan during the coming academic year, according to an announcement today by Robert X. Root, dean of the faculty.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 28. -- Contending that the will of John Willys, automobile financier, filed for probate here was not voluntarily made, but the result of domination and influence of Mrs. Florence E. Willys, his wife, Charles B. Mertz, former secretary to Mr. Willys, filed his objections today through an attorney.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The deposits of 768 insured commercial banks in New York on June 30 amounted to $11,818,431,000, an increase of 11.6 per cent, compared with the same date a year ago, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation revealed today in making public detailed figures by States of the last condition call.

Settlement last week of a strike in the bituminous coal fields involving 400,000 workers put an end to a dispute which has been hanging fire since last April. On no fewer than six occasions during the Spring and Summer a "truce" was arranged, sometimes at the last moment, to prevent an interruption of negotiations.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 28. -- A fleet-footed band of Duke University Blue Devils ran roughshod over the University of South Carolina eleven in Duke Stadium today, triumphing by 47 to 0. Eight thousand saw the game.

DUDE ranching, already one of the important industries of the West, made big gains this season and is now making plans for further expansion. The University of Wyoming is starting this Fall a four-year course in "dude wrangling," combining hotel management and "horseology."

Mayor La Guardia and Rufus E. McGahen, his budget director, passed all of yesterday wrestling with the problem of the city budget for 1936, the Mayor's version of which must be presented to the Board of Estimate on Wednesday.

The National League having settled its customary family squabble to determine who shall carry the banner, an issue which seems to be raised in that circuit each year with increasing violence, baseball swings gayly this week into its concluding spectacle of the year -- the world series, the thirty-sixth under the regulations of modern inter-league warfare konwn as the Brush rules.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -Consolidation of the War and Navy Departments into one department of national defense was urged today by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

Full of real adventure, this tale of a sea-going kitten who stowed away on an Antarctic expedition is told with a vigor and humor that should endear itself to children from 7 to 10. Born on the high seas, the son of a sea-cat, this kitten had never really found his land-legs.
New York City's application for a free port on the shore of Staten Island is to be considered at formal hearings beginning on Nov. 12, as announced by the United States Army Information Bureau.

The "refunding phase" of the investment market is presenting not only a problem to investors generally, but is working a hardship on many institutions dependent upon private endowments for a substantial part of the income essential to their activities, says Will J. Price of Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., in the current issue of the Stone Webster Bulletin.

Suing the city for damages, real and fancied, is a practice much on the increase. Its extent is illustrated by a $400 judgment recently obtained against the municipality by a storekeeper for the smashing of his show windows and loss of stock during the Harlem riot earlier this year.

With the addition of more than a thousand bales of cotton to certificated stocks of the New York Cotton Exchange last week, many men in the trade see in this a definite movement for rehabilitating the contract stock, which last week declined to less than 9,000 bales at the eight delivery points.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 28. -Pounding her way through a sea kick-up out in Long Island Sound today, Herman F Whiton's American yacht Cherokee won the final six-meter sloop race between craft of the Scandinavian countries and the United States.

A slumbering giant for three periods, Fordham awakened with a start in the final quarter of its opening game with Franklin and Marshall yesterday, struck twice with crushing force and defeated the rugged Diplomats, 14 to 7. A crowd of 15,000 at the Polo Grounds gazed at first with surprise and then with complete consternation as the big Pennsylvanians led the Rams from the start down to the home stretch.

Four months after he has been murdered, the body of Charles Diegel is found buried in a haystack. It is quickly identified, but the other questions that are asked are not so quickly answered. Diegel was a financial reporter on a London newspaper, married, but not living in complete harmony with his wife.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 28 (AP). -- The men who direct the welfare work of the Catholic Church today reported a survey showed a return of the "spirit of optimism" and indications that the nation was "on the way out of the depression."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -The soft coal industry soon will undertake the gigantic task of setting up a new price structure.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Chicago's hopes of utilizing Federal funds for the construction of a lakefront airport and a super-highway artery were dimmed this week by the decision of national officials to follow "boon-doggling" methods in allotting funds for Works Progress Administration projects.

ZAGRER, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27. -Political fermentation is restored in Croatia. The high hopes entertained in Croatia of the good intentions of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch when Prince Paul as Regent chose him to replace Bogolyub Yevtitch on June 20 have already ebbed away.

Miss Winifred Howe, 23 years old, an English playwright, who came here a month ago, committed suicide at 7:25 A.M. yesterday by leaping from a balcony on the sixth floor of the building where she lived at 230 West Fifty-ninth Street.

Upon reading Dr. Charles Wilner's letter 1 at first thought, naturally enough, that he was having his little joke with us ladies -- he's only using the words "women" and "females" in their sociological sense, I'm sure -- but after pausing to digest his findings it struck me that he actually was serious.

Despite the retarding effect of Indian Summer weather upon Fall purchasing, retail trade in the metropolitan area last week maintained a good part of the increases in sales volume over a year ago, noted in the preceding fortnight. Estimates indicated an average gain for leading department stores of about 5 per cent over the same period of 1934.

In your recent editorial, "Conservation," you mention Wyoming as a possible source of the New York movement whose semi-centennial has just been so fittingly observed. May I suggest another possible source?

The Colonial clubhouse of the Women's Club of Glen Ridge, regarded by its 780 members as a second home, will be opened Tuesday for a new club year. Mrs. Erroll O. Horner, president, will preside at a business session at 1 P.M.

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 28 (AP). -In a game which packed its drama into two breathless moments the University of Oklahoma defeated the University of Colorado football team today, 3 to 0, and crowned with glory the debut of Captain Lawrence (Biff) Jones as Sooner coach.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Calling on the public utility industry to cooperate in working out a plan for the administration of the Public Utility Act of 1935 on a basis which would be to the best interests of all concerned. James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System, said the commission would not shrink from a test of its constitutional powers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A letter from President Roosevelt to Senator Albert Barkley, which was read Jan. 29 before a meeting of the Democratic State Committee of Kentucky, reportedly in opposition to Governor Laffoon's desire to hold a convention in that State, is reported here to be the source of the political feud now splitting the Democratic ranks in Kentucky.

In the "Robert Peary" (a private car named for the North Pole discoverer; five bedrooms, dining room and observation platform; air-conditioned, finished in mahogany and equipped with radio), President Roosevelt left Washington Thursday night on a trip which wilt take him to California and thence by cruiser through the Panama Canal and back to Washington.

A VERY timely book, in view of the Ethiopian situation, is Carleton S. Coon's "Measuring Ethiopia -- and Flight Into Arabia," which Little, Brown Co. will publish on Oct. 4. This is Mr. Coon's account of an anthropological expedition that turned out to have its adventurous aspects.

ELLIS CREDLE'S rhythmically titled picture-book, "Down, Down the Mountain." was an unusually appealing story of a boy and girl in the Blue Ridge Mountains. With the same appreciation of the things which are important to a child, she now tells with gusto and humor of the antics of a group of children on a Southern plantation.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28. -- All industries and every corporation will be in danger of being declared "postal and commercial outlaws" unless they submit to the minutest government control if the constitutionality of the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utilities Holding Companies Act is upheld, John W. Davis, counsel for the Edison Electric Institute, argued here today in the final hearing of the first court test of the law.

M. Murray Weisman has been elected president of Carnegie Hall to succeed the late Robert E. Simon, who died suddenly three weeks ago. Robert E. Simon Jr., son of the late real estate operator, has been chosen vice president.

BY "a better economic order" Father Ryan means the approved social system envisaged by the progressive thinkers of the Catholic Church, and more particularly by Pope Pius XI. While its full development must be regarded largely in the light of an ideal, it nevertheless may be assumed to have received a practical start in the economic policies of the New Deal.

THE title of this yarn from the pen of Francis Stuart should have been enclosed between quotation marks, for it is, as he uses the caption, the title of the projected movie which is the background for his burlesque.

Even before Autumn frosts have tinged the leaves, the club season is in full swing. Earlier predictions of a crowded calendar already are fulfilled, with a midseasonal profusion of important functions clamoring for attention in various sections of the metropolitan area.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Republicans of the Middle West plan to force the campaigning that must culminate in national battle on the first Tuesday following the first Monday of November, 1936.

SALMON, Idaho, Sept. 28. -- One of America's youngest members of Congress, D. Worth Clark of Idaho, and a group of scientists will set out from here soon to seek the answer to the century-old lure the "River of No Return" has held for boatmen ready to risk their lives on its turbulent waters.

Pontifical Mass, opening the National Conference of Catholic Charities and the yearly meeting of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul at St. Mary's Cathedral, Peoria, Ill. The mass is under the direction of Amleto Giovanni Cicogagni, Apostolic Delegate to the Catholic Church in the United States: WABC, 11 A.M.-12 noon.

FREMONT, Neb., Sept. 28. -- President Roosevelt replied here today to the challenge of unconstitutionality made against his agricultural adjustment program by stating that he considered this program an expression "in concrete form" of the human rights guaranteed by the Constitution.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- For the second year in a row, the oldest timber race in America was decided in a cold, rainy setting today. And in that steel-gray background. Charley White established a record when he came home with his third winner in this race, the first time since its start in 1883 that any rider has won three times.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Don Peden, star halfback of Illinois ten years ago, came back to his old camping grounds today to upset his teacher, Bob Zuppke, and with his Ohio University eleven conquered Illinois, 6 to 0.

The Ethiopian crisis suggests that the world is faced by a much larger problem. What is at stake may not be Ethiopia alone but the colonial question as a whole. Germany, as well as Italy, is demanding colonies. Japan also aims at expansion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Erie Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to extend its nine notes to the RFC, maturing from Oct. 31, 1935, to Jan. 3, 1936, in the amount of $12,119,310, for three years with current interest at 4 per cent.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- With traditional, age-old pomp and ceremony, the Liverymen of the city today elected as the next Lord Mayor of London Sir Percy Vincent, who came to London at the age of 13 as an apprentice in a dry goods store.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- The latest daytime jewelry comes in sets which include matching ear clips, a buckle and mounting for a bag; sometimes there are also link buttons to fasten a reverless jacket at neckline. Smart sets are of carved jade, carnelian, rosequartz or coral.

The bond market merely marked time yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the dullest two-hour trading period of the month. At intervals during the morning trading was virtually at a standstill and prices in all major classifications moved within exceedingly narrow limits.

The Twentieth Century Limited will start operation today on the fastest time ever scheduled between here and Chicago, under the eye of Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad. The "highball" to the train crew will be signaled by Miss Doris Roosa, 16-year-old daughter of J.D. Roosa, the railroad's chief of police.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 28. -- Emperor Haile Selassie served notice upon Geneva tonight that if Italy continued her warlike preparations in East Africa he must, in self-defense, order a general mobilization of Ethiopia's warriors. Italy's provocative attitude indicates an offensive is near, the Emperor told the League of Nations.

CAN Europe settle down? The stress is on "can," the question mark stands for doubt, the accent betrays irritation. The voice comes surely from America. Though distances shrink under the wand of our modern magicians -- our Edisons and Marconis -- the Atlantic is still too wide for Europe's doings to appeal to American eyes as anything but an almost incomprehensible plot of an unnecessarily complicated tragicomedy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Although it is barely a month since the last gavels crashed down on Senate and House of Representatives rostrums and more than three months will pass before official business is resumed, a little band of perhaps thirty tireless statesmen is already at work in the inner sanctums of the Congressional office suites and decidedly in evidence around certain administrative departments.

The "Dinner to Dawn" dance which will formally open the new Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza on Thursday night has aroused much interest among personages of society, many of whom have subscribed to the party. The event is being given under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary to the New York City Cancer Institute.

VIENNA, Ga., Sept. 28 (AP). -Lewis Harris, a Negro, 50 years old, was lynched near here last night by a mob which overpowered Sheriff Bos Vinson of Dooly County as the officer was taking him to Fitzgerald, Ga., for safe-keeping. Harris had been arrested on a charge of drunkenness.

Attended by presidents of every security and commodity exchange here, the New York Cocoa Exchange will celebrate its tenth anniversary on Tuesday with a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange; George Hintz, president of the Cocoa Exchange, and W.F.R. Murrie, president of the Association of Cocoa and Chocolate Manufacturers of the United States, will be the principal speakers.

WITH the thirty-sixth annual National Automobile Show opening here Nov. 2 the motor exhibition returns to sponsorship by the manufacturers. Last year's show, for the first time in many years, was promoted by the local automobile dealers; the forthcoming exposition will be under the auspices of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

The first anniversary of the launching of the new Cunard White Star super liner Queen Mary, on Thursday, found her construction work well advanced, but most of the questions that interest the public still unanswered.

The boomerang, as almost every one knows, returns to the point from which it has been thrown, and that is why this story is called "The Boomerang Clue." The first clue that appears in the story brings the two amateur investigators back to very nearly the place from which they start.

ROME, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Italy's royal family, headed by King Victor Emmanuel, is rallying around Premier Mussolini's vast campaign in East Africa, and some of the Princes will fight side by side with the new Fascist aristocracy.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- Two outstanding teams were eliminated this afternoon in the quarter-final round of the annual invitation mixed two-ban foursome golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club after engaging in exciting battles over a rain-soaked course.

When the New York Philharmonic-Symphony opens its new season in Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, with Otto Klemperer conducting a program balanced between the classics of Bach, Beethoven and Brahms and the modernity of Shostakovich, the array of boxholders, particularly for the lower tier boxes, will be little changed from last year.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 28. -Notre Dame's Ramblers, with the dashing Fred Carideo showing the way, opened their bid for renewed football prestige today by smashing down the defenses of the University of Kansas for a 28-to-7 conquest.

The campaign being developed by a group of representatives of major associations to eliminate unfair trade practices and establish a set of standards in the food industry got under way last week when the newly organized National Food and Grocery Conference Committee formulated preliminary plans for attacking various evils in the field.

WITH the greatest precautions ever taken to guard a film at a preview, Warner Brothers this week unveiled to a handful of correspondents Dr. Max Reinhardt's celluloid version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

IN spite of the fact that Mr. Wight's book should have been half as long, he has written an interesting first novel. Though it has many faults and weaknesses, there is abundant evidence of talent. Mr. Wight can create character, and his narrative sense, when it has been disciplined, should serve him very well.

PRACTICING law is merely a sideline with Perry Mason. He admits that at heart he is an adventurer. That is why the books about him are so exciting and amusing. When Mason undertakes a case, no one, not even Mason himself, knows what it is going to turn out to be.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Business activity in the country in September has been maintained at the higher level reached in August, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Disquieting reports concerning a strike of 3,000 union longshoremen, scheduled for New Orleans on Tuesday, which will probably affect Atlantic and Pacific ports, are in the possession of the Labor Department, it was reported today.

NO New Yorker need languish this Fall with undeveloped talents or a suppressed desire for learning. Whether he would be an "air hostess" or a deep-sea diver, a taxidermist or a tax expert, he has only to telephone Algonquin 4-7150 to locate a possible school or teacher.

TOMORROW evening the Theatre Guild will present Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in "The Taming of the Shrew." Whatever faults or virtues it may disclose no one will suggest that it does not belong to the theatre; it will be theatre incarnadined.

Estimates that the membership of consumer cooperative societies in the United States expanded 40 per cent in the depression years from 1929 to 1934, made yesterday by the Cooperative League of the U.S.A., gave added point to statements made last week by retail authorities at the Boston Conference on Distribution that the consumer cooperative movement is destined to receive a "new impetus" in this country.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- The check-up on the Soviet population was intensified today by a decree issued by the Kremlin establishing a uniform document of identification throughout the country.
ROME, Sept. 27. -- Premier Benito Mussolini has never been a believer in "brain trusts" for running the affairs of his government. He feels that he himself supplies all the brains required.
TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 28 (AP). -Senator Capper, Republican, of Kansas, termed the Democratic agricultural program a "Godsend to farmers" today.

As a means of frustrating alleged connection between politics and the administration of criminal justice, the suggestion will be made at Governor Lehman's conference on crime at Albany tomorrow that assistant district attorneys -- save for bureau heads -- and possibly justices of the peace and magistrates be selected through competitive Civil Service examinations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP). -- With the business curve pointing upward, Treasury experts have compiled a new estimate of the government's financial condition. The estimate is expected to show a more cheerful situation than last January's budget, but it is being guarded carefully in advance of its official publication tomorrow.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Several hundred thousand able-bodied youths of 20 and 21 years, lugging naught but pasteboard cartons of variegated parcels, will be dotting railway station platforms throughout Germany within a few weeks and their comings and goings will be earmarked as a red-letter event by the National Socialist State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The only permanent feature of the Neutrality Act, which was rushed through Congress in the closing days of its last session to the accompaniment of vows that the United States should never be dragged into another war, is Section 2, under which President Roosevelt last Wednesday proclaimed a list of implements of war which their manufacturers are required to register with the Secretary of State.

Department store buyers from out-of-town reported continued good business last week, with the bright spot being the home furnishings division, which is showing remarkable country-wide increases, according to the market survey prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The champion Tigers split a doubleheader with the White Sox at Comiskey Park today, winning the final, 8 to 3, after dropping the opener, 6 to 3 to the fine hurling of the veteran Sam Jones.

Mrs. Charlotte Francoise Springer, who, before her marriage in 1910 to Emile Arthur Springer, was the Marquise Montarsolo d'Caregnano, a descendant of a Bourbon family, died Friday night at the age of 83 at her home at 91-49 Lefferts Boulevard, Forest Hills.

The greatest race of King Saxon's career was run at Jamaica yesterday, but it was also his narrowest squeak, for he won by only a nose. Most of the 15,000 who made the colt one of the hottest favorites of the season were carried from the flush of victory to the suspense of uncertainty as Jockey Wayne Wright lodged a claim of foul against the C.H. Knebelkamp racer.

After, it is charged, she tried to sell for $2 a diamond ring insured for $2,500, a Negro bride of 17, was arrested yesterday at Broadway and Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, by Detective Charles Byrnes of the Ralph Avenue station, on a charge of receiving stolen property.

FOUR new lines of automobiles, including a car in the $1,000 field, were introduced by Buick yesterday. The other three lines range in price from low-medium to medium, with prices lower than last year for all models.

The statements of condition for the third quarter of the year that commercial banks will begin to issue this week are expected to show a continued large rise in deposits, outstripping gains in loans and investments, with a resultant further piling up of holdings of cash on hand, on deposit with other banks and in the Federal Reserve banks.

EVERGREENS have always been favored by discerning gardeners for foundation plantings. But the idea of pushing the "foundation" planting away from the foundation, while still retaining all of the conventional advantages of its use, is something new.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 28. -- The ominous increase in the tension of Chino-Japanese relations, noted in four areas of China, South, Central, North and Inner Mongolia, appears to justify the repeatedly expressed Chinese apprehensions to the effect that Japan is certain to renew pressure as the Ethiopian crisis develops.

At a time when many miles of railroad are being torn up or abandoned in the open spaces of America, a large railroad-building project is going forward in crowded Manhattan. Thousands of curious citizen on West Side streets are attracted by the hum of drills, the sharp explosions of dynamite and the rumble of hoisting machinery.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Close-knit team work gave the Cubs their National League championship.

Lieut. Col. Herman Beukema, head of the Department of Economics, Government and History at the United States Military Academy at West Point, will lecture on "Existing Threats to International Peace," at 8:15 P.M. Tuesday in the high school auditorium at Amityville.

AN oft-quoted phrase, "The highway that leads to my door leads to the end of the world," is soon to become, for Americans, in some measure a reality. Progress is being made by the government on a scenic roadway network designed ultimately to link great national playgrounds that are far apart.

OUT of the general bombardment of screen announcements during the last few days, the most significant appears to be that concerning the return to the cinema fold of the Center Theatre, sister house of the Radio City Music Hall, which went legitimate a year ago to accommodate "The Great Waltz."

Plans have been completed for the annual Fall card party tomorrow afternoon at the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, for the benefit of South Nassau Communities hospital at Rockville Centre. The event is sponsored by the central council of auxiliaries to the hospital, of which Mrs. Christian Binner of Oceanside is president.

The Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, which is to be opened to the public next Thursday, has established a record for quietness in New York City, museum specialists revealed yesterday.

THERE is a saying in Paris that the city has two opera houses and five orchestras but no musical life. The explanation offered by the apologetic French musician is that his countrymen are not a musical race. Existing institutions are not the fulfillment of any compelling need, the accusers say, and artistic organizations that prosper and endure must be rooted in a fundamental responsiveness of the average man.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Aroused by depredations reminiscent of cattle rustling in the West of the Seventies and Eighties, farmers in Northern Illinois are organizing a force of about 20,000 "F men," as they term them, to fight criminal gangs whose raids are costing agriculturists millions of dollars annually.

IN spite of the fact that the majority of Connecticut's car owners remain unfamiliar with the new compulsory semi-annual inspection of motor vehicles, the process of testing more than 300,000 passenger and commercial cars is progressing throughout the State.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28. -- A Rutgers eleven with only two lettermen in the starting lineup was upset by the West Chester Teachers College, 19 to 7, in its opener before 7,000 today.

The Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians and the City Projects Council yesterday challenged the announcement made on Friday by General Hugh S. Johnson, retiring Works Progress Administrator for New York City, that 8,639 VVPA jobs for skilled workers were going begging because of the inability of the Emergency Relief Bureau to supply vocationally classified skilled workers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark were hosts today, according to their usual custom, at a large luncheon at Broad Hollow, their country home in this village, after the running of the Meadow Brook Cup steeplechase over the course on the estate.

SOME further slackening in retail trade because of the mild weather was reported for the week from most centres. The weather factor is for the time being dominant. Apparel buying feels most of the effect, and it is fortunate that the improvement in home furnishings business is well sustained.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Opposition to New Deal theories was the dominant note sounded by leaders of the Republican party, members of the executive committee of the national committee, who met here this week to decide on plans for an aggressive and thorough campaign against the re-election of President Roosevelt in 1936.

The trend of business in general continued along favorable lines last week in almost all sections of the country and, although the mild weather was responsible for temporarily retarding consumer buying to some extent, wholesale markets were active.

GLAMOROUS women and men whose senses whirl like whirling leaves at the sight of them are always with us -- at any rate, in fiction. To be thoroughly up-to-date, Miss Taber permits the depression to condition the whirling sense of her hero, if not the glamour of her heroine.

Although somewhat dubious of the constitutionality of the proxy rules promulgated last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission, leading corporate lawyers in Wall Street found the new regulations so unobjectionable that they have advised their clients to comply with them without protest.
NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Sept. 28. -- A crowd of several thousand persons greeted President Roosevelt late this evening when his train stopped briefly at North Platte, Neb., for servicing.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP). --South Dakota State, regarded as a good "warm-up" opponent for Wisconsin's football opener, handed the Badgers a 13-6 defeat today.

GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 28 (AP). -Two sons of Old Siwash -- namely Stevenson and Donaldson -- kept the fair name of Knox College from going down into history as the undisputed holder of a record of 28 consecutive losses, when they led their team today in an 18-to-0 victory over Principia of Elsah, Ill.

MUKDEN, Manchuria. -- One of the more interesting social experiments being undertaken by Japanese administrators in Manchuria involves the establishment of what are called, for want of a better term, "collective" villages.

Another tale of young America's insistence on seeing the sights of "the greatest city in the world" came to an end early yesterday when a patrolman discovered the huddled figure of William Donald, 15-year-old citizen of Norfolk, Va., asleep in the doorway of a frame dwelling at Freeman Street and Southern Boulevard, in the Bronx.

Ever so many young men and women just out of college have been publishing their memoirs, and the writer of the present lines by force of example finds his own thoughts winging their way back through the mists of time to reconstruct the picture of a vanished world as of the third week in September in the year 1935.

SAN SALVADOR. -- Chimoya Iwamoto, representing the Kiodo Gyo Gyo Kaisha, Ltd., of Tokyo, says the semi-official Diario Nuevo, has been discussing with the government the question of a fishing base of operations here to include part of the Gulf of Fonseca.

Miss Charl Williams of Washington, D.C., and Miss Grace Le-Gendre of Rochester, N.Y., respectively national and State presidents of the Federation of Business and Professional Women, will be guests of honor at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow evening under the auspices of the New York League of the organization.

THE fact that the season, which got under way last week with two performances by Carlos de Vega and Sarita, opened a full month earlier than usual this year is apparently not to be taken as merely an incidental breaking of the record but a symptom of a general tendency.

The broad program of industrial plant, store and home modernization and building, on which Great Britain is now embarked, provides concrete evidence of the rapid business recovery which that nation is making, Harry Arthur Hopf, president of the company that bears his name and chairman of the National Management Council of the U.S.A., declared yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28. -- Manager Frankie Frisch of the Cardinals today signed a one-year contract to continue at the helm of the club, its officials announced. His salary, the same as last year, was not disclosed.

Widely known opera, stage, screen and radio performers have volunteered their services for the theatrical program, "Night of Stars," to be given in Madison Square Garden Wednesday evening for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal.

BEFORE it was finally accepted by Harcourt, Brace Co., Lytton Strachey's manuscript -- "Queen Victoria" -- was refused by several New York publisher, who were unanimous in saying that nobody would want to read about that stuffy old lady -- and yet the book became a best seller overnight.

NEARLY 37,000,000 persons in 11,000,000 automobiles took vacations by motor this year, a gain of about 15 per cent over last season, it is estimated after a survey by the American Automobile Association. The expenditure for these extended outings by car is placed at $4,000,000,000, or about the size of the Federal Works Relief appropriation.
OMENS of trouble in the Mediterranean disturb the British without lessening their faith in the Royal Navy, which so long has guarded the British Isles and the British Empire against all enemies.

FOR at least ten years the officers of the American Museum of Natural History in New York have been planning a great Hall of Astronomy, to house, among meteorites, stone calendars of extinct civilizations, instruments and paintings, a great planetarium in which the glory of the heavens was to be revealed and the mysteries of stellar motions were to be clarified.

LONDON. -- The significant feature of the present crisis in Europe is the way in which Great Britain and France cling, equally, to the idea of a joint policy as the essential need of the international situation. As soon as the trouble between Rome and London grew serious public opinion in Britain became insistent upon the linking up of British and French policies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A national campaign against racketeers, comparable to the successful drive against perpetrators of violent crimes, is being prepared by the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, J. Edgar Hoover, its chief, announced today.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 28. -Massachusetts took the lead for the Lesley Cup in the opening day of competition at the Oyster Harbors Club today by piling up a total of 33 1/2 points in the foursomes and singles. The defending metropolitan golf team trailed the Bay Staters by 6 1/2 points, scoring 27.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Fleet-footed Tony Paczkowski and the passing combination of Stan Ferris and Gil Corinet carried St. Lawrence University to an upset 12-to-6 victory over Cornell before a crowd of 2,500 on Schoellkopf Field today.

UNIVERSITY, Ala., Sept. 28 (AP). -- A brilliantly executed forward pass shunted Howard College into the gridiron spotlight today as the fighting Bulldogs came from behind to tie the mighty Crimson Tide of Alabama, 7 to 7.

A RECENT press dispatch reports that Mahatma Gandhi has abandoned his customary diet of goat's milk for one of leafy vegetables and is feeling much benefited by the change. The significance of this item is in its relatively inconspicuous place in the news, compared with the attention it would have received ten years ago.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Construction of the Pratt dormitory library, made possible by gift of Mrs. Charles M. Pratt of New York City, will complete the system of house libraries which have been established in each of the dormitories on the Amherst College campus.

The Fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park, considered by many the most important of the season in this country, will begin tomorrow to run for two weeks. The session will end on Columbus Day with the running of the $100,000 Futurity and the Jockey Club Gold Cup, two of the most famous races in the United States.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 28. -- The Upsala College football eleven, with a line that averaged 193 pounds, went down to defeat in Taylor Stadium today, losing to Lehigh by 16 to 7. Five thousand spectators braved the elements to see the Engineers crash through for a victory in their inaugural.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Discussing the government's plan to go after racketeers, Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General in charge of crime cases, said today the year-old Federal Racketeering Law was "circumscribed by obvious sharp limits."

With the Spring buying season in many lines of merchandise under way, the volume of early orders indicates that the wholesale markets will enjoy, from a unit standpoint, their most active period since 1929, according to expressions of opinion yesterday by manufacturers and selling agents.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 28 (AP). -- A mere shadow of its great 1934 eleven, Minnesota was tested for strength today and was found wanting in a 26-to-6 victory over North Dakota State.

Women headed by Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt Jr. are showing much interest in the plans for a luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., which will take place at the opening of the Caprice Room of the Weylin on Oct. 10.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 28. -- Princess Marian Snowden Rospigliosi arrived hero this afternoon by airplane from Newark, presumably seeking information relative to making residence here for the purpose of filing a suit for divorce against Prince Girolomo Rospigliosi.

TENAFLY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- A hero and many times a winner in the show ring, Mrs. Florence B. Ilch's champion Lucason of Ashtead o'Bellhaven received first prize today in the collie class at the Englewood (N.J.) Kennel Club show from a judge who knew nothing of the dog's spectacular rescue yesterday of a 10-year-old boy from drowning.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 28. -- The Greenwich branch of the New York Junior League, of which Mrs. Edward Emerson of Greenwich is chairman, will present the Studio Workshop Players of Greenwic in "The Greenwich Daze of 1935 at the Greenwich Theatre on Oct. 3, 4 and 5.

WINDOW-SHOPPING is an indulgence which even the most indigent allow themselves. This pursuit threatens to become more tantalizing than ever, now that there is a completely invisible window glass. It does not reflect one's face, or the street traffic and buildings.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 28. -Dartmouth opened its football season in a driving rain today, running over Norwich, 39 to 0, as Eddie Casey, nephew of the former Harvard coach, provided the majority of thrills.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP). -A special commission of Presbyterian ministers and laymen will convene next week to investigate a ten-year dispute in Philadelphia and Chester Presbyteries over fundamental and liberal church policies.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- In a subdued tone, Grover A. Whalen Jr., 14 years old, son of the former New York City Police Commissioner, today related from his sick-bed how he had stumbled in woods more than a mile from his parents' Ashford Avenue estate yesterday and had injured his head against a rock.
On Tuesday Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign will go into its first active phase in a drive for "noiseless nights" in New York City.

THIS year the Metropolitan Museum's free story hours for boys and girls, opening in the large lecture hall next Saturday and continuing every Saturday and Sunday thereafter until May, will try new ways of interesting their young auditors.

In what degree does art represent a barometer of the social scene? This is a question difficult to answer; one that can never, perhaps, be answered with absolute finality. Yet that art does in a direct way, and more or less accurately, reflect the temper and the social outlook of its time must be apparent to all who look back across the years.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Everything looked favorable for the British battalion in the Ryder Cup engagement until they started to play golf. The weather was such as a home-loving Englishman would find at Woking or Dorking or Tunbridge Wells at this season of the year. A drenching drizzle that coated the turf and left the trees dripping sorrowfully through the day.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to submit to the voters at the general election in November a proposal to construct and operate a municipally owned $45,000,000 "yardstick" city power plant received a setback last evening.

IN the popular imagination, Afghanistan is generally identified with the Indian North West Frontier -- a region whose murderous excitements have lately made great appeal to movie-goers. Such excitements undoubtedly occur. But what the popular imagination does not realize is that they are as troublesome to the Afghan Government as to the Indian. For Afghanistan is a country as well as a frontier.

EXPERIENCED fliers in this country, especially marine aviators who took part in the two-year campaign to crush Sandino and his rebel partisans in Nicaragua, are inclined to view with some skepticism the advance declarations of Italian airmen on their plans in Ethiopia.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 26. -- Political play and counterplay, some of it deadly serious, some ludicrous, but all involving the vote of the State's delegation to the next Democratic National Convention, have held the interest of Georgia this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Senator Borah won 53 per cent of the ballots cast in a straw vote by Republican precinct workers in Southwestern Iowa, compiled this week by John M. Henry of Radio station KOIL of Council Bluffs, Iowa, it was announced today.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 28. -Leaden skies failed to dampen the ardor of the tanbark enthusiasts who packed every available space today to witness the finals of the thirty-ninth annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28. -- Pittsburgh was held to a two-touchdown victory by Waynesburg College as the Panthers won, 14 to 0, before a crowd of 12,000 in a drizzling rain today.

Confronted with sanctions which might, in the end, include the employment of overwhelming British and French fleets, Premier Mussolini has decided to take further time for conciliation before entering on the conquest of Ethiopia. His spokesman announces he is willing to have a truce of two weeks while the Council of the League of Nations decides what course it will take. The Rome Cabinet marks time.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Undergraduate enrolment in the men's colleges of Rutgers University shows an increase of forty-four students over last year's figure, with 1,239 fully qualified men registered, it was announced today by Luther H. Martin, registrar. The biggest enrolment jump was in the freshman class, where 409 first-year men were listed, compared with 372 in 1934.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- The directors of the Suez Canal Company will meet Oct. 7, as usual on the first Monday of every month, but it was said there was no intention or expectation of discussing the possibility of closing the canal to Italy by the League of Nations.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Forty-five Smith College students will study in Europe this year under the "junior year abroad" plan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Not since the days of Theodore Roosevelt has any American President known so well how to combine business and pleasure in a vacation as does the escaped prisoner of the White House, who, when this is published, will be traveling through the irrigated farms and blinding sands of Utah on his way to Boulder Dam.

MUCH has been written about Evangeline Booth and the Salvation Army, but there is still room for this monograph that gives a rapid, vitalized sketch of her life and of the force that is the Army, each fused with the other in that inextricable way that is characteristic of the organization William Booth gave to the world.
All divisions of Cooper Union, with about 2,200 "highly selective" students enrolled, will be in operation tomorrow for the seventy-sixth academic year when day art classes open.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 28. -State Senator William H. Clark, Republican leader of Chester County and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee during the last session of the Legislature, was found guilty today on four counts of extortion and malfeasance by a jury in the Dauphin County Court. He faces a possible prison sentence of six years and a fine of $1,000.

THE cable reports that next week's events in London are these: On Monday the Lyric, in Hammersmith, the scene of the late Nigel Playfair's revivals, reopens with "The Merchant of Venice" as the first item in a Shakespearean season.

THIS is the most comprehensive book published so far on the fall of the German Republic. It contains a detailed narrative and an abundance of thoughtful interpretation of events beginning with the collapse of the Western front and leading up to the Nazi dictatorship.

IN the new modes of fiction of the Nineteen Twenties and Thirties novelists have observed the best and the worst features of our historic past. Perhaps the complex currents in contemporary American life account in part for the surprisingly diversified and energetic interest in pioneer existence.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the names of 252 students in various undergraduate divisions who would lead the classes, publications and other organizations for the academic year.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 28. -- President Lazaro Cardenas, in a message received by Congress this afternoon, declared that educational reorganization in Mexico "must radically suppress the character of a monopoly privilege for the wealthy class that higher education has had to date as a result of the economic and social organization of the country and the dependence of the government upon the demands of minorities possessing riches and knowledge."
THE Louis-Baer million-dollar gate was apparently a million-listener gate on the radio. It may have been several millions, but no one knows exactly.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 28. -- Classical and modern dances, some never before presented in the metropolitan area, were in the repertoire tonight of the American Ballet at the first public appearance of the company this season. An audience of more than 2,000 persons attended the performance, held at the County Centre for the benefit of Westchester County Girl Scouts.
AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Amherst and Colby battled to a 6-6 tie this afternoon, as a heavy rain fell throughout the game. Both scores came in the second period.

MEMEL, Sept. 28. -- The campaign for the election of the Memel Diet, to which National Socialist propaganda has given the character of a plebiscite for the territory's return to Germany and to which a warning by Britain, France and Italy in Berlin furnished the final international pyrotechnic display, came to a close tonight with all indications pointing to a reduced but still sweeping German majority.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Scoring in every period except the third, Lawrenceville swept to a 33-0 victory over Germantown Academy today, exhibiting strong defensive and offensive power.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP). -The Athletics and the Senators spy a double-header today, the Mack men taking the first game, 5 to in eleven innings and the Senator scoring a 8-0 decision in a game stopped at the end of six inning on account of darkness.
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Nothing has heartened the British Government more throughout this dangerous Italo-Ethiopian crisis than the support its policies are receiving from dominions across the seas.

WHEN Joseph Sweeney made his first appearance on the New York stage it was another man who scored what they call in artillery circles a direct hit. The other man was Willard Mack, author-actor in his own play, "Santa Barbara," and what he aimed at was the protuberance on Mr. Sweeney's countenance, vulgarly called a snout.

The conflict between Italy and Ethiopia, with its ominous international complications, has brought to light many little-known historical facts about the mysterious land of the Conquering Lion of Judah.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 28. -- The Virginia eleven, which opened its season against William and Mary last week, was forced to bow to Hampden-Sydney today. The Tigers from Death Valley, led by a flashy halfback. Harold White, who scored two touchdowns, registered a well-earned 12-to-7 victory, the first they have registered over the Cavaliers in a long period of years.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Their freshman year course at Mount Holyoke-in-Hartford completed, the twenty-five girls who took part in this successful educational experiment last year are already at work in new fields, most of them electing to continue their studies at Mount Holyoke or some other college for women.

Discussion of the effect which new Federal social security taxes will have upon prices after Jan. 1, when the initial levy of 1 per cent goes into effect, occupied industrial purchasing executives and manufacturers last week. With the time for closing contracts for the new year rapidly approaching, purchasing executives are seeking to establish an understanding with suppliers concerning the tax.

MANY metropolitan stylists for men hold that the majority of new ideas in men's wearables get their start on college campuses. The validity of this opinion is amply proved this Fall in one instance, at least -- that of the reversible gabardine-camel's hair topcoat.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 28. -After an early session of fumbling, in which each team had about an equal part, the Navy team broke loose today to win from William and Mary, 30 to 0, the largest score in the history of the eleven-game series, before a crowd of over 12,000 in Thompson Stadium.

Gala as a harvest festival, but purposeful beneath its glitter, the fourteenth annual edition of the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries will fling wide its doors tomorrow in the ballroom of the Hotel Astor. It will be the focal point throughout the week for the feminine contingent of all the metropolitan area.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- Adoption of the League of Nations budget for 1936 at the closing session of the Assembly of the League today provided a picture of the dwindling of the League's machinery and activity for peace and prosperity.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- Without any word from Italy the sixteenth League of Nations Assembly today unanimously agreed because of "present political circumstances" not to dissolve as its predecessors always had done. Having finished its agenda it adjourned instead, subject to an emergency call by its president, Dr. Edward Benese, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia.

THE seventy-sixth Worcester Musical Festival will open in the Auditorium of the Massachusetts city tomorrow night when a Bach, Handel and Elgar program will be presented under the baton of the festival conductor, Albert Stoessel.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 28. -But for the two old war-horses on the British Ryder Cup team, Captain Charles Whitcombe and his 45-year-old brother, Ernest, the invaders would have been left completely in the ruck by the American representatives in today's Scotch foursomes, which opened the fifth international matches between the leading golf professionals of the two nations.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Williams opened its season auspiciously today overwhelming Massachusetts State, 28 to 0, in a steady downpour. Eddie Stanley scored three Purple touchdowns, but his brilliant running was equaled by the interference and defense work of his back-field mates, Holmes, Salsich and Moseley.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28. -- A record high scholarship average is found in the freshman class that entered Harvard last week, Dr. Richard M. Gummere, chairman of the committee on admissions, declared tonight. In the class are more students who won scholastic honors in preparatory schools than were in any previous Harvard class.
WASHINGTON (S.S.) -- Two Gibraltars guard the destiny of the British Empire -- and the other one is Ethiopia.

MISS JARRETTS earlier novel, "Night Over Fitch's Pond" was a psychological thriller so subtle and strange that it could hardly be classed with the ordinary detective story. It had an artfully developed technique of suspense which Jarrett has now reapplied for rather different purposes.

THE Louvre Museum has just received one of the richest gifts in its history -- the Baron Edmond de Rothschild collection of engravings and drawings. About 20,000 engravings of the finest quality and some 7,000 equally important drawings compose this world-famous collection of a gifted connoisseur who spent the spare moments of a long and useful lifetime at his genial task.

New engagements of gold in Europe totaling $6,642,000 for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, bringing the amount engaged since Sept. 9 to $208,500,000 of which $108,100,000 has already reached here.

EVER since the invention of printing the freedom of the press has been, in one form or another, an issue. It has been a confusing issue because at different times and in different places there have been variations in the question, from what and for what is the press to be free?

ABOUT a fortnight ago brief announcements appeared to the effect that in a letter to the British scientific weekly, Nature, Sir James Jeans had expressed himself again on the age of the universe. Now that the particular issue of Nature in which Sir James's letter appeared has reached this country we are able to learn how a great astronomer and mathematician attempts to solve a baffling problem in physics and cosmogony.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The Boerse was inactive today but gave evidence of some firmness. Heavy industrials showed resistance, Hoesch gaining 1/4 point. Firmness appeared in the chemicals group, I.G. Farben gaining 1 point. Electricals were quiet, but AEG gained 3/8 point.
About 100 persons stood around a plot in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn yesterday in a misty afternoon with heads bowed in memory of Henry George, at whose grave they had gathered.

THREE MILLION men, women and children today share a new hope, born of the generosity of the American people. They are the lepers -sufferers from one of the most terrible of human afflictions. Their hope is founded on the fact that the Leonard Wood Memorial has developed a program providing for international cooperation in an effort to ascertain how leprosy is communicated and why it persists in certain areas.

DURING his years of retirement from public office, Mr. Lansing, like other statesmen of the World War, prepared a narrative of the part that he played in events of infinite moment to mankind. In October, 1928, the writing of these memoirs was regrettably interrupted by Mr. Lansing's death.

The advent of the Jewish New Year of 5696 yesterday was signalized with a call to worship in the temples and synagogues of the city, where, in conformity to ancient ceremonials, the host of orthodox Jewry listened to the counsel of their rabbis.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 28 (AP) -Egypt's "real anxiety" in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis, a high official said today, "is to conclude a projected treaty with Great Britain enabling us to assume our own responsibilities in case of a national emergency."

Three out of every four exporters made gains in their foreign sales this year compared with last, Francis T. Cole, vice president of the American Manufacturers Export Association, announced yesterday. His statement was based on results of a questionnaire sent to 500 manufacturers in all sections of the country who export more than 2,000 items in forty general classifications.

THE English-speaking world is about to celebrate an event which occurred 400 years ago and yet today has an immediate significance. On Oct. 4, 1535, the first English Bible -- complete from Genesis to Revelation -- was issued from the printing press and made available to the people.

SUCCESS: Again last week the Prince of Wales did what was expected of him. Following in the footsteps of his grandfather, Edward VII, he went to St. Wolfgang, in Austria, to hunt the elusive chamois. The hunt started last Sunday; Tuesday the Prince departed for Munich, bearing with him the beard of a chamois, traditional trophy of success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The government budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1937, is in preparation. Prospective income is being forecast; expenditures are being planned. More than 1,000 persons -- government administrators, economists, accountants, printers, binders and other craftsmen -- will work on the budget until the President delivers it to Congress next January.

RAPID CITY, Sept. 28. -- A lighter, trimmer gondola is being rigged here to start aloft in the next few days, when weather permits, under a stronger balloon than was used in the stratosphere flight that resulted in a burst balloon and abandonment July 12.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- The country's good corn crop is the most important business news of the day, The Corn Belt Farm Dailies says in a report of a survey of the outlook of the agricultural territory that it serves.

ATLANTA, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Objections to Governor Talmadge, critic of the New Deal, having any part in Georgia's welcome to President Roosevelt in November are being voiced by admirers of the President.

THE Burge Memorial Trust was founded in 1926 to commemorate the work for international friendship of the Right Rev. Hubert Murray Burke, formerly Bishop of Oxford and president of the British Council of the World Alliance for Promoting International Friendship Through the Churches.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- Criticism of widespread parachute jumping in the Soviet Union without adequate instruction and inspection of the parachutes was voiced today by the Society of Aviation and Chemical Defense and the Central Committee of the Communist Youth.

ATHENS, Sept. 28. -- Royalist officers who were cashiered for political reasons by the Venizelist Government, have been restored in retirement to the grades that would have been theirs now if their careers had not been interrupted.

The city's anti-noise campaign will be started formally tomorrow night by Mayor La Guardia in a radio address from City Hall. He will proclaim October a month of "noiseless nights" and will ask the active support of every resident in the attempt to make New York City a quieter place in which to live.

As he swings westward he faces a nation waiting to be convinced that all is well and that the New Deal is in fact pulling it up into the sunlight of prosperity and security for all.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Prosecutor Abe J. David of Union County discredited today the stories of eight deputy sheriffs that they acted in self-defense when Mrs. Sophie Crempa was fatally wounded on her cottage porch here Thursday afternoon and filed a manslaughter charge against Charles Remley, 47-year-old deputy, of Cranford.

Mrs. Harry A. Marshall of Summit will be the speaker, on the topic, "The Responsibility of Being a D.A.R." Mrs. Franklin D'Olier will tell of the Community Chest drive.

THE hardiest perennial of the Soviet theatre, Valentine Katayev's "Squaring the Circle," comes to the Lyceum Theatre next Thursday evening in its first professional American production and haloed by an international reputation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Kentucky, the only State which is to elect a Governor next November, will elect a Republican to succeed Governor Ruby Laffoon, the Democratic incumbent, Republican leaders predicted today.
HAVANA, Sept. 28. -- A tropical hurricane killed and destroyed through a 150-mile belt of the heart of Cuba today and blew northward toward Florida.

After reading an advertisement in THE NEW YORK TIMES offering to sell me a carload of coal direct from the mines:

In addition to active hedging operations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday October contracts were strong and sold 5 points above December at one time.
