The stiff premium on the near month that had existed several weeks ago was wiped out when the manager of the government's pool released 200,000 bales of October contracts, which resulted in establishing a discount recently.

ACURIOUS literary problem is posed by that veteran author, Arthur Machen, in John o' London's Weekly. Imagine a man marooned on a desert island, and certain that he would remain there for the rest of his Life.

Although the Interborough subway division showed a 2.9 per cent loss in traffic for August, compared with August, 1934, its Manhattan division showed a gain of .17 per cent, according to a monthly report submitted to Federal Judge Julian W. Mack by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Simultaneously with the radio reproduction of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's recent speech on the Memel situation, demonstrations were conducted tonight in a number of German communities near the Memel border, with the result that the region was thrown into a high state of excitement. Strict discipline was reported everywhere.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28. -Holy Cross turned back Providence College, 12 to 0, on a rain-soaked field today. The Friars could do little against the bulwark defense of the Crusaders and were unable to register a single first down during the contest.

The former Miss Barbara Hutton will receive one-fifth of an estate valued at approximately $2,000,000, in the will of her former husband, Prince Alexis Z. Mdivani, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Although the exact amount of the residue was not disclosed in the petition, an estimate of its value was given by attorneys for the estate.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 28. -- Twenty miles west of this capital, on the floor of a valley green with an immensity of pastureland, a group of rectangular, metal-roofed buildings is the only sight within long eyeshot which seems touched by the hand of Western man.

VICHY, Sept. 9, 1935. THE Permanent Council for the International Cooperation of Composers, which opened here Sept. 2, closed on Sept. 9. The International Music Festival, which ran parallel to the council, closed the same evening with a gala concert in the Casino Theatre, under the direction of Richard Strauss, Kurt Atterberg and Louis Fourestier.

THE title of thin book is misleading in that it implies a general portraying of the men of literary eminence with whom the author of "The Nigger of the 'Narcissus,'" "Youth" and "Victory" was in intimate contact.

Directors of the Contemporary Club of White Plains will open the season tomorrow with a business session at the clubhouse. Mrs. Samuel W. Hamilton, the president, will preside. On Wednesday the first open meeting of the club is scheduled, with the program under auspices of the literature section.

PERHAPS the time has come to talk of Ian Hunter, the tall and slightly rugged Englishman who has filtered into Hollywood through London and Broadway. Not so long ago he was nursed through a broken heart and the DT's by Bette Davis in "The Girl from Tenth Avenue."

ROME, Sept. 28. -- The crisis thickening in Europe is a crisis of miscalculations. To go to London, Paris or Rome is to be painfully struck by the common dismay of all three capitals in the face of developments apparently unforeseen until they occurred.

FKOM a point of vantage almost behind the scenes, several of Columbia's practices have always struck us as being particularly commendable. Though the returns from the issue of albums of chamber music could never have been sensational, the company has steadily continued to issue these until its library, recorded in the main by the Leners, must be the most comprehensive in any catalogue.

ONE of the most valuable institutions for the cultivation of modern music in Switzerland is the Societe de Musique de Chambre Contemporaine, "Le Carillon," of Geneva, organized by four progressive musicians of that city: Andre de Blonay, Jean Binet, Henry Brolliet and A.F. Marescotti.

BEAVERS may once more become the basis on which all furs are valued, if experiments now being conducted by the Notional Parks branch of the Canadian Government are successful. Once their pelts were "the coin of the realm," and beavers became so scarce that today no white man may trap them in the Dominion, and Indians may do so only in limited areas.

LAST season in Paris when the Vionnet collection got under way onlookers were held spellbound. One breath-taking model after another swept through the vast salon. The showing encompassed not only the most sumptuous of evening gowns and wraps; it also contained charming daytime suits and frocks, simple enough for any young girl to wear.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The third in the series of tentative drafts completely revising the State Code of Criminal Procedure was made public today by State Senator John L. Buckley of New York City, Chairman of the Commission on the Administration of Justice.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Sept. 26. -Maybe the Roosevelt administration is slipping and some phases of the New Deal have been discredited, but the AAA is stronger than ever with the Kansas wheat farmers. In larger numbers this week they signed the four-year contract with the government to curtail wheat production.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 28. -Arthur Raimo, sophomore fullback from Everett, Mass., starred in Villanova's 31-0 victory over Ursinus College today. The New England lad scored three of the five touchdowns, the second coming on a sensational 67-yard dash around left end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Notre Dame, "long shot" mystery ship almost unknown and all but unheralded on Eastern waters, cut through the muddy Potomac today to finish miles ahead of old familiar, rivals and hang up a spectacular triumph in the first of three fifteen-mile heats for the President's Cup.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Gus Sumnick, Nebraska farmer, missing when his sons and daughters shook hands with President Roosevelt during the stop here today on the President's special train, did not miss his opportunity to visit with the President as the family at first thought.

THIS Country wants peace -- not only for itself but for all the nations of the world. This the basic principle of the foreign policy of the United States as interpreted by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State.

ONCE at home in most of Central and Western India, the lion is slowly vanishing from the peninsula. His last stronghold is the Gir forest in the State of Junagadh, in Kathiawar. Even there his numbers have dwindled until, at the turn of the century, it was said that fewer than a score of the animals remained.

THIS is an amazing book -- amazing in the story that it tells but amazing, too, that it could ever have been written at all. The book itself partakes of the mystery of the author. The first manuscript of the major part of it was lost in a railway station in England while Lawrence was changing trains back in 1919.

Advertising claims and selling practices of retail furniture dealers in this city have been "praiseworthy" in their honesty since the adoption of a self-regulating code on June 27, according to a report issued yesterday by James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealer of New York, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- La Salle College, undefeated since 1933, opened its football season today by downing Davis and Elkins in the Temple Stadium, 14 to 0.

ROADS OF COTTON: The South, anxious to devise new uses for cotton, made a road out of it last week. An experimental half mile was laid at Scott, Miss., and enthusiasts estimated that within a year $100,000,000 would be spent on similar highways. This is the way you make a cotton road:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28. -- For the first time in its twenty-one years of existence, the Girl Scout National Council will convene on the Pacific Coast for its annual meeting, when sessions open Wednesday in the Fairmont Hotel here.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27. -- Of all those who hitched themselves to Huey Long's political star the only one who is certain of a direct legacy from the dictatorship which Long established in Louisiana is Wade Omer Martin, chairman of the Public Service Commission, who for the brief space of little more than a year will be privileged to play the role of the late Senator before a national audience.

WITH Otto Klemperer conducting, the orchestra of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society will open its season in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. The opening program, consisting of Beethoven's "Egmont" overture, Shostakovich's symphony Op. 10, the Brahms A major Serenade and the Bach-Weiner Toccata in C major, will be repeated on Friday afternoon, Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon.

ADULT education, long the fragile project of idealistic educators who foresaw it as a vital part of some future Utopia, has grown almost overnight into a flourishing reality. This Fall in New York City alone about 100,000 adults between the ages of 17 and 70 are registered in the free classes offered by the adult education undertaking of the Board of Education and the WPA.

An intracity competition among the drama groups of eight colleges and universities in New York has been proposed by the Dramatic Society of City College, according to E. Lawrence Goodman, '36, chairman of the society. The competition, to be held in December, will be in the presentation of one-act plays, presumably original, by each of the schools represented.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 28. -- Wesleyan routed the Coast Guard Academy today, 27 to 0, in the first football game ever played by the two schools. The Coast Guard pinned its hopes on Blovin, who did most of the ball carrying.

Relaxation from the "war" tension was one of the most important characteristics of our security and commodity markets during the week just completed. While not matching the cheerfulness reported in London and in some of the Continental European markets, our share market held its own rather well in an extremely dull week.

A GREAT many things have happened to "The Taming of the Shrew" since the day in 1594 when Will Shakespeare walked into the Theatre and Curtain in Shoreditch and tossed the manuscript to Dick Burbage and his company of players.

Unity among shipping men with respect to legislative aims will be sought by leaders in the industry at the American merchant marine conference and ninth annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States, which will be held at the Waldorf Nov. 17-19.

A LARGE group exhibition composed of work by members of an organization known as Scandinavian American Artists is current in the Squibb Art Galleries, 745 Fifth Avenue. It will be on until Oct. 11. The work is extremely various and some of it proves out of the ordinary, though one notes a good bit of painting that is technically crude.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Mrs. Anna Sage, the "woman in red," who was with John Dillinger when the outlaw was slain July 22, 1934, was temporarily saved from deportation today on the ground that it was she who walked Dillinger in front of the guns of Federal agents and East Chicago (Ind.) policemen in return for a promise that she would not be deported.

THE big game of Western Canada, which once threatened to become extinct because of the many fur hunters, today roams unmolested over vast areas now set aside as refuges. Recent governmental policy has been to save wild life, especially types such as the buffalo and antelope, which were at the beginning of the century practically extinct.

LATEST of the camera entrepreneurs to come in out of the wilds with a cargo of raw celluloid tucked under an arm is the Marquis Henri de la Falaise, known to his friends as "Hank" and to the general public as the husband of Constance Bennett.

GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- The Italo-Ethiopian drama is being played in Geneva on a stage with acoustics unequaled in diplomacy. That applies to its diacoustics, which physicists say concern "sounds" coming directly from a sonorous body to the "ear," and even more to its catacoustics or "reflected" sounds or "echoes."

WITH registration for the Fall semester incomplete, 12,385 students had enrolled on the Berkeley campus of the University of California by Sept. 3, according to Registrar T.B. Steel. Air. Steel estimates there will be approximately 500 more late registrants, bringing the total close to 13,000.
The funeral yesterday morning of Roderick J. Kennedy, who organized the St. Patrick's Day parades here for the last fifty-five years, included a procession through the streets.
MOST of the men had their shirt-sleeves rolled up; some of the women carried babies in arms. It was a festive crowd: noisy and rollicking, it oozed good-humoredly around the Bastile, 300,000 strong.

Bequests to the trustees of Columbia University and to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, its president, were listed in the will of his sister, the late Miss Eliza Rhees Butler, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. The amount of the estate was not given, but specific bequests listed totaled $33,000.

In the Summer of 1934 the New York State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration chose Tompkins County as the unit for a demonstration in rural development. The immediate purpose was to supply work relief; the long-time objective, social and economic security of the inhabitants.

The feud between church and State is an old one; it fills many pages of ancient and modern history. Today in most countries church and State are independent in their own spheres, in accordance with the Biblical saying: "Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's." (Matthew XXII, 21.)

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The U.S.S. Flusser, a 1,500-ton destroyer, was launched today at the Federal Ship Building and Dry Dock Company plant on the Hackensack River here. The vessel was decked with flags and champagne dripped from its bow as it slid down the ways.

A NEW book by Walter De La Mare is a rare experience. "Early One Morning" strikes the first notes of its motif in its sub-title. "The main intention," says Mr. De La Mare, "is to present childhood by way of recollection -- early memories gleaned from many witnesses, not always perhaps of a very valuable kind, but chiefly from those who were best able to put them into words, since they were themselves writers."

THE NEW YORK TIMES has published excellent reports of the sessions of scientific societies which recently met to discuss various ills afflicting humanity. The speakers at these meetings have recommended for diseased bodies such ameliorations as can be secured by the use of hydrotherapy, hygiene, dietetics, , combined with "baths and bathing," using medicated solutions of hot and cold degree.

THE Packard Motor Car Company introduced yesterday its cars for 1936, including four lines headed by the "120" models. This car, brought out for the first time earlier this year, is in the $1,000 price field. The others, at higher prices, are the Eight. Super-Eight and Twelve.

WHEN we planned our trip by air from New York to Norway, along the Greenland-to-"Vinland" route which Leif Ericson followed, it was with the idea of playing safe and flying only when the weather gave us a good chance of getting through.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- A long column of memorial notices on the front page of The Times Wednesday and another half-column yesterday were reminders that it was the anniversary of the Battle of Loos. There were more than 60,000 British casualties -- killed, wounded and missing -- in that battle.

We have received the full text of the comprehensive "World Economic Survey," prepared for the League of Nations annually by its industrious economist and statistician, Mr. J.B. CONDLIFFE. It covers the period from the middle of 1934 to the middle of 1935, and draws its general conclusions from a mass of statistical information, obtained from all the countries.

Here is a murder mystery in the Tennessee mountains, and not a moonshiner is in sight. The scene is a mountain valley where CCC men are at work clearing away forests in preparation for building a dam which is part of a TVA project.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 28. -Three youths were injured here today on the New Jersey State Rifle Range when a discarded one-pound shell exploded after one of them playfully kicked it.

TRAVEL to Hawaii this year promises to set a new high mark. The record to date was set in 1929, when 22,190 tourists visited the islands. The traffic then dropped to 10,372 in 1932, rose to 16,161 in 1934, and this year, according to estimates based on records of the Chamber of Commerce of Honolulu, will probably exceed 23,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Bloomfield High School's football warriors gave evidence today that they have another powerful outfit to defend their New Jersey championship when they ran roughshod over James Madison of Brooklyn by a score of 41 to 0. Making and taking the breaks, Bloomfield registered twelve first downs.

Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College, in his annual report to the president of the university, made public yesterday, declares that symptoms of disorder cropping out on the college campus are largely due to the distrust which keeps the radical and the conservative elements in the student body apart.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28. -Clyde Coffman of the Kansas City A.A. won the national A.A.U. pentathlon championship with a score of 3,084 points today as three crowns were contested in Palmer Stadium. The 10,000-meter run and 3,000-meter steeplechase championships were also decided.

WHEN we planned our trip by air from New York to Norway, along the Greenland-to-"Vinland" route which Leif Ericson followed, it was with the idea of playing safe and flying only when the weather gave us a good chance of getting through.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- A long column of memorial notices on the front page of The Times Wednesday and another half-column yesterday were reminders that it was the anniversary of the Battle of Loos. There were more than 60,000 British casualties -- killed, wounded and missing -- in that battle.

We have received the full text of the comprehensive "World Economic Survey," prepared for the League of Nations annually by its industrious economist and statistician, Mr. J.B. CONDLIFFE. It covers the period from the middle of 1934 to the middle of 1935, and draws its general conclusions from a mass of statistical information, obtained from all the countries.

Here is a murder mystery in the Tennessee mountains, and not a moonshiner is in sight. The scene is a mountain valley where CCC men are at work clearing away forests in preparation for building a dam which is part of a TVA project.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 28. -Three youths were injured here today on the New Jersey State Rifle Range when a discarded one-pound shell exploded after one of them playfully kicked it.

TRAVEL to Hawaii this year promises to set a new high mark. The record to date was set in 1929, when 22,190 tourists visited the islands. The traffic then dropped to 10,372 in 1932, rose to 16,161 in 1934, and this year, according to estimates based on records of the Chamber of Commerce of Honolulu, will probably exceed 23,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Bloomfield High School's football warriors gave evidence today that they have another powerful outfit to defend their New Jersey championship when they ran roughshod over James Madison of Brooklyn by a score of 41 to 0. Making and taking the breaks, Bloomfield registered twelve first downs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- White Plains High School, W.I.A.A. champion last season, opened its 1935 campaign before a crowd of 3,000 in Parker Stadium today by turning back Derby High of Connecticut, 20 to 14.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 28. -- Lloyd Cardwell, Cornhusker halfback, stole the show in which Jay Berwanger of the Maroons was given the star billing as Nebraska defeated Chicago, 28 to 7, today in an interconference football game which opened the season for each team.

NEW YORK, city of superlatives, now turns its gigantic resources to preparation for a world's fair to open here in 1939. Announcement of preliminary plans, made last week, at first came as a shock to a metropolis that has nearly 200,000 families on the dole and 150,000 persons on work relief.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- Calling on young Communists to join Fascist youth organizations so that they may be able to approach the membership on a common footing, Wolf Mikhal of Czechoslovakia laid down a four-point program at yesterday's session of the Sixth Congress of International Youth.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- Tomorrow evening publication will be given to the British Government's reply to the French note asking for a specific statement on the attitude Great Britain would take in the event of an act of aggression by any European power against another.

PRAGUE, Sept. 10, 1935. THE thirteenth festival of the International Society of Contemporary Music which occupied the week of Sept. 1-8 was jinxed before it ever began. A neat little game of politics inspired from a somewhat more northerly latitude frustrated the original purpose of holding the event in Carlsbad.

The meeting at Town Hall last Sunday at which Mayor LA GUARDIA and former Governor SMITH spoke with fervor and moving effect was held at the call of the united faiths for the mobilization of their spiritual forces. The word "mobilization" has come to have association in the minds of the English-speaking world with military affairs; but "military" in the mother language, Sanskrit, meant merely an associated, a united movement with a common purpose.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 28. -- All hurricane warnings were hauled down along Florida's east coast at 11 o'clock tonight as the centre of the tropical disturbance moving up from Cuba and Jamaica passed out over the Atlantic Ocean about forty miles east of Miami.

Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony, will arrive this morning on the Gripsholm, coming from Sweden, where he recently conducted at the Stockholm Festival after having opened the Sibelius Festival in Helsingfors, Finland. He will begin rehearsals for the Boston Orchestra's new season, to open Oct. 11.

Germany's decree restricting citizenship to "German or racially related blood" will deprive Jews of German citizenship, leaving them in the yet undefined status of "State members," without the right to vote. Such revocations of privilege among a native-born group in a country is almost unprecedented in recent times.

More than 300 entries have been listed for the annual Soldiers and Sailors Club Horse Show to be held next Sunday at the Rockwood Hall Country Club, Tarrytown-on-Hudson, N.Y. The event is under the auspices of the American Horse Show Association and the net proceeds will further the maintenance of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Financial circles here believed tonight that they had identified the corporate vehicle through which O.P. and M.J. Van Sweringen of this city expect to fight for control of their vast railroad empire on Monday when the keys to it are offered for sale in New York.

IN the Summer just vanished -in late July, to be exact -- when the Broadway theatre smoldered and the fires of drama were being kindled in sundry barns hereabouts, an event purported to be of significance in the American theatre occurred in Iowa City, Iowa.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Tigers are convinced that power at the plate plus three ace pitchers and a great receiver will add up to Detroit's first world championship in half a century.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the item in the editorial section of THE TIMES of Sept. 22, "Labor Act Questioned," this chap Ickes is most versatile and sometimes droll. His present impersonation of a Hans Christian Andersen character is inimitable.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 28 (AP). -- The directors of the Coca-Cola Company today voted to recommend to a meeting of stockholders on Oct. 27 a split-up of the present outstanding 1,000,000 common shares into 4,000,000 shares. If approved, the increased capital stock will be distributed among common stockholders of record at a date to be fixed later.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- A nation-wide inquiry into the mounting costs of food will be conducted by the Federal Trade Commission, under direct orders from President Roosevelt, it was learned today. The President has authorized the commission to expend as much as $75,000 of its current appropriation in the work.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Business prospects in New England are distinctly "better." The surveys lately reported respectively by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, the New England Council and Dun Bradstreet differ slightly in detail while they agree that substantial gains are taking place.

The auction season at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., will be opened this week with a three-session sale, comprising property of Charles Roberson of London, England; the estate of Augustus Lukeman, A.N.A., Mrs. George R. Van Reed and others.

NEW YORK'S back yards with their apologetic ailanthus trees are emerging from obscurity with the conversion of an increasing number of tenements and brownstone fronts into modern living quarters. Sodded and planted to flowering shrubs and plants, back yards, courts and areaways adjoining old buildings are being turned into gardens to meet a growing demand for green things.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The voice of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler unexpectedly broke into the Saturday vesper broadcast this evening. It spoke in firm but reassuring tones to the Germans in Memel Territory, to whom all Germany is now looking for an impressive reiteration of loyalty to the fatherland in the election tomorrow.

IGNAZIO SILONE is an Italian and an artist who grew to maturity under Fascism. Just as he has been an uncompromising enemy of the Fascist regime, so has he remained an uncompromising adherent to that truth which the artist as realistic story-teller must follow at all hazards -- the truth of objective reality.

Since only 194 persons paid to view the proceedings at Ebbets Field yesterday, it may be news to a large number of baseball fans that the Dodgers scored their sixth straight triumph by trouncing the Phils, 12 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- From bookkeepers to politicians no two persons or groups of persons can be found who will agree about the expenditures of the New Deal. Not only do politicians disagree about the efficacy of the government's spending policy, but very few accountants could agree on exactly how much the government is spending.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- The Congress of Communist Youth today cheered the declaration of the Czechoslovak delegate, Wolf Mikhal, that the young generation of the world would defend the Soviet Union if it were ever attacked by Nazi Germany.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28. -Polo's high goal season came to a close today with the pink shirts of the Greentree riders shining in triumph through a cold gray mist of rain that shut down almost like a fog over International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 28. -- Thirty-six producing mines in Ontario added $6,627,242 to the Province's gold production in August, according to the monthly gold bulletin issued by the Ontario Department of Mines. This is an increase of $224,185 over the July production, amounting to $6,403,057, and an increase of $568,292 over the output in August, 1934.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Indans took both ends of a doubleheader with the Browns today, 3 to 0 in the first game and 7 to 3 in the final, clinching third place in the American League race.

LISBON, Sept. 12, 1935. A VALUABLE contribution to the incomplete music history of Portugal has just been made with the publication by Messrs. Schott (Mainz) of a notable collection of old Portuguese harpsichord music, edited under the title of "Cravistas Portuguezes" by Macario Santiago Kastner, a skilled investigator and performer on that instrument.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 28. -- President Roosevelt's letter to Senator Barkley was read by the Senator before the Democratic State Central Executive Committee in January as he urged committee to call a primary election to select Democratic nominees for Governor and other State offices.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- The possibility of reviving Roald Amundsen, who was lost seven years ago on an Arctic flight, if Amundsen is found frozen to death, is foreseen by Dr. S.S. Briukhanenko of the Moscow Blood Transfusion Institute in a report published in today's Pravda.
In a major dispute between members of the League of Nations, the Council of the League has gone further than ever hitherto toward bringing the obligations of the League into operation.

SEATTLE, Sept. 26. -- They are not yet sure that they can raise enough money to invite the interest of Gutzon Borglum, but only a sculptor who can work on a titanic scale will do for the group of Seattle enthusiasts who mean to have the likeness of James Delmage Ross stand forth from the rocky side of one of the Cascade Mountains.

LONDON, Sept. 6. APART from Charlot's new revue, "Stop . . . Go!" which is competent by the rule but no exception to it, the plays of the week have been Samson Raphaelson's "Accent on Youth," with which New York audiences are already familiar, and "As Bad as I Am," a farce by Brandon Fleming.

In connection with the tercentenary of Connecticut, 1635-1935, Fairfield County's oldest known original probate document has been reproduced by the Bridgeport-City Trust Company as one of its series of historical brochures.

THE last reel of Charles Chaplin's forthcoming picture, "Modern Times," has been materially affected by a conversation between the producer and B.Z. Shumiatsky, head of the Russian film industry, according to a statement made by the latter in Moscow immediately following his return from his recent visit to Hollywood.
HAVANA, Sept. 28. -- An area 150 to 200 miles wide in east central Cuba was swept by a hurricane last night and early today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- When divorces in the Soviet Union mounted so rapidly that they threatened to equal 50 per cent of the marraiges and the Soviet courts were compelled to handle 500,000 alimony cases in a three-year period, the government ruled that a frivolous attitude toward the family constituted a crime and dissoluteness in marriage an insult to morality.

THE Westchester Little Opera Company, with the cooperation of the Westchester Recreation Commission, will open its second esason with "Faust" on Saturday at the County Centre in White Plains. The opera will be repeated on Tuesday, Oct. 8.

If ever remarks were ill-timed, those of Senator BORAH last week about the League of Nations must be so designated. They were unlucky for him and for his reputation as a statesman, and must have filled his hearers with amazement. For he was attacking the League at the very time when it was rising to the full height of its power and the dignity of its function in the world.

When the street lights around Washington Square came on at nightfall yesterday the 450 artists who had exhibited at the eighth open-air art show packed up their unsold wares and went home, having made a total of $7,061 in the nine-day showing.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 29. -- In the event of disorder in the capital, it is agreed that the British Legation will be the rallying point for Europeans remaining here through the critical times of the approaching war, although no one has accurate knowledge, except the legation guards, of the strength of forces quartered there.

Your editorial "How Gilbert and Sullivan Collaborated" contains the statement that the composer "abdicated his right of initiative" and that Offenbach, "as Mr. Pearson points out, had very generally written the music and then left the librettist to do the best he could in fitting words to it."
The concept of religion as a divine disclosure from without was rejected by John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, returning to his pulpit yesterday morning at the Town Hall.

Two American composers, Edward MacDowell and Mrs. H.H.A. Beach, will be given prominent place in a program at the Riverside Baptist Church tonight under the direction of the music committee of the Youth's Division of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
Apparently it is impossible to obtain good eggs add real bacon in New York City. No matter what price one pays for eggs, or what guarantees are made regarding their quality, they all taste alike.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The return of the Bank of France dated Sept. 20 reflects a tightening money market. Bill discounts rose 500,000,000 francs, while sight liabilities increased from 95,085,000 to 95,376,000 francs. The gold reserve having decreased 117,000,000 francs, the cover ratio receded from 75.72 to 75.36 per cent.
BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The Giants closed their campaign today by breaking even in a double-header with the Braves before a crowd of 1,000.
With the city's noise abatement crusade scheduled to get under way tomorrow Mayor La Guardia approved yesterday a new Golden Rule, which will be the slogan in a drive for quiet nights.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 29. -- The twenty-third Fall invitation tennis tournament commences on the Homestead courts tomorrow and will continue throughout the week. The program includes men's and women's singles, men's and women's doubles and mixed doubles.

Governor LEHMAN'S Conference on Crime, the Criminal and Society opens in Albany today under favorable auspices. The Governor himself, with the aid of expert advisers, has given painstaking attention to the program, with the result that the subjects to be discussed during the week cover the broad ground indicated, while the speakers are men who will command respect for the views which they present.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 29. -- Emperor Haile Selassie was forced by the pressure of ardent nationalists to send today to the Council of the League of Nations a warning that immediate general mobilization was necessary because of the Italian threat at the frontiers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Prices of hogs were on the down-grade a good part of last week with the highest at the opening, $12.15 a hundredweight, and the lowest at the close, $11.65, which also was the lowest in a month. The average for the week was $10.90, a drop of only 5 cents from the previous week.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Some 5,000 men, women and children elbowed and crowded one another today to troop singly and by twos and threes into the house of death that has become in a few days a centre of widespread and sometimes seething contention.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- An advance in the living costs of wage earners and low-salaried workers was reported today by the Labor Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- In the mirror pool lying between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial twenty-one of the fastest little speed boats in the nation raced today for three cups given by the President's Cup committee, but a strong breeze which kicked up inch-and-a-half waves kept the miniature craft from attempting to break the world record of forty-six miles an hour, now held by England.

The number of unemployed workers in August was 9,901,000, according to the regular monthly estimate of the National Industrial Conference Board. This is a decrease of 2.2 per cent from the preceding month and a falling off of 3.2 per cent from the figures of August, 1934.

Professor Irwin Edman, poet and philosopher, of the Philosophy Department of Columbia University, said on his return from Europe yesterday that he had witnessed "frightening" Italian military manoeuvres at Cortina and had seen irrefutable evidence of the unprecedented popularity of Premier Mussolini.

Automobile accidents reported by the police yesterday included four hit-run cases involving two deaths and serious injury to two other persons. Three of these cases were in Brooklyn and the third in Bohemia, near Sayville, L.I.

ABOARD THE SATURNIA, en route to East Africa, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The first Prince of Italy's ruling house to go to East Africa to fight embarked today aboard the Saturnia, formerly on the Naples-New York run.

LONDON Sept. 27. -- Wheat trading is quieter and private estimates for the Argentine crop go up to 23,000,000 quarters. The figure is considered bearish, but it is generally regarded as an overestimate and 20,000,000 would be more likely.

The sponsorship of a radio program to be called "Hymns of all Churches" by a national food distributing concern was criticized by the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman in his sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

ATHENS, Greece, Sept. 29. -- In Saloniki two street ears were wrecked and about twenty persons injured, two seriously, when Royalists clashed with Republicans on the arrival of M. Sophoulis to open the anti-Monarchist campaign in Saloniki and Thrace.
HAVANA, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Civil and military authorities searched tirelessly today through storm-swept Central Cuba for victims of the hurricane yesterday that cost at least thirty-five lives.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- Premier Mussolini's willingness to argue is considered here a hopeful augury for peace and the City believes that Italy will obtain concessions without fighting, as the League of Nations seems anxious that he will find an "exit" without loss of prestige.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The wheat market in Berlin is unaffected by the price advance abroad. Experts are noting that 1935 is the third consecutive year when a price rise occurred immediately after the harvest and that in the Winters of 1933 and 1934 reactions ensued.

Announcement of the award of 282 scholarships, valued at $108,000, to students of Columbia University was made yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university. The new scholars include students from nearly every State in the Union as well as graduates.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The Tigers fell twice before the White Sox in closing their regular season schedule today, 3 to 2 and 14 to 2.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The text of the President's statement on the Summation of the 1936 Budget is as follows: ...
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The Athletics wound up their season today by downing the Senators, 11 to 8, and winning their final series, two games to one.

In his Nebraska address the President was mild in tone and adroit in exposition. This was very different from what some of his intimates had led the country to expect. They had pictured Mr. ROOSEVELT as eager to go out and start the Presidential campaign with a blast of trumpets.

Although the International Olympic Committee received from the German Olympic Committee three days ago the purported text of an invitation to Miss Helene Mayer, fencer, to be a member of the German team, Miss Mayer denied again yesterday that she had received such an invitation.
The public is entitled to the truth about JUAN IGNACIO POMBO. He is the young Odysseus of the skies who took four months to fly from Spain to Mexico while a romance-loving world held its breath.
Last week's foreign exchange market was less erratic in its movement than the preceding week, and at the close there was a mixture of advances and declines, none of which were large in any instance.
ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 29. -- Ethiopia can muster 2,000,000 soldiers if forced to fight Italy, one of Empe ror Haile Selassie principal counselors said tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The distrust that is felt toward the gold-bloc countries continues, and the movement of gold to the United States is likely to go on as long as nervousness exists concerning the franc and the guilder. The United States dollar now dominates the situation, being persistently demanded on commercial and financial account.

The Hollywood Restaurant, one of Broadway's more renowned seats of learning, changed its bill last evening, shifting gently into a future calendar and the "Revels of 1936." And an enterprising show the new one, too. It is fast and cheerful, brightly costumed and well rehearsed; the whole offered in the friendly manner that has come to be regarded as the Hollywood's vise.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- Staging a spirited drive in the seventh and final period, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Aiken Knights subdued the Hurricanes, led by Stephen (Laddie) Sanford, in the weekly high-goal polo competition on Bostwick Field today.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary disposed of a crowded social and political calendar today, and the appointment that provoked the most speculation was his two-hour talk with Chancellor Hitler after a call on Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath.

With much irregularity, there was some visible slackening of pace last week, both in trade activities and in financial markets. The stock market, though its prices crept up slowly after the setback of the preceding week-end, lapsed into inertia. Somewhat unexpectedly, steel production slowed down and retail buying, as reported by the mercantile agencies, showed less of the usual Autumn expansion.

Henry J. Parker's defense of nationalism does not stand analysis, nor is it based upon history. Analytically, it does not matter how goods are made -- in the old days by hand and now by mass or machine production -- when it comes to selling them. When they enter into foreign markets they are surpluses.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 30. -- Continuing the cautious policy adopted throughout the naval negotiations, officials here will not discuss or even disclose the nature of a British communication.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 29. -- The largest social event of the Autumn season at the Greenbrier was a tea dance given this afternoon in the Cameo Room, attended by more than 1,000 guests.

Moral alibis furnished by psychology were scored with "other sinister factors" by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, in a sermon yesterday morning at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 121st Street.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 29 (AP). -- A plea for a new deal in social justice was voiced tonight by the Right Rev. R. Marcellus Wagner of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The Reds split a double bill with the Pirates today, losing the first, 5 to 1, and winning a wild and woolly nightcap, 9 to 6, to close the season in sixth place in the National League race.

The Governors Island polo team defeated the First Division quartet, 9 to 7, in the third match of the annual five-game series for the Colyer Trophy before a crowd of 6,000 at Fort Hamilton yesterday. The triumph was the first gained by the Governors Island players in the three starts against their Fort Hamilton rivals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP). -- A "code" for the wholesale tobacco industry, the first of its kind since the collapse of NRA, was announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Although the mild weather in various sections of the country last week retarded retail purchases of Fall apparel and other merchandise, the wholesale markets here were active. Visiting buyers placed a large volume of reorders to fill in stocks and advance commitments were substantial, particularly on lines which show an upward price movement.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- New and striking developments in the world's grain markets are keeping them in a position where a large majority of traders are completely at sea. Observers of new features that are constantly appearing declare their past experience as handlers of cash grain and as traders in futures have to be passed up as obsolete.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of the New York State Historical Association, arrived this afternoon with the vanguard of more than 200 members coming here from all parts of the State to attend the association's annual meeting.

There is an engaging variety of talents in "The Perfect Fishel," the musical comedy with which the Folks Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street, opened its season on Saturday. Menashe Skulnik, with his dry, smothered manner of speech, is an excellent nitwit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- After construing President Roosevelt's speech at Fremont, Neb., to mean that he would move for revision of the Constitution if the Supreme Court declares the Agricultural Adjustment Act unconstitutional, Republican leaders here today expressed renewed confidence that amendment of the Constitution would be made a political issue in 1936.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP). -- As dusk settled over a field swept by a cold autumnal wind, the Indians took the second game of a closing double-header, 7 to 4, in six innings from the St. Louis Browns today after losing the first, 9 to 7. The second game was called because of darkness.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Milo Reno, president of the Farmers Holiday Association, in a radio talk today criticized some of President Roosevelt's statements at Fremont, Neb., as "only half-truths."
Mayor La Guardia refused yesterday to reveal whether he would seek abrogation of the bankers' agreement, under which the last three city budgets have been financed, before its expiration in 1937.

Commodity futures generally were higher last week in the most active dealings in several weeks. Rubber, raw silk and raw sugar futures commanded the most interest. In the cash markets wheat, corn, oats, coffee, tin, silk and rubber were higher, while rye, flour, lard and cotton were lower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- A five-man squad representing the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York performed brilliantly in the President's Cup canoe races on the Potomac today to upset the Washington Canoe Club, present national team champion, and annex the Sir Thomas Lipton point trophy.

MEMEL, Lithuania, Sept. 29. -- The election to the Memel Diet -- which has resolved itself into an international contest between Germany and Lithuania and which began at 8 A.M. today -- had to be prolonged for another day because the theoretically ideal but practically cumbersome and highly complicated election machinery broke down.
MANASQUAN, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Things seen and heard while covering the waterfront:

The leading competitive lines in the intercoastal passenger trade issued a joint statement yesterday announcing the completion of an agreement to issue interchangeable round-trip tickets between New York, Havana and the Panama Canal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Uncle Sam counted a surprising gain this Fall of more than 5,000 men in one department of his military establishment, the Reserve Officers Training Corps, a survey showed today.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- State Controller Morris S. Tremaine, in a condensed report today of the state's financial operations for the past fiscal year, cut up the tax dollar and the expenditure dollar in cartwheel fashion.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Sweeping through in five of the eight singles matches today, the American golf team, led by Walter Hagen, gained possession of the Ryder Cup, emblematic of the world's team match supremacy, for the third time.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29. -- While there were periods of fair activity in the cotton contract market here last week, business on the whole was rather hesitant. Uncertainty on the outcome of the serious European situation, mixed accounts of the weather in the belt and the comparatively small ginnings for the last period have been the main features in the situation.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29. -- President Roosevelt, in a greeting to the American Protestant Hospital Association, said that "from the great economic depression there is evolving a keener appreciation of social values than obtained when our thinking was more individualistic."

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 69.9 on Sept. 25. This compares with 68.4 a fortnight before, 67.9 a month previous, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The two-day observance of the coming of the Jewish year 5696 ended at sundown yesterday. From many pulpits of the orthodox and conservative Jewish faith were intoned solemn prayers for peace and brotherhood as rabbis urged their congregations to seek after age-old precepts of amity and social justice through the new year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Bill McGee, Houston right-hander, today made his major league debut with the Cards and hurled a 2-to-1 victory over the Cubs.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 29. -- The Caribbean hurricane was blowing harmlessly 200 miles at sea tonight after leaving at least thirty-five dead and millions of dollars damage in its wake through Central Cuba.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30. -- Month-end liquidation in speculative positions caused a heavy decline in Argentine grain prices last week. Wheat declined 4 1/2 cents a bushel, flaxseed, 3 cents, and corn, 2 1/8 cents. The peso declined 1/2 cent in relation to the dollar.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, a former New York State golf champion, and her brother, Frank Wattles of Pine Valley, today vanquished Miss Barbara Stoddard of women's national and Harvey W. Shaffer of Meadow Brook, 3 and 2, in the final round of the annual invitation two-ball foursome tournament at the Piping Rock Club.

Persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany is denounced by Governor Lehman in the souvenir journal to be issued in connection with the "Night of Stars," the benefit theatrical production to be given for Jewish relief Wednesday evening in Madison Square Garden, it became known yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The Brooklyn Dodgers scored first against the Boston Redskins, opening the National Football League season at Fenway Park here today when Ralph Kercheval kicked a 25-yard placement field goal on the closing play of the first half, but they were not able to hold their three-point edge and were beaten, 7 to 3, in the final period.

Awards in the dahlia group were made yesterday at the fourth flower exhibit of the year under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of Staten Island, which is being held at the Staten Island Museum, Stuyvesant Place and Wall Street, St. George.

ROME, Sept. 29. -- Whatever may be the ultimate deductions that can be drawn from the official communique issued after yesterday's Cabinet council, one thing is perfectly plain: Premier Mussolini expects war against Ethiopia to begin in the near future "with the League, without the League or against the League," as he himself once said he intends to proceed.

No one could have hoped that the American Legion, impressed by the potentially serious consequences of a rapidly mounting public debt, would about-face at its St. Louis convention and abandon its demand for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus. The tide of bonus sentiment has plainly been running in the Legion with increasing strength.

THE TIMES published a letter over the signature "One Who Remembers" in which an effort is made to designate the Republican leaders in the United States Senate whose unwillingness to approve of the League of Nations covenant resulted in the defeat of President Wilson's purpose to have the covenant ratified as an integral part of the Versailles Peace treaty.

The cotton futures market here last week see-sawed gently, with sales of contracts as hedges against purchases of new crop offsetting purchases of contracts to fix prices on past sales of spot cotton to mills. With these transactions generally in balance, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of the week were unchanged to 9 points lower.

Returning to his pulpit after an absence of six months, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, advised his congregation yesterday morning that it is the function of the church to take them away from the noise and activity of this "most turbulent epoch in human history," so that they may listen to the "still, small voice" within them.

It is painful to notice that Governor RUBY LAFFOON of Kentucky and Mr. RHEA, whom, being ineligible for a second term himself, he selected as his successor, refused to meet and greet Mr. ROOSEVELT, though his special train stopped from time to time to pick up visiting statesmen.

The Second Avenue Theatre also presented on Saturday night a musical comedy called "A Holiday in Town," which is more properly the subject of a sermon rather than a review. In the absence of space, the text of that sermon will be enough: "Lord, how extraordinary is the unoriginality of Thy creatures."
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

After battering down four keepers in the annex of the Bronx County jail, 161st Street and Third Avenue, with their fists and heavy metal jail keys, four youthful prisoners unlocked three steel doors and walked to freedom out of the jail's main entrance at 5:20 P.M. yesterday.

The pooling of natural resources by nations instead of fighting over them, was suggested by the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons as a way to peace, in a sermon yesterday in All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Britain's reply to the French inquiry as to the extent to which the French may be assured of British participation in sanctions against an aggressor in the event of a resort to force in Europe was made public today here and in Paris.

Having practiced with "Othello" last week, the local theatre will continue its Shakespearean studies tonight with the Theatre Guild -- John C. Wilson production of "The Taming of the Shrew." The Guild's home house will receive it, and, as is generally known by now. Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne are the chief players.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The Italo-Ethiopian conflict and fears of war in Europe have caused money to emigrate to the United States. Such capital movements are considered important here, as, despite purchases of silver abroad by the United States Treasury, they have caused United States balance payments to become clearly a credit, and a credit balance could be covered only by gold shipments.

The Dodgers' farewell to 5,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday was a mixture of brilliance and frustration. Behind the superlative pitching of Van Lingle Mungo, Brooklyn took the first game, 2 -- 0, to run its winning streak to seven straight and clinch fifth place.
A large lecture room for "students desiring to address their fellows on any topic" has been set aside at City College by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president, he announced yesterday.

Whether it shall be erected in conjunction with the forthcoming World's Fair or independently of that enterprise, Mayor La Guardia is planning to put forward soon a program for a municipal auditorium. He is hopeful of getting for the city the cooperation of the Metropolitan Opera Association and the Philharmonic symphony Society.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,276,995,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Five persons were killed and at least ten severely injured late tonight in a fire that followed a basement explosion in a three-story tenement at 558 Taylor Street, on the near West Side. Two women, two men and a boy were dead.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 29. -- Maintaining the sizzling pace which yesterday gave it a strong lead over the three other contending groups, the Massachusetts Lesley Cup golf team today captured the famous trophy at the Oyster Harbors Club.

Attendance at mass on Sunday is "the supreme act of homage to God" and fulfilment of His ancient command to keep the Sabbath a day "of rest and of sacrifice," the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Spokesmen for the Protestant Confessional Synod conceded today that they now had the painful choice of deliberately breaking the laws of the Reich or sacrificing their religious principles. The establishment yesterday of complete State supremacy over the Protestant Church, combined with the grant of new dictatorial powers to the new Minister of Church Affairs, Hanns Kerrl, has outlawed the principles upon which the Confessional Church movement was founded.

One of the most serious problems facing the business and the people of the United States today is the continued increase in taxes and government expenditures, says the National City Bank in its October bulletin, to be published today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Prices on grain futures in Chicago last week were as follows:

The Yankees did better than break even against the Red Sox yesterday at the Stadium as they bade adieu to their public for the season of 1935. The McCarthy men won three of five field events conducted as an extra attraction between games, in addition to dividing the double-header.
The slogan "Religion is the opium of the people" was criticized in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, the dean.

Governor Lehman's conference on crime, which opens at Albany today, is a meeting "of public-spirited men and women who have made themselves our crime experts," and the aim of the conference is to correct flaws in the State's criminal mechanism, Charles Poletti, counsel to Mr. Lehman, declared yesterday in a radio speech over WOR.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Interruption in the voting in Memel was promptly seized upon here today as demonstrating Lithuania's determination to prevent an orderly election, and the incident is openly designated as "grotesquely" demonstrating Lithuania's failure to make adequate provisions for today's polling.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP). -- About fifty national guardsmen left here late today to occupy Harlan County for the third time this year.

An Independent Democratic candidate for Representative from Queens was put into the field last night by the followers of Public Works Commissioner John J. Halleran for the seat from which Representative William F. Brunner, Democrat, is retiring.

Although the hard-headed practical man scoffs at the idea that angels exist, it is true that one often receives a spiritual message from God through His messengers, the angels, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

The decision of Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Pore in throwing out the municipal power plant referendum should constitute the beginning of a fight by citizens for the public ownership of the entire electrical industry of the city, speakers at a rally of the Socialist party in Town Hall declared yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29. -- The last of Andrew Carnegie's "old guard" will leave the steel industry tomorrow. Announcement by the Carnegie Steel Company of the retirement of Dr. John S. Unger as manager of the research bureau ends the career of one of America's pioneers in armor-plate production.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Commenting on Minister of Economics Schacht's "new plan," which on Sept. 24 celebrated its first anniversary, Reichsbank Director Blessing admits it has killed the transit trade and has compelled Germany to pay high prices for imports.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Monday, Sept. 30. -- Two policemen were shot, one of them fatally, within a block of police headquarters early this morning when they accosted a youth to question him concerning a radio store burglary. The assailant escaped.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Financial circles are favorably impressed by the budget estimates drawn up by the government, which formulate the economies realized by recent laws. Total ordinary expenditures are to be reduced from 47,000,000,000 francs in 1935 to 40,000,000,000 francs in 1936.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- George F. Hummel's drama of polar exploration, "The World Waits," scored the first unexpected success of the budding season here when produced by the Repertory Theatre tonight.

The Morgan liner Dixie, which went aground off the Florida coast in a hurricane Sept. 2, all her passengers being rescued, reached New York yesterday, towed by the tug Relief, of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, after a northern journey which began Sept. 22.

With George D. Widener's speed star, Sation, slated to start in the Highweight Handicap, the Fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will begin today at Belmont Park, four weeks later than usual. The switch from the first fortnight in September to the same period in October was a move to maintain the calibre of New York racing throughout the season.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT TRAIN, Sept. 29. -- President Roosevelt tonight put the finishing touches to a speech to be delivered at Boulder Dam tomorrow, in which he is expected to give further information on the future program of the administration as regards power development.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Mrs. Anna Sage, who soved herself temporarily from deportation by the statement in a Federal court that she had put John Dillinger "on the spot" for Department of Justice agents, today revealed more of her dealings with the agents.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP). -The Detroit Lions and Chicago Cardinals battled to a 10-10 tie in a thrill-packed National Football League contest before 10,000 fans today. The Lions, encountering a line as strong as their own, had to come from behind to tie the score in the final minutes, Glenn Presnell booting a field goal from the 14-yard line.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Late this week John R. (Dinny) McNamara will be heading back to New York with the Boston College football team to engage the eleven that he served for five years as assistant to the late Major Frank Cavanaugh of Fordham.

A committee of the Jersey City Medical Society conferred yesterday afternoon at Trenton with the medical advisory committee of the New Jersey State Medical Society seeking advice on how Jersey City physicians may share in the funds devoted to treatment of relief recipients.

The National Theatre on East Houston Street began its season Saturday night, bringing back Jennie Goldstein and Samuel Goldenburg to the local stage in "Madame Pagliacci," a novel by a Belgian-Jewish writer, Hirsch Zwier, dramatized by Meyer Schwartz and Miss Goldstein herself.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- A picturesque finale to a colorful show, the last of the open-air exhibitions, brought six of the leading contenders of the season in competition for the highest award today at the thirteenth annual fixture of the Westbury Kennel Association.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- H.C. Taylor's Barbara. a Class M boat with a shortened rig; E.A. Mitchell's Tlen Hoa and G.I. Steffen's Spinster were winners today as the handicap class celebrated its anniversary with a regatta conducted by the New Rochelle Yacht Club and Walter Sullivan, the class preisdent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Prospects for a peaceful settlement of the current San Francisco waterfront tie-up developed today when union bargemen and warehousemen suddenly lifted their ban against the handling of "unfair" cargo on the piers.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Cornelius Shields resumed competition in his Interclub sloop, Aileen, today and defeated five boats in a 10-mile race conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

Two new American agencies have been organized to raise funds, largely among Christians, for the rehabilitation of 10,000 non-Jewish refugees who have fled Germany and are living in other European countries, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Minister of Propa ganda and Public Enlightenment, asserted in an address tonight that the opposition church group might be "destroyed for the sake of the nation's future." His address was heard by thousands of Berlin residents assembled at Karlshorst, a suburb, to watch an exhibition by Reichswehr detachments.

The modern college student may be more "illiterate" than former students, because of a changing emphasis from reading to hearing through the influence of the radio and sound pictures, it is suggested in the annual report of Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College.

One of the chief difficulties confronting the baseball scholar who is endeavoring to find out for himself what to expect when two pennant winners collide in a world series, is the fact that those all absorbing averages, so carefully compiled and tabulated through a season, are often apt to be very much misleading.

During the last few weeks Dr. Clyde Fisher, curator of astronomy at the American Museum of Natural History, has been tinkering with the stars in the indoor universe of the new Hayden Planetarium at Central Park West and Eighty-first Street, in preparation for the opening night on Wednesday.

"The Legend of William Tell," filmed in Switzerland by a Swiss company and boasting an English-speaking cast headed by Conrad Veidt, Hans Mart and Deplef Willecke, begins an engagement today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.

If the appellate courts uphold Justice Dore's decision barring a referendum vote on a municipal power plant at the coming election. Mayor La Guardia will apply to the next session of the Legislature for relief, he indicated yesterday.

HIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Leo Diegel was trudging in the wake of the Ryder Cup players and worrying about the Detroit ball club in the approaching world series. They left Leo off the Ryder Cup team this time, thus giving him more time to talk about baseball while the international matches were on.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 29. -- Beginning Oct. 7 the Central Railroad is offering new and faster service to the mountain district about Oroya, including two express trains a week in each direction. The trains will employ the Central's best passenger equipment powered with the latest "consolidation" class locomotives, three of which recently arrived from England and three more of which are expected in the next four months.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29. -- The Yale class of 1919 is against the New Deal, although its members voted 152 to 88 for Roosevelt. It likes Mussolini, although this vote was taken before the Ethiopian war clouds began to thicken, but it dislikes Postmaster General Farley.

For the academic year 1934-1935, which marked the fiftieth anniversary of the school saving system, total deposits of $11,575,899 and net savings of $2,337,616 were reported, according to the annual survey of the pupils' thrift movement by W. Espey Albig, deputy manager of the American Bankers Association.

Several score of American Indians came out of their haunts in and near New York yesterday to turn the city's only Indian Reservation into a boisterous and colorful encampment, replete with big chiefs, eagle feathers, tomahawks, tom-toms, war-whoops, love-calls and tribal regalia, for the eighteenth annual celebration of American Indian Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- Members of the militant fundamentalist wing of the Presbyterian Church today disclosed plans for the publication of a new national religious paper, to be issued semi-monthly and known as The Presbyterian Guardian.

Miss Mary Coleman, well-known New York lawyer and at one time a militant suffragette, suffered a possibly fractured skull early this morning, and her husband, Frederick L. Hardenbrook, a broker, was cut about the face, during a fight that followed an argument in a Seventh Avenue subway train.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Governor Hoffman has recommended to the Court of Pardons that forty-five aliens serving sentences ranging from two years to life in the New Jersey State Prison be surrendered to the Federal authorities for deportation.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The Ethiopian dispute dropped this week into the background and was replaced as the centre of business interest by the firmness of prices in the world markets. The advance was not unwelcome in Germany.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Experimental dinghy sailing was indulged in today at the Larchmont Yacht Club by the British, Scandinavian and American yachtsmen who had engaged in the international six-meter and dinghy events. While the contests were informal, the outstanding performance was that of Colin Ratsey of the British team in his boat Runt.

Mrs. Carl A. Schrader of Belmont, Mass., will conduct an institute on "present-day problems facing consumer purchasers for the homes in America" at the opening this morning of the fourteenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 85.5, which compares with 85.2 the week before, 85.1 two weeks before, 84.5 three weeks before and 84.3 four weeks before.
GENEVA, Sept. 29. -- The League of Nations Secretariat gave out today a telegram from Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia warning that he could no longer delay general mobilization.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The lessening strain at Geneva a week ago helped to abate the pessimism of last week in the Paris market. Although still irregular and dull, the Bourse was not so ill disposed as in the previous week. Quotations were better at the beginning of the week, but they closed today on a heavier note.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 30. -- Sir Samuel Hoare's note to France on the British League of Nations policy appears to have the approval of the entire range of British opinion, from the Labor party on the Left to the Tories and even some of the isolationists on the extreme Right.

The National City Bank, fiscal agent, has notified holders of Irish Free State external loan sinking fund 5 per cent gold bonds due on Nov. 1, 1960, that $14,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption at par on Nov. 1.

H. Eliot Kaplan, secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, yesterday made public correspondence between himself and President Roosevelt on the question of the extension of the civil service to the recovery agencies under the Federal Government.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29. -- The voice of Great Britain's revolutionary youth was heard yesterday in the sixth International Youth Congress, spurring the world's young men and women onward in defense of democratic liberties, reechoing the challenge of the French delegate, Mr. Guyau, the night before.

The Holland-America liner Rotterdam, whose southern cruise route had taken her into the vicinity of the recent Caribbean hurricane, reported at 2:07 A.M. today that she had gone aground on Morant Cays, a hundred miles east of Kingston, Jamaica.

Objection may very easily be taken to the point of view propounded by Henry J. Parker in a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Parker declared that the United States experienced the blessings of nationalism for nearly one hundred years and only became embroiled in troubles when it became internationalistic.

A formula for a successful Christian life was offered yesterday morning by the Rev. Oscar Lowry, a Chicago evangelist, preaching in the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in closing a three-week revival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- An educational campaign to reduce home and farm accidents throughout the country will be started tomorrow, the American Red Cross said today. Residents and property owners will be asked to fill out forms showing potential hazards in their dwellings, and will be urged to remove them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Final approval of additional WPA projects for Connecticut, calling for the expenditure of $1,041,511 in Federal funds and $237,548 in local money, was announced today by the Division of Applications and Information.
SAN SIMEON, Calif., Sept. 29. -- think that Mr. Roosevelt can be defeated.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- Satisfaction qualified by several qualms for the future is expressed tonight in Paris at the reply that the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare, has sent to the French Ambassador's questions regarding the British attitude in the event of a violation of the League of Nations covenant and recourse to force by any European power, whether a member of the League or not.

A slight transposition of letters and Setup becomes Upset. That was something that some of the highly favored teams discovered to their sorrow over the past weekend, as form reversals and unexpectedly close scores gave football followers a series of shocking surprises.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 29. -- The New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, fell before the second-half rally of an inspired Green Bay eleven, 16 to 7, before 10,000 spectators today. Intercepting five Giant aerials in the second half, two of them for touchdowns, the Packers overcame a first-half lead piled up by the titleholders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- A brand new name today was added to those engraved on the base of the elaborate and ornate gold urn known as the President's Cup, for which motor boat speed drivers have been coming to Washington each September, but instead of a victory marked by thrills and excitement the triumph of Herbert Mendelsohn's Notre Dame was tame and hollow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The formation of a national organization by investment bankers which will cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission in supervising activities in the over-the-counter market, as the national securities Exchanges now do in the case of registered securities and those enjoying unlisted trading privileges in these markets, is expected to result from negotiations which have been carried on by the commission with the twenty-one members of the former Bankers' Code Committee.

DETROIT, Sept 29. -- William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, widely regarded as a spokesman for Henry Ford, declared tonight that the "American mind has made a remarkable recovery of equilibrium," and that the economic signs "have already changed for the better."

WINNIPEG, Sept. 29. -- Appealing for its vote on the ground that he had used the money of Eastern Canada to support the grain market of Western Canada so successfully that the whole world must again bid for Canadian wheat, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett last night bade good-bye to the West and started on his way back East.
The editorTl "A Time of Hesitation" deserves wide publicity. Thank you fo' it.
The North German Lloyd liner Berlin, arriving today from Bremen, Boulogne, Galway and Halifax, has on board:

Mr. and Mrs. J. Garfield Buell, who are departing today for their home in Tulsa, Okla., gave a farewell dinner last night in the garden of the Ambassador for their daughter, Miss Betry Jane Buell, and Miss Emily Custis L. Stevens, who will accompany Mr. and Mrs. Buell for a visit in Tulsa and at the Buell country estate in Muskogee, Okla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Emphasizing improvement in economic conditions and assuring the country that no new taxes or permanent increase in present tax rates would be necessary. President Roosevelt, in a supplemental budget message made public today by the Budget Bureau, estimated that the deficit at the end of the current fiscal year, on June 30, 1937, would fall $1,246,526,110 below the forecast made in his message to Congress last January.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. The report for September is expected to show an average of 50 to 51 per cent, making September the high month of the year so far, excepting February.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29. -- Fifty-five members of the Lenox Club attended a luncheon that followed the sixty-first annual meeting yesterday. Mrs. R. Jay Flick had fifteen guests, Giraud Foster twelve, Mrs. David T. Dana ten, and among others who entertained were Mrs. Hayden Channing, Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, John P.S. Harrison and Albert Eugene Gallatin.

The most striking anomaly of the recent business improvement has been the apparent failure of employment to keep pace with the increase in production. A recent chart prepared by the American Federation of Labor, for example, indicates that only about 10 per cent more persons were employed in midsummer of 1935 than in March, 1933.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The text of the British note on League of Nations policy, which Sir Samuel Hoars, Foreign Secretary, handed today to the French Ambassador Charles Corbin, follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Sales of confectionery and competitive chocolate products by 345 manufacturers increased 11.3 percent on a quantity basis and 15.1 per cent on a value basis from 1933 to 1934. Fletcher H. Rawls, chief of the Foodstuffs Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said today.

Something like an embarrassment of riches in new American compositions for the Boston Symphony's season, to open in Symphony Hall, Boston, on Oct. 11, was confessed by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, who arrived in New York yesterday on the Gripsholm to resume the leadership of the famous orchestra.

The government rested its case yesterday in the trial of William H. Rabell, former accountant investigator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who is accused of having solicited a bribe of $27,500 from J. Edward Jones, oil promoter, whose activities are being investigated by the commission.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30. -- Veterans' camps in South Carolina operated by relief authorities are rapidly being evacuated and the operation will probably be completed this week, according to Colonel J.D. Fulp, State ERA administrator.

MEMEL, Sept. 30. -- With the voters permitted to vote late into the night, the two-day election to the Memel Diet, which as a potential plebiscite commanded world attention and roused this border population to dangerous excitement, came to a close tonight amid a calmer atmosphere than yesterday but with the Germans feeling more certain of this contested territory than at any time since it was detached from Germany.

ROME, Sept. 30. -- That the most serious form of economic sanctions has been in force against Italy for three months and that the League of Nations can apply no measures more crippling than those already adopted by British and United States financial institutions is the view expressed by Professor Felice Guarneri, officially known as the Superintendent of Exchanges and actually the economic dictator of Italy.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 30. -- Officials administering the Federal welfare and social security programs took up public and private relief in addresses here today before the National Conference of Catholic Charities.
A coincidence, said to be unique in the history of banking in the United States, has been reported to the American Bankers Association.

Offering to the public a new issue of $4,435,000 city of Louisville, Ky., bridge-revenue 3 3/4 per cent refunding bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1955, is to be made today by a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc. The bonds are priced at 103 and accrued interest.

Motorists who fail to tone down their automobile radios after 11 P.M. were warned last night by Mayor La Guardia in a radio address in which he proclaimed a month of "noiseless nights" beginning tonight.
