The Morgan liner Dixie, which went aground on a Florida reef during the Labor Day hurricane, was towed to her pier yesterday by the Merritt-Chapman-Scott salvage tug Relief, after a voyage begun at Miami on Sept. 19. She was docked at Pier 51, North River, at the foot of West Twelfth Street, for unloading of cargo.

Those classes that were affected by the misplacement of a racing mark in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta off Greenwich, Conn., on Sept. 7, were notified yesterday that their competition had been called no contest.

HAVANA, Sept. 30. -- Twenty-five students were detained this morning at Colon Cemetery when policemen and soldiers dispersed a crowd of some 2,000 at services marking the anniversary of the death of the student leader Rafael Trejo, who was killed by the authorities during the Machado regime.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 30. -- Military circles revealed today that Hungarian reservists are being called to the colors and that the number of recruits for the army is being steadily increased.

Arguing the need for higher fares at a joint hearing of the Transit and Public Service Commissions yesterday morning, counsel for the Long Island Railroad conceded that some aspects of its service caused annoyance to commuters.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30. -- The Argentine Government has ordered troops and naval units to Rosario to preserve order. The two regiments garrisoned in Rosario are being held ready for an emergency, another regiment has been sent from San Nicholas and two are being sent from Buenos Aires.

Dividends declared in September were smaller than in August but larger than in September last year. Although several large corporations reduced their rate of disbursement distinct improvement was noted in payments over a year ago in most classes of industries.
Dr. Irving Lorge of Teachers College, Columbia University, made public yesterday the results of his experiments to discover the basic law by which propaganda influences a person's attitude.

Since Mr. Roosevelt's address of Aug. 24, I have given a great deal of thought to the influence which his remarks are likely to have upon the impressionable minds of the younger generation which we are so solicitously, and with so many sacrifices and so much difficulty, preparing to take up the work of life.

United States Senator James P. Pope of Idaho, who has been touring Europe to study conditions there, will return today on the Holland-America liner Volendam, accompanied by his wife. Others on the Volendam list are:

The most stringent shortage of wide sheetings, sheets and pillowcases since the war has developed in the last few weeks, with many mills unable to promise delivery on a selection of goods until February and March, according to reports by selling agents here yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- Hopes that the League of Nations powers will grant Ethiopia's request for impartial observers to be sent to her frontiers declined here today while some delegations admitted that the need for the observers had risen.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The prospects of rendering milking cattle immune to tuberculosis and thus save thousands of lives yearly were held out by a test of Professor Henri Spahlinger's vaccine which the government of Northern Ireland carried out, the results of which were given out tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Plans to crowd a ten-year airport expansion program into ten months of work and to spend upward of $50,000,000 in improving 1,000 fields were disclosed today with the appointment by the Bureau of Air Commerce of twenty men to supervise the work.

AS one sits down to review the seventh and eighth volumes of Jules Romains's multitudinous adventure in fictional multiplicity, "Men of Good Will," one feels rather like a baseball writer who is assigned to a team whose victories are so regular as to seem almost mechanical. Day after day the pitchers win, day after day the fielders field, day after day the hitters pull a ball or two into the right field stands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Securities worth about $12,500,000 were given away in August by officers, directors and large stockholders of corporations as Congress enacted increased taxes on gifts and estates, the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Tyler W. Dennett, wife of the president of Williams College, gave her first tea and reception of the Autumn this afternoon at President's House, Williamstown, for members of the Williams College faculty and their wives.
ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's address tonight, opening the Conference on Crime:

An estate of $39,995 gross and $34,893 net was left by Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, Chancellor Emeritus of New York University, when he died on Nov. 3, the appraisal showed yesterday. The assets included securities worth $18,993, cash and insurance of $18,893 and a pension payment of $994 from the university.

In a recent press interview Mrs. Roosevelt is quoted as saying: "I think this is a very good moment for all women everywhere to be thinking about war," adding that "force never really settles any question. * * * It simply destroys and destroys until the final point is reached, when there is nothing left to destroy."
Following is the text of Mayor F.H. La Guardia's radio address last night on "Noise Abatement":

A session of the Manasquan chapter of the National Piscatorial Post-Mortem and Alibi Association was going full blast down at Hoffman's Landing on the Jersey coast Saturday night. Some sad tales were being unfolded as the day's experiences were reviewed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Terming himself the "goat" of the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing of nineteen years ago, Warren H. Billings heatedly refused today to answer some questions at Tom Mooney's habeas corpus hearing.
Beginning tonight and continuing for an indefinite period many a sleepless head in town will toss on its pillow, many an aching form will turn from side to side in bed many a weary voice will groan "

Lacking any appreciable increase in demand by brokers for funds, interest rates for call and time loans in September were unchanged for the fifth consecutive month. Call money was offered at one-quarter of 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 1 per cent in September, 1934, and at three-quarters of 1 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange, against 1 1/2 per cent a year ago.

May I congratulate you on the editorial in your Sept. 27 issue, replying to the criticism by President Cutten of Colgate University? And may I mention one social law to which you did not refer, viz., the provision for workmen's compensation insurance?

" Most of the Game" will have what the trade calls a world premiere tonight at the Cort. It is by John van Druten, and concerns wealthy Britishers resident in New York. The leading man is a successful playwright and novelist. Another prominent character is an Oxford professor who spends part of his time lecturing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Two rulings were promulgated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, one temporarily exempting from registration the securities of a new company formed by the merging of a parent corporation with its subsidiaries, and the other calling for statistical services to file their publications on new security issues.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- Both musically and theatrically, George Gershwin's and the Theatre Guild's new folk opera, "Porgy and Bess," which had its first performance at the Colonial here this evening, was an event. An audience which assembled, uncertain whether they should find a heavy operatic work or something more closely resembling musical comedy, discovered a form of entertainment which stands midway between the two.

Jimmy Leto of Hartford, contender for the world's welterweight championship, defeated Harry Dublinsky, sturdy Chicago battler, in a hard-fought ten round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 4,000 persons saw the battle.

LYNN, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Carleton Nichols Sr., a member of the religious sect, Jehovah's Witnesses, went to jail on a charge of disturbing school today after he had sprawled his legs under a small third-grade desk and watched his 8-year-old son again refuse to salute the Stars and Stripes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Disdainful of the risk of head colds, aching backs and sore arches, more than 1,000 hardy Cub fans tonight stood, sat and leaned away the hours until world series tickets go on sale tomorrow morning.

WORCESTER, Mass., Tuesday, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Newell P. Sherman, choir singer, was convicted of murder in the first degree early today in the drowning of his wife, Mrs. Alice Sherman, on the night of July 20. The verdict carries a mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee, and Representative Chester C. Bolton, chairman of the Congressional Committee, attacked the administration today for what they termed its failure to keep its pre-election promises.

NASSAU, Sept. 30. -- After an air survey showed sweeping devastation but no loss of life on the island of Bimini, meager reports trickling in tonight from other islands in the path of the hurricane stated that ten were killed on Grand Bahama and four in Cornishtown on Abaco.
Starting the final week of its pre-season training, Columbia engaged Manhattan yesterday at Baker Field in an hour-and-a-half scrimmage.

ADDIS ABABA, Sept. 30. -- A mobilization decree was signed last night after the return of Count Luigi Orazio Vinci-Gigliucci, the Italian Minister, from Bishoftu. Contrary to the views of his foreign advisers, Emperor Haile Selassie is believed to favor a mobilization without the traditional drumming.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- Assailing public "indifference" and "inertia" as partly responsible for "a substantial increase in organized crime," Governor Lehman opened tonight a four-day Conference on Crime from which he plans to draw suggestions for a detailed program for revision of present crime laws, to be laid before the 1936 Legislature.
Twelve books on Ethiopia are on the publishers' Fall lists.

This week the new art season gets fairly under way, with briskly increased activity in the local galleries and with three exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, which open with a private view from 2 to 5 this afternoon and to the public tomorrow.

LAKE MOHONK MOUNTAIN HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Meeting in the heart of the "Rip Van Winkle Country," the 225 members of the State Historical Association and their guests received many intimate glimpses today of Ulster County through the medium of historical papers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Lady Montrose, owned by Jake Lowenstein of Chicago, won the fifth race at Hawthorne today, beating the Milky Way Farm's 2-year-old, Sir Gawaine, a length and a half in the five-and-one-half-furlong feature. F.P. Letellier's Dilwin was third.

Another symptom as well as another cause of recovery has been the slow but steady rise in commodity prices. This rise has been international in extent. While the threat of war between Italy and Ethiopia has no doubt been an influence, too much weight could easily be attached to this.

A plea to the church leaders of the United States to urge their parishioners to shun the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin as "one of the most effective means of expressing the moral indignation of civilized people at the return to barbarism" in Germany was made public yesterday in the form of an open letter sent by the National Council of Methodist Youth.

France was in full agreement with Great Britain at Geneva on the question of living up to the Covenant in the case of Italy against Ethiopia. Later the French Government sought further assurances from the British regarding other matters. Would Great Britain take the same attitude toward an aggressor in Europe as she maintains ought to be taken against an aggressor in Africa?

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The most notable aspect of the developments in diplomatic circles here today was the activity at the German Embassy. All over London, wherever the phrases of diplomacy are echoed and new interpretations might be gleaned, German emissaries were endeavoring to discover the exact meaning of the note sent to Paris defining Britain's policy in the League of Nations.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx racketeer, was released in $50,000 bail from the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City last night after an array of prominent attorneys succeeded in obtaining a writ of habeas corpus and a $25,000 reduction in the original bail from a Federal Circuit Court of Appeals judge in Philadelphia.

Hearings by the Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry, of Which Senator Ellison D. Smith of South Carolina is chairman, "as to whether there have been any manipulative operations or arbitrary influences operating On the cotton markets resulting in abnormal price fixation," will be begun early in November in Washington, according to Alfred S. Wyllie, attorney for the committee's investigation.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday handed down a decision upholding the report of Robert P. Stephenson, who, sitting as special master, recently rejected a plan for the reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation as proposed by the United Stores Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation offered today to lend $50,000,000 to the Great Northern Railroad to assist it in refunding $105,850,000 of 7 per cent bonds which mature on July 1, 1936.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Authorities in four gulf ports were making preparations today to preserve peace in the International Longshoremen's strike called for midnight, while both sides argued their points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today credited to the account of the Nickel Plate a $997,000 dividend which was paid to the RFC by the Wheeling Lake Erie. The RFC holds a prior lien on the Wheeling Lake Erie as collateral for a $15,500,000 loan to the Nickel Plate.

It is pleasant to see the shepherd of St. SIMEON picking out a Republican bellwether. Be Mr. HEARST'S intent wicked or charitable, nothing but good can be said of his candidate, Governor LANDON of Kansas. Mr. LANDON'S re-election, one of the rare bright spots in that Republican Dark Day of '32, may have been due to the presence of an Independent candidate, but his campaign was notable for the absence of ballyhoo.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 30. -- George Ashley Tomlinson, 66, disclosed in New York today as an associate of the Van Sweringen brothers in Mid-america Corporation, is a Great Lakes shipping man with the Western ranges, circus life and newspaper work for a background.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

In apparent apprehension of the financial condition of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, a wave of selling orders broke over the stocks and bonds of that company yesterday sending the common shares down 1 3/8 points to close at 5, while the preferred dipped 2 points to 10.
Francis G. Hooley of Rockville Centre, L.I., was nominated last night as the Democratic candidate for the Supreme Court at the Sec ond Judicial Convention in the Jefferson Building, Brooklyn.

As a consequence of the record movement to refund outstanding bonds, flotations of new securities here in September increased over the previous month and also a year ago. Public utility bond offerings led the new issues. They were the largest since July.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Labor party, which still calls itself "His Majesty's Opposition," began its annual conference at Brighton today by applauding the British Government's present policy in the Italian-Ethiopian crisis.
BOULDER DAM, Sept. 30. -- The address made here today by President Roosevelt at the dedication of Boulder Canyon Dam in Colorado River was as follows:

Mme. Anastasia Tschaikowsky, who started proceedings here ten years ago to have herself declared an heir to the estate of Czar Nicholas II of Russia on the ground that she was his daughter, the Grand Duchess Anastasia Nickolaevna, was blocked yesterday in her effort to establish this identity when Surrogate Foley ruled no proceeding involving the late Czar's estate was pending here to which she might become a party.

The members of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra assembled for the first rehearsal of the season on the stage of Carnegie Hall yesterday morning. Otto Klemperer, who will direct the first thirteen weeks of the season, stepped out on the stage wearing an old brown sweater and shirt open at the throat.
DETROIT, Sept. 30. -- Arkansas will furnish all the sharp-shooting ammunition for the opening of baseball's annual civil war.

A sharp break in the issues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company was the principal feature in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While declines of two to five points in those bonds unsettled the market for other second grade rail liens to some extent, the movement failed to exert much adverse influence on the bonds of other classifications.

The first quarter of the new fiscal year ended yesterday with the Federal Government $800,000,000 in the red. On the same day the President issued an optimistic statement regarding Federal finances. The gist of it is that revenues for the whole period of twelve months now promise to be about $480,000,000 larger than was originally anticipated, expenditures about $770,000,000 smaller, and the resulting deficit at the year's end accordingly some $1,250,000,000 less than was anticipated.
Extra detectives were assigned last night to special patrol duty on streets adjacent to Central Park West as a result of the stabbing of a young woman and her escort by a Negro at 3 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Action by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on its $15,600,000 loan to the New York Central Railroad, which falls due tomorrow, was postponed temporarily today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, after a brief talk with Harold S. Vanderbilt, one of the principal stockholders in the road.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- A limited exemption for public utility holding company subsidiaries which are not themselves utilities and which desire to issue stock against the exercise of conversion rights was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Two teams returned scores of 67 to finish in a tie for top honors in the Westchester P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball competition over the west course at Winged Foot today. Dick Chapman, the home club's former county champion, and Mike Turnesa of Fairview overcame a faulty finish to deadlock with Gus Jaeger and Sal DI Buono, the Bonnie Briar pair, for first prize.

The iron-thewed Sation, biggest horse ever to carry the colors of George D. Widener, shouldered 140 pounds at the opening of the Belmont Park Fall meeting yesterday and sped down the chute in the fastest time to be made since Balko set the record in 1930.

The 460 passengers and some of the crew of the stranded Holland-America liner Rotterdam, aground and leaking on Morant Cays, forty miles east of Jamaica, were safely transferred by boat early last night to the British twin-screw steamer Ariguani, out of Glasgow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Approval by President Roosevelt of an allotment of Federal funds totalling $2,331,203 for the Works Progress Administration program in New Jersey was announced today. An additional sum of $534,871, pledged by the various sponsors of the projects submitted by William H.J. Ely, State Administrator, brings to a grand total of $2,866,074 the funds now available to carry on the Works Program in New Jersey.

Joseph Amberg, 43 years old, small-time extortioner and narcotic peddler, and his chauffeur, Morris Kessler, 30, were shot dead at noon yesterday by three gunmen in a garage at Blake and Christopher Avenues in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 30. -- A birdie 2 by Johnny Hines, Old Westbury amateur, on the second hole enabled him and his amateur partner, the Rev. Francis G. Makowski, to take the first award in the weekly amateur-pro competition of the Long Island Golf Association at the Garden City Country Club today.
ROME, Sept. 30. -- Italians seized tonight upon Ethiopia's forthcoming call to arms as proof that Emperor Haile Selassie, not Premier Mussolini, was the "aggressor."
Trends were mixed in trading in commodity futures here yesterday. Cash prices advanced, the only decline being registered by corn.
BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Germany's scarcity of fats, meats and fruits threatened tonight to become serious.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30. -J. Robert (Bob) Haley of Winthrop, Mass., captain of this year's Harvard varsity football team, has been declared ineligible to represent the Crimson on any athletic team because he received financial aid without approval of the Harvard athletic committee, it was announced today.

Orris P. Van Sweringen, who, with his brother, Mantis J., built an initial investment of $550,000 into a financial pyramid controlling a $3,000,000,000 railroad system, regained control of this empire yesterday when it was knocked down at a creditors' sale to friendly interests.

The letter from Arthur C. Bartlett, which you publish under the head "Poking Fun at the Hub," interests me. Mr. Bartlett, I take it, is one of the Bartletts. My grandmother was one. She wore a little lace cap, white ruching at her throat and black silk mitts. She would have agreed grimly with Cousin Arthur; but she would not have said anything about it.
Mayor La Guardia spent another busy day yesterday trying to fit the 1936 budget into the $539,695,777 limit set for it by Controller Frank J. Taylor, but was reticent about the details of his task.

Mail reorders for women's apparel and accessories, received in this market yesterday, were lighter than those noted at the start of the previous week. The decrease in volume, however, was smaller than was anticipated in view of the let-up in retail demand for Fall garments during the recent spell of warm weather.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- A woman was shot and critically wounded and three men suffered lesser wounds in a daring robbery attempt by nine bandits this morning at the University State Bank, on the South Side. The bandits, armed with sawed-off shot guns and revolvers, were routed by tear gas discharged on the bank floor and shots fired by a wounded bank guard, and fled in two automobiles without any loot.

Three new firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange will open for business today. They are Richards, McMaster Co., Sadler Co., and MacKinney Lehmann. Several other firm changes also become effective today.

BRADFORD, Pa., Sept. 30. -- The Commercial National Bank, second largest bank in Bradford, failed to open today in a sequel to the discovery Saturday of its assistant cashier dead in his garage from carbon monoxide poisoning.

Women of the nation were urged to use their vast purchasing power as a weapon to force higher standards of quality in food, clothing and cosmetics at the opening sessions yesterday of the fourteenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor.

ABOARD THE S.S. ARIGUANI, Sept. 30. -- Gayety was sounding from the decks of the Holland America liner Rotterdam early this morning as late revelers from the Spanish costume ball of the evening before lingered on in the delightful tropical night.

SIMLA, India, Sept. 30. -- Mohmand tribesmen along the turbulent northwest frontier have given British troops a taste of the ambushing tactics that Ethiopian tribesmen may use against the Italian army in Africa. It is announced here today that two Britiish officers were killed and between seventy and eighty in the ranks were killed and wounded in an action yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- A ball in the early part of November may be given here for the benefit of the Army and Navy Y.M.C.A. The arrangements have not been completed as yet, but probably will be within the next week.

Miss Helen Nicklas gave a luncheon yesterday at the Central Park Casino for her sister, Miss Mary Nicklas, whose marriage to William Reynolds will take place Thursday afternoon in Old Trinity Church. The other guests were Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds, Mrs. William Dugan, Mrs. Hary Alker, Mrs. Thomas F. Staley, Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds Jr., the Misses Lucy Harrison, Mary Cathell and Mary Louise Wood.

The statement of the Lehigh Valley Railroad as of June 30, filed with the New York State Public Service Commission, shows profit and loss surplus of $35,638,010, compared with $38,455,531 on June 30, 1934. Total assets were $244,723,010, against $244,797,474.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Prices of hogs continued to decline today. The losses were 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight. The trade believes the market is going through the period of recessions to a new crop level which normally is experienced about this season.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Sept. 30. -President Roosevelt experienced the sensation not only of being lost in the mountains late this evening but also of being perilously near the brink of a precipice after he had accepted an invitation to inspect a highway and park project at Mount Charleston, about thirty miles from here.

TORONTO, Sept. 30. -- Five major political parties engaged in an unprecedented rush today to file nomination papers for the general election Oct. 14, when 245 seats in Canada's Parliament will be filled.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- President Roosevelt, in a letter read tonight to the National Recreation Congress, expressed his pleasure over the growing public interest in recreation and praised the work of the congress.

BOULDER DAM, Nev., Sept. 30. -- Standing on a platform perched high above the Colorado River at the eastern terminus of the great, towering Boulder Canyon Dam, President Roosevelt dedicated it today as a "splendid symbol" of employment-providing public works which he said have already given the necessary recovery spur to private industry while increasing the value of the nation's resources.

Good friends, the tumult in Fifty-second Street last evening was Shakespeare. Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne were pouncing on "The Taming of the Shrew" and playing it in the Guild Theatre like a game of ninepins. Most exceeding low, my friends, and most exceeding funny, for "The Shrew" is cabotinage and the Lunts have stuffed it with all the horseplay their barn loft holds.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Popular interest in foreign affairs today centres on Memel, and nothing but withering contempt for Lithuania and her conduct of the election is voiced by the entire German press. The trail of recrimination is even more lurid than that engendered by yesterday's news of the forced extension of the period of balloting.

The extent of the health problem presented by the families on relief was described in a report submitted yesterday by the medical and nursing service of the Emergency Relief Bureau to Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the bureau.

Reorganization of the executive staff of the WPA and salary increases for WPA executives and some 2,000 employes of the administrative staff, totaling about $20,000 a month, were announced yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, shortly before he left by plane for the San Diego Exposition.

The enmity between rival factions in Tammany, evidenced by the many contests in the recent primary election, reached a climax yesterday and last night in a series of court orders and tempestuous meetings.

ATHENS, Sept. 30. -- The Greek Parliament will meet Oct. 10 so its 94 per cent Royalist majority may invite former King George to return before the scheduled plebiscite, the monarchist press announced tonight. Governmental circles would not confirm or deny the report.

With $14,721,000 in gold received here yesterday from Europe, new engagements of the metal in Europe were confined principally to France as exports from London showed a tendency to diminish. A total of $6,872,000 was reported at the Federal Reserve Bank as having been engaged abroad yesterday, of which $6,758,000 was in Paris and $114,000 in Holland.
No change was apparent in any section of the money market. Business was light and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Kiefer Mayer gave a reception for several hundred guests in the Cameo Room at the Greenbrier tonight following a dinner in the Colonnades for 100.

HARRAR, Ethiopia, Sept. 30. -- Ethiopian military leaders on the southern front, facing Italian Somaliland, have just returned to Harrar from Addis Ababa, where they conferred with Emperor Haile SSelassie and the northern commanders during the feast of Maskal.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- League of Nations peacemakers went to work today on a new series of recommendations for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, realizing that their plan might be knocked in the head by the first shell in East Africa.

ROME, Sept. 30. -- The outbreak of hostilities in Africa is now considered a mere matter of days. Any further delay in the opening of the campaign that is designed to give Italy another colony will be the result more of military considerations connected with the impossibility of moving any large body of troops over ground still soft and muddy after the rains than of any lack of decision on the part of the government.

The "escape-proof" Federal House of Detention from which (Count) Victor Lustig, alleged leader of a gang of counterfeiters, vanished on Sept. 1, while he was a prisoner there, is not to be his home any more.

Frederick Gibbs, 29-year-old somber-faced Negro chauffeur and assistant pastor of a Harlem church, was held in Queens this morning on a charge of homicide for the death nearly four months ago of the pensioned widow of the Negro valet of Daniel G. Reid, colorful financier and "tin-plate king" who died in 1925.

Foreclosure auction sales made up the larger part of the urban realty activity reported yesterday. Nine Manhattan parcels and six in the Bronx were taken over by the plaintiffs at the forced sales. The Manhattan parcels included the ten-story Crillon apartment house at 13-15 East Forty-eighth Street and a group of five buildings at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Uncertainty regarding the outcome of the expiring September deliveries restricted speculative operations in the distant futures on the Board of Trade today and price changes were erratic. September wheat acted tight and closed 2 7/8 cents a bushel higher than on Saturday, while September corn, after a range of 3 cents, finished 2 1/4 cents higher, at about the best level of the day and season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Melvin H. Purvis, former head of the Chicago office of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, admitted today that he had promised to recommend cancellation of deportation proceedings against Mrs. Anna Sage, the "woman in red" who accompanied John Dillinger at the time he was slain by Federal agents.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 30. -- District Attorney William E. Parke asked Judge W. Butler Windle of the Chester County Court today to order the December grand jury to investigate the fatal shooting of Miss Evelyn Hoey, musical comedy actress, in the Summer home of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d, near Lyndell, the night of Sept. 11.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held within limits of a few points again yesterday and ended with a gain of 2 points to a loss of 5 points. Strength in October contracts increased the premium on the spot month to 5 points over December, while middling quotations in Southern markets averaged 10.40 cents a pound, compared with 10.48 for October here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Sept. 25, issued by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, shows increases for the week of $42,000,000 in total loans and investments, $155,000,000 in net demand deposits and $119,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The Boerse quiet today, with a definite tendency to weakness. Heavy industrials were mixed, Vereinigtestahl losing , 3/6 point. Machines were stagnant and Metallgesellschaft lost 1/2 point. Chemicals weakened slightly, I.G. Farben losing 3/4 point.

A new application for the examination before trial of Howard C. Hopson, a controlling stockholder and former vice president and director of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, was asked yesterday in the Supreme Court. The suit is by Henry I. Gilbert in behalf of himself and other Associated stockholders against Mr. Hopson and other officers and directors to compel them to account to the corporation for losses due to their acts.

About 600 members of the Metropolitan Fur Buyers Association attended a dinner last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania at which a drive was made for funds for a national advertising campaign for the fur business. Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbels, declared the country was prepared to buy furs provided there was a concentration of publicity.

Registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by investment trusts listed on the New York Curb Exchange, in addition to those made public last week, give the following statistics on principal stockholders, officers' salaries, and commissions paid to stock brokers:

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced yesterday that it had invited, through its president, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, leaders of thought and opinion on international affairs to an all-day meeting Thursday at Columbia University.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocksI for which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in] the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weeklyI transactions:

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocksI for which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in] the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weeklyI transactions:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -Head Coach Ducky Pond today sent the Yale eleven through a half hour's supervised scrimmage in opening the week's practice for the New Hampshire game, which will raise the curtain on the 1935 season Saturday.

Chairman Post of the City Housing Authority makes a long plea for government construction of low-rental dwellings. Boiled down, what he has to say amounts to this: In order to keep up existing land values there would have to be a great overproduction of high rental dwellings, but the private builders will not, or cannot, erect dwellings to be rented at a monthly rent of $7 a room.

ROME, Sept. 30. -- Italian police disclosed tonight that James Donahue, 19-year-old cousin of Barbara, Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, paid for his fun in shouting "Viva Ethiopia!" at a Fascist demonstration by taking an escorted trip to the French border.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30. -The Princeton eleven will be weak at the centre and fullback positions when it faces Penn Saturday, it was apparent at the end of practice today. At present the first and third string centres and the first two substitute fullbacks are on the injured list.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 30. -De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry of Brown stands high among the leaders in the football coaching profession, not only in his giant physique but also as a trail-blazer in devising attacking alignments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- A detailed plan of procedure to assist industry in taking advantage of voluntary codes under the skeletonized National Recovery Act, and which was approved by President Roosevelt prior to his departure last week, was made public at the White House today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Tiling of twelve additional registration statements under the Securities Act, irlvolving $12,9i3,70i, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The quinquennial election of additional members to the Hall of Fame begins today and continues to the 15th, at which time the "polls will close." Meanwhile the electors, approximately 100 in number and representative of the entire United States, are preparing for this extraordinary franchise.

The World Theatre, formerly the Westminster Cinema, will open tonight under the management of Irvin Shapiro and Archie Mayers, with the premiere of "Legong," a film photographed in Technicolor on the island of Bali. Tonight's showing will aid the Stony Wold Sanatorium.

A program of public education in which children would be freed from "water-tight compartment" grades to follow a path of "unbroken progress" from kindergarten to college is recommended by a committee on articulation and integration appointed in 1931 by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- The Cubs met in their clubhouse today before leaving for Detroit and voted twenty-six and one-half shares of their 1935 world series spoils.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman stepped into the Crempa case today. Pressed to take a hand and cognizant of the intense interest in the situation surrounding last Thursday's fatal shooting of Mrs. Sophie Crempa during a raid on her home by eight deputy sheriffs, the Governor tried to expedite the grand jury inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Treasury's refunding of $1,250,000,000 of the called 4 1/4 per cent Fourth Liberty Loan bonds continued to lag last week, and conversions to date aggregate $826,000,000, it was announced today.

Additional indictments charging second-degree assault and escape from custody were brought yesterday against the four youths who gained brief freedom Sunday by beating their four guards and escaping from the annex of the Bronx County Jail at 161st Street and Third Avenue.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, issued a warning yesterday in his annual report that business is being examined to determine at what point new taxes can be affixed.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 30. -- The final standing among the Victory class boats for the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association season which ended last Saturday was announced today by Robert W. Fraser, recorder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was confronted with its heaviest actual liability today with the closing of the Commercial National Bank of Bradford, Pa. The FDIC will make good a shortage estimated at $1,000,000.

TAKE them as they come. Here's Gabby Hartnett, tall and husky heavyweight catcher for the Cubs. Drives in a lot of runs. Has a cheery manner, a loud voice and curly hair. Well, Mickey Cochrane has curly hair, too. He also plays the saxophone. Gabby fancies himself as a singer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- An indictment of adult America was voiced here tonight by Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools of New York City, in describing the plight of the nation's children owing to a lack of adequate recreational centres in the populous areas.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1. -- Leningrad was under an air "bombardment" yesterday when "enemy" planes swooped down from behind a smoke screen and theoretically gassed and bombed railroad stations and factories for twenty-five minutes.

MADRID, Oct. 1. -- Premier Joaquin Chapaprieta, who is also Minister of Finance, presented his new Cabinet to the Cortes today, when it resumed its labors after the Summer vacation of 2 1/2 months. He promised that next year's budget would be balanced easily in view of a saying of 800,000,000 pesetas effected by his economy program, which eliminated four Cabinet Ministries and hundreds of State functionaries.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 1. -- In the aftermath of the mishap to the Rotterdam, which has imposed upon the 456 passengers pleasant imprisonment in Jamaica until the Volendam arrives next Sunday for their return to New York, speculation on the cause of the stranding of the vessel stands out over everything else.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The Walworth Company, one of the world's largest manufacturers of wrenches, pipes and valves, was authorized today to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

War News and Commodities. The developments in the Italo-Ethiopian controversy yesterday were reflected in the commodity markets, particularly those for wheat and cotton, both advancing sharply. Because of the likelihood of a war resulting in the closing of the Suez Canal and otherwise disrupting shipping, Egyptian and Indian cotton shippers are said to be nervous.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP). -- A Republican caravan, designed to carry the party's fight for control of the Assembly to the furthermost corners of the State, will start the trek from New York City on Monday.

Miss Sylva Annenberg, holder of the New York State championship, yesterday entered a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament for the first time in many months, and won handily with an 84, two strokes better than her nearest competitor, Mrs. M.G. Missir of the Westchester C.C.
ROSLYN, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Pete Cassella of Southern Parkway and Ralph Leaf of North Hills won first honors in the Scotch foursomes event of the Metropolitan P.G.A. at the Engineers Golf-Club today.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- Sir George Russell Clerk, the British Ambassador, formally laid before Premier Pierre Laval today a request from his government for information as to the attitude France would take in the event some incident occurred in the Mediterranean between the British and the Italian fleets during the period of diplomatic tension that may precede application of sanctions by the League of Nations under Article XVI of the covenant.

TRENTON, Oct. 1. -- Averting a fight on the floor that leaders of both factions feared would disrupt the party, the Republican State convention adopted today a compromise plank advocating repeal of the sales tax after permanent economies have been effected.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 1. -- As Ethiopia mad ready for war, American doctors and nurses prepared today to aid the wounded and ill.

After a completing a preliminary survey of the proposed site for the world's fair of 1939 at Flushing Meadows Park, Park Commissioner Robert Moses urged an immediate decision because of the effect on pending construction work of the city Park Department, the Triborough Bridge Authority and the Federal and State parkway system within the city.

It is already evident that the Albany conference on crime promises to be more precise and concrete in its proposals than ordinary gatherings of that kind. The speakers seem fully aware that they cannot attain the ends they desire without using the necessary means.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- Long lines of women standing in the markets this morning waiting for an opportunity to buy a quarter of a pound of butter bore witness to the continued acuteness of the Berlin butter shortage.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S little informal speech in the Los Angeles Coliseum yesterday was perhaps more effectual in making friends of the audience, if there were unfriendly persons in it, than a labored address swarming with figures and reciting achievements. California, especially Southern California, loves to praise itself and to be praised.

WARSAW, Oct. 1. -- A move leading to an understanding between the Ukrainian minority and the Polish Government was taken here during the week-end at a conference between Premier Walery Slaweck and two Ukrainian leaders, Mr. Mudryj, Ukrainian editor and prospective leader of the Ukrainian Parliamentary group, and Mr. Celewicz, general secretary of the Ukrainian Undo party.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Creation of a State Department of Justice, including appointive instead of elective Attorney General and District Attorneys, and of a State Bureau of Investigation like that of the "G" men was urged by George Z. Medalie today at Governor Lehman's crime conference.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Small receipts of hogs again today failed to check the declining tendency in the market. Because of consumer resistance to paying relatively high prices for pork products the market is easily influenced by even a moderate increase in arrivals.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, told Ulster County Republicans tonight that "illegal voting and political contacts with racketeers by Democratic organizations in the larger cities" should be discussed by Governor Lehman's crime conference.
The Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church is to be highly commended for his denunciation of the projected radio program, "Hymns of All Churches."

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Employment and payrolls in wholesale trade establishments increased 1 per cent from July to August, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner reported today. In the same period approximately 15,000 retail establishments indicated decreases of 2 per cent in employment and payrolls.
The recent letters of Lawson Purdy and Whidden Graham regarding the theory of natural rights are interesting and pertinent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Disagreement between Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and ten large banking houses over a $90,000,000 financing plan for the New York Central Railroad was disclosed today when Mr. Jones made public an exchange of heated correspondence between himself, Harold S. Vanderbilt, who is the road's chief stockholder, and representatives of the banks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A decrease of more than $1,200,000,000 in farm mortgage debt since 1930 was revealed today by Agriculture Department records.

In a suite on the tenth floor of the Sardi Building, at such a desk as becomes a theatrical titan, Ed Wynn sat yesterday and said that he had always wanted to be a fulltime producer. The news this morning is that Mr. Wynn is on the point of becoming just such a producer.

County Judge Cortland A. Johnson of Nassau was nominated yesterday as the Republican candidate for the Supreme Court bench in the Second Judicial District at a convention held in the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building. Judge Johnson will oppose Francis G. Hooley of Rockville Centre, L.I., who was nominated by the Democrats Monday night for the post of Justice Townsend Scudder.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, now serving by appointment of Governor Lehman, was unanimously nominated for that office last night at the Democratic First Judicial District Convention in Tammany Hall. As Justice Pecora had been endorsed previously by the Republican convention, his election is assured.

Weakness in gold-bloc currencies in the foreign exchange market here in September started another large-scale movement of gold to the United States. Shipments received at New York were the largest since June. It was the third big flow of the metal to this country since devaluation of the dollar.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Shaking with emotion and at times on the verge of tears, George Lansbury declared today that he would rather give up his leadership of the Labor party than approve the use of force against Italy or any other nation.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 1. -- John Crempa and his son, John, Jr., returned to their home here tonight after both had been freed in bail pending their trial on a charge of contempt of court. Their release will enable them to attend tomorrow the funeral of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, wife of John Crempa, who was killed in a Sheriff's raid on the Crempa farm last week.

ROME, Oct. 1. -- The attention of all Italians is turning more and more to the possible European consequences of an African conflict. Their enthusiasm has again returned to white heat now that action in East Africa seems imminent after a period of uncertainty; but they cannot close their eyes to the fact that Britain's attitude continues to represent a threatening, unknown quantity.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

MEMEL, Lithuania, Oct. 1. -- Having won a moral victory in the Memel Diet election, National Socialist Germany scored another point against Lithuania when the Kaunas government was forced to announce today the suspension of free exchange of money and the introduction of rigid foreign exchange control, effective immediately.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- William Lambert, a keeper at Sing Sing prison here, was discharged today by Warden Lewis E. Lawes as a result of a departmental trial which disclosed that 3,000 yards of cotton sheeting was stolen from the prison storeroom and sold to a local merchant.

The American Flag gelding, Patriotic, which races for the Geneseo Stable, under skillful handling by Twenty Grand's old rider, Charles Kurtsinger, made it two in a row at Belmont yesterday as favorites became hard to find after the clean sweep for form on the opening afternoon.

Diplomas and licenses were awarded yesterday to thirty-four cadets at the semi-annual graduation exercises of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

A cosmic ray, messenger from interstellar space, will switch on the stars tonight, promptly at 9 o'clock, in New York's first "artificial heaven," at the opening of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Two 16-inch coast defense guns boomed nine times at Fort Tilden, Rockaway, Queens, yesterday in the first test of firing guns of such size from a land position at a moving target, according to army officials who participated in the test.

TOKYO, Oct. 1. -- Under continued pressure from the Ministers of War and Marine, the Japanese Cabinet made still another attempt to dispose of the Minobe affair by issuing a detailed statement today on the measures being taken to "clarify national policy" as taught in the schools and universities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Applications of brokers and dealers for registration on Form 1-M in the period from Aug. 26 to Sept. 7 were made public today by the SEC. Those from New York City follow: The symbols are: C, corporation; S, sole proprietor; P, partnership.

In your editorial "Urging Moderation" you close with these words: "Much of the ground thus gained (by moral suasion) was lost when the idea of compulsion was brought into the picture and many of the reform groups, losing patience with the older method and seeking a short cut to the goal, switched from the hope of temperance by moral suasion to a demand for abstinence by law."

With former Governor Charles S. Whitman the toastmaster, the members of the victorious United States team were guests of honor at the dinner arranged last night by the Marshall Chess Club in recognition of their winning the international chess championship at Warsaw last month. The dinner was held at the Advertising Club.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 1. -- President Roosevelt ended another transcontinental journey when he arrived here at 7:45 P.M. (Pacific time) tonight. His arrival on a special train concluded a trip begun last Thursday evening at Washington, in the course of which he has made two notable addresses -- at Fremont, Neb., and Boulder Dam -- and a large number of platform appearances before crowds which gathered at service stops.

Every now and then, as Patrick J. O'Connor set up a dozen Cape Cods yesterday afternoon in his tiny oyster stand on South Street, he would glance out of the window and a smile of the deepest satisfaction would spread over his ruddy, bespectacled features.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 1. -- As Stanly M. Bruce, Australian delegate at Geneva, raised the question of increased consumption of nutritious food among the poorer classes as a solution of the world agricultural depression, Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons released a memorandum that he had recently sent to the Pope urging the Vatican to endorse his proposals along this line.

One man was sent to the penitentiary yesterday in the job-fixing racket and another was arrested on an indictment charging that he extorted $500 from a man in 1931 in the old district political headquarters of John F. Curry, former leader of Tammany.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Coach Reggie Root's much-heralded freshman eleven encountered the Yale varsity for the first time today and displayed unexpected strength.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $1,287,000 city of Schenectady, N.Y., bonds at a price of 100.30 for 2 1/2s. In the syndicate are the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, Estabrook Co., Kean, Taylor Co. and R.H. Moulton Co., Inc.
COPENHAGEN, Oct. 1. -- The lower chamber of the Danish Rigsdag was dissolved by royal decree this afternoon and a general election will be held Oct. 22.

Discussing Connecticut's Autumn trout fishing season with a group of sportsmen the other day, Arthur L. Clark, superintendent of the State Board of Fisheries and Game, said the experiment, if nothing else, would serve to show anglers just how poorly fitted some present-day streams are to support fish.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, who has been stripped of all his functions by the decree establishing complete State supremacy over the Protestant Church, is in favor of the decree. This statement was made by his personal spokesman, Count Korf.
Money market was dull. The only business reported covered routine demands, while quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

The Municipal Housing Authority should make certain that the model tenements it will erect for 2,000 persons at Macombs Place and 151st Street, in Harlem, are rented exclusively to persons of low income, the Real Estate Board of New York said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Oscar Ransome, 51, of Port Chester, N.Y., is being held by Greenwich police under $2,500 bail after admitting that he put poison in the coffee of the Misses Harriet and Anna Acker, daughters of Benjamin Y. Acker of Lake Avenue, Greenwich, after he had been rebuked by one of them.

Anatol Viltzak has been engaged as the premier dancer at the Metropolitan Opera during the coming season, it was announced yesterday by the American Ballet, which is in charge of the ballet features of the Metropolitan Opera Association. He will also be assistant to George Balanchine, maitre de ballet of the American Ballet and the Metropolitan.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 1. -- Lengthy conferences took place yesterday and today in Cairo and Alexandria between British military, air and naval authorities and Sir Miles Lampson, British High Commissioner, who has just returned to Egypt after curtailing his vacation in England.

AGAWAM, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Splendid weather, keen racing and fair pay-offs combined to give the first thoroughbred horse meeting in Western Massachusetts an auspicious launching before a crowd of 18,000 at Agawam Park today. Ladfield, the 6-year-old registered in the name of Mrs. Charles Crane of Detroit, who originally hailed from Western Massachusetts, fittingly enough won the Berkshire Handicap, feature race, which carried an added $5,000.

Keeping his pledge of last April that he would demand that the Long Island Railroad have its snow removal program ready by Oct. 1, Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell had the railroad officials report yesterday whether the equipment was in condition to prevent a repetition of last Winter's tie-ups when thousands of commuters were inconvenienced by the interruption.

The liner Rotterdam was still fast aground last night on Morant Cays, forty miles east of Jamaica, while her 460 passengers and almost half of her crew were ashore in Kingston, laughing and joking at their experience.

The Roosevelt administration is trying to "browbeat, coerce and wheedle" the State governments into line, Colonel William J. Donovan, former Republican candidate for Governor, charged last night in a speech at the Tenth Assembly District Club, 8 West Twenty-eighth Street.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 1. (AP). -- Overriding a stubborn minority after turbulent debate, Senator Huey Long's followers in the Democratic State Central Committee late today upheld the Senator's legislative act abolishing candidate representation by commissioners at the polls.

The New York Teachers Guild, with a "progressive labor philosophy," was organized yesterday at a meeting in the New School for Social Research by Dr. Henry R. Linville and other former officers of the Teachers Union who resigned in protest against left-wing factionalism in the union.

DETROIT, Oct. 1. -- Mike Jacobs, first of the million-dollar fight pro-motors since Tex Rickard, is about to take over the prize-ring privileges of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, the house that Rickard built when Jacobs was his silent partner.

For four hours during the height of the hurricane that swept the Morgan liner Dixie onto French Reef off the Florida coast on the night of Sept. 2 the ship was virtually unmanageable and drifted helplessly in the tremendous seas and furious gale, Captain Einer William Sundstrom told the United States Steamboat Inspection Service Inquiry Board yesterday.

Agents for O.P. and M.J. Van Sweringen completed formalities yesterday which transferred control of their $3,000,000,000 railroad system from a banking consortium to a new holding concern formed at their behest, but at the same time the Cleveland brothers were faced by another problem -- a default in the principal of a debt by the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 1. -- A plea for "non-extremists" to go into action to help save the democratic State was voiced today by President Park as Bryn Mawr College opened its year.

The Snyder Canadian Expedition, which has just completed the most extensive scientific expedition ever to go into Northwestern Canada, obtained more than 200 specimens of mammals, among them being the first specimens of black-tailed white sheep and elk to come out of the North, said George G. Goodwin, a member of the expedition, in an interview yesterday afternoon in the American Museum of Natural History, where he is assistant curator of mammals.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The names of the fifty-three men appointed to the Princeton University faculty for the coming academic year were announced today by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university. Included on the list late twenty-eight instructors, eighteen assistants, four assistant professors and three lecturers.
Departing tonight on the Hamburg- American liner Hamburg for channel ports and Hamburg will be H.M. Van Haersma de With, Netherlands Minister to the United States. Others on the list include:

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Two games in the sixteen-goal Autumn plates tournament were completed today at the Meadow Brook Club. The Hurricanes won a convincing victory over the Aiken Knights, 11 to 5, to reach the final, and in a first-round match William Zeigler's Great Island team vanquished the Camels, 8 to 4.

One place where the dedication of Boulder Dam should receive a great deal of sympathetic attention is Soviet Russia. It would be only a fair return for the enormous amount of public interest developed in the United States on the subject of Dnieprostroy.
The New York Stock Exchange suspended from dealings yesterday eleven bond issues and one stock issue and struck from the list the common and preferred stocks of another company. The issues were:

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- The regulations governing the enforcement of the so-called Nuremberg laws adopted by the National Socialist Reichstag Sept. 15 are still being worked out at the Ministry of the Interior, and no date has been set for their promulgation.

Charles D. Hilles is quoted in the press lately as advocating the selection of delegates for the national convention pledged nominally to favorite sons, but actually free at the convention to select a Presidential candidate from the scramble of these bee-bonnet candidates.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Minor disturbances today marked the start of a four-port Gulf Coast strike of longshoremen called by officials of the International Longshoremen's Association at New Orleans, Gulfport, Mobile and Pensacola.

The formation, if not the first fruits of the committee of fifty-eight lawyers, evokes the memory of a smaller but equally distinguished aggregation of lawyers in the Roosevelt-Parker campaign thirty-one years ago.

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- The Boerse was partly weak and partly stagnant today. Heavy industrial shares weakened, Vereinigtestahl losing 2 1/8 points. Machine stocks suffered considerable losses, including 1 7/8 points by Wuag, 3/4 point by Berlin-Karlsruhe, which for three days had not been quoted, and 1 1/8 points by Orenstein Koppel.
ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- The radio talk today of Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals to the children in the schools of the State was as follows:

Mr. van Druten describes "Most of the Game" as light comedy in the program of the Cort, where it was played last evening. As a maker of phrases he is buoyant and winning. His characters in the new piece include a popular novelist, his wife, a screen hero of hearts, an Oxford professor's daughter and a gauche and slightly fabulous male secretary whose impudence is natural enough to be enjoyable.

John J. Kemp, 51 years old, of 33 Riverside Drive, affable, distinguished-looking insurance broker with many leading stage, screen and radio clients, was booked at Police Headquarters yesterday on charges of forgery and grand larceny.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, disclosed yesterday that the association is making definite plans for a Spring subsidiary season. He said that the season would be sponsored probably by a new board of directors to be drawn from "the younger set" and added that such a development was "really necessary for the future of opera in America."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 1 (Reuters). -- Sixteen Italian submarines are reported to be in the Red Sea, and, according to information here, they will be employed in mainly in trying to intercept munitions that may be shipped to Ethiopia from foreign countries.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1. (AP). -- Off to a slow start because of a rainy morning, first and second round tennis matches in the annual Pacific Coast championships found favorites coming through largely as expected today.

A private preview of "Future House," the first of 500 model homes in the "New American" manner which are to be opened throughout the country this month, was held last night in Horticultural Hall, on the eleventh floor of the R.C.A. Building in Rockefeller Center.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1. -- The largest reception of his career burst unexpectedly on President Roosevelt today when he stopped for a few hours, en route to San Diego, to view the city and to receive its greetings.

More than 130 unpublished poems by Emily Dickinson have come to light at the Dickinson family home in Amherst, Mass. The poems will be published in an edition limited to 500 copies by Little, Brown on Nov. 22. The title will be "Unpublished Poems of Emily Dickinson," and Martha Dickinson Bianchi and Alfred Leete Hampson will be the editors.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Dolores Costello sealed her decision to divorce John Barrymore today by filing a new complaint, dropping charges of cruelty in an original action, but including a newly signed property agreement between them.

Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, in a letter yesterday to Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, demanded that he countermand the salary increases granted by General Johnson to 125 WPA executives in this city.

The directors of the American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday declared a dividend of $6.50 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. This payment, which will be made on Dec. 2 to stockholders of record of Nov. 8, will clear up all dividend arrears on that stock, including that for the quarter ended on Sept. 30.

The din-conscious city began an effort for a month of hushing at 11 o'clock last night and early this morning police were still distributing "admonitions" to drivers who honked their horns too loudly, pedestrians who showed a fondness for singing and sponsors of parties at which the fun seemed likely to be no fun at all for the sleep-seeking neighbors.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- With forty years of coaching behind him, Glenn Scobey (Pop) Warner of Temple still holds his place in the forefront of his profession, with his mental faculties as crystal clear as in the days when he stood forth as the progenitor of the wing-back formation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The United States in August increased its exports to all regions except South America, Asia and Oceania, as compared with the corresponding month of last year, the Commerce Department's monthly survey, issued today, showed.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The official British gaze is again turned toward the United States in this Italo-Ethiopian difficulty. It is being discovered anew that in the matter of sanctions to prevent Italy from making war on Ethiopia or to check her after she has started hostilities nothing practical can be done without the full cooperation of the United States and also of Germany.

"Small Investor" submits some questions regarding United States baby bonds. He asks if this issue has been submitted and approved by the Securities Exchange Commission and, if not, why not? "Is it possible that the government would seek to impose on others rules of conduct which the government itself refuses to follow?"

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Shaun Kelly Jr., a senior from Richmond, Mass., today was chosen to captain the Harvard varsity eleven, in a special election called to fill the vacancy caused by the forced resignation of J. Robert Haley of Winthrop.
Trading in commodity futures yesterday was generally quiet. In the cash markets wheat and oats made new high prices and cotton advanced while lard, tin, rubber and silk were losers.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 1, -- The "Little Island of Sailing Ships" of one square mile, known as New York, which has been lost to sight for 150 years, may now be reconstructed with some degree of accuracy through documentary evidence discovered by Samuel Duff McCoy of New York, it was revealed today at the session of the New York State Historical Association here.

Burton Emmett, who died May 6, last, in his sixty-fourth year, was so many-sided that it seems inadequate to refer to him just as a collector of art. It is, at any rate, as a collector that he is now being remembered at Contemporary Arts, 41 West Fifty-fourth Street, where an exhibition has been arranged, composed of works in various mediums selected from his very large private collection and booked to continue until Oct. 12.

Reports issued yesterday by the National Investors group of investment trusts for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 showed a sharp increase in the net assets of each, resulting from the rise in the market value of their portfolios. The statements were issued by the Second National Investors Corporation, the Third National Investors Corporation and the Fourth National Investors Corporation.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Twice today Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, made it clear to all the world that Britain had no intention of stabilizing her currency at the present time, whatever the other nations may want her to do.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,763,200 barrels, compared with 2,774,500 in the previous week, a decline of 11,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 11,400 barrels in California was the most important change.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1. -- Soviet opinion is crystallizing into the belief that the visit to Berlin of Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary and the talk of a German-Polish-Hungarian rapprochement constitutes a further step toward Fascist aggression in Central and Eastern Europe -- based at this moment on the Italian involvement in Africa.

IT might add interest to classroom work if the high school instructors in elementary physics would call the attention of their eager scholars to a little problem now spread before that eminent physicist, G. Stanley Cochrane, formerly of Boston University.

The tools of complicated arts, crafts and trades, formerly thought of as being open only to the professional, are made more conveniently accessible to amateur talent in a hobby craft exhibit that opened yesterday on the fifth floor of the R.H. Macy Co. store.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 2. -- While officials are silent, press reports reveal that the navy remains implacably hostile to the British proposal for a naval conference this year, contained in a note delivered to the government.

The awarding of election advertising by the Board of Elections to "mushroom" newspapers which change from weeklies to dailies long enough to publish election notices, was protested yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

DETROIT, Oct. 1. -- The bustle of world series traffic was intensified by the arrival of hundreds of ordinary fans as well as many baseball celebrities in Detroit on the eve of baseball's classic competition.

Contrary to the supposed movement toward extending greater liberties to Soviet citizens, the Kremlin has now decreed a uniform document of identification throughout the country. The new document, which will take the form of a birth certificate, will really be a sort of internal passport; it must contain a record of the holder's previous marriages and divorces and information regarding his occupation.
A corps of noise reporters, many of them wearing rubbers, turned in the following reports on various fronts in the campaign for quiet last night: ...

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the preceding week, but were slightly above the total for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 1. -- Next to the immediate beneficiary, the retailers of the nation will profit more from social legislation than any other group, Dr. Luther Harr, Secretary of Banking in Pennsylvania, told merchants tonight at the annual retail conference sponsored by the Pennsylvania State College.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A new "drive" by the American Red Cross to reduce the number of accidental deaths occurring annually in homes, on farms and along the nation's highways was announced today in a radio address by Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, national chairman.

A sharp increase in public utility retirements was the principal feature of the payments in September of bonds called before maturity. They accounted for almost half of the month's total of $350,611,000, which was the largest figure for a month since July.

Commercial failures declined slightly in the retail and wholesale divisions in the week ended Sept. 26, as compared with the previous week, but increased in the manufacturing group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Mrs. William Warren Tracy was elected president today of the Williamstown Garden Club at the annual meeting and tea which was held at the Williamstown home of Miss Laura E. Dwight, who declined re-election to that office.

Although the Tigers yesterday continued to be 7-10 favorites to win the world series, the Cubs are gaining support in the betting and indications are the odds at game-time today will be 9 -- 10 and take your choice, according to Jack Doyle, well-known betting commissioner.

Banks here began yesterday to issue reports of their condition at the end of September. These showed gains in deposits and resources, in some cases to the highest marks in the history of the institutions. Generally, there apparently have been only slight changes in the amount of United States Government securities held, according to the reports.

After deliberating nine hours without arriving at a verdict, a jury in the bribery trial of William H. Rabell, former investigator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was locked up at 11 P.M. last night at the Hotel McAlpin. The United States Marshal took the twelve men from the Federal building at 11 o'clock, and they will resume their deliberations this morning.

DETROIT, Oct. 1. -- A great mid-western metropolis, with its temperature running a trifle low, but its pulse unusually high, is waiting with nervous impatience tonight for another unveiling of baseball's greatest show on earth. It appears to be a bit uncertain as to what to expect but is positive something dramatic is on the wing.

The share market ushered in the new month in rather uncertain fashion yesterday. Following the irregular opening of the list, the automotive group was accorded good support so that many issues recorded new high marks for the year and longer; stocks worked irregularly higher in the afternoon but encountered a flurry of selling in the last half hour, to close generally lower, the losses ranging from fractions to 3 points.

United action by security and commodity brokers in meeting problems of external regulation and taxation was urged by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address last night at the tenth anniversary dinner of the New York Cocoa Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Should war develop in East Africa, requiring President Roosevelt by the terms of the Neutrality Act to place an embargo on arms, munitions and other war equipment, it is expected that the list of articles placed under the ban would not differ greatly from the one contained in the President's recent proclamation requiring arms and munitions manufacturers in this country to register with the government.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Operations generally were dull today on the London Stock Exchange, although oils enlivened the trading by a sharp advance in Trinidad lease-holds, due to the unexpected final dividend of 12 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Plans are being prepared for speeding construction of the $140,000,000 trans-Florida ship canal through expenditure of large additional sums on the first year's work. It was declared probable today that $20,000,000 in Work Relief funds would be spent in addition to the $5,000,000 already allocated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Heavy and persistent buying of wheat futures credited to New York interests and liberal purchases by brokers who generally act for mills carried prices sharply higher today on the Board of Trade with the December delivery selling at the highest price of the season and at 1 cent premium over the May.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A billion dollars' worth of public works and housing projects were left stranded today as the Works Progress Administration started syphoning off what was left of the $4,000,000,000 relief fund.
Members of the Council of Apparel Trade Executives will recommend to the garment industry the deferring of the showing of the so-called Southern resort and early Spring styles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A registration statement for a $58,300,000 stock issue by the Massachusetts Investors Trust of Boston was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Filmy waves of pink, blue and white billowed across East Fifty-fifth Street yesterday morning as the Purple Box, the lingerie and linen shop operated as an adjunct of the senior workshop of the East Side Crippled Children's Free School, moved from No. 11 to new and larger quarters at No. 26.

Mrs. Virginia Clayton Willys de Landa filed yesterday with Surrogate Henderson in the Bronx a petition for the appointment of a temporary administrator to conserve "more than $800,000" of the estate of her father, the late John N. Willys, automobile manufacturer, in this State.

The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows prices to have reached the highest since May, 1930, and to have advanced very nearly 4 per cent during September. This was the largest monthly increase since July, 1933.

Senator James P. Pope of Idaho whose tour of Europe evoked criticism by Americans who feared Europeans would regard him as a sort of envoy-at-large, returned yesterday on the Holland-America liner Volendam with Mrs. Pope and his secretary, Ralph Olmstead.

Salaries and stockholdings of the officers and directors of several companies whose stock is represented on the New York Stock Exchange by voting trust certificates were made public in registration statements released yesterday by the Exchange.

With "Count" Victor Lustig, counterfeiter and confidence man, locked up for a supposedly long tenancy in Tombs prison, Federal agents revealed yesterday for the first time just how he made his way last Sept. 1 from the "escape-proof" Federal House of Detention on Eleventh and West Streets.

The election of Albert A. Tilney, chairman of the board of the Bankers Trust Company, as president of the New York Clearing House Association and of James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, as chairman of the clearing house committee, was announced yesterday with the publication of the association's annual report for the year ended on Sept. 30.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Charles Mayo Jr., the youthful Long Island amateur golf champion, did not follow the customary procedure of playing the Rockville Country Club course, but he nevertheless scored a 76 today and won the Long Island Golf Association one-day tourney.

Probably most readers of the news of the Van Sweringen auction were perplexed at the announcement that, in an open competitive sale, securities carrying control of what was described as "a $3,000,000,000 railway empire" were bought in for $3,121,000. The matter was probably not made more intelligible from the fact that this block of shares was part of the collateral pledged with bankers against a defaulted $48,000,000 bank loan.

Although there has been some improvement in real estate and in renting in recent months, the new assessment figures still are "entirely too high," in the opinion of Douglas L. Elliman, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Taxable real estate in New York City is assessed tentatively for 1936 at $15,952,747,571, showing an increase of $100,640 in the final assessments for 1935. This is the first increase since 1932.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The big push for world series tickets at Wrigley Field lasted 3 hours and 55 minutes today.

ALBERT JAY NOCK, editor of the old Freeman, has taken time out from his life-work of anointing the feet of Mr. Thomas Jefferson to write a profound little book called "Our Enemy, the State" (Morrow, $2.25). It will shock Liberty Leaguers, it will shock New Dealers, it will shock Communists and Socialists. Fascists will commit it to the flames.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Judge Joseph Buffington, senior member of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here. issued a restraining order today stopping payment of $720,000 in interest due on two issues of gold notes of the Standard Gas and Electric Company totaling $24,649,500.
