An audience of women consumers kept speakers one hour overtime yesterday in a discussion of the relative merits of chain store and independent groceries. The session was held in connection with the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor.

Columbia started to polish its offense yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its opening encounter with Virginia Military Institute here on Saturday. Fairly well satisfied with the improvement on defense displayed by the Lions during the last ten days, Coach Lou Little had the Morningsiders go through a lengthy session, in which not more than two running formations were used.

The Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, in its quarterly report to stockholders issued yesterday, shows net income of $4,089,646 for the eight months ended on Aug. 31, 1935, after taxes, depreciation and fixed charges, equivalent after preferred dividends to $2.84 a share on the outstanding no-par common stock.
PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP). -- James Donahue, ushered out of Italy for cheering Ethiopia in Venice, said today he would like to square things with the Mussolini government.

Nervousness over developments in Africa and fears of interruptions to the free shipment of cotton to European ports advanced prices sharply yesterday on the Liverpool, New Orleans and New York Cotton Exchanges. The buying started in Liverpool, where Indian and Continental demand for contracts strengthened prices as shippers with forward commitments endeavored to protect themselves against contingencies.

Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday approved a reorganization plan for the bonds issued by the Mortgage and Bond Company of New York. The plan was accepted by Basil O'Connor, former law partner of President Roosevelt, who was named some months ago by Justice Valente to hear proposals by a committee of bondholders and attorneys for individual bondholders on the reorganization of the company and its properties.

The Wabash Railway, one of the first railroads to enter receivership after the collapse of the boom in 1929, is considering a plan of re organization, it was announced yesterday at the receivers' offices. The Pennsylvania Railroad, which acquired the control of the Wabash and the Lehigh Valley in a $106,000,000 deal prior to 1929, has had a reorganization of the Wabash under consideration for some time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The next Republican National Convention will have only 1,048 delegates instead of 1,154, as in 1932, according to a computation made today by Republican National Committee officials in preparing a call for a meeting of the committee to decide the date and place for the 1936 Republican convention.

Clerical leaders representing the various religious denominations throughout the metropolitan area gave added impetus yesterday to "the mobilization of the moral and spiritual forces of civilization" for the observance of "loyalty days" in all churches here on next Saturday and Sunday.

One reason for believing that no international complications will follow upon the Memel election is that a tensely awaited trial of strength has ended in something of a comic anticlimax. Ten years ago the population of this little segment of East Prussia which had been set up as an autonomous State inside of Lithuania was 70 per cent German and 30 per cent Lithuanian, according to German sources.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Passing up suggestions by representatives of the bondholders and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Federal Judge P. Barnes today appointed Charles P. Megan, former president of the Chicago Bar Association, as sole trustee for the Chicago North Western Railway Company pending reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The government answered the challenge to the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Act today with the argument that 85 per cent of bituminous coal is used either in States other than those which produced it or by railroads engaged in interstate commerce.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address made at the Memorial Coliseum today was as follows:

Prosperity of a sort was just around the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street last night, and pedestrians hurrying through the drizzle past the National Republican Club might have been some whit startled at about 11:30 P.M. to hear loud speakers blaring forth bids of thousands of dollars for items like hot water bottles and cartons of cigarettes.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 1. -- It is reported by an excellent source, although at present there is no official confirmation, that Emperor Haile Selassie telegraphed today to his son-in-law, Ras Desta, Governor of the Southern Province of Sidamo, to prepare to come to Addis Ababa to take over command of the city in the event of the Emperor's absence.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Solicitor General Stanley Reed told the National Conference of Catholic Charities tonight that a primary business spirit of service rather than profit was a requisite for American progress.

TRENTON, Oct. 1. -- Not only did the Democratic State convention ratify today a platform pledging support of the party's candidates for the 1936 Legislature to repeal of the sales tax, but it also adopted a resolution requesting Governor Hoffman to call the 1935 Legislature into special session to repeal the law at once.

Mike Jacobs, promoter for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club was mildly reprimanded by the State Athletic Commission yesterday for the manner in which he arranged and sold ringside seats for the Joe Louis-Max Baer fight last week at the Yankee Stadium, but left the meeting bearing the blessings of the fistic body for his excellent management of the show.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

"We have come to the point where private industry must bear the principal responsibility of keeping the processes of greater employment moving forward with accelerated speed." This sentence from the President's talk at Boulder Dam was given great prominence in the headlines, and was widely interpreted as a warning that the President considers it now the duty of private industry to supply more work.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The death penalty will be asked for two prisoners who are alleged to have plotted a tenement fire, fatal to ten persons, to collect $3,000 insurance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Convinced that the present surplus of cigar leaf tobacco cannot be eliminated without an adjustment program, Secretary Wallace approved today a curtailment plan to cover the years 1936-39, inclusive. Mr. Wallace said that an investigation had shown that normal production next year would exceed consumption, with the result that farm prices for growers would be below the fair exchange value.

A new issue of $5,000,000 of Atlanta Gas Light Company general mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1955, will be placed on the market today by a banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds will be priced at 98 1/2, and accrued interest, to yield about 4.615 per cent to maturity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Little Doggie, bearing the colors of Mrs. R.B. Fairbanks, today scored an impressive triumph in the Lake Front Purse, one of the features on the card at the Hawthorne track. The winner defeated Bubblesome by a length and the latter was three lengths ahead of Cotton Club at the finish.

Richard Schirrmann, a lean and bronzed man of sixty-odd years, known to youths all over the world as the founder of the youth hostel movement, came to the United States yesterday on the Holland-America liner Volendam to visit hostels here and speak this week in Chicago at a national congress of recreation leaders.

Several smiles were detected yesterday at the New York Library after officials had read a news dispatch from Moscow reporting that a "Columbus Diary" had been found in an obscure Russian museum at Kargapol.

John J. Kemp, who was insurance broker for the late Will Rogers and other stage, screen and opera celebrities, was held in $50,000 bail by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Yorkville Court yesterday for hearing Oct. 16 on suspicion of forgery and grand larceny.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- A Republican victory in the Philadelphia Mayoralty election next month would have "a very salutary effect throughout the country." Henry P. Fletcher, the party's national chairman, said during a visit here today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Stocks reacted sharply yesterday to the increased acuteness of the Italo-Ethiopian situation, leading issues declining from 1 to 4 points on the New York Stock Exchange on a turnover of 2,189,000 shares, the largest volume of trading in about two weeks. Wheat and cotton reached the limits allowed for one day's trading but eased slightly at the close.

King Boris ascended the throne of Bulgaria on Oct. 3, 1918, when he was 24 years old. When the country turned Fascist in May, 1934, by a coup, the King approved of the new regime. He forestalled another attempted coup and a rebellion by military leaders on April 22 last by arresting them.

The efforts of the League of Nations to avert war in the Italo-Ethiopian crisis have constituted the League a new force in the affairs of nations, according to James T. Shotwell, Professor of History at Columbia University and president of the League of Nations Association.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 2. -- The Southern tribes are pouring their fighting power into the vast Ethiopian reserves along the northern border, and the citizens of Addis Ababa remain in a frenzy of expectancy, playing the game of hare and hounds to watch the troops depart.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Eight fishemen, who struggled in a tempestuous sea for more than three hours off here when their boat overturned, were saved this morning after several hundred men and women had stood helplessly in suspense for an hour watching a slow rescue boat beat against a strong wind to reach the men.

The Hamburg-American freighter Tirpitz, an 8,000-ton vessel carrying coke from Germany, struck the Brooklyn Bridge in the middle of the East River yesterday morning as she was passing northward to unload cargo in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 2. -- Clement C. Williams became the seventh president of Lehigh University today when he was inducted into office at the annual Founders' Day exercises in Packer Memorial Chapel.

HAROLD NICOLSON'S biography of "Dwight Morrow" (Harcourt, Brace, $3.75), has suavity and literary good manners. These attributes are sufficient to emphasize the personal charm of the subject, the undoubted graciousness of his family life, and the love of the amenities that was best expressed, perhaps, in Dwight Morrow's affection for the blessed Mexican town of Cuernavaca.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard Professor of Geology, became the first member of the Harvard faculty tonight to publicly declare that he would refuse to take the teacher's oath as required by a new State law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The amount involved in applications for the issuance of securities under the Securities Act of 1933 from Jan. 1 reached $2,265,610,119 today with the filing by the Virginia Electric and Power Company of Richmond for the registration of $37,500,000 of 4 per cent bonds.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- "Captains Courageous," a book on which a whole generation of American and British boys modeled their ideal of manhood, which is on the recommended reading list in Boston public schools, has been attacked as fomenting racial animosity.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Golf will welcome a new style of metropolitan champion this week. Sponsor of amateur and open tourneys since its inception in 1894, the Metropolitan Golf Association today conducted its first match-play handicap tourney and will bestow a brand-new title on some fortunate player by Friday.

The Teachers Union has resumed its activities "with vigor and enthusiasm" and with no fear of competition from the New York Teachers Guild, which was organized by the former officers of the union, Charles J. Hendley, acting president of the union, announced yesterday.

PANAMA CITY, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Nelson Rounsevell, publisher of The Panama American, was convicted tonight by a Federal jury in the Canal Zone District Court on a libel charge resulting from his criticism of conditions at Fort Clayton. It was announced sentence would be passed Friday.

TORONTO, Oct. 2 (Canadian Press). -- A team of Toronto professional golfers today defeated the British Ryder Cup team, 9 1/2 points to 5 1/2, in a one-day match at the Rosedale Golf Club. The home pros won all five Scotch foursomes in the morning and captured four of the ten singles in the afternoon, squaring one.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Following is the text of the statement issued by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today urging economic and political peace:

The Amoskeag Company, manufacturer of cottons and worsteds, reported yesterday for the year ended on June 30, 1935, a net income of $489,243 after interest, expenses, Federal taxes and other charges. This compares with a net income of $507,783 in the preceding fiscal year.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Connecticut was termed "the birthplace of American industry" by Governor Wilbur L. Cross tonight as he formally opened the Tercentenary Industrial Exposition.

ON BOARD S. S. SATURNIA, on route to East Africa, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Fifteen thousand Italian troops, with a royal prince at their head, were borne through the Suez Canal by six ships today -- on to the East African powder keg. It was one of the most impressive transport exhibitions in history.

Action against national manufacturer organizations in nine industries, which through member agreements are alleged to be "continuing to operate under unjustified, oppressive and unwarranted provisions of NRA codes," is being taken by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was revealed in a report submitted yesterday at a meeting of the board of the association, by Irving C. Fox, counsel.

New regulations to govern the examination of merchandise by manufacturers and wholesalers before shipment were approved yesterday at a meeting of the fair trade practice bureau of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board at its offices, 132 West Thirty-fifth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Dr. Ernest de Mary Brumback, 63 years old, a member of a prominent family in the Middle West, was found hanged in the cellar of his home at 11 Chase Avenue by his wife, Jeanne, on her return from New York this afternoon.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 2. -- The Ethiopian warrior does not at all know the danger he is running in a fight with a modern-equipped European army, states General Erik Virgin, former political and military adviser to Emperor Haile Selassie. The general left Addis Ababa yesterday owing to ill health.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The Friends of the New Germany in the United States is regarded by leaders of the National Socialist party in Germany as a "nuisance," Waldemar Troest, official spokesman for the party's foreign organization, said today. He expressed the hope that the "Friends would come to their senses" and cease embarrassing the German Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Although increased rates effective tomorrow in intercoastal trade may be shown to be unreasonable in some cases, they cannot offset the "indisputable fact" that the coastal carriers must have greater revenue to meet substantial increases in operating expenses, and the Department of Commerce will not order suspension of the tariff changes, Secretary Roper said in a formal statement today.

President ROOSEVELT has delegated to the Federal Trade Commission and the skeletonized NRA authority to supervise the setting-up of "voluntary codes." He retains power to approve such agreements under the joint resolution adopted by Congress after the Supreme Court had spoken in the Schechter case.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The new flag law was observed today by better than 99 per cent of those who put out flags in commemoration of the late President Paul von Hindenburg's eighty-eighth birthday and in honor of the reinterment ceremonies at the Tannenberg war memorial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Federal Power Commission announced today the filing of two applications for consolidations, or mergers, of electrical utility companies. One application was that of subsidiaries of the American Waterworks and Electric Corporation and the other was by the Florida Power Corporation and two of its subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Exports of arms, ammunition and airplanes to Italy have been negligible since the East African crisis became acute, and there have been none to Ethiopia, so far as information here goes, according to a report made public by the State Department today on information "from all sources."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 2. -- Martial law was declared this morning throughout Bulgaria following the discovery of a conspiracy by Colonel Damian Veltcheff and his friends of the Zveno group of alleged revolutionaries. The aim of the conspiracy is said to have been the overthrow of the Royalist regime and the substitution of a republic for King Boris.

Three former employes of the immigration and naturalization service of the Department of Labor who pleaded guilty to naturalization frauds were sentenced yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 2. -- The Ethiopian frontier has been invaded by Italian forces in the neighborhood of Assab, the Ethiopian Government announced today on the receipt of a telegram from the Jibuti Consul, Lij Anderge Masai.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 2. -- The real purpose of Japan's concentration of a dozen destroyers at Swatow and seven gunboats at Hankow is a show force to increase the continuous diplomatic pressure for China's formal recognition of the independence of Manchukuo, in the opinion of Chinese Government leaders.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- John Barrett, an American expert observer of international relations who has passed four months in Europe visiting the countries from Russia to Germany and Italy, and afterward attending the opening sessions of the League of Nations Council and Assembly, sailed for home on the liner Normandie today. In a statement just before sailing, Mr. Barrett wrote:
DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series follows:

The new planetarium at the Museum of Natural History was set going last night by a cosmic ray captured on an extremely delicate machine. The ray was stepped up by a series of amplifiers until it was powerful enough to start the glorified $150,000 magic lantern which runs the whole heavenly show.

Directors of the Maytag Company declared yesterday a dividend of $3.75 a share on the $3 cumulative preference stock, thus reducing the accumulations to $2.25 a share. On Aug. 1, the company paid $1.50 a share on the stock. The regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the $6 first preferred stock also was declared.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Out of the West has come a new characterization of the League of Nations. We know it now in all its nakedness as a "screen for the hypocrites who are trying to divide the territory of Europe." The revelation was made by Senator Borah to an audience of farmers packed in a schoolhouse in Idaho.
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Meat trade conditions and, wholesale prices in New York.
Under the broadest general buying movement in more than a year, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose $2 a bale or more yesterday and ended at net gains of 36 to 44 points.

Card index files seized last Sept. 8 in the apartment of Mrs. Mae Scheible by Federal agents who were looking for "Count" Victor Lustig, counterfeiter and confidence man, who had escaped a week earlier from the Federal House of Detention, are being held by the United States Attorney's office to embarrass certain Republican politicians, it was charged yesterday before Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy.

Tony Canzoneri brought his training to an end yesterday at his camp at Marlooro, N.Y., where he has been preparing for the defense of his lightweight title against Al Roth at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. At the same time he received the official approval of Bill Brown of the State Athletic Commission, who watched the title-holder go through five brisk rounds of boxing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Counsel for Thomas J. Mooney asked the Supreme Court today to consider his motion for release from prison and end the "travesty of the judicial hearings the Supreme Court of California is giving."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will begin its ninety-fourth season tonight at Carnegie Hall, with Otto Klemperer conducting. The opening program, which will be repeated tomorrow afternoon, Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon, will consist of Beethoven's "Egmont" overture, Shostakovich's symphony Op. 10; Brahms's Second serenade and Bach-Weiner's Toccata in C.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 2. -- From the No. 2 barbette of the cruiser Houston President Roosevelt today watched the largest tactical manoeuvres in the naval history of the United States, as every arm of the service demonstrated the part it would play in a modern battle.

The report from Detroit that Mike Jacobs, promoter for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, would soon take over the boxing privileges at Madison Square Garden and thus end a rivalry that has existed for several months, met with a denial yesterday from Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Garden.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 2. -- According to the forecast of car loadings by the executive committee of the Midwest Shippers Advisory Board, meeting here today, business in the Middle West in the fourth quarter of 1935 will be approximately 8.2 per cent better than in the corresponding period of 1934.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 2. -- Having decided upon an earlier start, the committee in charge of the world chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of this city, the challenger, announced today that the first game would start tomorrow evening at the Hotel Carlton.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Before Judge Arthur J. Turtle in Federal court today witnesses testified to an agreement between Archie M. Andrews of New York, J. Walter Drake, a stockholder of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, and Alex J. Groesbeck, representing the corporation, for the formation of a compromise board of directors late last April.

Steamship men in New York believe that substantial fare increases in transatlantic travel will result from the meeting, beginning in London today, of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference. Principals of the companies in the conference have placed a rate discussion among the major topics and the foreign lines are expected to insist on higher fares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A complaint charging the National Electrical Manufacturers Association of New York City and sixteen member manufacturers of power cable and wires with unlawful combination, conspiracy and agreement to restrain competition was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Approval by President Roosevelt of additional WPA allotments of $1,116,981 for New York City and $1,681,873 for New Jersey was announced today, with a list of approved projects from which the local administrators, Victor Ridder and William H.J. Ely, will select those to which the Federal funds may be applied.

Selection of Jan. 20 to 24, 1936, as the date of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was made yesterday by the board of the association at a meeting here. The convention, which will mark the twenty-fifth or silver Jubilee anniversary of the association, will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Additions to the government's civil executive branch during August brought the grand total of employes to 770,128 and the payroll total to $115,789,000, a new post-war peak and a record exceeded only during the height of the World War period, when the number in and out of Washington rose to about 900,000.

The first meeting of the incorporators of the American National Theatre and Academy, which received Federal sponsorship through the Wagner-McLaughlin bill, signed by President Roosevelt on July 5, was held yesterday afternoon in the office of John Hay Whitney at 14 Wall Street.

Students of Columbia College were urged yesterday by members of their student board, through a resolution .published in The Spectator, the college newspaper, to boycott the 1936 Olympic Games if they are held in Germany.

Despite the protest filed with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce by distributers in the Eastern territory, an increase in intercoastal shipping rates on canned and other food products will be put into effect today, according to information received from Washington yesterday by wholesalers here.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The Red Sox board of strategy, here for the world series, put an abrupt quietus tonight on the talk that Boston already has gone so far toward rebuilding for 1936 as to offer more than $300,000 for three or more stars of the Athletics, including Jimmie Foxx.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2. - The women of New York State in "rebellion" against New Deal high food prices, according to a letter written to Assemblywoman Jane Todd by Mrs. Robert L. Bacon, vice chairman of the New York Republican State Committee, and made public here today at the annual convention of the Westchester Republican County Committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- When all the names of candidates for township supervisors had been filed today with the county election bureau here, it was found that the Mead family of the rural township of Lewisboro had two members aspiring to be the town's next supervisor.

In his address yesterday at San Diego, the last of his speeches on his present tour, the President made the fullest statement and defense of the New Deal policies which he has as yet offered. He covered nearly all of them, though several got only a passing reference.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Jumping to the front in the feature race at Hawthorne today, Miss Diavolo, racing for the Valdina Farm of Texas, made every post a winning one in the six-furlong dash.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 2. -- Lavish in their predictions of improved railroad business, shipping authorities assembled here today for the annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board. The opening session of the two-day meeting, closed to the public and dealing entirely with voluminous committee reports, attracted more than 500 shippers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Permission for an extension for four years of a $31,610,400 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has been asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. The extension would be from Nov. 21, 1935, to Aug. 1, 1939, if granted.

The possibility that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation may call a $15,511,587 loan extended to the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad as a result of the company's default on a debt payment on Tuesday was indicated in correspondence between the company and the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia broke ground yesterday at 4:15 P. M. for the $5,500,000 buildings of Brooklyn College on the Wood-Harmon site in Flatbush, between Nostrand and Ocean Avenues, near Avenue H.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Churches of all creeds were called upon tonight by Secretary of State Cordell Hull to engage in "a flaming crusade" against all evil and dangerous conditions, of which, he said, the worst at present was the menace of war.

Two new galleries announce their intention of opening in the near future. One of these, to be known as The Guild Art Gallery, has taken quarters at 37 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will be directed by Anna Walinska and Margaret Lefranc. Painting and sculpture by contemporary American artists will be shown.
BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The Boerse continued today to drop steadily, with the same evidence of public indifference toward the market dominating the floor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Smaller receipts of hogs here today due to the holding back of supplies by farmers resulted in sellers being able to halt the declining tendency in the market, but the demand was not aggressive. Prices ranged from steady to as much as 25 cents a hundredweight higher with lard types showing the most strength, while new crop light weights rallied least.

To offset the depredations of juvenile marksmen whose sling shots, air rifles, bows and arrows and "generally devilish intentions" have caused a rapid decline in wild life in the woods of upper New York City, a drive for the creation of a sanctuary for birds and wild flowers on a nine-acre wooded tract in the New York Botanical Garden was launched yesterday.

Gathering figs from thistles, Mayor LA GUARDIA has managed to balance the city budget for 1936. It hardly seemed possible. Departmental requests were $11,000,000 in excess of the constitutional limit, $29,000,000 above this year's total of appropriations and $38,000,000 over the limit imposed by the Bankers' Agreement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Oct. 1 is moving day in our city. Beds and chairs and boxes of china will be seen piled high on sidewalks and stairways. For most of us it will mean a lot of trouble, but Billy K. hopes it will mean good fortune for him.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- By the overwhelming majority of more than 21 to 1 the Labor party conference of Brighton went on record today in favor of sanctions by the League of Nations against Italy or any other aggressor nation.

The intensified threat of war abroad pressed upon the foreign exchange market yesterday, and declining rates continued to register the flight of capital to this country. The pound sterling fell to a new low of $4.89 3/4 on the movement and closed at $4.89 7/8, off 5/8 cent, while the franc dropped to 6.58 3/4 cents and closed at 6.59 cents, off 1/8 point.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 2. -- Nearly 250,000 Ethiopian fighters were reported on the march tonight, some toward the Italian colonial frontier, in anticipation of a general mobilization tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A tenant no longer, the Supreme Court moves into its magnificent marble home Monday for a term which may be epoch-making in political and social consequences. Its decisions will be read in a setting as modern as some of the laws it may pass upon.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange seemed to be in no mood today to follow the cheerful review of Great Britain's industrial position given yesterday by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, the dominating influence being again the international outlook.

Pig iron production in September, according to The Iron Age, totaled 1,772,856 gross tons, as compared with 1,761,286 tons in August. Output per day, at 59,09e5 tons, represented a gain of 4 per cent over the August daily rate of 56,816 tons. Furnaces in blast Oct. 1 numbered 103, against 99 on Sept. 1, a net gain of four.

The monetary gold stocks of this country will have increased about $2,500,000,000 since the end of January, 1934, when gold now on the way to the United States has been received, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its October review of credit and business conditions, published yesterday.

Inability of the bond market to absorb yesterday's heavy selling resulted in substantial declines in all sections. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange expanded $14,664,000 the heaviest turnover in more than two weeks, compared with $10,375,900 on Tuesday.

Steamship men and shippers here are worried about the mounting war-risk insurance applicable to cargo routed through the Red Sea and the Mediterranean as a result of the trouble between Italy and Ethiopia. Five important lines have already announced rerouting of their vessels away from the Suez Canal.

The Treasurer of the city of Springfield, Mass., announced yesterday that on Sept. 27 the city sold a new issue of $800,000 of short-term notes to a broker here on an interest basis of .365 per cent. The issue consists of $200,000 notes that will mature on Nov. 19, 1935; $300,000 on April 16, 1936, and $300,000 on June 17, 1936.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The State Department made plain tonight that delegations from Japan, China and other foreign countries would not be officially invited to represent their governments at the Philippine Commonwealth inauguration ceremonies at Manila Nov. 15.
Money market remained dull. Replacements made up the bulk of the day's turnover, little new money being engaged. Quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

SCOTCH PLAINS, Oct. 2. -- While a crowd of 500 filled St. Stanislaus's Roman Catholic Church in Plainfield and an equal number gathered in the streets in front of the edifice a high mass of requiem was offered this morning for Mrs. Sophie Crempa, who was slain during the arrest of her husband, John, by Sheriff's deputies here last Thursday.

Among the many prominent passengers returning from Europe today on the liner Bremen are Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, with Mrs. Welles; Walter Huston, actor, and Nan Sunderland, his wife; and Mrs. Edward W. Bok, founder of the Curtis Institute of Music.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Appointment of General Craig as chief of staff came as a surprise, not because of the selection but because it was made at this time.

Officials of the Aquarium were doubly puzzled yesterday as the result of an unsolicited and undesired gift of a rare lizard from an anxious Staten Island resident, who seemed considerably worried about the bizarre behavior of the reptile.

A cosmic ray from interstellar space lighted the stars last night at the official opening of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History and presented before 800 enthralled New Yorkers a new vision of the universe they live in.

Price advances on a variety of textile products, including sheetings and sheets, candlewick bedspreads and woolen and worsteds, featured a session of brisk activity in the merchandise markets yesterday. At the same time, the sharp advances in cotton, together with the heavy buying of gray goods, presaged further increases, selling agents said.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- New high levels for the season on all deliveries of wheat were established in North American markets today as the result of a wave of speculative buying and short covering which swept prices up 5 cents a bushel on this side of the international line, the maximum permitted for one day under Board of Trade regulations, while Winnipeg gained 3 cents, the limit in the Canadian market.

The trend of operations in the steel industry has turned upward again and ingot production has risen one point to 52 1/2 per cent of capacity, following a recession of one-half point to 51 1/2 per cent last week, Iron Age reported yesterday.

Sugar, cottonseed oil, raw silk and copper futures advanced yesterday in the trading in commodities here. Coffee, cocoa and crude rubber futures were lower. All of the grains, raw sugar, dairy products, cotton and hides moved forward in the cash markets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be hoped that Governor Lehman's war on crime may not degenerate into a war on the rank and file of the citizens, as it will certainly do if the conference in Albany looks with any favor on the suggestion of compulsory and universal fingerprinting made by Mr. Mulrooney.

Women attending the fourteenth annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor will turn their attention today from exhibits of women's work and contests in preparation of American dishes to the question of developing the American merchant marine. Chester H. McCall, special assistant to Secretary of Commerce Roper, will speak on the subject at a forum under the auspices of representatives of women's civic and patriotic societies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- General taxation, perhaps increased income taxes or even a general sales tax to finance farm benefit payments if the Supreme Court rejects the Agricultural Adjustment Act, loomed up as a strong possibility today in the opinion of administration officials.

The position of guaranteed mortgage certificate holders has been "improved tremendously" through the operation of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York, with the value of securities increasing by "many millions of dollars," Louis S. Posner, a member of the commission, told the Kiwanis Club yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin.

McKINNEY, Texas, Oct. 2. -- "Uncle Gus" Wilson, a farmer who amassed $800,000 during ninety-one years and gave it all away, was buried today in a remnant of his once vast land holdings, the family burial plot.

Present trade with Italy should be conducted only on a letter of credit basis, exporters held yesterday at the initial Fall round-table discussion sponsored at the Hotel Pennsylvania by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- A movement for universal fingerprinting as an important weapon against crime gained strength today at Governor Lehman's conference on crime, and drew support from Mr. Lehman, who expressed certainty that some extension of the present identification system would be recommended to the next Legislature and approved.

OTTAWA, Oct. 2. -- CanadianAmerican tariff relations, the issue on which the last Canadian general election, in 1930, that of 1911, and' many earlier elections turned, are playing an increasing part in the present election campaign. This year the issue is not over a reciprocal trade treaty with the United States, but merely over the question which party would stand a better chance of achieving such a treaty.
The text of the translation of Premier Mussolini's address yesterday, broadcast by networks of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company, follows:

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 2. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York told the 2,400 members of the National Conference of Catholic Charities tonight that the government never would be able to carry the relief and welfare load unaided by church and private agencies, and declared that so far as the Federal Government's Social Security Act was concerned the need for charity will never end.

A dispute before Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday between rival Tammany factions in the Ninth Assembly District caused the court to remark that he held the political conviction "Let the man who won win." Justice Collins said he adhered to the school of politics believing in honest elections and in "opening up everything" in question under dispute.

DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- The Tigers, champions of the American League the last two years and encircled by the largest crowd ever to witness a ball game in this city, felt certain today their hour had arrived. They were launching the 1935 world series, they had the mighty Schoolboy Rowe on the pitching mound, and a gathering of 48,000 was on hand to see the towering Arkansan come into his own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A plea for resumption of legislative responsibility by Congress, together with a vigorous attack upon the present "pliant and servile" Democratic majority was made in a radio speech tonight by Representative Chester C. Bolton of Ohio, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to obtain much information bearing on the report that it must make to Congress in January on unlisted trading in securities when arguments are made on Monday at a hearing upon the application of the Maryland Casualty Company to have its common stock stricken from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

The publication yesterday of the statement of condition of the Bankers Trust Company as of Sept. 30 disclosed that the country has a new $1,000,000,000 bank. Deposits and resources of the Bankers Trust rose to new records in the last quarter year and resources crossed the level of $1,000,000,000 for the first time in the history of the institution.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2. -- Baths for Eskimos in the Soviet Arctic, modern houses to replace igloos, and mechanized bakeries are basic needs if fur-trading posts are to be developed, said Professor Otto Schmidt, chief of the Great Northern Sea Route Administration, on his return to Leningrad by airplane and icebreaker from an inspection trip over a network of polar stations.
LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The first volume of Duff Cooper's official biography of Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig, to be published tomorrow, is disappointing, according to the military experts.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Dr. J. Duncan Spaeth of Princeton University has been chosen the first president of the University of Kansas City.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2. -- Moscow residents tore up their food ration cards yesterday and went out on a mass-buying spree to celebrate the Kremlin's decree cutting food prices 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The "Brooklyn radio fight" ended today when the Federal Communications Commission granted the applications of five stations and denied applications of five others. The order will become effective Nov. 15 at 3 A.M.

The Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History is the twenty-second of its kind in the world and the fourth in the United States. Chicago had the first with the Adler Planetarium. Philadelphia came next and Los Angeles was third.

Ripe corn-tops waved in the Bronx wind yesterday afternoon in the borough's only harvest festival of the year at the Crotona Park Children's Playground, St. Paul's Place and Fulton Street. All of the corn had tasseled out and some of it had actually eared, exposed though it was to the whir of passing motors and the not-far-distant thunder of the third Avenue "L."

The National Sugar Exporting Corporation is inviting tenders for the sale of Republic of Cuba Sugar Stabilization sinking fund 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Dec. 1, 1940, at a price not exceeding par, in an amount sufficient to exhaust $500,000. Tenders will be received until Oct. 9 by the Chase National Bank, here or at its Havana office.

Columbia and City College waged a lengthy scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field as their final heavy workouts in preparation for contests on Saturday. The Lions went through their drill with their opening encounter with Virginia Military Institute in mind, while the Beavers brushed up on offensive manoeuvres for their game with St. Francis.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP). -- New efforts of Germany to patch up her strained relations with the Vienna government and wean Austria from Fascist support were discernible here today. Colonel Franz von Papen, sent to Vienna as minister to evolve some scheme for bringing the two Germanic countries together, is playing the leading role in this new development.
BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

So much emphasis has been laid, and rightly, on the world's unprecedented accumulation of unsold wheat as a cause for the fall in its price after 1929 that an authoritative statement to the effect that the unbalanced position has at last been corrected is particularly interesting.

The Royal London Yacht Club's challenge for the America's Cup on behalf of its commodore, Charles R. Fairey, will be taken up officially this afternoon by the New York Yacht Club. The challenge will be laid before the club members at a meeting.

Two youthful Negroes who devised a shakedown racket on the war attitude of Italy toward Ethiopia were committed yesterday to indefinite City Reformatory terms by Judge Otto A. Rosalsky in General Sessions. The youths coerced an Italian ice peddler in Harlem to pay tribute to them or be forced out of business.

One of the oldest stakes in America's racing history went to one of the youngest owners on the turf yesterday at Belmont when the sixty-sixth running of the Jerome Handicap, which stretches back to post Civil War days, fell to the speed of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Harvest, a 25-to-1 shot.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 2. -- The text of the address delivered here today by President Roosevelt was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A plea for economic and political peace was made to the world today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a statement that was issued on what was generally believed to be the eve of war in East Africa.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Military, naval and marine guard, as extensive as any ever provided for a Chief Executive, marked President Roosevelt's progress today through San Diego.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- With the possible exception of one change at the right end, Coach Harvey Harman has selected his Pennsylvania varsity line-up to face Princeton in the opening game at Tigertown on Saturday.

Shares of the New York Central Railroad dropped nearly 3 points yesterday, following the making public by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, of correspondence between the RFC and the railway's management disclosing a difference of opinion as to the treatment of its $90,000,000 floating debt.

DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- The world series fever gripped the hub of the auto industry today. The greatest crowd ever to flow into Navin Field saw the Tigers and Cubs open the post-season struggle for baseball supremacy.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard today changed his mind about withholding his first team from scrimmage, and worked his varsity for more than half an hour against the scrubs.

Mayor La Guardia's executive tax levy budget for 1936 aggregating $545,356,833.11 was presented to the Board of Estimate in City Hall at 6 o'clock last night, with a statement showing that the city's estimated income next year exceeds the budget by $203,944.43.
DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- The victory of the Cubs today in the first game made them betting favorites to win the world series but did not dislodge the Tigers as favorites in tomorrow's game.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Determined to get his squad in fighting trim for the Penn game Saturday, Coach Fritz Crisler drove the Princeton football team through a hard session on University Field today. Another strenuous drill is planned for tomorrow, following which Crisler will ease up on the workouts during the rest of the week.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31 operating revenues of $76,109,212, compared with $72,191,709 in the preceding twelve months. Net income after taxes was $33,901,468, against $33,277,043, while the net profit after interest, property retirement and depletion reserves and preferred dividends, whether earned or unearned, was $1,899,700, against $1,596,370.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 2 (AP). -- A new story of a crippled white man living with the medicine man of a Dutch Guiana Indian tribe was linked tonight With the fate of Paul Redfern, united States flier who disappeared on a South African flight eight years ago.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Tentative approval has been obtained from Department of Interior officials for a WPA project to make a descriptive inventory of all public and private records and historical sites, buildings and monuments in the State at an estimated cost of $500,000.

More than 21,000 men and women crowded into Madison Square Garden last night to witness the "Night of Stars" program presented for the benefit of Jewish refugees from Germany. The proceeds totaled $45,000, which will be applied to the $3,250,000 fund sought by the United Jewish Appeal for the Settlement of Jews in Palestine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Two rival groups of building trades unions, each calling itself the "legitimate" building trades department of the American Federation of Labor, met in separate conventions at the Hotel Ambassador today and found themselves in agreement only on one objective -- the need for an extensive low-cost home building program.
DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- "Give the boys the credit, not me; they backed me up in great style."

Onrushing war clouds, intensified by Premier Mussolini's message to the Italian people yesterday, gave the stock market its most bearish news in many months and caused the widest break in the general list since July 26, 1934. Under a wave of liquidation many of the leading issues suffered declines of 1 to 4 points.

The acquisition by Gabriel Wells, New York bookseller, of an unpublished account of the Arab revolt, written by Lawrence of Arabia in January, 1919, is reported by The London Times. The account is written on twelve pages entirely in Lawrence's handwriting, and each page is signed.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, announced yesterday that he would appear this afternoon before the Board of Elections and present a detailed plan whereby the $101,000 cost of advertising the list of polling places for registration this year could be cut in half.

Details of the plan for reorganizing the Mortgage-Bond Company of New York, approved on Tuesday by Supreme Court Justice Valente, were announced yesterday by a committee of bondholders. The plan provides that the entire assets and business are to be held for the benefit of the bondholders who will receive all the bonds of a new company, the Mortbon Corporation of New York, and 60 per cent of its stock.

CALGARY, Alta., Oct. 2. -- Canada's EPIC -- End Poverty in Canada -- which swept the Social Credit League into power in Alberta Aug. 22 on a promise of a dividend of $25 a month to every adult, is now the disturbance centre of the Dominion general elections on Oct. 14.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, accompanied by his wife, left last night for the third Lutheran World Convention which will be held in Paris, France, Oct. 13-20. They were passengers on the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line.

Radical changes in the laws relating to the taking of game fish from the waters of Westchester and Putnam Counties were advocated at the first Autumn meeting of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association in White Plains on Tuesday evening.

" Squaring the Circle," the U.S.S.R.'s bow to comedy, achieves its first professional American production tonight at the Lyceum. It has been a long time coming to Broadway, having paused to play some thousands of performances in its own country and a good many in certain out-of-the-way spots in the United States.
The city rounded out the first twenty-four hours of its anti-noise campaign at 11 o'clock last night and officials declared the drive was progressing splendidly.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 2. -- A policy of keeping the United States "unentangled and free" was enunciated today by President Roosevelt in his first public utterance recognizing the gravity of the threat of war abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Showing the largest deficit in peace-time history for the first quarter of the fiscal year, the Treasury Department today made public a statement of the government's financial position on Sept. 30.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Norman Church's Riskulus, which found the pace too swift in the Havre De Grace Handicap and finished far back, today turned in one of his good races as he scored a driving victory in the Cumberland Handicap at the opening of Laurel's thirty-day meeting.
ROME, Oct. 2. -- Premier Benito Mussolini threw down the gauntlet to the world this evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The navy kept a watchful eye on Europe tonight after advancing America's naval expansion program another notch through receipt of a bid for the construction of a new light cruiser.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Parents who are not willing to have their children "enter the world of ideas" were advised tonight by Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, to "keep them at home."

PARIS, Oct. 2 (AP). -- A British assurance to France that Adolf Hitler will keep the peace was coupled tonight, French officials said, with Italy's promise that economic and financial sanctions will not mean war in Europe.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 2. -- In the days when he was the quarterback of the Four Horsemen, Harry Stuhldreher was the apple of Knute Rockne's appraising eye. If the late master of Notre Dame football could be present on the Villanova practice field his approbation would be no less wholehearted for the manner in which the brainy 1924 field general has carried out his precepts as a coach.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- While Italy was going through its spectacular mobilization of millions, and the Ethiopian Emperor was proclaiming an advance of Italian forces beyond an undemarcated frontier of Eritrea into a "No Man's Land" he has created by the withdrawal of his troops, the British Cabinet met today and listened to a report from Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, regarding the League Council's intentions.

Yesterday's selling of stocks could be ascribed plainly to the market's apprehension that a war in Europe would bring about a liquidation of foreign-owned securities comparable to what happened in 1914 when the force of selling was such as to compel the New York Stock Exchange to close.

The new film opening today at the Radio City Music Hall is "The Return of Peter Grimm." an RKO Radio screen version of the late David Belasco's stage production. Lionel Barrymore, Helen Mack and Allen Vincent head the cast.
MALDEN, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Four Roosevelts were concerned with civil suits filed today in Malden District Court.

John W. Davis, Democratic nominee for President in 1924, compared the social security program of the Roosevelt administration to the slavery of the Negroes in the South before the Civil War in an address yesterday at Founder's Day exercises of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, in the Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn.
SOFIA, Oct. 2. -- Conspirators in the revolt that the government claimed today it had nipped, planned to assassinate King Boris, it was learned upon good authority.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship tournament opened at the Westchester Country Club today. Headed by Mrs. Ronald H. Barlow of Philadelphia, the president and founder of the organization, seventy-seven players teed off in the twelfth title event.

A concerted drive by the WPA in this city to have 220,000 unemployed at work by Oct. 15 was begun yesterday on orders from General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator, who was preparing to return from San Diego to New York to direct completion of the placement program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- In a plea for "real" neutrality and universal peace, Bernard M. Baruch told the Army Ordnance Association tonight that "today, twenty-one years after the outburst of the volcano that shook the world, we see humanity in arms and embattled."

ROME, Oct. 2. -- The hour toward which fascism has been marching for thirteen years struck today. Premier Mussolini's regime is to be tested by war. Il Duce did not make a direct declaration of war in the speech that he assembled the whole nation to hear, but when the bells and sirens rent the air at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon the whole population understood that this was the reveille of Fascist Italy.

Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat of Oklahoma, declared here yesterday, on his way to a silver conference in Salt Lake City, that arrangements had been made with Congressional leaders to bring up the payment of the soldiers' bonus for a vote once more on Jan. 13 in the House and Jan. 15 in the Senate, and that he had no doubt a bill authorizing the immediate payment of $2,500,000,000 would be passed.

A majority of the members of the crew of the Holland-America liner Rotterdam were safe ashore in Kingston, Jamaica, yesterday, while Captain Johan Van Dulken, master, and a skeleton crew of eighty-six men remained aboard the old coal-burner, still stranded on a Morant Cays reef in the Caribbean.

The total of estimates for city and county government submitted to the Budget Director was $582,294,543.04, or $28,861,943.14 above the total of the 1935 budget. I have reduced these estimates by $36,937,709.93. They cannot be reduced further unless we ignore legal mandates or are willing to slash the allowances for departments over which we have control to the extent of crippling essential public services.

Real estate organizations continued yesterday their protests against the tentative assessment roll of $15,952,747,571 for 1936, announced by the Board of Taxes and Assessments, protesting that the total was too high and urging the city to take steps to ease the tax burden on real property.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Although he had won two of his previous three starts, Mrs. G.W. Ogle's chestnut Infidox, a 2-year-old colt, registered an upset victory today in the $7,500 added Constitution Handicap, the six-furlong feature of the Suffolk Downs Fall meeting inaugural.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP). -- A blunt notice that "I'm going to do all I can to avoid enforcing the Potato Control Bill" came from Secretary Wallace today, as growers gathered in the capital to consider a substitute for the statutory tax curb on potato production.

GENEVA, Oct. 2, -- A telegram declaring Italian troops had violated the Ethiopian frontier near French Somaliland to prepare a base there was received from Emperor Haile Selassie by Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, this afternoon.

DELHI, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, told Delaware Countians today that the Republicans would seek to cure the farmers' ills by solving distribution and marketing problems "when we regain control of the Assembly this Fall."

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- A pledge to formulate a broad program of action embracing the many proposals for waging war on the criminal, the racketeer and the shyster lawyer as advanced by almost 1,000 experts was given today by Governor Lehman as his four-day conference on the crime problem ended its work.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A display of football initiative in a minor game perhaps "saved" General Malin D. Craig for the army.

So much of good intention and achievement in municipal, judicial and other reform has come from Cleveland that Tuesday's primary there was watched with interest by students of urban good government. The primary was a nonpartisan affair. Two candidates for Mayor were to be nominated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- More than $3,000,000,000 has been repaid to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by banks, railroads, mortgage loan companies and other borrowers, according to the corporation's monthly report for September, made public today.

The Board of Elections, with President S. Howard Cohen dissenting, approved yesterday a plan advanced by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard for the printing of lists of registration polling places in a condensed form. This procedure, Mr. Blanshard estimated, will reduce the cost of printing by about $45,000 or nearly half the $101,000 appropriated for the advertising.
In the President's address at San Diego he had a striking passage about the American flag as a symbol, not only of national independence but of religious freedom. He proceeded to remark:

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $678,566,202 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Oct. 1 was $30.97, compared with $30.44 at the beginning of September.

GENEVA, Oct. 3. -- The League of Nations Council today was called to meet publicly Saturday morning to take up, it is semi-officially explained, the crucial question of judging whether Premier Mussolini has outlawed Italy by attacking Ethiopia in violation of the covenant.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- The constitutionality of the new Utilities Holding Company Act was attacked before Judge William C. Coleman in Federal District Court today in a brief filed by John W. Davis, counsel for an intervening plaintiff in the American States Public Utility Company's suit to escape operation of the statute.

HONOLULU, Oct. 3. -- Promising full and open-minded consideration of what to Hawaii is the all important subject of Statehood, the United States Congressional party which will conduct hearings into that matter throughout the Territory during the next two weeks, arrived from San Francisco today to be greeted by thousands of the city's residents.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 3. -- The outspoken declarations by Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of Japan's North China forces, and Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japanese military attache at Peiping, favoring the immediate independence of the five North China provinces are bound to create an unusual situation for the embassies and legations still maintained at Peiping.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 3. -- Emperor Haile Selassie proclaimed a general mobilization today from the balcony of his palace following a night of prayer in the shadows of the flickering candles of the little imperial chapel. The proclamation set his empire afire with patriotism.

Retail package deliveries increased 20 per cent for the week ended Sept. 28 over the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is the same as that for the previous week. For the four weeks ended Sept. 28 the delivery company noted a rise of 19 per cent, an increase of 3 per cent over the figure reported for the preceding four weeks period.

The National Cash Register Company reported yesterday that its domestic orders for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $14,107,825, or 14.3 per cent more than the $12,339,075 reported for the first nine months of 1934. Domestic orders in September, this year, gained 26.6 per cent over the same month of last year, amounting to $1,371,750, against $1,083,775.

The Rev. Dr. John A. Morehead, president of the Lutheran World Convention, the Rev. Dr. Samuel W. Trexler, former president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, and the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council, will head a group sailing tonight for the Lutheran convention to be held in Paris from Oct. 13 to 20.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Warsaw correspondent of the Manchester Guardian has sent to his newspaper a sensational story of the beating to death by Nazis of a Jewish soccer player at Ratibor, German Upper Silesia.

PARIS, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The correspondent of the Temps at Asmara, Eritrea, reported today that the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Italian Bombing Squadrons had opened hostilities in Ethiopia at 6 A.M. today (10 P.M. Wednesday, Eastern standard time).

Max Reinhardt, German stage director, arrived here yesterday on the Conte di Savoia to see the opening of his screen production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" next Wednesday night at the Hollywood and to start work on the stage production of Franz Werfel's "The Road of Promise" at the Manhattan Opera House, scheduled for the middle of December.

William B. Barry, Assistant United States Attorney, was nominated as the Democratic candidate to succeed Representative William F. Brunner in the Second Congressional District of Queens at a meeting last night of members of the party's county committee at the Jamaica High School, 168th Street and Gothic Drive, Jamaica.

If proof were needed of the reality of the Soviet world, nothing could be much more concrete than "Squaring the Circle," which was played at the Lyceum last evening. This is the Valentine Katayev farce which has been convulsing Russians with its horseplay derived from the Soviet dialectic and which has acquired a considerable word-of-mouth reputation in America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Corrington Gill, chief-of-staff of the New Deal Work Relief program, disclosed today that virtually all funds have been allotted for the drive designed to provide jobs for 3,500,000 needy and their families after Nov. 1.

Mr. BIRCHALL, writing from London the other day, said that European statesmen see in the new Germany that ADOLPH HITLER is building "a force stronger and better equipped than anything the last Kaiser ever dreamed of." If the "new" Germany here means the Greater Germany of HITLER'S dreams, then it is obvious that the European statesmen see the future correctly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The New York Central Railroad "has had too much banker domination and still has," Jesse H. Jones, Chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, asserted today as he defended the $90,000,000 refunding program that he has proposed for the road.
MADRID, Oct. 3. -Premier Joaquin Chapaprieta denied today a rumor that Spain was trying to obtain a loan from the United States Government following the collapse of trade negotiations with France.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The Crempa farmhouse in Terrill Road here, scene of a raid by a group of Sheriff's deputies last Thursday during which Mrs. Sophie Crempa was fatally shot and her husband, John, wounded, was closed today.
Some of the plans for spending the $27,000,000 allocated to the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration were outlined here yesterday by Holger Cahill, director of the project.
Frank J. Taylor, City Controller, said yesterday that he was preparing a critical analysis of Mayor La Guardia's executive tax levy budget for 1936 and expected to complete it on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Philadelphia stepped into the middle of the heavyweight fight picture today with a determined bid to have the proposed Joe Louis-Max Schmeling bout brought here next June.

The International Products Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $3 on account of accumulations of the i per cent preferred stock. This is the first distribution since July 15, 1931, when a similar amount was paid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,480,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $20,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Increased taxes imposed by the last session of Congress have made impractical the pending reorganization plans for the Missouri Pacific and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroads, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Mrs. Leila C. Dubois of Darien, Conn., and the Wee Burn Country Club, today won the senior women's national golf title at the Westchester Country Club by adding an 86 to a similar round yesterday for a total of 172 to lead Mrs. John H. Lapham of Woodway by a one-stroke margin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A new low death rate of 3.4 per cent from typhoid and paratyphoid fever in 1934 was reported today by the Census Bureau. Coincidentally, sharp increases in violent accidental deaths and of deaths due to measles and whooping cough were reported.

The appointment of Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, as chairman of a committee to draft a program of "unified action" on the part of various peace organizations in the United States to foster international understanding was announced yesterday following a meeting of members of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Here is the status of the Administration's Work Relief program and the way the funds have been allocated to date:

MONTREAL, Oct. 3. -- Almost all comparable indices showy that Canada has made more progress toward recovery than the United States, according to the October monthly letter of the Royal Bank of Canada. Statistics are shown for the first half of the year of 1935 in relation to the corresponding period of 1926, and the results throughout are almost uniformly favorable to Canada.

A special prayer composed by nine leading rabbis of Europe will be read in synagogues throughout Europe on Yon Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, which begins at sundown Sunday, according to an announcement yesterday by the newly enlarged news service of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, which has headquarters at 289 Fourth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3. -- As a prelude to the next Presidential campaign, Young Republicans of eleven Western States will open their "Spirit of '36" convention in Oakland tomorrow and continue their deliberations three days.

New York City's world's fair in 1939 must be the largest, the most impressive and the finest ever held anywhere if it is to be a success, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in an address before the State Chamber of Commerce at its hall, 65 Liberty Street.

Right on the heels of the President's optimistic statement regarding Federal finances, the Treasury has come forward with a report showing the largest deficit in peacetime history for the first quarter of a fiscal year. The excess of expenditures over income for the three months ending on Sept. 30 amounts to $832,000,000 -- an increase of $290,000,000 by comparison with the corresponding period last year.
Trading in the commodity futures broadened yesterday and practically all staples advanced. In the cash markets wheat, corn and cotton declined.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Two notable trophies were contested during the first day of the thirty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show, which opened this morning on the spacious show grounds of the Piping Rock Club and will continue through Saturday afternoon.

Fort Tryon Park, sixty acres of terraces, cliffs and wooded slopes at the northern end of Washington Heights, will be formally opened by the Park Department Oct. 12 at ceremonies in which Mayor La Guardia, General Hugh S. Johnson, Victor Ridder and John D. Rockefeller Jr. have been invited to participate.

Women's organizations were enlisted yesterday by Chester H. McCall, special assistant to Secretary Roper, in a campaign to lift the American merchant marine out of its perilous condition. Mr. McCall addressed a forum at the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at the Hotel Astor.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 3 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Government's deposits with the Bank of Canada declined $9,772,082 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement issued today. At the same time notes in circulation increased by $2,842,395.

As a protest against "the spiritual intolerance and suppression of free thought which the present German Government not only condones but openly boasts of," the American National Society of Mural Painters announced that at a meeting last week it had adopted a resolution that no member of the society would take any part in the exhibition of paintings to be held in connection with the Olympic Games to be held in Germany in 1936.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

A restless soldier's random shot at a bird may have been the cause of the war in Ethiopia, in the opinion of Dr. Pitman Benjamin Potter, a member of the international committee of four that adjudicated the Ualual incident on the Ethiopian border.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Old Westbury, with Mike Phipps roving throughout the team's line-up, made the most of a two-goal handicap to turn back Great Island and reach the final of the sixteen-goal division of the Autumn Plates polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Ethiopian Armies in the Field, via Harrar, Oct. 3. -- As war flares in the northern provinces, no one in this armed nerve centre of Ethiopian strategy cares to predict anything as to the nature of the conflict between Ethiopia and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A study of the extent and characteristics of company unions, made public today by the Bureau of Labor statistics of the Department of Labor, disclosed that only a small proportion of employes in plants where company unions exist are permitted to carry on these organizations as if they were independent entities.

AFTER looking at the record of the Roosevelt administration, James P. Warburg has written a little book called "Hell Bent for Election" (Doubleday, Doran, 50 cents). Although he doesn't put it in so many words, Mr. Warburg -- who was once one of Franklin D. Roosevelt's corps of economic advisers -- agrees with Albert Jay Nock that the new Democratic party, led by Jim Farley, is trying to effect a "coup d'etat by purchase."

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 3. -- Emperor Haile Selassie promised the "conquered lands" of Eritrea and Italian Somaliland to a crowd of wildly cheering warriors as a reward for Ethiopian victory in the struggle with Italy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Details of the temporary agreement which has been under negotiation between Japan and the United States for limiting Japanese cotton textile exports to the Philippine Islands have virtually been completed, and when two or three technical points have been adjusted the arrangement will be announced, probably next week.

EN ROUTE W1TH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT ON PACIFIC, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The cruiser Houston dropped anchor today at 1 P.M. (Pacific standard time) at the southeast tip of Cerros Island, off the jutting point of Lower California, to give President Roosevelt an afternoon of Pacific Ocean fishing.

PROVING GROUNDS, ABERDEEN, Md., Oct. 3. -- A huge gun which shoots thirty miles in seacoast defense, new mortars which will send poison gas or a smoke screen across a battlefield, barking 75's which scatter shrapnel over enemy lines, and airplanes dropping 1,100-pound bombs were among the exhibits displayed here today for more than 9,000 members of the Army Ordnance Association, Acting Secretary Woodring and representatives of foreign embassies and legations in Washington.

A surprise was sprung on the Fordham football squad yesterday at Fordham Field when the second scrimmage in two days was ordered by Coach Jim Crowley. The varsity opposed the Maroon freshman eleven for about forty-five minutes.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Attorneys General, State police chiefs and experts on criminal law from forty States have been invited to attend a national crime conference here Oct. 11 and 12, the New Jersey State Commission on Interstate Cooperation announced today.

Denouncing the attacks on the economic stability of Italy in press dispatches from European centres, Romolo Angelone, Commercial Attache of the Italian Embassy, in a statement issued here yesterday said that Italy was as sound economically as any time in her history.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- British authorities in India, this correspondent learns on sufficient authority tonight, were warned today to issue notices calling up certain classes of military reservists in India. The reason for this unexpected move is that the British Government now contemplates the possibility of having to provide a large body of troops in British Somaliland in case of emergency.

ROME, Oct. 3. -- It was officially admitted here tonight that Italian airplanes had dropped bombs today on Adowa, the Ethiopian town where the Italians suffered a crushing defeat at the hands of the African tribesmen in 1896.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 3. -- Count Luigi Vinci-Gigliucci, Italian Minister to Ethiopia, was startled by the suddenness of the Italian advance. The Minister was walking in the legation garden here shortly before noon today when Commandant Dothee of the Belgian mission went to him with news that Italian planes had bombed Adowa.

In your issue of Sept. 17 Mrs. Robert Law Bacon, wife of Representative Bacon, attacked prominent New Dealers because of their alleged support for the American Civil Liberties Union, which she implied was communistic. The implication is untrue.

Creation of a united textile industry export committee, composed of executives in all divisions, to coordinate the industry's demand for textile export relief as provided in Section 32 of the recently enacted amendments to the AAA, was announced here yesterday by Frank S. Bruyn, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States.

Adowa, today only a trading post and a station on one of the Ethiopian caravan trails, was the scene of the climactic battle of the Italian invasion of Ethiopia following the abrogation of the Treaty of Ucciali, on March 1, 1896.

Business at the Peck Slip freshwater fish market was at a virtual standstill yesterday and was expected to continue so this morning as a result of a strike of about 800 retail dealers, most of them members of the United Retail Fish Dealers Association, against prices charged by the wholesalers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- General Malin D. Craig took over his duties as Chief of Staff of the Army today without special ceremony. He was sworn in by Brig. Gen. Edgar T. Conley, acting Adjutant General, and immediately went to work, His successor as commandant of the War College has not yet been named.

Lithographs of the prize ring by George Bellows, a complete series, were placed on view yesterday at the Keppel Galleries, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain for several weeks. The recent Louis-Baer fight, of course, adds to the exhibition a note of timeliness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The following table shows employment under the Work Relief program based on reports received through Oct. 3. The difference between the total and those on WPA represents those under other agencies, exclusive of the CCC. Of the latter there were 559,640.
BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The Boerse was a trifle firmer today, with scattered signs of buoyancy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- President Roosevelt was kept fully informed by the State Department today of developments in the Ethiopian situation and is expected to issue his proclamation of an arms embargo against both Italy and Ethiopia when the department advises him that in its judgment this should be done.

American International Corporation reported yesterday net assets as of Sept. 30, 1935, of $22,326,118, equivalent to $1,615.37 for each $1,000 of debentures outstanding, and, after allowing for the debentures at par, to $8.43 a share on the common stock.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Opening a suit charging Anti-Trust Law violation today, the government declared that Warner Brothers and two other leading movie-picture production and distribution companies had "put a stain on a great industry."

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- The frost that was on the pumpkin descended today on the second game of the world series at Navin Field and made it the windiest, if not the coldest, on record. But neither wind, nor cold, nor rain, nor snow -- and we had all today -- could materially affect the ardor of the fans from all parts of the country who are taxing the city's accommodations to the limit.
ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 3. -- A brown warrior wheeled away from the palace steps. His hate and the hate of his ancestors for the white man crazed his face.

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -Br-r-r-r-r! This was more like a Byrd expedition than a ball game. Snow flurries in the morning and a general air of furthest north for a world series.
