The athletes thought they would be sitting by the fireside all day, but the weather report for this district was: Cold and colder. So Commissioner Landis came out of his igloo and ordered the campaign to proceed relentlessly.

SOFIA, Oct. 3. -- Premier Toscheff broadcast a statement throughout Bulgaria today, declaring that the government, by discovering at the last moment a widespread conspiracy yesterday and arresting its leaders, saved the country from a terrible civil war.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3. -- The Greenwich Theatre was the scene of a brilliant extravaganza, entitled "Greenwich Daze of 1935," tonight when the Greenwich Branch of the New York Junior League presented the Studio Players in a series of original skits, dances and songs.

Mr. and Mrs. Townsend M. McAlpin gave a dinner last night as the Central Park Casino. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Smart, Mr. and Mrs. John P. Duncan, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin McAlpin, Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. McAlpin, Dr. and Mrs. T.P. Allen, Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Chadbourne, Miss Faith Locke, Malcolm McAlpin, Howard MacAdams and Dr. Kenneth R. McAlpin.

The flight of capital from Europe took on increased momentum yesterday, as if in response to the quickened pace of the Italo-Ethiopian clash. Francs, guilders and other gold-bloc currencies declined sharply under the pressure of funds moving toward this country, and the engagements of gold abroad for shipment here increased sixfold over the level of the previous day to a total of $38,600,000.
DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's speeches during his trip across the continent aroused criticism and praise today among legislators.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- Commiseration for Ethiopia and unconcealed frowns for Premier Benito Mussolini and frank admiration for Great Britain's sturdy -- almost single-handed -- fight for perpetuation of the League of Nations enter the early press comment on the outbreak of hostilities in Northeast Africa.

MUSSOLINI'S speech on the eve of starting his war of "self-defense" against Ethiopia makes at least one thing perfectly clear. He is for the old order, the older and more ruthless the better. To him war is waged for the sake of "booty." He even revives the ideas and some of the phrases of the former German war lords.

The formal opening of the new Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza took place last night in the form of a "Dinner to Dawn" dance for the benefit of the Social Service Auxiliary to the New York City Cancer Institute. Many in society attended the event.

MADRID, Oct. 3. -- Socialist and self-styled liberal journals in the Spanish capital tonight proclaimed their willingness to renounce neutrality and all their pacifist ideals if their previous stand "will aid or appear to give moral support to Fascist Italy."

UVALDE, Texas, Oct. 3. -- John (Cactus Jack) Garner stopped feeding his bantam chicks, ducks and geese long enough today to assure any one interested that he would stick to "good, old cotton socks" on his forthcoming appearance before the Emperor of Japan.

Sentiment in the coat and suit industry is "solidly in favor of doing business solely with those woolen mills which restore the precode scale of discounts," it was reported yesterday at a meeting of representatives of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.; the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association, the Infants' and Children's Coat Association and the Western Area Coat and Suit Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Government motions to dissolve seven of twenty-four injunctions pending in this district, under which collection of millions of dollars in processing taxes is held up pending a decision on the constitutionality of the AAA Act, were denied today by Judges James H. Wilkerson and Charles E. Woodward in the Federal court.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- In the darkest hour of its gridiron history, following its first opening-game defeat on record, Cornell is buoyed up by the promise of a football revival such as it enjoyed in the early years of Gilmour Dobie's regime.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Coach Fritz Crisler took his Princeton football squad to Palmer Stadium today for its last hard workout before the encounter with Penn here Saturday.
Responding to the appeal of the Works Progress Administration for 12,000 skilled workers of various crafts, 1,000 men applied for such jobs yesterday.

The "first whole Bible printed in English," known as the "Coverdale Bible," was finished, according to its colophon, on Oct. 4, 1535. This date is still cherished as the birthday of the Bible as an English book -- the Book which, in its many translations and millions of copies, has had more influence in determining the character of Western civilization than any other book -- than all other books.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Business unquestionably is better, but the improvement may be short-lived, Harper Sibley of this city, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in an address here today.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia arrived yesterday from Mediterranean ports with a number of operatic singers, returning for the Winter season. Elisabeth Rethberg, German soprano, said she would appear in concerts and opera performances in San Francisco before the season here.

In spite of a rise of $23,000,000 in brokers' loans and a gain of $37,000,000 in all security loans, the total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city declined $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.

Recovering part of the ground lost on Wednesday, the bond market yesterday returned to more normal trading conditions and a steadier tone. Pressure during the first hour caused an extension of the decline in many groups in the list, but rallying tendencies predominated in trading during the remainder of the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Potato growers representing every State in the Union advanced on Washington today in a belligerent mood, due to reports of an assertion by Secretary Wallace that he would do all in his power to avoid enforcement of the potato control provisions of the amended Agricultural Adjustment Act.

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- The Tigers' victory in the second game today made the betting on the outcome of the world series practically an even-money proposition. Wagering on the result of tomorrow's game was similar.

August marked an improvement for railroads in the East and South, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. In previous months, augmented expenses in many cases offset increased gross revenues, but in August net operating income of the Eastern railroads gained 17.8 per cent and that of the Southern lines 11.4 per cent.

Mrs. Floyd B. Odlum, who became president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., on Oct 6 of last year, the first woman to head a department store in this city, announced yesterday that she would celebrate her first anniversary in her present position by organizing a "shoppers' committee."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Matches that developed some exciting battles and resulted in some unusual golf featured the second day's play in the Metropolitan Golf Association's handicap championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Re-establishment of confidence in security prices yesterday followed a calmer appraisal of the possibilities surrounding the current war talk. Wheat and cotton registered moderate declines, while bonds were slightly higher.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis held today that the Agricultural Adjustment Act became constitutional on Aug. 24, the day Congress amended it, but he ruled that the act was invalid as to tax levies made under it prior to the amendment.

Resolutions condemning the "Fascist invasion of Ethiopia," and authorizing the organization of a "student Ethiopian defense committee" were adopted at a meeting under the auspices of the student council of City College in Lewisohn Stadium yesterday afternoon.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $20,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $2,600,000000, according to the weekly statement, published yesterday. This relatively small net change was the result of unusually large fluctuations in the factors affecting bank reserves.
PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Forty-four line and construction corps officers were selected by the Navy Department today for aeronautical engineering duty only, under the provisions of legislation approved on June 5.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange today were generally weak, slumping sharply as a result of the news of Italian invasion of Ethiopia. British funds opened lower, although they recovered partly later. Italian bonds went down in the foreign section of the market.

The statement of J.P. Morgan Co. as of Oct. 1, issued yesterday, disclosed a drop of nearly $10,000,000 in the amount of surplus and partners' balances, reflecting withdrawals of funds by partners of the firm in connection with the recent retirement of a group of them and the formation of the investment banking company of Morgan, Stanley Co., Inc.

Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise drive, which started at 11 o'clock Tuesday night, rounded out its second day with a grand total of 2,899 warnings and five summonses, according to figures given out yesterday at police headquarters by the office of Chief Inspector John J. Seery.

Tony Canzoneri, veteran of the fistic wars, will place his world lightweight crown in jeopardy at Madison Square Garden tonight when he meets Al Roth of the Bronx in a fight scheduled for fifteen rounds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Lard type hogs were in good demand here today and prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight. Supplies of heavy hogs have been steadily diminishing of late and a pronounced tendency has developed to narrow the spread in prices with lighter kinds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The government's income topped a billion dollars today, but with the first quarter of the financial year gone it fell short of reaching one-fourth the year's budgeted total.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- United State Senator W. Warren Barbout opened today an exhibit of Japanese and American products of a similar nature, intended to show the need of tariff schedules to protect American labor and industry from what he considers unfair foreign competition.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Craft unionists took the offensive today in their struggle against advocates of industrial unionism when sixteen unions affiliated with the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor adopted a strong resolution demanding that the Association of Oil Field, Gas Well and Refinery Workers (an industrial union), turn over to the craft organizations all the members within the jurisdiction of these organizations.

Much local legislation has been formulated within the last two years in an attempt to cope with the problems arising out of the distress deflation of realty income and values in New York State. Our widespread economic upheaval had a calamitous effect upon mortgage investments particularly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- President Roosevelt, in messages to Secretary Swanson and Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, praised the performance of the navy in the tactical exercises he witnessed yesterday from the cruiser Houston. The messages were made public today by the Navy Department.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Closing of the Suez Canal against Italy would be a far more illegal action than violation of any "hazy clauses of the covenant of the League of Nations," Colonel Philippe Bunau-Varilla declared today in a speech to the American Club of Paris.

Broadway's schedule for next week shifted again yesterday when Walter Hampden set back his production of "Achilles Had a Heel" from next Thursday to a week from tomorrow night, at the Forty-fourth Street. This brings the Martin Flavin play into conflict with the opening of "Jubilee!" at the Imperial.

Customers' men have been advised by the New York Stock Exchange, it is learned, not to take too literally the bid and asked quotations on stocks furnished by telephone from the Exchange's bureau. This warning was issued because of customers' men's complaints that the bids were not always firm, particularly in declining markets, resulting sometimes in the disappointment of traders who assumed they had "hit" the market with an order.

ATHENS, Oct. 3. -- British and Italian airplanes and warships are visiting Greece with unaccustomed frequency, and the reports of fishermen that they have seen war vessels singly and in groups manoeuvring off the Cretan and Peloponnesian shores have gravely troubled public opinion over the imminence of a conflict in the Eastern Mediterranean.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- While shrieking newspaper headlines announced the start of war in Ethiopia, the Conservative party voted at Bourne-mouth today for the strengthening of every branch of Great Britain's fighting forces.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The German Government issued an appeal through the press tonight to citizens of Berlin to use less butter and more butter substitutes. The appeal follows conferences today between the Minister of Propaganda, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, and the Minister of Agriculture, Richard Darre.

The protest of the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman regarding the use of hymns in radio programs is undoubtedly prompted by a high regard for their sacred character, but it seems to miss the point that introducing hymns of the church in a commercial program is a distinct compliment to religion.

Two signs of the times, pointing to recovery of business activity this Autumn overtopping that of any other recent Autumn, have come to hand in the statements of the last few days. One is the increase in bank loans which have been made on other than Stock Exchange collateral and which therefore measure the use of credit in purely industrial operations.

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- The joy that should have been the lot of the Tigers in their clubhouse after today's victory was tempered by apprehension. Tommy Bridges had succeeded where Schoolboy Rowe had failed. Two of the three G-Men had started hitting and the other was a bulwark of defense.

In as close a finish as the Champagne Stakes has produced in all its sixty-five runnings, Brevity and Snark drove to the line yesterday at Belmont Park so closely locked that none save the judges could establish the former as the winner by a nose.

The campaign for compulsory fingerprinting of the entire population, which some police officials have been supporting, has now found no less a sponsor than Governor LEHMAN. Before such a radical step is taken, however, a few considerations ought to be kept in mind.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -Great Britain and France today agreed on a joint program before the League of Nations calling for the immediate severance by League members of financial and economic relations with Italy and for possible financial help to Ethiopia.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 3. -- Martial law was proclaimed today in Eritrea and Italian Somaliland. In a proclamation announcing the opening of hostilities, General Emilio de Bono, the Italian high commander, said:

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- Riding on the crest of a biting gale that froze spectators and combatants to the very marrow of their bones, an aroused band of Tigers laid violent hands on its tormentors today and battered its way to even terms in this 1935 world series by crushing the Cubs in the second game, 8 to 3.
A sloop named Windflower, approximately 75 feet on the water, is to be Charles R. Fairey's challenger for the America's Cup. She will be about eight feet shorter than the Endeavour of last year.

An increase of 37.1 per cent in bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday swelled the figure to the second highest total in nearly four years. The aggregate for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,401,824,000, contrasted with $4,669,787,000 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Mrs. Arthur Lehman and Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler will be the chairmen of the campaign conducted by the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies this Fall in connection with the federation's annual fund drive, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Great Britain was shown by official figures today to have outstripped Italy as a heavy buyer of munition materials in the United States during the last eight months. Figures worked out at the Commerce Department showed, however, that Japan outpurchased both of them.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in Iqew York.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3. -- A Brazilian neutrality pronunciamento is expected here. Late this afternoon officials queried by THE TIMES declared no action had yet been taken nor had the issue been discussed, but diplomatic observers believe that, pending a declaration of war, Brazil will continue maintaining the most friendly relations with Italy though disapproving the present situation, because Brazil does not countenance war and champions arbitration.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on June 30 a total income of $62,886,991, compared with $63,376,782 in the preceding year. Their income, after taxes, interest, amortization, dividends on preferred and class A stocks of subsidiaries and minority interest in net earnings of subsidiaries, amounted to $1,199,869, compared with $2,358,495. Earned surplus on June 30 was $9,137,440, compared with $11,102,440 a year before.

More than 10,000 persons gathered at Madison Square Garden last night to hear from Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, a firsthand report of the Seventh World Congress of the Communist International, held recently in Moscow.
Following were the chief developments yesterday in Ethiopia and the diplomatic background of the crisis:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Management and labor will be sounded out before any new industrial legislation is attempted, Major George L. Berry, new Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, said in a public statement today.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Criticisms of various New Deal tendencies were uttered this evening at a gathering of the Committee of One Hundred of Miami, Fla., assembled for their sixth annual Northern dinner with a group of New England professional and industrial leaders.
The territory which the Italian forces entered when they crossed the Mareb River, has been recognized as Ethiopian since 1896, when the Italians last invaded it and were slaughtered near Adowa.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Atlanta Constitution says it has learned that Governor Talmadge plans to place the State under martial law Jan. 1, collect taxes through Adjt. Gen. Lindley W. Camp and disburse the funds collected as he sees fit.

The International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on June 30 a total income of $62,886,991, compared with $63,376,782 in the preceding year. Their income, after taxes, interest, amortization, dividends on preferred and class A stocks of subsidiaries and minority interest in net earnings of subsidiaries, amounted to $1,199,869, compared with $2,358,495. Earned surplus on June 30 was $9,137,440, compared with $11,102,440 a year before.

More than 10,000 persons gathered at Madison Square Garden last night to hear from Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, a firsthand report of the Seventh World Congress of the Communist International, held recently in Moscow.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole, the Reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date.

FRENCH LICK SPRINGS, Ind., Oct. 3. -- Seven hundred mortgage bankers from forty-five States meeting at the twenty-second annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America at the French Lick Springs Hotel joined today informally in a strong condemnation of New Deal policies.

The challenge of youth in current religious movements must be met by cooperative efforts on the part of church leaders, according to the views expressed by several of them yesterday at the one-day conference held under the auspices of church federations in this city at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Criticisms of various New Deal tendencies were uttered this evening at a gathering of the Committee of One Hundred of Miami, Fla., assembled for their sixth annual Northern dinner with a group of New England professional and industrial leaders.
The territory which the Italian forces entered when they crossed the Mareb River, has been recognized as Ethiopian since 1896, when the Italians last invaded it and were slaughtered near Adowa.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Atlanta Constitution says it has learned that Governor Talmadge plans to place the State under martial law Jan. 1, collect taxes through Adjt. Gen. Lindley W. Camp and disburse the funds collected as he sees fit.

Four hundred and twenty farmers and other members of Midwestern rural communities arrived at 5:25 P.M. yesterday at the Grand Central Terminal. At 6:30 they were dining at the Paramount Hotel, and an hour and a half later were lost in the evening throngs of Broadway.
In your editorial "Pay for Internes" it appears to me that you hardly do full justice to the interne's view of the matter.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 3. -- Winning the first game of the match with Dr. Max Euwe of this city at the Hotel Carlton tonight, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world chess champion, made a most auspicious start in his defense of the title.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 3. -- Development of a serum which was declared to be as positive and effective in the treatment of infantile paralysis as the serum for treatment of diphtheria was announced and demonstrated before members of the Kentucky State Medical Association today by Dr. E.C. Rosenow of the Mayo Foundation of the University of Minnesota.

Melvin Horace Purvis, former agent of the Department of Justice, gave 300 business men at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday a soft-spoken, almost apologetic account of the killing of John Dillinger and Arthur (Pretty Boy) Floyd.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler handed down yesterday a decision in which he ruled that the 4,035 holders of $13,155,957 of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates designated as Series B-K sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company are to have an opportunity to vote on whether they want the series reorganized and administered by trustees appointed by him or elected by themselves.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 3. -- The general advance of the Italian armies from Eritrea has begun. At dawn today 20,000 men in four columns crossed the March River, which forms the Ethiopian boundary.

I have taken the time to go through with care the financial section of your issue of Sept. 29. I find it so widely informing, so ably edited, to my mind, that I believe space will be well taken by reference in detail to certain features.
Bolton Hall, in a letter to THE TIMES, hails the idea of solving the slum problem by Government subsidy to private enterprise.

About 1,000 uniformed policemen and from 200 to 300 detectives were ordered on special duty last night following the outbreak of trouble between Italian-Americans and Negroes in Harlem and Brooklyn. The precautions will be taken daily as long as the police authorities see danger of local violence as a result of the Italo-Ethiopian hostilities.

The Scientific Book Club has chosen as its October book "Autobiography of Earth," by John Hodgdon Bradley, which CowardMcCann will publish on Oct. 10. Mr. Bradley's previous book, "Parade of the Living," was also a club selection.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, discussed the general outlook for this basic industry at the annual dinner tonight of the American Society for Metals.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of the Greenwich Country Club gained low gross for the third straight time in the women's Westchester-Fairfield one-day tournaments when she carded an 83 to lead the field in today's event at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Right Rev. James M. Maxon, Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Church, diocese of Tennessee, came into full Episcopal jurisdiction of the diocese today upon the death of Bishop Thomas F. Gailor.
The 1935-36 season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Otto Klemperer conducting, opened under favorable conditions, if with no particular excitement, last night in Carnegie Hall.
PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Here as elsewhere events in the cycle started by the ambitions of Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy are moving toward a crisis.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 3. -- John S. Cannon, a Negro, had a Kentucky colonel's commission tonight, but he did not know why.

The New York Academy of Medicine, for the first time in its history, started last night a series of lectures intended to enlighten the lay public on various aspects of modern medicine. A capacity firstnight audience of nearly 1,000 men and women, including about 100 standees, attended the first lecture.

The fathers of our country "never intended and never suggested that new conditions should not bring about methods that would keep pace with the nation's growth," President Roosevelt declared in a letter made public here yesterday.

Because three of its members felt themselves disqualified to pass upon the merits of the case, the Appellate Division deferred yesterday until Tuesday the hearing of argument on the city's appeal from the recent decision by Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore barring from the ballot in the coming election Mayor La Guardia's referendum on a $49,000,000 municipal power plant.

The engagement of Rene Maison, Belgian dramatic tenor, and the return of Florence Easton, dramatic soprano, after an absence of six years were announced yesterday for the Metropolitan Opera by Edward Johnson, general manager. Queena Mario, lyric soprano, who has been a member of the company for several seasons, has been re-engaged.

More than two-thirds of the ex-service men who are receiving hospital care under the Veterans' Administration are suffering from maladies not connected with service, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator, told the members of the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States yesterday.
The Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game has issued a bulletin summarizing the State laws for hunting non-migratory birds and game. The seasons on most species open on Oct. 20.

DENVER, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A threat to "blow the lid" off an alleged liquor scandal was backed up today by Governor Johnson, who announced that a special session of the Legislature would be called for Oct. 30 to consider impeachment of James H. Carr, Secretary of State.
CEDAR FALLS, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Senator Gerald P. Nye called for public support tonight for a move to strengthen America's neutrality policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Wholesale prices were steady during the week ended on Sept. 28, the index based on 1926 averages, remaining at 81, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This compared with 77.2 on Sept. 29, 1934.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT ON THE PACIFIC, Oct. 4 (AP). -- President Roosevelt is satisfied, official sources said today, that his American neutrality policy is holding firm in the face of the Italo-Ethiopian war crisis.

Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney and Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt joined forces yesterday for the first time since Mrs. Vanderbilt sued Mrs. Whitney to compel her to give up custody of 11-year-old Gloria Vanderbilt, daughter of Mrs. Whitney's brother, Reginald C. Vanderbilt.

With the America's Cup challenge of the Royal London Yacht Club on behalf of Charles R. Fairey and his planned racer Windflower in the hands of the appointed cup committee of the New York Yacht Club, there was an attitude of watchful waiting yesterday on the part of yachtsmen.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Following is the text of the salient portions of the address tonight by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin before the Conservative conference at Bournemouth:

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 4. -- A great battle is raging tonight between the forces led by Ras Seyoum, Governor of East Tigre Province, defending Adowa, and the Italian invaders. It is reported that one of the big Caproni bombers was shot down by Ethiopian marksmen in the fight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Instructions to prosecute Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer on charges of conspiring to evade income taxes, the last Federal indictment standing against him, have been sent to Francis W.H. Adams, Federal Attorney in New York, the Department of Justice announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Answers filed by sixty Essex County residents, stockholders in the closed Bank of United States of New York, in the suit brought by George W. Egbert, Superintendent of Banking of New York, to collect an assessment equal to the par value of the stock, were struck out today in an opinion filed by Judge Newton H. Porter of the Essex County Circuit Court, sitting as a Supreme Court Commissioner.

" Loyalty Day" will be observed in synagogues and temples today and in Protestant and Roman Catholic churches throughout the United States tomorrow under the auspices of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery. The movement, which has been supported by President Roosevelt and by scores of other prominent persons, has for its slogan "Every member present or accounted for."
VALETTA, Malta, Oct. 4. -- This small Mediterranean island, only fifty miles from Italian Sicily, is now in the midst of feverish preparations against war.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- After juggling four or five line-ups and batting orders due to the injury to High-up Hank Greenberg, Manager Mickey Cochrane of the Tigers finally pulled one out of his hat or his hair when the umpires came on the field and demanded the official starting list for the third game of the world series.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 4. -- The American people fervently desire the security provided by President Roosevelt's Social Security Act, and it is up to the States to cooperate and make them available within a few months, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, said before delegates from forty States at the second National Congress on Labor Legislation here tonight.

Strength in United States Government loans and the better tone among the foreign issues were the features of an otherwise dull market for bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace slackened considerably as total transactions amounted to $10,777, 500, against $13,321,100 on Thursday, with selective trading characterizing the main body of domestic corporation issues.
Tony Canzoneri and Al Roth each weighed 133 1/2 pounds for their battle at Madison Square Garden last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and Charlie Lynch and Tommy Shortell the judges.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, asserted today that the rift between Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and ten large banks of the nation over the proposal that the banks convert $63,000,000 in demand loans to the New York Central Railroad into 4 per cent bonds has been exaggerated.

Niagara Falls, N.Y. Award was made yesterday of a new issue of $1,265,000 City of Niagara Falls, N.Y., sewerage disposal bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1935, and maturing on Jan. 1, 1937 to 1957, to a banking group composed of Lazard Freres Co., Inc., Blyth Co., Inc., and Graham, Parsons Co. on a price of 100.086 for 2.70 per cent bonds.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Terl Johnson, 24-year-old shot-maker from Winterhaven, Fla., flashed past many of the world's greatest golfers today with a one-under-par 69, to take the first round lead in the Indianapolis $5,000 open tournament.

Under the caption "Senator Lodge's Position" the writer of a letter to THE TIMES endeavors to dissociate the late Massachusetts Senator and his Republican colleagues from the defeat and overthrow of the League of Nations covenant, and the debarment of the United States from official participation in collective efforts to prevent a repetition of future wars.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Meeting with Governor Harold G. Hoffman and State Banking Commissioner Carl K. Withers, the advisory board authorized by law to assist the banking commissioner fixed today the interest rates for deposits in New Jersey banks, savings banks and trust companies at 2 per cent.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $14,452,766, including $6,002,500 of bonds to be offered for sale by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, acting as fiscal agent for the Public Works Administration, thus indicating another dull period in that field.

George W. Egbert, State Superintendent of Banks, issued yesterday a call for the publication of statements of condition as of Sept. 28, by all banks, private bankers and trust companies under his jurisdiction. The date selected fell upon a Saturday, which means that the figures shown in the reports issued in response to the official call will differ from those given in the statements issued by the banks as of Sept. 30, a Monday.

For the first time since the special New York County grand jury, investigating rackets, has been in session, it was necessary yesterday to cite a witness for contempt. Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook held a witness in contempt for refusing to answer questions and gave him an opportunity to produce his business books to purge himself.

Although the $19,000,000 Bronx Terminal Market was started more than a decade ago and was formally opened by Mayor La Guardia last April, one of its oldest facilities received what is believed to be its first use only yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 (AP). -- A pair of 2-year-olds from Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Sagamore Farm dominated the running of the Magothy Purse at Laurel today, finishing one, two in the five-and-one-half-furlong dash for juveniles foaled in Maryland which had never won a sweepstakes or two consecutive races.

Of the proceeds of an issue of common stock the Ludlum Steel Company will use approximately $700,000 to acquire the Wallingford Steel Company, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The balance will be added to working capital.

Walter Damrosch, conducting a large symphony orchestra, yesterday opened the eighth annual music appreciation series of radio concert-lectures for the school children of the nation. The hour broadcast went on the combined WEAF and WJZ nation-wide networks, beginning at 11 A.M., Eastern standard time.

A special committee of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene met last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania and allocated for the study and research of dementia praecox a fund of $40,000, donated by the Supreme Council, Thirty-third Degree, Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite, Northern Masonic Jurisdiction.

The preliminary rumbling of the past two week-ends grows into the blast of a full football season today as the parade of a new stretch of playing weeks finds its ranks swelled by practically all of the teams of major and minor importance in the game.

VIENNA, Oct. 4. -- There is little genuine support for Italy's invasion of Ethiopia in any part of Central or Southeastern Europe. The public generally seems to be horrified at the bombing of Ethiopian towns and an invasion without a declaration of war, but this feeling finds little reflection in the controlled newspapers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- A campaign for $7,750,000 to construct a new library, endow the School of Public Affairs and create additional scholarships for Princeton University was inaugurated here today when Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, outlined the program to 200 alumni and appealed for support.

CANBERRA, Oct. 4. -- After a Federal Cabinet discussion this morning Prime Minister Lyons stated that Australians were greatly disappointed at the apparent failure of Great Britain and the League of Nations to settle the Ethiopian dispute peacefully.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- A once discarded method of selecting workmen on PWA projects was virtually restored today in an order authorizing contractors to go outside of relief rolls if these failed to produce enough skilled labor.

Tony Canzoneri still holds the world's lightweight championship. The doughty Brooklyn veteran of ten years of ring service successfully defended his crown against Al Roth of the Bronx at Madison Square Garden last night in a fifteen-round bout that started out as a lark for the champion and ended as one of the bloodiest encounters he had ever been in.

It is said that Dr. SCHACHT. Germany's economic dictator, has made himself indispensable to the Nazis, because nobody else in Germany understands the labyrinthine network of controls that he has set up. Certainly Nazi finance from the beginning has been shrouded in mystery.

MARJORIE KINNAN RAWLINGS came near winning the Pulitzer Prize for last year with her first novel, "South Moon Under." Her second novel, "Golden Apples" (Scribner, $2.50), is an even better book. The setting is again a section of that wild forest land of Central Florida into which civilization has only barely penetrated.

FRENCH LICK SPRINGS, Ind., Oct. 4. -- The threat of further government dominance in the field of financial credit was delineated today by Silas H. Strawn, past president of the American Bar Association and the United States Chamber of Commerce, who addressed the clossing session of the twenty-second annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in the French Lick Springs Hotel here.

An 8 per cent drop in liquor and wine licenses in the State was reported yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, on the basis of a preliminary check of new licenses issued for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin announced tonight that Britain is about to rearm in earnest not only because of Italy's present defiance, but because of the challenge which all dictatorships have thrown down to the free peoples of Europe.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Pacing a field of forty teams, Mr. and Mrs. James Robbins of Pine Valley today won the qualifying round of the mixed foursome competition at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- An against-the-trend decline in bank reserve balances, despite a continuing flow of imported gold, day challenged the attention of Washington's economists. The last week has seen an increase of $117, 000,000 in the Treasury's gold stocks.

About the first-night audience at the new planetarium Mr. LAURENCE said that it was treated to more than a sight of the universe at work. The spectators were taken behind the scenes of the cosmos and shown just how it works.

I am sure if Governor Lehman has his way and all individuals of the State are fingerprinted that I, for one, will have a very guilty look when I march to the police station in company with my fellow-citizens.

Freight carloadings in the last three months of 1935 are expected to run 6.4 per cent above those in the same period of last year, according to estimates by the thirteen shippers' regional boards which were made public yesterday. Twelve of the boards forecast increases.
Alice Brady and Joel McCrea have been selected by Samuel Goldwyn to appear with Merle Oberon in her next stirring film to be based on a screen story by Lillian Hellman, playwright.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange recovered well generally today, as the belief is growing that the Italo-Ethiopian dispute will be localized. Notable in the demand for shares were those of armament companies, particularly Vickers, Baldwin and United Steel, while iron and steel and aircraft issues also strengthened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- President Roosevelt will declare an arms embargo against Italy and Ethiopia when he is convinced that there is war beyond question and without reference to the position the League of Nations takes.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 4. -- Because he had become unnerved each time he officiated at an execution in the electric chair, Frank D. Whipp, warden of the Joliet-Statesville prisons here, timed his resignation to the minute so that he would not be present at a sixth execution.

With the sudden drop in temperatures, retail buying gained sharply this week, following the moderate recession of the previous week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Gains for the country as a whole ranged from 5 to 15 per cent over the previous week and 8 to 12 per cent over the correspond ing period last year, the agency reports.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, sent yesterday to stockholders a letter explaining the action of the directors last month in reducing the dividend payable on Oct. 1 from 75 cents a share to 50 cents.

Memorial services for eight firemen who were killed in discharge of duty and twenty-eight who died in the last year will be held tomorrow afternoon at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive and 100th Street.

The announcement of the development of a serum which is effective in treatment of infantile paralysis, made by Dr. E.C. Rosenow of the Mayo Foundation of the University of Minnesota, was received with considerable skepticism yesterday by medical authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP). -- The Bureau of Mines reported today production of crude oil in August was 84,816,000 barrels, or a daily average of 2,736,000. This average was 21,600 barrels below July, 7 per cent above a year ago, and 81,000 barrels above the recommendation of the bureau for August.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 4. -- The chief raids by Italian airplanes today were made across the northern and southern frontiers. In the north machines from Eritrea flew over the Setit River, the boundary delimited in 1902, and bombed the posts of Jamadia and Hamat.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- The second day's program of the annual Piping Rock Horse Show today was well attended. Many luncheons were given.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4. -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, ruled today, in effect, that the 1,800 faculty members must comply with the new Massachusetts Teachers' Oath Law or resign.
AS one who was a Republican district captain for several years I have often wondered why apparently no one has ever suggested the disfranchisement of all appointive officeholders.

Today will be held at the Californian Oakland the fourth Republican regional gathering, conference, convention, consultation, rally, meeting of survivors, revival picnic. The movement has been processional. New England began it in April at Boston, a little coldly, slowly, solemnly, after the Yankee manner.

Eileen Wenzel, 25 years old, the former show girl, who sued Louis J. Ehret Jr. and his mother for $250,000 damages, got a verdict of $90,000 from a jury before Supreme Court Justice Pecora yesterday, after the jury had deliberated two hours and ten minutes. The court reserved decision on an application by Frederick Mellor, attorney for the Ehrets to reduce the award as excessive and against the weight of evidence.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commission of Baseball, began an investigation tonight into the controversy at the third world series game today between Umpire George Moriarty and the Chicago Cubs led by Manager Charley Grimm.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 4. -- Formal notice of an impending legal battle over the fortune of the late Alfred E. Dieterich of Millbrook was given today when a petition was filed in Surrogate Daniel J. Gleason's office for reconsideration of probate proceedings.

Put it down, if you like, to the peculiarities of provincial nature, but I went to church this morning, and left in record time -- three minutes. I threaded in through the revolving door with the crowd, and found that we were being divided by ushers. "Members only!" one was thundering, and those who ware not members were slinking off to somewhere with their heads down.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Premier Mussolini of Italy has renewed an offer made to the British Government some time ago in Rome to call off by mutual agreement the "precautionary" measures of a military naval nature taken by both sides to insure their security in the Mediterranean basin.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series follows:

GENEVA, Saturday, Oct. 5. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, pushed with all of Great Britain's weight for a definite decision by the League Council when it meets later today that Italy is the aggressor, together with the adoption of a stiff report on the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 4. -- A howling, snow-filled gale halted Great Lakes shipping over a wide area today, disrupted communications and drove at least three vessels aground, where one was threatened with destruction by the mountainous waves.

MADRID, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Alejandro Lerroux, Foreign Minister, stated today that Spain was inquiring of the Italian Government if Spanish merchant vessels plying Italian waters were in danger of internment in the event of war.

The remarks of ex-Senator Arthur R. Robinson of Indiana, upon his return from Berlin and Moscow, have brought forth praise and condemnation from your readers. May I tell of an interesting phenomenon? I saw Senator Robinson-all politicians like to be called by their former titles -- in both cities.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The following statement under the heading, "Massacre of the Innocents," was issued today by the Ethiopian Legation here:

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- A 21-year-old senior of Panzer College, Jerry De Rosa, today became the Metropolitan Golf Association's first handicap champion, carrying off the honors at the Winged Foot Golf Club by beating E. Kenneth Smith of Rockville, 4 and 3, in the final round.

A "tentative agreement" for the city's purchase of the stock equities of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company for $40,000,000 was announced last night by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP). -- Far Western Republicans opened a "spirit of '36" convention here today, heard a spokesman advance the Governor of Kansas as a Presidential possibility, and prepared to suggest planks for their party and to indict the New Deal.

Reports that any spreading of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict to include major European powers carries with it a threat of possible suspension of trading on the New York Stock Exchange were credited yesterday by the financial community to the "rumor factory."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Luigi Pirandello, Italian playwright, is among the passengers sailing tonight for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Also sailing on the ship are the Right Rev. Diego Venoni and the Right Rev. Carno Grano, Papal Delegates to the Eucharistic Congress in Cleveland, and:

Horace G. Knowles, former United States Minister to Rumania, announced yesterday, as treasurer of the newly formed Committee for Ethiopia, that the first American volunteer field hospital unit to aid Ethiopia had been completed. The entire unit, including all equipment and a staff of seven Negro physicians, will be transported to Addis Ababa at a cost of $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The government is preparing to go into the business of managing the thirty-seven low-cost apartment buildings to be constructed with over $100,000,000 of relief funds. In so doing it will collect rents, supply janitor service, redecorate quarters, and play the same part that any private landlord does.

ADDIS ABABA, Saturday, Oct. 5. -- Reports reached this capital early today of fierce fighting now under way in the Mount Mussa Ali sector, where the railway to Jibuti, Ethiopia's only real link with the outside world, is at stake.

The flight of capital, expelled from Europe by the rising fear of war, pressed heavily against the foreign exchange market again yesterday, driving the pound sterling down to the lowest price since May 15 and carrying with it a continued outpouring of gold from foreign countries, consigned to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Monongahela West Penn Public Service Corporation of Fairmont, W. Va., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for $32,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent series first and general mortgage bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1960, and $7,500,000 of 6 per cent debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1965, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The first in a series of Sunday evening lectures at the John Reed Club School of Art will be given in the club's new quarters tomorrow evening at 8:15 by Joe Jones, young St. Louis painter, who exhibited at the ACA Gallery last season. His subject will be "Painting with Social Content."

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday that a public hearing would be held by the Board of Health on Oct. 14-16, to consider a new plan for drug and cosmetic control in the city.

JASPER, Ala., Oct. 4 (AP). -- The driver of a WPA truck was ambushed and wounded near Creeltown today as he was preparing to transport a truckload of men to a WPA project which had been shut down because of a strike for higher wages.

The first concert of the Student Series will be played in Carnegie Hall tonight by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, with Otto Klemperer conducting. The program will include Beethoven's "Egmont" overture, Shostakovich's first symphony, Brahms's second serenade and the Bach-Weiner toccata, played at the opening concert of the season on Thursday evening and again yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- With the unanimous backing of his Cabinet, announced after a three-hour session today, Premier Pierre Laval returned to Geneva to continue in harmony with Great Britain in the application of the procedure laid down in the covenant of the League of Nations respecting such a situation as that caused by the Italian attack on Ethiopia.
Most commodity futures were higher in active trading here yesterday. Cash prices, except for oats, moved higher.
Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred day of the Jewish calendar, begins at sundown tomorrow and will be celebrated by special services in all congregations throughout the city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Armed United States deputy marshals rode the trains of the Chicago North Western Railroad through the Illinois and Wisconsin dairy country tonight to fend off attacks by farm pickets in the Chicago area milk strike.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 4. -- Fifty Republican leaders of Ohio, including Walter F. Brown, national committeeman and former Postmaster General, and former Senator Simeon D. Fess, met today and decided to advise the maintenance of a neutral position on Presidential candidates until the State Central and Executive committees have time to formulate a course.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 4. -- Bucknell defeated Ursinus, 20 to 0, tonight before a shivering crowd of 5,000 as Smith and Pfeiffer accounted for the three touchdowns.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Under the leadership of Leopold Stokowski, the Philadelphia Orchestra this afternoon opened its thirty-sixth season with a program in which a new "rhumba symphony" by Professor Harl McDonald of the University of Pennsylvania had its premiere before an enthusiastic audience.

On the French liner Lafayette when it arrived yesterday from Havre were 100 members of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which begins its third American season at the Metropolitan Opera House next Wednesday night with "Scheherazade," not previously given here by this company; "The Three-Cornered Hat" and "Aurora's Wedding," from Tchaikovsky's "Sleeping Beauty."

PRINCETON, N.T., Oct. 4. -- Renewing their gridiron rivalry after a lapse of forty years, he football teams of Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania will meet in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:30.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4. -- Organized labor will insist that the Government of the United States maintain strict neutrality in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute and in the event of war in Europe, it was announced here today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

About 125 students, half of whom were girls, were arrested last night shortly after 8 o'clock when they attempted to picket the front of the Rivoli Theatre in protest against "Red Salute," being shown there. The students, who ranged in age from 16 to 21 years, are members of the National Student League and the Student League for Industrial Democracy.

BUFFALO, Oct. 4. -- In an effort to end a strike of more than 1,400 workers on Emergency Relief and Works Progress Administration projects, city relief authorities told the strikers today they would add "relief" to WPA pay wherever workers could show that the wages were insufficient.

Sir RICHARD GREGORY, editor of Nature, in a recent address on "Science and the Press," said that it is desirable to cultivate in the mind of the public an understanding of the purposes for which men devote their lives to scientific experiment and inquiry. Too little attention, he contended, is given to the story of the quest itself -- of the way by which the goal of achievement has been reached.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- President Roosevelt's trip across the country has demonstrated his "hold upon the masses," Postmaster General Farley declared here today. He came to Chicago today to see the world series.

A thrilling two-touchdown comeback in the final quarter gave Poly Prep's smooth-functioning football team an 18-to-7 triumph over Adelphi Academy before 7,000 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday. The game, which was the season's opener for both, was staged under the auspices of the Good Neighbors of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities for the benefit of Brooklyn blind and crippled workers.
ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- Governor Lehman tonight proclaimed next week as "fire prevention week."

The printing of ballots containing the proposition for a municipal power plant favored by Mayor La Guardia will be started Monday unless the Appellate Division or the Court of Appeals issues a stay meanwhile, Paul Kern, legal secretary to the Mayor, asserted last night.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- Lyons and the whole surrounding region was flooded by a cloudburst, followed by steady rain all day today, and the quarter of the city which suffered a disastrous landslide in 1932 is being evacuated tonight.

ADDIS ABABA, Oct. 4. -- While Ethiopia's northern chieftains try desperately to check the Italian invasion of the provinces of the Tigre and Danakil. Emperor Haile Selassie is rushing more troops to the bush country on the Ogaden front, where 50,000 of his warriors are already present to resist Mussolini's legions as they pour across the border of Italian Somaliland.

Will Reigh Count's son, Count Arthur, the Saratogo Cup winner, follow in the footsteps of his sire and take the Lawrence Realization, and can the filly Forever Yours confirm her claim to the juvenile championship of her sex in the Matron Stakes? These are questions which will be answered today at Belmont Park, where the first triple stake program of the meeting will be on view.

A rivalry which began in 1912 and has flourished almost uninterruptedly since will be continued today when the Fordham football team takes the field against its ancient foe, Boston College, in the Polo Grounds for the twentieth time.

J. R. Youatt, treasurer of The Associated Press, resigned yesterday after forty-two years' service with this world news-gathering organization. Announcement of Mr. Youatt's retirement and the appointment of L. F. Curtis, superintendent of markets and elections, as his successor was made by the board of directors at its meeting.

Reiterating views expressed last Spring, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of the New York Conservation Department told members of the Madison County Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs at a meeting Thursday night that fishermen could not expect a marked improvement in their sport unless the department obtained additional income with which to enlarge its stocking activities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer of White Plains, N.Y., sharply attacked the administration of the National Youth Fund as a threat to freedom in education in an address at the closing session of the National Recreation Congress tonight.

Before entering Doctors Hospital for a slight operation, General Hugh S. Johnson, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, revealed yesterday afternoon that he was investigating Communist activities within his organization.

Bank exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in September amounted to $22,901,048,792. This was a decline of 5.6 per cent from the preceding month, but a gain of 16.9 per cent over September, 1934. The clearings were the smallest for a month since last February.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Federal agents and the Chicago police have been engaged for several weeks in an effort to seize a band of kidnappers who threaten to abduct Harold F. McCormick, chairman of the board of International Harvester Company, and William C. Cummings, president of the Drovers National Bank, unless huge payments are made.

Eleven bids for construction of the first section of the Sixth Avenue subway, from Fortieth Street to Forty-seventh Street, were opened yesterday by the Board of Transportation. An informal check of the bids, covering 262 items of specifications, showed George H. Flinn to be low bidder with an offer of $5,394,000.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- After four days of preliminaries, testimony was finally started late today in the movie anti-trust criminal case in Federal Court before Judge George H. Moore. Harry C. Arthur Jr. of New York, head of Fanchon Marco interests, began telling the jurors that Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., executives declared war eighteen months ago on the owners of three theatres here.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. has purchased for the Cloisters branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the chapter room of the ancient French abbey of Pontaut, according to announcement by The Art News.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Oct. 4. -- Italian troops continued to sweep in a swift advance across the thin strip of territory leading up to the hills that lie approximately parallel with the Ethiopian frontier.

The gradual building up of an underground mass-movement against the Hitler regime, which is gaining a momentum that may lead to its overthrow in the not too distant future, was reported yesterday by B. Charney Vladeck, president of the American ORT and general manager of The Jewish Daily Forward, who returned on the French liner Lafayette, after an extended tour of European countries.

Under the Neutrality Law enacted at the last session of Congress the President, before he can embargo shipments of munitions to either belligerent, must issue a proclamation that a state of war exists. For a time it was thought at Washington that this might prove embarrassing to Mr. ROOSEVELT.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A majority of the potato growers of New York State, who in 1934 produced 32,500,000 bushels, are skeptical of the success of Federal production control, their representatives testified today at the Department of Agriculture hearing on the potato farmers' situation and the results that may follow enforcement of the Warren Potato Control Law, passed at the last session of Congress.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Fencing faultlessly and combining quality with a smooth way of going between jumps of the long outside course, the bay gelding Firenze Marokan today won a leg on the Meadow Brook Masters Trophy, the leading cup event of the second day of the thirty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

The Board of Estimate awarded yesterday to the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation, a subsidiary of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, a ten-year franchise to operate buses on the surface car routes of the Eighth and Ninth Avenues Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Declaring its intent to subscribe to the Bituminous Coal Code set up under the Guffey Act, because failure to do so might result in bankrupting the company through imposition of the 15 per cent penalty tax, the Carter Coal Company today in the District Supreme Court answered the injunction suit of J. W. Carter, its president, suing as a stockholder.

A driverless seven-ton truck careened across Dover Street south of Pearl Street just before 6 P.M. yesterday, killing two small boys who were in its path before it crashed against a steel fence which is part of the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

TOKYO, Oct. 5 (Saturday) (AP). -- A high official source said today Great Britain has officially inquired concerning what the Japanese attitude would be in the event the League of Nations applies sanctions against Italy under Article XVI of the covenant. The Japanese reply was non-committal, this source said.

Wall Street continued yesterday to shift its attention from the war talk in Europe to the recovery in business in this country. As a result, most stocks moved up again in orderly trading, the bond market participating in the advance. Wheat generally was irregularly lower and cotton was higher.

Except for a comparatively small amount, described as a "kitty" on which the President can draw in order to meet administrative costs and to provide for unexpected emergencies, the entire $4,880,000,000 work-relief fund has now been allotted. The distribution finally made shows how far the plan has drifted from the original prospectus.

Twenty-two persons were injured shortly after noon yesterday when a Fire Department hook-and-ladder truck crashed into a bus carrying eighteen passengers at the intersection of Liberty Avenue and Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Limited receipts of hogs again today, the result of farmers holding back supplies, permitted sellers to advance prices 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight on the general run, while some underweights were up as much as 25 cents.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The German Government will await Saturday's action by the League of Nations before reaching a decision on the question of Germany's participation in economic sanctions against Italy, it was learned at the Foreign Office today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:...

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers' Association, Inc.:

Marry Engman Chariot, creator of "The Shadow," sinister figure of many detective-story thrillers and radio broadcasts, died Thursday night in a Bowery hotel in circumstances that, according to the police, may rival the strange deaths of many of his fiction characters. He was 31 years old.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area forged ahead actively during the week, with reports indicating that the new month has started off better than September did. Gains ranging from 5 to 12 per cent were reported for stores in the metropolitan area.

A lull in the investment market developed this week when a total of only $15,637,000 in new bond issues were offered to the public. This is the smallest volume of new bond financing since the week ended on May 17 this year, when $10,139,000 new issues were marketed, and compares with an aggregate of $134,233,000 placed on the market last week.

Having cut $16,000,000 out of the budget. Mayor LA GUARDIA proceeded to put $8,000,000 back. Most of these items of added appropriations, as compared with last year, are classed as "mandatory and inescapable." The mandatory increases include $3,370,000 for schools, $526,000 for the courts and $402,000 for election expenses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The domestic business situation in Great Britain continues to improve, the Commerce Department reported today in its weekly survey of conditions abroad. The advancement has been so notable that the effects of the August holiday period were hardly perceptible.

Mayor La Guardia's noise-abatement campaign received an unexpected impetus yesterday when County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn, aroused at a noise outside his court room, ordered three men engaged on a city subway project to be brought before him.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Saturday, Oct. 5. -- Official sources said early today that a heavy advance of Ethiopians had been "surprised by an Italian advance" frustrating an attack on Eritrea by the Ethiopians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The form of temporary registration of utility holding companies and regulations to guide utilities that decide to apply for exemption under the Public Utility Act are nearing completion, and it was indicated today that an announcement would be made probably early next week.

The large number of young persons who are flocking to New York in the hope of taking part in the amateur programs broadcast by numerous radio stations and who soon find themselves stranded here, is presenting a perplexing problem to the Emergency Relief Bureau, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- Now that the period of suspense favorable to speculation is over, the Bourse recovered well today and prices became steady and even strong, Rentes, which are at all times subject to control, recovered and gave the signal for a general rise. In the latter part of the session, however, prices became stabilized in view of the week-end closure.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a range of only 10 points yesterday and ended at gains of 4 to 8 points, but the turnover was much larger than the limited price changes indicated.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., a student at Harvard College, was asked today by State Registrar Frank A. Goodwin to "set an example as a law-abiding citizen" and arrange to appear in Municipal Court at Hampton, N.H., where he defaulted his hail instead of facing a charge of speeding in excess of sixty-five miles an hour.

ROME, Oct. 4. -- Italy received news of the outbreak of hostilities in East Africa without surprise or excitement and without manifesting any very deep emotion of any kind. When shortly after noon newsboys started running through the streets with special editions of newspapers people rushed to buy them and read today's official communique eagerly.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 4. -- Under blue skies the final steps were being taken today to make the first test tomorrow of salvaging the liner Rotterdam, which with 454 passengers struck a reef early last Monday morning on the southwest end of Morant Cays, sixty miles southeast of Kingston.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- A year ago Victor Hanson turned in his finest job of coaching since he took over the reins at Syracuse in 1930, only to have his masterpiece suffer the usual fate that has befallen the Orange against its dearest rival, Colgate, during the past decade.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $6,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts public works bonds, maturing serially from Sept. 15, 1936 to 1940. The price paid was 100.321 for 1 14/2s.

Actors Equity Association held the first of its fireside talks yesterday afternoon at the Astor. Some 234 members listened to Clayton Hamilton discuss "The Theatre" and to members discussing all matters from poetry to economic conditions.

For the first half of this year, the International Products Corporation and its subsidiary reported yesterday a net profit of $119,806, after depreciation, depletion, expenses, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after six months' dividend requirements on 22,516 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock, to 10 cents a share on 435,946 shares of common stock.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, in a radio message to President Roosevelt made public yesterday, voiced its strong support of the President's declared purpose to keep the United States from becoming involved in war.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- From the military viewpoint the main question involved in the initial operations in Ethiopia concern the strategy and tactics likely to be adopted by the Ethiopians.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The Boerse was firmer today but remained relatively quiet. Heavy industrials rose, but activity was limited to Hoesch shares, which went up 1 point. Potash issues remained at yesterday's levels. The machine list was firmer, Metalgesellschaft gaining 3 points.

TOKYO, Oct. 4. -- Japanese cooperation in sanctions, though not promised, was not excluded by the Foreign Office spokesman today. He stated that the government could not indicate its intentions regarding neutrality or sanctions until the situation was clearer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Lester A. Walton presented his credentials as United States Minister to President Edwin Barclay at Monrovia, Liberia, on Wednesday, thereby completing the re-establishment of formal diplomatic relations between the United States and Liberia after a lapse of five years, the State Department announced today.

SENECA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, asserted tonight that Governor Lehman was giving out "as thoroughly inaccurate fiscal statements as those of the present national administration headed by Roosevelt, the great spender."

While several cowboys were lounging near Forty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue last night, dressed in their best boots and sombreros, 600 horses and cattle were being unloaded at the New York Central yards at Forty-first Street and Eleventh Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The fortunes of baseball warfare traced a weird course across the 1935 world series chart today but when they finally came to a rest they alighted over the banner of Mickey Cochrane's fighting band of Tigers, who, after eleven innings of nerve-throbbing conflict, brought down the Cubs in the third game of the classic by a score of 6 to 5.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- With $40,000,000 from the work relief appropriation available by order of President Roosevelt and the superstructure of personnel set up for island reconstruction, Dr. Ernest Gruening, director of the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration, expects that this major island undertaking in the national recovery program will soon be under way. Of the money to be expended approximately three-fourths will go into rural rehabilitation with back-to-the-land and land redistribution as the main objectives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why should so many normal human beings speak of nothing but their physical status? Two acquaintances meet. They ask each other, "How do you do?" One says, "I have a cold." The other says, "I had a rash yesterday; I thought it might be something serious but it's all right now." "How is your wife?" "Oh, she is quite well.

Business conditions are appreciably better than a year ago and business men are more optimistic, but sentiment for and against the policies of the New Deal is sharply divided, according to the fourth business survey conducted by Fenner Beane, security and commodity brokers, through their forty branch offices in this country.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Wesleyan scored in the last quarter today to defeat Connecticut State, 6 to 0, J. Jones carrying the ball over from the 15-yard line on a lateral pass from Captain Johnson.

DUBLIN, Oct. 4. -- Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, returned from Geneva this week to face a battery of criticism both from the Right and the Left upon the Free State's attitude on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a rule, effective today, intended to prevent inadvertent termination of registration on Stock Exchanges of the securities of corporations where the original registration application contains an agreement that registration shall end on a specified date unless additional data are supplied.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The Mayoralty ticket for the election on Nov. 5 was completed today with the nomination of Joseph F. Weiler by the Democrats. He will oppose Mayor Jasper McLevy, Socialist, seeking his second term, and former Mayor Clifford B. Wilson, Republican.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 5. -- A single touchdown by Frank Golden in the third period and the point after was Lafayette's margin of victory over Muhlenberg on Fisher Field this afternoon. A lateral pass which Golden took from Curran was worked to perfection and Golden raced 84 yards down the sidelines for the touchdown.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 5. -- Student dormitory councils, to serve as cooperative agencies between campus residents and the administrative management of residential halls, will be appointed at Brown University this Fall as a step in a general plan for the readjustment of dormitory life.

BIOGRAPHIES of some men resolve themselves into the story of tangible achievements in which the man becomes a tiny figure sitting on the top of a factory, a mountain, an empire, a pile of skulls or a heap of dollars. Dwight Morrow deserved a better fate, and in this biography of Mr. Nicolson's he has it.

A public coin exhibition in which will be shown many of the rarest United States and foreign coins from the collections of the leading members of local numismatic clubs will be held next Saturday and Sunday in the British Empire Building at Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

IN the State of New York and all over the Northern regions of the nation the thin ranks of a widely scattered army are now battling an enemy that launches a devastating campaign every Autumn. The enemy is the forest fire.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- With much personal reluctance, Premier Laval, who at first believed he could "arrange things" between Italy and England, has been little by little forced by events into a position of having to stand by the League of Nations and follow the English lead in the attitude the latter country has taken concerning the Italian campaign against Ethiopia.

LONDON. -- Wars and rumors of wars are great teachers of geography. The present threat of war from Italy has made the little known Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa almost a familiar term. It might have been a more familiar term in the past if Ethiopia had not formed the habit of changing its capital fairly often.

LEE'S FERRY, Ariz., Oct. 5. -- At the crossing where the first expedition of Mormon emigrants spanned the Colorado River in 1873 homage will be paid to their courage and vision in a celebration here Oct. 11, 12 and 13. Several thousand persons from Utah and Arizona are expected during the three-day festivities.

THE big temptation for any one reviewing, recommending, or merely mentioning "Thunder Over the Bronx" is to fall into the rich and roiling idiom of the Bronx. The zest and humor of the language in Mr. Kober's pages is irresistibly infectious.

Officers of the Westchester Woman's Club of Mount Vernon, headed by the president, Mrs. Hans Rasmus Hansen, will receive members and their guests on Wednesday at a reception in the library of the clubhouse prior to a luncheon. Mrs. Howard B. Hancock, chairman of the department of the American home of the General Federation, will be the speaker.

AN important centre for the manufacture of glass and pottery during the Roman occupation of Britain was recently discovered at Prestatyn, a Welsh village about thirty miles west of Chester. Excavations have been going on in the district for several months.

Proceeds of the sale of a series of stamps issued by the Turkish Government to commemorate the progress of the international women's suffrage movement will go toward the work of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, committee headquarters announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Automobile assemblies showed a slight gain in the week ended on Sept. 28 although most of the large plants were closed preparatory to putting out new models, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly domestic business survey. Production for the United States and Canada was estimated by Cram's at 16,000 units, compared with 12,600 in the previous week and 42,000 a year ago.

Luigi Pirandello, the Italian author, playwright and Nobel Prize winner, expressed the wish yesterday "that a more thorough understanding of the just and historically unavoidable reasons which are determining Italy's present course will modify the present attitude of the American people."

A FAVORITE gag-line in the graveyard humor of prisons is, "They can't do that!" Convicts say this with mock earnestness to one another when they feel that they are being forced to take too much kicking around. The standard answer, so well understood as to be seldom voiced, is, "Sure they can't -- but they do."

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The Boerse was quiet today. Heavy industrials gained slightly, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/2 point. Potashes were virtually inactive, but nevertheless Westeregeln gained 2 1/2 points. Machines were quiet, but Metallgesellschaft lost 2 points. Chemicals were little changed, I.G. Farben closing at yesterday's level. Electricals were firmer throughout; Siemens Halske gained 1 1/2 points. Shipping shares were slightly firmer, Hapag gaining 1/2 point.

The New York University varsity football team struck through the air and over the ground with equal effectiveness to rout Bates College, its first opponent of the season, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 10,000 saw the Violet put on one of its most impressive debuts in several years as it rolled up a 34-to-7 count against the Maine eleven.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Discovery, chestnut son of Display, went out for a gentle mile and a quarter gallop today and came back to collect $11,125, the victor's share of the $15,000 added Hawthorne Gold Cup race, for his owner, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt.

IN "Golden Apples" Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings is again dealing with the poor whites of the Florida swamplands whom she portrayed so movingly in "South Moon Under." The swamps furnish a strange and wild locale, sinister, yet harboring exotic beauties.

Ten American inventors are among the sixty-six famous Americans whose names will appear on the 1935 ballot for election to the Hall of Fame on the New York University campus, it was announced yesterday by the College of Electors.

IN these weeks before the opening of the National Automobile Show here on Nov. 2 there is a natural -- and impressively widespread -- curiosity about what the manufacturers will present to the motor-minded public. What's so-and-so going to do for next year?

VIENNA, Sept. 26, 1935. ALTHOUGH with the present alarms, excursions and rumors of imminent calamity the destinies of mankind seem to lie upon the knees of the gods, there are still optimists in this part of the world who, flushed by the success of this past Summer's Salzburg festival, are already vigorously discussing projects for the next.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5, -- A nimble-fingered, elusive-footed galaxy of backs in blue put on a typical Notre Dame attack behind a strong, unbalanced line today as Yale launched its football season in the bowl with a highly edifying 34-0 victory over New Hampshire.

THE stroke of noon tomorrow will mark a historic moment in the judicial history of the United States. At that instant a hush will come over the crowd of attorneys, newspapermen and spectators, distinguished and undistinguished, in the court room of the new United States Supreme Court Building, across the Plaza from the Capitol.

Either an amendment to the Federal Securities Act or a lessening in the enforcement of its provisions pertaining to the syndicating and marketing of new securities is held by investment bankers to be the only development through which can be found a satisfactory solution of the increasing problems confronting underwriters and distributers, a canvass of leading bankers made last week shows.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 5. -- Rhode Island State College, which failed to score a touchdown in her games with Holy Cross and Maine, came from Kingston today and upset Brown, 13 to 7.

Several members of the younger set will display the latest costumes for Autumn and Winter wear which will be a feature of the entertainment at the luncheon in aid of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., to be held on Thursday at the formal opening of the new Caprice Room of the Weylin.

THE title of this book is somewhat misleading. Written by a Russian emigre now residing in the United States, it does not deal with his Americanization, but offers an account of his personal experience in his native country during the first three years of the revolution.

IT was Henry James who remarked that as he grew older he had become ignobly fond of not traveling. "To keep up not doing it," he wrote, "is in itself for me the most thrilling of adventures." At the time when he made this interesting discovery James had already done some traveling.
